description: On April 2, 2024, at approximately 9:45 PM during evening shift operations, Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, was conducting routine inventory verification in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). While moving a 55-gallon drum of acetone (cleaning solvent) using a hand dolly to reposition it for stock rotation, the drum's bung plug became partially dislodged due to vibration during transport. Approximately 12-15 liters of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor and began pooling near the chemical storage cabinet. The volatile fumes rapidly dispersed throughout the exterior zone area. Natasha immediately activated the area ventilation emergency system and evacuated 8 meters upwind from the spill. She notified Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), the Warehouse Supervisor, who initiated spill containment procedures. The spill was contained using absorbent pads and properly disposed of in accordance with CNESST chemical waste protocols. No employees experienced acute chemical exposure symptoms. The incident was attributed to improper drum bung sealing during the previous inventory cycle and inadequate vibration dampening on the transport dolly.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Mold Technician Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021) was removing a completed injection mold from Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area (UNIT-003). He was using a standard mold release agent spray to facilitate removal. While spraying the mold surface at close range without adequate ventilation adjustment, solvent vapors accumulated in the enclosed workspace. After 8 minutes of continuous spraying, Stéphane experienced acute onset dizziness, headache, and mild nausea. Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) noticed Stéphane stumbling and immediately called for assistance. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) arrived within 2 minutes and moved Stéphane to the fresh air break room. The symptoms resolved within 15 minutes. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) conducted an evaluation and determined the incident was caused by inadequate local exhaust ventilation and improper work technique. The employee had not adjusted the overhead exhaust fan before beginning the spraying operation.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-015 adjacent area). An improperly secured 55-gallon drum of hydraulic oil, stored on a raised pallet, tipped over during routine inventory movement by Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093) and Shipping Clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019). Approximately 40 gallons of ISO 32 hydraulic oil leaked onto the concrete floor, flowing toward floor drain systems. The spill created a visible oil sheen in the storm water retention area outside the facility, indicating potential environmental contamination pathway. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was notified immediately and activated spill containment procedures. Absorbent materials were deployed, and the flow to the storm drain was blocked with temporary barriers within 8 minutes. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) assessed air quality and found no VOC exceedances. Environmental remediation contractor was called to assess soil and groundwater impact. Approximately 45 gallons of contaminated soil required excavation and proper disposal. The incident triggered a CNESST environmental reporting review.

On March 20, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019). Packaging Operator Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066) was manually stacking finished composite material parts into shipping crates positioned on the edge of the loading dock. A forklift operated by Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) was moving pallets in the adjacent zone. Raymond was focusing on backing up to align with another pallet and did not notice Lucia standing at the dock edge with her back to the traffic flow. The forklift's outer edge came within approximately 18 inches of Lucia before Raymond's spotter, Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), shouted a warning and Raymond immediately braked. The forklift stopped without making contact. Lucia was startled but unharmed. The incident was classified as a near-miss because no physical contact occurred, but the potential severity was high—a collision at 3 mph could have caused serious leg crushing injuries given the proximity to the dock edge. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) initiated an investigation and determined that inadequate traffic control signage, unclear pedestrian zones, and insufficient communication protocols between equipment operators and floor personnel contributed to the hazard.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was preparing Injection Molding Line C for a production run of medical device housings in the clean room area. While adjusting the mold closing mechanism, she noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge was fluctuating abnormally between 180-220 PSI instead of the stable 200 PSI specification. She immediately stopped the machine and stepped back from the equipment. Within seconds, a small hydraulic line connection partially separated, releasing a brief spray of pressurized hydraulic fluid into the air where Svetlana had been standing just moments before. The spray dissipated safely without contacting her skin or eyes. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) was notified immediately. Svetlana's quick recognition of the abnormal gauge reading and her decision to step away prevented a potential pressure release burn injury. The incident was reported as a near-miss by Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107). The hydraulic connection was temporarily capped and the line scheduled for replacement. No equipment damage occurred beyond the minor leak.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, packaging operator Amara Diop (EMP-00110) was processing finished consumer packaging components on Injection Molding Line D in the south zone of the main production building. While reaching to stack completed parts onto a wooden pallet, a splinter from the pallet's weathered surface penetrated the side of her left hand between the thumb and index finger. The splinter was approximately 1.5 inches long and embedded approximately 0.5 inches into the skin. Assembly Lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) observed the incident and immediately helped Amara to the first aid station. Production Supervisor Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141) was notified. The splinter was carefully removed by trained first aid responder Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) using sterile tweezers. The wound was cleaned with antiseptic solution, dressed with antibiotic ointment and a sterile bandage. No sutures were required. Amara returned to work after 15 minutes of first aid treatment. The incident was documented in the first aid log and reported to the Joint Health and Safety Committee.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, maintenance supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) was conducting preventive maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the central maintenance workshop when his right hand became caught in the rotating spindle during a machine startup test. Despite proper lockout procedures being posted, a communication breakdown occurred: Mailhot believed the machine was de-energized, but night shift production supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) had not yet completed the final isolation verification checklist. When Mailhot initiated a low-speed test rotation, his gloved right hand was drawn into the cutting area, causing a deep laceration across the palm and fingers requiring immediate first aid intervention. Material handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was nearby and called emergency services. Mailhot was transported to Laval Hospital emergency department where he received 12 stitches and was treated for the laceration. X-rays confirmed no fractures. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was notified and initiated a formal incident investigation. The incident was classified as a reportable injury under CNESST regulations.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a solvent storage cabinet in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) overheated due to a malfunctioning temperature control sensor. The cabinet, which stores flammable resin solvents and mold release agents, reached an internal temperature of 68°C (154°F), exceeding the safe operating range of 20-25°C. Natasha Ivanov, Chemical Inventory Specialist, noticed an acrid smell and visible vapor emanating from the cabinet vents while conducting routine inventory. She immediately activated the emergency ventilation system and evacuated the area. The facility's fire alarm system was triggered automatically by heat-activated sensors at 2:47 PM. Emergency response personnel from the Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the cabinet's cooling system had failed due to a corroded thermostat relay. No fire occurred, but the incident prevented a potentially catastrophic solvent fire that could have spread to adjacent storage areas containing composite materials and adhesives. The facility was evacuated for 45 minutes while emergency personnel assessed the situation and reset the fire suppression systems.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:15 PM during evening shift, Abdul Rahman, Machine Operator on Injection Molding Line C (UNIT-003), discovered that the hydraulic pressure gauge on the medical component injection molding machine had failed. The analog gauge display showed erratic readings (fluctuating between 0 and 350 bar), making it impossible to monitor proper injection pressure for the sterile medical device housings in production. Abdul attempted to calibrate the gauge manually using a backup portable pressure meter, but this workaround proved unreliable. At approximately 10:42 PM, the machine's hydraulic system experienced a pressure spike to 425 bar (exceeding the 400 bar safety limit) due to undetected calibration drift. The over-pressure event triggered the machine's emergency relief valve, which activated as designed, venting hydraulic fluid into the collection reservoir. However, the relief valve seal had developed micro-cracks from months of exposure to composite resin vapors, causing a slow hydraulic leak that continued throughout the shift. By end of shift at 11:30 PM, approximately 3 liters of hydraulic fluid had accumulated in the containment area. Quality control identified that 47 medical device housings produced during the pressure spike period required full rejection due to dimensional variance exceeding ISO 13485 tolerances. The equipment was taken offline for maintenance and seal replacement.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift transition period, Marwa Saleh, Material Handler, sustained a significant hand laceration while performing manual removal of hardened plastic flash (excess material) from freshly molded automotive dashboard components at the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005). The components had been removed from the injection mold approximately 15 minutes prior and were still radiating residual heat (approximately 65°C). Marwa was using a manual flash removal tool (hand-held deburring knife) to trim sharp edges from component perimeters when the tool slipped on a still-warm mold release agent residue, causing the blade to cut deeply across her left palm and index finger. The laceration was approximately 4 cm long and 5 mm deep, severing a superficial vein and damaging tissue nerves in the palm. The wound began bleeding profusely, saturating her work gloves within seconds. A nearby composite materials technician, Lina Sokolova, immediately applied direct pressure with clean cloth and called for first aid response. The facility's first responder arrived at 6:35 AM and applied pressure bandaging. Marwa was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval at 6:42 AM via facility emergency vehicle. She received 12 sutures and was kept under observation for potential nerve damage assessment. She was unable to return to work for 8 days pending medical clearance.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45, a significant material spill occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). Karim Bouazizi, Machine Setter - Day Shift, was unloading a delivery of polyethylene pellets from a supplier truck. While repositioning stacked bags of raw material using a manual hand truck, one of the upper bags shifted and fell, rupturing and spilling approximately 200 kilograms of pellets across the warehouse floor. The spill created a slippery surface covering an area of roughly 8 meters by 6 meters. Additionally, the falling bag struck and damaged three storage shelving units, bending metal frames and dislodging several containers of liquid resin additives. The immediate consequence was $34,000 in property damage to warehouse infrastructure and loss of materials. The spill was contained within 2 hours using industrial vacuum equipment and manual cleanup. No employees were physically injured, though the incident created a significant safety hazard that could have resulted in serious slip-and-fall injuries or chemical exposure if the liquid additives had mixed with the pellets.

On November 18, 2024, at 09:30 during the day shift, Luis Fernandez, Assembly Operator, sustained a minor laceration to his left palm while assembling medical device components in the Composite Materials Processing Area. While manually preparing fiber-reinforced plastic components for final assembly, Fernandez handled a piece of cured composite material that had rough, unfinished edges with exposed glass fiber strands. As he gripped the component to position it in an assembly fixture, a protruding strand of glass fiber cut into his palm, creating a 2-centimeter laceration that bled moderately. Fernandez immediately reported the injury to his supervisor, Sébastien Carrier, Production Engineer. First aid was administered on-site: the wound was cleaned with antiseptic wipe, pressure was applied for 3 minutes to stop bleeding, and the laceration was covered with an antibiotic ointment and sterile bandage. No stitches were required. The injury did not prevent Fernandez from returning to work after 15 minutes of first aid treatment. The component was flagged for rework to remove sharp edges before assembly.

On November 20, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Lina Sokolova, Composite Materials Operator, suffered a significant burn injury to her right forearm while operating a composite curing oven in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. Sokolova was removing a batch of heat-treated composite parts from an industrial oven operating at 180°C. While extracting a mold assembly using insulated gloves, her glove caught on the edge of the oven door frame. This caused her to stumble slightly, and her right forearm made contact with the exposed heating element on the side of the oven for approximately 2-3 seconds. She sustained a deep thermal burn covering approximately 12 square centimeters of her forearm. Sokolova immediately reported the injury to her supervisor. She was transported to the on-site first aid station where the burn was cooled under running water for 10 minutes, covered with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment, and wrapped in non-adherent dressing. Given the severity (partial thickness burn), she was referred for immediate transport to the regional burn center. Sokolova was unable to return to work and required 14 days of medical leave for wound care and healing. The incident was caused by inadequate machine guarding on the oven's heating elements and insufficient PPE specifications for the task.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine mold maintenance when his left hand became entangled in the rotating coupling of the injection unit. The machine had not been properly locked out according to LOTO procedures - a supervisor had assumed the equipment was de-energized when it was still in standby mode with residual pressure. Bruno's hand was caught between the coupling and the mold frame, resulting in severe crush injuries to his fingers and palm. Co-workers immediately activated the emergency stop button and called for medical assistance. Bruno was transported via ambulance to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé with crush injuries requiring emergency surgery. He will require extended hospitalization and rehabilitation, resulting in an estimated 12-week lost-time injury. The incident was witnessed by Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), the Automation Technician, who was assisting with the maintenance work.

On November 9, 2024, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, the facility's Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) experienced a significant ventilation system failure. The primary exhaust fan, which had been operating continuously for removing airborne composite fiber dust and volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes, suddenly ceased operation due to bearing failure in the motor. The night shift supervisor did not immediately notice the failure as no automated alarm system was in place. For approximately 90 minutes, hazardous air contaminants accumulated in the confined space, including styrene vapors from resin mixing operations and glass fiber dust particles. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) arrived at 6:00 AM to conduct a routine air quality check and detected the failure using a handheld gas detector. At that time, three employees had been working in the mixing room: Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160), Production Operator; Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), Inventory Control Specialist; and Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), Material Handler. All three employees reported symptoms of dizziness, throat irritation, and minor respiratory discomfort. Immediate evacuation protocols were activated, emergency ventilation was established, and the facility's occupational health nurse was notified. Environmental air sampling was conducted post-incident to assess exposure levels.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a first-aid level burn injury while removing parts from a mold cavity. The mold temperature was operating at 95°C as part of the standard polycarbonate (PC) production run for medical device components. While using a part removal tool, Youssef's left hand made contact with the heated mold surface for approximately 2-3 seconds. He immediately reported mild redness and minor blistering on his palm. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) was called to the production area within 5 minutes. The injury was assessed as a first-degree to superficial second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 3% of the palm surface. Treatment consisted of immediate cool water irrigation for 10 minutes, application of sterile gauze with antibiotic ointment, and light bandaging. Youssef remained on modified duty for the remainder of the shift, avoiding heat-intensive tasks. He was advised to monitor for infection and return for daily dressing changes. No lost time occurred, and the employee returned to full duties the following day.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a forklift-related material handling incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), an experienced forklift operator, was transferring a pallet stack of polypropylene (PP) resin packages (approximately 1,200 kg total weight) from a high storage rack (approximately 4 meters height) to a staging area for shipment. While maneuvering the loaded forklift in a confined aisle space, the operator made a sharp left turn. Due to the uneven load distribution and the high center of gravity, the pallet stack shifted during the turn. Three heavy polypropylene packages (each approximately 400 kg) fell from the pallet and struck two adjacent storage racks in Section B, causing structural damage. The fallen packages dented the right side of both racks, bending vertical support columns and compromising the structural integrity of shelving. Additionally, one package broke open, spilling approximately 150 kg of resin pellets across the warehouse floor. No employees were injured as the incident occurred in a designated heavy materials zone with no personnel in immediate proximity. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) arrived within 10 minutes and secured the area with caution tape and warning signs. Maintenance estimated repair costs for the damaged racks at approximately $8,500, and additional cleaning and resin recovery labor totaled $1,200.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a Production Operator working the night shift rotation, sustained a serious back injury while manually handling chemical containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Kwame was transferring fifteen 20-liter containers of mold release agent from the receiving staging area to storage shelves approximately 2 meters high. Each container weighs approximately 22 kg when full. After moving nine containers, while attempting to lift and place the tenth container, Kwame felt sudden acute lower back pain radiating down his left leg. He immediately set the container down and reported the injury to the night shift supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139). Initial assessment suggested acute lumbar strain with possible nerve involvement. Kwame was transported by ambulance to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur in Montreal at 7:15 AM. Diagnostic imaging confirmed a L4-L5 intervertebral disc herniation with mild nerve compression. The employee was hospitalized for 3 days for pain management, physical therapy assessment, and specialist consultation. Work capacity evaluation determined Kwame could not return to normal production duties for a minimum of 6 weeks, requiring light-duty reassignment. This incident resulted in 72+ hours hospitalization, lost work time, and significant medical expenses, qualifying as a recordable injury under CNESST guidelines.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a major chemical spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C). Fatou Ndiaye, Production Operator, was transferring approximately 20 liters of acetone solvent from a bulk storage container to a smaller working container when the transfer hose became disconnected at the coupling point. The acetone spilled across the concrete floor, spreading approximately 4 meters in diameter and creating a significant vapor hazard in the enclosed warehouse section. The spill occurred because the coupling had not been properly secured during setup—a maintenance technician had replaced the hose the previous day but failed to use a locking collar mechanism. Within minutes, three additional workers in the vicinity (Leila Farah, Paul Demers, and Jasmine Patel) began experiencing respiratory irritation and dizziness from the fumes. Fatou immediately notified her supervisor and the HSE department. The area was evacuated, ventilation fans were activated, and the spill was contained using absorbent materials. Emergency responders arrived within 15 minutes. All affected employees were assessed and two required medical evaluation at the facility clinic. The incident resulted in approximately 6 hours of production downtime while the area was decontaminated and investigated.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Bertrand Jalbert, Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a lost-time injury while performing routine machine maintenance. While attempting to clear a blockage in the hopper feed system on his injection molding machine, Bertrand did not fully follow the Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedure. Although he placed a lockout device on the main power switch, he failed to verify that all residual pressure in the hydraulic system had been relieved before proceeding. When he inserted a clearing tool into the hopper, a sudden hydraulic pressure release occurred, violently ejecting the tool and striking Bertrand's right hand and forearm. He sustained a deep laceration on his palm, a fracture to the third metacarpal bone, and soft tissue damage requiring 23 stitches and surgical repair. Bertrand was immediately transported to the hospital by ambulance and subsequently placed on medical leave. The incident was witnessed by Paul Demers, who was operating the adjacent Line A. Root cause investigation revealed that Bertrand had not completed the required LOTO retraining course that expired two months prior, and he had developed a habit of bypassing the pressure relief step to save time. This is Bertrand's second LOTO-related incident in three years.

On April 5, 2024, at 9:30 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident was narrowly avoided at the Shipping and Receiving Dock (Loading Area). Luc-André Beaudoin, Warehouse Supervisor, was observing forklift operations when he noticed that Rania Abdallah, Composite Materials Operator, was operating a propane-powered forklift in an enclosed section of the dock while moving pallets of finished composite parts. The forklift had been running continuously for approximately 45 minutes without adequate ventilation, and Luc-André observed that the propane exhaust appeared unusually heavy. Several crates were positioned directly in front of the only emergency exit door, partially blocking egress. When Luc-André checked the area's carbon monoxide detector, it read 85 ppm, approaching hazardous levels (OSHA PEL is 50 ppm for 8-hour TWA). Rania reported feeling slightly nauseous but had not stopped operations. Luc-André immediately halted all forklift operations, moved the blocking crates, activated emergency ventilation, and evacuated the area as a precaution. He contacted the HSE department and environmental compliance specialist. Air quality readings returned to normal within 20 minutes. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed multiple safety system failures: propane forklift use in enclosed spaces without proper monitoring, blocked emergency exits, inadequate ventilation activation protocols, and lack of real-time carbon monoxide monitoring.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). Marco Rossi, Mechanical Maintenance Technician, was transferring a 25-liter container of acetone solvent from a storage drum to smaller working containers when the transfer hose connection failed due to corrosion and age-related wear. Approximately 8 liters of acetone spilled onto the workshop floor, creating a hazardous vapor environment. The chemical spread across approximately 15 square meters of the concrete floor, and vapors rapidly filled the 400-square-meter workshop space. Two other maintenance staff members (Aya Tanaka and an external contractor) were present in the area. Marco immediately notified facility management, and the HSE team initiated emergency response protocols. The workshop was evacuated, ventilation systems were manually activated at maximum capacity, and the spill was contained using absorbent materials. CNESST reporting requirements were assessed. No direct contact occurred, but two workers experienced mild respiratory irritation from vapor exposure. The root cause was identified as inadequate preventive maintenance on fluid transfer equipment and lack of spill containment measures at the transfer station.

On November 10, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019). Patricia Martin, Packaging Supervisor, was instructing Aaliyah Jackson, Assembly Operator, on proper placement of finished composite material components into shipping boxes. The work area has multiple trip hazards including air hoses running across the floor from pneumatic equipment and power cables from the labeling printer. As Patricia was demonstrating correct box orientation, Aaliyah stepped backward toward a stack of empty boxes and her left foot caught on a coiled air hose. She lost her balance and began to fall forward, her arms extended toward the labeling machine's moving conveyor belt. Patricia immediately reached out and grabbed Aaliyah's right arm, preventing her from falling into the conveyor system. Had Patricia not intervened, Aaliyah's arm would have likely contacted the moving belt rollers, resulting in potential laceration or crush injury. Both employees remained calm, and Patricia documented the incident as a near-miss. Investigation revealed that the air hose had not been properly secured to the floor and was creating a significant tripping hazard that violated facility housekeeping standards.

On November 8, 2024, at approximately 6:50 AM during the night shift, an occupational injury occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025), located on the Maintenance Workshop storage mezzanine. Monique Dion, Warehouse Associate, was retrieving a replacement motor assembly from a high shelf approximately 2.1 meters above the floor when she lost her grip on the item. The motor assembly, weighing approximately 12 kilograms, fell directly onto her left shoulder and upper arm area. Monique immediately fell to the floor in pain. Normand Ouellette, Warehouse Lead on the day shift arriving for handover, discovered her and immediately called for medical response. First aid was administered, and Monique was transported to the nearest emergency department. Medical examination confirmed a fractured left humerus (upper arm bone) and significant soft tissue trauma. The injury required hospitalization for 2 days and surgical intervention. Investigation determined that the shelf was not equipped with edge guards or lip restraints, and no fall-arrest protective equipment was required for retrieving items above 2 meters. Additionally, Monique had not received specific training on safe retrieval techniques for elevated storage, and the shelf arrangement did not follow ergonomic weight distribution principles.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, injection molding operator James Thompson (EMP-00029) was working the day shift on Line D in the Main Production Building when he reached into the hopper area to clear a blockage of resin pellets without properly engaging the machine lockout-tagout procedure. A co-worker, unaware of his presence, initiated a machine restart sequence from the control panel. The hopper auger suddenly engaged, catching Thompson's right hand and pulling it partially into the feed mechanism. His hand was severely crushed between the auger and the hopper housing, resulting in fractures to three metacarpal bones and deep lacerations requiring emergency transport to Laval General Hospital. The incident occurred during routine production troubleshooting. Supervisor Michael Chen immediately stopped all operations on Line D and activated emergency response protocols. Paramedics arrived within 12 minutes. The employee underwent surgical intervention and hospitalization for four days, resulting in a lost-time injury lasting 23 days before returning to light-duty work.

On April 8, 2024, at 09:30, packaging supervisor Patricia Martin (EMP-00035) conducted a routine inspection of the Assembly and Finishing Department during the day shift. While walking through the East Wing, she observed that several finished composite parts stacked on wooden pallets in the staging area displayed visible signs of surface deterioration and discoloration consistent with early-stage mold contamination. The parts had been stored for approximately 14 days in a zone where the humidity monitoring system had malfunctioned two weeks prior. Environmental conditions had exceeded the 55% relative humidity threshold for composite material storage. Martin immediately flagged the area, photographed the affected inventory (approximately 280 units valued at $18,500), and documented the humidity sensor malfunction. She notified quality control technician Léa Parent and production supervisor Michael Chen of the potential contamination risk. No employee exposure or injury occurred. This was classified as a preventive declaration to address the environmental control failure before product could be shipped to customers and to prevent similar incidents in the future.

On April 22, 2024, at 22:15, material handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was working the evening shift in the Warehouse and Shipping section, preparing bulk orders for the next day's shipments. While manually organizing injection-molded automotive components on metal shelving units, she sustained a laceration to her left index finger when the sharp edge of a freshly molded plastic part contacted her hand. The part had not yet been deburred—a standard post-production finishing step. The cut was approximately 1.2 centimeters long and required immediate first aid treatment. The employee reported the injury to shift supervisor André Paradis immediately. On-site first aid provider Johanne Paquette assessed the wound, cleaned it with antiseptic solution, and applied a sterile bandage with antibiotic ointment. The laceration did not require sutures and did not result in lost work time. The employee completed her shift and reported for work the following day with no restrictions. The part in question was immediately quarantined pending review by quality control.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45 during the day shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was organizing raw material pallets in the Raw Materials Warehouse Section A when a stack of polypropylene resin bags weighing approximately 500 kg became unstable. The stack had been placed on a wooden pallet that showed visible signs of rot and structural damage. As Bianchi attempted to reposition the stack using a hand pallet jack, the wooden pallet suddenly collapsed, causing the entire load to shift and crash onto a nearby forklift that was parked in the aisle. The impact damaged the forklift's hydraulic system, causing a significant fluid leak across the warehouse floor. The hydraulic fluid spread approximately 8 meters in diameter, contaminating the storage area. Bianchi was not physically injured but immediately reported the incident. The forklift was taken out of service, and cleanup operations took approximately 4 hours. This incident resulted in an estimated $12,500 in property damage to the forklift and loss of warehouse operational capacity.

On April 22, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was preparing a batch of mold release agent in the chemical mixing area adjacent to the production floor. While transferring acetone solvent from a 25-liter container into a heated mixing vessel, she did not notice that the heating element had malfunctioned and was operating at 185°C instead of the intended 140°C. As the acetone (flashpoint 88°F/31°C) contacted the overheated vessel surface, vapors ignited immediately. The resulting flash fire spread rapidly across the work surface and ignited a nearby shelf containing additional flammable materials including isopropanol bottles and colorant masterbatch containers. The fire spread approximately 1.5 meters along the workbench before Popescu activated the emergency suppression system. Fire suppression foam contained the fire within 90 seconds, but flames had already spread to the adjacent composite fiber storage area, igniting approximately 3 bags of glass fiber material. The facility's automatic fire suppression system activated, and the local fire department responded within 8 minutes. Total fire damage included destruction of chemical processing equipment, loss of raw materials valued at $28,000, and significant smoke damage to adjacent production areas requiring 2 days of facility decontamination.

On May 8, 2024 at 09:30 during the day shift, Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine in Injection Molding Line A. He had initiated a partial lockout procedure but failed to completely isolate all energy sources before reaching into the mold cavity to clear a suspected resin blockage. A coworker, Quality Control Technician Léa Parent (EMP-00121), inadvertently reset the machine's cycle timer from another control station while investigating sensor readings, not realizing Bouazizi was inside the mold area. The mold clamping mechanism activated unexpectedly, trapping Bouazizi's left hand between the mold halves. The crushing pressure caused severe lacerations and fractures to the index and middle fingers of his left hand. Bouazizi screamed, alerting nearby workers. The emergency stop button was activated immediately by Assembly Operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), releasing the mold within 8 seconds. Bouazizi was rushed to the facility's first aid station where the Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided emergency care including tourniquet application to control bleeding. He was transported via ambulance to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval where he underwent emergency surgery. Diagnosis: crushing injury with partial amputation of index finger, multiple fractures of middle finger, and severe soft tissue damage requiring 6 hours of surgical reconstruction.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B in the Main Production Building, sustained a pinch point injury while removing a molded part from an injection molding machine. The 150-ton machine had completed its cycle and Youssef was extracting a automotive interior panel when the hydraulic arms unexpectedly reactivated due to a malfunctioning proximity sensor. His left hand was caught between the mold cavity and the moving core pin, resulting in bruising and a laceration to his index and middle fingers. The machine's emergency stop was activated by a nearby operator, Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), who witnessed the incident. First aid was administered immediately by Hana Al-Rashid, the Occupational Health Nurse, who treated the wound with antiseptic and applied sterile dressing. The employee was evaluated for deeper tissue damage but did not require hospitalization. The proximity sensor malfunction was documented and the machine was taken offline for maintenance inspection.

On November 16, 2024, at 10:30 PM during evening shift, Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a Material Handler in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B), sustained a minor burn while transferring a batch of composite resin-coated parts that were still warm from the post-processing oven. While handling a carton of parts that had been removed from the curing process approximately 15 minutes prior, Marwa accidentally spilled hot resin residue from an improperly sealed container onto the dorsal surface of her right hand. The burn covered approximately 2 square inches and was classified as a first-degree superficial thermal burn with minor redness and mild pain. Hana Al-Rashid provided immediate first aid, flushing the affected area with cool running water for 10 minutes and applying a sterile, non-adhesive burn dressing. The employee remained on duty as the injury did not limit work capacity. The incident was attributed to the container not being adequately cooled before handling and insufficient segregation between hot and ambient-temperature work areas. A written incident report was filed with documentation of the first aid treatment.

On November 18, 2024, at 6:45 AM during night shift, Vincent L'Étourneau (EMP-00075), an Instrumentation Technician in the Central Maintenance Workshop, identified a near-miss incident involving potential electrocution hazard while performing routine electrical panel diagnostics. While accessing the main electrical distribution panel to check voltage readings on a 480V three-phase system, Vincent noticed that the panel's lockout/tagout hasp had been improperly reinstalled by the previous shift technician, leaving a quarter-inch gap that would allow the main breaker to be engaged without physically removing the padlock. The circuit breaker was currently in the OFF position, but the improper installation created a critical safety gap. Vincent did not proceed with work inside the panel and immediately documented the condition. He photographed the hasp installation and reported the finding to Plant Manager Jean-François Lefebvre (EMP-00002). Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) was contacted to review lockout/tagout procedures with all maintenance personnel. A detailed inspection revealed that three other panels had similar installation deficiencies. No personnel were injured, and no electrical contact occurred.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during the day shift, Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier conducted a routine inspection of Injection Molding Line A and discovered that the emergency stop (E-stop) buttons on three injection molding machines had accumulated plastic dust and resin residue, making them difficult to activate in an emergency. During a preventive maintenance walk-through, she also noted that the machine guarding on the hopper feed systems showed signs of wear with small gaps where operator fingers could potentially contact moving screws. Additionally, she observed that the lockout/tagout (LOTO) hasp attachment points on two machines were corroded and may not securely hold locks during maintenance operations. The production area supervisor, Stéphane Moreau, was present during the inspection and confirmed these observations. Karine immediately documented these findings and initiated this preventive declaration to address potential machine entanglement and equipment failure hazards before an incident occurs. No injuries resulted from this inspection, but the hazards identified pose significant risk to operators working on these critical production lines.

On April 2, 2024, at 09:15 during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator James Thompson was removing a finished part from mold cavity on Line D when his right palm made direct contact with a hot mold surface that had cooled to approximately 140°C (284°F). The mold had just finished its cooling cycle, but the thermal sensor had malfunctioned and failed to trigger the automated cooling fan. Despite warning labels, the surface temperature remained dangerously high. James suffered a second-degree thermal burn approximately 3 inches in diameter on his palm and the web of his hand between thumb and forefinger. He immediately immersed his hand in cool water from the nearby safety station and reported the injury to his supervisor, Ibrahim Yusuf, who provided first aid and contacted the facility medical clinic. The employee was treated for the burn, required 8 stitches at the clinic, and was given over-the-counter pain medication. James was temporarily reassigned to light duty for 5 days while the burn healed. The mold was removed from service and the thermal sensor was replaced the following day. This incident resulted in a lost-time injury recordable under CNESST regulations.

On May 8, 2024, at 22:30 during the evening shift, Facilities Technician Georges Plante was performing routine maintenance on the cooling water circulation system in the Composite Materials Processing Area when he discovered that the primary cooling pump (Model CP-2500) had experienced a catastrophic seal failure. Pressurized cooling water was spraying from the pump housing at approximately 120 PSI, creating a high-pressure water jet that had already soaked the surrounding work area and damaged several electrical connection boxes nearby. The pump had been in continuous operation for 18 months without receiving the scheduled seal replacement maintenance. Upon discovery, Georges immediately shut down the pump and isolated the system using emergency isolation valves, preventing further water spray and potential electrical hazards. However, approximately 200 liters of cooling water had already leaked onto the workshop floor, creating a slip hazard. The cooling water, which contains inhibitor chemicals, required containment and disposal according to environmental regulations. Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham was notified and determined that the pump would need to be replaced entirely due to internal corrosion damage discovered during inspection. The replacement took 6 hours and delayed composite material production for the following day shift.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components clean room area). Production Operator Leila Farah was transferring a 20-liter container of polycarbonate colorant concentrate from storage to the material mixing station when the container's cap was improperly secured. The container slipped from her hands and fell approximately 1.5 meters to the epoxy floor, rupturing the bottom seam. Approximately 15 liters of the concentrated colorant—a proprietary blue dye formulation containing organic solvents and trace heavy metals—spilled across the clean room floor, flowing under equipment and toward the floor drain system. The spill immediately contaminated approximately 8 square meters of the sterile production area. Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel, working nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency response protocol. The facility's chemical spill kit was deployed, and the area was cordoned off within 5 minutes. However, approximately 3 liters reached the floor drain before containment, creating potential environmental and wastewater system contamination. The medical device production line was shut down for decontamination, resulting in 6 hours of lost production time.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a critical equipment failure occurred on Injection Molding Line D. Injection Molding Operator Rémi Charbonneau was conducting routine material feeding when he noticed irregular molding output and heard an unusual grinding noise from the machine's injection unit. He immediately halted operations and notified Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi. Upon inspection, Marco discovered that the machine's hydraulic pressure relief valve had malfunctioned and was stuck in a partially open position, causing erratic pressure fluctuations. More critically, the main hydraulic pump drive belt showed severe wear and was beginning to fray. The relief valve malfunction had caused the system to lose pressure stability over approximately 4 hours of operation, resulting in 23 defective parts produced. The frayed drive belt represented an imminent failure risk that could have resulted in sudden loss of all hydraulic pressure and potential machine collision. Marco immediately shut down the machine and isolated it from production. The valve was temporarily sealed, and the drive belt was flagged for immediate replacement. Process Engineer Raj Patel was called to assess production impact. The machine remained offline for 18 hours pending parts replacement and recalibration.

On January 12, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez sustained a laceration injury while performing manual assembly operations in the Assembly and Finishing Department. Elena was inserting small plastic components into a precision-molded automotive part when a sharp plastic burr on an edge created during the molding process cut deeply into the fleshy area of her left palm between the thumb and index finger. The burr had resulted from inadequate mold cavity surface finishing and was not detected during the quality inspection process. The cut was approximately 2 centimeters long and penetrated to a depth of approximately 8 millimeters, severing a minor blood vessel and causing significant bleeding. Elena immediately wrapped her hand in her work apron and alerted her supervisor, Diego Morales, who was approximately 10 meters away. Diego applied direct pressure using clean gauze from the first aid station and assessed that the injury required immediate medical attention. An ambulance was called at 6:27 AM. Elena was transported to the nearest urgent care facility where the wound required 12 stitches and tetanus update. She was released at 8:45 AM and prescribed antibiotics. The incident was classified as a lost-time injury due to Elena's inability to perform assembly work for 5 days while healing.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a thermal burn while removing a finished part from the mold. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C (185°F). While using tongs to extract a polycarbonate medical component, Rémi's left forearm made contact with the hot mold surface for approximately 2 seconds. He immediately reported the injury to his supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037). Linh Tran (EMP-00046), a Quality Assurance Specialist, witnessed the incident and assisted in providing first aid. The affected area showed a second-degree burn approximately 4cm x 6cm on the inner forearm. First aid was administered immediately with cool water and sterile dressing. Rémi was treated by the on-site nurse and released with instructions to monitor the wound. The incident was caused by insufficient grip on the tongs due to moisture on the tool surface and inadequate cooling time before part extraction.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 PM during evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Unit 018) due to an electrical malfunction in the material dryer control panel. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, detected smoke emanating from the control panel housing and immediately activated the nearest fire alarm pull station. The facility's automatic sprinkler system engaged within 90 seconds, suppressing the localized electrical fire before it spread to adjacent regrind material storage. Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) and Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), both Material Handlers, were working in the adjacent waste sorting area and evacuated safely following emergency procedures. Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), Electrical Maintenance Lead, arrived on scene and confirmed the fire was extinguished by the sprinkler system. The electrical fire resulted from deteriorated insulation on a high-amperage wire within the control panel, causing an arc. No injuries occurred. The incident highlighted inadequate preventive maintenance on aging electrical equipment.

On April 18, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift, a forklift operated by Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), Material Handler, struck a poorly secured cardboard storage rack in the Packaging and Labeling Station (Unit 019). The rack was laden with approximately 200 kilograms of packaged medical device components destined for shipment to a major automotive client. The impact caused the entire top shelf to collapse, and approximately 15 cartons of finished parts fell to the concrete floor, with debris spreading across a 3-meter radius. Nour Jaber (EMP-00188), Packaging Operator, was positioned approximately 2 meters away and narrowly avoided being struck by falling materials. André Paradis (EMP-00037), Night Shift Production Supervisor, immediately halted all forklift operations and surveyed damage. Preliminary assessment revealed approximately 180 units were damaged or destroyed, representing approximately $8,400 in material loss. The root cause was improper rack anchoring to the floor and lack of load weight verification before placement. Forklift navigation path markings were also unclear in this area.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), a Machine Setter, was adjusting tooling on Injection Molding Line A when he noticed excessive vibration in the mold cooling system. While investigating the source of the vibration near the equipment's base, Rodrigue observed a small crack beginning to form in the cooling water line coupling. The pressurized cooling system was still operational at 80 psi. Recognizing the immediate hazard of a potential high-pressure water spray and potential equipment damage, Rodrigue immediately isolated the machine using the emergency stop button and notified his supervisor. The line was depressurized within 2 minutes, preventing what could have been a significant pressure release incident. Layla Hussein (EMP-00098), an Assembly Operator working nearby, witnessed the employee's swift response and corroborated the observation. No injuries occurred, but the near-miss indicated a critical gap in preventive maintenance scheduling for cooling system components.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), a Material Handler, was moving pallets of regrind plastic material in the Regrind and Recycling Department using a manual pallet jack. While navigating between stacked material bins, Amani's foot caught on a coiled air hose that had been left across the main aisle after maintenance work earlier that day. The hose had not been properly stored in the overhead cable tray system. Amani stumbled but managed to regain balance by grabbing onto an adjacent material rack, preventing a fall. However, the pallet jack momentarily tilted, and several small plastic resin bags shifted precariously but remained on the rack. Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), another Material Handler nearby, immediately moved to assist and observed the near-miss. Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), the Warehouse Supervisor on evening shift, was notified and confirmed the air hose hazard. The area was cleared and the hose was immediately coiled and secured. This near-miss highlighted inadequate housekeeping controls and lack of post-maintenance inspection protocols in the materials handling area.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was manually removing molded parts from a hot mold cavity. Despite wearing heat-resistant gloves, Stéphane's left hand came into contact with residual hot plastic material on the mold surface that had cooled to approximately 65°C but still hot enough to cause thermal injury. He experienced an immediate burning sensation across the palm and two fingers of his left hand. The operator immediately immersed his hand in cool water from the emergency eyewash station for approximately 3 minutes and then reported to the on-site first aid station. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer, was nearby and responded immediately. First aid assessment revealed superficial partial-thickness thermal burns (approximately 2nd degree) affecting approximately 8% of the hand surface. The burns were treated with sterile gauze, antibiotic ointment, and a protective bandage. Stéphane was provided written instructions for home care and advised to monitor for signs of infection. No hospitalization was required, but the employee was restricted from hot-work duties for 5 days during the healing period. The incident was documented and logged as a first-aid case.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Layla Hussein (EMP-00098) was working at Station 3 in the Medical Components assembly area when she experienced a severe laceration to her right hand. While manually assembling sterile housing components for diagnostic equipment, a sharp edge on a partially-trimmed plastic part caught her palm as she reached to position it in the assembly fixture. The laceration extended 4 centimeters across her palm and severed two tendons, requiring immediate first aid response from occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid. The employee was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval at 2:45 PM and admitted for surgical repair. She remained hospitalized for 18 hours and required two surgical interventions to repair the lacerated tendons and assess for nerve damage. The incident was witnessed by assembly lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) who immediately activated the emergency response protocol. Root cause analysis revealed that the part deburring process in the prior molding line had not been completed, and quality control documentation was not properly flagged before the parts reached assembly.

On October 28, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, regrind operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) suffered a thermal burn injury while performing routine maintenance on the regrind collection hopper in the Regrind and Recycling Department. While cleaning out accumulated plastic residue from the hopper discharge area, pressurized steam from the adjacent resin mixing line was inadvertently released through a valve that should have been isolated and locked out. The steam contacted Comeau's left forearm and the lateral side of his torso, resulting in second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 60 square centimeters. He was treated on-site with first aid cooling measures and topical burn ointment by occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) and remained on light duty for 12 days. The incident was reported by regrind supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) who was present in the adjacent area. Investigation revealed that the lockout/tagout procedure was not followed because the maintenance work was considered 'routine' and took only a few minutes, and the line isolation checklist was not properly completed by the evening shift supervisor.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 4:00 AM during the night shift, purchasing coordinator Christine Desrosiers (EMP-00055) was conducting a physical inventory count in the Warehouse and Shipping facility when she stepped on a small pool of spilled hydraulic fluid near the fork truck charging station. Her foot slipped on the slippery surface, and she fell onto her left knee and elbow on the concrete floor. She sustained minor abrasions and localized swelling to the knee and elbow, and mild inflammation of the left wrist. Occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided immediate first aid treatment including wound cleaning, topical antibiotic ointment application, and ice application. Desrosiers was able to resume light duty work after two hours of rest. The incident was witnessed by night shift supervisor Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) who was in the adjacent maintenance area. Investigation revealed that the hydraulic fluid spill occurred from a leaking connection on the forklift charger, the spill had not been immediately cleaned up by maintenance staff, and no slip-hazard warning sign was posted in the area.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was transferring a pallet of polypropylene resin from the receiving dock to the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) using a motorized pallet jack. As she navigated through the narrow aisle between storage racks, a wooden pallet leaning against an upper shelf began to shift. Mansour noticed the pallet tilting and immediately stopped her pallet jack, stepping back from the load area. The pallet fell approximately 8 feet and struck the concrete floor less than 2 meters from where she had been standing moments earlier. No impact occurred with Mansour or her equipment. The incident was witnessed by Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) who was conducting inventory nearby. Immediate inspection revealed that the pallet had been improperly stacked without securing straps, violating warehouse storage protocols. The near-miss highlighted critical gaps in load securing procedures that could have resulted in serious injury or death had the pallet struck Mansour. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi was notified and declared the incident within 30 minutes of occurrence.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift, Injection Molding Operator Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171) was operating Line D in the Main Production Building when a pneumatic pressure regulator on the mold clamping system failed catastrophically. The regulator, which had been in service for 47 months without maintenance interval review, suddenly lost seal integrity and released pressurized air at 120 PSI directly through the equipment housing. The sudden pressure release caused a valve assembly to dislodge and strike the protective guard adjacent to the molding machine, creating a noise level exceeding 140 dB and causing minor vibration damage to the machine frame. Operator Jalbert was positioned 1.5 meters away and experienced immediate hearing discomfort but sustained no physical injury. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) responded within 2 minutes and immediately shut down the machine using emergency stop protocols. Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123) was notified and assessed the scene. Technical inspection revealed that the regulator had exceeded manufacturer-recommended replacement interval of 36 months due to a missed maintenance cycle in the preventive maintenance schedule. The pneumatic line showed evidence of micro-corrosion internally.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during evening shift operations, Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) discovered that the automated material handling system in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011) had malfunctioned during a routine disposal cycle. The robotic arm, a 6-axis ABB IRB 6700 unit designed to move spent mold release agent containers (25-liter drums) into the containment basin, suddenly reversed direction mid-transfer without completing its programmed sequence. The reverse motion caused one 25-liter drum of acetone-based mold release agent to swing erratically and strike the concrete wall, creating a small containment breach. Approximately 2 liters of mold release agent spilled onto the ground before the system automatically shut down via emergency stop sensors. Material Handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was present 4 meters away and immediately retreated to the exit. The spilled liquid was contained using absorbent material and properly disposed of within the hour. Technical diagnostics revealed that the robot's servo motor controller had experienced a firmware corruption issue, likely caused by an unsaved parameter change during recent maintenance on March 16. No personnel were directly exposed to the chemical, but the equipment failure created potential for serious chemical splash injury.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), an Assembly Operator, was working in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005) on a composite materials assembly line. While removing a finished part from a manual press, Luis reached into the compression zone to extract a molded automotive interior trim component. The part was still partially warm and sticky. As he pulled the component, his right hand slipped on the mold surface and his left forearm made contact with the edge of the descending upper mold plate. The press continued its automatic cycle for approximately 0.8 seconds before the safety interlock engaged. Luis sustained a laceration approximately 8 cm long on his left forearm with partial thickness soft tissue damage and minor crush injury to the underlying muscle tissue. Immediate first aid was administered by onsite medical staff. Luis was transported to a local hospital for evaluation and received 12 stitches. The incident was witnessed by Samantha Brown (EMP-00146), the Composite Materials Lead, who immediately halted operations and activated the emergency response protocol.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) when she noticed unusual vibration and a burning smell emanating from the resin dryer unit (Model CTD-450) where pre-dried glass-fiber reinforced polypropylene pellets are stored at 80°C. Rania immediately notified her supervisor, Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), Evening Shift Production Supervisor. Lucie inspected the unit and observed that the internal heating element thermostat had malfunctioned, causing the chamber temperature to rise to an estimated 156°C—nearly double the setpoint. The high-temperature environment was causing material degradation and releasing acrid fumes of burnt polymer and decomposition byproducts into the surrounding production area. The facility's ventilation system in this zone was operating at reduced capacity due to scheduled maintenance filters not being reinstalled after service that morning. Within 5 minutes of detection, Lucie manually shut down the dryer and activated the emergency ventilation boost. No employee contact with high-temperature surfaces occurred. However, three operators (including Rania) reported mild respiratory irritation from the fumes over the next 2 hours before air quality returned to normal. This represents a near-miss incident where potential chemical exposure and fire hazard were averted through prompt detection and response.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, assembly operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) during the day shift. While manually lifting a 35-kg carton of finished composite parts from a lower shelf to a conveyor belt, she experienced acute lower back pain. The carton was awkwardly positioned and required a twisting motion to extract from the tight shelf space. Ana immediately reported severe pain in her lumbar region and could not continue working. She was assisted by supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) to the first aid station. Medical evaluation revealed a grade 2 lumbar strain with muscle spasm. Ana was referred to a physician and placed on modified duty. She required 8 days away from her regular assembly line duties, returning to light-duty tasks on March 22, 2024. The incident was witnessed by Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) who was nearby restocking supplies.

On February 8, 2024 at 22:15, during the evening shift, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was working in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) on the maintenance workshop mezzanine. While retrieving a hydraulic hose assembly from an upper shelf approximately 2.3 meters high, the storage rack shifted slightly due to uneven weight distribution. A 12-kg metal coupling and bracket assembly began to slide off an adjacent shelf. Dimitri quickly moved laterally and the assembly fell, missing him by approximately 30 centimeters and impacting the concrete floor where he had been standing seconds earlier. The incident was immediately reported by witness Production Engineer Sébastien Carrier (EMP-00065) who was present conducting a maintenance inventory audit. No injuries occurred. The near-miss was documented and investigated, revealing that the storage rack had not been secured to the wall and items had been stacked without attention to weight distribution or securing straps.

On April 2, 2024 at 06:30, during the night shift transition, Injection Molding Operator Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) was operating Injection Molding Line B (UNIT-001) in the main production building north zone. While performing a routine mold change, he attempted to manually retrieve a cooling line connection that had become disconnected from the mold cooling jacket. The pressurized cooling system (operating at 6 bar) suddenly released, spraying 65-degree Celsius cooling water mixed with glycol heat transfer fluid across Youssef's right arm, shoulder, and upper chest. He sustained second-degree thermal burns to approximately 8% of his body surface area (arm and shoulder region). Youssef immediately stepped into the safety shower station and remained there for approximately 8 minutes. Night Shift Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) called emergency medical services, and Youssef was transported to Laval Hospital at 06:52. Medical evaluation confirmed partial-thickness burns requiring hospitalization for 5 days and subsequent outpatient care. Youssef was unable to return to work for 18 days, resuming light-duty tasks on April 20, 2024. Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) was the initial witness who assisted with first aid.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a laceration to his right palm while removing cooled plastic parts from the ejection area of an injection molding machine. The parts had sharp edge burrs from the mold cavity that had not been properly deburred during the previous quality inspection. Marcel was working at a normal pace when his hand slipped while gripping a part, causing the sharp edge to cut into his palm approximately 2 inches long and 0.5 inches deep. The wound required immediate first aid treatment including wound cleaning, antibiotic ointment application, and sterile bandaging. Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) from the evening shift, who was present for shift changeover, witnessed the incident and immediately notified supervisor Jade Wong (EMP-00140). The injury was treated on-site by the HSE team and did not require hospitalization, but workplace first aid intervention was necessary.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-018, Regrind and Recycling Department adjacent section) when a 20-liter container of isopropanol cleaning solvent tipped over during restocking operations. The container, placed on a high shelf without proper secondary containment, was accidentally struck by Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, while retrieving a different chemical container. Approximately 18 liters of isopropanol spilled onto the concrete floor and partially into the facility's stormwater drain system before containment measures could be initiated. The spill created a significant slip hazard and released volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors into the work area. Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), the Mechanical Maintenance Technician on evening shift duty, immediately activated the emergency response protocol, deployed absorbent materials, and notified the HSE coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102). The incident area was ventilated using portable exhaust fans and the spilled material was containerized for proper disposal according to Quebec environmental regulations.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, an environmental incident occurred when a hydraulic fluid leak from an aging injection molding machine (Molding Line C) was discovered pooling near the Raw Materials Warehouse loading area. The equipment, installed in 2008, had developed microscopic cracks in the main hydraulic line due to metal fatigue and corrosion. Over an 8-hour period, approximately 40 liters of ISO 32 hydraulic oil had leaked onto the concrete floor and seeped toward the facility's perimeter French drain system that connects to the municipal stormwater infrastructure. The hydraulic fluid contains polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) at legacy levels from manufacturing before the 2024 equipment upgrade cycle. Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073), the night shift Shipping Coordinator conducting early morning inventory, discovered the spill and immediately reported it to maintenance. Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead called in for night shift coverage, initiated shutdown of the machine and deployed absorbent materials. Nina Santos (EMP-00084), the Industrial Hygienist, was notified and determined that environmental reporting to Quebec's Ministry of Environment was required due to the PCB content and proximity to stormwater drainage.

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Building 5) during the day shift. Employee Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator, was assisting Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) in transferring a 55-gallon drum of acetone-based mold release agent from a storage shelf to a mixing station. While attempting to position the drum on a hand truck, the drum slipped and fell approximately 4 feet to the concrete floor, rupturing a seam and releasing approximately 20 gallons of solvent. The spill generated significant vapor and created a slick surface across approximately 300 square feet of the mixing room floor. Although both employees were wearing basic nitrile gloves and safety glasses, neither was equipped with respiratory protection as the ventilation system was operating. Within minutes, both employees experienced dizziness, headaches, and respiratory irritation. Emergency response procedures were activated at 2:52 PM. Hazmat containment was deployed, the area was evacuated, and the facility's ventilation system was confirmed to be functioning but inadequate for the volume of vapors. Local occupational health clinic evaluated both employees; neither required hospitalization but both experienced symptoms consistent with inhalation of solvent vapors for approximately 4 hours post-exposure.

On November 21, 2024 at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, Packaging Operator Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066) sustained a significant crush injury while operating Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area (UNIT-003). At approximately 11:10 PM, Lucia noticed that the mold cavity was not closing properly after the injection cycle completed. Following inadequate lockout/tagout procedures, she manually reached into the mold cavity to investigate a suspected jam without fully de-energizing the equipment or securing the mold in the open position. At 11:15 PM, the automated mold-closing cycle unexpectedly initiated—likely due to residual pressure in the hydraulic system or a sensor malfunction—trapping her left hand and forearm in the closing mold. The crushing force resulted in severe lacerations, crushing injuries to the metacarpal bones, and partial tissue damage requiring immediate hospitalization. Lucia remained trapped for approximately 5 minutes until Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) arrived, emergency-stopped the equipment, and called emergency medical services at 11:20 PM. Lucia was transported to Laval Hospital emergency department and underwent surgery for hand reconstruction. She is unable to work and remains hospitalized. This incident represents a critical failure in machine guarding and lockout/tagout protocols.

On November 28, 2024 at approximately 9:35 AM during the day shift, Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le (EMP-00036) suffered a lost-time injury while conducting material tensile testing in the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006). Tran was transferring fiber-reinforced polycarbonate test specimens from an autoclave oven that had cooled to approximately 65°C (149°F). While attempting to remove a wooden pallet containing 24 test specimens stacked in a metal frame from the oven's lower shelf, a splinter approximately 3 inches long from the pallet's underside penetrated his left palm during the transfer. The splinter became embedded beneath the epidermis, causing immediate pain and minor bleeding. Tran attempted to remove the splinter himself using tweezers but was unable to fully extract it due to the depth of penetration and the fragile nature of the wood splinter, which broke into fragments. Contamination concerns regarding the wooden pallet material near sterile test specimens used for medical device components prompted immediate consultation with supervisory staff. Tran was sent to the occupational health clinic at 9:50 AM where the embedded splinter fragments were surgically removed. Minor cellulitis developed at the wound site, requiring a 5-day course of oral antibiotics. Tran returned to modified duty on December 2, 2024, and full duty on December 5, 2024, representing 6 workdays lost.

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn while performing routine mold maintenance in UNIT-004 (Injection Molding Line D - Consumer Packaging). Marcel was clearing a plastic blockage from the injection nozzle using a metal scraper when he inadvertently contacted the heated mold surface, which was operating at approximately 95°C. Despite wearing standard cotton work gloves, the heat penetrated the material, causing second-degree burns to his right palm and fingers. The incident occurred because the mold had not been properly cooled or shut down before maintenance began—a deviation from standard lockout/tagout procedures. Marcel immediately ran his hand under cold water for approximately 10 minutes before reporting to the on-site first aid station. The burn covered approximately 8% of his right hand and required emergency room treatment. A witness, Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141), who was working on an adjacent machine, observed the incident and called for medical assistance.

On November 18, 2024 at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, experienced a crush injury while assisting with a material hopper changeover in UNIT-016 (Material Drying and Preparation Room). Paul and his partner Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) were repositioning a 200-pound polypropylene resin hopper from the drying racks when the securing straps failed. The hopper tipped laterally, pinning Paul's left foot and lower leg between the hopper base and a fixed support column. Abdul immediately called for emergency response, and on-site medical personnel arrived within 4 minutes. Paul was hospitalized with a fractured tibia, a severely contused ankle, and soft tissue damage. He required surgical intervention and was admitted for a 5-day inpatient stay. The root cause was identified as corroded and weakened straps that had not been replaced during the facility's last maintenance cycle (overdue by 3 months). This incident resulted in Paul being unable to return to work, triggering CNESST lost-time injury reporting requirements.

On November 22, 2024 at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a critical equipment failure was discovered in UNIT-009 (Shipping and Receiving Dock) when Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler, was preparing the first shipment of the day. The main hydraulic lift gate on the dock had experienced a complete system pressure loss overnight, rendering it inoperable. Upon investigation by maintenance technician Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021), a fractured hydraulic hose was identified as the source—the hose had likely ruptured during the previous evening shift's heavy loading operations when a pallet jack was being maneuvered in close proximity. The fracture was in a high-pressure line connecting the pump to the lift cylinders. Approximately 15 liters of hydraulic fluid had leaked onto the dock floor, creating a slipping hazard and environmental contamination. The lift gate remained non-functional for 18 hours until the hose was replaced.
