This equipment failure prevented the shipping of time-sensitive medical device components (ISO 13485 certified product) totaling approximately $85,000 in value, causing a production delay and customer delivery miss. The incident was classified as an equipment failure with significant operational and financial impact.

On March 15, 2025 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine Line B in the Main Production Building. While clearing a material jam in the hopper using a manual tool, the machine's safety interlock failed and the injection unit suddenly actuated. Gosselin's right hand was caught between the mold platens, suffering a severe crushing injury to his fingers and partial laceration of the palm. A coworker, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), immediately triggered the emergency stop and called for assistance. The injured employee was transported to the hospital with crush injuries requiring surgical intervention. Investigation revealed that the LOTO procedure was not properly followed—the machine was not fully isolated and locked out before maintenance began. The safety interlock had been previously reported as sticky but was never serviced.

On February 22, 2025 at 10:30 AM during day shift operations, Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) was performing final assembly of automotive dashboard components at the Packaging and Labeling Station in the Warehouse and Shipping area. While handling sharp-edged plastic trim pieces, Lopez sustained a deep laceration to the inner surface of her left palm from a burr on a freshly molded component. The cut, approximately 3 inches long and 0.25 inches deep, was bleeding profusely. A coworker, Diego Morales (EMP-00056), applied direct pressure with sterile gauze. Supervisor on duty radioed HSE Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) who arrived within 2 minutes. The wound was cleaned with sterile saline, inspected, and deemed appropriate for first aid treatment with butterfly bandages and antibiotic ointment rather than emergency medical care. The employee received tetanus prophylaxis counseling and was instructed to monitor for signs of infection. Work was resumed after 45 minutes with modified duties avoiding hand contact with sharp edges.

On March 8, 2025 during the evening shift (6:15 PM), Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) conducted a routine inspection of the Hazardous Waste Management Area in the Chemical Storage Building exterior zone. During her inspection, she identified that several large containers of uncured epoxy resin waste were stored immediately adjacent to a propane-powered forklift charging station, with residual resin vapors detected at 45 ppm (below OSHA PEL of 100 ppm but significantly elevated). Additionally, she observed that the fire suppression system nozzles in this area were partially obstructed by stacked material pallets. No immediate hazard resulted, but the configuration presented a significant fire risk given the flammable epoxy vapors and potential ignition sources from the charging station. Dubois documented the findings with photographs and immediately notified the HSE team. The area remained operational but with enhanced monitoring.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, James Thompson (EMP-00029), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a laceration to his right hand while removing a molded part from the injection press. The part, a consumer packaging component made from ABS plastic, had sharp flash edges from the molding process that had not been adequately deburred. As Thompson reached into the mold cavity to extract the part without waiting for the cooling cycle to complete, his hand made contact with the sharp edge, causing a 2-inch laceration on his palm requiring 8 stitches. The incident occurred because the part design had increased complexity with thinner walls, creating more pronounced flash. A coworker, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), witnessed the incident and immediately notified the supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015). First aid was administered on-site, and Thompson was transported to the occupational health clinic for suturing. The employee returned to work the same day with a bandaged hand but was reassigned to light-duty tasks for one week during wound healing.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a Machine Operator, was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on a resin drying unit in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) when the dryer's heating element malfunctioned and overheated unexpectedly. The unit, which normally operates at 80°C, rapidly increased to 145°C without triggering the automatic temperature cutoff. When Traore opened the dryer access panel to investigate an unusual grinding sound, a pressurized burst of superheated steam and desiccant powder was released directly onto her face, neck, and left shoulder, causing second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 12% of exposed body surface. The employee immediately ran to the emergency eyewash station and alerted her supervisor, Régean Simard (EMP-00077), the Mold Maintenance Technician who was working nearby. Emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes. Traore was transported by ambulance to the regional burn center and hospitalized for 5 days requiring specialized burn wound treatment. Root cause investigation identified a failed temperature sensor and non-functional pressure relief valve that had not been replaced during the last preventive maintenance cycle scheduled 6 months prior. This incident resulted in a lost-time injury with an estimated 21 days away from work during recovery and scar tissue management.

On May 8, 2024, at 6:15 AM during the night shift, Jing Wang (EMP-00054), a Materials Engineer, was conducting a routine inspection of the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) when she observed that a large stack of polycarbonate resin pallets (approximately 8 feet high, weighing roughly 2,400 pounds total) had shifted out of alignment and was leaning at a 12-degree angle toward the main aisle where warehouse staff regularly walk. The stack was positioned on a standard pallet rack system that appeared to have uneven weight distribution due to improper stacking of pallets during the previous evening shift. Wang immediately recognized the serious potential for a load drop incident and took the following actions: (1) she cordoned off the affected area with yellow safety tape and placed "Do Not Enter" warning signs, (2) she radioed to Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), the Warehouse Associate on duty, to evacuate the immediate vicinity, and (3) she contacted supervisory personnel to report the near-miss condition. No employee was injured during this event, and no load actually fell. Within 2 hours, the unstable stack was safely secured by warehouse management personnel using proper load stabilization techniques and rearranged according to documented stacking procedures. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the hazardous condition was identified before any person was struck or any load was dropped, though the potential consequences would have been severe given the mass and height of the load.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was performing routine preventive maintenance on Injection Molding Line A in the Main Production Building - North Zone. While inspecting the hydraulic pressure release valve on the injection unit, Sana noticed excessive heat emanating from the valve assembly and observed a small drip of hydraulic fluid accumulating beneath it. She immediately stopped the machine and notified her supervisor, Michael Chen (EMP-00004). Upon examination, the valve showed signs of corrosion and the sealing surface appeared compromised. Sana and Michael determined the valve required immediate replacement to prevent a potential catastrophic pressure release event that could result in severe thermal burns or equipment damage. The machine was locked out (LOTO procedures followed) and the valve assembly was isolated. Sana documented her findings in the preventive maintenance log and reported the issue to the HSE Office as a proactive measure to prevent future incidents. No injury occurred during this inspection. This preventive declaration demonstrates the company's commitment to identifying and addressing potential hazards before they escalate to actual incidents.

On April 8, 2024, at 09:15, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) was working at the Assembly and Finishing Department on the automotive component line. While transferring a batch of composite parts from a curing station to the next assembly stage, Elena reached across a conveyor belt to grab a part. Her sleeve caught on the moving conveyor belt, causing her arm to be pulled toward the roller mechanism. Elena immediately shouted for help and managed to pull her arm back before it became entangled. Witness Assembly Lead Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128) quickly shut down the conveyor using the emergency stop button and assessed Elena for injuries. Elena experienced minor abrasions and bruising to her forearm but no fractures or lacerations. The incident was investigated and determined to be a near-miss with high potential for serious injury. Root cause analysis identified that Elena was reaching across the conveyor due to awkward workstation layout and inadequate spacing between work zones. No machinery damage occurred, and Elena was treated by the on-site first aid station.

On May 22, 2024, at 16:42, a small electrical fire was discovered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) noticed smoke coming from a junction box near the resin mixing tanks and immediately activated the fire alarm system. The alarm triggered automated response protocols: the facility was evacuated, and the automatic fire suppression system activated, deploying dry chemical extinguishing agent appropriate for electrical fires. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) coordinated the evacuation and confirmed all personnel were accounted for at the assembly points. The Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the fire was extinguished. Investigation revealed that the junction box serving the resin dryer had accumulated dust and moisture from the humid environment inside the chemical storage area, leading to an electrical arcing condition. The fire was contained to the junction box area with no damage to adjacent equipment or chemical storage. No injuries occurred. The incident was classified as a fire alarm event requiring immediate facility-level response and hazard remediation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine maintenance on the medical-grade injection molding machine when a coworker, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), inadvertently restarted the equipment without proper lockout/tagout procedures. Stéphane's left hand was caught in the mold closing mechanism, resulting in crush injuries to his fingers and palm. The machine was immediately shut down by production supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) who witnessed the incident. Stéphane was transported to Laval Hospital with crush injuries requiring surgical intervention and hospitalization for 6 days. Investigation revealed that the LOTO checklist had not been completed and the machine's emergency stop was obscured by production documentation. This incident resulted in 42 lost work days due to recovery and rehabilitation.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:30 AM during day shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler in the Material Drying and Preparation Room, noticed an unusual grinding sound and visible overheating of the resin dryer unit designated for processing polycarbonate materials. The equipment's temperature gauge was reading 185°C, exceeding the safe operating limit of 160°C. Elif immediately notified her supervisor and Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, was called to investigate. Upon inspection, it was determined that the dryer's thermostat had failed, causing temperature escalation that could result in material degradation and potential equipment fire. The equipment was immediately powered down and tagged out. A review of maintenance logs revealed the dryer had not received preventive maintenance in 8 months, exceeding the 6-month service interval specified by the manufacturer. This represents a potential hazard that could have resulted in significant equipment damage or facility fire.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during evening shift, Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), a Forklift Operator, was moving a pallet of finished composite materials from the Assembly and Finishing Department toward the warehouse when the rear forks of his electric forklift caught the corner of a structural support column that had been temporarily marked with faded yellow paint. The impact caused the pallet, which contained approximately 2,400 pounds of finished medical-grade composite components, to shift and fall approximately 6 feet to the concrete floor below. The pallet broke apart upon impact, destroying an estimated 847 components valued at $31,500 CAD. The scattered materials created a temporary hazard in the production area, requiring cleanup and safety containment. A review of incident conditions revealed that the column marking had deteriorated over time and was nearly invisible under the facility's evening shift lighting, and the forklift's load capacity warning system was not audible due to background noise levels in the facility.

On March 14, 2025 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186), an Assembly Operator, was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station in the Warehouse and Shipping Prep Area. She was manually assembling medical device housings for final packaging when her right hand made contact with a sharp, freshly-molded edge on a polycarbonate component. The edge, which should have been deburred during post-processing, created a laceration on her palm requiring immediate first aid. A coworker, Monique Dion (EMP-00119), witnessed the incident and immediately notified the station supervisor. The cut was cleaned, bandaged, and documented. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the deburring station had been temporarily bypassed due to equipment maintenance that was not properly communicated to the assembly team. The employee experienced minimal bleeding and pain but was able to continue work after receiving first aid.

On February 28, 2025 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, James Thompson (EMP-00029), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was monitoring the production cycle in the Main Production Building North Zone (UNIT-002). A hydraulic pressure sensor malfunction caused the injection pressure to spike unexpectedly during the mold closing phase. Although the mold did not close on any body part, the sudden pressure surge caused the machine to emit a loud hissing sound and vibrate violently for approximately 3 seconds before the emergency stop function activated automatically. James immediately stepped back from the machine and observed the safety barrier. No physical contact occurred. His supervisor, André Paradis (EMP-00037), responded immediately and confirmed the emergency stop had been activated. The machine was locked out per LOTO procedures. No injury occurred, but the potential for a crush injury existed. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the automatic safety system prevented contact during the critical moment when a hand could have been positioned in the mold area.

On April 2, 2025 at 8:30 AM during the day shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, was transferring bulk polypropylene resin from pallets in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) to the compounding area using an electric forklift. While navigating through the narrow aisle between two 12-foot-high storage racks, Elif attempted to turn the forklift too sharply while at an elevated platform. The front-left fork caught the edge of an upper shelf, destabilizing a 400-pound bundle of carbon fiber reinforcement material. The bundle fell approximately 8 feet, striking Elif on the left shoulder and upper back before she could move clear. She was knocked to the ground and sustained a fractured left clavicle, contused ribs, and significant soft tissue trauma. Co-worker Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) immediately called for emergency assistance. Elif was transported by ambulance to Sacré-Cœur Hospital in Montreal and hospitalized for 48 hours. She required imaging, orthopedic consultation, and pain management. The incident resulted in 14 days of lost work time while recovering.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Packaging Operator Amara Diop (EMP-00110) was working in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) when she sustained a laceration to her left index finger. While manually loading recycled plastic pellets into the regrind hopper, her gloved hand made contact with a rotating auger blade that was insufficiently guarded. The blade caught her glove and pulled her finger into the rotating mechanism, resulting in a 2-inch laceration across the finger pad. Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) immediately stopped the equipment and applied first aid with sterile gauze and bandaging. Paramedics arrived within 10 minutes and assessed the injury as non-threatening but requiring stitches. The employee received first aid treatment on-site and was transported to the local medical clinic for wound closure. No lost work time resulted from this incident. The equipment guard was found to have been partially dislodged during routine maintenance performed the previous day.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:30 AM, Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) conducted a routine inspection of the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (UNIT-017) and identified a significant hazard requiring immediate preventive declaration. During her inspection, she discovered that the industrial oven ventilation system, which exhausts fumes from composite fiber processing, had been operating at reduced capacity for approximately 2 weeks due to a partially blocked intake filter. The blockage was attributed to accumulated composite dust not being properly filtered. Area air quality measurements showed respirable particulate levels at 4.2 mg/m³, approaching the exposure limit. Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) was stationed in this area during the inspection and was interviewed regarding any health symptoms. No acute symptoms were reported, but Ms. Patel mentioned occasional throat irritation during high-production days. The ventilation system was immediately shut down pending filter replacement and duct cleaning. An interim portable HEPA filtration unit was deployed to maintain air quality. This preventive declaration was issued to prevent respiratory issues and ensure compliance with CNESST air quality standards.

On April 22, 2024, at 6:15 PM during the evening shift, an automated material handling system malfunction in the Injection Molding Line A facility (UNIT-001) resulted in significant property damage. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) was monitoring production when the robotic arm servicing the injection molding line experienced a hydraulic pressure surge, causing the arm to move erratically. The malfunctioning arm struck and damaged a finished parts conveyor system, bending the conveyor frame and destroying approximately 2,400 precision plastic components awaiting quality inspection. The total value of damaged parts was estimated at $47,000, and conveyor repair costs were estimated at $12,500. The root cause was determined to be a faulty pressure relief valve in the hydraulic system that had been showing signs of degradation for several weeks but was not replaced during routine maintenance. Machine Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) was operating nearby but was not physically injured. The incident was reported by Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), and the equipment was immediately taken offline for repair and safety inspection.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), an Assembly Operator on the day shift, was removing finished medical components from Injection Molding Line C in the clean room area. While extracting a polycarbonate housing unit from the mold cavity, her left hand made contact with the semi-hot mold surface (approximately 65°C), causing a thermal burn across her palm and three fingers. The incident occurred because the automatic cooling cycle had been partially bypassed due to a malfunctioning temperature sensor that had not been replaced during the previous maintenance window. Isabella immediately ran her hand under cool water from the nearby safety station and reported the burn to her supervisor. A first aid assessment determined the burn was superficial to moderate (second degree), affecting approximately 5% of body surface area. The safety officer applied sterile dressing and arranged transport to the on-site occupational health clinic where the wound was professionally treated. No hospitalization was required. The employee was able to return to modified duty the following day with protective bandaging.

On April 2, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), a Composite Materials Operator, was transferring containers of glass-fiber reinforced thermoplastic material from the staging area to the compounding equipment in the production facility. While manually moving a 25 kg container of raw material, she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. The container had not been properly balanced on the transport cart due to uneven weight distribution, causing her to experience a sudden twisting motion while lifting. Lina immediately stopped work and reported pain but attempted to continue her shift. By 23:30, the pain had intensified significantly, and she was unable to perform her duties. She was transported to the emergency department by a company vehicle where diagnostic imaging revealed a herniated disc at the L4-L5 level with nerve compression. She was admitted for overnight observation and prescribed medication and physical therapy. The employee was placed on medical leave for 6 weeks, resulting in lost work time. Investigation revealed that proper lifting equipment (lift-assist devices) had been removed from the composite staging area three weeks prior for maintenance but were never reinstalled.

On May 8, 2024 at 03:30 during the night shift, Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate, was restocking raw material resin containers in Section A of the Raw Materials Warehouse. He was moving a pallet of polypropylene resin using an electric forklift to position containers on the upper shelving (approximately 2.8 meters high). While lowering the pallet, Marc lost control of the forklift briefly due to uneven floor surface near the loading dock. The pallet shifted and one 50 kg container of resin fell, striking Marc on the right shoulder and upper arm. The force of impact caused him to fall backward onto the concrete floor, resulting in a fractured right clavicle and a laceration to his right forearm requiring 12 stitches. Normand Bergeron, the Regrind Supervisor who was present doing inventory, immediately called emergency services. Marc was transported by ambulance to the Regional Hospital where he underwent X-rays and suturing. He was hospitalized for 24 hours for pain management and observation. The employee was placed on medical leave and unable to work for 8 weeks due to the severity of the fracture and required physical rehabilitation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, material handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was organizing raw material storage in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) when she noticed a strong chemical odor emanating from the southeast corner. Upon investigation, she discovered that a storage rack containing approximately 15 drums of polypropylene resin had shifted, causing three drums to leak onto the concrete floor. The spilled resin had begun to accumulate in a low-lying area near the floor drain, and the fumes were noticeably concentrated in that zone. Marwa immediately reported the situation to EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury. The area was evacuated, and the ventilation system in the warehouse section was manually increased. Environmental Services team arrived within 30 minutes to contain the spill using absorbent materials and temporary barriers. Approximately 12 liters of resin were recovered. Root cause analysis determined that the rack had not been properly secured following a recent inventory reorganization, and the drums had shifted due to vibrations from nearby forklift operations. The incident resulted in no direct injuries but created an environmental hazard requiring containment and cleanup. Air quality monitoring confirmed resin particulate levels returned to baseline within 4 hours.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was cleaning residual plastic debris from ventilation ducts above the mixing equipment using compressed air when a spark from an adjacent grinder ignited accumulated plastic dust that had accumulated on horizontal surfaces despite recent cleaning. The dust cloud ignited with a flash that spread along the ventilation system, creating flames approximately 6 feet in height. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), who was conducting an evening safety walkthrough, immediately activated the emergency alarm and deployed a 20-pound dry chemical fire extinguisher, successfully suppressing the flames within 90 seconds. Emergency responders arrived 8 minutes later and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. Investigation revealed that the dust accumulation resulted from inadequate frequency of ventilation duct cleaning (last cleaned 6 months prior) and lack of hot work permits for the concurrent grinding operation. The compressed air used in cleaning should never have been used for dust removal per standard protocols. No employees were injured, but the incident resulted in minor surface damage to equipment and required facility evacuation for 2 hours while air quality was verified.

On May 8, 2024, at 8:20 AM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186) sustained a laceration to her left index finger while performing a manual part removal operation at a production workstation in the Cafeteria and Break Room area (UNIT-024) where a temporary assembly station had been set up to accommodate increased production demand. While removing a finished molded plastic component from a fixture, Valentina's finger contacted a sharp edge that had not been properly deburred during the molding process. The laceration was approximately 1.5 centimeters long and created moderate bleeding. Valentina immediately notified her supervisor and made her way to the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006) where first aid supplies were available. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) provided immediate first aid treatment: wound cleansing with sterile saline, application of pressure dressing, and wound closure using sterile adhesive strips after bleeding subsided. The injury did not require sutures or external medical attention. Valentina returned to work after 30 minutes of treatment and observation. Root cause analysis determined that quality control inspection procedures had not flagged the sharp edge burr, likely due to inspector fatigue during high-volume production periods. The temporary workstation setup also lacked the standard ergonomic guards typically present at permanent assembly stations.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum to smaller containers for distribution to production areas when the transfer pump malfunctioned, causing approximately 12 gallons of acetone to spill onto the concrete floor. The spill spread rapidly across the room due to the floor's slight slope toward the drain. Mansour immediately notified her supervisor and activated the emergency response protocol. The facility's secondary containment system was inadequate, allowing acetone vapors to accumulate. Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140) and Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) responded to assist with containment. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and the area was evacuated due to elevated vapor concentrations. No personal injuries occurred, but the incident highlighted deficiencies in chemical handling procedures and equipment maintenance. The chemical spill posed risks to both employee health and environmental contamination.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) suffered a significant lost-time injury at Injection Molding Line A while performing routine mold changeover operations. While loosening retaining bolts on a mold assembly, Ndiaye's left hand became caught between the mold and the machine frame when an overhead crane operator (Tariq Aziz, EMP-00118) inadvertently moved the mold despite Ndiaye's hand being positioned in the pinch point. The incident resulted in crushing injuries to fingers and hand tissues, requiring immediate emergency response. Ndiaye was transported via ambulance to Laval Medical Center at 10:35 AM. Diagnosis included three fractured metacarpal bones, extensive soft tissue trauma, and temporary nerve compression. The attending physician prescribed 8 weeks of medical leave with restricted duty upon return. Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was present and witnessed the incident, immediately calling emergency services. The root cause analysis identified inadequate lockout/tagout procedures and lack of communication protocol between crane operators and ground-level workers during equipment changeovers.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 8:50 PM during the evening shift, Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le (EMP-00036) narrowly avoided a serious injury while performing viscosity testing on a resin sample in the Quality Control Laboratory. Le was operating a rotational viscometer when the equipment's safety guard, which had been improperly secured during routine maintenance, suddenly detached. The rotating spindle became partially exposed, and Le's left sleeve made contact with the exposed rotating element, causing immediate fabric catching and minor abrasion to the forearm. Le quickly disengaged the equipment, preventing more severe laceration or entanglement. Materials Supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031) was present in the lab and witnessed the incident, immediately securing the equipment and providing first aid. A friction burn approximately 3 cm in length was treated with topical antibiotic and dressing. The incident was classified as a near-miss with minor injury consequences. Investigation revealed that the safety guard's fastening mechanism had not been properly reinstalled after the previous day's cleaning and maintenance, and there was no verification checklist for equipment safety features.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45, production operator Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109) was operating Injection Molding Line B when he reached into the mold cavity to manually remove a stuck part without following proper LOTO procedures. The mold unexpectedly closed due to a timing sensor malfunction that had been reported but not yet repaired. Gendron's right hand was caught between the mold halves, sustaining a crush injury to his index and middle fingers. Coworker Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026) immediately witnessed the incident and activated the emergency stop. Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) arrived as first responder and assisted in carefully opening the mold. The employee was transported to Laval Hospital with suspected metacarpal fractures and soft tissue damage. The incident occurred because the timing sensor repair had been deferred for 3 weeks due to production scheduling pressure, and the employee had not been reminded of LOTO requirements before shift.

On November 16, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, regrind technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was transferring spent plastic material from the injection molding lines to the regrind station in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. While decanting a 5-gallon container of acetone-based mold release agent into a collection tank, the container slipped from his grip due to wet gloves and fell, spilling approximately 3 gallons of acetone across the concrete floor and into the facility's storm drain system. The chemical spread across a 12-square-meter area. Ramirez immediately reported the incident to his supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147). Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified and initiated spill containment procedures. The area was evacuated and ventilation systems activated to full capacity. Approximately 2 hours were required for cleanup using absorbent pads and chemical neutralizers. Samples were collected to assess environmental contamination in the storm drain system. Root cause was inadequate grip on aging chemical containers combined with wet handling conditions and lack of secondary containment.

On November 18, 2024, at 06:30 during night shift operations, production operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) discovered that the ventilation system serving the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (Unit 010) had failed during the overnight period. The system's motor had seized, cutting air exchange from approximately 12 changes per hour to zero. Upon discovering the malfunction, Mensah immediately notified Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157). The building air monitoring system triggered alarms indicating rising concentrations of organic vapor compounds from the stored isopropanol and acetone supplies. The chemical storage building was evacuated and secured pending system repair. All chemical transfer and mixing operations were halted. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) was called in to assess the damage. The ventilation motor bearing had degraded due to lack of preventive maintenance; oil analysis had not been performed in 14 months despite quarterly requirements. The system remained offline for 18 hours pending motor replacement. Environmental testing confirmed no chemical release to the exterior environment, but indoor air quality standards were temporarily exceeded.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was operating Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging area when the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned. The valve, which should maintain pressure between 1800-2000 PSI, suddenly failed to release excess pressure during the mold closing cycle. This caused the injection pressure to spike to 2400 PSI, forcing hot molten polypropylene resin to escape from a hairline crack in the mold assembly. The pressurized plastic spray escaped through the mold's vent hole and contacted Rémi's right forearm, causing second-degree thermal burns across approximately 8 square inches of skin. The immediate response included shutting down the line, ice water cooling of the affected area, and emergency medical transport to the hospital. The line remained non-operational for 48 hours pending hydraulic system inspection. Root cause analysis revealed the relief valve had not been serviced since installation 18 months prior, exceeding the manufacturer's 12-month maintenance interval by 6 months.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was preparing to load a pallet of raw ABS resin pellets from the Material Drying and Preparation Room onto a warehouse storage rack using a powered pallet jack. As she approached the rack location, she noticed the floor had a small spill of hydraulic oil from a maintenance activity earlier that day. Although the spill had been partially cleaned, a slick residual film remained on the concrete floor. Elif attempted to maneuver the pallet jack around the slick area but the jack's wheels lost traction and began to slide sideways. She immediately released the handle and stepped back, allowing the jack to drift slowly into an empty storage bay where it contacted the wall at low speed with no damage. Had the jack continued on its original path, it would have struck Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045) who was organizing inventory 6 feet away and unaware of the situation. Patrick saw the situation unfold and shouted a warning that had already prompted Elif's reaction. The near-miss was documented and reported by Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) who was in the warehouse conducting a routine safety inspection.

On March 28, 2024 at 03:30 during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing scheduled preventive maintenance on the composite materials processing equipment in the west wing of the main production building. He was cleaning the internal mixing chamber of a fiber-reinforced polymer batch mixer, which had been powered down and locked out per LOTO procedures. While using compressed air to dislodge cured resin residue from the chamber walls, Alain positioned his face approximately 8 inches from the chamber opening to observe the cleaning process. A high-pressure air jet (operating at 90 PSI) unexpectedly directed a small fragment of hardened composite material directly at his left eye. The fragment struck his eye but caused only minor irritation and slight redness. Alain immediately ceased the compressed air operation and reported the incident. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) responded and conducted an eye examination, determining no corneal abrasion had occurred, but recommended precautionary eye drops and a follow-up examination the next day. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the fragment's velocity was reduced due to distance and the fragment's small size.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was transferring resin pellets from a storage hopper to a drying unit in the Material Drying and Preparation Room when the hopper lid suddenly detached due to corroded mounting bolts. The 45-pound aluminum lid fell approximately 4 feet, striking a nearby injection molding cart and damaging the cart's framework and electrical control panel. The cart, valued at $8,500, sustained significant structural damage to its left side support beams and the integrated PLC control system was rendered inoperable. No personnel were directly struck, though Osman was standing within 6 feet of the impact zone. The incident was witnessed by Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) who was working on an adjacent molding line. Facility maintenance discovered the bolts had corroded due to moisture exposure from the humidified air circulation system. The damaged cart was removed from service and sent for repairs, disrupting production schedules for two consumer packaging product lines for approximately 6 hours.

On April 2, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D's hydraulic press when a coworker, Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), accidentally activated the machine start sequence while Gosselin was working within the press cavity. Gosselin's right hand became trapped between the press platens, sustaining a crush injury to his fingers and palm. The press was immediately stopped by emergency stop button activation by nearby Quality Supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079). Gosselin was transported to the emergency room with severe contusions, two fractured fingers (ring and middle), and partial soft tissue damage requiring surgical intervention and 12 weeks of recovery. Investigation revealed that the LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure had not been properly followed—the machine was in service mode rather than locked-out maintenance mode, and the hydraulic system remained pressurized. No audible or visual warning system was active to alert personnel to imminent machine startup. This incident resulted in significant lost work time and required modification of maintenance protocols.

On May 8, 2024 at 01:30 during the night shift, a spontaneous fire erupted in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when stored containers of incompatible materials (acetone-based mold release agent and isopropanol cleaning solvent) were inadvertently placed adjacent to each other on an unsecured shelf. An apparent vibration from nearby equipment caused one container to tip and rupture, spilling approximately 8 liters of acetone onto the floor and adjacent shelving. The spilled liquid contacted an improperly stored aerosol masterbatch canister, which created an exothermic reaction and ignited spontaneously at 01:47. The fire spread rapidly across the chemical storage area, consuming cardboard boxes of colorant and several additional solvent containers. Tool Room Technician Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173), the only night-shift personnel present in that zone, discovered the fire and immediately activated the facility's fire suppression system and emergency alarm at 01:48. The automatic sprinkler system and dry chemical suppression equipment contained the fire to the storage area, but not before approximately 120 square feet of shelving and $34,000 worth of chemical inventory were destroyed. The fire department arrived at 02:05 and confirmed the area was secure. The incident was declared by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) who responded to the facility. Investigation identified multiple root causes: lack of chemical segregation signage, inadequate shelf stability, insufficient separation of incompatible materials per WHMIS guidelines, and incomplete night-shift staff training on chemical storage protocols.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a fire originated in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (UNIT-017) located in the South Zone of the main production building. Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), a Mechanical Maintenance Technician, was performing routine maintenance on a resin dryer when he noticed overheating in the control panel. While attempting to adjust the temperature settings, an electrical arc ignited residual resin dust that had accumulated on the equipment frame and surrounding work surfaces. The fire spread rapidly across approximately 8 square meters before being detected by the facility's automated smoke detection system at 2:17 PM. The emergency alarm was activated, and production supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) immediately initiated evacuation procedures. The facility's fire suppression system activated automatically, but the fire required additional intervention from the Laval Fire Department, who arrived within 8 minutes. The fire was fully extinguished by 2:52 PM. No injuries were sustained, but damage to the resin dryer and surrounding equipment was estimated at approximately $145,000. The incident was declared by Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), the Workplace Safety Representative, following initial investigation.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, an environmental incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) located in Warehouse Section B. Material handlers Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) and Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) were organizing finished composite products on storage racks when a forklift operated by a contract worker (not on TechnoPlast roster) struck the base of a tall storage rack containing approximately 240 kg of polycarbonate (PC) injection-molded parts. The impact destabilized the rack, causing approximately 60 kg of polycarbonate components to cascade onto the warehouse floor. Several containers ruptured, and the PC pellets mixed with an estimated 15 liters of spilled acetone-based mold release agent stored on the adjacent lower shelf. The chemical and plastic material mixture created a hazardous spill covering approximately 12 square meters. Diallo immediately contacted facility management. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer, responded and initiated containment procedures using absorbent materials and chemical spill kits. The warehouse was partially evacuated, and the affected area was cordoned off for 6 hours pending cleanup. Environmental monitoring detected airborne acetone vapors at 180 ppm (OSHA PEL: 750 ppm), but concentrations exceeded comfort levels. The incident was formally declared by André Bellavance (EMP-00157), Confined Space Entry Supervisor, following cleanup completion.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), a Quality Inspector, suffered a significant crush injury while conducting final product inspection in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Patel was manually removing a completed polypropylene injection-molded component from a two-plate mold that was mounted in a compression press. While attempting to separate the mold halves using the manual opening mechanism, the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned, causing the mold to close unexpectedly while her right hand was still positioned between the cavity and core halves. The mold compressed with an estimated force of 45 metric tons, crushing the distal portion of her right index and middle fingers and causing significant contusion to the dorsal hand surface. Patel immediately cried out for assistance. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) heard her distress and activated the emergency mold release button, which depressurized the system and allowed manual separation within 8 seconds. Patel was removed from the press with visible trauma to her right hand. Emergency medical services were called, and she was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital in Cartierville, Quebec. Initial assessment revealed partial amputation of the index fingertip (distal phalanx), crushing fracture of the middle finger, and extensive soft tissue damage requiring surgical repair. She was hospitalized for 4 days and subsequently placed on medical leave. Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), Workplace Safety Representative, declared the incident following immediate scene investigation.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, an equipment malfunction in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) resulted in a significant environmental incident. Vincent Létourneau, Instrumentation Technician, was conducting routine maintenance on the resin dryer system when a temperature control valve failed catastrophically. The failure caused a pressurized release of hot resin fumes and solvent vapors directly into the production area. Approximately 150 liters of partially polymerized resin material leaked onto the concrete floor, spreading across the material handling zone. The spill contained volatile organic compounds (VOCs) that immediately began evaporating, creating a hazardous vapor cloud. Emergency ventilation systems activated automatically, but not before several nearby workers reported respiratory irritation and eye discomfort. The incident was contained within 45 minutes through emergency response procedures, but the environmental contamination affected approximately 800 square meters of floor space. Roland Dostie, Maintenance Planner, responded immediately and coordinated isolation of the affected equipment. The spill required specialized hazardous waste disposal, and the facility temporarily relocated affected production operations to alternative zones.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 11:20 AM during the day shift, a minor burn incident occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017). Lucia Martinez, Packaging Operator, was assisting with manual removal of composite parts from a cooling conveyor belt when she inadvertently made contact with a residual hot surface on the equipment. The part temperature measured approximately 65°C at the point of contact. Upon contact with the back of her left hand, she immediately experienced localized thermal burn sensation. The burn was limited to a 3cm x 2cm area with slight erythema (redness) but no blistering. Lucia immediately immersed her hand in cool water for 10 minutes at the nearby safety station and reported the incident to her supervisor, Anika Johansson. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid was called to the production floor and assessed the injury within 5 minutes of the incident. The burn was classified as a superficial first-degree thermal burn. First aid treatment consisted of continued cool water irrigation, application of topical antibiotic ointment (bacitracin), and application of a sterile non-adherent dressing. The employee experienced minimal discomfort and returned to work within 30 minutes with modified duties avoiding heat exposure. No hospitalization or lost time was required.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a serious entanglement injury occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Denis Savard, Purchasing Manager, was performing an unscheduled walk-through inspection of warehouse operations when he observed that recycled material was not properly feeding into the grinding hopper. Against established procedure, he reached into the hopper to manually dislodge what appeared to be a blockage without first de-energizing the grinding mill equipment. His right hand was approximately 15cm into the hopper when the auger system unexpectedly activated (the equipment had a malfunctioning proximity sensor that failed to detect his hand). His right forearm was immediately caught between the rotating auger flighting and the hopper wall, causing significant compression and abrasion injuries. A nearby employee, Natalya Kozlov (Quality Technician), heard his cry for help and immediately pressed the emergency stop button located 2 meters away. Response time was approximately 8 seconds, but by that time, Denis had suffered deep lacerations, crushing injuries to the forearm, and partial thickness burns from friction heating. Emergency response personnel (led by responder Roland Dostie) carefully reversed the auger rotation to extract his arm without additional trauma. Denis was transported by ambulance to Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal Emergency Department where he received surgical treatment for laceration repair, tissue assessment, and infection prevention. He sustained permanent partial loss of grip strength in the right hand requiring 6 months of occupational rehabilitation.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician on the day shift, sustained a significant thermal burn while operating Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone. Pascal was removing a finished automotive component from the mold when the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned, causing pressurized hot plastic material (approximately 280°C) to spray onto his right forearm and hand. He immediately ran to the emergency eyewash station and cooled the affected area with water for approximately 15 minutes. A colleague, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), witnessed the incident and immediately notified supervision. Deepa Gupta (EMP-00080), the Process Quality Engineer, responded and assessed the injury as a deep partial-thickness burn covering approximately 12% of the right forearm. Pascal was transported via ambulance to Laval Hospital where he received treatment for second-degree burns and was admitted for overnight observation. The incident was attributed to inadequate preventive maintenance on the hydraulic system and a lack of proper machine guarding around the hot plastic ejection point. Pascal required 5 days off work for medical treatment and wound care.

On March 22, 2025, at approximately 8:45 PM during the evening shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), a Machine Setter, was transferring a 20-liter container of acetone-based mold release agent from storage to a mixing tank when the container's spout connector failed, causing approximately 8 liters of solvent to spill across the concrete floor. The spill spread rapidly across approximately 15 square meters of the preparation room and began seeping toward a floor drain connected to the facility's wastewater system. Tomas immediately activated the emergency alarm and evacuated the immediate area. Valerie Pelletier (EMP-00031), the Materials Supervisor, responded within 2 minutes and implemented spill containment protocols using absorbent pads and barriers. However, approximately 2-3 liters had already entered the drain system before containment was achieved. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, was called in to document the spill and coordinate cleanup. The facility's environmental management procedures required reporting to the Quebec Ministry of Environment, as the spill exceeded the 5-liter reporting threshold for volatile organic compounds. The solvent vapors caused minor respiratory irritation to two nearby warehouse staff members, though no serious injuries occurred. Root cause analysis identified the connector as defective due to improper maintenance and lack of secondary containment protocols.

On March 18, 2025, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), a Facilities Maintenance Technician, was conducting a routine inspection of the compressed air distribution system in the Assembly and Finishing Department when he identified a potential safety hazard. While performing pressure tests on the main air header line, Gilles noticed that several connection points in the system exhibited visible corrosion and micro-fractures in the tubing. The system had been operating for 12 years without major overhaul, and Gilles recognized that continued operation could lead to catastrophic pressure release, potential equipment failure, or injury to nearby workers. He immediately isolated the affected section using shutoff valves and documented his findings with photographs. Gilles reported his observations to Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead, who serves as the shift's senior maintenance coordinator. Claude confirmed the risk assessment and initiated a work order to schedule a comprehensive system inspection and replacement. No immediate incident occurred, but the proactive identification prevented a potential high-severity pressure release burn or explosive failure. This preventive declaration was logged in the facility's near-miss database on March 19, 2025, and formally reported to the JHSC at the monthly safety meeting.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) was working at Injection Molding Line B when she contacted a freshly applied mold release agent while removing a finished component from the mold cavity. Despite wearing nitrile gloves, the agent seeped through a small tear in the glove at her right wrist. Within minutes, Zainab experienced skin irritation, redness, and localized burning sensation. She immediately reported the incident to her supervisor and proceeded to the eye wash station where she flushed the affected area with water for 15 minutes. The occupational health nurse, Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), assessed the injury and determined it was a mild chemical irritation requiring first aid treatment. The area was cleaned, dried, and a topical cortisone cream was applied. Zainab was given a replacement pair of gloves and returned to work after 30 minutes of observation. No lost work time was recorded. The incident was documented by Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001), Director of HSE.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Packaging Operator Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066) was transferring finished composite material parts from a storage cart to the packaging station at the Packaging and Labeling Station. While lifting a 12-pound batch of parts, she experienced a sudden sharp pain in her lower back. The pain was concentrated in the lumbar region and radiated slightly down her left leg. She immediately stopped the activity and reported the incident to Packaging Supervisor Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), who assessed the situation. The pain was consistent with a minor muscle strain. Lucia was directed to sit down and apply an ice pack for 20 minutes. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) arrived at the workstation within 15 minutes, performed a physical assessment, and provided over-the-counter ibuprofen and a compression back support. The nurse documented the injury as a mild muscular strain and advised Lucia to monitor symptoms. Lucia returned to light-duty work on modified tasks avoiding heavy lifting for the remainder of her shift. The incident was officially reported by Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001).

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Automation Technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) was conducting routine preventative maintenance on an injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. While preparing to perform a lockout/tagout procedure on the machine's hydraulic system, Aya noticed that the previous shift's maintenance tag had not been properly removed and was partially blocking access to the main power disconnect. Before removing the old tag, Aya checked the machine's status display and noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge showed unexpected fluctuation—the pressure was registering at 85 PSI when it should have been at zero during idle state. This indicated a potential hydraulic leak or valve malfunction. Aya immediately stopped her maintenance activities and instead of proceeding with the work, she documented the pressure anomaly, took photographs of the gauge reading, and notified Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie (EMP-00199) via the facility's emergency communication system. Roland responded within 5 minutes and confirmed that the anomaly represented a potential safety hazard that could result in unexpected machine movement during maintenance. The machine was immediately isolated, a work permit was issued, and the hydraulic system was scheduled for professional inspection by an external contractor. This near-miss was reported by Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), as it prevented a potential crush injury hazard.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Operator Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024) was removing finished automotive trim components from a cooling chamber when the hydraulic pressure release valve on the industrial oven malfunctioned. The valve, which had not been serviced in 18 months despite a recommended 12-month maintenance schedule, suddenly released pressurized hot air and residual plastic vapor. The discharge struck a stack of freshly molded polycarbonate door handle components stored on an adjacent cart, causing approximately 847 parts valued at $12,400 to be damaged beyond recovery. The hot air also melted portions of the cart's polymer frame and scorched the vinyl safety matting on the floor. Yasmin was not physically injured but reported the incident immediately. Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi responded within 10 minutes and secured the equipment. The damaged inventory required write-off, and production was delayed by 4 hours while the oven was inspected and the valve was replaced.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) sustained a significant laceration requiring emergency hospitalization. While inspecting finished medical device housings in the Quality Control Laboratory, she was reaching across a workbench to retrieve a light gauge component when her left forearm contacted the sharp edge of an improperly deburred polycarbonate housing. The part, which should have undergone post-mold edge finishing per ISO 13485 specifications, had slipped through the quality verification process due to a temporary line speed increase implemented without corresponding QC adjustments. The laceration was approximately 4 inches long and severed a small subcutaneous vessel, resulting in significant bleeding. Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), working nearby, immediately applied pressure with gauze and called emergency response. Paramedics arrived at 10:31 PM and transported Mei to Laval General Hospital where she received 12 stitches and tetanus prophylaxis. She was unable to return to work for 6 days, making this a lost-time injury. Root cause analysis revealed the debur process had been bypassed to meet production deadlines, and no compensatory quality checks were implemented.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Mold Maintenance Technician Réjean Simard (EMP-00077) sustained a minor laceration and chemical burn while performing routine cleaning on injection mold cavity surfaces in the Injection Molding Line B area. While applying a cleaning solvent (acetone) to dissolve accumulated resin deposits on a complex automotive mold cavity, Réjean accidentally splashed approximately 15 milliliters of the solvent onto his left hand and forearm. The acetone immediately caused skin irritation and a minor chemical burn characterized by redness and slight blistering across an area approximately 3 inches by 2 inches. Although he was wearing nitrile gloves, they had developed small tears from prolonged use during the 2-hour cleaning session, allowing the solvent to contact skin. Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) was working nearby and immediately directed Réjean to the eyewash and emergency shower station. Réjean irrigated the affected area for 10 minutes with cool water per WHMIS protocol. The burn was classified as first-aid treatable; no emergency transport was required. HSE Coordinator Jamal Thompson arrived at 6:50 AM, documented the incident, provided burn care cream and protective bandaging, and cleared Réjean to continue work on other assignments not involving solvents. The employee fully recovered within 4 days.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing unit. Natasha Ivanov, Chemical Inventory Specialist, was conducting routine inventory management when she noticed that a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin had developed a hairline fracture along its base seam. The drum was positioned on a wooden pallet in the storage area, approximately 3 meters from the secondary containment system. As Ivanov attempted to move the drum to inspect the damage more closely, the fracture propagated and approximately 20 gallons of polyester resin began leaking onto the concrete floor. The resin spread across an area of roughly 25 square meters before containment efforts began. The spill generated moderate fumes and created a slippery hazard. Ivanov immediately activated the emergency alarm and notified Marco Rossi (Mechanical Maintenance Technician) and the HSE office. The leak was contained within 15 minutes using absorbent materials and the damaged drum was transferred to a secondary containment vessel. No personnel were directly exposed to the chemical, but the area remained hazardous for approximately 3 hours during cleanup operations.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (Machine Setter - Night Shift) sustained a crush injury while performing mold changeover operations on Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Main Production Building. Desbiens was working with Armand Lévesque (Mold Repair Technician) to replace a worn mold assembly. Despite lockout/tagout procedures being initiated, a critical safety interlock on the machine's hydraulic press mechanism had been previously bypassed during emergency repairs and not documented or restored. As Desbiens was removing fasteners from the mold clamp assembly, the hydraulic system suddenly pressurized, causing the mold closing mechanism to activate unexpectedly. Desbiens' left hand and forearm were caught between the mold plate and the machine frame, resulting in a crush injury. Lévesque immediately activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. Desbiens was transported to Laval Hospital where X-rays revealed a fractured radius, significant soft tissue trauma, and compartment syndrome requiring emergency surgery. The incident occurred due to inadequate documentation of machine modifications, lack of verification of safety system integrity before operation, and insufficient communication between maintenance teams regarding equipment status.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM during the day shift, Gaétan Laplante (Lockout/Tagout Coordinator) conducted a preventive inspection of the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014) and identified a significant gap in the current hazard management system. While reviewing maintenance records and equipment logs, Laplante discovered that several power tools, extension cords, and electrical testing equipment had not been subjected to electrical safety testing or documentation in over 18 months, well beyond the recommended annual interval. Additionally, he noted that multiple electrical panel access points lacked proper labeling and that the LOTO procedures for electrical systems did not include adequate provisions for arc flash hazard assessment or appropriate PPE requirements. The inspection also revealed inadequate documentation of ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI) testing schedules. Laplante immediately documented these findings and escalated the issue to Claude Rioux (Electrical Maintenance Lead) and the HSE office. This preventive declaration triggered a comprehensive electrical safety audit and remediation planning to prevent potential electrocution incidents and electrical fires. No immediate incident had occurred, but the risk exposure was substantial and required urgent corrective action to maintain workplace safety.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a Production Operator working at Injection Molding Line A in the Main Production Building, sustained a repetitive strain injury to her right wrist and forearm. Naomi has been assigned to the part removal and assembly station for the past 8 months, performing continuous manual extraction of molded components from the injection machine every 45-60 seconds. She reported experiencing progressive pain and swelling in her right wrist over the previous two weeks but continued working without reporting the initial symptoms. On the day of the incident, after approximately 6 hours of continuous operation, Naomi experienced acute sharp pain in her wrist and was unable to continue her duties. She immediately notified her supervisor, François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105), who arranged for her to see the on-site nurse. The nurse recommended immediate medical evaluation, and Naomi was referred to an external occupational health clinic where she was diagnosed with acute carpal tunnel syndrome with inflammation. She was placed on modified duty for three weeks and subsequently required 4 weeks of partial leave. The incident was investigated and found to be related to inadequate ergonomic assessment of the workstation, insufficient break intervals, and lack of job rotation protocols. No other employees witnessed the acute injury event, though colleagues noted Naomi had been favoring her right arm throughout the day.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, an overhead bridge crane used in the Warehouse and Shipping section failed catastrophically. The crane, a 5-ton capacity unit installed in 2004, was being operated by Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019), Shipping and Receiving Clerk, to move a pallet of finished goods from the storage area to the loading dock. At approximately 10:15 PM, while the pallet was suspended 8 feet above ground and approximately 15 feet from the loading bay, the main load hook fractured due to metal fatigue and stress corrosion cracking. The pallet of composite materials weighing approximately 2,200 pounds fell to the concrete floor below, scattering product across an area approximately 25 feet in diameter. The fallen pallet narrowly missed Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), Injection Molding Operator, who was walking through the warehouse area and only sustained minor lacerations from scattered debris. Mélanie was in the operator's cab and was uninjured. Immediate investigation by maintenance personnel revealed that the hook had not been inspected in over 18 months, well beyond the required 6-month inspection interval per ASME standards. The failure was attributed to deferred maintenance, inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling, and lack of compliance with lifting equipment inspection protocols. Approximately $34,000 worth of finished medical device components were damaged. The crane was immediately taken out of service.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a chemical storage technician was transferring acetone solvent from a large storage drum to smaller containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. While connecting the transfer hose to the outlet valve, the employee accidentally knocked over a 5-liter container of isopropanol that was sitting on the work bench. The container's cap was not fully secured, resulting in approximately 3 liters of isopropanol spilling onto the concrete floor and partially onto the employee's work apron and shoe. The spill created a slick surface and released significant solvent vapors into the work area. The employee immediately moved to fresh air and notified their supervisor. The spill was contained using absorbent material and neutralized with appropriate chemical absorbent powder. Environmental and health monitoring confirmed no long-term exposure risk, and the area was thoroughly cleaned and ventilated. The incident was discovered to result from inadequate valve fastening procedures and missing secondary containment on the work surface.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 7:45 AM during the early day shift at Injection Molding Line B, Production Operator Yara Mustafa was performing routine part removal from a cooling mold when her right wrist became caught between a partially ejected component and the mold guide rail. The machine was in semi-automatic cycle mode, and despite safety interlocks, a mechanical binding condition prevented the mold from fully opening. As the operator attempted to free her hand, she experienced significant acute pain and was unable to extract herself without assistance. A nearby machine setter, Rodrigue Tremblay, immediately activated the emergency stop button and called for first aid. The production engineer and maintenance technician responded within 2 minutes. The operator's wrist was immobilized, and she was transported to the emergency department where X-rays revealed a non-displaced fracture of the scaphoid bone and severe soft tissue contusion. She was placed in a cast and prescribed pain management. Medical evaluation confirmed the injury would result in lost work time of approximately 6-8 weeks. Root cause investigation revealed inadequate clearance specifications in the mold design and insufficient operator training on recognizing binding conditions.

On March 20, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit, Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang was conducting visual inspection of composite material samples that had just been removed from an industrial curing oven operating at 185°C. As she reached for a sample on the cooling rack with her bare right hand, she inadvertently touched the edge of a freshly extracted component that retained residual heat. She immediately experienced a first-degree thermal burn on the dorsal surface of her hand and fingers, with localized erythema and mild blistering. The employee moved away from the heat source and immediately immersed her hand in cool running water for 15 minutes. Her supervisor, Isabelle Tremblay, responded and provided first aid treatment using sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment from the first aid station. The burn was assessed as minor, affecting approximately 2% of body surface area. The employee remained on duty but was instructed to monitor the wound and report to occupational health the following day. No time away from work was required, and the injury healed within one week with standard wound care. The incident occurred because heat-resistant gloves were not available at the inspection station and the employee was not wearing appropriate PPE.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on a Husky injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. While adjusting the mold clamp pressure settings, François reached toward the moving platen to inspect a thermal sensor. His left hand became partially caught between the mold cavity and the moving platen as the machine cycled unexpectedly due to a failed safety interlock. François sustained a laceration to his palm and two fingers, with swelling and moderate pain. His supervisor Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) immediately activated the emergency stop and called the Occupational Health Nurse. François was treated on-site and released to light duty for two weeks. Investigation revealed the machine's proximity sensor had not been calibrated in six months, contributing to the failure.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, was repositioning pallets of raw polypropylene resin near the Shipping and Receiving Dock using a powered forklift. While attempting to stack three pallets high, the load shifted unexpectedly due to improper weight distribution. The stack began to tip, and Elif jumped from the operator's seat. However, her right foot caught the forklift's running board, causing her to fall heavily to the concrete floor. She sustained a fracture to her right tibia (shinbone) and a severe ankle sprain. Emergency responders transported her to Centre Hospitalier Laval, where she underwent X-ray imaging and was admitted for overnight observation. She remained hospitalized for two days with a diagnosis of fractured tibia requiring a cast. The incident was caused by inadequate load securing procedures and the absence of a load capacity verification system on the dock.

On March 28, 2024 at 3:30 PM, during resin mixing operations in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building, approximately 45 liters of acetone solvent was accidentally spilled when a 55-gallon drum's valve coupling failed due to corrosion. The coupling, which had not been inspected in 18 months, gave way while Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a Production Operator, was positioning the drum on a transfer cart. The acetone rapidly spread across the concrete floor, creating a volatile vapor cloud that activated the chemical detection alarm. Naomi immediately evacuated the area and notified the HSE coordinator. The spill covered approximately 120 square meters and migrated toward the storm drain system in the exterior zone. Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) and Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) implemented containment using absorbent booms and neutralizing agents while maintaining proper respiratory protection. The spill was contained within 40 minutes. No injuries occurred, but environmental remediation required specialized hazmat contractor services and CNESST notification.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Machine Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) was working at Injection Molding Line C when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the 300-ton injection molding machine malfunctioned. The valve, which had not been serviced in 18 months despite a recommended 12-month maintenance schedule, failed to properly regulate system pressure. At 2:47 PM, pressurized hydraulic fluid suddenly released through a fractured seal, spraying hot fluid (approximately 65°C) across the operator's right arm and shoulder. Traore immediately notified his supervisor and moved to the emergency safety station. First aid was administered on-site, and Traore was transported to Laval General Hospital with second-degree thermal burns requiring hospitalization and specialized burn treatment. The incident was witnessed by Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) who was working in the adjacent area. The equipment was immediately shut down and locked out pending investigation. Root cause analysis identified inadequate preventive maintenance tracking and lack of real-time pressure monitoring systems.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was working in the Shipping and Receiving Dock performing routine inventory organization. While reaching across a 2-meter-high storage rack to reposition plastic resin pellet bags, the entire top tier of four bags (approximately 25 kg each) became unstable due to improper stacking alignment. The bags fell directly onto Bianchi's head and upper torso, causing her to collapse to the floor. Fellow worker Amina Ba (EMP-00164), a Packaging Operator nearby, immediately called for assistance and activated the emergency response protocol. Bianchi was transported by ambulance to Laval General Hospital with a fractured left clavicle, severe contusions to the head and shoulders, and a moderate concussion. She required surgical intervention and hospitalization for 4 days. Investigation revealed that storage racks lacked weight capacity labels, stacking guidelines were not visibly posted, and staff had not received formal training on proper material stacking techniques. The damaged resin bags resulted in product loss valued at approximately $3,400.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during the night shift, Mold Maintenance Technician Réjean Simard (EMP-00077) was performing scheduled maintenance on a temperature control unit servicing the medical-grade cleanroom injection molding line. While cleaning the resin dryer's heating element chamber, Simard inhaled high concentrations of volatilized plastic compound fumes. The dryer, which had been operating at elevated temperatures (220°C) to process specialty medical-grade polycarbonate, had not been properly ventilated before maintenance began. Despite wearing a standard N95 mask (insufficient for chemical vapor exposure), Simard began experiencing acute respiratory distress within minutes, including chest tightness, difficulty breathing, and dizziness. He immediately exited the area and reported symptoms to the night shift supervisor. Simard was evaluated at the site medical station and transported to Laval General Hospital by ambulance at 12:45 AM.
