Hospital assessment confirmed acute inhalation injury with elevated carboxyhemoglobin and evidence of thermal and chemical airway irritation requiring overnight observation and oxygen therapy. Simard required 3 weeks off work for full recovery. No other employees were in the immediate work area, preventing secondary exposures.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a significant repetitive strain injury while performing part removal and manual finishing operations. Over the previous 8 weeks, Rémi had been assigned to continuous part extraction from molded components without adequate rest breaks or task rotation. The production schedule demanded 95% uptime, resulting in Rémi performing over 2,000 manual grip-and-twist motions per shift. On this date, Rémi experienced acute sharp pain in his right wrist and forearm while removing parts from a 300-ton injection molding machine. The pain was severe enough to cause immediate loss of grip strength and temporary inability to continue work. First aid was administered on-site, and Rémi was transported to the occupational health clinic where X-rays revealed early signs of carpal tunnel syndrome and tendon inflammation. He was prescribed anti-inflammatory medication and provided a wrist brace. Medical clearance restricted him to light duty for 4 weeks, resulting in lost production capacity and requiring temporary reassignment of his Line D responsibilities to other operators.

On October 22, 2024, at 10:45 AM, Nina Santos, Industrial Hygienist (EMP-00084), conducted a routine workplace hazard assessment in the Materials Management and Warehousing area (UNIT-019 equivalent operations in the main warehouse). During inspection of the material storage racks in the North Zone, Nina identified that stacks of plastic resin bags (approximately 25kg each) had been loaded to heights exceeding the manufacturer's rated load limits by approximately 30%. The racks showed visible signs of stress and minor buckling at the joints. Witness accounts indicated that materials had been stacked this way for at least 2 weeks without incident, but the hazard was clearly present. Multiple employees worked in the area daily directly beneath these elevated loads. Nina immediately initiated a STOP WORK protocol in the affected zone and documented the hazard with photographic evidence. She issued a formal written hazard alert to warehouse management and the HSE committee. No immediate injury occurred, but the potential for serious crush injuries from falling materials was classified as HIGH PROBABILITY and HIGH GRAVITY. This preventive declaration triggers mandatory corrective action to prevent future incidents.

On September 8, 2024, at 11:30 PM during night shift operations, Claude Rioux, Electrical Maintenance Lead (EMP-00185), was performing routine maintenance on electrical connections in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). While tightening a terminal connector on a 480V distribution panel using an insulated screwdriver, Claude's gloved hand accidentally made brief contact with an adjacent live conductor that was not properly labeled as energized. The contact duration was approximately 0.3 seconds. Claude immediately felt a sharp electrical shock sensation and jerked his hand away. No sustained contact occurred, and no burn marks were visible. However, Claude experienced momentary disorientation and rapid heart rate elevation lasting about 2 minutes. A nearby maintenance technician (Oscar Ramirez, EMP-00092) witnessed the event and immediately shut down the affected circuit breaker. Claude was evaluated by first aid personnel and monitoring revealed normal vital signs within 5 minutes. He was advised to seek medical evaluation for potential cardiac monitoring, which he completed the following morning with normal results. This near-miss incident revealed critical deficiencies in electrical safety labeling and lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures that could have resulted in serious injury or fatality under different circumstances.

On March 15, 2025 at 14:45, Maya Kumar (EMP-00138), a Production Operator on the day shift, was working at Injection Molding Line D in the South Zone when she experienced a severe burn injury. While performing routine material loading operations, the hopper's temperature control malfunctioned, causing molten polypropylene resin to reach approximately 320°C instead of the normal 280°C. As Maya was inserting the next batch of raw material, a sudden pressure release occurred from the heated barrel, projecting hot resin onto her left forearm and hand. She immediately ran to the emergency eyewash station and immersed her arm in cool water for 15 minutes. Her supervisor, Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), witnessed the incident and called for first aid assistance. The burn covered approximately 8% of her forearm with partial-thickness damage. Maya was taken to the on-site medical clinic and then transferred to Laval Hospital's burn unit where she was admitted for specialized treatment and remained hospitalized for 5 days. She subsequently lost 12 working days due to wound care, physical therapy, and medical restrictions on hand use.

On March 18, 2025 at 09:20, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator on the day shift, sustained a laceration requiring first aid treatment at the Assembly and Finishing Department. While performing precision component assembly work at her station, Elena was handling small plastic parts removed from the injection molding process. A burr or sharp edge on one of the plastic components caught her right index finger as she was placing it into an assembly jig. The laceration was approximately 1.5 cm long on the lateral surface of her fingertip, with moderate bleeding. Elena applied direct pressure with clean gauze and immediately reported the injury to her team lead. Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180), the Quality Inspector, responded to the incident and applied first aid treatment including wound cleansing, hydrogen peroxide irrigation, antibiotic ointment application, and a sterile bandage. The injury required no stitches and Elena continued working for the remainder of her shift with modified duties to avoid re-injury. She applied topical first aid treatments as needed throughout the day and the wound showed no signs of infection during the 48-hour follow-up assessment.

On March 22, 2025 at 02:15, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on the evening shift, suffered a serious laceration to his left hand while performing cleaning operations in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility during the night shift transition. Abdul was assigned to clean the interior of the resin mixing tank after the shift change at 22:30, but due to staffing constraints, the cleaning was delayed until 02:15. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) discovered that Abdul had entered the tank without completing proper lockout/tagout procedures and without atmospheric testing for chemical fumes. While scrubbing the tank interior with a wire brush, Abdul's hand made contact with a sharp edge of internal equipment that had not been properly secured. The laceration was deep, approximately 4 cm long with significant bleeding. Abdul climbed out of the tank and immediately sought medical assistance. The facility's first aid responders provided initial wound care, but due to the depth and location of the laceration across his palm and fingers, Abdul required emergency transport to Hôpital Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval. He received 12 stitches in the emergency department and was diagnosed with a partial laceration to the flexor digitorum superficialis tendon in his left ring finger. Abdul was released after 4 hours but required 18 days of lost time for wound healing, occupational therapy, and functional recovery before returning to modified duties.

On January 8, 2024 at 09:30, Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030), a Machine Setter on the Day Shift, was cleaning the hopper discharge area of a plastic injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. Despite following standard procedures, Karim reached into the discharge chute to remove a partial blockage of hardened plastic material. Approximately 3 seconds after beginning the removal, a batch cycle automatically initiated when a new production run was queued in the system by quality control personnel. The rotating screw mechanism engaged and caught Karim's right hand and wrist, pulling it into the discharge zone. Karim screamed for help, and Industrial Engineer Priya Sharma (EMP-00038) and Machine Operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) heard the commotion and immediately activated the emergency stop button, halting the machine within 2 seconds. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) arrived within 3 minutes. Karim sustained deep lacerations to his right hand and wrist, with partial laceration of the extensor carpi radialis longus tendon. He was transported by ambulance to Laval Medical Center where he underwent emergency surgery and required 4 days hospitalization plus 12 weeks of medical leave with occupational therapy. Root cause: The machine lacked appropriate guarding on the discharge zone, and the system did not prevent automatic cycling during maintenance mode.

On March 18, 2024, during the evening shift (approximately 19:30), Assembly Operator Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162) was working at a medical device component assembly station in UNIT-005 when she noticed an unusual acrid smell emanating from the ventilation ductwork above her workstation. She immediately halted her work and alerted her supervisor. Within minutes, Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), a CNC Operator from the nearby maintenance area, was called to investigate. Upon inspection, Bianchi discovered that the ventilation filter in the secondary air intake system had become severely clogged with composite fiber dust and resin particles, causing the system to draw air from an alternative bypass that was compromised. No immediate release of toxic fumes occurred, but the situation posed a potential respiratory hazard had operations continued. The ventilation system was immediately shut down, and the area was evacuated as a precaution. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) conducted a full assessment confirming the bypass route was unsafe and recommending immediate filter replacement and system recalibration. This near-miss was documented as it could have resulted in acute respiratory exposure for multiple employees.

On March 22, 2024, during the night shift (approximately 02:15), Injection Molding Operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) was operating Injection Molding Line A in UNIT-001 when he observed erratic temperature fluctuations on the control panel. The resin dryer, which maintains precise temperature for material conditioning, began displaying readings that oscillated between 85°C and 145°C instead of the required stable 110°C set point. Gagnon immediately notified his shift supervisor and Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) was called to investigate. Upon inspection, Laplante discovered that the thermostat sensor had become dislodged from its mounting, causing incorrect temperature readings and potential overheating of the resin. The dryer's safety shutoff had not engaged as designed due to a malfunctioning thermal cutoff switch. The equipment was immediately isolated using proper LOTO procedures, and the facility's maintenance team was alerted. No material was damaged and no personnel were injured, but the situation represented a critical equipment failure that could have resulted in resin degradation, equipment fire, or thermal injury to personnel. The incident was declared by Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) after receiving full details from the equipment assessment.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was working at Injection Molding Line A when she reached to remove a finished part from the mold. Despite wearing nitrile gloves, her left index finger made direct contact with the mold surface, which was maintaining a temperature of 185°C for polycarbonate processing. Ndiaye immediately withdrew her hand and reported a sharp burning sensation. Quality Control Lead Petra Mueller (EMP-00166) witnessed the incident and immediately applied cold water to the affected area for 15 minutes. A first-aid blister approximately 1.5 cm in diameter formed on the fingertip. Mueller applied sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment, and Ndiaye was cleared to continue work with a protective bandage. The incident occurred because the standard mold cooling cycle had been shortened by 30 seconds to meet production targets, leaving the mold hotter than normal when parts were extracted. Production Supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) was notified and documented the incident.

On March 20, 2025, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, an electrical fire initiated in the chemical mixing room (UNIT-010) when an overcharged battery charger for the automated material handling system malfunctioned. The charger, located near a shelf containing 15 liters of acetone-based solvent in partially sealed containers, began emitting smoke and sparks. Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) noticed the smell of burning plastic and smoke and immediately alerted her supervisor Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114). Rahman attempted to move nearby materials but did not activate the fire suppression system. The fire spread to adjacent solvent containers, causing vapors to ignite and creating a visible flame approximately 1.5 meters high. An emergency alarm was triggered by another employee, and the facility's automatic sprinkler system activated, extinguishing the fire within 4 minutes. The local fire department arrived 12 minutes later to confirm the area was secure. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) conducted an immediate investigation and found the battery charger had no overload protection and was positioned too close to flammable materials. No personnel were injured, but the incident caused approximately $28,000 in equipment and material damage, and the chemical storage room required ventilation before operations resumed.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, an employee in the Composite Materials Processing Area was transferring a 55-liter drum of epoxy resin from a storage rack to a mixing station. While maneuvering the drum onto a hand truck, the employee lost grip and the drum fell, rupturing at the seam. Approximately 40 liters of epoxy resin spilled across the floor, spreading into multiple adjacent work areas. The spill created a slippery hazard and released strong chemical vapors. The employee immediately notified supervision. Facility maintenance responded within 10 minutes with absorbent material and began containment. The affected area was evacuated, and emergency ventilation was activated. Environmental compliance specialists assessed the spill extent and initiated cleanup procedures following WHMIS protocols. No direct skin contact occurred, but three workers reported mild respiratory irritation from fumes. The spill took approximately 3 hours to fully contain and remediate. Root cause investigation revealed the drum had sustained prior impact damage during a previous material handling incident that had not been documented or quarantined.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 22:10 during the evening shift, a Quality Control Inspector was conducting final product inspection and testing in the Administrative Building quality laboratory. While retrieving solvent bottles from an under-bench storage cabinet to prepare cleaning solutions for equipment calibration, the employee accidentally knocked over a 2-liter container of acetone. The container's cap was not fully secured, and approximately 1.5 liters of acetone spilled directly onto the concrete floor and spread toward electrical equipment and instrument storage areas. The pungent vapor immediately filled the small laboratory space. The employee quickly vacated the area and activated the laboratory fume hood at maximum capacity. Facilities maintenance and environmental compliance personnel arrived within 5 minutes. The spill was contained using acid-absorbent material and collected into a hazardous waste container. The laboratory remained closed for 2 hours to allow vapor dissipation and air quality verification. Investigation revealed that storage bottles were being placed cap-down in the cabinet, creating pressure that loosened caps over time.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM, assembly operator Soraya Alami (EMP-00196) was working at Station 3 in the Assembly and Finishing Department when she experienced a sharp pain in her left index finger. While hand-assembling composite brackets, her finger made contact with a burr on a freshly molded part. The small cut, approximately 8mm long, began bleeding immediately. A coworker, Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134), witnessed the incident and helped Soraya to the first aid station. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) responded within 5 minutes and provided first aid treatment: thorough cleaning with antiseptic solution, application of antibiotic ointment, and a sterile adhesive bandage. The wound was minor with minimal bleeding. Soraya remained at work, and the injury was documented in the incident log. Root cause analysis revealed that the post-processing quality check had missed this particular sharp edge on the part batch, which should have been caught and deburred during the finishing phase.

On March 22, 2024 at 11:45 PM during the night shift, maintenance technician Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141) was performing routine inspection work in the Central Maintenance Workshop when he discovered hydraulic fluid leaking from a pressure coupling on a spare injection molding machine actuator. While attempting to tighten the coupling with a wrench, the fitting suddenly gave way and a small jet of pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed onto his right forearm and hand. The hydraulic oil, at approximately 45°C, caused immediate redness and mild discomfort. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was notified and arrived at the scene within 10 minutes. The affected area was immediately flushed with cool water for 15 minutes at the emergency eyewash/shower station. After flushing, a non-adherent sterile dressing with antibiotic ointment was applied. Raoul reported continued mild irritation but refused transport to medical facilities. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) documented the incident and investigated the coupling failure. The root cause was determined to be fatigue cracking in the coupling threads due to inadequate preventive maintenance intervals on older equipment slated for retirement.

On April 5, 2024 at approximately 9:30 AM on the day shift, quality control technician Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013) was inspecting finished composite parts in the Finished Goods Warehouse near Section B. She was reaching into a storage rack approximately 5 feet high to retrieve a part sample when she lost her grip. The approximately 2-kg polycarbonate assembly fell, striking her left shoulder and upper arm. Sophie immediately felt pain radiating down her arm. Coworker Julien Racine (EMP-00177), a shipping clerk working nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately called for assistance. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) and supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) responded. Initial assessment revealed significant shoulder pain, limited arm mobility, and visible swelling developing on the upper arm. Ice was applied immediately, and Sophie was transported to the emergency department for evaluation where X-rays confirmed a Grade 2 shoulder strain with minor soft tissue trauma. Medical leave of 5 days was recommended. The root cause included inadequate shelf design with insufficient lip protection, combined with the weight and awkward shape of the part, which made gripping difficult.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area (UNIT-003). While adjusting the mold temperature controller, Robert inadvertently contacted the hot mold surface with his right forearm, sustaining a thermal burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters on the inner forearm. The burn was classified as second-degree with blistering. Robert immediately reported the injury to his supervisor Pierre Bouchard (EMP-00023), who provided first aid with cool running water for 15 minutes and applied sterile dressing. The employee was transported to the on-site medical station where the wound was cleaned and bandaged. Due to the severity and location on the forearm, Robert was referred to Laval Medical Center for evaluation and prescribed topical antibiotic treatment. The incident occurred because the mold surface temperature warning label was obscured by production material residue, and Robert was not wearing the required heat-resistant forearm sleeves that had been temporarily removed during a previous adjustment task.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-005) and discovered a potential safety concern during quarterly hazard assessment. While reviewing chemical storage procedures and inventory logs, Natasha identified that several containers of polyester resin (approximately 200 liters total) were stored on a shelf system rated for maximum 150 kilograms per shelf, but the actual load was approximately 180 kilograms based on container weights and recent shipment records. Additionally, she noted that the chemical storage area's ventilation system had not been professionally calibrated or air-flow tested since the facility expanded medical device production capacity in 2023. The ventilation intake readings suggested potential inadequacy for the increased resin mixing volume. No immediate exposure or injury occurred. Natasha immediately documented her findings and reported them to the HSE Office (UNIT-020), recommending preventive action to avoid potential shelf failure and chemical exposure risks. She submitted a formal Preventive Declaration to ensure these hazards were addressed before they could result in an incident.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 5:30 AM during night shift operations, Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), Fire Safety Coordinator, received a maintenance alert from the automated facility monitoring system indicating that the temperature in the Maintenance Workshop spare parts storage mezzanine (UNIT-025) had exceeded normal operating parameters at 58°C (normal range 18-25°C). Upon immediate investigation at 5:45 AM, Sanaa discovered that a resin dryer unit positioned near the mezzanine had malfunctioned and was operating in a continuous heating mode without proper temperature regulation. The unit's thermostat had failed, and internal heating elements remained engaged. The surrounding storage area contained boxes of spare parts including plastic tubing, connectors, and electronic components. While no fire had ignited, the elevated temperature and proximity to combustible materials presented a significant fire risk. Sanaa immediately disabled power to the dryer unit via the emergency disconnect, activated the facility's automated cooling system, and ventilated the mezzanine area. She documented the equipment malfunction and submitted a Preventive Declaration to prevent potential fire incidents, noting that the dryer unit requires immediate servicing and that temperature monitoring protocols need enhancement.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, was operating Injection Molding Line A when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the 250-ton molding machine failed catastrophically. The valve, which had not been serviced in 18 months despite manufacturer recommendations for annual maintenance, suddenly released pressurized hydraulic fluid at high velocity. The fluid spray struck Pascal's left arm and torso, causing second-degree thermal burns across approximately 15% of his body surface. The immediate temperature of the hydraulic fluid was approximately 65°C. Pascal was immediately moved to the emergency eyewash and shower station by coworkers Luis Fernandez and Aisha Kamara, who witnessed the incident. Emergency services were called and Pascal was transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur for burn treatment and observation. The machine was immediately shut down and locked out pending investigation. Root cause analysis revealed the relief valve had worn internal seals and lacked proper pressure monitoring due to a gauge calibration failure six months prior.

On November 16, 2024, at 9:45 PM during evening shift operations, Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073), Shipping Coordinator, was moving finished goods pallets in the Warehouse and Shipping area using an electric forklift. While attempting to stack four pallets of automotive composite parts onto a high storage rack (approximately 4.2 meters high), the load shifted unexpectedly. The pallet load began to slip, and Normand attempted to reposition the forks by accelerating the forklift laterally. This aggressive movement caused the front wheels to lift, and the entire load—weighing approximately 1,850 kg—fell from the forks onto the warehouse floor with significant force. The falling pallet struck a nearby storage bin and fragmented into several large pieces of composite material (reinforced polycarbonate panels worth approximately $28,000). The bin was damaged and several smaller finished goods were crushed. Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), a Material Handler working nearby, witnessed the incident. No employees were struck, but the incident resulted in significant material loss and potential safety hazard from scattered debris. Investigation revealed improper load balancing procedures were not followed, and the forklift's load-sensing system had not been calibrated in 14 months.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on the hydraulic system of the injection molding machine. While adjusting a pressure relief valve, the pressurized hydraulic line ruptured unexpectedly, spraying hot hydraulic oil across Paul's left arm and torso. The temperature of the hydraulic fluid exceeded 60°C. Paul immediately reported severe burning pain and was assisted by nearby colleague Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), who helped him remove the contaminated clothing and apply cold water to the affected areas. Emergency first aid was administered on-site, and Paul was transported to the local hospital with second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 15% of his upper body and arm. The incident occurred because the hydraulic line had not been properly depressurized before maintenance work began—a critical step that was omitted from the work procedure. Investigation revealed that the LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure for hydraulic systems had not been followed, and pressure relief protocols were unclear to operators. Paul required hospitalization for three days and was unable to return to work for six weeks.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, was organizing composite material stock in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop mezzanine. The room was cluttered with tools, spare injection molds, and packaging materials stacked unevenly on shelves. While reaching for a box of glass-reinforced nylon pellets on the upper shelf (approximately 2.1 meters high), Elif inadvertently dislodged a heavy aluminum fixture weighing approximately 12 kg that had been carelessly placed on the edge of an upper shelf during the previous day's activities. The fixture fell directly, striking Elif on the right shoulder and upper arm. Elif fell to the floor with the object and struck his head on a metal storage bin. Coworker Georges Plante (EMP-00179), a Facilities Technician, immediately called for assistance and the HSE team. Elif was transported to the hospital where X-rays revealed a fractured right collarbone and moderate concussion. He was unable to work for eight weeks. The root cause was identified as inadequate storage practices, lack of proper shelf organization procedures, and absence of fall protection systems in the storage area. Investigation also revealed that no one had been assigned responsibility for maintaining the storage room organization.

On November 28, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013), a Quality Control Technician, sustained a sharp laceration on her left index finger while inspecting finished injection-molded automotive components in the Injection Molding Line B facility. The components, specifically dashboard trim pieces for a major automotive customer, had rough edges and burrs from the injection molding process that had not been adequately removed during the de-gating procedure. While manually handling approximately 50 components to perform dimensional and surface quality checks, Sophie's finger came into contact with a sharp burr edge, creating a deep cut approximately 3 cm long on the lateral side of her index finger. The wound bled profusely and Sophie was unable to continue work immediately. She applied first aid with pressure bandaging and was evaluated by the on-site occupational health nurse, who determined stitches were not required but advised wound care and observation for infection. Sophie was able to return to light-duty work the following day with the wound bandaged, but experienced pain and limited dexterity for one week. No lost work time occurred beyond the remainder of the incident day (4 hours). The incident was attributed to inadequate de-gating procedures and the absence of hand protection PPE for quality control technicians working with sharp-edged components. Inspection revealed that the mold design allowed for inadequate gate separation, and workers lacked awareness of the sharp edge hazard.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103) was operating Line A in the Main Production Building when a hydraulic hose connection on the injection molding machine failed catastrophically. The pressurized hose whipped violently, striking a nearby control panel and spraying hydraulic fluid across a 12-foot radius. The fluid damaged electrical components in the panel, causing a complete shutdown of the injection molding line. Additionally, approximately 40 liters of hydraulic fluid leaked onto the production floor and seeped into the adjacent warehouse area through floor cracks. The incident was immediately reported when Paul noticed the hose failure and activated the emergency stop. The spill required cleanup by the hazardous materials team and resulted in the line being offline for 18 hours while repairs were completed and the floor was decontaminated. No personnel were injured, but equipment damage was estimated at $28,000 including panel replacement, hose repairs, and environmental cleanup costs.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was preparing a batch of colorant masterbatch in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when she detected a strong chemical odor inconsistent with the normal mixing process. Elena immediately stopped the mixing operation and notified her supervisor. Upon investigation, it was discovered that a concentrated isopropanol drum had a hairline crack developing along the bottom seam, slowly leaking solvent vapor into the confined space. The ventilation system's airflow readings showed a 15% reduction from normal operating levels due to partial blockage in the intake filter. Elena had been exposed to elevated solvent vapor concentrations for approximately 8 minutes before detection. She reported experiencing mild lightheadedness and eye irritation. No medical intervention was required, but the incident was properly documented as a near-miss event. The drum was immediately isolated and transferred to secondary containment, the ventilation filter was replaced, and the area was aired out for 30 minutes before operations resumed.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a Production Operator on the day shift, was operating Injection Molding Line A when she attempted to clear a material jam from the hopper without following proper lockout/tagout procedures. A colleague, Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), was working nearby as the Machine Setter. While Naomi was reaching into the feed mechanism to dislodge compacted polypropylene resin, the machine suddenly cycled due to a residual pressure surge in the hydraulic system. Her right hand became caught between the hopper wall and the rotating auger screw, causing crush injuries to her palm and fingers. Ibrahim immediately activated the emergency stop button and called for assistance. Naomi was transported to the hospital via ambulance with a fractured right metacarpal, severe lacerations, and partial tendon damage requiring surgical intervention. The incident was witnessed by Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026) who was conducting line inspection nearby.

On April 2, 2024 at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) was retrieving raw material spools from the high-bay storage system in the Materials Management area. While pulling a 40-kg spool of glass-filled nylon from a shelf approximately 2.1 meters high using the manual pallet jack, the securing strap suddenly failed due to metal corrosion on the buckle. The spool tilted forward and fell, striking Monique's left shoulder and upper arm. She fell backward onto the concrete floor, sustaining a deep laceration on her left forearm that required 12 stitches and a minor contusion on her left hip. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) witnessed the incident and immediately provided first aid using the facility's first aid kit, cleaning the wound and applying pressure bandaging. Emergency responders were called but upon assessment, Monique was treated on-site for the laceration and advised to monitor for bruising. She was able to continue work with modified duties for the remainder of the shift.

On March 28, 2024 at 11:45 PM during the night shift, Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was preparing to clean the solvent recovery system in the Composite Materials Processing Area. A 20-liter container of acetone-based mold release agent was being transferred from a 55-gallon drum into smaller containers when a transfer hose connection failed due to inadequate coupling torque specification. Approximately 8 liters of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a volatile vapor cloud and immediate fire hazard near the resin dryer units. Oscar immediately activated the spill containment protocol, shutting down adjacent equipment and alerting other night shift personnel. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) responded and used absorbent material to contain the spill while HVAC systems were activated to ventilate fumes. The spill was fully contained within 15 minutes. Environmental remediation contractor was called for proper chemical disposal. No personal injuries occurred. CNESST was notified per regulatory requirements due to the environmental incident classification.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, injection molding operator Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024) was removing finished parts from a 250-ton injection molding machine on Line C in the Main Production Building when her right hand made contact with the hot mold surface as it was retracting. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C. She immediately withdrew her hand and reported a burning sensation to her supervisor Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090). First aid was administered by occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid at the on-site medical station. The employee sustained second-degree thermal burns to the palm and three fingers. Contributing factors included: inadequate insulation barriers on the mold cooling system, lack of recent refresher training on thermal hazard recognition, and the operator's attempt to accelerate cycle time by manually assisting part removal before the automatic ejection sequence completed. The operator was hospitalized for observation and pain management, requiring 3 days of treatment. Production was halted on Line C for 2 hours to allow investigation and temporary containment measures.

On March 22, 2024 at 06:15 during the night shift, maintenance technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) was performing routine chemical tank inspection in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. He noticed a hairline crack (approximately 8cm long) in a 500-liter epoxy resin storage tank mounted on the upper shelf, with early signs of resin seepage. The crack was at a height of approximately 2.1 meters, accessible only via a 6-step aluminum ladder. Giguère immediately secured the area with hazard tape and notified Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) of the potential chemical spill hazard. The tank was approximately 70% full. Before attempting any remedial action, the technician followed emergency protocols and contacted Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) for guidance. The tank was carefully lowered to ground level using a pneumatic hoist system over the next 3 hours, and the damaged tank was isolated in the spill containment area. No chemical exposure occurred, and no employees were injured. The incident demonstrated proper hazard recognition and adherence to safety procedures, preventing what could have been a significant environmental and health incident. The crack was attributed to thermal stress from repeated heating cycles and age-related material degradation of the tank (purchased 2018, beyond manufacturer's 5-year lifecycle recommendation).

On April 3, 2024 at 10:30, composite materials technician Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042) was preparing fiber-reinforced plastic resin batches in the Composite Materials Processing Area. While transferring a 25-liter container of uncatalyzed polyester resin from the primary storage cabinet to the mixing station, the container slipped from her grip due to inadequate hand-hold surface and spilled approximately 18 liters onto the work bench and floor. The resin spread across approximately 3 square meters of work surface. Although the spill was contained within the facility's secondary containment tray system (designed capacity: 30 liters), a portion of the resin vapors began concentrating in the enclosed workspace. Co-worker Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), working at an adjacent station, detected the strong styrene fume odor and immediately activated the local exhaust ventilation system and opened emergency windows. Both employees evacuated the area within 2 minutes. Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123) responded and supervised cleanup using absorbent materials and proper hazardous waste protocols. The spill was fully contained and cleaned within 45 minutes. No chemical exposure to skin or eyes occurred. Environmental air monitoring showed fume levels returned to baseline within 15 minutes of ventilation activation. Root cause analysis identified: container design with inadequate grip surface, insufficient ergonomic training for chemical handling, and operator fatigue (employee was on day 5 of 6-day work week). This near-miss highlighted the inadequate secondary containment capacity relative to single-batch volumes.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a laceration to his left hand while removing finished parts from a mold. Rémi was extracting a batch of automotive dashboard components when his hand contacted a sharp edge on a partially cooled part. The mold had not been properly cleaned after the previous production run, leaving burrs and sharp edges on the internal surfaces. As Rémi reached into the mold cavity to retrieve parts, his palm made contact with a 3mm sharp edge, resulting in a 2-inch laceration requiring five stitches. The incident was witnessed by Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), the Machine Setter, who immediately applied first aid and summoned Hana Al-Rashid, the Occupational Health Nurse. The laceration was cleaned, sutured, and bandaged in the on-site medical station. Root cause analysis identified inadequate mold inspection procedures and lack of edge deburring after production changeovers.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of colorant masterbatch using acetone as a solvent when she noticed an unusual strong chemical odor and slight visible haze in the air near her workstation. She immediately recognized the potential hazard of chemical fume exposure. Upon investigation, she discovered that the local exhaust ventilation system serving her workstation had partially failed—one of the two intake ducts had become disconnected from its coupling, causing fumes to escape directly into the work area rather than being captured and vented outside. Elena immediately shut down her operation, activated the area emergency stop, and notified Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), the Warehouse Supervisor for the evening shift. The area was evacuated and ventilation systems were checked by facilities staff. No employee exposure occurred because Elena detected the hazard before significant vapor accumulation. The root cause was inadequate maintenance scheduling and lack of visual inspection of ventilation ductwork connections.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), a Production Operator, sustained a minor burn injury to the dorsal surface of her right hand while performing post-processing work in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. Yara was removing medical device component housings from an industrial oven that had cooled to approximately 65°C (149°F). Although the oven temperature was below boiling, the composite material retained significant residual heat. When Yara reached into the oven to retrieve a tray of parts, her hand briefly contacted the edge of a mold surface, causing a first-degree burn covering approximately 2 square inches. She immediately removed her hand and ran cold water over the burn at the facility washstation. The burn was assessed by Hana Al-Rashid during a scheduled facility check at 6:45 AM. Treatment included gentle cleansing, application of antibiotic ointment, and non-adherent gauze dressing. No hospitalization was required. Yara continued light duty work for the remainder of her shift. Root causes included inadequate warning signage on the oven, lack of heat-resistant gloves at the workstation, and insufficient cooling time protocol between production runs.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45 during day shift, Assembly Operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040) was working at Injection Molding Line B when she attempted to remove a finished part from the mold. As the mold was closing for the next cycle, her right hand became caught between the upper and lower mold halves. The machine's automatic safety interlock failed to stop the descent, resulting in a crush injury to her palm and fingers. Silva immediately screamed for assistance. Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was nearby and immediately triggered the emergency stop button. Medical responders arrived within 8 minutes. Silva sustained fractures to the 3rd and 4th metacarpals, severe bruising, and partial crush syndrome. She was transported to Hôpital de Laval where she underwent surgical repair. The incident was caused by a malfunctioning safety interlock that had not been properly tested during recent maintenance, combined with inadequate guarding on the pinch point.

On March 22, 2024 at 02:15 during night shift, Forklift Operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) was moving pallets of raw polycarbonate resin in the Materials Management and Warehousing area when he encountered a wet floor from an unattended cleaning spill. The propane-powered forklift's front tires lost traction on the slick surface. Santos attempted to regain control but the vehicle continued to slide. The forklift struck a storage rack containing composite material components, causing approximately 12 boxes to fall from the upper shelves. One box struck Santos on the left shoulder and upper arm, causing contusions and a partial rotator cuff strain. Shipping Clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019), who was preparing shipments in the adjacent area, witnessed the incident and immediately called HSE. Santos was evaluated at the facility and transported to urgent care where imaging confirmed no fractures but significant soft tissue damage. The root cause was inadequate floor maintenance during night shift when staffing is reduced, combined with lack of visible wet floor warnings.

On March 29, 2024 at 10:30 during day shift, Quality Documentation Specialist Gabrielle Levesque (EMP-00095) was in the Quality Control Laboratory examining a batch of medical-grade plastic components under the inspection lighting. While reaching across the workbench to retrieve a part for dimensional analysis, she accidentally knocked over a small container of isopropyl alcohol (IPA) used for surface cleaning. Approximately 150 mL of the liquid splashed onto her left hand and forearm, and a small amount contacted her face near the left eye. The fumes immediately caused irritation and redness. Levesque quickly moved to the eyewash station located 4 meters away and flushed her eye for approximately 3 minutes. She then washed her hands and forearm with soap and water. The affected area developed mild erythema (redness) and slight irritation that resolved within 20 minutes. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) responded and evaluated her condition. Thompson documented the incident and provided first aid care including reassessment after 30 minutes. Levesque elected not to seek external medical care as symptoms fully resolved. The incident was caused by inadequate workspace organization and lack of spill containment for chemical solvents.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Injection Molding Machine Line D (500-ton press) experienced a critical cooling water system failure in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Robert Fournier, an Injection Molding Setter, was performing routine maintenance on the machine's hydraulic lines when he noticed abnormal pressure readings on the system gauge. Within minutes, the cooling water circulation pump seized due to internal bearing degradation that had not been detected during the predictive maintenance schedule. The sudden pressure buildup caused a micro-fracture in the main cooling line connector, spraying pressurized cooling water containing corrosive additives across the work station. Fournier sustained minor thermal and chemical contact injuries to his left forearm and hand before shutting down the machine using the emergency stop button. The equipment damage included a compromised cooling jacket requiring complete line replacement (estimated $8,500 in parts and labor). Production on the line was halted for 14 hours. Petra Mueller, the Quality Control Lead, witnessed the incident and immediately initiated first aid procedures and contacted HSE personnel.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 PM during evening shift, Lina Sokolova, a Composite Materials Operator, sustained a significant back injury while manually transferring uncured composite material batches in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Sokolova was moving a 45-pound bag of fiberglass-reinforced polyester resin from a storage shelf (waist height) to a weighing station approximately 15 feet away. She was required to perform this task 47 times during her 8-hour shift as part of the production schedule. On her 38th repetitive lift, she felt a sharp pain in her lower lumbar region when twisting to place a bag on the scale. She attempted to continue working but experienced increasing pain and muscle spasms. After completing her shift and reporting to work the following morning, her symptoms had worsened significantly—she could barely walk. Medical evaluation revealed a herniated disc at L4-L5 requiring immediate treatment and resulting in 18 days of lost work time. The root cause was identified as: (1) no mechanical lifting assist equipment available for this repetitive task; (2) inadequate ergonomic assessment of the work station; (3) no job rotation to break up repetitive strain; and (4) insufficient training on proper lifting mechanics for this particular material type. Chiara Bianchi, a Material Handler, witnessed the incident and helped Sokolova to the first aid station.

On March 29, 2024, at 12:30 AM during night shift operations, Thanh Pham, a Maintenance Planner, was conducting a routine inspection of the machine guarding systems on the automated material handling robotic arms in the Finished Goods Warehouse. While checking the protective enclosure around the robotic palletizer arm on Station 3, Pham discovered that the safety interlock switch on one of the access gates was malfunctioning—the gate was ajar but the machine had not automatically shut down as designed. The robotic arm was in mid-cycle operation, moving finished composite material cases at approximately 2 meters per second. Pham immediately recognized the critical hazard: if anyone had reached into the enclosure to retrieve a fallen piece of material (a common occurrence), the rotating arm could have caused severe entanglement or amputation. Pham did not enter the danger zone and instead activated the emergency stop button from outside the enclosure, halting all operations on the palletizer line. He then locked out the machine using the LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure and notified Brigitte Mathieu, the Incident Investigation Specialist. Investigation revealed that the interlock switch had suffered mechanical wear over 8 months of operation and had never been included in the preventive maintenance schedule. No personnel were injured, and the near-miss was caught before any worker entered the hazard zone. This was classified as a NEAR_MISS due to the high potential for serious injury that was prevented through proper hazard recognition and emergency response procedures.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Nour Jaber (EMP-00188), a Packaging Operator, was working in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit removing finished composite parts from a cooling conveyor. While manually extracting a fiber-reinforced plastic component, a sharp edge on the part made contact with the inside of his left palm, creating a laceration approximately 2 cm in length. The part had not been properly deburred after the molding process. Nour applied direct pressure with a clean cloth and reported to the first aid station within 5 minutes. The wound was cleaned, bandaged, and monitored. No sutures were required, but the injury resulted in minor bleeding and swelling. Yves Thibault, the Quality Supervisor, witnessed the incident and provided immediate assistance. The part was retained for quality investigation. First aid treatment was administered on-site by the HSE team, and the employee returned to modified duties within 2 hours.

On February 28, 2025, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine maintenance on his assigned injection molding machine. While attempting to clear a material jam in the heating barrel using a metal rod, the machine unexpectedly cycled despite what he believed was a complete shutdown. The heated barrel made contact with his right forearm, causing a thermal burn covering approximately 8 cm² with blistering and redness consistent with a second-degree burn. Stéphane immediately removed himself from the hazard and submerged his arm in cool water. He reported to the medical clinic at 11:05 PM. Medical evaluation confirmed a moderate thermal burn requiring wound dressing, topical antibiotic application, and pain management. The employee was placed on modified duty assignment away from heat sources for 6 days. François-Xavier Mailhot, the Maintenance Supervisor, responded to secure the machine and investigate. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate lockout/tagout (LOTO) compliance—the machine had not been fully isolated and locked despite maintenance procedures requiring it.

On April 2, 2025, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), a Composite Materials Operator, was working in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room preparing a batch of epoxy resin for a medical device component production run. While transferring a 5-liter container of hardener from a shelf to the mixing station, the container slipped from her grip due to inadequate grip surface on the wet container exterior. The container fell approximately 1.2 meters to the concrete floor, rupturing at a seam and releasing approximately 3 liters of isocyanate-based hardener. The chemical immediately vaporized, creating an irritant vapor cloud. Lina inhaled vapors and experienced immediate respiratory irritation, coughing, eye watering, and mild wheezing. She self-evacuated to the outdoor fresh air intake area and notified the night shift supervisor immediately. Wei Liu (EMP-00088), the Production Scheduler on night shift, assisted with ventilation activation and emergency response coordination. Medical evaluation revealed chemical inhalation with transient respiratory effects. Lina was transported to the external occupational health clinic for observation and monitoring over 4 hours. She was cleared to return to modified duty the following day but experienced lingering symptoms for 36 additional hours, meeting the lost-time injury threshold.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler in the Finished Goods Warehouse, was organizing stacked pallets of finished composite parts when she noticed an unusual vibration coming from the overhead conveyor system. She immediately stopped her work and alerted her supervisor. Upon inspection, maintenance personnel discovered that a critical bearing on the conveyor's drive mechanism was severely worn and on the verge of complete failure. If the bearing had failed while the system was operating at full capacity, multiple pallets of high-value medical-grade components (valued at approximately $85,000) would have fallen from 12 feet above, creating an extremely hazardous situation with potential for serious injury to workers below. The near-miss was documented by Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), EHS Coordinator, who initiated immediate shutdown of the system and coordinated with maintenance to complete emergency repairs before resuming operations.

On April 3, 2024 at 09:15 during the day shift, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn injury while performing routine mold release and product ejection on an active injection molding machine. While removing a completed molded composite part from the mold cavity, Ahmed accidentally contacted the mold surface which was operating at 185°C (365°F). He received second-degree burns across the palm and inner fingers of his right hand. Despite wearing standard cotton work gloves rated for 100°C, the gloves provided insufficient protection and the heat transfer to his skin occurred within 2-3 seconds of contact. Ahmed immediately reported the injury and was transported by company vehicle to the occupational health clinic where the burn was treated, cleaned, and dressed with specialized burn dressing. The incident was witnessed by production supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) who immediately initiated first aid response and documented the event. Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, investigated and filed the injury report.

On May 22, 2024 at 02:30 during the night shift, Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042), a Composite Materials Technician, was performing routine cleaning and maintenance of the epoxy resin mixing apparatus in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. While cleaning the interior of a large mixing hopper following lockout/tagout procedures, Olga experienced sudden onset dizziness, nausea, and visual disturbance. A coworker, Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), found her sitting on the floor complaining of headache and weakness. The ventilation system in the chemical mixing area had failed approximately 2 hours earlier but this was not immediately reported or addressed during the shift changeover. Olga had been exposed to concentrated epoxy resin vapors and solvent fumes (primarily xylene and acetone) for an extended period. Emergency response was initiated; Olga was moved to fresh air immediately and given oxygen. She was transported via ambulance to the Regional Medical Center in Laval where she was admitted for 3 days of observation and treatment for acute chemical inhalation injury with secondary respiratory tract inflammation. She required hospitalization including IV fluids, respiratory support, and monitoring. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), Safety Trainer, filed the lost-time injury report and initiated the investigation.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn to his right forearm while removing a finished part from the mold cavity. The ambient temperature of the injection molding equipment was approximately 85°C. While extracting a polycarbonate housing component using manual tongs, Hassan's glove slipped and his bare forearm made contact with the hot mold surface for approximately 2 seconds, resulting in a first-degree burn measuring roughly 6 cm × 4 cm. The operator immediately cooled the affected area under running water at the nearby emergency eyewash station for approximately 10 minutes. First aid was administered by Johanne Paquette (Emergency Response Team Leader) at 3:00 PM. The wound was cleaned, treated with antibiotic ointment, and dressed with sterile gauze. Hassan continued working for the remainder of his shift with modified duties. No hospitalization was required. The incident was attributed to inadequate grip maintenance on the handling tongs and the operator's rushed pace to meet production targets.

On March 18, 2024 at 6:15 PM, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Maintenance Workshop (Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room). Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), Mold Maintenance Technician, was performing routine preventive maintenance on the mezzanine level storage system when a hydraulic lifting platform suddenly collapsed. The platform, which supported approximately 450 kg of mold components and tooling, had experienced a complete failure of its main hydraulic cylinder seal due to lack of preventive maintenance (maintenance records indicated the last full inspection was 14 months prior). The platform descended rapidly, but Simard was positioned to the side and sustained only minor contusions to his left leg. However, the falling molds caused approximately $38,000 in damage to precision mold tooling and surrounding equipment. The incident was immediately reported to Guillaume Deschamps (Operations Manager) at 6:20 PM. CNESST was notified, and the platform was immediately locked out pending investigation and repair. Analysis revealed that scheduled preventive maintenance intervals had been extended beyond manufacturer recommendations due to budget constraints.

On March 22, 2024 at 12:30 AM during the night shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), Composite Materials Operator, experienced a minor laceration to her left index finger while manually trimming excess resin from a finished composite part at the Packaging and Labeling Station. The part had sharp, jagged edges along the perimeter where mold separation had occurred improperly. Despite wearing cotton work gloves, a sharp resin edge penetrated the fabric and cut Abdallah's finger to a depth of approximately 3 mm, causing minor bleeding. Abdallah immediately reported the incident to her supervisor at 12:35 AM. First aid was provided by Sanaa Rachidi (Fire Safety Coordinator) at 12:40 AM, consisting of wound cleansing, application of antibiotic ointment, and sterile bandaging. No stitches were required, and Abdallah returned to modified duties within 30 minutes. The incident was documented in the facility's incident log. Root cause analysis identified inadequate de-burring procedures and improper mold ejection angle as contributors.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a fire alarm was triggered in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) in the Main Production Building West Wing. Olga Ivanova, Composite Materials Technician, was conducting routine fiberglass layup operations when she noticed smoke emanating from a resin dryer unit that had been operating continuously for 8 hours without proper temperature monitoring. The dryer's thermostat had malfunctioned, causing internal temperatures to exceed safe operational limits. Olga immediately activated the nearest fire alarm pull station and evacuated the area. The facility's automated suppression system activated, and the on-site fire response team arrived within 2 minutes. Upon inspection, the resin dryer showed signs of thermal stress but no active flames were detected. The smoke was caused by degradation of composite material residue on internal heating elements. Production Supervisor André Paradis coordinated the evacuation of 15 workers from the West Wing. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos and Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi responded to investigate. The facility was cleared for re-entry after 45 minutes following visual inspection and air quality verification.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM on the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007), Section A. Maya Kumar, Production Operator, was retrieving a 5-gallon container of mold release agent (silicone-based, classified as hazardous per WHMIS 2015) from a storage shelf at approximately 1.8 meters height. Due to inadequate shelf labeling and poor lighting in that section of the warehouse, Maya selected the wrong container and attempted to transport it alongside other materials. The container's cap was not fully tightened, likely from the previous operator's handling. While navigating between rows of stacked materials, Maya bumped the container against a storage rack edge, causing the cap to dislodge. Approximately 3.2 liters of mold release agent spilled onto the concrete floor, spreading across an estimated 8 square meter area. The substance created a slippery surface and produced volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes. Julien Racine, Shipping Clerk working in the adjacent section, immediately notified the HSE department. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos and Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance responded. The area was cordoned off with caution tape, and Maya was moved to fresh air. Emergency ventilation fans were deployed. The spill was contained using absorbent granules and disposed of according to hazardous waste protocols. Incident duration: 1.5 hours including cleanup and air quality monitoring.

On June 8, 2024, at approximately 4:20 PM during evening shift operations, a property damage incident occurred at Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-004) in the South Zone of the Main Production Building. Yasmin Ali, Injection Molding Operator, was conducting a material changeover from medical-grade polycarbonate to standard polypropylene. During the cleaning cycle, a pressure relief valve on the hopper heating unit malfunctioned, releasing pressurized steam and causing a sudden rupture in the insulation jacket. The burst of pressurized steam struck an adjacent quality control equipment station, damaging a spectrophotometer valued at approximately $42,000 used for color verification of molded parts. The equipment's optical sensor array was warped by thermal stress, rendering it inoperable. Additionally, the steam discharge caused superficial damage to plastic containment panels around the injection molding machine and scorched approximately 12 square meters of floor epoxy coating. Daniel Kim, Electrical Maintenance Technician, immediately shut down the affected line and secured the area. Quality Control Technician Sophie Lapointe assessed the spectrophotometer damage. Production Supervisor Normand Bergeron notified management and industrial hygienist Nina Santos. The incident resulted in 18 hours of production downtime on Line D and required emergency procurement and installation of replacement quality control equipment. No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident highlighted inadequate equipment maintenance protocols and pressure vessel monitoring.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM, a significant fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). An employee, Amina Mansour (EMP-00044), was transferring acetone solvent from a 55-gallon drum into smaller containers for distribution to production areas. Due to inadequate ventilation in the storage area and a buildup of flammable vapors, when she placed the container near a wall-mounted electrical outlet to plug in a heating apparatus, a spark from the outlet ignited the acetone fumes. The initial flash fire spread rapidly to nearby containers of mold release agents and isopropanol. Within minutes, flames reached approximately 8 feet high and threatened to spread to adjacent resin storage. Emergency response was initiated immediately. The facility's automated fire suppression system activated, extinguishing the fire within 90 seconds. One employee (Amina) sustained first-degree burns to her left arm and hand. The incident resulted in the evacuation of 60 personnel, approximately $47,000 in damaged materials and equipment, and a 6-hour production halt. Root cause analysis revealed that the ventilation system had been operating at only 60% capacity due to a clogged intake filter that was not on the maintenance schedule. Additionally, the electrical outlet near chemical storage did not meet current safety standards for hazardous locations.

On February 28, 2024, at 6:15 PM during the evening shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a machine operator on an injection molding line, experienced a critical equipment failure that resulted in a near-miss injury event. While operating Line B in the Main Production Building, a hydraulic pressure relief valve on the injection head malfunctioned, causing the pressure to exceed safe operating parameters. The valve, which should have been serviced 180 days prior according to maintenance schedules, had not been replaced and was operating 320 days past its service interval. As the hydraulic pressure surged to 450 PSI (well beyond the 280 PSI rated maximum), the pressure release mechanism activated unexpectedly, sending a high-velocity spray of hydraulic fluid across the operator station. The spray missed Hawa by approximately 18 inches, passing directly where her upper torso would have been positioned if she had been standing at her normal work station rather than temporarily stepping back to retrieve a parts container. The hot hydraulic fluid (approximately 140°F) contacted the production floor and dissipated. Hawa immediately reported the incident to Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), who shut down the line. Investigation revealed that maintenance records were incomplete and the relief valve replacement had been overlooked during a transition in maintenance planning systems six months prior.

On April 10, 2024, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident was prevented through proper safety protocols at the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), the Warehouse Lead on night shift, observed that a forklift operator (who had called in sick) had not properly secured a stacked pallet of finished composite materials before the start of the shift. The pallet, containing approximately 2,800 pounds of packaged products, was positioned on the dock at an estimated height of 6.5 feet, balanced precariously with only two of four corner securing straps fastened. The load sat approximately 8 feet away from where personnel regularly work to prepare shipping manifests. Michel immediately identified the hazard and cordoned off the area with safety cones and caution tape, preventing access. He then contacted Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142), the Receiving Coordinator, to stand by while he carefully repositioned the pallet and secured all four corner straps properly. No injuries occurred, but the potential hazard was significant—the load could have fallen at any moment during the night shift when only 15-20 personnel were present, potentially striking workers below or in the vicinity. The incident highlighted inadequate shift-to-shift communication regarding outstanding material handling tasks and the absence of a pre-shift safety walkthrough procedure. Video review showed no safety officer or supervisor had conducted a dock inspection before shift start.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine hopper material loading in the Injection Molding Line A facility. While opening the material hopper access port to load virgin polycarbonate resin, a pressurized hopper overflow occurred unexpectedly. Approximately 40 kilograms of hot plastic material (approximately 95°C) spilled onto the production floor directly in front of the hopper station. Marcel immediately slipped on the spilled material while attempting to move away from the hazard zone. He fell backward, striking his lower back against the edge of a nearby machine guard. Two colleagues, Natalya Kozlov and Jasmine Patel, witnessed the incident and immediately assisted by alerting the shift supervisor and securing the area. Marcel reported acute lower back pain and was transported to the on-site occupational health clinic where Nurse Al-Rashid assessed him for potential spinal injury. X-rays revealed no fractures, but significant soft tissue contusion was documented. The hopper pressure relief valve had failed to function properly, creating a hazardous condition that should have been caught during the morning maintenance check.

On March 22, 2024 at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area on a manual fiber-reinforced plastic lay-up procedure. While handling a large roll of fiberglass cloth to position it on the mold surface, tiny glass fibers became airborne due to the material's dry state and inadequate local ventilation capture. Rania inhaled a significant quantity of glass fibers and began experiencing severe itching and irritation in her respiratory passages and exposed skin areas on her arms and neck. She immediately notified her supervisor and proceeded to the wash station for decontamination. Despite thorough washing, she continued experiencing throat irritation and skin reactions. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid examined her at approximately 10:45 PM and confirmed acute glass fiber dermatitis with respiratory tract involvement. The employee was advised to cease work and was sent home with instructions for continued hydration and use of prescribed antihistamine cream. Investigation revealed that the local exhaust ventilation system serving that workstation had reduced airflow efficiency (later confirmed at 60% of rated capacity), and employees were not wearing respiratory protection equipment during dry fiber handling activities.

On March 28, 2024 at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility. The main industrial oven, a 15-year-old model used for curing composite resins, experienced an internal electrical fault within its heating element array. The fault caused an uncontrolled thermal runaway condition, causing internal temperatures to exceed safe operating limits (reached approximately 480°C versus the intended 200°C setpoint). The excessive heat caused thermal stress on the oven's exterior casing and internal structural components, resulting in visible warping of the metal frame and cracking of the insulation. Additionally, the intense heat caused the thermal overload switch to fail, preventing the automatic shutdown mechanism from functioning. The oven's cooling system engaged but could not overcome the thermal event. When night shift supervisor Julien Racine (EMP-00177) and two maintenance technicians arrived to investigate an unusual alarm condition, they discovered the oven exterior was too hot to approach safely (surface temperature approximately 85°C) and the interior was still glowing visibly through observation ports. The equipment was immediately de-energized and isolated using lockout procedures. The oven sustained severe internal damage requiring complete replacement of the heating element assembly and control system, with replacement parts and labor costs exceeding $180,000. No employees were physically injured during this incident, as the night shift crew was performing remote monitoring at the time of failure. However, the incident resulted in significant production downtime and financial loss.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, James Thompson (EMP-00029), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, suffered a significant thermal burn while performing routine mold cleaning. Thompson was spraying mold release agent on a recently ejected injection mold from a 250-ton molding machine when pressurized residual plastic material at approximately 165°C suddenly discharged from a vent port. The scalding plastic contacted his right forearm and hand, causing immediate pain and visible blistering. Thompson immediately immersed his arm in cold water at a nearby sink and alerted his supervisor. First aid was administered on-site, and after assessment by the on-site occupational health nurse, Thompson was transported to a local emergency clinic for treatment of second-degree burns covering approximately 8% of his right arm. The incident was witnessed by Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a production operator on an adjacent line. Investigation revealed that the mold cooling cycle had not fully completed and pressure relief procedures were not followed before cleaning commenced. Thompson was wearing standard cotton gloves, which provided minimal protection against thermal contact.

On January 22, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, was transferring acetone (a primary cleaning solvent used in mold cleaning operations) from a 208-liter storage drum to a smaller operational container using a manual hand pump when the pump mechanism failed suddenly, causing the pressurized drum outlet to disconnect. Approximately 35 liters of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor of the chemical storage area, with approximately 12 liters subsequently flowing into the facility's stormwater drainage system located immediately adjacent to the storage unit. The spill created both an immediate indoor air quality hazard (acetone vapors) and an environmental contamination risk. Emergency response protocols were triggered: the building was partially evacuated, the spill area was cordoned off, and absorbent material was deployed. Environmental sampling indicated acetone concentrations of 850 ppm in the immediate spill area (OSHA PEL: 750 ppm TWA). An estimated 100 gallons flowed to the municipal stormwater system before drainage was isolated. The incident revealed that: (1) the hand pump had not been inspected or maintained in over 18 months, (2) no secondary containment system existed under the transfer point, (3) stormwater drain isolation valves were not accessible, and (4) the spill response kit was incomplete.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, machine operator Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141) was working at Injection Molding Line A when he experienced a crush injury to his right hand. Blanchard was removing finished automotive trim parts from the mold cavity when the hydraulic press unexpectedly cycled due to a faulty proximity sensor that failed to detect the open mold position. The mold closed with significant force, trapping his hand between the upper and lower mold halves. Material handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button. Blanchard sustained a fractured metacarpal bone in his right hand and severe soft tissue bruising. He was transported by ambulance to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval where he received surgical intervention. The incident resulted in 18 days of lost work time. Investigation revealed the proximity sensor had not been included in the preventive maintenance schedule, and lockout/tagout procedures had not been properly followed during the last maintenance cycle.

On February 8, 2024, at 10:15 AM, Materials Engineer Jing Wang (EMP-00054) conducted a routine inspection of the Composite Materials Processing Area and identified a potential fire hazard. During her walkthrough of UNIT-015, Wang discovered a significant accumulation of plastic dust and composite fiber particles on horizontal surfaces, elevated structures, and within electrical equipment enclosures throughout the West Wing production area. The dust layer exceeded 2mm depth in several locations, creating conditions that meet the threshold for combustible dust ignition. The accumulation appeared to have occurred over a 4-week period due to inadequate vacuum collection maintenance on the central dust extraction system. Wang immediately notified HSE Director Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001) who declared a preventive work stoppage in that zone. Air sampling confirmed airborne fiber concentrations at 85% of the CNESST exposure limit. No employee was exposed to dangerous conditions as the area was cleared for housekeeping operations before any work resumed.

On March 22, 2024, at 4:30 PM during evening shift operations, machine operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) sustained a minor laceration to the dorsal surface of her left hand while performing part removal from an injection mold at Injection Molding Line A. Traore was retrieving finished automotive components from a mold cavity when her gloved hand contacted a sharp burr that had formed on the mold cavity edge during the previous production run. The burr, approximately 3mm in height and extremely sharp, caused a 2cm laceration through the glove into the epidermis.
