First aid responder Diego Morales (EMP-00056) responded immediately, cleaned the wound with sterile saline solution, applied antibiotic ointment, and covered it with a sterile adhesive bandage. The incident did not result in lost work time as Traore was able to continue operations with modified glove protection. The wound required no sutures and was categorized as a minor first-aid level injury. Tool Room Technician Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173) was notified to deburr the mold cavity before the next production shift.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was organizing composite resin containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) when she noticed an unusual odor and visible crystalline residue on the floor near several storage drums. Upon closer inspection, she discovered that a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin appeared to have a hairline crack in its base, slowly leaking material. The employee immediately notified her supervisor and evacuated the area. The spill covered approximately 3 square meters and had not yet contacted any other materials or personnel. Emergency response team was called at 2:22 PM. The spill was contained using absorbent material and the damaged drum was transferred to a secondary containment vessel. No personnel were exposed to fumes or direct contact with the leaking material. The incident was declared as a preventive measure to improve storage inspection protocols and drum integrity monitoring.

On October 29, 2024, at approximately 4:30 AM during the night shift, Injection Molding Technician Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045) was removing a finished composite part from Molding Press #3 when his right hand came into contact with residual hot plastic material at approximately 85°C. The technician was wearing standard nitrile gloves, which provided insufficient thermal protection. He sustained a partial-thickness burn covering approximately 8% of his right palm and first three fingers. The burn resulted in immediate blistering and significant pain. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided emergency first aid with cool water immersion and sterile dressing. The employee was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur emergency department at 4:52 AM where the burn was treated with topical antimicrobial ointment and covered with specialized burn dressing. Due to severe pain and impaired hand function, Patrick was placed on medical leave for 4 weeks, during which he received weekly wound care and physiotherapy. The incident was classified as a lost-time injury requiring work restrictions and hospitalization-equivalent treatment.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Elena Popescu, a Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring a 50-liter container of polycarbonate resin solvent when the container's valve coupling failed due to corrosion, releasing approximately 35 liters of solvent onto the concrete floor. The solvent, a mixture of aromatic hydrocarbons and esters, began pooling near the floor drain system. Within minutes, vapors accumulated near ground level where two material handlers, Chiara Bianchi and Amani Mwangi, were working on the opposite side of the room. Both workers began reporting dizziness and mild headaches within 5 minutes of the spill. The facility's ventilation system activated automatically, but the localized vapor concentration remained elevated for approximately 20 minutes until the spill was fully contained and cleaned. Emergency response protocols were initiated, and both affected employees were moved to fresh air. No external release to the environment occurred as the material was contained within the facility's secondary containment system. The incident was identified as an environmental hazard with potential regulatory implications under Quebec's environmental protection regulations.

On March 18, 2024 at 02:15 during the night shift, an overhead crane failure occurred in Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components (UNIT-003). Bruno Landry, an Injection Molding Operator, was positioning a finished part crate using the facility's 2-ton overhead bridge crane when the crane's load cell sensor malfunctioned, causing it to fail to prevent an overload condition. A second crate weighing approximately 2.8 tons was being lifted simultaneously by a visiting maintenance technician who was not fully aware of the weight. The overloaded crane's structural beam began to show visible deflection, and emergency load-drop safety mechanisms activated, automatically lowering both crates to the floor without incident. No personnel were in the direct drop zone, as the crane operator (who was observing from the operator's station) had implemented proper isolation protocols. However, the deflection caused minor surface cracks in the adjacent composite material storage shelves. The equipment was immediately taken out of service. Investigation revealed the load cell sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months, well beyond the recommended 6-month calibration interval specified by the crane manufacturer.

On March 22, 2024 at 08:30 during the day shift, a potential hand injury near-miss was prevented through quick intervention at Injection Molding Line B - Automotive (UNIT-002). Yara Mustafa, a Production Operator, was performing routine part ejection and inspection when she reached toward a hot molded part on the conveyor line while wearing a torn glove that had a small opening near her right index finger. The part temperature was approximately 75°C (just above the 70°C threshold for thermal injury risk). As her unprotected fingertip made contact with the part surface, she immediately withdrew her hand due to the heat sensation. A nearby supervisor, André Paradis, witnessed the incident and immediately stopped the line. Upon inspection, Yara's finger showed mild erythema (redness) but no blistering or deeper tissue damage. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the injury did not develop beyond first-degree thermal exposure. Root cause analysis identified that the protective glove had degraded due to repeated thermal cycling and had not been replaced per the 90-day replacement schedule. Standard operating procedures require inspection of PPE before each shift, but this inspection had been omitted that morning.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a thermal burn to her right forearm while removing finished medical device components from the injection molding machine. The machine had completed its cycle, but residual heat in the mold cavity remained above 280°C. Yasmin was wearing standard nitrile gloves but they provided insufficient insulation against the radiant heat. She briefly contacted the mold frame while extracting a part, resulting in a first-degree burn covering approximately 3 inches of her inner forearm. The burn caused immediate pain and redness but did not require hospitalization. Jade Wong (EMP-00140), the Process Technician on duty, witnessed the incident and immediately applied cold water to the affected area for 10 minutes and administered first aid using the facility's burn care kit. The employee reported to the on-site first aid station where the burn was dressed with antibiotic ointment and sterile gauze. She remained at work for the remainder of the shift but reported discomfort with gripping tasks. The incident was documented in the facility's injury log and reported to the JHSC.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the evening shift, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, sustained a minor laceration to his left index finger while manually clearing a material jam in the regrind collection hopper. The hopper's screw conveyor had become blocked with hardened polycarbonate fragments from a rejected batch. Oscar attempted to dislodge the material using a metal rod while the conveyor was powered off, but a subsequent partial fragment became lodged between his gloved finger and the conveyor housing as he withdrew his hand. The sharp plastic edge caused a 1-inch laceration on the side of his finger, resulting in minor bleeding through the work glove. Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), the Production Supervisor for the evening shift, observed the incident from the adjacent quality control station and immediately instructed Oscar to proceed to the first aid station. The laceration was cleaned with antiseptic solution, and a sterile adhesive bandage was applied. No sutures were required. The employee completed his shift with modified duties that did not involve direct material handling. The incident was reported to the HSE department, and the regrind equipment was inspected for sharp edges or protrusions.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:00 PM during the night shift, a pressure relief incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility resulting in minor equipment damage and material spillage. Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter on the night shift, was preparing a batch of heat-stabilized resin when an improperly closed relief valve on the 500-gallon reaction vessel began leaking pressurized vapors. The facility's automated monitoring system detected the pressure anomaly at 3.2 bar (above the 3.0 bar safety setpoint). The leak caused approximately 50 liters of volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors to vent into the chemical storage area before the pressure relief valve fully activated as designed. The escaping vapors created a localized zone of elevated VOC concentration. The automatic ventilation system activated as programmed, and the facility's alarm system alerted the night shift supervisor. No employees were directly exposed to high vapor concentrations due to the rapid ventilation response. However, the incident resulted in approximately $8,500 in property damage: 200 liters of partially processed resin material was deemed unusable and required proper hazardous waste disposal, and the relief valve required replacement ($3,200) due to damage from the pressure surge. André Bellavance (EMP-00157), the Confined Space Entry Supervisor, was called in to assess the situation and verify facility air quality before resuming operations. The incident was recorded as a CNESST-reportable environmental release.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198), a Production Operator on Line B, was performing routine cleaning of an injection molding machine (Model: Engel 500-ton) at the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. The machine had been in operation until 2:30 PM. While Laila was wiping down the mold cavity with a cloth, a coworker, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), accidentally activated the machine startup sequence from the control panel, unaware that cleaning was in progress. The mold clamped shut at high pressure, trapping Laila's left hand between the upper and lower mold halves. The emergency stop was activated immediately by a nearby supervisor, Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128), who witnessed the incident. Laila sustained a severe laceration to her left palm, crushing injuries to fingers 2-4, and significant bruising across the dorsal surface of her hand. Emergency services transported her to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval where she received 47 stitches and was treated for potential compartment syndrome. The incident was attributed to the absence of proper LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures and inadequate communication between operators during shift transitions.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B) experienced a fire alarm activation with no visible flame or smoke. Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), Machine Operator on the evening shift, was moving palletized finished medical device components using an electric forklift near a storage rack containing high-density polyethylene (HDPE) regrind material. The battery charging station for the forklift fleet is located approximately 15 meters from the storage area. A battery charger on a three-year-old Hawker unit malfunctioned, generating excessive heat (estimated 180°C) that ignited accumulated dust deposits inside the charger housing. The thermal event triggered the warehouse's advanced smoke detection system (Honeywell Fire-Lite system) at 10:16 PM. Facility Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) initiated the emergency shutdown, evacuated all personnel using designated assembly points, and contacted the Laval Fire Department. The charger was isolated immediately by disconnecting the main electrical panel. No fire propagated beyond the charger itself, but the incident halted all warehouse operations for 90 minutes pending inspection and clearance. Root cause analysis identified inadequate preventive maintenance records for the charging equipment and insufficient clearance (dust accumulation) around the charger.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the Chemical Mixing Room (Materials Management area) experienced a cooling water system failure. Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), Hydraulic Systems Technician, was performing routine inspections of the closed-loop cooling system that circulates chilled water through the resin dryer heating jackets. The system maintains a critical 18°C setpoint for temperature-sensitive polyester and epoxy composites. Andrei discovered a corroded copper-nickel coupling on the main supply line had fractured, allowing approximately 150 liters of antifreeze-treated cooling water (containing ethylene glycol at 40% concentration) to leak into the containment basin over a 45-minute period. The leakage exceeded the 100-liter capacity of the secondary containment, and approximately 50 liters of contaminated water overflowed onto the concrete floor and infiltrated the storm drain system via floor drains without proper diversion. The spill reached the facility's exterior yard perimeter before Andrei activated the emergency shutoff and placed absorbent pads. Immediate mitigation included plugging the storm drain, deploying granular absorbent material (100 kg), and collecting free product. CNESST (Quebec occupational health authority) and Laval municipal environmental services were notified per regulatory requirements. Analytical testing revealed ethylene glycol concentrations of 1,800 mg/L in recovered samples, exceeding the 500 mg/L environmental discharge threshold. Root cause: corrosion from acidic process water conditions and lack of preventive replacement schedule for aging copper-nickel couplings.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone of the Main Production Building. While attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper feed system, she did not properly engage the lockout/tagout procedure. A colleague, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), was working nearby when the machine unexpectedly cycled. Leila's left hand was caught between the rotating screw assembly and the hopper wall, resulting in severe lacerations to her palm and fingers. She was unable to free herself and called for assistance. Bruno immediately stopped the machine using the emergency stop button and called for first aid response. The HSE team arrived within 3 minutes. Leila was treated on-site for the laceration and transported to Laval General Hospital where she received 14 stitches and was diagnosed with a partial tendon laceration. She was unable to return to work for 6 weeks, resulting in significant lost time.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a critical failure occurred in the cooling water system serving the composite materials processing equipment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) and Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) noticed unusual vibration and temperature fluctuations on the equipment monitoring display. Upon investigation, they discovered that the main circulation pump had seized due to bearing corrosion and inadequate preventive maintenance. The pump failure caused a complete loss of cooling capacity, resulting in overheating of the resin mixing tanks. By the time the equipment was shut down, two large composite material batches valued at approximately $180,000 had degraded beyond recovery. The batch loss necessitated production delays affecting three major automotive client deliveries scheduled for the following week. Emergency maintenance was performed to repair and replace the pump assembly, requiring 16 hours of overtime labor.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, packaging operator Amara Diop (EMP-00110) was organizing finished goods in the Warehouse and Shipping area when she reached for a carton on a high shelf approximately 7 feet above the ground. As she pulled the carton toward her, the stack above it became unstable. Four large boxes containing polycarbonate components cascaded down, striking her shoulder and upper back. The impact knocked her to the ground where she struck her head on the concrete floor. Witness Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), who was working in the adjacent receiving section, heard the commotion and immediately called for emergency assistance. Amara was conscious but experiencing significant shoulder pain and mild confusion. Emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes. She was transported to the hospital where imaging revealed a Grade 2 shoulder separation (AC joint) and a mild concussion. She was kept for observation and discharged with restrictions on heavy lifting for 8 weeks.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler in UNIT-018 (Regrind and Recycling Department), was preparing to transfer a batch of processed regrind material from the collection hopper to a storage bin using a powered pallet jack. As she approached the designated storage area in Warehouse and Shipping - Section C, she noticed that the access path was partially blocked by a pallet of raw polypropylene resin that had been left in the walkway. Rather than returning the pallet jack to the staging area, she attempted to navigate around the obstruction. While maneuvering, the pallet jack's front wheel caught on an air hose routed across the floor, causing the jack to suddenly stop. Mariam stumbled forward but caught herself on a nearby support column, preventing a fall. Warehouse Supervisor (Evening Shift) Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) was working approximately 20 feet away and witnessed the near-miss. He immediately assessed the area and confirmed no injury occurred. Upon investigation, the incident revealed three hazards: the improperly stored raw material blocking the walkway, the air hose not secured in a protective conduit, and the lack of clear signage indicating the regrind department's equipment circulation path. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) was notified and documented the incident as a near-miss with significant potential for serious injury.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), a Regrind Operator, was working in UNIT-015 (Composite Materials Processing Area) preparing reinforced plastic material for recycling. While operating a grinder to process composite scrap material, he experienced a sudden burst of compressed air from a pneumatic cleaning line that had become detached from its coupling. The pressurized air stream, traveling at approximately 80 psi, struck him directly in the left eye and upper cheek area. Mohamed immediately experienced sharp pain and reflex tearing. He ceased work immediately and moved to the emergency wash station. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) was performing night rounds and found Mohamed at the wash station. He assisted with eye irrigation for 15 minutes using the station's eyewash system and immediately contacted Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) who arrived at the facility within 30 minutes despite the hour. Initial assessment revealed mild corneal abrasion and significant conjunctival irritation. Mohamed was referred to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur emergency department for ophthalmologic evaluation and treatment. The injured eye showed redness and slight swelling but no apparent structural damage. Root cause investigation identified that the pneumatic coupling had corroded, and the coupling retaining clip had failed due to inadequate preventive maintenance of the air distribution system. The compressed air line had been operating without proper safety pressure regulation or emergency shutoff mechanisms readily accessible to operators.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was operating Injection Molding Line D when he attempted to clear a material jam in the hopper without following proper lockout/tagout procedures. A coworker, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), was assisting nearby. As Rémi reached into the hopper to dislodge compacted polypropylene resin, the auger mechanism suddenly activated due to a malfunctioning proximity sensor. His right hand became caught in the rotating auger, resulting in severe laceration to his palm and fingers. The machine was immediately shut down by Bertrand, who called for emergency response. Rémi was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital where he required surgical intervention and received 14 stitches. The incident was witnessed by quality control technician Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013) who was conducting routine inspections nearby. Investigation revealed that the LOTO coordinator had not been notified of the maintenance issue with the proximity sensor.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, regrind technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was performing routine material handling in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) when he noticed an unusual chemical odor near the storage racks for cleaning solvents. Upon investigation, he discovered that a 55-gallon drum of acetone had developed a slow leak at the bottom seam, with approximately 8-10 gallons pooled on the concrete floor. The solvent had spread across an area approximately 12 feet by 15 feet. Oscar immediately evacuated the immediate area and notified facilities manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) via radio. The chemical safety officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) was called to the scene. Containment measures were implemented using absorbent materials and chemical-compatible spill kits. The affected area was cordoned off with warning tape, and the leaking drum was transferred to a secondary containment system. Ventilation was increased to the warehouse, and air quality was monitored. No employee exposures occurred due to rapid response. The spill was contained within the warehouse and did not reach storm drains or groundwater.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, machine operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) was moving a pallet of raw polycarbonate resin bags using an electric forklift in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). As he navigated between storage racks, the forklift's left front tire caught on a coiled air hose that had been left on the floor near the drying ovens. The sudden jolt caused the pallet load to shift slightly and tilt, with one of the 25-kilogram bags beginning to slide off the stack. Emmanuel immediately recognized the hazard and lowered the pallet gently to the ground, allowing the bag to settle without falling. No equipment was damaged, and no personnel were in the immediate drop zone. Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the workplace hazard assessment specialist who was conducting a night shift safety walk-through, observed the incident and commended Emmanuel for his quick reaction. The incident was immediately logged as a near-miss with potential for serious injury had the bag struck someone below.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was removing finished parts from the mold cavity when his right hand became caught between the closing mold halves. The mold had been programmed to cycle automatically, and a sensor malfunction failed to detect Ahmed's hand in the danger zone. He sustained a crush injury to his index and middle fingers with significant tissue damage. Ahmed immediately withdrew his hand and alerted his supervisor Julie Bergeron. The production line was stopped, first aid was administered on-site, and Ahmed was transported to Laval General Hospital where X-rays confirmed fractures to both fingers. The incident occurred at 2:45 PM during the day shift in the Main Production Building - North Zone. Contributing factors included inadequate guarding on the mold access point, failure of the safety interlock system, and insufficient work procedure enforcement for hand placement during part extraction.

On November 16, 2024 at 09:15, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator, was transferring a large batch of cooled plastic components from a pallet to the assembly staging area using a powered pallet jack in the Assembly and Finishing Department (East Wing). As Amal maneuvered the jack around a tight corner near the storage racks, the front wheel struck an oil slick left from maintenance work performed the previous evening. The pallet jack lost traction and tipped sideways. Amal's left leg was pinned between the jack and a storage rack, causing a crushing injury to the calf muscle and resulting in a compound fracture of the fibula. David O'Connor, the Warehouse Supervisor, witnessed the incident and immediately called for emergency response. First aid was administered, and Amal was transported by ambulance to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé. The incident was caused by inadequate cleanup of the maintenance area, insufficient slip-resistant flooring treatment, and lack of proper traffic control barriers.

On November 18, 2024 at 22:30 during the evening shift, Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), an Assembly Operator, was manually assembling automotive interior trim components on a workstation in the Assembly and Finishing Department. The work required repetitive gripping, twisting, and insertion motions for 8 consecutive hours. Luis reported sharp pain in his right wrist and forearm to his supervisor Julie Bergeron around 10:30 PM. Upon examination, he exhibited signs of acute repetitive strain injury with swelling in the wrist and reduced grip strength. Luis applied ice and received over-the-counter pain medication at the facility's first aid station. He was advised to seek medical evaluation and was offered modified duty assignments for the following week. The incident was documented as a first-aid case since Luis did not require hospitalization or emergency transport. Contributing factors included inadequate workstation ergonomics, lack of job rotation, insufficient rest breaks, and no stretch break protocol.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198), a Production Operator on Line C, sustained a minor chemical splash injury while transferring polypropylene resin from a storage container to the material drying hopper in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. While opening a 25-kg bag of colorant masterbatch, a small quantity of fine powder became airborne and contacted her left eye and exposed facial skin. She immediately reported the incident to her supervisor and proceeded to the eyewash station where she rinsed her eye for approximately 5 minutes. A co-worker, Roberto Santos (EMP-00012), witnessed the incident and alerted the area supervisor. Laila experienced mild irritation and redness but no significant vision impairment. She was treated with first aid by the on-site first aid attendant and returned to work after 30 minutes. The incident was attributed to the bag being opened without proper containment procedures and inadequate PPE compliance—Laila was wearing safety glasses but not a full face shield as required for colorant handling operations.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator, experienced a minor laceration and contusion to her right index and middle fingers while performing manual assembly tasks at Station 3 in the Assembly and Finishing Department. While assembling composite components with an adhesive-bonded joint, Elena's fingers became briefly caught between two plastic parts as she applied pressure to hold the assembly during curing. The parts were not equipped with inter-lock guards or finger guards at the assembly interface. The pinching lasted approximately 2 seconds before she withdrew her hand. Elena immediately reported the incident and applied direct pressure with a clean cloth. The wound was assessed by the first aid attendant and treated with antiseptic wash, antibiotic ointment, and a sterile adhesive bandage. The laceration was approximately 8mm long with moderate bleeding that stopped within 5 minutes. She continued working with protective wrapping on her fingers and completed her shift. Luc Girard (EMP-00039), a nearby Maintenance Technician, witnessed the incident and documented the scene.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 11:20 during the day shift, a near-miss incident was identified by Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173), a Tool Room Technician, in the Maintenance Workshop during routine equipment inspection. While performing preventive maintenance on hydraulic press equipment that was supposedly locked out and tagged out (LOTO), Raynald discovered that the lockout procedure had been improperly executed. The main power disconnect had been switched to OFF, but the energy isolation lock had not been applied and the LOTO tag was attached to the wrong control panel. Additionally, residual hydraulic pressure remained in the system at approximately 800 PSI due to incomplete pressure relief procedures documented in the maintenance manual. If an operator had inadvertently reset the equipment during this maintenance window, the press would have cycled with potentially catastrophic consequences. Raynald immediately shut down the system properly, applied the correct locks, tags, and isolated all energy sources following proper LOTO protocol. He photographed the non-compliance evidence and reported the situation to Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist. No injury occurred, but the incident represented a critical control failure that could have resulted in serious trauma or amputation if the machine had operated.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, Assembly Operator Zara Khan (EMP-00106) was working at a manual assembly station in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005) when she sustained a significant laceration to her right hand from sharp edges on a molded polycarbonate component. The part had not been properly deburred during the post-processing phase, leaving multiple sharp edges and burrs. While removing the part from the fixture, Khan's hand slipped and made contact with the unfinished edge, causing a deep cut requiring 8 stitches. The incident occurred during day shift operations with Assembly Lead Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128) witnessing the event. First aid was administered immediately, and the employee was transported to the local clinic. The root cause investigation revealed that the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (UNIT-017) had skipped the deburring step due to equipment downtime, but this communication failure was not escalated through proper channels. Khan missed 3 days of work due to infection prevention protocols and wound care requirements.

On April 22, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift operations, a chemical storage area alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-004 area). Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) noticed a distinct acetone smell emanating from the chemical mixing section and immediately activated the emergency alarm as per protocol. Upon investigation by Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) and EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), a flexible acetone transfer hose connecting Injection Molding Line D's cooling system to the main solvent recovery tank was found to have a micro-leak, releasing acetone vapor into the work environment at approximately 2.5 gallons per hour. The ventilation system in that area had been operating at 60% capacity due to a partially blocked intake duct (discovered during inspection). The leak was not immediately visible but the accumulation of vapors triggered the chemical detection sensors set at 50% of the Lower Explosive Limit (LEL). The area was immediately evacuated, the leak was isolated by shutting down the transfer line, and facilities staff cleared the blockage and ran the ventilation system at full capacity for 45 minutes. No personnel were exposed to dangerous concentrations, and the alarm functioned as designed to prevent a potentially hazardous situation.

On May 8, 2024, at 06:30 during night shift operations, a small fire initiated in the Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) when Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) was performing routine cleaning of a CNC milling machine tool bit holder. He inadvertently sprayed acetone-based cleaning solvent onto a portion of compressed air tubing that was in contact with a hot surface (approximately 85°C) from a recently powered-down thermal stress testing unit. The compressed air line had been recently installed without proper heat shielding in close proximity to the thermal unit. The acetone vapors ignited, creating a small localized fire approximately 15 inches in diameter on the tubing insulation. Girard immediately deployed the nearby Class B dry chemical fire extinguisher, successfully extinguishing the fire within 30 seconds. The facility's automated fire suppression system did not activate as the fire was localized to a small area. However, the incident resulted in damage to approximately 8 feet of compressed air tubing insulation, charring of the thermal unit's outer casing, and scorch marks on adjacent tool racks. Night shift supervisor Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) was on-site as a responder and confirmed no personnel were injured and the area was properly ventilated post-incident. The root cause was inadequate spacing between high-temperature equipment and flammable materials, combined with failure to follow proper chemical handling procedures in proximity to heat sources.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-005). Lina Sokolova, a Composite Materials Operator, was transferring a 20-liter container of epoxy resin from the storage shelf to a mixing station when the container's lid failed to seal properly. The resin began leaking at a rate of approximately 2 liters per minute onto the concrete floor, creating a spreading puddle measuring roughly 4 meters in diameter within 3 minutes. The spill was not immediately contained due to the absence of a readily available spill kit in the immediate work area. Approximately 8 liters of resin were released before Lina activated the emergency response protocol and confined the spill using absorbent pads and containment barriers stored 15 meters away. The spill generated volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes that triggered the building's ventilation alarm. Normand Ouellette, Warehouse Lead, arrived as a responder and assisted in securing the area. Environmental contamination was limited to the designated chemical storage zone, but the incident required a 2-hour facility shut-down for ventilation recovery and spill remediation. Root cause investigation revealed that the container lid had sustained microscopic cracks from improper handling during a previous inventory transfer.

On March 22, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Karim Bouazizi, a Machine Setter on Line B (UNIT-002), sustained a significant burn injury to his right forearm and hand while performing maintenance on an injection molding machine. Karim was adjusting the temperature settings on the machine's heating element when he inadvertently contacted a mold surface that had retained residual heat of approximately 165°C. Although the machine had been powered down 20 minutes prior, the thermal mass of the mold had not sufficiently cooled. The burn resulted in a second-degree thermal injury covering approximately 8% of his right forearm and 5% of his hand. Karim immediately applied cold water and reported to the on-site medical facility where he received first aid treatment including wound cleaning and protective dressing. Due to the severity of the burn and associated swelling, Karim was transferred to a local hospital for evaluation and treatment. He was unable to return to work and commenced medical leave. The incident investigation revealed that the facility's lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure did not include a mandatory cooling verification step before personnel contact with heated mold surfaces. Ahmed Hassan, another operator on Line B, witnessed the incident and called for emergency response.

On April 3, 2024, at 11:20 PM during night shift operations, Maya Kumar, a Production Operator assigned to Line C (UNIT-003), narrowly avoided a serious entanglement incident while performing a routine material load operation. Maya was inserting a fresh batch of pre-dried medical-grade plastic pellets into the hopper of the injection molding machine when she noticed that the safety interlock gate had not fully engaged after the previous cycle. The equipment control system indicated the machine was in idle mode, but the rotating screw mechanism inside the injection chamber continued to rotate at a low speed—a condition inconsistent with the machine's display status. Maya noticed the discrepancy when she observed pellets being drawn into the partially open access port of the machine. She immediately withdrew her hand, which had been approximately 10 centimeters from the rotating mechanism, and activated the emergency stop button. The machine halted within 2 seconds. No physical contact occurred between Maya's hand and the rotating components. An investigation revealed that the safety interlock gate had developed a mechanical failure in its locking mechanism due to wear and lack of preventive maintenance over the previous 8 months. The malfunction created a dangerous gap between the actual machine state and the displayed control system status. Giovanni Bianchi, a CNC Operator working nearby, heard the emergency stop activation and responded to assist Maya.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a significant burn injury while performing routine material loading operations. Gagnon was transferring polypropylene resin from a heated hopper (maintained at 220°C) to the injection molding machine when the hopper's temperature control valve malfunctioned, causing an unexpected pressure release. Liquefied plastic material sprayed onto his right forearm and hand, resulting in second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his right upper extremity. The operator immediately ran his arm under cold water at the nearest safety station and called for assistance. Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), working on adjacent Line B, witnessed the incident and alerted the HSE team. Medical response was initiated within 3 minutes. The employee was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur in Montreal for treatment of the burns, where he was admitted for 5 days of hospitalization and skin grafting procedures. Post-incident investigation revealed that the temperature control sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months, exceeding the manufacturer's recommended maintenance interval of 12 months.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, Diego Morales (EMP-00056), an Assembly Operator assigned to the Automotive Assembly station, sustained a laceration to his left palm while handling newly molded dashboard components. The parts had sharp flash residue—thin plastic burrs remaining from the injection molding gate—that had not been properly removed during the quality control deburring stage. Morales was manually assembling interior trim components when his hand slipped during positioning and made contact with an unfinished edge of a polycarbonate housing, creating a 2-inch laceration requiring 6 stitches. The cut was immediately treated at the on-site first aid station by the trained first aid attendant using standard wound care protocol including cleaning, application of antiseptic, and sterile dressing. No hospitalization was required, and the employee returned to light-duty work the following morning. Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128), the Assembly Lead on duty, investigated and discovered that quality control had fallen behind schedule due to a equipment malfunction on the deburring machine, causing approximately 400 parts with incomplete finishing to be released to the assembly line.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 03:30 during the night shift, a fire was discovered in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C of the warehouse) that was traced to accumulated plastic dust ignition. Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), the Warehouse Lead on night shift, discovered smoke and small flames in a storage bin containing ground polyethylene regrind material near a hot water circulation line maintained at 65°C. The fire appeared to have originated from spontaneous ignition of dust that had accumulated on the exterior surfaces of the regrind equipment and electrical components over a 3-week period due to insufficient cleaning protocols. The night shift team immediately activated the emergency alarm at 03:32, initiated evacuation procedures, and Laflamme deployed a Class C dry powder fire extinguisher, bringing the fire under control within 4 minutes. The on-site fire suppression team arrived at 03:45 and confirmed the area was secure. Local fire marshal was notified and attended the facility at 04:15. Damage was limited to approximately 180 kg of regrind material and minor charring of equipment surfaces. The facility was cleared to resume operations at 06:00 after thorough inspection. Root cause investigation revealed that the automatic dust collection system had been inoperative for 14 days due to a failed blower motor, but this condition had not been documented or escalated through maintenance channels.

On March 15, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024) was operating Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building when she noticed a slight grinding noise coming from the hydraulic pump assembly. Rather than stopping the machine immediately, she continued monitoring production for approximately 20 minutes while the sound gradually worsened. At 10:50 AM, the hydraulic fluid began leaking from a corroded fitting, spraying onto the hot mold surface and creating a visible vapor cloud. Yasmin immediately activated the emergency stop and evacuated the area. The incident was discovered by her supervisor, Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), who called for industrial hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084). No employee contact with hydraulic fluid occurred, but the potential exposure to inhalation of solvent vapors and the risk of hydraulic injection injury were significant. The equipment was tagged out and maintenance was called. This preventive declaration is being made to document the near-miss and the equipment deficiency before a more serious incident occurs.

On April 22, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078), an assembly operator working in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit, was manually finishing composite parts fresh from the curing oven. Despite wearing cut-resistant gloves, she sustained a laceration to her left index finger on a sharp edge of a fiberglass-reinforced plastic component. The cut was approximately 1.5 cm long and 0.5 cm deep, bleeding significantly. Co-worker Amal Farsi (EMP-00200) applied first aid while Carmen proceeded to the on-site occupational health office. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed the wound, cleaned it with antiseptic, applied sterile gauze, and provided tetanus prophylaxis. The wound required 4 stitches and Carmen was placed on light duty for the remainder of the day due to pain and reduced dexterity. She returned to full duty the following day after wound re-evaluation. Total lost time: 7 hours. The incident was caused by inadequate edge finishing on the part and insufficient PPE protection.

On May 8, 2024, at 1:20 AM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a maintenance technician, was performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. He was adjusting the temperature calibration on the hopper dryer when the machine unexpectedly activated. The hopper drum began rotating rapidly with residual plastic resin inside. Alain's right arm was caught between the rotating drum and the mounting bracket, sustaining a crushing injury to his forearm with visible bruising and swelling. He immediately called for emergency assistance. Night shift supervisor Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was first responder and immediately de-energized the equipment using the main disconnect. Alain was transported via ambulance to the emergency department where imaging revealed a fractured radius (right forearm bone). He required surgical intervention including plating and screws. Total lost time: 42 days. Root cause: the machine's LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure was not fully followed—the main power was not isolated during the maintenance task, only the control circuit was powered down.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, during day shift operations, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Employee Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), Environmental Compliance Specialist, was inspecting the facility when she discovered approximately 45 liters of epoxy resin had leaked from a damaged storage container on the lower shelf of the chemical storage rack. The container's seal had deteriorated due to inadequate temperature control in the storage area, causing the resin to seep onto the concrete floor and migrate toward the floor drain system. The spill created a slippery hazard and posed environmental contamination risk. Immediate actions included: cordoning off the affected area with warning tape, activating the spill containment protocol, and notifying the maintenance team. The spill was contained using absorbent material and properly disposed of according to WHMIS regulations. An estimated 2 hours was required for full cleanup and area decontamination. Root causes identified: inadequate storage container maintenance, insufficient environmental controls in the storage room, and lack of secondary containment measures for bulk chemical storage.

On April 2, 2024 at 22:15 during evening shift, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a significant burn injury resulting in lost work time. While performing routine mold cleaning and material feed maintenance on Injection Molding Line A (UNIT-001), Conrad inadvertently made contact with the heating barrel of the injection molding machine. The barrel temperature was approximately 245°C (470°F). Despite wearing standard cotton gloves, the heat penetrated the glove material, causing second-degree thermal burns to his right palm and fingers. The employee immediately reported to the on-site medical station where Hana Al-Rashid, Occupational Health Nurse (EMP-00052), provided first aid treatment including cool water irrigation, sterile dressing application, and tetanus assessment. Conrad was subsequently transported to Laval General Hospital for specialized burn care and received hospitalization for 3 days. Medical evaluation determined 15% body surface area involvement and the employee required 6 weeks medical leave before returning to modified duty. The incident was formally reported to CNESST within 24 hours as a lost-time injury.

On May 8, 2024 at 09:30 during day shift, an injury incident occurred in the Warehouse and Shipping facility. Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), Material Handler, was retrieving plastic component pallets from racking on the upper storage level (approximately 2.8 meters high) when a wooden pallet supporting finished goods shifted unexpectedly. The pallet was improperly secured to the rack due to inadequate spacing calculation during the previous day's inventory reorganization. As the pallet began to slide, Amani attempted to stabilize it manually but was struck on the left shoulder and upper arm by falling cartons of automotive trim components (total weight approximately 22 kg). The impact caused immediate pain and limited mobility. Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, who was conducting inventory verification nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately provided first aid and called for emergency response. Amani was examined by on-site medical staff and diagnosed with a grade 2 shoulder strain and contusion. The employee was treated with ice application, compression bandaging, and released for light-duty work with restrictions on lifting above shoulder height for 10 days. The incident was classified as a non-lost-time injury but was formally documented and reported to the JHSC.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45 during day shift operations, Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a Production Operator at the Regrind and Recycling Department, was operating the material hopper feeder when she noticed unusual vibration and grinding sounds from the regrind machine. She immediately suspected a foreign object had entered the system. Before shutting down the equipment, Naomi attempted to peer into the hopper opening to investigate. As she leaned over, a fragment of metal suddenly ejected from the hopper at high velocity, missing her face by approximately 15 centimeters and striking the overhead lighting fixture. The metal fragment was later identified as a broken tool bit left accidentally during maintenance two days prior. Naomi quickly reported the incident to her supervisor Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who secured the machine and notified Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) from EHS. A thorough equipment inspection revealed no additional foreign materials. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the projectile did not make contact with the employee, though consequences could have been severe.

On December 3, 2024, at 09:30 during day shift, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator in the Packaging and Labeling Station, sustained a minor chemical splash injury while transferring containers of cleaning solvent between work areas. Elena was carrying a 2-liter container of isopropyl alcohol without a secure cap when she negotiated a tight turn between storage racks. The container tilted, and approximately 200 milliliters of solvent splashed onto her right forearm and wrist. The liquid caused immediate skin irritation and mild stinging. Following established procedures, Elena immediately moved to the emergency eyewash/body wash station and rinsed the affected area for five minutes with lukewarm water. She then reported to the on-site first aid station where Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), Packaging Supervisor, applied a sterile gauze pad with antibiotic ointment and observed for any delayed reactions. Elena experienced no systemic symptoms and only mild localized redness. Incident was documented as a first-aid case. No lost work time was required as Elena returned to light duties after 30 minutes.

On December 10, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, sustained a significant thermal burn injury in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Pascal was removing heat-treated composite parts from a high-temperature curing oven operating at 165°C. Despite wearing standard cotton work gloves, he made contact with a metal oven rack edge while reaching for a part positioned at the back of the chamber. The glove provided insufficient insulation, and Pascal received a second-degree burn across the dorsal surface of his right hand, spanning approximately 12 square centimeters. The intense pain caused Pascal to withdraw immediately. He was assisted by nearby technician Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), who applied cool running water to the burned area for eight minutes and then applied a sterile non-stick dressing. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, was notified and determined hospital evaluation was necessary due to burn severity. Pascal was transported to Laval Hospital where physicians confirmed partial-thickness second-degree burns and prescribed antimicrobial ointment with follow-up wound care. The employee was placed on modified duty for one week and lost approximately 16 hours of work during recovery.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine Line B in the Main Production Building when a sudden unexpected machine startup occurred. Marcel had disabled the main power switch but had not engaged the full lockout/tagout procedures due to time pressure from production schedules. A colleague, Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), who was working the evening shift setup nearby, inadvertently activated the machine's emergency restart button while moving materials. The machine's heating element and mold clamping mechanism engaged suddenly, catching Marcel's left hand in the mold closing zone. He sustained a crush injury to his left hand with fractures to the metacarpal bones and severe tissue damage. First aid was administered on-site by Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039), and Marcel was transported to Laval Hospital via ambulance. The incident was immediately reported to the JHSC and HSE department.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Assembly Operator Soraya Alami (EMP-00196) was performing repetitive component assembly work at Station C in the Main Production Building, attaching small plastic connectors to medical device housings. She had been working continuously for 6.5 hours without a break. Around hour 7, she began experiencing sharp pain in her wrists and numbness in her fingers. The medical device assembly line operates at high speed with minimal variation in hand and wrist motions. Soraya did not report her symptoms immediately, attempting to continue working through the discomfort for another 45 minutes. Eventually, the pain became severe enough that she notified her supervisor, Ana Silva (EMP-00040), who was working at the adjacent assembly station. Ana immediately reported the incident to the HSE department. Occupational Health assessment confirmed early-stage carpal tunnel syndrome with nerve compression in both wrists. Soraya was placed on modified duty and referred to occupational therapy. The incident revealed a systemic issue with inadequate work rotation and break schedules on the assembly line.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 4:20 AM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) discovered a significant chemical spill in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (Building 5) during his routine facility inspection rounds. A 55-gallon drum of polyester resin had developed a crack in its bottom seam, likely from temperature cycling and material stress, causing approximately 40 gallons of resin to leak onto the concrete floor over a 6-hour period. The spilled resin created a 400-square-foot contamination area and had seeped approximately 18 inches into the facility's drainage system, threatening to enter the municipal stormwater system and the nearby Saint-Lawrence tributary. The spill was not immediately detected because the area had no continuous monitoring and the night shift had reduced staffing. Upon discovery, Alain immediately halted all activities in the adjacent areas and contacted Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) from the Electrical Maintenance Lead position, who triggered the facility emergency response protocol and notified the HSE director Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069). Environmental containment teams were mobilized, absorbent materials were deployed, and the affected stormwater drain was isolated with temporary plugs. The spill was documented as a reportable environmental incident under Quebec environmental protection regulations (LOI sur la qualité de l'environnement). A environmental consultant was contracted for soil and groundwater assessment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) was working at Injection Molding Station 7 in the Main Production Building when she experienced a minor laceration to her left index finger. While removing a finished component from the mold cavity, the mold gate—a sharp plastic protrusion—caught her finger as she withdrew her hand. The injury resulted in a 2cm laceration with minimal bleeding. Zainab immediately reported the incident to her supervisor and proceeded to the first aid station where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) cleaned and dressed the wound with antibiotic ointment and a sterile bandage. No sutures were required. Packaging operator Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066) witnessed the incident while working at the adjacent station. The root cause was identified as inadequate hand positioning technique due to fatigue and the operator's unfamiliarity with this particular mold design. Zainab returned to modified duties after 30 minutes and full duties the following day. The incident was documented and reported to the HSE Office.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. Material handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was preparing a batch of mold release agent when she inadvertently spilled approximately 2 liters of solvent concentrate onto the floor near an active electrical outlet and portable work light. The solvent fumes accumulated rapidly in the inadequately ventilated space. Within minutes, a static discharge from the work light ignited the vapors, creating a flash fire that spread across the work surface and ignited stored containers of acetone and isopropanol on nearby shelves. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was conducting preventive maintenance in the adjacent maintenance workshop when he heard the explosion and immediately activated the facility fire alarm and emergency response procedures. He used two Type ABC fire extinguishers to contain the flames while evacuation was underway. The facility evacuation was completed in 8 minutes. Emergency response personnel arrived and secured the area. The fire was fully extinguished within 35 minutes. Damage included loss of approximately 40 liters of chemical inventory, damage to storage racks, and minor smoke damage to adjacent areas. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed critical deficiencies in chemical storage protocols and ventilation adequacy.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 5:30 AM during the night shift, quality inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026) sustained a minor contusion and superficial abrasion to her right knee while performing pre-production quality checks in the Composite Materials Processing Area. While walking between inspection stations, Catherine tripped over a coiled electrical extension cord that had been left on the walkway behind station C-4. She fell forward onto the concrete floor, catching herself with her hands but striking her right knee against the edge of a plastic pallet. The fall resulted in swelling, minor bleeding from the knee area, and visible abrasion. Shipping clerk Julien Racine (EMP-00177), who was conducting an early inventory count in the adjacent area, heard the fall and immediately assisted Catherine to the first aid station. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) evaluated the injury, cleaned the wound, applied antibiotic ointment, and provided ice therapy for 15 minutes. X-rays were not required as there was no indication of fracture. Catherine was able to return to full duties after 2 hours of rest. The root cause was attributed to inadequate housekeeping practices and improper equipment storage in the production area. The night shift supervisor was notified and the extension cord was properly secured.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:47 PM during the day shift, a chemical storage cabinet in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT not specified in incident but area involved) experienced a pressurized solvent leak. Elena Popescu, the Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring polyester resin from a 55-gallon drum into the automated mixing system when the pressure relief valve on an adjacent storage container malfunctioned. The resulting spray of flammable solvent (methylethylketone) created a visible mist in the work area, triggering the facility's automated fire detection system. The fire alarm was activated at 2:48 PM, and all personnel were evacuated per emergency procedures. No fire occurred, but the incident exposed a critical gap in equipment maintenance scheduling. The spilled solvent (approximately 2 liters) was immediately contained by absorbent material, and the area was ventilated. Investigation revealed the pressure relief valve had not been inspected in 18 months, exceeding the manufacturer's 12-month maintenance interval. Jamal Thompson, Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, arrived on scene and confirmed no airborne hazard remained after 10 minutes of ventilation. The incident was declared at 3:15 PM by Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, after all-clear was confirmed.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Giovanni Bianchi, CNC Operator, was programming a CNC milling machine for a new composite materials batch in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. While setting up fixture tolerances, Giovanni reached toward a rotating spindle to manually adjust a guide pin. His gloved finger made contact with the spinning tool at approximately 1,200 RPM, causing the glove to begin pulling toward the rotating mechanism. Giovanni immediately withdrew his hand and activated the emergency stop button within 1.5 seconds. His coworker, Léa Parent (Quality Control Technician), witnessed the near-miss from approximately 8 feet away and immediately alerted supervision. Medical examination by the facility nurse revealed minor abrasion to the index finger with no tissue damage. The spindle contact was momentary due to Giovanni's quick reaction. Investigation identified that the machine's safety interlock, designed to pause rotation during manual adjustments, had been manually overridden by a previous operator to improve cycle time on the prior shift. No documentation existed for this override, and it was not communicated to the incoming shift. The incident was declared at 10:45 PM by Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer, as a near-miss with significant injury potential.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:22 AM during the night shift, Marcel Duchesne, Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was removing finished automotive components from the ejection area of an injection molding machine when his right hand came into contact with the mold cavity. The mold had cooled to approximately 80°C, but residual heat and a sharp edge on a partially formed component caused a laceration across his palm and two fingers. The cut measured approximately 4 cm in length with moderate bleeding. Marcel immediately withdrew his hand and applied pressure with a work towel. His coworker, Fernand Comeau (Regrind Operator), was nearby and immediately radioed for first aid assistance. The facility nurse treated the wound with antiseptic, applied sterile bandaging, and determined that stitches were not required, though the cut was deep enough to warrant medical monitoring for infection risk. The incident occurred during a production run of medical-device components for a high-volume order. Investigation revealed that Marcel was attempting to manually remove a component that had partially adhered to the mold due to inadequate cooling time in the previous cycle. The machine's semi-automatic ejection system had malfunctioned, and instead of following lockout procedures to address the mechanical failure, Marcel improvised a manual removal method. He was not wearing cut-resistant gloves rated for this application. The incident was declared at 6:48 AM by Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, who responded to the night shift incident report.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Ana Silva (EMP-00040), an Assembly Operator, was working at Station 4 in the Injection Molding Line C when she experienced a minor skin irritation incident. While removing freshly molded medical device components from the injection mold, Ana's left forearm came into contact with dried mold release agent residue on the mold surface. The contact caused localized redness and mild burning sensation on approximately 3 square inches of skin on her inner forearm. Ana immediately reported the incident to her supervisor Claudine Desjardins and proceeded to the first aid station where the affected area was washed with soap and water for 5 minutes. A light moisturizing cream was applied, and the redness subsided within 30 minutes. No further medical intervention was required. The incident was attributed to incomplete cleaning of the mold surface following the previous production run and inadequate PPE compliance—Ana was not wearing the recommended nitrile arm guards that day.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), the Crane Operator, was positioning a loaded pallet of finished medical device components on the upper shelf of the high-bay storage rack (approximately 18 feet high). As Raymond carefully lowered the pallet, a loose banding strap on an adjacent pallet on the shelf above began to unravel. The banding strap became caught on the load hook of Raymond's crane, creating mechanical tension. Within seconds, the neighboring pallet shifted forward on its shelf, and approximately 40 pounds of finished components slid toward the edge. Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler positioned below to receive inventory, immediately noticed the movement and shouted a warning. Raymond immediately halted crane operations and stepped back from the area. The shifting pallet stabilized without falling, and no components were lost or damaged. A visual inspection revealed that had the pallet fallen, it would have struck the workstation below where Salma was standing, potentially causing serious injury.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician, was performing scheduled preventive maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. While attempting to access the cooling water circulation system, Alain noticed a small but steady drip of water from a connection point on the main coolant supply line. He immediately investigated and discovered that the compression fitting on the cooling water inlet line had begun to loosen, likely due to thermal cycling stress over the previous 72 operating hours. Before attempting any corrective action, Alain followed lockout/tagout procedures and isolated the machine from electrical power. However, he did not drain the system before attempting to re-tighten the fitting. As he loosened the fitting slightly to re-thread and tighten it, a jet of pressurized cooling water (approximately 45 PSI at 85°F) sprayed directly onto his chest and upper torso, soaking his work uniform. The water stream lasted approximately 2 seconds before Alain managed to reposit the fitting and stem the flow. Alain immediately stepped back and assessed himself for injury. Although shocked by the unexpected spray, he experienced no burns, eye injuries, or other apparent damage. Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), an Instrumentation Technician nearby, heard Alain's exclamation and came to assist. Together they properly depressurized the system using the bleed valve before completing the repair. No equipment damage occurred, and no production downtime resulted beyond the 15-minute maintenance window.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was organizing resin bags in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility when he noticed an unusual hissing sound coming from a polyester resin storage tank. Upon closer inspection, Kwesi detected a small pinhole leak in the tank's lower section, approximately 1.5 meters from the ground. The leak was releasing resin vapor into the enclosed storage area. Kwesi immediately notified his supervisor and evacuated the immediate area, closing the storage room door behind him. The facility's ventilation system was still operational, preventing significant vapor accumulation. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was called to the scene and confirmed the leak, implementing containment procedures by placing absorbent materials beneath the leak and reducing storage room access. The tank was isolated within 45 minutes using the facility's emergency shut-off procedures. No employees were exposed to harmful concentrations of fumes, and the incident was contained before escalating. The root cause was determined to be a manufacturing defect in the tank's weld seam.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was performing routine part removal and stacking from Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging unit. Abdul had been on the line for 6 hours without a significant break, performing repetitive grasping, twisting, and lifting motions to extract molded parts from the machine's discharge area and place them onto collection pallets. At approximately 10:50 PM, Abdul experienced acute sharp pain in his right wrist and forearm. He immediately reported the pain to his line supervisor, Wei Liu (EMP-00088). Wei assessed the situation and noted visible swelling in Abdul's wrist. Abdul was taken to the on-site first aid station where the injury was evaluated. Clinical assessment indicated acute inflammation consistent with repetitive strain injury, possibly early-stage carpal tunnel syndrome aggravated by the intense, uninterrupted repetitive activity. Abdul was unable to continue work and was sent to an external medical facility for further evaluation via X-ray and neurological testing. Medical professionals confirmed acute wrist strain with inflammation but no fracture. Abdul required 3 days of medical leave and ongoing physiotherapy.

On March 21, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was performing maintenance and material transfer operations in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Oscar was repositioning a 200-liter resin waste container near the regrind hopper when the container's drain valve was inadvertently opened, releasing approximately 80 liters of partially degraded polyester resin and mixed plastic waste directly onto the concrete floor. The spilled material mixed with residual moisture on the floor, creating a viscous, difficult-to-contain slurry that began spreading toward a floor drain connected to the facility's stormwater system. Oscar immediately shut the valve and attempted to contain the spill using available absorbent materials, but the quantity exceeded standard spill kit capacity. At 1:45 AM, Oscar notified the night shift supervisor and the on-call Environmental Compliance Specialist. Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was called to the facility and arrived at 2:15 AM. The spill had partially drained into the stormwater system before containment berms could be erected. Nathalie initiated the facility's environmental incident protocol, notifying CNESST and local environmental authorities as required. Recovery and remediation took approximately 8 hours, requiring specialized waste removal contractors and environmental testing of the affected drainage system.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, production operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was performing routine setup on Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components) in the clean room area when she noticed the mold cavity temperature sensor reading fluctuating between normal and elevated levels. Before consulting with her supervisor, she decided to manually adjust the hydraulic pressure valve on the mold assembly while the machine was running at low speed. As she reached toward the valve with an adjustable wrench, the mold suddenly cycled and partially closed, trapping her left hand between the mold plate and the fixed guide rail. She immediately withdrew her hand and experienced sharp pain in her fingers. A nearby quality control technician, Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013), heard her cry out and rushed over. Sophie administered first aid and alerted EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003). Upon inspection, Sana had sustained abrasions and minor contusions on her left hand and wrist, but no fractures or lacerations. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the mold closure did not result in significant tissue damage, though it easily could have caused a crush injury. Root cause analysis revealed that the employee had bypassed the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure and did not wait for supervisor authorization before attempting maintenance.

On April 2, 2024 at 10:15 AM, packaging operator Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) during the day shift. While transferring finished composite material components from a heated curing rack to foam packaging containers, she accidentally made contact with a component that had cooled to approximately 65°C (still above safe handling temperature). The component's edge brushed against her left forearm, causing a minor thermal burn approximately 3 cm in diameter with slight blistering and redness. Lucia immediately submerged her arm in cool water from the station's safety eyewash station for approximately 5 minutes. Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) observed the incident and immediately notified EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003). Samira applied first aid treatment including antibiotic ointment and a sterile gauze bandage. Lucia was directed to monitor the burn for infection and was given clear instructions to report any worsening. She remained at work and continued her duties with the burn covered. No hospitalization was required, and the incident was documented as first aid treatment only. The root cause was insufficient cooling time verification before component handling.

On March 28, 2024 at 11:50 PM during the night shift, warehouse lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) was organizing raw material storage in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) when he picked up a 40 kg box of polypropylene resin pellets from a lower shelf. While lifting the box to place it on a higher shelf, he felt a sharp strain in his lower back and experienced immediate pain. Michel set the box down carefully and notified Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) by radio. Karine arrived within 10 minutes and assessed Michel's condition. Michel reported localized lower back pain rated at 5/10 severity with some muscle stiffness but no radiating pain or loss of sensation. Karine applied first aid including application of an ice pack from the facility's first aid kit, rest positioning, and over-the-counter ibuprofen from the medical supply cabinet. Michel remained on light duty for the remainder of the shift, assisting with administrative tasks. He was advised to monitor his condition and seek medical attention if pain worsened. The incident was classified as first aid treatment for a minor back strain. Root cause analysis identified that Michel had not used proper lifting technique—bending at the waist rather than the knees—and no mechanical lifting assistance was available at the storage location.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin was operating Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building when he sustained a burn injury to his right forearm. Gosselin was removing a finished part from the mold when contact was made with the heated mold cavity, which operates at approximately 95°C. The employee was wearing standard production gloves, but the contact duration was sufficient to cause a first-degree burn with minor blistering across a 4 cm area on the inner forearm. The incident occurred during peak production of consumer packaging components. Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye witnessed the event and immediately assisted Gosselin to the first-aid station. Gosselin's supervisor applied cold water treatment for 15 minutes followed by topical burn cream and sterile bandaging. The employee remained on duty but was monitored for the remainder of the shift. No hospitalization was required. Root cause analysis indicated that the mold temperature had drifted 5°C higher than programmed setpoint due to a calibration drift in the temperature controller.

On April 8, 2024 at 10:47 AM, Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran sustained a serious crush injury while working in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Tran was manually transferring heat-treated plastic composite parts from the curing oven to a cooling rack when the automated mold closing mechanism on adjacent equipment malfunctioned. The safety interlock failed to prevent mold closure, and Tran's left hand became trapped between the closing mold plates while reaching across to position a part. The crush resulted in fractures to the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th metacarpals and contusions across the dorsal hand surface. Assembly Operator Ana Silva heard Tran's cry and immediately activated the emergency stop button, releasing the mold within 8 seconds. First responders (Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand) applied ice and compression while calling emergency services. Tran was transported via ambulance to Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal at 11:15 AM and admitted for orthopedic surgery. Lost time from work: 42 days. Root cause: safety interlock mechanism had not been inspected or tested for 18 months; preventive maintenance log showed scheduled inspection was missed in October 2023.

On May 3, 2024 at 1:32 PM, an uncontrolled chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room during resin batch preparation. Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye was adding polyester resin from a 50-liter bulk container to the automated mixing tank when the pressure relief valve on the container failed catastrophically. Approximately 15-18 liters of polyester resin spilled directly onto the concrete floor, with additional liquid aerosolizing into the immediate work area. The spill spread across approximately 12 square meters of floor space, entering the facility's storm drain system through floor drains.
