Ndiaye was exposed to significant quantities of resin vapor and particulate, experiencing acute eye irritation and minor respiratory irritation. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi was notified immediately and activated containment procedures. Rachidi directed Ndiaye to the emergency eyewash station and ensured ventilation fans were maximized. Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand arrived within 5 minutes with spill containment materials and absorbent granules. The spill was contained to prevent further environmental migration. Environmental Ministry was notified per Quebec environmental regulations. Estimated spill volume reaching watershed: 3-4 liters. Root cause: pressure relief valve was original equipment installed in 1998 and had never been replaced or serviced during the facility's operational history.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (Building 5). Samantha Brown, Composite Materials Lead, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin from storage to the mixing station using a hand truck. While navigating through the narrow aisle between storage racks, the drum shifted and fell to the floor, rupturing the drum's seam. Approximately 40 gallons of epoxy resin spilled across the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard and releasing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the air. The spill reached within 6 feet of the emergency eyewash station. Immediate response included evacuation of the area, activation of the facility's HVAC emergency ventilation system, and containment using absorbent materials. Hassan Diallo, Material Handler, assisted with the initial containment while Luc Girard, Maintenance Technician, responded to ensure proper cleanup protocols were followed. No personnel were directly exposed to significant quantities of resin, but the incident highlighted deficiencies in spill containment procedures and secondary containment infrastructure.

On November 22, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Raj Patel, Process Engineer, conducted a comprehensive ergonomic assessment at Injection Molding Line D (Consumer Packaging production) as part of TechnoPlast's preventive health monitoring program. During his observation of packaging operators Amara Diop and Lucia Martinez, he identified several ergonomic concerns: awkward wrist positioning during part removal, inadequate workstation heights causing forward trunk flexion, and repetitive reach patterns extending beyond recommended distances. He observed both operators exhibiting signs of cumulative strain fatigue. No acute injury had occurred, but Patel documented the risks using video analysis and postural assessment tools, noting that both employees had filed ergonomic complaints in the past 6 months. This preventive declaration was submitted to Marie-Claude Beaumont, Director of HSE, to implement proactive controls before serious musculoskeletal injuries developed. The observation revealed that current workstation design had not been updated since 2018 and did not account for the newer, faster injection cycles introduced in 2023.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 6:45 PM during the evening shift, a critical equipment failure occurred at Injection Molding Line A (Automotive Components). Conrad Therrien, Injection Molding Operator - Line A, was running a production cycle for automotive dashboard trim when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the 150-ton injection press began leaking pressurized hydraulic fluid at an accelerating rate. Within 15 minutes, pressure in the system dropped from 2,500 PSI to 890 PSI, causing incomplete part injection and automatic machine shutdown. The leaking hydraulic fluid sprayed approximately 12 gallons across the machine base and surrounding floor area before the operator successfully triggered the emergency stop. Luc Girard, Maintenance Technician, and Claude Rioux, Electrical Maintenance Lead, responded to isolate the hydraulic system and prevent further fluid loss. Investigation revealed that the relief valve had not been replaced since the machine's installation in 2008—16 years of operation beyond the manufacturer's recommended 10-year replacement interval. The failure caused production downtime of 7.5 hours, resulting in approximately $18,000 in lost production capacity and requiring emergency valve replacement.

On January 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine operator Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B when he noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge reading was fluctuating abnormally. While inspecting the hydraulic line connections near the mold clamping mechanism, a small pinhole leak in a high-pressure hose began spraying hydraulic fluid. Zaidi attempted to tighten the connection with his bare hand to stop the leak. The pressurized hydraulic fluid penetrated the skin of his palm, causing a deep puncture wound approximately 3mm in diameter. He immediately felt sharp pain and noticed discoloration around the injection site. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier responded within 5 minutes and called emergency services. Zaidi was transported to Laval Hospital where imaging confirmed the hydraulic fluid had penetrated subcutaneous tissue. He required surgical exploration and antibiotics due to the risk of infection from hydraulic fluid injection injuries. The incident was caused by inadequate inspection protocols and lack of awareness regarding the dangers of pressurized hydraulic systems. No lockout/tagout procedure had been initiated before maintenance began.

On January 22, 2025, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was organizing raw material pallets in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) when she attempted to retrieve a pallet of polycarbonate resin from the upper storage rack. The pallet was positioned approximately 8 feet high on a cantilever rack system. As Saleh pulled the pallet forward using improper technique—leaning too far forward with poor footwork—the entire pallet shifted unexpectedly. She quickly repositioned her feet and stepped backward, maintaining her balance. However, approximately 40 kilograms of resin material from the pallet edge spilled onto the floor near her left foot, missing contact by approximately 15 centimeters. A nearby forklift operator, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), witnessed the incident and immediately assisted in securing the remaining material. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi was notified and conducted an initial assessment. No injury occurred, but the incident demonstrated critical gaps in material handling procedures and racking system maintenance. The pallet retention system had not been inspected in over 18 months, and operators had not received current load capacity training.

On January 28, 2025, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was setting up a new composite materials processing operation in the Composite Materials Processing Area when he encountered a malfunctioning pneumatic pressure regulator on the compressed air line. The regulator was stuck in a partially open position, causing erratic air pressure fluctuations throughout the system. To quickly address the issue before production start time, Sokolov decided to use an air line blow-down gun to manually clear the regulator obstruction. He directed the compressed air jet directly at the regulator housing from approximately 8 inches away without proper PPE—specifically missing safety glasses and a face shield. A small piece of corroded regulator housing material became dislodged and struck Sokolov's right cheekbone with significant force, creating a laceration approximately 2 centimeters long that required 6 stitches. He immediately reported the injury to Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid, who provided first aid and arranged follow-up care at a local clinic. Investigation revealed that no formal compressed air safety procedures existed, operators received minimal training on air system hazards, and PPE requirements for pneumatic equipment work were not established. The regulator had not been replaced in 5 years despite manufacturer recommendations for replacement every 3 years.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Omar Said (EMP-00122), a Production Operator on the day shift, was performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Line C when he noticed excessive vibration and unusual noise from the machine's hydraulic system. Rather than immediately stopping the equipment and following lockout/tagout procedures, Omar attempted to inspect the source of the noise while the machine was still energized. His sleeve became caught in the rotating coupling of the hydraulic pump, causing a minor laceration to his forearm and significant bruising. The incident was witnessed by Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117) who immediately shut down the machine and alerted supervisors. First aid was administered on-site, and Omar was treated for the laceration and contusion. Investigation revealed that Omar had not completed the most recent LOTO certification refresh and was unaware of recent updates to lockout procedures. The machine coupling lacked proper machine guarding as specified in the equipment manual.

On April 8, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Materials Management area when a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent (petroleum-based solvent) was being transferred from storage to a mixing station. David O'Connor (EMP-00010), the Warehouse Supervisor, was overseeing the transfer when a forklift operated by Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) struck the drum with its load arm, rupturing the drum's side seam. Approximately 30 gallons of the solvent spilled across the warehouse floor, creating a slick hazardous surface. The vapors from the evaporating solvent triggered the facility's VOC monitoring system alarm. Immediate response included shutting down HVAC circulation to affected areas, activating the emergency response kit, and deploying absorbent materials. The spill was contained within secondary containment trays, but approximately 5 gallons reached the floor drain system before complete containment. Environmental response activated, and Quebec CNESST was notified per regulatory requirements. The drum was inadequately secured in the storage rack, and the forklift operator was unfamiliar with the revised warehouse layout implemented two weeks prior.

On February 22, 2024 at 6:20 AM during the night shift, Jade Wong (EMP-00140), a Process Technician, was removing finished composite parts from an industrial oven when she experienced a severe burn to her left forearm. The incident occurred when she misjudged the distance to the oven door while reaching in to retrieve a batch of carbon-fiber reinforced plastic components. Her forearm contacted the interior oven surface which was operating at 180°C. Jade immediately withdrew her arm and ran to the first aid station. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) administered emergency first aid, applying cool running water to the burn for 20 minutes and applying a sterile burn dressing. The burn was classified as a second-degree burn measuring approximately 8 centimeters in length. Medical assessment was arranged, and Jade was transported to the local clinic for professional evaluation and treatment. She remained on modified duty for one week and required topical antibiotic treatment. The oven lacked proper heat guards on the door area, and Jade had been working on the night shift for only three weeks with minimal hands-on experience with this particular oven model.

On March 14, 2024 at 10:45 AM, Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was preparing Injection Molding Line A for a production run of automotive connectors when he observed that the hydraulic pressure gauge on the machine was fluctuating erratically between 800 and 1200 PSI. Rather than immediately stopping operations, Yusuf attempted to manually adjust the pressure relief valve while the machine was energized. Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175) was nearby conducting a quality audit and witnessed Yusuf working on the pressurized system. Surprenant immediately instructed Yusuf to cease work and called Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) to inspect the machine. Upon inspection, Lafleur discovered that the hydraulic line connection was partially corroded and beginning to weep fluid, creating a potential spray hazard. The machine was immediately locked out and tagged. No injury occurred, but the hazardous condition posed significant risk for hydraulic fluid injection injury or skin contact exposure. The machine remained out of service for inspection and repair.

On March 19, 2024 at 2:15 PM during the evening shift, Assembly Operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) was manually loading finished polycarbonate medical device components into cardboard shipping boxes on a workbench in Post-Processing and Heat Treatment. The production floor had received a fresh coating of anti-slip finish approximately 30 minutes prior as part of routine maintenance. Fernandez stepped backward to reach for another stack of components and his left foot caught on a wet edge where the new coating had not fully cured, causing him to slip. He attempted to stabilize himself by grabbing the edge of the workbench but lost his balance and fell onto his right knee on the concrete floor. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) immediately assisted Fernandez and called for Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) to document the incident. Fernandez experienced immediate sharp pain and swelling in the knee but was able to stand with assistance. He was transported to the on-site first aid station where initial treatment was administered. The incident was narrowly avoided becoming a more serious injury due to the proximity of heavy molding equipment in the work area.

On March 22, 2024 at 6:40 PM during the evening shift, Composite Materials Operator Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086) was transferring cured composite material samples from a heat treatment oven to a cooling rack in Post-Processing and Heat Treatment. The samples, made of fiberglass-reinforced polyester resin, were still at approximately 110°C when removed from the oven. Abdallah was wearing standard nitrile gloves but had not applied mold release agent protective cream to her forearms as required by protocol. While placing the fourth sample onto the cooling rack, her left forearm made direct contact with the hot material surface for approximately 2 seconds before she pulled away. The contact resulted in a thermal burn covering an area approximately 8 centimeters by 6 centimeters on her inner forearm with partial-thickness involvement. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) immediately activated emergency first aid procedures, applying cool running water to the burn site for 15 minutes and applying sterile non-adherent dressing. Abdallah was transported to the emergency department of Hôpital Cité de la Santé where she received additional treatment including topical antibiotic application and tetanus prophylaxis. She was released after 4 hours of observation but was placed on restricted duty for 10 days pending wound healing assessment.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Operator Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174) was monitoring a fiber-reinforced polymer (FRP) curing oven when the heating element control circuit failed, causing an uncontrolled temperature spike to 380°C. The thermal expansion caused internal pressure to build rapidly. At 2:17 PM, a weld seam on the oven's right side ruptured, releasing superheated resin vapor and fragmenting the outer steel panel. Fragments struck nearby molding equipment valued at approximately $185,000, causing severe denting, electrical damage, and structural compromise to the injection unit frame. The oven's control panel was destroyed entirely. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) immediately activated emergency shutdown protocols and evacuated the area. Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) discovered the failed thermal regulator was 18 months past recommended replacement interval. No personnel were injured, but equipment damage halted composite production for 72 hours, resulting in significant customer order delays.

On March 19, 2024 at 10:42 PM during evening shift operations, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-005) at TechnoPlast Industries. Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) was conducting routine inventory when she discovered a 5-gallon container of polyol resin had developed a slow leak due to a defective cap seal. Approximately 2 liters of resin had pooled on the concrete floor near an electrical junction box. The resin, being flammable with a flash point of 95°C, began vaporizing when ambient temperature in the storage area elevated to 48°C due to a malfunctioning HVAC cooling unit. The accumulating vapors reached the spark ignition source when an overhead fluorescent light fixture experienced an electrical arcing event at 10:41 PM. Flames erupted from the chemical spill, immediately triggering the integrated fire detection system and initiating facility-wide fire alarms at 10:42 PM. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) coordinated immediate evacuation protocols. The facility's automated suppression system activated, extinguishing the fire within 90 seconds using dry chemical foam. The incident caused no injuries but resulted in facility evacuation for 4 hours and contamination of approximately 300 square feet of floor space.

On March 22, 2024 at 6:55 AM during night shift operations in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012), Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) suffered a significant workplace injury while performing routine mold maintenance on an injection molding press. Gravel was attempting to manually release hydraulic pressure from a clamping mechanism before beginning disassembly work. He had confirmed the machine's emergency stop was activated and believed pressure had been released through the manual valve. However, due to a malfunctioning pressure gauge that showed zero when residual pressure of 380 PSI remained, Gravel did not verify pressure release using alternative methods. When he removed the access panel, pressurized hydraulic fluid forcefully ejected, striking his left forearm and face. The high-pressure jet caused severe laceration to his left arm requiring 47 stitches, contusion to his left eye socket with temporary vision loss, and chemical burns from the hydraulic fluid. Gravel was transported by ambulance to Hospital Jean-Talon at 7:02 AM. The incident resulted in 28 days of lost work time as Gravel recovered from his injuries. Tool and Die Maker Mario Bélisle (EMP-00149) witnessed the incident and immediately initiated emergency response procedures.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a significant burn injury while performing routine part extraction from a 250-ton injection molding machine. The machine had completed its cooling cycle, and Bertrand attempted to remove a batch of automotive door handle components from the mold without allowing sufficient post-cycle cooling time. As he reached into the mold cavity with his bare right hand, he made contact with residual molten plastic material at approximately 180°C that had not fully solidified. The burn resulted in second-degree thermal injuries covering approximately 8% of his right palm and inner forearm. Bertrand immediately removed his hand and submerged it in a nearby water station. His coworker, Production Operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), witnessed the incident and immediately notified Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057). Medical first aid was administered on-site, followed by transport to Laval Hospital for advanced burn treatment. The incident was caused by insufficient machine cycle time documentation and inadequate operator awareness of residual heat hazards. Machine Line D was shut down for the remainder of the shift pending investigation.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift, Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) sustained a minor laceration requiring first aid treatment while working in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Unit 018). Amani was manually transferring rejected plastic components from a quality control bin onto wooden pallets for material reprocessing. While handling a batch of rejected automotive trim pieces with sharp molded edges, a small fragment from a door trim component caught the skin between Amani's left thumb and index finger, causing a superficial laceration approximately 2 cm in length with minor bleeding. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), conducting a routine inspection in the department, observed the incident immediately. Nathalie administered on-site first aid including wound cleaning, disinfection with antiseptic solution, and application of sterile adhesive bandage dressing. The wound was minor and did not require external medical attention or off-work time. Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) witnessed the incident and helped document the event. Root cause analysis identified inadequate edge finishing on rejected parts and lack of protective gloves for manual sorting operations. No machine downtime resulted from this incident.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during night shift operations, the primary ventilation system serving the Central Maintenance Workshop (Unit 012) experienced a catastrophic failure. Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) discovered that the main exhaust fan bearing had seized, resulting in complete loss of airflow through the chemical storage and equipment cleaning areas. The failure occurred during a routine maintenance window when three technicians were inside the workshop preparing equipment for the following day's production line modifications. Without adequate ventilation, airborne fumes from solvent containers left open for equipment cleaning began accumulating to hazardous levels. The workers began experiencing headaches and eye irritation within 20 minutes of the failure. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) was contacted via emergency call and immediately ordered evacuation of the workshop and activation of the facility's backup outdoor air system. All three technicians were evacuated to fresh air and monitored for symptoms. The facility's environmental monitoring equipment registered solvent vapor concentrations at 85% of the IDLH (Immediately Dangerous to Life and Health) threshold. Emergency Services were notified and attended the scene to verify air quality restoration. Root cause investigation revealed that the bearing maintenance interval had been extended beyond manufacturer specifications due to budget constraints, and no predictive maintenance monitoring was in place to detect early bearing degradation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a 500-ton injection molding machine (Machine #28) experienced a catastrophic hydraulic system failure in the Production Operations area. Operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was performing routine material loading when high-pressure hydraulic fluid sprayed across the machine's control panel and onto adjacent workstations. The fluid ignited due to contact with hot mold surfaces, creating a small fire that spread to stored plastic pellets nearby. Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the nearest fire suppression system, successfully containing the blaze within 90 seconds. The machine's hydraulic pump seal had deteriorated due to inadequate maintenance scheduling, and no preventive inspections had been performed in 14 months. The incident resulted in approximately $87,000 in equipment damage, destroyed approximately 450 kg of raw materials, and damaged the workstation area. No employee injuries were sustained, but the machine was taken offline for emergency repairs lasting 72 hours.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift, Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) discovered an unauthorized chemical spill in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While conducting routine end-of-shift inventory, she noticed approximately 40 liters of uncapped polycarbonate resin (epoxy-based, containing bisphenol A and hardening agents) had leaked from a damaged 200-liter intermediate bulk container (IBC) onto the concrete floor. The spill had occurred approximately 2-3 hours earlier but was not reported by any staff member. Investigation revealed that Regrind Operator Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034) had carelessly stacked a small metal rack against the IBC during material reorganization around 8:00 PM, damaging the container's side valve. The chemical had seeped under wall panels into the adjacent administrative building foundation area, approximately 8 linear meters of contamination. Environmental containment protocols were immediately activated: absorbent materials (75 kg) were deployed, the spill was isolated with temporary barriers, and the facility's environmental contractor was notified for remediation. Initial assessment indicated no groundwater contamination, but soil testing was required. Cleanup and remediation costs reached $23,500. No employees experienced direct chemical exposure due to evening shift's reduced occupancy.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during day shift, Packaging Operator Nour Jaber (EMP-00188) sustained a first-aid treatable thermal burn while working in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019). While removing finished composite parts from the automatic cooling conveyor belt, Nour inadvertently contacted a section of the conveyor belt that had recently processed high-temperature components (approximately 65-70°C). The burn covered approximately 8 cm² on the inside of his right wrist, causing immediate pain and visible redness with minor blistering. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) responded immediately, applying running cool water for 10 minutes, then applying sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment from the first-aid station. Nour was able to continue working with a protective bandage after 15 minutes of treatment. Root cause analysis identified that the conveyor belt section lacked proper thermal insulation shielding, and operators were not wearing the required heat-resistant arm sleeves. Nour had been working the station for only 3 weeks and had not received complete heat hazard awareness training. No hospitalization was required, and the wound was monitored over two subsequent days with daily first-aid station visits.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, production operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was working the day shift on Injection Molding Line A when she experienced acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath while standing at the molding station. She had been performing repetitive manual tasks loading plastic resin into the hopper and monitoring part quality for approximately 6 hours without a break. A colleague, quality inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026), immediately notified shift supervisor who called emergency services. Leila was transported to Laval Hospital where she was diagnosed with acute anxiety and stress-induced chest pain following assessment. Medical evaluation revealed elevated stress markers and fatigue-related symptoms. She remained hospitalized for 8 hours for observation and cardiac workup. The incident was attributed to high workload demands during a critical production run for automotive components, combined with inadequate break scheduling and insufficient staffing on the line that day. This incident exposed systemic stress management issues within the production operations.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, injection molding operator Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165) was monitoring Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components) when the cooling water system suddenly developed a catastrophic leak from a corroded pipe junction. High-pressure cooling water sprayed across the molding machine control panel, causing an electrical short circuit. The machine's emergency stop failed to activate due to water damage to the safety relay module. The pressurized water sprayed onto Stéphane's right shoulder and arm, causing minor thermal and moisture exposure, but the primary incident was equipment failure. Warehouse associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), working nearby, immediately shut down the electrical supply at the main breaker. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi was notified and responded to assess for secondary hazards. The cooling system had not been inspected in 18 months despite being installed in 2015. Corrosion from mineral deposits in the recycled cooling water had weakened the pipe connections, creating a failure point. No preventive maintenance schedule was active for this critical system.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during day shift, a hydraulic hose rupture occurred on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building South Zone. Machine Operator Raoul Blanchard was conducting routine production monitoring when he noticed a sudden drop in machine pressure and heard a distinctive hissing sound. The rupture released approximately 12 liters of hydraulic fluid across the production floor, creating a slippery surface that spread across an 8-meter radius. The leaked fluid contained synthetic hydraulic oil (ISO VG 46) mixed with equipment residue. Raoul immediately activated the emergency stop on the molding machine and notified his supervisor. Within 10 minutes, maintenance technician Luc Girard arrived with absorbent material to contain the spill. The area was cordoned off with yellow caution tape, and production on Line D was halted for 3 hours while cleanup and equipment inspection were completed. Environmental coordinator Sakura Kobayashi documented the incident and verified that the spill did not reach storm drains or enter the building's waste system. No direct contact with the hydraulic fluid occurred, but the potential for slips and environmental contamination was significant.

On April 2, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift, a chemical storage container breach occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (Chemical Storage Building Exterior Zone). Material Handler Bianca De Luca was organizing waste containers in preparation for scheduled pickup when she discovered that a 200-liter drum of acetone cleaning solvent had corroded at the base, creating a small leak onto the concrete floor. The drum, dating from 2019, showed visible rust patterns indicating prolonged moisture exposure. Approximately 8 liters of acetone had pooled beneath the container, releasing pungent vapors into the storage area. Bianca immediately notified supervisor Anika Johansson and evacuated the immediate vicinity. Environmental coordinator Sakura Kobayashi was called to the scene and deployed absorbent materials while ensuring proper ventilation through the area's exhaust system. The affected acetone was carefully transferred to a new container, and the damaged drum was marked for disposal as hazardous waste. Air quality readings confirmed acetone vapors remained below OSHA PEL thresholds, but the incident exposed inadequate container maintenance procedures and storage condition monitoring. Investigation revealed that inspection logs for hazardous waste containers had not been reviewed in eight months.

On May 8, 2024, at 03:30 during night shift, a dust accumulation fire hazard was discovered in the Raw Materials Warehouse Section A during a routine facility inspection by IT Systems Administrator Jean-Pierre Nadeau, who was conducting after-hours network maintenance. He noticed significant accumulation of plastic resin powder (polypropylene and nylon particles) on horizontal surfaces, electrical equipment, and above ceiling areas. The dust layer, estimated at 2-4 millimeters in most areas and up to 8 millimeters near material handling equipment, had built up over approximately six weeks due to reduced cleaning frequency on night shifts. Powder had accumulated around electrical conduits, motor housings, and heating equipment—all potential ignition sources. The warehouse area temperatures ranged from 18-24°C with approximately 35% humidity, creating favorable conditions for static electricity buildup. Jean-Pierre immediately reported the hazard to HSE Director Marie-Claude Beaumont, who arrived within 30 minutes. The facility's night shift supervisor issued work cessation for the affected area, activated the warehouse industrial vacuum system (equipped with explosion-proof features), and manually removed accumulated powder using non-sparking tools over a 4-hour period. Material Handler Bianca De Luca assisted with careful dust collection and disposal in sealed bags. This incident revealed gaps in night shift cleaning protocols and preventive housekeeping standards that could have resulted in a catastrophic dust explosion.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a solvent storage container in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-020 vicinity but operationally tied to chemical operations) experienced a catastrophic failure. Technician Fernand Giguère was transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum into smaller distribution containers when the transfer pump malfunctioned, causing pressurized vapors to escape rapidly. The acetone mist accumulated near the heating element of an adjacent industrial oven set to 180°C for post-processing operations. At approximately 2:18 PM, the accumulated solvent vapors ignited, creating a flash fire that extended 8 feet across the workspace. Giguère sustained first and second-degree burns to his right arm and face before evacuating. The facility's automated fire suppression system activated within 45 seconds, extinguishing the fire. No additional personnel were injured. Emergency responders arrived at 2:31 PM. The incident was contained to the chemical storage area with minimal structural damage, but the section was cordoned off for investigation and remediation. Root cause analysis identified inadequate ventilation system maintenance, a malfunctioning pressure relief valve on the transfer pump, and insufficient clearance between flammable material storage and heat-producing equipment.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:45 AM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez was performing manual assembly work on injection-molded components at Injection Molding Line D. She was preparing parts for quality inspection when her left hand made contact with a sharp, undebarred edge on a freshly molded polycarbonate component. The edge lacerated her palm and caused a deep wound requiring 12 stitches. Lopez immediately reported the injury to Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert, who initiated first aid and arranged transportation to the facility medical clinic at 11:02 AM. The worker received medical treatment and was released with instructions for wound care. The incident was documented and reported to CNESST within 24 hours. Investigation revealed that the PC resin batch used that morning had a higher brittleness index, causing premature edge crystallization during cooling. Deburring equipment had not been calibrated for the specific resin batch specifications, leaving sharp edges that normally would have been smoothed. Quality Control Technician Sophie Lapointe verified that quality control procedures did not include pre-assembly edge verification for this particular product line.

On March 28, 2024, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand was performing routine cleaning and inspection in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025). While retrieving spare injection platen components from the upper storage mezzanine (approximately 12 feet high), he lost his grip on one component weighing approximately 8 kilograms. The part fell from the mezzanine level toward the ground directly below. Marchand was positioned on the floor directly beneath the falling object. He heard the noise of the falling component and immediately moved sideways approximately 18 inches, narrowly avoiding the falling platen which impacted the concrete floor 8 inches from where he had been standing. The component struck the floor with sufficient force to crack the concrete and sustain minor damage itself. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance, who was on night shift safety patrol, heard the impact and arrived within 2 minutes to assess the situation. Marchand confirmed he had not sustained any injuries. The near-miss was documented, and investigation revealed that the component storage racks on the mezzanine lacked proper edge guards, retaining clips, and fall prevention systems. Additionally, Marchand had not been wearing a hard hat despite working in an overhead hazard zone. The mezzanine storage procedure did not require secondary retrieval methods or spotters for items stored above 8 feet.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was operating in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the Maintenance Workshop Storage Mezzanine. While retrieving hydraulic hose assemblies from a high shelf approximately 2.4 meters above the concrete floor, a bundle of metal fittings and spare parts weighing approximately 12 kg became dislodged from an improperly secured storage rack due to vibrations from ongoing maintenance equipment operation in the adjacent area. The bundle fell directly onto Bianchi's left shoulder and upper back, causing immediate sharp pain and visible bruising. She fell to the ground, unable to bear weight on her left side. Witness Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) immediately called for emergency response. Bianchi was transported by ambulance to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval with suspected left shoulder dislocation and fractured clavicle. She required surgical intervention and was hospitalized for 3 days. Work was lost for 8 weeks during recovery and physiotherapy.

On December 3, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Unit 7 in the production area. He was checking the hydraulic pressure relief valve and accidentally left the LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) point unsecured after temporarily removing his personal lock to retrieve tools from the workshop. While Abdul stepped away for approximately 3 minutes, Hydraulic Systems Technician Andrei Popov (EMP-00094) arrived at the machine to perform corrective maintenance as scheduled, unaware that the machine had not been properly locked out. Popov actuated the hydraulic pump prime sequence, which activated the mold closing mechanism. The mold plates began to close with Abdul's left hand still positioned near the mold cavity from his previous work. Abdul was alerted by the sound of movement and immediately withdrew his hand just as the mold plates closed, with metal edges missing his fingers by approximately 2 cm. Abdul experienced acute anxiety response and psychological shock from the near-miss event. His hand was uninjured but he sustained minor abrasion to his palm from the rapid withdrawal motion.

On January 9, 2025 at 08:30 during the day shift, Sales Coordinator Annie Leclerc (EMP-00125) was performing administrative work in the Administration and Finance Office on the 1st floor of the Administrative Building. While preparing customer documentation and quality certificates for several completed medical device orders, she was organizing stacks of technical specification sheets, drawings, and regulatory documentation. As she was transferring a large bundle of approximately 200 pages from one filing cabinet to a work table, the paper stack shifted and caused a sharp edge of a plastic file divider to contact the inner surface of her left index finger. The contact resulted in a superficial paper cut approximately 2 cm in length. Annie applied immediate first aid with a tissue and a small adhesive bandage from the office first aid kit. There was minimal bleeding and no tissue damage beyond the epidermal layer. The incident was documented in the office incident log. While the injury was minor with no lost work time, it highlighted improper paper handling practices and inadequate workspace organization.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic failure occurred on Injection Molding Machine #7 (500-ton capacity) located in the Main Production Building. Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) was performing routine maintenance on the cooling water circulation system when the primary pump bearing seized unexpectedly. The bearing degradation caused metal shavings and debris to contaminate the entire cooling circuit. Within minutes, the hydraulic pressure in the mold clamping system spiked dangerously due to the blockage. The pressure relief valve, which had not been inspected in 18 months due to deferred maintenance schedules, failed to activate properly. This caused the mold to release prematurely during a cycle, ejecting a partially-formed automotive dashboard component at high velocity toward the operator station. Although no personnel were directly struck due to the protective enclosure, the equipment sustained significant damage to the injection barrel ($89,000), hydraulic manifold ($34,000), and control systems ($28,000). Production was halted for 6 days. The root cause investigation revealed inadequate preventive maintenance documentation and missing calibration records for pressure relief systems across multiple machines.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:15 AM, Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) conducted a routine preventive inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) as part of quarterly HSE audits. During his walkthrough, he observed inadequate ventilation in the resin mixing area where polyurethane compounds are processed. Air velocity measurements using a handheld anemometer revealed that the exhaust ventilation was operating at only 65% of design capacity (target: 150 linear feet per minute; actual: 98 lfm). Investigation identified that intake filters had not been changed in 14 months despite manufacturer recommendations of every 6 months. The degraded filter performance reduced negative pressure in the mixing zone. Bélanger also discovered that the carbon monoxide and volatile organic compound (VOC) monitoring system had been non-functional for 7 weeks due to a sensor malfunction that was not reported. Upon further inspection, he noted that two of four emergency eyewash stations had expired rinse solution cartridges. No personnel had been exposed to harmful chemical concentrations during this period (verified by air sampling), but the potential for exposure to isocyanate fumes and VOCs existed. This preventive declaration was made to prevent future health hazards including respiratory irritation, sensitization, and occupational asthma among the 8-12 employees regularly working in this area.

On March 21, 2024, at 11:30 PM during the night shift, Injection Molding Operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) sustained a thermal burn injury while working at Line D in the Main Production Building. Landry was removing a finished plastic component from a 200-ton injection molding machine that had recently completed a cycle. Despite wearing heat-resistant gloves rated to 250°C, he inadvertently made direct contact with the exposed mold surface, which was measured at 187°C. The mold ejector pins, which should have fully retracted per the machine's automatic cycle, had partially jammed due to accumulated polymer residue. This mechanical failure prevented the normal mold opening sequence, leaving the mold surface accessible and hotter than expected. Landry's glove material (standard nitrile composite) provided insufficient insulation at that temperature range. He sustained second-degree thermal burns across the palm and three fingers of his right hand. The burn area measured approximately 12 square centimeters. First aid was administered on-site by Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037), with ice water cooling applied for 20 minutes. Landry was transported to Laval Hospital emergency department at 11:50 PM by company vehicle. Treatment included wound cleaning, topical antibiotic application, and specialized burn dressing. He remained hospitalized for 2 days for observation and infection monitoring. Medical records indicated healing progressed normally with minimal scarring. Landry was released to restricted duty on March 23, returning to full production duties on April 8.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine cleaning of injection molding machine #18 in the Production Operations area. While using compressed air to clear plastic resin buildup from the machine's hopper, the nozzle unexpectedly came loose from the air line. The high-pressure compressed air (120 psi) struck Stéphane's left forearm, causing immediate pain and localized bruising but no penetrating injury. A coworker witnessed the incident and immediately shut down the air supply. The employee was evaluated by the on-site first aid responder and remained on light duty for two hours. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the air line coupling lacked a proper safety retaining clip and the nozzle was not rated for the system pressure. This near-miss was prevented from becoming a serious injury only due to the employee's quick reaction and the minimal duration of exposure. Stéphane reported the incident immediately to his supervisor, François-Xavier Mailhot.

On April 22, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), a Machine Setter on evening shift, was assisting maintenance technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) in transferring a 50-liter container of mold release agent (a hydrocarbon-based solvent) from bulk storage to smaller working containers. While positioning the container on the transfer stand, the valve cap was not fully secured. As the container was tilted, approximately 15 liters of mold release agent spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous slick that spread across approximately 120 square feet of the storage room floor. The strong solvent fumes immediately triggered the area's ventilation system alarm. Tomas quickly activated the emergency response protocol, evacuating the room and alerting François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) and Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152). The facility's spill response team deployed absorbent materials and contained the spill within 20 minutes. No personnel were exposed to skin contact or significant inhalation. The spill was documented, containerized, and scheduled for hazardous waste disposal. Root cause analysis revealed the container valve had an improperly fitting cap due to cross-threading during the previous storage cycle.

On May 8, 2024 at 6:30 AM during the night shift, an environmental incident was discovered in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) located in the maintenance workshop storage mezzanine. Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), the Crane Operator arriving for morning rounds, observed a significant coolant leak from an overhead hydraulic system used for material handling equipment. Approximately 200 liters of industrial hydraulic oil had leaked from a corroded pipe coupling and accumulated on the mezzanine floor, with an estimated 40-50 liters having dripped through floor grating into the facility's drainage system below over an unknown duration (likely 6-12 hours based on equipment inspection history). The hydraulic fluid contains mineral oil with potential toxicity to aquatic life and soil organisms. Martin immediately notified Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) and François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) of the environmental hazard. Emergency containment procedures were initiated: the leak was stopped by closing isolation valves, absorbent materials were deployed on the mezzanine, and the environmental services coordinator contacted municipal environmental authorities to report the discharge to the storm drainage system. Recovered fluid was containerized for hazardous waste disposal. Investigation revealed the pipe coupling had not been included in the quarterly preventive maintenance schedule due to an oversight in the equipment inventory database.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 14:45, Injection Molding Operator Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024) was conducting routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building when a hydraulic hose burst without warning. The hose, which supplies pressure to the mold closing mechanism, had been in service for 8 years without documented inspection or replacement. High-pressure hydraulic fluid sprayed across the production floor, saturating approximately 200 square feet of work area and coating finished polycarbonate components staged for quality control. The operator immediately shut down the line and activated the emergency spill containment protocol. Maintenance Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) responded and confirmed the hose failure. Environmental cleanup took 3 hours, requiring disposal of contaminated materials and thorough floor decontamination. The incident resulted in approximately $18,000 in lost production time and material waste. No personnel were directly exposed to the fluid spray due to the operator's positioning, but the facility's environmental response procedures were activated.

On March 18, 2024 at 09:15 AM, Quality Control Technician Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013) was performing UV light testing on cured composite samples in the Quality Control Laboratory when she accidentally splashed a small amount of acetone-based cleaning solvent into her left eye while transferring samples between testing chambers. The solvent was being used to clean optical testing equipment per standard QC procedures. Sophie immediately flushed her eye with water from the emergency eyewash station for 5 minutes and reported the incident to Quality Control Lead Petra Mueller (EMP-00166). The eye exhibited mild redness and temporary irritation but no visible damage. Petra administered basic first aid including saline rinse and placement of a cool compress. Sophie's vision returned to normal within 30 minutes. She was monitored for the remainder of the shift with no complications. The incident was documented in the facility's first aid log. Root cause analysis indicated inadequate eye protection compliance—Sophie was wearing standard safety glasses rather than chemical splash goggles rated for organic solvents.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:30 during the evening shift, Machine Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) was feeding raw polypropylene resin into the hopper of Injection Molding Line D when her right hand became caught between the rotating auger shaft and the hopper wall. The machine's safety interlock had been temporarily bypassed by Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) approximately 15 minutes earlier to clear a resin jam, but the bypass had not been re-engaged after clearing the blockage. Hawa was unaware the interlock was disabled. When she reached into the hopper to position material, the auger engaged and trapped her hand, causing laceration and crushing injuries to her index and middle fingers. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) immediately activated the emergency stop, halting the auger. Hawa was freed within 30 seconds but sustained significant bleeding and partial lacerations to both fingers. She was transported by ambulance to Laval General Hospital at 22:45. Emergency department assessment revealed deep lacerations requiring 18 stitches and a 3-week recovery period with modified duty restrictions. The incident investigation revealed the safety interlock bypass had not been properly documented or communicated to other operators on the shift.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Amina Mansour (EMP-00044), a Material Handler, was moving stacks of resin drums in the Regrind and Recycling Department using a pallet jack. As she was maneuvering the loaded pallet up a slight incline near the storage racks, her left foot became caught on an air hose that was routed across the floor near workstation C-7. The hose created a trip hazard that she did not notice due to poor lighting in that section. Amina stumbled forward but managed to catch herself on the pallet jack handle, preventing a fall. She immediately stopped work and reported the hazard to her supervisor, Patricia Martin (EMP-00035). No injury occurred, but the incident revealed inadequate housekeeping practices and improper cable management. The air hose was immediately repositioned and secured with cable ties. A near-miss report was completed and submitted to the HSE office for review.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator, was setting up a new composite material compression run at Press Station 4 in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. While closing the hydraulic press platen to the initial compression position, a sudden pressure release occurred in the system due to a failed check valve. The rapid decompression and lateral movement of the platen caused it to move approximately 15 centimeters to the right, striking Bernard's left forearm. Bernard immediately experienced acute pain and significant swelling. He called for assistance, and Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), the Instrumentation Technician on night shift, responded and provided immediate first aid. Bernard was transported to the emergency department by ambulance, where X-rays confirmed a non-displaced fracture of the radius bone in the left forearm. He was treated and released with a cast and restricted duty orders for 8 weeks. An incident investigation revealed that the check valve had not been included in the routine monthly maintenance schedule for this press model.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 4:30 PM during the evening shift, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was preparing to perform routine cleaning and maintenance on Molding Machine 12 in the Production Engineering and Planning area. He followed LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures and secured the energy isolation points with his personal padlock. However, due to confusion about shift handoff communication, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician from the incoming night shift, was not aware that Machine 12 was in lockout status. Oscar attempted to restart the machine remotely from the control panel approximately 15 minutes later without verifying the LOTO status. The machine cycled briefly before the electrical safety interlock detected the locked-out condition and automatically stopped the operation. Conrad was working inside the machine cavity at that moment but was not in the direct path of any moving components. The brief activation lasted less than 2 seconds and caused no physical injury. However, Conrad experienced significant shock and emotional distress at the near-miss. The incident was immediately reported to the HSE office. Investigation revealed gaps in shift handoff procedures and inadequate LOTO communication protocols.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was adjusting the mold closing mechanism on Injection Molding Line C when the mold unexpectedly cycled. The automatic closing sequence had not been properly locked out despite maintenance work being performed. Karim's left hand was caught between the closing mold halves, resulting in crush injuries to his index and middle fingers. The mold was immediately stopped by nearby operator Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), who witnessed the incident and activated the emergency stop button. Karim was taken to the on-site first aid station and subsequently transported to Hôpital de Laval for emergency care. X-rays confirmed fractures to the second and third metacarpals with significant soft tissue damage. The employee required hospitalization for 3 days and surgical intervention to realign the bones. Root cause analysis indicated inadequate LOTO procedures and insufficient verification that the mold safety interlocks were engaged before maintenance commenced.

On November 18, 2024, during the evening shift at approximately 6:15 PM, quality auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) was conducting a routine inspection of the Composite Materials Processing Area when she noticed a chemical spill in progress. A 5-gallon container of epoxy resin had developed a hairline crack during storage, and approximately 2 gallons had leaked onto the concrete floor near workstation C-14. The spill created a slippery hazard and released volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes into the work environment. Indira immediately activated the area's alarm system and notified production supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) via radio. She posted warning signs around the affected area and instructed nearby workers to evacuate to a safe distance. Maxime contacted the HSE department and initiated the chemical spill response protocol. The spill was contained and cleaned up using absorbent materials, and the area was ventilated for 30 minutes before resuming limited operations. Environmental monitoring showed VOC levels returned to acceptable ranges. The container had not been inspected for integrity as part of the quarterly inventory check, and the storage area temperature had fluctuated, potentially causing the crack to develop.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the night shift, forklift operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was moving a pallet of finished composite components from the Post-Processing area toward the warehouse when he encountered wet flooring near the south dock transition. Tariq had been informed of floor cleaning but proceeded at normal speed. The rear wheels of the forklift slipped on the wet epoxy coating, causing the vehicle to lose traction. Although Tariq maintained control and came to a stop, the load shifted on the pallet. Approximately 12 high-value composite structural components (worth approximately $8,400 total) fell from the pallet and struck the concrete floor, resulting in significant damage. Eight components suffered irreparable cracking and delamination; four others sustained cosmetic surface damage requiring rework. Electrical technician Viktor Novak (EMP-00116) was nearby and witnessed the incident, confirming that Tariq had demonstrated good vehicle control to prevent a more serious outcome. Investigation revealed that wet floor signs had been placed, but the forklift path had not been rerouted, and the cleaning crew had not coordinated their schedule with material handling operations.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a thermal burn while removing a finished component from a 300-ton injection molding machine. The mold temperature was set to 185°C for a medical-grade composite part production run. François attempted to extract the part using his bare hand instead of waiting for the automated removal system to complete its cycle. His left palm made direct contact with the hot mold surface for approximately 3 seconds before he withdrew his hand. The burn resulted in a first-degree thermal injury affecting approximately 15 square centimeters of his left palm, with minor blistering visible. First aid was administered immediately by the shift supervisor Patrick Ouellet, who applied cool water for 10 minutes and applied a sterile burn dressing. François remained on duty but was restricted from manual mold handling for the remainder of the shift. The incident was reported to Johanne Paquette within 30 minutes.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:47 PM during the evening shift, Natalya Kozlov (EMP-00192), a Quality Technician, was struck by falling composite material from an improperly secured storage rack in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop mezzanine. Natalya was retrieving spools of reinforced fiber material (carbon fiber and fiberglass composites) for the post-processing department when a shelf bracket on the upper tier of the storage rack failed due to overload and corrosion of the mounting bolts. Approximately 40 kilograms of bundled composite material fell from approximately 2.1 meters height, striking her left shoulder and upper back. The impact caused a severe contusion, partial muscle strain in the trapezius region, and acute pain requiring immediate medical attention. Natalya was transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur by ambulance and admitted for imaging and pain management. She remained hospitalized for 18 hours for observation and was subsequently placed on modified duty for two weeks. The incident was witnessed by Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042), who immediately called emergency services and reported the incident to Brigitte Mathieu within the hour.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:08 AM during the night shift, Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), a Mold Maintenance Technician, nearly suffered a serious hydraulic fluid injection injury while performing maintenance on a 400-ton injection molding machine in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. While depressurizing the hydraulic system prior to replacing a failed pump seal, Réjean inadvertently opened a secondary relief valve instead of the designated pressure bleed-off point. High-pressure hydraulic fluid (approximately 180 bar) was still present in the primary circuit and began spraying toward his right hand and forearm. Réjean immediately noticed the mist of fluid and pulled his hand back, moving his limb away from the spray within 2 seconds. No fluid entered his skin, but approximately 500 milliliters of fluid was dispersed across his work area, and a small amount contacted his gloved hand without penetrating. The incident was immediately reported to Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), the Instrumentation Technician on duty, who secured the equipment and documented the near-miss. Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was notified and conducted a preliminary investigation confirming that immediate intervention prevented a potentially serious occupational injury.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on a high-speed injection molding machine in the Main Production Building when a sudden, unexpected machine startup occurred. While he was cleaning the mold cavity with a cloth, a co-worker accidentally activated the machine controls from the operator station, unaware that Conrad was working inside the mold chamber. The machine's clamp mechanism engaged, pinching Conrad's right hand between the mold halves. He sustained a severe laceration to his palm and fractures to his index and middle fingers. Emergency response was immediate; first aid was administered on-site, and he was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital where he underwent surgical repair. The incident was witnessed by Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), the Assembly Line Lead, who called emergency services. The root cause was identified as inadequate machine lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures and lack of communication between maintenance and operations staff.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, was operating the material regrind station in the Production Operations area when he experienced a sharp laceration to his left forearm. While feeding recycled plastic scraps into the grinding hopper, his glove caught on a rotating blade assembly that was inadequately guarded. The blade caused a deep 3-inch laceration requiring seven sutures at the on-site first aid station, with follow-up treatment at a clinic. Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), an Inventory Control Specialist working nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately applied pressure to the wound and alerted supervisory staff. The injured employee was able to return to modified duty the following day but experienced pain and limited mobility for two weeks. Investigation revealed that the machine's guard had been partially removed during a maintenance cycle three days earlier and not properly reinstalled, creating an unprotected hazard zone.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was transferring 200 liters of acetone solvent from a bulk storage tank to smaller containers for distribution to production areas when the transfer pump malfunctioned, causing a pressurized discharge. The pump nozzle detached suddenly, spraying approximately 80 liters of acetone across the work surface, floor, and into an open floor drain before the containment system was activated. The spill created a hazardous vapor zone affecting the immediate work area. Claude Poirier (EMP-00071), a Forklift Operator conducting inventory in the adjacent warehouse, noticed the chemical odor and alerted facility management. Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), a Facilities Maintenance Technician, activated emergency containment protocols and supervised the cleanup using absorbent materials and proper disposal procedures. The spill was fully contained and remediated within two hours. Environmental monitoring detected no groundwater contamination. Root cause analysis identified worn pump seals and inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was working at Injection Molding Line A removing finished automotive dashboard components from the mold. While extracting a part from the hot mold surface, Said's left forearm made direct contact with the mold cavity temperature reading approximately 285°C. He immediately withdrew his arm and reported the burn to his supervisor. Said experienced a significant thermal burn across the inner forearm with blistering and erythema. Emergency first aid was administered on-site by the facility nurse, and Said was transported to Laval General Hospital for evaluation and treatment of second-degree burns covering approximately 8% of his forearm. The incident occurred because the mold temperature warning placards were obscured by production scheduling notices, and Said had not completed refresher training on hot surface hazards in the past 18 months.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, maintenance technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) was performing routine cleaning beneath the composite materials processing equipment in the West Wing. While descending a 1.2-meter stepladder to access the equipment base, Giguère's foot slipped on a film of uncured resin residue on the floor. He managed to grab the ladder frame, preventing a fall to the concrete floor below. Giguère remained suspended momentarily before releasing and landing awkwardly on his left ankle. Although Giguère was able to walk, he reported immediate pain and swelling. Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), the evening warehouse supervisor who was nearby, immediately assisted and ensured Giguère received ice elevation. Giguère's ankle was later assessed as a grade 1 ankle sprain with no fracture. This near-miss incident revealed critical control gaps: no anti-slip floor treatment in maintenance areas, inadequate resin cleanup procedures between shifts, and no handrails on the stepladder.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 11:50 PM during the night shift, assembly operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) was preparing medical device component housings in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. While transferring a 5-liter container of epoxy resin from a storage shelf to the mixing station, Fernandez inadvertently knocked over an open container of volatile solvent thinner that had been left on the shelf by the previous shift. Approximately 2 liters of solvent vapors immediately filled the confined space of the room. Fernandez began experiencing dizziness, headache, and respiratory irritation within seconds. He quickly exited the room and notified Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), the warehouse lead on an adjacent break, who immediately activated the emergency ventilation system and opened all access doors. Fernandez was moved to fresh air and given oxygen via the first aid kit. Emergency services were called and Fernandez was transported to the hospital where he was diagnosed with acute solvent inhalation exposure resulting in temporary pulmonary irritation and mild hypoxia. He remained hospitalized for 6 hours for observation. Investigation revealed the solvent container had no secure lid, there was no secondary containment system, and night shift staff had not received chemical handling refresher training in 22 months.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM, during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195) was performing routine mold maintenance on Line A in the North Zone production building. While removing hardened plastic overflow from a mold cavity using a wooden scraper, Conrad noticed slight discoloration and warping on the mold surface that could indicate potential contamination affecting part quality. He immediately halted operations and documented his observations. The operator suspected that cooling water residue combined with trace amounts of colorant masterbatch from the previous production run may have contaminated the mold interior. Conrad photographed the affected areas and reported the concern to his supervisor before any parts entered quality control. Quality Systems Coordinator Sakura Kobayashi (EMP-00158) was called to inspect the mold and confirmed early-stage mold contamination. The contamination was caught before any defective parts were distributed to the customer. Immediate corrective action involved thorough mold cleaning and documentation of the incident for preventive purposes. This proactive identification prevented potential customer complaints and product recalls.

On April 8, 2024 at 10:47 PM during the evening shift, Machine Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) was walking through the production area carrying quality control samples to the adjacent laboratory when her right foot caught on a compressed air hose that had shifted from its normal routing along the floor near the regrind station in Section C. She stumbled forward but managed to regain her balance by grabbing a nearby equipment frame, preventing a fall. The air hose was partially blocking the established walkway between the regrind area and the Quality Control Laboratory. Hawa did not fall or sustain any injury. She immediately alerted Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147), who repositioned the hose and secured it with cable ties to the wall. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the hose had become dislodged from its clamp when a forklift passed nearby earlier that evening. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was notified and assessed the trip hazard. No injury occurred, but the situation had significant potential for a serious fall given the proximity to heavy machinery and the multiple shift transitions through that area.

On May 22, 2024 at 6:35 AM during the night shift, Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) was performing routine maintenance on the overhead cooling system in the Central Maintenance Workshop. While descending a 12-foot fixed aluminum ladder after inspecting ductwork connections on the ceiling, Georges's grip loosened at approximately the 8-foot mark. He fell approximately 4 feet onto the concrete workshop floor below, landing on his left side. Georges sustained a fractured left radius and severe bruising to his ribs and left shoulder. He remained conscious and immediately called for emergency assistance using the workshop communication system. Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), who was nearby restocking maintenance supplies, heard the call and summoned emergency medical services. Georges was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital by ambulance and admitted for treatment. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was notified immediately and investigated the incident at 7:20 AM. The ladder was found to be in good structural condition, but Georges reported that his gloved hands were damp from humidity in the maintenance area, reducing grip friction. He had been working for 4 hours without a break at the time of the incident, suggesting fatigue may have contributed. The fall resulted in lost-time injury requiring hospitalization, emergency treatment, and an estimated 12-week recovery period.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 10:45 AM, machine operator Raoul Blanchard was performing routine setup on Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area (UNIT-003). While adjusting mold parameters for a new production run of surgical instrument handles, the machine's hydraulic pressure gauge began exhibiting erratic readings. Blanchard noticed the needle fluctuating wildly between 800 and 1200 PSI, which is outside normal operating parameters of 900-1000 PSI. He immediately paused the operation and notified Gaétan Laplante, the LOTO Coordinator. Laplante arrived within 5 minutes and confirmed the gauge malfunction. Before any maintenance personnel could be called, the pressure stabilized. However, upon closer inspection, they discovered a small hydraulic fluid leak around the pressure relief valve connection. The situation was contained by isolating the machine using proper LOTO procedures. No employee contact with pressurized fluid or moving equipment occurred. The incident was discovered before the machine resumed cycling, preventing potential exposure to the spray hazard or equipment malfunction during operation. Production was halted for 2.5 hours pending maintenance inspection and repair of the relief valve assembly.

On March 18, 2024 at approximately 8:15 PM during the evening shift, material handler Bianca De Luca was organizing finished goods inventory in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). She was stacking boxes of packaged medical device components (approximately 15 kg each) on a pallet using the standard two-person team method. However, her partner, warehouse associate Marc Hébert, stepped away temporarily to assist with a shipping documentation issue. De Luca continued stacking independently, reaching the fifth level of the pallet stack (approximately 1.2 meters high). As she positioned a box on the upper level, her foot slipped on a small amount of plastic film that had fallen on the floor near the pallet base. She lost her balance and caught herself on the pallet edge, preventing a fall. However, she twisted her left ankle in the process and felt sharp pain. She immediately lowered herself to the ground and called for assistance via the warehouse radio. Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette responded and assessed the situation. De Luca was able to walk with assistance but reported significant ankle pain. No boxes fell or struck anyone. The incident lasted approximately 8 minutes from the near-fall to the call for medical evaluation.

On March 22, 2024 at approximately 2:30 PM, injection molding technician Christian Gosselin was working on production Line B in the Main Production Building. He was performing routine mold release agent application on ejector pins inside an open mold cavity for automotive door handle components. Gosselin wore standard cotton work gloves and latex examination gloves as secondary protection, following standard procedure. He sprayed the mold release agent (a petroleum distillate-based product) onto the pins using a small pressurized applicator bottle. During the application, a small amount of spray mist contacted his left hand where the latex glove had a small undetected tear near the thumb joint. Within 60 seconds, Gosselin felt mild burning and itching sensations on the affected area of skin. He immediately removed both gloves and washed the area with soap and water at the nearest sink. His coworker, Production Operator Leila Farah, who was monitoring the adjacent mold, noticed his reaction and alerted the area supervisor. Gosselin was transported to the on-site first aid station where the HSE team applied topical cooling gel and antihistamine cream. The affected area showed localized redness and mild edema. After 20 minutes of treatment and monitoring, the symptoms subsided. Gosselin was cleared to return to work with instructions to take frequent hand-washing breaks and was provided with new gloves.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM, Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine in the Main Production Building when she noticed excessive resin fumes emanating from the hopper heating system. Instead of immediately shutting down the machine and evacuating, she continued working while experiencing dizziness and mild respiratory irritation. Her supervisor, Sébastien Carrier (EMP-00065), was present in the area and also noticed the strong chemical smell. After approximately 15 minutes, Claudine reported feeling nauseous and complained of throat irritation. Sébastien immediately evacuated the work area and contacted the HSE department. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer, investigated and determined that the resin dryer temperature control had malfunctioned, causing the material to decompose and release hazardous fumes. The area was ventilated and Claudine was monitored by first aid staff but did not require hospitalization. This incident was declared as a preventive action to address the underlying ventilation and equipment maintenance deficiencies that allowed hazardous fume concentrations to develop.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:15 AM during day shift, Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), a Crane Operator, was positioning a pallet of raw polycarbonate resin pellets above a staging area in the Raw Materials Warehouse when he noticed the load appearing slightly unstable as it swayed. He immediately halted the crane's horizontal movement and carefully lowered the load back to the ground. Upon inspection, he discovered that the wooden pallet beneath the 1,200-pound bag stack had begun to splinter and one corner edge was visibly cracked, which would have caused a partial load collapse if the movement had continued. The pallet was immediately removed from service and replaced with a certified sturdy pallet. Raymond reported the near-miss incident to his supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031), who documented it with photographs.
