Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) was notified and categorized this as a near-miss with high potential consequence, as a load drop in this warehouse area would have created a serious hazard for personnel working below and could have caused critical injuries.

On May 22, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift, Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), a Material Handler, was transferring containers of mold release agent from storage shelves to a chemical distribution cart in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. While reaching for a container on the upper shelf, his gloved hand made contact with a leaking valve on an adjacent storage drum, causing approximately 2 liters of adhesive bonding agent to spill across the work bench and partially onto the floor. Amani immediately stopped work and used absorbent material to contain the spill. He notified his supervisor, who activated the facility's spill response protocol. Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead, and Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) responded to assess the situation. The spill was contained and cleaned using proper chemical disposal procedures. No personnel were exposed to significant quantities, though Amani reported mild skin irritation at the contact point where the adhesive touched his glove. This incident was declared preventively to address the underlying hazard of deteriorating equipment valves and inadequate chemical storage organization that created the spill risk.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components clean room area (UNIT-003). An employee, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), was performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine when he noticed smoke emanating from the hopper heating element. The heating element had developed an electrical fault, causing overheating of the plastic resin material. François immediately activated the nearest fire alarm pull station and notified his supervisor. The facility's automatic fire suppression system activated within 30 seconds, and the alarm was sounding throughout the entire production floor. All personnel in the clean room area were evacuated following standard emergency procedures. The fire department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed no active fire, only localized overheating contained by the suppression system. The incident lasted approximately 45 minutes from alarm activation to all-clear signal. No injuries occurred, but the medical device production line was shut down for safety inspection.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant fire incident occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120), a CNC machinist, was operating a CNC milling machine to fabricate a custom injection mold when he discovered a small fire had started near the tool storage area. The fire originated from improperly stored flammable solvents and cleaning materials that had accumulated near an electrical outlet with exposed wiring. The solvents had been placed in inadequately labeled containers without proper ventilation. Dimitri immediately used a nearby Class B fire extinguisher to suppress the flames, which spread rapidly across approximately 2 square meters of the workbench. He activated the emergency alarm and evacuated the area while calling emergency services. The fire department arrived within 12 minutes and confirmed complete extinguishment. The incident resulted in moderate smoke damage and damage to equipment valued at approximately $8,000. Two nearby employees, Ahmed Hassan and Raj Patel, were evacuated as precautions. The facility conducted an emergency building inspection and discovered multiple WHMIS violations in chemical storage protocols.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), a packaging operator, sustained a significant laceration to her left hand while operating the automated packaging line in the Shipping and Receiving Dock area (UNIT-009). Lucia was attempting to clear a jam in the seal mechanism of the packaging machine when the machine suddenly restarted without warning. Her left hand became caught between the heated sealing plates and the product feed mechanism, resulting in a deep laceration approximately 3 cm long on the dorsal surface of her left hand, along with thermal burns from contact with the heated sealing plates. The incident occurred because the machine's emergency stop button was not prominently accessible and lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures were not being followed during maintenance operations. Lucia immediately withdrew her hand and applied pressure to the wound. A nearby coworker, Mélanie Fortin, immediately notified the Occupational Health Nurse (Hana Al-Rashid, EMP-00052), who provided first aid and arranged immediate transport to the hospital. The injury required 8 stitches and tetanus prophylaxis. Lucia was hospitalized for 4 hours and subsequently placed on modified duty for 2 weeks.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a significant burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance in the Main Production Building North Zone. While attempting to remove a hardened plastic accumulation from a mold cavity using a metal scraper, Paul accidentally made contact with an active heating element on the mold that was still at approximately 180°C. The operator's right forearm and hand sustained second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of body surface area. Paul immediately alerted his supervisor and was taken to the on-site first aid station, then transferred to Laval Medical Center for advanced burn treatment. Investigation revealed that the mold had not been properly de-energized and cooled according to LOTO procedures, and Paul was not wearing the required heat-resistant gloves specified for this task. The incident resulted in 6 weeks of lost work time during wound healing and rehabilitation.

On April 22, 2024 at 11:18 PM during the evening shift, a fire suppression system was accidentally discharged in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) was performing routine inspection of the fire suppression system piping when his ladder made contact with a thermal sprinkler head in the ceiling, causing it to activate. This triggered a cascading activation of adjacent heads, releasing approximately 2,000 gallons of fire suppression foam throughout the chemical storage area over a 45-second period. The discharge damaged inventory of approximately $85,000 in raw plastic resins and composite materials, contaminated the warehouse floor, and forced evacuation of personnel within a 200-meter radius. No injuries occurred. The facility operations were disrupted for 8 hours while cleanup and environmental remediation occurred. Post-incident investigation revealed inadequate labeling of the sprinkler system height clearance requirements and insufficient training on proximity hazards during equipment maintenance.

On May 8, 2024 at 10:30 AM, Amina Ba (EMP-00164), a Packaging Operator in the Assembly and Finishing Department, reported early warning signs of repetitive strain injury to the HSE office during a routine preventive workplace health assessment. Amina described progressive pain and stiffness in her right wrist and forearm that began approximately 4 weeks prior, coinciding with increased production demands requiring sustained gripping and sorting motions for up to 7 hours per shift. She reported discomfort particularly during the final hours of her shift, though symptoms currently resolve with rest. Amina proactively sought evaluation before incurring a lost-time injury. Clinical assessment by the occupational health nurse indicated early-stage inflammation consistent with cumulative trauma disorder risk. This preventive declaration prompted immediate implementation of job rotation protocols and ergonomic workstation assessment to prevent progression to a debilitating injury. The case was documented for trend analysis and used as a model for early intervention in the department.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine mold changeover in the Main Production Building. While removing a hot mold from the injection press without waiting for adequate cooling time, the mold shifted unexpectedly and François grabbed the mold frame to stabilize it. His left hand made direct contact with the heated mold surface, causing a severe thermal burn across his palm and fingers. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C (185°F). François immediately removed his hand and reported the injury to his supervisor, Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175). First aid was administered on-site, and François was transported to the local hospital emergency department where he was diagnosed with a second-degree thermal burn requiring specialized burn treatment. He was hospitalized for three days and required wound care and pain management. The incident revealed that the production team had not been following the mandatory 15-minute cooling protocol established in the lockout/tagout procedures.

On March 22, 2024, during the evening shift at approximately 6:15 PM, Claude Poirier (EMP-00071), a Forklift Operator, was moving a pallet of finished goods in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). While navigating between storage racks, Claude's foot caught on a piece of splintered wooden pallet material that was protruding from a deteriorating pallet stack. The splinter punctured through his work boot and embedded approximately 1.5 cm into his left foot between the first and second metatarsal bones. Claude immediately stopped work and reported the injury to the warehouse supervisor, Anika Johansson (EMP-00144). The warehouse first aid kit was used to clean the wound, and Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), the Emergency Response Team Leader, was called to assess the injury. Upon inspection, it was determined the splinter had caused a puncture wound with minimal bleeding but significant contamination risk. Claude received first aid treatment including wound irrigation, antiseptic application, and a sterile bandage. Tetanus status was verified as current. The employee was able to return to modified duties the same shift but walked with discomfort.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM during the day shift, Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), a Production Operator assigned to Post-Processing and Heat Treatment operations, experienced a minor allergic reaction to latex gloves she was wearing while handling composite materials being cured in the industrial ovens. Yara developed localized itching and mild redness on her hands and wrists approximately 15 minutes after putting on the gloves. She immediately removed the gloves and notified her supervisor, Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175). Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), the Ergonomics Specialist and EHS resource, was contacted and arrived within 10 minutes. Upon assessment, Yara showed typical signs of latex sensitivity: erythema (redness) limited to areas of glove contact, mild urticaria (hives), and itching. No systemic symptoms or difficulty breathing were present. Alain administered first aid care including gentle hand washing, application of a hydrocortisone cream from the first aid kit, and monitoring for 30 minutes. The reaction subsided within one hour. Yara was fitted with non-latex nitrile gloves as an alternative and continued her shift without further incident. Yara was advised to inform occupational health of her latex sensitivity for future reference.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line C when he noticed the mold temperature controller displaying erratic readings. While investigating the electrical connections behind the molding machine, Ibrahim observed that a hydraulic hose coupling near the mold base showed signs of slight seepage. He immediately notified his supervisor Michael Chen and did not attempt to tighten or repair the coupling himself. The supervisor confirmed the issue and locked out the machine following LOTO procedures. Maintenance was called to properly inspect and replace the coupling if necessary. The situation was contained before any hydraulic fluid contact occurred or the machine was inadvertently restarted. Ibrahim's proactive identification of the potential hazard and his adherence to safety protocols prevented a potentially serious incident involving electrical shock risk and hydraulic fluid exposure.

On November 18, 2024, Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-025) during the evening shift. While reviewing storage procedures and material inventory, Simon identified that several containers of mold release agents and cleaning solvents (acetone and isopropanol) were stored in close proximity to heat-generating equipment including the resin mixing apparatus and an older space heater. According to CNESST regulations and company policy, flammable liquids must be stored at least 15 feet from ignition sources. The current configuration placed volatile chemicals within 6 feet of the heating equipment. Simon immediately documented this finding, photographed the layout, and declared this as a preventive safety issue. He recommended immediate relocation of the chemical storage to a designated cool storage cabinet on the opposite side of the facility. No incident occurred, but the conditions created significant potential for a fire or explosion event.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the night shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was transferring resin pellets from a storage bin to a material drying hopper in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. As she was pouring pellets from a 25-kg bag, some pellets spilled onto the concrete floor. While cleaning up the spill, Chiara accidentally stepped on a loose pellet that rolled under her foot, causing her to slip. She fell backward onto her left elbow and sustained a minor laceration approximately 3 cm long on her forearm. The cut began bleeding moderately. Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) was nearby and immediately assisted Chiara to the first aid station. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was called and provided first aid treatment: the wound was cleaned with antiseptic solution, the bleeding was controlled with pressure and gauze, and the laceration was covered with sterile adhesive bandages. No stitches were required. Chiara's tetanus status was verified as current. She was able to continue her shift after a 30-minute observation period.

On November 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) was working at Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building's South Zone when she noticed the hopper level indicator was not functioning properly. She attempted to manually check the material level by reaching into the top of the hopper while the system was still powered. As she leaned over the edge, a surge of polypropylene resin pellets suddenly discharged from the material drying system above, causing approximately 40 pounds of material to spill across the hopper rim and onto the floor adjacent to the molding line. The unexpected overflow created a slip hazard and scattered material blocked the emergency exit pathway. Yara immediately stepped back and called for assistance. Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) responded and helped clear the spillage while EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) was notified. The incident was caught before any employee slipped or sustained injury, but the near-miss highlighted a critical gap in lockout procedures during maintenance checks.

On November 18, 2024 at 10:47 PM during the evening shift, Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was operating the recycling grinder in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse and Shipping - Section C) when a mechanical malfunction occurred. While processing failed injection-molded parts, the feed hopper jammed with a tangled mass of partially shredded ABS plastic. Following established procedure, Oscar attempted to clear the blockage using a wooden dowel to push material through the discharge port while the grinder was still running at reduced speed—a violation of lockout procedures. His right hand came into contact with the still-rotating grinding rotor teeth, causing a laceration to his palm and fingers requiring 12 stitches. Material Handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) heard Oscar's cry and immediately pressed the emergency stop button. Oscar was transported by ambulance to the local hospital where he received emergency treatment. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) responded and documented the incident. A contributing factor was inadequate training on emergency jam-clearing procedures and failure to enforce LOTO compliance.

On November 20, 2024 at 6:30 AM during the night shift, a catastrophic failure occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (Main Production Building - Material Handling Zone). The drying hopper's pneumatic pressure relief valve experienced seal degradation, causing an uncontrolled pressure buildup within the system. The increased internal pressure forced the hopper sidewall panel to rupture outward with significant force, ejecting approximately 200 pounds of heated nylon pellets (PA6 with glass fiber reinforcement) and metal debris across the work area. The rupture was preceded by an audible hissing sound but no warning alarm activated because the facility's aging pressure monitoring system had not been calibrated in 18 months. Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was working 15 feet away when the rupture occurred; shrapnel from the panel struck her left shoulder causing bruising and a small laceration. Training Coordinator Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) and another night shift supervisor arrived within minutes and evacuated the area. A subsequent investigation revealed the relief valve had been due for preventive maintenance since July 2024, and maintenance logs were incomplete. This represented a critical failure in predictive maintenance protocols and equipment inspection scheduling.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was removing cooled plastic components from an injection molding machine in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005). While extracting a batch of polypropylene automotive housings, her left hand made contact with a sharp mold edge that had not been properly deburred during routine maintenance. The operator sustained a laceration to her palm and fingers, requiring immediate first aid and subsequent medical evaluation. The wound was approximately 8 cm long with moderate bleeding. Assembly operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) witnessed the incident and immediately notified the supervisor. First aid was administered within minutes, and the employee was transported to a local urgent care facility for sutures. Investigation revealed that the mold maintenance schedule had been delayed by three days due to equipment unavailability, and no additional hand protection measures had been implemented for the interim period.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:20 PM during the evening shift, material handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was transferring bags of polypropylene resin from the warehouse to the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) using a manual pallet jack. While navigating through a narrow aisle in the Warehouse and Shipping area (UNIT-009), the jack's wheel caught on a piece of loose wooden flooring, causing the jack to tip sideways. Approximately 12 bags of resin (each weighing 25 kg) shifted and fell, with several bags landing on the operator's right lower leg and foot. Mwangi sustained contusions, a possible fracture of the tibia, and significant bruising across the dorsum of his foot. Coworker Tran Le (EMP-00036), a quality control lab technician who was conducting material testing nearby, immediately called for emergency response. The employee was transported via ambulance to a local hospital where imaging confirmed a non-displaced tibial fracture requiring immobilization for 6 weeks. Root cause investigation identified that the warehouse floor had deteriorated in that location, creating a 2.5 cm depression that was not marked as a hazard.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a 500-ton injection molding machine (Machine #28) in the Main Production Building experienced a catastrophic hydraulic system failure. Operator Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053) was performing routine cycle monitoring when the machine's upper platen began descending uncontrollably due to a ruptured main hydraulic line. The platen crashed into the mold cavity, destroying the custom automotive part mold valued at $180,000 and damaging the machine's frame and electrical components. The impact also scattered mold fragments across a 10-foot radius. Quality Documentation Specialist Gabrielle Levesque (EMP-00095) was nearby reviewing production logs and witnessed the failure. Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) immediately shut down the machine using the emergency stop button and isolated the hydraulic system. Investigation revealed that the hydraulic line had not been inspected during the scheduled preventive maintenance cycle two weeks prior, allowing a hairline fracture to propagate. Total equipment damage exceeded $320,000.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Composite Materials Operator Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086) was transferring polyurethane resin from a 55-gallon drum to a smaller mixing container when the container's lid was not fully seated. A batch of approximately 15 gallons of uncatalyzed polyurethane resin spilled across the concrete floor, spreading toward the electrical panel area. The spill created a slip hazard and vapors began accumulating. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) was conducting evening safety rounds and immediately initiated the chemical spill response protocol. The area was evacuated and ventilation fans were activated manually. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) helped contain the spill using absorbent materials and established a perimeter. Environmental and Safety Coordinator cleanup took 3 hours. The incident was caused by inadequate communication about proper container seating procedures and lack of a secondary containment tray under the transfer operation.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the main ventilation system serving the Production Operations area experienced a complete failure. The system's primary motor bearing seized due to lack of lubrication during the overnight maintenance window. Equipment Storage and Spare Parts handler discovered the failure when routine air quality sensors triggered alarms indicating elevated volatile organic compound (VOC) levels from the injection molding processes. Within 45 minutes, ambient temperature in the production area rose to 38°C (100°F) and workers reported respiratory irritation and dizziness. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) activated the backup ventilation system, but it operated at only 60% capacity. Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) initiated an emergency repair response. Production operations were suspended for 6 hours until the main system was restored. Investigation revealed that the preventive maintenance log for the ventilation system had not been updated in 8 months and the bearing lubrication schedule had been inadvertently deleted from the maintenance management system during a software upgrade.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine hopper cleaning when she noticed plastic material beginning to overflow from the top of the hopper. The hopper had been filled to capacity just minutes earlier by the automatic feed system. Yasmin immediately recognized the overflow risk and stepped back from the equipment. She notified her supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) of the situation before any material contacted her skin or contaminated the medical-grade clean room environment. The overflow was caused by a malfunctioning level sensor that failed to stop the automatic feed system. Maxime quickly shut down the line and engaged the emergency stop button, preventing further material spillage. The incident was contained within 10 minutes with no material reaching the production area. This was a near-miss situation where proper awareness and quick action prevented potential product contamination and material handling injuries. The level sensor malfunction could have resulted in significant waste and potential chemical exposure if the operator had not been attentive.

On April 22, 2025, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a back injury while manually lifting a 45-pound tray of finished consumer packaging components. Rémi was transferring completed parts from the molding line discharge area to a staging cart positioned approximately 8 feet away. The staging cart had been positioned at an awkward height (18 inches below waist level) due to earlier damage to its pneumatic height adjustment system. Rémi attempted to lower the full tray to cart level using only his back muscles rather than engaging his core and leg muscles. He felt a sharp pain in his lower back as he began the lowering motion and immediately set the tray down, but the damage was done. Rémi reported the injury to Production Supervisor, who arranged immediate first aid and documented the incident. Within 2 hours, Rémi's pain intensified, and he was transported to the local hospital emergency room where imaging revealed a herniated L4-L5 disk. Rémi required hospitalization overnight for pain management and was placed on medical leave. This injury resulted in 23 days of lost work time.

On May 8, 2025, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter, sustained a burn injury to his right hand while performing maintenance on Line A molding machine. Robert was attempting to manually adjust a stuck mold release valve on the heated press assembly. The valve, typically operated by an automated solenoid system, had failed to respond to control signals and was showing signs of pressure buildup. Robert used a wrench to attempt manual rotation of the valve while the machine was still at operational temperature (approximately 280°F). Without warning, a pressurized release of hot plastic resin and steam escaped from a hairline crack in the valve body, spraying across Robert's hand and forearm. Robert immediately ran cold water over the affected area and alerted the night shift supervisor. The burn covered approximately 15% of his right hand and caused second-degree injuries requiring emergency medical treatment. Robert was transported to the burn center at the regional hospital where he received specialized burn care, pain management, and dressing changes. He was hospitalized for 3 days and provided with a prescription for pain management and wound care protocols. Robert was placed on restricted duty for 14 days before returning to full production duties.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM, quality inspector Catherine Leblanc was conducting a routine inspection of finished composite parts in the Quality Control Laboratory when she noticed a skin irritation on her left forearm. She had been handling several parts that were being tested for surface finish quality using acetone-based cleaning solutions. Despite wearing latex gloves, the solvent had apparently seeped through a small tear in the glove that she had not noticed. The affected area showed mild redness and localized itching. Leblanc immediately washed the area with soap and water and reported the incident to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen. First aid was applied with hydrocortisone cream and an antihistamine was administered by the on-site health support personnel. The incident was minor and resolved within 30 minutes. No medical leave was required. The employee was advised to use nitrile gloves with longer cuffs in the future when handling solvents.

On April 2, 2025, at 8:45 AM during the day shift, injection molding operator Bruno Landry (Line D) sustained a significant thermal burn while clearing a material jam on his assigned machine. Landry had noticed that the extruder temperature was running higher than normal and attempted to manually clear what he believed was a blockage in the hopper area. While reaching toward the material feed point, his right forearm made direct contact with the heated barrel surface, which was maintaining an operating temperature of approximately 240°C (464°F). The contact lasted approximately 2-3 seconds before he pulled his arm away. A full-thickness thermal burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters was sustained on the lateral aspect of his right forearm, with partial-thickness burns extending an additional 5 square centimeters. Production Supervisor Michael Chen immediately applied cold water irrigation for 15 minutes and called emergency medical services. Landry was transported to the hospital's burn unit where he was treated and admitted for observation. He required a 10-day hospitalization and extensive wound care. The incident resulted in lost work time and significant medical intervention.

On May 8, 2025, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, material handler Amani Mwangi sustained a back injury while manually lifting and moving 25-kg bags of polypropylene resin from a pallet to a staging area near the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The shipment had arrived from the supplier and required inventory processing. Mwangi was working alone in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (exterior zone) when he lifted an incorrectly positioned bag from the pallet with an awkward twisting motion, loading it into a materials cart. He immediately felt acute lower back pain in the L4-L5 region. He attempted to continue working but the pain intensified, forcing him to stop. He reported the injury to Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur via radio. Emergency medical assessment was conducted on-site, followed by transport to urgent care. Medical imaging revealed a moderate lumbar strain with some disc bulging. Mwangi was prescribed 5 days of medical leave, physical therapy, and restrictions on lifting over 10 kg for 3 weeks. This resulted in loss of production capacity and medical costs.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), a Machine Setter working in Injection Molding Line D (Consumer Packaging), was performing routine mold changeover procedures on a 250-ton injection molding machine. While manually positioning a heated mold assembly (approximately 180°C) into the machine's cavity plate, the mold slipped from the lifting fixture due to inadequate grip surface on the handling brackets. The mold dropped onto Ibrahim's left hand and forearm, causing immediate severe thermal and crush injuries. Ibrahim sustained second-degree burns across his palm and fingers, as well as a fractured radius in his left forearm. The incident was witnessed by Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician working on the adjacent line. Emergency response was initiated immediately, with first aid applied and Ibrahim transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval. Lost time from work: 47 days during recovery and rehabilitation.

On April 3, 2024 at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit, was transferring finished composite parts from a curing oven to a cooling station using a metal transfer cart. As she was lifting a large fiber-reinforced plastic panel (approximately 8 kg) from the oven shelf, a small amount of loose glass fiber insulation material dislodged from the oven door frame and fell directly toward her face. She instinctively turned to the side, preventing direct eye contact, but received fiber particles across her cheek and neck area. Rania immediately reported the incident and was taken to the first aid station where superficial skin irritation was observed. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, responded and provided immediate rinse protocol. Medical assessment determined the exposure was minor with no lasting effects, classified as a near-miss with potential for serious eye injury if direct contact had occurred. The employee resumed work after 15 minutes of observation.

On April 22, 2024 at 11:45 PM during the night shift, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler working in the Regrind and Recycling Department, was performing routine cleaning and maintenance of the plastic regrind equipment. While flushing the grinder discharge chute with water to clear accumulated residue, he inadvertently directed contaminated rinse water containing traces of uncured polyurethane resin, coupling agent solvents, and glass fiber fragments into the facility's wastewater collection sump without proper segregation. The contaminated water mixed with approximately 200 liters of standard industrial waste already in the sump. The discharge pathway led directly to the municipal sanitary sewer system serving the Laval industrial park. This breach was discovered 8 hours later when the night shift supervisor noticed discoloration in the wastewater and conducted an investigation. Environmental monitoring indicated the discharge contained volatile organic compounds (VOCs) exceeding provincial limits by approximately 340%. The incident triggered mandatory notification to CNESST and Quebec's Ministry of Environment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) was operating Line A injection molding machine when the cooling water system began leaking from a corroded fitting on the main supply manifold. The operator noticed water spraying across the machine control panel and floor. Within seconds, the leak worsened and water contacted an exposed electrical connection on the machine's hydraulic pump motor, causing an electrical short circuit and complete system shutdown. The machine's safety interlocks failed to engage properly due to the electrical fault, leaving the mold in a partially open position. A second operator, Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), approached to assist and slipped on the wet floor, narrowly avoiding contact with the hot mold cavity. The machine required emergency shutdown by Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185). Investigation revealed the cooling manifold fitting had been corroded for several weeks due to inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling. The failure resulted in 8 hours of production downtime, approximately $12,000 in lost output, and near-miss injury potential from the electrical hazard and slipping hazard.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) was conducting post-molding inspections at her workstation in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area when she accidentally contacted a freshly ejected plastic component still at approximately 65°C (149°F). The part had been removed from the injection mold less than 30 seconds prior and was placed on the inspection conveyor without adequate cooling time. Patel touched the inside surface of a medical device housing component and immediately experienced thermal burns across the palm and three fingers of her right hand. She immediately immersed her hand in nearby cool water and reported the injury to her supervisor. First aid assessment revealed first-degree burns across approximately 15% of the affected area with mild blistering on the index and middle fingers. The employee was treated on-site by the company nurse with topical antibiotic ointment and sterile bandaging. No hospitalization was required, but the employee experienced pain and limited hand function for 4 days, resulting in modified duty assignment during recovery. Root cause analysis identified that the automatic part ejection timing had drifted, allowing parts to be routed to inspection before reaching safe handling temperature.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the evening shift, a fire incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C) when reclaimable plastic scrap material spontaneously ignited inside a collection hopper. Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) had been consolidating regrind material from multiple processing lines throughout the shift. The hopper contents, consisting primarily of recycled polypropylene (PP) and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) mixed with residual processing oils and heat-releasing exothermic additives, accumulated to approximately 300 kg. Due to inadequate ventilation in the storage area and poor heat dissipation from the densely packed material, internal temperatures exceeded the ignition point of the resin blend. At 11:32 PM, visible flames emerged from the top of the hopper, followed by thick black smoke. Osman immediately activated the facility's emergency alarm and evacuated the area. Evening shift supervisor Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) discovered the fire during a perimeter check and deployed a nearby Class D dry powder extinguisher (appropriate for metal fires but ineffective on polymer fires). The fire spread to adjacent cardboard scrap boxes and wooden pallet storage. Building facility manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) and local fire department responders arrived within 8 minutes. The fire was extinguished using ABC dry powder and water fog suppression after 23 minutes of active firefighting. The incident resulted in complete destruction of the collection hopper ($18,000 loss), damage to surrounding materials ($7,500 loss), evacuation of 45 night shift employees for 3 hours, and one firefighter treated for minor smoke inhalation. Root cause investigation identified inadequate fire suppression system design for the regrind department, lack of ventilation controls, and use of inappropriate fire extinguisher types.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic failure occurred in Injection Molding Line C's hydraulic pressure system. Production Engineer Sébastien Carrier was conducting routine quality checks near the molding station when the main hydraulic line connecting to the injection cylinder ruptured without warning. High-pressure hydraulic fluid sprayed across the clean room area, coating equipment and the surrounding workspace. The sudden loss of pressure caused the injection platen to drop unexpectedly, though no personnel were directly struck. Carrier immediately activated the emergency stop and notified Maintenance. Technician Luc Girard responded within minutes and isolated the hydraulic system. The rupture was traced to a hairline fracture in the steel tubing that had developed over months due to vibration and inadequate support bracket maintenance. Approximately 40 liters of hydraulic fluid leaked onto the production floor, requiring hazmat containment procedures. The incident halted production for 8 hours while repairs were completed. Environmental cleanup and disposal of contaminated materials cost approximately €4,200.

On December 3, 2024, at 10:15 AM, an electrical control panel failure occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard was attempting to troubleshoot a malfunctioning programmable logic controller (PLC) when the 480-volt main distribution panel experienced an internal fault. The primary disconnect switch failed to respond to manual activation, trapping electrical load on the circuit. When Girard attempted to manually reset a circuit breaker, a capacitor bank inside the panel discharged unexpectedly, creating an arc flash that scorched the panel interior and caused visible damage to internal components. The incident triggered an automatic facility-wide power cut-off due to the integrated safety relay system. No personnel were injured due to adequate distance and PPE, but the panel sustained approximately €18,000 in damage to internal wiring, bus bars, and terminal blocks. The facility was without primary electrical power for 6 hours while the panel was inspected, the fault isolated, and temporary power restored. Root cause analysis identified that the capacitor bank was 14 years old, well beyond its 10-year design life, and had not been replaced during the facility's 2022 electrical upgrade.

On December 10, 2024, at 4:20 PM during evening shift transition, a near-miss incident was identified in the Raw Materials Warehouse. Forklift Operator Claude Poirier was moving a pallet stack of raw plastic resin (approximately 1,200 kg) from the receiving dock when he noticed that one of the four pallet feet was not properly seated on the forks. The load was shifted slightly to the left and appeared unstable. Rather than continuing to the storage location, Poirier immediately lowered the load to the ground at the current position. Material Handler Bianca De Luca, who was staging incoming shipments, witnessed the event and alerted Warehouse Supervisor Normand Vaillancourt. Investigation revealed that the pallet had been damaged during shipping—one corner post was cracked, reducing its structural integrity. Had Poirier accelerated sharply, taken a turn at speed, or encountered an obstacle, the pallet would likely have tipped from the forks, creating a crush hazard for personnel and potential chemical exposure from broken resin bags. The damaged pallet was immediately segregated and marked as unsafe. Receiving procedures were reviewed to identify how the damaged pallet passed initial inspection. Root cause was found to be incomplete damage assessment during the receiving check-in process due to shift transition time pressure.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, a fire alarm was triggered in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) during the day shift. An operator, Fatou Ndiaye, was performing routine maintenance on a resin dryer unit when she noticed excessive heat emanating from the equipment and a burning plastic smell. The dryer's temperature control system had malfunctioned, causing the internal temperature to exceed safe operating parameters by approximately 85°C. Plastic resin granules began to char and emit smoke, triggering the facility's smoke detection system and activating the fire alarm at 2:17 PM. The facility initiated immediate evacuation procedures. The Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed no active fire but identified charred material inside the dryer. The equipment was shut down and cooling systems activated. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed a critical gap in preventive maintenance scheduling for temperature monitoring systems on drying equipment. The root cause was identified as a failed thermal sensor that had not been replaced during the last scheduled maintenance cycle in September.

On December 3, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, conducted a routine workstation ergonomic assessment in the Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components facility (UNIT-003). During her inspection, she identified that Fatima-Zahra El Amrani, an Assembly Operator, was experiencing progressive discomfort in her right wrist and forearm consistent with repetitive strain injury (RSI) symptoms. The operator reported that over the past three weeks, she has been performing continuous part removal and quality checking operations without job rotation or adequate rest breaks. Her workstation lacked proper ergonomic supports and her wrist positioning during part extraction was suboptimal. While no acute injury had occurred, the early signs of occupational strain were clearly evident through employee reporting and postural observation. This preventive declaration identified the hazard before it could develop into a reportable injury or lost-time claim. The root causes were identified as: insufficient job rotation practices, absence of ergonomic workstation modifications, and inadequate break scheduling in the production schedule.

On December 7, 2024, at 9:45 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). Machine Operator Abdul Rahman was operating a propane-powered forklift to move palletized finished goods when he noticed the vehicle's engine idling roughly and the cabin beginning to fill with a faint hazy vapor. He immediately recognized potential carbon monoxide accumulation from incomplete propane combustion. Abdul shut down the forklift, exited the vehicle, and notified his supervisor. The dock was manually ventilated by opening large bay doors, and all personnel were moved to fresh air. A portable carbon monoxide detector reading taken 15 minutes later showed CO levels of 32 ppm (OSHA permissible exposure limit is 50 ppm ceiling but 35 ppm for 8-hour TWA). No employee reported symptoms of CO exposure, but the incident clearly demonstrated the potential for hazardous exposure. The root cause was identified as a clogged propane burner nozzle that had not been serviced during the last scheduled maintenance, causing incomplete combustion and CO generation. Abdul's quick recognition and decisive action prevented what could have been a serious multi-person exposure incident.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a Production Operator, was removing finished parts from Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone of the Main Production Building. While performing repetitive part removal operations from the mold cavity, she experienced sharp pain in her right wrist and forearm. The operator had been performing this task continuously for 3.5 hours without breaks, removing approximately 800 parts per hour with forceful hand motions and gripping actions. Co-worker Indira Singh (EMP-00104), a Quality Auditor, noticed Leila favoring her right hand and called for assistance. Upon examination by the emergency response team leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Leila exhibited signs of acute repetitive strain with swelling and reduced grip strength. The incident was reported immediately to the EHS Coordinator. Leila was transported to the on-site first aid station for initial assessment and ice therapy. The operator was instructed to seek medical evaluation at an urgent care facility for proper diagnosis and treatment recommendations.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, was processing recycled plastic material in the Material Drying and Preparation Room when he sustained a minor laceration to his left index finger. While manually feeding shredded regrind material into the dryer hopper, his finger made contact with a sharp edge on a piece of contaminated regrind material that contained fragments of a mold component. The sharp edge created a 1-inch laceration on the dorsal surface of his finger, resulting in minor bleeding. Rene Caron (EMP-00097), a Tool Maker working nearby, immediately provided first aid by cleaning the wound with sterile gauze and applying direct pressure. The wound was then treated with an antiseptic solution and covered with a sterile adhesive bandage at the on-site first aid station. Oscar was advised to monitor the wound for signs of infection and to keep the bandage clean and dry. No sutures were required, and the operator was able to return to light duties within 30 minutes.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 5:30 PM during the evening shift, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter, sustained a significant burn injury to his right hand and forearm while performing maintenance on an injection molding machine. While adjusting hydraulic connections on Line D, a pressurized injection nozzle unexpectedly released a burst of superheated molten plastic at approximately 280°C (536°F). The plastic contacted approximately 15% of his right hand and forearm, causing second-degree burns across the dorsal surface of the hand and partial thickness burns on the inner forearm. Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), another Injection Molding Operator on Line D, immediately recognized the emergency and activated the emergency eyewash/shower station. Robert partially cooled the affected area with water from the shower for approximately 2 minutes. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified and initiated emergency protocols, contacting emergency medical services at 5:42 PM. Robert was transported by ambulance to the nearest burn trauma center where he was admitted with a diagnosis of second-degree and partial-thickness thermal burns requiring 4 weeks of medical treatment and 3 weeks off work. Investigation revealed that the pressure relief valve on the injection nozzle had not been properly maintained and the lockout/tagout procedures were not followed during the equipment adjustment.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:47 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area when she noticed discoloration on several molded parts. Upon investigation, she discovered that mold release agent had accumulated on the mold surface and was transferring to the components, compromising product quality. While attempting to manually clean the mold with a cloth, Sana inadvertently made direct skin contact with the mold release agent on her right forearm and wrist. The chemical caused immediate skin irritation and a localized allergic reaction with redness, swelling, and mild burning sensations. Quality Supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079) was notified and immediately directed Sana to the first aid station where her arm was rinsed with water and soap. The incident was documented, and Sana was advised to monitor for further symptoms. She continued her shift with a bandage and topical hydrocortisone cream applied to the affected area. No lost time resulted from the incident.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing scheduled maintenance on an overhead crane in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). While working from a 6-foot aluminum ladder to access the crane's electrical junction box, Alain lost his footing due to an uneven floor surface covered with residual water from earlier cleaning operations. He fell backward off the ladder, landing on his lower back and left hip against a concrete storage shelf. The fall resulted in immediate pain and inability to move without assistance. Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), who was present in the area, immediately called for emergency response. First responders arrived within 8 minutes. Alain was transported to Hopital du Sacre-Coeur and admitted with a fractured left hip and compression fracture of the L4 vertebra. He underwent surgical intervention and remained hospitalized for 5 days. Total lost time from work: 42 days (6 weeks off-site recovery and light duty). Incident was immediately reported to CNESST per Quebec regulations.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) was conducting routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B when he noticed excessive plastic material accumulating in the hopper. While attempting to clear the overflow manually using a wooden rod, the material suddenly shifted and the hopper partially released its contents. Zaidi quickly stepped back, avoiding direct contact with the hot plastic material. However, approximately 15 kg of polypropylene resin at 80°C spilled onto the floor and workstation area, creating a hazardous condition. The material cooled and solidified, blocking emergency access to the equipment shutdown controls. Immediate area evacuation was initiated, and the spill was contained using the facility's standard cleanup procedure. No personnel were physically injured, but the near-miss was serious given the proximity to the operator and the potential for severe thermal burns. Witness Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant observed the incident and immediately notified the Occupational Health Nurse. The incident demonstrated gaps in preventive maintenance protocols for hopper overflow management.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) and Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) were conducting inventory management in the Materials Drying and Preparation Room. While repositioning a large storage rack containing fiber reinforcement materials (approximately 800 kg), the forklift operator inadvertently struck the base of the rack with excessive force. The collision caused the rack to become unstable and tip over onto an adjacent workbench containing quality control testing equipment worth approximately $28,000, including a UV light exposure chamber and calibration instruments. The equipment was damaged beyond economical repair. Additionally, several containers of glass fiber reinforcement material scattered across the floor, creating a minor containment issue. No personnel were injured as the area was cleared before the collapse. The incident resulted in production delays for medical device components requiring the damaged testing equipment.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Composite Materials Operator Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086) was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area preparing reinforced plastic composites using glass fiber and epoxy resin. While transferring a container of hardened epoxy resin mix from one work surface to another, Abdallah's grip slipped on the container and it fell onto the counter edge. The container fractured, and residual uncured epoxy resin splashed onto her left hand and forearm. Due to the thermal exothermic properties of the epoxy, Abdallah experienced immediate burning sensation and contacted dermatitis within seconds. She immediately rinsed the affected area with cool water for approximately 10 minutes and reported to the Occupational Health Nurse. Examination revealed second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of the hand and forearm, with blistering evident. Abdallah was provided on-site wound care and referred to a local hospital emergency department where she received treatment including pain management and sterile dressing application. She required 3 days of medical leave for wound management and was cleared to return to light duty on day 4. The incident was classified as a recordable injury requiring OSHA documentation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Céline Morin (EMP-00153) was working at Line A in the Main Production Building when she noticed the mold closing speed appeared slower than normal. While investigating the issue, she observed hydraulic fluid beginning to drip from a connection point on the injection molding machine. She immediately stopped the machine and notified her supervisor. The cooling water system connection had begun to separate due to vibration-induced loosening of the fitting, which could have resulted in a significant leak flooding the production area. Céline's quick observation prevented potential equipment damage, chemical spillage, and worker exposure to pressurized hydraulic fluid. The incident was reported within 30 minutes of discovery. Maintenance was called and the connection was re-secured and tested before resuming operations.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 AM, Packaging Operator Amina Ba (EMP-00164) was removing finished plastic components from a finished goods pallet at the Packaging and Labeling Station when she sustained a laceration to her left palm. A sharp edge on one of the plastic parts protruding from the packaging caught her hand as she reached for a component. The cut was approximately 2 inches long and required 7 stitches at the urgent care clinic. Amina had been wearing standard work gloves, but the particular component design had an unforeseen sharp burr that was not caught during quality inspection. Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) was present and immediately provided first aid and accompanied Amina to medical treatment. The incident was reported to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen within one hour. Investigation revealed that the mold used to produce this component had developed micro-fractures causing the burr.

On April 18, 2024, at 11:30 PM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent (silicone-based) from the storage area to a mixing station when the drum's bung fitting became loose, likely due to improper seating during the previous shift's use. Approximately 20 gallons of mold release agent spilled onto the concrete floor before the leak was noticed. The strong solvent fumes immediately filled the 400 sq ft storage building. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) was performing night shift facility checks and smelled the fumes within 5 minutes. He immediately evacuated René, activated the emergency ventilation system, and notified the HSE on-call manager. The spill was contained using absorbent granules and disposed of according to provincial hazardous waste protocols. No employees required hospitalization, but René experienced mild eye irritation and headache lasting 2 hours after fresh air exposure.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B when he sustained a minor burn injury. While checking the temperature calibration on a mold cavity, Robert inadvertently made contact with the heated mold surface at approximately 85°C. The incident occurred in the Main Production Building's North Zone during the day shift. Robert was wearing standard nitrile gloves, which provided minimal thermal protection. He immediately withdrew his hand and reported a first-degree burn to his left palm approximately 2 inches in diameter. A coworker, Maxime Boisvert (Production Supervisor), witnessed the incident and immediately directed Robert to the first aid station where cold water treatment was applied for 10 minutes. The burn was cleaned and dressed with antibiotic ointment and a sterile gauze bandage. Robert returned to light duty work within 30 minutes. The incident was reported to the HSE office by Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi. Root cause analysis identified inadequate thermal PPE guidance for the specific maintenance task.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, sustained a moderate back strain injury while unloading plastic pellet bags from a delivery truck in the Warehouse and Shipping area (Section C - Regrind and Recycling Department). Elif was attempting to manually remove a 25 kg bag of virgin polycarbonate resin from the truck bed without using the forklift, as the vehicle positioning made forklift access difficult. The bag was stacked three levels high, and Elif lifted from a bent-back position rather than properly engaging the legs. Upon lifting, Elif felt acute lower back pain and immediately set the bag down. Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), the Warehouse Supervisor, witnessed the incident and instructed Elif to stop work immediately. Elif reported pain radiating from the L4-L5 region. First aid responder assessed and recommended medical evaluation. Elif attempted to continue work but experienced increasing discomfort. By 23:00, HSE was notified by Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois. Elif was sent for medical evaluation at an urgent care facility and diagnosed with acute lumbar strain with muscle spasm. Initial prognosis: 3-5 days of modified duty recommended.

On April 3, 2024 at 05:30 during the night shift, Georges Plante (EMP-00179), a Facilities Technician, fell from a 6-foot extension ladder while performing preventive maintenance on the ventilation system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. Georges was attempting to clean accumulated dust from an overhead air intake duct when the ladder unexpectedly shifted on the concrete floor due to an uneven surface. The shift caused Georges to lose balance and grip the ladder frame with his left hand as he fell backward approximately 5 feet, landing on his left shoulder and back on a concrete floor. Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), a Material Handler working night shift inventory, heard the impact and immediately called for emergency assistance. Georges reported acute pain in the left shoulder and was unable to move his left arm. Emergency response was initiated at 05:35, and paramedics arrived at 05:50. Georges was immobilized and transported to a local hospital via ambulance. Medical evaluation revealed a left shoulder dislocation with associated rotator cuff strain and two fractured ribs (ribs 4 and 5 on the left side). Hospitalization was required for 2 days with orthopedic consultation. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante was notified immediately and documented the incident. Georges was placed on lost-time injury status, requiring approximately 8 weeks of recovery with modified duty restrictions.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Céline Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine mold cleaning in the Main Production Building's South Zone when she noticed the machine control panel displaying an unusual error code. Before she could alert her supervisor Maxime Boisvert, the injection molding machine unexpectedly initiated its cycle while the mold cavity was still open and her hand was positioned near the mold closing mechanism. The machine began its closing sequence, and Céline's left hand was suddenly at risk of being caught. She reflexively withdrew her hand just as the mold closed, missing her fingers by approximately 2 centimeters. No physical contact occurred, but the incident created an immediate hazardous situation. Maxime Boisvert responded immediately, emergency-stopped the machine, and reported the near-miss to the HSE department. Investigation revealed the error code was triggered by a malfunctioning pressure sensor that failed to detect the mold was open, bypassing critical safety interlocks designed to prevent cycle initiation.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a Machine Operator, noticed the ventilation system in the Main Production Building serving the composite materials processing area was producing significantly reduced airflow. She observed visible resin fumes accumulating near her workstation that normally would be immediately extracted. The HVAC system had begun making an irregular grinding noise earlier in the shift. When Hawa reported this to maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), an inspection revealed the main exhaust fan bearing had seized due to inadequate lubrication, causing the motor to overheat and reduce speed significantly. The bearing temperature reached 87°C, well above safe operating parameters. The equipment failure directly compromised the ventilation system's ability to capture composite fiber dust and resin vapors, creating a respiratory hazard for all workers in the zone. Alain immediately isolated the system and placed an out-of-service notice. Emergency portable ventilation units were deployed while the bearing assembly was replaced.

On November 20, 2024, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, completed her routine ergonomic self-assessment during the start of her day shift and reported cumulative wrist and hand discomfort consistent with repetitive strain patterns developing over the past 8 weeks. While working in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room, Rania spends approximately 6 hours daily performing precise hand-mixing operations of fiber-reinforced resin compounds, requiring significant gripping force and repetitive wrist flexion/extension motions. She proactively reported her symptoms to Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) before pain escalated to a work-limiting injury level. Alain conducted a workstation assessment and identified that Rania's current work surface height was 4 inches above optimal ergonomic positioning for her height (5'2"), forcing compensatory shoulder elevation and increased wrist strain. The mixing vessel positioning required her to reach across her body, creating additional strain. Her current task rotation allowed only 15 minutes of varied activities per 8-hour shift, failing to provide adequate micro-break relief. This preventive declaration captures the early indicators of potential carpal tunnel syndrome development before injury becomes recordable.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was working at Injection Molding Line D removing cooled parts from the mold cavity. While extracting a medical-grade polycarbonate component, his left hand became caught between the mold platen and the ejector pin assembly as the machine completed its automatic cycle. The machine's safety interlock had been bypassed due to a maintenance override that was not properly documented or removed. Charbonneau's middle finger sustained a laceration and crushing injury with partial bone involvement. He immediately called for assistance, and Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180) responded and administered first aid while summoning emergency services. The employee was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé with a confirmed fracture to the middle finger metacarpal. The incident was declared by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) following emergency response protocols.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire suppression system accidental discharge occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Automation Technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) was performing routine electrical maintenance on an automated fiber-layup system and inadvertently struck the ceiling-mounted sprinkler head with a calibration tool while reaching to access upper control panels. The impact triggered the dry-pipe suppression system, which discharged pressurized water across approximately 800 square feet of the production area. The discharge affected three composite molding presses and damaged approximately $42,000 in raw materials (spools of carbon fiber and resin pre-impregnated materials) stored nearby. No personnel were injured, but Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) and Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) evacuated the area and initiated containment procedures. The incident was declared by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) following facility protocols.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was retrieving boxes of processed polymer pellets from a high storage rack in the Regrind and Recycling Department. As he reached to grasp the third box from the top shelf, the supporting cardboard corrugated box directly above his head began to slip due to moisture damage from a recent roof leak. The box shifted approximately 2 inches and made audible creaking sounds. Habib immediately stepped backward and looked up, recognizing the imminent hazard. He called out a warning to alert nearby warehouse associates and moved to a safe position 8 feet away. The box remained precariously balanced but did not fall during his observation period of approximately 90 seconds. He then notified Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) and together they safely removed the unstable box using a forklift and placed it on the ground for inspection. The box contained approximately 200 pounds of material and would have caused serious head and spinal injury had it fallen. The incident was declared by Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) following near-miss reporting procedures.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was organizing polypropylene resin bags in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) when he noticed an air hose running across the floor creating a potential trip hazard. Rather than moving the hose immediately, Mwangi continued working and began repositioning bags near the hose. While turning to reach a stack of bags, his foot caught on the air hose and he stumbled but managed to catch himself on a nearby shelf unit, preventing a fall. Coworker Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) from Quality Control witnessed the near-miss incident. The hose had been positioned that morning by maintenance staff during equipment calibration and was left unsecured. Mwangi reported the incident to Training Coordinator Amélie Roy within 30 minutes. No injury occurred, but the incident highlighted a systematic failure in housekeeping protocols and the need for better cable management in high-traffic areas.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Composite Materials Operator Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174) was processing fiber-reinforced plastic (FRP) components in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Unit-005) when she noticed an abnormal odor and white vapors emanating from a 200-liter storage tank containing acetone-based cleaning solvent. The tank pressure gauge showed 2.8 bar (higher than the normal 0.5 bar range). Sokolova immediately evacuated the area and activated the facility emergency alarm at 6:32 AM. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) arrived within minutes and confirmed the pressure buildup. The facility HSE team, including Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157), responded and isolated the area with barrier tape. Environmental response procedures were initiated. Investigation revealed that the tank had been stored near a heat source (an improperly placed portable heater used during routine maintenance) for the previous 8 hours, causing pressure and vapor buildup. No vapor release occurred beyond the immediate storage area, and external air circulation prevented off-site impacts. However, approximately 15 liters of product were lost to evaporation.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, sustained a thermal burn while performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D. Pascal was inspecting the nozzle temperature sensor on the extruder barrel when a small amount of molten plastic residue (~200°C) dripped from the heating element directly onto the dorsal surface of his right hand between the thumb and index finger. The employee immediately submerged the affected area in cold water at the nearby emergency eyewash station. First aid was administered by the on-site health and safety coordinator, consisting of gentle cleansing, application of topical antibiotic ointment, and non-adherent sterile gauze dressing. The burn area measured approximately 2cm x 1.5cm and was classified as a first-degree thermal injury with minimal blistering. Pascal remained at work for the remainder of the shift, maintaining the dressing and monitoring for signs of infection. The incident occurred because the insulation jacket on the nozzle had degraded over time, and no protective gloves rated for high-temperature contact were being worn during the inspection. The employee completed an incident report and attended a brief toolbox talk regarding thermal hazards.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a Material Handler, was transferring a 20-liter container of mold release agent (silicone-based, WHMIS-classified irritant) from the storage shelf to a cart when the container's cap was inadvertently left partially unscrewed. As Marwa tilted the container to position it on the cart, approximately 8-10 liters of the oily liquid spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous slick surface approximately 4 meters in length and 2 meters in width. The spill pooled near the base of a metal shelving unit and began to create vapors. Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate working nearby, immediately recognized the hazard and alerted Marwa, then contacted Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), the Environmental Compliance Specialist on call. Nathalie responded within 8 minutes with absorbent materials and initiated containment procedures. The warehouse area was evacuated to prevent slip hazards and vapor inhalation. No employees were injured, but the spill required 90 minutes to fully contain and remediate. The root cause was identified as inadequate training on proper container handling and the absence of spill prevention trays for chemical transfers.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during night shift operations, a near-miss incident was narrowly averted in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (Unit 017). Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician - Night Shift, was performing routine lubrication of the conveyor drive mechanism on the heat treatment oven. Per standard procedure, Alain had applied a LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) lock to the main electrical panel and placed his personal tag. However, due to inadequate lighting in the maintenance access area and fatigue from the night shift, Alain did not notice that the motor had been re-energized by another technician who was unaware of the ongoing maintenance work. As Alain reached toward the conveyor drive belt to apply lubricant, the belt suddenly engaged and began rotating at operational speed. Alain's sleeve caught momentarily on the edge of the drive assembly, causing him to pull his arm back reflexively. The sleeve tore but his arm was not drawn into the mechanism. Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021), a Mold Technician, observed the incident from across the room and immediately called out a warning, prompting Alain to step back. The incident lasted approximately 3 seconds before the machinery cycled through and disengaged. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the secondary LOTO procedure requiring verification of all locks before equipment restart was not being followed consistently. Additionally, the maintenance area lacked adequate lighting for detailed work in low-visibility zones.

On February 28, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift operations in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C), Material Handler Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) was manually loading ground plastic material into a hopper feeder when the hopper overflow mechanism malfunctioned. The material continued to be fed into the system despite reaching maximum capacity. Beaudoin attempted to manually divert the overflow by redirecting material flow using his hands and a metal scoop. Approximately 12 kilograms of hot resin material (at approximately 180°C) spilled directly onto his left forearm and hand. The material adhered to his skin, causing second and third-degree thermal burns across a 15cm area. Witness Luc Girard, Maintenance Technician (EMP-00039), was nearby and immediately used cold water rinse from the emergency eyewash station, then contacted Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052). Beaudoin was transported to the burn center at Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur. Treatment required skin grafting and resulted in 8 weeks of medical leave. The incident root cause was lack of preventive maintenance on the hopper overflow sensor.

On April 2, 2024, at 1:30 AM during night shift in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (East Section), Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was working on replacing a faulty pneumatic valve assembly when he inadvertently depressed the compressed air trigger mechanism without proper isolation. High-pressure air (approximately 8 bar) was directed at his left hand at close range, causing a compressed air injection injury to his palm. The penetrating wound allowed pressurized air to enter tissue planes, creating subcutaneous emphysema. Caron immediately recognized the severity and activated the emergency alarm. Crane Operator Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), the only other worker in the vicinity, called emergency services. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) was notified and provided incident support. Caron was transported by ambulance to the hand surgery unit at Hôpital de Sacré-Cœur where he underwent emergency decompression and antibiotic treatment. The injury required 4 weeks of restricted duty and resulted in temporary loss of fine motor control in his left hand. Investigation revealed that Caron had not followed the compressed air isolation procedures outlined in the LOTO standard.

On March 15, 2025, at 2:45 PM, Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050), a Production Operator on the Day Shift, was working at Injection Molding Line B when she experienced a sharp pain in her left index finger. While removing cooled plastic components from the mold cavity, her finger made contact with a jagged edge on a poorly finished part ejector pin. The contact caused a superficial laceration approximately 1.5 cm long on the dorsal surface of her finger. The wound bled moderately but was controlled within 2 minutes using direct pressure. The injured employee immediately reported to the First Aid station where the cut was cleaned, assessed for depth (determined to be minor, not requiring stitches), and dressed with antibiotic ointment and a sterile bandage. Fatou remained at work and continued her duties with a protective glove over the bandage. No lost work time occurred. Her supervisor, Sébastien Carrier (Production Engineer), was notified and examined the equipment. The incident was witnessed by fellow operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) who alerted Fatou to seek immediate treatment.

On March 18, 2025, during the Evening Shift (4:15 PM start time), Sanaa Rachidi, Fire Safety Coordinator, was conducting routine inspection of the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) when she identified a potential fire hazard in the Tool Room storage area. A significant accumulation of plastic dust and resin powder was observed on horizontal surfaces, electrical equipment, and in elevated areas above machinery. The dust layer, estimated at 2-5 mm thickness, had accumulated over several weeks due to insufficient ventilation and incomplete cleanup procedures following grinding and finishing operations. Sanaa immediately notified Roland Dostie, Maintenance Planner, and Luc Girard, Maintenance Technician, of the hazardous condition.
