The area was cordoned off with warning tape, and all hot work operations were suspended pending remediation. Investigation revealed that the workshop's dustcollection system had experienced partial blockage in one of three main ductwork sections, reducing airflow by approximately 40%. The dust accumulation represented a significant ignition risk given the proximity of electrical equipment and occasional grinding operations. This finding was classified as a Preventive Declaration to document the hazard and initiate corrective action before an incident occurred.

On March 22, 2025, at 12:30 AM during the Night Shift, Alain Gravel, Maintenance Technician (Night Shift), was performing routine equipment checks in the Quality Control Laboratory when he inadvertently touched an exposed electrical contact on a resin analyzer unit that was being serviced. The equipment, model RTX-3000 Rheological Analyzer, had been partially disassembled by the Day Shift maintenance team to access the heating chamber for recalibration. A temporary equipment lock-out/tag-out (LOTO) had been placed on the main power disconnect, but the internal 230V circuit terminals remained live due to an isolated capacitor bank that holds charge independent of main power. Alain received a mild electrical shock (estimated 100-150mA, 230V AC) causing involuntary muscle contraction and a brief loss of balance. He immediately released contact and reported to the Night Shift supervisor. First Aid assessment showed no burns or entry/exit wounds, but Alain experienced localized tingling in his right hand and minor temporary disorientation. He was transported to the on-site medical clinic for observation and ECG monitoring (duration 2 hours). No hospitalization was required. The incident highlighted inadequate communication between shifts regarding equipment status and incomplete de-energization procedures for equipment with isolated power storage systems.

On March 15, 2025 at 10:30 AM, production operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was working on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building when she noticed excessive heat emanating from the mold assembly and unusual pressure readings on the control panel. Before activating the emergency shutdown, she alerted her supervisor to the anomaly. Upon inspection, maintenance technician discovered a hairline fracture in the heating element manifold that could have resulted in a pressure release burn incident. The equipment was immediately isolated and tagged out of service. A compressed gas cartridge nearby was also found to have minor corrosion on its valve. The facility's Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator was notified to assess potential chemical vapor exposure risk in the area. The equipment remained offline for 6 hours pending replacement parts and safety verification. This preventive declaration identified a critical equipment failure before personnel injury could occur. The incident highlights the importance of operator vigilance and immediate reporting protocols.

On March 22, 2025 at 2:15 PM, material handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was retrieving plastic resin bags from the top shelf of Storage Rack Unit 7 in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room when the uppermost row of bags, weighing approximately 180 lbs total, became unstable due to improper stacking. The bags fell striking Amina on the left shoulder and upper arm. She immediately fell backward but was caught by colleague Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) who was working nearby. Amina sustained a laceration on her left arm requiring 8 stitches, significant bruising, and a sprained shoulder. Emergency medical services arrived within 12 minutes. She was transported to Hopital Sacre-Coeur for X-rays which revealed no fractures. The incident was caused by the previous shift's improper bag stacking that exceeded the rack's rated load capacity in that section. Warehouse supervisor conducted a full rack inspection and discovered three additional improperly loaded sections. CNESST was notified per Quebec workplace regulations. This lost-time injury resulted in Amina requiring 3 weeks of modified duty assignment.

On March 28, 2025 at 7:45 PM during the evening shift, composite materials operator Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086) was preparing resin mixture in the Composite Materials Processing Area when she noticed an unusual odor and slight discoloration in a batch of fiber-reinforced plastic material being processed. She immediately stopped her operation and called over her supervisor, production engineer Sébastien Carrier (EMP-00065). Upon examination, they discovered that the previous shift operator had accidentally used a contaminated regrind material batch that was stored in an unmarked container, potentially compromising the medical-grade certification of parts in production. The batch was approximately 40% through processing on Line 15. Sébastien immediately shut down the line and quarantined all parts produced from that batch for full inspection. Quality control was notified and confirmed the regrind contamination through chemical analysis. No parts reached customers. The contaminated batch was isolated in the Hazardous Waste Management Area pending disposal. This near-miss incident could have resulted in product liability, customer sanctions, and ISO 13485 certification violation if the contamination had gone undetected. The situation was resolved without customer impact or regulatory notification due to the operator's attentiveness.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Machine Operator Raoul Blanchard was performing routine material handling at Injection Molding Line A when he noticed the hopper level indicator was malfunctioning. While attempting to manually verify the resin level by looking into the top of the hopper, he observed that the automatic feed system had jammed with partially solidified polypropylene blocking the discharge chute. Rather than following proper lockout/tagout procedures, Raoul used compressed air from the facility air line to attempt to dislodge the blockage. The high-pressure air stream unexpectedly dislodged a sharp plastic fragment that struck his left hand at the base of his thumb, creating a small but bleeding laceration. Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf witnessed the incident and immediately directed Raoul to the first aid station. Facilities Manager Guillaume Deschamps assessed the wound, which required cleaning and three stitches but no hospitalization. The incident was reported by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen. Root cause analysis revealed that compressed air was being misused for purposes other than tool operation, and the lack of proper guarding on the hopper discharge created the hazard.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the evening shift, Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu was preparing a batch of adhesive bonding agent in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. While transferring a 5-liter container of isopropanol solvent from storage shelving to the mixing station, the container's cap was not properly secured. As she set the container on the work bench, approximately 200 milliliters of isopropanol spilled across the bench surface, with some liquid dripping onto the floor. Elena immediately noticed the characteristic solvent odor becoming strong and recognized the spill. She quickly moved the remaining closed containers away from the area and notified Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert, who was nearby. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen arrived within minutes and assessed the situation. The spill was contained using absorbent material and disposed of properly according to company procedure. No personal exposure occurred as Elena was wearing appropriate PPE including nitrile gloves and safety glasses. The incident was classified as a near-miss because while a chemical spill occurred, containment procedures prevented environmental release and no personnel injury resulted. Air quality monitoring in the area showed solvent vapor levels remained below OSHA permissible exposure limits due to facility ventilation.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Luc Girard was performing routine CNC milling machine maintenance in the Central Maintenance Workshop. He was removing old hydraulic oil from the primary injection mold cooling system using a hand pump and collection container. While working beneath the elevated mold assembly, the temporary support jack began to slip due to inadequate floor preparation around the work area. The mold assembly, weighing approximately 850 pounds, descended rapidly and struck Girard's left leg just above the knee. Girard immediately called for help using the emergency communication system. Forklift Operator Roberto Santos, who was working nearby in the warehouse area, heard the call and quickly contacted Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette. Paquette arrived within 3 minutes and assessed the injury. Girard had a compound fracture of the left femur with significant swelling and bruising. Emergency Medical Services were activated immediately, and Girard was transported to Centre Hospitalier Régional where he underwent surgical intervention for femur fixation. He remained hospitalized for 4 days and returned home with restrictions requiring 8 weeks of medical leave and physical rehabilitation. This was classified as a lost-time injury resulting in over 7 days away from work.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, a critical spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department when a bulk container of contaminated polycarbonate material ruptured during unloading from a delivery truck. Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was positioning the container using a pallet jack when the bottom seal failed, releasing approximately 180 kg of regrind material mixed with residual chemical additives across the warehouse floor. The spill covered an area of roughly 400 square feet and extended toward the adjacent raw materials storage section. Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran (EMP-00046) and Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) immediately responded to contain the spread and alert supervision. The material was traced back to a supplier quality issue—the container had not been properly sealed at the source facility. Environmental protection protocols were activated, and the contaminated material was segregated for proper hazardous waste disposal per CNESST regulations. Clean-up took approximately 6 hours with two additional staff members assisting. No personal injuries occurred, but the incident resulted in temporary shutdown of regrind operations and approximately $8,500 in material loss and remediation costs.

On November 8, 2024 at 10:20 PM during the evening shift, Production Operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) detected abnormal vibration and a grinding noise from Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone. Upon investigation by Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) and Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169), they discovered that the hydraulic pump coupling had developed severe internal wear, causing metal-to-metal contact and generating particulate contamination in the hydraulic fluid. The coupling's rubber isolator had completely degraded, reducing vibration dampening to near zero. While investigating the noise source, Technician Giguère observed a small hydraulic fluid leak pooling beneath the equipment, indicating seal degradation secondary to the coupling failure. The equipment was immediately shut down using proper LOTO procedures to prevent catastrophic coupling seizure and potential high-pressure fluid injection hazard. A complete coupling replacement and hydraulic fluid filtration cycle was required, taking the injection molding line offline for 16 hours. Root cause analysis revealed that preventive maintenance records showed the coupling had not been formally inspected or replaced according to manufacturer specifications since 2019, representing a five-year maintenance gap. The equipment supplier confirmed that coupling assemblies typically require replacement every 3-4 years under standard production conditions.

On January 22, 2025 at 1:15 AM during the night shift, Production Operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) was performing routine part removal from Injection Molding Line A when he noticed the automated ejector mechanism had become stuck in the extended position. The hydraulic cylinder controlling the ejector ram was producing intermittent jerking motions rather than smooth operation, and the electronic limit switches appeared to be malfunctioning, preventing the safety interlocks from engaging. Mensah properly followed LOTO procedures and activated an emergency stop before manually attempting any intervention. Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) responded within 15 minutes and began diagnostic testing. He discovered that the hydraulic solenoid valve controlling the ejector function had failed, leaving the ejector ram hydraulically pressurized but unable to retract. Additionally, the proximity sensor detecting the retracted position had corroded contacts, preventing the electronic controller from confirming safe machine status. The combined failures created a significant pinch-point hazard with 35 bar hydraulic pressure continuously applied to the stuck ram. The machine remained safely locked out for 8 hours while replacement solenoid and sensor components were procured and installed. This was the third solenoid valve failure on molding lines within the past 18 months, indicating a systemic component reliability issue in the facility's hydraulic control systems.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, sustained a minor laceration to his left index finger while operating Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone of the Main Production Building. Pascal was performing routine mold cleaning and maintenance when he inadvertently contacted a sharp edge on the mold cavity while removing hardened resin buildup. The cut required immediate first aid treatment including wound cleaning, minor suturing (3 stitches), and bandaging by occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid. The injury was classified as a first-aid case with no lost time. Pascal was able to return to modified duties within 24 hours. Production supervisor Maxime Boisvert was present in the area and provided immediate assistance. The incident was caused by inadequate hand protection and lack of awareness regarding sharp points on the mold cavity during cleaning operations.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, an environmental incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). A forklift operated by an unidentified operator struck a stacked pallet of polypropylene (PP) resin bags, causing approximately 40 kilograms of loose resin pellets to spill onto the warehouse floor. The material spread across approximately 15 square meters of the concrete storage area. While PP resin itself poses minimal environmental hazard in solid form, the incident revealed improper pallet stacking height (exceeding the marked safe limit by 1.2 meters) and inadequate warehouse racking maintenance. The spilled material created a slip hazard and obstructed access to emergency equipment storage. Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette was notified and supervised cleanup. The incident was declared by safety representative Serge Lafleur. The material was swept and collected into disposal containers within 2 hours. Investigation revealed the pallet had been stored above the maximum safe height for 3 weeks, violating warehouse storage protocols.

On March 20, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Composite Materials preparation area within the Main Production Building. Samantha Brown (EMP-00146), the Composite Materials Lead, was transferring acetone (cleaning solvent) from a 20-liter industrial container to smaller working containers when the transfer hose detached from the valve connection due to improper coupling. Approximately 8 liters of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor before Brown discovered the leak and immediately closed the source valve. The spill created a visible hazard area affecting approximately 25 square meters. Fumes from the volatile solvent were detected in the adjacent production areas. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi was immediately notified and initiated spill containment procedures. The area was evacuated and ventilation systems were activated to maximum capacity. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and the contaminated material was properly disposed of in accordance with hazardous waste protocols. No personnel were directly exposed to significant vapors. The incident was caused by a loose coupling that had not been properly secured during the previous shift and inadequate inspection procedures before chemical transfers.

On March 14, 2025 at 2:15 PM, packaging operator Amina Ba (EMP-00164) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station preparing finished parts for shipment. While manually lifting a 25 kg box of molded plastic components from a lower shelf to place it on the conveyor system, she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. She had been performing repetitive lifting and bending motions throughout her 6-hour shift without proper mechanical assistance. The box slipped slightly during the lift, causing her to overextend her lumbar region. She immediately felt muscle spasm and discomfort in her lower back region. Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104), who was conducting a routine audit in the area, witnessed the incident and helped Ba sit down. Ba applied ice from the first aid station and remained on light duty for the remainder of the shift. She reported the incident to her supervisor the following morning, noting persistent soreness but no radiating pain. The incident was likely caused by inadequate ergonomic assessment of the packaging workflow and lack of mechanical lifting aids in the station.

On March 18, 2025 at 11:45 PM during the night shift, production operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) was monitoring Injection Molding Line D when he noticed resin material beginning to overflow from the material hopper. The hopper level indicator had malfunctioned and failed to alert operators that the resin level was approaching maximum capacity. Mensah attempted to manually divert incoming material by redirecting the feed chute, but approximately 15 kg of polypropylene resin pellets spilled onto the production floor around the injection molding machine base. The material scattered across approximately 2 square meters of floor space, creating a slip hazard. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie (EMP-00199), who was performing preventive maintenance nearby, quickly assisted Mensah in cleaning up the spilled material using the facility's industrial vacuum system. The spill was contained within 30 minutes. No personnel were injured, but the incident revealed that the hopper's automated level monitoring system had not been calibrated in over 8 months. The spill created a temporary operational disruption to Line D, requiring a 45-minute restart sequence.

On March 22, 2025 at 9:30 AM, maintenance supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) was performing routine inspection of the CNC milling machines in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. While checking the alignment of a cutting head on one of the five-axis CNC machines, he noticed that the machine's emergency stop (E-stop) button was difficult to press due to accumulated plastic dust and coolant residue. Mailhot attempted to clean the button with compressed air while the machine was still powered on but in standby mode. As he directed the air stream across the control panel, he accidentally bumped the cycle start button with his knee, causing the CNC spindle to rotate unexpectedly at 2,000 RPM. His left hand was positioned near the cutting tool at the moment of activation. The rotating cutter made contact with the edge of his work glove, catching approximately 2 inches of fabric but not penetrating to skin. The machine was immediately halted by pressing the E-stop button. Mailhot experienced a brief moment of alarm but confirmed no injury had occurred. Industrial Engineer Priya Sharma (EMP-00038), who was nearby conducting a process study, witnessed the near-miss event. The incident demonstrated that inadequate machine guarding protocols and poor control panel maintenance created unnecessary hazards during routine maintenance activities.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a hydraulic hose ruptured on Injection Molding Machine Line B (automotive section) in the Main Production Building's North Zone. The machine was in active operation when the hose connecting the mold clamping system failed, spraying pressurized hydraulic oil across the work area. The spray extended approximately 8 feet, coating the production floor, nearby equipment, and creating a slippery surface. Karim Bouazizi (Machine Setter) was positioned at the machine's control station and immediately initiated an emergency shutdown. The spilled hydraulic oil contaminated approximately 200 square feet of production floor and damaged electrical junction boxes serving the injection molding line. Cleanup and decontamination required 6 hours. Root cause analysis determined the hose had not been inspected during routine maintenance due to a gap in the preventive maintenance schedule. The incident was witnessed by Ahmed Hassan (Injection Molding Operator - Line B) and Rodrigue Tremblay (Machine Setter). No personnel injuries occurred, but the machinery remained offline for 14 hours pending hose replacement and electrical system inspection.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Stéphane Moreau (Mold Technician) sustained a severe thermal burn while removing a mold from Injection Molding Machine Line A. The mold, which had been in the heating chamber at 185°C, was extracted using standard metal tongs. However, a defective thermometer in the machine's display had registered an incorrect temperature of 140°C. The mold surface temperature was significantly higher than expected. When Moreau lifted the mold, his left forearm contacted the mold surface directly, resulting in a deep partial-thickness burn covering approximately 4 inches by 3 inches on the inner forearm. He immediately immersed the affected area in cool water and called for emergency assistance. Hana Al-Rashid (Occupational Health Nurse) arrived within 2 minutes and provided first aid treatment before paramedics transported Moreau to Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM) for specialist burn care. The burn required hospitalization, surgical cleaning, and application of topical antibiotic therapy. Moreau was absent from work for 12 days and received restricted duty upon return. The thermometer was found to have a calibration error exceeding acceptable tolerances.

On February 19, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Roberto Santos (Forklift Operator) was repositioning a pallet stack of raw polypropylene resin in the Warehouse and Shipping facility when the rear wheels of his forklift tilted unexpectedly on uneven floor surface. The forklift began to tip laterally while carrying approximately 2,400 pounds of material. Santos immediately abandoned the equipment by jumping from the operator seat. As he landed, his right foot caught on a cable running along the warehouse floor (used for floor heating system), causing him to fall forward. He struck his head against a metal storage rack support beam, resulting in a laceration requiring 8 stitches above his right eyebrow and a concussion with temporary loss of consciousness. He remained unconscious for approximately 90 seconds before regaining awareness. Mélanie Fortin (Shipping and Receiving Clerk) immediately called emergency services. Paramedics arrived within 8 minutes and transported Santos to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé for CT imaging and neurological evaluation. He was hospitalized for 24 hours for concussion monitoring. Subsequent investigation revealed the warehouse floor had a 2-inch elevation change that was not clearly marked, and the electrical cable was not secured or covered, creating both a tripping hazard and a contributing factor to the forklift instability.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, injection molding operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103) was operating Line A in the production area. While performing routine mold changeover procedures on a high-temperature polycarbonate injection molding machine, Paul failed to properly engage the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures before attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper assembly. The machine cycles unexpectedly, and his right hand came into direct contact with a rotating screw conveyor mechanism inside the hopper. Paul sustained a partial amputation of his right index fingertip and significant laceration to his right palm requiring emergency surgical reattachment. Process Improvement Engineer Yuki Yamamoto (EMP-00112), working nearby on Line B, witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop, cut power to the machine, and called occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052). Hana provided immediate first aid with direct pressure and ice, and paramedics transported Paul to Sacré-Cœur Hospital's emergency surgery department within 18 minutes. Root causes included inadequate LOTO training reinforcement, operator fatigue from overtime hours, and lack of real-time machine status verification systems.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, forklift operator Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167) was moving pallets of raw polypropylene resin from the Finished Goods Warehouse receiving area to the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. While navigating a tight corner near the warehouse intersection point, Hugues misjudged the turning radius of his loaded forklift. The pallet load shifted slightly, and forklift contact with a floor-mounted cable tray caused the forklift's load to tilt. Simultaneously, warehouse associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) was walking through the same corridor carrying documentation, unaware of the forklift operation. The shifting pallet load partially dropped, striking Yvon on his left shoulder and upper back, causing him to fall to the ground. Yvon sustained a fractured left scapula, severe muscle contusion, and significant pain. Hugues immediately applied emergency stop and called for assistance. Night shift supervisor (on-call) responded and contacted occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) at home; paramedics arrived in 22 minutes. Root causes included inadequate forklift operation area communication procedures, insufficient lighting in warehouse corridors, and lack of ground-level load verification systems on the equipment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) was working at an injection molding machine in the Production Operations area when her right hand became caught in the machine's closing mold cavity. She had been manually removing a finished part and failed to fully retract her hand before the machine cycle automatically resumed. A colleague, Packaging Operator Amara Diop (EMP-00110), was working nearby and immediately heard Elena's cry. The machine's safety gate had been propped open to speed up production, bypassing the standard interlocked safety system. Elena sustained lacerations and contusions to her right hand with possible fracture to the third metacarpal bone. Emergency response was initiated by Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) within 2 minutes. Elena was transported to the hospital for X-ray and treatment. The incident resulted in a 6-hour production shutdown and investigation by the HSE department.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift, Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was operating the chemical compounding mixer in the Raw Materials Warehouse when the equipment experienced a catastrophic hydraulic system failure. The hydraulic line ruptured, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid across the mixer housing. The high-pressure jet impacted Oscar's left forearm and abdomen, causing a penetrating injury. Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) was present and immediately shut down the equipment using the emergency stop button. The incident resulted in approximately 2 liters of hydraulic fluid released onto the floor, creating a slip hazard and potential environmental contamination. Oscar was treated for a laceration requiring stitches and was sent for observation due to the nature of high-pressure fluid injection injuries. The mixer was taken offline for 48 hours pending mechanical inspection and repair. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) responded to secure the area and document the hazard.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift, Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was consolidating regrind plastic material in the Hazardous Waste Management Area when he noticed an unusual odor coming from a container of acetone-based cleaning solvent stored near the regrind hoppers. Upon investigation, Hassan discovered that a 55-gallon drum of flammable solvent had developed a slow leak at its base. The leak had accumulated approximately 15 liters of volatile liquid on the concrete floor. The area's ventilation fan had stopped operating (maintenance issue from 6 days prior, not repaired). Hassan immediately activated the facility's fire alarm to alert all personnel and initiated evacuation per protocol. Fire Chief Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) coordinated emergency response. The local fire department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed an actual fire hazard due to the solvent vapors accumulating in the poorly ventilated space. No ignition source was present at the time of discovery, but the concentration of fumes exceeded safe OSHA exposure limits (1000 ppm with 200 ppm ceiling). All personnel evacuated safely. The facility was ventilated and the spill was professionally contained and cleaned by a hazmat contractor over 6 hours.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A), Material Handler Amani Mwangi was organizing plastic resin pellet bags on storage racks when he noticed an unstable stack of approximately 15 bags positioned precariously on the third shelf level. As Mwangi attempted to reposition the bags to improve stability, the entire stack suddenly shifted. He quickly stepped back and the bags tumbled down, missing him by approximately 18 inches. The bags impacted the concrete floor with significant force, with two bags rupturing and spilling approximately 40 kg of polycarbonate resin pellets across the warehouse floor. Receiving Clerk Jacques Lachance, working nearby, witnessed the near-miss and immediately assisted in containing the spill. The incident was contained within 30 minutes with no personal injury, though the damaged materials represented approximately $800 in losses. Investigation revealed that the bags had been stacked in violation of the 4-bag-per-shelf maximum protocol, and the shelf support system showed minor corrosion that had weakened structural integrity.

On November 19, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift operations in the Injection Molding Line B - Automotive (North Zone), Production Operator Aisha Kamara was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine. While cleaning the hopper area with compressed air (set to 90 PSI), she did not notice that a small debris blockage had accumulated at the hopper outlet. When she directed the compressed air stream toward the blocked area, the sudden pressure release caused a violent discharge of accumulated plastic pellets and dust mixture. The material sprayed forcefully outward, creating a momentary cloud that briefly obscured visibility. Though Kamara was wearing safety glasses, no direct eye contact occurred. The incident dispersed residual composite fiber dust that had accumulated in the hopper, causing temporary localized dust visibility. Assembly Operator Aaliyah Jackson, working at an adjacent station approximately 8 meters away, heard the discharge but was not directly impacted. The operator experienced no respiratory distress and environmental air quality returned to normal within 5 minutes. The incident highlighted inadequate hopper cleaning procedures and lack of proper isolation protocols.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift operations in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (Tool Room), Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu was preparing specialized polyester resin compound for an urgent composite manufacturing order. While manually transferring heated resin from a 10-liter mixing vessel to a smaller intermediate container using a funnel and pouring technique, the vessel slipped slightly in her hand due to condensation on the outer surface. Approximately 2 liters of resin at approximately 75°C spilled directly onto her right forearm and hand. She immediately plunged her arm into a nearby sink containing cool water, which she had prepared in advance as standard practice. However, the thermal contact caused second-degree burns across approximately 12% of her right forearm and dorsal hand surface. Facilities Technician Georges Plante, monitoring the night shift operations, responded within 2 minutes and activated the emergency response protocol. First aid was administered, and EMS was called. Popescu was transported to Hôpital de Laval where she was treated for thermal burns and released after 4 hours with follow-up care instructions. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury and 3 weeks of modified duty assignment. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate vessel handling equipment and insufficient thermal protection PPE.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, suffered a significant laceration to his right hand while attempting to clear a hopper overflow. The Material Drying and Preparation Room had experienced a resin backup due to a malfunctioning moisture sensor that failed to trigger the automatic shutoff sequence. As polypropylene pellets accumulated beyond safe levels, material began cascading onto the floor. Marcel attempted to manually redirect the overflow using his bare hand without first shutting down the hopper circulation system. His hand made contact with the active auger blade inside the hopper chute, resulting in a deep laceration across his palm and fingers requiring 14 stitches and causing nerve damage that resulted in temporary loss of sensation. The incident was immediately witnessed by quality control technician Léa Parent (EMP-00121), who initiated emergency response protocols and applied pressure with sterile gauze while emergency services were contacted. Marcel was transported to Laval Medical Center where he underwent examination and surgical repair. The employee was unable to return to full duty for 8 weeks due to the severity of nerve involvement and required physical rehabilitation.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift operations, Tran Le (EMP-00036), a Quality Control Lab Technician, sustained a moderate chemical burn to his left forearm and hand while transferring acetone-based cleaning solvent from a 55-gallon drum to smaller dispensing bottles in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. The employee was wearing standard nitrile gloves but no protective coat or arm guards. While pouring solvent into a laboratory beaker, the pouring lip of the source container cracked suddenly due to thermal stress (the facility had recently conducted a temperature calibration in the chemical storage area that caused rapid ambient fluctuations). Approximately 150 mL of acetone splashed onto his forearm and wrist, causing immediate erythema and blistering consistent with a second-degree chemical burn. Tran immediately rinsed the affected area with water from the eyewash station for approximately 8 minutes before reporting to the occupational health nurse. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided initial first aid and documented the incident. The employee was sent to the Urgences-Santé clinic where the burn was treated with topical antibiotics and dressed with sterile gauze. Tran returned to modified duty (administrative tasks only, no chemical handling) for 10 days while the burn healed, resulting in lost production time.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift operations in the Warehouse and Shipping area, a structural failure of a tall storage rack system caused approximately 850 kg of boxed composite materials and plastic resin to collapse and fall onto the adjacent shipping dock floor. The incident occurred in the north section of the warehouse where finished goods inventory is staged for shipment. The rack system, which was approximately 18 feet tall with 6 shelf levels, had been installed approximately 11 years prior and had never undergone a structural inspection or load-bearing verification audit. Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), the receiving clerk working the night shift, was positioned approximately 8 feet away when he heard a loud cracking sound followed by the collapse. No personnel were directly struck, and Jacques immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency alarm. The fallen materials blocked approximately 60% of the dock access route, damaging 7 finished goods boxes containing automotive component assemblies valued at approximately $28,000. The structural failure was attributed to accumulated corrosion of the steel support columns and welds, combined with shelf brackets that had gradually loosened over years of vibration from forklift operations. Night shift supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) documented the incident and contacted facilities management. A structural engineer was brought in and deemed the entire north rack section unsafe pending reconstruction.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine mold changeout procedures in the Main Production Building North Zone (UNIT-002). While removing the hot mold from the injection press after completing an automotive interior trim component run, Gendron contacted the mold surface with his bare left hand despite the equipment temperature gauge reading 185°C. The mold cooling system had been placed in maintenance mode earlier that morning but the status board was not updated. Gendron sustained a partial-thickness thermal burn across his palm and fingers. First aid was administered on-site by Maya Kumar (EMP-00138), the Production Operator on the adjacent line who witnessed the incident. The burn was treated with cool water irrigation and a sterile dressing applied by the on-site nurse. Gendron reported experiencing significant pain but declined hospitalization. Safety Representative Serge Lafleur was notified and documented the incident as a preventive declaration to identify systemic communication gaps in equipment status tracking.

On April 22, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), a Material Handler, was transferring pallets of polycarbonate resin from the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) to the production area using an electric pallet jack. While navigating through a congested storage aisle, Habib misjudged the clearance between the pallet load and an overhead storage rack structure. The top of the pallet load struck the structural support beam, causing approximately 45 kg of bundled polycarbonate sheets to shift and fall. One bundle struck Habib on the left shoulder and upper arm, causing him to lose grip on the pallet jack controls. The pallet jack veered into a secondary racking unit, and Habib fell backward, landing on the concrete floor. He was unable to rise without assistance and reported acute left shoulder pain and limited arm mobility. Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), the Forklift Operator on duty, immediately called emergency services. Habib was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur with suspected shoulder dislocation and rotator cuff injury. He was hospitalized for 4 days and received diagnostic imaging and orthopedic consultation. Medical assessment indicated lost work time of 8 weeks. This incident was classified as a Lost Time Injury and reported to CNESST by Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov.

On May 8, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was preparing glass fiber-reinforced plastic stock for the day shift production schedule at the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (UNIT-017). While moving a cart of freshly cured composite panels toward the inspection station, the cart's front left wheel caught on uneven flooring, causing the entire cart to suddenly lurch sideways. Three large composite panels (approximately 2 m × 1 m × 8 mm thick, weighing 18 kg each) began to slide from the unstable cart. Abdallah instinctively reached out with both hands to prevent the panels from falling, stopping their descent but causing the cart to rotate further. However, her quick reaction prevented the panels from crashing to the floor, avoiding potential breakage of $4,200 worth of product and preventing the panels from striking her legs or feet. Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), the Injection Molding Technician conducting pre-shift equipment checks, observed the incident from 8 meters away and immediately approached to assist. Abdallah reported experiencing momentary fear and elevated heart rate but had no physical injuries or contact. No property damage occurred. The incident was classified as a Near Miss because the hazard was present and acute, but practical intervention prevented injury and loss. Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier documented the incident and investigated the flooring condition.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was operating Injection Molding Line B when he attempted to remove a partially cooled plastic component from the mold cavity. Despite wearing standard heat-resistant gloves, Gosselin made direct contact with the mold surface which had reached 185°C. The mold temperature indicator at the station was malfunctioning and displayed an incorrect reading of 120°C. Gosselin sustained second-degree thermal burns across the dorsal surface of his right hand and fingers. He immediately notified his supervisor and received first aid at the facility medical station before being transported to Laval General Hospital for advanced burn treatment. The incident was witnessed by Ana Silva (EMP-00040), an Assembly Operator who was nearby performing quality checks. Investigation revealed that the temperature monitoring system had not been calibrated in 14 months, well beyond the required 6-month maintenance interval. Gosselin required hospitalization overnight and missed 8 days of work.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, was transferring a 45-kilogram bag of polypropylene resin from a pallet to the hopper of the Material Drying and Preparation Room. The bag was awkwardly positioned on the lower shelf of the pallet, requiring Yilmaz to bend at the waist with knees slightly bent to lift it. As Yilmaz lifted and rotated the bag toward the hopper, she felt acute pain in her lower back. She attempted to continue the movement but experienced sharp spasms that forced her to lower the bag and stop work. Yilmaz reported the injury to her supervisor Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), Assembly Lead, who was performing evening round checks. Emergency first aid was provided on-site, and Yilmaz was advised to seek medical evaluation. She was unable to return to duty for 12 days and was subsequently diagnosed with a lumbar strain with muscle spasm. The incident was examined by Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) who identified that material storage protocols had not been updated to follow ergonomic best practices for bag placement. Witness Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), another Material Handler, confirmed that similar lifting techniques were commonly used throughout the shift.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), a Quality Inspector, was conducting visual and dimensional inspection of medical component parts in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. While examining a batch of newly molded polycarbonate components, Patel handled a part with a sharp, unfinished edge where mold separation had left a small burr. The sharp edge of the burr made contact with the lateral aspect of Patel's left index finger, creating a small laceration approximately 2 centimeters in length. The wound was superficial but bled moderately. Patel immediately moved to the nearby sink, washed the wound, and applied pressure with a clean cloth. After 5 minutes of direct pressure, bleeding subsided. She applied a sterile adhesive bandage and antibiotic ointment, then returned to work. Supervisor Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), the Injection Molding Operator assigned to this production line, observed the incident and reported it to the HSE office. No hospitalization was required, and Patel continued work with modified duties avoiding water contact for 24 hours. The incident was documented as a first-aid case and investigated to determine if deburring procedures were being followed consistently.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Ibrahim (EMP-00090), a Machine Setter, was operating Injection Molding Line D in the South Zone when a hopper overflow occurred. Ibrahim had been loading polypropylene resin pellets into the heated hopper when the automatic level sensor malfunctioned, allowing material to continue flowing beyond capacity. Approximately 80 pounds of hot plastic pellets spilled onto the production floor around the machine base. Ibrahim attempted to clear the material using compressed air without proper containment, causing hot plastic particles to scatter. One particle struck Ibrahim's left eye, and he immediately reported pain and redness. A coworker, Raj Patel (EMP-00018), a Process Engineer, was present nearby and witnessed the incident. The facility First Aid responder, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), administered ice and arranged transport to the local urgent care clinic where Ibrahim was treated for a corneal abrasion. Ibrahim was unable to return to work for 5 days due to eye pain and light sensitivity, resulting in lost work time. Investigation revealed the hopper sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift, Sylvain Jodoin (EMP-00155), an Automation Engineer, was performing routine maintenance in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (mezzanine level, UNIT-025). Sylvain was retrieving a replacement cooling pump module from a shelf approximately 8 feet high when he accidentally dislodged a box of metal machining fixtures stored on the same shelf. The box, weighing approximately 35 pounds, fell and passed directly beside Sylvain's head, missing him by approximately 18 inches, before striking the concrete floor below with significant force. Sylvain immediately froze in place, realizing how close the object had come to striking him. His coworker, Daniel Kim (EMP-00025), an Electrical Maintenance Technician, was working on nearby equipment and heard the crash. Daniel rushed over and found Sylvain visibly shaken but unharmed. Both employees reported the incident to Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) on night shift. Investigation revealed the box had been placed on the shelf without proper restraint, and the shelf layout violated the company's weight distribution guidelines. No injury occurred, but the near-miss demonstrated a critical hazard requiring immediate correction.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 1:20 AM during night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter on night shift, was removing a molded consumer packaging component from an injection mold on Line D when his right index finger contacted a sharp edge on the ejected part. The plastic component had a raised parting line with unfinished sharp edges that had been produced due to a worn mold cavity. As Louis grasped the part to remove it from the conveyor, his finger slid across the sharp edge, resulting in a laceration approximately 1.5 inches long on the palmar side of his index finger. Louis immediately reported bleeding and was taken to the First Aid station by André Paradis (EMP-00037), Night Shift Production Supervisor. The wound was cleaned and bandaged, requiring 5 stitches from the occupational health nurse. Louis returned to work the same shift with his hand bandaged. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer, investigated and found that the mold had not been inspected for wear in 4 months, and the parting line had developed rough edges due to metal degradation. Additionally, workers were not wearing cut-resistant gloves as required by SOP during part handling.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140) was operating the automatic material handling system to feed glass-reinforced resin into the processing line when the cooling water system developed a significant leak. The pressurized coolant sprayed onto the electrical control panel, causing a short circuit that disabled the emergency stop function. The conveyor belt continued operating uncontrolled, and the robotic arm cycled unexpectedly, striking Wong on the left shoulder. Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) responded immediately and manually shut down the system. Wong was treated on-site for a contusion but refused further medical attention. The root cause investigation revealed that the cooling water pump seal had deteriorated due to lack of preventive maintenance, and the system lacked proper isolation procedures between coolant and electrical systems.

On November 16, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Receiving Clerk Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085) was unloading a shipment of raw polypropylene resin bags at the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). While stacking heavy bags on a storage rack approximately 7 feet high, one of the lower support brackets on the rack failed due to corrosion and fatigue, causing the entire stack of approximately 40 bags (weighing roughly 800 pounds total) to shift suddenly. A single bag fell from the 5-foot level, striking Lachance on the right forearm and causing a laceration approximately 3 inches long. Quality Control Technician Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013), who was verifying incoming materials nearby, immediately applied first aid using the dock's first aid kit, cleaning and bandaging the wound. Lachance was transported to the on-site occupational health clinic where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) evaluated the injury, determined sutures were not required, and applied antibiotic ointment and a sterile dressing. The incident was documented as a first-aid case requiring professional medical assessment.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, Injection Molding Operator Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117) was performing routine part removal from a Line C injection molding machine. While extracting cooled plastic components from the mold cavity, her right hand came into contact with residual mold release agent that had accumulated on the mold surface. Within minutes, Desjardins experienced acute skin irritation characterized by redness, burning sensation, and minor blistering on the palm and fingers. She immediately rinsed her hand with water at the adjacent eyewash station for approximately 5 minutes. Plant Manager Jean-François Lefebvre (EMP-00002), who was performing night-shift facility checks, was notified and accompanied Desjardins to the on-site health clinic. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) examined the affected area, applied antihistamine cream, and provided a clean gauze dressing. The irritation subsided within 2 hours with symptomatic treatment. Investigation revealed that the mold release agent application system had malfunctioned, leaving excessive residue on the mold surface without proper warning labels or protective equipment reminders posted at the workstation.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, Finishing Operator Amal Farsi was working on Injection Molding Line C, removing cured medical-grade polycarbonate components from a mold when she contacted a sharp edge on a freshly ejected part. The edge, approximately 2mm in height, caught the inside of her left wrist as she reached into the collection bin. She sustained a shallow laceration measuring 3cm, with minimal bleeding. A coworker, Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes, immediately applied direct pressure with a clean cloth. The wound was assessed by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid within 10 minutes. After cleansing and evaluation, the injury was determined to require only first aid treatment: application of antibiotic ointment, a sterile adhesive bandage, and tetanus prophylaxis review. The employee was able to return to modified duty within 30 minutes, with no loss of work time. The part was flagged for deburring before customer shipment.

On March 18, 2024 at 09:20, Material Handler Hassan Diallo was performing routine inventory checks in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop mezzanine when he observed an unusual odor and discoloration in one of the resin dryer units scheduled for use on the production line. The unit, a 400-liter industrial resin dryer, showed signs of moisture accumulation and an oily residue inside the hopper. Upon closer inspection, Hassan discovered that the equipment's temperature controller had malfunctioned, causing the internal temperature to drop to 28°C instead of the required 85°C for the past 6 hours. The accumulated condensation combined with residual resin created a potential fire hazard, as reheated degraded resin can spontaneously ignite under certain conditions. Hassan immediately notified Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère and documented the condition with photographs. The equipment was immediately quarantined and tagged out. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger was consulted to assess the contaminated material and confirm whether the batch of resin must be discarded. The incident was classified as a preventive declaration to ensure corrective maintenance protocols were established and to prevent similar equipment failures.

On March 21, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Production Operator Hawa Traore was manually adjusting a material hopper on Injection Molding Line B when she accidentally knocked over a container of cleaning solvent (acetone, approximately 2 liters) that was stored on the adjacent work surface. The liquid spilled across the concrete floor near electrical equipment and created a slick hazard. Within seconds, the fumes from the acetone accumulated near a wall-mounted electrical panel housing the line's control circuitry. A static electrical discharge from a nearby plastic component being processed ignited the vapors, causing a small localized fire approximately 15cm in diameter at the base of the panel. The employee immediately activated the nearest dry chemical fire extinguisher, which successfully suppressed the flames within 60 seconds. However, the incident triggered the facility's automated fire suppression system due to the heat signature, resulting in accidental discharge of the overhead sprinkler head in the north production zone, creating additional water damage to electrical control boxes and causing approximately 4 hours of production downtime. The evening shift supervisor and facilities technician responded immediately. Fire Department was called as a precautionary measure but determined the fire was fully extinguished. This incident was classified as a FIRE_ALARM damage event due to the accidental discharge of the suppression system and associated property damage.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (Unit-011). Nicole Proulx, Inventory Control Specialist, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin from storage to the mixing station using a manual hand pump system. The drum's outlet valve was not fully secured, and as the drum was being repositioned on the transport cart by Roberto Santos (Forklift Operator), approximately 12 gallons of the resin spilled onto the concrete floor. The liquid spread rapidly across a 200 square-foot area, creating a slip hazard and releasing volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes. Immediate response included evacuation of the area, activation of the facility's spill containment procedures, and notification of the HSE department. Jamal Thompson responded within 10 minutes with absorbent materials and assisted in containing the spill. The area was cordoned off and ventilation systems were increased. No personal injury occurred, but respiratory irritation was reported by two nearby workers. The spill was fully contained and cleaned within 3 hours. Root cause analysis indicated inadequate valve inspection procedures and insufficient training on proper drum handling protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the afternoon shift, a near-miss incident was identified in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Unit-025). Emmanuel Kouassi, Machine Operator on the Evening Shift, arrived early to locate a replacement motor coupling for Line C injection molding machine. While accessing the second mezzanine level via a fixed ladder, he observed that several heavy metal tool boxes (approximately 40 pounds each) were stored on the edge of the upper shelf with no guardrailing or edge protection. As Kouassi was ascending the ladder, one of the boxes shifted slightly and nearly fell, stopping only inches from his head. Indira Singh, Quality Auditor, who was conducting a routine inventory audit on the mezzanine, immediately secured the boxes and alerted François-Xavier Mailhot, Maintenance Supervisor. Investigation revealed that the storage arrangement violated facility safety standards requiring edge restraints for mezzanine-level items. The boxes had been repositioned during recent equipment maintenance work without proper securing. No injury occurred, but the incident highlighted a critical gap in storage management protocols on elevated work platforms. This was classified as a near-miss due to the high probability of serious head injury or fracture had the box made contact.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, a first-aid incident occurred in the Assembly and Finishing Department (Unit-005). Valentina Rossi, Assembly Operator, was performing manual assembly work on precision injection-molded components for a medical device contract. While handling a finished plastic part with a sharp, molded edge, Rossi sustained a laceration on the inside of her right index finger. The cut was approximately 0.75 inches long and penetrated approximately 1/8 inch into the dermal layer. The injury caused moderate bleeding. Rossi immediately reported the incident to Sana Iqbal, Production Operator on the same shift, who accompanied her to the facility's first-aid station. Marie-Claude Beaumont, Director of Health, Safety and Environment, was on-call and responded within 15 minutes. The wound was cleaned with antiseptic solution, bandaged with sterile gauze, and wrapped with medical tape. After assessment, it was determined that sutures were not necessary, though the wound was monitored for infection risk. The employee was cleared to continue work with modified duty (avoiding sharp-edged parts) for 48 hours. The incident was documented and the defective part edge was flagged for quality control review to prevent future similar injuries.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Olga Ivanova, a Composite Materials Technician, was transferring a 20-liter container of epoxy resin from a storage rack to a mixing station when the container's lid became loose due to improper sealing. As she lifted the container, approximately 12 liters of liquid epoxy resin spilled onto the production floor. The spill spread across an area of roughly 50 square meters, creating a slippery hazard and releasing fumes into the work environment. The spill occurred near active workstations where three other employees were operating composite layup equipment. Immediate response included evacuation of the immediate area, ventilation system activation, and containment using absorbent material and spill kits. No direct chemical contact occurred with employees, but respiratory irritation was reported by two nearby workers. The incident was contained within 45 minutes. Root cause investigation determined that the container was not properly inspected before transfer, and the lid mechanism had a manufacturing defect.

On February 8, 2024 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Conrad Therrien, an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a serious hand laceration while attempting to remove a finished part from an injection molding machine. The 250-ton injection molding machine (Machine #14) had completed its cycle, but the part ejection system malfunctioned, leaving the component partially stuck in the mold cavity. Following standard procedure, Conrad waited 30 seconds for the machine to cool slightly before manually reaching into the mold to assist removal of the part. However, the machine's safety interlock had been temporarily bypassed earlier that shift due to a sensor malfunction reported by the machine setter. When Conrad's hand entered the mold cavity, a secondary pressure pulse from the hydraulic system caused the mold to close unexpectedly, resulting in a deep laceration to his right hand between the thumb and index finger, severing a tendon and causing significant bleeding. Immediate first aid was provided by Ibrahim Yusuf, the Machine Setter on duty, who applied direct pressure and tourniqueting. Emergency services were called, and Conrad was transported to the hospital at 11:35 PM. He required surgical repair and received 18 stitches. The employee lost 6 weeks of work time during recovery and rehabilitation.

On April 3, 2024 at approximately 8:20 AM during the day shift, Zara Khan, an Assembly Operator in the Medical Components assembly area (UNIT-016), sustained a puncture wound to her left palm while handling a batch of newly molded medical device housings. The plastic components had sharp molded edges that had not been properly deburred according to post-production specifications. While assembling subcomponents into housings, Zara compressed a sharp edge directly against her palm, creating a deep puncture wound approximately 1.5 centimeters deep. The wound penetrated the palm surface and caused immediate bleeding and pain. First aid was administered immediately by her supervisor Tatiana Volkov, including wound cleaning, antibiotic ointment application, and sterile dressing. The laceration was minor but required monitoring for infection given its depth. Zara remained at work but reported ongoing pain and swelling throughout the shift. Root cause analysis determined that the deburring process step had been skipped on this batch of 500 units due to a production scheduling error and improper communication between the molding line and finishing departments.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, machine setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was performing routine adjustment work on Injection Molding Line C in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area when molten plastic material unexpectedly discharged from a heating cylinder. The material, heated to approximately 280°C, sprayed across her left arm and shoulder, causing immediate second-degree thermal burns over an area of approximately 15 cm². She was wearing standard work gloves but no additional thermal protection on her upper arm. Coworker Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124) immediately activated the emergency stop and assisted her to the eyewash/safety shower station. First aid was administered on-site, and she was transported to Laval Hospital's burn unit via ambulance. Investigation revealed that the thermocouple on the heating cylinder had malfunctioned, causing temperature overshoot. The equipment's thermal safety cutoff had not been tested in 14 months, exceeding the 6-month maintenance interval specified in the equipment manual.

On February 28, 2024 at 22:15 during evening shift operations, a solvent fire erupted in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011) located in the Chemical Storage Building exterior zone. Maintenance technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) was conducting routine equipment checks when he noticed fumes emanating from a 55-gallon drum of acetone that had been improperly sealed. The drum had been left with its cap loose after a partial transfer of material approximately 3 hours earlier. Vapors accumulated in the confined storage area, and when Luc approached with a flashlight to investigate, the beam ignited the acetone vapor cloud. The resulting flash fire extended 4 meters across the storage area, singeing nearby equipment and causing temporary localized heating of adjacent chemical containers. Quick-acting responder Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) activated the fire suppression system and evacuated the area. The facility's fire suppression system contained the fire within 2 minutes. No injuries were sustained. Root cause analysis identified incomplete closure procedures for chemical containers and inadequate ventilation in the hazardous waste area during low-activity evening shifts.

On April 2, 2024 at 09:20 during day shift operations, forklift operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) was transporting a pallet of finished composite material parts from the Post-Processing area to the Packaging and Labeling Station. As he navigated through the narrow access corridor between storage racks in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room, the right side of the pallet caught the edge of a storage rack support beam due to insufficient clearance. The impact dislodged approximately 12 injection molding components from the upper shelf of the adjacent rack (approximately 2 meters high). The components, totaling approximately 85 kg, fell onto the pallet being transported, causing significant damage to both the freshly processed parts on the pallet and the falling inventory. Additionally, two components struck the external rear-view mirror of the forklift, shattering it. Witness Chantal Côté (EMP-00017) immediately documented the scene. Investigation revealed that the corridor width had been reduced 6 months prior when additional shelving was installed, reducing clearance from 3.2 meters to 2.8 meters, but the pallet dimensions (2.9 meters wide when loaded) had not been adjusted. No formal notification had been communicated to forklift operators about the reduced clearance.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, suffered a laceration to her right palm while performing routine mold changeout procedures at Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building. During the afternoon shift, Sofia was cleaning and preparing a mold cavity using compressed air and a wire brush when the mold clamping mechanism unexpectedly activated due to a faulty pressure relief valve. The sudden closure of the mold trapped her right hand between the mold plates, causing a deep laceration approximately 4 cm long. Sofia immediately withdrew her hand and notified her supervisor, Chantal Côté (EMP-00017). First aid was administered by the facility nurse, and Sofia was transported to the local emergency clinic where the wound received 8 stitches. The incident was investigated by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), who identified that the pressure relief valve had not been serviced according to the preventive maintenance schedule. Additionally, no lockout/tagout procedures were being followed during the mold changeout. Sofia experienced significant pain and required 3 days off work for wound healing and monitoring for infection.

On November 21, 2024 at 11:20 during the evening shift, a significant equipment malfunction occurred at the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (South Zone of Main Production Building) when a resin dryer's thermal regulation system failed catastrophically. The unit, which was processing a batch of glass-filled nylon pellets at 120°C, experienced a thermostat failure that prevented proper temperature monitoring. The heating elements remained active beyond the normal cycle, causing the internal temperature to rise to approximately 180°C. The excessive heat caused the resin dryer's internal pressure to build up abnormally. A safety relief valve eventually activated, venting pressurized hot air and plastic particles violently through the exhaust vent, which struck and damaged an adjacent quality control workstation and storage cabinet containing approximately 50 kilograms of sensitive optical inspection equipment valued at approximately $85,000. The workstation's computer monitor was destroyed, various calibration instruments were damaged, and quality control documentation was scattered and partially burned. Equipment malfunction sensors detected the anomaly 45 minutes into the cycle, but the system's redundant safety features had not been maintained. Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), a Crane Operator present nearby, immediately initiated emergency shutdown procedures. Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) declared this incident after discovering the damage during evening safety rounds.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Soraya Alami (EMP-00196) was working at a quality control station in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) when she reached into a hopper to retrieve a sample of dried polycarbonate pellets. As she withdrew her hand, the edge of a sharp molded part protruding from the hopper caught her right palm, creating a laceration approximately 2 cm long. The cut was bleeding moderately. Soraya immediately notified her supervisor and proceeded to the on-site first aid station where Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) cleaned and dressed the wound with antibiotic ointment and a sterile bandage. No stitches were required, but the injury was documented and monitored. The incident was caused by inadequate sorting of finished parts that had accidentally been mixed with raw material in the hopper, creating a sharp object hazard in an area where workers regularly reach with bare or lightly protected hands.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le (EMP-00036) was preparing samples for UV light testing in the Quality Control and Assurance laboratory when he inadvertently exposed his left forearm to the UV chamber during equipment calibration. The exposure lasted approximately 8 seconds before another technician noticed the open chamber and warned him to step back. Tran experienced immediate mild erythema (redness) and a burning sensation on the exposed skin. Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) provided immediate first aid by having Tran rinse the affected area with cool water for 10 minutes and apply aloe vera gel. The burn was superficial and did not blister. Tran was monitored for 2 hours post-incident and released to continue work with protective measures in place. The root cause was missing warning signage on the UV chamber and lack of proper shielding guards around the equipment opening, combined with Tran's unfamiliarity with the newly recalibrated unit.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 4:30 AM during the night shift, Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) discovered a significant chemical spill in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). A 20-liter container of isopropyl alcohol (IPA) used for mold cleaning had toppled from an improperly secured shelf, spilling approximately 80% of its contents onto the concrete floor near the tool washing station. The spill covered an area of approximately 12 square meters and created a slipping hazard. The acrid vapor was noticeably detectable throughout the work area. Georges immediately cordoned off the affected zone using warning tape and yellow caution signs, evacuated all personnel from the immediate area, and activated the facility's local ventilation fans. He then contacted Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) and Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) to coordinate the cleanup response. The spill was contained using absorbent material and properly classified for hazardous waste disposal according to TDG regulations. Root cause analysis revealed that the storage shelf was rated for general items but not certified for flammable liquid storage, and no secondary containment was in place. The IPA container was also not properly secured against toppling.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45 during day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, noticed the automated material handling robotic arm was moving erratically while loading raw plastic pellets into the injection machine hopper. The arm's gripper appeared to be malfunctioning, opening and closing unpredictably. Before Mathieu could activate the emergency stop, the robotic arm's pneumatic gripper suddenly released a 50-pound batch of hot polycarbonate pellets directly onto the conveyor system near where he was standing. The pellets scattered across the floor creating a slip hazard. Mathieu quickly moved away and alerted his supervisor Roland Dostie. No direct contact with the hot material occurred, but the near-miss was serious—had Mathieu not moved, he could have sustained severe thermal burns to his torso and arms. The incident was immediately reported to the HSE department. Investigation revealed the gripper's pressure sensor had drifted out of calibration, causing the malfunction. The equipment was immediately taken offline for maintenance.

On April 2, 2024 at 22:15 during evening shift, Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a crush injury while attempting to clear a material jam in the injection machine's feed throat. Despite receiving LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) training during her employment, Claudine did not properly execute the lockout procedure before placing her left hand into the machine cavity to dislodge compacted polymer material. The injection cycle resumed unexpectedly—the machine's safety interlock had not been properly engaged—and the closure mold compressed with significant force, crushing Claudine's left hand between the top and bottom cavity plates. She suffered a fractured left ring finger, two metacarpal fractures, and severe contusions requiring emergency room treatment and hospitalization for 3 days. The incident was witnessed by quality inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), who immediately activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. Root cause investigation revealed: (1) the LOTO tagout cable was not fully inserted into the safety interlock receptacle, (2) Claudine was not following established procedures due to production pressure, and (3) no supervisor verification of lockout status occurred before work commenced.

On March 28, 2024 at 09:30 during day shift, Nina Santos (EMP-00084), Industrial Hygienist at TechnoPlast, conducted a routine air quality assessment in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Unit-018) as part of the company's quarterly compliance monitoring program. While performing this preventive inspection, Nina identified elevated volatile organic compound (VOC) concentrations near the solvent-based adhesive application station. Measurements indicated solvent vapor levels at 85% of the WHMIS 2015 exposure limit, with inadequate local exhaust ventilation due to a partially blocked capture hood. This was classified as a preventive declaration—a potential hazard identified before any worker exposure incident occurred. The regrind equipment operates for extended periods weekly, and warehouse associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) works in this area regularly. Nina immediately notified facility management and the HSE committee of the finding. The work area was flagged with warning signage, and all personnel in the department were informed to increase break frequency and utilize supplied-air respirators until corrective action was completed. This proactive identification prevented a potential occupational health incident involving respiratory irritation or sensitization among recycling department staff.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, an injection molding operator on Line D was performing routine mold changeover procedures. While removing a large polycarbonate mold from the injection press using overhead crane equipment, a rigging cable became partially detached from the mold fixture due to improper attachment during the morning setup. The 850-pound mold began to swing uncontrollably as it was being lowered. The operator attempted to stabilize the load manually, but the mold struck the corner of the press frame, causing significant structural damage to the equipment's mounting bracket system and denting the mold cavity surface. The mold sustained approximately $28,000 in damage and required immediate repair before production could resume. A nearby material handler witnessed the incident and immediately raised the alarm. No personnel were physically injured, but the equipment downtime lasted 16 hours, disrupting production schedules for three major automotive component orders.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a hydraulic systems technician was performing scheduled maintenance on a critical hydraulic line serving the regrind and recycling department's material grinding equipment. While replacing a worn pressure hose, the technician inadvertently created a small kink in an adjacent copper hydraulic line that controls the material feeder system. The kinked line gradually restricted fluid flow over the subsequent 6 hours of operation. By 4:30 AM the following morning, the restricted flow caused excessive back-pressure to build up in the feeder system, resulting in a rupture of the main hydraulic coupling. This failure sprayed pressurized hydraulic fluid across the control panel area and damaged several electrical connection points on the regrind equipment. The equipment required a complete hydraulic system flush and replacement of the ruptured coupling, electrical rewiring, and control system recalibration—totaling approximately $42,000 in repairs and materials.
