Production in the recycling department was halted for 24 hours. No injuries occurred as the area was unoccupied during the pressure failure. The technician's supervisor discovered the incident during the morning shift changeover.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 8:20 AM during the day shift, a CNC tool maker in the Central Maintenance Workshop was operating a precision CNC milling machine to fabricate a replacement wear plate for one of the injection mold assemblies. The machine's spindle bearing, which had exhibited minor vibration issues for approximately two weeks, suddenly failed catastrophically during a high-speed cutting operation. The bearing seized without warning, causing the cutting tool to jam violently against the workpiece. The sudden impact generated sufficient rotational energy to shatter the cutting tool and crack the machine's main spindle housing. The damaged spindle requires complete replacement at a cost of approximately $38,000, and the milling machine will be out of service for an estimated 6 weeks pending parts availability and installation. The incident caused a loud noise and shower of metal debris confined to the machine enclosure, but no personnel were injured as the machine operator was wearing appropriate PPE including a full face shield. The incident was immediately reported by the tool maker to the maintenance supervisor.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a significant burn injury while performing routine mold cleaning. Bertrand was removing cooled plastic parts from the injection molding machine in the Main Production Building - North Zone when he inadvertently contacted a heated mold surface that had not fully cooled. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C (185°F). Despite wearing standard cotton work gloves, the heat penetrated quickly, causing second-degree burns to his right palm and fingers covering approximately 5% of his body surface area. Bertrand immediately alerted his supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079) who activated first aid protocols. The burn was cooled with running water for 15 minutes, and Bertrand was transported to the Laval General Hospital emergency department by ambulance at 3:15 PM. He remained hospitalized overnight for pain management, fluid replacement, and wound assessment. The incident resulted in 48 hours of lost time as Bertrand was released with medical restrictions preventing him from operating machinery for 2 days. Root cause analysis identified that the mold temperature indicator had malfunctioned, displaying incorrect readings, and the standard cooldown checklist had not been followed due to production pressure.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 AM, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, experienced a minor skin contact incident with mold release agent while transferring pallets of raw plastic resin in the Warehouse and Shipping area. Hassan was moving stacked pallets containing pre-treated composite materials when his left forearm brushed against a leaking container of mold release agent (a silicone-based chemical). The contact resulted in localized skin irritation and mild inflammation approximately 3 inches in diameter on his forearm. Hassan immediately reported the exposure to his supervisor and proceeded to the first aid station where Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), the EHS Coordinator, was present. The affected area was washed with soap and water for 5 minutes, and a mild topical corticosteroid cream was applied. Hassan experienced no systemic symptoms or respiratory effects. He remained on duty and returned to work after 20 minutes of first aid treatment. The incident was documented in the first aid log. Investigation revealed the container had a loose cap due to improper storage practices, and the material was not clearly labeled as requiring skin contact precautions on the exterior of the pallet.

On March 29, 2024 at 4:30 PM during evening shift operations, Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), a Composite Materials Operator, identified a potential hazard condition during routine equipment inspection in the Composite Materials Processing Area. While performing her pre-shift equipment checks, Lina discovered that the ventilation intake grates for the fiber dust collection system were partially blocked with accumulated composite material dust and debris. The blockage was reducing airflow efficiency by approximately 40%, creating a situation where airborne fiber particles would not be adequately captured, potentially exposing workers to respiratory hazards. Lina immediately documented the condition with photographs and notified her supervisor Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), Machine Setter - Evening Shift, who escalated the finding to Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator. This represents a proactive preventive declaration where the hazard was identified before any worker injury or exposure incident occurred. The ventilation system was immediately taken offline to prevent further exposure risk, and maintenance was scheduled for the following day. Investigation confirmed that the quarterly ventilation maintenance schedule had been missed due to calendar error, and the preventive maintenance program needed strengthening.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45 during day shift operations, Injection Molding Line A experienced a catastrophic equipment failure in the primary hydraulic system. François Gagnon (EMP-00008), the line operator, was performing routine part removal when he noticed unusual noise from the hydraulic pump assembly. Within seconds, the pump seized completely, causing the mold clamping mechanism to lose pressure and fail to open properly. The 450-ton mold remained partially closed, trapping several finished parts inside. The equipment shutdown was immediate, but the malfunction revealed that critical preventive maintenance on the hydraulic fluid filtration system had been deferred for 8 weeks past its scheduled interval. Post-incident inspection by Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) found that hydraulic fluid had become contaminated with micro-particles, accelerating pump wear. The line remained inoperative for 36 hours, impacting automotive component production schedules and delaying shipments to two major OEM customers. No personnel were directly injured, but the incident highlighted systemic maintenance scheduling failures.

On November 18, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift operations, a significant fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Unit-015 adjacent). Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), a material handler, was transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum to smaller containers for use in mold release agent preparation. A nearby 2000-watt halogen work light, positioned approximately 30 cm from the acetone containers, malfunctioned and its filament briefly contacted the drum's rim. The highly flammable acetone vapor immediately ignited, creating a localized flash fire. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified and activated the facility's emergency protocols. The fire was contained to approximately 1.5 square meters using nearby ABC fire extinguishers deployed by Paquette and two witnesses. The heat damage affected storage shelving, chemical inventory, and resulted in approximately $78,000 in property damage and loss of materials. No personnel sustained burns, though Habib experienced significant smoke inhalation and was transported to hospital for observation. The root causes were identified as: inadequate electrical equipment certification in hazardous zones, improper chemical storage arrangement (flammable materials too close to ignition sources), and insufficient clearance around work areas.

On November 22, 2024, at 09:30 during day shift operations, a forklift collision event resulted in significant property damage in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), Warehouse Lead, was operating a propane-powered forklift (Model Toyota 8FGU25) to retrieve a pallet of finished automotive components from high-bay storage racks (Section B, approximately 5 meters height). While reversing the lift to position it for another retrieval, Ouellette did not adequately check his rear visibility. The lift struck a structural support beam reinforcement bracket protruding from the floor, causing the mast assembly to tilt. The load (approximately 1,200 kg of packaged plastic components) shifted and fell approximately 3.5 meters onto a lower storage rack containing finished medical device housings. The impact damaged approximately 47 units of medical-grade components (valued at $63,400) and partially collapsed the lower storage rack. No personnel were in the impact zone, but the incident revealed that: (1) the forklift's rear-view mirror was missing, (2) floor obstructions were not clearly marked, and (3) warehouse layout efficiency had created tight maneuvering spaces. Emergency Response protocols were activated, and the warehouse section was cordoned off for 8 hours during damage assessment and cleanup.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a fire originated in the Hazardous Waste Management Area located in the exterior Chemical Storage Building. Employee Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler, was consolidating empty chemical drums when she noticed smoke emanating from a 55-gallon container of uncured polyurethane resin that had been improperly stored near a heat source (ambient temperature had reached 28°C that day). The container had developed a hairline crack, allowing vapors to escape. A nearby electric heating element for the drum preparation station, set to 35°C, ignited the escaping fumes. The initial flame spread rapidly to adjacent containers of flammable composite materials. Salma immediately activated the nearest pull-station fire alarm and evacuated the area. The facility's automated fire suppression system activated within 60 seconds, discharging dry chemical powder throughout the 2,000 sq ft storage building. No injuries occurred, but the fire caused significant smoke damage to stored materials and temporary evacuation of the entire facility for 45 minutes. Emergency services arrived on scene at 2:28 PM and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. The incident was investigated by the JHSC and revealed that chemical inventory had not been properly rotated, and temperature controls on the heating element were not functioning correctly.

On February 8, 2024, at 10:45 AM during the day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a significant burn injury while performing routine mold temperature adjustment work. Mathieu was troubleshooting a temperature sensor malfunction on a 300-ton injection molding machine when he inadvertently contacted the exposed mold surface which was maintained at 95°C (203°F) for the automotive composite part production run. The mold lacked proper insulation shielding on its access points, a known equipment deficiency documented in the previous month's maintenance log but not yet remedied. Mathieu's bare forearm made direct contact with the metal surface for approximately 2-3 seconds before pulling away. He sustained a severe thermal burn covering approximately 8 cm x 6 cm area on his right forearm, with blistering and tissue damage extending into the dermis layer. Coworker Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), an Instrumentation Technician working nearby, immediately applied cold water irrigation for 15 minutes and alerted safety personnel. Mathieu was transported via ambulance to the regional burn center at 11:15 AM. He was hospitalized for 4 days and required skin grafting surgery. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury with 28 calendar days off work and modified duties for an additional 45 days upon return.

On January 29, 2024, at approximately 11:50 PM during the night shift, a collision occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room between two pieces of material handling equipment. Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), an Instrumentation Technician, was operating an electric pallet jack to move a batch of dried polycarbonate pellets (approximately 800 kg across 4 pallets) from the drying oven staging area toward the storage racks. Simultaneously, Jade Wong (EMP-00140), a Process Technician, was navigating the narrow aisle with a motorized cart transporting temperature-monitoring equipment for overnight system calibration. Due to poor lighting conditions in that specific section of the room (two of four overhead fixtures were non-functional) and inadequate aisle markings, neither operator saw the other until the last moment. The pallet jack's front forks collided with the left side of Jade's cart at approximately 8 km/h. The impact caused the cart to tip partially, spilling electronic monitoring equipment and metal calibration weights across the floor. The pallet jack remained stable. Damage assessment revealed: 1) three temperature probes destroyed (value: $2,800), 2) one calibration weight set rendered unusable ($1,200), 3) cart frame bent and wheel assembly damaged ($3,400), 4) pallet jack hydraulic line compromised ($950), 5) approximately 40 kg of polycarbonate pellets spilled and contaminated (loss: $680). Total property damage: $9,030. No personnel injuries occurred, though both operators were shaken. The incident was reported to the HSE office at 12:15 AM.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was conducting routine mold changeover procedures in the Main Production Building. While removing a hot mold from the injection press without allowing adequate cooling time, he made direct contact with the mold surface, which was still at 185°C. The employee was wearing standard cotton work gloves instead of the required heat-resistant silicone gloves specified in the standard operating procedure. Upon contact, the glove material degraded rapidly, and the employee sustained second-degree thermal burns across his right palm and fingers. The incident was immediately reported to his supervisor, Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), who initiated first aid and called emergency medical services. The employee was transported to Laval Hospital with burns affecting approximately 12% of his hand surface. Initial investigation revealed that the mold cooling protocol had been bypassed due to production schedule pressure, and the employee had not received refresher training on heat protection requirements in over 18 months.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), a Regrind Operator, was transferring recovered plastic material from the grinding hopper to the reprocessing bin in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. While positioning a large aluminum container beneath the discharge chute, the container's rim caught on an protruding bolt from the hopper support structure. As Fernand attempted to reposition the container by pulling it forward, the regrind hopper's discharge valve suddenly opened partially due to a stuck linkage mechanism, causing approximately 40 kg of hot plastic granules (at 95°C) to discharge directly into the container. The sudden influx of material created pressure that caused the container to tip sideways. Fernand quickly stepped backward and laterally, narrowly avoiding contact with the spilled material, which scattered across the floor in a 2-meter radius. Had he maintained his original position, he would have sustained severe thermal burns and potential crush injuries from the falling container. Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), the Facilities Maintenance Technician, witnessed the incident and immediately assisted with cleanup while Fernand reported the near-miss to his supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147). The stuck linkage was identified as the root cause—maintenance records indicated the discharge valve had not received lubrication during the scheduled preventive maintenance cycle that month.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter working on Line B in the Main Production Building, was performing a routine temperature calibration on the injection molding press when he noticed an unusual grinding noise coming from the hydraulic pump assembly. Following standard troubleshooting procedures, he attempted to isolate the problem by manually moving the machine's hydraulic arm through its range of motion—a task normally requiring proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures. While moving the arm, Louis failed to verify that the energy isolation locks had been properly engaged. The press suddenly lurched forward as residual pressure in the hydraulic line was released through a micro-leak in a bypass valve, causing the machine's mold clamping mechanism to partially close. The mold moved approximately 8 centimeters toward the open position where Louis was standing, missing his left hand by an estimated 15-20 centimeters. Louis immediately released the manual control and the machine stabilized. Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) heard the noise from his nearby workstation and arrived to find Louis visibly shaken but unharmed. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the LOTO checklist had been incomplete—three isolation points were not properly tagged, and the maintenance work order had not been verified against the energy isolation diagram before work began. This represents a significant systems failure in the safety management process for high-risk equipment operations during low-staffing night shift conditions.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a burn injury while clearing a material jam from a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Production Operations area. The machine had been running at normal operating temperature (approximately 280°C for the polycarbonate resin being processed). Following standard procedure, Bruno attempted to manually clear a blockage in the injection nozzle without properly waiting for the barrel to cool. His left hand came into direct contact with the heated mold surface, causing a second-degree burn to his palm and fingers. The burn area measured approximately 8 cm². Bruno immediately withdrew his hand and reported the incident to his supervisor. First aid was administered on-site with cool running water for 15 minutes, followed by application of sterile gauze. The employee was transported to the occupational health clinic for assessment and dressing. No hospitalization was required, but the burn required specialized wound care for 10 days. The incident was witnessed by Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), another operator on an adjacent line, who immediately called for first aid support.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), a Machine Setter on the evening shift, discovered a near-miss incident while performing routine maintenance in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). While setting up a CNC milling machine for a mold repair operation, Tomas noticed that the emergency stop (E-stop) button on the control panel was partially obstructed by a roll of masking tape that had been placed on the console by an unknown person during the day shift. The obstruction was discovered before any machinery was activated. Tomas immediately removed the obstruction and documented the issue. Upon inspection, he found that three additional E-stop buttons on other milling stations were similarly compromised by accumulated dust and debris buildup, reducing their accessibility and effectiveness. Tomas immediately reported this to Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, who conducted a full facility audit. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the hazard was identified and remediated before any machine was activated and before any worker exposure occurred. Had a machine emergency occurred during this shift, the inability to quickly activate the E-stop could have resulted in serious injury or amputation.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), a Material Handler in the Raw Materials Warehouse, sustained a pinch point injury while repositioning large rolls of raw plastic resin material. The warehouse was receiving a shipment of fiber-reinforced polycarbonate pellets stored in 500-kg plastic drums. While attempting to move two drums from a pallet onto adjacent shelving using a hand truck, Bianca's left index finger became caught between the edge of a drum and the metal frame of the shelving unit. The finger was pinched as the drum shifted during repositioning. Bianca immediately withdrew her hand but sustained a crushing injury resulting in a fracture to the distal phalanx of the index finger, significant bruising, and laceration. She was first-aided on-site by Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead who was present conducting preventive maintenance on the warehouse climate control system. Claude applied pressure, ice, and secured the finger with a temporary splint. Bianca was transported to the hospital emergency department where X-rays confirmed a non-displaced fracture. She underwent wound closure and required 5 days of medical leave. The incident root cause was identified as: (1) inadequate space between shelving and drum for safe handling, (2) lack of mechanical assist equipment for heavy drum repositioning, and (3) insufficient training on proper pinch point awareness.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn injury while performing routine part removal. Gendron was extracting finished polycarbonate (PC) components from injection mold tool #7 without waiting for the mold temperature to cool below the safe handling threshold of 60°C. The mold surface was at approximately 85°C. While removing a batch of automotive dashboard components, Gendron's right forearm contacted the heated mold cavity, resulting in a partial-thickness burn approximately 8 cm x 5 cm on the inner forearm. The employee immediately reported the injury to his supervisor and proceeded to the on-site first aid station where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided initial treatment: cooling with running water for 15 minutes, sterile non-adherent dressing application, and topical antibiotic cream. The injury was classified as a FIRST_AID incident requiring basic wound care and monitoring but no hospitalization. Root cause analysis identified that Gendron was under time pressure to meet production quotas and bypassed the standard 10-minute cool-down protocol established in the LOTO procedures.

On March 18, 2024, at 11:15 PM during night shift operations, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead, discovered an environmental incident in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). During a routine inventory inspection, Laflamme identified a corroded 55-gallon drum containing mixed cleaning solvents (acetone and isopropanol mixture) that had been leaking for an estimated 4-6 hours. Approximately 8-12 liters of solvent had accumulated in a retention basin, with visible vapors indicating continued evaporation. The drum, positioned near the exterior chemical storage zone, showed significant rust perforation on the base seam. Secondary containment had partially collected the spill but was nearing capacity. The nearby ground showed no external contamination as the concrete pad had contained the release. Laflamme immediately isolated the area with warning tape, stopped all personnel entry within 10 meters, and notified the HSE Director Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001) at 11:28 PM. Environmental response protocols were activated: the building HVAC system serving that zone was switched to emergency exhaust-only mode, and the spill was contained using absorbent pads and transferred to emergency storage. Air quality monitoring indicated solvent vapor concentrations peaked at 145 ppm (below IDLH of 2000 ppm but above TWA of 500 ppm). The incident was reported to CNESST and Environment Canada as required.

On March 22, 2024, at 1:30 PM during day shift, Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189), Mold Repair Technician, sustained a moderate laceration requiring first aid treatment while performing emergency mold maintenance. Lévesque was using a pneumatic die grinder to remove plastic residue from a complex automotive mold cavity (mold #12) when the workpiece suddenly shifted due to inadequate clamping in the vise. The mold edge caught Lévesque's left hand, resulting in a 4 cm laceration across the dorsal surface between thumb and index finger. The cut was approximately 3-4 mm deep, bleeding moderately but not arterial. Lévesque immediately applied direct pressure using shop towels and reported to the Quality Control Manager Isabelle Tremblay (EMP-00005), who was nearby. Isabelle escorted him to the first aid station where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) cleaned and irrigated the wound with saline solution, applied surgical glue for closure, and dressed with sterile gauze. The laceration did not require stitches but was monitored for infection risk. The employee was permitted to continue light duties after 2 hours observation. Root cause investigation revealed that the pneumatic die grinder lacked proper guards, the mold-holding vise jaw was damaged and provided inadequate grip, and Lévesque had not used work-holding clamps as specified in the maintenance procedure manual (deviation attributed to time pressure on emergency mold repairs).

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-005). Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170), a Material Handler, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin from storage shelving to a mixing station using a manual pump cart. While positioning the drum over the cart, the drum's bung cap became loose, and approximately 12 gallons of uncatalyzed polyester resin spilled onto the concrete floor. The spill created a slippery hazard and emitted strong chemical vapors. Bianchi immediately notified her supervisor Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183) who evacuated the immediate area and activated the spill response protocol. The spill was contained using absorbent pads and the area was ventilated. No personnel were directly contaminated, but the incident highlighted deficiencies in drum transport procedures and bung cap securing methods. The area remained cordoned off for 6 hours during cleanup and decontamination.

On March 18, 2024 at 09:20 during day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a crush injury to his left hand. Gagnon was performing routine mold maintenance when he reached to manually close an injection mold cavity for inspection purposes without fully disengaging the automatic closure mechanism. Another operator on the line, unaware of Gagnon's position, initiated the mold closing sequence remotely. Gagnon's left hand was caught between the upper and lower mold halves, resulting in compression injuries to his palm and all fingers. Emergency response was activated immediately; the machine was stopped within 2 seconds. Gagnon was treated on-site for crush injuries and transported to Laval Hospital with suspected metacarpal fractures and soft tissue damage. He was hospitalized for 3 days. Witness Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) confirmed the machine was running when Gagnon reached into the mold cavity.

On March 21, 2024 at 23:15 during evening shift, an overhead crane load drop incident occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), a Mold Maintenance Technician, was using an electrically-powered overhead crane to hoist a 380-pound precision injection mold assembly from the tool room floor to a workbench height of 8 feet. Approximately halfway through the lift, the cable developed a visible fray and suddenly parted. The mold assembly fell 4 feet onto a steel work table, causing the mold to crack along the primary cavity. The fallen mold narrowly missed striking Réjean, who was standing directly below the load. Daniel Kim (EMP-00025), the Electrical Maintenance Technician, was present as a witness working on an adjacent equipment repair. The mold damage was estimated at $34,000 with a 2-week production delay for customer orders. Investigation revealed the cable had not been inspected within the past 8 months, violating the required quarterly inspection schedule.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a machine operator on Injection Molding Line D, sustained a laceration to his right palm while removing finished parts from the mold cavity. The employee was clearing away cooled plastic components when his hand made contact with a sharp edge on a finished consumer packaging part. Despite wearing standard work gloves, the edge penetrated the material and caused a 2-inch laceration across his palm. The employee immediately reported the injury to his supervisor and proceeded to the first aid station. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid provided initial treatment including wound cleaning, topical antibiotic application, and sterile bandaging. The employee was able to continue working after treatment with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. The incident was caused by inadequate hand protection PPE for the specific sharp-edge hazards present during part removal operations.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a machine operator, was struck by a sudden startup of Injection Molding Line C while performing routine cleaning and maintenance inside the machine guard. The employee was not properly locked out and tagged out during the cleaning procedure. A supervisor's communication breakdown resulted in the mold press initiating a closing cycle while Rahman was still reaching into the mold cavity with cleaning solvents. The employee's right hand was compressed between the mold plates, resulting in a crush injury to his palm and fingers. Emergency response personnel immediately used the emergency stop button to halt the press. Rahman was transported via ambulance to Laval Hospital where he was treated for severe contusions, a fractured metacarpal bone in his right hand, and soft tissue damage. The employee required surgical intervention and was hospitalized for 3 days. Root cause investigation revealed LOTO procedures were not followed and the work permit system failed.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), a forklift operator, was removing palletized spools of glass-reinforced nylon material from the storage mezzanine in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room when a securing strap on an upper-level storage rack failed due to corrosion and metal fatigue. Approximately 180 kg (400 lbs) of nylon resin spools fell from approximately 3 meters above, striking Fontaine on the left shoulder and upper back. The employee fell to the ground and suffered acute pain in the shoulder joint. Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a material handler working nearby, immediately called for medical assistance. First aid responder Hana Al-Rashid assessed the injury and determined that while the employee had significant bruising and localized swelling, there was no loss of consciousness or visible fracture. The employee was taken to the hospital for imaging, which revealed a severe contusion to the shoulder girdle and soft tissue damage but no fractures. Fontaine was released with pain management and advised to rest, resulting in a 5-day absence from work.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building experienced a critical hydraulic system failure during routine production of consumer packaging components. Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), the Line D operator, was monitoring the injection cycle when the hydraulic pressure gauge suddenly spiked to dangerous levels. Within seconds, the mold clamping mechanism malfunctioned, causing the hydraulic fluid line to rupture under 2,500 PSI pressure. Pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the machine's work area, coating equipment and the floor. The machine automatically shut down via emergency stop protocol. Michael Chen (EMP-00004), the Production Supervisor, was notified immediately and secured the area. Maintenance technician Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) arrived within 10 minutes and isolated the hydraulic system. The incident resulted in approximately 45 liters of hydraulic fluid contaminating the production floor and rendering Line D inoperable for 18 hours. Root cause investigation revealed a hairline fracture in the main hydraulic hose coupling that had been weakened by thermal cycling and inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling. No injuries occurred, but the equipment downtime cost approximately $12,000 in lost production.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:15 during the night shift, a storage rack collapse occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), the Warehouse Lead, was overseeing inventory operations when he observed that a four-tier metal storage rack holding approximately 1,200 kg of finished plastic injection-molded components had become unstable. The rack, which was 2.1 meters tall and contained stacked pallets of automotive dashboards and medical device housings, had been improperly loaded with heavier items on the upper tiers—a direct violation of weight distribution protocols. A forklift had grazed the side of the rack earlier in the shift, causing a minor misalignment of the frame. The rack then gradually shifted, and within 90 minutes it completely collapsed, spilling pallets of finished goods across approximately 120 square meters of the warehouse floor. Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a material handler, was working 8 meters away when the collapse occurred and was not in the immediate impact zone but witnessed the incident. Damage included: 347 damaged or destroyed units (approximately $21,000 in product loss), two cracked pallets, and the destruction of the storage rack itself ($8,500). No injuries occurred. Root cause: inadequate rack maintenance, improper weight distribution training, and lack of post-collision inspection procedures.

On March 28, 2024 at 09:30, Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), an Assembly Operator working in the Assembly and Finishing Department (East Wing), sustained a burn injury to her right hand and forearm while performing quality control assembly of precision plastic components. Isabella was manually assembling a medical device housing that required bonding of two molded plastic components using a thermoplastic adhesive that was heated to 165°C in an open-air heated tray positioned on her work station. While attempting to remove an assembled component from the heating tray using metal tongs, the tongs slipped due to condensation on her gloved hands, and the hot component made direct contact with the inside of her right wrist for approximately 2-3 seconds before she jerked her hand away. The component was still at approximately 155°C. Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), an Automation Technician working at an adjacent station, immediately assisted by running Isabella's arm under cool water for 15 minutes and alerting Michael Chen (EMP-00004) and the on-site first aid responder. Isabella experienced significant pain and visible blistering across a 7cm x 5cm area of her inner wrist and lower forearm. She was transported to the occupational health clinic where she was treated for a second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 6% of her forearm. She required wound dressing, tetanus prophylaxis, and pain management. Isabella was placed on modified duty (non-production work) for 14 days and will require ongoing wound care for 3 weeks. Root causes: inadequate thermal protection on assembly workstations, lack of high-temperature-rated PPE specification, and insufficient ergonomic workstation design for hot material handling.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator, was operating a 400-ton injection molding press in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). While removing a finished composite component from the mold, Bernard's right hand made contact with a hot mold surface that had reached 185°C. The mold temperature indicator light had burned out two days prior, and Bernard was unaware the mold was still at elevated temperature. He sustained second-degree thermal burns across his palm and three fingers. Bernard immediately ran his hand under cold water from a nearby emergency wash station for 15 minutes. His supervisor, Sonia Dasilva, applied a sterile burn dressing and drove Bernard to the on-site medical clinic. The injury was treated as a first-aid case with topical antibiotic ointment and non-adherent gauze. Bernard returned to light duties the following day with restricted hand use for 5 days. The incident was witnessed by assembly operator Luis Fernandez, who was working at an adjacent station.

On February 28, 2024, during a night shift inspection at 1:30 AM, Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, conducting routine safety rounds in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010), discovered a significant hazard condition. Two large containers of acetone-based mold release agent were stored directly on the floor near an active propane heater used to maintain ambient temperature during winter months. The heater was positioned approximately 1.2 meters from the chemical containers. No secondary containment trays were in use, and no fire suppression equipment was readily accessible in the immediate storage zone. Zahra immediately notified André Paradis (EMP-00037), the Night Shift Production Supervisor, who secured the area and relocated the chemical containers to proper shelving with appropriate secondary containment. This hazard was flagged as a preventive declaration to eliminate the risk of fire before any incident could occur. The facility's propane heater had been in continuous use for 6 weeks without documented maintenance, creating additional fire risk through potential malfunction.

On April 7, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Amina Ba (EMP-00164), a Packaging Operator, slipped on a wet floor in the Cafeteria and Break Room (UNIT-024) while carrying a hot beverage from the coffee station. The floor had been recently mopped by maintenance staff, but no wet floor warning signs were posted. Amina fell backwards, striking the base of her spine and right hip against a metal chair frame. She sustained a minor contusion to her right hip and experienced moderate lower back strain. Amina was initially able to stand but experienced sharp pain when bending. Her colleague, Amara Diop (EMP-00110), another Packaging Operator who witnessed the fall, immediately assisted and accompanied Amina to the on-site medical clinic. The clinic nurse assessed the injury and provided ice therapy, compression wrapping, and over-the-counter pain medication. Amina was released with instructions for rest and mild stretching. She returned to full duties the following day but continued to report mild discomfort for 3 days. The incident was reviewed by Brigitte Mathieu, Incident Investigation Specialist, who determined the root cause was inadequate communication between maintenance and operational staff regarding floor conditions.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring a 20-liter container of polyurethane resin from a storage cabinet to the mixing station in the chemical mixing room (UNIT-017, Post-Processing and Heat Treatment). While navigating through the crowded workspace near the heat treatment ovens, the container slipped from her gloved hands and fell to the concrete floor. The impact caused the seal to rupture, releasing approximately 15 liters of the caustic resin mixture onto the floor in a 3-meter radius. The spilled material began to pool and emit toxic fumes. Elena immediately notified her supervisor, and Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer, was called to the scene within 5 minutes. The area was evacuated, and containment procedures were initiated using absorbent pads and sand. The chemical residue was collected in approved disposal containers. No direct skin contact occurred, but two nearby workers experienced mild respiratory irritation from the fumes. The facility's ventilation system was supplemented with portable HEPA filters for 2 hours to clear vapors. Root cause analysis determined that the container grip handle was damaged and the operator was unfamiliar with the new chemical supplier's container design.

On March 22, 2024 at 9:15 AM during the day shift, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), Injection Molding Operator - Line B, sustained a thermal burn injury while performing preventive maintenance on injection molding equipment at UNIT-006 (Quality Control Laboratory area, adjacent to Line B production floor). While attempting to clean residual plastic buildup from the mold heating block, Marcel inadvertently made contact with an active heating element that was operating at 210°C. He was wearing standard work gloves, but the brief contact (approximately 2-3 seconds) caused a first-degree burn with blister formation on the palm and two fingers of his right hand. Marcel immediately removed the glove and ran his hand under cool water at the nearby safety station for 15 minutes as trained. His supervisor, Pierre Bouchard (EMP-00023), Production Planner, was notified and accompanied Marcel to the on-site first aid station where Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) and Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) provided initial care: cleaning the wound with antiseptic, applying antibiotic ointment, and wrapping with sterile gauze. The injury was assessed as non-reportable to CNESST as it required only first aid without lost work time. Marcel was cleared to return to modified duties within 1 hour. The root cause was identified as inadequate temperature shielding on the heating block and insufficient lockout procedures during maintenance operations.

On March 28, 2024 at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Monique Dion (EMP-00119), Warehouse Associate, conducted a routine inspection of the equipment storage and spare parts area (UNIT-025, Maintenance Workshop - Storage Mezzanine) as part of the monthly safety audit protocol. While performing this inspection, Monique identified a potential safety hazard: several boxes of hydraulic spare parts weighing approximately 15-20 kg each were stacked near the edge of the mezzanine platform, approximately 2 meters above the workshop floor below. The stacks were insufficiently secured with only a single rope tie, and the boxes extended beyond the safety railing by approximately 30 centimeters. Additionally, she noted that no fall protection equipment or warning signage was present despite workers regularly retrieving parts from this location. Monique immediately notified Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), Workplace Safety Representative, of this hazardous condition. Rather than waiting for a reportable incident to occur, they jointly prepared a preventive declaration documenting the hazard, the risk of falling objects striking workers below (with potential for critical injury), and the inadequacy of current storage procedures. The declaration was submitted to Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer, recommending immediate corrective actions. This proactive approach prevented potential harm by identifying and escalating the hazard before anyone was injured.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper of a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Production Operations area. While reaching into the hopper with a wooden stick to dislodge compacted polycarbonate resin, the hopper suddenly overflowed due to a faulty level sensor malfunction. Approximately 80 kg of hot material (temperature ~180°C) spilled from the hopper, cascading onto a nearby storage rack containing finished medical device components worth approximately $34,000. The hot plastic material damaged 240 completed sterile housings and 180 surgical instrument handles, rendering them non-compliant with ISO 13485 sterilization requirements. Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop. The damaged inventory required destruction and replacement, causing a 6-day production delay for a critical medical device customer. Root cause investigation revealed the hopper level sensor had drifted out of calibration over 8 weeks without scheduled maintenance verification.

On March 18, 2024 at 09:15 during the day shift, Soraya Alami (EMP-00196), an Assembly Operator, sustained a laceration injury to her right index finger while performing manual trimming of plastic flash from automotive interior trim components at her assembly workstation in the Finished Goods Warehouse Section B. As she guided a freshly molded part through a manual deburring process using a fine-toothed carbide file, a sharp edge on the part caught her gloved finger, creating a 2.8 cm laceration with minor bleeding through the latex glove. Immediate first aid was administered by Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), the Ergonomics Specialist, who cleaned the wound with antiseptic solution, applied direct pressure for 3 minutes, and dressed it with a sterile adhesive bandage and antibiotic ointment. The wound was superficial with no arterial involvement. Soraya continued work after first aid with an additional protective layer (cotton glove over the bandage) and reported no further symptoms. The incident was documented in the first aid log and reported to the JHSC. Root cause was identified as inadequate edge radiusing on the part from the injection molding process and operator lack of awareness regarding proper gripping technique for sharp parts.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:47 during the evening shift, a fire alarm was activated in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C of the Warehouse) when a thermal fire detection sensor detected elevated temperatures near the material grinding station. Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead on the night shift, was conducting inventory counts when he noticed particulate accumulation around the base of the industrial grinding mill used to process post-consumer and post-industrial plastic scrap. The grinding mill had been operating continuously for 11 hours, processing 2.4 tons of mixed polymer waste including polycarbonate, ABS, and polystyrene. Despite standard cooling fan operation, internal friction heat had caused a 15 cm diameter accumulation of fine plastic dust against the motor casing, partially blocking air circulation. The temperature sensor on the motor housing reached 78°C, triggering the facility's automatic fire alarm system set at 75°C threshold. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) led immediate evacuation procedures. The facility was evacuated safely with all 78 evening shift employees accounted for within 8 minutes. Fire response personnel confirmed no active fire but identified significant dust accumulation constituting a Class D combustible dust fire hazard. The grinding mill was shut down for 3 hours for manual cleaning and inspection. Root cause: inadequate preventive maintenance schedule for dust extraction systems and extended operating cycles without rest periods.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Maya Kumar (EMP-00138) was operating Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Production Operations area when a catastrophic mold closure failure occurred. While the machine was in normal operation producing medical-grade polycarbonate components, the mold failed to open properly after the injection cycle completed. Maya reached into the machine cavity to manually check the mold position without activating the emergency stop or performing a proper lockout. The mold suddenly cycled and closed, crushing her right hand between the mold plates. Her index and middle fingers sustained severe crush injuries requiring immediate emergency room treatment and hospitalization for surgical intervention. Co-worker Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop and called for assistance. The incident resulted in 42 hours of lost time and ongoing medical treatment.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was transferring acetone solvent from a 55-gallon drum into a smaller storage container when the transfer pump malfunctioned, causing a pressurized discharge. Approximately 12 gallons of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor and partially into the facility's floor drain system, which connects to the municipal wastewater treatment infrastructure. The spill created a significant vapor hazard in the enclosed space, and the volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors were detected migrating toward adjacent areas. Elena immediately evacuated and reported the incident. The spill was contained with absorbent material, but approximately 3 gallons entered the drainage system before containment was achieved. Environmental monitoring indicated VOC concentrations exceeding Quebec's environmental discharge limits for a 4-hour period. The incident triggered mandatory reporting to CNESST and the Quebec Department of Environment.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 8:50 AM during the day shift, a near-miss incident was averted in the Quality Control Laboratory. Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le (EMP-00036) was conducting UV light testing on molded composite samples when he noticed the UV exposure chamber door interlock switch was not functioning properly. The door could be opened while the UV light source was still active, creating a direct eye exposure hazard. Tran immediately stopped the test procedure and did not open the door. He reported the equipment malfunction to Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), who confirmed the interlock switch had failed due to a loose connector. The faulty interlock was disabled temporarily, requiring manual procedural controls until repair. No exposure occurred, but the failure represented a critical control gap that could have resulted in severe ocular damage or temporary vision loss if the door had been opened during operation. The incident was documented as a near-miss with immediate corrective action implemented.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, a chemical spill occurred in the Materials Management area at the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). Hassan Diallo, a Material Handler, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyurethane resin from a storage rack to a forklift when the drum's bung plug became loose due to improper installation during the previous shift. Approximately 15 gallons of resin spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard and releasing fumes into the work area. The spill occurred near the loading dock where multiple employees were present. Hassan immediately notified his supervisor, who initiated emergency procedures. The area was evacuated and ventilation fans were activated. Environmental cleanup crew arrived within 30 minutes and contained the spill using absorbent material. Two nearby employees reported mild respiratory irritation from the fumes but did not require medical attention. The incident was traced to inadequate drum handling procedures and lack of verification protocols for bung tightness before transport.

On March 22, 2024, at 14:15 during afternoon shift, Diego Morales, an Assembly Operator at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019), sustained a laceration to his left index finger while manually assembling precision plastic components. While positioning a small component into an assembly jig, his finger caught between two metal guides, resulting in a 2-inch laceration requiring 4 stitches. The wound was cleaned immediately by the facility's first aid responder, Anh Nguyen (Safety Officer), who arrived within 3 minutes. Anh applied pressure bandaging and determined that while the laceration was minor, it required professional medical evaluation. Diego was transported to the on-site medical clinic where a nurse practitioner evaluated and stitched the wound. The employee returned to light duty the same day. Investigation revealed that the assembly jig's protective guards had been removed during maintenance two weeks prior and were never reinstalled. No formal work order tracked the guard removal or reinstallation requirement.

On April 3, 2024, at 02:30 AM during night shift operations, Lucia Martinez, a Packaging Operator, discovered a significant chemical spill in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017). While performing routine facility inspection rounds, she observed approximately 30 gallons of isopropyl alcohol-based cooling fluid leaking from a ruptured connection on the main recirculation pump serving the heat treatment tanks. The fluid had pooled on the concrete floor and was beginning to run toward the facility's floor drain system. The cooling system supplies multiple injection molding lines and had been operating continuously. Lucia immediately shut down the affected equipment and activated the emergency spill response procedures. She isolated the area with warning tape and alerted the night shift supervisor, Benoit Arsenault. The Environmental Spill Response Team was contacted and arrived within 45 minutes. Environmental technicians deployed absorbent pads to contain the spill, cleaned the affected area using approved solvents, and documented the incident. The pump connection was found to have corroded fittings, indicating inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling. The spill did not reach the main drain system due to rapid response.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) was working at Injection Molding Line A when he noticed excessive heat radiating from the mold cavity. The mold temperature had been rising steadily throughout the morning despite the cooling water system functioning normally. Diego immediately informed Production Supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) about the abnormal temperature readings on the machine's digital display. Upon inspection, they discovered that the mold release agent applicator nozzle was partially clogged, causing uneven distribution of the release agent across the mold surfaces. This buildup of residual plastic and release agent was insulating the mold and preventing proper heat dissipation. Diego reported the potential risk of thermal burns to personnel handling parts immediately after removal from the mold. Michael Chen documented the issue and temporarily reduced production speed while maintenance was notified. Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), Facilities Maintenance Technician, was called to the line to assess the situation. The team determined that without immediate intervention, the next shift workers would face elevated burn risk. This preventive declaration ensured that corrective maintenance could be scheduled before any actual injury occurred.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was organizing plastic resin bags in the warehouse when she accidentally brushed her left arm against a sharp edge of a metal shelf bracket. The bracket, which had been installed years ago with inadequate edge finishing, had developed a rough burr. Amina sustained a laceration approximately 4 cm long on her forearm, causing bleeding and immediate pain. Her coworker, Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010), witnessed the incident and immediately escorted her to the break room where he applied pressure with clean cloth to control bleeding. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, happened to be in the area and retrieved the first aid kit. She cleaned the wound with antiseptic, applied antibiotic ointment, and dressed it with sterile bandages. After 15 minutes of observation, the bleeding had stopped. Amina's arm was elevated and monitored. Although the laceration did not require stitches, it was documented as a first aid case with treatment provided on-site. David O'Connor photographed the sharp bracket and reported it for immediate repair to prevent future incidents.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the automated cooling water circulation pump that serves Injection Molding Lines B and C suddenly ceased operation. Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) discovered the failure during his routine equipment check in the Maintenance Workshop. The pump, a centrifugal unit installed in 2019, had developed internal bearing failure causing complete loss of coolant flow. Without active cooling circulation, the injection molding equipment would overheat within 45 minutes, forcing emergency shutdown of both production lines. Additionally, the failed pump had leaked approximately 8 liters of mineral oil-based coolant onto the maintenance workshop floor before the leak was detected. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) was immediately notified and confirmed the bearing failure through acoustic and visual inspection. The unit could not be repaired on-site and required complete replacement. Emergency protocols were activated: production supervisors were notified to prepare for line shutdown, the spilled coolant was contained and cleaned per WHMIS procedures, and a replacement pump was ordered from emergency inventory. The equipment remained out of service for 4.5 hours while the new unit was installed and tested. This equipment failure resulted in significant production loss but was managed through proper maintenance documentation and emergency procedures.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, suffered a significant repetitive strain injury while performing part removal operations. Ms. Ali has been assigned to the same molding line for the past 18 months, working 8-hour shifts with only two 15-minute breaks. Over the course of the shift, she was removing approximately 180-200 plastic components per hour from the injection mold using manual extraction and trimming techniques. By mid-afternoon, she reported acute pain in her right wrist, forearm, and elbow to her supervisor Patricia Martin. Upon examination by occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid, Ms. Ali demonstrated classic signs of carpal tunnel syndrome with significant inflammation and reduced grip strength. An X-ray and ultrasound at the local hospital confirmed tendon inflammation and nerve compression. The employee was hospitalized for 3 days and prescribed anti-inflammatory medication and physical therapy. This incident represents the third repetitive strain injury on Line C in the past 6 months, indicating a systemic workplace design issue rather than an isolated event.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), a Composite Materials Operator, was operating the resin dryer system when the thermostat malfunction caused the heating element to overheat. The system, which normally operates at 120°C, reached an uncontrolled temperature of approximately 240°C within 15 minutes. The excessive heat caused a rupture in the resin storage tank mounted directly above the drying chamber. Approximately 200 liters of liquid epoxy resin spilled across the processing area, spreading over 450 square feet of floor space and saturating multiple rolls of fiberglass reinforcement material. The spilled resin began to cure and smoke when it contacted the hot equipment surfaces, creating a significant fire hazard. An electrical fire ignited in the heating element control panel, which required activation of the dry chemical fire suppression system. Damage to equipment included complete loss of the resin dryer ($85,000), partial damage to the refrigeration unit ($12,000), destruction of materials inventory ($28,000), and contamination requiring professional hazmat cleanup ($22,000). No employees were physically injured, but the facility was evacuated and operations were suspended for 72 hours pending equipment replacement and facility decontamination.

On January 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift transition period, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on the evening shift who was finishing his shift, experienced a minor laceration and allergic reaction while cleaning the injection molding equipment. Mr. Rahman was performing routine end-of-shift cleaning of Injection Molding Line D using a standard cleaning solution containing quaternary ammonium compounds per company protocol. While wiping down the mold cavity with a cloth dampened in the cleaning solution, a small piece of hardened plastic trim broke loose and created a sharp edge that caught the cloth and his left index finger, creating a 2-cm laceration on the finger pad. Simultaneously, Mr. Rahman experienced localized skin irritation and mild itching around the cut site. He immediately reported to occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid, who assessed the injury as minor (less than 1mm depth). The nurse cleaned the wound with sterile saline, applied antibiotic ointment, and covered it with a sterile bandage. Upon further questioning, Mr. Rahman reported a history of sensitive skin and mild contact dermatitis. The nurse suspected a reaction to the quaternary ammonium cleaner in combination with the open wound. She provided hydrocortisone cream for topical application and monitored the employee for 30 minutes with no signs of systemic allergic reaction. The injury was documented as first aid treatment with no lost work time required. The employee returned to normal duties after the monitoring period.

On March 14, 2025 at 14:45 during day shift, Injection Molding Operator Claudine Desjardins was performing routine mold cleaning on Line C in the Production Operations area when she noticed excessive plastic buildup around the mold cavity. While attempting to clear the blockage using compressed air at approximately 95 psi, the pressurized stream dislodged a small plastic fragment that ricocheted and struck the safety glasses frame, causing the left lens to crack slightly. The operator immediately felt a sharp sensation but reported no eye penetration or injury to the cornea upon initial assessment. Safety Officer Simon Bélanger was notified within minutes and conducted an examination. The employee was directed to the occupational health nurse for precautionary evaluation. Hana Al-Rashid performed a thorough eye assessment and found no foreign body or abrasion—the impact was absorbed by the protective eyewear which functioned as intended. However, the incident revealed that compressed air pressure at several workstations was not adequately regulated, and operators had not received recent refresher training on compressed air safety protocols. The near-miss was particularly significant because had the operator not been wearing proper PPE, serious eye injury could have resulted. The employee's quick reporting and the effectiveness of existing eye protection prevented a serious injury.

On March 20, 2025 at 22:15 during evening shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi was retrieving fiber-reinforced plastic raw material from the upper storage shelves in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (mezzanine level). While reaching for a container of carbon-fiber-reinforced resin approximately 4 feet above shoulder height, her hand made contact with a cardboard box containing smaller composite material samples that was precariously positioned at the edge of the shelf. The box shifted but did not fall completely; instead, it tilted and a single small plastic component (approximately 8 cm) slipped out and fell, passing within 6 inches of Bianchi's head before landing on the concrete floor below. The material handler immediately stepped back and reported the incident to Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor, who was conducting routine rounds. Upon investigation, O'Connor discovered that the mezzanine storage area had no fall prevention netting, edge protection bumpers were missing from several shelves, and inventory items were stacked beyond the recommended height limits without proper securing. A second employee, François-Xavier Mailhot from Maintenance, was present and confirmed seeing unstable stacking practices on multiple occasions over the previous weeks but had not formally reported the hazard. The fallen component weighed approximately 180 grams; had it struck the employee's head at velocity, it could have caused significant injury. This near-miss highlighted critical gaps in fall protection systems and storage organization protocols.

On March 25, 2025 at 09:30 during day shift, Composite Materials Lead Samantha Brown was supervising post-processing work in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment department when Material Handler Mariam Osman reported discomfort and visible skin irritation on her forearms and neck area. Upon closer inspection, Brown observed erythema (redness) and multiple small red welts consistent with acute irritant contact dermatitis. Osman had been assisting with the removal of cured composite components from the industrial curing oven, a task that normally requires protective gloves and long-sleeved garments. Investigation revealed that Osman's gloves had developed two small tears during the morning shift while handling rough-edged composite materials, and she had continued working for approximately 35 minutes before reporting the discomfort. During this period, she had direct skin contact with uncured fiberglass-resin composite residue that adhered to the defective gloves. The residual resin and glass fiber fragments caused mechanical irritation and a mild chemical reaction on exposed skin. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid was immediately called to assess the injury. She provided first aid care including gentle washing with cool water, application of hydrocortisone cream, and oral antihistamine to manage itching. The employee was sent to a local clinic for follow-up evaluation, where minor irritant dermatitis was confirmed with no systemic complications. Al-Rashid documented the incident and recommended improved glove inspection procedures and employee training on recognizing and reporting PPE damage immediately. The injury was minor but required off-site medical evaluation and resulted in 2 hours of lost productivity.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a Husky injection molding machine (Serial #HM-847) in the Composite Materials Processing Area experienced catastrophic hydraulic system failure. Samantha Brown, Composite Materials Lead, was performing routine maintenance on the machine's pressure relief valve when the primary hydraulic pump seal ruptured without warning. High-pressure hydraulic fluid (approximately 3000 PSI) sprayed across the work area, saturating the floor and creating a slipping hazard. The machine's safety interlock failed to trigger, leaving the injection ram in a partially extended position. Immediate consequences included: contamination of approximately 40 square feet of production floor, damage to electrical control panels worth approximately $28,000, and displacement of three workers from the area for safety reasons. René Caron, Tool Maker, and Lucia Martinez, Packaging Operator, were nearby and assisted in emergency shutdown procedures. Response team activated emergency protocols, isolated the machine, and performed floor decontamination using absorbent materials. Root cause investigation revealed the hydraulic seal had not been replaced during the scheduled preventive maintenance cycle three months prior due to parts unavailability.

On April 2, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Nour Jaber, Packaging Operator, sustained a thermal burn injury while operating packaging line equipment in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Jaber was manually transferring finished composite part trays from a cooling conveyor into corrugated shipping boxes. Due to inadequate spacing between the conveyor discharge point and the packing station, Jaber's left forearm made direct contact with the heated tray surface (approximately 165°F/74°C). The contact duration was approximately 2-3 seconds before Jaber pulled away. Second-degree burn injury developed across an 8 cm × 6 cm area of the forearm. Immediate response included: first aid administration by shift supervisor Michael Chen (ice water immersion for 15 minutes), application of sterile gauze dressing, and transport to Laval General Hospital for medical evaluation and topical antibiotic treatment. The employee was released with pain management recommendations and instructed to return for follow-up assessment in 48 hours. Production continued with modified workflow. Root cause: conveyor guard had been removed during routine maintenance two weeks prior but was never reinstalled; no re-installation verification procedure existed.

On April 18, 2024 at 8:30 AM during the day shift, Ana Silva, Assembly Operator, experienced minor eye irritation requiring first aid intervention at the Health, Safety and Environment Office. While performing manual assembly of medical device housings in the Production Engineering area, Silva accidentally rubbed her eyes with contaminated gloved hands after handling composite resin components. The resin dust and trace amounts of mold release agent (silicone-based) transferred to her eye mucous membranes, causing mild conjunctival irritation, tearing, and temporary vision blurring. Silva immediately reported to the first aid station where HSE Coordinator Jamal Thompson administered appropriate treatment: saline eye wash irrigation (5 minutes), examination for foreign particles (none found), and application of lubricating eye drops. Symptoms resolved within 30 minutes. No hospitalization or medical referral was necessary. The incident was documented as a minor occupational exposure. Root cause: employee was transitioning between tasks without adequate hand hygiene protocol compliance; inadequate separation between resin handling and assembly work areas; insufficient signage regarding mold release agent hazards in the assembly zone.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, assembly operator Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) was working at a manual assembly station in the Assembly and Finishing Department when she felt a sharp pain in her left index finger. She had been applying pressure to insert a small polycarbonate connector into a medical device housing when her finger slipped and caught between the component and the assembly jig. The pinch lasted approximately 2 seconds before she withdrew her hand. She immediately experienced minor bleeding and swelling at the base of the fingernail. Her supervisor, Yves Thibault, responded within minutes and applied first aid—cleaning the wound with sterile gauze, applying antibiotic ointment, and bandaging the area. Jackson reported mild discomfort but no numbness or loss of function. She was able to continue working for the remainder of the shift with modified duties. The incident was witnessed by assembly operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) who was working at the adjacent station. Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) was notified and conducted an assessment, determining the incident was a minor pinch point injury requiring first aid only, with no lost time.

On April 2, 2024, at 09:15 during day shift operations, injection molding operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) was performing routine maintenance on injection molding Line D when a critical incident occurred. While attempting to clear a partial mold blockage on a production run of automotive dashboard components, Landry failed to properly execute the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure before accessing the mold cavity. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) had verbally communicated that the machine was being shut down, but no physical lockout devices were applied. When Landry inserted his left hand into the mold area to clear the obstruction, the mold unexpectedly closed due to a faulty pressure relief valve that had not been properly maintained. His hand was caught between the upper and lower mold plates, resulting in crush injuries to his palm and four fingers. He sustained fractures in three metacarpal bones, severe contusions, and lacerations. Emergency response was activated immediately; coworker James Thompson (EMP-00029) called emergency services while Landry was carefully extracted from the equipment. He was transported to Hôpital de l'Enfant-Jésus in Quebec City where he underwent emergency surgery. Landry was hospitalized for five days and required two weeks off work before returning to modified duty. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) investigated and identified multiple causal factors: inadequate LOTO training refresher, failure of preventive maintenance on the pressure relief valve, and lack of supervision during the maintenance procedure.

On March 28, 2024, at 22:35 during evening shift operations, material handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was performing routine inventory movement in the Raw Materials Warehouse when a near-miss incident was narrowly avoided. Mwangi was retrieving a pallet of polypropylene resin (1200 kg total weight) from the third shelf level of a storage rack system using a forklift. While positioning the forklift beneath the pallet, the load became unstable due to improper weight distribution within the pallet wrapping. The pallet shifted laterally and began to slide from the rack shelf. Mwangi immediately recognized the hazard and quickly reversed the forklift away from the rack. The pallet fell to the concrete floor approximately 8 feet below, narrowly missing the forklift and Mwangi's position by an estimated 3-4 feet. The impact of the falling pallet caused a visible dent in the concrete floor and scattered several bags of resin across the warehouse area. Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), who was nearby performing equipment inspections, witnessed the incident and rushed to assist. No injuries were sustained, but the near-miss represented a critical safety gap. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was immediately notified and conducted an emergency investigation, identifying that the pallet racking system lacked load capacity signage, there was no verification procedure for proper load distribution before lifting, and material handlers had not received formal training on load stability assessment. The incident was classified as a near-miss with high severity potential (severity score indicates what could have occurred).

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Youssef Zaidi, an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, suffered a severe thermal burn while performing routine mold temperature adjustment in the Main Production Building - South Zone. Zaidi was working on a 250-ton injection molding machine that was actively processing polycarbonate automotive components. While reaching across the machine to access the cooling water temperature controls, his left forearm contacted the exposed mold surface, which was operating at approximately 185°C. The employee immediately withdrew and was escorted to the first aid station. Due to the extent of the burn (approximately 8% of forearm surface with second-degree tissue damage), he was transferred to the regional burn center for specialized treatment and hospitalization. The incident was witnessed by Pascal Bisson, the Injection Molding Technician on the adjacent station. Investigation revealed that the mold surface insulation had deteriorated, and the machine's emergency stop button was partially obstructed by maintenance equipment. The employee was unable to work for 47 hours of production time before returning to modified duties, qualifying as a lost-time injury under CNESST regulations.

On December 3, 2024 at 22:15, a fire alarm was triggered in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse and Shipping - Section C) during the evening shift operations. Mohamed Ibrahim, the Regrind Operator, was processing reclaimed plastic materials through the automated grinding and compounding equipment when electrical overload in the material dryer's heating element caused localized overheating and smoke generation. The automatic fire detection system activated, triggering the facility-wide alarm and sprinkler system in the affected zone. The fire suppression system extinguished the incipient fire within 90 seconds. Emergency response was immediate, with Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne coordinating evacuation procedures and isolating the electrical panel serving the dryer. No injuries occurred, but equipment damage was estimated at $34,000. The incident was classified as a fire alarm event because the automated suppression system responded before any open flame developed. Fire department personnel arrived and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished and the building was safe for re-entry after 45 minutes.

On November 28, 2024, during a routine Health and Safety Committee inspection of the Quality Control Laboratory, Safety Officer Anh Nguyen identified a preventive occupational health concern related to repetitive strain patterns among laboratory technicians. Analysis of work-related assessment data and interviews revealed that quality control personnel performing tensile testing and dimensional measurement on completed composite components were experiencing cumulative musculoskeletal stress in wrists, forearms, and shoulders due to repetitive positioning and force application during specimen manipulation. While no acute injuries had been recorded in the past 12 months, ergonomic screening identified three employees with early signs of discomfort consistent with developing carpal tunnel syndrome or tendinitis. The condition was classified as a preventive declaration because the hazard was identified through proactive health surveillance before any lost-time injury materialized. Work station evaluations confirmed improper positioning of testing equipment, inadequate task rotation, and insufficient microbreak protocols. This incident was documented as a preventive occupational health matter requiring administrative and ergonomic interventions to prevent future occupational disease.

On 2024-03-15 at 14:45, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator on the day shift, was performing manual assembly work on medical device components at her workstation in the Assembly and Finishing Department.
