While lifting a stackable plastic container filled with finished parts weighing approximately 15 kg from a lower shelf to place on an upper work surface, she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. The lifting motion was awkward due to poor ergonomic positioning and the container's weight distribution. Elena immediately reported the discomfort to her supervisor. First aid was administered on-site, consisting of ice application and rest. The employee continued working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. The incident was witnessed by her supervisor, who documented the event and recommended ergonomic assessment of the workstation. No lost time occurred, but the employee experienced localized muscle soreness requiring over-the-counter pain relief.

On 2024-05-22 at 23:15 during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician, was performing preventive maintenance on a 200-ton injection molding machine at the Medical Components clean room facility. While inspecting the cooling water system, a corroded section of the high-pressure cooling line ruptured unexpectedly, spraying hot (65°C) cooling water containing glycol mixture onto his left forearm and hand. Alain immediately removed his work glove and ran his arm under cool running water for 15 minutes. The immediate pain and superficial burn were documented, requiring emergency medical attention. He was transported to the hospital where second-degree burns covering approximately 8% of his forearm were treated and bandaged. The employee was hospitalized overnight for observation and pain management. Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), the Warehouse Lead on night shift, witnessed the incident and activated emergency protocols. The cooling system was immediately isolated and tagged out.

On 2024-07-10 at 09:30 during the day shift, Claude Poirier (EMP-00071), a Forklift Operator, was moving pallets of raw plastic resin from the receiving area to the Regrind and Recycling Department. While navigating a tight corner in the warehouse aisle near the mezzanine storage area, the forklift struck a vertical structural support column with its left load arm, causing a wooden pallet stacked on a high shelf approximately 2.5 meters above the floor to become dislodged. The pallet tipped but stopped against a cross-brace before falling completely. Had the pallet fallen, it would have struck Claude directly, potentially causing serious head and torso injuries. Natalya Kozlov (EMP-00192), a Quality Technician, witnessed the near-miss incident and immediately alerted the supervisor. The warehouse was secured, the unstable pallet was safely removed using proper equipment, and a facility inspection identified three other similar unstable loads on high shelving. No injuries occurred. The incident revealed critical gaps in storage rack maintenance and load securing procedures.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:45 AM, Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a Material Handler working the day shift in the Regrind and Recycling Department, reported a potential safety concern to Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069). While processing recycled plastic materials, Marwa noticed that the ventilation system was producing reduced airflow and the facility was experiencing unusual accumulation of composite fiber dust in the breathing zone. The issue was preventing proper dispersal of particulate matter from the crushing and grinding equipment. Marwa, who has been with TechnoPlast for 4 years, recognized this as a deviation from normal operating conditions and correctly followed the preventive reporting protocol rather than attempting to resolve the issue independently. Simon immediately conducted air quality measurements using portable air sampling equipment and confirmed elevated dust concentrations at 3.2 mg/m³ (normal operating range is 0.8-1.5 mg/m³). The facility ventilation contractor was called and identified a partially blocked intake filter and failing fan bearing. The equipment was shut down for maintenance, preventing potential occupational health exposures among the seven workers in that department.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, an automated material handling system in Injection Molding Line D (Consumer Packaging) experienced a catastrophic failure. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) reported that a robotic arm's hydraulic coupling ruptured during a routine part transfer cycle, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid across the production area. The fluid contacted several completed plastic components awaiting quality inspection and packaging, contaminating approximately 2,400 units of high-volume consumer packaging products valued at $18,700. The affected batch was destined for a major retail customer (40% of monthly revenue for this product line) with strict delivery deadlines. The maintenance team responded within 20 minutes and isolated the system. Subsequent inspection revealed that the coupling had not been properly torqued during the previous maintenance intervention 6 days earlier, and there was no documented inspection log confirming proper installation. The spilled hydraulic fluid also required environmental remediation of the surrounding concrete floor area and collection as hazardous waste. Delivery to the customer was delayed by 4 days while replacement inventory was produced on overtime.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45 during the day shift, Machine Operator Raoul Blanchard was setting up Injection Molding Machine #18 in UNIT-001 (Injection Molding Line A - Automotive) when he noticed unusual vibration and grinding sounds coming from the hydraulic pump assembly. The machine had been in continuous operation for 18 hours without maintenance inspection. Blanchard attempted to adjust the pressure relief valve manually when the pump suddenly seized, causing the connected hydraulic line to rupture violently. Pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the control panel and work area, causing an electrical short circuit that triggered a small fire in the motor housing. The machine automatically shut down due to the electrical fault. Blanchard sustained minor burns on his left forearm from the hydraulic spray and was treated on-site by the HSE team. The incident was caused by inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling and failure to perform required pre-shift equipment inspections. Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel, working nearby, witnessed the event and immediately notified emergency response personnel.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT building) when an acetone cleaning solvent container accidentally overturned in the chemical storage area near heating equipment. The spilled solvent (approximately 15 liters) created flammable vapors that were detected by the facility's vapor detection system, causing an automatic alarm activation. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette immediately initiated the facility evacuation protocol and coordinated with the Laval Fire Department who arrived within 8 minutes. Material Handler Salma Haddad, who was organizing chemical inventory nearby, evacuated safely and assisted in guiding other employees to assembly points. The fire suppression system activated automatically, deploying foam suppression agents that contained the spill and prevented ignition. Investigation revealed that the chemical storage shelf had deteriorated mounting brackets due to corrosion from previous solvent exposure, causing structural failure. All employees evacuated safely with no injuries reported. The incident exposed gaps in chemical storage area inspection protocols and maintenance of storage infrastructure.

On April 2, 2024 at 06:30 during the night shift, Tool and Die Maker Mario Bélisle was operating CNC Milling Machine #7 in the Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) when the automatic tool changer mechanism failed mid-operation. The spindle continued rotating while attempting to extract a worn cutting tool, causing the tool bit to lodge improperly in the spindle. When Bélisle manually attempted to clear the jam using a removal tool, the spindle unexpectedly resumed rotation despite the emergency stop button being engaged. The rotating tool contacted his gloved right hand, causing a laceration to his index and middle fingers and crushing the fingertip area. The machine's control system failed to register the emergency stop command due to a faulty safety relay module that had not been replaced during the previous maintenance cycle. Bélisle immediately withdrew his hand and activated the main power disconnect. First Aid was administered on-site and he was transported to the hospital with moderate hand injuries. The incident revealed critical failures in the machine's safety interlock system and inadequate preventive maintenance documentation for critical safety components.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak was discovered in the Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components area. Operator Bertrand Jalbert noticed water pooling beneath the main cooling circuit and immediately notified his supervisor. The leak originated from a corroded coupling joint on the secondary cooling line that supplies temperature control fluid to the injection molds. Water had been accumulating for approximately 2-3 hours before detection, creating a slip hazard on the production floor and saturating electrical junction boxes nearby. The cooling fluid mixture (water and glycol-based additive) spread across approximately 15 square meters of the clean room area, requiring immediate containment and environmental response. The production line was shut down, and the hazardous materials team was called to assess contamination risk. No direct contact injuries occurred, but the incident highlighted critical maintenance gaps in the cooling system preventive maintenance schedule. The leak was temporarily sealed, and the affected area was cleaned and dried within 4 hours. Environmental monitoring confirmed no release beyond the contained area.

On November 22, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Rania Abdallah was preparing composite materials in the Material Drying and Preparation Room when she observed abnormal smoke generation from the resin mixing vessel. She immediately recognized the early warning signs of potential thermal runaway in the epoxy-fiber composite batch and activated the emergency shutdown procedure before any ignition could occur. The batch temperature had climbed to 78°C (normal operating range is 45-55°C) due to a malfunctioning thermostat control unit that failed to regulate heating properly. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion was notified and arrived within 2 minutes. The material was safely cooled using the emergency water bath protocol, and the batch was quarantined pending analysis. A near-miss situation was averted—had the operator not recognized the warning signs, the exothermic reaction could have escalated to a fire incident involving flammable resin vapors and potential chemical exposure to all personnel in the vicinity. The thermostat unit was immediately isolated and replaced with a manual backup control. No injuries occurred, and material damage was limited to one batch worth approximately $3,200.

On December 3, 2024, the HSE Coordinator Samira El-Khoury conducted a routine ergonomic assessment in the Quality Control Laboratory as part of TechnoPlast's preventive health surveillance program. During the assessment, she identified that quality technician Natalya Kozlov has developed early signs of repetitive strain injury (RSI) in her right wrist and forearm. Natalya performs approximately 400-500 manual tensile strength tests per shift, involving repetitive grasping, pulling, and twisting motions. She reported intermittent pain and stiffness in her wrist but had not previously reported these symptoms due to initial belief they would resolve independently. Samira documented the findings using standardized ergonomic assessment tools (RULA and NIOSH lifting index) and classified this as a preventive declaration—no lost time or medical incident has occurred, but early intervention is warranted to prevent progression to a reportable occupational illness. The assessment revealed multiple ergonomic risk factors: inadequate wrist support on the testing apparatus, non-adjustable work surface height, and lack of job rotation to distribute repetitive strain across different muscle groups. This finding triggers proactive corrective action before any lost-time injury occurs.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring a 20-liter container of epoxy resin catalyst from a storage shelf in the chemical mixing room (UNIT-017) to the mixing station. While repositioning the container on the work bench, the cap became loose and approximately 3 liters of the catalyst spilled across the floor and partially onto Elena's left leg and work boot. The spill occurred near an active heat source (curing oven set at 120°C) located 2 meters away. Elena immediately notified her supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079) and relocated to a safe distance. The spill was contained within 15 minutes using absorbent material and neutralizing agent per protocol. The area was ventilated and cleaned. Elena experienced mild skin irritation on her leg but declined medical attention. Root cause investigation revealed the container cap had not been properly sealed during previous use, and the shelf storage location was inadequate for preventing tipping. The incident was reported by EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) at 15:30.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine maintenance cleaning around the mold ejection area of the injection molding machine. While reaching into the machine cavity to remove accumulated plastic debris, his right sleeve caught on the mold safety interlock sensor, partially disengaging it from the safety mechanism. Before the machine could be restarted for the next cycle, Mathieu noticed the unusual sensor position and immediately stopped work. He contacted his supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079) and reported the issue. Investigation revealed that the safety sensor had become misaligned due to vibration and would have allowed machine startup with the cavity access door open—a critical safety failure that could have resulted in severe hand or arm entanglement. The near-miss was caught because Mathieu followed proper lockout procedures and maintained situational awareness. Quality Supervisor Yves documented the incident and reported it to EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) at 22:45. No injuries occurred.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 06:20 during the night shift, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead, was retrieving stacked composite material storage bins from the upper shelf in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) using a step ladder. He had removed three bins and was reaching for a fourth bin when the ladder shifted on the concrete floor, causing him to lose his balance. Michel fell approximately 1.5 meters to the floor, landing on his left side. He sustained a fracture of the left radius and ulna (forearm) and significant bruising to his left shoulder and ribs. Coworker Nour Jaber (EMP-00188), Packaging Operator, who was nearby, immediately called for emergency assistance. Michel was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval and admitted for treatment. X-rays confirmed a displaced fracture requiring surgical intervention. Root cause analysis identified that the ladder had been placed on an uneven floor surface with debris underneath, and the ladder lacked proper non-slip feet. Additionally, no spotter was present to stabilize the ladder. Michel's incident was reported by Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) at 08:00 and classified as a lost-time injury.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron was transferring a 20-liter container of mold release agent from a storage shelf to a mixing station when the container's lid was not properly secured. As he positioned the container on the work surface, approximately 8 liters of the solvent-based release agent spilled across the floor and onto adjacent storage containers. The spill created a slippery hazard and released volatile organic compound vapors into the workspace. Production Operator Yara Mustafa, who was working in the adjacent area preparing materials for mixing operations, immediately noticed the fumes and alerted Bergeron. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher responded within 5 minutes with absorbent materials and activated the ventilation system to full capacity. The spill was contained and cleaned within 20 minutes. No personnel were physically exposed to the chemical, but two workers experienced mild eye and throat irritation from vapor exposure. The incident was traced to inadequate container inspection procedures and missing containment protocols during material transfers.

On February 22, 2024, at 09:30 during the day shift, Production Operator Conrad Therrien sustained a burn injury while operating Injection Molding Line A. Therrien was removing finished parts from a mold cavity when contact with molten plastic residue still on the mold surface caused a second-degree burn to his right palm and lower forearm. The mold had been insufficiently cooled after the injection cycle; normal operating procedure calls for a 45-second cooling period, but production pressure led supervisors to reduce this to 30 seconds. Therrien was not wearing the required heat-resistant gloves—he had removed them moments before contact, placing them on a nearby workstation. Production Supervisor Michael Chen observed the injury immediately and provided first aid using the first aid station, applying cool water to the affected area for 10 minutes and applying sterile gauze. The employee was transported to the on-site occupational health nurse, Hana Al-Rashid, who assessed the burn as requiring medical attention beyond first aid capability. Therrien was sent to the urgent care clinic for professional wound treatment. The incident report identified inadequate cooling time protocols and non-compliance with PPE requirements as contributing factors.

On January 18, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme suffered a back injury while manually handling large plastic resin bags in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). Laflamme was attempting to relocate a pallet of 50-pound polypropylene resin bags from one storage section to another using improper lifting technique. He bent from the waist with straight legs, lifted a single bag to shoulder height without bending his knees, and twisted his torso while placing the bag on a high shelf. Immediately upon placing the bag, he felt sharp lower back pain and was unable to straighten up. Quality Systems Coordinator Sakura Kobayashi, who was conducting an evening inventory audit, witnessed the incident and called for assistance. Production Supervisor André Paradis responded and found Laflamme in considerable pain. First aid assessment indicated acute lower back strain. Laflamme was transported to the occupational health nurse and subsequently to an emergency room for imaging studies. X-rays revealed no fractures, but MRI imaging confirmed a moderate lumbar strain with mild disc bulging at L4-L5. Medical clearance restricted Laflamme from lifting duties for 8 weeks, resulting in lost work time and reassignment to light-duty administrative tasks. Root cause analysis identified inadequate ergonomic training, absence of mechanical lifting equipment for bulk materials, and pressure to move inventory quickly.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine maintenance on a resin dryer unit in Production Operations. The equipment had been in continuous operation since the morning shift began. While attempting to clear a suspected blockage in the material feed line, Youssef noticed the dryer temperature gauge reading 285°C, significantly higher than the standard 220°C operating range. Despite the elevated temperature, he proceeded to loosen a pressure release valve to clear the blockage. A sudden pressurized burst of hot resin vapor and molten plastic particles erupted from the valve opening, causing severe thermal burns to his face, neck, and right forearm. The employee immediately fell backward and was caught by nearby operator Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), who activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. First responders arrived within 8 minutes. The incident was caused by a malfunctioning temperature controller that had failed silently during the morning shift, and inadequate pre-maintenance equipment status checks. Youssef was transported to Hôpital Général de Montréal with second-degree burns covering approximately 15% of his body surface. He required surgical intervention and skin grafting, resulting in 6 weeks of lost work time and ongoing rehabilitation.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 09:30 during the day shift, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, was retrieving composite fiber reinforced resin spools from the upper shelves of the Regrind and Recycling Department storage racks in Warehouse and Shipping Section C. While reaching overhead to pull a 35-pound spool from the third shelf (approximately 2.2 meters high), Hassan's grip slipped due to residual resin dust on the spool surface. The spool fell directly, striking Hassan's left shoulder and upper back. Hassan immediately experienced sharp pain and numbness down his left arm. Co-worker Nour Jaber (EMP-00188), a Packaging Operator in the adjacent area, witnessed the incident and helped Hassan sit down while calling for first aid assistance. The facility's on-site first aid attendant, Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), arrived within 5 minutes and provided initial assessment. Hassan was treated with ice application and pain management medication. Medical evaluation at a local clinic confirmed a mild rotator cuff strain and contusion with no fractures. Hassan returned to work the next day with modified duties (no overhead lifting) for 3 days. This incident was caused by inadequate storage rack design for heavy items, lack of mechanical assistance for overhead retrieval, and insufficient slip-resistant surface treatment on composite materials.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), a Machine Setter, was performing setup procedures on Injection Molding Line D in preparation for a production run of polycarbonate automotive components. While adjusting the mold clamping pressure with a manual hydraulic control valve, Svetlana did not follow proper Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedures. The machine had been de-energized but not properly locked out. Another operator, attempting to perform a routine cycle check from the control panel, inadvertently activated the injection unit. The hydraulic pressure surge caused the mold to partially open with extreme force, striking Svetlana's left hand that was positioned near the mold interface. Svetlana sustained a crush injury to her index and middle fingers with fractures at the metacarpophalangeal joints and significant soft tissue damage. Evening shift supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) immediately activated emergency protocols, safely shut down all equipment, and called emergency medical services. Svetlana was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where she underwent emergency surgery including internal fixation of the fractures. She was hospitalized for 4 days and required 8 weeks of recovery with modified duties before returning to full production work. The incident was caused by non-compliance with LOTO procedures, inadequate supervision of setup activities, and lack of machine guarding during the setup phase.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Zara Khan (EMP-00106) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area. While removing finished composite medical components from the mold cavity, Khan developed acute pain in her right wrist and hand. Over the preceding 6 weeks, she had been experiencing progressive numbness and tingling in her fingers during her shift work. Despite reporting discomfort to her supervisor on two occasions, no ergonomic assessment was conducted. On this date, Khan could no longer grip the components and experienced severe sharp pain radiating from her wrist to her fingertips. She immediately informed her lead, Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), who contacted HSE. Khan was sent to occupational health services where she was diagnosed with Stage 2 carpal tunnel syndrome with nerve compression. She was placed on medical leave for 3 weeks and prescribed physical therapy. The incident was triggered by repetitive gripping motions without adequate rest periods, combined with poor workstation ergonomics and lack of job rotation. Khan's hand remained swollen for several days post-incident.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, Injection Molding Line C experienced a significant hopper overflow incident. Injection Molding Operator Yasmin Ali was processing a batch of polypropylene resin when the automatic hopper level sensor malfunctioned, failing to stop material flow into the hopper. The hopper, designed to hold 500 kg of material, accumulated approximately 750 kg of resin before the overflow became apparent. Molten plastic spilled across the production floor, spreading approximately 12 meters in a fan-shaped pattern. The material came into contact with electrical conduit, a hydraulic line, and damaged three injection mold temperature controllers valued at approximately $8,500. Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi, who was nearby performing routine equipment checks, immediately activated the emergency stop on the line. Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant initiated the facility evacuation protocol and contacted maintenance. The spilled material cooled and solidified, requiring 4 hours of manual removal using chisels and heat guns. No personnel were burned, but the incident resulted in 8 hours of production downtime on Line C.

On April 3, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, a significant chemical storage incident occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois discovered that a 50-liter container of acetone-based mold release agent had developed a pinhole leak, spraying approximately 8 liters of solvent across the storage mezzanine. The container was stored on a metal shelf with inadequate secondary containment, and the liquid had spread across multiple shelves, damaging packaging materials and staining the concrete floor over an area of approximately 15 square meters. The chemical pooled beneath a propane storage area, creating a potential fire hazard. Facilities Technician Georges Plante was called to respond and immediately implemented spill containment using absorbent materials and barriers to prevent further chemical migration toward the electrical panel area. The incident resulted in $3,200 in damaged materials (packaging, labels, and product) and required professional hazmat cleanup costing $2,400. The spill generated strong solvent fumes affecting air quality throughout the warehouse section, necessitating temporary ventilation system enhancement and worker rotation to minimize exposure.

On May 22, 2024 at 08:30 during the day shift, Quality Control Technician Sophie Lapointe was transporting finished parts in the Finished Goods Warehouse using a manual pallet jack when the jack's wheels became caught on a raised edge where the warehouse floor had settled and cracked. The pallet jack suddenly stopped, and the load of 24 plastic injection-molded automotive components shifted forward, toppling from the pallet and crashing to the concrete floor. The parts, valued at approximately $11,400 (representing 2 days of production for that specific customer order), sustained significant damage with 18 units showing stress cracks, warping, and surface damage rendering them non-saleable. The remaining 6 parts had minor cosmetic damage requiring rework. Quality Control Manager Isabelle Tremblay responded and conducted an immediate quality assessment. The customer order, destined for a major automotive supplier in Ontario, experienced a 4-day delay while replacement parts were manufactured. Floor condition analysis revealed the crack was 8 mm wide and had been progressively widening for approximately 3 months. No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident resulted in expedited production scheduling and customer relationship strain.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050), a Production Operator on Injection Molding Line D, sustained a laceration to her right hand while removing finished parts from the molding machine. The machine had completed its cycle and Fatou was manually extracting consumer packaging components when her hand made contact with a sharp edge that had formed on one of the ejector pins during the cooling phase. The part had developed a burr during the injection process due to a worn mold insert. Her hand slipped while gripping the part and her index and middle fingers contacted the sharp edge, resulting in deep lacerations requiring 8 stitches. First aid was administered immediately by the plant medical responder. Sébastien Carrier, the Production Engineer, was present at the line and witnessed the incident. The incident was reported to the HSE department within 15 minutes, and the machine was taken offline for mold inspection. The sharp-edged part was retained as evidence.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on the evening shift, nearly sustained a serious injury while performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine's hydraulic pressure relief system. Abdul was attempting to access the pressure release valve to check for leaks when he did not properly follow the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure—he failed to de-energize the hydraulic pump before beginning work. As he loosened the valve connection, a sudden pressure release from the equipment sprayed hot hydraulic fluid (approximately 65°C) across his torso and left arm. Quick reflexes and his proximity to the emergency shower station allowed him to immediately rinse away the fluid. He experienced minor skin irritation but no permanent burn injuries. A witness, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), observed the incident and immediately notified the HSE team. The incident was classified as a near-miss because while exposure occurred, no medical intervention beyond observation was required and no lost time resulted. The chemical safety officer conducted a hazard debrief immediately after.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-015) when a spontaneous combustion event began in a container of uncovered, waste-saturated cotton rags stored near the resin mixing station. The night shift supervisor, noticing a faint smell of burning material and seeing wisps of smoke rising from a storage bin, immediately activated the fire alarm and evacuated all personnel from the chemical storage section. The Laval Fire Department responded within 8 minutes. No employees were injured, and the fire was extinguished before any significant damage occurred, though the waste container and approximately 15 kilograms of surrounding material were destroyed. Investigation revealed that the cotton rags had absorbed uncured polyester resin and were improperly stored in an open bin directly adjacent to a heat-generating resin dryer unit. The spontaneous oxidation of the resin-saturated material, combined with ambient heat from the dryer, created conditions for spontaneous combustion. The incident was classified as a fire alarm event because the fire was detected and suppressed through alarm activation and emergency response before substantial property damage or injury occurred.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45 hours, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-012) during the evening shift. An operator, Jade Wong (EMP-00140), was conducting routine maintenance on the resin mixing equipment when she noticed excessive heat emanating from the heating element of the composite resin dryer. The temperature gauge had malfunctioned, causing the dryer to overheat beyond safe operating parameters. Within minutes, the thermostatic safety cutoff failed to activate. Smoke began rising from the equipment, and the facility's automatic fire detection system activated the alarm at 14:48 hours. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) immediately initiated evacuation procedures. The facility was evacuated within 8 minutes with all 47 personnel present accounted for. The local fire department arrived at 15:02 hours and extinguished the fire using dry chemical powder, preventing ignition of nearby flammable resin materials stored within 3 meters of the dryer. The fire was contained to the dryer unit itself with minimal damage. Root cause analysis revealed the heating element thermostat had not been calibrated in 18 months, exceeding the manufacturer's recommended 12-month calibration interval.

On October 22, 2024 at 09:30 hours, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) during the day shift. Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyurethane adhesive when the forklift operated by Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) struck a protruding storage rack support beam. The impact caused the drum to shift and fall from the pallet, rupturing on the concrete floor. Approximately 12 gallons of the adhesive spilled across an area of approximately 120 square feet. The material began spreading toward the warehouse drainage system. Salma immediately notified her supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) at 09:33 hours. The HSE team, led by Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), arrived at 09:41 hours. They established a perimeter using barrier tape and deployed absorbent granules to contain the spill. The spill was completely absorbed within 45 minutes. No personnel came into direct contact with the spilled material. Root cause investigation determined that the storage rack had been installed with insufficient clearance for forklift operations, and operators had not received updated training on the new warehouse layout implemented three weeks prior.

On December 3, 2024 at 16:20 hours, Quality Systems Coordinator Sakura Kobayashi (EMP-00158) submitted a preventive declaration to the HSE department regarding a potential occupational health risk identified during routine assembly line observation in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019). While observing afternoon shift operations, Sakura noted that assembly operators including Zara Khan (EMP-00106) and Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) were performing repetitive hand and wrist motions at high frequency without scheduled rest breaks. Sakura observed that operators were applying labels and performing final packaging checks continuously for 4-hour periods. She documented that two operators reported subjective wrist discomfort at the end of shift, and medical records showed that over the past 6 months, three workers in this station had filed claims related to carpal tunnel syndrome symptoms. Sakura's concern centered on the absence of job rotation protocols and lack of ergonomic micro-break procedures. She noted that workstations had not been ergonomically assessed in over 18 months. This preventive declaration was submitted to Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) on December 3, 2024 to initiate proactive intervention before additional cases develop.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was organizing resin pallets in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) when she noticed an unstable stack of polypropylene resin bags that had been improperly stacked the previous evening. The bags were tilted at a dangerous angle and positioned near the main aisle where multiple employees regularly walk. Rather than attempt to manually correct the situation, Bianchi immediately notified her supervisor and cordoned off the area with caution tape. She documented the hazard with photographs and reported it to the HSE department as a preventive measure. The unstable arrangement posed a significant risk of falling materials onto personnel working below. Her proactive identification prevented a potential struck-by incident that could have caused serious injuries. No employee was injured, and the situation was rectified within two hours by the warehouse team using proper material handling equipment.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:47 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm was accidentally activated in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (East Section) when Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) was performing routine maintenance on a hydraulic power unit. While cleaning around the equipment with compressed air, Marchand inadvertently dislodged accumulated plastic dust and fibers that entered the optical sensor of a heat detection system mounted directly above the equipment. The sensor misinterpreted the dust passage as a flame signature and triggered the fire suppression system activation. The facility's automatic fire suppression system discharged its contents, releasing approximately 800 gallons of inert gas-based suppressant throughout the workshop and adjacent areas. This caused temporary respiratory irritation to Marchand and two other technicians working nearby (Giovanni Bianchi, EMP-00032, and Armand Lévesque, EMP-00189). The electrical equipment sustained no damage, but suppressant residue contaminated several precision instruments. Emergency response teams arrived within 6 minutes and confirmed no actual fire. The facility was ventilated over 3 hours.

On March 18, 2024, at 6:35 AM during the night shift, Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) was performing routine startup checks on Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components) when she observed a material handler, Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), placing her hand into a material feeder that was inadvertently running at low power. Haddad had not realized the equipment was partially energized and reached into the hopper to dislodge a bridged resin pellet. Upon seeing this hazardous act, Fillion immediately shut down the line with the emergency stop button and called out to Haddad to withdraw her hand. Haddad's hand was grazed by rotating auger blades, resulting in superficial lacerations on two fingers and minor abrasions on her palm. The incident was immediately reported. First aid was administered on-site by the night shift coordinator, including wound cleaning, antiseptic application, and sterile bandaging. Haddad was assessed for tetanus prophylaxis and released to continue work with modified duty restrictions. No fractures or deep tissue damage occurred. The equipment was locked and tagged pending investigation.

On March 14, 2025 at 2:15 PM, Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a Production Operator on the day shift, noticed unusual vibrations and a faint burning smell emanating from Injection Molding Machine Line C in the Main Production Building. She immediately stopped the machine and informed her supervisor. Upon inspection, maintenance personnel discovered that the cooling water system had developed a significant leak at one of the connection joints, causing coolant to spray onto the machine's heating elements. The leaked coolant had pooled on the floor beneath the machine, creating a slipping hazard. Approximately 15 liters of cooling fluid were lost before the leak was isolated. The machine was shut down for repairs, and the area was cordoned off with warning tape. No personnel were directly exposed to the leaked fluid, but the incident highlighted a critical maintenance gap in the preventive inspection schedule. The machine required 4 hours of downtime for repair and system refilling.

On March 18, 2025 at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, reached into the mold extraction area to remove a completed part. As he withdrew his hand, the injection cycle unexpectedly triggered due to a malfunctioning proximity sensor, causing the mold to close rapidly. Paul's left hand remained partially within the mold cavity during closure. He immediately felt pressure on his fingers and shouted for assistance. His coworker, Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), was nearby and immediately hit the emergency stop button, halting the machine within 2 seconds. Paul sustained minor crushing injuries to his middle and ring fingers, with surface bruising and a small laceration but no fractures. He was able to withdraw his hand immediately after the emergency stop. First aid was administered on-site, and Paul was advised to seek medical evaluation. The malfunction was traced to a failed sensor that had not been replaced during the previous maintenance cycle, creating a critical hazard that could have resulted in severe amputation.

On March 22, 2025 at 3:20 AM during the night shift, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, was transferring resin containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building when he noticed a crack had developed in the side seam of a large epoxy resin storage tank (approximately 50 gallons capacity). The crack was releasing a steady drip of amber-colored epoxy resin onto the concrete floor. Hassan immediately evacuated the immediate area, activated the facility alarm, and notified the on-duty supervisor. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, responded and estimated approximately 8-10 gallons of epoxy resin had leaked before containment measures were initiated. The leaking tank was carefully tilted and positioned to direct remaining resin into emergency containment drums. The spill area was covered with absorbent materials and the hazardous waste disposal procedures were followed. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) conducted air quality testing which showed no volatile organic compound (VOC) exceedances in the facility atmosphere. The storage tank was subsequently removed and replaced. Investigation revealed the crack was caused by internal corrosion from moisture contamination in the stored resin, combined with improper storage temperature maintenance during a weekend when the facility HVAC system had partially failed.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a minor thermal burn while performing routine mold maintenance. While removing a completed part from the heated mold cavity, Gendron inadvertently contacted the mold surface with his left forearm. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C (185°F). Despite wearing standard heat-resistant gloves, the contact duration of approximately 2 seconds resulted in a first-degree burn affecting an area of approximately 4cm x 3cm on his forearm. The employee immediately removed his arm and notified his supervisor, Michael Chen. First aid was administered on-site by the production supervisor within 5 minutes—cool water irrigation for 15 minutes followed by sterile gauze application. The burn did not require medical attention beyond first aid and the employee continued working for the remainder of the shift with topical burn cream and a protective bandage. The incident was attributed to momentary lapse in attention while retrieving parts quickly to meet production targets.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler, was transferring a 20-liter container of mold release agent from a shelf when the container's lid became unsealed due to improper closure from the previous shift. Approximately 3 liters of the volatile organic compound spilled onto the floor, creating a hazardous slick surface and emitting strong solvent vapors. Haddad immediately stepped back and did not slip or fall, and she quickly notified her supervisor. The spill was contained within 8 minutes using absorbent material and proper cleanup procedures per WHMIS guidelines. Ventilation systems in the storage area were activated and the room was evacuated for 20 minutes. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed a critical gap: the container lid inspection procedure was missing from the chemical handling checklist. A coworker in the adjacent hallway reported experiencing slight dizziness from vapor exposure, though this resolved upon exiting the area.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 06:45 during night shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014). Luc Girard (EMP-00039), a Maintenance Technician, was performing routine preventive maintenance on a 480-volt electrical control panel for Injection Molding Line C. While attempting to access the interior components, Girard positioned himself directly in front of the open panel door to review schematic diagrams. A sudden voltage transient event (later attributed to a utility-side fluctuation) caused an electrical arc to flash across exposed bus bars within the panel, generating an intense light and heat burst. Girard reflexively turned his head away, and the arc flash did not make direct contact with him, though he experienced significant startle response. The incident was discovered when Thanh Pham (EMP-00062), the Maintenance Planner on rounds, observed scorch marks on the interior panel components and found Girard shaken but uninjured. Investigation revealed that the panel's arc flash mitigation labels were illegible due to age and fading, and Girard had not consulted the updated electrical safety protocol that required temporary de-energization and lockout/tagout for this specific maintenance task.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, injection molding operator Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117) was working at Line C in the Medical Components clean room area. While removing a finished part from the 250-ton injection molding machine, her left hand came into contact with the mold release agent residue on the ejector pins. The contact caused immediate skin irritation and chemical burn symptoms. Desjardins reported burning sensation and redness on her palm and fingers within minutes. She immediately washed the affected area with water and reported to first aid. Quality inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) witnessed the incident and assisted her to the first aid station. The mold release agent used was a silicone-based spray cleaner (REACH-compliant but still caustic). Upon inspection, it was determined that the automatic ejector pin cleaning cycle had malfunctioned, leaving residual chemical on the pins. The employee had worn standard nitrile gloves, which provided insufficient protection against the specific chemical composition. First aid was administered, and the employee experienced ongoing irritation for approximately 6 hours before symptoms subsided.

On March 18, 2025, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift, the material drying and preparation room experienced a critical equipment failure. A resin dryer unit (Model XDR-3000) used for pre-processing composite materials suddenly began overheating. The internal temperature sensor failed to trigger the automatic shutdown protocol, causing the dryer's internal temperature to exceed safe operating parameters by approximately 80°C. Maintenance planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) was conducting rounds when he noticed smoke emanating from the unit's ventilation outlet and a burning plastic odor. He immediately initiated an emergency shutdown by cutting power to the unit and activated the facility fire alarm as a precaution. The dryer's heating element partially melted, and approximately 150 kilograms of resin material inside charred and became unusable. Initial investigation revealed that the temperature sensor's calibration had drifted beyond acceptable tolerance, and the unit had not received scheduled preventive maintenance in 8 months due to staffing shortages. The incident resulted in approximately 18 hours of production downtime for the Material Drying and Preparation Room and required replacement of the heating element assembly and all affected resin batches.

On March 22, 2025, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift operations, warehouse supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) was performing inventory verification in the warehouse section. While manually lifting a pallet of resin pellets weighing approximately 35 kilograms from a mid-level storage rack (approximately 1.5 meters high), his lower back suddenly seized with acute pain. O'Connor had bent forward without proper knee flexion and twisted his torso while retrieving the pallet. He immediately felt sharp pain in his lower lumbar region and was unable to straighten up. Forklift operator Claude Poirier (EMP-00071) witnessed the incident and called for medical assistance. O'Connor was helped to a sitting position and first aid attendant Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) applied ice to the affected area. After 45 minutes, O'Connor was able to stand with assistance but reported continued pain rated at 7/10. He was transported to the emergency clinic for evaluation where imaging confirmed acute lumbar strain with mild disc bulge. The employee was unable to return to work and required a 10-day recovery period. Root cause analysis revealed that O'Connor had not followed proper lifting procedures, the storage rack required reaching beyond the recommended height, and he had not used the available mechanical lift-assist equipment.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165) was performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building. While wiping down the exterior surfaces near the hydraulic connections, Couture's work glove became caught between the mold closing mechanism and its protective guard. The employee immediately pulled his hand back, and the glove tore free without entangling his hand or fingers. Couture noticed the incident had exposed a gap in the machine guarding that should have prevented access to the pinch point. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette responded within minutes and verified no injury occurred. The machine was immediately shut down and a temporary barrier was erected. Investigation revealed that a section of the interlocked safety guard had been improperly reinstalled after recent maintenance, leaving a 1.5-inch gap at the machine's side panel. The near-miss was documented and the guard was properly repositioned. This incident highlighted a critical gap in lockout/tagout verification procedures following equipment maintenance.

On March 18, 2024 at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a propane-powered forklift operated by Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) in the Warehouse and Shipping section collided with stacked pallets of finished goods during a routine material repositioning task. Croteau was moving three pallets of packaged automotive components toward the shipping dock when the forklift's left front tire encountered a piece of discarded plastic film on the warehouse floor. The tire caught the debris, causing a sudden pull to the left. The operator attempted to correct the trajectory but overcompensated, striking a storage rack holding approximately 2,400 kilograms of finished medical device housings stacked on pallets six feet high. The impact caused approximately 800 kilograms of packaged inventory to fall from the upper pallets onto the ground and several pallets to shift. The product damage is estimated at $47,000 due to packaging damage and potential contamination of sterile medical components. No employees were struck by falling materials. Croteau sustained minor bruising on his right forearm from impact with the forklift seat. The warehouse floor was thoroughly inspected and the debris removed. The damaged inventory has been quarantined pending quality assessment.

On March 20, 2024 at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was performing precision mold finishing work in the Maintenance Workshop. While machining a complex injection mold cavity, a small aluminum chip approximately 8mm in diameter was ejected from the cutting tool at high velocity and struck Sokolov directly in the left eye. Despite wearing standard safety glasses, the sharp chip penetrated between the lens and the employee's face, striking the eye tissue. Sokolov immediately experienced pain and noticed blood pooling beneath the eyelid. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette was notified and arrived within 2 minutes. First aid was administered including gentle eye irrigation with sterile saline solution and application of a sterile eye pad. Sokolov was transported by company vehicle to the nearby emergency clinic at Hôpital de Laval approximately 3 kilometers away, arriving at 6:35 AM. Emergency medical examination revealed a superficial corneal abrasion with minor subconjunctival hemorrhage. No permanent vision loss occurred. Sokolov received antibiotic eye drops and was instructed to rest with eye closure for 24 hours. He was cleared to return to modified duty after 48 hours with follow-up appointments scheduled. Investigation revealed the CNC machine's chip deflector shield had not been properly repositioned after the previous day's preventive maintenance.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (UNIT-017). Production Operator Laila Hamdan was transferring cured composite parts from an industrial oven when she noticed smoke accumulating near the ventilation ductwork. She immediately activated the nearest fire alarm pull station. The smoke was subsequently traced to a buildup of plastic dust and resin particles that had accumulated on the heating elements and ventilation filters over several weeks of continuous operation. Although no active fire had ignited, the combination of high temperatures (180°C) and accumulated flammable dust created a critical pre-fire condition. The facility was evacuated safely within 4 minutes, with all 47 employees on the day shift exiting through designated emergency routes. The fire department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the hazardous condition. Facilities Technician Georges Plante and the maintenance team performed an immediate shutdown of all heating equipment and initiated thorough cleaning of the ventilation system. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed a significant gap in preventive maintenance procedures.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant fire incident occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) located on the maintenance workshop storage mezzanine. Tool and Die Maker Mario Bélisle was retrieving replacement injection nozzles when he knocked over a container of solvent (isopropyl alcohol) near a portable electric heater that had been placed in the storage area for warmth during cooler evenings. The spilled solvent immediately ignited from the heater's exposed heating coil, creating a rapidly spreading fire. Bélisle immediately activated the manual fire alarm and used a nearby Class B fire extinguisher to contain the initial flames while evacuating the area. Production Supervisor André Paradis from the night shift responded within 60 seconds and assisted with extinguisher deployment. The facility's automatic sprinkler system activated at 10:17 PM, fully extinguishing the fire. However, approximately 35% of stored spare parts and equipment were destroyed, with an estimated replacement value of $67,000. The fire spread across approximately 8 square meters before suppression. A minor burn to Bélisle's left forearm (first-degree) was treated on-site by the first aid team. Root cause analysis determined that the portable heater was stored in violation of facility fire safety protocols—flammable materials must be stored at least 3 meters away from any ignition source.

On March 28, 2024, at 8:20 AM during the day shift, an occupational injury incident occurred at Injection Molding Line A in the automotive production section (UNIT-001). Production Operator Benoit Arsenault was performing routine quality checks on molded automotive components when his right hand inadvertently contacted the exposed mold platen of an active injection molding machine. The machine had been programmed for a 0.8-second cycle time, and Arsenault's hand remained in contact with the hot mold surface (approximately 165°C) for approximately 1.2 seconds before he reflexively withdrew his hand. He sustained a partial-thickness thermal burn affecting the dorsal surface of his right hand, covering approximately 3% of total body surface area. The burn involved the back of the hand and two fingers (index and middle). Arsenault immediately reported the injury to Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert, who initiated first aid with cool water irrigation for 15 minutes and applied sterile dressings. The employee was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval, where the burn was assessed as requiring outpatient treatment with follow-up wound care. Medical documentation confirmed estimated healing time of 10-14 days. Investigation revealed that the machine's guard had been partially disassembled for maintenance 90 minutes prior and had not been fully reinstalled before production resumed. The guard would have prevented hand access to the mold surface.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, was assisting Natasha Ivanov with inventory management when a 55-gallon drum of acetone-based mold release agent was being transferred to a smaller container. The drum was positioned on an unstable metal shelf that had been overloaded with other chemical containers. Due to inadequate shelf support and vibration from nearby equipment, the drum tipped over, spilling approximately 40 gallons of acetone solvent onto the concrete floor. The spill immediately created a hazardous vapor cloud and spread across approximately 120 square feet of the storage area. Natasha Ivanov immediately activated the emergency response protocol, evacuating personnel and calling for containment. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and neutralizing agents over a 3-hour period. No personnel were directly exposed to the liquid, but two employees (Valerie Pelletier and Roland Dostie) reported respiratory irritation from the vapors and were assessed by first aid responders. The incident was caused by inadequate shelf design, improper load distribution, and lack of secondary containment for hazardous liquids.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a critical equipment failure occurred on Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building. Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), the Injection Molding Operator assigned to Line B, was running a standard production cycle for automotive components when the primary hydraulic pump experienced an unexpected catastrophic failure. The pump seal had degraded over time due to lack of preventive maintenance, and without warning, high-pressure hydraulic fluid began spraying from a fractured coupling. The fluid leaked rapidly onto electrical components and control systems, causing an electrical short circuit and loss of power to the entire molding line. The failure triggered an emergency shutdown, but not before the mold clamp mechanism partially failed to retract, leaving a mold assembly in a partially open and unstable position. Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147), the Regrind Supervisor, responded immediately and initiated lockout/tagout procedures coordinated with Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161). The line was safely de-energized and contained. Initial investigation revealed that the pump had never been included in the facility's preventive maintenance schedule despite manufacturer recommendations for service every 500 operating hours. The failure resulted in 16 hours of production downtime and approximately $85,000 in lost output.

On May 18, 2024, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, a fire incident began in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) in the Main Production Building's West Wing. Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), a Production Operator, was preparing resin batches for composite layup operations when she noticed a small spark emanate from an electrical junction box that had been improperly sealed, allowing dust and resin particulates to accumulate inside the enclosure. The spark ignited the accumulated composite fiber dust, which is highly flammable when suspended or concentrated. The initial small flame quickly spread through the dust-laden air, igniting a partially-opened storage bin containing approximately 50 pounds of uncovered carbon fiber scraps nearby. Within seconds, the fire expanded to approximately 8 feet in diameter. Yara activated the nearest fire alarm and attempted to use a standard ABC fire extinguisher, but the composite dust fire required specialized handling and the extinguisher was ineffective. The night shift supervisor (limited staff of only 2 people) called emergency services immediately. The fire was contained by the Laval Fire Department using specialized dry powder extinguishing agents and thermal imaging to locate hidden combustion areas. The fire caused damage to manufacturing equipment valued at $156,000, destroyed composite materials worth $34,000, and forced evacuation of the entire facility for 8 hours. No personnel were seriously injured, though Yara suffered minor first-degree burns on her hands and smoke inhalation requiring brief observation at the local hospital. The root cause was identified as inadequate housekeeping (accumulated composite dust in electrical enclosures), failure to maintain proper separation of flammable materials, and lack of specialized fire suppression systems for composite manufacturing areas.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Mariam Osman, a Material Handler, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin from storage to the mixing station when the drum's bung plug became loose due to improper seating during the previous shift. As Mariam positioned the drum on the cart, approximately 12 gallons of resin spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard. The spill also released volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors into the area. Mariam immediately notified her supervisor, and the area was evacuated within 2 minutes. The facility's spill response kit was deployed, and absorbent material was applied to contain the spill. No direct chemical contact with skin occurred, but the vapor exposure affected three nearby workers who reported mild respiratory irritation. Environmental response was initiated per Quebec environmental protocols. Root cause investigation revealed that the drum had not been properly secured during the previous evening shift, and the bung cap inspection procedure was not being consistently followed.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during evening shift operations, Mathieu Gendron, an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a significant laceration to his right hand while clearing a material blockage from an injection molding machine's hopper. Despite being instructed to use the provided mechanical clearing tools, Mathieu manually reached into the hopper opening to dislodge compacted composite material. The hopper vibration system unexpectedly activated—likely due to a malfunctioning proximity sensor—and caught his right hand between the vibrating hopper wall and the material blockage. His hand suffered a deep 3-inch laceration across the palm and lower forearm with partial exposure to underlying tissue. Mathieu immediately withdrew his hand and called for emergency assistance. He was transported by ambulance to Hôpital de l'Enfant-Jésus where he received 14 stitches and was admitted overnight for observation due to concerns about potential nerve damage. The employee lost 8 work days following the incident and required ongoing physical therapy. Investigation revealed that the proximity sensor on the hopper had not been functionally tested as part of the preventive maintenance schedule for 18 months.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during night shift operations, a significant chemical spill was discovered in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). Vincent Létourneau, an Instrumentation Technician, was conducting routine calibration checks on the waste containment system sensors when he noticed the secondary containment berm was saturated with liquid. Investigation revealed that a 200-liter intermediate bulk container (IBC) of uncured epoxy resin had developed a hairline crack in its plastic wall during the previous evening shift, likely due to thermal stress from temperature fluctuations between 18°C and 28°C. Approximately 80 liters of epoxy had leaked into the secondary containment over a 12-hour period, but the containment capacity was only 75 liters, resulting in approximately 5 liters of epoxy contaminating the exterior concrete pad and approaching a storm drain approximately 15 meters away. The spill extended into the adjacent soil. Immediate containment measures were implemented, including placement of absorbent booms and diversion of drainage flow. The contaminated soil required excavation and disposal as hazardous waste. Environmental authorities were notified and conducted a site assessment. No worker exposure to the spill occurred due to the night shift discovery. Root cause analysis identified that the IBC had been stored in direct sunlight without shade protection, and the facility's environmental monitoring system had not flagged the temperature variance.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a solvent storage container in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) developed a leak from a corroded valve connection. An employee, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), was retrieving acetone for the production line when he noticed the leak. Within minutes, approximately 15 liters of acetone had spilled onto the concrete floor near stacked polypropylene resin bags. The volatile fumes quickly accumulated in the poorly ventilated section of the warehouse. At 2:52 PM, a spark from a nearby forklift's electric motor ignited the acetone vapor, creating a flash fire that spread rapidly across the spilled material and up the side of several resin storage racks. The fire engulfed an area approximately 4 meters by 3 meters before facility sprinklers activated at 2:54 PM. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) was working nearby and immediately activated the emergency alarm and coordinated evacuation. Local fire services arrived at 3:08 PM and fully extinguished the fire by 3:25 PM. One resin storage rack was severely damaged, and approximately $85,000 in materials were lost or contaminated. No employee injuries were reported, though the facility was evacuated as a precaution.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), a CNC Operator, was operating a milling machine in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) to prepare custom mold inserts for a plastic injection molding job. While adjusting the cutting depth without fully disengaging the rotating spindle, Giovanni's left hand made contact with the spinning cutting tool. The high-speed rotation caught the edge of his work glove, pulling his hand toward the cutting surface. He sustained a deep laceration across the dorsal surface of his left hand between the thumb and index finger, approximately 6 centimeters in length, with minor damage to the underlying tendons. Giovanni immediately withdrew his hand and activated the emergency stop button. Colleague Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), a Mechanical Maintenance Technician, was present in the workshop and provided immediate first aid, applying pressure with a clean cloth to control bleeding. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen was contacted at 10:20 PM and coordinated transport to the nearest emergency clinic. Giovanni received 12 stitches and was cleared to return to light duty after 3 days. The incident revealed that the machine lacked functional guards in the cutting tool area and that lockout procedures were not being consistently followed for minor adjustments.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator, was loading finished composite parts into a pallet for packaging and shipping in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). The warehouse was dimly lit, with only essential night shift lighting activated. While lifting a large fiberglass-reinforced plastic panel (approximately 8 kg) from a work table to place it on the pallet, Amal experienced a sudden sharp pain in the lower back. The panel slipped from her grip and fell to the floor, cracking on impact. Amal immediately felt numbness radiating down her left leg and was unable to continue working. Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), the Material Handler on the night shift, assisted Amal to sit down and called for emergency assistance at 6:35 AM. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen responded from on-call status at 6:50 AM and arranged transport to the hospital. Imaging revealed a herniated disc at L4-L5, likely aggravated by the improper lifting technique combined with inadequate lighting and lack of mechanical lifting equipment. Amal was placed on medical leave for 6 weeks and required physical therapy. Investigation showed the warehouse lifting area lacked adjustable work tables, mechanical lifts, or ergonomic guidance signage.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, suffered a laceration to his left hand while performing routine mold cleaning. Paul was cleaning the cavity of a large automotive trim mold using compressed air and a brush when the air pressure suddenly increased due to a faulty pressure regulator that had not been serviced in 8 months. The sudden pressure surge caused the brush to strike his hand with significant force, creating a deep laceration across his palm. A coworker immediately applied pressure with clean gauze, and Paul was transported to the on-site first aid station where Alain Mercier, the Ergonomics Specialist, provided wound irrigation, antiseptic treatment, and a sterile dressing. The wound required 6 stitches but did not result in lost work time as Paul returned to modified duties the following day. The incident was witnessed by two assembly operators working nearby.

On April 8, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, suffered a significant back injury while manually transferring large spools of fiber-reinforced plastic material from a storage rack to a processing station. The spools, each weighing approximately 35 kg, were stacked 1.8 meters high on an inadequately designed rack. While reaching overhead to retrieve a spool, Rania lost her grip and the spool fell, striking her lower back and causing her to fall to the ground. She experienced immediate severe pain and was unable to stand without assistance. Luc-André Beaudoin, the Warehouse Supervisor for the evening shift (who was monitoring night operations), immediately called emergency services. Rania was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur and diagnosed with two compressed lumbar discs and acute lumbar strain. She was hospitalized for 3 days and prescribed 6 weeks of modified duty work. The incident resulted in 42 hours of lost productive time in the first week alone.

On May 22, 2024, at 3:20 PM during the day shift, Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), a Mechanical Maintenance Technician, suffered a severe laceration to his right hand while performing maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Marco was attempting to clear a jam in the cutting head without first de-energizing the equipment or engaging the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures. When he inserted his hand to dislodge what he believed to be a stuck piece of plastic, the spindle suddenly restarted (likely due to a proximity sensor malfunction) and his hand was caught in the rotating end mill, resulting in lacerations across his palm and fingers requiring emergency surgical intervention. A coworker heard Marco's cry and immediately activated the emergency stop. He was rushed to the emergency department of Hôpital de la Cité where he underwent a 4-hour surgical procedure. Marco has been unable to return to work and faces potential permanent nerve damage. The incident was not prevented despite the existence of LOTO training, indicating a procedural compliance failure.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Injection Molding Operator Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024) was performing routine maintenance on Line C in the Medical Components clean room area when she reached into the mold cavity to remove a stuck component. The machine's safety interlock had been bypassed by a previous operator and not reset. When Yasmin's hand entered the mold area, the injection cycle automatically initiated due to residual pressure in the system. Her right hand was caught between the mold halves as they closed, resulting in crushing injuries to her palm and three fingers. She immediately cried out, and Production Supervisor Richard Beaulieu heard her screams from the adjacent station. He activated the emergency stop, but the mold had already closed for 3 seconds before pressure released. Yasmin was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital with suspected fractures and deep lacerations. The incident was witnessed by CNC Operator Giovanni Bianchi who was performing quality inspections nearby. Initial assessment suggests the bypass interlock, combined with failure to follow LOTO procedures, created a lethal combination of hazards.

On March 18, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was operating a powered pallet jack in the Warehouse and Shipping dock area, moving pallets of finished composite materials toward the shipping area. The concrete loading dock floor was wet due to cleaning operations that had occurred 2 hours earlier, though the area had been marked with wet floor signs. Rashid was traveling at approximately 8 km/h when the pallet jack encountered a puddle of residual water near dock bay 3. The wet surface caused the jack's front wheels to lose traction. The pallet jack tipped forward and to the left, spilling approximately 2,200 kg of packaged polyethylene and polycarbonate materials across the dock floor. Approximately 85 pallets of finished goods were damaged, with outer packaging crushed and some internal components showing stress fractures. Crane Operator Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041) witnessed the incident and immediately called for cleanup assistance. The spilled materials blocked access to two shipping bays for approximately 6 hours while the area was cleared and inventory assessed. Preliminary damage assessment estimates $47,000 in destroyed finished goods inventory.

On March 22, 2024 at 03:30 during the night shift, Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was cleaning and resetting injection molding equipment in the Main Production Building after a production run change. While performing routine resin dryer maintenance in the composite materials prep area, he discovered that the heating element had overheated and caused thermal damage to the dryer's internal components. The unit's thermostat had malfunctioned, allowing internal temperatures to exceed 320°C (normal operating range 260-280°C). The excessive heat caused the resin hopper's protective coating to degrade, and approximately 180 kg of processed polypropylene resin had partially fused inside the hopper and auger system. The heating element coil had partially melted, and the control panel showed signs of electrical damage from heat stress. The dryer was immediately isolated and powered down. Maintenance Workshop Supervisor Richard Beaulieu was notified and inspected the unit at 04:15. Preliminary assessment indicates the dryer requires complete replacement of the heating element assembly, thermostat control system, hopper interior coating, and electrical components. Estimated repair cost is $38,500, with equipment downtime affecting production schedules for the composite materials line for approximately 5 business days.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator in the Assembly and Finishing Department, was manually removing flash and trimming edges from molded polycarbonate medical device housings. While working at Station 7, Amal noticed slight discoloration and warping on several finished parts from the morning production run. Upon inspection, Amal discovered that the parts had been inadvertently exposed to temperatures exceeding the specified cooling parameters, likely due to a malfunctioning thermostat on Injection Molding Line D. The affected batch consisted of approximately 2,400 units destined for a major medical device manufacturer. Amal immediately segregated the affected parts, documented the batch numbers, and notified Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), the shift Assembly Operator supervisor. No workers were injured, but the incident represents a potential quality control failure that could have resulted in non-compliant medical device components being shipped to customers. The root cause investigation identified inadequate preventive maintenance procedures and lack of real-time temperature monitoring on the molding equipment. Amal completed the required incident declaration form and submitted it to the EHS department for documentation and corrective action planning.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 5:45 PM during the evening shift, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a Machine Operator, was cleaning the hopper area of Injection Molding Line D following a color changeover. While using a compressed air line to dislodge residual polypropylene resin granules from the hopper's internal surfaces, Emmanuel accidentally directed compressed air toward his face at close range, causing a sharp plastic granule to strike his left eye with considerable force. Emmanuel immediately experienced sharp pain, tearing, and temporary vision blurring.
