He applied immediate first aid by rinsing his eye with water from the eyewash station located 15 meters away in the production area. Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), the evening shift Machine Operator supervisor, was notified and provided transport to the on-site first aid station. TechnoPlast's certified first aider, Amélie Roy (EMP-00028), the Training Coordinator, examined the eye and detected a small corneal abrasion approximately 2mm in diameter on the left eye surface. Emmanuel was given sterile eye drops and antibiotic ointment, and was advised to visit an external ophthalmologist for follow-up examination within 24 hours. The incident was properly documented on the first aid treatment form, and Emmanuel was returned to full duty after 30 minutes of rest and observation.

On April 5, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the night shift, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, was operating the plastic regrind system in the Materials Management area when he noticed an unusual vibration and grinding sound emanating from the main shredder motor. Oscar immediately suspected a potential bearing failure or material jam in the shredding chamber. Following proper procedure, he moved to shut down the equipment using the emergency stop button. However, before reaching the button, a loose safety guard suddenly detached from the shredder assembly, nearly striking Oscar's left shoulder as it fell to the floor approximately 30 centimeters from his foot. Oscar retreated to a safe distance and activated the emergency stop from the remote control panel. Upon inspection by Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147), the Regrind Supervisor, it was discovered that the mounting bolts securing the safety guard had corroded and failed, and the guard had been improperly reinstalled after recent maintenance work. No worker sustained injury, but the near-miss represented a serious hazard—had the guard struck Oscar's head instead of falling beside him, the outcome could have been catastrophic. The equipment was taken out of service pending repair of the mounting structure and replacement of all corroded fasteners.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Injection Molding Line A (Automotive) when a 250-ton injection molding machine's hydraulic system ruptured. Operator Paul Demers was performing routine mold changeover when pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the machine control panel and work surface, causing an electrical fire that engulfed the adjacent control station. The fire spread to nearby stacks of polypropylene resin bags stored temporarily near the machine. Emergency response personnel (Gilles Marchand from Facilities Maintenance) arrived within 3 minutes and activated the nearby fire suppression system, extinguishing the blaze before it reached the main material storage area. The incident resulted in approximately $87,000 in equipment damage, destruction of 12 resin bags valued at $4,200, permanent damage to the machine's hydraulic pump and manifold assembly, and charring of the aluminum control enclosure. No personnel were injured due to Paul's quick reaction to step back from the machine. The machine remained out of service for 18 days during repairs and inspection.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a chemical storage incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility when a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent (silicone-based, containing volatile organic compounds) developed a hairline crack along its bottom weld seam. The drum, which had been stored on a metal pallet for 18 months, had not been inspected for corrosion or structural integrity according to the facility's chemical inventory records. Approximately 8 gallons of the mold release agent leaked onto the concrete floor over a 40-minute period before warehouse supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin discovered the spill during his routine facility walk-through. The chemical pooled near a floor drain and the residual fumes created a localized VOC concentration estimated at 450 ppm (well above the 200 ppm exposure limit). Three employees working in adjacent areas reported headaches and throat irritation. The spill was contained using absorbent pads and commercial containment foam. Environmental testing confirmed contamination in the facility's stormwater collection sump, requiring notification to Quebec's environmental authority. Cleanup and remediation cost $23,400.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a significant environmental incident occurred in the Warehouse and Shipping facility when a forklift operated by Roberto Santos accidentally punctured a 300-gallon intermediate bulk container (IBC) of recycled resin washings containing acetone and isopropanol solvents. The container, positioned on a wooden pallet near the loading dock, had been marked with faded labels that were no longer legible. The puncture occurred when Roberto was maneuvering pallets in a congested storage area with limited visibility. Approximately 120 gallons of the solvent mixture spilled across approximately 800 square feet of the warehouse floor, creating a vapor cloud that forced evacuation of the facility. The spill migrated toward floor drains and through a damaged section of the warehouse foundation, contaminating an estimated 1,200 gallons of soil beneath the structure. Remediation required excavation, soil removal, and environmental assessment by a certified hazmat contractor costing $34,600. The incident triggered an emergency environmental notification to CNESST and resulted in a 72-hour facility shutdown for comprehensive air quality testing and remediation verification.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, Production Operator Yara Mustafa was operating Injection Molding Line D when she noticed unusual vibrations and a grinding noise emanating from the hydraulic pump assembly. She immediately notified her supervisor and shut down the machine following proper procedures. Upon inspection by Maintenance Manager Carlos Rodriguez and Instrumentation Technician Vincent Létourneau, they discovered that the hydraulic pump's internal pressure relief valve had malfunctioned, causing excessive pressure buildup in the system. The valve's seal had deteriorated due to inadequate lubrication and lack of preventive maintenance. As technicians attempted to depressurize the system manually, a high-pressure hydraulic line ruptured unexpectedly, spraying hot hydraulic oil at approximately 80°C across a 2-meter radius. Vincent Létourneau sustained second-degree thermal burns on his right arm and shoulder. Emergency response was activated, the area was evacuated, and Vincent was transported to the hospital where he received treatment for thermal burns covering approximately 12% of his body surface. The incident was contained within 30 minutes with no secondary injuries.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 09:15 during the day shift, Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez was transferring reclaimed polypropylene pellets into a chemical mixing tank in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. While opening a sealed container of mold release agent concentrate (a solvent-based product containing acetone and isopropanol), the pressurized container cap malfunctioned and failed to release pressure gradually. The sudden depressurization caused the concentrated liquid to spray forcefully, with approximately 2 liters of mold release agent splashing directly onto the floor and lower wall surfaces, and an estimated 500 milliliters aerosol mist dispersing into the air. Oscar was wearing safety glasses but not chemical splash goggles, and he inhaled a significant quantity of the vapors, experiencing immediate respiratory distress and eye irritation. Nearby Quality Control personnel smelled the pungent chemical odor and activated the facility's emergency ventilation system. The spill area was cordoned off, chemical absorbent materials were deployed, and Oscar was moved to fresh air. He was examined by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid and treated with saline irrigation for eye exposure and supplemental oxygen for inhalation exposure. The incident resulted in approximately 45 minutes of production downtime in the mixing area while cleanup and ventilation restoration occurred.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 22:40 during the evening shift, Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi was conducting routine maintenance on the heating elements of an injection molding machine in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. While cleaning accumulated plastic residue from the heating blocks using acetone-soaked cotton rags, he accidentally knocked over a 500-milliliter container of acetone solvent stored on a nearby work surface. The acetone spilled onto the hot heating element surface (temperature approximately 160°C), causing immediate ignition. The small fire rapidly spread to the acetone-soaked rags Emmanuel had been holding, which ignited with a bright blue flame. A nearby roll of plastic film material stored temporarily against a wall approximately 1 meter from the heat source also ignited from radiant heat exposure. Emmanuel dropped the burning rags and attempted to use a water-based extinguisher from a wall-mounted cabinet, but this proved ineffective on the solvent fire. Process Quality Engineer Deepa Gupta, working the evening shift in an adjacent area, heard the commotion and immediately activated the building's fire alarm. The automatic Halon fire suppression system for the Post-Processing zone discharged, suppressing the flames within 45 seconds. Emergency responders arrived on-site within 8 minutes. No injuries were sustained, though Emmanuel experienced first-degree burns to his hands from contact with the burning rags. The fire was fully extinguished with no structural damage, though equipment in the immediate vicinity (approximately 15,000 dollars in apparatus) required replacement.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was removing finished parts from Injection Molding Line B when she contacted a hot mold surface with her left forearm. The mold temperature was measured at 185°C. Aisha immediately reported the burn to her supervisor and was directed to the first aid station where the burn was assessed as superficial with minor redness and slight swelling across a 3cm x 2cm area. Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) provided initial first aid treatment including cool water rinse, topical antibiotic ointment, and sterile gauze dressing. The employee experienced mild pain but continued working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. No hospitalization was required. The incident occurred because Aisha was rushing to meet production targets and did not allow adequate cooling time after the mold cycle completion, contrary to standard operating procedures which require a 2-minute cooling period before part removal.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 6:15 PM during the evening shift, Forklift Operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was transporting a pallet containing 24 resin bags from the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009) to the warehouse storage area. At the intersection near the Regrind and Recycling Department, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was crossing the traffic lane with a hand cart containing empty containers. Tariq did not see Chiara due to the pallet's height obstructing his line of sight. Chiara did not hear the forklift approaching due to ambient noise from nearby equipment. The forklift struck Chiara's left leg, resulting in a compound fracture of the tibia and fibula. Chiara was immediately immobilized by responding supervisor Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128) and emergency services were called. Chiara was transported to Laval General Hospital where she underwent emergency surgery and was admitted for a 3-day stay. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) investigated the incident and determined the root cause was inadequate facility traffic management, lack of audible warning systems on equipment, and failure to establish dedicated pedestrian pathways separated from vehicle traffic zones.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 2:30 AM during the night shift, Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) was emptying a batch of contaminated plastic waste into the designated hazardous waste container in the Regrind and Recycling Department. The waste contained residual acetone solvent from a cleaning operation that had not been properly documented or segregated. As Fernand poured the material, approximately 15 liters of acetone-contaminated mixture splashed from the container, creating a liquid spill approximately 3 meters in diameter on the concrete floor. The spill was not immediately contained. Vapors from the acetone began to accumulate in the confined area, creating an inhalation hazard. Fernand experienced dizziness, headache, and eye irritation within 5 minutes of exposure. He evacuated the area and activated the facility emergency alarm. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) responded to the scene and initiated hazardous spill protocols. The area was evacuated, ventilation systems were activated, and the spill was contained using absorbent materials. Fernand was assessed by first aid responders and experienced full recovery within 2 hours. The root cause was inadequate segregation and labeling of contaminated waste streams combined with insufficient waste handling training for night shift personnel.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of uncured polyester resin from storage to a waste consolidation container when the drum's bung plug became loose during transport on a dolly. Approximately 12 gallons of the highly flammable, volatile resin spilled onto the concrete floor and began to spread toward the storm drain system. The liquid emitted strong chemical fumes that caused immediate respiratory irritation to Ms. Haddad and alerted nearby Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093) who was conducting a materials audit in the adjacent storage section. Ms. Proulx immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency alarm. The facility's emergency response team, led by Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), initiated containment procedures by deploying absorbent materials and establishing a perimeter around the spill. The area was ventilated for 2 hours, and the contaminated absorbent materials were properly containerized for hazardous waste disposal. No injuries were sustained, but the incident revealed gaps in drum transport procedures and inadequate equipment maintenance.

On April 22, 2025, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014). Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was preparing to calibrate temperature sensors on an injection molding machine's cooling system when she inadvertently knocked over a gallon container of mineral coolant fluid that had been stored on a maintenance workbench. The container had no secure lid and approximately 0.75 gallons of the clear, odorless mineral oil spilled directly onto electrical equipment, wiring harnesses, and the concrete floor. The spill created a slippery surface and posed an electrical hazard, as the coolant is a conductive medium. Ms. Petrov immediately reported the incident to her supervisor. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) was contacted and arrived to assess the situation, while Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) initiated cleanup using absorbent materials and dry cleaning procedures to avoid pushing the conductive fluid toward energized equipment. The affected electrical components were isolated from power and the area was restricted for 4 hours until thorough decontamination and equipment inspection were completed. No personnel were injured, but the incident demonstrated inadequate storage practices for hazardous fluids in work areas.

On May 8, 2025, at 09:30 during the day shift, Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) conducted a preventive workplace safety inspection of Injection Molding Line A - Automotive (UNIT-001). During his routine walkthrough, Mr. Lafleur identified that the emergency stop button (E-stop) on molding machine #7, a 250-ton injection unit that operates continuously, had degraded to the point where it no longer produced the required tactile feedback when pressed. The button's dome actuator was worn, and testing revealed a 15-millisecond delay in signal transmission to the machine's PLC controller—exceeding the 5-millisecond safety specification. Additionally, Mr. Lafleur observed that the machine guarding around the mold closure area showed visible cracks in two polycarbonate panels, potentially compromising containment in the event of a mold ejection anomaly. He also noted that recent preventive maintenance logs showed the last E-stop function test was conducted 8 months prior, well beyond the manufacturer's recommended quarterly testing interval. Mr. Lafleur documented these findings in the facility's CMMS (Computerized Maintenance Management System) and immediately flagged them as high-priority safety hazards requiring urgent remediation. No incident or near-miss had occurred, but the deficiencies posed significant risk to operators Leila Farah (EMP-00130) and other production staff who work in close proximity to this equipment.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), a Regrind Operator, was operating Material Drying and Preparation Room equipment (UNIT-016) when the resin dryer's heating element malfunctioned. The dryer, a critical component for preparing recycled polypropylene (PP) resin, began overheating beyond safe operating parameters. Mohamed noticed the temperature gauge reading 285°C, exceeding the maximum safe operating temperature of 240°C. Despite attempting to manually shut down the unit, the heating control system failed to respond. The dryer's exterior surface became dangerously hot, radiating intense heat into the surrounding work area. Approximately 5 minutes later, the thermal safety cutoff finally engaged, but not before the equipment had reached critical temperatures. Mohamed sustained first-degree burns on his left forearm and hand when he briefly contacted the dryer housing while attempting to access the emergency shut-off valve. The incident was immediately reported to Sanaa Rachidi, Fire Safety Coordinator, who initiated emergency response protocols. The affected dryer was immediately isolated and quarantined pending inspection and repair. Mohamed received first aid treatment on-site and was referred for medical evaluation.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift operations in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005), Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, experienced a critical equipment failure. The automated robotic arm, responsible for removing finished parts from Injection Molding Machine #18 (a 250-ton Engel system), abruptly malfunctioned during normal operating cycle. The robotic arm's servo motor encoder failed, causing the arm to lose positional awareness and execute an erratic movement pattern. Instead of following its programmed trajectory to the parts bin, the arm swung violently toward the open molding cavity where Benoit was performing routine maintenance on the mold ejector pins. The mechanical arm's gripper struck Benoit's right shoulder and upper arm, causing him to fall backward into an adjacent workstation. Benoit sustained a contusion to his shoulder, a laceration above his elbow, and minor fractures in his right wrist. Emergency response team leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) immediately arrived, activated the machine emergency stop, and coordinated medical response. The robotic arm was immediately locked out and tagged. Benoit was transported to hospital for X-ray evaluation and treatment.

On March 28, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler, was transferring used mold release agent (a solvent-based product containing acetone and isopropanol) from a full 55-gallon drum to smaller 5-gallon containers for disposal. While maneuvering the heavy 55-gallon drum using a drum hand truck, the drum's bung cap dislodged from vibration and impact, releasing approximately 12 gallons of chemical solvent onto the concrete floor. The spill occurred in the secondary containment area, but the volume exceeded the containment capacity by approximately 3 gallons. The chemical rapidly spread across the floor, flowing toward the facility's storm drain system located 8 meters away. Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer, was conducting routine night shift inspections and discovered the spill within 2 minutes. Emergency response protocols were activated immediately. Anh deployed absorbent materials to contain the spill and block the storm drain. The spill area was cordoned off with warning tape. Environmental services were contracted to properly remediate the contaminated soil and concrete. The incident required facility ventilation system activation at maximum capacity for 6 hours to clear airborne chemical vapors. No personnel injuries occurred, though three workers in adjacent areas reported mild headaches and eye irritation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room area. While manually removing a finished part from the mold cavity, her left hand became caught between the closing mold and a fixed support bracket. The safety interlock had been bypassed by maintenance technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) two hours earlier for equipment calibration and was not re-enabled. Laila sustained a severe crush injury to her left ring and middle fingers, resulting in two fractures and significant soft tissue damage. She was unable to return to work and required hospitalization for surgical intervention. The incident was discovered immediately by supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) who called emergency services. Root cause analysis identified that the interlock re-enablement procedure was not followed, and no secondary notification system existed to prevent operator access during maintenance mode.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Forklift operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was moving a pallet of polypropylene resin near the solvent storage area when he inadvertently struck a shelf containing containers of acetone and isopropanol cleaning solvents. One 5-liter container of acetone ruptured on impact, creating a significant spill on the concrete floor. The volatile vapors accumulated near a nearby electrical junction box. A spark from a faulty relay in the junction box ignited the solvent vapors, triggering an automatic fire suppression system and emergency alarm. The incident was contained by the automated foam suppression system within 90 seconds. No personnel were injured, but the area was evacuated and remained closed for 6 hours for ventilation and cleanup. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) coordinated the response. Investigation revealed inadequate shelving stability, improper chemical segregation, and insufficient ventilation system maintenance.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 8:20 AM during the day shift, assembly operator Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134) was working at her station in Post-Processing and Heat Treatment, performing manual assembly of composite material components. While applying an adhesive to bond two parts, she accidentally made contact with acetone-based solvent residue on the work surface. The chemical migrated through a small tear in her latex glove and caused immediate skin irritation and localized allergic reaction on her left hand. She developed urticaria (hives) and angioedema (swelling) within 15 minutes. Her coworker, James Thompson (EMP-00029), noticed her distress and immediately notified supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151). Fatima-Zahra was taken to the on-site first aid station where she received treatment with antihistamines and topical corticosteroids. Medical evaluation at an urgent care facility confirmed latex allergy with cross-reactivity to chemical exposure. She returned to work the next day with alternative glove materials. Root cause analysis identified that glove integrity was not verified pre-shift, chemical residue cleanup procedures were inconsistent, and no latex-free alternatives were readily available.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT area). An employee was transferring isopropanol solvent from a 55-gallon drum to smaller containers using a manual pump system. The hose connection at the pump inlet became loose due to vibration from nearby equipment, causing approximately 12 liters of isopropanol to spill onto the concrete floor. The spill spread rapidly across an area of approximately 4 square meters. Simon Bélanger, Chemical Safety Officer, was notified immediately and initiated spill containment procedures. The area was cordoned off with hazard tape, absorbent pads were deployed, and ventilation fans were activated. No personnel were directly exposed to the chemical, but the spill created a slipping hazard and elevated vapor concentrations in the storage area. The spill was fully contained and cleaned within 2 hours. A secondary containment tray was damaged and required replacement. No injuries occurred, but the incident highlighted gaps in equipment maintenance protocols for chemical transfer equipment.

On March 18, 2025, at 2:15 PM during evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred at the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Normand Bergeron, Regrind Supervisor, was operating a plastic grinding machine when he noticed unusual vibration and a grinding noise from the equipment. He immediately stopped the machine and performed a visual inspection. He discovered that the safety interlock on the access door had partially disengaged, which would have allowed door opening while the grinding chamber was still rotating—a critical safety violation. The door remained closed only because of the latch mechanism catching on the frame. Had the door opened fully, there was significant risk of hand entanglement in the rotating grinding blades. Bergeron immediately reported the issue to Gaétan Laplante, LOTO Coordinator, who placed the equipment under a lockout/tagout procedure. The machine remained offline for 48 hours while maintenance replaced the faulty interlock mechanism. No personnel were injured, and no materials were damaged. The incident demonstrated that the preventive maintenance schedule had missed the early signs of interlock wear.

On March 22, 2025, at 11:20 PM during night shift operations, a lost-time injury occurred in the Main Production Building (UNIT-014). Marcel Duchesne, Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing part removal from a recently cycled injection mold. While extracting a thermoplastic component, his left hand became caught between the ejector pins and the mold frame as the mold began its closing sequence prematurely due to a timing sensor malfunction. Duchesne sustained a crushing injury to his left ring finger and index finger, with fractures to both fingers at the proximal phalanx and significant soft tissue damage. He immediately reported the injury to the line supervisor. First aid was administered on-site, and Duchesne was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval via ambulance at 11:35 PM. He required surgical intervention and was hospitalized for 4 days. The root cause was identified as a faulty proximity sensor on the mold that failed to detect operator presence during the closing cycle. The machine was immediately placed under lockout and taken offline for comprehensive sensor replacement and recalibration.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a fire initiated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (Building 5) when a container of polyester resin was being transferred from a 55-gallon drum to a smaller working container. René Caron, a Tool Maker, was assisting with the transfer process. Due to insufficient grounding of the transfer equipment, a static electricity discharge occurred as the resin was being poured. The static ignited vapors above the resin surface, causing an immediate flash fire. The flames spread rapidly to nearby containers of acetone and methylene chloride stored on the adjacent shelf. Within minutes, the fire reached approximately 8 feet in height. Emergency response was triggered immediately. Fire suppression systems activated automatically, and the facility's emergency evacuation alarm sounded. Building occupants evacuated to the designated assembly points. The on-site fire response team deployed two ABC dry powder extinguishers while waiting for the Laval Fire Department to arrive. The fire was fully extinguished within 12 minutes of discovery. No employees sustained burn injuries, though the heat damaged approximately $47,000 worth of chemical inventory and storage infrastructure. The incident resulted in temporary shutdown of production operations in Building 5 for safety inspection and remediation.

On October 3, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, Mathieu Gendron, Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a significant thermal burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. Gendron was attempting to remove hardened plastic overflow from a mold cavity using a manual scraper tool without proper lockout/tagout procedures in place. The injection molding machine was powered down but not locked or tagged out as per LOTO requirements. An electrical short in the machine's control circuit caused the heating system to unexpectedly activate while Gendron had his left hand positioned near the mold cavity. The mold surface temperature rose to approximately 185°C within 8 seconds. Gendron sustained second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 12% of his left hand and forearm. He immediately withdrew his hand and alerted shift supervisor Sonia Dasilva via emergency call button. First aid was administered on-site by the occupational health nurse, who applied sterile dressing and initiated cooling procedures. The employee was transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur emergency department where he received treatment for thermal burns requiring hospitalization for 3 days. The incident resulted in 8 lost workdays and modified duty assignment upon return.

On September 27, 2024, at approximately 1:30 PM during the day shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Shipping and Receiving Dock when Hugues Fontaine, Forklift Operator, was transporting a pallet load of finished composite parts. Fontaine was traveling at approximately 12 km/h through the narrow access corridor connecting the warehouse to the loading dock when the right rear tire of the propane-powered forklift struck a palletized stack of empty plastic bins that had been positioned too close to the travel lane. This collision caused the forklift's load to shift laterally. The stack of composite parts (approximately 800 kg) began to tip toward the right side of the vehicle. The load shifted approximately 15 degrees from vertical before Fontaine's quick reaction—he immediately cut power and applied emergency braking—prevented complete tip-over. The load settled back into stable position on the pallets. No parts were damaged, no employees were injured, and no materials were spilled. However, the incident revealed critical gaps in aisle management protocols. Had the forklift tipped completely, the load would have struck Jacques Lachance, the Receiving Clerk, who was standing approximately 2 meters away inspecting incoming materials. Lachance witnessed the entire near-miss event. The incident was immediately reported to the Safety Officer and investigated to identify preventive measures.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was performing routine setup adjustments on Injection Molding Line A when he noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge reading fluctuating erratically. While inspecting the hydraulic line connections near the mold clamping mechanism, he observed a fine mist of hydraulic fluid spraying from a loose fitting. Recognizing the hazard of potential hydraulic fluid injection injury, Karim immediately stepped back and activated the emergency stop button on the machine. He notified his supervisor and Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur of the situation. The area was cordoned off, and the hydraulic system was depressurized following proper LOTO procedures before maintenance could inspect the connection. The loose fitting was discovered to be inadequately torqued during the last maintenance cycle. No direct contact with pressurized hydraulic fluid occurred, and no injuries were sustained. The incident was classified as a near-miss with high-consequence potential. Response time was approximately 3 minutes from discovery to system shutdown.

On April 3, 2024, at 6:15 PM during evening shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-015 adjacent facility). Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent (silicone-based) from the storage rack to the mixing station using a hand pump dispenser. The drum was not properly secured on the transfer dolly, and as Bianca navigated around a support column, the drum shifted and fell onto its side. Approximately 35 gallons of mold release agent spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard and releasing volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors. The spill extended across approximately 250 square feet and reached the floor drain system. Bianca immediately notified Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) via radio. Johanne activated the spill response protocol, evacuated the immediate area, and deployed absorbent materials (diatomaceous earth and spill pads). The facility's ventilation system was increased to full capacity. Environmental Services contained the spill, preventing entry into the main drainage system by installing a drain plug. Cleanup took approximately 2.5 hours. The spilled material was collected in waste containers for proper hazardous waste disposal per CNESST regulations.

On May 18, 2024, at 11:50 PM during night shift operations, an environmental incident was detected in the warehouse cooling water system. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) was conducting routine night-shift equipment checks when he discovered an active leak in the cooling water circulation line running through the Warehouse and Shipping facility. The leak, estimated at 8-10 gallons per hour, was originating from a corroded coupling joint where the main cooling loop connects to the Part Washing Station. Coolant solution (a proprietary water-glycol mixture containing biodegradable surfactants and corrosion inhibitors) had been leaking for an estimated 6-8 hours based on the volume pooled under the system. Approximately 50-60 gallons had accumulated on the concrete floor, with a portion migrating toward the facility's secondary storm drain system. Luc immediately isolated the section using gate valves, reducing pressure on the damaged coupling. He notified Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur and Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson. The spill was contained using absorbent pads and plugs were installed in the storm drain access points. Environmental monitoring was conducted to ensure no contaminants had reached the groundwater monitoring wells. The damaged coupling was replaced, and the system was flushed and refilled. All contaminated materials were disposed of as industrial wastewater per Quebec Environmental regulations.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), a Packaging Operator, sustained a minor burn injury while working in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Martinez was manually transferring hot plastic pellets from a cooling tray to storage containers using a metal scoop. A colleague, Roberto Santos (EMP-00012), was nearby operating a forklift in the same area. While repositioning a pallet of raw materials, Santos inadvertently kicked over a beaker of hot mold release agent that had been left on a work surface. The scalding liquid splashed onto Martinez's right forearm and wrist, causing immediate redness and minor blistering. Martinez immediately ran cold water over the affected area for approximately 10 minutes at the nearest safety station. First aid was administered on-site by the shift supervisor, and the burn was treated with antibiotic ointment and covered with sterile gauze. No hospitalization was required. The incident was reported within 30 minutes to the HSE office. Root causes included inadequate storage of hot chemicals on elevated surfaces and insufficient communication between operators working in proximity.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Diego Morales (EMP-00056), an Assembly Operator, sustained a laceration requiring first aid while working at Injection Molding Line A - Automotive. Morales was manually removing finished plastic components from a molding machine and placing them into assembly fixtures. The parts had been recently ejected and retained sharp flash edges from the injection molding process. While handling a polycarbonate housing unit, Morales inadvertently grasped the component at an angle, and a protruding edge made contact with the inner aspect of his left palm, creating a 2-centimeter laceration. The cut bled moderately for approximately 3 minutes. Morales immediately reported the injury to his shift supervisor, Jean-François Lefebvre (EMP-00002), who provided first aid including wound cleaning, antibiotic ointment application, and sterile bandaging. The employee continued work with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. No stitches or hospitalization were required. The incident was documented within 2 hours. Root cause analysis identified inadequate deburring procedures on finished parts and lack of cut-resistant glove utilization.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the HSE department received an anonymous report through TechnoPlast's hazard reporting system regarding potential inadequate maintenance of the compressed air system serving the Main Production Building. The report indicated that pressure relief valves on the air distribution manifold appeared to be leaking visible moisture and oil residue, creating a potential hazard for workers operating compressed air tools in multiple production zones. The report was submitted by night shift personnel who observed the condition but did not report it directly to their supervisor, instead using the confidential reporting system to avoid interpersonal conflict. Upon immediate inspection by André Bellavance (EMP-00157), Confined Space Entry Supervisor, and maintenance technicians, it was confirmed that two of four pressure relief valves were malfunctioning, causing excessive pressure fluctuations and contamination of the compressed air supply. This condition posed a risk of compressed air injection injury to any worker using pneumatic tools. The maintenance workshop was immediately notified, and the affected sections of the air distribution system were tagged out pending repairs. The issue was rectified within 12 hours through replacement of both defective valve assemblies. No employees were injured, but the hazard was identified before an accident could occur.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Céline Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine mold removal and part ejection when her left hand became caught between the closing mold plates. The incident occurred in UNIT-004 (Injection Molding Line D - Consumer Packaging) when a safety interlock failed to prevent mold closure during the part removal cycle. Céline attempted to manually extract a stuck part from the mold cavity when the hydraulic system unexpectedly advanced, trapping her fingers between the upper and lower mold halves. Her screams alerted nearby coworker Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186), who immediately activated the emergency stop button. First responder Bernard Allard (EMP-00145) arrived within two minutes and manually retracted the mold using the backup hydraulic release. Céline sustained a crush injury to her left index and middle fingers with significant soft tissue damage, lacerations, and suspected fractures. She was transported by ambulance to Hôpital de Laval with a severity assessment of 8/10. The root cause investigation revealed that the safety interlock solenoid had been bypassed three weeks prior during maintenance work and was never restored to operational status.

On March 18, 2025, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a Machine Operator, was transferring 25kg bags of polypropylene resin from the warehouse staging area to the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) using a manual hand pallet jack. While navigating through the material handling zone in dim lighting conditions, Hawa's foot caught on a compressed air hose that was left loosely coiled across the walkway, causing her to stumble. She nearly fell completely but caught herself on a nearby storage rack, avoiding contact with the ground. The hand pallet jack tipped slightly, causing three bags of resin to shift precariously, with one bag landing approximately 30 centimeters from her left foot. Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), working in an adjacent area, witnessed the incident and immediately assisted in stabilizing the load. No physical injury occurred, but the near-miss was documented as a high-risk event because if the full pallet load had tipped, it could have resulted in crush injuries and potential fractures. The root cause was inadequate housekeeping procedures; the air hose should have been secured with cable clips and the walkway should have been clear of obstacles per ISO 14001 standards.

On March 22, 2025, at approximately 3:40 PM during the day shift, Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator working in UNIT-013 (Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop), sustained a minor laceration to his right palm while handling a freshly machined aluminum mold component. Bernard was transferring a completed mold from the CNC milling machine to the inspection station when a burr on the sharp edge of the machined surface caught his hand as he repositioned his grip. The laceration was approximately 2 centimeters long and approximately 3 millimeters deep, causing immediate bleeding. Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073), the Shipping Coordinator who was retrieving completed molds for packaging, witnessed the incident and immediately directed Bernard to the First Aid station. The injury was treated by Nina Santos (EMP-00084), the Industrial Hygienist on duty, who cleaned and bandaged the laceration with sterile gauze and applied antibiotic ointment. The wound did not require stitches, but Bernard was advised to monitor for signs of infection and was issued a protective sterile bandage for the remainder of his shift. This was classified as a first-aid treatable injury with severity score 2/10. The root cause was inadequate deburring of the mold component after CNC machining operations.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a minor electrical fire occurred in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014). Technician Claude Rioux was performing routine maintenance on a 150-ton injection molding machine's control panel when an arc flash ignited insulation material on bundled electrical wires behind the panel. The fire was approximately 12 inches in diameter and generated visible smoke and a burning electrical odor. A nearby maintenance supervisor, Patrick Ouellet, immediately activated the emergency fire alarm at 2:47 PM and used a Class C fire extinguisher to suppress the blaze within 90 seconds. The facility's automated sprinkler system was triggered at 2:48 PM as a backup measure. The alarm was confirmed at the main security desk and no further action was required. The incident resulted in approximately 45 minutes of production downtime while the affected panel was inspected and electrical systems verified safe. Root cause investigation determined that a connector had loosened over time, creating a high-resistance connection point that generated excessive heat and sparked ignition of the surrounding materials.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:20 PM during the evening shift, a significant property damage incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). Warehouse supervisor David O'Connor was directing the placement of a pallet containing 48 boxes of polycarbonate resin (approximately 2,400 pounds total) using an electric forklift operated by packaging operator Amara Diop. While maneuvering the loaded pallet into a storage position on the upper shelf of a 4-tier racking system, the left fork tine struck an overhead horizontal support beam at an angle, causing the load to shift. The pallet tilted approximately 35 degrees, and 18 boxes fell approximately 8 feet onto the concrete floor below, scattering resin pellets across an area approximately 20 feet by 15 feet. Three boxes impacted and cracked three injection molding machine hoppers on the adjacent Line B workstation, rendering those hoppers temporarily unusable. Estimated material loss (spilled resin, damaged boxes, and damaged equipment) totaled approximately $18,500. The incident was contained within 2 hours with cleanup and repositioning of remaining inventory. Root cause analysis identified inadequate overhead clearance awareness and insufficient load positioning verification before lifting.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:15 AM during the day shift, an employee injury incident occurred in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005). Assembly operator Soraya Alami was manually removing cooled plastic components from a finished goods bin and placing them into packaging containers. While performing this repetitive task, she felt a sharp stabbing pain in her lower back and left hip area. She reported difficulty straightening and immediate pain when attempting to lift her left leg. Initial assessment by the facility's first aid responder and occupational health consultant indicated acute lower back strain with possible sciatic nerve involvement. She was transported to a local urgent care facility where imaging confirmed acute lumbar strain with mild disc bulging at the L4-L5 level. Alami was prescribed rest, physical therapy, and anti-inflammatory medication, with an expected recovery timeline of 4-6 weeks. She was placed on modified duty restrictions limiting lifting to 10 pounds maximum and prohibiting bending/twisting motions. The incident resulted in 3 lost work days in the first week. Root cause analysis identified that the assembly bin height was 28 inches, requiring excessive forward bending and trunk flexion during repetitive part removal—a classic ergonomic hazard pattern.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Machine Operator Raoul Blanchard was performing routine part removal from injection molding machine #7 in the Main Production Building. While extracting a batch of composite materials components, Blanchard experienced severe repetitive strain and sudden acute pain in his right wrist and forearm. He attempted to continue working but the pain intensified, causing him to lose grip strength. A colleague, Luis Fernandez, noticed Blanchard favoring his arm and immediately alerted Supervisor Normand Bergeron. Blanchard was transported to the on-site first aid station where initial assessment revealed significant swelling and restricted range of motion consistent with acute carpal tunnel syndrome exacerbation. He was referred to a local hospital for X-rays and specialized evaluation. Diagnosis confirmed acute inflammation and partial nerve compression requiring immediate work restriction. Blanchard was placed on modified duty and subsequently on medical leave for 8 days. Root cause investigation revealed that the part removal process required excessive gripping force due to tight mold tolerances, combined with inadequate rest intervals between cycles and insufficient ergonomic workstation design. The incident was classified as a lost-time injury and reported to CNESST.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:47 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Composite Materials Technician Olga Ivanova was preparing a batch of epoxy resin by mixing components in a ventilated hood when she noticed a small spark near a 20-liter container of solvent-based release agent. The spark appeared to come from an improperly grounded metal mixing paddle contacting the steel container rim as she stirred. Fearing ignition, Ivanova immediately ceased mixing, turned off ventilation fans to avoid air circulation, and activated the nearest fire alarm pull station at 10:47 PM. The facility's automated alarm system triggered evacuation procedures and notified the Laval Fire Department. Material Handler Salma Haddad, who was accessing nearby raw material storage, heard the alarm and assisted in evacuating the chemical storage area. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger arrived within 2 minutes and quickly assessed the situation, determining no actual fire had occurred but the static discharge had created genuine ignition risk given the flammable vapors present. The Laval Fire Department arrived at 11:04 PM and confirmed the area was safe. Full evacuation lasted 18 minutes. Investigation revealed inadequate grounding procedures for metal mixing equipment and insufficient static electricity control measures in the chemical mixing area.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim was performing preventive maintenance on the warehouse racking and retrieval system conveyor in the Warehouse and Shipping facility (UNIT-018). The system, which automates movement of finished composite product cases, had been scheduled for bearing replacement on the main drive pulley. Kim was working from a raised platform accessing the motor assembly when the drive belt, previously marked as due for replacement, suddenly fractured under the tension of residual system pressure. The broken belt segments violently struck the motor housing and snapped backward, striking Kim on the left shoulder and causing him to lose balance on the platform. Kim fell approximately 4 feet to the warehouse floor, sustaining a left shoulder contusion and minor laceration. Material Handler Amani Mwangi, stocking nearby shelves, heard the equipment failure and immediately called for assistance. Forklift Operator Claude Poirier, operating equipment nearby, responded and contacted HSE personnel. Initial examination revealed Kim had significant bruising but no fractures. The conveyor system sustained damage to the motor housing, pulley assembly, and electrical control panel, rendering it non-operational. The system remained offline for 48 hours pending replacement of the motor, belt, pulley, and electrical components. Total equipment damage estimated at $67,000. Root cause: Inadequate predictive maintenance protocols failed to schedule belt replacement before failure, and insufficient lockout/tagout verification before maintenance work commencement.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM, Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler, was organizing incoming shipments of polycarbonate resin in the Receiving area of the warehouse when she noticed that several 50-pound bags of raw material were stacked irregularly on a pallet, creating an unstable tower approximately 6 feet high. The bags appeared to shift slightly during a routine forklift operation nearby. Haddad immediately flagged the unsafe stacking condition to her supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin and reported the observation to the EHS Coordinator. The shipment had arrived that morning from a supplier with improper load securing. No injury or material damage occurred, but the hazard was recognized as a potential crushing injury risk if the stack had collapsed. The incident was documented as a preventive observation to improve receiving procedures and supplier quality standards for load preparation.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:47 PM during the evening shift, James Thompson (EMP-00029), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was removing finished components from a 150-ton injection molding machine when he felt a sharp pain in his right hand. Thompson had felt a slight vibration from the machine's hydraulic system but continued working. Upon inspection, it was discovered that a small hydraulic fluid leak had created a slippery area on the machine's control panel. When Thompson reached for a part, his hand brushed against the pressurized hydraulic line, directing a fine spray of hot hydraulic fluid (approximately 140°F) directly against his palm and fingers for approximately 2 seconds before he pulled away. The operator experienced minor thermal burns and localized fluid chemical irritation to the skin. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) responded immediately, applied first aid with cold water and sterile dressing, and documented the incident. No lost time occurred, but the near-miss indicated a critical equipment maintenance gap. The hydraulic system was immediately shut down and serviced.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:35 AM during the night shift, Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), a Material Handler, was transferring cured composite material trays from a post-processing oven in the South Zone when he attempted to manually lift a heavy tray (approximately 65 pounds) that had been inadequately cooled. The tray was removed from the industrial oven set at 220°F, and although it appeared solid, residual heat was still present in the composite material. As Habib lifted the tray using only his hands and forearms without mechanical assistance, the sudden thermal shock and heat penetration through his work gloves caused severe thermal burns to both palms, inner forearms, and partial burns to his wrists. The temperature of the material surface was approximately 165°F. Habib immediately dropped the tray and immersed his hands in cool water. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) called emergency services, and Habib was transported to the hospital where he received treatment for second-degree burns covering approximately 12% of his upper body surface area. He was admitted for pain management and infection prevention, requiring 8 days of hospitalization and anticipated 6-week recovery period with work restrictions.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a solvent storage cabinet in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) caught fire. Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was transferring acetone from a bulk container to smaller bottles when he accidentally knocked over a container of MEK (methyl ethyl ketone) near an electrical outlet. The solvent pooled near the outlet's base, and static electricity from the plastic transfer equipment ignited the vapors. The fire rapidly spread to adjacent storage shelves containing additional flammable materials including polystyrene pellets and resin compounds. The sprinkler system activated after approximately 90 seconds, containing the fire to a 12-square-meter area. The emergency response team evacuated the warehouse and activated the facility alarm at 2:47 PM. Fire suppression took 8 minutes, resulting in significant water damage to approximately 2,000 kg of raw materials. No personnel were injured, but the incident exposed critical gaps in chemical storage organization and electrical safety near hazardous materials.

On November 16, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Mold Maintenance Technician Réjean Simard (EMP-00077) sustained a laceration and first-aid injury while performing routine mold cleaning in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). While using a compressed air line to clear debris from a complex injection mold cavity, Simard inadvertently directed pressurized air toward his left hand, where a metal chip or burr from the mold severed the webbing between his thumb and index finger, causing moderate bleeding. Coworker Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173), a Tool Room Technician, immediately applied pressure with clean gauze and activated the emergency first-aid station. The wound was cleaned, disinfected, and properly bandaged on-site by the trained first-aid attendant at 10:42 AM. The injury did not require external medical attention beyond workplace first aid, but it exposed inadequate work practices regarding compressed air safety and inadequate PPE protocols for mold maintenance work.

On November 18, 2024, at 4:15 PM during the evening shift, an overhead crane load drop incident occurred in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) was lowering a 650-kg pallet of finished automotive components toward a staging area when the load suddenly shifted. Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was guiding the load from the ground while Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) observed from the side. The sling's eyelet slipped from the lifting lug, causing the pallet to drop approximately 1.8 meters onto the concrete floor and scattering components across a 6-square-meter area. The falling pallet narrowly missed Habib by approximately 0.5 meters. While no personnel were struck, approximately 180 units valued at CAD $24,000 were damaged beyond recovery, with an additional 45 units suffering minor cosmetic damage. Immediate investigation revealed improper sling rating for the load weight and operator failure to perform pre-shift equipment inspection.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, during the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Elena Popescu, Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring a 20-liter container of mold release agent from storage to a mixing vat when the container's lid was not properly secured. The container tipped during transfer, spilling approximately 15 liters of the release agent onto the concrete floor and directly into the facility's storm drain system. The spill created a slippery hazard across a 4-meter radius and released volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes into the ventilation system. The incident was discovered when nearby Production Operator Aisha Kamara noticed the strong chemical odor and slipping hazard. Immediate response included cordoning off the affected area with safety tape, activating local ventilation fans, and notifying environmental compliance. The facility's emergency response team contained the spill using absorbent materials and documented the environmental release per Quebec environmental protection requirements. The incident exposed gaps in container handling procedures and ventilation adequacy for this material.

On March 18, 2024 at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Alain Mercier, Ergonomics Specialist, conducted a preventive ergonomic assessment of Injection Molding Line B (UNIT-002) in anticipation of expanding the automotive parts production volume scheduled for Q2. During his walkthrough, Alain observed that Youssef Zaidi, Injection Molding Operator - Line B, was performing repetitive part removal and placement operations from the molding press approximately 50 times per hour without adequate rest periods or job rotation. Zaidi reported experiencing mild wrist discomfort after 6 hours of continuous operation. Analysis of the workstation revealed that the part ejection height was positioned 8 inches below ergonomic neutral shoulder height, forcing sustained forward reaching and wrist flexion. Additionally, the conveyor system feeding finished parts to quality inspection was running continuously without scheduled micro-breaks. Alain identified this as a precursor condition for cumulative trauma disorder development, specifically repetitive strain injury from part removal operations. The declaration was made proactively to prevent escalation to a reportable injury, as Zaidi had not yet filed a health complaint but showed early signs of ergonomic strain.

On March 21, 2024 at 11:30 PM during the night shift, a near-miss incident was detected in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) located on the maintenance workshop storage mezzanine. Oscar Ramirez, Regrind Technician, was ascending the metal staircase to retrieve a replacement bearing assembly when he noticed that the safety railing on the mezzanine was loose and partially detached from its anchor points. The top rail had shifted approximately 2 inches out of position due to corroded bolts, creating a gap that did not meet CNESST fall protection standards. Oscar immediately halted his ascent and did not proceed. He reported the condition to Normand Bergeron, Regrind Supervisor, who was working nearby. The supervisor cordoned off the mezzanine access and notified maintenance. Upon inspection, the engineering team found that the railing bolts had corroded due to humidity and chemical vapor exposure in the warehouse, weakening the fasteners by approximately 60%. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the hazard was identified and controlled before any employee contact with the compromised railing or fall from height occurred. However, the condition represented a critical gap in preventive maintenance and could have resulted in a catastrophic fall from the elevated mezzanine (approximately 10 feet high).

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a significant thermal burn while performing routine mold maintenance. Bruno was inspecting the cooling water system on a molding machine that had been shut down only 10 minutes prior. Despite verbal warnings from the machine's control panel, he attempted to manually open a pressure valve on the hot mold assembly to check the coolant flow. The valve cap was extremely hot (approximately 160°C), and when he removed it without proper insulated gloves, boiling coolant sprayed onto his right forearm and hand, causing second-degree burns over approximately 8% of his right upper extremity. The incident was witnessed by Amara Diop (EMP-00110), a Packaging Operator who was nearby. Bruno was immediately treated with cold water irrigation by Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), the Occupational Health Nurse, and transported to the Laval Regional Hospital burn center. He required hospitalization for 5 days and has been on lost-time medical leave for 3 weeks with ongoing outpatient care.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Packaging and Labeling Station (Unit 019). Soraya Alami (EMP-00196), an Assembly Operator, was manually arranging finished injection-molded components on a conveyor belt when she noticed that a storage rack approximately 2 meters away was visibly unstable, with boxes of raw materials beginning to shift on the third shelf. The rack had been recently restocked by Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, who had overloaded the upper shelves without properly distributing the weight. Soraya immediately stepped back and used the emergency stop button to halt the conveyor belt operations, preventing any continuation of the work that could have led to additional personnel exposure. She then alerted Julien Racine (EMP-00177), a Shipping Clerk working nearby, who confirmed the instability. Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), the Safety Officer, responded within 5 minutes and secured the area with caution tape. The boxes remained in place but were at imminent risk of falling. The incident was documented immediately, and the rack was stabilized by securing the top boxes with strapping. No personnel were struck, but the severity of the potential incident was high—boxes could have fallen on multiple workers in the immediate area.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of mold release agent by pouring acetone solvent from a 5-liter container into a mixing tank. Due to inadequate ventilation—one of two exhaust fans was inoperative and had not been reported for maintenance—acetone vapor accumulated rapidly in the enclosed space. Elena began experiencing dizziness and mild respiratory irritation but continued working for approximately 8 minutes before recognizing the hazardous condition. She immediately evacuated the area and activated the facility's ventilation emergency override, clearing the space within 3 minutes. Gaston Picard (EMP-00193), a Crane Operator working in the adjacent maintenance workshop, noticed her distress and called for assistance. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) responded and conducted respiratory function checks, which indicated mild solvent vapor exposure with rapid recovery after fresh air exposure. The incident was documented as a near-miss because no medical intervention was required and there was no respiratory damage, but the potential for serious inhalation injury or loss of consciousness was present. The faulty exhaust fan was immediately tagged out and replaced the following day.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, an operator in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin from a storage rack to a transport cart using an electric forklift. The drum's locking ring was not properly secured due to inadequate inspection during the previous shift. As the forklift tilted the drum to position it on the cart, approximately 35 gallons of resin spilled across the warehouse floor, mixing with water from a nearby drain and creating a hazardous slurry. The spill covered approximately 400 square feet and exposed multiple employees to fumes and skin contact risk. Material handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was in the immediate vicinity when the spill occurred and was exposed to volatile organic compounds. Shipping clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019) assisted with emergency containment using absorbent materials. The incident was declared within 30 minutes of occurrence. Environmental contamination posed risk to the facility's ISO 14001 compliance, and cleanup required 8 hours of intensive remediation work.

On November 18, 2024, at 4:45 PM during the evening shift, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). A CNC milling machine (3-axis model used for precision mold manufacturing) experienced catastrophic spindle bearing failure while machining a complex automotive component mold. The spindle motor began emitting high-pitched grinding sounds and vibration, which continued for approximately 45 seconds before automatic shutdown was triggered by vibration sensors. The bearing had accumulated 3,847 operating hours since the last scheduled maintenance interval of 3,500 hours—the overdue maintenance was not logged due to a scheduling error in the maintenance tracking system. Upon investigation, the bearing cage showed signs of stress fractures and metal shavings contaminated the cutting fluid. The CNC machine requires complete spindle replacement, estimated at $65,000 in parts and labor. Production of a critical automotive customer order was delayed by 5 days, impacting TechnoPlast's delivery commitments. Quality Control Lead Petra Mueller (EMP-00166) witnessed the failure and immediately notified Maintenance, and Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux responded to secure the equipment.

On November 22, 2024, at 11:47 PM during the night shift, a hydraulic press (500-ton unit used for composite material compression molding) in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) experienced a critical control system malfunction that prevented normal shutdown procedures. Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was monitoring the press when the emergency stop button failed to halt the machine's downward platen movement. The platen continued descending beyond its normal cycle, compressing the upper mold tool beyond design pressure and temperature specifications. Fatou immediately initiated manual emergency isolation by pulling the hydraulic supply disconnect switch, but not before the mold tool was damaged. Upon inspection, the control system's programmable logic controller (PLC) had experienced a firmware corruption event, causing loss of input signal recognition from the emergency stop circuit. The damaged mold required replacement at a cost of $42,000 and the machine was taken offline for 96 hours for system diagnostics and reprogramming. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) responded to the emergency and secured the equipment. No physical injuries occurred, but the failure revealed critical gaps in safety-critical system redundancy and monitoring.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Omar Said (EMP-00122), a Production Operator, was working on Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room area. While removing a finished molded part from the injection machine, Omar's right hand made contact with the hot mold surface which had not cooled to safe handling temperature. The mold was still at approximately 185°C despite the machine's cooling cycle indicator showing completion. Omar sustained a second-degree burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters on his palm and fingers. He immediately immersed his hand in cool water and reported to the first aid station. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) was present and witnessed the incident. Emergency response protocol was followed, and Omar was transported to the local medical center for burn treatment and dressing. Investigation revealed that the machine's temperature sensor had drifted out of calibration, causing premature cycle completion signals while the mold remained dangerously hot.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 9:15 PM during the evening shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, was operating a powered pallet jack in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) to move pallets of virgin plastic resin toward the production area. While navigating a narrow aisle between high storage racks, the pallet jack's hydraulic steering system suddenly failed, causing loss of directional control. The equipment veered to the right, and Elif struck an overhead racking support column with the jack's forks at high velocity. The impact caused structural damage to the column's welded connection points, visible cracking along a 30-inch section, and bent the left lifting fork. The pallet jack was rendered inoperable, and the racking remained temporarily unstable until structural assessment could be completed. Elif was unharmed but shaken. Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), another material handler nearby, witnessed the collision and helped secure the area. A structural engineer was called for emergency assessment of the racking system, which required temporary closure of that warehouse section for 16 hours pending repairs.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a fire originated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when a 55-gallon drum of isopropyl alcohol (used in resin formulation) developed a slow leak at a seam weld defect. The alcohol vapors accumulated in the poorly ventilated storage enclosure and reached the ignition threshold. Proximity to an electrical heating panel used for resin temperature control provided an ignition source when a minor electrical arc occurred during routine thermostat cycling. Initial flames were contained within the storage cabinet, but smoke spread into adjacent areas. The night shift supervisor, Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), was conducting a routine safety walk-through and discovered the fire at 1:32 AM. She immediately activated the facility alarm and initiated the fire suppression system. The automated foam suppression system deployed and extinguished the fire within 2 minutes. Emergency response team arrived at 1:48 AM to confirm full suppression and ventilate the area. The fire caused approximately $67,000 in damage to chemical inventory, storage infrastructure, and temporary facility evacuation. No personnel injuries occurred. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate ventilation maintenance, defective drum quality control, and improper storage compartment electrical grounding.

On November 14, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160), a Production Operator on the Day Shift, was performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building when she noticed excessive coolant leakage from the cooling water system manifold. She immediately halted production and notified her supervisor. Upon inspection, a hairline crack was discovered in the copper tubing junction where coolant circulates through the mold cooling channels. The 190°F coolant had begun spraying intermittently onto the production floor, creating a slick surface and potential burn hazard. Zainab had not yet made direct contact with the hot liquid due to her positioned at a safe distance during the initial observation. She retreated to a safe zone and activated the emergency stop button. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen responded within 5 minutes, cordoned off the area with caution tape, and shut down the entire production line. The equipment was depressurized and allowed to cool before maintenance assessment began. This near-miss incident highlighted the critical importance of regular preventive maintenance inspections and the effectiveness of emergency response protocols.

On November 18, 2024 at 10:15 AM, Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), a Packaging Operator working the Day Shift in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008), was manually removing plastic injection-molded automotive components from a bulk storage bin for packaging into customer cartons. While reaching deeply into the bin to extract parts from the bottom layer, her right hand made contact with a sharp injection gate runner—the thin plastic sprue that remains attached to molded parts after the injection process. The gate runner lacerated the webbing between her thumb and index finger, causing immediate bleeding. Lucia applied direct pressure using a clean cloth and reported the injury to her supervisor, Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183). The supervisor immediately escorted her to the on-site first aid station in the Administrative Building where Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) provided first aid treatment. The wound required cleaning, antiseptic application, and a sterile adhesive bandage. No sutures were necessary, but the injury was documented as a first aid case requiring monitoring for infection. The incident was traced to inadequate workstation lighting that prevented Lucia from clearly identifying the sharp gate runner before contact.

On November 21, 2024 at 11:50 PM during the Night Shift, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a Production Operator, was working in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) manually feeding reject plastic parts into a granulation machine that processes scrap material for reuse. While transferring a batch of blue-tinted rejected dashboard components from a collection cart to the feed hopper, Kwame's left index and middle fingers became pinched between a jagged edge of a part and the metal hopper rim. The compression lasted approximately 3 seconds before he withdrew his hand with immediate pain and visible swelling. Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), who was staging incoming reject bins nearby, immediately alerted the Night Shift supervisor via radio. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), who was performing routine equipment checks in the adjacent Maintenance Workshop, responded with emergency first aid supplies. The fingers were cleaned, ice-wrapped, and elevated. Despite visible bruising and minor abrasion, no fractures were detected upon visual inspection. First aid treatment consisted of ice application, compression wrapping, and ibuprofen administration. The injury was documented and Kwame was placed on light duty for the remainder of his shift to prevent further aggravation of the injured digits.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area (UNIT-003). While wiping down the exterior of a 150-ton injection molding machine with a damp cloth, Omar inadvertently left the machine in a partially energized state after power-down procedures. A colleague, Assembly Lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), approached to retrieve a toolbox from near the machine. At 2:18 PM, the machine's automated cycle unexpectedly reactivated due to residual electrical charge in the control system, and the mold clamp began closing rapidly. Tatiana's right hand was positioned near the mold opening and was nearly caught in the closing mold cavity. She quickly withdrew her hand with a reflex action, avoiding direct contact by approximately 2 centimeters. The machine cycled completely before alarm systems engaged. No physical injury occurred, but the incident revealed critical gaps in the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure verification process. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) was immediately notified and investigated the scene within 15 minutes. The machine was fully de-energized and secured with proper LOTO tags and chains. This near-miss occurred because the energized state verification step was omitted from the standard shutdown checklist.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 9:45 PM during the evening shift, Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) discovered a critical failure in the automated material handling conveyor system in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). The primary electric motor driving the conveyor belt had seized, causing the belt to jam and accumulate dried plastic pellets and resin materials. Investigation revealed that the motor bearing had completely failed due to inadequate lubrication and lack of preventive maintenance scheduling. The motor had been in continuous operation for 847 hours since the last service interval, well beyond the manufacturer's 600-hour recommendation.
