The conveyor failure immediately halted material supply to three active injection molding lines, disrupting production of automotive components scheduled for shipment the following morning. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was called in at 10:15 PM to assess the situation. The failed motor was determined to be irreparable and required complete replacement. The equipment downtime lasted 14 hours until a replacement motor was installed and tested on November 19 at 11:30 AM. Production was delayed for 847 units of finished automotive trim parts, resulting in approximately $34,000 in recovery costs and expedited shipping fees to meet customer deadlines.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 7:50 AM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) was manually assembling medical device component housings on the clean room assembly line (UNIT-003) when she sustained a laceration to her left index finger. Elena was fitting precision-molded plastic housing components together when a micro-fracture in one of the injection-molded parts created an extremely sharp edge. As she applied pressure to seat the component into its assembly fixture, the sharp edge cut through her surgical-grade nitrile glove and lacerated the palmar surface of her left index finger approximately 1.2 centimeters in length and 0.3 centimeters in depth. She immediately withdrew her hand, and blood dripped onto one completed assembly housing, requiring it to be scrapped due to ISO 13485 contamination protocols. Elena reported the injury to her supervisor, Assembly Lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), at 7:52 AM. First aid was administered in the on-site medical clinic by the facility's occupational health nurse at 8:05 AM. The laceration was cleaned with sterile saline, treated with antibiotic ointment, and closed with three sterile adhesive strips. No stitches were required. Elena completed a worker incident report and received written instructions for wound care and tetanus status verification. She returned to modified duty with bandaged finger for the remainder of her shift, performing assembly tasks that did not require gripping pressure. The injury was classified as a recordable first-aid incident per CNESST guidelines. Quality inspection on all similar housing batches from that production run was immediately enhanced.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician on the day shift, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line A when his left hand became caught between the rotating barrel and the fixed housing of the machine. The incident occurred while Pascal was adjusting the temperature probe without properly engaging the machine's lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure. A colleague, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), was present and immediately activated the emergency stop button. Pascal sustained a laceration to his left palm and two fingers, with partial crushing of the ring finger. He was transported to the facility's first aid station and then to Laval General Hospital for suturing and X-rays. No fractures were detected, but the injuries required 12 stitches. The incident was witnessed by Christian Gosselin, who alerted supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147). Root cause analysis determined that Pascal had skipped the LOTO lockout step due to time pressure to meet production quotas, and the machine's interlocks were not functioning properly.

On March 18, 2024 at 10:45 PM, during the evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Nour Jaber (EMP-00188), a Packaging Operator who was reassigned to assist with material staging, accidentally knocked over a 20-liter container of epoxy resin mixture while moving it on a manual pallet jack. The container fell and ruptured on the concrete floor, releasing approximately 18 liters of reactive resin and hardener mixture. The spill spread across an area of approximately 12 square meters, damaging $34,500 worth of raw composite fiber material stored on the floor below the mixing station, as well as permanently staining and slightly etching the facility's polished concrete floor (estimated cosmetic damage: $8,200). The spilled material also destroyed two cardboard work order files and a laptop computer that was temporarily placed on a lower shelf. The resin began to cure and harden on the floor, requiring professional chemical remediation services to remove and properly dispose of the material. No personnel were exposed to harmful fumes due to the facility's ventilation system, and no injuries occurred. The incident was reported by materials supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031), who was on duty in an adjacent area.

On March 21, 2024 at 1:30 AM during the night shift, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a Production Operator on night shift, conducted a routine walkthrough inspection of Injection Molding Line A and identified that the electrical interlocks on three injection molding machines (units 7, 9, and 14) were not engaging properly. Upon closer inspection, Kwame discovered that the interlock switches had accumulated dust and composite material residue that prevented proper switch closure. This discovery prevented a potential serious incident, as these safety interlocks are critical components designed to stop machine operation when access doors are opened. Kwame immediately documented the findings using the facility's mobile inspection app and notified his supervisor and the maintenance department. The issue was classified as a preventive finding because no actual injury or malfunction occurred, but the condition represented a significant safety vulnerability that could have resulted in employee entanglement if machinery had cycled unexpectedly during maintenance activities. The incident was reported by Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), the Safety Officer, who reviewed the night shift logs during the morning safety briefing and determined this finding met criteria for formal incident documentation and corrective action.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Laila Hamdan was operating Injection Molding Line B (Automotive) when a hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned on the mold clamping system. The valve, which should have released excess pressure at 2,500 PSI, failed to open, causing pressure to build to 3,200 PSI. This excessive pressure caused the mold halves to separate unexpectedly while the machine was in mid-cycle. Hot plastic material and metal fragments ejected from the mold opening, striking Ms. Hamdan on the right forearm and shoulder. She sustained second-degree burns and lacerations requiring immediate first aid and emergency room treatment. The incident was witnessed by Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes and Process Technician Jade Wong, who immediately activated the emergency stop and assisted with first aid. Investigation revealed the relief valve had not been serviced in 18 months, exceeding the manufacturer's 12-month maintenance interval.

On March 18, 2025, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Automation Technician Aya Tanaka from the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop conducted a routine safety walkthrough of the Composite Materials Processing Area. During her inspection, she identified a significant hazard that had not been previously documented: multiple compressed air hoses running across the main production floor pathway were not adequately secured or routed through overhead conduit. The hoses created a trip hazard that personnel crossed multiple times daily. Additionally, she observed that electrical cables from automated fiber laying equipment were loosely coiled and positioned at ankle height in high-traffic zones. Ms. Tanaka also noted inadequate signage identifying these pinch points and the absence of regular air hose and cable inspection protocols. As a preventive measure before an injury occurred, she documented the findings in detail and submitted a formal hazard report to the HSE department. No immediate injury had occurred, but the conditions posed a clear and imminent danger to the 15-20 production staff working in this area daily.

On March 21, 2025, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, a critical incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne was performing end-of-shift inventory and equipment checks when he noticed a significant chemical spill had occurred in the solvent storage area. Investigation revealed that a 55-gallon drum of acetone (cleaning solvent) had tipped over on a storage shelf, likely due to inadequate stabilization and uneven stacking. The drum's valve had cracked upon impact, releasing approximately 35 gallons of acetone onto the concrete floor. The spill had spread across approximately 800 square feet of the storage room and had begun seeping toward the floor drain connected to the facility's water treatment system. Additionally, three smaller containers (5-gallon jugs) of isopropanol had fallen from the same shelf and their caps had loosened, contributing to additional chemical release. The combined vapors created a hazardous atmospheric condition exceeding OSHA exposure limits. Champagne immediately activated emergency response protocols, evacuated the area, notified the night shift supervisor Omar Said, and contacted the HSE director. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois was called in to assess contamination and coordinate cleanup. Total material loss was estimated at $8,400. The incident required 18 hours of environmental remediation and posed risk of regulatory violation for unauthorized chemical release.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant water line rupture occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) was transferring dried plastic pellets from a drying hopper when he noticed water spraying from a corroded section of the facility's cooling water line that runs overhead. The pressurized water spray caused approximately 800 gallons to spill across the production floor over 12 minutes before the main water valve was shut off. The spill damaged three injection molding machines worth approximately $180,000, destroyed inventory of pre-dried materials valued at $45,000, and rendered the floor slippery and hazardous. Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) slipped on the wet surface but did not fall. Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) responded immediately and isolated the water source. The facility had to halt production for 18 hours for cleanup, drying, and equipment inspection. Root cause investigation revealed the water line had not been inspected or maintained in over 5 years despite being in a corrosive environment with high humidity and chemical vapors.

On March 22, 2024, during the evening shift at approximately 8:15 PM, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) was performing routine setup of an injection molding machine (Machine #47) in the Main Production Building when he noticed the hopper vibration sensor was not functioning. He powered down the machine and called Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) to diagnose the issue. Upon inspection, Daniel discovered that the sensor's electrical connector had corroded and the sensor itself was outputting erratic signals, preventing proper hopper level monitoring. However, when Daniel attempted to reset the control panel after reconnecting the sensor, the machine unexpectedly re-energized without proper lockout procedures being followed. The hydraulic pump began running without warning, causing the machine's clamp mechanism to partially close. Christian's left hand was in the danger zone at the moment of unexpected activation. Fortunately, the clamp stopped before causing injury due to the machine's safety limit switches engaging. The incident was classified as a near-miss with potential for serious hand crushing injury. Investigation revealed that the LOTO procedures had not been reviewed with maintenance staff in 14 months, and the electrical connector had not been inspected as part of the standard preventive maintenance routine. No serious injury occurred, but the risk was significant.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM during the day shift, Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) was conducting routine inspections in the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006) when she observed a potential safety hazard. She noticed that the cabinet containing ultraviolet light testing equipment had its safety interlocks removed or disabled, allowing direct access to the UV light chamber. The UV exposure protection shielding around the equipment showed visible signs of wear and deterioration. Additionally, she discovered that three staff members had been working in the laboratory earlier that morning without wearing required UV-protective eyewear, and there was no documentation of their UV light exposure times. The UV testing equipment operates at wavelengths that can cause acute photokeratitis and retinal damage with minimal exposure. Jasmine immediately reported this observation to Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) and Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152). The laboratory was immediately secured and no testing was performed for the remainder of the shift pending a full safety review. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the safety interlocks had been disabled by a previous technician three weeks ago to improve workflow efficiency, and this non-compliant modification had not been documented or reported. No eye injuries resulted from this near-miss incident, but the exposure risk was substantial and ongoing. The incident highlighted gaps in equipment safety audits and enforcement of PPE requirements.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator, was working at Line C in the Medical Components clean room (UNIT-003) during the day shift. She was manually assembling composite medical device components when her right hand made contact with a sharp edge on a freshly molded polycarbonate part. The part had not been properly de-flashed and retained a 3mm sharp burr along its perimeter. As Elena reached to position the component into the assembly fixture, her palm was lacerated along the thenar eminence, producing approximately 2cm of bleeding. A nearby Quality Inspector, Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), witnessed the incident and immediately applied pressure with sterile gauze. Elena was escorted to the first aid station where the wound was cleaned, assessed as a minor laceration requiring 3 sutures, and dressed with antibiotic ointment and a sterile bandage. No hospitalization was required. The incident was caused by inadequate quality control procedures for edge finishing on composite parts and lack of proper handling training for sharp-edged components.

On November 13, 2024 at 08:30, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C during the day shift, was performing a routine material changeover at the injection molding machine. She was connecting a new supply line of melted polypropylene resin from the hopper to the injection chamber when the connection coupling became loose due to vibration during normal operation. A small but steady stream of approximately 240°C molten plastic began flowing from the connection, spraying onto her left hand and forearm. Despite being dressed in standard work attire including cotton gloves, the extreme temperature caused immediate thermal burns across approximately 15% of her left hand and lower forearm. Sofia immediately ran to the emergency eyewash/safety shower station (UNIT-003) and cooled the affected area for approximately 5 minutes. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) was notified and responded to the scene. The burns were assessed as moderate depth thermal injuries requiring professional medical evaluation. Sofia was transported to the occupational health clinic where the burns were treated with topical antimicrobial therapy, covered with non-adherent dressings, and pain management was provided. The incident was caused by inadequate coupling design, lack of vibration-resistant fastening mechanisms, insufficient thermal protection PPE, and absence of guarding around the injection point.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Céline Morin, an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine cycle monitoring when she noticed excessive vibration and unusual grinding sounds emanating from the hydraulic pump assembly. She immediately halted the production line and notified her supervisor. Upon inspection, the maintenance team discovered that a critical hydraulic seal was deteriorating and leaking pressurized oil, which had accumulated on the machine base near the operator's station. The situation presented a significant risk of hydraulic fluid spray exposure and potential equipment failure. Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer, responded to the scene and observed that the operator had properly followed lockout procedures before investigation. The near-miss was successfully contained through quick detection and immediate shutdown protocols. No injuries occurred, and the equipment was secured pending replacement of the hydraulic system components.

On April 2, 2024 at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Emmanuel Kouassi, a Machine Operator, was transferring finished composite parts from the cooling station to the finished goods staging area. As he reached for a stack of parts on a high shelf (approximately 5 feet above floor level), his hand brushed against a sharp fiber reinforcement edge that had not been properly deburred during finishing. The contact caused a minor laceration on his left palm but did not result in significant bleeding or functional impairment. Emmanuel reported the incident immediately to his supervisor, and the area was inspected. It was determined that several finished parts in the batch had inadequate edge finishing, creating an unexpected cutting hazard. Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, was notified and investigated the quality control failure. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the injury was superficial, but it revealed a critical gap in the finishing process quality checks that could have resulted in more serious hand or eye injuries.

On May 8, 2024 at 6:15 AM during the night shift, warehouse associate Yvon Croteau completed a routine walk-through inspection of the Hazardous Waste Management Area in the exterior chemical storage building. During his inspection, he identified that three 55-gallon drums of acetone-based solvent were stored directly adjacent to a large propane tank used for equipment heating, with only 18 inches of separation between them. Company policy requires a minimum 10-foot clearance between flammable liquids and pressurized gas containers. Additionally, the drums lacked proper secondary containment barriers, and one drum showed signs of minor surface corrosion. The situation presented a significant fire and explosion hazard, particularly given the facility's proximity to the production buildings and employee work areas. Yvon immediately reported this finding to Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer, who conducted a thorough assessment and documented the hazardous storage configuration. This preventive declaration was made before any incident occurred, demonstrating proactive hazard identification and the effectiveness of routine safety inspections.

On March 15, 2024 at 10:45 AM, Assembly Operator Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134) was performing manual part removal from completed automotive interior trim components on Assembly Line C in the Main Production Building. While extracting a polypropylene dashboard component from the molding fixture, she noticed her right wrist experiencing sharp pain and tingling in her fingers. She immediately stopped work and reported the sensation to her Assembly Lead Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128). Upon examination, Fatima-Zahra's wrist showed signs of inflammation but no visible injury. The incident was identified as an early warning sign of repetitive strain developing from the high-frequency gripping and twisting motions required during part removal operations. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) was notified and documented the near-miss condition. The employee was temporarily reassigned to lighter administrative tasks while ergonomic assessment was conducted. No lost time occurred, but the condition required monitoring to prevent escalation to a full injury.

On April 8, 2024 at 2:15 PM, Mold Repair Technician Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189) was performing routine maintenance on an injection mold assembly in the Maintenance Workshop when a hydraulic connection became unexpectedly loose due to vibration-induced wear. While applying a wrench to tighten the fitting, residual hydraulic pressure was suddenly released, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid directly onto Armand's left forearm and hand. The fluid caused immediate chemical burns and skin irritation across approximately 15 square centimeters of exposed skin. Armand immediately immersed the affected area in cool water for 10 minutes and reported to the first aid station. Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) was notified and provided first aid treatment including cleaning, antibiotic ointment, and sterile dressing. The wound was documented but determined to require only topical treatment without hospitalization. Armand remained on full duty. The incident was attributed to insufficient pressure relief procedures and lack of equipment lockout prior to maintenance work.

On May 22, 2024 at 8:30 PM, Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was relocating pallets of raw polypropylene resin in the Warehouse and Shipping area during evening shift operations. While maneuvering a forklift loaded with approximately 1,200 pounds of material, Elif encountered a section of floor with a large spill of isopropanol cleaning solvent from earlier maintenance work that had not been properly cleaned up. The forklift's front wheels lost traction on the slippery surface, causing the vehicle to skid laterally. The loaded pallet shifted and toppled, causing the forklift to tip over with Elif still in the operator seat. Elif was thrown from the tipping forklift and sustained a fractured left leg (tibia and fibula fractures requiring surgical intervention), contusions to the torso, and abrasions to both arms. Night Shift Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) witnessed the incident and immediately called emergency services. Elif was transported via ambulance to the hospital where orthopedic surgery was performed. The employee required hospitalization for 3 days and was placed on medical leave with lost work time projected at 12 weeks during recovery and rehabilitation.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, suffered a severe burn injury while performing routine maintenance on injection molding equipment in the Main Production Building. Mathieu was clearing a blockage in the hopper feed system when hot plastic resin at approximately 280°C made contact with his left forearm and hand. He was not wearing appropriate heat-resistant gloves, only standard nitrile gloves. The incident occurred because maintenance lockout/tagout procedures had not been fully completed—the machine's heating elements were still energized. A coworker, Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190), immediately called for emergency assistance and provided first aid while Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) from the Emergency Response Team coordinated rapid transport to the local burn center. Mathieu sustained second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his body surface area on his left arm and hand, resulting in hospitalization for 5 days and 12 weeks of lost work time during recovery and physical therapy.

On October 3, 2024, at 23:15, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead on the Night Shift, was struck by falling composite materials from an improperly secured storage rack in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). Michel was conducting inventory counts when approximately 180 kg of fiber-reinforced plastic resin spools shifted and fell from the third shelf of a metal racking unit. He did not hear a warning sound and was unable to move clear before the materials struck him on the left shoulder and upper back. Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), working nearby in inventory control, heard the impact and immediately called emergency services. Michel was transported to the hospital with a fractured scapula, several fractured ribs, and significant soft tissue contusions. He underwent surgical stabilization and required 16 weeks of recovery before returning to work. Investigation revealed that the racking unit did not have proper load-bearing plates, and materials were stacked higher than weight limits specified for that shelf configuration. No risk assessment had been conducted on warehouse racking systems in over three years.

On January 22, 2025, at 09:30, the cooling water system for the composite materials processing line experienced a catastrophic failure when a 25-year-old copper pipe junction in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-015) corroded through and fractured. The rupture released approximately 850 liters of recirculating cooling water containing trace amounts of uncured epoxy resin into the facility. The spillage flooded the floor of the west wing production area and began migrating toward electrical equipment and the adjacent medical device cleanroom storage. Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), the Regrind Operator, first detected the issue when he noticed the production line temperature rising abnormally and water pooling near equipment. He immediately shut down the line and notified Georges Plante (EMP-00179), Facilities Technician, who initiated emergency protocols. Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) coordinated containment and cleanup efforts. The failure forced a 48-hour production shutdown affecting two major customer orders. The pipe fracture was caused by years of corrosion from acidic cooling additive without proper inhibitor replacement. System design had not been updated since the facility's 1998 opening, and preventive maintenance records showed the cooling system had not received internal inspection for 8 years.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn while performing routine maintenance on a mold assembly. Mathieu was cleaning residual plastic material from an injection mold that had been removed from the 250-ton molding machine. Despite following standard cooling procedures, the mold retained significant internal heat. When Mathieu attempted to access the mold cavity with a cleaning tool, pressurized steam unexpectedly released from an internal cooling passage, directly contacting his right forearm and hand. He received immediate first aid from the on-site medical station, including cold water irrigation and sterile dressing application. The burn covered approximately 8% of his right arm (approximately 40 square centimeters) with partial-thickness involvement. Mathieu was released after assessment and provided with care instructions and pain management guidance. No hospitalization was required. The incident was witnessed by his line supervisor, Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128), who immediately shut down the machine and initiated incident response procedures.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift operations, an environmental incident was discovered in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Unit 018). Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), Regrind Operator, discovered that approximately 180 liters of contaminated plastic granules had accumulated in an unauthorized storage area near the grinding equipment. The granules contained residual amounts of uncured epoxy resin and fiberglass composite material from a recent production run. During routine inventory procedures, Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) noted that the material had not been logged in the waste management system and appeared to be destined for improper disposal through a general waste contractor. Testing revealed the material contained volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and fiber fragments that could pose environmental contamination risks if released to landfill without proper processing. The contaminated batch was immediately quarantined and secured in designated hazardous waste containment. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was notified and conducted air quality monitoring in the affected area. No environmental release occurred, but potential exposure existed for 6-8 hours before discovery. The incident highlighted gaps in waste stream tracking protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift operations, a near-miss incident occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment Department. Diego Morales (EMP-00056), Assembly Operator, was preparing to enter an industrial curing oven (operating at 180°C) to retrieve finished medical device housings. Standard procedure requires the oven to cool to below 60°C and be verified by thermal measurement before operator entry. Diego began removing the access panel without performing the required temperature verification. As he reached toward the interior, he felt intense radiant heat and noticed steam emerging from the chamber. A nearby quality technician, Natalya Kozlov (EMP-00192), immediately called out a warning, causing Diego to step back from the opening. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified and verified that the oven temperature was still 142°C—well above the safe entry threshold. Investigation revealed that the digital temperature display had malfunctioned earlier that shift, showing a reading of 45°C when the actual internal temperature was significantly higher. The cooling cycle had not completed fully due to a scheduling error. No physical contact or burn injuries occurred, but Diego was exposed to severe thermal radiation hazard for approximately 30 seconds. The incident demonstrated a critical control failure in the verification process.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, a fire alarm was inadvertently triggered in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (South Zone). Rodrigue Tremblay, Machine Setter, was performing routine maintenance on an industrial oven used for composite curing when he accidentally bumped the manual fire pull station while repositioning equipment near the southeast wall. The alarm activated, triggering the facility-wide evacuation protocol and automatic fire suppression system discharge in the immediate area. Water sprayed from overhead sprinklers for approximately 3 minutes before the alarm was manually reset. No actual fire occurred. However, several batches of post-curing composite parts were exposed to water, and production was halted for 4 hours to assess material integrity and dry the affected equipment. Approximately 120 day-shift employees evacuated to the designated assembly point. The incident exposed gaps in fire suppression system sensitivity and the need for protective guards around manual pull stations in high-traffic maintenance areas. Nina Santos, Industrial Hygienist, conducted a post-incident review and documented the event.

On March 22, 2024, at 08:30 during the day shift, Paul Demers, Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a thermal burn injury while performing a routine mold changeout in the Assembly and Finishing Department. Paul was transferring a recently ejected mold assembly from the 300-ton injection molding machine to a cooling rack when he inadvertently made direct contact with an external mold surface that remained at 145°C. The mold had been removed from the heating phase but was not yet fully cooled. Paul's left forearm and dorsal hand sustained second-degree burns across approximately 8% of skin surface. He immediately reported the injury to his supervisor, Michael Chen, who applied cold water irrigation and provided first aid before transporting Paul to the facility's emergency medical clinic. Paul received treatment including pain management and burn care, and was released with follow-up appointments scheduled. The incident revealed inadequate waiting time protocols between mold removal and handling, and deficient heat-resistant PPE specifications. Michael Chen notified the HSE department immediately. Medical treatment costs were incurred, and Paul required modified duty for 3 weeks during recovery.

On April 8, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Bianca De Luca, Material Handler, suffered a crush injury to her right hand while operating the automated material handling system in the Raw Materials Warehouse. Bianca was restocking polypropylene (PP) resin bags on a high-density storage rack when the rack's safety latch mechanism failed. The mechanism, which was designed to prevent uncontrolled descent of the hydraulic lift platform, had not been inspected or serviced in 18 months despite the manufacturer's recommended 12-month service interval. When Bianca positioned a 25-kg resin bag on the upper shelf level, the platform unexpectedly dropped 0.6 meters, trapping her right hand and fingers between the descending platform and the fixed frame support. Her hand remained trapped for approximately 90 seconds before André Paradis, Production Supervisor for night shift, and Yvon Croteau, Warehouse Associate, manually engaged the emergency release valve and freed her hand. Bianca sustained crush injuries to four fingers and mild fracturing of the third metacarpal bone. Emergency services transported her to the regional hospital where she received surgical evaluation and casting. She was hospitalized for 18 hours for observation and pain management. The incident was documented by Marie-Claude Beaumont, HSE Director, and revealed critical maintenance deficiencies in hydraulic equipment oversight.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:47 PM during the day shift, a fire originated in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C) when an accumulation of plastic dust near the shredding equipment ignited from friction heat generated by a malfunctioning bearing in the regrind mill. The equipment had been operating with a known vibration issue for three days despite maintenance requests. Operator Claude Poirier noticed the smell of burning plastic and activated the nearest fire extinguisher, but the fire had already spread to approximately 2 square meters of regrind material stockpile. The facility's Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi responded within 90 seconds and deployed the overhead sprinkler system in that section. The fire was fully extinguished within 4 minutes. No employees were injured, but the incident resulted in equipment damage valued at approximately $18,000 and loss of production for 6 hours. The root cause was identified as inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling and insufficient dust collection in the regrind area, combined with combustible dust accumulation exceeding safe levels per NFPA 654 standards.

On November 16, 2024, at 10:22 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Naomi Okafor sustained a thermal burn injury while performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging area (South Zone). While cleaning the injection barrel at 185°C (365°F), her left forearm made contact with the heated barrel surface for approximately 2 seconds when she lost her grip on the cleaning brush. The initial contact caused a second-degree burn approximately 3 inches by 2 inches on the lateral forearm. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen immediately applied cold water for 15 minutes and provided basic first aid, applying sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. The employee was transported to the on-site medical clinic where the wound was documented, photographed, and additional treatment was provided including pain management and a tetanus update. The employee received 5 stitches and was released with instructions for wound care. No hospitalization was required. Root cause analysis indicated the employee was not wearing the thermal-resistant sleeve provided by the company, and the machine's temperature warning label was partially obscured by production labels.

On November 19, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme identified a potential ergonomic hazard in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) that had been developing over the previous two weeks. The warehouse shelving system had gradually settled unevenly due to the weight distribution of stored polycarbonate resin pallets (each weighing 1,200 kg), causing the middle shelves to sag approximately 3-4 centimeters and creating an awkward reaching angle for material handlers. No incident had yet occurred, but the condition created an elevated risk of back injuries and potential shelf collapse under continued loading. Laflamme immediately halted operations in that area and notified Safety Officer Anh Nguyen. A visual inspection confirmed the structural concern, and the warehouse section was cordoned off pending engineering assessment. The root cause was identified as improper load calculation during the 2023 warehouse redesign—the shelving manufacturer's weight rating was exceeded by 15% in the center section. This is a preventive declaration, as the hazard was identified and controlled before injury occurred.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM, Machine Operator Hawa Traore was performing routine material feeding on Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room when she noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge reading was fluctuating abnormally. Before alerting her supervisor, she attempted to manually adjust the pressure relief valve while the machine was still in standby mode. As she reached toward the valve assembly, a small hydraulic line fitting suddenly separated due to a hairline crack in the connector, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid across her left arm and shoulder. She immediately stepped back and activated the emergency stop. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron responded within 2 minutes. The employee was decontaminated using the facility's eyewash and emergency shower station. No personal injury occurred due to quick reaction time, but the incident exposed a critical gap in pre-operational equipment inspection protocols. The hydraulic fluid spill was contained using absorbent pads and proper waste disposal procedures were followed. The near-miss was identified as a serious potential injury scenario that could have resulted in hydraulic fluid injection injury or contamination of medical device components.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area. Waste coordinator Emmanuel Kouassi was transferring incompatible solvent residues into a consolidation drum when he inadvertently placed a container of uncured epoxy resin catalyst (containing peroxide-based hardener) adjacent to a drum of acetone waste. A forklift operator maneuvering nearby accidentally struck the smaller catalyst container, rupturing it and causing approximately 8 liters of hazardous material to spill directly into the acetone drum. The chemical reaction between the peroxide catalyst and acetone generated exothermic heat, causing the drum to begin venting vapors and creating a localized thermal hazard. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette was immediately notified and initiated emergency procedures. The area was evacuated, ventilation systems were manually increased, and the spill was contained using granular absorbent material rated for organic solvents. A secondary containment berm prevented environmental release. Fire services responded as a precaution but determined no active fire was present. The spill required professional hazardous waste remediation contractor involvement for proper disposal of approximately 15 liters of contaminated material, costing $3,200 in emergency response fees.

On March 22, 2024, at 8:20 AM on day shift, Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes was inspecting finished medical device components at the Assembly and Finishing Department workstation. She was manually removing intricate plastic parts from a finished goods pallet, stacking them into quality assurance trays for dimensional verification. Due to the repetitive nature of the work and high daily quota pressures (200+ parts per shift), she was working at an accelerated pace without taking the recommended 10-minute breaks every hour. During her fifth consecutive hour of part removal, she experienced a sharp pain in her right wrist and forearm. She attempted to continue working but the pain intensified and became accompanied by numbness in her fingers. Production Supervisor Michael Chen observed her difficulty and called for immediate assistance. She was taken to the on-site first aid station where initial assessment indicated probable repetitive strain injury with potential carpal tunnel syndrome symptoms. She was sent to an occupational health clinic for evaluation, where X-rays ruled out fractures but confirmed significant inflammation and synovial fluid accumulation consistent with acute wrist strain. The employee was placed on modified duty for 3 weeks with restricted gripping activities and prescribed anti-inflammatory treatment and physical therapy.

On March 22, 2024, during the evening shift at approximately 18:30, Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) discovered a significant coolant leak in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) reported noticing wet spots beneath injection molding equipment Line A-7, but did not immediately report it. Upon investigation, Nathalie identified a corroded cooling water line that had developed two pinhole leaks, releasing approximately 45 liters of fluorinated cooling fluid containing biocides onto the concrete floor. The spill had migrated toward the facility's storm drain system. Nathalie immediately activated the spill containment protocol, deploying absorbent materials and erecting barriers. The area was cordoned off and ventilation was increased. Environmental testing revealed no groundwater contamination. The root cause was inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling and failure to conduct routine cooling system inspections. The corrosion indicated the cooling lines had not been replaced in over 8 years despite manufacturer recommendations for 5-year replacement cycles.

On March 28, 2024 at approximately 02:15 during the night shift, Composite Materials Technician Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042) suffered a chemical burn while working in the Injection Molding Line A. She was preparing a batch of epoxy resin mixed with hardener when the container cap became loose due to inadequate sealing. As she lifted the container to transfer material to the mixing station, approximately 200 milliliters of the uncured resin splashed across her left forearm and the left side of her face, including near her left eye. Ivanova immediately notified her supervisor, who activated emergency protocols. She was guided to the eyewash and emergency shower stations where she rinsed for 15 minutes. Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) assisted with first aid while calling emergency medical services. Hospital assessment revealed first and second-degree chemical burns covering approximately 8% of her exposed skin. She was hospitalized for 48 hours for wound care and pain management. The container had been previously damaged and the cap's threads were compromised, but this was not documented in the equipment maintenance log.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during day shift operations, Benoît Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a laceration to his right hand while attempting to remove a partially cooled plastic component from the mold cavity. The part had not fully solidified, and when Benoît used an inadequate hand tool to pry it loose, his hand slipped and made contact with the sharp edge of the mold's cooling channel. He sustained a 3cm laceration requiring 8 stitches. Immediate first aid was provided by the on-site medical team, and the injury was documented. The root cause was identified as inadequate tooling design and insufficient operator training on proper part removal techniques. No witnesses were present at the exact moment of injury, though Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), the Crane Operator, responded to assist in getting Benoît to the medical station. The incident occurred in the Production Operations area near the molding line, and immediate corrective action included reviewing all hand tool designs and scheduling retraining for all operators on safe part removal procedures.

On April 8, 2024, at 06:15 during night shift operations, Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, was conducting routine inventory checks in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing) when she observed that the resin dryer unit (Model RD-2500) was operating at abnormally elevated temperatures. The digital display indicated 165°C, exceeding the maximum safe operating temperature of 135°C by 30 degrees. Natasha immediately shut down the unit and notified Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), the Hydraulic Systems Technician, who was present in the maintenance area. Upon investigation, they discovered that the temperature sensor had malfunctioned, causing the heating element to remain in continuous operation without proper regulation. The unit had been operating at this elevated temperature for approximately 3 hours before discovery. No material was damaged, and no personnel were injured as the dryer is contained within a sealed cabinet. This incident represents a critical potential hazard, as prolonged exposure to this malfunction could have resulted in fire, material degradation, or toxic fume release. The preventive declaration is being made to address the temperature control system failure and implement enhanced monitoring procedures.

On May 22, 2024, at 10:30 during day shift operations, Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013), Quality Control Technician, sustained a minor cut to her left index finger while handling a sheet of documentation during routine inspection paperwork in the Quality Control area. As Sophie was flipping through quality control records and material certifications stored in the Quality Assurance Specialist's station (UNIT-022, Administrative Building), the edge of a sheet of high-gloss coated paper caught the side of her finger, creating a superficial laceration approximately 0.5cm long. The paper edge, which was unusually sharp due to industrial cutting equipment used to trim inspection forms, caused immediate bleeding. Sophie immediately applied pressure with a tissue and reported the incident to Linh Tran (EMP-00046), Quality Assurance Specialist, who was working nearby. First aid was administered on-site by Sophie herself using a small adhesive bandage and antiseptic wipe from the workplace first aid kit. No external medical attention was required. The incident was minor and resolved completely within 30 minutes. This type of incident is preventable through improved document handling procedures and awareness of sharp edges present in administrative work environments.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Naomi Okafor was working at Injection Molding Line B when she noticed mold release agent residue accumulating on the molded components. While cleaning the mold cavity with a cloth, she failed to properly apply PPE gloves and directly contacted the mold release agent on the hot mold surface. She immediately experienced skin irritation and localized redness on her right hand and forearm. Naomi reported the incident to Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov, who was working nearby and immediately directed her to the emergency eyewash/shower station. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen was notified and responded within 5 minutes. Medical assessment revealed mild chemical dermatitis requiring topical treatment but no hospitalization. The incident was attributed to inadequate communication regarding chemical handling procedures during shift changeover and insufficient PPE compliance enforcement at the production line.

On March 18, 2025, at 4:45 PM during the evening shift, Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi was performing routine material loading at the Material Drying and Preparation Room. While retrieving a 50-pound bag of polypropylene resin from the upper shelf of a material storage rack (approximately 6 feet high), the bag shifted unexpectedly due to improper stacking. The bag struck Kouassi on the left shoulder and upper chest, causing him to lose balance and fall backward onto the concrete floor. He struck his head on the edge of a material cart, resulting in a loss of consciousness for approximately 90 seconds. Coworker Marc Hébert immediately called for emergency medical assistance. Kouassi was transported to Laval Hospital where CT imaging revealed a moderate concussion, left shoulder contusion with grade 2 sprain, and a 2-inch laceration requiring 8 stitches. He was hospitalized overnight for observation and released the following morning with 7 days off-work restriction. Root cause analysis identified improper material stacking procedures and inadequate rack weight distribution guidelines.

On March 20, 2025, at 2:30 AM during the night shift, Production Operator Kwame Mensah was performing routine maintenance cleaning on the Composite Materials Processing equipment using acetone solvent as per standard procedures. While wiping down high-temperature curing racks with a solvent-soaked cloth, he inadvertently placed the cloth too close to an open electric heating element that was left accidentally powered on by the previous shift. The acetone vapor ignited suddenly, creating a localized flash fire approximately 18 inches from Mensah's face and hands. Mensah immediately jumped back and dropped the cloth onto the floor where the small fire continued to burn. Mensah activated the nearby Class B fire extinguisher and successfully suppressed the flames within 30 seconds. The incident was immediately reported to Night Shift Supervisor and Safety Officer Anh Nguyen arrived within 10 minutes. Upon inspection, the heating element remained energized despite end-of-shift shutdown procedures. No personnel injuries occurred. Equipment damage was minimal (scorched cloth and slight surface discoloration on racks). Investigation revealed failure in LOTO compliance and inadequate hazard awareness regarding solvent flammability near heat sources.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the Production Operations area when she experienced a minor burn injury. While removing a finished part from the mold, a small amount of molten plastic (approximately 285°C) splashed onto her left forearm despite wearing standard production gloves. The incident occurred because the operator had not fully engaged the safety interlock before reaching into the mold zone, and the machine cycled slightly earlier than expected. She immediately ran her arm under cool water for approximately 5 minutes and reported the injury to her supervisor, Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101). The burn resulted in first-degree redness and minor blistering covering an area approximately 3cm x 5cm. The employee was treated with topical antibiotic ointment and a sterile bandage in the first aid station. No lost time resulted from this incident. The employee returned to modified duties for the remainder of the shift, avoiding direct contact with hot materials.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a potentially serious near-miss incident was narrowly avoided in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Material handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was transferring resin drums from storage to the mixing station using a forklift. As she approached the loading dock area, a propane forklift operated by another worker (not from the provided roster) suddenly reversed out of an adjacent aisle without sounding its backing alarm. Elif immediately swerved her forklift to the left, coming within approximately 60 centimeters of a collision. Both operators stopped their vehicles and assessed the situation. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) witnessed the near-miss and reported it immediately. Investigation revealed that the backing alarm on the other forklift had been disabled due to a mechanical fault for the past 3 days without being reported to maintenance. No contact occurred, no injuries resulted, and no equipment damage was sustained. However, if Elif had not been actively monitoring her surroundings and reacted quickly, a serious crush injury or fatality could have resulted given the combined weight and momentum of the two loaded forklifts.

On May 2, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the main ventilation system serving the Composite Materials Processing Area experienced a catastrophic failure. The equipment, a 15-year-old industrial centrifugal fan unit, suddenly seized due to bearing degradation that had not been detected by the predictive maintenance program. The fan stopped operating completely, cutting off fresh air circulation to the resin compounding station where volatile organic compounds and solvent vapors are routinely released. The failure was discovered when night shift supervisor discovered decreased airflow while making rounds. The production area began accumulating fumes within 25 minutes. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) was called to assess the situation at 6:55 AM and immediately initiated emergency shutdown protocols. All work in the affected area was halted, emergency ventilation windows were opened, and the facility was partially evacuated as a precaution. Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) from EHS was notified and confirmed potential exposure risks. The fan unit required complete replacement rather than repair, resulting in 18 hours of operational downtime and approximately $67,000 in replacement equipment costs plus lost production revenue.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on the hydraulic system of the injection molding machine. While attempting to disconnect a pressurized hydraulic hose without properly following lockout/tagout procedures, the hose connection suddenly released. Pressurized hydraulic fluid (approximately 200 bar) was forcefully injected directly into Arsenault's right palm and forearm. The fluid penetrated through the skin, causing severe tissue damage and necessitating immediate medical intervention. A coworker immediately applied first aid and called emergency services. Arsenault was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval and required surgical intervention to remove damaged tissue and prevent infection. He was hospitalized for 4 days and required 18 days of lost time for recovery and follow-up medical appointments. The incident investigation revealed that the lockout/tagout isolation point was not properly identified, and no isolation energy verification was performed before the maintenance attempt.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Layla Hussein (EMP-00098), an Assembly Operator in the Assembly and Finishing Department, was working on a custom medical component assembly line. While reaching across her workstation to retrieve a finished part from the upper shelf, her left foot caught on an air hose that had been routed along the floor near her station. The hose created a trip hazard that was inadequately secured with temporary wire ties. Hussein fell forward onto the assembly table edge, sustaining a fracture of the left radius (wrist bone) and significant bruising to her left hip and leg. She was immediately attended to by the evening shift supervisor and emergency services were called. Hussein was taken to the emergency department at Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur de Montréal where X-rays confirmed a non-displaced fracture of the distal radius requiring casting. She required 21 days of lost time including hospitalization overnight for pain management and follow-up orthopedic appointments.

On November 28, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when a 55-gallon drum of acetone (cleaning solvent) toppled over during inventory consolidation by Materials Supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031) and Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183). The drum had been improperly stacked on a pallet adjacent to other drums in a storage rack. A nearby forklift operation created vibrations that destabilized the stack. Approximately 40 gallons of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor before the drum could be righted. The spill pooled in an area approximately 12 meters long by 8 meters wide, creating a significant vapor cloud and exposing both employees to solvent vapors. Pelletier immediately activated the emergency alarm, and the area was evacuated. The spill response team, led by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), contained the spill using absorbent materials and contained it with a portable berm. All acetone vapors were managed through the facility's ventilation system. The spilled material was collected and disposed of according to hazardous waste protocols. Both employees experienced mild respiratory irritation but did not require hospitalization. The incident was contained within approximately 45 minutes.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was retrieving resin pellets from the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) when he noticed an electric forklift charging station displaying unusual sparking near the battery terminals. The forklift had been plugged in for over 8 hours, and the charging cable appeared corroded. Hassan immediately stopped and moved away from the area, then reported the issue to Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne. Before Éric could inspect the equipment, the battery began emitting a chemical odor consistent with battery acid vapors. Hassan experienced mild eye irritation and throat discomfort but did not sustain any injury. The incident was identified as a potential exposure to battery acid fumes that could have caused respiratory irritation or chemical burns if the employee had remained in close proximity. The equipment was immediately de-energized and quarantined. No lost time occurred, but the near-miss highlighted critical gaps in preventive maintenance of charging infrastructure.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) was performing routine mold removal from Machine 12 in the Injection Molding Line D facility (UNIT-004). After completing the molding cycle, Christian attempted to manually extract a composite mold that had cooled to approximately 65°C. Despite wearing standard heat-resistant gloves, he made direct contact with the mold surface while clearing plastic residue from the ejection pins. The mold temperature was significantly higher than expected due to a thermostat malfunction that had not been detected during the morning shift. Christian sustained second-degree thermal burns on the dorsal surface of his left hand, affecting approximately 8% of the burned area. He was immediately provided first aid by Evening Shift Supervisor Emmanuel Kouassi and transported to Hôpital de la Cité in Laval for emergency treatment. The injury required 12 stitches and resulted in 8 lost workdays. Root cause analysis revealed that the thermostat had not been calibrated for 18 months, exceeding the recommended maintenance interval by 6 months.

On May 22, 2024, during a routine preventive maintenance assessment, Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) conducted an inspection of the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) and identified a potential hazard that had not yet caused injury. While reviewing mold maintenance procedures, Anh discovered that the workshop's portable ladder storage rack was improperly secured to the wall and showed signs of stress fractures in the mounting brackets. The rack, which held 8 aluminum ladders ranging from 6 to 12 feet in height, was mounted on a section of wall that had been compromised by water infiltration from a roof leak that occurred 3 months prior. Mold Maintenance Technician Réjan Simard (EMP-00077) confirmed that he had noticed the structural instability but had not reported it, assuming it was stable enough for continued use. No employee had been struck by falling materials, but the risk was classified as HIGH probability given daily traffic through the workshop and the weight of the stored equipment (approximately 400 pounds total). This preventive declaration was filed to trigger corrective action before an incident could occur.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) during the day shift. An employee, Jing Wang (Materials Engineer), was transferring acetone from a bulk container into smaller storage bottles when a static discharge ignited vapors near an open container. The resulting flash fire activated the facility's fire detection system, triggering the alarm throughout the building. Facility Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand was working nearby and immediately activated the emergency response protocol, evacuating all personnel from the chemical storage building within 3 minutes. The fire was contained to a small area measuring approximately 2 feet by 3 feet on the work bench. Emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes and extinguished the remaining flames using a Class B dry chemical extinguisher. No injuries were sustained, but the incident resulted in minor damage to work surfaces and storage containers. The facility's emergency response team functioned effectively, with all personnel safely evacuated and accounted for within 5 minutes.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 AM during the day shift, an employee experienced acute chemical exposure while working at Injection Molding Line A (UNIT-001). Layla Hussein, Assembly Operator, was removing finished automotive components from the mold when she noticed an acrid smell and began experiencing eye irritation and respiratory discomfort. The cause was traced to a small leak in a mold release agent dispenser that had been dripping onto the heating element below, vaporizing the chemical. Hussein immediately reported her symptoms to her supervisor, Yves Thibault (Quality Supervisor), who assisted her to the first aid station. She was treated for chemical eye irritation using the eyewash station and administered supplemental oxygen. A qualified occupational health nurse from the on-site medical clinic assessed her condition and documented the exposure. Her symptoms resolved within 45 minutes. The incident was classified as a first aid case with no lost work time. The defective dispenser was immediately removed from service and sent for repair. An investigation revealed that routine maintenance checks on dispensing equipment had been missed due to scheduling conflicts over the previous two weeks.

On March 28, 2024 at 4:50 PM during the evening shift, a serious hand injury occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Réjean Simard, Mold Maintenance Technician, was operating a CNC milling machine to repair a damaged injection mold when his gloved hand became caught between the rotating cutting tool and a metal clamp. Despite the presence of machine guards, Simard had partially removed one guard to better access the workpiece, a deviation from standard operating procedures. The machine's emergency stop button failed to respond immediately due to a loose electrical connection, prolonging the contact time. Simard's right hand was pulled into the cutting tool, resulting in deep lacerations across his palm and partial amputation of his index and middle fingertips. Co-worker Daniel Kim (Electrical Maintenance Technician) heard Simard's distress call and immediately shut down power to the machine from the main disconnect. Emergency medical services were called and arrived within 12 minutes. Simard was transported to Hopital du Sacre-Coeur and admitted for emergency surgery. The injury resulted in significant tissue damage and permanent functional impairment requiring 8 weeks of recovery and ongoing rehabilitation.

On November 8, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Mohamed Ibrahim, Regrind Operator, was transferring acetone from a large storage container to smaller work containers when he noticed smoke emanating from an electrical outlet near a solvent dispensing station. The outlet had become overloaded due to multiple high-wattage equipment connections, causing internal arcing and creating a small electrical fire within the outlet box. Ibrahim immediately evacuated the area and activated the nearest fire alarm pull station at 2:16 PM. Gaétan Laplante, Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, responded as the facility's trained fire response coordinator. The facility's automated fire suppression system activated within 90 seconds, extinguishing the fire before any material became involved. Emergency services arrived at 2:28 PM and confirmed the fire was contained with minimal damage. The incident lasted approximately 12 minutes from alarm activation to all-clear confirmation. Root cause investigation revealed the outlet had been used beyond its rated capacity without proper load management or circuit breaker protection upgrades. No personnel were injured, but the incident exposed a critical gap in electrical infrastructure management in chemical storage areas.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, a significant property damage incident occurred at Injection Molding Line A (UNIT-001). Fatou Ndiaye, Production Operator, was conducting routine maintenance on the hydraulic cooling system when a hydraulic hose assembly suddenly ruptured near the mold clamping mechanism. The rupture was caused by metal fatigue and corrosion from inadequate preventive maintenance; the hose had exceeded its design life by approximately 18 months. Pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the production line, damaging multiple electronic control components, sensor wiring, and the thermal regulation display panel. The fluid also contaminated approximately 200 kilograms of ABS resin material staged for the next production run, rendering it unsuitable for use. Ndiaye immediately shut down the line using the emergency stop button and notified her supervisor. Roberto Santos, Forklift Operator, assisted in isolating the damaged equipment section to prevent cross-contamination. The incident resulted in approximately 16 hours of production downtime while the hose assembly was replaced and control systems were cleaned and recalibrated. Estimated material and equipment damage was assessed at $47,000.

On November 10, 2024, at approximately 8:20 PM during the evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Nadia Belkacem, Receiving Coordinator, was transferring a shipment of colorant masterbatch (polyethylene-based dye carrier) when one of four sealed containers fell from a storage shelf approximately 1.5 meters high. The container's seal fractured upon impact with the concrete floor, releasing approximately 18 kilograms of fine powder colorant into the air and across the floor. The incident created a visible dust cloud that spread through the chemical storage area and into an adjacent preparation room. Belkacem immediately initiated emergency ventilation procedures and evacuated personnel from the affected zones. Amélie Roy, Training Coordinator, responded and established a containment perimeter using plastic sheeting. The spill was contained and cleaned using HEPA vacuum equipment and damp cloth methods to prevent dust re-suspension. Air quality monitoring was conducted post-cleanup with results showing acceptable particulate levels within 2 hours. The incident resulted in 4 hours of disrupted operations and loss of the spilled material (approximately $2,800 in product loss).

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift, operator Rémi Charbonneau was performing routine material loading on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building when he noticed molten plastic material beginning to overflow from the hopper. He immediately stopped the line and attempted to clear what he believed was a minor jam. Upon closer inspection, he discovered that the material dryer thermostat had malfunctioned, causing the resin drying chamber to reach approximately 285°C instead of the normal 95°C operating temperature. The supervisor, Pierre Bouchard, was notified immediately. Rémi did not attempt to touch any heated components and maintained a safe distance. The equipment was safely powered down and locked out within 10 minutes. No thermal burns or injuries occurred. The facility's preventive maintenance schedule had missed the last quarterly thermostat calibration check. This near-miss was identified as a critical control point failure that could have resulted in serious burns or equipment damage if Rémi had attempted to manually clear the hopper without visual inspection first.

On November 20, 2024 at 10:45 AM during day shift, Assembly Operator Diego Morales was working at Station 3 of the Assembly and Finishing Department when he reached across his workstation to retrieve a finished composite bracket from the drying rack. His left hand made contact with a sharp burr (approximately 3mm protrusion) that had remained on the part edge following injection molding. The burr deeply lacerated his left index finger between the first and second knuckle, severing a small tendon and causing significant bleeding. First aid was administered immediately by coworker Aaliyah Jackson who applied direct pressure and called for medical response. Diego was transported to Hopital Sacre-Coeur by ambulance at 11:10 AM. He required surgical intervention and received 12 stitches. The injury resulted in 5 lost workdays as Diego underwent follow-up care and was medically cleared to return to light duty. Root cause investigation revealed the Quality Control Manager Isabelle Tremblay had not flagged this particular batch of parts as containing defects due to increased production quotas that week. Standard burr-removal processes had been bypassed to meet delivery deadlines.

On November 25, 2024 at 11:30 PM during evening shift, forklift operator Abdul Rahman was executing a routine pallet retrieval operation in the Warehouse and Shipping dock area. He was maneuvering a Toyota 8FGJU25 forklift while transporting finished goods pallets to the loading dock when the right front tire suddenly became detached from its rim due to a pre-existing hairline crack in the wheel assembly that had not been identified during the morning equipment inspection. The tire separation caused the forklift to shift violently to the right, causing the load (approximately 1,200 lbs of composite materials in corrugated boxes) to tip from the forks and crash onto the concrete floor. The pallets broke apart, scattering product across a 15-meter area. Several boxes were damaged, resulting in approximately $34,000 in ruined material. The forklift's mast was bent and hydraulic lines were compromised. Abdul was able to jump clear of the falling load and was not physically injured. No workers were in the immediate impact zone. Equipment damage to the forklift was estimated at $28,500. Root cause: the wheel assembly had a manufacturing defect that should have been caught during the pre-shift inspection, which Electrical Technician Viktor Novak had conducted but failed to identify due to a missing visual inspection checklist specific to forklift tire conditions.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 hours, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). An employee, Jing Wang (EMP-00054), was transferring acetone solvent from a 55-gallon drum into smaller containers for cleaning operations when the transfer pump malfunctioned. The pump's pressure valve failed without warning, causing approximately 12 liters of acetone to spray across the work surface and floor. The spill spread across approximately 8 square meters of the room. Initial responders included Facility Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133), who arrived within 2 minutes and initiated containment using absorbent materials. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was notified and coordinated evacuation of the Material Handling Zone. The spilled acetone created fumes that affected air quality in the adjacent production area, requiring temporary shutdown of molding lines A and B for 3 hours while ventilation systems cleared the vapors. No employees required medical attention, but the incident exposed gaps in equipment maintenance protocols and chemical transfer procedures. The facility's spill kit was located too far from the work area, delaying initial containment efforts.

On April 8, 2024, at 09:20 hours during the day shift, a potential near-miss incident was identified in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014). Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) noticed that the electrical cabinet door on Injection Molding Line D had swung partially open, exposing energized circuit breakers and terminals. The cabinet was actively supplying power to the molding press, which was operating under automatic cycle mode. Fatou immediately halted the production line by engaging the emergency stop button and reported the issue to James Thompson (EMP-00029), the Line D operator, and André Paradis (EMP-00037), the night shift supervisor who was present during the transition period. Initial investigation revealed that the cabinet door latch mechanism had corroded and failed to maintain a secure closure. No employee made direct contact with exposed electrical components, and the hazardous energy was successfully de-energized within 90 seconds. However, had the cabinet door fully opened or had an employee reached toward the circuit breakers during automatic operation, serious electrical shock or arc flash could have resulted. The incident was classified as a near-miss and reported by Training Coordinator Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) to the JHSC for root cause analysis.

On May 22, 2024, at 22:15 hours during the evening shift, an environmental incident was detected in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (UNIT-017). Composite Materials Technician Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042) was monitoring the discharge from the heat treatment cooling system when she observed that cooling water containing small amounts of composite material fibers was overflowing from the collection tank into the facility's floor drain system. The drainage overflow had continued for approximately 45 minutes undetected before discovery. Environmental assessment indicated that fiber-contaminated water had entered the primary facility drainage line, with approximately 8 liters of contaminated water reaching the external environmental discharge point near the facility's north parking area. The discharge had pooled near landscaping and storm drain access points. Olga immediately notified Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133), who shut down the cooling system and identified the root cause: the collection tank's overflow valve had been inadvertently closed during maintenance activities 2 weeks prior and not reopened. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was notified and initiated environmental impact assessment protocols. The incident required notification to local environmental authorities per CNESST regulations. While no acute environmental damage resulted, the incident demonstrated gaps in equipment status verification procedures following maintenance work.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) when Material Handler Mariam Osman was transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum to smaller containers for distribution to production areas. While repositioning the drum on a pallet jack, the drum's bung plug loosened, causing approximately 12 gallons of acetone to spill across the concrete floor. The spill created a significant slick surface and released flammable vapors into the confined storage area. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher responded immediately, activating emergency ventilation and placing absorbent materials around the spill perimeter. The chemical storage area was evacuated for 90 minutes while the spill was contained and cleaned. No personnel were injured, but the incident resulted in an estimated $2,800 in lost product, cleanup materials, and emergency response costs. The root cause was identified as inadequate secondary containment procedures and improper drum handling techniques during transfer operations.

On April 3, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Injection Molding Operator Céline Morin sustained a significant thermal burn while performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line A. The operator was removing solidified plastic residue from a hot mold cavity (maintained at 95°C) using a metal scraper when she lost her grip on the tool. Her right hand made contact with the mold surface for approximately 2-3 seconds before she withdrew. Céline immediately reported the injury to night shift supervisor Yves Thibault, who provided first aid with cool water and sterile dressing. She was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval by ambulance at 11:40 PM. Medical evaluation confirmed a second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 8% of her right palm and fingers. Céline was hospitalized for 3 days for pain management, wound care, and monitoring for infection. Lost-time injury reporting was initiated; she was unable to return to production duties for 18 days. Root cause analysis identified inadequate thermal protection gloves (prior gloves had worn thin) and insufficient cooling time before maintenance procedures.

On May 12, 2024, at 9:30 AM during the day shift, the primary ventilation system serving the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) experienced a catastrophic failure. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard was conducting routine filter inspections when he discovered that the main fan motor had seized due to bearing failure and lack of lubrication maintenance over the previous 8 months. The system is designed to capture glass fiber particulates and volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes from resin mixing and layup operations. With the ventilation offline, airborne glass fiber concentrations and VOC levels rapidly exceeded safe exposure limits within 20 minutes.
