Composite Materials Operator Rania Abdallah and Production Operator Yara Mustafa, both working in the area, reported difficulty breathing, skin irritation, and eye discomfort. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux was immediately notified and initiated emergency procedures: all operations in UNIT-015 were halted, the area was evacuated, and all personnel were moved to fresh air. Emergency portable ventilation units were deployed. The facility remained shut down for 14 hours while the main fan motor was replaced and the system was tested. Both operators received medical evaluations; neither required hospitalization, but both experienced respiratory symptoms persisting for 48 hours. Root cause: preventive maintenance schedule for the fan motor had lapsed due to staffing shortages and inadequate maintenance tracking procedures.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, a hydraulic hose rupture occurred on Injection Molding Machine #8 in Line A (Automotive production). Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay was performing routine maintenance on the machine's pressure system when a 20-year-old high-pressure hose connecting the main hydraulic manifold to the mold clamping unit failed without warning. The pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the work area, coating the machine controls, floor, and nearby equipment with approximately 15 liters of hydraulic oil. The rupture also caused the machine's clamping unit to lose pressure and partially open, creating a secondary safety hazard. Production Supervisor Michael Chen and Material Handler Elif Yilmaz witnessed the incident and immediately shut down the machine using the emergency stop button. The spilled hydraulic oil created a slippery hazard on the production floor. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois was called to assess the spill and coordinate cleanup. No personnel were directly injured, but the incident resulted in 6 hours of lost production time and required professional cleanup services.

On March 18, 2024 at 10:15 AM, Injection Molding Operator Céline Morin suffered a laceration to her right palm while removing a finished composite component from the ejection area of Molding Machine #15 in Line B (Automotive). The part had rough, unfinished edges with sharp micro-burrs typical of composite fiber-reinforced plastic parts that had not yet undergone finishing operations. As Morin reached into the ejection zone to remove the part, her hand contacted the sharp edge, resulting in a 4-centimeter laceration requiring 6 stitches at the on-site first aid station. Blood contamination of the immediate work area and equipment required sanitation before production resumed. Benoit Arsenault, another operator on Line A, witnessed the incident and called for first aid response. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur investigated immediately. The incident was classified as a recordable injury under CNESST regulations. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate edge finishing procedures and missing protective gloves appropriate for handling rough composite parts.

On March 20, 2024 at 4:30 PM during the evening shift, an unauthorized discharge of approximately 8 liters of acetone-based mold release agent was discovered in the hazardous waste management area. Tool Room Technician Raynald Vézina discovered the spill when he arrived for his shift to dispose of used maintenance materials. The container had been improperly stored on a shelf above other flammable materials without secondary containment, and the plastic cap had deteriorated, allowing slow leakage over a 24-hour period. The spill contaminated the concrete floor and seeped toward the floor drain system before Vézina isolated the drain valve. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois was immediately notified and activated the spill response protocol. The area was secured with warning barriers, and professional environmental remediation contractors were called to assess soil and groundwater contamination risk given the proximity to the facility's perimeter. Initial investigation revealed inadequate chemical storage protocols and lack of secondary containment systems for flammable liquids in the hazardous waste area.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone when he noticed material residue blocking the hopper feed mechanism. While attempting to clear the blockage with a wooden stick, the automated material handling robotic arm suddenly activated without warning, nearly striking his arm. The robot's gripper came within 6 inches of his hand before he jerked back. Ibrahim immediately halted the machine and reported the incident to his supervisor. Investigation revealed that the emergency stop button on the line had been accidentally bumped by another technician working in the adjacent area 30 minutes earlier, partially disabling the safety interlock system. No physical contact occurred, and no injuries were sustained. The incident was witnessed by quality inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) who was monitoring the production line nearby.

On November 16, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, composite materials operator Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174) was transferring resin-impregnated fiber materials from the mixing station to the curing oven in the Composite Materials Processing Area. While carrying a large tray of composite material across the workspace, she stepped over a coiled compressed air hose that ran along the floor near workstation alignment marks. The hose caught on her foot, causing her to stumble and nearly drop the tray of materials valued at approximately 2,400 dollars. She regained her balance and prevented the fall, but the tray tipped slightly, spilling approximately 200 milliliters of uncured resin onto the floor. Receiving Coordinator Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142) was nearby and immediately assisted with cleanup using absorbent materials and proper chemical containment procedures. The incident was reported to Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) within 15 minutes. Root cause analysis identified that air hoses were improperly routed with temporary fastening methods and lacked proper floor conduit protection.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine servicing on a 300-ton injection molding machine in Line A when he inadvertently contacted a mold release agent residue on the machine's ejector rod with his bare left hand. The mold release agent, a petroleum-based product containing mineral oil and silicone, caused immediate skin irritation and a localized allergic reaction characterized by redness, swelling, and mild burning sensation across his palm and fingers. Alain immediately washed the affected area with soap and water at the emergency eyewash/wash station located 40 feet away from his work position. Production scheduler Wei Liu (EMP-00088) found him at the wash station and alerted the night shift supervisor. The affected area was treated with antibiotic ointment and bandaged. Alain experienced mild discomfort for approximately 3 hours but did not require medical leave or hospitalization. The incident was reported to Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) the following morning. Investigation determined that the technician was not wearing nitrile gloves despite having them available at the workstation.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176), an Assembly Operator on Injection Molding Line B, identified a potential hazard while performing routine part removal tasks. Jackson noticed that the mold release agent dispenser nozzle on the injection molding machine had developed a hairline crack, creating a visible mist of aerosol particles during machine cycles. She immediately halted her workstation and reported the issue to her supervisor, Yves Thibault (EMP-00079), before any exposure incident could occur. Thibault visually confirmed the crack and documented the finding as a preventive safety declaration. The equipment was tagged out and isolated from production. Jackson's proactive identification prevented potential skin contact and inhalation exposure to mold release agents that could have affected multiple operators during the afternoon shift. The declarant, EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), was notified and formally documented this preventive declaration in the safety management system. The machine remained offline until maintenance could repair the dispenser assembly.

On April 8, 2024, at 11:15 PM during night shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-011). Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a Machine Operator assigned to resin mixing duties on the evening shift, was transferring a 20-liter container of polyester resin from storage to the mixing tank using the gravity-feed transfer system. A coupling on the transfer line failed, releasing approximately 18 liters of uncured polyester resin and catalyst mixture onto the concrete floor. The spill spread across approximately 120 square feet and began pooling near the electrical panel housing. Kouassi immediately notified his supervisor and activated the facility's emergency response protocol at 11:18 PM. André Bellavance (EMP-00157), the Confined Space Entry Supervisor, was called in to assess hazards and coordinate containment. The chemical mixture posed immediate risks of fire hazard, respiratory irritation from fumes, and slip/fall dangers. The area was evacuated, and containment barriers were established using absorbent pads and chemical containment booms. Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, assisted with equipment deployment. The spill was contained by 11:47 PM with no personnel exposure. Environmental cleanup and waste management procedures were initiated per CNESST protocols.

On May 2, 2024, at 8:20 AM during day shift operations in the Packaging and Labeling Station, Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186), an Assembly Operator, was arranging finished composite material parts for quality inspection and packaging. While reaching across a work table to position a large molded housing component, Rossi's left hand caught the sharp, unfinished edge of a newly molded composite part that had not been deburred. The edge lacerated her left palm, creating a 2-inch wound with minor bleeding. Rossi immediately removed her hand from the sharp edge and applied pressure with a cloth. A coworker, Ana Silva (EMP-00040), also an Assembly Operator nearby, called for first aid assistance at 8:22 AM. Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), the EHS Coordinator, responded with the facility's first aid kit and assessed the injury. After cleaning the wound with antiseptic and applying a sterile gauze bandage with antibiotic ointment, El-Khoury determined the laceration did not require stitches or external medical attention. She documented the incident as a first-aid treatable injury, monitored Rossi for signs of infection, and provided verbal instructions for home care. Rossi resumed light-duty work after 30 minutes of observation. The incident highlighted a gap in deburring procedures for newly received composite parts in the warehouse workflow.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Bianca De Luca was operating a powered pallet jack in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B) to move a stack of packaged automotive components. While navigating between rows of stored inventory, the pallet jack's steering mechanism suddenly became unresponsive. De Luca attempted to regain control but the jack continued forward toward Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette, who was conducting inventory verification nearby. Ouellette noticed the approaching jack with approximately 3 seconds to spare and quickly stepped aside, narrowly avoiding being struck. The pallet jack came to rest after striking an empty storage rack. De Luca immediately stopped operations and reported the incident to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen. Investigation revealed that the jack's hydraulic steering hose had partially disconnected due to vibration-induced loosening of the coupling nut, a maintenance issue that should have been caught during the weekly inspection. No injuries occurred, but the incident highlighted critical gaps in preventive maintenance procedures and equipment inspection protocols.

On November 18, 2024, at 9:45 AM during the day shift, Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu sustained a thermal burn while working in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. Popescu was transferring a batch of epoxy resin from a large storage drum to a heated mixing tank when the resin temperature probe registered 78°C instead of the required 65°C. She attempted to touch the outer surface of the mixing tank to assess its heat with her gloved hand, but her sleeve caught on a protruding valve handle, pulling her arm closer to the surface. The hot tank surface contacted her right forearm (approximately 8 cm of skin), causing a second-degree thermal burn. Popescu immediately ran cold water over the injury for 10 minutes and reported to first aid. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi assessed the injury, applied sterile dressing and antibiotic ointment, and determined first aid treatment was appropriate. The employee was advised to monitor for signs of infection and given contact information for occupational health services. The underlying cause was a malfunctioning temperature controller on the mixing tank that had drifted 13°C above setpoint without triggering an alarm. The incident was documented and the equipment was immediately taken out of service.

On November 21, 2024, at 2:30 AM during the night shift, a fire incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C of Warehouse and Shipping). Night Shift Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme discovered flames emerging from a plastic scrap bin containing ground polycarbonate waste material near the shredding equipment. The fire had apparently been smoldering for an indeterminate period before becoming visible. Laflamme immediately activated the building fire alarm, evacuated nearby personnel, and deployed a Class D dry powder fire extinguisher appropriate for plastic fires. The extinguisher successfully controlled the flames within 90 seconds. Local fire department responded within 8 minutes and confirmed complete extinguishment. Investigation revealed that the scrap bin had been positioned directly adjacent to a heat lamp used to dry cleaned plastic pellets, with insufficient clearance (12 inches instead of required 36 inches). Additionally, a spontaneous heat source may have been generated within the compacted scrap material due to friction during shredding operations and inadequate ventilation in the bin area. The bin sustained significant damage but no structural damage to the building occurred. No injuries resulted. The fire was contained to the single bin and immediate surrounding area. Post-incident analysis indicated multiple failures in segregation procedures, equipment spacing standards, and heat management protocols for recyclable plastic waste.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, experienced a minor laceration while removing hardened plastic parts from a mold press. While extracting components from the injection molding machine in the Assembly and Finishing Department, her left index finger made contact with a sharp edge on a partially ejected part. The contact caused a small but bleeding laceration approximately 1.5 cm in length on the fingertip. Yasmin immediately withdrew her hand and applied pressure with her gloved hand. Her supervisor, Julie Bergeron, was nearby and directed her to the first aid station where occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid cleaned the wound, applied antiseptic, and dressed it with a sterile bandage. No sutures were required. The incident was attributed to the operator's repetitive hand movements in the confined work area and the naturally sharp edges created by the injection molding process. This is a common occurrence in the department despite the use of gloves. The employee was able to return to work after first aid treatment with no lost time.

On November 18, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a Machine Operator on the evening shift, suffered a significant chemical exposure incident in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. While preparing a batch of mold release agent, Hawa was transferring concentrate from a 20-liter container into a mixing vessel. The container's lid was not fully secured from the previous shift, and approximately 2 liters of the solvent-based release agent splashed onto her exposed left forearm and the upper portion of her face. The chemical, containing dimethyl phthalate, caused immediate skin irritation and mild eye stinging. Hawa immediately went to the emergency eyewash station and rinsed her face and arm for approximately 8 minutes. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid was called and assessed the exposure. The affected skin area showed erythema (redness) and mild chemical burn characteristics. Hawa was transported to the urgent care facility for evaluation where she received treatment for first-degree chemical burns and was cleared to return to work the following day. The incident was attributed to inadequate container labeling, failure to secure lid properly after previous use, and insufficient spillage containment protocols in the mixing area.

On November 21, 2024 at 02:30 during the night shift, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a Production Operator on the night shift, sustained a minor hand laceration while loading finished composite material packages into the warehouse storage racks. Kwame was arranging finished molded components on a high shelf (approximately 1.8 meters above floor level) in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room when a bundle of metal strapping used to secure package pallets shifted and pinched his right middle finger between the metal strap and the shelf edge. The metal strap caused a small laceration and mild bruising on the dorsal surface of his finger. Kwame immediately removed his hand and sought first aid at the nearby first aid station. The occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid evaluated the injury, cleaned and bandaged the wound, and applied ice for swelling reduction. The employee returned to work within 30 minutes with no lost time. Investigation revealed that the metal strapping was not properly contained in its designated holder and had been loosely coiled on the shelf, creating a pinch point hazard. The night shift supervisor had not conducted a pre-shift inspection of the storage area.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) was operating Injection Molding Line B when she noticed unusual pressure fluctuations in the hydraulic system. Rather than immediately shutting down the equipment, she attempted to adjust the pressure relief valve manually while the machine was still pressurized. At 2:47 PM, the valve suddenly released, expelling hot hydraulic fluid onto her right forearm and hand. She sustained second-degree thermal burns across approximately 12% of the affected area. The incident was witnessed by Injection Molding Setter Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), who immediately activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. First aid was administered by Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) within 4 minutes. The root cause was inadequate lockout/tagout procedures during maintenance operations and insufficient employee training on pressure release protocols. Yara was transported to Hôpital de la Cité in Laval for treatment of burns and observation.

On December 3, 2024, at 8:42 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Mold Repair Technician Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189) was transferring a 55-liter drum of acetone-based mold release agent from storage to the preparation tanks when the drum's valve fitting failed, causing approximately 40 liters to spill onto the concrete floor. The chemical spread across an area of approximately 180 square meters, creating a slip hazard and potential fire risk. The spill occurred at 8:42 PM and was discovered at 8:55 PM when Evening Shift Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) performed routine facility checks. Immediate actions included: activation of the spill containment protocol, notification of all personnel to evacuate the affected area, deployment of absorbent materials, and ventilation system activation. The facility's emergency response procedures were partially effective but revealed gaps in secondary containment capacity. Two employees (Carmen Lopez and Deepa Gupta) reported mild chemical exposure symptoms (eye irritation, dizziness) and were monitored but did not require hospitalization. The spill was fully contained and cleaned by 10:30 PM. Root cause analysis identified inadequate drum inspection protocols and lack of secondary containment in the material preparation area.

On January 8, 2025, at 11:47 PM during the night shift, Forklift Operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) was transporting a pallet of polypropylene resin from the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) to the Injection Molding Line B staging area. At 12:03 AM on January 9, while navigating through the narrow warehouse corridor near Section A-7, the forklift struck a stacked storage rack containing composite material reinforcements. The impact caused approximately 15 bags (approximately 300 kg) of glass fiber reinforcement to fall onto the operator's cabin roof and partially into the elevated operator position. Although the cabin structure prevented direct impact, Santos was knocked backward in his seat and struck his head against the cabin wall. He immediately reported dizziness, neck pain, and confusion. Emergency responders (Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur - EMP-00107 and Night Shift Supervisor André Paradis - EMP-00037) arrived within 4 minutes. Santos was immobilized as a precaution and transported via ambulance to Hôpital de la Cité where he was diagnosed with a Grade II concussion, cervical strain, and contusion to the right shoulder. He was hospitalized for 23 hours for observation and released on January 9 with restrictions on operating equipment for two weeks. The root cause was inadequate warehouse lighting in Section A-7, combined with improperly secured storage racks and a forklift near-miss history in that location that had not been addressed. This incident resulted in lost time totaling 14 days during recovery and light-duty assignment.

On November 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM, machine setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was performing routine setup adjustments on Injection Molding Machine Line D when he noticed the hopper material level indicator was not functioning properly. While attempting to manually check the resin level inside the hopper by peering over the top edge, a sudden surge of polypropylene pellets from an upstream feeder caused an overflow. Approximately 40 kg of hot resin material cascaded over the hopper rim, partially contacting Bouazizi's left shoulder and upper arm. He immediately stepped back and moved away from the machine. His coworker Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) witnessed the event and immediately notified the shift supervisor. Bouazizi experienced minor thermal discomfort but no visible burns. The incident was caught before serious injury could occur because the material had cooled slightly during the short descent. However, the near-miss revealed that the hopper overflow prevention system had been bypassed during maintenance three weeks prior and never reinstalled. No lost time occurred, and Bouazizi declined medical evaluation, but the event demonstrated the potential for more serious thermal burn injuries.

On November 21, 2024 at 9:47 AM during the day shift, Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), Hydraulic Systems Technician, was performing scheduled maintenance on the hydraulic power unit that supplies pressure to the automated robotic arm on Assembly Line E. Following standard lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures, Popov had de-energized the main hydraulic pump and placed warning tags on the electrical panel. However, a secondary pressurized accumulator that stores residual hydraulic energy for emergency functions had not been fully depressurized through the manual bleed valve due to a procedural oversight. While Popov was disconnecting a high-pressure hose fitting to replace a worn seal, the residual pressure in the accumulator released suddenly, forcing hot hydraulic fluid (approximately 65°C) forcefully through the connection point. The pressurized spray contacted Popov's right forearm, hand, and torso, causing thermal burns and chemical irritation. Popov immediately moved away and called for assistance. Packaging Supervisor Patricia Martin (EMP-00035) heard the emergency call and activated first aid response. Emergency medical services arrived within 12 minutes. Popov was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval with second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his body and chemical irritation on exposed skin. He required 14 days of medical treatment and remained off work for 18 days. The investigation revealed the accumulator bleed procedure in the maintenance manual was incomplete and had not been updated since equipment installation in 2008.

On November 25, 2024 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, the automated fire detection system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Building (UNIT-011) triggered a full alarm activation. Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) was conducting inventory in the adjacent hazardous waste management area when he noticed faint smoke emanating from behind shelving in the chemical storage zone. The source was traced to spontaneous oxidation of improperly stored acetone-soaked rags that had been placed in a non-compliant cardboard container with inadequate ventilation. The rags, which were being held pending disposal, had accumulated heat over several hours, reaching ignition temperature. The fire alarm system activated automatically, triggering facility evacuation protocols. Night shift supervisor notified emergency services immediately. The Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes and extinguished a small but actively burning pile of rags using a Class B extinguisher before the fire could spread to adjacent chemical inventory. No personnel were injured, and evacuation procedures functioned correctly with all 20 night shift employees accounted for within 6 minutes. However, the incident resulted in approximately $47,000 in damage: destruction of chemical storage shelving, damage to approximately 15 kg of specialty resins from heat and water exposure, and replacement of activated fire suppression systems. The root cause investigation identified that the chemical storage SOP had not been updated since 2019 and did not include procedures for temporary storage of contaminated cleanup materials or specify compliant disposal containers.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) was operating Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone when she reached to clear a jam near the mold ejection area. Despite wearing heat-resistant gloves, she made contact with molten plastic material at approximately 280°C that had accumulated on the machine's heated platen. The material adhered to her glove and forearm, causing second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of her left forearm and hand. She immediately removed her glove and ran to the emergency eyewash/safety shower station. First aid was administered on-site by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), who assessed the severity and arranged immediate transport to Laval General Hospital. The employee was hospitalized for 3 days for wound management and pain control. The incident was witnessed by Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) who was working adjacent to the line. Investigation revealed that the machine's thermal barrier guard had a gap of approximately 2 inches that had developed due to vibration loosening mounting bolts over several weeks.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Forklift Operator Claude Poirier (EMP-00071) was moving pallets of raw resin materials in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) when he observed a stack of composite material drums on a middle shelf beginning to shift. As he approached the rack to assess the situation, approximately 150 kilograms of material threatened to fall from a height of approximately 2.5 meters. Poirier immediately sounded the forklift horn, stepped back from the impact zone, and called for assistance via radio. Supply Chain Analyst Miriam Cohen (EMP-00132) and Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) responded immediately and secured the materials using a reaching pole and stabilization straps. The materials were carefully lowered to ground level using proper procedures. No employee was struck, though the potential energy of the falling materials at that height could have caused serious injury or fatality had anyone been directly beneath. Investigation revealed that the drum rack shelf support bracket had developed micro-fractures from corrosion and metal fatigue, and the load weight slightly exceeded the rated capacity. This near-miss was reported immediately to the HSE department.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) was conducting routine maintenance on the resin mixing system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when a high-pressure coupling on the solvent distribution line failed catastrophically due to metal fatigue and corrosion. Approximately 120 liters of mixed solvent (a blend of methylethylketone, toluene, and proprietary additives) was released over a 45-minute period before the failure was discovered during shift rounds. The spill covered approximately 35 square meters of the mixing room floor, with approximately 10 liters entering the floor drain system before secondary containment activated. The room is equipped with adequate spill containment infrastructure, and the drainage system routed to the facility's neutralization tank as designed. Plante immediately activated the emergency procedures, shut down all ignition sources, and called in Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) for hazardous material response. Evacuation of the mixing room was executed, and external ventilation was activated. Environmental sampling confirmed the spill was contained within the facility's secondary containment system with minimal environmental release. The incident was reported to CNESST and environmental authorities as required.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Elena Popescu, Chemical Mixing Operator (EMP-00022), was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyurethane resin from storage to the mixing vessel when the drum's bung wrench slipped from her hand. The drum fell approximately 3 feet, striking the concrete floor and rupturing a seam along its side. Approximately 20 gallons of polyurethane resin spilled across the floor, flowing toward the floor drain. The spill activated the facility's chemical emergency response protocol. Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) arrived within 5 minutes and deployed spill containment materials. The area was immediately evacuated and ventilation systems were increased to maximum capacity. No direct contact with the chemical occurred, but three employees experienced mild respiratory irritation from fumes during the first 10 minutes before ventilation took effect. The spill was fully contained and cleaned within 2 hours. Environmental Services was notified per Quebec regulations, and the incident was documented for provincial environmental reporting.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Réjan Simard, Mold Maintenance Technician (EMP-00077), was performing routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine. He had completed a lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure and was removing a precision cutting tool from the spindle using an allen wrench. While reaching across the machine bed to access the spindle from a better angle, his sleeve caught on a protruding chuck jaw that had not been fully retracted. The cloth tore slightly, but his arm was not drawn into any rotating equipment. He immediately froze and carefully extricated his sleeve. Upon inspection, he realized that the machine's LOTO had been applied correctly, but the spindle had not been fully stopped—it was decelerating but still rotating at approximately 40 RPM (well below normal operating speed of 2000+ RPM). The incident was reported to Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037), who immediately stopped all maintenance activities and conducted a LOTO procedure review. No injury occurred, but the potential for serious laceration or entanglement was significant.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident was identified in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). Nadia Belkacem, Receiving Coordinator (EMP-00142), arrived for the day shift and noticed that a forklift (operated by Hugues Fontaine, Forklift Operator EMP-00167, during the evening shift) had been left with its forks elevated approximately 5 feet high while parked in the staging area. The forks were supporting a partially loaded pallet of finished composite parts, but the load was not properly secured with shrink wrap or strapping—only resting on the forks. During the night shift, there had been vibrations from equipment operations in the adjacent production area. Belkacem immediately recognized the hazard: any additional vibration or uneven settling could cause the pallet to shift or fall from the forks onto personnel or equipment below. She immediately contacted Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037), who responded within 10 minutes. The load was safely lowered to the ground, inspected for damage (none found), and properly wrapped before being returned to storage. Investigation revealed that Fontaine had left the load elevated due to a miscommunication about the receiving schedule—he believed the load would be picked up during the night shift but it was not. No injuries occurred and no equipment was damaged, but the potential consequences of a pallet falling from 5 feet were significant.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:30, during day shift operations at Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building, Assembly Lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) observed excessive heat radiating from the cooling water circulation system serving the automotive component molds. Temperature readings on the gauge showed 78°C, well above the normal 55-60°C range. Volkov immediately notified Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), who investigated and discovered a significant leak in the high-pressure cooling lines connecting the mold manifold to the central chiller unit. The leak, approximately 2-3 mm diameter perforation in the braided steel hose, was spraying pressurized coolant onto nearby electrical junction boxes and creating a slippery floor hazard. Rossi immediately isolated the line using manual shut-off valves and placed warning tape around the affected area. The incident was declared preventatively as the cooling system malfunction could have led to equipment failure, fire risk from electrical contact, or employee slip hazard if the leak had progressed. No injuries occurred. The system was taken offline and repaired within 4 hours.

On April 8, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift operations in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A), Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) was manually stacking polypropylene resin bags (25 kg each) onto wooden pallets using a hand truck when the bottom pallet shifted unexpectedly. The wooden pallet had a pre-existing crack in its upper deck that was not visible during routine inspection. As Haddad placed the fifth bag onto the stack at approximately 1.5 meters height, the weakened pallet deck fractured completely under the concentrated load, causing the entire stack (approximately 125 kg total) to collapse. Four bags fell directly onto Haddad's left foot and lower leg. She immediately experienced acute pain and was unable to bear weight. Co-worker Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) called emergency services at 22:18. Haddad was transported to Laval Hospital with suspected tibia fracture and severe soft tissue trauma. X-rays confirmed a closed fracture of the left tibia with displacement. She was hospitalized overnight and admitted to the orthopedic ward for surgical evaluation.

On May 22, 2024, at 03:45 during night shift operations in the Maintenance Workshop, Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was operating a CNC milling machine to fabricate a replacement component for an injection molding cavity insert. The machine was in autonomous cutting mode when Caron reached into the work envelope to check dimensional accuracy with a precision caliper, bypassing the machine's safety interlock system by manually disabling the proximity sensor. His left hand made contact with the rotating cutting tool (8 mm carbide end mill rotating at 2,800 RPM) while checking the workpiece. The tool created a 4 cm deep laceration across his palm and middle finger, severing two extensor tendons and causing significant arterial bleeding. Caron immediately withdrew his hand and applied direct pressure to the wound using a clean shop towel. Night shift supervisor called emergency services at 03:47. Paramedics arrived at 03:58 and provided tourniquet application above the wrist to control bleeding. Caron was transported to Laval Hospital's trauma center where hand surgery was performed at 04:45. The surgical team successfully repaired both tendons and arterial damage with anticipated 6-8 month recovery period requiring intensive physiotherapy.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Zara Khan (EMP-00106) was working at Station 3 in the Assembly and Finishing Department when she developed a sudden allergic reaction. She had been applying a new batch of epoxy adhesive to medical component parts without realizing the supplier had changed the formulation. Within 10 minutes, she experienced localized skin irritation and mild swelling on her hands and forearms. A coworker, Ana Silva (EMP-00040), immediately notified the department supervisor. Zara was taken to the on-site first aid station where Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos assessed the reaction. The affected areas were thoroughly rinsed with water and mild soap, and antihistamine cream was applied. Zara remained under observation for 30 minutes and her symptoms resolved completely. She was cleared to return to work with instructions to avoid contact with the adhesive until the ingredient change could be verified. The incident was classified as a minor allergic reaction requiring first aid intervention.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) was performing routine maintenance on Molding Machine #18 in Line A (Automotive). While adjusting the cooling water system valve, a pressurized hose connection suddenly ruptured due to corrosion that had weakened the fitting over months of operation. The high-velocity cooling water stream struck Christian's left shoulder and upper arm, causing thermal burns estimated at second-degree across approximately 60 square centimeters of skin. The immediate pain caused him to step backward, slipping on the wet floor and falling against an adjacent equipment frame. Christian sustained a moderate contusion to his left hip and buttocks from the impact. Colleague Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) immediately activated the emergency shower station and directed Christian to rinse the burned area for 10 minutes. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) shut down the cooling system and called emergency medical services. Christian was transported to the regional burn center for evaluation and treatment. He was hospitalized for 3 days for wound care and pain management, resulting in a lost-time injury.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 11:50 PM during the night shift, Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was transferring raw plastic resin pellets from a bulk storage container to the chemical mixing equipment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Hassan was using a pneumatic transfer system but noticed the flow rate was unusually slow. He attempted to clear what he believed was a blockage by manually tapping on the transfer hose section. Unknown to Hassan, a pressure relief valve had failed silently, allowing pressure to build abnormally in the system. When he struck the hose, the accumulated pressure suddenly released, rupturing a section of flexible tubing. A jet of pressurized resin powder mixed with compressed air struck Hassan in the face and chest with significant force. The fine resin particles irritated his eyes, nasal passages, and respiratory tract. Hassan fell backward, striking his head against a storage cabinet. Materials Engineer Jing Wang (EMP-00054), who was conducting a night shift quality check in the adjacent area, heard Hassan's cry and rushed to assist. Hassan was experiencing significant respiratory distress, eye irritation, and a developing headache. Emergency medical services were called immediately. Hassan was transported to the emergency department where he was diagnosed with chemical inhalation exposure, corneal abrasion to both eyes, and a mild concussion. He spent 5 days hospitalized for observation and recovery, resulting in a significant lost-time injury.

On February 8, 2024 at 06:15 during the night shift, maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine cleaning of the hopper feed system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when he noticed what appeared to be a partial blockage of the resin auger chute. Before attempting to clear the blockage manually, he contacted his supervisor and was instructed to perform a dry-run test of the auger system. However, the technician did not fully implement the facility's lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures—he failed to de-energize the main power disconnect and place a lock on the circuit breaker. When he reached into the hopper opening to assess the blockage visually, the auger suddenly activated due to a faulty limit switch sensor. His right glove became caught in the rotating screw conveyor, and his hand was drawn approximately 3 inches into the mechanism before an automatic emergency stop activated by adjacent worker Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142) halted the equipment. The near-miss was classified as such because the emergency stop activated before tissue damage occurred, though significant bruising and abrasion resulted. Root cause: inadequate adherence to LOTO procedures combined with a defective proximity sensor.

On April 3, 2024 at 11:30, assembly operator Layla Hussein (EMP-00098) was working at a manual assembly station in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit when she cut her left index finger on a sharp edge of a composite material part during the trimming and fitting phase. The laceration was approximately 1.5 centimeters in length with moderate bleeding. The operator immediately applied pressure to the wound and reported the incident to her line supervisor. She was escorted to the on-site first aid station where occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) cleaned and inspected the wound, determined it did not require stitches, and applied antibiotic ointment with sterile gauze dressing. The operator received a tetanus shot as a precautionary measure given the nature of composite materials potentially harboring contaminants. No other employees were in the immediate vicinity. The incident was triggered by the operator's hand slipping while gripping the part—the composite material edge had not been properly chamfered during the manufacturing process, creating an unintentionally sharp edge. The operator was released to light duty for the remainder of the shift with instructions to keep the wound clean and dry and to return for dressing change the following day.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was removing finished parts from a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. The machine's safety interlock had been manually bypassed by maintenance personnel earlier that morning for calibration work but was not properly re-engaged. As Youssef reached into the mold cavity to remove a stuck automotive dashboard component, the machine's proximity sensor malfunctioned and the mold began closing unexpectedly. Youssef's right hand was caught between the upper and lower mold halves, resulting in crushing injuries to his middle and ring fingers. The machine was immediately stopped by an emergency button activated by a nearby Quality Assurance Specialist, Linh Tran (EMP-00046). Youssef was transported to Laval Hospital with fractures to both fingers and partial tissue damage. The incident was witnessed by three other operators on the line. Root cause analysis revealed the safety interlock had not been properly reset after maintenance completion, and there was no verification protocol in place.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), a Warehouse Associate, was retrieving a pallet of raw polycarbonate resin from the high-storage mezzanine level in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room using an electric forklift. As Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), the Crane Operator assisting from ground level, was guiding the forklift positioning, a box of composite fiber reinforcement material located on the edge of the mezzanine shelf became dislodged. The box weighing approximately 45 pounds fell from approximately 18 feet above and passed within 2 feet of Martin's head, landing on a wooden crate behind him. Martin immediately stopped all operations and reported the near-miss to his supervisor. Physical inspection confirmed the box would have caused serious head trauma if it had made contact. Investigation revealed that storage procedures did not require edge guards or lip restraints on mezzanine shelving, and no weight limit signage was posted. The storage arrangement had been modified three weeks prior without HSE review. Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123) conducted the near-miss investigation and documented the hazard.

On May 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, René Caron (EMP-00097), a Tool Maker in the Maintenance Workshop, was performing routine CNC milling machine maintenance in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop. René was cleaning the machine tool bit holder assembly using compressed air and a hand brush to remove plastic shavings and residue from the previous day's mold manufacturing run. As he directed compressed air into a narrow cavity near the spindle head, a small piece of hardened plastic (approximately 1 cm) that was lodged inside became dislodged. The fragment ejected at high velocity and struck the protective acrylic shield on the machine, creating a small spider-web crack in the shield but not penetrating it. The fragment came to rest approximately 3 feet from René's face. Had the shield not been in place, the fragment would have potentially struck René's face or eyes. René immediately ceased work and reported the incident to the night shift supervisor. Inspection revealed the compressed air pressure regulator was set to 120 PSI, significantly above the manufacturer's recommended 60 PSI for this maintenance task. André Bellavance (EMP-00157) investigated and classified this as a near-miss incident.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Production Operator Sofia Gonzalez was operating Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building when she noticed the mold temperature display fluctuating abnormally. While reaching to manually check the mold surface temperature with her hand, she came within 2 inches of touching the hot mold surface estimated at 180°C. A coworker, Emmanuel Kouassi, who was passing by, immediately called out a warning, causing Sofia to pull her hand back just before contact. The mold thermostat had malfunctioned, failing to trigger the cooling cycle. Sofia reported experiencing a tingling sensation in her fingertips from the radiant heat but sustained no burn injury. The near-miss was reported to Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier within 30 minutes. The machine was immediately shut down and isolated for maintenance inspection. Root cause analysis revealed a faulty temperature sensor that had been showing intermittent readings for two weeks but was not flagged during routine maintenance checks.

On March 22, 2024 at 09:30, Packaging Operator Nour Jaber was working in the Assembly and Finishing Department, manually removing finished plastic parts from conveyor lines and placing them into packaging boxes. While handling a batch of automotive interior trim pieces, a part with a sharp edge made during the molding process caught the webbing between Nour's left thumb and index finger, causing a laceration approximately 1.5 cm long. The cut bled moderately for about 3 minutes. Nour immediately reported the injury to his supervisor, Guillaume Deschamps, who directed him to the first aid station. First aid responder Amélie Roy cleaned the wound with antiseptic solution, applied sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment, and covered it with a waterproof bandage. No stitches were required. Nour received tetanus status verification and was cleared to return to work with instructions to monitor the wound for signs of infection. The parts that caused the injury were identified and forwarded to quality control for edge assessment and process adjustment.

On March 28, 2024 at 16:15, Maintenance Technician Armand Lévesque was performing routine maintenance on resin mixing equipment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. While inspecting connection points on a large composite resin tank, he discovered a small hairline crack in a hose coupling that had begun to weep acetone solvent. Unable to immediately stop the leak with the valve, approximately 2-3 liters of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor over approximately 8 minutes before Armand could isolate the tank and contain the spill using absorbent pads and a spill kit. The volatile fumes created a strong odor that spread to adjacent areas. Armand immediately notified Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance and activated the facility's chemical spill protocol. The chemical storage area was evacuated, ventilation systems were maximized, and the spilled material was containerized in accordance with waste disposal procedures. Environmental monitoring showed acetone vapor levels peaked at 850 ppm (ACGIH TLV is 250 ppm) but dispersed to acceptable levels within 12 minutes of enhanced ventilation activation. No personnel exposure injuries occurred. The incident was contained within 30 minutes.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), a Machine Setter, was configuring a new resin batch in the Material Drying and Preparation Room when she inadvertently made skin contact with mold release agent while transferring a 5-gallon container. She was wearing nitrile gloves; however, the gloves had a small tear on the right index finger that she was unaware of. Within minutes, Svetlana experienced localized skin irritation, redness, and mild burning sensation on the affected finger. She immediately rinsed the area with water and reported the exposure to her supervisor. The incident was assessed by Nina Santos (EMP-00084), Industrial Hygienist, who evaluated the chemical exposure and observed the glove defect. The Safety Data Sheet for the mold release agent indicated potential skin irritation from direct contact. Svetlana was transported to the occupational health clinic where she received topical treatment and monitoring. The exposure was mild and resolved within 24 hours without requiring hospital admission. The incident highlighted the need for improved glove inspection procedures before chemical handling tasks.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine when his left hand became caught in the machine's mold closing mechanism. Despite the presence of a lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure, a breakdown in the communication process between the night shift operator and the maintenance technician resulted in the machine not being properly locked out before Bruno began work. The machine cycled unexpectedly, catching his left hand and fingers between the fixed cavity and the moving platen. Bruno immediately called for assistance. His supervisor, Richard Beaulieu (EMP-00043), Tool Room Supervisor, responded and initiated emergency stop procedures. The machine was stopped within seconds, but not before Bruno sustained a crush injury to his left hand with fractures to three metacarpal bones and significant soft tissue damage. Emergency medical services were called, and Bruno was transported to the regional trauma center where he underwent surgical repair. He was hospitalized for three days and required post-operative care and rehabilitation. The incident resulted in significant lost work time—Bruno was unable to return to his position for 12 weeks. The investigation revealed that the night shift had reduced staffing, communication of the maintenance schedule was not clearly posted, and LOTO procedures had not been refreshed for night shift personnel in eight months.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Hassan Diallo (Material Handler, EMP-00020) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent from the storage area to Injection Molding Line B in the Automotive section. While navigating through the narrow corridor between the production lines, the drum became unstable on the hand truck and tipped over, rupturing the seal. Approximately 40 liters of the solvent-based mold release agent spilled across the concrete floor, creating a hazardous zone approximately 4 meters by 3 meters. The liquid began pooling near electrical junction boxes and posed both fire and electrical hazard risks. Hassan immediately reported the incident to his supervisor, who initiated emergency response protocols. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) arrived within 5 minutes and began containment procedures. The affected area was evacuated, ventilation fans were activated to address vapors, and absorbent material was deployed. Approximately 15 workers were temporarily relocated to safe zones. The spill was fully contained within 25 minutes. There were no personal injuries, but the incident resulted in a 2-hour production delay on Line B.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, François Gagnon (Injection Molding Operator - Line A, EMP-00008) sustained a thermal burn injury while attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper feed system. François noticed reduced resin flow and attempted to manually clear the blockage without following lockout/tagout procedures or waiting for supervisor authorization. As he reached into the hopper area with his right hand, contact was made with the heated barrel of the injection molding machine, which operates at approximately 220°C during production. The burn affected the dorsal surface and palm of his right hand, covering approximately 8% of the hand area, classified as a second-degree thermal burn. François immediately withdrew his hand and alerted nearby colleague Valentina Rossi (Assembly Operator, EMP-00186), who called for first aid assistance. First aid responders applied cool water and sterile dressing within 8 minutes. François was transported to the local medical clinic for evaluation and treatment. He required 4 stitches and was prescribed topical antibiotic ointment and pain management. The injury required 3 weeks off work during the healing process and resulted in a lost-time incident recordable under CNESST regulations.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during the evening shift, Linh Tran (Quality Assurance Specialist, EMP-00046) was conducting a routine inspection in the Quality Control Laboratory when she observed a potentially hazardous condition. While examining UV light testing equipment used for color consistency verification on medical device components, Linh noticed that the UV light chamber door interlock switch had become misaligned, creating a gap that allowed direct UV light exposure without the protective shielding. The equipment had been in use for 45 minutes that day without incident, but the exposure risk was substantial. Linh did not attempt to operate the equipment and immediately documented the finding and reported it to supervisor Jamal Thompson (Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, EMP-00152). This was classified as a preventive safety declaration intended to halt use of the equipment before any worker sustained an occupational exposure injury. The equipment was immediately taken out of service, and a "Do Not Use" tag was affixed. Maintenance was scheduled for the following morning. Linh's prompt identification prevented potential eye injury and dermatological issues that could result from uncontrolled UV exposure.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator in Assembly and Finishing Department, was manually deburring plastic components from Injection Molding Line D when a sharp edge on a finished part lacerated the palm of his left hand. The operator was working at Station 3 without wearing cut-resistant gloves, relying only on standard nitrile gloves that provided insufficient protection against the sharp plastic edges. The laceration was approximately 2 inches long and required immediate first aid treatment including wound irrigation, antiseptic application, and a sterile bandage. The employee reported the incident to his supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot within 5 minutes. First aid was administered on-site by the facility's trained first aid responder. The wound did not require stitches or medical attention beyond first aid. No work time was lost beyond the 15 minutes required for treatment and documentation. The incident was classified as a first aid case and properly documented according to CNESST requirements.

On March 18, 2024 at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a Machine Operator on evening shift, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D when he noticed coolant water leaking from a cracked fitting on the cooling system. While attempting to tighten the fitting with a wrench to stop the leak, the pressurized coolant water sprayed onto his face and neck, causing mild thermal irritation and minor redness. The operator immediately moved away from the spray and rinsed his face with water from the eyewash station located near the machine. The incident occurred because the operator did not follow proper LOTO procedures and did not depressurize the cooling system before attempting repairs. The spray resulted in first-aid level irritation with no lasting effects. The operator reported the incident to the maintenance supervisor and documented it immediately. No further medical attention was required beyond the immediate rinsing and observation period of 20 minutes.

On March 22, 2024 at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, suffered a severe thermal burn to his right forearm and hand when he came into contact with the hot mold surface while attempting to manually clear a material jam on the injection press. The operator approached the mold while it was at 185°C without waiting for the temperature to drop or using appropriate thermal protective equipment. The contact resulted in second-degree burns covering approximately 4 square inches of skin on the forearm and hand. The employee immediately reported the injury to the night shift supervisor Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190), who called for emergency medical assistance. First aid was administered immediately including cool water immersion for 15 minutes at the facility, then the employee was transported by ambulance to the emergency department at Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval. The employee was hospitalized for 2 days and required prescription-strength pain medication and specialized burn care. This incident resulted in a lost-time injury with the employee missing 8 working days before returning to restricted duty.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing unit (UNIT-005). Mélanie Fortin, Shipping and Receiving Clerk, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin from a storage rack when the drum's bung plug became loose due to vibration from nearby forklift operations. Approximately 20 gallons of epoxy resin spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard and releasing volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes into the work area. The spill occurred near the mixing station where two other employees (Bruno Landry and Claudine Desjardins) were working on Line D operations. Initial response included immediate evacuation of the affected area, activation of the facility's ventilation system, and notification of the HSE team. Bruno Landry experienced mild respiratory irritation from fume exposure and reported feeling dizzy. The spill was contained using absorbent material and neutralizing agents, requiring approximately 3 hours to fully remediate. Root cause investigation determined that the drum was improperly secured during storage and that forklift operators lacked awareness of nearby hazardous material storage areas.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:45 AM during the night shift, Alain Mercier, Ergonomics Specialist, conducted a preventive ergonomics assessment in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005) as part of the quarterly JHSC proactive inspection program. During this routine walkthrough, Mercier observed that multiple injection molding operators were performing repetitive upper-limb tasks at workstations that had not been adjusted in over 18 months. Specifically, operators on Line B were reaching across their bodies at awkward shoulder angles to access material bins, and work surface heights were not optimized for the range of operator heights (ranging from 5'2" to 6'1"). No complaints had been formally filed, but Mercier's biomechanical analysis indicated that 4 of 6 observed operators were utilizing compensatory postures that could lead to cumulative trauma disorder within 12-18 months. Additionally, Mercier noted that footrests at three workstations were missing or damaged, forcing operators to maintain unsupported lower-extremity positions. Environmental temperature was 18°C, contributing to muscle stiffness. This preventive declaration was documented as a near-miss condition with significant risk potential. No acute injury had occurred, but the conditions represented a clear pathway to future musculoskeletal disorders if left unaddressed.

On April 5, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM during the day shift, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). A resin dryer unit (Model XR-500 industrial dryer, manufactured 2015) suddenly experienced a thermostat malfunction causing the heating elements to cycle continuously without temperature regulation. The unit's internal temperature rapidly escalated from the setpoint of 80°C to an estimated 145°C within 8 minutes, triggering only the high-temperature alarm but failing to initiate the safety shutdown sequence. Claudine Desjardins, Injection Molding Operator, was monitoring the dryer when she noticed the unusual temperature spike on the digital display and smelled an acrid burning odor coming from the unit. She immediately evacuated the area and alerted maintenance personnel. Roland Dostie, Maintenance Planner, and Yves Thibault, Quality Supervisor, responded to investigate. Upon opening the dryer access panel, they observed that the secondary temperature sensor (RTD probe) had disconnected internally, preventing the redundant safety system from functioning. Approximately 150 kg of polycarbonate resin inside the dryer had partially degraded, releasing toxic fumes (carbon monoxide and hydrogen cyanide precursors). The equipment was immediately powered down, the area was ventilated, and no personnel sustained injuries, though Claudine reported mild throat irritation. Root cause: preventive maintenance interval had been extended from 6 months to 12 months in 2023 due to budget constraints, and the RTD probe connection had not been inspected.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift operations, machine setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was performing routine mold changeover on Injection Molding Line B (Automotive) in the North Zone when a malfunction occurred in the automated robotic arm system. While Louis was manually removing a partially completed component from the mold cavity, the robotic arm unexpectedly reactivated due to a software glitch in the PLC (programmable logic controller) that had not been properly reset after maintenance. The arm's gripper mechanism caught Louis's left hand between the mold clamp and the extraction mechanism, crushing his index and middle fingers. Co-worker Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) immediately triggered the emergency stop button and called for medical assistance. Louis was transported to Laval General Hospital by ambulance where X-rays confirmed fractures to the metacarpal bones and severe contusions. He was admitted for observation and pain management, resulting in a lost-time injury requiring 14 days of hospitalization and subsequent rehabilitation. The robotic arm system was immediately shut down for inspection, revealing the software had not been properly cleared after the previous day's maintenance by Viktor Novak.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during routine production operations in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing), Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) conducted a walk-through inspection and observed elevated levels of volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions near the chemical mixing and compounding equipment. While performing air quality sampling near workstations where operators were manually mixing resin and hardener compounds for composite layup, Nina detected that the local exhaust ventilation system was operating at only 60% of its designed airflow capacity. The ventilation system failure was caused by accumulated dust and resin residue in the intake ductwork, reducing effective capture velocity below the OSHA-recommended 100-150 linear feet per minute threshold. Three workers (Fernand Comeau, Armand Lévesque, and Natalya Kozlov) had been working in this area for 6 hours without complaint, though all reported mild headaches and eye irritation consistent with VOC exposure. Nina immediately notified the facility supervisor to halt mixing operations and increase natural ventilation using bay doors. No acute injuries occurred, but this was declared as a preventive incident to address the system deficiency before occupational exposure limits (OELs) could be exceeded. Air samples were collected for laboratory analysis and maintenance was scheduled urgently.

On March 28, 2024, at 11:30 PM during night shift operations, forklift operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was moving a palletized load of finished composite parts from the Materials Management and Warehousing area to the shipping dock when he stepped on a wet spot near the dock entrance. The floor had become slippery due to condensation dripping from the overhead crane system, which had not been properly maintained and was leaking hydraulic fluid. Tariq's left foot slipped as he was transitioning from the forklift to the loading dock, causing him to fall backward approximately 3 feet onto the concrete dock surface. He struck his lower back and right elbow on impact. Coworker Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019) witnessed the fall and immediately called for assistance. Tariq was able to walk but reported significant pain in his lower back and right elbow. The facility first aid responder, Roland Dostie (EMP-00199), applied ice packs and pain relief. After initial assessment, Tariq was transported to the urgent care clinic at Laval Walk-In Medical Centre where X-rays confirmed no fractures but soft tissue bruising was documented. He was treated with a topical analgesic, instructed to apply heat therapy, and released with a recommendation for rest and observation. The incident was treated with first aid only, requiring no hospitalization or lost work time after the incident day.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Injection Molding Line A experienced catastrophic equipment failure in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi was loading desiccant cartridges into the hopper of a Conair Desiccant Dryer when the unit's heating element thermostat malfunctioned, causing uncontrolled temperature escalation to 185°C (normal operating range 60-80°C). The excessive heat degraded the polymer pellets being processed, releasing caustic fumes into the confined space. The equipment's ventilation shroud detached due to thermal expansion, creating a safety hazard. Bouazizi experienced minor respiratory irritation and evacuated immediately. The equipment was shut down manually by Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham, who responded within 3 minutes. No serious injuries occurred, but approximately 150 kg of raw material was destroyed, and the dryer required replacement of internal components. Root cause analysis identified a failed temperature sensor and absence of redundant safety cutoffs. The incident was witnessed by Quality Engineer Deepa Gupta, who called emergency response protocols.

On November 16, 2024, at 10:45 AM during day shift, Assembly Operator Ana Silva sustained a laceration requiring first aid treatment in the Production Engineering area (UNIT-021). While manually trimming flash from medical device components using a utility knife with a freshly sharpened blade, the knife slipped on the polished plastic surface and contacted the base of her left index finger, creating a 2 cm laceration across the proximal interphalangeal joint. The wound bled moderately but did not penetrate to deeper structures. Silva immediately applied manual pressure and walked to the medical station where Safety Officer Anh Nguyen provided first aid: thorough wound cleaning with sterile saline, application of antibiotic ointment, and sterile dressing with 5 stitches closed by occupational health nurse. Silva was released to modified duty (no manual trimming) for 3 days pending reassessment. The utility knife handle lacked adequate grip texturing and the work surface had insufficient grip mat. Karim Bouazizi witnessed the incident and reported it to HSE immediately. No lost work time occurred beyond the 45-minute first aid treatment and documentation period.

On November 18, 2024, at 11:20 PM during night shift operations, Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components) in the Clean Room Area (UNIT-003) experienced pump seal failure in the primary hydraulic system serving the mold clamping mechanism. CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov was performing routine equipment inspections when he detected a hydraulic fluid leak from the pump housing. Within 15 minutes, the leak rate increased exponentially as the seal degraded completely. Approximately 40 liters of ISO 32 hydraulic fluid sprayed into the containment basin below the equipment, but secondary containment failed to fully capture the overflow due to a crushed drain line. Approximately 8 liters of fluid entered the facility floor drainage system before the main hydraulic valve was manually shut off by Maintenance Manager Carlos Rodriguez. The spill activated emergency protocols: production halted, containment materials deployed, and environmental response initiated. Sokolov and Rodriguez wore appropriate PPE and suffered no injuries. However, equipment downtime extended 16 hours, disrupting medical device component production commitments. Root cause: seal material incompatibility with new synthetic hydraulic fluid formula introduced 6 weeks prior during system maintenance.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine. While cleaning the mold cavity with a compressed air hose, the machine unexpectedly cycled and activated. The operator's right hand was caught between the closing mold halves, resulting in crush injuries to his hand and two fingers. The machine was not properly locked out despite company LOTO procedures requiring it. Colleagues immediately stopped the machine using the emergency stop button. Stéphane was transported to Laval Hospital with severe crush injuries, a fractured metacarpal bone, and significant soft tissue damage. He required emergency surgery and was hospitalized for 8 days. The incident was witnessed by Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186), who called emergency services. Investigation revealed the operator had bypassed the lockout procedure due to time pressure to meet production quotas.

On April 3, 2024, at 09:30 during day shift, Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), a Material Handler, was organizing raw material pallets in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). While manually lifting a 35-pound bag of polycarbonate resin from a lower shelf to an overhead pallet rack, he experienced acute lower back pain. The material handling area lacked proper lift-assist equipment and ergonomic workstations. Amani had not received recent ergonomics training and was using improper lifting technique—bending at the waist instead of using his legs. He immediately reported the injury to his supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010), who provided first aid consisting of ice application and a pain relief gel. Amani was able to continue working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. The incident was documented in the first aid log and reported to Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), Environmental Compliance Specialist. While the injury did not result in lost time, it indicates a significant ergonomic hazard in the warehouse.

On April 18, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift, Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160), a Production Operator, was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area. While handling freshly cured composite parts that had just been removed from an industrial oven operating at 180°C, she inadvertently touched a section of the part that retained residual heat. The oven temperature indicator was obscured by accumulated dust and vapors, and she did not wait the required five minutes for parts to cool before handling. She sustained a first-degree burn on her left palm and fingers. Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050), also working in the area, immediately applied cold water to the burn and provided first aid consisting of antibiotic ointment and sterile gauze dressing. The incident was reported to Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), Fire Safety Coordinator, who documented the first aid treatment. The employee continued work for the remainder of the shift with modified duties and applied a protective bandage.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a critical failure occurred in the resin dryer system located in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-008 adjacent area). Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was monitoring the automated material preparation when he noticed the dryer temperature display reading 285°C, well above the normal operating range of 80-120°C. The heating element thermostat had malfunctioned due to a corroded temperature sensor, causing the system to continuously heat without cutoff. Within minutes, the resin pellets inside began to decompose, releasing acrid smoke and triggering the facility's smoke detectors. Abdul immediately activated the emergency shutdown protocol and evacuated the area. The maintenance team, led by Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), arrived within 10 minutes and safely powered down the system. A subsequent inspection revealed the thermostat had failed due to moisture ingress from inadequate sealing around the sensor port. Approximately 500 kg of polypropylene resin was destroyed, and the production line remained offline for 8 hours for equipment cooling and inspection. No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident highlighted critical gaps in preventive maintenance procedures for temperature control systems.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 6:45 PM during evening shift operations in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008), Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) sustained a significant back injury while manually lifting a heavy carton of finished plastic components. The carton, weighing approximately 35 kg, was positioned on a lower shelf and required an awkward lifting technique due to limited workspace around existing pallet stacks. Bianca attempted to lift using primarily her lower back without bending her knees properly, a technique contrary to company ergonomics training. Immediately upon lifting, she felt a sharp pain in her lower lumbar region and dropped the carton. She reported the injury to Shipping and Receiving Clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019), who immediately notified the HSE department. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) arrived at the scene within 15 minutes and conducted an initial assessment. Bianca was transported to the occupational health clinic where X-rays confirmed a strain of the L4-L5 vertebrae with muscle strain. She was prescribed rest, physical therapy, and placed on restricted duty for 3 weeks. The incident was classified as lost-time because Bianca required modified duty assignments preventing normal warehouse operations.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 11:50 PM during night shift operations in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012), Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) sustained a serious electrical injury while performing routine maintenance on a 460-volt injection molding machine power distribution panel. Despite following company lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures, Claude failed to verify that the main disconnect switch had been properly engaged before beginning work. A second technician had partially completed maintenance earlier and left the panel in an intermediate state with power still flowing to certain circuits through a bypass contactor. When Claude opened the panel door and reached toward what he believed was a de-energized terminal block, he made contact with a live 460-volt conductor.
