The electrical arc caused severe burns to his right hand and arm, causing him to involuntarily pull away and strike his head against the adjacent equipment. Claude was thrown backward and fell approximately 1.5 meters onto the concrete floor. Night shift supervisor Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041) discovered Claude unconscious 15 minutes later during a routine facility check. Emergency services were contacted immediately, and Claude was transported via ambulance to the trauma center with third-degree burns covering 18% of his right upper extremity and a concussion. He remained hospitalized for 14 days and required surgical intervention. This incident resulted in 42 days of lost work time as Claude recovered.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050), a Production Operator assigned to Injection Molding Line B, experienced a minor laceration to her right index finger while performing routine mold cleaning operations. The incident occurred when Fatou was manually removing cooled plastic flash from a mold cavity using a small handheld scraper tool. While applying pressure to dislodge a stubborn piece of plastic, her hand slipped, and the sharp edge of the scraper contacted the inner surface of her finger, creating a shallow but bleeding wound approximately 1.5 cm in length. The injury was immediately witnessed by her supervisor, Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), who was conducting mid-shift quality checks. First aid was administered on-site by the Occupational Health Nurse, Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), who applied pressure dressing and antibiotic ointment. The wound did not require stitches but was monitored for infection risk. The incident was attributed to inadequate tool design, lack of proper hand protection during flash removal, and insufficient training on safe manual part finishing techniques. No work stoppage occurred beyond the 10 minutes required for first aid treatment.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), a Warehouse Associate in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Unit-008), reported discomfort and mild muscle soreness in his lower back after performing repetitive bin stacking operations for approximately 7 hours. Yvon had been manually loading plastic injection-molded automotive components into storage bins, repeatedly bending at the waist and lifting containers weighing 8-12 kg each from conveyor height to shoulder height without adequate mechanical assistance or rotation to lighter tasks. The warehouse area maintains ambient temperature around 12-15°C due to climate control requirements for material stability, contributing to muscle stiffness. Yvon reported the discomfort to his supervisor, David O'Connor (EMP-00010), who advised stretching and rest. The Ergonomics Specialist, Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), performed an assessment and documented the case. While the discomfort resolved within 24 hours with over-the-counter analgesics, it triggered a preventive review of warehouse ergonomic practices. Root causes identified include absence of lift-assist equipment, insufficient task rotation, inadequate microbreak scheduling, and cold warehouse conditions. No lost work time occurred, but the incident represents a precursor to potential cumulative trauma disorder development.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill incident was discovered in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (Unit-011). Roland Dostie (EMP-00199), Maintenance Planner, conducting routine night shift facility walkthrough, found approximately 85 liters of mixed solvent waste (primarily acetone and isopropanol) leaking from a deteriorated storage drum positioned in the exterior hazardous waste zone. The drum, marked as containing composite material processing solvents, had developed a hairline fracture along its bottom seam, likely from corrosion and age (estimated 8+ years in service). The solvent had pooled on the concrete floor and begun flowing toward the facility's stormwater drain system via surface gradient. Immediate actions included: securing the area with warning tape, shutting the manual drain valve, and notifying the Environmental Safety Officer. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) was called and arrived within 15 minutes to coordinate response. The spill was contained using absorbent pads and secondary collection, with approximately 60 liters recovered. The remaining 25 liters reached the stormwater system before containment was complete, potentially impacting local groundwater infiltration. The incident was classified as an environmental non-compliance event requiring regulatory notification to CNESST and Quebec's environmental authority. Root cause: inadequate drum inspection protocol, lack of preventive drum replacement schedule, and insufficient secondary containment capacity.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) was working at Injection Molding Line D when she noticed unusual grinding sounds coming from the machine's hydraulic system. She immediately stopped the production run and notified her supervisor, Pierre Bouchard (EMP-00023). Upon inspection, they discovered that the cooling water circulation hose was beginning to separate from its coupling due to a loose retaining clamp, which could have led to a pressurized water spray. Khalil's quick recognition of the anomalous noise and immediate shutdown prevented potential thermal burns or electrical hazards. The hose was properly resecured and the machine was tested before resuming operations. No injury occurred, but the situation represented a significant near-miss given the proximity of workers and high-temperature equipment.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 11:15 AM during day shift, Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) was preparing test samples in the Composite Materials Processing Area when she inadvertently made contact with a freshly mixed batch of epoxy resin. The mold release agent on her gloved hands and exposed forearms caused immediate skin irritation and a localized allergic reaction manifested as erythema (redness) and mild hives. She rinsed the affected areas thoroughly with water and reported to first aid. The facility nurse applied topical hydrocortisone cream and monitored the reaction, which resolved within 4 hours. Zhang was able to continue her shift after the incident but with additional protective equipment (nitrile gloves doubled and long sleeves). The incident was treated as first aid requiring only topical treatment and observation.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during night shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine maintenance on the Material Drying and Preparation Room equipment when he attempted to remove a jammed conveyor belt tensioner using an overhead crane. The cable securing the tensioner assembly slipped due to inadequate rigging, and the 85-pound component fell, striking Gravel on the left knee and lower leg. He fell to the ground, unable to bear weight on the affected limb. Co-worker Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075) immediately called emergency services. Gravel was transported to the hospital via ambulance where X-rays revealed a fractured tibia and fibula. He required surgical repair with internal fixation and was admitted for post-operative monitoring. Lost time began immediately, and Gravel was placed on medical leave for an estimated 12-16 weeks recovery with mandatory work restrictions.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line A when she noticed excessive vibration in the hydraulic pump assembly. While investigating the source of the vibration with a handheld inspection mirror, a section of the pump's outer casing suddenly fractured and ejected a small metal fragment that passed within inches of her face, narrowly missing her eye. The fragment struck the production floor behind her. Ms. Wong immediately stepped back and reported the incident to her supervisor, François-Xavier Mailhot. A complete inspection revealed internal pressure buildup due to a blocked relief valve—a maintenance oversight from the previous night shift. The equipment was immediately shut down and isolated using lockout/tagout procedures. No injuries were sustained, but the near-miss represented a critical failure in preventive maintenance protocols. The incident was witnessed by Assembly Operator Layla Hussein, who was working adjacent to the line.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) sustained a minor thermal burn while transferring post-processed composite material from the industrial oven to a cooling station in the Materials Management area. As he opened the oven door using tongs, a residual steam pocket was released, and his left forearm made brief contact with the oven's exterior frame, which retained surface temperature of approximately 65°C (150°F). He immediately reported the injury to Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot and proceeded to the on-site first aid station where Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) provided treatment: cooling the area with sterile water for 15 minutes, applying antibiotic ointment, and covering with a sterile non-adherent dressing. The burn was classified as first-degree with slight erythema covering approximately 8 square centimeters. Mr. Ramirez completed incident documentation and returned to modified duties (administrative work) for the remainder of the shift as a precautionary measure. He was advised to monitor for infection and report any worsening symptoms within 24 hours.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) sustained a crush injury to his right hand while performing maintenance on an overhead crane system in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Mr. Gravel was manually adjusting a cable tension on the hoist mechanism when a sudden load shift occurred—approximately 800 pounds of improperly secured finished goods on a pallet suspended 12 feet above the floor. The pallet tilted, causing one of the support cables to slacken suddenly, which in turn caused the mechanical brake assembly to engage with extreme force. Mr. Gravel's right hand was caught between the brake housing and a structural beam, resulting in crushing injury to his index, middle, and ring fingers with fractures to the metacarpals and potential nerve damage. He immediately called for assistance; fellow night shift worker Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) responded and carefully released the tension on the hoist to free his hand. Emergency medical services were called at 6:25 AM, and Mr. Gravel was transported to Laval Regional Hospital with the hand immobilized. Diagnostic imaging revealed compound fractures requiring surgical intervention. Mr. Gravel was hospitalized for three days and remains on medical leave with expected recovery timeline of 8-12 weeks. Root cause investigation identified that the pallet securing straps had been improperly applied during the day shift, and the overhead crane brake system lacked secondary load-holding safety features.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, an employee in the Chemical Mixing and Compounding area (UNIT-005, Assembly and Finishing Department) was preparing a batch of epoxy resin compound for the medical device production line. While transferring a 20-liter container of hardener chemical to the mixing tank, the employee lost grip due to wet hands from a leaking container cap. The 20-liter container fell approximately 1.5 meters, striking the concrete floor and rupturing. Approximately 18 liters of hazardous epoxy hardener (containing aliphatic polyamines) spilled across approximately 12 square meters of the production floor. The chemical immediately began spreading toward a floor drain, creating a vapor hazard. Two nearby workers detected strong chemical odors and alerted the Safety Officer. Emergency response protocols were activated: the area was evacuated, ventilation systems were maximized, and the spill was contained using absorbent materials and temporary barriers. The Chemical Inventory Specialist arrived within 5 minutes and documented the spill. No personnel were directly exposed to liquid contact, but three workers reported mild respiratory irritation from vapor exposure. The cleanup took approximately 3 hours. Root cause analysis indicated inadequate container handling procedures and poor grip conditions.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, the ventilation system in the Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components clean room area) experienced a gradual loss of air pressure. The Maintenance Technician on the evening shift (EMP-00131) noticed differential pressure gauges showing declining values but did not report the condition until 11:20 PM when backup alarm sensors triggered. The clean room is designed for medical device production requiring strict environmental controls (ISO Class 7 cleanroom). The failure resulted in approximately 65 minutes of inadequate air filtration and pressure maintenance. During this period, ambient air containing particles and potential contaminants entered the controlled environment. Three workers were performing final assembly and quality checks on sterile medical component batches when the failure occurred. Upon detection, production was immediately halted and all in-process materials were quarantined pending contamination assessment. Facility maintenance activated redundant HVAC systems and conducted a full system inspection, revealing a failed damper motor in the main intake manifold. The night shift crew documented the incident time and environmental conditions. Laboratory analysis of samples from affected batches required 48 hours, ultimately determining that one batch of 2,400 units required rework due to particle contamination.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). Material Handler EMP-00082 was operating an electric forklift to arrange pallets of finished composite products on high-density storage racks (approximately 5.5 meters tall). The second rack level was being loaded when a combination of factors caused failure: the forklift's load capacity had been exceeded by approximately 15% (loaded pallet weighed 1,280 kg versus rated capacity of 1,000 kg), and the load was not evenly distributed on the forks. As the forklift elevated, the left fork gradually bent under stress, causing the pallet to tilt. The supporting rack leg (welded steel assembly) fractured at a weld joint, and the entire 1.4-meter-wide section of shelving collapsed. The collapsing structure struck the forklift cab, causing severe damage to the vehicle and bending the vertical mast. Approximately 18 pallets (roughly 22,000 kg of finished medical and automotive composite components) fell 3-4 meters to the floor, scattering product across an area of approximately 80 square meters. The Material Handler was uninjured but shaken. Cleanup and assessment required 8 hours. Facility inspection revealed the rack welds had not been inspected in over three years, despite manufacturer recommendations for annual inspections. Approximately 68% of the fallen product was damaged beyond recovery, representing significant financial loss.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Benoit Arsenault was working at Line A in the Main Production Building (North Zone) when he reached into the mold cavity to remove a partially ejected part from the 150-ton injection molding machine. Due to a malfunction in the proximity sensor, the machine's safety interlock failed to prevent mold closure. As Arsenault's hand was still inside the cavity, the mold clamps activated unexpectedly, trapping his right hand between the upper and lower mold halves. The operator screamed for assistance, and coworkers immediately hit the emergency stop button. He was freed after approximately 90 seconds with severe crushing injuries to his right hand, including fractures to multiple metacarpals and phalanges, and deep lacerations requiring emergency surgical intervention at Laval Hospital. The incident resulted in a hospitalization and loss of work time exceeding 30 days. A contributing factor was inadequate preventive maintenance on the safety interlock system—the last calibration was 18 months prior, exceeding the recommended 12-month interval.

On April 22, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Salma Haddad was transferring a 1,200-pound spool of glass-reinforced nylon material through the warehouse using a propane forklift. While maneuvering between storage racks in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A), the forklift's rear bumper contact with a heavily loaded metal storage rack, causing approximately 8 large drums of hydraulic oil (approximately 2,800 pounds total) to fall from the third shelf onto the concrete floor. The drums ruptured, spilling their contents across approximately 500 square feet of the warehouse floor and creating a significant slip hazard. The hydraulic oil also contaminated adjacent finished goods inventory valued at approximately $87,000. Although no direct employee injury occurred, the incident caused the floor to become extremely slippery, creating a dangerous work environment. Haddad was able to stop the forklift and safely dismount, but the spill required immediate closure of the warehouse section and emergency cleanup by the maintenance team. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate rack spacing for forklift operations and insufficient load capacity verification before stacking.

On May 8, 2024, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, Tool Maker René Caron was performing routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the Material Drying and Preparation Room when he sustained a laceration to his left palm. While cleaning dried plastic residue from the machine's rotary spindle chuck, Caron's hand slipped on the lubricant-covered surface and contacted the spinning chuck, which was rotating at 1,200 RPM for spindle cleaning operations. The sharp edges of the chuck jaws created a 2-inch laceration on his palm requiring 8 stitches. Caron applied first aid and reported the incident to the night shift supervisor. Medical evaluation confirmed no arterial damage or deeper tissue involvement, but the injury required immediate medical attention. Root cause analysis revealed that the CNC machine had not been placed in lockout/tagout status despite being in active maintenance mode, and the operator had not worn required cut-resistant gloves during the maintenance procedure. Additionally, the emergency stop button on the machine was partially obstructed by maintenance tools and cleaning materials.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, a fire started in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (South Zone) when an industrial oven malfunctioned during a routine curing cycle for composite parts. An operator, Rémi Charbonneau, noticed smoke emanating from the oven's heating element chamber and immediately activated the emergency stop. However, residual heat ignited accumulated plastic dust and resin vapors near the oven's exhaust vent. The fire spread rapidly to nearby stacked composite material inventory on wooden pallets. Quick response from the facility's fire suppression system and manual extinguishers by production staff Jade Wong and Fatou Ndiaye prevented the fire from spreading beyond the immediate 8x10 foot area. Approximately 2 hours of production downtime occurred. The oven's heating coil had not been cleaned in 6 months, violating maintenance protocols. Root cause: inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling and accumulation of flammable materials in close proximity to heat sources.

On November 18, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, a critical hydraulic system failure occurred on Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-001). The main hydraulic pump began leaking pressurized fluid after a seal failed, causing a rapid pressure drop that prevented the 250-ton injection molding machine from opening properly. Operator Rémi Charbonneau and nearby production worker Luc Girard (Maintenance Technician) were unable to manually open the mold, trapping a partially-formed automotive component inside. The leak sprayed approximately 15 liters of hydraulic fluid across the machine platform and floor over 30 minutes before being contained. Investigation revealed the seal had not been replaced during the last scheduled maintenance (due 2 weeks prior). Preliminary assessment shows the pump motor suffered burnout damage worth approximately $47,000. Equipment downtime: 18 hours for repairs and fluid cleanup. Root cause: missed preventive maintenance interval, worn seal material, and lack of real-time pressure monitoring on critical systems.

On November 21, 2024 at 09:30 during day shift operations, a laceration injury occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Tool Maker René Caron was operating a CNC milling machine to finish-cut a complex mold cavity when the cutting tool seized unexpectedly due to coolant line blockage. The sudden stop caused the workpiece to shift, and René's left hand came into contact with the rotating cutting tool, resulting in a laceration across the dorsal surface of his hand between thumb and index finger. The cut was approximately 3 inches long and 0.25 inches deep, requiring emergency department evaluation and 12 stitches. René was transported by co-worker Wei Liu to the local hospital. The machine's emergency stop was activated by Mold Technician Stéphane Moreau within 2 seconds. Root cause: inadequate coolant maintenance schedule, lack of machine guarding updates, and insufficient operator training on emergency procedures for tool seizure situations.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). An operator, Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), was transferring a 55-liter drum of epoxy resin from storage to the mixing station using a manual pump cart. The cart's wheels caught on a floor irregularity near the entrance, causing the operator to lose control. The drum tipped over, spilling approximately 40 liters of epoxy resin across the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard that extended 8 meters in length. The spill immediately triggered the facility's chemical response protocol. Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead, arrived within minutes and began containment using absorbent mats and sand. The area was cordoned off with caution tape, and evacuation of the immediate workspace was initiated. The spill was fully contained within 45 minutes. Environmental sampling confirmed no seepage into the storm drain system. Root cause analysis identified inadequate floor maintenance and lack of proper spill prevention equipment at transfer points.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred at Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-004). Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), a machine setter, was conducting routine maintenance on the injection press when he discovered a hydraulic line partially disconnected at the coupling. The machine was scheduled for a cleaning cycle after a production run. While Gosselin was inspecting the connection, a colleague, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), approached from the other side of the machine without noticing the maintenance activity. Gosselin called out a warning and held up his hand signal just as Gonzalez reached the emergency stop button area. Had the machine started its auto-cycle as scheduled 30 seconds later, Gonzalez would have been struck by the platen arm. The near-miss was immediately reported to Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist. Investigation revealed that the hydraulic coupling had been improperly torqued during the previous maintenance shift (night shift) and was slowly leaking. The communication breakdown between shifts regarding equipment status was identified as a contributing factor.

On March 21, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the early morning hours of the night shift transition, a first-aid incident occurred in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019). Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073), a shipping coordinator, was applying product labels to finished composite material housings when his right hand made contact with a freshly applied adhesive that had not fully cured. The adhesive contained a volatile organic compound (VOC) solvent base that caused acute irritation to the skin. Vaillancourt immediately experienced burning sensation, localized erythema (redness), and minor blistering on his right palm and fingers. He reported the incident to Lea Parent (EMP-00121), the Quality Control Technician working nearby. Parent immediately directed Vaillancourt to the first-aid station where he flushed his hand with cool water for 15 minutes, applied sterile gauze, and took two acetaminophen tablets for pain management. The incident was treated as first-aid level without requiring external medical attention or time away from work. Investigation revealed the adhesive labeling equipment had a worn safety guard that previously prevented direct hand contact during application.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a hydraulic leak was discovered in the mold release system serving Injection Molding Line B (Automotive). Rania Abdallah, Composite Materials Operator, noticed an accumulation of hydraulic oil on the floor near the equipment base while performing routine equipment checks. Upon closer inspection, she identified a fractured hydraulic line connection on the main pump assembly. The leak had been occurring for approximately 4 hours, creating a 15-liter spill across the production floor. The oily residue posed both slip hazards and environmental contamination risks. The area was immediately cordoned off with caution tape, and the hydraulic system was shut down. Absorbent materials were deployed to contain the spill, and the maintenance team was notified. Environmental compliance procedures were initiated to document and properly dispose of the contaminated materials according to CNESST and Quebec environmental regulations. The incident was contained within 30 minutes, but the floor required extensive cleaning and decontamination before operations could resume.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, François Gagnon, Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a thermal burn injury to his right forearm. While performing mold changeover procedures, Gagnon inadvertently made direct contact with a mold surface that had not reached safe cooling temperatures. The mold had been running continuously since the morning shift and was approximately 180°C. Gagnon was transitioning between injection cycles and believed the previous cycle had completed cooling protocols. He did not use the standard thermal protection sleeve provided, stating it was uncomfortable during extended operations. The contact lasted approximately 2-3 seconds before Gagnon withdrew his arm. The burn resulted in a painful erythematous patch approximately 8cm x 6cm on the ventral forearm. Immediate first aid was administered by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid, who was on-site. Ice water immersion was applied for 15 minutes, and the wound was covered with sterile gauze. Gagnon was transported to the local hospital for assessment; burn depth was classified as partial thickness (2nd degree). He required sutures and was placed on medical leave for 5 days.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift operations, a forklift collision occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). Luc-André Beaudoin, Warehouse Supervisor Evening Shift, was operating an electric forklift to retrieve palletized finished medical device components for loading onto a delivery truck. While maneuvering through the narrow warehouse aisles between high-density storage racks (approximately 5.5 meters high), Beaudoin misjudged the clearance and struck an overhead storage rack support column with the left fork. The impact force knocked approximately 12 pallets of packaged product from the upper shelf levels onto the warehouse floor. Products were distributed across a 20-meter area. Estimated inventory loss was 2,847 units of medical device housings, valued at approximately $142,350. Additionally, one pallet of raw polycarbonate resin (approximately 500kg) fell and split open, creating a material spillage hazard. No personnel were in the immediate vicinity of the falling materials, so no injuries occurred. The area was cleared and a warehouse inventory accounting was initiated. All damaged goods were assessed for scrap versus rework possibilities.

On April 8, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a Machine Operator, was performing routine maintenance on the chemical mixing equipment in the Hazardous Waste Management Area when a spontaneous dust accumulation fire began in the material handling ducting system. The operation involved transferring plastic resin powder from storage containers to mixing hoppers. Over several weeks, fine composite fiber dust had accumulated on internal surfaces of the ductwork despite scheduled cleaning. A static electrical discharge during a transfer operation ignited the dust cloud, creating a rapid fire that spread through the ducting toward the main storage area. The facility's fire suppression system was activated automatically, and emergency responders were called immediately. The fire was contained to the ducting system with no structural damage to the building or secondary areas. Traore evacuated safely and no injuries occurred. The incident revealed inadequate dust control procedures and insufficient frequency of preventive ductwork cleaning.

On February 22, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134), an Assembly Operator, was working at the Shipping and Receiving Dock when she slipped on a wet floor surface caused by a minor coolant system leak from an electric forklift that had been parked nearby. El Amrani fell backward onto the concrete dock surface, sustaining a deep laceration to her left elbow and minor bruising to her hip and shoulder. She immediately notified her supervisor, Éric Champagne (EMP-00049), who provided first aid by cleaning the wound, applying antibiotic ointment, and bandaging the laceration with sterile gauze. The wound was approximately 2 inches long and required careful cleaning to remove embedded concrete dust. El Amrani remained on-site and returned to light duty work after treatment. The forklift was removed from service for maintenance. The incident resulted from inadequate spill response procedures and insufficient floor surface matting in high-traffic dock areas.

On March 14, 2024, at 14:45 during the day shift, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was operating Injection Molding Machine #7 on Line A when she noticed unusual vibrations and a grinding noise coming from the machine's hydraulic system. The machine had been in continuous operation for 18 hours without scheduled maintenance. Within minutes, a hydraulic seal failed catastrophically, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid across the machine's control panel and work area. The fluid ignited when it contacted the heated mold cavity, creating a small fire that spread to nearby material storage bins containing polypropylene resin. The machine automatically shut down via thermal sensor, preventing further damage. Ndiaye immediately activated the nearest fire extinguisher and alerted her supervisor Julie Bergeron. The evening shift supervisor arrived within 2 minutes with additional fire suppression equipment. The fire was contained to a 3-square-meter area. Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel was called to assess the damage. No personnel were physically injured, but the hydraulic system required complete replacement, and the control panel suffered $45,000 in damage. The root cause was deferred preventive maintenance and absence of secondary containment for high-pressure hydraulic lines. The incident was declared by EHS Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu.

On February 28, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) was performing routine cleaning of Composite Materials Processing equipment in the West Wing when he discovered a partially detached 40-pound fiberglass-reinforced plastic (FRPS) storage container suspended from overhead storage racks approximately 8 feet above the work floor. The container's mounting bracket showed visible corrosion and one of the two fastening bolts had corroded away completely, leaving the container precariously balanced on a single bolt. Kouassi immediately stopped work and notified his supervisor, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), who was working at an adjacent station. Traore evacuated the immediate area and called the Maintenance Workshop. Crane Operator Gaston Picard (EMP-00193) arrived within 10 minutes and carefully lowered the container to the ground using an overhead crane. The container held approximately 150 pounds of moisture-contaminated composite material that would have caused significant injury if it had fallen onto personnel below. Post-incident inspection revealed that at least 6 other containers on adjacent racks showed similar corrosion patterns, indicating systematic failure of fastening hardware due to moisture exposure and inadequate protective coating. No injuries occurred. The incident was declared by Training Coordinator Amélie Roy.

On March 22, 2024, at 08:30 during the day shift, Assembly Operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) sustained a laceration and partial crush injury to his right hand while assembling medical device component housings at the Packaging and Labeling Station. Fernandez was using a pneumatic press to secure threaded inserts into polycarbonate enclosures when a material handling error occurred. Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) had just delivered a pallet of preformed components that did not meet specification—the inner cavity dimensions were 2mm smaller than required due to a tooling drift in the injection molding process. Fernandez began processing these components without verifying the specification variance. When he loaded the first substandard component into the press and activated the foot pedal, the press chamber became misaligned, causing the insert punch to strike the edge of the housing at an angle. The plastic fractured and bound the operator's right ring finger and pinky finger between the punch and the housing edge as the press cycled through its stroke. The press cycled for 1.2 seconds before the safety sensor detected the obstruction and triggered emergency stop. Fernandez immediately experienced severe pain and pulled his hand free. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron applied direct pressure with clean gauze and called for emergency response. Paramedics arrived at 08:47. Fernandez was transported to Laval Hospital where X-rays confirmed a comminuted fracture of the 4th metacarpal bone, deep laceration requiring 12 stitches, and crush syndrome affecting the 5th digit. He was hospitalized overnight and released the following day with anticipated 6-week recovery period and work restrictions. Root causes included: (1) insufficient component inspection protocol before processing, (2) absence of press safety interlocks to prevent operation with non-compliant parts, and (3) inadequate handoff communication between materials management and production. The incident was declared by Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:15 AM, Quality Control Technician Léa Parent (EMP-00121) was conducting routine material handling in the Quality Control Laboratory when she observed that a material hopper on the automated filling system was beginning to overflow. She immediately stopped the feeding mechanism and notified Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) who was monitoring the line remotely. Upon investigation, they discovered that the hopper level sensor had become partially obstructed by accumulated plastic resin dust, preventing accurate level detection. The system had continued dispensing material beyond capacity, with approximately 15 kg of raw composite material having spilled onto the floor around the equipment base. Parent carefully cleaned the sensor and verified proper operation before resuming production. No one was injured, but the situation could have resulted in material coming into contact with electrical components or creating a slip hazard. This near-miss was caused by insufficient maintenance interval documentation for sensor cleaning in composite processing areas where fine particulate accumulation is common.

On March 20, 2024, at 8:20 PM during the evening shift, an automatic fire detection system activated in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing). Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) received the alarm notification and immediately initiated the facility evacuation protocol while also investigating the source. Upon arrival at the scene, she discovered that a waste bin containing cured composite trim scraps had been positioned too close to a recirculating air vent. The vent's warm airflow had gradually dried out the bin contents and raised the temperature of the accumulated material. A small smoldering fire had begun in the bottom of the bin, detected by the infrared thermal sensor mounted on the ceiling. Dubois immediately activated the dry chemical fire suppression system localized to that area, extinguishing the fire before it could spread. The fire department was called as a precaution and found the situation under control upon arrival. No employees were in immediate danger due to early detection, but this represented a significant potential for spreading to adjacent stored materials and equipment. The root cause was inadequate spacing guidelines between waste storage areas and HVAC infrastructure.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations in the Main Production Building, Injection Molding Operator James Thompson (EMP-00029) was performing routine part removal from Line D when he noticed the machine's safety interlock had been manually bypassed with a wooden wedge. Before removing the wedge to reset the system properly, Thompson immediately notified his supervisor and halted operations. Upon inspection, the machine's heating system had malfunctioned and was cycling erratically, creating a pinch point hazard that would have caused serious hand entrapment if the machine had cycled while anyone was near the mold cavity. The machine was immediately locked out and tagged. Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) witnessed the discovery and documented the condition. This near-miss was reported to the JHSC within 24 hours and identified a systemic issue where operators had been disabling interlocks to work around slow cycle times rather than reporting equipment problems through proper maintenance channels.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:30 AM, Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) discovered a spill in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building during routine inventory inspection. Approximately 45 liters of polyester resin containing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) had leaked from a deteriorated storage container onto the concrete floor and was beginning to seep toward the facility's stormwater collection area. The container, originally scheduled for replacement in Q2 2024, had developed a hairline fracture that went undetected during the previous week's weekly inspection due to inadequate lighting in that storage section. Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) had moved the container the previous day during reorganization but did not report the damage he observed. The spill was immediately contained using absorbent materials and the affected area was isolated. Dubois coordinated emergency cleanup and notified the CNESST duty officer as required. Approximately 12 liters may have entered the stormwater system before containment, requiring environmental notification to Quebec's Ministry of Environment.

On May 2, 2024, at 11:15 PM during night shift operations in the Warehouse and Shipping building, Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) sustained a significant back injury while unloading a pallet of raw plastic resin pellets from a delivery truck. Habib was lifting 50-kilogram bags from the truck bed to floor level using incorrect lifting technique (bending at the waist with straight legs rather than squatting) when he felt acute lower back pain. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) immediately assisted Habib to the first aid station. Medical evaluation at Laval Hospital confirmed acute lumbar strain with possible disc involvement. Habib was hospitalized for pain management and imaging studies, resulting in a lost-time injury (LTI) with an estimated recovery period of 6-8 weeks. Investigation revealed that the new delivery protocol implemented two weeks prior had removed the requirement for two-person lifts on bags over 40 kg as a cost-reduction measure, and Habib had received no ergonomics refresher training on the new procedure.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) was conducting a visual inspection of raw material storage racks in the Warehouse and Shipping facility when she noticed unusual condensation and mineral deposits accumulating around the base of the cooling water system serving the adjacent injection molding equipment. The deposits suggested a slow but persistent leak in the system piping that runs beneath the storage area. Dion immediately reported the observation to Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), noting that while no active pooling was visible, the moisture pattern indicated potential water system degradation. The observation was made before any worker injury or equipment failure occurred. Lafleur documented the finding and initiated a preventive maintenance work order. The cooling water system supplies critical temperature control to Injection Molding Line A and other production equipment. A full system rupture could result in equipment damage, worker exposure to hot water spray, and production downtime. This declaration demonstrates TechnoPlast's proactive hazard identification protocol where near-miss and precursor conditions are formally reported to prevent escalation into serious incidents.

On November 18, 2024, at 4:45 PM during evening shift operations, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) sustained a laceration injury to her left hand while working at the Assembly and Finishing Department. Vasquez was manually removing finished composite parts from a stainless steel assembly fixture when her left index and middle fingers came into contact with unexpectedly sharp burrs on the interior edge of a molded part. The sharp edges, typically removed during the finishing process, had not been adequately deburred due to a temporary malfunction of the automated deburring machine that had been repaired earlier in the shift. A fellow Assembly Operator, Diego Morales (EMP-00056), was working at an adjacent station and heard Vasquez cry out. Morales immediately notified Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) who was conducting line inspections. Vasquez received first aid on-site for the laceration and was transported to a local urgent care facility where three stitches were required to close the wound on her left index finger. The incident was caused by the combination of the equipment malfunction and inadequate verification procedures before resuming production after maintenance. Root cause analysis identified that the post-maintenance test run was abbreviated due to production pressure, and the deburring effectiveness was not fully verified before production resumption.

On November 21, 2024, at 11:45 PM during night shift operations, Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) was conducting routine maintenance in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when he descended an 8-foot aluminum step ladder to inspect the drainage system beneath chemical storage tanks. While descending from the third step from the bottom, Marchand's right foot slipped on a wet rung that was contaminated with a thin film of polyester resin residue from earlier mixing operations. Marchand fell approximately 5 feet, landing on his left side and striking the concrete floor. He sustained a fractured left radius (forearm bone) and experienced acute pain in his left shoulder. Composite Materials Technician Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042) was working in an adjacent area of the chemical storage facility and heard the impact. She immediately activated the emergency response protocol, calling for medical assistance and notifying the night shift supervisor. Marchand was transported by ambulance to a regional hospital where X-rays confirmed the fracture. Surgical consultation was required, and he was admitted for overnight observation. The root cause investigation determined that the ladder maintenance log showed no documentation of cleaning or slip-resistance verification for the past three months. The wet chemical residue on the rungs created an unexpected slip hazard that was not addressed in pre-shift inspections.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, operator Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074) was working at Injection Molding Line C when she noticed unusual vibration and a burning smell emanating from the mold heating unit. Before proceeding with her regular production cycle, she immediately notified her supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) and maintenance planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062). The resin dryer temperature reading showed 285°C, significantly above the normal operating range of 220-240°C. Upon inspection, Thanh discovered a faulty thermostat sensor that had failed to regulate temperature properly. The situation was identified as a near-miss because Sofia recognized the warning signs and halted operations before material degradation could occur or equipment damage could result. The faulty sensor was immediately isolated, and the line was safely shut down. No injuries occurred, and no product was lost. This incident demonstrated the effectiveness of operator awareness but highlighted the need for improved preventive maintenance protocols.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the afternoon shift, an environmental incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Unit 018). While Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was transferring recycled plastic pellets into a storage hopper, approximately 50 liters of uncovered acetone solvent container tipped over and spilled onto the production floor. The acetone rapidly evaporated and the fumes dispersed throughout the warehouse and adjacent shipping area. The spill was discovered by Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010), who immediately activated the emergency response protocol. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) was notified and coordinated containment efforts. The root cause was identified as inadequate secondary containment for chemical storage and insufficient labeling of the acetone container. Air quality monitoring detected elevated VOC (volatile organic compound) levels at 120 ppm in the immediate area and 45 ppm in the shipping dock. The incident triggered mandatory ventilation system activation and required evacuation of personnel within a 30-meter radius for 45 minutes until air quality returned to safe levels below 10 ppm. No environmental release occurred beyond the facility boundaries, but the incident demonstrated significant gaps in chemical management protocols.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 11:50 PM during the night shift, a lost-time injury occurred at the Shipping and Receiving Dock. Material handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was manually loading plastic component pallets onto a loading truck when he attempted to lift a pallet that weighed approximately 45 kg without using the available pallet jack. As he bent forward with improper body mechanics, straining through his lower back, Hassan felt a sharp pain and immediately stopped work. He attempted to continue but experienced radiating pain down his left leg. Witness Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), the crane operator present at the dock, immediately notified night shift supervisor and occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) was called in. Hassan was evaluated and diagnosed with a lumbar strain with possible disc involvement affecting the L4-L5 region. He was transported to the facility's occupational health clinic and subsequently referred to emergency care. Diagnostic imaging revealed a significant lumbar strain requiring 6 weeks medical leave. Root causes included inadequate training on proper lifting mechanics, fatigue during late-night shift operations, and Hassan's failure to utilize available mechanical assistance despite receiving prior training. The incident resulted in 240 hours of lost time over the recovery period.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a Production Operator at Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone, noticed unusual vibration and temperature readings on injection molding machine #8 (a 250-ton unit). The machine's resin dryer, which had been operating continuously for 18 hours without scheduled maintenance, showed a temperature spike of 35°C above normal operating parameters. Leila immediately reported the anomaly to her supervisor and the EHS Coordinator. Upon inspection, the resin dryer's thermostat was found to be malfunctioning, and internal temperature had reached 285°C—dangerously close to the resin's thermal degradation point of 300°C. If the dryer had continued operating for another 2-3 hours without intervention, it could have caused resin ignition, creating a significant fire hazard in the facility. The machine was immediately shut down, and the defective thermostat was removed for replacement. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed a critical gap in preventive maintenance scheduling. The facility's production schedule was delayed by 8 hours as a result of the shutdown and corrective actions.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:20 AM during the day shift, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a laceration to his left hand while performing routine cleaning of finished plastic components at the quality inspection station in the Main Production Building North Zone. The components—medical-grade polycarbonate connector housings—had sharp flash edges from the injection molding process that had not been adequately deburred. While reaching into a basket of freshly molded parts to extract samples for dimensional verification, Conrad's left index and middle fingers made contact with exposed razor-sharp edges. The laceration to his index finger was approximately 2 cm long, penetrating into subcutaneous tissue and requiring 12 stitches at the on-site occupational health clinic. His middle finger sustained a superficial 1 cm laceration. Conrad was treated by the Occupational Health Nurse (Hana Al-Rashid) and remained on modified duty for 3 days due to pain and restricted finger mobility. Root cause investigation revealed that the deburring process for this particular mold cavity had been bypassed due to production scheduling pressure, and operators were not wearing cut-resistant gloves during the manual part handling phase. The incident was witnessed by fellow operator Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), who assisted Conrad immediately after the injury occurred.

On April 18, 2024, at 9:35 PM during the evening shift, Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), an Inventory Control Specialist, suffered a back injury while manually loading composite material resin drums into a storage rack system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Nicole was attempting to lift and position a 45-kilogram (99-pound) drum of epoxy resin onto the third shelf of a four-tier rack, approximately 1.5 meters above ground level, when she felt a sharp pain in her lower lumbar region. The drum slipped slightly during the lift, causing her to hyperextend her back while attempting to catch and stabilize it. Although she successfully prevented the drum from falling, she immediately experienced acute pain radiating down her right leg. Nicole was assisted to a nearby chair by her colleague, Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), who called for the Occupational Health Nurse. Medical evaluation confirmed a strained L4-L5 disc with mild herniation. Nicole was hospitalized for 48 hours for observation and MRI imaging, prescribed pain management and muscle relaxants, and placed on restricted duty limiting lifting to 10 kg maximum for 4 weeks. The incident was documented by Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), the EHS Coordinator, who arrived on-site at 10:15 PM to conduct the investigation. Root cause analysis identified multiple contributing factors: inadequate ergonomic training, lack of mechanical lifting assistance equipment in the chemical storage area, improper lifting technique, and absence of a two-person manual lifting requirement for loads over 25 kg as specified in TechnoPlast's ergonomics guidelines (which had not been effectively communicated to all staff).

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift, Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050), a Production Operator on Injection Molding Line A, noticed an unusual vibration and grinding noise coming from the hopper heating system. Rather than immediately shutting down the machine and notifying maintenance, she continued monitoring the line. Within 30 minutes, the material drying system began emitting visible white fumes and the temperature control display showed readings exceeding safe operating parameters (240°C instead of the standard 190°C setting). The resin material in the hopper began to decompose, releasing acrid fumes throughout the production area. Three additional operators in the North Zone reported eye irritation and respiratory discomfort. Fatou immediately activated the emergency stop and evacuated the area. The facility's automated ventilation system engaged, but localized chemical exposure had already occurred. No serious injuries resulted, but the incident highlighted the critical need for proactive equipment monitoring and operator awareness protocols.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift, Luc Girard (EMP-00039), a Maintenance Technician, was performing routine ladder work in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop to inspect overhead conveyor systems for the CNC milling area. While ascending a 12-foot extension ladder positioned against a work shelf, Luc's foot slipped on the third rung. He attempted to catch himself but lost his grip on the side rail. Luc fell approximately 8 feet, landing on his left side on a concrete floor partially covered with metal shavings and machining coolant residue. He sustained a fractured left radius and ulna, significant bruising, and a laceration on his left forearm from sharp metal debris. A coworker immediately called for emergency response, and Luc was transported to Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal for surgery and hospitalization. Investigation revealed the ladder's base was not secured with a locking mechanism, and the floor area had not been swept or cleaned in over 8 hours. The landing zone contained typical machining debris that increased fall severity.

On May 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift transition, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, was moving a pallet of resin pellets from the Materials Management and Warehousing area toward the injection molding production line. As he approached an intersection near the Material Drying and Preparation Room, a palletized stack of cooled composite material components suddenly shifted and tipped, striking Tariq's right shoulder and upper arm with an estimated force of 45-50 pounds. The collision caused Tariq to fall to the ground and sustain a significant contusion to his right shoulder, upper arm strain, and a minor laceration from packaging straps. Tariq was conscious and alert but experiencing acute pain. A nearby forklift operator and warehouse staff immediately responded. Tariq received first aid treatment at the on-site medical station including wound cleaning, ice application, compression wrapping, and pain management. He was transported to a local clinic for radiographic evaluation, which ruled out fractures but confirmed severe soft tissue trauma. Root cause investigation revealed the pallet had not been properly secured with shrink wrap, the load had shifted during the prior night's material handling, and inspection procedures had not detected the instability.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013), Mario Bélisle (EMP-00149), a Tool and Die Maker, was performing routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine. While adjusting the tool holder with the machine powered on but spindle supposedly stopped, the spindle suddenly restarted due to an electrical fault in the control circuit. Mario's left hand was caught between the rotating tool and the fixed workpiece clamp. A coworker, Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189), heard the commotion and immediately shut down the machine using the emergency stop button. The incident was prevented from becoming severe because Mario instinctively withdrew his hand within 2 seconds; however, he sustained minor lacerations and significant bruising on his left palm and fingers. Nina Santos (EMP-00084), Industrial Hygienist, was notified and responded immediately. Mario was treated on-site with first aid and did not require hospitalization. The root cause investigation revealed that the machine's interlock system had not been properly tested during the previous month's preventive maintenance cycle, and the emergency stop responsiveness was slower than ANSI standards require.

On November 16, 2024, at approximately 6:45 PM during evening shift operations in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009), a fire alarm was triggered by an overheated hydraulic fluid hose connection that had begun smoking. Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator, was preparing to move a large pallet of finished composite components using a manual hydraulic pallet jack. The hydraulic hose on the jack exhibited visible external corrosion and had a slow leak that had been intermittently reported over the previous two weeks but never formally documented or repaired. The friction from the leaking hydraulic fluid dripping onto the heated metal frame of the nearby forklift charging station created an ignition source. Smoke from the smoldering hydraulic fluid triggered the facility's ceiling-mounted heat and smoke detector, activating the fire alarm system at 6:47 PM. Emergency procedures were executed: Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133), Facilities Manager, responded immediately and isolated the hydraulic equipment from the electrical circuit. The fire department arrived within 8 minutes but found the situation already controlled due to quick thinking. Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), Ergonomics Specialist, documented the incident. No injuries occurred and no actual fire developed, but the incident highlighted critical maintenance gaps in hydraulic equipment inspection protocols.

On November 19, 2024, during routine shift planning for the day shift (7:00 AM start), Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, conducted her weekly inspection of the Materials Management and Warehousing area and discovered that the solvent storage cabinet in the production materials section had not been checked for proper seal integrity in over 3 months. During her inspection of stored acetone, isopropanol, and mold release agent containers, Natasha noticed that three containers of acetone showed visible crystallization patterns on their exterior surfaces, indicating slow evaporation through improperly sealed caps. She also observed that the storage cabinet's ventilation port had accumulated dust and fibers, potentially restricting air circulation designed to prevent solvent vapor accumulation. While there was no immediate emergency or worker exposure event, Natasha recognized this as a preventive opportunity to address cumulative hazards before they could result in chemical exposure incidents, fire risk from solvent vapors, or inhalation hazards to production workers. She immediately documented her findings and initiated a preventive declaration to address deficiencies in chemical storage and inventory management procedures. Michael Chen (EMP-00004), Production Supervisor for Day Shift, was notified to halt any new solvent usage from the affected storage area until corrective actions were completed. Natasha's proactive identification prevented a potential chemical hazard from developing further.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine material hopper maintenance in the Production Engineering and Planning area when he noticed excessive plastic pellet accumulation around the hopper base. While attempting to clear the overflow manually using a compressed air line without proper PPE precautions, a high-pressure air stream forcefully ejected a cluster of composite fiber-reinforced plastic pellets directly into his face and eyes. The operator immediately stepped back and flushed his eyes with water from the emergency eyewash station. His supervisor, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), witnessed the incident and ensured proper first aid was administered. No injury resulted, but the near-miss highlighted the risk of improper compressed air use combined with inadequate protective measures. The incident was immediately reported to the HSE team and investigated within 24 hours. Charbonneau received medical clearance and vision was unaffected, confirming this as a near-miss event with significant potential for serious eye injury.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of polyurethane resin in the composite materials processing area when she discovered that the chemical waste collection container had not been emptied since the previous day. The container exceeded capacity, causing approximately 12 liters of mixed resin waste and solvent to overflow into an uncovered floor drain system in the warehouse area. The spill contained volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and residual epoxy components. Elena immediately notified her supervisor Omar Said (EMP-00122) and the HSE team. The facility's environmental spill response procedure was activated, and the area was cordoned off. Approximately 4 hours were required for cleanup and neutralization of the spill using approved absorbent materials and secondary containment. A subsequent investigation revealed that the waste container maintenance schedule had lapsed due to staffing changes, and there was no backup system to prevent overflow into the facility's drainage system. The spill was properly reported to CNESST within the required timeframe. No employees were directly contaminated, but the incident posed significant risk to groundwater and local water system contamination.

On December 2, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was conducting preventive maintenance on a high-temperature mold assembly when he inadvertently triggered an unexpected pressure release from the hydraulic system. The operator was reaching across the mold interface to access a temperature sensor when the relief valve activated, expelling a high-pressure stream of hot hydraulic fluid across his right forearm and hand. Hassan immediately withdrew his arm and experienced severe burning pain. His coworker James Thompson (EMP-00029) immediately applied cold water from the emergency shower station for approximately 15 minutes while another operator, Claude Poirier (EMP-00071), contacted medical services. Hassan was transported to Centre Hospitalier Laval Emergency Department at 6:45 AM where he was diagnosed with second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his right upper extremity, requiring hospitalization for 3 days and resulting in 14 days of lost work time. Investigation revealed that the hydraulic pressure gauge had been damaged during a previous shift and not reported, preventing operators from knowing that system pressure had increased to 2,400 psi (normal operating range: 1,800 psi). The accident occurred because the damaged gauge had not been replaced and no lockout/tagout procedure was in place for pressure relief maintenance.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a thermal burn injury while performing routine mold inspection. Demers was checking a mold cavity temperature on one of the 200-ton injection molding machines in the Production Operations area when he inadvertently contacted the exposed mold surface with his left forearm. The mold had been running continuously at 85°C and Demers was not wearing the required heat-resistant sleeves, relying instead on his standard cotton work shirt. The contact resulted in a second-degree thermal burn approximately 3 inches in diameter on his left forearm. Demers immediately reported the injury to Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), the Evening Shift Machine Operator present in the adjacent zone, who assisted him to the first aid station. The burn was treated with cool water and sterile dressing by the on-site first aid attendant. Demers did not require hospitalization but was deemed unable to work for the remainder of the shift due to pain and limited arm mobility. The incident was witnessed by Kouassi and documented by safety personnel within 30 minutes of occurrence.

On April 3, 2024 at 11:15 PM during night shift operations, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a Production Operator on night shift, sustained a severe laceration to his right hand while attempting to dislodge a jammed plastic component from a 150-ton injection molding machine in the main production area. Mensah noticed that the part ejection system was not functioning properly and, without proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures being followed, reached into the machine cavity to manually remove the stuck part. At that moment, a secondary operator inadvertently activated the machine cycle, causing the mold to close rapidly and trap Mensah's right hand between the mold halves. Mensah sustained deep lacerations to his palm and fingers, with partial laceration of the median nerve. Emergency response was initiated immediately; the machine was stopped and Mensah's hand was carefully extracted by Roland Dostie (EMP-00199), the Maintenance Planner on call. Mensah was transported by ambulance to the local trauma center where he underwent emergency surgical repair. He required a 4-day hospitalization and is expected to miss 8 weeks of work during recovery and rehabilitation. The incident was witnessed by Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician present in the adjacent area.

On May 22, 2024 at approximately 6:30 PM during evening shift transition, a minor electrical fire was detected in the chemical mixing room (Regrind and Recycling Department) when a fluorescent light fixture malfunctioned near the solvent storage cabinet. The cabinet contained approximately 50 liters of acetone and isopropanol used for cleaning molds and equipment. Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), the Regrind Technician assigned to the evening shift, discovered visible sparking and flames emanating from the light fixture ballast. Ramirez immediately activated the nearest fire alarm pull station and evacuated the area, alerting all nearby personnel. Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) heard the alarm and initiated facility evacuation procedures. The facility's automatic dry chemical suppression system activated within 45 seconds of alarm activation, extinguishing the fire before it could ignite the volatile solvent vapors. The local fire department responded within 12 minutes and confirmed the fire was fully suppressed. Air quality monitoring showed acetone vapor concentrations reached 850 ppm in the immediate area (OSHA PEL is 750 ppm), but evacuation occurred before dangerous exposure levels were sustained in populated zones. The electrical fixture was damaged and the cabinet's exterior showed minor scorch marks. Investigation revealed the light fixture had not been serviced in over 18 months and showed signs of age-related degradation. No injuries occurred and no chemical spill resulted from the incident.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was operating Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building when a malfunction in the mold cooling system caused excessive pressure buildup. While attempting to manually adjust a valve without following proper lockout/tagout procedures, the pressurized hydraulic line ruptured unexpectedly. The sudden release of pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed directly onto Rémi's left arm and torso, causing thermal and chemical burns across approximately 15% of his body surface. The employee immediately reported severe pain and was rushed to the on-site first aid station by coworker Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160), who witnessed the incident. Emergency response team leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) coordinated immediate medical transport to the nearest hospital. Rémi was hospitalized for 8 days with second-degree burns requiring wound care and pain management. Investigation revealed the machine had not been properly de-energized and the pressure relief valve was malfunctioning due to inadequate maintenance records.

On May 8, 2024 at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, automation technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) was conducting preventive maintenance in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop when she observed a small leak developing in the hydraulic line of a clamping device used for precision mold work. The leak involved a pressurized mineral oil-based hydraulic fluid containing additives that included potential skin irritants. While inspecting the connection point, Aya noted that the hose showed signs of age-related degradation with visible micro-cracks in the outer sheath. Although the leak was minor at the time of observation, Aya recognized the potential for sudden failure given the pressure cycling that occurs during normal mold operations. She immediately shut down the equipment, notified her supervisor Guillaume Deschamps (EMP-00051), and documented her findings in the maintenance system. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) was consulted to establish proper safety protocols. No employee was injured during this inspection, and the equipment remained offline pending repair evaluation. This incident exemplifies effective hazard recognition and early reporting by a trained technician.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a minor thermal burn while performing routine material feeding operations in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While retrieving pre-heated plastic pellets from a drying hopper set to 85°C, Yasmin inadvertently touched the exterior metal surface of the hopper with her bare forearm while adjusting the material feed chute. She immediately experienced a superficial burn approximately 3 cm x 4 cm on her inner forearm. The employee notified her supervisor immediately and was directed to the first aid station where she received cold water treatment for 10 minutes and a sterile dressing was applied. The burn did not require medical attention beyond first aid. Root cause analysis revealed that the hopper lacked proper thermal insulation and warning labels, and the employee had not been wearing her assigned forearm protective sleeve due to discomfort during the warm shift. No lost time occurred.

On April 2, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter normally assigned to night shift but working overtime coverage, suffered a significant laceration and partial amputation of his right index fingertip while performing maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #18 in the main production area. Louis was attempting to clear a material jam in the machine's hopper throat using a metal rod when the machine's automated feeder unexpectedly cycled on due to a faulty sensor override that had been reported but not repaired for six weeks. The feeder mechanism pinched his finger between the feed screw and the hopper wall, resulting in a partial amputation at the first knuckle and severe laceration. The machine was not locked out during maintenance, despite clear LOTO procedures in place. Emergency response was immediate; colleagues applied pressure with sterile gauze while calling 911. Louis was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur and underwent surgical reattachment attempts. He remained hospitalized for 3 days and has been on medical leave for ongoing recovery and physiotherapy. The incident triggered an immediate production halt and full facility safety audit.

On April 18, 2024, at 11:20 PM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) when a 55-gallon drum of PVC-specific processing additive (Tin-based heat stabilizer, CAS #7440-31-5) ruptured due to corrosion from an incompatible cleaning solvent that had been improperly stored adjacent to it. The drum was positioned on a pallet rack approximately 1.2 meters above the concrete floor. Approximately 38 liters of the additive dispersed across the warehouse floor, spreading across an estimated 12 square meters before pooling against the eastern wall near the material storage section. The night shift supervisor, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), discovered the spill during a routine inventory check at 11:25 PM. The spill released fumes containing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) with a strong chemical odor detected throughout the warehouse area. Immediate actions included activation of emergency ventilation systems, evacuation of the immediate area, and notification of the HSE office. The spill was contained using absorbent pads and disposed of according to hazardous waste protocols. Environmental monitoring was conducted at 12:30 AM showing VOC levels at 85 ppm in the warehouse (OSHA PEL: 200 ppm for 8-hour TWA), below critical thresholds but elevated above normal baseline. The facility remained in partial operation with affected zone restricted.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine part removal from a recently completed molding cycle. While reaching into the mold cavity to extract finished automotive dashboard components, his left hand became caught between the mold halves as the machine unexpectedly initiated a new cycle due to a faulty proximity sensor. The sensor had been malfunctioning for two days but was not flagged for maintenance due to inadequate equipment status communication protocols. Mathieu sustained a severe crush injury to his left hand with fractures to three metacarpal bones and significant soft tissue damage. He was immediately transported to Laval Hospital by ambulance at 3:15 PM. Emergency response was initiated by Julie Bergeron (Production Supervisor - Evening Shift, EMP-00015), who was present in the production area and called emergency services. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury requiring hospitalization and a 6-week recovery period. LOTO procedures were not in place for routine part removal, and the machine's safety interlocks were not functioning properly.

On February 28, 2024 at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was preparing fiber-reinforced plastic material in the mixing area when she noticed unusual pressure buildup in a heated resin storage tank. The tank had recently undergone maintenance but the pressure relief valve had not been properly tested after reassembly by Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097). As Rania attempted to manually bleed pressure from the valve using a wrench, a small jet of superheated resin (approximately 180°C) suddenly released from a connection point, spraying toward her right arm and shoulder. She immediately stepped back and called for assistance. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) responded within 30 seconds and applied first aid with cool water and a sterile dressing. The incident was contained with no environmental release. Rania experienced minor first and second-degree thermal burns to approximately 8% of her arm surface area but did not require hospitalization. She returned to full duty after 3 days of light duty work. The near-miss nature was recognized because protective PPE (fire-resistant apron and welding gloves) partially mitigated exposure. Investigation revealed the pressure relief system testing procedure was incomplete and inadequate communication existed between maintenance and operations regarding equipment changes.

On April 9, 2024 at approximately 8:40 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area when Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, was transferring spent solvent from a production line collection cart to a large 55-gallon storage drum. Hassan had been working overtime and was not fully familiar with the evening shift protocols. He failed to verify that the receiving drum was empty before beginning the transfer, and approximately 12 gallons of isopropyl alcohol (IPA) with dissolved plastic resins overflowed from a partially-filled drum onto the concrete floor. The spill spread across approximately 450 square feet of the warehouse floor near electrical equipment and material storage. Hassan immediately stopped the transfer and notified Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) at 8:42 PM. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) was contacted and initiated containment procedures using absorbent materials and proper secondary containment protocols. The spill was fully contained within 45 minutes with no environmental release beyond the facility floor. The contaminated absorbent materials were properly disposed of as hazardous waste. Investigation revealed inadequate labeling of receiving containers, lack of pre-transfer verification procedures, and insufficient training for evening shift material handlers on hazardous liquid transfer protocols.
