The facility's spill response procedures proved effective in preventing environmental impact.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Bianca De Luca was operating a propane-powered forklift in the Materials Management and Warehousing area to transport a pallet of polypropylene resin bags to the Material Drying and Preparation Room. While maneuvering through the narrow corridor between storage racks, the forklift's right front tire struck a wet spot on the concrete floor left from morning cleaning operations. The tire lost traction, causing the forklift to tilt approximately 15 degrees to the right. The load of resin bags (approximately 1,200 lbs) shifted and several bags fell onto the adjacent storage rack, which collapsed partially. Approximately 400 lbs of composite material spilled across the warehouse floor, and one resin bag was punctured, releasing fine particulate material into the air. De Luca safely dismounted the forklift and immediately reported the incident to her supervisor. The area was evacuated briefly, and facility maintenance was called to assess structural damage to the storage rack and clean up the spilled material. No employees were injured, but the incident resulted in an estimated $8,500 in property damage including the damaged storage rack, lost material, and floor repairs required due to chemical exposure from the ruptured resin bag.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM during the day shift, Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos conducted a routine air quality monitoring inspection in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) as part of TechnoPlast's preventive health and safety program. During her walkthrough, Santos identified that the ventilation system's exhaust fan was operating at significantly reduced capacity—approximately 40% of its designed airflow rate based on handheld airflow measurements. Monitoring equipment detected elevated concentrations of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from cleaning solvents and resin fumes at 85 parts per million, approaching the occupational exposure limit of 100 ppm. The root cause investigation revealed that the exhaust duct had accumulated approximately 2 inches of fine plastic particulate buildup over the past 8 months due to inadequate maintenance scheduling. Additionally, the intake air filter had not been replaced in 14 months, significantly restricting fresh air circulation. Santos immediately documented the findings and issued a Preventive Declaration notice recommending that the ventilation system be serviced before any further chemical mixing operations. She coordinated with Maintenance Supervisor Marco Rossi to schedule emergency ductwork cleaning and filter replacement within 48 hours to prevent ongoing employee exposure to harmful fumes.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, Machine Setter Louis Desbiens was performing routine setup adjustments on a CNC milling machine in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014) while preparing it for an early morning production run. The machine had been scheduled for a tool change operation, and Desbiens was working without proper lockout/tagout procedures due to time pressure and an incorrectly communicated deadline from the production planning department. While positioning a new cutting tool in the machine's chuck, an unexpected servo motor restart occurred—triggered by a faulty proximity sensor that had been showing intermittent signs of failure for two weeks but was never logged in the maintenance system. The rotating chuck caught Desbiens's left hand, causing a laceration to his palm and fingers, and trapping his hand for approximately 8 seconds before he was able to pull free. The incident triggered the machine's emergency stop, preventing a more severe crushing injury. Desbiens immediately reported the injury to Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur, who responded to the scene, provided first aid (three stitches required at the facility's medical station), and documented the incident. The employee was transported to the local emergency clinic for evaluation and imaging to rule out tendon or nerve damage. The machine remained idle for investigation and repairs.

On March 14, 2024 at 10:45 AM, Injection Molding Operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103) was working at Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Main Production Building when his right hand came into contact with a sharp edge on a freshly ejected polycarbonate component. The part had an unexpected burr formation along its edge due to a worn mold cavity that had not been properly maintained. As Paul reached to remove the part from the ejection area, his gloved hand brushed against the sharp edge, causing a laceration to his palm and index finger. The injury required immediate first aid and subsequent medical attention for stitches. Crane Operator Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041) witnessed the incident and immediately assisted Paul to the first aid station. The operator reported the incident to Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) within minutes. The mold cavity wear was identified as the root cause, suggesting inadequate preventive maintenance procedures and insufficient operator awareness of sharp edge hazards on components.

On March 18, 2024 at 2:15 AM during the night shift, Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) was performing routine quality checks in the Finished Goods Warehouse when he slipped on a wet spot on the floor near the loading dock. The floor had accumulated moisture from condensation and incomplete cleaning from the previous evening shift. Normand fell heavily, striking his left knee and lower leg against the concrete floor. He experienced immediate pain and swelling and was unable to bear weight on the injured leg. Quality Supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079), working late to monitor equipment, discovered Normand on the floor and called for emergency response. Normand was transported to the facility's first aid station and subsequently to a local hospital where imaging revealed a severe knee contusion with possible ligament involvement requiring hospitalization for 48 hours. The investigation revealed that the warehouse cleaning crew had failed to properly dry the floor after their 11:30 PM shift completion, and no slip hazard signage had been posted.

On March 21, 2024 at 4:30 PM, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when an automatic smoke detector triggered due to unexpected fume accumulation. Instrumentation Technician Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075) had been conducting routine maintenance on the ventilation system dampers when he inadvertently partially closed one of the supply dampers while adjusting controls. This resulted in reduced airflow through the room despite continued chemical mixing operations happening in an adjacent area. As resin compounds were being mixed, volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes accumulated beyond normal levels, triggering the sensitive smoke detector at 4:28 PM. The facility's fire alarm system activated, initiating full emergency evacuation procedures. Approximately 85 employees evacuated safely within 12 minutes. Fire department personnel arrived at 4:47 PM and confirmed no actual fire but detected elevated VOC levels requiring immediate ventilation system repair. The root cause was identified as inadequate communication between maintenance and operations staff regarding damper adjustments, combined with insufficient labeling of ventilation controls.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a critical cooling water system failure occurred on Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone. Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye was monitoring the line when she noticed unusual temperature readings on the molding machine's display panel. Within minutes, cooling water began leaking from a corroded coupling joint in the hydraulic cooling circuit. The pressurized water spray struck the machine's electrical control panel and created a slip hazard on the production floor. Fatou immediately activated the emergency stop button and notified her supervisor. Maintenance technician Andrei Popov responded and discovered that the cooling system coupling, originally installed in 2018, had suffered corrosion due to mineral deposits and inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling. The leak resulted in approximately 200 liters of water discharge before the main valve could be manually closed. No direct injury occurred, but the incident revealed significant deficiencies in equipment maintenance protocols and created immediate safety risks from electrical hazard and slip conditions. The line was shut down for 8 hours pending repairs and system inspection.

On April 2, 2025, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Aaliyah Jackson sustained a minor laceration injury while performing quality inspection work at the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Aaliyah was handling dried plastic pellets in preparation for loading into the material hopper system when a sharp edge on a metal scoop, commonly used for material transfer, caught her left index finger. The cut was approximately 1.5 inches long and produced moderate bleeding. She immediately applied pressure with paper towels and reported the incident to her supervisor. First aid responder Jacques Lachance arrived within 3 minutes and provided initial wound care using the facility's first aid kit. The wound was cleaned with sterile gauze and saline solution, and after the bleeding stopped, a sterile bandage was applied. Jacques determined the injury did not require medical treatment beyond first aid, as the laceration was shallow and did not affect underlying structures. The root cause investigation revealed that the metal scoop had a burr on its edge created during routine maintenance, and the burr had not been smoothed or reported. Aaliyah was able to return to work 15 minutes later after the first aid treatment was completed.

On April 8, 2025, at 9:30 PM during the evening shift, Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel suffered a minor eye irritation incident while conducting surface inspection of composite materials in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Jasmine was examining finished parts under the inspection lamp when a small particle of cured composite material became dislodged from a part she was handling and contacted her right eye. She immediately experienced discomfort and mild redness. She reported the incident to her supervisor and proceeded to the first aid station where EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury was present. Samira performed an eye wash protocol using the emergency eyewash station, flushing the eye with sterile saline for approximately 2 minutes. The particle was successfully removed, and Samira applied a soothing antibiotic ointment. Jasmine's vision returned to normal within 15 minutes. The incident occurred because Jasmine was not wearing safety glasses despite working with materials known to produce sharp particles. The composite material being inspected had recently been modified with a new reinforcement fiber that created sharper, more durable particles than the previous formulation. No underlying eye damage was identified.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building. While cleaning residual plastic material from the mold cavity using a compressed air hose, she inadvertently activated the machine's start cycle. The mold clamps engaged suddenly, and her right hand was caught between the mold plates and a fixed support structure. The compression resulted in a laceration to her palm and crush injuries to her middle and ring fingers. Coworker James Thompson (EMP-00029), who was working on an adjacent line, heard her cry out and immediately stopped the machine using the emergency stop button. First aid was administered on-site, and she was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where X-rays revealed two fractured metacarpals and deep tissue damage requiring surgical intervention. The incident occurred because the machine's lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure had not been properly followed—the equipment was in maintenance mode but not physically de-energized or locked. This represents a critical control failure in the company's machine safety protocols.

On March 21, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the night shift, maintenance planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) was working in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) to repair a faulty cooling system pump from one of the injection molding machines. While using a CNC milling machine to fabricate a replacement coupling, his left hand slipped on the rotating workpiece. His index and middle fingers made contact with the high-speed rotating cutting tool, resulting in deep lacerations to both fingers and partial amputation of the index finger tip. Production supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) was nearby and immediately shut down the CNC machine. Thanh was given immediate first aid and transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur for emergency surgical evaluation. During the investigation, it was determined that the machine's safety guard had been removed two weeks prior for a tooling change and was never reinstalled. Additionally, Thanh was not wearing the required cut-resistant gloves specified in the workshop's PPE requirements—he reported they were uncomfortable and slowed his work. The incident represents a combination of inadequate machine guarding maintenance and non-compliance with personal protective equipment protocols.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 4:30 PM during the evening shift transition, shipping coordinator Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073) was preparing finished goods for shipment in the Warehouse and Shipping area. While stacking plastic composite containers on a hand pallet truck near the loading dock, he encountered a spill of hydraulic fluid from a leaking forklift that had been parked nearby for routine maintenance. Normand's shoe sole lost traction on the slippery surface and he fell backward, striking his lower back against the edge of a plastic crate. He immediately reported severe lower back pain. Materials supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031) witnessed the fall and called for first aid support. Normand was evaluated on-site and transported to the emergency department where imaging revealed a compression fracture of the L4 vertebra. Investigation revealed that the forklift maintenance had been scheduled but not tracked, and hydraulic fluid containment protocols had not been followed during maintenance activities in the warehouse area. The spill cleanup procedures were inadequate, and no warning signage had been posted. The root cause was a combination of inadequate maintenance scheduling, missing spill containment, and lack of environmental hazard controls in the warehouse.

On April 8, 2024 at 10:30 AM during day shift, Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), the Safety Officer, conducted a routine inspection of the Material Drying and Preparation Room located in the Main Production Building's Material Handling Zone. During this walk-through, Anh identified a potential fire hazard related to accumulated plastic dust and particulate matter on the overhead ventilation ducts and along the upper shelving. The dust accumulation, estimated at 8-12 millimeters in depth across multiple surfaces, had not been addressed during regular maintenance cycles. According to the facility's fire code documentation and CNESST regulations, this accumulation presents a significant risk for spontaneous combustion or rapid fire spread in the event of an ignition source. Anh documented the finding with photographs and measurements, noting that the last comprehensive duct cleaning was performed 18 months prior. The material handling area operates at elevated temperatures due to the drying equipment, increasing the hazard potential. Anh immediately notified the Facilities and Maintenance departments and escalated the concern to HSE leadership. This preventive declaration was made to address the hazard before any incident occurred.

On February 22, 2024 at 10:45 PM during evening shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was removing finished composite parts from the ejection station when he observed that Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198), a Production Operator working nearby, had reached down to pick up a fallen part from the floor directly beneath a storage rack containing stacked polycarbonate resin materials. The rack, positioned approximately 1.8 meters high, showed visible signs of uneven loading with materials shifted toward one side. Bruno immediately called out a warning to Laila, and she moved away from the area just as several kilograms of resin blocks began to shift and cascade onto the spot where she had been standing moments before. The materials fell approximately 1.5 meters, scattering across the production floor. No one was struck, but the near-miss was significant given the potential for serious injury or fatality. Bruno remained in the area to ensure safety and immediately reported the incident to Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), the Mold Maintenance Technician, who was working nearby. The incident was documented and reported to the HSE office by Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) during the next shift, who reviewed the surveillance footage and interviewed both employees.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, suffered a laceration to his left hand while clearing a material jam from the injection molding machine's feed throat. The 150-ton machine was supposed to be locked out per LOTO procedures, but due to a shift handover miscommunication, the lockout had been released 15 minutes earlier by the outgoing operator without proper verification. When Stéphane reached into the feed mechanism to dislodge a compacted polypropylene blockage, the machine cycled unexpectedly, trapping his hand between the rotating screw and the barrel. Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), working the adjacent position on Line C, heard his cry and immediately activated the emergency stop. The injury resulted in a deep 4-centimeter laceration across his palm and two fingers requiring 18 stitches and a 3-day hospitalization for infection risk assessment. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) responded as Emergency Response Team Leader, coordinating first aid and transport. Root cause analysis identified inadequate LOTO communication protocol during shift transitions as the primary failure factor.

On November 22, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, the primary cooling water circulation pump serving the CNC milling machines in the Maintenance Workshop experienced a catastrophic bearing failure, resulting in loss of cooling water flow to three active machines. The pump, a 3-horsepower centrifugal unit manufactured in 2004, had been in continuous operation for 18 months beyond its recommended 10-year service life despite being flagged in the predictive maintenance reports from September 2024. The bearing seized suddenly, causing the impeller to jam and creating a complete blockage in the main circulation line. Cooling water pressure dropped from 60 PSI to 0 PSI within 90 seconds, triggering emergency shutdowns on two CNC machines. However, the third machine (being operated by Giovanni Bianchi, EMP-00032) continued running without coolant for approximately 8 minutes before operators realized the system failure, resulting in severe thermal stress and permanent damage to the machine's spindle bearings and precision cutting head. Estimated equipment damage: $187,000 in repairs and replacement. Thanh Pham (EMP-00062), Maintenance Planner, identified that the failure was caused by deferred maintenance and lack of timely pump replacement despite clear engineering recommendations. The incident required a 96-hour production shutdown for repairs and diagnostics.

On November 28, 2024, at 4:30 AM during the night shift, an overhead crane load-holding mechanism malfunctioned in the Finished Goods Warehouse, resulting in the partial failure of the main bridge crane's load engagement system. The crane was being operated by a contract worker supervised by Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031), Materials Supervisor, to move a suspended pallet of finished polycarbonate components (approximately 2,800 pounds) from the staging area to the shipping dock. As the crane operator began lowering the load, two of the four load pins in the spreader bar assembly became disengaged from their locking positions simultaneously, causing the pallet to shift laterally and tilt approximately 25 degrees. While the load did not drop completely, it created an unstable suspension that required an emergency stop and a 90-minute controlled descent to the ground. Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), Receiving Clerk, was working 40 feet away and immediately vacated the area when he recognized the crane malfunction. No personnel were injured, but approximately $34,000 of finished goods were damaged due to the tilting and compression of components. Investigation by Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist coordinating with maintenance, revealed that the load pins had experienced corrosion and microcracking from inadequate lubrication and the absence of scheduled preventive maintenance inspections. Inspection records showed the last crane certification was performed 14 months ago, exceeding the 12-month requirement.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a catastrophic failure occurred in the hydraulic system of Injection Molding Machine Line B located in the Main Production Building's central production area. Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay was performing routine maintenance and had just completed a pressure test when the main hydraulic hose connection failed suddenly. The rupture caused a spray of pressurized hydraulic fluid that struck and damaged approximately $185,000 worth of adjacent electronic control systems and instrumentation panels. The fluid also contaminated approximately 2,000 lbs of raw polypropylene resin stored nearby, rendering it unusable. Production Supervisor Michael Chen was present and immediately initiated shutdown procedures. No personnel were injured, but the incident resulted in complete Line B shutdown for 72 hours while repairs and equipment replacement were completed. The root cause was determined to be corroded ferrule connectors that had not been replaced during the previous maintenance cycle despite manufacturer recommendations.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:30 PM during evening shift operations, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Building without an apparent active fire. Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le was conducting end-of-shift cleanup in the adjacent laboratory when he noticed smoke emanating from the resin mixing station area. Upon investigation, he discovered that a batch of epoxy resin had been inadvertently left heating on a hot plate set to 180°C with the temperature controller malfunctioning. The resin had begun to decompose and generate smoke, activating the sensitive smoke detector. Tran immediately notified Natasha Ivanov, the Chemical Inventory Specialist, who coordinated evacuation and contacted emergency services. The fire department responded within 8 minutes but confirmed no actual fire had developed. The alarm activation was legitimate but resulted from a process control failure. Investigation revealed that the hot plate's thermostat had failed three weeks prior and had been replaced with a manual adjustment unit without documenting the change or updating equipment logs. The incident resulted in a 90-minute facility evacuation and production stoppage affecting the evening shift.

On May 8, 2024, at 3:15 AM during night shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse Section A. Material Handler Hassan Diallo was transferring a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent (silicone-based) from storage to a transport cart when the drum's bunged lid was not secured properly. The cart struck a slight incline near the warehouse door, causing the drum to tip and approximately 40 gallons of the oily liquid to spill across approximately 800 square feet of the concrete floor and into a floor drain that connects to the facility's stormwater system. Hassan immediately stopped operations and notified Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor, who activated the chemical spill response protocol. Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, arrived within 12 minutes and directed containment and cleanup efforts. The spilled material was absorbed using 150 lbs of absorbent material, collected in regulated waste drums, and properly disposed of. An environmental consultant was contracted to verify that the stormwater drain was properly isolated and that no environmental release occurred beyond the facility boundary. The incident resulted in 6 hours of cleanup work, material loss of approximately $8,400, and a follow-up environmental investigation.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) was working at Injection Molding Line B when she sustained a minor laceration to her left index finger. While removing a finished automotive dashboard component from the mold cavity, her finger made contact with a sharp edge on the partially ejected mold insert. The cut, approximately 1.5 cm in length, resulted in minimal bleeding. Yara immediately reported the injury to her supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), who assessed the wound and administered first aid including cleaning, antibiotic ointment application, and a sterile adhesive bandage. The injury did not require medical attention beyond first aid and the employee was able to continue working after a 10-minute break. No production downtime occurred. The incident was witnessed by fellow operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008), who confirmed the sequence of events. Root cause analysis indicated that the mold insert's edge had developed a small burr from repeated thermal cycling, which had not been detected during the morning maintenance inspection.

On November 19, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Production operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was manually transferring pre-dried composite material pellets from a drying hopper into a blending container when the hopper discharge valve partially stuck, causing a sudden release of pressurized material. Approximately 15 kg of composite fiber-reinforced pellets discharged rapidly, creating an airborne dust cloud that dispersed across the work area. The material did not contact Leila directly due to her positioning approximately 1.5 meters from the hopper exit, but the dust cloud containing fine composite fibers reached her face level. She immediately stepped back and exited the dust cloud, experiencing mild upper airway irritation but no respiratory distress. Witnesses included maintenance technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), who was performing nearby equipment checks. No injuries occurred, but the incident demonstrated a failure in the preventive maintenance schedule—the hopper discharge mechanism had not been lubricated or inspected for 47 days, exceeding the 30-day maintenance interval. If Leila had been positioned closer to the discharge point, serious respiratory exposure could have resulted.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 3:45 AM during the night shift, a fire incident occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013) requiring evacuation and emergency response. Maintenance technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) was performing routine cleaning of CNC milling machine debris when a accumulation of fine plastic dust and composite fiber material in the machine's lower enclosure came into contact with a sparking condition generated during a routine spindle bearing wear test being conducted by process improvement engineer Yuki Yamamoto (EMP-00112). The temperature rise from the bearing friction exceeded ignition threshold for the accumulated dust, initiating a small localized fire within the machine's cabinet. The flames were confined to the interior of the CNC enclosure but generated visible smoke. Yamamoto immediately activated the emergency stop button and notified plant operations. Building fire suppression systems were manually triggered and the night shift supervisor evacuated all personnel from the facility. Local fire department arrived within 12 minutes and confirmed full containment. No injuries occurred but the CNC machine sustained approximately $34,000 in internal component damage including control circuit boards and wiring harnesses. Root cause analysis revealed that dust collection and removal protocols had not been enforced during the night shift due to reduced supervision, and the bearing test procedure lacked clearance verification requirements.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine part removal from a mold when his left hand became caught between the mold closing plates. The machine's safety interlock had been bypassed due to a maintenance override that was not properly cleared after repairs earlier that morning by Thanh Pham. Gendron attempted to extract a jammed part without waiting for the cooling cycle to complete. When the automatic closing cycle initiated, his hand was pinched, resulting in a crush injury to three fingers. He immediately pressed the emergency stop button and called for assistance. Raj Patel, the Process Engineer, responded and called emergency services. Gendron was transported to Hôpital de la Cité with fractures to the index and middle fingers and severe soft tissue damage. He required surgery and was hospitalized for 2 days, resulting in a 6-week lost-time injury during his recovery period.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, was manually unloading a pallet of composite material resin drums from a delivery truck in the Materials Management area near the Composite Materials Processing section. As he attempted to lift a 50-kilogram drum using improper lifting technique (bending at the waist rather than lifting with legs), he felt acute lower back pain. Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), the Machine Setter on duty, witnessed the incident and immediately directed Owusu to sit down and applied ice to the affected area. Owusu remained at the workstation and was able to complete his shift with reduced activity. However, the next morning, Owusu reported significant pain and mobility limitations. He sought medical evaluation which revealed a minor lumbar strain with muscle sprain. Medical recommendations included 3-4 days of rest and restricted duty. The incident was caught early through immediate response, preventing what could have become a more serious injury, but it highlighted a gap in proper ergonomic technique implementation.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a fire suppression system accidental discharge occurred in the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006). Gaston Picard (EMP-00193), a Crane Operator who was assisting with equipment repositioning nearby, was in close proximity when a pre-action fire suppression sprinkler head in the laboratory was inadvertently triggered due to vibration from heavy equipment movement in the adjacent storage area. The discharge activated the entire system in that zone, releasing approximately 8,000 gallons of fire suppression fluid over an estimated 90-second period. The spray affected laboratory test equipment, several ongoing quality control samples, and documentation files. Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), the Injection Molding Setter on night shift, observed the discharge and immediately notified emergency response personnel and André Bellavance, the Confined Space Entry Supervisor. No personnel were directly struck by the discharge, but the incident resulted in significant property damage: approximately $52,000 in damaged laboratory equipment requiring replacement, $18,000 in contaminated samples requiring disposal, and 4 days of laboratory downtime impacting production quality verification schedules. The root cause was inadequate vibration isolation and clearance specifications for equipment placement near the fire suppression system.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a second-degree burn to his right forearm while performing routine mold maintenance. Jalbert was cleaning the mold cavity with a cloth when he inadvertently made contact with the hot mold surface, which was operating at 280°C. The mold's temperature warning light had been malfunctioning for three days, and no alternative temperature monitoring system was in place. The employee did not have heat-resistant sleeves available at his workstation, only standard cotton gloves. A colleague, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), immediately applied cold water and notified Georges Plante (EMP-00179), the Facilities Technician, who provided first aid and arranged transport to the on-site medical clinic. The burn covered approximately 8cm x 6cm and required medical attention, resulting in 3 days of lost work time. Root cause analysis identified inadequate temperature monitoring equipment maintenance and insufficient PPE provisions for operators working with high-temperature molds.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM during the day shift, Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042), a Composite Materials Technician, experienced acute respiratory distress while working in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (East Section - UNIT-014). She was assisting with the preparation of glass-reinforced composite materials using acetone-based cleaning solvent to remove uncured resin from equipment. The shop's ventilation system was partially blocked due to accumulated dust in air intake filters that had not been cleaned for 6 weeks. Additionally, several solvent containers were left open during the cleaning process, and Ivanova was not wearing the appropriate respiratory protection, only a dust mask insufficient for organic vapor exposure. After approximately 45 minutes of exposure, she reported dizziness, chest tightness, and difficulty breathing. Deepa Gupta (EMP-00080), the Process Quality Engineer working nearby, recognized the symptoms and immediately moved Ivanova to fresh air and contacted the on-site medical clinic. Emergency response personnel administered oxygen, and Ivanova was transported to the hospital where she was diagnosed with acute chemical bronchitis. She spent two days hospitalized. Investigation revealed that the ventilation maintenance schedule had lapsed, and training records showed Ivanova had not received updated WHMIS training on solvent hazards in the past two years.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, suffered a significant thermal burn while performing routine mold maintenance. François was removing cooled molds from an injection molding machine (250-ton capacity) when he inadvertently contacted a mold surface that had not fully cooled to ambient temperature. Despite following standard procedures, the residual heat from the injection cycle (approximately 85°C) caused second-degree burns to his right palm and fingers covering approximately 8% of his hand surface. The incident occurred in the Main Production Building's North Zone. François immediately alerted his supervisor Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), who initiated first aid with cold water irrigation and activated emergency protocols. François was transported to the on-site medical station and subsequently to Laval Regional Hospital for advanced burn treatment and wound management. The employee required 6 weeks of medical leave for wound healing and rehabilitation. Investigation revealed that the automatic mold temperature monitoring system had malfunctioned, failing to alert operators that cooling cycles were incomplete.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Amara Diop (EMP-00110), a Packaging Operator, sustained a laceration to her left index finger while performing packaging operations in the Warehouse and Shipping area. Amara was manually unpacking injection-molded automotive components from wooden pallets and positioning them into corrugated shipping boxes when a wooden splinter became embedded in her finger as she gripped a pallet edge. The splinter penetrated approximately 1.5 cm into the subcutaneous tissue of her fingertip. Amara immediately reported the injury to her supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037), who was stationed nearby. First aid was administered by the site nurse, who removed the splinter using sterile instruments and cleaned the wound thoroughly. Amara received tetanus prophylaxis and was cleared to return to duty with modified work restrictions (no direct pallet handling for 3 days). The incident was documented as a minor puncture wound requiring on-site medical intervention but not hospitalization. Root cause analysis revealed that wooden pallets used for material storage had not undergone scheduled surface maintenance or splinter treatment per warehouse protocol in over 8 weeks.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, production operations in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building were temporarily halted after Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), Environmental Compliance Specialist, identified a potential chemical spill hazard during a routine late-night facility inspection. While conducting her monthly compliance audit, Nathalie observed that several storage containers of polyester resin (approximately 50-liter capacity) were stored on shelving units that lacked secondary containment trays, violating CNESST storage regulations and internal WHMIS protocols. The inspection also revealed that one container's lid was partially unsecured, creating an immediate risk of spillage during the night shift's material transfer operations. No actual spill had occurred at the time of discovery, but the hazardous condition posed significant risk to André Paradis (EMP-00037), the Night Shift Production Supervisor, and his team of 3 operators who were actively mixing compounds in the adjacent work area. Nathalie immediately issued a work suspension order and documented the violation in the compliance database. The production supervisor was notified, and corrective actions were initiated immediately to secure the container and relocate materials to compliant storage. This preventive declaration averted potential chemical exposure incidents and regulatory non-compliance citations.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45, a fire originated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (Building 5) when a 55-gallon drum of acetone solvent was improperly stored near a heat source. A maintenance technician, Gilles Marchand, had been cleaning equipment in the area and left a portable work lamp (250W halogen) positioned 18 inches from the acetone drum while he attended to other tasks. The ambient temperature in the storage area had reached 28°C (82°F) due to a malfunctioning ventilation system that had not been serviced in 14 months. At 14:47, the solvent vapors ignited, creating a localized flash fire. The fire spread to adjacent stored materials including mold release agents and colorant masterbatches. Sanaa Rachidi, the Fire Safety Coordinator, was conducting a routine inspection nearby and immediately activated the emergency alarm and deployed a Class B fire extinguisher, containing the fire within 4 minutes. Emergency services arrived at 14:58. No personnel were injured, but approximately $67,000 in raw materials were destroyed, and the storage facility sustained significant structural damage to shelving systems and ventilation ducting. The incident exposed critical gaps in chemical storage protocols and heat source management.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, equipment damage occurred in the Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components) clean room facility. An injection molding machine (Model: Engel Duo 5070) experienced a catastrophic hydraulic system failure that resulted in uncontrolled pressure release and subsequent fire in the hydraulic fluid reservoir. Machine operator Tomas Jimenez was performing routine mold changeover procedures when he noticed unusual vibration and audible hissing from the machine's hydraulic manifold. He immediately evacuated the immediate area and notified shift supervisor. Within 90 seconds, pressurized hydraulic oil (ISO 32, highly flammable) sprayed across internal machine components and ignited from contact with hot mold surfaces operating at 210°C. The resulting fire was contained within the machine's protective enclosure but caused severe thermal damage to the hydraulic pump assembly ($189,500 in repairs), hydraulic lines and manifold system ($47,200), electrical control panel ($23,400), and surrounding tooling ($31,900). Total equipment damage exceeded $292,000. The fire was extinguished by the machine's integrated fire suppression system within 2 minutes. Investigation revealed that the hydraulic system had not been serviced per manufacturer specifications in 28 months, and internal seals had deteriorated, causing the failure. No personnel sustained injuries, but production on this critical medical component line was halted for 14 days pending repairs and recertification.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 09:30, an occupational health incident occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (Main Production Building - South Zone). Assembly operator Isabella Ricci, who had been working on finishing composite material parts for the past 6 hours, experienced acute respiratory distress and eye irritation. She had been handling carbon fiber-reinforced polymer (CFRP) parts during a grinding and sanding operation in an area with inadequate local exhaust ventilation. The task required removing flash and burrs from approximately 200 parts, generating substantial quantities of fine composite fiber dust. Despite wearing a standard dust mask (not rated for composite fibers), Ricci began experiencing severe coughing, wheezing, and eye burning at 09:28. Coworker Diego Morales immediately alerted shift supervisor who directed Ricci to the first aid station. First aid responder Claude Poirier (trained in basic first aid) flushed her eyes with sterile saline solution for 10 minutes and administered oxygen therapy. Ricci's respiratory distress improved within 15 minutes but she remained symptomatic. She was transported via ambulance to the adjacent medical clinic at 09:50 where she was treated for acute allergic airway reaction and chemical conjunctivitis. She received nebulized bronchodilator treatment and antihistamine therapy. Medical assessment diagnosed occupational asthma exacerbation secondary to composite fiber exposure. Ricci was placed on 2-day medical leave and provided with an inhaler and occupational health referral. Investigation revealed the grinding area's local exhaust system had been inoperative for 4 days due to a clogged filter that had not been replaced per maintenance schedule.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a catastrophic hopper overflow occurred at Injection Molding Line B. Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was loading virgin polycarbonate pellets into the material hopper when the automated level sensor malfunctioned, failing to trigger the cutoff valve. Approximately 1,200 kg of raw material accumulated and spilled onto the production floor, adjacent equipment, and partially into the electrical conduit area. The material spread across an estimated 45 square meters of floor space, creating a significant slip hazard and partially blocking emergency exit routes. Material handlers Elif Yilmaz and a visiting contractor worked to contain and sweep up the spill. The incident required approximately 4 hours of cleanup and production was halted for 6 hours. No injuries occurred, but equipment damage included water damage to electrical components when cleaning water was used near the electrical conduit, resulting in approximately $8,500 in equipment repairs and disposal costs for contaminated material.

On April 3, 2024, at 10:45 AM during the day shift, Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) sustained a first-aid level eye injury while inspecting molded automotive components at the quality control station in Unit-019. While examining the surface finish of a dashboard trim part under bright lighting, a small plastic chip approximately 3mm in diameter became dislodged from the edge of the component and struck her left eye. The particle caused minor corneal abrasion and immediate tearing. Despite wearing standard safety glasses, the chip's trajectory bypassed the lens protection. The employee immediately reported to the on-site first aid station where Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) was present. First aid treatment included eye flushing with saline solution, application of sterile eye drops, and protective eye patch placement for 2 hours. No emergency room visit was required. Vision returned to normal within 24 hours. The incident was treated and resolved with first aid only, with the employee returning to modified duty (non-inspection work) for 48 hours as a precaution.

On April 18, 2024, at 11:30 PM during the night shift, Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) conducted a preventive safety inspection of the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (Unit-017) and identified a critical potential hazard during routine maintenance documentation review. Upon examining maintenance records and performing a walkthrough inspection, he discovered that the emergency shutdown (E-stop) button on Industrial Oven #3 had not been tested or verified for functionality in over 18 months, despite company policy requiring quarterly testing. The control circuit showed visible corrosion around the button mechanism, and the mechanical linkage to the heating element cutoff appeared stiff and potentially unreliable. Additionally, Laplante observed that the LOTO hasp attachment points on the oven had shifted slightly due to vibration, making proper tagout application difficult. This preventive discovery was made before any maintenance work was performed and before any incident occurred. The coordinator immediately documented the findings and initiated a work order for oven remediation. This represents a proactive safety intervention that prevented a potential catastrophic failure during future maintenance activities.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a hydraulic hose rupture occurred on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone of the main production building. Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an experienced operator on Line D, was assisting with a routine maintenance inspection when the high-pressure hose connected to the mold clamping system suddenly burst. The rupture sprayed pressurized hydraulic fluid across approximately 8 square meters of the production floor, soaking electrical enclosures, control panels, and machinery components. The fluid also splashed onto the concrete floor creating a significant slip hazard. Operations Manager Guillaume Deschamps (EMP-00051) was present during the incident and immediately initiated emergency shutdown procedures. No personnel were directly struck by the fluid stream, but the incident resulted in production line downtime lasting 18 hours while the hose was replaced, hydraulic fluid was cleaned up, and all affected electrical components were inspected and dried. The root cause was identified as inadequate maintenance scheduling and failure to conduct pressure relief inspections on the hydraulic system.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a material storage shelving unit in the Hazardous Waste Management Area experienced a partial structural failure. Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a forklift operator, was retrieving containers of used cleaning solvents when the top shelf bracket failed due to corrosion and material fatigue. Approximately 15 kilograms of chemical waste containers fell from the shelf, landing on pallets stored below and causing significant spillage. Several containers of acetone and isopropanol leaked onto the concrete floor and into the drainage system. Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was working nearby and witnessed the collapse. No personnel were directly struck by falling materials, but the chemical spill created an environmental hazard and necessitated immediate containment procedures. The incident resulted in a 6-hour production delay while the spill was contained, cleaned, and environmental monitoring was conducted. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) supervised the remediation. The root cause was determined to be deferred maintenance and failure to conduct regular structural integrity inspections on aging chemical storage infrastructure.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Patricia Martin (EMP-00035), Packaging Supervisor, sustained a minor thermal burn to her left forearm while inspecting the automated packaging line in the Assembly and Finishing Department. While checking seal quality on recently molded polypropylene containers, Patricia inadvertently made contact with a heated press plate that maintains a surface temperature of approximately 85°C. The plate was part of the sealing station and was temporarily exposed due to a maintenance access panel that had not been fully closed by the previous shift. The contact lasted approximately 2 seconds, resulting in a first-degree thermal burn approximately 3 centimeters in diameter with minor redness and slight blistering. Patricia immediately immersed the affected area in cold water for 10 minutes and reported the incident to her direct supervisor, Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128). First aid treatment was administered at the facility's first aid station with application of antiseptic cream and sterile gauze dressing. No hospitalization was required, and Patricia continued working with modified duties. The incident was attributed to inadequate guards on heated equipment and insufficient procedural enforcement for maintenance access panel closure.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:22, during day shift operations, Assembly Operator Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station when she noticed her colleague Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) reaching across a conveyor belt to retrieve finished consumer packaging containers. As Elena extended her arm over the moving belt, her sleeve caught momentarily on a protruding label applicator nozzle. The nozzle was not properly guarded and posed an entanglement hazard. Elena quickly pulled her arm back, but the incident was nearly catastrophic as her sleeve tore and she could have been drawn into the equipment. Isabella immediately stopped the line using the emergency stop button and reported the near-miss to Samira El-Khoury (EMS-00003) in the HSE office within minutes. No injury occurred, but the equipment's insufficient guarding was identified as a critical control gap. The incident was witnessed by Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran (EMP-00046) who was inspecting nearby work stations.

On April 8, 2024 at 22:47 during evening shift operations, a fire alarm was activated in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was operating the regrind shredder when she noticed smoke emanating from the motor housing of the recycling conveyor system. The motor had overheated due to bearing wear and lack of preventive maintenance, causing the electrical insulation to degrade and emit smoke. Elif immediately activated the facility-wide fire alarm pull station, causing all personnel to evacuate according to established emergency procedures. Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183) coordinated the evacuation and accounted for all staff members at the designated muster point. Emergency responders from the Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the fire alarm activation was appropriate. No actual fire occurred, but the motor's bearing seized completely. The incident demonstrated both the effectiveness of TechnoPlast's alarm system and a critical gap in preventive maintenance procedures for high-risk equipment.

On May 22, 2024 at 09:15 during day shift, Injection Molding Operator James Thompson (EMP-00029) was working at Line D when he briefly contacted a cooling water line that had developed a hairline fracture. The pressurized line sprayed hot water (approximately 65°C) onto his right forearm, resulting in first and superficial second-degree thermal burns across an area approximately 8 centimeters in length. James immediately ran cold water over the affected area for 10 minutes and reported the incident to his supervisor Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128). Sonia administered first-aid treatment using TechnoPlast's on-site first-aid station, applying sterile burn dressing and antibiotic ointment. The wound was bandaged with non-adherent gauze. James was monitored for signs of shock and remained at the facility under observation. Given the extent and severity, Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) from the HSE office advised that James proceed to a local clinic for professional medical evaluation and documentation, though hospitalization was not required. The incident was attributed to inadequate inspection of cooling water lines and lack of temperature warning labels.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Raoul Blanchard (Machine Operator) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B when he noticed excessive heat emanating from the hydraulic cooling system. Before implementing proper lockout/tagout procedures, Raoul attempted to manually check the coolant level by opening an access panel on the still-energized system. A pressurized spray of hot coolant (approximately 65°C) unexpectedly discharged, spraying his right forearm and hand. He immediately reported to first aid where the burn was assessed as a minor thermal burn covering approximately 8% of the affected limb. The incident was prevented from escalating into a more serious injury because Raoul wore his standard work gloves, which provided partial protection. Witnesses Sonia Dasilva (Assembly Lead) and two other production staff immediately brought ice water and activated the emergency response protocol. Root cause analysis revealed that the cooling system pressure relief valve had deteriorated, and the operator had bypassed standard LOTO procedures due to production time pressure.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 PM during evening shift, Oscar Ramirez (Regrind Technician) was operating the plastic material regrind system in the Regrind and Recycling Department when a mechanical jam occurred in the grinding chamber. Following standard procedure, Oscar initiated an emergency stop and attempted to manually clear the jam using a wooden dowel stick through the access port. However, the grinding blade had not fully stopped rotating—approximately 8 seconds had elapsed since the emergency stop button was pressed. As Oscar inserted the dowel, it contacted the still-moving blade, causing the dowel to splinter and propel fragments into his left eye and face. Oscar immediately reported severe eye pain and vision disturbance. He was transported by company vehicle to the nearby urgent care clinic where ophthalmological assessment revealed a corneal abrasion and multiple small lacerations to the left eyelid. The incident occurred because the emergency stop system had a delayed response time of 7-10 seconds rather than the required 3-second maximum. Witness Abdul Rahman (Machine Operator - Evening Shift) called for medical assistance and documented the incident timeline.

On April 5, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift operations, Olga Ivanova (Composite Materials Technician) and Elena Vasquez (Assembly Operator) were preparing resin dryer equipment in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. The dryer had been set to preheat to 180°C for the morning composite material batch. Olga manually checked the internal chamber temperature by briefly opening the dryer door—a violation of standard operating procedures that requires waiting 15 minutes after power-down before manual temperature verification. A sudden surge of superheated air and steam escaped, delivering severe thermal burns to Olga's face, neck, and upper chest area (estimated 12-15% total body surface area). Elena immediately activated the emergency shower station and called for medical assistance. TechnoPlast security and first responders arrived within 8 minutes; Olga was transported by ambulance to the regional burn center in Laval with burns classified as second-degree (partial thickness) requiring hospitalization and specialized wound care for approximately 21 days. Root cause investigation determined that: (1) the dryer's internal temperature sensor had malfunctioned, causing actual chamber temperature to exceed setpoint by 45°C, (2) Olga had not received recent refresher training on resin dryer hazards, and (3) no automated temperature cutoff safety system existed to prevent over-temperature conditions.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Maya Kumar (EMP-00138) was operating Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone when she inadvertently touched a hot mold surface while removing a finished component. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C. Maya sustained a thermal burn to her right palm and inner fingers. She immediately notified her supervisor and reported to the first aid station where the burn was assessed and treated with cool water irrigation and sterile dressing. The injury resulted in redness and mild blistering covering approximately 2% of body surface area. Witness Sébastien Carrier (EMP-00065), the Production Engineer, was present during the incident and confirmed that the thermal warning label on the mold was faded and barely visible. Root cause analysis determined inadequate hazard communication and insufficient cooling time protocols before manual part removal. The employee received first aid treatment and returned to light duty within 2 hours, with full recovery expected within 5 days.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) was performing routine maintenance on an overhead crane system in the Warehouse and Shipping area when a corroded support bracket failed catastrophically. The bracket, which had not been inspected in 18 months, gave way causing a 150-pound steel cable tensioner to fall onto a storage rack containing high-value medical device molds. The impact damaged approximately 12 precision molds valued at $185,000, and bent the storage rack frame beyond repair, causing approximately $28,000 in property damage. The tensioner itself sustained damage valued at $6,500. No employees were injured as the area had been cleared during maintenance operations. Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) was present as a safety observer and documented the incident. The root cause was deferred preventive maintenance and lack of proper inspection scheduling for critical load-bearing equipment.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing cleaning and resin mixing in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when he accidentally knocked over a 55-liter drum of acetone solvent while retrieving materials from a storage shelf. The drum fell to the concrete floor, rupturing a seam and releasing approximately 48 liters of acetone into the facility. The spill covered an area of approximately 320 square feet across the floor and began pooling near a drain system that connects to the municipal storm water system. The strong acetone vapor created hazardous air conditions, triggering the facility's chemical alarm system at 1:35 AM. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) responded immediately, initiating emergency spill procedures. The area was evacuated, ventilation fans were maximized, and absorbent material was deployed. The spill was fully contained and remediated by 3:00 AM. No environmental release to external systems occurred. Root causes included inadequate storage rack stability, lack of secondary containment, and insufficient labeling of chemical storage areas.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was removing finished parts from Injection Molding Line D when he made contact with residual hot plastic material on the mold surface. The material, cooling to approximately 85°C, caused a second-degree thermal burn to his left palm and fingers. The incident occurred during the evening shift transition when production was being ramped down. Christian had removed his heat-resistant gloves momentarily to inspect a part's surface finish, failing to wait for the standard 5-minute cooling period after mold opening. First aid was immediately administered by the shift supervisor Julie Bergeron, who applied cool running water for 15 minutes and applied sterile gauze dressing. The injury did not require hospitalization but necessitated medical attention at the on-site occupational health clinic where the burn was documented and treated with antibiotic ointment. Christian was cleared for light duty work after 2 days with restrictions on mold contact.

On March 18, 2024 at 22:15 during night shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was transferring a 55-liter drum of polyester resin into the main mixing tank when the drum's lug cap failed due to corrosion of the threaded coupling. Approximately 35 liters of highly viscous resin spilled across the warehouse floor, spreading approximately 45 square meters. The resin mixed with residual moisture on the concrete, creating a slippery hazardous surface. Additionally, volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from the resin created localized air quality concerns in the facility's ventilation zone. The spill immediately activated the facility's chemical containment protocol. Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) deployed absorption granules and placed containment barriers. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was called to assess air quality and coordinate cleanup. The entire south warehouse section was evacuated for 90 minutes while ventilation systems were increased to maximum capacity. Cleanup required 6 hours of specialist attention and generated approximately 80 kg of hazardous waste requiring proper disposal. Estimated material loss: $3,200 CAD.

On March 22, 2024 at 09:30 during day shift operations, a catastrophic equipment malfunction occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (UNIT-017). Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) was removing composite test specimens from an industrial oven operating at 180°C when the oven's internal heating element support structure failed. The structural collapse caused the heating element to dislodge and fall, striking the oven's exterior steel casing with significant force. The impact created a large dent approximately 25 cm across on the front face of the oven, rendering it non-functional. Simultaneously, the internal element failure triggered a minor electrical short in the control panel, though safety systems prevented any serious electrical hazard. The oven, a critical piece of equipment valued at $185,000 CAD, sustained damage requiring complete replacement of the heating element assembly (estimated $18,500) plus structural repair work (estimated $8,200). The incident forced shutdown of all post-processing operations for 72 hours, halting production of 400 units of composite automotive components valued at approximately $32,000 CAD. An equipment maintenance technician discovered that the heating element support had never been serviced per manufacturer recommendations, indicating a maintenance scheduling failure. No personnel injuries occurred due to proper lockout procedures being in place.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 PM during the day shift, a chemical storage container in the Hazardous Waste Management Area began leaking due to corrosion of its metal base. The container, which held approximately 55 gallons of acetone-based mold release agent, developed a crack along a seam that had been compromised by moisture accumulation in the storage area. Within 20 minutes, approximately 12 gallons of the flammable liquid had spilled across the concrete floor and was beginning to flow toward a floor drain system that connects to the facility's stormwater infrastructure. Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) discovered the leak while conducting routine inventory checks. He immediately notified Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), who activated the spill response protocol. The area was evacuated, secondary containment materials were deployed, and the spill was contained and cleaned up within 90 minutes. No personnel were exposed to vapors or direct contact with the liquid. The incident was caused by inadequate container maintenance inspection procedures, lack of secondary containment infrastructure for bulk chemical storage, and insufficient awareness of corrosion risks in the humid Quebec climate.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072), a Production Operator on Injection Molding Line D, sustained a serious back injury while manually transferring finished plastic components from the production line to storage bins. The employee was lifting stacked consumer packaging parts (approximately 12-15 kg per lift) repeatedly without proper ergonomic technique or mechanical assistance. After approximately 90 minutes of continuous manual transfers, the employee felt a sharp pain in her lower lumbar region while lifting a bin. She immediately reported the injury to her supervisor and was assessed by Hana Al-Rashid, the Occupational Health Nurse. Initial examination revealed acute lower back strain with suspected lumbar disc involvement. The employee was unable to continue work and was sent for medical evaluation at a local clinic. X-rays ruled out fractures, but MRI confirmed a minor disc bulge at L4-L5. The employee required 8 days off work for recovery and physiotherapy. Contributing factors included the lack of mechanical lifting assists, inadequate training on proper manual handling techniques, and high-volume repetitive lifting tasks without rotation schedules.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during evening shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), a Machine Setter on evening shift, was transferring a 20-liter container of acetone-based mold release agent from a storage shelf to a mixing station. The container's lid was improperly sealed, and approximately 15 liters spilled onto the concrete floor when the container tipped during transfer. The chemical spread across approximately 8 square meters of flooring, creating a slip hazard and releasing volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors into the room. The employee immediately notified his supervisor, Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031), who activated the spill response protocol. The area was evacuated, and emergency ventilation systems were activated. Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the LOTO Coordinator, arrived at 11:35 PM to oversee containment and cleanup. Absorbent materials and spill containment kits were deployed, and the chemical was neutralized and disposed of according to WHMIS protocols. The room remained closed for 4 hours to allow adequate ventilation. Investigation revealed the container's seal had corroded due to improper storage conditions and the employee had not verified the lid integrity before moving the container. Approximately 300 liters of contaminated absorbent material required disposal as hazardous waste, generating approximately 45 kg of waste.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 7:15 AM during day shift startup procedures, a critical equipment failure occurred involving the cooling water system on Injection Molding Machine #8 (located in UNIT-004). Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), a Mold Maintenance Technician, was performing routine pre-shift maintenance checks when he discovered a significant leak in the main coolant distribution manifold. The manifold's internal seal had catastrophically failed, spraying pressurized cooling fluid (a synthetic polyol-based coolant) onto the machine's electrical control panel and surrounding equipment. Within minutes, the electrical system short-circuited, triggering the emergency stop mechanism and disabling the machine. Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006), the Maintenance Manager, arrived at 7:25 AM to assess the situation. The leak resulted in the loss of approximately 80 liters of coolant fluid, creating an oily residue on the production floor and presenting a slip hazard. The electrical panel sustained approximately $22,000 in damage and required replacement. Investigation revealed that the manifold had not been replaced per the predictive maintenance schedule (due at 8,000 operating hours; the machine was at 7,950 hours), and routine pressure checks had been skipped for the previous two weeks due to staffing shortages. The machine remained out of service for 18 days pending parts procurement and replacement. The failed manifold was dismantled and analyzed, revealing advanced corrosion and material degradation inconsistent with documented maintenance intervals.

On February 28, 2025, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), a Forklift Operator, was transporting a pallet of polypropylene resin (approximately 800 kg) from the Materials Management warehouse to the production floor. As he maneuvered around a blind corner near the Shipping and Receiving Dock, he struck Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), an Injection Molding Technician who was walking between production lines without looking at oncoming traffic. The forklift's left front tire ran over Patrick's right foot, causing immediate severe pain and visible deformation. Hugues immediately called for emergency response at 10:32 AM. Johanne Paquette arrived with the first aid kit and applied pressure dressings while immobilizing the foot. Emergency medical services arrived at 10:58 AM and transported Patrick to the emergency department. Imaging revealed a comminuted fracture of the right metatarsals and soft tissue damage requiring surgical intervention. Patrick underwent surgery the same day and remained hospitalized for 3 days.

On January 9, 2025, at 6:15 PM during the evening shift, Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189), a Mold Repair Technician, was performing maintenance on a 300-ton injection molding machine (Unit-B32) when he failed to properly follow lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures. While he was working inside the mold assembly, Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the LOTO Coordinator, was conducting a routine safety check and discovered that the energy isolation had not been fully completed—the hydraulic pressure relief valve had not been depressurized. Before Gaétan could intervene, a supervisor in another area remotely activated the mold closure sequence due to miscommunication about maintenance status. The mold began closing with Armand's left hand still inside the cavity. Armand suffered a crushing injury to his left hand with fractures to multiple metacarpals and crushing damage to soft tissues. He screamed and the operator immediately stopped the machine, but the damage was severe. Emergency responders arrived at 6:35 PM and transported him to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur. Despite surgical intervention, Armand required a 6-week hospitalization and lost use of two fingers on his left hand. He did not return to his technician role and was reassigned to light duty administrative work.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was operating Injection Molding Line B when she noticed the mold temperature controller displaying erratic readings. She informed her supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) of the unusual behavior. Before proceeding further, Julie decided to shut down the line for inspection. Upon closer examination by Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), a loose electrical connection was discovered on the heating element control panel. The connection was corroded and partially disconnected, which could have resulted in an uncontrolled mold overheating incident or electrical hazard if operation had continued. The issue was immediately resolved by reseating and cleaning the connector. No employee was injured, but the near-miss was recognized as a critical safety event that could have caused burns or electrical shock to personnel. The line was safely brought back online after verification of all connections and proper function of temperature controls.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the evening shift, Materials Supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031) discovered a significant leak in the composite materials processing area. A 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin had developed a crack on its lower sidewall, resulting in approximately 20 gallons of resin spilling onto the warehouse floor in UNIT-015. The spill created a hazardous situation as epoxy resin is classified as a chemical hazard with skin irritant and respiratory sensitizer properties. Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) was in the immediate vicinity when the leak was discovered. Valérie immediately implemented emergency response procedures by isolating the area with caution tape and evacuation signage. She notified Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) to coordinate spill cleanup and contacted the HSE department. The spilled resin was contained using absorbent material and disposed of according to provincial hazardous waste regulations. Air quality monitoring was performed to ensure no harmful vapors remained elevated. The defective drum was removed from service, and all other resin drums were inspected for similar damage before restocking.

On March 27, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) sustained a laceration to his left hand while performing routine inspection and cleaning of overhead crane components in the Materials Management and Warehousing area. While cleaning dried plastic residue from the crane's load hook assembly, Raymond's hand struck a sharp, burr-like edge on a partially broken bracket where previous wear had created an irregular sharp point. The laceration was approximately 2 inches long on the palm side of his hand between the thumb and index finger, requiring immediate first aid intervention. Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the facility's first aid response by alerting nearby personnel. First aid station personnel applied direct pressure with sterile gauze, cleaned the wound with antiseptic solution, and applied butterfly closures and a sterile bandage. After assessment, it was determined that the laceration did not require stitches but needed monitoring for infection. Raymond was provided with additional sterile dressings and clear instructions for wound care. An incident report was completed and the defective bracket was tagged out of service pending replacement.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained thermal burns while performing routine mold changeout on an injection molding machine in UNIT-004. The machine was supposed to be powered down and cooled, but due to a miscommunication between shift supervisors, residual heat remained in the mold cavity at approximately 280°C. When Conrad opened the mold to inspect the cooling channels, steam and hot plastic material sprayed onto his right forearm and hand, causing second-degree burns covering approximately 15% of the affected area. He immediately notified his supervisor, received first aid at the on-site medical station, and was transported to Laval Hospital for advanced burn treatment. The incident was witnessed by Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler, who assisted in providing emergency first aid and calling emergency services. Root cause analysis indicated failure to follow LOTO procedures and lack of temperature verification before mold access.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in UNIT-010 (Chemical Storage and Mixing Room) when Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147), the Regrind Supervisor, nearly collided with an improperly stored oxygen cylinder while moving between storage racks. The cylinder, which should have been secured in the designated compressed gas storage area, was propped against a stack of chemical mixing containers with only a single bungee cord securing it. When Normand moved a case of polycarbonate resin, his elbow brushed the cylinder, causing it to shift and nearly tip forward. The cylinder was caught by Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), a Crane Operator who happened to be in the area, before it struck anyone. The incident was immediately reported to Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator. Investigation revealed that a temporary storage solution had been implemented due to overcrowding in the compressed gas storage area, but no formal approval or safety assessment had been conducted. No injuries occurred, but the potential for serious injury from a falling pressurized cylinder was significant.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 5:30 AM during the night shift, Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler, sustained a serious back injury in UNIT-015 (Composite Materials Processing Area) while manually lifting a 40-kg bundle of carbon-fiber-reinforced plastic (CFRP) sheets from a pallet. The material was stacked at waist height without proper ergonomic supports or mechanical lifting aids. Mariam attempted to lift the bundle using improper body mechanics, twisting her torso while lifting with her knees locked. She felt an immediate sharp pain in her lower lumbar region and was unable to complete the lift. The material fell back onto the pallet, striking her left foot. Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate who witnessed the incident, immediately assisted and called for medical support. Mariam was evaluated by the on-site nurse and transported to Laval Hospital where imaging revealed a herniated L4-L5 disc and lumbar strain. This is her second back injury in 18 months. Night shift staffing was minimal (only 4 material handlers for the entire facility), contributing to pressure to work faster and take shortcuts on proper lifting procedures.
