Root causes included inadequate mechanical lifting equipment, insufficient staffing, and incomplete ergonomics training specific to composite materials handling.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was removing finished goods from storage racks in the Warehouse and Shipping area (UNIT-019) when she noticed that several boxes of packaged medical components appeared unstable on the third shelf. While attempting to redistribute the load to prevent a potential collapse, Bianchi carefully repositioned three heavy boxes of polycarbonate medical device housings. As she moved the third box, she observed that the entire rack structure seemed to shift slightly, though no materials fell. She immediately stopped work and reported the observation to supervisor Nicole Proulx. Upon inspection, it was discovered that two of the four anchor bolts securing the storage rack to the concrete floor had corroded significantly and were no longer providing adequate support. The rack was immediately marked out of service with yellow caution tape. This near-miss event could have resulted in a catastrophic failure causing multiple boxes to fall from an 8-foot height, potentially striking personnel below. The incident highlights inadequate maintenance procedures for metal storage infrastructure in the warehouse environment.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Production Operator Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198) was operating Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components Clean Room (UNIT-003) when she experienced a significant thermal burn to her right forearm. Hamdan was performing routine mold removal and part extraction procedures when the thermostat on the injection molding machine malfunctioned, causing the mold temperature to exceed safe operating parameters by approximately 45 degrees Celsius. The mold surface, which should have been maintained at 120°C, had reached 165°C. When Hamdan removed the protective metal barrier to inspect the mold temperature sensor, she inadvertently made direct contact with the hot mold cavity while attempting to extract a part. She immediately withdrew her arm and submerged the burn in cool water from the emergency eyewash station. A blister approximately 4 inches in diameter formed on her inner forearm, classified as a second-degree thermal burn. She was transported to the occupational health clinic for treatment and received antibiotic ointment and sterile dressing. Work-related time loss was 2 days. The root cause was identified as a failed temperature control module that had been showing warning signals for one week but was not prioritized for repair.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) was moving a pallet of glass-fiber reinforced nylon resin (approximately 2,200 pounds) from the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-015) to the Composite Materials Processing Area staging zone. The overhead crane was being operated at approximately 15 feet above floor level when Tessier heard a metallic cracking sound followed by immediate loss of load control. The hook assembly, which had been in service for 8 years and had never been formally inspected for fatigue cracks, fractured under the heavy load. The pallet of resin drums fell 14 feet to the concrete floor below, striking Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) on the left shoulder and upper back as she was walking across the staging area. Bianchi fell to the ground and suffered a fractured left scapula, significant bruising to her left side, and a laceration above her left eye requiring 8 stitches. Emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes. Bianchi was transported to the hospital where imaging confirmed the scapular fracture and a mild concussion. She was hospitalized for 2 days for pain management and observation. The incident resulted in 14 days of modified work assignment and significant investigation into crane maintenance failures.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:47 PM, a small electrical fire initiated in the control panel of Injection Molding Line B during afternoon shift operations. An operator, Stéphane Couture, noticed smoke emanating from behind the machine's electrical enclosure while adjusting injection parameters. He immediately activated the emergency stop button and evacuated the immediate area. The facility's fire alarm system was manually triggered by Celine Morin, a neighboring operator on Line A, who called out the emergency. Responding to the alarm, maintenance technician Daniel Kim arrived within 2 minutes with a Class C fire extinguisher and successfully suppressed the small electrical fire before it could spread to nearby hydraulic lines or plastic resin storage. The fire was caused by a loose electrical connector that had been gradually heating due to resistance buildup over several weeks. The connector was located near flammable plastic pellet storage materials. No injuries occurred, but the incident resulted in a 4-hour production shutdown while electrical systems were inspected and the connector was replaced.

On March 18, 2024 at 10:35 PM during the night shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when Louis Desbiens, a machine setter, inadvertently spilled approximately 2 liters of acetone-based mold release agent while transferring it between storage containers. The spilled liquid contacted a hot-surface element on a chemical heating unit that maintains compound viscosity at 85°C. The volatile fumes ignited immediately, creating a contained flame approximately 12 inches in height within the storage area. The facility's heat/smoke detection system automatically activated the fire alarm at 10:36 PM. Emergency responders from the Laval Fire Department arrived at 10:42 PM to find that Desbiens had already evacuated and that facility personnel had secured the area. Facility maintenance supervisor Daniel Kim used a Type B fire extinguisher to fully suppress the flame before external response. The incident was caused by inadequate secondary containment procedures and lack of clear separation between hot equipment and volatile chemical storage. The room was ventilated for 45 minutes before resuming operations. No injuries were sustained.

On March 22, 2024, Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, conducted a routine workplace inspection in the Hazardous Waste Management Area and identified a significant preventive safety concern. During the inspection, she observed that the secondary containment system for hazardous waste drums had degraded over time, with visible cracks in the concrete floor of the containment area and rust forming on the steel containment walls. Additionally, she noted that several drums were stored without proper labeling indicating their contents, cure dates, or disposal status. The inspection also revealed that the facility's waste manifest documentation was incomplete for materials stored over 90 days. While no active spill or exposure incident occurred, El-Khoury recognized this as a preventive safety and regulatory compliance matter requiring immediate documentation and corrective action. The degraded containment system could allow hazardous materials to contaminate soil and groundwater in the event of a drum rupture. The lack of proper labeling created confusion regarding waste classification and emergency response procedures. This preventive declaration was issued to address systemic gaps in hazardous waste management infrastructure and documentation before an actual incident occurs.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a Production Operator on Injection Molding Line C, reported experiencing significant pain and numbness in her right wrist and hand after completing approximately 6 hours of continuous assembly work on medical device components. The employee had been performing repetitive hand movements involving precise component placement and manual assembly throughout her shift without adequate breaks. Upon interview with the EHS Coordinator, Naomi described symptoms consistent with early carpal tunnel syndrome, including tingling sensations and localized swelling. The employee's workstation assessment revealed inadequate ergonomic support, with the work surface positioned 3 inches too high and no wrist rest provided. Naomi continued working but reported reduced productivity due to discomfort. This incident was identified as a preventive declaration—an early warning sign of a developing musculoskeletal disorder that could progress to a serious recordable injury if ergonomic conditions are not corrected. The incident highlights systemic issues with workstation design in the clean room production area.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a fire incident occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (Unit-015) involving a spontaneous ignition of composite fiber-reinforced plastic waste. Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), a Regrind Operator, was processing reclaimed composite material through the regrinding system when he noticed excessive heat generation from the grinder discharge. Within seconds, fine fiber dust accumulation near the grinder's exhaust became ignited due to friction-generated heat, resulting in a small but rapidly spreading fire. The flames spread across scattered composite dust and scrap material on the work surface before spreading to nearby stored composite resin containers. Mohamed immediately activated the nearest fire extinguisher and evacuated the area while sounding the alarm. Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, assisted with emergency response, retrieving additional extinguishers. Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), the EHS Coordinator, arrived and assisted in confirming the fire was extinguished before emergency services departed. Estimated damage to equipment and materials was approximately $12,000. Root cause analysis indicated inadequate cleaning procedures and lack of preventive maintenance on the grinder cooling system, allowing internal friction temperatures to exceed safe operating limits.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, an environmental incident involving a cooling water system leak was detected in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (Unit-013). Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), a Mold Maintenance Technician, discovered a rupture in a flexible cooling water hose connected to a CNC milling machine that had been operating unattended for approximately 3 hours. The rupture was located at a connection point where corrosion had weakened the fitting. Approximately 1,500 liters of coolant-contaminated water had spilled across the maintenance shop floor and continued draining toward the facility's storm water system through a floor drain. The spilled fluid contained cutting oil, metal particulates, and industrial coolant—materials classified as hazardous under Quebec environmental regulations. Réjean immediately shut off the equipment and called the spill containment team. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, responded and deployed absorbent materials to contain the spread, preventing further environmental release. The spill required professional cleanup by a licensed environmental contractor and reporting to CNESST and Quebec's Ministry of Environment. Investigation determined the hose had not been inspected during routine maintenance rounds, and no secondary containment systems were in place beneath the equipment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Natasha Ivanov, Chemical Inventory Specialist, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin from storage to the mixing station using a forklift. While positioning the drum near the mixing equipment, the drum's securing straps became loose due to improper fastening by the previous shift. The drum tipped off the forklift and ruptured on the concrete floor, releasing approximately 40 gallons of epoxy resin across an area of roughly 200 square feet. The spill created a hazardous slippery surface and released volatile organic compound fumes into the facility. Immediate response included activating the emergency ventilation system, cordoning off the affected area with caution tape, and notifying the Emergency Response Team. Cleanup required 4 hours using specialized absorbent material and proper waste containment procedures. No personnel were directly exposed to the chemical, but the incident highlighted critical deficiencies in material handling procedures and drum securing protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Line B experienced a critical hydraulic system failure. Andrei Popov, Hydraulic Systems Technician, was performing routine pressure monitoring when he noticed abnormal fluctuations in the main hydraulic pump. Within minutes, a high-pressure hose coupling on the primary injection cylinder developed a micro-fracture, causing a pressurized hydraulic fluid spray to escape at approximately 2,500 PSI. The failure forced an emergency shutdown of the line, which was manually triggered using the E-stop button. Hydraulic fluid (approximately 15 gallons) escaped and pooled beneath the injection molding machine. The incident caused Line B to be completely non-operational for 18 hours while the coupling was replaced and the system was flushed, bled, and recalibrated. Youssef Zaidi, the Line B operator, witnessed the failure and immediately evacuated the area. Investigation revealed the coupling had not been inspected in over 14 months, exceeding the manufacturer's recommended 12-month inspection interval. The equipment damage was estimated at $28,000 including lost production time.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 1:30 PM during the day shift, Diego Morales, Assembly Operator, sustained a thermal burn while working at Injection Molding Line D. While assembling consumer packaging components, Diego reached toward a freshly ejected molded part from the injection machine without allowing adequate cooling time. The part, still at approximately 140°C (284°F), made contact with the outer surface of Diego's left forearm for an estimated 2-3 seconds before he instinctively pulled away. The contact resulted in a partial-thickness burn approximately 8 cm x 5 cm on the forearm. Diego immediately notified his supervisor and was directed to the first aid station where Johanne Paquette, Emergency Response Team Leader, provided emergency care: irrigation with cool running water for 15 minutes, application of sterile burn dressing, and pain management with over-the-counter analgesics. Diego was transported to the occupational health clinic for professional evaluation and wound documentation. The burn was classified as a second-degree thermal injury requiring topical antibiotic treatment and follow-up care. Diego was able to return to modified duties the following day. The incident was attributed to inadequate cooling time enforcement and insufficient guarding of hot mold surfaces.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #12 in UNIT-002 (Injection Molding Line B - Automotive). While Pascal was wiping down the mold cavity with a cloth, a maintenance technician from a different crew inadvertently activated the machine's start button from the control panel, not realizing someone was working inside the mold area. The machine cycled suddenly, trapping Pascal's right hand between the mold plates. He sustained a crush injury to his hand with fractures to three metacarpal bones and significant soft tissue damage. Emergency response personnel freed him within 8 minutes. He was transported to Hôpital de Saint-Jérôme and hospitalized for 3 days. The incident occurred because the machine had not been properly locked out using LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures, and communication between crews was inadequate.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 9:45 PM during evening shift, the cooling water circulation system for the industrial ovens in UNIT-017 (Post-Processing and Heat Treatment) began leaking coolant from a corroded section of 2-inch copper piping near the main manifold junction. The leak was discovered by Stéphane Moreau (Mold Technician) when he noticed a puddle forming beneath the oven array. Within 15 minutes, the coolant flow rate had diminished by 40%, causing oven temperatures to rise uncontrollably. The oven chamber temperature climbed to 285°C instead of the normal operating temperature of 210°C, causing a batch of 180 composite material parts currently undergoing thermal curing to develop surface distortion and color variations. The system was manually shut down by Rashid Habib (Material Handler) following emergency shutdown protocols. Investigation revealed the copper piping had experienced progressive corrosion over 18 months due to inadequate water treatment chemistry and absence of preventative inspection maintenance. The incident resulted in approximately $24,000 in scrap material loss and production downtime of 6 hours.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during night shift, Nadia Belkacem (Receiving Coordinator) was retrieving raw material resin pellets from the upper shelving in UNIT-007 (Raw Materials Warehouse). She was using a 6-foot aluminum ladder positioned against the storage rack while collecting inventory samples for the morning shift quality control testing. As she reached for a box positioned approximately 5 feet high on the middle shelf, her left foot slipped on the ladder's third rung, which had become slightly greasy from residual moisture and dust accumulation. She began to fall but grabbed the shelf frame and prevented a complete fall to the ground. Her right knee struck the ladder's horizontal brace during her fall arrest, causing mild bruising and temporary pain, but she did not sustain a significant injury. She carefully descended and reported the near-miss to her supervisor Omar Said (Production Operator), who was in the warehouse area. The incident was documented as a near-miss because while there was physical contact and bruising, there was no lost-time injury or hospitalization. Root cause analysis identified that regular ladder maintenance and cleaning protocols had lapsed due to staffing changes, and the warehouse received minimal lighting at night.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Injection Molding Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was operating Line B in the Main Production Building when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the injection unit failed catastrophically. The valve, which had not been inspected in 18 months despite quarterly maintenance schedules, ruptured under normal operating pressure of 1,200 PSI. Pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the operator's station, coating the machine console and surrounding work area. Hassan immediately shut down the machine and reported the incident to his supervisor. The hydraulic line ruptured, causing fluid to drip onto electrical components, creating a short circuit that sparked near a pile of polypropylene resin bags stored 3 feet away. Maintenance Technician Vincent Letourneau arrived within 10 minutes and safely isolated the hydraulic system. No fire resulted due to quick response, but the incident highlighted critical gaps in preventive maintenance protocols. The equipment remained offline for 4 hours while repairs were completed. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury was notified and documented the equipment failure.

On March 22, 2024 at 09:15, Assembly Operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) was manually removing finished components from a cooling fixture at the Packaging and Labeling Station in the Warehouse and Shipping area. The components, small automotive trim pieces, had cooled to approximately 65°C (still warm but below the automatic mold temperature). As Fernandez reached to grasp the component with his bare hand, his palm made contact with a sharp parting line edge on the molded part that had not been properly deburred. The sharp edge lacerated his palm, causing a 4cm deep cut that severed a small blood vessel. Bleeding was immediate and significant. Colleague Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), the Assembly Line Lead, applied direct pressure and called for medical assistance. The facility's first aid responder, Tran Le (EMP-00036), arrived within 2 minutes and elevated the hand while maintaining pressure. Fernandez was transported to the local hospital where he received 8 stitches and tetanus prophylaxis. The incident resulted in 6 hours of lost work time and temporary loss of grip strength. Root causes included inadequate post-molding deburring procedures and lack of proper cut-resistant gloves for material handling.

On March 28, 2024 at 22:30 during the evening shift, Regrind Operator Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034) was processing plastic scrap in the Regrind and Recycling Department located in Warehouse Section C. A significant volume of acetone-based cleaning solvent had accumulated in the collection tray beneath the regrind hopper due to incomplete drainage of wet scrap material. Ibrahim did not notice the solvent pooling beneath the equipment. At 22:45, an electrical short circuit in the regrind motor (caused by a pinhole leak in the motor jacket) created a spark inside the wet environment. The spark ignited the acetone vapor and liquid, causing a flash fire that spread across the solvent-soaked floor area covering approximately 8 square meters. The fire triggered the overhead sprinkler system in that zone, which discharged water for 3 minutes before the fire was extinguished. Smoke filled the warehouse section, triggering the facility alarm system. Although no personnel were directly in the fire zone, the incident exposed serious hazard management failures: inadequate solvent containment, poor ventilation, failure to ground equipment, and lack of hazard communication regarding solvent accumulation. The department was evacuated; fire department response time was 8 minutes.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, injection molding operator Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) was performing routine mold maintenance on Injection Molding Line A when he accidentally made contact with a hot mold surface. While removing a finished part from the mold cavity, Zaidi's left forearm brushed against the mold heating block that was operating at 240°C. The contact lasted approximately 2-3 seconds before he pulled away. Zaidi sustained a second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters on his inner forearm. He immediately reported the incident to his supervisor Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141), who provided first aid with cool water and a sterile dressing. Zaidi was transported to the local medical clinic for evaluation and received treatment. The incident was attributed to inadequate awareness of hot surface locations and lack of proper thermal protective equipment being worn during mold handling operations. No production equipment failure was involved. Quality supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079) witnessed the immediate response and assisted with incident documentation.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 5:30 AM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (South Zone, Main Production Building). Material handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent solvent from the storage rack to a mixing station when the drum's bung plug failed to seat properly, causing approximately 25 gallons of isopropyl alcohol and silicone-based mold release agent to spill onto the concrete floor. The volatile solvent immediately began evaporating and created an inhalation hazard in the enclosed post-processing area. The spill spread across approximately 400 square feet of floor space and contacted the base of a wall-mounted electrical cabinet. Owusu immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency alarm at 5:32 AM. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) arrived within minutes and assessed the hazard, confirming elevated vapor concentrations in the workspace exceeding WHMIS safe exposure limits (measured at 1,850 ppm, limit is 400 ppm). The facility activated the containment protocol: activated ventilation exhaust systems, deployed absorbent spill kit materials, cordoned off the area with caution tape, and notified Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist. Hazmat procedures were initiated with professional cleanup contracted to an external vendor. The incident was traced to improper drum handling technique and inadequate bung plug inspection procedures.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Omar Said (EMP-00122), a Production Operator, sustained a minor laceration to his left hand while manually removing cooled plastic components from injection molding machine #12 in the Production Operations area. The incident occurred when Omar attempted to separate two parts that had partially bonded together due to improper cooling. His hand slipped across a sharp edge on the part, resulting in a 2-inch cut across his palm. The cut was superficial but required immediate first aid treatment including wound cleaning, antiseptic application, and a bandage. Omar's colleague, Léa Parent (EMP-00121), a Quality Control Technician, was working nearby and immediately alerted supervision. The wound was treated on-site by the first aid station attendant. No lost time was required, and Omar returned to work after 30 minutes of treatment. The incident was attributed to inadequate part design considerations regarding sharp edges and the absence of handling gloves for this particular task.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift operations, a chemical storage container malfunction occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142), Receiving Coordinator, was processing an incoming shipment of mold release agent when she noticed the top seal on a 55-gallon drum had become compromised, likely due to improper storage stacking in the warehouse earlier in the day. As she attempted to inspect the container, approximately 3 gallons of mold release agent spilled across the storage room floor, spreading approximately 15 feet across the sealed concrete surface. The spill created a significant slip hazard and minor fume exposure (acetone-based product). Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), Warehouse Supervisor for the evening shift, immediately initiated spill containment procedures, deploying absorbent pads and notifying the HSE office. The area was cordoned off, and ventilation systems were increased. The cleanup required 45 minutes, and the container was transferred to a secondary containment tray. Material value loss was estimated at $1,200. No personnel injuries occurred, though the incident could have resulted in serious slips or chemical exposure. Root cause was improper drum stacking without adequate support structures.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 4:20 AM during night shift operations, a significant equipment malfunction resulted in property damage in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), Material Handler, was operating the industrial shredder to process post-consumer plastic waste when a metal fastener (approximately 1-inch steel bolt) became lodged in the shredder's feed hopper. The metal object contacted the rotating drum, causing a sudden mechanical jam that resulted in catastrophic failure of the shredder's drive belt and bearing assembly. The impact generated sparks and a loud mechanical failure, causing an immediate shutdown of the equipment. The shredder remained inoperable following the incident. Samantha Brown (EMP-00146), Composite Materials Lead, who was on shift for material staging, heard the failure and verified Kwesi's safety. Inspection revealed approximately $18,500 in equipment damage including replacement of the main drive belt, bearings, and motor coupling. The fastener was traced to inadequate inspection protocols for incoming recycled material batches. No personnel injuries occurred, but the equipment failure resulted in production delays affecting the regrind operations for 72 hours pending repairs.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine part removal from a 250-ton molding machine in the Main Production Building's North Zone (UNIT-001). After completing the morning shift's production run, she began extracting cooled plastic components from the mold cavity. While reaching into the machine to remove a batch of automotive door handles, her right hand made contact with a sharp edge burr on an internal mold component that had developed from normal wear. The sharp protrusion cut her palm deeply, causing immediate bleeding. Yasmin withdrew her hand and applied pressure to the wound using a clean cloth. Her supervisor, Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), was notified immediately and assisted in cleaning and bandaging the wound. The cut required 4 stitches at the on-site first aid station. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) investigated the incident and determined that routine mold maintenance had not identified the developing burr, and that operators lacked clear procedural guidance on safe part removal techniques from aged molds. This preventive declaration aims to capture the near-miss potential and systemic maintenance gap before a more serious injury occurs.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), a Forklift Operator, was transferring pallets of raw resin materials from the loading dock area to the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-018). While navigating through the Warehouse and Shipping section, he noticed that several pallets of finished goods had been stacked directly in front of the emergency exit door marked with reflective signage. The blocking materials—consisting of three pallets of bagged plastic components awaiting shipment—completely obscured the double doors and prevented them from opening. Fontaine immediately halted his work and reported the obstruction to the evening shift supervisor, Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151). The pallets were relocated within 20 minutes using available forklift capacity. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) responded to conduct an inspection and documented that this was the second occurrence of emergency exit blockage in the past two months. The root cause was attributed to insufficient warehouse space management procedures and lack of clear accountability for material staging zones. No actual emergency occurred, but the preventable hazard created serious life-safety risk during normal operations.

On March 18, 2024 at 03:30 during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter on the night shift, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B's cooling water system in the Main Production Building. While adjusting valve settings on the recirculation pump to increase water flow, he did not fully secure one of the quick-disconnect coupling connectors. As he moved to the adjacent machine, the unsecured connector popped loose under system pressure, spraying cooling water mixed with minor traces of corrosion inhibitor across his work area and partially onto his left shoulder and arm. The spray lasted approximately 3 seconds before he manually shut down the pump. Desbiens assessed his exposure and determined it was minimal, with only minor skin irritation. Production Supervisor for night shift (on-call) was contacted and confirmed no chemical burns resulted. The incident was logged as a near-miss because the mixture was dilute and exposure was brief, but the potential for chemical exposure to resin fumes combined with standing water created secondary hazards. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) investigated and identified that cooling system maintenance procedures did not explicitly require verification of connector security before pressurizing the system, and no lockout-tagout procedure was in place for this particular maintenance task.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a serious repetitive strain injury to his left wrist and forearm. Over a 6-month period, Rémi had been manually removing plastic parts from the injection molding machine at a high production rate (approximately 2,000 parts per day), performing the same gripping and twisting motion repeatedly without adequate breaks. The part removal task required forceful pinching and rotation of the wrist. On the day of the incident, Rémi experienced acute sharp pain in his wrist while performing his routine tasks. He immediately reported the pain to his supervisor, Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), who initiated first aid and documented the incident. Medical examination revealed inflammation, micro-tears in the tendons, and early signs of carpal tunnel syndrome. Rémi was unable to continue work and was referred to occupational health services. The incident was witnessed by Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176), an Assembly Operator working adjacent to Line D. This injury resulted in 14 days of lost work time and required physical therapy intervention.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170), a Material Handler, was transferring a 20-liter container of epoxy resin from a storage shelf to a mixing station. As she lifted the container, she noticed the lid was not fully secured and immediately felt liquid beginning to drip from the container. The resin was dripping toward her face and upper torso. She quickly tilted the container away and called for assistance. Samantha Brown (EMP-00146), Composite Materials Lead, immediately responded and helped Chiara secure the container and place it safely on the work surface. The container was repositioned and the lid was properly sealed. No chemical contact with skin or eyes occurred, and no clothing was contaminated. However, approximately 50 mL of epoxy resin was spilled on the floor near the workstation. The incident was investigated immediately by Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, who identified that the container's lid mechanism had been damaged during a previous transfer, and the damage had not been documented or addressed. This near-miss demonstrated a critical gap in equipment inspection procedures and container handling protocols.

On March 28, 2024, at 6:20 AM during the night shift, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead for the night shift, discovered a critical failure in the cooling water circulation system serving the injection molding machines in the Main Production Building. The system had developed a significant leak in the main supply line near the connection to Lines B and C. Water was actively dripping from multiple connection points, creating a pool on the production floor approximately 2 meters long and 1 meter wide. The leak had been ongoing for an estimated 3-4 hours undetected due to reduced night shift staffing (only 20 employees across the entire facility). Michel immediately shut down Lines B and C to prevent further water damage to electrical connections and hydraulic systems. He deployed absorbent materials and cordoned off the affected area to prevent slip hazards. Upon inspection, the main coupling on the circulation pump's discharge line was found to have a hairline fracture in the brass fitting, likely caused by pressure cycling and metal fatigue from continuous 24/7 operation. The cooling system had been operating continuously for 18 months without scheduled inspection or replacement of wear components. The rupture caused estimated 2,500 liters of cooling water to be released before detection. Gaston Picard (EMP-00193), Crane Operator, assisted with containment efforts. This equipment failure resulted in 16 hours of production downtime while repair parts were sourced and installed.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine part removal from a consumer packaging mold when he noticed the mold cooling system displaying erratic temperature readings. As he leaned closer to inspect the digital control panel, the mold halves unexpectedly began closing due to a malfunctioning proximity sensor that had accumulated plastic residue. Jalbert's left hand was partially inserted into the mold cavity. He immediately withdrew his hand, experiencing a sharp pinch to his thumb and index finger. The mold completed its closure cycle within 2 seconds. Jalbert immediately notified his supervisor Sébastien Carrier (EMP-00065). Upon inspection, Jalbert had sustained minor lacerations and significant bruising to both fingers but no fractures or amputations. The incident was contained within seconds, preventing a more serious crush injury. First aid was administered on-site, and Jalbert was cleared to return to work after a 15-minute observation period. The faulty proximity sensor was immediately flagged for maintenance.

On April 2, 2024 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a Material Handler working in the Material Drying and Preparation Room, was transferring a 40-kg bag of polypropylene resin from a pallet to a drying hopper using a manual lift technique. The facility's ventilation system was operating at reduced capacity due to scheduled maintenance. As Saleh lifted the bag, she felt a sharp twisting sensation in her lower back and immediately experienced acute pain radiating down her left leg. She set the bag down carefully and remained stationary for several minutes. A coworker, Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), witnessed the incident and alerted the night shift supervisor. Saleh was evaluated by the on-site first responder (Gaétan Laplante, EMP-00161) and transported to the local medical clinic for imaging. Radiographs revealed a lumbar strain with possible disc involvement in the L4-L5 region. Saleh was placed on modified duty for two weeks and prescribed physical therapy. The incident investigation revealed that the employee had not been trained on proper mechanical lifting techniques and was unaware of the availability of assist equipment on the shift.

On April 18, 2024 at 6:32 AM during the early morning transition between night and day shifts, a fire alarm was triggered in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) following an electrical arc event originating from an aging fluorescent light fixture in Section B. The arc caused momentary sparking but did not result in an active fire. However, the alarm system functioned as designed, and all personnel evacuated immediately through designated emergency exits within 3 minutes. Emergency response personnel (including Raymond Tessier, EMP-00143, crane operator, and Hugues Fontaine, EMP-00167, forklift operator) assisted in accounting for all 18 personnel in the warehouse at that time. Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), Chemical Safety Officer, conducted a thorough walkthrough of the affected area and confirmed no active fire or hazardous material release. The electrical fixture was immediately de-energized, and the area was cleared for re-entry after 45 minutes. Investigation revealed the light fixture had exceeded its rated service life by four years and had not been included in recent preventive maintenance cycles. The fixture posed a potential ignition source given the presence of packaging materials (cardboard, foam, plastic) in nearby storage areas.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45, Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) was working at Injection Molding Line D when she experienced a minor chemical splash while manually adding mold release agent to the tooling system. The chemical contacted her left forearm and caused localized skin irritation and mild redness over approximately 15 square centimeters. She immediately rinsed the affected area with cool water at the nearby safety station for 5 minutes. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid assessed the injury at 15:00 and determined it required first aid treatment only: gentle cleansing, application of antibiotic ointment, and a light dressing. The employee experienced minor discomfort but no systemic symptoms. She remained on duty and completed her shift. Root cause investigation revealed that the squeeze bottle dispenser nozzle had a small crack, causing unexpected spray pattern during application. The incident was witnessed by Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran who was conducting line monitoring.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was unloading raw plastic resin from a delivery truck at the Raw Materials Warehouse. While transferring 50-pound bags from the truck bed to a pallet using manual lifting technique, she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. She attempted to continue working but the pain intensified, causing her to stop operations and sit down at approximately 22:30. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) immediately assessed her condition and contacted Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid. The nurse evaluated Chiara at 22:50 and diagnosed acute lower back strain with muscle spasm. Due to the severity of pain and limited range of motion, Chiara was unable to continue work and was sent home on modified duty. Medical consultation the following day confirmed lumbar strain without fracture. Chiara remained off work for three days, returning on modified duty on day four. Root cause analysis identified that the material handler was lifting bags improperly—bending at the waist rather than using leg strength—and that bags had been stacked at waist height rather than at ergonomic working height (approximately 30 inches). Forklift Operator Claude Poirier witnessed the incident and provided immediate assistance.

On July 22, 2024, at approximately 02:30 during the night shift, Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) discovered a significant ventilation system malfunction while performing routine equipment checks in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The HVAC system serving the chemical storage area had failed, causing the room's internal temperature to rise to 34°C (93°F) and allowing potentially hazardous solvent vapors to accumulate without adequate air exchange. Area monitors detected elevated concentrations of acetone and styrene vapors at approximately 45% of the OSHA Permissible Exposure Limit. Rioux immediately shut down active chemical mixing operations and evacuated all personnel from the affected area by 02:45. He activated the backup ventilation system and initiated emergency protocols. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid was notified and arrived on-site at 03:00 to assess any personnel exposure. Two employees (CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov and Composite Materials Technician Olga Ivanova) who had been working nearby for approximately 25 minutes were evaluated for symptomatic effects but reported no acute respiratory distress or neurological symptoms. Environmental monitoring continued throughout the remainder of the shift. The primary HVAC unit was found to have a seized compressor motor due to lack of preventive maintenance. No work-related injuries were recorded, but the incident represented a significant environmental and health hazard.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Mold Technician Stéphane Moreau was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone. While removing excess plastic flash from a completed mold using a handheld scraping tool, Moreau inadvertently contacted the mold release agent residue on the mold surface with his unprotected left hand. Within minutes, he experienced localized skin irritation, redness, and mild burning sensation across his palm and fingers. The mold release agent (silicone-based) caused contact dermatitis. Moreau immediately washed his hands thoroughly with soap and water at the nearby washstation and reported the incident to his supervisor, Valérie Pelletier. First aid treatment consisted of applying a cooling compress and antihistamine cream. The irritation subsided within 2 hours. No lost time occurred, and the employee returned to full duties the same day after decontamination.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le was transferring acetone solvent from a 5-liter container to smaller 500ml bottles for distribution to production stations in the Injection Molding Line C clean room area. Le was working alone in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room without adequate ventilation activated. While pouring acetone, approximately 200ml was spilled on the work surface due to an unsteady hand grip on the container. The spill immediately evaporated, creating a high concentration of acetone vapor in the confined space. Within 10 minutes, Le experienced dizziness, mild headache, and eye irritation but did not immediately evacuate. A facilities technician, Georges Plante, entered the room for a scheduled equipment inspection at 10:28 PM and detected the strong chemical odor. Plante immediately notified Le to evacuate and activated the emergency ventilation system. Le moved to fresh air and symptoms resolved within 20 minutes. First aid consisted of flushing eyes with water and providing oxygen via the facility's emergency oxygen system. The incident was reported to the HSE department with no lost time.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, Composite Materials Operator Rania Abdallah was processing glass-fiber reinforced plastic materials on a fiber composite layup workstation in the Medical Components production area (UNIT-003). While manually layering pre-cut glass fiber sheets onto a mold using a hand roller to compress and bond the material, Abdallah did not notice that a sharp edge of the glass fiber mat had protruded slightly above the work surface. As she rolled across the area, the fiber mat edge caught the exposed skin on her left forearm, causing a 3-inch laceration with minor glass fiber fragments embedded in the wound. The cut was approximately 0.25 inches deep with moderate bleeding. Abdallah immediately applied direct pressure using a clean cloth and alerted her shift supervisor, Carlos Rodriguez, who was performing equipment inspections. Rodriguez applied first aid including wound cleaning, removal of visible glass fiber fragments using tweezers, and a sterile dressing with antibiotic ointment. The wound required 4 sutures at the on-site medical station. Abdallah experienced pain and swelling but continued working light-duty tasks for the remainder of the shift. X-rays confirmed no retained glass fragments. Incident was classified as recordable but non-hospitalized injury.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a Production Operator on the day shift, noticed a slow chemical odor emanating from the resin mixing station in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT area). Upon investigation, she discovered a hairline crack in a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin that had been stored for approximately 3 weeks. The drum was positioned on a lower shelf, and approximately 2-3 liters of resin had leaked onto the concrete floor, creating a slick surface and releasing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the air. The employee immediately notified her supervisor and evacuated the area. No personnel were directly exposed to high concentrations of fumes. The leak was contained using absorbent material and the damaged drum was transferred to the waste management area. This preventive declaration was made to highlight inadequate drum inspection procedures and deteriorating storage conditions that could have resulted in significant environmental and health hazards.

On April 8, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a Machine Operator, was operating Injection Molding Line C when the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned during routine part production. The valve, which should have released pressure at 1,500 PSI, failed to activate at the proper threshold. Pressure built to approximately 1,850 PSI before a secondary safety interlock detected the overpressure condition and automatically shut down the machine. No personnel were injured, but the excessive pressure caused a hairline fracture in the hydraulic line coupling, resulting in a slow spray of hydraulic fluid onto the production floor over approximately 8 minutes before automatic shutdown occurred. The hydraulic fluid created a slipping hazard and left a 15-square-foot contamination zone. Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), the Hydraulic Systems Technician, was called to repair the coupling and inspect the relief valve. The relief valve was found to have internal spool stiction due to inadequate maintenance intervals, preventing proper pressure regulation.

On May 22, 2024 at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Nour Jaber (EMP-00188), a Packaging Operator, was manually removing completed composite parts from a heat treatment fixture at the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. The fixture had been cooling for approximately 30 minutes but retained significant residual heat (approximately 65°C). While gripping a large fiber-reinforced composite housing with his ungloved left hand, Jaber's grip slipped on the still-warm part. As he attempted to regain grip, his left index and middle fingers made contact with an exposed edge of the heating element cavity on the fixture itself, causing a superficial thermal burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters on the palmar surface of both fingers. The employee immediately withdrew his hand and reported the incident to his supervisor, Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), who was working in the receiving area. First aid was administered immediately, and the employee was transported to the local urgent care facility for treatment and wound assessment. Medical evaluation determined the burn was first-degree with minor second-degree involvement and required 7 days of modified duty assignment. Root cause analysis revealed that heat-resistant work gloves were not provided at the station despite high-temperature operations, and no cooling indicators were present on the fixture to signal safe handling temperatures.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift, machine setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was performing routine maintenance on injection molding machine #12 in the Main Production Building. Following established LOTO procedures, Ibrahim locked out the machine and placed a tagout notice. However, another operator, Céline Morin (EMP-00153), was unaware that maintenance was in progress and attempted to restart the machine for a new production run. The sudden startup caused the machine's hydraulic arm to activate violently, striking Ibrahim's left shoulder and upper back as he was working near the mold cavity. Ibrahim was thrown backward against the machine frame, sustaining significant blunt force trauma. He immediately reported severe pain and was unable to move his left arm. Emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes. Ibrahim was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé with suspected rotator cuff injury and multiple contusions. He required hospitalization for 3 days and was unable to return to work for 6 weeks, resulting in a lost-time injury recordable under CNESST regulations.

On April 8, 2024, at 5:15 PM during evening shift, warehouse associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) was performing manual inventory restocking at the Warehouse and Shipping facility. He was transferring 50-pound bags of raw polycarbonate resin from a pallet to a shelf at shoulder height when he felt a sharp pain in his lower back. The bags had been stacked improperly on the pallet, causing uneven weight distribution. As Yvon lifted the 7th bag using improper bending technique (bending at the waist rather than the knees), the awkward angle combined with the heavy load caused acute strain to his lumbar region. He immediately felt muscle spasms and could not continue working. Production supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) witnessed the incident and called for first aid assistance. Yvon was evaluated by the on-site occupational health nurse and sent home with instructions for ice therapy and rest. He missed 3 days of work and returned on light duty for 2 weeks with restrictions on lifting over 15 pounds.

On May 22, 2024, at 11:20 PM during night shift, chemical inventory specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) was conducting a routine inventory check in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility when she discovered a 12-liter container of unsaturated polyester resin that had developed a small crack in its base. The container was positioned on a metal shelf approximately 4 feet above the floor, and resin had been actively dripping into a catch tray below. However, the catch tray had overflowed, and approximately 8-10 liters of resin had spread across the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard. The resin fumes were noticeable, and the ventilation system appeared to be operating at reduced capacity. Natasha immediately evacuated the area, activated the emergency spill kit, and notified the night shift supervisor. She placed warning cones around the affected area and contacted the HSE office. The spill was contained using absorbent material, and the contaminated waste was properly segregated for hazardous waste disposal. Environmental testing confirmed no soil contamination occurred, and the area was decontaminated within 4 hours.

On March 15, 2024, at 10:45 AM during day shift operations at Injection Molding Line A, operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) was removing completed parts from the mold when he noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge reading abnormally high at 285 bar, compared to the normal operating range of 200-220 bar. Before adjusting any controls, he immediately stopped the machine and notified maintenance technician Réjan Simard (EMP-00077), who was working nearby. Upon investigation, Simard identified a partially clogged hydraulic filter as the root cause of the pressure spike. The situation was resolved before any equipment damage or personnel injury occurred. Quality Engineer Daniel Turgeon (EMP-00137) was present during the shutdown and verified that no parts were compromised. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the abnormal pressure could have led to hydraulic system rupture, hose failure, or sudden equipment malfunction if the operator had not caught the issue immediately. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette was notified and documented the incident within 30 minutes of discovery.

On March 18, 2024, at 2:15 PM during evening shift operations in the Composite Materials Processing Area, Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) discovered that a ventilation duct in the fiber reinforcement storage section had become disconnected from the main extraction system. This ductwork supplies fresh air to the resin-curing oven and should prevent volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from accumulating. The disconnection was caused by vibration from heavy compressor equipment located adjacent to the ductwork support bracket. Without proper ventilation, composite fiber dust and resin fumes had accumulated in the work area, creating an indoor air quality hazard. Haddad immediately evacuated the area and reported the issue to Director of Health, Safety and Environment Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001). Air quality monitoring showed VOC levels at 450 ppm, exceeding the TLV of 200 ppm for the resin components in use. The facility temporarily relocated composite processing work to an alternative area and scheduled emergency ductwork repairs. This environmental incident was classified as requiring investigation into workplace air quality management and equipment stability protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift operations at the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop, maintenance technician Réjan Simard (EMP-00077) was cleaning control panel components using acetone solvent when a 2-liter container of isopropanol (stored on an adjacent shelf) was accidentally knocked over by another technician reaching for tools. The isopropanol splashed across the work surface, mixing with the acetone residue and creating a reactive chemical mixture. Approximately 1.5 liters of the combined solvents spilled onto the concrete floor near electrical equipment and toolboxes. The spill created a fire hazard due to the flammable vapors accumulating in the enclosed space, and the toxic fumes activated the shop's air quality alarm within seconds. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was immediately notified and initiated emergency response protocols. The area was evacuated, ventilation fans were activated to maximum capacity, and the spill was contained using absorbent pads rated for flammable liquids. Laval Fire Department was called as a precautionary measure. The spill required 45 minutes to fully contain and absorb.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, was operating Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone when he attempted to clear a material jam near the hopper. He did not properly engage the machine lockout-tagout (LOTO) procedure before reaching into the equipment. When a colleague briefly restarted the injection system to assess the blockage, Pascal's right hand became caught between the advancing platen and the mold cavity, resulting in a significant thermal burn and laceration to his palm and fingers. The mold temperature was approximately 280°C. James Thompson (EMP-00029), working nearby on Line D, immediately shut down the system and activated the emergency stop. First aid was administered on-site, and Pascal was transported to the hospital where he received treatment for second-degree burns covering 8% of his hand. The incident was witnessed by Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171) and responded to by Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, who coordinated the medical response and initial investigation.

On March 19, 2024, during a routine safety inspection of the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A), Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), Safety Trainer, identified a significant hazard related to improper storage of propane forklift cylinders. Several propane tanks were stacked horizontally on a wooden pallet without proper securing straps or valve protection caps, creating an unstable condition. Additionally, the storage area lacked adequate ventilation signage and was positioned within 15 feet of the electrical distribution panel, violating CNESST safety regulations for flammable gas storage. The warehouse temperature had been elevated to approximately 28°C due to summer heat, increasing the risk of pressure buildup within the tanks. No immediate injuries or incidents had occurred, but the hazardous condition posed a critical risk of tank rupture, carbon monoxide exposure, or explosion. Karine documented the findings with photographs and coordinates with Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), Maintenance Technician, who was present during the inspection as a witness. The declaration is made as a preventive measure to address these violations before an incident occurs.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), Maintenance Technician on night shift, was performing routine maintenance on a resin dryer in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C). While inspecting the heating element connections, he noticed that the equipment's thermostat display was malfunctioning, showing readings that fluctuated erratically between 150°C and 280°C. Despite the erratic readings, the dryer continued operating at elevated temperatures. During the inspection, Alain observed visible heat distortion around the heating chamber and detected an unusual electrical burning odor. He immediately powered down the equipment and reported the malfunction to Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, who was contacted via the night shift communication system. Investigation revealed that the internal temperature control sensor had degraded, causing the heating element to cycle continuously without proper regulation. The condition posed an imminent risk of equipment fire and potential chemical decomposition of the plastic resin materials. André Bellavance (EMP-00157), Confined Space Entry Supervisor, was brought in to assess ventilation safety before further inspection. No personnel were injured, but the hazard was significant enough to warrant preventive corrective action.

On March 15, 2025 at 14:45, Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was performing routine setup adjustments on Injection Molding Line A when his left hand became caught between the mold clamp and the fixed machine frame. The incident occurred during the mold closing cycle after Ibrahim had manually repositioned a component without waiting for the automatic lock-out sequence to complete. A colleague, Production Operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008), witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button. Ibrahim sustained a laceration to his palm and contusion to his left ring finger. He was treated on-site by first aid responders and transported to the clinic for X-rays to rule out fractures. The root cause was identified as inadequate communication between the automatic safety interlock system and manual setup procedures, combined with time pressure to meet production targets. Ibrahim had worked 10 consecutive hours and may have experienced fatigue-related decision-making errors.

On March 18, 2025 at 02:15 during the night shift, the cooling water circulation system for the composite materials processing area (UNIT-015) experienced a catastrophic pump seal failure. Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) noticed a steady decline in water pressure and temperature readings on the monitoring panel at 02:10. Within 5 minutes, the system pressure dropped below safe operating limits, triggering automatic shutdown of the resin dryer and processing equipment. The pump ceased functioning entirely, preventing circulation to the three active composite molds in processing. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was called to the site and identified a failed ceramic pump seal with evidence of internal corrosion. Investigation revealed the cooling system had not received scheduled preventive maintenance in 14 months due to budget constraints, and mineral deposits had accumulated in the impeller housing. The equipment failure resulted in loss of 8 hours of production time affecting a high-priority medical device component order. No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident highlighted critical gaps in the predictive maintenance program.

On March 20, 2025 at 16:30, Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was unloading a pallet of polycarbonate resin from an incoming shipment in the Materials Management area when a stack of three aluminum storage racks on the upper mezzanine level became unstable. The racks, each containing 12 boxes of glass-filled nylon (PA-GF30) weighing approximately 25 kg each, had been shifted during earlier inventory reorganization by Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139). A box from the middle rack dislodged due to the unstable positioning and fell approximately 3.5 meters, striking Hassan on the shoulder and upper back. Hassan immediately fell backward but was caught by nearby shelving, preventing a more serious outcome. Assembly Operator Zara Khan (EMP-00106), who was working nearby, called for immediate assistance. Hassan suffered significant bruising, a sprained shoulder, and was transported by ambulance to the emergency department where imaging revealed no fractures but confirmed soft tissue injury requiring 5 days off work. Root cause analysis identified that weight distribution guidelines were not being followed during restocking, and no inspection had been conducted after the reorganization.

On March 15, 2024 at 10:45 AM, Assembly Operator Soraya Alami (EMP-00196) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station in the Warehouse and Shipping area when she experienced an allergic reaction to latex gloves she had just put on. She reported itching and mild swelling around her wrists and hands within 5 minutes of contact. A coworker, Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), noticed her scratching intensely and immediately alerted Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), the Assembly Lead. Soraya removed the gloves immediately and washed her hands thoroughly with soap and water. The reaction subsided within 15 minutes. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was called to the scene and documented the incident. The employee had previously tolerated latex gloves without issue, but this was the first time she had used a new batch of gloves from a different supplier. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the new glove batch contained higher levels of latex protein residue than the previous supplier's product. First aid was administered on-site with antihistamine cream provided from the facility's medical cabinet. The employee continued working after symptoms resolved and reported the incident to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) for formal documentation.

On March 28, 2024 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Quality Systems Coordinator Sakura Kobayashi (EMP-00158) was performing routine inspection of composite material batches stored in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop mezzanine. She accessed the elevated storage area via a fixed ladder with standard handrails. While retrieving sample materials from a shelf positioned approximately 2.4 meters above the main workshop floor, she leaned back slightly to reach a container and felt lightheaded and dizzy. She immediately experienced nausea, blurred vision, and mild chest tightness. Recognizing she was experiencing signs of heat stress and inadequate ventilation exposure, she carefully descended the ladder and notified Instrumentation Technician Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), who was also working the night shift. Vincent assisted her to a break area with better ventilation and provided cool water. Sakura rested for 30 minutes and the symptoms resolved. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was contacted and conducted air quality testing in the storage mezzanine. Testing revealed carbon dioxide levels of 850 ppm (elevated) and inadequate air circulation. The night shift maintenance had not activated the supplementary ventilation system as required by protocol. First aid consisted of rest, hydration, and removal from the hazardous environment. The incident was documented as a near-miss with first-aid intervention.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a catastrophic failure occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was operating the granulator machine when the main motor coupling suddenly fractured and separated. The coupling failure caused the rotor to become unbalanced, creating severe vibrations that propagated through the equipment frame. Within seconds, the vibrations caused the hopper support brackets to crack and weld seams to rupture. Metal shards were ejected from the equipment, and the hopper partially collapsed, spilling approximately 200 kg of recycled polycarbonate material onto the factory floor. The machine's emergency stop was activated by nearby operator Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142). Facility maintenance personnel discovered that the coupling had not been replaced during the previous scheduled maintenance cycle 8 months prior—it was listed as "acceptable" despite visible stress corrosion marks noted in maintenance logs. The incident resulted in complete shutdown of recycling operations for 6 days during equipment repair and investigation.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift, a serious chemical exposure incident occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017). Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was transferring epoxy resin from a 55-liter drum to a smaller working container when the transfer hose coupling suddenly disconnected. Pressurized resin sprayed directly into her face and upper torso, covering her safety glasses, nose, and mouth area with volatile organic compound-rich epoxy. She immediately experienced severe respiratory distress, burning sensations in her eyes and nasal passages, and acute nausea. Two coworkers, Layla Hussein (EMP-00098) and Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), witnessed the incident and immediately assisted her to the emergency eyewash station. After 15 minutes of flushing, Rania reported continued severe eye pain and respiratory difficulty. Local paramedics transported her to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where she was treated for chemical conjunctivitis and reactive airway dysfunction. Investigation revealed the hose coupling had corroded internally due to inadequate drainage between uses, and the pressure regulator on the resin drum had not been checked in 14 months. Rania was hospitalized for 2 days and missed 8 work days during recovery.

On November 22, 2024, at 3:30 AM during night shift, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter working the night shift, was operating the CNC milling machine to finish precision mold cavities for a medical device client. At approximately 3:25 AM, the spindle bearing assembly began experiencing excessive vibration and emitted an audible grinding noise. Louis attempted to reduce spindle speed, but the vibration intensified. Within 60 seconds, the bearing failed catastrophically, causing the cutting tool to shatter and embed fragments into the aluminum workpiece. Metal shavings scattered across the work surface, and the spindle shaft became locked, creating a grinding sound that lasted 15 seconds before the emergency stop function engaged. Post-incident inspection revealed the bearing had been in operation for 2,847 hours—well beyond the manufacturer's 2,000-hour service life—and maintenance records showed no lubrication service had been performed in the past 9 months. The milling machine was out of service for 72 hours pending bearing replacement and realignment. Critical mold orders were delayed, impacting client delivery schedules.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, noticed unusual vibrations and a slight burning smell emanating from the resin dryer unit in the Material Preparation Area of the Production Building. The dryer, which had been operating continuously for 18 hours without interruption, was heating plastic pellets to 95°C. Yasmin immediately notified her supervisor Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169), the Maintenance Technician, who arrived within 10 minutes. Upon inspection, Fernand discovered that the thermostat calibration had drifted, causing the dryer temperature to climb to 142°C—significantly above the safe operating range. The heating element showed signs of potential malfunction, with scorch marks on adjacent insulation material. Fernand immediately shut down the dryer and isolated it from the production line using LOTO procedures. No injuries occurred, but the incident highlighted a critical gap in preventive maintenance protocols. The resin dryer overheating risk had been identified in previous JHSC meetings but had not been formally addressed in the maintenance schedule. Marie-Claude Beaumont, Director of HSE, was notified and declared this as a preventive safety issue requiring systematic corrective action to prevent future occurrences and potential equipment fires.

On April 3, 2024, at 10:20 AM during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn injury while performing routine mold release agent application. Youssef was manually applying a silicone-based mold release agent to finished molds using a cloth applicator when the plastic collection container at the injection molding station malfunctioned. The heated residual plastic (approximately 85°C) unexpectedly sprayed onto his right forearm and hand, causing an immediate first-degree burn across approximately 12 cm of skin. Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), working at an adjacent station on Line B, witnessed the incident and immediately alerted the shift supervisor. First aid was administered by Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), the Warehouse Lead trained in workplace first aid, who flushed the affected area with cool running water for 20 minutes and applied a sterile antibiotic dressing. The victim was transported to the on-site first aid station where the burn was assessed as moderate (approximately 60 square centimeters of first-degree burn with minor second-degree involvement on the wrist). No hospitalization was required, but the employee received medical evaluation by occupational health services and was able to return to modified duty after 2 hours. Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), Workplace Safety Representative, documented the incident as a first-aid case requiring investigation into equipment malfunction and mold release agent hazard management.

On May 8, 2024, at 9:15 PM during the evening shift, Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078), an Assembly Operator in the Assembly and Finishing Department, suffered an eye injury while preparing composite materials for final packaging. Carmen was mixing a batch of epoxy resin and hardener in an open container when a coworker, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), accidentally bumped the workbench, causing the container to tip and splash approximately 30 milliliters of liquid epoxy directly into Carmen's right eye. The chemical splash caused immediate pain, redness, and partial vision obstruction. Elena immediately called for first aid assistance while Carmen went directly to the eyewash station and flushed her eye for the recommended 15 minutes. Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), the Facilities Maintenance Technician on duty, was present nearby and assisted in ensuring proper eyewash station operation and called the occupational health hotline for guidance. Carmen was evaluated by occupational health services via telehealth consultation and was referred to local urgent care for ophthalmological examination to rule out corneal damage. Medical assessment revealed chemical conjunctivitis with superficial eye irritation but no permanent damage. The employee returned to modified duty (non-chemical work) after 4 hours and received a full ophthalmological clearance the following morning. Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), Chemical Safety Officer, documented this as a first-aid incident involving chemical eye exposure requiring investigation into workspace organization and chemical handling procedures.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a forklift operated by Claude Poirier (EMP-00071) was transporting a pallet of polypropylene resin bags in the Warehouse and Shipping area. While maneuvering through the narrow aisle between two storage racks, the forklift's left rear tire struck a support post of the lower rack. The impact caused the structural integrity of the rack to be compromised, and approximately 12 boxes of finished composite parts (valued at approximately $28,000) cascaded from the upper shelf onto the concrete floor below. The boxes were damaged beyond repair, and the racking structure sustained a visible bend in the vertical support beam. No employees were struck by the falling materials as the incident occurred in an unoccupied section. Claude immediately reported the incident and work was halted in the area. Facility maintenance was called to assess structural damage and temporary barriers were erected around the damaged rack.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Celine Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine part removal from a mold cavity on a 200-ton injection molding machine. The machine had completed its cooling cycle and initiated the mold opening sequence. However, due to a hydraulic system malfunction that was not identified in the morning pre-shift inspection, the mold opened partially and unexpectedly reversed direction while Celine had her right hand positioned near the closing mold surfaces. Her hand became partially trapped between the mold halves, causing significant crush injuries to her right palm and fingers. She immediately called for assistance, and machine operators Emmanuel Kouassi and Abdul Rahman responded within seconds. The machine was manually opened by emergency release, and Celine was freed. She was conscious and aware but in severe pain. Emergency medical services were called, and she was transported to the hospital where X-rays revealed fractures of the 3rd and 4th metacarpals and significant soft tissue trauma requiring surgical intervention and a 12-week recovery period.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 3:30 PM during the evening shift transition, Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was conducting a routine walkthrough of the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when she noticed unusual condensation and ice formation on the ventilation duct work above the resin mixing station. Upon investigation with facility maintenance personnel, it was determined that the ventilation system's damper mechanism had become partially frozen due to condensation buildup, restricting airflow to approximately 30% of designed capacity. Real-time air quality monitoring showed elevated levels of styrene vapor (measured at 85 ppm vs. normal operating levels of 20-30 ppm) and isopropanol fumes in the mixing area where two employees, Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) and Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170), were working. Both employees reported mild headaches and eye irritation but had not yet realized the ventilation system was compromised. Nina immediately implemented emergency procedures: work in the chemical area was halted, employees were moved to fresh air, portable ventilation units were deployed, and maintenance commenced emergency duct clearing. No injuries were recorded, but this represents a serious near-miss where extended exposure could have resulted in acute respiratory health effects.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a high-pressure resin supply line in the Material Drying and Preparation Room ruptured unexpectedly while Naomi Okafor was performing routine equipment checks. The line, which feeds into the material hopper system, had developed a hairline fracture over several weeks due to thermal stress cycles. When the pressure reached 850 PSI during the afternoon production run, the weakened section gave way with a violent spray of uncured polyester resin mixture coating an approximate 15-foot radius of the workspace.
