The pressurized resin mist contacted multiple equipment surfaces, structural framing, and the floor area. Immediate production shutdown was initiated by supervisor André Paradis who was in the adjacent area and heard the rupture. The affected zone was cordoned off and ventilation systems were manually increased. Environmental containment procedures were activated, with the spilled material requiring specialized cleanup using industrial solvent and manual collection. Estimated material loss: approximately 250 liters of resin mixture valued at approximately $3,800. Equipment damage included surface contamination of three material bins and partial coating of the drying oven exterior. No personnel were directly contacted by the resin spray, though the incident prompted immediate evacuation of non-essential personnel from the facility section.

On April 2, 2024 at approximately 10:20 AM during day shift, Paul Demers sustained a superficial laceration and chemical splash exposure while removing a mold from an injection molding press on Line A. As Demers was using compressed air to clear plastic residue from the mold cavity, a small amount of residual uncured epoxy resin droplets sprayed upward and made contact with his left forearm and the inside of his left wrist. The chemical contact area measured approximately 3 inches by 2 inches and caused immediate skin reddening and mild burning sensation. Demers immediately notified his supervisor Mathieu Gendron and proceeded to the emergency eyewash station where he rinsed the affected area with copious amounts of water for five minutes. Following decontamination, an abrasion measuring approximately 1 inch was visible where the resin had dried on his skin, causing minor mechanical irritation. The incident was reported to the on-site occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid, who examined the affected area and applied basic first aid treatment including gentle cleaning with soap and water, application of antibiotic ointment, and a sterile gauze bandage. The nurse determined no systemic chemical absorption occurred and no hospital referral was necessary. Demers was cleared to return to modified duty with the recommendation to avoid water-based work for 24 hours while the skin healed. Documentation was completed in the workplace incident log.

On May 8, 2024 at approximately 11:15 PM during night shift operations, Martin Lavoie, the overhead crane operator, sustained a crush injury to his right foot while repositioning a two-ton finished goods pallet using the facility's main overhead crane system in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Lavoie had lowered the pallet to the loading dock surface and was attempting to make a final positional adjustment by moving his position to achieve better sight lines for mold placement. As he stepped under the suspended load to verify alignment, the safety cable attaching the pallet to the crane hook suddenly sheared due to accumulated corrosion and fatigue micro-fractures. The unsecured pallet fell approximately three feet onto Lavoie's right foot, crushing his metatarsal bones and causing severe lacerations. Night shift supervisor André Paradis heard the impact and immediately called emergency services. First responders arrived within 12 minutes and stabilized Lavoie's foot with an improvised splint before transport to Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM). Hospital examination confirmed multiple fractures to the right foot including the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th metatarsals, compartment syndrome requiring emergency fasciotomy, and extensive soft tissue damage. Lavoie underwent emergency surgical intervention lasting 4.5 hours. Hospital admission continued for seven days with discharge on crutches and non-weight-bearing status. Lost time from work began immediately and extended for 16 weeks during the healing and rehabilitation phase.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, suffered a significant burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. François was attempting to clean residual polymer material from a hot mold cavity (estimated temperature 180°C) using a metal scraper without waiting for the proper cooling cycle to complete. His left hand made direct contact with the mold surface when the scraper slipped. François sustained a second-degree thermal burn across his palm and three fingers, requiring immediate first aid and subsequent hospitalization for 48 hours. The incident occurred in the Main Production Building's North Zone. Coworker Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024) witnessed the accident and immediately alerted Raj Patel (EMP-00018), the Process Engineer, who initiated emergency response protocols. François was unable to return to work for 14 days, resulting in lost production time on Line A.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (Building 5). Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), Warehouse Supervisor - Evening Shift, discovered flames emanating from a storage shelf where acetone containers were stored in proximity to an electrical work lamp that had been improperly positioned. An inventory error had resulted in overstocking of acetone (flammable solvent with flash point -9°C) directly adjacent to the lamp. The fire reached approximately 1.5 meters in height before emergency response was initiated. Luc-André immediately activated the facility fire alarm and initiated evacuation procedures. Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), Inventory Control Specialist, assisted with evacuation while Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), Warehouse Associate, operated the chemical storage room's fire suppression system, successfully extinguishing the blaze within 4 minutes. Local fire department responded and confirmed no structural damage beyond charring on shelving and walls. Root cause: inadequate chemical storage procedures, improper placement of electrical equipment near flammable materials, and insufficient ventilation in the storage area.

On May 2, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Thanh Pham (EMP-00062), Maintenance Planner, nearly suffered a serious injury while performing preventive maintenance on a molding machine in the Main Production Building. Thanh was conducting routine inspection of a 250-ton injection molding machine when he discovered a tangled mass of air hoses and electrical cables beneath the machine's control panel area. As he knelt to examine and reorganize the cables to improve airflow for the cooling system, his right knee caught on a coiled air hose that extended unexpectedly across the walkway. Thanh lost balance and fell, his right arm striking the machine's metal frame. His colleague Soraya Alami (EMP-00196), Assembly Operator, heard the impact and immediately came to his aid. Thanh suffered only minor bruising to his right shoulder and elbow; no fractures were detected upon evaluation by occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052). The incident resulted in approximately 45 minutes of disrupted work and one near-miss documentation. Root cause: poor cable management practices, lack of protective covers over hoses, and inadequate workspace organization in the maintenance area.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Material Handler Rashid Habib was organizing stacked pallets of polycarbonate sheets in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). While repositioning a heavy pallet using a manual pallet jack, the load shifted unexpectedly as he was navigating around a corner near the warehouse exit. The pallet tipped slightly, and one corner of the composite material bundle came within 6 inches of striking Habib's left foot. He quickly moved backward and avoided direct contact with the falling material. Habib immediately notified his supervisor Michael Chen, who inspected the pallet configuration and the warehouse layout. The incident was a near-miss with no injuries sustained. Investigation revealed that the pallet had been improperly stacked by a prior shift worker, with weight distribution concentrated on one side. The warehouse aisle was also cluttered with packaging materials that restricted Habib's maneuvering space.

On March 19, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift operations, Production Operator Maya Kumar was performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Machine Line A in the main production building. As she was wiping down the exterior cooling water lines with a cloth, she noticed a small spray emanating from a connection point on the cooling circuit near the mold cooling manifold. The spray appeared to be warm water mixed with a light mist of hydraulic fluid. Kumar immediately stepped back and alerted her supervisor Maxime Boisvert, who shut down the machine and tagged it out of service pending maintenance inspection. No worker sustained any chemical exposure or burns. The incident was classified as a near-miss due to the potential for thermal and chemical exposure. Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux conducted an investigation and determined that a hose clamp on the cooling water manifold connection had partially loosened, likely due to thermal cycling stress and vibration from extended machine operation.

On March 25, 2024, at 6:20 AM during night shift operations, Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf was preparing Injection Molding Machine Line B for a new production run. While testing mold positioning with the machine in manual mode, he inadvertently activated the automatic closing cycle without proper notification to nearby workers. Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang was simultaneously reaching across the work area to retrieve a sample from the previous mold cavity when the mold began closing. Yusuf immediately pressed the emergency stop button, but not before the mold edge made contact with Zhang's right hand, causing a crush injury to her middle and ring fingers. Zhang was transported to St. Mary's Hospital in Laval where X-rays confirmed fractures in both fingers and crushing injuries to soft tissues. She was treated and released with a cast and prescribed 10 days of medical leave. The incident occurred because the machine's interlock system had not been properly engaged, and communication between setup personnel was inadequate. The night shift supervisor Roland Dostie responded immediately and initiated first aid.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, machine setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B when he attempted to clear a plastic jam from the mold cavity without properly engaging the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures. A coworker, production operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130), had briefly stepped away from her station. While Rodrigue was manually extracting molded parts from the machine using a small tool, the injection cycle unexpectedly re-initiated. His right hand was caught between the closing mold plates, resulting in a crush injury to his middle and ring fingers. The mold closed with approximately 2,000 PSI of force before the emergency stop button was activated by quality engineer Daniel Turgeon (EMP-00137), who witnessed the incident. Rodrigue experienced severe pain and immediate swelling. Emergency medical services were called, and he was transported to Hôpital de Saint-Jérôme where X-rays revealed fractures to both fingers requiring surgical intervention and a 6-week recovery period.

On December 3, 2024, at 10:45 AM, occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) conducted a routine workplace inspection of the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) during day shift operations. While observing chemical mixing operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) working with glass-filled nylon preparations, Hana identified several concerning practices that could lead to respiratory issues from composite fiber dust. The room's ventilation system, recently upgraded in 2023, was operating but showed dust accumulation on surfaces indicating incomplete capture. Elena was not consistently wearing the required N95 respirator mask during material handling, particularly when transferring fiber-reinforced materials between containers. Additionally, there was no secondary containment system for spill management, and material safety data sheets (MSDS) were not prominently displayed. While no immediate injury occurred, Hana documented these hazardous conditions and issued a preventive declaration to address cumulative respiratory exposure risks. The inspection revealed that recent staff turnover had resulted in inconsistent enforcement of PPE requirements and lack of refresher training on composite material hazards.

On November 20, 2024, at 2:30 AM during night shift operations, safety officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) received a report from warehouse supervisor about potential safety concerns in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) at the Maintenance Workshop. Upon inspection at 3:00 AM, Anh discovered that the mezzanine level storage area, which contains critical spare parts for injection molding equipment, had inadequate fall protection and insufficient lighting. The mezzanine lacks guardrails on two sides, creating a falling objects hazard for personnel working on the ground floor. Additionally, several heavy steel components (mold bases weighing 80-120 lbs) were stacked precariously near the edge without securing straps. Anh observed that tool and die maker Mario Bélisle (EMP-00149) had just completed retrieving parts from this area minutes before the inspection and noted that the nightshift maintenance crew (approximately 5 personnel) routinely access this location multiple times per shift. The current spacing between the mezzanine level and ground floor is 16 feet. Anh immediately issued a preventive declaration and temporarily restricted access pending corrective action implementation. The hazard arose from recent facility reorganization that had increased storage density without corresponding safety upgrades.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Elena Popescu, a Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring approximately 50 liters of acetone from a storage drum to a secondary mixing tank when the transfer hose became disconnected from the drum valve due to improper coupling. The acetone spilled across the concrete floor, creating a hazardous pool approximately 3 meters in diameter. The vapors rapidly accumulated in the poorly ventilated storage area, triggering the facility's volatile organic compound (VOC) alarm at 14:52. Immediate response included evacuation of the Chemical Storage Building, activation of ventilation fans, and containment using absorbent materials. No personnel were in the immediate vicinity of the spill when it occurred, preventing direct exposure. However, the incident revealed critical deficiencies in secondary containment systems and coupling integrity protocols. The spill was contained within 45 minutes, and the area was deemed safe at 16:15. Environmental samples confirmed acetone concentration reached 1,850 ppm, exceeding the OSHA action level of 1,200 ppm.

On February 8, 2024, at 10:30 AM, Luc Girard, a Maintenance Technician, suffered a laceration to his right hand while performing routine cleaning operations on a plastic injection molding machine in the Production Operations area. While cleaning the mold release agent residue from a 150-ton Engel injection molding machine, Girard inadvertently placed his right hand in close proximity to the open mold cavity during the automated mold closing sequence. The machine's safety interlock had been temporarily disabled by a production operator to expedite mold changes, contrary to lockout/tagout procedures. The mold closed, causing a crushing laceration across Girard's palm and three fingers. Immediate first aid was administered by on-site trained first aiders, including wound cleaning, hemostasis application, and proper bandaging. The laceration required three sutures and tetanus prophylaxis but did not result in hospitalization. Girard remained on restricted duty for five days. The incident investigation revealed that the production operator had disabled the safety interlock at 9:45 AM and failed to re-enable it after completing the mold change, creating the unsafe condition.

On April 3, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Jasmine Patel, a Quality Inspector, was conducting post-production inspections of finished composite components in the Composite Materials Processing Area when she experienced acute respiratory distress. She had been working for approximately 45 minutes in an area where glass-fiber reinforced plastic (GFRP) parts were being cured in industrial ovens. The ventilation system in the south section of UNIT-015 had been partially blocked by a misplaced storage rack, reducing airflow by an estimated 60%. Consequently, airborne composite fiber dust and volatilized resin compounds accumulated to hazardous levels. Patel complained of chest tightness, persistent dry cough, and shortness of breath. She immediately left the area and reported to the first aid station at 22:20. The on-site occupational health nurse examined her, provided oxygen therapy, and administered bronchodilator inhalers. Patel's symptoms improved within 30 minutes but she was referred to a local urgent care facility for further evaluation and pulmonary function testing. She was diagnosed with acute reactive airway obstruction and placed on medical leave for two days. Environmental air sampling conducted after the incident revealed respirable crystalline silica concentrations of 0.85 mg/m³, exceeding the OSHA PEL of 0.025 mg/m³ for an 8-hour time-weighted average.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. While cleaning the nozzle area with a cloth, the machine unexpectedly activated due to a failure in the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure implementation. The rotating screw mechanism engaged, catching Bertrand's right hand and drawing it into the machine. His index and middle fingers sustained crush injuries with partial lacerations. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) immediately halted operations and activated emergency response protocols. First aid was administered on-site, and Bertrand was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval. Medical evaluation confirmed fractures to both fingers and partial soft tissue damage requiring surgical intervention. The employee was hospitalized for 3 days and subsequently placed on 6 weeks of modified duty. Root cause investigation revealed that the LOTO lockpin was improperly seated and the secondary verification step was skipped by the operator due to time pressure from production scheduling demands.

On November 18, 2024, at 4:45 PM during evening shift, Amina Mansour (EMP-00044), a Material Handler in the Warehouse and Shipping area, was transferring chemical containers from the chemical storage section to the mixing preparation area. While moving a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin, Amina's gloved hand made contact with the drum's edge, causing a small abrasion to her left palm where the latex glove had a microscopic tear. Within 10 minutes, she noticed mild redness and slight swelling around the abrasion site. Concerned, she reported the incident to Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031), Materials Supervisor, who immediately directed her to the first aid station in the Administrative Building. Nina Santos (EMP-00084), the Industrial Hygienist, was notified and assessed the situation. The area was cleaned with mild soap and water, and a standard adhesive bandage with antibiotic ointment was applied. Nina verified that this was consistent with a minor allergic reaction response to the combination of latex and resin contact, though no severe systemic reaction occurred. Amina was monitored for 30 minutes and cleared to continue work with a replacement nitrile glove. The incident was documented as first aid only with no further medical intervention required.

On November 21, 2024, at 10:30 PM during night shift operations, Omar Said (EMP-00122), a Production Operator, was performing end-of-shift cleanup in the chemical mixing area (Chemical Storage and Mixing building). While disposing of hardened resin residue from a mixing vessel, Omar accidentally knocked over a 2-liter container of isopropyl alcohol cleaning solvent onto the concrete floor. Approximately 1.5 liters spilled across an area of roughly 4 square meters. The spill created a slippery hazard and released vapor fumes into the confined space of the mixing room. Omar immediately stepped back and reported the incident via radio to the night shift supervisor. Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), Environmental Compliance Specialist, who was conducting a routine facility inspection, responded within 8 minutes. She instructed Omar to remain at a safe distance while she deployed absorbent granules over the spill and increased ventilation by opening emergency exhaust vents. Omar experienced mild upper respiratory irritation and eye watering from fume exposure during the 4-minute period before proper ventilation was established. He was moved to fresh air and provided with water to rinse his eyes. Medical evaluation by the facility first aid responder confirmed no systemic effects, only minor mucous membrane irritation consistent with solvent vapor exposure that resolved within 30 minutes. The spill was fully contained, remediated, and documented per provincial hazardous materials protocols.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, noticed excessive vibration and unusual grinding sounds emanating from the hydraulic system of his assigned 250-ton injection molding machine. The machine had been operating continuously for 6 hours without scheduled maintenance. Rémi immediately halted production and notified his supervisor. Upon inspection by Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), the Hydraulic Systems Technician, a cooling water line was found to be partially blocked, causing system pressure to rise dangerously. The technician identified that the blockage was due to accumulated mineral deposits from hard water, a known issue that had not been addressed in preventive maintenance protocols. This discovery was made before any equipment failure or injury occurred. The machine was safely isolated and tagged out. This preventive declaration identifies a systemic gap in water system maintenance procedures that could lead to hydraulic system failure and potential operator injury from sudden machine malfunction.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, sustained a minor first-aid injury in the Warehouse and Shipping area. Hassan was manually transferring resin pellets from a storage pallet to a hopper feeder when he accidentally cut his left palm on a sharp, jagged edge where the plastic pallet had fractured. The cut was approximately 2 inches long but superficial, bleeding moderately but not profusely. A coworker, Julien Racine (EMP-00177), witnessed the incident and immediately guided Hassan to the on-site first aid station. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist who maintains the first aid supplies, was called to the warehouse. She cleaned and dressed the wound with antibiotic ointment and sterile gauze, then applied a pressure bandage. Hassan required no stitches but was advised to monitor the wound for infection and keep it clean and dry. He was able to return to modified duties (non-handling work) for the remainder of his shift. The incident was documented in the workplace injury log.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), a Regrind Operator, experienced a near-miss incident in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. Mohamed was operating the material regrind machine when he noticed that the safety interlock guard on the conveyor intake was partially lifted, likely due to accumulated plastic debris jamming the sensor. He was about to reach into the hopper area to remove the blockage when he noticed the warning light was not illuminated, indicating the machine was still receiving power. Rather than proceeding, Mohamed immediately activated the emergency stop button and locked out the machine using the facility's LOTO procedures. Upon investigation by Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), the Regrind Technician, it was discovered that the interlock mechanism had failed due to plastic dust accumulation around the sensor. Had Mohamed reached into the hopper without verifying the machine was truly de-energized, his hand could have been drawn into the rotating auger mechanism, resulting in a serious crushing or amputation injury. The incident was reported to Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123), the Incident Investigation Specialist, who documented it as a near-miss with high potential severity.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn while performing routine mold maintenance. Marcel was cleaning the exterior surfaces of a Husky 300-ton injection molding machine that had been shut down 20 minutes prior. Following standard procedure, he waited for the mold temperature to drop below 80°C before beginning work. However, due to a malfunctioning thermostat sensor on the mold cooling circuit, the actual mold temperature remained at approximately 110°C, though the digital readout indicated 65°C. When Marcel touched the mold surface with his bare right hand to wipe condensation, he immediately experienced a first-degree burn across his palm and fingers. The burn measured approximately 8 cm² with visible redness and minor blistering. He immediately immersed his hand in cool water at the first aid station and reported to the HSE office. First aid treatment was administered by the on-site nurse, including cleaning, topical antibiotic application, and sterile dressing. The employee continued working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. No hospitalization was required. Anh Nguyen, the Safety Officer, was notified and documented the incident.

On March 22, 2024 at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop mezzanine. Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), a Crane Operator, was repositioning a 450-kilogram injection mold assembly on an upper storage shelf using the overhead chain hoist system. As Raymond hoisted the mold, the lifting lugs (attachment points) began to flex abnormally, and the securing chain suddenly slipped approximately 15 centimeters before catching on an intermediate link. The mold drooped precariously over the storage area where Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, had been standing moments before to retrieve parts. Elif had stepped away just 30 seconds prior to obtain a work order form from the adjacent office. Had Elif remained in his original position directly beneath the suspended load, the mold could have struck him with sufficient force to cause critical injury. The incident was immediately halted, and both employees evacuated the area. Upon inspection, investigators found that one of the four lifting lugs was cracked, reducing load-bearing capacity to approximately 60% of design specifications. The chain hoist inspection records showed that load testing had not been performed in 18 months, exceeding the 12-month interval required by company policy and CNESST regulations. Serge Lafleur, the Workplace Safety Representative, documented the near-miss and initiated corrective action.

On April 3, 2024 at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Jade Wong (EMP-00140), a Process Technician, was operating a CNC milling machine to manufacture precision cooling channels in a complex automotive mold cavity when the automatic work-holding clamp failed to fully engage. The work clamp indicator light showed 'SECURED' on the control panel, but the clamping pressure had actually degraded to only 40% of normal force due to a leaking hydraulic seal in the clamp actuator cylinder. As Jade initiated the cutting sequence at high spindle speed (4,200 RPM), the workpiece shifted slightly within the clamp. She noticed the subtle movement in her peripheral vision just as the cutting tool began approaching the workpiece at high feed rate. Jade immediately depressed the emergency stop button, halting the spindle within 0.8 seconds. The cutting tool grazed the edge of the workpiece by approximately 2 millimeters but made no contact with Jade's hands or body. The tool tip did create a minor 1-centimeter scratch on the workpiece edge, requiring rework but not scrapping of the $18,000 mold. Investigation revealed that the clamping system's pressure indicator had not been verified as part of the morning pre-operation checklist for the past 6 weeks, following a recent shift in responsibility when the night shift supervisor position was eliminated. Zahra Nasri, the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, documented the incident.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Miguel Fernandez, a Material Handler, was operating the industrial shredder when a hydraulic hose connecting the main pressure system ruptured suddenly. The pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the equipment console and control panel, causing significant damage to electrical components, pressure gauges, and the control interface. The shredder's emergency stop mechanism failed to engage due to fluid contamination in the sensor lines. A secondary failure occurred when the backup hydraulic pump continued operating for 8 seconds before the system pressure dropped sufficiently to trigger the mechanical relief valve. Total damage included destruction of the control panel (estimated $47,000), replacement of three hydraulic hoses ($8,500), contamination of 1,200 liters of recycled plastic resin requiring disposal ($6,200), and equipment downtime lasting 18 hours. The incident was immediately reported by Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, who was performing a routine safety walk-through when the failure occurred. No personnel were injured, but the facility experienced significant production disruption affecting the composite materials production schedule.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during day shift in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (UNIT-017), Stéphane Couture, an Injection Molding Operator assigned to Line C, sustained a serious thermal burn injury. Couture was performing manual part removal from a heated mold cavity operating at 185°C. He was removing a polycarbonate automotive dashboard component when his right forearm made direct contact with the exposed mold surface for approximately 3-4 seconds. The operator was wearing standard cotton work gloves which provided insufficient thermal protection. The burn resulted in first and second-degree thermal injuries covering approximately 8% of his right forearm, including the wrist area. Immediate first aid was administered on-site by Luis Fernandez, an Assembly Operator and trained first responder, who applied cool running water and sterile dressings. Emergency medical services were called at 10:22 AM, and Couture was transported to Hôpital de Laval where he received medical treatment including pain management and burn wound care. He was hospitalized for 6 hours for observation and released with outpatient follow-up care. The incident was reported by Nathalie Dubois, Environmental Compliance Specialist, who documented the incident and initiated the investigation protocol. Couture has been placed on light duty pending recovery.

On March 19, 2024, at 11:30 PM during night shift operations in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009), a near-miss incident was identified and reported by Michel Laflamme, Warehouse Lead for the night shift. Elif Yilmaz, a Material Handler, was operating a powered pallet jack to move a stack of polycarbonate resin pallets (approximately 2,400 kg total) when she failed to notice that the dock's emergency exit door (located 3 meters to the right of the loading area) was propped open with a plastic wedge. The pallet jack passed within 0.3 meters of the open doorway. Given the dock's mezzanine-level storage structure above this exit route and the accumulation of small plastic component boxes on the mezzanine edge (approximately 15 kg distributed load), there was potential risk of falling objects striking either the operator or equipment if sudden movement or collision had occurred. Additionally, the open emergency exit violated facility safety protocols and CNESST regulations regarding unobstructed emergency routes. Michel Laflamme immediately investigated, removed the wedge, verified the door closure mechanism was functional, and documented the observation. He noted that the door wedge had likely been placed to facilitate ventilation due to the cooling system being offline for maintenance. No equipment damage occurred, no personnel were injured, and no actual falling objects were dislodged. However, the incident represented a convergence of three hazardous conditions that could have resulted in serious injury.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Injection Molding Operator Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159) was operating Line B in the Main Production Building North Zone when the hydraulic pressure relief system on the 250-ton molding machine malfunctioned. The system failed to properly regulate pressure during the injection cycle, causing the mold to open prematurely with excessive force. A partially solidified plastic component ejected from the machine and struck Marcel in the chest and right shoulder, causing significant bruising and a suspected rib fracture. The machine then experienced a secondary failure where cooling fluid began leaking from a compromised hydraulic line, creating a hazardous condition on the production floor. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux responded immediately, performing emergency shutdown procedures and isolating the equipment. Medical personnel assessed Marcel at 15:15 and recommended hospital evaluation. The machine remained offline for investigation and repair, requiring complete hydraulic system inspection and recalibration of all pressure sensors.

On November 18, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Assembly Operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040) was removing finished automotive trim components from an assembly line station in the Assembly and Finishing Department. While performing repetitive extraction motions on component number 847, Ana experienced a sudden sharp pain in her right wrist and hand. She immediately stopped work and reported the incident to Assembly Lead Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128). Examination revealed immediate swelling and restricted wrist mobility consistent with acute carpal tunnel syndrome exacerbation. Ana had been performing this same repetitive motion for 6 hours without break, extracting approximately 180 components per hour. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) responded and provided initial first aid assessment, recommending immediate removal from the assembly task and medical evaluation. Ana was sent to occupational health where imaging and clinical assessment confirmed acute repetitive strain injury requiring 48-hour rest and anti-inflammatory treatment. The incident was classified as a work-related musculoskeletal disorder with lost-time status.

On November 21, 2024 at 06:30 during the night shift, Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) was operating the plastic material grinding and compounding equipment when the hopper overflow material spill system malfunctioned. The regrind machine was processing recycled plastic scrap when the material feed sensor failed, causing continuous material input beyond the hopper capacity. Approximately 340 kilograms of plastic granules and recycled material overflowed onto the production floor in the Materials Management area, creating a significant slip hazard and blocking emergency walkways. The overflow also spilled into the ventilation intake area, potentially contaminating the air filtration system. Forklift Operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) discovered the spill during his rounds and immediately contacted Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069). The production floor was cordoned off, cleaned, and ventilation system inspected for damage. Fernand was not injured, but the spill caused a 3-hour production delay and required equipment shutdown for thorough cleaning and sensor recalibration. The incident highlighted inadequate preventive maintenance on material handling sensors.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Production Operator Naomi Okafor was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station preparing finished medical device components for shipment. While manually sorting and stacking completed plastic housings, she sustained a laceration to her left palm when a sharp edge on a plastic part broke during handling. The part had a manufacturing defect—a stress fracture that was not detected during quality inspection. As she was transferring the part to a labeling bin, the edge fractured and cut across her palm requiring five stitches at the on-site first aid station. The incident was immediately reported to Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc who was working nearby. The cut required cleaning, butterfly stitches, and a sterile dressing. Employee was able to return to modified duty after treatment, avoiding lost time. Root cause analysis revealed the defect originated from improper cooling during the injection molding process, creating internal stress concentrations.

On April 8, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, a fire started in the Hazardous Waste Management Area when a rag saturated with acetone solvent came into contact with improperly stored oxidizing agent containers. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard was performing routine chemical storage inventory when he noticed smoke emanating from a corner storage rack. The fire was small (approximately 2 feet in diameter) but growing rapidly due to the volatile nature of the materials. Girard immediately activated the facility alarm and used a Class B fire extinguisher to suppress the flames. Plant emergency response team arrived within 3 minutes and fully extinguished the fire using additional extinguishers and implemented foam suppression. No injuries occurred. Laval Fire Department was called as a precaution and inspected the area. Investigation revealed that acetone-soaked rags had been improperly stored in an open container placed directly adjacent to oxidizer containers, violating WHMIS storage protocols. The chemical storage building exterior zone lacked proper fire-rated segregation between incompatible chemical categories.

On May 2, 2024 at 06:30 during the night shift, an environmental incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room when the resin dryer thermal sensor malfunctioned, causing an undetected overheating condition. Production Operator Leila Farah arrived for her shift and noticed a strong chemical smell and visible steam escaping from the dryer unit. The resin material inside had reached approximately 180°C (normal operating temperature is 80°C), causing decomposition and volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions. The automatic shutdown system had failed due to a corroded sensor contact. Farah immediately shut down the equipment manually and evacuated the room, activating the facility alarm. The overflow of fumes was detected by building ventilation sensors. Environmental Health and Safety Officer Simon Bélanger arrived and determined that approximately 45 kilograms of polycarbonate resin had thermally degraded, releasing gaseous emissions that exceeded acceptable VOC levels in the production building air for approximately 20 minutes before ventilation systems brought levels back to normal. No airborne hazard remained after evacuation and ventilation correction. Local environmental authorities were notified per Quebec regulations.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) was performing repetitive part removal operations at Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone of the Main Production Building. She was extracting cooled plastic components from an injection mold cavity on a 300-ton molding machine. After working continuously for 4.5 hours without a break, Vasquez began experiencing sharp pain in her right wrist and fingers. By 2:30 PM, she reported numbness and tingling in her right hand, consistent with early carpal tunnel symptoms. Machine Operator Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) witnessed the incident and immediately notified her supervisor. Vasquez was directed to the first aid station where the HSE team assessed her condition. She was fitted with a wrist brace and instructed to report any worsening symptoms. The incident was attributed to prolonged repetitive gripping and pinching motions required during part extraction, combined with insufficient rest periods. No lost time occurred, but the employee experienced discomfort for approximately 6 hours.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was retrieving reground plastic pellets from the automated regrind storage system in the Materials Management area. The electric overhead crane operated by Machine Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) was retrieving a 500-pound bin of regrind material from the upper storage rack when a failure in the crane's cable support bracket occurred. The bracket, which had not been inspected since installation in 2019, suddenly fractured due to metal fatigue and corrosion. The 500-pound bin became partially unsecured and shifted, though the load did not fall due to redundant safety cables. However, the sudden shift caused the bin to strike the lower storage rack support beam with significant force, creating a 6-inch dent in the structural steel. The incident was immediately reported to Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049), who secured the area. A subsequent inspection revealed three additional support brackets showing similar corrosion patterns. Fortunately, no employees were injured, but the equipment failure created a serious risk of falling materials.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift transition, Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was performing routine maintenance on a 150-ton injection molding machine in the Injection Molding Line A when he accidentally contacted the hot nozzle assembly. The machine's temperature monitoring display had malfunctioned, showing an incorrect lower temperature than the actual operating temperature of 380°C. Caron was checking for material residue on the nozzle tip using an ungloved hand when he made direct contact with the nozzle body. He immediately experienced a second-degree thermal burn affecting approximately 15 square centimeters of his right palm and fingers. Caron withdrew his hand and immersed it in cool water from a nearby emergency wash station. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was notified within 2 minutes and arrived at 6:35 AM. First aid was administered: the burn was rinsed with cool water, a sterile dressing was applied, and ibuprofen was provided. The employee was transported to a local clinic where the burn was professionally treated. Caron required 3 hours of first aid and medical attention. The equipment display malfunction was documented as the root cause.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was removing a finished part from a mold when his right hand made contact with the hot mold surface. The mold temperature was 185°C, and Stéphane had not waited the full cooling cycle as production pressure to meet customer deadlines was high. He sustained a second-degree burn across his palm and three fingers. Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a Material Handler working nearby, immediately alerted Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), the Assembly Line Lead, who called for medical assistance. First aid was administered in the on-site medical station, and Stéphane was transported to Hôpital de Laval for further treatment. The employee required hospitalization for 18 hours and missed 5 days of work due to pain and limited hand mobility. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate cooling time protocols and insufficient emphasis on temperature hazard awareness during the recent shift change.

On October 28, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator, was conducting routine maintenance on a cooling water system in the Composite Materials Processing Area when he noticed a small pressurized leak from a connection joint on the main cooling line. The leak was approximately 2mm in diameter and spraying water at low pressure. Abdul immediately isolated the section using the isolation valves, depressurized the system, and notified Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), a Machine Setter, who was working on an adjacent line. Ibrahim confirmed the finding and together they flagged the area with warning tape. The incident was reported to Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, who documented it as a preventive maintenance discovery. No employee was exposed to hazardous spray or pressure release. The cooling system connection was scheduled for replacement during the next planned maintenance window. This near-miss was significant because uncontrolled pressurized spray could have caused skin lacerations or eye injuries if left unaddressed.

On December 3, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift operations, André Paradis (EMP-00037), the Production Supervisor for night shift, conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room as part of monthly HSE audits. While reviewing inventory records against actual chemical stock levels, André discovered that several containers of mold release agent (aerosol cans) were stored on a high shelf in close proximity to acetone containers, in violation of TechnoPlast's chemical segregation procedures outlined in the Chemical Compatibility Matrix. The aerosol cans posed an explosion risk if exposed to heat or static electricity near the volatile acetone. No employee had been exposed to this hazard because the area had remained undisturbed throughout the night shift. André immediately relocated the aerosol cans to a separate, designated storage zone with proper ventilation and distance spacing per WHMIS guidelines. He initiated a Preventive Declaration with Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, to document the storage violation, determine how it occurred (likely during recent inventory adjustment), and implement corrective warehouse management procedures to prevent recurrence.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, Assembly Operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040) was working at Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging zone, removing finished parts from the mold. While extracting components from the hot mold surface, her left hand made contact with a mold section that had not cooled sufficiently. The surface temperature was approximately 85°C. Silva sustained a thermal burn across her palm and two fingers. She immediately reported the burn to her supervisor Guillaume Deschamps. First aid was administered on-site with cold water irrigation for 15 minutes, followed by sterile dressing application. The burn was classified as a first-degree thermal injury with minor blistering. Silva completed an incident report and was advised to monitor the injury. No hospitalization was required, and she returned to modified duties the following day with protective glove modifications.

On December 2, 2024, at approximately 23:15 during the evening shift, a solvent container fire occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). Instrumentation Technician Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075) was preparing to clean hydraulic system components using acetone-based solvent. A 5-liter container of cleaning solvent was positioned near a workbench approximately 1 meter from an active arc welding station where Tool Room Technician Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173) was performing maintenance welding on equipment brackets. A spark from the welding operation traveled approximately 1.5 meters and ignited solvent vapors emanating from the open container. The fire rapidly spread across the workbench surface, engulfing approximately 2 square meters. The facility's automated fire suppression system activated within 45 seconds, discharging CO2 into the workshop zone. Both technicians evacuated immediately and activated the emergency alarm. Fire department response time was 8 minutes. No personnel injuries were sustained. The fire was fully extinguished by the suppression system before fire department arrival. Investigation revealed inadequate spatial separation between flammable material storage and hot work operations.

On November 28, 2024, at approximately 06:45 during the night shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Production Operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) and Packaging Operator Amara Diop (EMP-00110) were conducting routine material feeding operations when the main drying oven's heating element experienced a massive electrical fault. The malfunction caused a violent internal explosion within the oven chamber, rupturing the stainless steel housing on the left lateral panel and ejecting high-pressure hot air and fragmented internal components. The explosion forcefully discharged a 45-kilogram section of the oven's inner baffle plate, which traveled 3.2 meters horizontally and impacted a secondary storage cabinet containing colorant masterbatch containers. The impact destroyed the cabinet structure, scattering approximately 120 kilograms of plastic pellets across the floor and causing severe denting and structural damage to the adjacent wall. The oven itself sustained complete thermal shutdown and became non-operational. Both operators were standing approximately 4 meters away and were not struck by debris. They immediately evacuated the area and activated emergency protocols. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) responded and confirmed the oven was inoperable and the wall damage required structural assessment. No personnel injuries occurred, but equipment replacement value exceeded $85,000 and facility downtime was 14 hours until a backup oven could be brought online.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM, Injection Molding Operator Céline Morin (EMP-00153) was operating Line A when she inadvertently made contact with a hot mold surface while removing a finished part. The mold temperature had reached 185°C due to a malfunctioning temperature sensor that failed to trigger the cooling cycle notification. Céline immediately withdrew her hand and reported significant thermal pain on her palm and three fingers. A colleague, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), who was working adjacent to Line A, witnessed the incident and immediately directed Céline to the first aid station. Plant Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid administered first aid treatment including immediate cooling with sterile water, application of topical burn ointment, sterile bandaging, and pain management. The burns were classified as moderate superficial partial-thickness (second degree) affecting approximately 8% of her hand surface. Céline was able to return to light duty after first aid treatment but was restricted from operating Line A for 5 days pending medical clearance. The incident occurred during peak production hours on day shift with full supervision present.

On May 8, 2024 at 10:45 PM during evening shift, Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was transferring plastic resin pellets from bulk storage containers to the Material Drying and Preparation Room. While refilling a hopper connected to an active drying system, an equipment malfunction caused sudden pressure buildup, resulting in approximately 180 kilograms of damp polymer resin pellets overflowing from the hopper outlet onto the warehouse floor. The spilled material accumulated near UNIT-016's entrance, creating a slippery hazard and partially blocking emergency egress. Rashid immediately activated the equipment emergency stop button and reported the incident to Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151). Within 15 minutes, the warehouse had been cordoned off and Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123) initiated response procedures. The spilled resin—containing trace amounts of organic additives and colorant compounds—began to absorb moisture from the facility's 65% humidity environment. Environmental protocols required immediate collection and proper disposal as manufacturing waste. The cleanup required 3 hours of work, including vacuum collection of pellets, decontamination of affected floor area with industrial-grade cleaner, and proper segregation of contaminated waste in designated bins. No personnel exposure to hazardous material vapors occurred. The incident was contained entirely within the facility with no environmental release to external areas.

On June 22, 2024 at 6:30 AM during night shift, Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) discovered a slow drip emanating from a damaged pressure relief valve on a secondary hydraulic system located in Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). The valve—part of the automated robotic arm's secondary brake system—had developed a micro-fracture, releasing approximately 2.8 liters of ISO VG 46 hydraulic fluid over an estimated 18-hour period onto the workshop floor and into the facility's integrated drainage system. The fluid had partially migrated toward a floor drain that connects to the external stormwater management system. Michel immediately shut down the affected robotic arm and notified Maintenance and Engineering personnel. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) was called to assess potential environmental release and implement containment measures. The affected floor area was cordoned off, and absorbent material was deployed to prevent further migration. Analysis confirmed that approximately 1.2 liters had reached the external storm drain system before the leak was discovered. Although the volume and composition (synthetic ISO hydraulic fluid) posed minimal acute toxicity risk, the incident violated Quebec environmental regulations regarding fluid discharge without treatment to natural water systems. The facility's Environmental Management System (ISO 14001:2015) required notification to CNESST within 48 hours and implementation of corrective actions to prevent recurrence. No personnel were exposed to hazardous vapors due to night shift minimal occupancy and adequate ventilation in the workshop area.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a Production Operator at Injection Molding Line A, suffered a thermal burn while clearing a material jam from the injection molding machine. The machine had been running ABS resin at 240°C. Following standard procedure, Leila attempted to remove partially solidified plastic from the barrel entrance using a metal tool without first allowing adequate cooling time. The residual heat from the resin and the heated barrel made contact with her right forearm, causing a first-degree burn approximately 3 inches in diameter. She immediately reported the incident to her line supervisor and went to the on-site medical station. The occupational health nurse, Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), provided initial treatment including cold water irrigation, application of antibiotic ointment, and a sterile dressing. The employee did not require hospitalization but was advised to monitor for signs of infection. The incident was caused by insufficient cooling time protocols and the employee's limited awareness of residual heat dangers after machine shutdown.

On March 18, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, a pressurized hydraulic line ruptured on Injection Molding Line D while the machine was operating. Gaston Picard (EMP-00193), a Crane Operator who was performing routine material transport nearby, heard a sudden hissing sound followed by a loud bang. A section of the high-pressure line carrying hydraulic fluid at 2800 PSI failed catastrophically due to metal fatigue and corrosion that had gone undetected during routine maintenance. The pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the work area, and the sudden pressure release caused a powerful directional jet that struck Gaston's left shoulder and chest. He was knocked backward approximately 6 feet, suffering a crush injury and partial laceration from the debris. The night shift supervisor immediately called emergency services. Gaston was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur and admitted with multiple fractured ribs, a fractured left clavicle, and deep tissue contusion requiring 6 days of hospitalization. The incident investigation revealed that the hydraulic line had not been pressure-tested during the previous month's maintenance cycle.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM during the day shift, a forklift collision occurred at the Shipping and Receiving Dock. Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), a Crane Operator, was operating a propane-powered forklift to reposition pallets of finished composite components when the vehicle's brake pedal became unresponsive due to a hydraulic seal failure. The forklift was moving at approximately 8 km/h across the dock when Raymond applied the brakes to avoid a stack of incoming raw materials. The brakes failed completely, and the forklift continued forward, striking three wooden pallets containing approximately 1,200 kg of finished polycarbonate injection-molded automotive components valued at approximately $38,000. The pallets were damaged and the components shattered due to impact. Fortunately, no personnel were in the direct path at the moment of impact—the dock was relatively clear due to the shift change. However, David O'Connor (EMP-00010), the Warehouse Supervisor, witnessed the incident from approximately 15 meters away. The forklift itself sustained damage to the front frame and bumper. The incident was caused by deferred maintenance on the forklift's brake hydraulic system; the vehicle had been flagged for inspection 6 weeks prior but the work had not been completed due to scheduling conflicts.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, the primary resin dryer unit in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility experienced a catastrophic failure. Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147), Regrind Supervisor, was monitoring the dryer's heating cycle when the temperature control thermostat malfunctioned, causing the internal chamber temperature to spike to 285°C—well above the safe operating limit of 120°C. The heating element failed to de-energize, and internal pressure built rapidly. At 14:52, a rupture occurred in the dryer's side panel, expelling hot resin vapor and fragments of composite material throughout the facility section. The incident resulted in approximately 45 minutes of emergency response, including facility evacuation, fire suppression system activation, and containment of the escaped materials. The dryer unit sustained approximately $180,000 in damage. No personnel were directly struck by debris due to the physical distance of workers at the time. The failure was attributed to a malfunctioning temperature controller that had not been serviced in 18 months despite manufacturer recommendations for annual inspection.

On April 2, 2024 at 09:15, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), Injection Molding Technician on Line A, sustained a laceration to his right hand while performing routine maintenance cleaning on an injection molding machine. Ouellet was using a soft brush to clean plastic residue from the mold cavity when his hand accidentally made contact with a sharp internal edge of the mold that had not been properly smoothed during the manufacturing process. The contact caused a 2-inch laceration across the palm of his hand, resulting in moderate bleeding. Ouellet immediately removed his hand and applied direct pressure using his work apron. His colleague, Linh Tran (EMP-00046), Quality Assurance Specialist, observed the incident and immediately summoned the Occupational Health Nurse. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) arrived within 3 minutes, assessed the wound, cleaned and bandaged the laceration, and recommended on-site first aid treatment. The wound required 6 stitches but did not necessitate hospital transfer. Ouellet returned to light duty work after 2 hours of observation. The root cause was inadequate mold surface finishing and lack of protective gloves during maintenance cleaning.

On May 8, 2024 at 22:30 during the evening shift, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), Regrind Operator, experienced acute respiratory distress while working in the Raw Materials Warehouse section where regrind material was being processed and stored. Ibrahim noticed an unusually strong chemical odor and began experiencing difficulty breathing, throat tightness, and eye irritation. He immediately left the work area and moved to fresh air. Within 5 minutes, Claude Poirier (EMP-00071), Forklift Operator, found Ibrahim sitting outside the warehouse and called for medical assistance. Nina Santos (EMP-00084), Industrial Hygienist on evening shift standby, arrived within 8 minutes. Santos assessed Ibrahim's vital signs, which showed elevated heart rate (112 bpm) and slightly elevated blood pressure. She administered supplemental oxygen and placed Ibrahim under observation in the first aid station. Ibrahim's symptoms gradually resolved over the next 45 minutes. Investigation revealed that a container of composite resin solvent had developed a small leak during transport, releasing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the confined warehouse section. The container had been improperly secured on a storage shelf and its containment tray was not in use. Ibrahim was treated and released to light duty with instructions to monitor for delayed symptoms.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, suffered a significant burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. While removing a finished part from Molding Machine #18 in UNIT-002, Charbonneau inadvertently contacted the upper mold surface which was still at 285°C. The machine had been in automatic cycle mode, and a temperature indicator light had burned out two days prior, leaving operators unaware the mold had not cooled to its safety threshold of 60°C. Charbonneau's right palm and fingers sustained second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 15% of his hand. He immediately reported to the on-site first aid station where initial treatment was provided, followed by transport to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur in Cartierville for specialized burn care and infection prevention. The incident was witnessed by Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), who called emergency services. Charbonneau required hospitalization for 5 days and was unable to return to production work for 6 weeks due to wound management and occupational therapy requirements.

On October 28, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, an overhead crane system failure occurred in UNIT-009 (Shipping and Receiving Dock). Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), the Machine Setter for the evening shift, was positioning a 450-kg pallet of finished composite parts above the staging area using the facility's main 2-ton capacity overhead crane (Serial: OC-2847, last inspected March 2024). Approximately 3 meters above the dock floor, one of the four load-bearing wire ropes suddenly fractured due to undetected metal fatigue and corrosion. The remaining three ropes could not distribute the load, causing the pallet to drop. The pallet struck the concrete dock surface with significant force, scattering composite parts across a 4-square-meter area. Fortunately, no workers were directly beneath the load at the moment of failure, though Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler working nearby, was approximately 2 meters away and experienced a minor laceration to his left forearm from a ricocheting composite fragment. The incident was immediately reported to evening shift supervisor, and the crane was taken out of service pending full inspection.

On December 3, 2024, at 06:30 during the night shift, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a serious repetitive strain injury that resulted in lost work time. Over an eight-week period, Yasmin had been assigned to manually remove and stack finished polypropylene components from her molding line approximately 800-1,000 times per shift (roughly every 30-45 seconds). The repetitive grasping, twisting, and stacking motion caused cumulative microtrauma to the flexor tendons and median nerve in her right wrist. On the morning of December 3, Yasmin reported severe pain and numbness in her right hand upon arriving for her 11 PM shift. She attempted to work but experienced progressive weakness and was unable to maintain grip strength after the second hour. Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), the Ergonomics Specialist, was called to assess the situation. Clinical evaluation and subsequent MRI imaging confirmed median nerve compression and early carpal tunnel syndrome. Yasmin was placed on modified duty and eventually required a 4-week medical leave for conservative treatment and occupational therapy. The incident revealed that no ergonomic risk assessment had been performed on Line C production tasks since the line was reconfigured in March 2024.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45, a hydraulic pressure line ruptured on Injection Molding Machine Line B in the Main Production Building, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid across the equipment and workstation. The rupture occurred due to metal fatigue in a 15-year-old coupling that had not been replaced during the last scheduled maintenance cycle. Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was standing 3 meters away performing setup work when the line failed explosively. The resulting spray damaged approximately $47,000 in equipment, including the machine's hydraulic pump assembly, control panel wiring harness, and nearby mold inventory stored on adjacent shelves. The incident resulted in complete shutdown of Line B for 18 days during repairs. Immediate response included emergency shutdown of the machine, containment of spilled hydraulic fluid using absorbent materials, and notification of the maintenance team. No personnel injuries occurred, though the incident created a significant slip hazard from the fluid spray that required extensive cleaning. The root cause was identified as inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling and lack of condition monitoring on aging hydraulic components.

On March 22, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Production Operator Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was preparing materials in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building when she noticed a strong acetone vapor odor emanating from a storage container with a cracked lid. The container, holding approximately 200 liters of acetone solvent, had been damaged during an earlier material handling operation but was not immediately removed from the active storage area. Petrov observed visible vapor plumes rising from the crack and immediately evacuated the area, alerting nearby colleagues. Upon investigation by the HSE team, the container was found to have a 3-inch crack in its upper sidewall, allowing continuous evaporation into the facility. Air quality testing revealed acetone vapor concentrations reaching 850 ppm in the immediate vicinity (OSHA PEL: 750 ppm 8-hour TWA; IDLH: 20,000 ppm). The situation represented a potential inhalation hazard and fire risk, as acetone vapors are highly flammable. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) classified this as a near-miss incident, as no worker inhalation exposure or ignition source contact occurred. The damaged container was isolated, its contents transferred to an undamaged vessel, and the area was ventilated for 90 minutes to reduce vapor concentrations below safe levels. No medical attention was required, but the incident exposed gaps in damage assessment procedures for chemical containers.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:20 AM, Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) was in the Cafeteria and Break Room preparing a hot beverage when she inadvertently knocked over a coffee mug filled with approximately 240 milliliters of freshly brewed coffee (estimated temperature: 82°C). The mug fell from the counter edge and struck her left forearm, causing the hot liquid to splash across her skin from wrist to elbow. Singh immediately ran cold water over the affected area for approximately 3 minutes as per first aid training. Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), who was nearby, assisted in locating ice packs from the cafeteria refrigerator and helped transport Singh to the on-site first aid station. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) assessed the burn wound, which presented as a first-degree thermal burn with mild erythema across approximately 80 square centimeters. The affected area showed no blistering, and the burn was localized to the epidermis only. Singh received treatment consisting of continued cold water application, aloe vera gel application, and a sterile gauze dressing. She was advised to monitor the area for infection and given first aid discharge instructions. The incident required no further medical intervention beyond first aid, and Singh returned to work after 45 minutes following treatment completion. The root cause was identified as a slippery counter surface from morning cleaning operations combined with inattention while reaching across the counter for additional condiments.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a fire originated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) when a container of polyurethane resin was improperly sealed and left near a heat source. Mohamed Ibrahim, the Regrind Operator, was transferring solvent-contaminated materials when the container's volatile fumes accumulated near a 65°C curing lamp used for test samples. The combination of flammable resin vapors and sustained heat ignition resulted in an open flame spreading across several chemical storage shelves. Emergency response was initiated immediately; the fire suppression system activated within 2 minutes, containing the fire to a 4-square-meter area. No personnel were directly exposed to flames, though smoke inhalation affected nearby workers. The facility's day shift supervisor evacuated the chemical building and surrounding areas as a precaution. Fire department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed complete extinguishment. Investigation revealed the resin container cap was left unsecured during inventory procedures, and the curing lamp placement violated the 1-meter minimum clearance protocol from flammable materials.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift, a property damage incident occurred in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009) when a material handling forklift operated by Hassan Diallo struck a support column while maneuvering a pallet stack of finished composite materials. The operator was backing toward the loading dock to position a 2.5-ton load of fiber-reinforced plastic components when visibility was obstructed by the height of the stacked materials. The forklift's rear-right corner impacted the steel support column with sufficient force to cause a 15cm dent in the column and bend the forklift's mast frame. The load shifted during impact, causing approximately 47 units of composite parts to fall from the pallet, resulting in an estimated $34,000 in product damage. The support column structural integrity was assessed by maintenance; no critical damage was found, but the column required straightening and repainting at an estimated cost of $8,500. No personnel were struck. Investigation revealed that the dock's spotting mirrors had been removed two weeks prior for maintenance and were never reinstalled, and the forklift operator had not received refresher training on blind-spot protocols in over 18 months.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift, an accidental fire suppression system discharge occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017) when Bernard Allard, a Hydraulic Press Operator, inadvertently bumped an overhead sprinkler head while adjusting ceiling-mounted equipment guides. The suppression head was damaged by contact with a metal bracket being repositioned, causing micro-fractures in the seal mechanism. Within seconds, the head began discharging water at full system pressure (85 psi), activating the zone's full suppression cycle. Approximately 4,000 gallons of water was released over 3 minutes before the system could be manually shut down by the night shift supervisor. The discharge resulted in significant water damage to electrical panels controlling six heat-treatment ovens (estimated damage: $52,000), ruined approximately 180 units of composite materials in post-processing stages ($28,600 loss), and created a temporary 8-hour operational shutdown. The night shift had only two personnel present (Bernard Allard and Raynald Vézina, Tool Room Technician), neither trained in emergency suppression system shutdown procedures. No injuries occurred, but the facility sustained substantial production delays on customer orders.

On April 2, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator, was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) on Line C. She was applying pressure-sensitive labels to medical device components when her glove became caught between the automated label applicator roller and a partially molded part. The operator could not retract her hand quickly enough, and her right hand was pinched, resulting in partial lacerations to her middle and ring fingers and significant contusion of the palm. First aid was administered immediately by the site, and Elena was transported to Centre Hospitalier Régional de Laval. Medical examination revealed deep lacerations requiring 14 sutures, crush injury to soft tissue, and contusions on the dorsal hand surface. Elena was unable to work for 12 weeks due to pain and restricted grip strength, making this a lost-time injury requiring workers' compensation.

On May 8, 2024, at 03:20 during the night shift, a spontaneous fire originated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-019) near a storage cabinet containing flammable solvents and mold release agents. The facility's automated fire detection system triggered at 03:22, and the fire alarm activated throughout the compound. Security monitors observed the initial flame development originating from accumulated dust around an improperly sealed solvent container that had degraded over time, likely due to vibration from nearby equipment. The night shift supervisor Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) immediately initiated emergency procedures, evacuating all personnel and activating the suppression system. The on-site sprinkler system extinguished the fire within 4 minutes, preventing significant structural damage. However, approximately 35 square meters of shelving and stored materials were damaged, and the chemical storage area was rendered non-operational for 6 days pending remediation and inspection by the Laval Fire Department and CNESST representatives. No personnel injuries occurred, but smoke evacuation took 8 hours.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Storage Mezzanine). Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx was conducting a routine inventory count when she knocked over a 20-liter container of acetone cleaning solvent from a shelf approximately 1.5 meters high. The container's cap was not properly secured, and upon impact with the concrete floor, the container cracked and released approximately 15 liters of acetone. The spill spread rapidly across the mezzanine floor, flowing toward electrical equipment and the edge of the platform. Nicole immediately activated the emergency alert and evacuated the area. The spill vapors created a strong chemical odor detectable throughout the warehouse section. Initial response included cordoning off the affected area with hazard tape and activating the ventilation system. The cleanup involved use of absorbent materials and proper disposal procedures. No personal injury was sustained, but the incident exposed gaps in secondary containment protocols and storage procedures for flammable solvents.

On December 3, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Youssef Zaidi sustained a lost-time injury while working at Injection Molding Line B. Youssef was manually removing cooled plastic components from the mold cavity when his left hand contacted a sharp edge on the mold insert, causing a deep laceration across his palm and extending into the webbing between thumb and index finger. The cut was approximately 4 centimeters long and penetrated into subcutaneous tissue. Despite immediate first aid application and wound pressure, bleeding was difficult to control due to the depth of the laceration and proximity to underlying blood vessels. Youssef was transported to Laval Hospital Emergency Department at 22:35. Clinical assessment revealed the laceration required 12 stitches and there was concern for potential tendon involvement. He was prescribed antibiotics and kept under observation for 8 hours. Youssef was unable to return to work and was placed on medical leave. Investigation revealed the mold edge had become sharp due to corrosion and wear, and the sharp edge guard had been removed during a maintenance procedure 3 days prior but never reinstalled.

On January 8, 2025, at 09:30 during the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Quality Control Laboratory. Process Quality Engineer Deepa Gupta was performing resin analysis using solvent extraction procedures when she was transferring a 500-milliliter aliquot of acetone from a secondary container to a graduated cylinder. Due to a slippery work surface (residual moisture on the bench) and inadequate grip on the container, Deepa's hand slipped and the container fell, spilling approximately 450 milliliters of acetone directly onto the laboratory benchtop, floor, and partially onto adjacent technical equipment including a spectrophotometer and analytical balance. The spill created significant vapor pressure in the enclosed laboratory space, triggering the chemical vapor alarm at 09:32. Deepa immediately notified Safety Officer Anh Nguyen and evacuated the laboratory.
