The facility's emergency response team activated the secondary ventilation system for the lab and positioned portable fume extractors at the spill site. Absorbent materials and specialized chemical cleanup kits were deployed. The area was cordoned off for 6 hours during cleanup, remediation, and equipment assessment. Equipment damage assessment identified the spectrophotometer required recalibration (approximately $3,200 in services). Root cause analysis revealed inadequate housekeeping protocols and lack of procedural controls for solvent handling in laboratory settings.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a thermal burn to his right hand while attempting to clear a blockage in the mold cooling line. The employee was retrieving a plastic part from the 150-ton injection molding machine when pressurized cooling water unexpectedly released from a deteriorated hose connection, spraying scalding water at approximately 85°C onto his hand and forearm. The incident occurred in UNIT-004 (Injection Molding Line D - Consumer Packaging). The employee immediately moved to the safety shower and flushed the affected area for several minutes before seeking medical attention in the facility's first aid station. Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), a nearby Crane Operator, witnessed the incident and immediately assisted the employee to the first aid station. Initial assessment revealed second-degree burns covering approximately 8% of the hand and forearm. The employee was transported to Hopital de Laval for further treatment and remained hospitalized for 3 days. Root cause investigation identified that the cooling water hose had not been inspected or replaced according to the preventive maintenance schedule, and the employee had not been wearing heat-resistant gloves as required by facility protocols.

On April 3, 2024 at 7:15 AM during the night shift, Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, conducted a routine facility inspection in UNIT-007 (Raw Materials Warehouse - Section A) and identified a significant accumulation of plastic resin dust in the ductwork and on horizontal surfaces throughout the facility. The dust accumulation measured approximately 3-5mm in depth across overhead pipes, storage shelving, and ventilation intake areas. The inspection revealed that the dust collection system had not been cleaned for approximately 6 weeks, significantly exceeding the 2-week maintenance interval specified in facility procedures. This preventive declaration was issued because the accumulated dust presented a serious fire hazard risk given the proximity to the raw material storage area, which contains flammable polypropylene resin bales and acetone cleaning solvent stored in a cabinet 8 meters from the accumulation zone. Weather conditions that day included dry air with humidity at 28%, creating ideal conditions for dust ignition. No active fire or immediate personnel injury occurred, but the hazard was severe enough to warrant facility evacuation protocols and immediate corrective action. Amelie Roy (EMP-00028), Training Coordinator, was notified and documented the finding.

On May 12, 2024 at 4:30 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in UNIT-014 (Electrical and Instrumentation Shop - East Section) when a 20-liter container of acetone cleaning solvent tipped over during material reorganization. The container, stored on an unstable mobile cart without secondary containment, spilled approximately 18 liters of acetone across the concrete floor in the equipment maintenance area. The spill spread across an estimated 12 square meters before reaching a floor drain. The chemical exposure affected an area containing sensitive electrical equipment worth approximately $180,000 and created an immediate vapor hazard in the enclosed space. Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120), CNC Machinist, was working adjacent to the spill area and experienced acute inhalation exposure to acetone vapors, reporting dizziness and headache symptoms. Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, was immediately notified and coordinated emergency response. The facility activated its spill response protocol, evacuating the affected section and deploying absorbent materials and ventilation equipment. The spill was contained and neutralized using approved chemical absorbent and collected into proper hazardous waste containers. Environmental protection measures were implemented to prevent acetone from entering the municipal water system. The incident was reported to CNESST and local environmental authorities as required.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (Unit-011). Employee Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate, was transferring acetone solvent from a 55-gallon drum to smaller containers using a hand pump when the pump connection failed unexpectedly. Approximately 12 gallons of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor and began evaporating rapidly, creating a hazardous vapor cloud. The employee immediately notified nearby staff and evacuated the immediate area. Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), the Facilities Maintenance Technician, responded by opening emergency ventilation and placing absorbent material around the spill. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was called to assess vapor concentrations and coordinate cleanup. The spill was contained within 20 minutes and the area was ventilated for 90 minutes before resuming operations. No personnel required medical attention, but the incident highlighted deficiencies in equipment maintenance and spill response procedures.

On November 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Main Production Building due to a minor electrical fire in Injection Molding Line D (Unit-004). Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was working near the molding equipment when she noticed sparking from an overloaded electrical junction box adjacent to the machine's control panel. She immediately activated the nearest fire alarm pull station and alerted her supervisor. Emergency response personnel, including Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) and Plant Manager Jean-François Lefebvre (EMP-00002), coordinated the evacuation of approximately 60 workers from the south zone production area. The on-site fire suppression system activated and extinguished the small fire within 2 minutes. Local fire department arrived 8 minutes after the alarm and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. The electrical junction box had experienced a gradual overload due to aging wiring and inadequate circuit protection, creating an arc that ignited insulation material. No injuries occurred, but the incident resulted in a 4-hour production shutdown for investigation and equipment inspection.

On February 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Assembly Operator Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) sustained a significant repetitive strain injury while performing part removal operations on Injection Molding Line A (Unit-001). The employee had been extracting molded plastic components from the machine for over 4 hours consecutively without rotation or adequate break periods, using forceful gripping and twisting motions that placed extreme stress on her wrists, forearms, and shoulders. By the end of the shift, she experienced severe pain in both wrists and the right shoulder, with visible swelling. She reported the injury to her supervisor and was referred to occupational health. Medical evaluation confirmed acute inflammation of the extensor carpi radialis tendons in both wrists and early symptoms of impingement syndrome in the right shoulder. The employee was placed on modified duty restrictions and prescribed physical therapy. Investigation revealed that the automated part ejection system on Line A had been malfunctioning for three weeks, requiring manual removal of significantly more components than normal. No replacement operators had been assigned to rotate with Aaliyah during this period.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024) was performing routine part removal from Molding Line C when her hand became caught between the mold closing mechanism and a freshly ejected plastic component. The operator had not fully disengaged the safety interlock after the automated ejection cycle completed. Her right hand sustained a pinch injury affecting the index and middle fingers, resulting in contusions and minor lacerations. Co-worker Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) witnessed the incident and immediately called for assistance. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) responded within minutes, assessed the injury, and accompanied the employee to the on-site first aid station. The employee was treated for soft tissue damage and released to continue modified duty work. The incident was attributed to operator fatigue combined with inadequate awareness of machine state after cycle completion.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:20 AM during the day shift, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was operating a CNC milling machine in the mold manufacturing area when a grinding wheel fractured unexpectedly during a high-speed finishing operation. A fragment of the wheel ejected and struck his left forearm, causing a deep laceration approximately 4 inches in length that severed a minor artery. The machinist experienced significant blood loss over approximately 8 minutes before emergency response personnel arrived. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified immediately and coordinated emergency medical services transport. The employee was hospitalized for surgical repair of the laceration and blood vessel, requiring 12 stitches and 2 days of hospitalization. Investigation revealed the grinding wheel had not been properly balanced and had exceeded its recommended service life by 40 operating hours. The equipment maintenance schedule had been interrupted due to staffing shortages.

On April 18, 2024, at 11:45 PM during the night shift, Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) was restocking composite fiber materials in the Regrind and Recycling Department when she lifted a 50-pound box of glass-filled nylon using improper technique. She bent her back excessively while keeping her knees straight, compressing her lower lumbar region. Immediately following the lift, she experienced acute lower back pain and could not straighten up. She sat down and remained in the warehouse for 45 minutes before being able to move. CNC Operator Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), who was nearby performing equipment cleaning, discovered her in distress and notified her supervisor. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) responded and assisted her to the first aid station. The employee was evaluated by occupational health and diagnosed with acute lumbar strain with muscle spasm. She was prescribed rest and was unable to return to work for 8 days, during which she received physical therapy. The incident was caused by inadequate training on proper lifting biomechanics and lack of mechanical lifting equipment for boxes exceeding 40 pounds.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Production Operator Yara Mustafa was operating Injection Molding Line B when she noticed unusual vibration and noise coming from the machine's hydraulic pump. She immediately stopped the machine and notified her supervisor. Upon inspection, a small hydraulic fluid leak was discovered at a connection point near the injection unit. The leak could have potentially escalated to a full hydraulic system failure, which would have resulted in uncontrolled machine movement and potential spray of hot hydraulic oil onto operators. Yara's quick recognition of the warning signs and immediate action prevented what could have been a serious incident. The area was cordoned off, and the maintenance team was called. No injuries occurred, and the equipment was safely repaired within 2 hours.

On March 18, 2024 at 10:30 AM, Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (night shift supervisor filling in during day shift) observed that several pallets of raw polypropylene resin were stacked to an unsafe height near the loading dock and were beginning to shift. Upon visual inspection, he noted that forklift operators had been stacking pallets beyond the racking system's load capacity markings, creating a serious falling object hazard. The warehouse environmental conditions (humidity fluctuations from the shipping dock proximity) had also caused some pallet packages to become unstable. Michel immediately initiated a warehouse safety stand-down and coordinated with Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx to redistribute the load properly. He also noticed that several operators were unfamiliar with weight distribution best practices. No injuries occurred. This preventive declaration prompted a comprehensive review of material storage procedures before an incident could manifest.

On March 20, 2024 at 11:15 PM during night shift, Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme discovered that Resin Dryer Unit #3 in the Post-Processing area was displaying erratic temperature readings and producing unusual buzzing sounds from its control panel. Upon opening the electrical panel for visual inspection, he observed visible corrosion on the terminal connections and evidence of moisture ingress into the enclosure. The unit had been operating continuously for 18 hours without the standard 2-hour cooling break. The dryer's heating elements were at 187°C (normal operating range is 150-170°C) due to a malfunctioning temperature thermostat. Had this equipment continued operating unmonitored, the thermostat failure could have caused resin material to degrade, equipment thermal damage, or potential electrical fire within the control cabinet. The equipment was immediately powered down and isolated using LOTO procedures. Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne was notified and the unit was removed from service pending repair.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, an operator at Injection Molding Line C was performing routine mold cleaning with acetone solvent when they noticed unusual vibration in the injection unit. The operator immediately stopped the machine and called for maintenance support. Upon inspection, Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand discovered that the hydraulic pressure relief valve was beginning to fail, causing erratic pressure fluctuations. The operator had correctly identified the anomaly before attempting further cleaning work. The machine was isolated using LOTO procedures, and the faulty valve was identified as the root cause. No injuries occurred, but had the operator continued working without stopping, the sudden pressure release could have caused hot plastic spray or mechanical failure resulting in severe burns or crush injuries. The incident was witnessed by Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion who documented the near-miss event.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift, Material Handler Mariam Osman was transferring raw polypropylene resin bags from the receiving dock to the Raw Materials Warehouse when she inadvertently spilled concentrated mold release agent on her left forearm and hand. The spill occurred when a defective pump dispenser on a 5-gallon container malfunctioned during transfer. She immediately rinsed the affected area with water at the emergency eyewash station for approximately 3 minutes, then reported to the first aid station. Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le provided first aid treatment, cleaning the area thoroughly and applying a protective barrier ointment. Minor erythema (redness) was observed but no blistering occurred. The employee was monitored for 30 minutes and released to return to duty with instructions to avoid getting the area wet for the remainder of the shift. No lost time occurred. The incident was documented and reported by EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 9:30 PM during evening shift operations, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov was performing precision mold maintenance in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop when he noticed a small ladder (used for accessing upper tool storage) positioned near a CNC milling machine. While retrieving a specialized cutting tool from the top shelf, he placed the ladder approximately 18 inches from the machine base. As he climbed to the third rung, the ladder's left foot shifted on the smooth epoxy floor, causing it to tilt slightly toward the milling machine. The machinist immediately descended and repositioned the ladder away from the machine on a rubber mat. No injury occurred, but had the ladder tipped completely, he could have fallen 6-8 feet directly onto the active spindle area or machinery frame. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette was conducting her evening shift safety rounds and observed the near-miss incident being corrected in real-time, and documented the observation.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198) was performing routine cleanup around Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building when she accidentally contacted liquid mold release agent that had pooled on the machine's exterior surface. The agent, a petroleum-based formulation, made direct contact with her left forearm and hand. She immediately experienced skin irritation, redness, and mild burning sensation. Laila reported the incident to her supervisor within 5 minutes. She was directed to the first aid station where Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) provided immediate treatment: thorough washing with soap and water for 15 minutes, followed by application of non-irritating moisturizer and a light bandage. The affected area showed minor inflammation that resolved within 4 hours. The incident was traced to a leaking connector on the mold release distribution system that had not been identified during the morning maintenance check. Laila was able to return to full duties after receiving first aid and demonstrating no further symptoms.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Shipping Clerk Julien Racine (EMP-00177) was organizing finished goods inventory in the Warehouse and Shipping area when he stepped on a small puddle of spilled hydraulic oil that had accumulated near the regrind equipment area. The slippery surface caused his foot to slide and he fell backward, striking his lower back and left hip against the concrete floor. He experienced immediate sharp pain in the lumbar region and left hip joint. Composite Materials Technician Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042), working nearby, immediately called for assistance. Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) responded and provided first aid: ice application to the affected areas for 15 minutes, careful assessment of mobility, and pain management guidance. An incident form was completed and Julien was able to walk with minimal discomfort after 20 minutes of rest. He returned to modified duties the following day with restrictions on heavy lifting. The root cause was inadequate cleanup procedures following scheduled maintenance on the regrind compressor, which had begun leaking hydraulic fluid from a worn seal.

On May 22, 2024, at 7:20 AM during the day shift, Mold Repair Technician Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189) was performing scheduled preventive maintenance on a 300-ton injection molding machine in the Central Maintenance Workshop. He had initiated the lockout/tagout procedure and was preparing to disassemble the hydraulic manifold when he discovered that the energy isolation was incomplete—the secondary air supply valve had not been properly de-energized. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) was conducting his periodic LOTO compliance audit in the area and noticed the incomplete isolation before any work was begun on energized components. Gaétan immediately stopped Armand's work, re-verified all isolation points, and ensured the air supply valve was properly lockout-tagged. The incomplete isolation was traced to a modification made to the machine's air supply routing six months prior that had not been documented in the current LOTO procedure. No injury occurred, and the incident was classified as a near-miss because potential contact with the pressurized manifold could have caused severe laceration or crushing injury. A corrected and comprehensive LOTO procedure was issued within 48 hours.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, a cooling water system leak was discovered in the Injection Molding Line A - Automotive unit located in the Main Production Building North Zone. Patrick Ouellet, an Injection Molding Technician, noticed water dripping from the mold cooling circuit connections while performing routine machine checks. Upon investigation, he identified a corroded fitting on the secondary cooling line that had developed a hairline crack, spraying pressurized coolant water onto the electrical junction box serving the injection molding machine. The coolant contaminated the electrical connections, creating a potential shock hazard. Yuki Yamamoto, the Process Improvement Engineer, was alerted immediately and the machine was safely shut down using lockout procedures. The area was cordoned off with safety tape, and maintenance personnel were called to assess the damage. No personnel were directly exposed to the pressurized water spray due to the quick discovery, but the contaminated electrical box required complete replacement of internal components. The incident highlighted inadequate preventive maintenance protocols for aging cooling system infrastructure.

On February 8, 2024 at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, Lina Sokolova, a Composite Materials Operator, sustained a thermal burn while transferring heated composite resin from the mixing vessel to the molding station in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Sokolova was wearing standard nitrile gloves that were not rated for high-temperature applications. As she poured the resin at approximately 145°C (293°F) into a transfer container, the liquid contacted the glove cuff and penetrated to her left wrist, causing a second-degree burn approximately 8 centimeters in diameter. André Paradis, the Night Shift Production Supervisor, observed the incident immediately and directed Sokolova to the emergency eyewash/safety shower station for rapid cooling. First aid was administered on-site by Sanaa Rachidi, the Fire Safety Coordinator who was conducting her evening rounds. The burn was cooled with running water for 15 minutes and covered with a sterile dressing. Sokolova was transported to the local hospital for professional medical evaluation and received three stitches. She returned to work the following day with modified duties pending medical clearance.

On March 2, 2024 at approximately 8:20 AM during the day shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse when Raymond Tessier, the Crane Operator, was transferring a pallet of plastic pellet bags from the upper storage rack to the material drying preparation area using the overhead bridge crane. As Tessier positioned the load directly above the receiving station where Luis Fernandez, an Assembly Operator, was staging incoming materials, a worn wire rope showed visible signs of fraying at one of the attachment points. André Paradis, the Production Supervisor covering day shift operations, noticed the fraying during a routine safety walkthrough and immediately halted all crane operations in that section by radio communication. No load was dropped; no personnel were struck. The crane was immediately removed from service, and a detailed inspection revealed that the wire rope had approximately 8% wire breaks—just below the critical failure threshold. Upon further investigation, maintenance records showed that the rope inspection schedule had lapsed by three months due to staffing shortages in the Maintenance and Engineering department. The incident was classified as a near-miss with significant potential for serious injury or fatality had the load released.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050), a Production Operator on Injection Molding Line C, was monitoring the medical component production cycle when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the injection unit malfunctioned. The valve failed to release excess pressure, causing the system to over-pressurize. At 2:47 PM, a connection joint on the heating manifold ruptured, spraying pressurized hot oil (approximately 180°C) across the operator station. Fatou sustained second-degree burns to her right forearm and hand despite wearing standard PPE. The incident was immediately reported by line supervisor Yves Thibault, who activated emergency procedures and called for medical assistance. The facility's emergency response team arrived within 3 minutes, applied first aid, and Fatou was transported to the hospital for treatment. The equipment was immediately shut down and isolated. Post-incident investigation revealed that the hydraulic system had not undergone its scheduled maintenance in 6 weeks due to staffing constraints in the Maintenance department.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 AM, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, was transporting a pallet stack of pre-dried polycarbonate resin from the Raw Materials Warehouse to the Material Drying and Preparation Room. As Tariq navigated through the narrow aisle between storage racks in Section A of the warehouse, his forklift's right rear wheel caught on a metal pallet edge protruding from a lower shelf that had been improperly stacked by another material handler the previous evening. The impact caused the forklift to pitch sharply to the right, and the pallet load—weighing approximately 1,200 kg—shifted and fell onto the adjacent storage shelving unit. The shelving unit collapsed, scattering approximately 40 resin bags across a 15-meter area. No personnel were in the immediate impact zone, but the incident caused significant property damage estimated at €18,500, including damage to the shelving unit (€12,000), damaged resin inventory (€4,200), and a bent forklift right frame (€2,300). Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), another material handler present in the warehouse, witnessed the incident and immediately reported it to warehouse supervisor, who conducted the incident assessment.

On March 28, 2024 at 11:20 PM during the night shift, Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), a CNC Operator in the Maintenance Workshop, was performing routine cleanup of machining debris from a CNC milling station when he noticed material accumulation around the spindle area. He decided to perform an unscheduled inspection of the spindle alignment without following the proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures. Giovanni manually rotated the spindle using the control pendant while leaning close to observe the cutting tool position. However, the spindle did not completely stop from the previous operation—it had entered an idle state rather than being fully powered down. When Giovanni engaged manual rotation, the spindle suddenly accelerated due to residual motor momentum, and the rotating cutting tool made contact with his left index and middle fingertips, causing a deep laceration requiring 12 stitches. Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120), the CNC Machinist working the adjacent station, heard Giovanni's cry of pain and immediately summoned Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123), the Incident Investigation Specialist on emergency callback. First aid was administered immediately, and Giovanni was transported to the emergency clinic at 11:35 PM. The incident was documented as a recordable injury with lost work time of 8 days.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine maintenance on the cooling water system when he noticed an unusual hissing sound emanating from the hydraulic connection near the injection unit. Upon closer inspection, he identified a slow leak in the cooling water system's secondary circulation line. Before he could shut down the equipment and isolate the system, the weakened connection suddenly ruptured, releasing pressurized coolant water mixed with hydraulic oil across the production floor in a 3-meter radius. The fluid splashed onto nearby equipment and created a slippery surface. Gendron immediately notified his supervisor Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), who secured the area and stopped production on Line B. The maintenance team arrived within 10 minutes and isolated the system. No direct contact with the fluid occurred, and the spill was contained and cleaned within 45 minutes. However, the incident highlighted the lack of regular preventive inspection protocols for aging cooling systems. A near-miss assessment determined that had an employee been standing in the direct spray zone, serious thermal or chemical burns could have resulted from the heated coolant-oil mixture.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate, was retrieving a 200-kg roll of polycarbonate material from a high storage rack (approximately 2.8 meters high) in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Hébert was using the warehouse's manual pallet jack to position himself beneath the storage location. While attempting to grab the roll from its metal cradle, the cradle's locking pin—which had corroded and weakened over several months—failed without warning. The 200-kg polycarbonate roll fell directly onto Hébert's left shoulder and upper back, pinning him momentarily against the pallet jack. Colleagues immediately responded and carefully lifted the roll away. Hébert experienced acute pain and was unable to move his left arm. The facility's first aid responder, Petra Mueller (EMP-00166), arrived within 3 minutes and called emergency services. Hébert was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital where X-rays revealed a displaced fracture of the left scapula and a compression fracture of vertebra T3. He required surgical intervention and was hospitalized for 6 days. Investigation revealed that the storage rack's maintenance inspection schedule had lapsed due to staffing changes in the maintenance department, and the corroded cradle pin had never been flagged for replacement.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 3:45 AM during the night shift, Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), a Regrind Operator, was cleaning the hopper discharge port of the regrind machine in the Regrind and Recycling Department when he noticed a partial blockage of recycled polypropylene pellets. The blockage had formed overnight due to moisture accumulation in stored material. Following standard procedure, Comeau should have logged out and tagged the machine, but due to operational pressure to maintain production targets and reduce downtime, he decided to clear the blockage manually without properly completing lockout/tagout procedures. He inserted his right hand into the hopper opening while instructing another operator, Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), to briefly activate the regrind auger to dislodge the material. When the auger began rotating, it caught Comeau's glove and pulled his right hand into the grinding mechanism. Tessier immediately shut down the equipment, but not before the auger caused significant lacerations and contusions to Comeau's right hand, particularly around the thumb and index finger web space. Emergency responders arrived within 12 minutes and transported Comeau to the hospital where he received 27 stitches and was treated for a partial laceration of the first dorsal interosseous muscle. He was able to retain all fingers but experienced permanent loss of grip strength and fine motor control in his right hand. Root cause analysis determined that the operator had not received formal LOTO recertification in the previous 18 months, and supervisory oversight of LOTO compliance during the night shift was minimal.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, during day shift operations at Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone, Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was performing routine setup adjustments on an injection molding machine when he noticed unusual vibration and noise coming from the hydraulic cooling system. The machine had been operating continuously for 8 hours without scheduled maintenance. Upon closer inspection, Yusuf observed a small leak in the cooling water hose connection near the mold cavity. Rather than immediately shutting down the machine and reporting the issue through proper channels, he attempted to tighten the connection manually while the machine was still in operation. During this action, his left hand came into contact with a moving pinch point on the machine arm, causing a laceration to his palm. The incident was immediately reported to supervisor Richard Beaulieu, who initiated first aid and documented the event. The machine was subsequently shut down for inspection and maintenance. The cooling system leak was traced to improper hose fitting installation during the last maintenance cycle. Yusuf received four stitches and returned to modified duty. Quality Control Technician Léa Parent (EMP-00121) witnessed the incident and provided immediate assistance.

On April 22, 2024 at 10:30 PM during evening shift, Shipping and Receiving Clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019) was organizing finished composite material components in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) when she observed that the emergency exit door leading to the warehouse loading area was partially blocked by stacked pallets of raw material inventory. The pallets had been placed there temporarily earlier in the day by the incoming materials team and never relocated. During a routine fire safety awareness walk-through by Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), the blockage was officially documented as a safety violation. The emergency exit had approximately 18 inches of clearance remaining, which violates CNESST regulations requiring full, unobstructed access (minimum 36 inches width and 80 inches height). Fortin immediately reported the issue to her supervisor, and the pallets were relocated within 15 minutes. However, this incident revealed a systemic issue with material staging procedures and lack of accountability for maintaining emergency access zones. No emergency occurred during this incident, but the preventive assessment indicated significant risk exposure in case of actual fire or medical emergency requiring rapid evacuation.

On May 8, 2024 at 6:15 AM during night shift, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) was monitoring Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components Clean Room) when the primary cooling water circulation pump suddenly failed, causing an immediate temperature spike in the injection mold cavity. The pump, which had been in continuous operation for approximately 18 months without preventive maintenance beyond routine oil checks, experienced bearing failure and seized completely. The temperature in the mold reached 94°C within minutes, exceeding the safe operating range of 85°C maximum for medical-grade composite materials. This caused the batch of polycarbonate components currently in production to become thermally degraded, resulting in approximately 150 units of waste material worth an estimated $8,400. The equipment shutdown was automatic due to temperature threshold sensors, which prevented potential secondary hazards such as material combustion or mold damage. Gosselin immediately notified his supervisor Samantha Brown (EMP-00146) and called the maintenance emergency line. The bearing replacement and system pressure testing took 4 hours to complete. This incident was classified as equipment failure due to inadequate preventive maintenance protocols. No personnel injuries occurred during this incident.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), an Injection Molding Technician on the day shift, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line C in the clean room area. While cleaning around the mold release agent dispenser, Patrick's left hand came into contact with residual mold release agent on the equipment surface. Within minutes, he developed acute skin irritation and erythema across his palm and fingers. The substance had not been properly wiped down following the previous production run. Patrick immediately reported the exposure to his supervisor, Michael Chen, who directed him to the eyewash station for decontamination. After thorough washing with soap and water for 15 minutes, the irritation persisted. Patrick was transported to the on-site first aid station where Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos applied a topical barrier cream and documented the incident. The employee remained on duty but experienced discomfort for the remainder of the shift. No lost time was recorded, but the incident was classified as a recordable minor injury.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a Production Operator on night shift, was operating a material handling crane to move a 300-pound composite material batch from the Regrind and Recycling Department to the Injection Molding staging area. While guiding the suspended load, Kwame's right foot became caught between a pallet edge and the warehouse floor, trapping his foot as he pivoted to direct the crane load. The load descended slowly, creating pressure on his trapped foot. Kwame immediately signaled the crane operator to stop movement. Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) and Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) responded to the call for assistance. They carefully lifted the load using the crane while another worker freed Kwame's foot from the pallet. Kwame experienced immediate sharp pain and swelling in his right ankle and midfoot region. He was unable to bear weight on the injured foot. Emergency medical services were called, and Kwame was transported to Laval Medical Center where X-rays revealed a fractured cuboid bone and severe soft tissue trauma. He was placed on medical leave for 8 weeks with restrictions upon return.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift operations, the primary ventilation system serving the Hazardous Waste Management Area experienced a catastrophic failure. The system had been operating continuously for 18 months since the last scheduled maintenance, which was overdue by 3 months. The blower motor bearing seized, causing the entire 15-horsepower unit to shut down suddenly. This left the hazardous waste storage area without mechanical ventilation for 4 hours until the day shift maintenance team arrived. During this period, volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from stored solvent containers began accumulating in the enclosed space. At 7:45 AM, Purchasing Coordinator Christine Desrosiers (EMP-00055) entered the area to retrieve documentation on stored chemical inventory and immediately noticed strong chemical odors. She alerted Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), who conducted air quality readings showing VOC concentrations at 85% of the lower explosive limit in certain zones. The area was immediately evacuated and isolated. A replacement blower unit was expedited and installed by 2:30 PM the same day. The equipment failure created an 8-hour period of elevated explosion risk and potential occupational exposure to hazardous vapor concentrations. No personnel were hospitalized, but this represented a critical near-miss incident.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, James Thompson (EMP-00029), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, suffered a severe burn injury while performing routine material loading operations in the Main Production Building South Zone. Thompson was loading polypropylene resin into the hopper of Molding Machine D-7 when the machine's temperature control system malfunctioned, causing the barrel temperature to spike to 285°C (normal operating range: 220-240°C). As Thompson reached to adjust the material feed rate, hot plastic material ejected from a loose connection point, contacting his right forearm and hand. The burn covered approximately 15% of his right upper extremity with deep partial-thickness injuries. Co-worker Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) immediately activated the emergency stop and called for first aid. Thompson was treated on-site and transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé with second and third-degree burns. He required hospitalization for five days and underwent grafting procedures. The incident resulted in 42 days of lost work time during recovery and rehabilitation. Root cause analysis determined that the temperature sensor had failed due to inadequate preventive maintenance, and the material feed connection had corroded fittings that were not replaced per schedule.

On December 2, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Amina Ba (EMP-00164), a Packaging Operator, sustained a laceration and soft tissue injury to her left hand while performing final product packaging operations at the Warehouse and Shipping Packaging and Labeling Station. Ba was manually sealing cardboard boxes containing precision plastic medical device components when a wooden pallet, which had been stacked on an elevated shelf approximately 1.8 meters above her workstation, became dislodged. The pallet struck the edge of Ba's workbench, sending a splinter of approximately 8 cm length and 2 cm diameter directly into her left palm below her thumb. The wooden splinter penetrated through the skin and into the subcutaneous tissue, creating a puncture wound with embedded wood fragments. Ba immediately reported the injury to the night shift supervisor, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), who initiated first aid and contacted the on-site nurse. Ba received wound care, tetanus prophylaxis, and removal of embedded wood fragments. She was treated for a penetrating puncture wound with moderate contamination risk. The incident was classified as a non-lost-time injury but required two follow-up medical visits for infection monitoring. Investigation revealed that the pallet had been improperly stacked during the previous shift, with inadequate spacing and no safety netting to prevent dislodgement.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, suffered thermal burns to his right hand and forearm while removing a finished part from the injection molding machine. The mold temperature was operating at 95°C, and François was working without the thermal insulating gloves that should have been provided at his workstation. He attempted to remove a part manually before it had fully cooled, making direct contact with the hot plastic material. The part was still at approximately 78°C. François immediately immersed his hand in cold water from the nearby emergency station and was transported to the on-site first aid station by fellow operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103). The burns covered approximately 15% of his hand and forearm, resulting in redness, blistering, and minor tissue damage. François was sent to the local hospital for evaluation and treatment. Investigation revealed that thermal insulation gloves had not been restocked at the workstation following the previous day's cleaning procedures.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141), a Machine Operator working in the Regrind and Recycling Department, experienced acute respiratory distress and eye irritation while processing composite fiber-reinforced waste material. The facility's ventilation system in Section C had been operating at reduced capacity due to a clogged filter that had not been replaced during the previous week's maintenance window. As Raoul shredded composite scrap material, airborne fiber particles and resin dust accumulated in concentrations exceeding safe exposure limits. He reported difficulty breathing, burning sensation in his eyes, and persistent coughing. His supervisor, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), immediately moved Raoul to the fresh air area and contacted the HSE Coordinator. Raoul was taken to occupational health services where he was treated for acute respiratory irritation. Air quality measurements conducted after the incident showed respirable crystalline silica levels at 1.8 mg/m³, exceeding the exposure action level of 1.5 mg/m³. Investigation revealed that the preventive maintenance schedule for ventilation filters had not been followed, and no one had verified system functionality that day.

On March 20, 2024, at approximately 6:00 AM during the night shift, during routine facility walkthrough, Nina Santos (Industrial Hygienist, EMP-00084) identified a critical safety concern in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop. An elevated mezzanine level used for storage of spare parts and electrical components was lacking proper edge protection along a 12-foot section of its perimeter. The mezzanine is approximately 15 feet above the shop floor level. Additionally, there are no railings, toe boards, or warning barriers to prevent objects from falling to the work area below. The structural engineering review indicated the mezzanine has not been formally assessed for fall protection compliance since its original installation in 2015. Three technicians regularly work directly below this mezzanine area without any awareness of the falling object hazard. No incidents have occurred yet, but the potential for serious injury or fatality is present if any of the stored items were to fall. This is classified as a PREVENTIVE_DECLARATION because no injury has occurred, but a critical hazard has been identified requiring immediate corrective action.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 10:45 AM, Assembly Operator Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station when she sustained a minor laceration to her right index finger while manually removing plastic trim from packaged medical device components. The sharp edge of a newly molded part caught her finger as she was transferring items between containers. A small amount of bleeding occurred, and the wound was approximately 1.5 cm in length. Immediate first aid was applied by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) who was conducting a routine facility walkthrough. The wound was cleaned, antibiotic ointment was applied, and a sterile adhesive bandage was applied. No sutures were required. The injury did not result in any lost work time, and Ms. Ricci returned to her station after approximately 10 minutes of treatment. The incident was attributed to inadequate awareness of sharp edges on newly molded parts and the lack of proper hand protection during the finishing process.

On May 22, 2024 at 11:20 PM during the night shift, Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B when he sustained a significant thermal burn to his left forearm and hand. While adjusting the temperature calibration on a molding machine following a production issue, Mr. Desbiens inadvertently made contact with an uninsulated section of heated barrel tubing that was operating at approximately 280°C. The contact occurred for approximately 2-3 seconds before he withdrew his arm. Despite wearing standard work gloves, the heat penetrated the protective equipment, resulting in a second-degree burn covering approximately 8% of his left arm and hand. The burn was severe enough to cause blistering and significant pain. Emergency response was initiated immediately by Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105), who applied ice water to the affected area and contacted emergency medical services. Mr. Desbiens was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé where he received treatment including topical antibiotic ointment and specialty burn dressing. He was released after 4 hours of observation but required 8 days off work for healing and pain management, resulting in a lost-time injury.

On June 8, 2024 at 2:15 PM, Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) suffered a back strain injury while unloading a pallet of raw polystyrene pellets from a delivery truck at the Raw Materials Warehouse. The pallet contained twelve 25-kg bags stacked in a 4-high configuration. While attempting to manually slide a lower-tier bag toward himself using a jerking motion rather than proper lifting technique, Mr. Croteau felt a sharp pain in his lower back. He completed the task but experienced increasing pain and stiffness throughout the afternoon shift. By end of shift, he could barely walk and reported to Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) with complaints of acute lower back pain radiating slightly into his left leg. X-rays performed at a local clinic ruled out fractures but confirmed acute lumbar strain with mild muscle spasm. Mr. Croteau was prescribed muscle relaxants and anti-inflammatory medication and was placed on light-duty restrictions for 12 days, unable to perform warehouse duties. During this period, he performed administrative tasks in the HR department. The incident was attributed to failure to use proper lifting mechanics, inadequate awareness of bag weight, and lack of mechanical assistance for material handling.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was performing routine cleaning and material loading on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone. While reaching into the hopper area to remove partially cured plastic debris, his left hand became caught in the rotating auger mechanism. The equipment was supposed to be in lockout/tagout status, but a new temporary worker had inadvertently reset the safety interlock while performing upstream material preparation. Abdul's hand was drawn approximately 3 inches into the auger before the emergency stop button was activated by nearby coworker Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191). Abdul sustained a compound fracture to his fourth and fifth metacarpal bones, along with deep lacerations requiring immediate hospitalization at Sacré-Cœur Hospital. Emergency responders arrived within 12 minutes. The incident revealed that LOTO procedures had not been properly communicated to temporary staff, and the interlock system lacked redundant safety verification.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, quality inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) was conducting post-production inspection of finished composite material samples in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (South Zone). While handling a freshly extracted component from the cooling rack, she felt a sharp stinging sensation across the dorsal surface of her right hand. Investigation revealed that she had sustained multiple small lacerations from sharp edge burrs on the composite material's edge. The burrs, typically removed during post-processing, had not been properly deburred due to a maintenance backlog on the edge-finishing machine. The cuts were superficial but bled moderately. Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140) provided immediate first aid using the medical kit stored in the department, applying antiseptic solution and sterile gauze dressing. The injury required no hospitalization or external medical attention beyond company first aid. The incident was documented as a minor occupational injury suitable for workplace first aid treatment.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 11:50 PM during the night shift, Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) was performing routine warehouse inventory and organization in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). While reorganizing stacked pallets of raw plastic resin on overhead storage racks, an improperly secured pallet of composite fiber material shifted due to vibration from nearby forklift operations. The pallet, weighing approximately 850 pounds, fell approximately 9 feet and struck a backup power supply unit mounted on the warehouse wall. The impact caused significant damage to the electrical component, resulting in complete loss of backup power functionality for the climate control system serving the medical device production cleanroom. The medical cleanroom's environmental controls continued to function on main power, but the redundant safety system was compromised. Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) witnessed the incident and immediately secured the area. No personnel were in the direct impact zone at the time of the fall. Assessment revealed that the pallet had been placed on the rack without proper securing straps and the storage rack itself was not certified for the weight load being stored.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 hours during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (Building 5). Natasha Ivanov, Chemical Inventory Specialist, was conducting routine inventory checks when she discovered that a 200-liter container of epoxy resin had developed a hairline fracture along its side seam. The container, which had been stored on a lower shelf in the hazardous materials section, was leaking approximately 15-20 liters of resin onto the concrete floor before the leak was detected. The spill created a viscous pool approximately 2 meters in diameter, spreading toward the floor drain system. Ivanov immediately notified Simon Bélanger, Chemical Safety Officer, and activated the spill response protocol. The area was cordoned off using hazard tape, and absorbent materials (clay-based spill kit) were deployed to contain the spill. A potential root cause investigation revealed that the container had been damaged during a recent inventory reorganization, but the damage was not immediately visible. The spill was contained within 30 minutes, and the contaminated materials were placed in appropriate hazardous waste containers for disposal per WHMIS protocols. No personnel were exposed to hazardous fumes, and no injuries occurred. The incident highlighted gaps in container inspection procedures post-reorganization.

On November 18, 2024, at 09:20 hours during the day shift, a near-miss incident was identified in the Production Engineering and Planning unit located in the Administrative Building. Sylvain Jodoin, Automation Engineer, was performing maintenance on an injection molding machine's conveyor system when he noticed that the emergency stop (E-stop) button on the control panel was not functioning properly. During a routine test cycle, when Jodoin pressed the E-stop, the machine continued operating for approximately 3.5 seconds before coming to a complete halt. This delay violated safety protocols and could have resulted in serious entanglement or crush injuries if an operator had been in contact with moving parts during operation. Jodoin immediately stopped work and reported the incident to Luc Girard, Maintenance Technician, who confirmed the malfunction. The machine was locked out and tagged out (LOTO) per company procedure, and the control system was investigated. The root cause was determined to be a corroded relay contact in the safety circuit, likely due to moisture exposure and inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling. The affected machine remained out of service until the safety circuit was replaced and fully tested. This near-miss demonstrated that the current preventive maintenance interval for safety-critical components was insufficient and that environmental controls in the production area were allowing moisture accumulation.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 22:15 hours during the evening shift, an occupational injury occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Aisha Kamara, Production Operator, was manually moving stacked plastic component boxes from a pallet to a staging area in preparation for quality control inspection. Each box weighed approximately 18 kg, and she was required to lift boxes from waist height to shoulder height repeatedly over a 45-minute period. After removing approximately 40 boxes, Kamara reported sudden sharp pain in her lower back and was unable to continue working. She immediately notified her supervisor, who contacted first aid responders. Initial assessment suggested acute lumbar strain consistent with repetitive lifting without proper body mechanics or lifting assistance. Kamara was provided with ice application and pain relief, and after 30 minutes was able to walk but with visible discomfort. She was sent to occupational health for evaluation and was prescribed rest and modified duty restrictions for 3 days. The incident was classified as a recordable injury due to the requirement for modified work duty. Root causes included: inadequate mechanical lifting equipment availability (only 2 manual pallet jacks for the 35,000 sq ft warehouse), lack of proper lifting technique reinforcement in recent training, and absence of regular ergonomic assessments for repetitive material handling tasks. A witness, Monique Dion, Warehouse Associate, confirmed that no assistance was available and that Kamara was working alone in that section.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, the ventilation system serving the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013) experienced a catastrophic failure. The main exhaust fan motor bearing seized, causing complete shutdown of airflow to the tool room where CNC milling operations were occurring. Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), Machine Setter on the evening shift, and Thanh Pham (EMP-00062), Maintenance Planner called in to diagnose the issue, were working in the enclosed space when fumes from milling operations began accumulating. Within 15 minutes, visible solvent vapors (likely isopropanol used in cutting fluids) became concentrated in the 800 square-foot room. Thanh detected the problem via HVAC monitoring dashboard and immediately evacuated both workers from the space. He activated the building emergency alarm and opened all windows. The facility's HSE Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) responded within 8 minutes with a calibrated multi-gas monitor confirming elevated vapor concentrations (180 ppm isopropanol detected, exceeding 100 ppm TWA exposure limit). The room was ventilated naturally for 45 minutes before mechanical ventilation could be restored via rerouted ductwork. No workers required hospitalization, but Svetlana reported mild headache and dizziness.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a leak was discovered in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011) exterior storage zone. A 55-gallon drum containing used hydraulic oil contaminated with trace heavy metals had corroded at its base seam, allowing approximately 12 gallons of fluid to seep into the surrounding soil and surface drainage system over an estimated 48-hour period. The leak was detected by Georges Plante (EMP-00179), Facilities Technician, during his routine morning inspection of the chemical storage building perimeter. Upon closer examination, he identified that the drum had been stored on a wooden pallet (not the required secondary containment tray) for approximately 14 months, and rainwater had accumulated beneath it, accelerating corrosion. The contaminated soil area measured approximately 8 feet by 10 feet. Georges immediately isolated the area with caution tape, notified Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, who served as incident commander. Soil samples were collected and sent for analysis. An environmental remediation contractor was contacted for soil excavation and disposal. The incident was reported to CNESST and Quebec's Ministry of Environment within 24 hours as required.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic failure occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Samantha Brown, the Composite Materials Lead, was operating Injection Molding Line C when the primary resin dryer unit suddenly overheated and experienced thermal runaway. The dryer's temperature control system malfunctioned, causing internal pressure to build rapidly. At 2:47 PM, a relief valve failed to activate properly, and the dryer casing developed a hairline fracture along the heating element assembly. Pressurized hot resin vapor began escaping from the compromised seal. The facility's automated alarm system triggered, and emergency response protocols were activated. Johanne Paquette, Emergency Response Team Leader, coordinated immediate evacuation of the area and shutdown of adjacent equipment. No personnel were in the direct vicinity when the valve failed, preventing serious injury. The incident resulted in approximately 8 hours of production downtime, contamination of approximately 200 kg of composite material inventory, and damage to the dryer's heating chamber estimated at $67,000. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling and a failed temperature sensor that had been flagged for replacement 6 weeks prior but was deprioritized.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Mohamed Ibrahim, a Regrind Operator, sustained a significant hand laceration while operating the material regrind system in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Ibrahim was manually clearing a material jam near the intake hopper when he failed to properly engage the equipment lockout. A coworker, unaware of Ibrahim's presence at the equipment, restarted the grinder as part of routine shift changeover procedures. The high-speed regrind blade made contact with Ibrahim's left hand, causing a deep laceration across the palm and partial laceration of the index finger tendon. Immediate response included first aid application by Jamal Thompson, Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, who was nearby. The injury required emergency transport to Laval Regional Hospital for wound closure and orthopedic assessment. Total time from incident to hospital arrival was 18 minutes. Ibrahim received 12 stitches and was placed on modified duty with work restrictions. The incident was classified as a lost-time injury requiring reporting to CNESST. Root causes included: (1) incomplete LOTO procedure documentation, (2) lack of communication between operators during equipment state changes, and (3) inadequate signage indicating equipment hazards.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Olga Ivanova, Composite Materials Technician, experienced an acute allergic reaction to resin processing fumes while working in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Ivanova had been operating the fiber layup station for approximately 3 hours when she began experiencing respiratory distress, facial flushing, and throat irritation. She reported symptoms to Louis Desbiens, the Night Shift Machine Setter, who immediately notified emergency response. Johanne Paquette responded within 4 minutes and assessed Ivanova's condition as a moderate acute allergic response with respiratory component. Ivanova was moved to fresh air in the adjacent Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) where ventilation is superior. Emergency medical services were called as a precaution. Paramedics arrived at 6:38 AM and administered antihistamine and oxygen support. Ivanova was transported to Laval Regional Hospital for observation and monitoring, where she remained for 4 hours before being released with a diagnosis of acute occupational asthma exacerbation. The incident was classified as a recordable injury with hospitalization. Investigation revealed that the ventilation system in the composite processing area had been operating at 65% capacity due to a partially blocked filter that maintenance had noted but deprioritized. Ivanova had not reported previous respiratory symptoms.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140) was working at Injection Molding Line D when she noticed unusual vibration and noise from the mold cooling water system. She immediately stopped the machine and notified her supervisor. Upon inspection, a small hairline crack was discovered in the main cooling line connector, with pressurized water beginning to spray intermittently. Wong correctly identified this as a potential hazard and did not attempt to repair it herself. The equipment was immediately locked out and tagged out per LOTO procedures. Maintenance was called and arrived within 15 minutes. The crack was minor enough that no water damage occurred to surrounding equipment or electrical systems. The quick identification and proper response prevented what could have escalated into a flooded production area or electrical hazard. The incident was reported by Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) to the HSE office.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:15 PM during the evening shift, Crane Operator Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041) was operating an overhead crane to move a pallet of finished goods from the production area to the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). While repositioning the load, the left hoist cable developed a stress fracture at the attachment point near the hook assembly. The cable snapped suddenly under load, causing the pallet (approximately 800 kg) to drop approximately 3 meters onto the concrete floor of the warehouse. The pallet struck the ground with significant force, scattering the packaged plastic components across a 4-meter radius. No personnel were directly beneath the load at the moment of drop. However, Assembly Operator Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186), who was working nearby organizing finished inventory, was startled by the impact and experienced minor abrasions when she stumbled backward. The incident was immediately reported to the HSE office. Investigation revealed the cable had been in service for 8 years without replacement, exceeding the manufacturer's recommended 5-year service life. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) declared the incident.

On March 28, 2024, at 11:50 PM during the night shift, Injection Molding Technician Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181) was performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine when he failed to fully secure the Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) padlock on the main power disconnect. At approximately 12:20 AM on March 29, another night shift worker attempted to restart the machine, not realizing LOTO procedures were still in effect. As Pascal reached into the machine hopper to clear a blockage, the machine suddenly activated, catching his right arm in the auger screw mechanism. Pascal sustained significant lacerations and crushing injuries to his forearm and hand. Emergency response was activated immediately, and he was transported by ambulance to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur in Cartierville, arriving at 12:45 AM. Diagnosis included deep lacerations requiring 47 stitches, a non-displaced fracture to the radius bone, and contusions. He was admitted for overnight observation and discharged the following evening with significant soft tissue damage. The incident resulted in 8 lost work days. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) declared the incident to the HSE office and initiated the investigation.

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a thermal burn while performing routine part removal from an active injection molding machine. Sofia was extracting cooled plastic components from the mold when a residual pocket of hot melted polymer (approximately 260°C) splashed onto her right forearm and hand as she withdrew a part. The hot plastic adhered to her skin, causing a partial-thickness burn affecting approximately 8% of her right upper extremity. Sofia immediately removed her arm from the machine and ran to the nearest eyewash station where she rinsed the affected area with cool water for several minutes. Her supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079) arrived within seconds and called for first aid assistance. The company's trained first aider assessed the burn, applied sterile non-adherent dressing, and provided pain management. Sofia was conscious and alert throughout and did not require hospitalization, but was released from work for the day with instructions for wound care and follow-up. The incident was caused by inadequate thermal insulation on the mold's ejection point and insufficient cooling time protocol before part removal.

On November 12, 2024 at 8:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Unit-007) when a 55-gallon drum of polypropylene release agent (containing dimethyl siloxane, flash point 185°C) was inadvertently knocked over while Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050), a Production Operator, was retrieving materials using a manual hand truck. The drum's bung cap was not fully secured, allowing approximately 35 gallons of the oily liquid to spill across the concrete floor of Section A, creating a hazardous slipping surface and releasing volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors. The spill extended approximately 12 meters in length and 4 meters in width. Fatou immediately evacuated the immediate area and notified her supervisor. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) was called and initiated the facility's chemical spill response protocol. The area was cordoned off, ventilation systems were activated, and absorbent materials (diatomaceous earth) were deployed. Cleanup took approximately 2 hours. Air quality monitoring indicated VOC concentrations peaked at 185 ppm (acceptable limit is 200 ppm), but well-being monitoring of nearby employees was conducted. No personnel sustained direct exposure-related injuries, but the incident created significant operational disruption and environmental concern.

On November 16, 2024 at 12:30 AM during the night shift, René Caron (EMP-00097), a Tool Maker in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop, sustained a laceration and thermal injury while performing maintenance on a fiber-reinforced composite curing oven. René was inspecting heating element connections when his hand made contact with an actively heating ceramic element at approximately 180°C that was inadequately guarded. The exposure resulted in a first-degree burn across the palm and dorsal surface of his left hand, approximately 5% total body surface area equivalent, along with a minor laceration from contact with a sharp ceramic edge. René immediately withdrew his hand, applied pressure with a clean cloth, and sought the first aid station located within the tool room. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was present in the facility and provided immediate first aid including cool water irrigation for 20 minutes and application of sterile non-adherent dressing with topical burn cream. Pain management was provided and hand mobility assessment indicated no structural injury or significant functional impairment. René was able to continue working with modified duties and elevated hand. No hospitalization was required. The root cause was removal of a heat shield cover that was previously installed as a guard, which had been temporarily removed 6 weeks earlier for equipment access and never reinstalled.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 10:15 AM, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator on the day shift, was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) preparing medical components for shipment. While removing finished parts from a storage bin, a sharp edge on a polycarbonate component caught the back of his left hand as he withdrew it, creating a laceration approximately 2 cm long. The injury occurred because the parts were stacked without protective separators, contrary to established procedures. A coworker, Indira Singh (EMP-00104), witnessed the incident and immediately applied pressure with clean gauze. First aid was administered by the on-site health officer, and the wound was cleaned, bandaged, and monitored for infection. Amal completed his shift with modified duties. The incident was reported to the HSE office within 30 minutes by Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107).

On March 18, 2024 at approximately 9:45 PM during the evening shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), an Evening Shift Machine Operator, was operating Injection Molding Line C (UNIT-003) producing medical-grade polypropylene components. While retrieving a part from the cooling tray, steam from the mold cooling water system contacted her right forearm, causing a first-degree thermal burn approximately 8 cm in diameter. The incident resulted from a loose hose clamp on the cooling water circulation line that had gradually loosened over the previous shift, causing a minor spray that vaporized on contact with hot mold surfaces. Coworker Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124) immediately assisted by moving Hawa away from the heat source and applying cool water from the emergency eyewash station to the burn. The burn was mild with minimal redness and no blistering. First aid was administered on-site, and the injury was documented. The hose clamp was immediately tightened and the line pressure verified by Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie (EMP-00199). Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) completed the incident report.

On March 22, 2024 at approximately 2:30 AM during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Night Shift Machine Setter, was performing maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013) to prepare it for production of a specialized cavity insert. While making adjustments to the tool offset settings with the machine in what he believed was a safe standby mode, the spindle suddenly engaged due to a residual program command that had not been properly cleared from the machine's memory. The rotating mill bit contacted Louis's left hand, which was positioned near the cutting area, causing a deep laceration to his palm and the base of his index finger requiring 12 stitches. The incident occurred because the machine's emergency stop (E-stop) button had not been activated despite established LOTO procedures requiring it during maintenance operations. Louis immediately withdrew his hand and activated the E-stop himself. Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021), the Mold Technician, was present in the shop and called for emergency response. An ambulance arrived within 15 minutes and transported Louis to the hospital. The incident was investigated and reported by Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) within two hours. Louis was hospitalized overnight for wound assessment and infection prevention protocols.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Nicole Proulx, Inventory Control Specialist, was transferring a 20-liter container of acetone from a delivery pallet to the storage rack when the container's cap was not properly seated. As she lifted the container onto the upper shelf, approximately 12 liters of acetone spilled onto the floor and adjacent storage containers. The spill created a significant puddle approximately 3 meters in diameter. Nicole immediately notified her supervisor, and the facility's emergency response protocol was activated. The area was evacuated, ventilation systems were maximized, and absorbent materials were deployed to contain the spill. No personnel were directly exposed to skin contact, but two workers experienced mild respiratory irritation from fumes. The spill was contained and cleaned within 45 minutes. Root cause analysis revealed that the delivery container arrived with a loose cap that was not inspected upon receipt, and the storage shelf height exceeded recommended safe lifting practices for this container size.

On February 28, 2025, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred at Production Line B in the main manufacturing facility. Mathieu Gendron, Injection Molding Operator, was removing a completed part from a 250-ton injection molding machine when he noticed that the machine's interlock safety gate had not fully closed after the previous cycle. The safety system should have prevented machine operation, but Gendron observed that the hydraulic press chamber was beginning to pressurize. He immediately pressed the emergency stop button and moved away from the machine. The machine halted within 2 seconds. Investigation revealed that the interlock microswitches had become misaligned due to thermal expansion of the mounting bracket, preventing proper detection of the open gate position. Had Gendron's hand remained inside the mold cavity, severe crushing injuries would have resulted. The incident was a clear manifestation of the 'Electrical Shock from Equipment' and machine guarding hazards. No injuries occurred. The interlock system was immediately taken offline and replaced.

On January 10, 2025, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, an equipment failure incident occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Alain Gravel, Maintenance Technician on the night shift, was performing routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine when the main hydraulic pump's pressure relief valve failed catastrophically. The valve, which should limit system pressure to 210 bar, remained open, causing the pump to operate continuously at maximum pressure and begin overheating. The hydraulic fluid temperature rose to 85°C within 15 minutes, and pressure gauges indicated readings exceeding 250 bar. Gravel noticed the unusual sounds and heat and immediately shut down the machine. He then isolated the hydraulic system and contacted the day shift supervisor. The failure resulted in approximately 3 liters of hydraulic fluid leaking onto the workshop floor, creating a slip hazard and minor environmental contamination. Root cause analysis determined that the relief valve had not been replaced since the machine's installation 12 years ago, well beyond its manufacturer-recommended 5-year service life. The incident also revealed inadequate maintenance scheduling documentation.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a 150-ton injection molding machine (Machine 12-A) in the Main Production Building experienced a catastrophic hydraulic system failure. Operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103) was performing routine cycle maintenance when the machine's cooling water system rupture occurred, spraying pressurized fluid across the work area. The hot hydraulic fluid damaged surrounding equipment, including control panels, pneumatic hoses, and electrical conduits. The incident resulted in approximately $67,000 in equipment damage and forced a complete production shutdown of the injection molding line for 18 hours. Material handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) witnessed the incident from an adjacent workstation. The root cause was determined to be a failed pressure relief valve that had not been replaced during the last preventive maintenance cycle scheduled for February 2024. The machine had been operating beyond its recommended service interval due to increased production demand for automotive components.
