On April 8, 2024 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, a 55-gallon drum of uncatalyzed polyester resin was being transferred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-011) when Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a material handler, accidentally knocked over the drum with a forklift while positioning it near the mixing station. Approximately 40 gallons of liquid resin spilled across the concrete floor, with some liquid flowing toward the floor drain and drainage system. The spill spread across an estimated 450 square feet and began seeping into the ground outside through cracks in the exterior foundation. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, discovered the spill during her routine 11:30 PM rounds and immediately activated the emergency response protocol. The facility's secondary containment system was overwhelmed due to improper placement of drums outside designated storage areas. Environmental response crews were called, and the spill was contained after approximately 6 hours. Initial assessment indicated potential groundwater contamination requiring environmental remediation and Quebec Ministry of Environment notification.

On May 2, 2024 at 1:20 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Zara Khan (EMP-00106) sustained a laceration to her right hand while performing final assembly operations on medical device housings in the Quality Control Laboratory area. While manually handling a molded composite part with sharp edge burrs, Khan inadvertently cut her palm on an improperly deburred section of the component. The laceration was approximately 1.5 inches long and required on-site first aid treatment including wound cleaning, antiseptic application, and sterile bandaging administered by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052). No hospitalization was required, but the injury prompted a review of the deburing process for medical-grade components. The part had passed quality control inspection despite the presence of sharp edges that should have been removed during post-processing. The incident was captured on facility cameras showing the exact moment of injury. Khan was able to continue working after initial treatment with modified duties for 2 days while the wound healed.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was preparing Injection Molding Line A for a production run when he noticed the hopper discharge chute appeared partially blocked. Following standard procedure, he attempted to clear the blockage using a wooden dowel while the equipment was still energized but in idle state. As he probed the chute opening, a sudden pressure release from the resin dryer system caused a burst of compressed air and hot plastic pellets to discharge forcefully. The stream narrowly missed Karim's face and hands, striking the nearby wall instead. Karim immediately stepped back and reported the incident to his supervisor Patrick Ouellet. The hopper was secured and inspected. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed a critical failure in the pressure relief valve isolation procedure. The equipment was immediately taken offline for maintenance inspection by Gaétan Laplante, LOTO Coordinator, who documented the near-miss and identified that proper lockout procedures had not been followed during the idle maintenance activity.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, material handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was transferring spools of glass-fiber reinforced nylon from the Materials Preparation Room (UNIT-016) to the Composite Materials Processing Area staging zone. The finished goods warehouse shelving unit (a 8-tier metal rack system) was heavily loaded with spools of various materials. As Chiara approached the rack to retrieve a spool from the third tier, she noticed that the uppermost spool on tier 7 appeared to be positioned precariously close to the edge due to prior uneven stacking. She carefully alerted nearby co-worker Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a composite materials operator, about the hazardous positioning. Rather than immediately removing the load, Chiara contacted supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031) to assess the situation. Before Valérie could respond, an adjacent vibration from a passing forklift operation caused the unstable spool to shift. It tipped forward but was caught by the horizontal frame brace at tier 6, preventing a full drop. The spool remained suspended but unstable. Karine Cloutier, Safety Trainer, was immediately notified and secured the area while the spool was carefully repositioned and the entire rack was inspected for structural integrity.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:10 AM during the night shift, packaging operator Nour Jaber (EMP-00188) was preparing finished medical component trays for shipment in the Finished Goods Warehouse Section B (UNIT-008). While transferring a stack of sterilized polycarbonate trays from the cleaning station to the packaging workstation, Nour's left hand made contact with a freshly cleaned tray that retained residual mold release agent on its surface. The oily coating combined with moisture caused the tray to slip from his grip. As he attempted to catch the falling tray, the edge made sharp contact with his left palm, creating a laceration approximately 1.5 inches long with minor bleeding. The cut was sustained on the hypothenar eminence of the palm. Nour immediately reported the injury to Night Shift Supervisor Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), who provided basic first aid: rinsing the wound with soap and water, applying direct pressure with clean gauze for 5 minutes, and applying an antibiotic ointment with a sterile adhesive bandage. The laceration was shallow, approximately 2mm deep, with no arterial involvement. Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer, was notified and assessed the incident as requiring first aid treatment only. The injury was documented in the company medical log and the employee was cleared to return to work with a protective glove.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Layla Hussein (EMP-00098), an Assembly Operator on the day shift, was manually removing cooled plastic components from a mold at Production Station 7 in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). The mold had been in the cooling cycle for approximately 8 minutes. While extracting a large automotive door handle component, Layla inadvertently touched the mold surface which retained residual heat of 85°C. She sustained a second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 12 square centimeters on her right palm and inner forearm. Layla immediately ran her hand under cold water for 15 minutes and reported the injury to her supervisor, Mario Bélisle (EMP-00149). The incident occurred because the mold temperature indicator light had malfunctioned, providing no clear safety signal that the mold retained dangerous heat despite completing its cooling cycle. Layla was transported to the on-site first aid station and then to a local urgent care facility for burn treatment and dressing. She was prescribed topical antibiotic ointment and pain management. Layla took 4 consecutive days off work due to pain and burn care requirements. Mario Bélisle witnessed the incident and immediately documented it.

On March 20, 2024 at 10:15 PM, during the evening shift, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, was moving resin pellet pallets from the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) to the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While navigating through the warehouse loading corridor, the forklift's left hydraulic cylinder began leaking pressurized hydraulic fluid onto the warehouse floor. The leak originated from a corroded fitting that had degraded over an estimated 6-8 weeks without being serviced. Tariq noticed the leaking fluid and attempted to continue operation, but the left side of the forklift began to sag. The equipment became unstable during a turn near the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009), causing the forklift to tilt and strike a wooden storage rack structure. The collision caused the rack to collapse partially, scattering approximately 80 cartons of polycarbonate resin onto the floor. Material damage was estimated at $34,000 (resin loss and rack destruction). The forklift sustained structural and hydraulic damage valued at $18,500 and was removed from service. Tariq was not injured. Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), the Hydraulic Systems Technician, responded and documented the equipment failure. Root cause: preventive maintenance schedule was not followed; the hydraulic system had not been inspected in 12 weeks despite a 6-week service interval requirement.

On March 25, 2024 at 8:30 AM, Raj Patel (EMP-00018), a Process Engineer, was conducting a routine inspection of the composite material curing ovens in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While examining the ventilation system above Oven #3, Raj accidentally spilled approximately 200 milliliters of acetone-based mold release agent from a portable mixing container onto his left forearm and the inside of his left wrist. The chemical caused immediate skin irritation and mild stinging sensation. Raj reacted quickly by running to the emergency eyewash station and rinsing the affected area with water for 8 minutes. He then applied first aid by thoroughly washing with soap and water at a handwashing station. The skin showed redness and minor chemical irritation but no blistering or severe damage. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) arrived on scene within 5 minutes and assessed the situation. She applied antihistamine cream and monitored Raj for any signs of delayed reaction over the next 2 hours. Raj remained at work and continued his duties with periodic monitoring. The incident was recorded as a first aid treatment. Root cause: the container was not properly sealed during transport and positioning on the elevated inspection platform; secondary cause was inadequate secondary containment in the storage area.

On November 3, 2024, at 2:15 PM, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building (North Zone). While attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper using a compressed air hose, the hose detached suddenly from the coupling, creating a high-pressure spray of plastic pellets and compressed air. The unexpected release caused Arsenault to lose his footing and stumble backward approximately 3 feet, narrowly avoiding contact with the adjacent moving conveyor belt that was operational. Michael Chen (EMP-00004), the Production Supervisor, was present and immediately shut down the equipment. No physical contact with the conveyor occurred, but the incident demonstrated a serious gap in equipment maintenance procedures. The loose hose coupling had corroded connection threads that should have been inspected during the previous preventive maintenance cycle. This near-miss event was properly documented during the shift handover meeting.

On November 5, 2024, at 9:45 AM, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Building when equipment operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was transferring a 20-liter container of epoxy resin from a secondary containment tray to a mixing vessel. A forklift operated by Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167) was maneuvering pallets of raw materials in the adjacent storage zone. The forklift's load shifted unexpectedly, causing the operator to swerve sharply. This sudden movement startled Hassan, who lost grip on the resin container. Approximately 8 liters of the epoxy resin spilled onto the concrete floor in the hazardous waste management area, spreading across an area of approximately 4 square meters. The chemical began pooling near the floor drain. Hassan immediately activated the area alarm and notified Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist. Response teams deployed absorbent pads and cordoned off the area within 12 minutes. The spill was fully contained within 45 minutes. No personnel were exposed to the chemical. The root cause was determined to be inadequate spatial separation between active forklift operations and chemical handling activities, combined with insufficient communication protocols between the two operations.

On November 7, 2024, Tran Le (EMP-00036), a Quality Control Lab Technician, submitted a preventive hazard declaration regarding exposure risks in the Quality Control Laboratory located in the Administrative Building. During routine environmental monitoring, Le identified that the laboratory's UV spectrophotometer, which has been in use for 18 months, lacks the updated light-filtering protective shield that was recently recalled by the manufacturer due to degradation of the UV-absorbing material over time. The original shield allows approximately 12% more UV radiation to pass through than safety standards permit. While no acute exposure incidents have occurred, Le's declaration noted that technicians routinely spend 2-3 hours per week in close proximity to the equipment during material analysis procedures, creating a cumulative exposure risk. The equipment is used for quality verification of medical device components and consumer packaging materials. Le documented the concern through the JHSC preventive reporting system, recommending immediate replacement of the protective shield before any further equipment operation. This declaration was supported by the manufacturer's technical bulletin and corresponding safety data sheet revisions.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during day shift operations, a significant spill of acetone cleaning solvent occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). While Material Handler Kwesi Owusu was transferring a 20-liter container of acetone from the storage shelving to a work cart, the container's cap was not fully secured. The container tipped during transfer, spilling approximately 15 liters of acetone onto the warehouse floor. The solvent spread rapidly across the concrete surface, creating a slip hazard and releasing strong chemical vapors throughout the 2,000 square-foot warehouse area. The spill was discovered by Purchasing Manager Denis Savard, who immediately evacuated nearby personnel and activated the emergency response protocol. Facility ventilation systems were set to maximum capacity. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and proper chemical disposal procedures. No personnel were exposed to significant vapor concentrations due to rapid evacuation. The warehouse remained closed for 3 hours pending air quality testing and floor remediation. Root cause analysis identified inadequate container securing procedures and insufficient training on proper chemical handling during transfer operations.

On November 16, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during evening shift operations, Assembly Operator Ana Silva sustained a burn injury while working at Injection Molding Line D (Consumer Packaging section). Silva was removing finished parts from a mold that had completed its cooling cycle. Despite the nominal cooling time of 45 seconds, the mold surface temperature was approximately 65°C (149°F) due to a malfunctioning temperature control sensor that failed to register the true coolant system status. Silva's left hand made contact with the mold surface while removing a part, resulting in a thermal burn affecting approximately 8 square centimeters of skin on her palm and inner wrist. The burn was classified as a first-degree/partial second-degree thermal injury. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron immediately initiated first aid procedures, applied cool water for 15 minutes, and arranged for Silva to receive medical treatment at a local urgent care facility. Incident investigation revealed the temperature sensor had not been calibrated in eight months, exceeding the recommended maintenance interval. Silva was treated for the burn and released with topical antibiotic recommendations and follow-up care instructions. She was placed on modified duty for three days.

On November 12, 2024, at approximately 06:30 during night shift operations, Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi narrowly avoided a serious injury while performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine in the Central Maintenance Workshop (Main Floor). Rossi was adjusting hydraulic pressure settings on a machine that was supposed to be locked out and tagged out per LOTO procedures. However, Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante discovered that only a partial lockout had been performed—the main electrical disconnect was secured, but the hydraulic system isolation valve had not been locked in the closed position, contrary to documented procedures. While Rossi was working near the hydraulic manifold, a pressure release cycle was triggered remotely by night shift supervisor personnel who were unaware of the active maintenance work. Pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the work area, missing Rossi by approximately 30 centimeters but saturating his protective clothing. Rossi was not injured due to his positioning and the presence of protective eyewear. Laplante immediately secured the hydraulic isolation valve, terminated operations, and initiated a safety stand-down. Investigation revealed that the night shift supervisor did not have access to the current LOTO clearance board, and communication between maintenance and operations personnel was insufficient during shift transitions.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, Remi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a thermal burn while performing routine mold maintenance. Remi was working in the Main Production Building - South Zone (UNIT-004) and inadvertently made direct contact with a mold surface that had been recently ejected from an active injection molding machine. The mold temperature was approximately 180°C. Despite wearing standard production gloves, the contact duration was sufficient to cause a first-degree burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters on the dorsal surface of his right hand. Remi immediately notified his supervisor and proceeded to the first aid station where the burn was cooled with running water for 15 minutes and treated with antimicrobial ointment and a sterile dressing. The incident was witnessed by Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), an Assembly Operator working adjacent to Line D. No additional medical intervention was required; the employee continued work for the remainder of the shift with modified duties avoiding further heat exposure. The incident was likely caused by inadequate communication regarding mold temperature status and insufficient cooling time verification before maintenance activities.

On May 22, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), a Machine Setter, sustained a serious laceration while clearing a material jam from a composite materials processing hopper in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Svetlana was attempting to dislodge hardened resin material using a metal scraper tool when the hopper's internal auger unexpectedly restarted despite a manual shutdown. The rotating auger caught Svetlana's left forearm, causing a deep laceration approximately 12 centimeters in length requiring 18 stitches. The incident resulted in immediate loss of consciousness for approximately 2 minutes due to pain and shock. Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, immediately activated the emergency stop and called for emergency response. Svetlana was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital where she received emergency treatment and was admitted for overnight observation due to concerns about potential nerve damage. She was placed on medical leave beginning May 23, 2024. Investigation revealed the lockout/tagout procedure had not been fully engaged; a hasp was open and the electrical circuit was not properly isolated before maintenance commenced.

On July 8, 2024 at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Gaston Picard (EMP-00193), a Crane Operator, suffered a back injury while repositioning a 2,400-pound mold assembly suspended from the overhead crane in the Maintenance Workshop Equipment Storage area (UNIT-025). Gaston was guiding the load using positioning lines while the mold assembly was being lowered to a work surface. The load shifted unexpectedly due to an improperly seated sling connection, causing the load to swing laterally. In attempting to stabilize the load, Gaston pivoted and strained his lower back, experiencing immediate sharp pain in the lumbar region. He was unable to continue work and was examined by the facility nurse who documented the injury and advised medical evaluation. Gaston sought treatment at an urgent care clinic on July 9, 2024, where imaging revealed a moderate lumbar strain with muscle spasms. He was provided with anti-inflammatory medication and prescribed physical therapy. Gaston was placed on modified duty restrictions for 10 days, unable to perform crane operations or heavy lifting. Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), an Assembly Operator working in the maintenance area, witnessed the incident and immediately assisted Gaston to a sitting position. Investigation determined the four-point sling harness had not been properly tightened before the lift commenced, violating standard rigging procedures.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, injection molding operator Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171) was working at Line D in the Production Operations area when he attempted to remove a finished part from the mold without waiting for the cooling cycle to complete. The mold temperature was approximately 160°C. As Bertrand reached into the mold cavity with his bare hand to extract the polycarbonate component, his right palm and fingers made direct contact with the hot mold surface. He immediately withdrew his hand and reported severe pain and visible blistering to his supervisor. The burn affected approximately 8% of his right hand, with second-degree burns on the palm and first-degree burns on the fingers. He was immediately escorted to the on-site first aid station where the wound was cleaned, cooled, and dressed with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. Coworker Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159) witnessed the incident and assisted in contacting medical personnel. Bertrand was released after first aid treatment but advised to seek medical follow-up.

On March 22, 2024 at 02:15 during the night shift, material handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was stacking resin hoppers in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop storage mezzanine. While attempting to position a 50-pound polypropylene hopper onto the third shelf, the shelf support bracket suddenly fractured due to metal fatigue and stress from years of overloading. The hopper fell approximately 6 feet, striking Chiara's left shoulder and arm. The impact caused immediate sharp pain and temporary loss of sensation in her hand. Forklift operator Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), who was nearby retrieving spare parts, immediately assisted and called for medical support. First aid responder Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181) arrived within 3 minutes and assessed the injury. Diagnostic imaging later revealed no fractures but significant soft tissue trauma and a possible rotator cuff strain. The incident was narrowly avoided becoming more serious as no other workers were in the immediate vicinity.

On April 2, 2024 at 11:30, composite materials operator Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174) was processing glass fiber reinforced nylon sheets at the Composite Materials Processing Area when she noticed an unusual burning smell and visible chemical vapors emanating from the curing oven. The facility's resin fumes monitoring system indicated elevated levels of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) at 185 ppm, exceeding the recommended threshold of 100 ppm. Lina immediately evacuated the work area and reported the issue to her supervisor. Quality inspector Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180), who was nearby conducting routine quality checks, assisted in notifying the HSE department. Environmental compliance specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) arrived at 11:45 and confirmed that a heating element malfunction had caused the oven temperature to spike 40 degrees above the setpoint, causing accelerated resin decomposition and excessive fume generation. The area was evacuated for 2 hours while maintenance corrected the equipment. No employees experienced acute respiratory symptoms, but all exposed workers were monitored for 24 hours. This incident was classified as a near-miss because potential chemical exposure occurred but was interrupted by early detection.

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 14:45, an isopropanol spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-011). Maya Kumar (EMP-00138), a Production Operator assigned to assist with resin preparation, was transferring a 20-liter container of isopropanol from a storage shelf to a mixing station when the container slipped from her grip and fell approximately 1.2 meters to the concrete floor. The container's cap partially dislodged upon impact, releasing approximately 8 liters of isopropanol across a 4-meter radius on the floor and creating a visible vapor cloud in the storage area. The spill occurred near compressed gas cylinders and electrical equipment. Maya immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency response alarm at 14:47. Deepa Gupta (EMP-00080), Quality Engineer, and Daniel Kim (EMP-00025), Electrical Maintenance Technician, arrived as first responders and implemented the facility's spill containment protocol, deploying absorbent materials and establishing a 10-meter safety perimeter. The spill was fully contained by 15:30. No direct skin contact occurred, but vapor exposure affected respiratory comfort. The incident was declared by Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), EHS Coordinator, at 15:45 following initial investigation.

On November 18, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, an electrical arc flash incident triggered the facility's fire alarm system in the Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-020 administrative building connection). Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), Machine Setter on the Evening Shift, was performing routine maintenance on injection molding machine Line D control panel when he inadvertently contacted a live 480-volt terminal with a metal wrench, creating an electrical arc. The arc ignited insulation material inside the panel, causing localized fire and heavy smoke generation at 22:16. The fire alarm was automatically triggered by the smoke detection system. Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), Assembly Line Lead, coordinated immediate evacuation of the production floor and assembly areas. Emergency response personnel arrived at 22:22. Fire suppression using CO2 extinguishers controlled the fire by 22:28, preventing spread to adjacent equipment. Approximately 85 employees were evacuated from the production building within 8 minutes following established protocols. The incident resulted in damage to the control panel and temporary shutdown of Line D operations. No injuries were reported. Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), Ergonomics Specialist, was assigned as the incident investigator and filed the formal report at 23:45.

On November 22, 2024 at 10:30, a near-miss incident was identified during routine production operations in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), Forklift Operator, was moving a pallet stack of finished composite materials using a 5,000-pound capacity forklift when he noticed that upper boxes on the 1.8-meter-high stack were shifting laterally and beginning to tilt. The stack had been loaded improperly the previous evening by an unfamiliar night-shift team member, with boxes placed off-center on the pallet and not shrink-wrapped according to protocol. Hugues immediately lowered the forks to ground level and stopped the forklift, preventing the inevitable collapse that would have occurred within meters. He carefully repositioned the load and requested assistance from Gaston Picard (EMP-00193), Crane Operator, to restack the materials properly using the overhead crane system with proper load-securing equipment. No boxes fell, no employees were struck, and no injuries occurred. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), Occupational Health Nurse, was notified and documented the near-miss incident at 10:55, recognizing that under different circumstances, this could have resulted in a critical load-drop incident affecting multiple workers in the shipping area below.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, material handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was organizing raw plastic pellet bags in the Materials Management and Warehousing area when she noticed an unusual hissing sound emanating from a pressurized resin storage tank. She immediately moved away from the area and notified her supervisor, Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031). Upon closer inspection, a small crack was detected in the tank's discharge valve assembly, which was releasing pressurized resin fumes into the workspace. The area was evacuated within minutes, and emergency ventilation systems were activated. No personnel were exposed to hazardous concentrations, and the tank was immediately isolated using emergency isolation procedures. The incident was contained before any chemical release occurred. Jamal Thompson, the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, responded and monitored air quality during the response.

On March 18, 2024, at 4:15 PM during the evening shift, machine setter Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124) was removing finished parts from Injection Molding Line D when he experienced a sharp laceration to his right palm from an undeburr edge on a newly molded component. The part had inadequate edge finishing and was still warm from the mold. Tomas immediately went to the first aid station where his wound was cleaned and dressed. Given the depth of the laceration (approximately 2 cm) and the significant bleeding, he was transported to a nearby urgent care facility by company vehicle where he received 8 stitches and a tetanus update. Tomas was unable to return to work for the remainder of the shift and the following day due to pain and limited hand mobility. His supervisor, Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), documented the incident and Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) initiated the lost-time injury investigation. The incident resulted in approximately 16 hours of lost work time over two days.

On March 22, 2024, at 2:30 AM during the night shift, warehouse lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) was conducting routine inventory checks in the Finished Goods Warehouse when he observed that Hydraulic Systems Technician Andrei Popov (EMP-00094) had begun maintenance work on an overhead bridge crane that had been showing intermittent movement issues. During the maintenance, the crane's brake mechanism suddenly failed while Andrei was working beneath the suspended hook and load. The 2-ton load (plastic component batch) began to descend uncontrollably. Andrei was able to move away from the immediate impact zone, but the load descended rapidly and struck the concrete floor approximately 18 inches from where he had been standing, scattering components across a 15-foot radius. The load impact caused structural damage to a neighboring storage rack. Emergency responders assessed Andrei for injuries; while he sustained minor bruising to his left shoulder from the near-miss impact wave, he was not trapped or struck directly. Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001), Director of HSE, was immediately notified and responded to the scene. The crane was immediately taken out of service.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was transferring a 50-liter container of polyester resin from storage to the mixing station when the container's lid became loose due to improper sealing during the previous shift. As Mwangi lifted the container onto the transfer cart, approximately 15 liters of resin spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous pool that also splashed onto adjacent work surfaces and storage bins. The resin, containing styrene monomer, began to vaporize rapidly in the warm room environment. Within minutes, the strong chemical odor was detected by nearby personnel. Mwangi immediately alerted his supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin and activated the emergency response protocol. The spill was contained using absorbent material and neutralizing agents. The room was evacuated and ventilation systems were maximized. No personnel sustained direct contact injuries, but three workers reported mild respiratory irritation from vapor exposure. The incident was likely caused by inadequate container sealing procedures and insufficient verification checks before material transfers.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) sustained a burn injury while performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D in UNIT-004. Charbonneau was attempting to clear a material blockage in the injection nozzle assembly when he inadvertently contacted the heated barrel section of the molding machine. Despite wearing standard work gloves, the extreme temperature of the barrel (approximately 240°C) caused a second-degree burn to his right palm and inner wrist, affecting approximately 8% of the contact area. The burn resulted in visible blistering and significant pain. Charbonneau immediately removed his hand from the heat source and flushed the affected area with cool water for several minutes. His supervisor was notified, and first aid was applied on-site. However, due to the severity and blistering nature of the injury, Charbonneau was transported to Laval General Hospital for evaluation and treatment. The investigation revealed that the machine's thermal safety guard had been removed during the previous maintenance cycle and was not reinstalled. Additionally, Charbonneau had not received the updated machine-specific burn prevention training recently implemented by the safety department.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 6:15 PM during the evening shift, Quality Control Technician Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013) fell from a loading dock edge while retrieving finished product samples in the Shipping and Receiving Dock area (UNIT-009). Lapointe was standing on the 4-foot elevated dock edge attempting to reach a product crate that had been placed slightly back from the dock edge when her left foot slipped on a wet surface caused by earlier equipment cleaning. She fell approximately 3.5 feet to the concrete floor below, landing on her right side. The impact resulted in a fractured right ribs (confirmed via X-ray), severe bruising to the right hip and abdomen, and a minor laceration to the right elbow. Lapointe was unable to return to work and was transported to Laval General Hospital for evaluation and treatment. Investigation revealed that the dock area had been recently cleaned but wet floor signage was not posted, and no anti-slip coating was present on the dock edge surface. Additionally, protective railings on the dock edge were found to be incomplete, with a 6-foot gap in the existing barrier near the area where the fall occurred.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, a fire originated in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) during a resin curing operation. Employee Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was monitoring an industrial oven set to 120°C when she noticed the temperature controller began malfunctioning, displaying erratic readings. She notified her supervisor, but before maintenance could respond, an exothermic reaction in the uncured composite batch inside the oven caused the temperature to spike uncontrollably to 180°C. The excess heat ignited volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from the epoxy resin, initiating a small fire inside the oven chamber. The fire alarm was activated by another operator, Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), who was working nearby at the automation systems. Plant Manager Jean-François Lefebvre (EMP-00002) coordinated the emergency response. The facility's automatic suppression system activated within 90 seconds, extinguishing the fire. No injuries occurred, but the oven sustained significant damage. The root cause was inadequate preventive maintenance on the temperature control system and lack of real-time oven monitoring protocols.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 AM, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). Employee Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler working the day shift, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent (acetone-based) from storage to a processing station using a hand pump transfer system. The drum's cap was not fully secured, and during movement across the facility floor, the drum tilted against a metal corner support, causing a pinhole rupture in the sidewall. Approximately 20 liters of mold release agent spilled onto the concrete floor and began flowing toward the facility's storm drain system. Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183) witnessed the spill and immediately activated the emergency response procedures. The area was cordoned off, and absorbent material was deployed to contain the spill. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was notified and oversaw the cleanup and disposal process. The spill was fully contained within 45 minutes. No personnel were exposed to hazardous concentrations, and no environmental release beyond the facility occurred. Root causes included inadequate container inspection procedures and improper securing of drum caps during transport.

On March 28, 2024 at 11:30 PM during the night shift, a near-miss incident was prevented in Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-004). Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) was conducting routine maintenance on one of the 250-ton injection molding machines when he discovered that a previous operator had failed to properly engage the Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) system. The machine's emergency stop button had been reset, and the power disconnect switch showed signs of tampering. Emmanuel immediately halted his work and did not attempt to service any components. He notified Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), who conducted an emergency investigation. The machine was properly locked out and tested using the proper LOTO procedures. Investigation revealed that the evening shift operator had rushed through the end-of-shift shutdown procedure to leave early for personal reasons and had circumvented LOTO protocols. No worker was injured, and the serious hazard of unexpected machine activation during maintenance was averted. The incident was classified as a near-miss with high severity potential, as an unaware maintenance worker could have suffered severe entanglement or amputation injuries.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire originated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-020 adjacent area). An employee, Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021), was transferring polyester resin from a 55-gallon drum into smaller containers using a manual pump system. Due to inadequate ventilation and accumulated resin fumes in the storage area, an ignition source—likely from static electricity generated during the transfer process—ignited the vapor-rich atmosphere. The initial flame spread rapidly across spilled resin residue on the concrete floor, reaching approximately 8 feet in height within seconds. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) activated the facility alarm and coordinated evacuation. The facility's fire suppression system engaged, but not before the fire spread to adjacent storage shelving containing flammable composite materials. Local fire department responded within 8 minutes and contained the blaze. The incident resulted in significant damage to chemical inventory, destruction of approximately 20% of composite material stock, and temporary shutdown of operations for 36 hours. No personnel were physically injured, but three employees experienced smoke inhalation and were treated on-site.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a Machine Operator, was operating the plastic regrind processing line when a malfunction in the material hopper feedgate caused approximately 45 liters of liquid colorant concentrate (containing organic solvents and pigments) to spill onto the production floor. The spill immediately spread across the concrete surface, covering approximately 120 square meters. Due to inadequate training on chemical spill response and missing emergency absorbent materials at the spill location, the liquid began seeping toward the floor drain system that connects to the facility's wastewater treatment pre-treatment area. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, was notified and immediately initiated spill containment by placing temporary barriers. However, an estimated 12 liters had already entered the drain system before complete containment was achieved. The facility's environmental management system required notification to CNESST and Quebec's environmental authority (MELCCFP) due to exceeding the 10-liter threshold for reportable spills to waterways. Response and cleanup took 8 hours. Laboratory analysis confirmed trace contamination in downstream water systems, requiring enhanced monitoring for 60 days.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a Production Operator working on Injection Molding Line B, sustained a significant thermal burn injury. Mensah was performing routine quality checks on injected automotive components when a pressurized resin hopper failed unexpectedly, releasing superheated plastic material at approximately 280°C directly onto his left forearm and hand. The operator was wearing standard work gloves, which provided insufficient insulation against the high-temperature polymer. The material adhered to his skin, causing deep partial-thickness burns covering approximately 8% of his body surface area (forearm and dorsal hand). Immediate response involved submersion in cool water at a nearby safety station and urgent transport to the regional burn center (Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur in Montreal) by ambulance. The incident was witnessed by two colleagues, Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) and Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), who activated emergency response protocols. Mensah required hospitalization for 4 days, surgical debridement, and skin grafting. He was placed on medical leave for 12 weeks with expectation of partial permanent scarring and reduced hand mobility. The incident triggered loss-of-time classification due to extended work incapacity.

On April 22, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, was operating the plastic regrind machine in the Raw Materials Warehouse when he experienced acute onset severe burning and blistering on his right hand and forearm. While attempting to clear a blockage in the hopper feed mechanism, hot recycled polypropylene material at approximately 185°C contacted his skin when his glove partially snagged on the rotating auger. His glove became partially melted to his skin. Coworker Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), the Warehouse Lead, immediately deactivated the equipment using the emergency stop button and applied cold water to the affected area for 15 minutes. Emergency medical services arrived at 11:15 PM. Oscar was transported to the Burn Unit at Centre de traumatologie du Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM) with severe second and third-degree burns covering approximately 15% of his right upper extremity. He required hospitalization for 8 days, multiple debridement procedures, and extensive wound care. Medical assessment indicates he will require 6-8 weeks off work and subsequent occupational therapy. The incident was reported by Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) under the company's mandatory incident reporting protocol.

On May 8, 2024, at 3:47 AM during the night shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Central Maintenance Workshop when sparks from a grinding operation on a metal component initiated an unexpected fire in a waste disposal bin containing rags contaminated with hydraulic oil and acetone solvent residue. The bin was located within 3 meters of the active grinding workstation. The fire suppression system activated automatically, extinguishing the small fire (estimated 2-3 square meters) within 2 minutes. However, the fire spread rapidly due to the presence of highly flammable solvent-saturated materials. Night Shift Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) and an unnamed maintenance technician evacuated the area immediately upon alarm activation. No personnel were injured. The Laval Fire Department responded at 4:12 AM to confirm fire containment and inspect for any residual hazards. The facility was cleared for re-entry at 5:30 AM. Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), Fire Safety Coordinator, completed the incident investigation and determined that the waste bin lacked proper fire-resistant labeling, was overfilled, and stored materials that should have been segregated according to chemical compatibility protocols. The incident was reported as a potential CNESST recordable event due to building evacuation and emergency response.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a significant material spill occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment department (UNIT-017). Normand Bergeron, Regrind Supervisor, was overseeing the loading of recycled polypropylene pellets into the main hopper when the automated auger system malfunctioned. The hopper overflow sensor failed to trigger, causing approximately 800 kg of mixed regrind material to overflow onto the production floor and adjacent equipment. The spilled material contained traces of colorant masterbatch and contaminated the thermal processing unit's exterior surfaces. The overflow also damaged electrical junction boxes and ventilation ductwork valued at approximately $47,000. The facility's maintenance team, led by Carlos Rodriguez, responded immediately to contain the spill and assess equipment damage. Production was halted for 6 hours to allow cleanup and inspection. Investigation revealed that the hopper level sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months, and preventive maintenance records were incomplete. No personnel were injured during the incident, but the spill created a slip hazard and contaminated the adjacent assembly area's clean room entrance.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Abdul Rahman, Machine Operator on Evening Shift, sustained a significant burn injury while performing maintenance cleaning on Injection Molding Machine Line 8. Rahman had just completed the standard end-of-shift temperature reduction procedure but did not fully allow the mold surfaces to cool. While wiping down the exterior of the mold assembly with a damp cloth, he inadvertently touched the interior mold cavity which was still at approximately 145°C. His right palm and fingers sustained a severe thermal burn covering approximately 15% of the hand surface. The burn caused immediate blistering and tissue damage. Rahman was immediately escorted to the on-site first aid station by Marcel Duchesne, Injection Molding Operator - Line B, who witnessed the incident. First aid was provided, and Rahman was transported to Hôpital Fleury via ambulance at 11:15 PM. Medical evaluation confirmed a partial thickness burn requiring specialized wound care and resulted in 12 days of lost work time. Investigation revealed that Rahman had not completed the mandatory annual burn safety refresher training (due October 2024) and the machine's cool-down indicator light had been non-functional for two weeks.

On November 20, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the early morning portion of the night shift, Kwame Mensah, Production Operator - Night Shift, experienced a near-miss incident involving a compressed air line malfunction in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). Mensah was using a compressed air line to dry pallets after cleaning the dock floor following a chemical spill cleanup. The compressed air hose connection at the wall outlet suddenly detached due to improper securement (the quick-disconnect coupling was partially unscrewed). The hose whipped violently, striking Mensah's upper torso and face with high-pressure air, causing temporary disorientation but no apparent physical injury. Martin Lavoie, Crane Operator, immediately secured the air line and assessed Mensah for injuries. The incident was reported to Karine Cloutier, Safety Trainer, who arrived on-site at 7:00 AM. Medical evaluation confirmed no lacerations, contusions, or hearing damage. However, the near-miss investigation revealed several critical gaps: (1) the compressed air system had no pressure relief valve visible on the dock outlet, (2) there was no documentation of compressed air safety training completion for night shift personnel, (3) hose maintenance inspection records were missing for the past 3 months, and (4) no personal protective equipment (face shield or protective glasses) was available at the dock workstation.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building when she noticed the mold temperature gauge displaying an unusually high reading of 285°C, well above the standard operating range of 200-220°C. As she leaned in to inspect the control panel more closely, a small stream of pressurized resin vapor suddenly burst from a relief valve on the adjacent injection unit, passing within inches of her face. Farah immediately stepped back and activated the emergency stop button. The vapor dissipated within seconds with no contact to her skin or eyes. She reported the incident to her supervisor Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), who was working nearby on Line A. Upon investigation, it was determined that the temperature controller had malfunctioned, causing the system pressure to build beyond safe limits. The relief valve functioned correctly and prevented a potential explosion. The machine was taken offline for maintenance, and no injuries occurred. This incident was a near-miss that could have resulted in serious chemical burns or more severe injuries had the relief valve not operated properly.

On March 18, 2024, during the evening shift at approximately 8:45 PM, Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was working in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B) preparing orders for shipment. While manually stacking plastic storage containers on wooden pallets near the loading dock staging area, a stack of approximately 15 containers suddenly began to tilt unexpectedly. Diallo immediately recognized the instability and quickly stepped backward, creating distance between himself and the tilting stack. The containers did not fall but remained in a precarious, tilted position at approximately 45 degrees. Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), who was conducting inventory verification nearby, witnessed the near-incident and assisted Diallo in safely repositioning the containers and stabilizing the stack. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the pallet beneath the stack had a previously undetected crack running along one side, compromising its structural integrity. The crack had likely been caused by repeated forklift impacts during materials movement earlier in the day. No injuries occurred, but the incident demonstrated a potential for serious crushing injuries if containers had fallen on a worker. The damaged pallet was immediately removed from service and disposed of.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, Automation Engineer Sylvain Jodoin (EMP-00155) was performing routine maintenance on the hydraulic injection pump assembly in the Main Production Building when he discovered that the pump's pressure relief valve had corroded internally and could no longer regulate system pressure effectively. The valve displayed visible rust deposits and mineral scale buildup from prolonged use in a humid manufacturing environment without adequate protective coating. When Jodoin attempted to adjust the valve during diagnostic testing, the pressure gauge fluctuated erratically between 1,200 and 2,800 psi, far exceeding the design specification of 1,800 psi maximum. The malfunctioning relief valve could not maintain consistent pressure, rendering the entire molding line inoperable and creating a safety hazard if the system were to be pressurized during operation. The valve had to be completely replaced with a new unit featuring improved corrosion-resistant materials and a protective coating. This equipment failure resulted in approximately 16 hours of lost production time while replacement parts were procured and the new valve was installed and tested. The failed valve was sent for analysis to determine if the corrosion issue affected other valves in the facility.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant ventilation system failure occurred in the Injection Molding Line A facility (North Zone). Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) was operating injection molding machine #8 when he noticed a sudden decrease in air extraction and an unusual buildup of acrid plastic fumes in the work area. Within minutes, multiple operators in the North Zone reported respiratory irritation and eye discomfort. Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) immediately activated the emergency ventilation reset, but the system did not respond. The facility's HVAC system, which had not been serviced since December 2023, had experienced a complete motor failure in the main extraction unit serving the molding line. The backup ventilation system failed to engage automatically due to a faulty damper valve. Approximately 18 workers in the North Zone were exposed to elevated styrene and other volatile organic compound concentrations (estimated at 3-4x normal levels) for approximately 2.5 hours until the HVAC maintenance team restored manual operation of the backup system. Three employees reported to first aid with headaches and mild respiratory irritation. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois arrived on scene at 4:15 PM and immediately declared the incident.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse Section C). Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of uncured epoxy resin from a storage rack approximately 8 feet high using a powered pallet jack when the drum's locking ring became loose during transport. As the drum shifted position on the pallet, approximately 12 gallons of epoxy resin spilled onto the concrete floor. The material flowed approximately 30 feet across the warehouse floor and seeped into the facility's storm drain system through a crack in the concrete flooring. Assembly Operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056), who was working nearby, immediately notified shift supervisors. Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) initiated containment using absorbent pads and berms. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) was called at 10:50 PM and arrived at the facility by 11:15 PM to assess the environmental impact and implement cleanup protocols. Water sampling later confirmed trace epoxy compounds in the local storm water runoff. The incident required environmental notification to local CNESST authorities and an estimated 18-hour remediation effort.

On March 28, 2024, at 8:15 AM during the day shift, a laceration injury occurred in the Mold Manufacturing area (part of Maintenance and Engineering operations). Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was operating a CNC milling machine to manufacture a precision mold insert for an automotive component when the chuck key was left in the rotating spindle. As Caron reached toward the machine to measure the workpiece, his left hand made contact with the spinning key, which acted as a projectile and struck his palm, laceration his left hand between the thumb and index finger. The injury penetrated approximately 2 centimeters into the tissue and required 8 stitches. Automation Technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), working at an adjacent station, heard the impact and immediately shut down the machine, calling for first aid assistance at 8:18 AM. Caron was transported to Laval Hospital emergency department at 8:35 AM for evaluation and treatment. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) arrived within 15 minutes of the incident notification and documented the scene. Investigation revealed that Caron had not completed the most recent CNC machine safety refresher training (overdue by 6 weeks) and was not wearing cut-resistant gloves, which were available but not being consistently enforced. The machine's spindle lock warning light was also non-functional.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Mixing Room (UNIT-022). Elena Popescu, Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring a 25-liter container of acetone from storage to a mixing vessel when the container's cap failed due to corrosion, causing approximately 18 liters of acetone to spill across the floor and into a floor drain system. The spill created a visible vapor cloud in the enclosed space, triggering the facility's chemical alarm system. Elena immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency response protocol. The facility's hazmat team responded within 8 minutes, deployed absorbent material, and ventilated the space using portable extraction fans. No direct contact with the chemical occurred, but the incident exposed inadequate container maintenance procedures and insufficient secondary containment infrastructure. The spill entered the facility's waste water management system, requiring environmental remediation notification to Quebec authorities. The event was witnessed by two other operators who evacuated safely.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Naomi Okafor, Production Operator on Injection Molding Line B (UNIT-002), nearly experienced a severe burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. After completing a production cycle, Naomi approached the mold surface to remove residual plastic material using a handheld tool. She did not verify that the machine's heating system had cooled to safe operating temperature, as indicated by the control panel display. When her hand inadvertently contacted the mold surface, she immediately felt intense heat and pulled back within 0.5 seconds. Her work glove provided minimal insulation, and the contact lasted approximately 1 second. She experienced moderate redness on her hand but no blistering or deep tissue damage. A nearby machine operator, Raoul Blanchard, witnessed the near-miss and called the supervisor. Naomi was assessed by the on-site first aid responder and given ice treatment. The incident was averted from becoming a serious burn injury by rapid withdrawal and protective glove material, but highlighted inadequate temperature monitoring procedures and insufficient PPE guidance.

On March 28, 2024, at 11:50 PM during the night shift, Luc-André Beaudoin, Warehouse Supervisor, nearly sustained a serious fall injury while inspecting inventory on the elevated racking system in the Materials Management and Warehousing facility. The night shift operates with minimal staffing (only Beaudoin and one warehouse associate present). While climbing a 14-foot portable ladder to access storage bins on the upper shelf, Beaudoin noticed the ladder's left rail wobbled slightly as he positioned it against the racking. He paused and tested the ladder's stability by shifting his weight, which caused noticeable movement. Despite recognizing the instability, he continued climbing because the associate was occupied elsewhere. At approximately 11 feet height, the ladder suddenly shifted laterally about 4 inches as the base feet slipped on the polished concrete floor. Beaudoin maintained his grip on the ladder and halted his ascent, then carefully descended. The ladder had no anti-slip feet and was positioned without a spotter. The near-miss prevented a potential fall from height of 11+ feet onto concrete flooring with high probability of multiple fractures or head trauma.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator, was manually removing finished plastic components from a cooling rack in the Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components area. While handling a batch of polycarbonate medical device housings, Amal made contact with a sharp edge on one of the molded parts, causing a 3-inch laceration on the inner surface of the left palm. The injury occurred because the part had a burr left from the molding process that had not been fully deburred. Amal immediately reported the incident to supervisor Michael Chen. The wound was cleaned, treated with antiseptic, and covered with a sterile bandage at the on-site first aid station. The injury required 5 stitches but did not necessitate lost work time. The employee returned to duties the following day with modified tasks to prevent reopening the wound. Root cause analysis identified inadequate quality control procedures in the finishing department.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine when a pressure release valve unexpectedly malfunctioned. While attempting to manually reset the valve to relieve residual system pressure, the valve cap suddenly released under full system pressure (approximately 1,200 PSI), striking Bruno's right forearm and causing a severe thermal and pressure burn. The scalding hydraulic oil spray also contacted the operator's right shoulder and neck area. Emergency response team leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) immediately provided first aid while emergency medical services were called. Bruno was transported to the hospital with second-degree burns covering approximately 12% of his body. He required 7 days of hospitalization and was unable to return to work for 21 days, resulting in lost wages and workers' compensation claim. Investigation revealed the pressure release valve had not been properly maintained and tested within the required quarterly inspection schedule.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a catastrophic failure occurred in the chemical storage containment system at the Hazardous Waste Management Area. Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, had been transferring excess acetone solvent from a 55-gallon drum to secondary containment bins when a structural crack developed in a plastic secondary containment tray. The tray had been in service for 8 years beyond its rated lifespan and had experienced repeated thermal stress from temperature fluctuations. Approximately 40 gallons of acetone solvent spilled onto the concrete floor, with approximately 8 gallons flowing toward the storm drain system before Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), the night shift production operator, discovered the spill during a routine check. Emergency containment procedures were initiated immediately. Absorbent materials were deployed to contain the remaining liquid, and the environmental remediation team was called. The storm drain system was secured to prevent environmental discharge. Investigation estimated approximately 6-8 gallons entered the storm drainage system before being intercepted. CNESST and environmental authorities were notified. Cleanup and environmental monitoring cost approximately $45,000. Root cause: inadequate equipment lifecycle management and inspection protocols for secondary containment systems.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a burn injury while removing a finished component from the molding machine. The part temperature was approximately 85°C, and Bertrand was not wearing heat-resistant gloves despite the equipment's safety requirements. He reached directly into the ejection zone to retrieve a consumer packaging component that had partially stuck, making direct contact with both the hot plastic part and the heated mold cavity. The contact resulted in second-degree thermal burns on his right palm and fingers. His workstation supervisor, Sonia Dasilva, immediately applied cold water for 15 minutes and called for first aid assistance. The facility's first aid responder, Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), administered initial treatment including antibiotic ointment and sterile dressing. Bertrand was able to return to work the same day with modified duties. The incident was attributed to the employee not following standard PPE requirements and inadequate communication regarding the machine's thermal hazards during the shift handover.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, a potential hazardous condition was identified in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) by Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006), Maintenance Manager. During a routine inspection, Carlos discovered that the overhead crane used for lifting heavy mold assemblies (up to 2 tons) had not been inspected or certified for over 18 months, well beyond the required 6-month inspection interval mandated by provincial regulations. Additionally, the crane's load-limiting device was found to be non-functional, creating a serious risk of overload situations. Four maintenance technicians, including Réjan Simard (EMP-00077), regularly operate this crane for mold installation and removal tasks. No incident had occurred at the time of discovery, but the condition represented a critical compliance gap. Carlos immediately shut down the crane and posted warning signage. Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer, was notified for corrective action planning.

On November 21, 2024, during the evening shift (approximately 6:45 PM), Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), Chemical Mixing Operator, discovered a significant safety concern in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While preparing a batch of mold release agent, Elena noticed that multiple containers of flammable solvents (acetone and methylethylketone) were stored directly adjacent to the emergency eyewash station and emergency exit, blocking approximately 60% of the exit pathway. Additionally, the fire extinguishers mounted on the wall were partially obscured by stacked pallets of raw resin materials. Emergency lighting above the exit was not functioning. No active fire or chemical spill had occurred at the time of discovery, but the condition represented multiple serious violations of workplace safety and fire code regulations. Elena immediately reported the concern to Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, who conducted a full walkthrough and documented the violations with photographs. The area was flagged as hazardous, and restricted access was implemented pending corrective action.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper of a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. Despite following standard lockout/tagout procedures, a residual pressure surge in the hydraulic system caused the machine's clamp to partially open unexpectedly. Conrad's right hand was caught between the mold cavity and the clamp base, resulting in crushing injuries to his index and middle fingers. Co-worker Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button. Hana Al-Rashid, the Occupational Health Nurse, arrived within 3 minutes and provided immediate first aid. Conrad was transported to Laval General Hospital with suspected fractures and severe contusions. He missed 18 working days and required surgical consultation. The incident was attributed to incomplete pressure relief procedures and inadequate preventive maintenance on the hydraulic accumulator.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, was transporting a pallet of polypropylene resin bags from the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) to the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The forklift's left hydraulic cylinder failed catastrophically, causing the load to tilt approximately 35 degrees. Two pallets of raw materials (approximately 1,200 kg total) slid from the forks and struck the concrete floor, rupturing several resin bags and damaging the warehouse floor. The forklift came to rest against a support column, incurring damage to its left mast assembly and hydraulic lines. Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), a Warehouse Associate nearby, was not struck but witnessed the incident. Karine Cloutier was notified and immediately inspected the scene. No personnel injuries occurred, but equipment damage was significant and resin contamination required immediate cleanup. The forklift was deemed unsafe to operate pending repairs.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 8:15 AM during the day shift, Soraya Alami (EMP-00196), an Assembly Operator in the Assembly and Finishing Department, was manually deburring composite parts using a fine-grit sanding block. Despite wearing standard cotton gloves, small fragments of glass fiber reinforcement became embedded in the glove material. As she continued working, microscopic fibers penetrated through the fabric and lodged in the skin of her left palm and fingers, causing localized itching and mild skin irritation appearing as a rash. She immediately reported the discomfort to her supervisor, Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175). The area was washed thoroughly with soap and water, and Hana Al-Rashid applied a soothing cream and provided antihistamine wipes. The irritation subsided within 2 hours with no medical attention required. However, the incident revealed that many assembly operators were unaware of the specific hazards of glass fiber contact and the limitations of standard cotton PPE in this application.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), Injection Molding Operator on Line D, noticed unusual vibration and noise coming from the hydraulic pump system on his injection molding machine. Rather than immediately stopping production and reporting the issue through proper channels, he attempted to diagnose the problem himself by manually adjusting the pressure relief valve while the machine remained partially energized. While inspecting the hydraulic lines, he observed a small pinhole leak spraying hydraulic oil mist. Upon closer inspection, he discovered that the main seal on the pump had deteriorated significantly, and the entire hydraulic system was operating at elevated pressure. The machine's pressure gauge was reading 3200 PSI versus the normal operating range of 2800 PSI. Bruno immediately powered down the machine and reported the situation to his supervisor, Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070). This preventive reporting prevented a potential catastrophic failure that could have resulted in a high-pressure hydraulic line rupture and serious injury from ejected fluid or flying debris. The incident was proactively declared to prevent similar conditions on other production lines.

On April 8, 2024, at 8:15 PM during evening shift, Nour Jaber (EMP-00188), Packaging Operator, was manually removing finished medical device components from a cooling conveyor when his left hand made contact with residual hot plastic material still adhering to the interior of a mold cavity. The material, approximately 180°C (356°F), caused immediate first-degree and partial second-degree thermal burns across his palm and first three fingers. The employee instinctively withdrew his hand and called out for help. Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180), Quality Inspector, heard the call and immediately escorted Nour to the first aid station. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, was summoned and administered first aid including immediate cold water immersion (5 minutes at approximately 15°C), application of sterile gauze, and pain management. The affected area was cleaned and covered with antibiotic ointment and sterile dressings. Local ice pack application was applied for 15 minutes. Nour was offered medical evaluation, which he declined, stating the pain had diminished significantly. The incident was documented and he was advised to monitor the injury and seek medical attention if symptoms worsened.

On May 22, 2024, at 11:45 PM during night shift, an electrical fault developed in a 480-volt power distribution panel serving the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). The fault caused a sustained arc flash within the panel enclosure, generating extreme heat and igniting residual solvent vapors (acetone and isopropanol) that had accumulated in the area due to inadequate ventilation. The resulting fire quickly spread to nearby storage containers of cleaning solvents and colorant masterbatches, creating a rapidly expanding chemical fire. The night shift supervisor immediately activated the facility's emergency alarm system at 11:47 PM and initiated evacuation procedures. Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), Warehouse Associate, who was conducting inventory in an adjacent area, detected the fire alarm and heavy smoke. He evacuated safely and alerted Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), Workplace Safety Representative (who was on-site for a night inspection), of the fire location. Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), Environmental Compliance Specialist, arrived at the facility within 15 minutes (called in from emergency protocols) and coordinated with the Laval Fire Department. The fire was extinguished at 12:23 AM using Class C dry powder extinguishers and foam suppressants. Damage was contained to the electrical panel and two storage racks. No injuries occurred. Post-incident investigation revealed the electrical fault was caused by corroded terminals and inadequate maintenance of the distribution panel.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Machine Operator Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195) was performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Line A in the Main Production Building when he noticed excessive material buildup in the hopper. While attempting to manually clear the blockage with a wooden rod, the machine's automatic cycle unexpectedly activated. The hopper auger began rotating, and the rod became caught, creating a dangerous pinch point. Therrien immediately withdrew his hand, but the wooden rod was pulled into the mechanism with considerable force. Although he avoided direct contact with the rotating auger, the incident created a near-miss scenario where serious hand laceration or amputation could have occurred. The machine was immediately stopped by an emergency stop button activated by nearby operator Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00159). Investigation revealed that the machine's interlock system, designed to prevent operation during cleaning cycles, had not been properly engaged due to inadequate training on lockout/tagout procedures for this specific maintenance task.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Regrind Operator Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034) was processing recycled plastic material in the Composite Materials Processing Area. While transferring regrind material from a collection bin to the hopper using a metal scoop, his left hand came into contact with warm mold release agent that had been applied to recently processed parts. The chemical contact caused immediate skin irritation and a localized allergic reaction manifesting as redness, swelling, and intense burning sensation across the palm and between his fingers. Ibrahim immediately reported the incident to Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), who assisted him to the first aid station. First aid personnel flushed the affected area with water for 15 minutes and applied a topical antihistamine cream. Despite first aid treatment, the reaction persisted and intensified. Ibrahim was transported to a nearby urgent care facility where he was diagnosed with acute chemical contact dermatitis and prescribed additional medication. He was unable to return to work for the remainder of his shift and required two additional days off for the reaction to subside. Root cause analysis identified that Ibrahim was not wearing appropriate chemical-resistant gloves, and the mold release agent containers in the processing area lacked clear warning labels about skin contact hazards.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was conducting preventive maintenance on the composite materials curing oven in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. While inspecting the heating elements, he discovered that a section of the oven's exterior aluminum frame had corroded significantly due to prolonged exposure to humidity and chemical vapors from the adjacent Hazardous Waste Management Area. Upon closer inspection and pressure testing, he found that the structural integrity of the oven's mounting brackets had been compromised, with visible metal fatigue cracks extending through two of the four support brackets. The corrosion had weakened the equipment to the point where continued operation posed a risk of structural failure. Additionally, Gravel discovered that the oven's control panel electrical connections had been exposed to moisture ingress, creating potential electrical hazards. He immediately shut down the equipment and isolated it with warning tags. The oven was taken out of service, and a structural assessment by external engineers determined that the equipment required immediate replacement rather than repair. The damage extended beyond visible corrosion to internal frame deterioration, affecting an estimated $47,000 piece of equipment. The incident resulted in a 5-day production delay as alternative curing arrangements were established at a contract manufacturer, incurring additional costs.

On March 14, 2024, at 14:45 during the day shift, a chemical storage tank valve malfunction in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room resulted in an uncontrolled release of approximately 120 liters of acetone solvent. The incident occurred when Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler, was retrieving cleaning supplies from the storage area. She noticed a strong chemical smell and observed liquid pooling beneath Storage Tank C-7. Upon investigation, she discovered the tank's outlet valve had corroded and failed due to inadequate maintenance scheduling. The acetone vapor quickly spread through the ventilation system, affecting nearby areas. Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), a Packaging Operator in the adjacent assembly area, reported eye irritation and respiratory discomfort.
