Emergency response was initiated immediately: the area was evacuated, the valve was manually shut-off by Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), the Chemical Safety Officer, and the spill was contained using absorbent material. The facility's ventilation system was increased to full capacity. Environmental cleanup took 3 hours. No injuries requiring hospitalization occurred, but the incident exposed significant gaps in preventive maintenance protocols for critical chemical equipment.

On April 2, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, a catastrophic failure occurred in one of the company's 32 plastic injection molding machines (Unit M-28) in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. The machine's hydraulic pressure relief valve ceased functioning properly, causing system pressure to exceed safe operating limits. This resulted in rupture of a main hydraulic line, spraying pressurized hydraulic oil across the work area. Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), the Warehouse Lead on night shift, was working in the adjacent storage area and was struck by pressurized hydraulic fluid, causing chemical burns to his left arm and minor lacerations. The machine automatically shutdown due to loss of hydraulic pressure, but not before significant damage occurred. Maya Kumar (EMP-00138), a Production Operator at the station, witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop. Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, responded and isolated the machine from all energy sources using LOTO procedures. The hydraulic system required complete flushing and the relief valve required replacement. Investigation revealed the valve had not been serviced in 18 months, far exceeding the 6-month maintenance interval specified by the equipment manufacturer.

On May 8, 2024, at 06:30 during the night shift, equipment failure occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse when an automated material handling system's drive motor seized suddenly. Nour Jaber (EMP-00188), a Packaging Operator, was positioned near the robotic arm conveyor when the motor failure caused the robotic arm to jerk violently and strike a stack of palletized finished goods. The sudden movement caused approximately 15 boxes of precision composite components to fall from the upper pallet rack. Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), a Material Handler working 8 feet away, was struck on the shoulder by a falling box, causing bruising and temporary loss of range of motion. Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), the Regrind Operator nearby, called for emergency assistance. The incident was brief but resulted in inventory damage estimated at $12,000 and one employee injury requiring medical evaluation. Post-incident inspection revealed that the drive motor had not been lubricated in over 8 weeks, causing progressive bearing degradation. Maintenance records showed a failure to perform routine lubrication checks per the equipment's maintenance manual.

On November 21, 2024, at 6:20 PM during the evening shift, Assembly Operator Soraya Alami (EMP-00196) was performing final assembly and packaging of medical device components on Injection Molding Line B (UNIT-002). While removing cured plastic parts from the active injection molding machine's output tray without proper lockout procedures, her right hand became trapped between the advancing platen and the stationary mold housing. The automatic injection cycle continued for approximately 3 seconds before being manually stopped by Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190), who was working nearby. Alami sustained a crushing injury to her right hand including two fractured metacarpals, lacerations requiring 12 stitches, and significant soft tissue damage. She was transported to Hopital Pierre-Boucher at 6:45 PM and underwent emergency surgery. Root cause investigation revealed that the machine's manual emergency stop button was partially obstructed by stacked finished goods containers, and the required LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) checklist had not been completed prior to maintenance access. Alami remained hospitalized for 5 days and required 8 weeks off work during recovery.

On November 18, 2024, at 1:15 AM during the night shift, Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) was conducting preventive maintenance on the hydraulic pump system in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). While disconnecting a high-pressure hydraulic hose to replace a worn fitting, he noticed a small spray of pressurized hydraulic fluid escaping from the connection point. Mailhot immediately closed the isolation valve and depressurized the system per protocol. However, he observed that approximately 200 milliliters of hydraulic fluid had leaked onto the concrete floor and splashed onto his work gloves and the lower portion of his protective apron. Upon closer inspection of the hose connection, he identified that the ferrule crimping on the hose was defective, with microscopic cracks visible under magnification. Mailhot immediately reported the incident to Training Coordinator Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) via emergency call. The fluid was cleaned up using approved absorbent material and properly disposed of. No personal injury occurred because Mailhot was wearing appropriate PPE including nitrile gloves, chemical-resistant apron, and safety glasses. The incident was classified as a near-miss because exposure occurred but no skin contact or ingestion took place. The defective hose assembly was removed from service and quarantined for evidence.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, production operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was operating Injection Molding Line B when she attempted to clear a material jam in the hopper without following proper lockout/tagout procedures. While reaching into the hopper to dislodge compacted polypropylene resin, the auger suddenly activated, catching her left hand and wrist. The equipment was not properly de-energized, and no LOTO tags were in place. Co-worker Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) immediately shut down the line and called for emergency response. Leila sustained a compound fracture to her left radius, severe lacerations, and significant crush injury requiring immediate hospitalization and emergency surgery. She underwent orthopedic surgery and was admitted for 5 days with subsequent loss of work for 12 weeks. The incident was witnessed by quality inspector Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180) who was present on the production floor. Investigation revealed the LOTO procedure was bypassed to save time during a high-demand production run.

On February 8, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, machine setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was conducting routine mold change-over on Injection Molding Line D when she noticed a small hydraulic fluid leak from a connection point on the press actuator. Rather than attempting to clear the leak herself, she immediately flagged the issue and discontinued operation of the equipment. She placed warning signs around the machine and notified her supervisor. Maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) from the night shift responded and confirmed the leak was from a deteriorated O-ring seal. The issue was contained, documented, and scheduled for repair during the next maintenance window. No fluid contacted personnel, no production was disrupted beyond the planned downtime, and no injuries occurred. The incident was properly reported as a near-miss because the hazard (potential for hydraulic fluid injection injury and subsequent chemical exposure) was identified and controlled before any harm could result. This exemplifies proper hazard recognition and reporting culture.

On January 22, 2024, at 09:30, material handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was transferring rolls of glass-fiber reinforced nylon from the raw materials storage area to the central maintenance workshop for processing. While manually lifting a 45-pound roll from a pallet onto a workbench, he felt a sharp pain in his lower back. Hassan completed the task and continued working for approximately 2 hours before pain intensified. He reported the incident to safety officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) at 12:00. Hassan was assessed and given first aid treatment including ice application and anti-inflammatory medication. He returned to modified duty for lighter material handling tasks for 3 days before resuming full duties. X-rays revealed no fracture but significant muscle strain in the lumbar region. The incident was classified as an injury because there was tissue damage and temporary work restriction, though not requiring hospitalization. Production operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was present and witnessed Hassan's difficulty with the lift, noting he was lifting with improper form rather than using the available mechanical lift equipment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Building 5). Oscar Ramirez, the Regrind Technician, was transferring approximately 20 liters of mold release agent from a bulk container into smaller 5-liter storage bottles using a manual pump system. While disconnecting the transfer hose from the bulk container, the quick-disconnect coupling failed, causing the hose to rupture and spray mold release agent across the floor and work surface. Approximately 8 liters of the oily, slippery liquid spread across a 4-meter radius before the spill was contained. The chemical created a significant slip hazard and minor vapors were detected. Oscar was on-site and immediately notified Serge Lafleur, the Workplace Safety Representative, who initiated spill containment procedures. The area was cordoned off, absorbent materials were deployed, and the chemical was properly contained within 30 minutes. No personnel were directly exposed to the chemical, but the incident highlighted inadequate quick-disconnect maintenance procedures and insufficient spill containment protocols in the chemical mixing area.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident was identified on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building. Bertrand Jalbert, an Injection Molding Operator, noticed that the automatic part ejection system on the injection mold was not functioning properly. Instead of investigating further, he attempted to manually remove a partially-cooled plastic component from the mold while the machine remained in standby mode with residual heat still present. As he reached into the mold cavity with his bare hand, a residual pressure release from the hydraulic system caused the mold to shift slightly. Bertrand's hand was approximately 2 centimeters away from a contact point that would have resulted in serious thermal burn when Rémi Charbonneau, another operator on the line, shouted a warning. Bertrand withdrew his hand immediately. Investigation revealed that the machine's LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure had not been followed, and the operator had not verified complete pressure dissipation before attempting manual part removal. The incident was reported to Zahra Nasri, the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, who documented it as a serious near-miss with high potential for severe thermal burns.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, an equipment failure incident occurred at the Regrind and Recycling Department in the Warehouse and Shipping area. Viktor Novak, the Electrical Technician, was performing routine checks when he discovered that the primary ventilation system serving the regrind operation had ceased functioning. The system, responsible for removing plastic dust and fumes from the regrind process, had been offline for an estimated 3-4 hours before detection. Ibrahim Yusuf, the Machine Setter assigned to night shift regrind operations, had continued processing recycled plastic material unaware of the ventilation failure. Upon discovery, the regrind area showed elevated airborne particulate levels and staff reported mild respiratory irritation and burning eyes. Karine Cloutier, the Safety Trainer, was called to assess the situation and implement emergency ventilation measures, including opening additional emergency exhaust windows and relocating affected personnel. Investigation revealed that the automated ventilation monitoring system had malfunctioned and failed to trigger the alarm that should have alerted maintenance personnel. The primary motor bearing had seized due to lack of preventive lubrication maintenance. No serious medical complications resulted, but the incident highlighted critical gaps in equipment maintenance procedures and system redundancy for safety-critical ventilation equipment.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn to his right forearm while removing parts from a mold cavity. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C. While wearing standard cotton work gloves, Mathieu reached into the mold to clear a partially ejected plastic component that had stuck due to inadequate mold release agent application. His glove slipped, and his forearm made direct contact with the hot cavity wall for approximately 2 seconds before he withdrew his arm. The burn resulted in a 4cm x 3cm area of first-degree erythema with minor blistering on the inner forearm. Mathieu immediately reported to the first aid station in the Production Operations area where Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), the Workplace Safety Representative, provided treatment: cooling with water for 15 minutes, application of sterile gauze, and topical antibiotic ointment. No hospitalization was required. The incident was documented and the employee returned to modified duty (non-molding tasks) for two days to allow healing.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:15, during the evening shift, a critical failure occurred in the cooling water circulation system serving the post-processing heat treatment ovens in the South Zone. Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, noticed water leaking from connection joints on the main cooling header. She immediately shut down the affected oven and notified Fernand Guigère (EMP-00169), the Maintenance Technician on call. Upon investigation, Fernand discovered that two flexible hose clamps had corroded and fractured due to inadequate maintenance intervals and lack of stainless steel fasteners in the saltwater-adjacent facility environment. The resulting coolant spray damaged three critical temperature sensors and caused a $47,000 loss in specialized composite material in the oven chamber that could not be salvaged. The system remained non-operational for 18 hours pending parts replacement. Production of medical device components was delayed by two days, impacting customer delivery schedules. Root cause analysis revealed the cooling system had not received scheduled maintenance in 14 months, exceeding the recommended 12-month interval.

On April 3, 2024 at 08:20 during the day shift, Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), Warehouse Lead, was directing material handling operations in the Shipping and Receiving Dock when a critical incident occurred. Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler, was using an electric forklift to move a pallet stack of resin bags (approximately 1,500 kg) when the load became unstable due to improper stacking. As she navigated a turn near the dock edge, the pallet load shifted and approximately 12 resin bags fell onto her left leg, trapping her foot between the pallet and a steel storage rack. She immediately cried out in pain. Normand rushed to assist and carefully removed the bags with help from two other workers. Salma sustained a compound fracture of the left tibia and fibula with significant soft tissue damage and crushing injury. Emergency services were called at 08:22, and paramedics arrived at 08:31. She was transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur and underwent emergency surgery for fracture stabilization and compartment syndrome management. She will require 4-6 months recovery with expected lost time of 20+ weeks. Root cause: pallet load was unstacked 38cm above recommended height (stacking guide violation) and no load stability verification occurred before forklift movement.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire initiated in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) in the main production building's west wing. An assembly operator, Ana Silva (EMP-00040), was applying epoxy resin to composite layup materials near an industrial oven set to 180°C. A container of solvent-based cleaning solution was inadvertently placed on a heat exchanger outlet vent, causing the liquid to vaporize and ignite when it contacted the heating element. The resulting flash fire spread to nearby rolls of fiberglass mat and pre-impregnated composite materials stored within 3 meters of the oven. The employee immediately activated the nearest emergency alarm and evacuated the area. The on-site fire suppression system (foam-based) was manually activated by production supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015), who was working nearby. The fire was contained within 8 minutes, but the intense heat damaged approximately €45,000 of raw materials and temporary equipment. No personnel were physically injured, but two employees experienced minor smoke inhalation. The facility's ventilation system was strained during the response, and investigation revealed that chemical storage procedures had not been reinforced during recent shift changes.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 9:15 PM during the evening shift, a serious hand laceration and crush injury occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) located in the warehouse and shipping section A. Forklift operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) was unloading a pallet of pre-molded plastic resin pellets from an incoming truck. As he positioned the pallet onto a stacking rack, warehouse supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) was guiding the load from the side to ensure proper alignment. A mechanical failure in the forklift's hydraulic system caused the load to suddenly drop approximately 18 inches. Roberto's left hand was positioned between the descending pallet and the support frame of the rack, resulting in significant crushing and laceration of his left ring and middle fingers. The pallet landed with sufficient force that the frame supporting it bent, trapping the employee's hand until David manually operated the forklift's manual hydraulic release valve. Emergency medical services arrived within 12 minutes. The employee was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where he underwent surgical repair of lacerated tendons and partial tissue reconstruction. He was admitted overnight with moderate crush syndrome but recovered full hand function after 6 weeks of physiotherapy. Investigation identified that the hydraulic system had not been serviced according to the preventive maintenance schedule due to equipment downtime delays.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017) located in the main production building's south zone. CNC machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was performing routine maintenance on an industrial oven used for thermal curing of composite parts. The oven was supposed to be in lockout/tagout (LOTO) status during maintenance, with the main power disconnected and controlled by an authorized maintenance lock. However, a second CNC operator, Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072), who had completed the night shift startup procedures, inadvertently failed to receive the LOTO notification and activated the equipment warm-up cycle remotely from the production control panel. When the oven began heating, Dimitri was inside the internal chamber cleaning heating elements with a steel brush, exposing him to intense radiant heat and near-electrocution hazard from the heating elements still carrying residual electrical charge. He immediately exited the oven and shouted an alert. The oven reached 95°C before the heating elements were manually de-energized by quality control inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068), who was present in the area. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed critical communication gaps in the LOTO procedure and shift handover protocol. Investigation found that the LOTO notice had been placed on the oven control panel but not communicated through the facility's electronic alert system.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a resin dryer malfunction occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Material Handler Amani Mwangi was preparing polyamide resin pellets for Line C production when the industrial dryer began emitting a strong chemical odor and visible vapor. The thermostat had failed, causing the heating element to overheat to approximately 280°C instead of the standard 80°C operating temperature. Within minutes, resin fumes began spreading throughout the material handling zone. Mwangi immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency ventilation system. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos responded to the scene and measured airborne resin fume concentrations at 8.5 ppm, exceeding the company's 5 ppm action level. The facility was partially evacuated as a precaution. Environmental monitoring continued for 3 hours until the dryer cooled. No employees reported acute respiratory symptoms, but the incident triggered investigation into preventive maintenance schedules and equipment monitoring protocols. The dryer was taken offline for inspection and repairs.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Yasmin Ali suffered a significant burn injury while operating Injection Molding Line C (UNIT-003). Ali was retrieving finished medical device components from the injection molding machine when she inadvertently contacted the heated nozzle assembly of the machine, which was operating at 260°C. Her right hand made direct contact with the nozzle for approximately 2-3 seconds before she pulled away. Ali sustained second-degree thermal burns across the palm and first three fingers of her right hand, with blistering and significant pain. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron immediately provided first aid by running cool water over the injury for 15 minutes and applying a sterile burn dressing. Emergency Medical Services were called and arrived within 8 minutes. Ali was transported to Laval General Hospital for evaluation and treatment, where she received additional burn care and tetanus prophylaxis. She was placed on medical leave for wound management. Investigation revealed that the machine's nozzle guard had been improperly installed during the morning shift setup, leaving the heating element partially exposed.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Mold Maintenance Technician Réjan Simard sustained a minor laceration requiring first aid treatment. While performing routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013), Simard was inspecting a newly machined steel mold cavity when his left index finger contacted a sharp edge that had not been properly deburred. The contact created a shallow but clean laceration approximately 1.5 inches long on the palm side of his finger, with minor bleeding. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury was alerted and arrived at the work area within 5 minutes. She cleaned the wound with antiseptic solution, applied direct pressure to control bleeding, and dressed the laceration with a sterile adhesive bandage and antibiotic ointment. The wound did not require stitches. Simard continued working with protective glove coverage over the bandage for the remainder of his shift. The sharp edge on the mold was immediately deburred by another technician to prevent recurrence. The incident was documented in the first aid log but did not result in lost work time or medical attention beyond on-site first aid.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in Injection Molding Line D (Consumer Packaging). Process Technician Jade Wong was performing routine mold changeover when the hydraulic system of the 150-ton injection molding machine suddenly failed. The mold clamping mechanism malfunctioned, causing the upper and lower mold halves to separate unexpectedly while pressurized resin was still being injected. Hot molten plastic material (approximately 280°C) sprayed across the production floor in a 3-meter radius, damaging the machine's control panel, electrical wiring harnesses, and auxiliary cooling equipment valued at approximately $47,000. The heated material also ignited insulation material near the equipment base, creating a small fire that was quickly extinguished by the on-site automatic suppression system. No workers were in the direct spray path, though the incident caused significant equipment damage and a 16-hour production shutdown. Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne responded immediately and isolated the affected equipment. The root cause was identified as inadequate preventive maintenance on the hydraulic pump seal, which had been scheduled but delayed due to production demands.

On March 28, 2024 at 8:30 AM during the day shift, a significant equipment failure and material loss incident occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Maintenance personnel were performing routine CNC milling machine calibration on a critical mold repair operation when the machine's spindle bearing seal failed catastrophically. This resulted in uncontrolled release of machine coolant (approximately 180 liters of industrial cutting fluid) that flooded across the workshop floor and into the adjacent Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. The spilled fluid contaminated multiple work-in-progress molds, precision grinding equipment, and quality control tools, causing estimated material and equipment damage of approximately $62,500. The coolant also migrated toward the chemical storage area, creating environmental and safety concerns that triggered hazmat response protocols. Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne and maintenance staff immediately deployed absorbent materials and initiated containment procedures. The incident resulted in an 18-hour workshop closure for cleaning and remediation. Secondary damage included damage to 12 precision injection molds in progress, CNC machine control system contamination requiring deep cleaning, and loss of two days of production scheduling. Root cause analysis identified that the spindle bearing seal replacement was overdue by 340 operating hours due to inadequate tracking of maintenance intervals.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Maya Kumar (EMP-00138) was working at Injection Molding Line A when she accidentally contacted hot plastic material that had extruded from a mold cavity. While adjusting a part ejector mechanism, her right forearm made brief contact with melted polycarbonate at approximately 280°C. She immediately pulled her arm back and reported a sharp burning sensation. A blister approximately 3 cm in diameter formed within minutes on her inner forearm. Her supervisor called for first aid support, and Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid responded within 5 minutes. The burn was rinsed with cool water for 15 minutes, covered with sterile gauze, and treated with topical antibiotic ointment. Maya received tetanus prophylaxis and was cleared to continue work with modified duties. The incident occurred because the machine's thermal guard had a loose mounting bracket, allowing easier-than-normal contact with the hot zone. No lost time occurred, but Maya experienced discomfort for 3 days.

On November 18, 2024, at 9:47 PM during the evening shift, Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) suffered a laceration to his left index and middle fingers while feeding reclaimed plastic material into the granulator at the Material Drying and Preparation Room. The hopper feed mechanism had a partially exposed rotating auger screw due to a missing safety interlock cover. As Fernand guided compacted material into the feed chute, his gloved hand was caught between the incoming material and the rotating auger, causing a 4 cm laceration on his index finger and a 2 cm cut on his middle finger. The machine emergency stop button was activated by nearby Quality Supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079) within 3 seconds. Both wounds bled moderately but did not penetrate deeper than the dermal layer. Fernand was transported to the hospital emergency department by ambulance where he received 8 stitches total and tetanus prophylaxis. He was released the same night with pain management medications. Root cause analysis revealed the interlock cover had been removed 6 weeks prior for maintenance and never reinstalled. The incident resulted in 24 hours lost time and significant concern from other operators.

On November 22, 2024, at 11:58 PM during the night shift, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when a resin dryer unit (Model HDR-450X) began overheating due to a failed thermostat sensor. The dryer was processing glass-fiber-reinforced polypropylene at an intended temperature of 85°C when the thermostat malfunction caused the heating element to remain engaged continuously, raising the internal chamber temperature to approximately 156°C. At 11:58 PM, the facility's automatic fire detection system triggered the alarm after detecting smoke and elevated temperature near the dryer exhaust vent. The night shift supervisor immediately activated the emergency evacuation protocol. All 20 night shift employees evacuated safely to the designated assembly point in the north parking lot within 4 minutes. The automated dry chemical suppression system in the storage room activated automatically, discharging 45 kg of ABC powder and extinguishing the smoldering resin material. Emergency services arrived at 12:07 AM and verified no active fire remained. The dryer sustained significant damage (estimated $35,000) and two storage shelves of uncured composite materials were damaged. Root cause: The thermostat had not been replaced during the last scheduled maintenance cycle due to supply chain delays that were not properly communicated to operations. This was the second instance of deferred maintenance on this equipment.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a laceration to his left palm while removing a finished component from the mold cavity. The part, a precision automotive connector housing, had sharp edge burrs that were not fully deburred in post-processing. While reaching into the mold area to extract the component, Marcel's hand contacted an unfinished edge, resulting in a 2-inch laceration requiring 4 stitches at the on-site first aid station. The incident was immediately reported to Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), the Evening Shift Production Supervisor who was present for cross-shift briefing, and first aid was administered by the on-duty health services technician. The root cause was identified as incomplete deburring due to a downstream process backlog, combined with inadequate protective equipment (bare hands instead of cut-resistant gloves) during component handling. No lost time occurred as the employee was treated and returned to modified duties within 2 hours.

On March 18, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, discovered a significant chemical spill in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). While conducting routine inventory checks, a 20-liter container of polycarbonate resin solvent (methylene chloride, CAS 75-09-2) was found leaking from a compromised storage shelf. Approximately 12 liters had already spilled onto the concrete floor and was spreading toward the main drain system. The container appeared to have been damaged during a previous forklift movement, with a small crack in the lower sidewall that gradually worsened due to vibration from adjacent equipment. Natasha immediately activated the spill response protocol, evacuated the area, and notified Giorgio Plante (EMP-00179), Facilities Technician, who cordoned off the zone with warning tape and placed absorbent barriers. The spill was contained before reaching the storm drain, and cleanup took approximately 3 hours. During this time, the chemical storage area remained inaccessible to other staff. No personnel were directly exposed to hazardous vapors due to the quick response and existing ventilation system, but the incident highlighted gaps in container inspection procedures and shelf stability protocols.

On March 21, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift operations, Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), Hydraulic Systems Technician, sustained a severe thermal burn to his right forearm while performing emergency maintenance on Injection Molding Machine Line C (UNIT-003). Andrei was responding to a pressure release valve malfunction that was causing intermittent high-pressure hydraulic fluid discharge. Despite the machine being placed in a maintenance lockout state, a residual pressure pocket in the secondary hydraulic accumulator remained pressurized. When Andrei removed the valve assembly coupling to inspect internal seals, a sudden pressurized release of hydraulic fluid at approximately 85°C (185°F) sprayed across his right arm from wrist to elbow, causing second-degree burns across approximately 15% of his forearm surface. The incident occurred at 18:35, and immediate first aid was administered (cold water immersion for 20 minutes), followed by transport to the emergency department at Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé. Andrei required hospitalization for 4 days and received specialized burn treatment, including topical antibiotics and dressing changes. The root cause was identified as incomplete LOTO procedure: the technician failed to isolate and bleed the secondary accumulator system before beginning work. Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), Mechanical Maintenance Technician, was present as a witness and assisted with first aid response. This was classified as a lost-time injury requiring restricted duty modification for 8 weeks during healing and rehabilitation.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Injection Molding Operator Bruno Landry was performing routine maintenance on Line D when a cooling water pump bearing seized suddenly. The pump, which had been operating continuously for 8 hours without scheduled maintenance checks, began making grinding noises before the impeller fractured internally. Pressurized cooling fluid sprayed from the pump housing, damaging adjacent electrical components and shutting down the entire molding line. The operator quickly isolated the system using the emergency shut-off valve and notified maintenance. No personnel were directly struck by fluid, but the equipment failure caused $47,000 in damage to the pump assembly and related cooling system infrastructure. The incident revealed that the predictive maintenance program recently implemented had not yet been applied to Line D equipment. Investigation showed the bearing lacked adequate lubrication due to a blocked grease fitting that had gone unnoticed during the previous week's visual inspection.

On April 3, 2024 at 09:15, Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc was removing molded parts from an injection molding cavity when she noticed the press had cycled without proper ejection sequence triggering. Upon closer inspection, she discovered the proximity sensor that detects mold closure position had become misaligned, causing the machine's safety interlock to malfunction. The machine was still actively pressurizing the mold cavity, which could have resulted in personnel contact with high-pressure hydraulic systems or unexpected mold ejection. Leblanc immediately activated the emergency stop button and called for maintenance support. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the sensor misalignment. The issue was traced to a loose mounting bracket that had vibrated free over the past week of continuous operation. No injuries occurred because the operator followed proper lockout procedures before attempting manual part removal. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the safety system ultimately prevented contact with the hazard, though equipment failure nearly disabled the protective mechanism.

On April 22, 2024 at 22:30, during the evening shift, Production Operator Omar Said was extracting completed parts from an injection molding cavity when his left hand made contact with a mold surface that was hotter than expected. The mold temperature had climbed to 145°C due to a malfunctioning cooling cycle regulator that failed silently during the shift transition. Despite wearing standard nitrile gloves, Omar sustained second-degree thermal burns across his palm and three fingers. He immediately immersed his hand in cool water and alerted his supervisor. Emergency response personnel treated the burns with sterile dressing and referred Omar to the hospital for evaluation. X-rays revealed no underlying bone damage, but the burns required hospitalization for 18 hours for pain management and fluid therapy. Omar was placed on modified duty for 8 days and experienced significant discomfort during healing. The investigation determined that the cooling regulator had never been included in the facility's preventive maintenance schedule because it was overlooked during the ISO 45001 implementation. The operator who worked day shift failed to report the rising mold temperature readings, which escalated the hazard.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, material handler Amina Mansour was organizing plastic resin bags in the storage mezzanine of the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room when she noticed a large cardboard box of metal fasteners positioned precariously near the edge of the mezzanine railing. As she reached up to adjust the box's position to prevent it from falling, the box shifted suddenly and nearly fell onto Rashid Habib, another material handler working below on the warehouse floor. Rashid quickly moved out of the way, and the box landed approximately 2 feet from where he had been standing. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the box had been improperly stacked during the previous evening shift without adequate securing straps or edge protection barriers. No injuries occurred, but the near-miss highlighted a critical gap in the materials management procedures for the elevated storage areas. The incident was immediately reported to Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher, who secured the area and initiated a walkthrough of all mezzanine storage locations.

On March 22, 2024, during the evening shift (4:30 PM), Simon Bélanger, Chemical Safety Officer, conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room as part of TechnoPlast's preventive hazard assessment program. During this inspection, Bélanger identified that three large containers of thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) resin stored in the back corner of the facility were approaching their expiration dates (expiring within 60 days). Additionally, he noted that the temperature and humidity monitoring system for the chemical storage area had not been calibrated in 14 months, exceeding the company's 12-month maintenance standard. The containers' safety data sheets indicated that TPU resin should be stored at temperatures between 18-25°C and humidity below 60% to prevent degradation and potential chemical instability. Upon further review, Bélanger discovered that environmental records for the past 4 months were incomplete, with only sporadic manual readings rather than continuous automated monitoring. No chemical leak, fire, or exposure incident had occurred, but the control system failure represented a significant gap in preventive safety measures. Bélanger immediately documented the findings and reported them to Zahra Nasri for formal declaration and corrective action planning.

On April 5, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the night shift, a fire incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Normand Bergeron, Regrind Supervisor, was overseeing the operation of the plastic pellet grinding and collection system when fine plastic dust that had accumulated on horizontal surfaces near the regrind mill ignited from an electrical spark generated by a worn bearing in the grinding equipment. The fire began as a small flame in the accumulated dust layer but quickly spread across the collection bin area, reaching approximately 4 feet in height within 60 seconds. Night shift personnel (approximately 8 workers present) immediately activated the facility's emergency alarm system at 10:47 PM. Facility Manager Gérard Boucher and two staff members responded with portable CO2 fire extinguishers and successfully suppressed the flames by 10:52 PM. No employees were injured, and the fire was contained to the immediate regrind equipment area with no spread to adjacent sections. However, the incident revealed critical failures: the equipment had not been thoroughly cleaned in 6 weeks (dust accumulation exceeded safe levels), preventive maintenance on the bearing assembly was 3 weeks overdue, and the dry chemical fire suppression system serving the area had not been pressure-tested in 18 months. The facility was evacuated for 2 hours while air quality was assessed and the scene was secured.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was working at Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging area when she noticed sharp burrs on newly molded plastic components. While manually removing parts from the molding machine, she sustained a laceration on her left index finger from a sharp edge on a part. The injury required cleaning and three stitches at the on-site first aid station. Ndiaye reported the issue proactively to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen, noting that the mold cavity had developed micro-cracks that were creating the sharp edges. This preventive declaration highlighted a quality control issue that could affect multiple workers if not addressed. The sharp edges were discovered during routine part inspection by Quality Control Technician Léa Parent, who also sustained a minor cut. The incident was classified as low-severity but high-probability given the high volume of parts processed daily.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, the primary ventilation system serving the Regrind and Recycling Department experienced a catastrophic failure. Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) discovered that the main exhaust fan motor had seized, causing a complete halt to air circulation in the recycling area. Within minutes, plastic fume concentrations began accumulating from the ongoing compounding and regrinding operations. Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) reported feeling dizzy and experiencing respiratory irritation. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was immediately notified and initiated emergency protocols. The affected area was evacuated; all regrinding operations ceased. Investigation revealed that the fan motor bearings had deteriorated due to lack of scheduled preventive maintenance—the motor had operated 6,500 hours beyond its recommended service interval. The facility's backup ventilation system was insufficient to handle full production load. Emergency repairs took 4.5 hours, during which operations were suspended and three workers received medical evaluation for respiratory exposure.

On May 2, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Receiving Coordinator Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142) was organizing incoming material shipments at the Shipping and Receiving Dock. Forklift Operator Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167) was unloading pallets of raw plastic resin when Nadia stepped into the blind spot behind an incoming pallet, unaware of the forklift's position. Fontaine was backing up to position another pallet when Quality Control Manager Isabelle Tremblay (EMP-00005), who was inspecting incoming materials, shouted a warning. Fontaine immediately stopped the forklift, halting movement within 18 inches of Nadia. The near-miss was extremely close—had Fontaine been moving at normal speed, Nadia would have been struck. The incident was immediately reported by Tremblay to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen. Investigation revealed that visibility from the forklift operator position is severely compromised when loading certain pallet configurations, and there was no positive communication protocol between dock personnel and equipment operators. The dock lacked audible backup alarms on the forklift, and pedestrian pathways were not clearly marked.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053) was working at Injection Molding Line A in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. While removing a batch of cooled plastic components from the automated removal system, Benoit's left hand came into contact with a sharp edge on one of the molded parts. The edge, approximately 2mm in length, created a laceration on his palm requiring immediate first aid. The injury occurred because the part's edge had not been properly deburred during quality control inspection. Benoit was wearing standard nitrile gloves, which proved insufficient against the sharp plastic edge. The wound was cleaned and bandaged on-site by the first aid responder. Investigation revealed that the CNC deburring machine had been running below optimal settings for the past two shifts due to a calibration drift that went undetected. Benoit continued working after receiving first aid, but the incident was properly documented as a recordable minor injury.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, forklift operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was navigating through the Raw Materials Warehouse carrying a pallet of plastic resin pellets. As he approached the southeast corner of Section A, Tariq encountered an air hose that had become disconnected from its mounting bracket and was now lying partially across the floor pathway. Tariq did not immediately notice the hose due to the dim lighting in that corner of the warehouse combined with the reflective nature of the polyethylene coating on the hose. He swerved his forklift to avoid the hose, but the sudden maneuver caused the pallet to shift slightly on the forks. No materials fell, and Tariq maintained full control of the equipment. The forklift did not strike any objects or personnel. Receiving Coordinator Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142), who was nearby organizing incoming shipments, observed the incident and immediately alerted Tariq to the hazard. The air hose was repositioned and secured within minutes. Investigation determined that the hose bracket fastener had loosened due to vibration from nearby material handling equipment, and the warehouse lighting in that zone measured only 45 lux compared to the required 200 lux minimum.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during the night shift, crane operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) was preparing to hoist a large mold assembly from the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room mezzanine to transfer it to the Maintenance Workshop. The mold, weighing approximately 850 kilograms, was positioned on the overhead crane and the rigging had been inspected. As Raymond initiated the lift at approximately 30% of maximum speed, he noticed that the load seemed to be shifting slightly within the rigging straps. Raymond immediately stopped the lift and did not raise it any further. He contacted LOTO Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) to inspect the rigging configuration. Upon investigation, Gaétan discovered that one of the four rigging straps was not fully seated in the load-bearing saddle bracket—a gap of approximately 8mm existed. If the load had been lifted further or to full height, the strap would have slipped entirely, likely causing the mold to fall from 4.5 meters onto the mezzanine floor or equipment below, potentially causing serious injury to personnel in the area. The rigging was immediately repositioned correctly, and the lift was completed successfully. The root cause was determined to be inadequate employee training on proper rigging setup procedures and a lack of a standardized pre-lift verification checklist.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Maya Kumar (EMP-00138) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room when she noticed the resin dryer temperature gauge reading abnormally high at 285°C, exceeding the safe operating range of 260°C. She immediately reported this observation to her supervisor Maxime Boisvert without attempting to adjust the equipment. The dryer's heating element had partially malfunctioned due to a failed thermostat control, which had not been caught during the morning maintenance check. Quality Engineer Daniel Turgeon (EMP-00137) was called to the scene and safely powered down the equipment before any thermal damage or fire could occur. The incident was contained within 15 minutes with no personnel exposure to excessive heat or flames. Investigation revealed that the preventive maintenance schedule for thermostat calibration had been extended beyond recommended intervals due to equipment availability issues.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 7:15 PM during the evening shift, Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) sustained a laceration to her left index finger while manually removing finished composite parts from a cooling rack in the Materials Management area. While placing parts into a shipping container, her hand caught on a sharp, burr-edged plastic protrusion on one of the freshly molded components. The cut was approximately 1.5 inches long and 0.25 inches deep, causing active bleeding. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) immediately provided first aid by applying direct pressure with sterile gauze from the first aid kit, cleaning the wound with antiseptic solution, and bandaging it with a sterile adhesive bandage. After 10 minutes, the bleeding had stopped and the wound was properly dressed. Carmen was able to continue working with the bandaged finger and did not require further medical intervention or lost time. The incident occurred because quality control had not been flagged for the specific parts with rough edges, and no protective gloves rated for sharp material handling were available in the workstation.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 2:20 AM during the night shift, Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was loading a pallet of raw polypropylene resin bags onto the upper shelf of a storage rack in the Materials Management and Warehousing area. While stacking the third bag at approximately 6 feet height, another pallet on the adjacent lower shelf shifted slightly due to accumulated settling of bags underneath it, causing the entire upper shelf to tilt approximately 8 degrees. René immediately recognized the instability and quickly stepped backward, allowing the stack of bags to settle without crushing him. The shelf stabilized after shifting, and no bags fell. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) arrived minutes later and secured the storage system with additional bracing to prevent further movement. Investigation revealed that the storage rack had not been leveled properly during installation 18 months prior, and routine rack inspections had not identified the cumulative settling issue. The incident could have resulted in serious injury or death if René had not reacted quickly.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Line D experienced a critical hydraulic system failure. Operator James Thompson (EMP-00029) was monitoring the injection cycle when he noticed abnormal pressure readings on the control panel. The hydraulic pump, which had been in continuous operation for 18 months without scheduled maintenance, began emitting a high-pitched grinding noise. Within seconds, hydraulic fluid began spraying from a fractured seal on the pump assembly, coating the operator station and nearby equipment with approximately 40 liters of hydraulic oil. The pressurized spray caused the emergency stop mechanism to malfunction temporarily, preventing immediate shutdown. Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), the secondary operator on the line, quickly activated the manual emergency cutoff valve. The incident resulted in significant equipment damage to the hydraulic pump ($28,000 replacement cost), contamination of the injection molding machine's control electronics, and temporary shutdown of Line D for 6 hours. No personnel were injured, though Thompson sustained minor oil splash exposure to his face and arms. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer, was called to document the incident and assess the failure root cause.

On November 19, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant material handling incident occurred in the Shipping and Receiving Dock. Forklift operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was repositioning pallets of finished composite products in preparation for a scheduled shipment to a medical device manufacturer. The storage rack system, which had been installed in 1998 and had not undergone structural inspection since 2015, was loaded with 24 pallets weighing approximately 18 metric tons total. As Aziz raised his load to access the upper shelf level at 3.5 meters height, one of the corroded anchor bolts on the left support column suddenly fractured. The entire upper section of the rack collapsed catastrophically, sending 6 loaded pallets cascading onto the dock floor. The falling materials damaged approximately $145,000 worth of finished goods (medical-grade polycarbonate assemblies) and destroyed 4 wooden pallets. Aziz was fortunately positioned safely in the forklift cab and was not struck. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) immediately evacuated the dock area and secured the scene. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, documented the incident and initiated the incident report as the primary EHS contact available on shift.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, a chemical storage incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Machine Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) was preparing resin batches for the morning production run when she noticed an unusual odor near the acetone storage cabinet. Investigation revealed that a 55-gallon drum of acetone solvent had experienced a pinhole leak approximately 12 inches from the base, likely caused by corrosion of the drum's steel exterior. The acetone had been leaking slowly for an estimated 8-10 hours, accumulating approximately 15 liters of flammable liquid beneath the cabinet and pooling toward the facility's electrical panel located 2 meters away. Traore immediately notified Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, who arrived within 15 minutes and assessed the situation as a critical fire hazard. The spilled acetone had infiltrated the electrical enclosure, creating an explosion risk if any spark or arc occurred. Ivanov coordinated the activation of the facility's emergency ventilation system, isolated the electrical panel, and secured the area pending professional hazmat cleanup. Approximately 18 liters of contaminated absorbent material was required for cleanup, and the affected electrical panel required professional inspection and dry-out procedures ($8,500 remediation cost). No personnel were exposed to hazardous concentrations of acetone vapor, and no fire occurred.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, sustained a minor laceration to his left index finger while inspecting finished parts at Injection Molding Station 7. While manually removing a cooled plastic automotive dashboard component from the mold cavity, Gosselin's finger contacted a sharp edge burr on the part's perimeter that had not been properly deburred during the post-processing stage. The burr, approximately 2mm in length, created a superficial 1.5cm laceration requiring immediate first aid. Gosselin reported to the Cafeteria break room where Hana Al-Rashid, the Occupational Health Nurse, provided wound cleansing, topical antiseptic application, and a sterile adhesive bandage. No sutures were required. The injury was classified as first aid treatment only, with no lost work time. The employee returned to duty after treatment, with close monitoring for signs of infection over the following 48 hours.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, a hydraulic systems malfunction in Injection Molding Machine 18 resulted in a high-pressure fluid spray incident affecting Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), the Hydraulic Systems Technician. While performing routine maintenance on the machine's pressure relief valve in the Production Operations area, Popov failed to fully depressurize the system despite following standard lockout/tagout procedures. When he opened the valve housing, residual hydraulic fluid at approximately 800 PSI was released, striking Popov's right shoulder and upper arm with significant force. The spray caused a deep laceration measuring 4cm along his shoulder and minor blunt force trauma. Popov was immediately transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur in Montreal where he received 8 stitches and was diagnosed with a Grade 2 muscle strain. He required hospitalization for 6 hours for observation and imaging to rule out deeper tissue damage. The incident resulted in 3 days of lost work time. Investigation revealed the pressure gauge was malfunctioning and had not been calibrated in 14 months.

On April 18, 2024, at 6:15 AM during the night shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department when Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, accidentally knocked over a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin containing approximately 10% uncured epoxy during material transfer operations. The drum, stored on an unstable wooden pallet without proper containment, was being repositioned using a hand truck when the pallet collapsed, causing the drum to overturn. Approximately 30 gallons of resin fluid spilled onto the concrete floor, spreading across approximately 150 square feet of the warehouse section. The spill created a slipping hazard and released volatile organic compounds (VOCs) with a strong chemical odor detectable throughout the adjacent production area. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was immediately notified and initiated spill containment procedures. The area was evacuated for 45 minutes while ventilation systems were activated. Spill was contained using absorbent materials and collected into hazardous waste containers. Air quality monitoring revealed VOC levels reached 85 ppm (OSHA PEL is 50 ppm). The incident was classified as an environmental release requiring documentation with CNESST. Root cause analysis identified inadequate storage infrastructure and lack of secondary containment systems.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine material changeover at the Consumer Packaging injection molding station in the South Zone. While replacing a hopper of polycarbonate resin, Bruno's left hand came into contact with the heated barrel of the molding machine, which operates at approximately 280°C. The operator's glove caught on the barrel edge, pulling his hand partially into the hot zone. Bruno immediately withdrew his hand and alerted his line supervisor. A severe thermal burn covering approximately 15% of his left hand and forearm resulted. First aid was administered immediately by the on-site occupational health nurse, Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), who applied cool water and sterile dressings. Bruno was transported to the Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé emergency department for evaluation and treatment of second-degree burns. The incident was witnessed by fellow operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) who helped document the sequence of events. Investigation revealed that the heat shield guarding the barrel had partially deteriorated and was not providing adequate protection.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), a Warehouse Associate, was operating a propane-powered forklift to move pallets of finished composite material from the production area to the shipping dock. While maneuvering in a congested area near the Shipping and Receiving Dock loading area, the forklift wheels encountered spilled hydraulic fluid from a maintenance repair kit left unattended on the warehouse floor. The wet surface caused the forklift to lose traction during a sharp left turn. The machine tipped over, with the mast striking the ground and partially crushing the operator's right leg between the mast and the seat. Yvon was trapped in the cab for approximately 8 minutes until rescue personnel from the day shift (Marco Rossi, EMP-00016, and Richard Beaulieu, EMP-00043) manually lifted the mast sufficiently to free him. Emergency medical services were called immediately by Nina Santos (EMP-00084), the Industrial Hygienist who witnessed the incident from the adjacent prep area. Yvon was transported to emergency care with a fractured fibula and severe contusions to his right leg. Due to the severity of the fracture and required surgery, Yvon was unable to work for 12 weeks, resulting in a lost-time injury.

On March 28, 2024, at 9:30 PM during the evening shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of composite resin in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility. While transferring a 25-liter container of liquid resin from a storage tank into a mixing vessel using a manual siphon pump, the container slipped from her grip due to inadequate labeling and a narrow grip surface on the container. Approximately 8 liters of uncured epoxy resin spilled across the concrete floor, splashing backward onto Elena's left arm and shoulder. She immediately contacted Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, who assisted with decontamination using the emergency eyewash and shower station. Elena experienced skin irritation, mild chemical burns, and respiratory discomfort from epoxy vapors. She was evaluated by the occupational health nurse and treated with topical agents for the chemical exposure. Elena remained at work but with modified duty for 2 days as the skin irritation resolved. The incident was documented by Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) and investigation revealed that container labeling was faded and the manual transfer procedure lacked adequate ergonomic controls.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Rajesh Patel (Process Engineer) was conducting a routine inspection of Injection Molding Line A when he noticed a pneumatic air hose that had partially detached from its coupling, creating a visible whipping hazard near the machine's control station. As Patel moved to secure the hose connection, he stepped over several other hoses and cables that were bundled loosely across the floor adjacent to the molding station. His boot caught on a compressed air line, causing him to trip and stumble forward. While Patel caught himself on nearby machinery to prevent a fall, he narrowly avoided contact with the rotating screw mechanism of the injection unit. The incident was immediately observed by Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf, who was operating an adjacent line. Both employees remained uninjured, but the near-miss highlighted a significant trip hazard and inadequate cable management issue. Patel reported the incident to Zahra Nasri, the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, within 30 minutes of the event. Immediate corrective actions included securing the loose air hose and temporarily clearing the cable pathway.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Ana Silva (Assembly Operator) was performing routine part removal and quality inspection tasks at a post-molding assembly station in the Injection Molding Line A area. Silva had been performing repetitive gripping and twisting motions to separate molded plastic components from their gates for approximately 6 hours during her shift. While removing a particularly difficult automotive trim piece from a mold sprue, she experienced a sharp, sudden pain in her right wrist and forearm. The pain was consistent with repetitive strain, and Silva immediately reported discomfort to Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert. Initial assessment suggested acute strain rather than a significant injury, but Silva's continued complaints and visible swelling in her wrist within 30 minutes prompted Boisvert to have her evaluated by the facility's occupational health nurse. Medical assessment confirmed inflammation consistent with repetitive strain injury (RSI) affecting the extensor tendons in the right wrist. Silva was placed on modified duty with restricted hand gripping activities and prescribed ice therapy and rest. X-rays were ordered to rule out fractures. The incident was recorded as a recordable injury requiring medical treatment and work restrictions lasting 8 days. Zahra Nasri, the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, was notified and investigated ergonomic factors at the assembly station.

On May 8, 2024, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, Material Handler Rashid Habib was transferring resin bags from the Material Drying and Preparation Room to a staging area near Injection Molding Line A. The facility had recently received a large shipment of polypropylene resin in 25-kilogram bags. As Habib was moving a pallet of resin bags using a hand truck, he inadvertently pulled the truck too close to a low-hanging flexible air duct that supplied heated, dry air to the material drying station. The edge of the pallet caught the air duct, partially dislodging it from its connection point. Rather than stopping to secure the duct properly, Habib continued moving the pallet and the duct became further disconnected, creating a significant gap at the connection. Within minutes, humid ambient air began entering the drying chamber, and the drying system's automatic controls initiated a heating cycle to compensate. However, because the duct connection was compromised, the heated air was being vented directly into the warehouse area instead of into the drying chamber. This created a localized high-temperature zone near the Material Drying room exit. Machine Setter Louis Desbiens, who was on break and walking through the area at 1:45 AM, felt the intense heat and immediately notified Night Shift Supervisor of the hazard. The situation was quickly corrected by reconnecting the duct and inspecting the drying system. A thermal imaging check confirmed that ambient air temperature in the affected zone had risen to approximately 48°C (118°F) for roughly 15 minutes. Had an operator spent an extended period in that area, risk of heat stress or thermal burn was significant. The incident was classified as a near-miss because no employee was directly exposed to the hazardous condition for an extended duration. Alain Mercier was notified to assess thermal hazard controls.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) was working at Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) when he noticed a potential hazard. While preparing medical device housings for final packaging, Fernandez observed that the conveyor belt speed had increased unexpectedly, causing stacked components to shift and several units nearly fell off the edge of the workstation. Fernandez immediately stopped the conveyor manually using the emergency stop button and notified his supervisor. The near-miss occurred because the conveyor's variable frequency drive had been adjusted during maintenance that morning without proper documentation or speed verification. No components were damaged and no injuries occurred. Fernandez remained attentive and prevented what could have resulted in product damage, lost production time, and potential injuries from falling materials. The incident was immediately reported to the Production Operations department and the HSE office.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:30 AM, the Health, Safety and Environment Office conducted a routine facility inspection as part of the quarterly preventive safety program. During inspection of the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018), EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) identified a potential concern regarding the regrind material storage protocol. Inspection revealed that while no immediate hazard was present, the material handling process for contaminated regrind materials did not include formal documented procedures for quality verification before reintroduction into the production cycle. Materials were being visually inspected only, without reference to written standards or batch traceability documentation. This preventive declaration was issued to formalize inspection protocols and eliminate potential for contaminated material entering the medical device production line, which operates under ISO 13485 standards. The declaration was logged in the HSE office and communicated to Materials Management for immediate procedural development. No actual contamination or product quality issues were identified; this represents proactive risk management before any incident could occur.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:50 PM during the evening shift, Mold Repair Technician Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189) was working in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009) area, performing routine mold transport and preparation tasks. While moving a large composite mold fixture weighing approximately 250 pounds using the dock's overhead crane system, Lévesque noticed that the lift cable appeared to have a slight twisting pattern that was unusual. He immediately lowered the mold back to the dock surface and carefully inspected the cable. Upon inspection, he discovered that one of the four cable strands showed minor fraying at the attachment point to the hook—a condition that could have potentially led to cable failure during a load if operation had continued. Lévesque immediately tagged the crane out of service and reported the condition to Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133). The crane was locked and a maintenance work order was generated for immediate cable replacement. No load was dropped, no injuries occurred, and no equipment was damaged. The incident demonstrates proper hazard recognition and immediate corrective action by an experienced technician.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Oscar Ramirez, Regrind Technician, was transferring acetone from a 55-gallon bulk container to smaller working containers using a manual pump system. The connection coupling on the pump inlet became loose due to vibration from nearby equipment, causing approximately 12 gallons of acetone to spill onto the concrete floor. The spill spread rapidly across an area of roughly 200 square feet, creating a hazardous vapor zone with strong fumes detected throughout the adjacent production area. Two assembly line workers in the vicinity (Carmen Lopez and Omar Said) immediately evacuated the immediate area. Emergency response was initiated at 2:20 PM. Ventilation systems were activated, and the area was cordoned off with caution tape. The spill was contained using absorbent pads and neutralizing compound within 45 minutes. The incident resulted in temporary shutdown of adjacent operations for 3 hours to allow proper ventilation and cleanup. No employee injuries were reported, but the chemical exposure triggered activation of the facility's incident response protocol.

On May 8, 2024, during the evening shift (approximately 6:45 PM), an environmental incident involving resin dust contamination occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Rania Abdallah, Composite Materials Operator, was conducting routine glass fiber reinforcement preparation when she noticed the air handling system's pre-filter had become clogged with accumulated fiber particles, causing reduced airflow and visible fiber dust concentration in the work zone. The inadequate ventilation resulted in visible suspended fiber particles in the breathing zone above the work surface. Despite wearing an N95 mask, Rania began experiencing respiratory irritation and coughing within 30 minutes. She reported the issue to her supervisor at 7:15 PM. The pre-filter was immediately replaced by maintenance staff, and full facility ventilation was increased to maximum capacity over the next 2 hours. Air quality measurements taken post-incident confirmed fiber particulate levels had returned to acceptable ranges (below 5 mg/m³ respirable dust). Rania was monitored by on-site first aid personnel and provided with a respiratory assessment form. The incident highlighted a gap in the preventive maintenance schedule for air filtration systems.

On June 22, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the night shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Louis Desbiens, Machine Setter on night shift, was troubleshooting a material mixing station when he discovered a fractured discharge valve on the resin mixing tank containing a batch of colorant masterbatch suspension in isopropanol solvent. Approximately 8 gallons of the colorant-isopropanol mixture leaked onto the warehouse floor before the valve was manually shutoff at 10:35 PM. The spill spread across approximately 150 square feet of concrete flooring and created a strong chemical odor throughout Section C of the warehouse. The night shift supervisor (Hassan Diallo, Material Handler) was immediately notified and initiated containment procedures using absorbent pads and spill kit materials. A respiratory hazard assessment was conducted at 10:50 PM, confirming isopropanol vapor concentrations of 450 ppm (well below the 400 ppm 8-hour OSHA PEL but approaching concern levels). Ventilation doors were opened and portable fans activated to increase air exchange. Cleanup and decontamination were completed by 12:15 AM. The fractured valve was replaced the following morning. Root cause investigation determined the valve failure resulted from improper tightening during previous maintenance and lack of predictive maintenance monitoring.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Layla Hussein (EMP-00098) was working at Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building's South Zone, removing finished parts from the molding machine's output tray. While reaching to extract a stack of consumer packaging components, her left hand became caught between the automatic ejector mechanism and a stationary guard rail as the machine cycled unexpectedly. The incident occurred because the emergency stop button had been partially obstructed by accumulated plastic trim, preventing immediate shutdown. Her hand was pinched for approximately 8 seconds before the cycle completed and the mechanism retracted. She sustained significant bruising and superficial lacerations to her left palm and fingers. Coworker Carmen Lopez witnessed the incident and immediately alerted shift supervisor Rémi Charbonneau, who administered first aid and completed incident documentation. The employee was transported to a local urgent care facility for evaluation and released with pain management recommendations.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) was performing routine inspection of the hazardous waste management area in the Chemical Storage Building's exterior zone. While carrying a 25-liter container of spent solvent to the designated storage rack, he lost his footing on a wet section of concrete floor caused by a recent cleaning operation. The floor had not been properly dried or marked with wet-floor signage. Giguère fell backward, striking his lower left leg against the concrete edge of a storage platform. The chemical container fell and spilled approximately 3 liters of volatile organic compound solvent onto the surrounding area. He remained conscious but experienced immediate intense pain in his left shin and calf. His foot was swollen within minutes. Coworker Salma Haddad, a material handler nearby, immediately called emergency services and secured the spilled chemical area with absorbent materials per protocol. Paramedics arrived within 12 minutes and transported him to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé for imaging and treatment, where an undisplaced fibular fracture was diagnosed.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) was performing a stock count in the Finished Goods Warehouse Section B when a stack of five plastic bins containing automotive components became unstable on an upper shelf approximately 1.8 meters high. The bins had been stacked without proper spacing or restraint brackets as per standard procedure. Singh was pulling inventory tags from the lower shelves when the stack shifted, and four of the five bins fell directly onto her, striking her left shoulder and upper torso. She collapsed to the ground with significant pain. The bins, each weighing approximately 12 kilograms when full, impacted with considerable force. Warehouse staff member Miriam Cohen heard her call for help and immediately notified the night shift supervisor. Emergency responders arrived within 10 minutes. Singh was transported by ambulance to the emergency department where X-rays revealed a fractured left clavicle and multiple contusions. She required overnight hospitalization for pain management and orthopedic consultation. The incident was categorized as a lost-time injury with Singh placed on modified duty for 6 weeks post-discharge.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) was operating Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building - North Zone (UNIT-002). While removing finished automotive trim parts from the mold cavity, the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the 250-ton injection molding machine malfunctioned, causing sudden depressurization. This unexpected pressure drop caused the mold to close prematurely while Landry's right hand was still positioned in the cavity for part removal. His hand was caught between the mold halves for approximately 8 seconds before the machine's emergency stop was activated by nearby packaging supervisor Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), who witnessed the incident. Landry sustained a crushing injury to his right palm and three fingers with significant tissue damage. He was immediately transferred to the facility's first aid station and subsequently transported to Laval Hospital by ambulance. The machine was immediately locked out and tagged out pending full inspection.
