Root cause investigation revealed the relief valve had not been serviced according to the preventive maintenance schedule due to a scheduling oversight.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, material handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was repositioning wooden pallets containing finished composite materials in the Finished Goods Warehouse - Section B (UNIT-008). While manually lifting a pallet approximately 45 pounds in weight from ground level to shoulder height using improper technique (bending at the waist instead of using leg muscles), she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. She continued working for another 30 minutes before noticing increased stiffness and radiating pain down her left leg. Coworker forklift operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012), who was present in the warehouse, helped her sit down and notified supervisor Anika Johansson via radio. Occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) responded to the scene and conducted an initial assessment, noting muscle spasm and limited range of motion. Saleh was transported to the company's occupational health clinic where she was diagnosed with acute lumbar strain with probable disc involvement. She was placed on light duty for two weeks and prescribed physical therapy. The incident occurred in an area where several wooden pallets had been improperly stacked, creating an unstable situation.

On November 22, 2024, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, workplace safety representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) conducted a routine safety inspection of the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) in the Main Production Building - West Wing. During this inspection, he identified a potential hazard: the ventilation system's emergency stop button for the fume extraction unit had become obstructed by stacked raw material containers, and several chemical storage cabinets were not properly labeled according to WHMIS standards. Additionally, Lafleur observed that two workers had not been wearing safety glasses in an area where uncured resin fumes and particulate matter were present. He also discovered that the Secondary Containment system for the epoxy resin storage tanks was partially blocked by equipment, which could prevent proper containment in case of a spill. No immediate injury occurred, but Lafleur recognized these as serious pre-incident conditions that could lead to chemical exposure incidents, environmental contamination, or inability to respond to emergencies. He immediately notified the night shift supervisor and documented all findings in the safety management system. The root causes were identified as inadequate workspace organization, lack of enforcement of safety protocols on the night shift, and missing secondary containment inspection procedures.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift, Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le (EMP-00036) was performing routine quality testing on molded medical device components in the QC Lab when he experienced a sharp laceration to his left index finger from a burr on a freshly ejected plastic part. The part had been removed from the injection mold without proper post-processing smoothing, leaving sharp edges. Tran was conducting dimensional verification when his finger caught on the burr while handling the component. The wound bled moderately and required cleaning and bandaging. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier responded and provided first aid treatment. The injury was superficial with no nerve or tendon damage. Tran was able to continue working after receiving treatment. The incident was attributed to inadequate communication between Production Operations and Quality Control regarding post-processing requirements for this particular medical device component run. Investigation revealed that the heat treatment station (UNIT-017) had been bypassed due to equipment maintenance, but this status was not communicated to the QC team.

On March 18, 2025, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) identified a potential electrical hazard in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) during a routine preventive maintenance inspection. While examining the power distribution panel serving the drying equipment, Claude discovered that the emergency stop (E-stop) button for the primary drying oven had corroded electrical contacts and was not functioning properly when tested. The E-stop mechanism, which is critical for worker safety, had degraded due to moisture exposure and lack of regular maintenance. Claude immediately isolated the circuit breaker to the affected equipment and declared the area restricted until repairs could be completed. This hazard was classified as a preventive declaration because no worker was exposed to injury, but the potential for electrical hazard or inability to perform emergency shutdown posed significant risk. The equipment remained offline for 4 hours while repairs were completed. Claude documented the finding and initiated a facility-wide audit of all E-stop mechanisms to identify similar degradation.

On March 20, 2025, at approximately 9:30 PM during the evening shift, Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was operating the plastic regrind and recycling equipment in UNIT-018 when he nearly caught his work glove in the rotating grinder shaft while clearing a jam in the material hopper. Oscar had noticed reduced material flow through the system and attempted to manually dislodge accumulated plastic scrap while the equipment was running. His left glove became momentarily caught on the edge of the rotating shaft, causing him to pull his hand away reflexively just as the material cleared and equipment returned to normal operation. No injury occurred—Oscar's hand was not pulled into the equipment and the glove sustained only minor fraying. Oscar immediately stopped the equipment and reported the near-miss to Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier, who was called to investigate. The incident revealed that Oscar was not aware of the proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures required before clearing equipment jams, and the equipment lacked adequate warning labels regarding rotating shaft hazards. This near-miss demonstrated the potential for a serious amputation or crush injury had the glove become more firmly engaged.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). Warehouse Associate Monique Dion was organizing inventory of epoxy resin containers on the second shelf when one of four 55-gallon drums of polyester resin accidentally tipped over due to improper stacking. The drum fell approximately 4 feet to the concrete floor, rupturing on impact. Approximately 40 gallons of uncatalyzed polyester resin mixed with hardener dispersed across the warehouse floor, creating a slippery hazard approximately 20 feet in diameter. The spill emitted strong fumes characteristic of unsaturated polyester compounds. Initial response included immediate evacuation of the warehouse area and activation of the emergency ventilation system. Hazmat absorbent material was deployed to contain the spill. The incident was discovered by Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes, who immediately notified the HSE office. Root cause analysis indicated that the drum storage protocol had been violated—drums were stacked three high instead of the maximum two-high configuration specified in the handling procedures. Additionally, the secondary containment berm was not in use at the time of the incident.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Omar Said sustained a laceration to his left palm while manually removing parts from Injection Molding Machine #12 in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Omar was removing a just-cooled plastic automotive trim component from the machine's part ejector when his hand slipped on the residual cooling oil that had accumulated on the ejector assembly. His palm made contact with the sharp edge of the mold's parting line, creating a 2-inch laceration approximately 1/8 inch deep. The wound bled moderately and was secured with direct pressure. Machine Setter Robert Fournier immediately provided first aid using the first aid kit stationed at the workstation, cleaned the wound with sterile gauze, and applied antibiotic ointment and a sterile bandage. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette was notified and assessed the injury. The laceration required three sutures from the on-site occupational health nurse. Omar continued working for the remainder of the shift but reported the incident to HSE for documentation. Root cause included inadequate housekeeping on the machine (cooling oil not cleaned regularly) and insufficient awareness of the hazard posed by sharp mold edges during part removal.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 1:20 AM during the night shift, Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov experienced a significant back injury while performing a routine mold changeover on Injection Molding Machine #7. The night shift had been operating short-staffed due to an illness callout, leaving only two operators for three active production lines. Svetlana was manually lifting a 65-pound mold assembly from a storage rack positioned at knee height when she felt a sharp pain in her lower back and immediately stopped the lift. She had not used the mechanical hoist available at the workstation because it was positioned approximately 30 feet away in the maintenance area, and time pressure from production demands led her to attempt the manual lift. She was assisted to a chair and reported severe lower back pain radiating down her left leg. First aid was administered on-site, but pain persisted and she was unable to continue working. Emergency medical transport was called at 1:45 AM, and she was transported to the hospital for evaluation. Imaging revealed a herniated L4-L5 disc requiring conservative treatment with extended leave from work. This resulted in 14 days of lost work time due to medical restrictions. Root causes included inadequate staffing levels that created time pressure, lack of proximity of mechanical lifting equipment, and insufficient reinforcement of safe lifting protocols during high-workload periods.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, production operator Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198) was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on Injection Molding Machine 12 in Unit 004 (Injection Molding Line D - Consumer Packaging). While wiping down the machine's exterior with a solvent-dampened cloth, she noticed dried plastic residue on the mold cavity. She applied additional solvent to dissolve the buildup. Approximately 10 minutes later, machine setter Louis Desbiens inadvertently activated the machine startup sequence from the control panel, unaware that the cleaning operation was still in progress. The machine cycled suddenly, and Laila's right hand was caught briefly in the mold closing motion. She experienced a sharp laceration across her palm and three fingers, with minor pinching injury to the ring finger. She immediately withdrew her hand and applied pressure with a clean cloth. Coworker Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) witnessed the incident and immediately notified Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer. First aid was administered on-site by the facility nurse, who cleaned and bandaged the laceration. No stitches were required, but the injury was documented as a first-aid case requiring ongoing wound monitoring.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, a significant fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Unit 020, though incident location is adjacent Warehouse Section C). Forklift operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was transferring pallets of raw polypropylene resin when his propane-powered forklift struck a fluorescent light fixture mounted on a support column, causing it to fall and shatter near a 55-gallon drum of acetone solvent. The impact created a small puncture in the drum, causing approximately 3-5 gallons of acetone to spill across the warehouse floor near the chemical storage zone. The volatile fumes immediately began accumulating, and the electronic fume sensors detected dangerous vapor concentrations. The facility's fire alarm system automatically activated due to solvent vapor detection. Approximately 40 employees immediately evacuated through emergency exits per standard protocol. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) and Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) responded to assess the situation. Using the spill kit, they contained the spill with absorbent materials and properly disposed of contaminated materials. Hazmat protocols were followed, and no fire occurred, though the potential for ignition was extremely high. The area remained cordoned off for 6 hours until full ventilation clearance was achieved.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift operations, machine setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was performing preventive maintenance on the automated material handling system in the Composite Materials Processing Area (Unit 015). He was attempting to clear a jam in the robotic arm's material feed mechanism when he failed to verify that the arm had been fully powered down and isolated per LOTO procedures. Another night shift technician, Daniel Kim (EMP-00025), had initiated the power-down sequence but was interrupted by a phone call and did not complete the lockout procedure. When Louis reached into the equipment cavity to remove tangled composite fiber strands, the robotic arm unexpectedly initiated a programmed cycle sequence. The arm rotated rapidly and struck Louis on his left shoulder and upper back, causing him to fall backward against a support structure. He suffered a displaced shoulder dislocation, acute muscle strain, and multiple bruises across his back. The impact rendered him unable to continue work. Coworker Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) called emergency medical services. Louis was transported to the hospital by ambulance at 2:15 AM, where X-rays confirmed the shoulder dislocation. He required surgery to repair soft tissue damage and was hospitalized for observation. Medical evaluation determined he would be unable to return to work for a minimum of 8 weeks, resulting in significant lost-time injury classification with extensive rehabilitation required.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine maintenance on the mold temperature controller when he inadvertently placed his left hand near an active heating element. The mold surface temperature was approximately 180°C. While reaching to adjust a thermocouple connection, Marcel's gloved hand made direct contact with the heated mold cavity as the machine cycled. The contact lasted approximately 3 seconds before he reflexively withdrew his hand. Despite wearing standard cotton work gloves, Marcel sustained a second-degree burn covering approximately 15% of his left palm and three fingers. Immediate first aid was administered by Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013), the Quality Control Technician who was working nearby. The burn was cooled with running water for 15 minutes, and Marcel was transported to the facility's medical clinic. He was treated for thermal burns and released the same day with instructions for ongoing wound care. The incident occurred because the mold temperature warning label had faded and was difficult to read, and no lockout/tagout procedure was in place for this routine maintenance task.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a Machine Operator, was transferring finished composite material parts from the post-curing oven to a storage rack. The oven temperature was 140°C and the parts were still radiating significant heat. As Hawa used a dolly to move a tray containing approximately 24 polycarbonate housings, the wheel assembly suddenly caught on a gap in the concrete floor near the oven zone. The dolly tipped, causing approximately 15 parts to spill onto the production floor. In the rush to prevent further damage, Hawa bent down quickly to retrieve parts, experiencing immediate dizziness and disorientation. Coworker Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), the Warehouse Lead, noticed Hawa's unsteady gait and recognized symptoms of heat stress. The ambient temperature in that section of the facility was 38°C due to oven proximity and inadequate ventilation. Normand immediately moved Hawa to the break room, provided water, and applied cool compresses to her neck and wrists. Hawa recovered within 30 minutes but reported continued fatigue. The incident was attributed to cumulative heat exposure combined with physical exertion in a poorly ventilated area with high ambient temperatures.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Daniel Kim (EMP-00025), an Electrical Maintenance Technician, was performing routine inspection of the automated material handling system in the Medical Components production area (UNIT-003, Clean Room). The system had been scheduled for preventative maintenance but had not been formally locked out or tagged. While Daniel was examining the conveyor belt alignment beneath the robotic arm assembly, an unexpected system startup occurred when a remote control was inadvertently activated by another technician working in the adjacent area. The conveyor belt engaged, catching Daniel's work glove and pulling his left arm into the gap between the conveyor and support frame. Daniel immediately called out and the system was manually halted within 2 seconds. Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead, was present and immediately assessed the situation. Upon careful examination, Daniel had no fractures or lacerations, but significant bruising and edema were apparent across his left forearm and wrist. He was transported to the emergency clinic for imaging and observation. X-rays revealed no fractures, but soft tissue damage required 3 days off work. Root cause analysis identified that the LOTO procedure had not been followed despite being documented policy, and the automated system restart control was accessible without proper override protection.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was operating Injection Molding Line D when he noticed a partially ejected part stuck in the mold cavity. Following standard procedure, he initiated a machine stop and applied a lockout tag. However, while attempting to manually clear the obstruction with a small rod, the machine unexpectedly cycled due to a faulty proximity sensor that had not been replaced during the previous maintenance window. The clamp mechanism moved approximately 2 inches before the emergency stop was activated by a coworker who witnessed the near-miss. Charbonneau's hand was positioned near the clamp but was not contacted. The incident was immediately reported to Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), who secured the machine and notified the maintenance team. Investigation revealed that the proximity sensor failure had been flagged in the predictive maintenance log but was deferred due to production schedule pressure. No injury occurred, but the potential for a serious hand crush injury was significant.

On October 28, 2024, at approximately 4:15 PM during the evening shift, Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), a warehouse associate, was retrieving spools of polycarbonate resin from a high storage rack in the Shipping and Receiving Dock. He was using a manual pallet jack to position himself at approximately 6 feet height when a spool (approximately 50 lbs) became dislodged from an upper shelf due to improper securing. The spool fell and struck Croteau on the left shoulder and upper arm. He immediately felt sharp pain and was unable to lift his left arm. First aid was administered on-site, and he was transported to a local medical facility where X-rays revealed a non-displaced fracture of the left humerus. Croteau was treated with pain management and immobilization. The incident was witnessed by fellow warehouse associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), who called emergency services. Root cause analysis identified that the storage rack had no lip guards to prevent spool rollout, and employees had not received recent training on secure stacking procedures for cylindrical materials.

On September 19, 2024, at approximately 1:20 AM during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a machine setter on night shift, was performing routine maintenance on the hydraulic system of a 200-ton injection molding machine at Injection Molding Line A. He was replacing a worn hydraulic seal when pressure unexpectedly released from a secondary line that had not been fully depressurized. The escaping high-pressure hydraulic fluid created a forceful spray that contacted Desbiens' right forearm and hand, causing a significant thermal and chemical burn. The hydraulic fluid temperature at the point of release was approximately 65°C (149°F). Desbiens immediately withdrew his hand and activated the emergency shower station. He was transported to the regional burn center where he was treated for second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his forearm and hand. Medical assessment indicated significant pain and potential for scarring. Investigation revealed that the pressure relief procedure in the LOTO checklist had not been followed completely - a secondary accumulator had not been bled as required. Desbiens remained hospitalized for 3 days and required surgical intervention for wound management. He was unable to return to work for 18 weeks due to ongoing treatment and functional recovery of his hand.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. While cleaning the mold release agent residue from the machine's guide rails using a cloth dampened with solvent, Rémi noticed the machine's cooling water system was dripping excessively from a connection point near the hydraulic pump. He immediately ceased work and informed his supervisor. Upon inspection, a maintenance technician identified a hairline crack developing in the cooling water circuit coupling. The coupling was showing early signs of crystallization from thermal stress and repeated pressure cycling. Before the crack could rupture completely and cause a pressurized water spray or potential electrical hazard near adjacent power lines, the area was cordoned off and the affected circuit was isolated using manual shut-off valves. The incident was classified as a near-miss because while the cooling water system remained contained, failure to detect this defect during the next operational cycle could have resulted in a high-pressure water spray, potential electrical contact, or scalding injury to personnel. No injuries occurred, but the hazardous condition was averted through vigilant observation and prompt action.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on the evening shift, was unloading finished composite parts from a curing oven in the Composite Materials Processing Area. The oven temperature setpoint was 180°C for post-processing fiber-reinforced plastic housings. Abdul was wearing standard cotton work gloves and a short-sleeved shirt as prescribed by company PPE standards. As he reached into the oven to retrieve a part from the upper shelf, his left forearm brushed against the interior oven wall, which was at 165°C. The contact lasted approximately 2-3 seconds before Abdul withdrew his arm. He immediately reported a burning sensation and pain to his shift supervisor. The injury resulted in a partial-thickness thermal burn measuring approximately 8 cm × 5 cm on the inner forearm, with visible blistering and redness extending into the dermis layer. First aid was administered on-site with cool water irrigation for 15 minutes, followed by application of sterile dressing and pain management. Abdul was transported to the local urgent care facility where the burn was classified as a second-degree thermal injury. He was advised to seek follow-up care and received a 3-day medical leave recommendation. The root cause was identified as inadequate PPE for the specific task—standard cotton gloves lacked sufficient insulation for sustained contact with high-temperature equipment surfaces.

On December 8, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead for the night shift, was performing inventory verification in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). The warehouse was experiencing below-average winter temperatures due to an HVAC maintenance shutdown scheduled for that evening. Michel had been working for approximately 6 hours in an ambient temperature of approximately 8°C (46°F), with warehouse humidity at 72%. He was dressed in standard work clothing without thermal underlayers or a heated vest, as winter gear is typically not required during normal operations. After 6 hours of continuous warehouse activity involving movement between the refrigerated composites storage section and ambient storage areas, Michel began experiencing symptoms of cold stress, including persistent shivering, difficulty concentrating on inventory documentation, and progressive loss of manual dexterity. At approximately 1:25 AM, while reaching to label a pallet of raw plastic resin, Michel's grip strength diminished and he dropped a 15 kg container of polycarbonate pellets onto his left foot. The container impacted the dorsal surface of his left foot, causing immediate pain and swelling. A night shift co-worker assisted Michel to the first aid station where an ice pack was applied and the foot was elevated. Subsequent examination revealed significant bruising across the midfoot with possible stress fracture of the fourth metatarsal. Michel was transported via company vehicle to the emergency department where imaging confirmed a non-displaced stress fracture. He received a walking boot, pain management, and was placed on modified duty status for 2 weeks, prohibiting weight-bearing work.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-025 area). Mariam Osman, a Material Handler, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyurethane resin from the storage rack when the drum's bung plug became loose due to improper seating during the previous shift. As Mariam tilted the drum onto a hand truck, approximately 20 gallons of resin spilled onto the concrete floor. The spill created a hazardous slick surface and released volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes throughout the immediate area. The employee moved to a safe distance and immediately activated the emergency alarm. Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer, responded within minutes and initiated containment procedures using absorbent materials and activated the ventilation system. The spilled material was partially contained; however, approximately 5 gallons reached the facility's storm drain system before containment dikes could be fully deployed. Environmental response protocols were triggered, and the Quebec Ministry of Environment was notified per regulatory requirements. The incident resulted in approximately 4 hours of facility disruption and required professional hazmat cleanup contracted externally. Root cause investigation revealed inadequate verification procedures for drum plug integrity during transfer operations and insufficient training on proper drum handling protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, a critical equipment failure occurred at Injection Molding Line B - Automotive (UNIT-002). Rémi Charbonneau, an Injection Molding Operator, was operating a 250-ton injection molding machine (Equipment ID: IM-B-04) when the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned. The valve failed to release excess pressure, causing the machine's clamping force to exceed design specifications. As Rémi attempted to manually open the mold to remove a finished part, the excessive clamp pressure suddenly released, projecting the mold halves apart with significant force. One mold half struck Rémi's left arm, causing a laceration approximately 8 centimeters long and a partial crushing injury to the forearm tissue. Bruno Landry, another operator at the adjacent station, witnessed the incident and immediately called for emergency response. Johanne Paquette, Emergency Response Team Leader, arrived within 2 minutes and provided first aid while EMS was summoned. Rémi was transported to the hospital with a compound laceration and crush injury requiring 47 stitches and observation for compartment syndrome. The machine was immediately shut down and locked out. Post-incident investigation revealed that the relief valve had not been replaced during the scheduled preventive maintenance interval (which had been deferred 6 weeks due to production pressure), and the pressure gauge had been misread during the morning safety check, showing readings 40% above normal operating parameters that were not acted upon.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Thanh Pham, Maintenance Planner, was conducting routine inspections of the drying equipment when he noticed water pooling beneath one of the three industrial dryers. Upon closer examination, he discovered a hairline crack in the copper tubing section of the cooling circuit on Dryer Unit #2, approximately 1.8 meters above floor level. The leak had been ongoing for an estimated 2-3 hours before discovery, resulting in approximately 45 liters of water accumulation on the floor and damage to several resin storage bins positioned below the leak. The water had compromised packaging materials and caused minor corrosion to metal support structures. Mario Bélisle, Tool and Die Maker, assisted in isolating the system by closing isolation valves while Thanh documented the damage. Facilities maintenance was notified immediately and the area was cordoned off pending repairs.

On November 19, 2024, at 4:45 PM during the evening shift transition, Stéphane Couture, Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a thermal burn injury while removing finished parts from the mold cavity. While operating within standard protocols, Couture reached into the mold area with minimal protective gloves (standard nitrile gloves, not heat-rated) to manually extract a polycarbonate component that had partially jammed in the cooling phase. The mold surface temperature was measured at 87°C (188°F), above normal parameters due to a malfunctioning thermostat on the temperature control unit. Upon contact, Couture immediately experienced pain and withdrew his hand, but not before sustaining partial-thickness thermal burns across the dorsal (back) surface of his right hand affecting approximately 40 square centimeters. Abdul Rahman, Machine Operator on evening shift, witnessed the incident and immediately alerted supervision. First aid was administered on-site with cool water irrigation for 15 minutes, followed by sterile dressing application. Couture was transported to the urgent care facility at Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé where the burns were assessed as moderate (Grade 2) requiring topical antibiotics and pain management. He was released with instructions for wound care and scheduled follow-up assessment in 48 hours.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident involving a potential forklift collision with personnel occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). Rashid Habib, Material Handler, was manually counting resin inventory near the back wall of the warehouse when Gilles Marchand, Facilities Maintenance Technician, was moving a pallet of incoming polypropylene resin using a propane-powered forklift to reposition it from the receiving dock staging area to higher storage racks. Due to inadequate aisle lighting in the warehouse (only 150 lux in the inventory counting area versus recommended 300+ lux for material handling zones), Marchand did not see Habib standing behind a stack of pallets approximately 2 meters from the intended storage path. Habib heard the forklift approaching and shouted a warning just as Marchand began to turn the vehicle toward the storage location. Marchand immediately applied brakes, bringing the forklift to a complete stop with the front bumper/mast assembly approximately 0.8 meters from Habib's position. No physical contact occurred, no injuries were sustained, and no equipment damage resulted. The incident was immediately reported to the HSE team. Root cause analysis identified that the warehouse aisle lighting had degraded to below minimum illumination standards and that warehouse traffic management procedures did not adequately address pedestrian positioning during equipment movement.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, suffered a significant burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. Gendron was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) to remove a mold from injection molding machine #18 for scheduled cleaning. Following standard procedures, he believed the mold had cooled sufficiently after the cooling cycle completed. However, residual heat remained in the mold cavity. When Gendron made contact with the mold surface to remove it manually, his right palm and fingers came into direct contact with the hot surface, resulting in second-degree burns covering approximately 15% of his hand. The incident was witnessed by Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who immediately alerted supervisory staff. First aid was administered on-site, and Gendron was transported to the local hospital for treatment. The root cause investigation revealed that the cooling system had experienced a 40-minute delay that morning, and the standard wait time protocols were not followed due to production pressure to meet customer deadlines.

On March 18, 2024, at 9:15 AM during day shift operations, Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, conducted a routine hazard assessment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-025 equivalent facilities in Maintenance Workshop). During her quarterly inspection rounds, Ivanov observed multiple deficiencies that pose fire hazards: (1) dust accumulation on horizontal surfaces and equipment ledges approximately 1-2mm thick composed of recycled plastic particulates and resin powder; (2) three cardboard storage boxes containing plastic scrap materials stored within 2 meters of the chemical storage cabinet containing flammable solvents; (3) a non-functional fire extinguisher that was due for annual inspection but had been overlooked. No active incident or injury occurred during this preventive inspection. Ivanov immediately documented findings and initiated a Stop Work Order for the affected area, notifying facility management of the serious fire hazard potential. The assessment revealed that the last comprehensive safety walkthrough had been conducted 18 months prior, and the facility's automated dust collection system in the chemical area had been operating at reduced capacity for several weeks due to filter clogging.

On March 20, 2024, at approximately 11:00 PM during the evening shift, a cooling water system malfunction in the Main Production Building caused significant property damage. The cooling system supply line for injection molding machine cluster #12-15 experienced a catastrophic failure due to corrosion-induced pinhole leaks that had been progressively deteriorating over several months. The rupture released an estimated 3,500 liters of pressurized cooling water into the production area over approximately 2.5 hours before being discovered by night shift supervisor Marco Rossi (EMP-00016). Water cascaded across the production floor, saturating electrical junction boxes, partially submerging the CNC milling equipment control cabinet, and flooding approximately 120 square meters of the facility floor. The flooding damaged approximately 45 finished goods units staged for shipment (valued at approximately $28,000), destroyed quality control documentation stored in floor-level filing systems, and caused approximately $52,000 in equipment damage to the CNC machines and control systems. The incident was detected when electrical circuits began tripping and alarm systems activated. Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi immediately shut off the main water supply and isolated the affected machines. No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident required 36 hours of emergency cleanup and equipment assessment before production could resume.

On March 14, 2025, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141), a machine operator, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Production Operations area when he failed to properly engage the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures. While adjusting the mold release agent dispenser nozzle, the machine unexpectedly cycled and the heated mold made contact with his right hand, causing a second-degree thermal burn across the palm and three fingers. The burn covered approximately 15 square centimeters. A coworker, Deepa Gupta (EMP-00080), witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button. First aid was administered on-site, and the employee was transported to the local medical facility for treatment and observation. The incident was likely caused by inadequate communication between the maintenance procedure and machine start/stop protocols, combined with the operator's unfamiliarity with the specific equipment revision that had been installed two weeks prior.

On March 18, 2025, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C) when Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) and Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034) were transferring contaminated regrind material from a storage hopper to the reprocessing unit. The hopper's overflow prevention sensor malfunctioned, and approximately 850 kilograms of mixed plastic regrind material—predominantly polypropylene with residual masterbatch colorant—cascaded onto the warehouse floor and adjacent electrical equipment. The spilled material damaged three industrial pallets, contaminated approximately 40 square meters of warehouse flooring, and caused minor damage to the base of a nearby transformer junction box. Environmental protocols were immediately activated, and the area was cordoned off. The clean-up operation required 6 hours and involved temporary shutdown of the recycling line. Root cause analysis revealed that the hopper sensor had not been included in the preventive maintenance schedule and had drifted out of calibration over the past 4 months.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was operating Injection Molding Machine #7 in UNIT-002 (Injection Molding Line B - Automotive) when the machine's hydraulic pressure relief valve failed catastrophically. The valve, which had not been serviced since the facility's move to preventive maintenance scheduling 18 months ago, suddenly burst under normal operating pressure (1,800 PSI). High-pressure hydraulic fluid sprayed across the production floor, damaging approximately 12,000 units of automotive trim components worth an estimated $18,500 staged for quality inspection. The fluid also saturated electrical control panels and damaged the machine's PLC interface. Machine Operator Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141) witnessed the incident from an adjacent station. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified and initiated shutdown protocols. The machine remains non-operational pending hydraulic system replacement. Root cause investigation revealed the relief valve had reached end-of-service-life but was not included in the preventive maintenance schedule due to a documentation gap during the system transition.

On October 3, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was operating a CNC milling machine in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) to manufacture replacement mold components. The machine's spindle drive motor exhibited intermittent stuttering during the previous shift but was not flagged for maintenance. As Sokolov positioned a composite material blank into the machine's chuck, the spindle motor failed completely, causing the workpiece to become lodged and jam. When Sokolov attempted to manually extract the workpiece without following lockout/tagout procedures—believing the motor was already dead—the spindle unexpectedly restarted due to a capacitor discharge from the unshutdown control circuit. His right hand was caught in the rotating chuck, causing lacerations to his palm and fingers. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) responded and provided first aid before the employee was transported to the clinic for sutures and tetanus prophylaxis. The incident was witnessed by Quality Documentation Specialist Gabrielle Levesque (EMP-00095) who was retrieving materials from the adjacent storage area. Root cause: inadequate pre-shift equipment inspections, missing emergency stop verification, and non-compliance with LOTO procedures.

On December 8, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, the overhead hydraulic crane system serving the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009) experienced a critical cable failure. Night Shift Production Operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) was using the crane to position a pallet of finished medical device housings (approximately 800 pounds) onto a truck bed when the main lifting cable, which had developed micro-fractures from metal fatigue, snapped suddenly. The pallet dropped 4 feet onto the truck bed, destroying 95% of the components (approximately $22,000 in finished goods valued at medical device pricing). The pallet narrowly missed Logistics Support staff member Noor Ahmed (EMP-00076), who was standing adjacent to the truck. Supply Chain Analyst Miriam Cohen (EMP-00132) and day shift supervisor Roland Dostie (EMP-00199) were called in to assess the damage. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) documented the incident and secured the damaged crane. Investigation revealed the overhead crane had last been inspected 14 months ago, exceeding the manufacturer's recommended annual inspection interval by 2 months. The cable showed signs of corrosion and fatigue that would have been detectable during a proper inspection.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine part removal from a Husky injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. While extracting cooled plastic components from the mold cavity, François noticed the machine's safety interlock appeared to be malfunctioning—the guard could be opened while the mold was still in the closing cycle. He immediately stopped the operation and did not attempt to reach into the machine. François notified his supervisor and the maintenance team. Upon inspection, Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) confirmed that a proximity sensor on the interlock system had failed, which would have allowed worker contact with the mold during operation. The issue was immediately tagged with a lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure, preventing machine use until repairs were completed. No injuries occurred. This near-miss highlighted a critical gap in the preventive maintenance schedule for safety interlocks.

On November 22, 2024, at 8:45 PM during evening shift operations, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on evening shift, was manually removing finished plastic components from a cooling conveyor line in the Assembly and Finishing Department. While reaching across the conveyor to grab a stack of parts, Abdul's left hand made contact with hot mold release agent residue (approximately 85°C) that had pooled on the conveyor belt surface. The contact caused immediate thermal burns to the palm and three fingers. Abdul immediately withdrew his hand and notified his supervisor. First aid was administered by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), who assessed the burns as second-degree over approximately 12% of the hand surface. Abdul was transported to the hospital where he received additional treatment including cleaning, pain management, and bandaging. He was unable to return to work and was placed on medical leave. Subsequent investigation revealed that the mold release agent cleanup procedure was not being followed consistently, and protective equipment (heat-resistant gloves) had not been restocked after the previous shift.

On November 28, 2024, at approximately 11:20 AM during day shift operations, Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), Warehouse Lead, was overseeing the unloading of raw polypropylene resin pallets from a delivery truck using an overhead crane system in the Materials Management and Warehousing area. While positioning a pallet weighing approximately 1,200 kg above the storage rack, the lifting sling attachment on the pallet shifted unexpectedly due to inadequate packaging by the supplier. The pallet tilted and approximately 180 kg of resin bags fell onto three adjacent finished product storage racks containing approximately 45,000 CAD worth of medical device components (sterile housings for diagnostic equipment). The components sustained crushing damage and contamination. The fell material also damaged the warehouse racking structure, bending two support beams. No employees were in the direct fall zone, preventing injuries. Immediate area was cordoned off. Damage assessment revealed total loss of the medical components (medical-grade items cannot be reclaimed) and structural damage to racking requiring replacement. Total property damage estimated at 68,000 CAD.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141), a machine operator on Injection Molding Line C in the clean room area, was performing routine part removal from a medical-grade polycarbonate mold. The mold had just completed its cooling cycle and reached approximately 65°C. While extracting a finished component, Raoul's left hand made direct contact with the mold's ejector pin assembly, sustaining a thermal burn across the palm and fingers. The employee immediately reported pain and visible redness to his supervisor. First aid was administered on-site with cold water irrigation for 15 minutes, followed by application of sterile dressing. The injury resulted in second-degree burns affecting approximately 8% of the hand surface. Raoul was sent to the on-site medical clinic and subsequently to a local hospital for evaluation and treatment. The incident was witnessed by Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), the evening shift operator who was conducting handoff observations. Root cause analysis revealed that the mold temperature warning indicator on the injection molding machine had malfunctioned, displaying a false 'ready for removal' status when the mold was still above safe handling temperature.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, Monique Dion (EMP-00119), a warehouse associate in the Materials Management and Warehousing building, was restocking raw material bins in the storage area when she stepped on a wet floor surface near the chemical mixing zone. The floor had become slippery due to a cleaning solution spill from an overturned mop bucket that had not been properly secured on a nearby work cart. Monique lost her footing and fell backward onto the concrete floor, striking her lower back and left hip. She initially remained on the floor for approximately 2 minutes before attempting to stand. Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), a receiving clerk working in the adjacent section, heard the fall and immediately came to assist, helping Monique to a seated position. The employee reported sharp pain in the lumbar region and difficulty standing. Emergency response was initiated, and Monique was transported via stretcher to the company medical clinic. Medical evaluation confirmed a lumbar strain with possible compression of L4-L5 vertebrae. The employee was prescribed bed rest and sent home with pain management recommendations. The incident was reported and documented by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) who conducted the initial scene investigation.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 08:30 during the day shift, Philippe Nouvél (EMP-00129), a mold designer working in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop, was cleaning and inspecting a large precision mold cavity using solvents and compressed air. The mold had been recently used for producing automotive components and residual polycarbonate material remained in tight undercut sections. While using acetone-based cleaning solvent to dissolve remaining polymer deposits, Philippe did not wear proper respiratory protection despite the known volatile organic compound (VOC) exposure risk. Over the course of approximately 90 minutes of continuous exposure in the poorly ventilated tool room area, Philippe began experiencing dizziness, headache, and mild nausea. His coworker Richard Beaulieu (EMP-00043), the Tool Room Supervisor, noticed Philippe appearing unsteady and pale at approximately 10:15. Richard immediately moved Philippe to the well-ventilated administrative area and alerted the HSE department. Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), the Safety Officer, was notified and responded immediately. Medical evaluation confirmed acute solvent inhalation exposure with blood oxygen saturation slightly below normal and mild central nervous system depression consistent with acetone vapor exposure. The employee was transported to the hospital for observation and was released after 4 hours with recommendations for follow-up monitoring. Root cause analysis revealed that the ventilation system in the tool room had been operating at 60% capacity due to a partially blocked intake filter that had not been replaced during the most recent maintenance cycle.

On March 14, 2024, at 14:45, Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) was working at Station 7 in the Finished Goods Warehouse when she noticed excessive vibration and unusual noise coming from the automated labeling conveyor system. Rather than immediately stopping operations, she continued monitoring the equipment while adjusting label alignment. At 15:10, a section of the conveyor belt frayed and threatened to entangle loose packaging material. Lopez immediately pressed the emergency stop button and notified her supervisor. The incident was caught before any product damage or personnel injury occurred. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos arrived on-site at 15:25 to document the condition. Root cause investigation revealed that the conveyor belt had developed stress cracks from improper tension settings that were not corrected during the previous week's maintenance cycle. The equipment was secured with lockout/tagout procedures and removed from service pending professional inspection.

On April 2, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift operations, Mold Repair Technician Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189) was performing routine maintenance on a hydraulic press in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. While adjusting the press alignment using hand tools, he experienced a sudden unexpected activation of the equipment due to a sticking solenoid valve. Lévesque's left arm was momentarily compressed between the press frame and moving carriage before he was able to disengage the equipment using the emergency stop. He experienced sharp pain and swelling but refused initial medical attention. Upon inspection by Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) at 22:35, no fractures were evident, though significant bruising was observed. Lévesque was treated on-site with ice and elevation and monitored for 2 hours. He was released to continue work with restricted duty limitations. The solenoid valve was immediately isolated and the equipment was secured with LOTO procedures. Investigation revealed the valve had not been serviced in 8 months despite maintenance protocols calling for quarterly inspection.

On May 8, 2024, at 08:30 on the day shift, Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was retrieving polypropylene resin from the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room storage racks using a standard forklift. While positioning the forklift to access a pallet on the third tier of the rack, the rear right tire of the forklift encountered a depressed concrete floor section caused by water drainage erosion near the building's exterior door. This caused the forklift to tilt approximately 3 degrees to the right. The left side of the top pallet load shifted slightly, and two 25-kg bags of colored masterbatch material fell from the pallet, landing on an empty work table 1.2 meters below. Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran (EMP-00046) was working at an adjacent station and witnessed the incident. No personnel were struck by the falling materials, though the bags ruptured and scattered approximately 50 kg of blue masterbatch powder across the work surface and floor. The forklift was immediately shut down and Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123) arrived at 08:50 to investigate. Root cause analysis determined that inadequate preventive maintenance had allowed the concrete floor to deteriorate, and the forklift's load capacity had not been recalibrated following recent repairs.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 hours, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Building 5) during the day shift. A routine material drying cycle in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) resulted in an unexpected temperature spike in the adjacent chemical storage zone. Plastic resin dust had accumulated on ventilation ductwork due to deferred maintenance, and when hot air from the drying process contacted the dust layer, spontaneous combustion initiated. The fire suppression system activated automatically, releasing dry chemical suppressant throughout the storage area. No active fire spread beyond the initial ignition point. Emergency response personnel (Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher and Facilities Technician Georges Plante) arrived within 3 minutes and confirmed containment. The facility was evacuated following protocol, with all 47 personnel on shift accounted for within 12 minutes. Local fire department attended as precaution and cleared the area after 90 minutes. Ambient smoke detection triggered the facility-wide alarm at 14:47, initiating full evacuation procedures. No injuries were sustained, but the incident exposed critical gaps in dust control maintenance procedures and ventilation system monitoring.

On April 2, 2024, during evening shift operations (20:15 hours), Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) discovered a critical cooling system leak on Injection Molding Machine #7 (50-ton capacity) located in UNIT-001. The machine had been in continuous operation for 6 hours when coolant began spraying from a fractured coupling connection on the cooling circuit manifold. Abdul immediately triggered the emergency stop and notified his supervisor. The leak resulted in loss of approximately 40 liters of hydraulic cooling fluid into the machine's collection tray and surrounding floor area. Production Operator Maya Kumar (EMP-00138) and Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) responded to assess damage. Initial inspection revealed the coupling had corroded internally, causing metal fatigue and failure. The machine remained non-operational for 8 hours pending replacement parts delivery and system pressure testing. Secondary damage included contamination of raw materials staged nearby and staining of floor coating. Maintenance logs showed this machine had not received planned preventive maintenance for 14 months due to scheduling conflicts. The incident disrupted production of automotive trim components scheduled for shipment the following day, affecting three customer orders.

On March 28, 2024, at 09:30 hours during day shift operations, Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri conducted a routine walkthrough inspection of the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) and identified a significant ergonomic hazard affecting inventory control operations. Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx has been performing manual pallet stacking operations for inventory repositioning, reaching heights between 4.5 and 6 feet repeatedly throughout her 8-hour shift without mechanical assistance. Observation of her working posture revealed sustained awkward back flexion, shoulder elevation, and lateral bending to perform product placement. Over a 3-week period, Nicole reported cumulative lower back discomfort and right shoulder strain but had not filed a formal incident report, instead managing symptoms with over-the-counter pain relief. Zahra interviewed Nicole and reviewed historical warehouse operations, discovering that the recently installed automated material handling system had been underutilized due to operator unfamiliarity and perceived inefficiency for smaller order fulfillment. Additionally, the warehouse lacks height-adjustable work platforms or mechanical lift assists suitable for the diverse product dimensions stored. Zahra classified this as a preventive declaration under the ISO 45001 implementation initiative to address ergonomic risks before acute injury occurs. The observation revealed systemic risk affecting all 15 warehouse personnel performing similar tasks.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a dust accumulation fire hazard was identified in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. Nathalie Dubois, Environmental Compliance Specialist, was conducting routine safety inspections when she noticed a significant buildup of plastic composite fiber dust along the ventilation ducts and in the corners of the resin mixing area. The dust layer, approximately 2-3 inches thick in some areas, had accumulated due to inadequate cleaning protocols following recent equipment upgrades. While inspecting the area, a static electrical discharge from equipment contacted the accumulated dust near the solvent storage cabinet, triggering a small ignition that was immediately extinguished by the facility's automatic fire suppression system. The fire alarm was activated at 2:47 PM, and all 12 employees in the building evacuated safely. Emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the fire was fully suppressed. No injuries occurred, but the incident exposed critical gaps in housekeeping and dust management procedures. The investigation revealed that cleaning schedules had not been updated following recent ventilation system modifications, allowing dust to accumulate to dangerous levels.

On March 22, 2025, at 4:15 AM during the night shift, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, suffered a significant crush injury that resulted in lost work time. Arsenault was performing routine mold adjustment work on an automated injection molding machine (IMM-2847) when the machine's interlock safety system malfunctioned. According to witness statement from Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), who was working the same line, Arsenault was reaching into the mold cavity to manually adjust a cooling line when the mold closure cycle initiated unexpectedly. The mold press descended rapidly, crushing Arsenault's left hand and forearm between the upper and lower mold plates before the emergency stop button could be engaged. The crush occurred despite the safety interlock that should have prevented operation while the mold door was open. Emergency services were called immediately at 4:17 AM. Arsenault was transported to Hôpital de l'Enfant-Jésus with severe crush injuries including multiple fractures of the metacarpals and radius, tissue damage, and partial circulation compromise. He underwent emergency surgical intervention and required 6 weeks of hospitalization and subsequent rehabilitation. The incident was reported by Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), Electrical Maintenance Lead, who responded to investigate the machine malfunction. Root cause analysis identified a failed proximity sensor in the interlock circuit that had degraded over the previous 72 hours but was not caught by preventive maintenance inspections.

On March 28, 2025, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, a near-miss incident was identified in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on a high-precision mold cooling system when he nearly suffered an electrical shock. Gosselin was working on a mold temperature controller (model STT-850) that had reportedly been powered down according to facility LOTO procedures. However, while disconnecting a thermal sensor cable, he made direct contact with a live 240V electrical terminal that should have been de-energized. The terminal was part of a secondary heater circuit that had not been properly isolated by the LOTO procedure due to incomplete equipment documentation in the maintenance manual. Gosselin received a minor electrical contact (approximately 50mA, sub-lethal but dangerous) that caused involuntary muscle contraction and resulted in his hand striking a sharp mold edge, creating a small laceration on his left palm. The incident was immediately reported by Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141), Machine Operator and coworker in the area, who witnessed the contact and heard Gosselin cry out. Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001), Director of HSE, was notified and responded within 2 minutes. Gosselin was examined by the facility first aid attendant and cleared, though he experienced minor residual muscle soreness. The incident investigation revealed that the temperature controller documentation had not been updated when the equipment was modified in 2023, leaving technicians unaware of the dual-circuit configuration. This near-miss could have resulted in fatal electrocution had contact been more direct or sustained.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM, Céline Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Main Production Building. Despite receiving LOTO training during her onboarding, Céline failed to properly engage the lockout procedure before beginning work on the machine's hydraulic pressure release valve. A co-worker, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), was nearby preparing materials for the evening shift and witnessed the incident. As Céline removed the pressure relief valve using a socket wrench, pressurized hot resin (approximately 210°C) suddenly discharged from the equipment, spraying directly onto her right arm and shoulder. She sustained second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 15% of the affected area. Hawa immediately called for emergency assistance and activated the on-site first aid response. Céline was transported via ambulance to Sacré-Cœur Hospital in Montreal where she was treated and admitted for overnight observation. The incident was immediately reported to the HSE department, and the machine was secured for investigation.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 PM, during the night shift, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead for Night Shift, was conducting inventory in the Warehouse and Shipping area, specifically in the Hazardous Waste Management Zone (exterior area). Michel was walking along the perimeter of the chemical storage yard when he noticed that a 55-gallon drum of uncured resin had shifted from its designated position on a wooden pallet and was precariously balanced at a 45-degree angle, with approximately 40 gallons of liquid content still inside. The drum appeared to have been inadequately secured during the previous day shift's receiving operations. Michel immediately recognized the hazard: if the drum fell, it could rupture, spilling highly flammable resin solvent across the concrete pad, creating a fire risk near adjacent material storage areas. He immediately cordoned off the area using caution tape, alerting production supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) on the adjacent shift. André assisted in carefully repositioning the drum to a stable, upright position using proper handling procedures and confirming all tie-down straps were secure. No chemical spill occurred, and the incident was documented as a near-miss. The receiving procedures were immediately reviewed to identify gaps in the securing process.

On April 3, 2024, at 9:30 AM, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator working the day shift, was performing quality control assembly tasks on medical device component housings at the Packaging and Labeling Station in the Warehouse and Shipping Prep Area. Elena was manually assembling precision plastic components for a large automotive OEM order when she manipulated a molded part with sharp, unfinished edges that had not been properly deburred during the production process. The part contained a thin, blade-like edge approximately 2 millimeters wide. As Elena gripped the component to align it with a mating part, the sharp edge lacerated the webbing between her left thumb and index finger, creating a deep cut approximately 1.5 centimeters in length. The wound bled significantly, and Elena immediately applied direct pressure and elevated her hand. A co-worker notified the shift supervisor, who provided first aid treatment including thorough cleaning and sterile bandaging. The injury required 4 stitches at an urgent care facility. Elena was able to return to light duty work after the wound was treated. The incident investigation revealed that the quality control process had failed to catch several parts with incomplete edge finishing due to a tool wear issue on the deburring equipment.

On March 19, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, an electrical maintenance lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) discovered a significant malfunction in the automated conveyor belt system that transports finished molded parts from Production Line B to the Assembly and Finishing Department. The conveyor's primary motor coupling had developed a hairline fracture in the cast iron body, evidenced by visible seepage of gear oil and unusual vibration signatures. The coupling failure was traced to metal fatigue caused by extended operation beyond the manufacturer's recommended service interval of 40,000 operating hours. Records indicated the equipment had operated for approximately 58,000 hours without replacement. When the coupling finally fractured completely during a restart cycle, metal shards ejected from the coupling housing damaged the adjacent hydraulic line, causing pressurized hydraulic fluid to spray across the equipment area. Production halted for 18 hours while repairs were completed. An estimated 45,000 CAD in lost production time resulted, and replacement coupling and hydraulic line repair costs totaled 22,000 CAD.

On March 22, 2024 at 1:30 AM during the night shift, injection molding operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) was performing routine mold release and part extraction from an active 250-ton injection molding machine (Molding Station A). Despite having completed the standard LOTO (lockout/tagout) checklist for manual intervention, Mensah did not verify that the hydraulic pressure had fully dissipated before reaching into the mold cavity to remove a partially stuck composite automotive component. While extracting the part, residual hydraulic pressure in the mold actuator system suddenly released, causing the mold to close with significant force. Mensah's right hand was caught between the mold plates, sustaining a crush injury to the palm and two fingers. The injury resulted in a compound fracture of the right ring finger and lacerations to the palm requiring emergency surgical intervention and 47 stitches. Confined space entry supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) responded immediately and performed initial first aid. The incident was attributed to inadequate pressure relief verification procedures and insufficient wait time between LOTO implementation and manual intervention.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. While cleaning the mold cavity with a brush, the machine's hydraulic system unexpectedly activated due to a failure in the safety lockout system. The mold closed rapidly, trapping Paul's right hand inside the mold cavity. Coworkers immediately heard his screams and activated the emergency stop button. Paul sustained severe crush injuries to his right hand with fractures to multiple metacarpals and lacerations. He was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital where he underwent emergency surgery. The incident was witnessed by three colleagues on the production line. Investigation revealed that the LOTO procedures had not been properly followed—the machine had been locked but not fully de-energized, and the isolation points were not verified.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Julien Racine (EMP-00177), a Shipping Clerk, was moving heavy resin pellet containers from the Raw Materials Warehouse to the loading dock using an electric forklift. As he navigated through the narrow corridor between storage racks in Section A, a poorly secured stack of fiber reinforcement spools (weighing approximately 180 kg) on an upper storage shelf became dislodged. The entire stack fell directly onto the forklift cab, striking Julien on the left shoulder and upper back. He fell from the forklift and struck the concrete floor, sustaining a displaced fracture of the left clavicle, three fractured ribs, and significant soft tissue trauma to the back. Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073), the Shipping Coordinator, witnessed the incident and immediately called emergency services. Julien was hospitalized for 6 days and required surgical intervention for the clavicle fracture. Post-incident investigation revealed that the storage rack had exceeded its weight capacity and the securing straps had not been properly inspected in over 18 months.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), an Automation Technician, was performing diagnostic work on the robotic arm system in the Central Maintenance Workshop. While testing the arm's movement sequence, Aya noticed that the pressure relief valve on the hydraulic actuator was beginning to show signs of potential failure—slight audible hissing and visible oil seepage around the connection point. Although the arm was functioning normally, Aya recognized that the deteriorating seal could lead to sudden pressure release or unexpected movement. She immediately isolated the arm, documented the observation with photographs, and reported the issue to Claude Rioux, the Electrical Maintenance Lead. The issue was escalated to the Safety Officer as a preventive declaration because it had not yet resulted in an incident but posed significant hazard potential. The worn component was scheduled for replacement and additional monitoring protocol was established for similar equipment.

On December 3, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, injection molding operator Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171) was performing routine maintenance on Line D injection molding machine when a LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure failure occurred. Bertrand had allegedly locked the machine's main electrical disconnect but had not properly verified that all residual pressure in the hydraulic system had been relieved. A coworker, production operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056), who was not assigned to the maintenance task, mistakenly reset a secondary safety interlock to retrieve a completed mold. The machine's hydraulic ram suddenly actuated, crushing Bertrand's left hand between the mold clamps. Bertrand sustained a compound fracture of the third and fourth metacarpals and deep tissue lacerations requiring immediate surgical intervention. Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), the night shift supervisor, discovered the incident within seconds and immediately shut down the machine using the emergency stop button. Emergency medical services transported Bertrand to Hôpital Maisonneuve-Rosemont with injuries requiring two surgical procedures and 6 weeks of recovery. Investigation identified that: (1) LOTO checklist had not been completed; (2) secondary interlock access was not restricted; (3) Diego had not received adequate LOTO awareness training.

On October 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a dust accumulation fire ignited in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse Section C). Production operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) was conducting routine material processing when he noticed a small spark emanating from the ventilation duct leading from the grinding equipment to the collection bin. Within 30 seconds, fine plastic dust particles suspended in the air above the regrind bin ignited, creating a localized fire approximately 3 feet in diameter. The facility's automated fire suppression system activated within 45 seconds, discharging dry chemical suppression agent over the affected area and extinguishing the fire. However, the rapid ignition and intensity of the dust fire caused damage to ventilation ducting, the collection bin housing, and control panels, resulting in approximately $67,000 in equipment damage and temporary shutdown of the entire regrind operation for 8 days. Investigation revealed that: (1) ventilation duct had not been cleaned in over 6 months despite facility accumulation of approximately 3/8 inch of plastic dust throughout the ductwork; (2) facility temperature had been elevated to 28°C due to HVAC malfunction; (3) ignition source was likely friction from degraded fan bearing; (4) fire suppression system inspection records were incomplete. No personnel were injured, but the incident was classified as a serious near-miss with high potential for facility evacuation and personnel harm if fire had spread to adjacent material storage areas.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) on Line B (UNIT-001) was performing a routine mold changeover. While closing the mold assembly after inserting the new mold set, Ahmed's right hand became caught in the mold closing mechanism. The hydraulic press closed with approximately 800 metric tons of force, crushing his right index and middle fingers between the mold halves. Co-worker and Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran (EMP-00046) heard Ahmed's screams and immediately activated the emergency stop button, halting the press. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) and the evening shift supervisor responded. Emergency services arrived at 11:08 PM. Ahmed was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where surgery was performed to treat severe crush injuries; both fingertips required amputation at the distal interphalangeal joint. The root cause was inadequate guarding on the mold closing point of operation and lack of a two-hand control safety interlock that should have been required for this hazardous maintenance task.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) was performing preventive maintenance on the material drying and preparation equipment in UNIT-016. The resin dryer (a Piovan DRX-1000 model) had been operating for 72 hours continuously on a high-temperature cycle for polycarbonate drying. Georges was checking temperature sensors and thermostat calibration when he noticed the external surface temperature was significantly higher than expected (approximately 85°C versus normal 55°C). He initiated a manual inspection of the heating element chamber and discovered that the internal temperature sensor (PT-100 RTD probe) had become loose within its thermowell, causing it to read artificially low. The heating element continued cycling to maintain the setpoint reading, resulting in actual internal temperatures reaching 215°C—well beyond the safe maximum of 160°C for this equipment model. The malfunction had gone undetected for approximately 6 hours. Georges immediately powered down the unit and initiated cooling protocols. Upon cooling and inspection, the heating element showed significant thermal stress and micro-cracks in the ceramic insulation layer, and the thermostat control circuit showed signs of thermal degradation. The root cause was inadequate preventive maintenance procedures, missing sensor security lock-clips, and lack of automated temperature limit monitoring as a backup safety system.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM, Machine Operator Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141) sustained a thermal burn while operating Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building. Blanchard was removing a finished component from a 500-ton injection molding machine when the mold temperature sensor malfunctioned, causing the mold to remain at 280°C instead of the normal cooling cycle of 120°C. As he reached into the mold cavity to extract the part, his left forearm contacted the hot mold surface, resulting in a second-degree burn approximately 8cm x 6cm on his inner forearm. The employee immediately ran cold water over the wound and reported to the on-site nurse. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), the Occupational Health Nurse, provided first aid treatment including cooling, cleaning, and application of sterile dressing. The burn was classified as minor but required documentation and monitoring for infection. Production was halted for 30 minutes while the temperature sensor was inspected and replaced. The mold was tagged out and sent to maintenance for full calibration review.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM, Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093) discovered potential respiratory hazard exposure in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. During a routine stock inventory, Proulx noticed inadequate ventilation and visible resin fumes accumulating near the compounding equipment where synthetic polymer resins were being mixed. She observed that two of the four extraction fans were not functioning, and the area ventilation system had not been serviced since May 2024. The chemical storage room temperature had risen to 28°C (normal operating range: 18-22°C), which accelerates volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions. Proulx immediately evacuated the area and reported the hazard to Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123), the Incident Investigation Specialist. She also notified Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006), Maintenance Manager, who confirmed that the extraction fans required replacement motor bearings.
