This was classified as a preventive declaration because the hazard was identified before any employee experienced symptoms, but the risk of chemical exposure to resin fumes was significant given the nature of the work performed daily in this area. The area was restricted pending repairs.

On November 16, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a material handling incident occurred in the Warehouse and Shipping area. Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) was overseeing inventory movement when a stack of plastic composite material pallets stored on a metal shelving rack became unstable due to improper weight distribution. The top three pallets, containing approximately 180kg of finished composite products destined for an automotive customer, shifted and fell from a height of approximately 2.1 meters. The pallets struck a forklift (the property of TechnoPlast) parked directly below, causing significant damage to the vehicle's roof canopy, rear light assembly, and hydraulic hose on the right side. The estimated damage to the forklift exceeded $18,000 in repairs, including replacement of structural components and system diagnostics. Additionally, two pallets of products were damaged beyond recovery due to impact fracturing, representing approximately $8,500 in material loss. The incident was immediately reported to David O'Connor (EMP-00010), Warehouse Supervisor for the day shift, who documented the scene and initiated the damage assessment. No injuries occurred due to the area being properly cleared during material movement. The root cause was identified as inadequate load labeling on the storage rack that led to improper stacking configuration.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162) was working at UNIT-019 (Packaging and Labeling Station) in the Warehouse and Shipping prep area. While manually lifting a box of assembled medical device components weighing approximately 18 kg from the lower shelf of a storage rack to place it on the labeling conveyor, she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. The box was positioned awkwardly, requiring her to bend at the waist with a twisted torso while maintaining an awkward grip. Ricci completed the lift but immediately experienced acute lower back pain and muscle spasms. She informed her supervisor, Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), who directed her to the first aid station. Medical evaluation confirmed acute lumbar strain with muscle strain to the lower back. The incident was reported to the HSE department as a potential work-related musculoskeletal disorder. Root cause analysis identified improper lifting technique, inadequate training on ergonomic lifting procedures, and improperly positioned storage racks that forced non-neutral lifting postures.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195) was retrieving finished parts from the cooling tray of Injection Molding Line C (UNIT-003) located in the clean room area of the Main Production Building. The Medical Components line produces sterile device housings that require careful handling. While reaching across the cooling conveyor to grab a completed part, Therrien's safety glasses became partially dislodged. A small plastic flash particle (approximately 3mm) from a molded edge ejected forcefully during the cooling cycle and entered his left eye beneath the glasses, embedding in the conjunctiva. Therrien immediately felt intense pain and was escorted to the first aid station by Machine Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178). The particle was successfully removed by emergency medical personnel, but significant corneal abrasion was confirmed. He was referred to an ophthalmologist for follow-up care and was unable to work for 2 days due to vision impairment and pain. The incident investigation revealed that safety glasses were not properly fitted and worn, cooling cycle controls had degraded ejection pressure suppressors, and operators lacked training on recognizing and reporting PPE fit issues.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, packaging operator Amina Ba (EMP-00164) was working at the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009) preparing medical device components for shipment. While manually loading plastic-packaged parts onto a pallet, a stack of containers from an upper shelf became unstable. A box weighing approximately 8 kg fell from approximately 1.8 meters above, striking Amina's left shoulder and upper arm. She immediately reported sharp pain and difficulty moving her left arm. First aid was administered on-site by the facility nurse, and Amina was transported to Hôpital Cité-de-la-Santé for evaluation. X-rays revealed a fractured left clavicle and contusion to the shoulder region. The incident was witnessed by packaging operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) and responded to by production supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101). Root cause analysis revealed that the shelving unit lacked proper weight distribution labels and load capacity was exceeded due to recent high-volume orders.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire incident occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Mold maintenance technician Réjean Simard (EMP-00077) was performing preventive maintenance on a hydraulic injection molding press when he accidentally spilled approximately 2 liters of flammable mold release solvent (acetone-based product) near an electrical junction box. The solvent vapors accumulated in the enclosed workshop area with limited ventilation. When another technician, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), attempted to inspect an electrical connection using a handheld troubleshooter, a minor electrical arc ignited the solvent vapors. A small fire approximately 0.5 meters in diameter rapidly developed. Emergency response was initiated immediately; Réjean activated the fire extinguisher and brought the fire under control within 45 seconds before facility fire suppression systems engaged. The fire was completely extinguished within 3 minutes. Emergency services were notified as a precaution. No injuries resulted, but equipment damage included scorched insulation on electrical conduits and minor structural damage. Root cause: inadequate spill containment procedures, insufficient ventilation, and lack of proper hazard isolation during maintenance.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, injection molding technician Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was setting up Injection Molding Line B for medical device component production when a sudden machine startup occurred. Despite line shutdown procedures being initiated, Line B's automated control system malfunctioned due to corrupted firmware in the PLC (Programmable Logic Controller), causing the injection press to cycle unexpectedly. Ahmed's right hand was positioned near the mold gate performing a manual temperature probe adjustment when the press initiated its clamping cycle. His right hand became caught between the moving mold halves, sustaining crushing injuries to his index and middle fingers. Machine setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was positioned 3 meters away and immediately heard Ahmed's cry of pain. Louis triggered the emergency stop button within 2 seconds. Ahmed was extracted from the machine and transported to the emergency department at Hôpital Laurentien. Diagnostic imaging revealed displaced fractures of the metacarpal and phalangeal bones in both fingers, with tissue laceration requiring surgical intervention. The incident was declared by Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136). Root cause: inadequate lockout/tagout procedures during setup, unverified equipment repairs, and lack of guarding on manual work positions.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) was working at Station 5 in the Injection Molding Line A when she sustained a laceration to her left index finger. Jackson was removing a finished polycarbonate automotive component from the injection mold when her hand made contact with a sharp, unfinished edge on the part. The edge, which should have been deburred during post-processing, caused a 2-inch laceration requiring 4 stitches. Jackson immediately reported the injury to her supervisor, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), who provided first aid and documented the incident. The component was removed from production for investigation. No witnesses were present at the immediate moment of injury, though Gosselin arrived within 30 seconds of Jackson's call for assistance. The injury was treated by the on-site occupational health nurse and Jackson returned to modified duty after bandaging.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of acetone solvent using a pneumatic hand pump when the connection between the pump and the drum coupling failed due to corrosion. Approximately 8 gallons of acetone spilled across the concrete floor, creating an immediate vapor hazard and slip risk. Popescu lost her footing while attempting to isolate the spill and fell, striking her right hip and lower back against a metal storage rack. She was unable to stand without assistance and complained of severe pain in her right hip and lower back. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) responded to Popescu's emergency call within 2 minutes and immediately called emergency services. Popescu was transported to Laval Hospital and admitted with a fractured right femoral neck requiring surgical intervention. She was hospitalized for 6 days and has been on medical leave for 8 weeks post-operation, resulting in significant lost work time.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident was reported in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Forklift Operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was moving a pallet of recycled polypropylene resin pellets when he noticed the wooden pallet was degraded and potentially unstable. Aziz was approximately 15 feet from the loading dock, moving at low speed (approximately 2 mph), when he observed the load shifting slightly on the forks. Rather than continue, Aziz immediately lowered the forks to the floor and stopped operations. Upon inspection, three wooden deck boards on the pallet were severely compromised and cracked, and the weight of the approximately 2,200-pound load had begun to shift, with pellets spilling onto the floor. Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) was in the adjacent area and witnessed Aziz's quick decision-making. Tessier assisted in repositioning the load and transferring pellets to a certified plastic pallet. The incident was reported to the HSE department as a potential loading dock fall hazard that was successfully prevented through operator awareness.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak occurred in Injection Molding Line B (North Zone). Mohamed Ibrahim, the Regrind Operator assigned to material preparation, was performing routine hopper maintenance near the molding line when he noticed water pooling beneath the injection machine's cooling jacket. Upon investigation, he discovered a corroded copper fitting on the primary cooling loop had fractured, spraying approximately 80 liters of coolant-water mixture across the production floor. The coolant spread across an area of roughly 20 square meters, creating a slippery surface hazard. Emergency shutdown procedures were initiated, and the area was cordoned off with caution tape. Facilities maintenance responded within 15 minutes and shut off the cooling system isolation valve. The leak resulted in approximately 6 hours of production downtime for the automotive component line and required extensive cleanup of the hazardous coolant mixture. Environmental containment protocols were activated, and the spilled coolant was collected for proper disposal. Root cause analysis determined the fitting had experienced corrosion from hard water mineral deposits combined with age-related material degradation over 7 years of continuous operation.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a material hopper overflow incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (Main Production Building). Amina Mansour, a Material Handler, was loading pre-dried polycarbonate pellets into the resin dryer hopper while operating the automated feed system. She failed to notice that the hopper level sensor had malfunctioned, causing the load cell to incorrectly display the hopper as only 60% full when it was actually at 95% capacity. Continuing to feed material, Amina initiated another 50-kg batch load. The hopper overflow caused approximately 35 kilograms of plastic pellets to spill onto the floor and into the surrounding equipment area, including the cooling fans of an adjacent injection molding machine. The overflow also contaminated a bin of medical-grade resin intended for ISO 13485 certified production, rendering approximately 120 kilograms of material ($3,200 value) unsuitable for use. The material required disposal as hazardous waste. Production was halted for 4 hours while the area was cleaned and the contaminated resin was properly documented and removed. The incident also resulted in delayed shipment of medical device components to a key customer.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, a serious hand crushing injury occurred in the Mold Maintenance Workshop. Réjean Simard, a Mold Maintenance Technician with 12 years of experience, was performing scheduled maintenance on a large automotive mold assembly weighing approximately 250 kilograms. The mold was positioned horizontally on a maintenance table with pneumatic support cylinders designed to hold it stable during work. Simard was using a pneumatic die grinder to remove burrs from the mold cavity when he heard a hissing sound. One of the support cylinder seals had failed catastrophically, causing a rapid loss of pressure. The mold shifted suddenly and dropped approximately 15 centimeters, crushing Simard's right hand between the mold base and the maintenance table surface. His right index and middle fingers sustained crush injuries with fractures to both fingers and significant soft tissue damage. The ring finger sustained a partial amputation at the first knuckle. Simard immediately called for emergency assistance at 6:22 AM. First responder Johanne Paquette arrived within 2 minutes and initiated emergency first aid protocols while activating the emergency medical services. An ambulance arrived at 6:35 AM and transported Simard to Laval Hospital where he underwent emergency surgery. The incident resulted in lost-time injury requiring 8 weeks of recovery and permanent functional limitation to his right hand.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a quality control technician was conducting routine inspection of parts from Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components). While reaching across an active molding machine to retrieve a sample part from the output conveyor, the technician's sleeve caught on a small burr protruding from the mold cavity. The technician immediately pulled back, narrowly avoiding contact with the moving mold clamp. A co-worker witnessed the incident and immediately pressed the emergency stop button. The technician sustained no physical injury, but reported feeling startled and disoriented. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the mold had a manufacturing defect creating an unintended sharp edge that had not been caught during the previous maintenance cycle. The incident was immediately reported to the Maintenance Supervisor, who removed the mold for inspection and repair. This near-miss highlighted a gap in the pre-production mold inspection procedure.

On March 18, 2024 at approximately 10:30 PM during evening shift operations in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A), a warehouse lead was performing inventory verification using a battery-powered forklift. While moving pallets of polypropylene resin bags, the forklift battery terminal corroded due to improper maintenance came into contact with the operator's bare arm as they were adjusting the load. The battery acid immediately caused a chemical burn to a 2-inch area of the operator's right forearm, resulting in redness, blistering, and mild pain. The operator immediately rinsed the affected area with water from a nearby eyewash station for approximately 5 minutes. First aid was administered on-site by the Safety Trainer, who was contacted immediately. The wound was covered with a sterile dressing and the employee was sent to the local occupational health clinic for assessment and documentation. The employee returned to work the following day with minor restrictions. Root cause analysis identified that forklift battery maintenance had not been performed according to schedule, allowing corrosion to develop on terminal connections.

On March 21, 2024 at approximately 6:15 AM during night shift operations in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (Maintenance Workshop - East Section), a maintenance technician was performing solvent cleaning of precision instrumentation components using acetone in an open container. The technician was working in a confined area near the shop's ventilation system. During the cleaning process, acetone fumes accumulated in the breathing zone despite the ventilation system operating. After approximately 45 minutes of continuous exposure, the technician reported experiencing dizziness, mild headache, and nausea. The technician immediately moved to fresh air outside the workshop area. Symptoms subsided within 20 minutes of exposure cessation. The incident was reported to the Safety Trainer and occupational health was contacted for assessment. The technician was examined and released with recommendations for rest and hydration. Investigation revealed that the ventilation system intake was partially blocked by stored materials, reducing air exchange effectiveness in the work area. The open container cleaning method had inadequate local exhaust ventilation at the point of use.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Operator Leila Farah was monitoring an industrial oven set to cure composite materials at 180°C when a thermostat malfunction caused the heating element to overheat uncontrollably. The oven temperature spiked to 320°C within minutes, causing the internal heating coils to rupture and spray hot thermal fluid across the interior chamber. The force of the rupture also damaged the oven's external insulation panels, which cracked and partially detached from the unit. Approximately 45 liters of synthetic thermal fluid was lost, pooling on the concrete floor and creating a slipping hazard. The oven sustained approximately $87,000 in damage including replacement of the heating element assembly, insulation panels, and internal piping. Production was halted for 36 hours while repairs were completed. Emergency response included immediate shutdown of the unit by facilities manager Gérard Boucher and containment of the thermal fluid spill using absorbent materials. No personnel were injured due to the automatic emergency shutdown mechanism triggering when temperature exceeded safe parameters.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a serious machinery entanglement incident occurred in the Injection Molding Line B - Automotive unit. Machine Operator Abdul Rahman was performing routine maintenance on an injection molding machine (a 200-ton Engel unit) when a co-worker, Injection Molding Technician Patrick Ouellet, inadvertently restarted the machine from a remote control panel without confirming that maintenance was complete. Abdul's right arm was caught between the mold clamp and the fixed frame of the machine as the hydraulic rams engaged. The entanglement lasted approximately 3 seconds before emergency stop buttons were activated by nearby Production Operator Zainab Khalil, who witnessed the incident. Abdul sustained a severe crush injury to his right forearm with fractures to the radius and ulna bones, significant soft tissue damage, and partial nerve damage. He was transported by ambulance to Jean-Talon Hospital where he underwent emergency surgery. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury requiring hospitalization and surgical intervention. Investigation revealed that the machine's LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures were not properly followed, as the energy isolation lockout was not engaged during maintenance work.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a minor first-aid incident occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Hydraulic Systems Technician Andrei Popov was performing routine maintenance on a propane forklift's hydraulic system when he accidentally punctured his left palm with a sharp edge of a fractured hydraulic hose connector. The puncture wound was approximately 1.5 cm deep with minor bleeding. Andrei immediately moved to the first aid station and applied direct pressure with sterile gauze for 5 minutes. The bleeding stopped, and the wound was thoroughly cleaned with antiseptic solution and covered with sterile adhesive bandages. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher, who was performing night shift rounds, assessed the injury and determined first aid was sufficient. The wound was not deep enough to require stitches or medical referral. Andrei completed an incident report and continued his shift. Root cause analysis identified that the hydraulic hose connector had corroded over time due to moisture exposure, making it brittle and prone to fracture. The worker was wearing standard work gloves which provided minimal protection against sharp puncture wounds.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189), a Mold Repair Technician, was performing routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the Maintenance Workshop when his right hand became caught between the rotating spindle and a fixed cutting tool holder. The machine was in operation during the maintenance procedure, and proper lockout/tagout procedures were not fully implemented. Armand had disabled the main power switch but failed to verify that residual energy had been safely discharged from the hydraulic system. When he reached to adjust a tool position, the spindle suddenly rotated due to residual pressure, trapping his hand. He sustained a deep laceration to his palm and fingers, with partial nerve damage. Coworker René Caron immediately stopped the machine by cutting secondary power. Armand was transported via ambulance to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur with significant bleeding. The incident was witnessed by Tool Maker René Caron who called emergency services. Investigation revealed the machine's energy isolation protocol was incomplete and had not been reviewed in 18 months.

On November 8, 2024 at 09:20, Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), a Warehouse Associate, was manually transferring plastic pellet containers from the Raw Materials Warehouse Section A to a staging area for processing. He was moving approximately 50 kg containers of reinforced nylon composite pellets using improper lifting technique—bending at the waist with a curved spine rather than lifting with his legs. After moving approximately 15 containers, Yvon felt a sharp pain in his lower back and attempted to continue working through the discomfort. By 11:00, the pain had intensified significantly, and he reported experiencing numbness in his left leg. He was assessed by on-site first aid personnel and referred to occupational health. Medical examination revealed a herniated disc at L4-L5 with nerve compression. Yvon was prescribed a medical leave of absence for two weeks with physiotherapy. No witnesses to the incident itself, but coworker Mariam Osman observed him limping and reported the incident to HSE. The facility lacks an ergonomic assessment program for material handling tasks, and employees receive only generic lifting instruction during annual orientation.

On November 12, 2024 at 16:15 during the evening shift, Léa Parent (EMP-00121), a Quality Control Technician, was conducting visual inspection of molded plastic components in Injection Molding Line A when a small fragment of hardened plastic became dislodged from a finished part and struck her left eye. The part had been insufficiently cooled before removal from the mold, and micro-fractures had developed in the material. As she examined the part surface with a magnifying lens, a chip approximately 3mm in diameter broke free and impacted her cornea. Despite wearing standard safety glasses, the fragment penetrated the glasses' edge and caused corneal abrasion with minor laceration. She immediately reported eye pain and blurred vision. First aid responder Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), an Instrumentation Technician, flushed her eye with sterile saline solution from the on-site eyewash station for approximately 5 minutes. Léa was transported to the urgent care facility where ophthalmologic examination confirmed corneal abrasion. She received topical antibiotic ointment and was cleared to return to modified duty the following day, avoiding close visual work for 48 hours. The incident was reported by Quality Control Supervisor (not specifically named but implied responder).

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) was conducting routine visual inspections of finished composite parts in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) when she noticed discoloration and potential mold contamination on a batch of 200 polycarbonate components scheduled for shipment to a medical device manufacturer. The parts had been stored in Section B for 5 days following production. Upon closer examination under UV light testing equipment, Zhang discovered microscopic fungal growth on the interior surfaces, likely caused by improper humidity control in the storage area during the recent warehouse climate system maintenance. She immediately segregated the affected batch and notified Production Scheduler Wei Liu. The discovery prevented shipment of non-compliant parts that could have caused customer complaints and potential product recalls. Zhang documented the finding and escalated to the HSE department for investigation of storage conditions.

On March 22, 2024, at 02:15 during the night shift, Production Operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) was performing routine cleaning of an idle injection molding machine (Line C) in the Main Production Building when he nearly experienced a serious incident. While using compressed air to clear resin granules from the hopper area, Mensah failed to notice that the machine's emergency stop button had been accidentally bumped by another technician, resetting the lockout/tagout procedure. As Mensah reached toward the mold cavity area, the machine suddenly cycled and the mold began closing. He immediately jerked his hand back, narrowly avoiding crushing his fingers in the closing mold. His coworker Instrumentation Technician Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075) was nearby and heard the alert and pulled the emergency stop. Investigation revealed that the LOTO procedure documentation was unclear about verification steps, and the night shift staff had not received recent refresher training on the procedure.

On March 28, 2024, at 10:30, Packaging Operator Amina Ba (EMP-00164) was manually assembling protective composite covers at a packaging station in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) when she nearly sustained a hand injury. While reaching across a semi-automated assembly conveyor to retrieve finished parts, her loose laboratory coat sleeve caught on a rotating shaft coupling that was inadequately guarded. The coupling pulled the fabric taut, and Ba's hand was drawn toward the rotating mechanism. She immediately felt the tension and pulled her arm back forcefully, tearing the coat sleeve but avoiding direct contact with the rotating equipment. Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068), who was observing production metrics, witnessed the incident and immediately notified the Production Engineer Sébastien Carrier. Investigation found that the shaft coupling guard had been partially removed three weeks earlier for maintenance and never reinstalled.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone of the Main Production Building. While adjusting the hopper valve to clear a suspected blockage, he noticed a significant buildup of granular resin material that appeared ready to overflow. Gosselin immediately ceased all operations and activated the hopper emergency stop procedure. Assembly Lead Sonia Dasilva, working nearby on the automotive line, witnessed the situation and assisted in safely securing the area. Upon inspection by Automation Technician Aya Tanaka, it was determined that the hopper level sensor had malfunctioned, failing to trigger the automatic cutoff sequence. The equipment was immediately isolated, and no material spill occurred. The near-miss was classified as a potential Level 3 incident had the overflow proceeded uncontrolled, as excessive material accumulation could have led to equipment damage, operator injury from flying debris, or chemical exposure if composite resin materials had dispersed. The team's quick recognition of the hazard and proper response prevented the incident from escalating.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM on the day shift, Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau sustained a first-aid injury while processing recycled plastic material in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C of Warehouse and Shipping). While monitoring the regrind mill output, a sharp plastic edge fragment ejected from the grinding chamber and struck Comeau's right forearm, creating a 2-inch laceration approximately 1/4 inch deep. The fragment came from a batch of composite material that was improperly pre-sorted and contained cured resin with protruding edges. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger immediately responded, provided first aid by cleaning and bandaging the wound, and applied antibiotic ointment and a sterile dressing. Comeau was assessed and cleared for continued work on modified duties with his arm protected. The wound was properly documented, and Bélanger verified that Comeau's tetanus vaccination was current. The incident was attributed to inadequate material sorting procedures and insufficient operator guarding during the grinding process. No lost work time occurred, though Comeau experienced minor pain and swelling for approximately 48 hours.

On March 28, 2024, the HSE department received a preventive declaration regarding potential electrical hazards in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (East Section of Maintenance Workshop). During a routine facility inspection, Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson identified that several pieces of electrical test equipment had reached their calibration expiration dates, and some extension cords showed visible wear, fraying, and tape repairs inconsistent with electrical safety standards. Additionally, Thompson noted that the personal grounding straps used by technicians during sensitive equipment repair work were not being systematically stored or maintained, with several showing signs of oxidation on the conductive contacts. While no injury or incident had occurred, Thompson classified this as a critical preventive issue given that Automation Technician Aya Tanaka and other maintenance staff routinely work with energized circuits in this area. The declaration triggered an immediate review of all electrical safety procedures, equipment maintenance logs, and technician certifications. This preventive action identified systematic gaps in electrical safety compliance that could have led to serious injury or equipment damage if left unaddressed.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Technician Olga Ivanova was transferring a 20-liter container of polyol resin from a storage shelf to a preparation tank when the container's lid became loose during transfer. Approximately 8 liters of the chemical spilled onto the concrete floor and partially onto her work apron. The spill created a hazardous pool extending about 2 meters across the room. Ivanova immediately notified her supervisor and evacuated the immediate area. The room's ventilation system activated automatically, but fumes were detected in the adjacent material handling zone. Material Handler Amani Mwangi, working 15 meters away, reported eye irritation within minutes. Emergency response team arrived within 8 minutes. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and neutralizing agents. No employees required hospitalization, but both workers received medical evaluation. The incident was caused by improper container securing procedures and lack of secondary containment in the transfer area.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift, a significant equipment failure occurred on Injection Molding Machine Line C (UNIT-003). Machine setter Tomas Jimenez was performing routine setup for a medical device component production run when he heard an unusual grinding noise from the hydraulic pump assembly. Before he could alert maintenance, the pump's internal seal failed catastrophically, causing a high-pressure hydraulic fluid discharge that impacted the machine's control cabinet and surrounding equipment. The impact bent the cabinet door, damaged three proximity sensors, and compromised electrical connections. Hydraulic fluid sprayed approximately 2 meters, coating the machine frame and some nearby tooling. The machine immediately shut down via emergency stop protocol. Jimenez sustained minor cuts to his left hand from metal fragments and reported to occupational health. Maintenance technician Réjan Simard responded within 12 minutes and secured the equipment. The incident resulted in approximately 16 hours of production downtime. Root cause investigation revealed that routine maintenance on the hydraulic pump had been deferred by 3 weeks due to production scheduling pressures.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift, a near-miss incident occurred at the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). Shipping coordinator Normand Vaillancourt was preparing a pallet of packaged medical device components for loading onto a refrigerated truck when he noticed the overhead crane's load indicator display was flickering intermittently. The display showed conflicting weight readings—alternating between 850 kg and 920 kg for a load that should have weighed exactly 875 kg. Vaillancourt immediately stopped the crane operation and did not proceed with the lift. He reported the issue to Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor, who was present. O'Connor secured the crane with lockout/tagout procedures and called Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim. Investigation revealed a loose electrical connection in the load cell sensor that was causing erratic readings. The potential consequence of continuing the lift would have been uncontrolled load drop, risking injury to dock personnel and product damage. The cause was attributed to vibration from nearby forklift operations loosening the connector over several weeks of operation. No personnel were injured and no equipment was damaged because Vaillancourt recognized the hazard and halted operations.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was removing finished components from Injection Molding Machine Line B in the Main Production Building. After 6 hours of continuous part removal work, she began experiencing sharp pain in her wrists and forearms. By 3:30 PM, she reported numbness in her fingers and difficulty gripping parts. The repetitive motion of extracting small plastic components from the mold cavity—performed approximately 400 times per hour—had aggravated existing inflammation in her carpal tunnel. Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) witnessed her difficulty and alerted Line Manager Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109). She was immediately sent to first aid where ice was applied and the area was wrapped. Initial assessment suggested early carpal tunnel syndrome exacerbation. The employee was placed on modified duty for the remainder of the shift and recommended for medical evaluation.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Forklift Operator Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167) was moving pallets of raw polypropylene resin from the Warehouse and Shipping building toward the Material Drying and Preparation Room. While navigating through a narrow corridor near the chemical storage area, the forklift's left tire struck a spilled pool of hydraulic fluid that had leaked from a maintenance equipment storage area. The slippery surface caused the forklift to lose traction and skid laterally. A stack of four pallets, each weighing approximately 900 pounds, began to shift on the forklift's forks. Fontaine attempted to stabilize the load but lost control, and the entire stack collapsed onto the concrete floor, rupturing multiple resin bags and scattering approximately 1,800 pounds of raw plastic material across a 20-foot area. Material Handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was nearby and sustained a minor laceration to his left arm from scattered plastic debris. The hydraulic spill and scattered resin created an additional slip hazard. The area was immediately cordoned off and cleaned by the maintenance team. Approximately $18,000 in raw materials was lost.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) experienced an environmental incident. Night shift operator Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181) was preparing a batch of colorant masterbatch using isopropanol solvent when a mixing valve on the storage tank malfunctioned. The valve remained partially open, and approximately 40 liters of isopropanol vapor began escaping into the room's ventilation system. Due to reduced night shift staffing, the buildup was not immediately detected. By 7:15 AM, day shift employee Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) arrived for pre-shift setup and detected a strong chemical odor. She immediately notified Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107). The room was evacuated, and emergency ventilation was activated. Indoor air quality monitoring indicated isopropanol vapor concentration of 850 ppm in the chemical room (OSHA PEL: 400 ppm), exceeding safe exposure limits. The leak was traced to corroded valve seals that had not been replaced during recent maintenance. Outdoor air quality monitoring revealed contamination at the facility's west boundary, affecting a 50-meter radius. Local environmental authorities were notified per Quebec environmental regulations.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, experienced a minor chemical splash incident in the Main Production Building - North Zone. While transferring a batch of colorant masterbatch from a storage container to the hopper feeder system, the container's seal was defective and pressurized liquid sprayed unexpectedly. A small amount of colored polypropylene mixture contacted Zaidi's left eye and upper cheek area before he could react. He immediately flushed his eye at the emergency eyewash station for approximately 3 minutes. The incident was witnessed by Léa Parent (EMP-00121), a Quality Control Technician who was performing routine checks nearby. First aid was administered on-site with no need for medical attention beyond the eyewash. The defective container was identified as having a manufacturing defect from the supplier. Zaidi experienced minor irritation for approximately 2 hours post-incident with full recovery by end of shift. The root cause was traced to inadequate quality control on incoming containers from the chemical supplier.

On November 18, 2024 at 22:15 during evening shift operations, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, developed acute lower back strain while manually handling composite fiber reinforcement spools in the Materials Management and Warehousing area. Diallo was repositioning multiple 50-pound glass fiber spools from a pallet to elevated storage racks approximately 5.5 feet high. After moving the seventh spool, he felt a sharp pain in his lower lumbar region and was unable to continue work. He reported the incident to Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), the Packaging Supervisor, who provided basic first aid and rest. Diallo applied ice for 30 minutes and took over-the-counter ibuprofen. He remained on modified duty for the remainder of the shift, performing light administrative tasks. The pain subsided to a dull ache by shift end, allowing him to complete his work without further medical intervention. Root cause analysis revealed that no mechanical lift assist equipment was available in the warehouse despite repeated requests. The repetitive bending, lifting, and twisting required to move the spools from floor to elevated heights exceeded ergonomic guidelines. No witnesses were present when the injury occurred.

On November 20, 2024 at 09:30 during day shift operations, Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189), a Mold Repair Technician, sustained a laceration to his right hand while removing a stuck component from a damaged mold assembly in the Main Production Building - North Zone. Lévesque was using a steel pry bar to remove a reinforcing insert that had become bonded to the mold cavity due to solidified polyester resin. While applying downward leverage, the pry bar slipped and struck a sharp edge of the fractured mold, causing a 2-inch laceration across the dorsal surface of his right hand between the thumb and index finger. The injury severed a small superficial vein, resulting in moderate bleeding. Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), a Receiving Clerk who was nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately called for first aid assistance. François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105), the Maintenance Supervisor, responded and applied direct pressure with clean gauze for 8 minutes until bleeding stopped. The wound was cleaned and bandaged on-site, but given the depth and location, Lévesque was transported to the urgent care facility by company vehicle for professional evaluation and suturing. Five stitches were required. Lévesque was cleared to return to modified duty after 2 hours of observation. Root cause: inadequate tool quality and no secondary containment during pry-bar operations. The mold had been scheduled for professional repair but was being expedited.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components Clean Room (UNIT-003). While wiping down the mold cavity with compressed air to remove residual plastic material, Pascal inadvertently directed the air stream toward his face at close range. The compressed air entered his right ear canal with significant force, causing immediate sharp pain and temporary hearing disruption. A nearby colleague, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), witnessed the incident and immediately notified Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid. Initial assessment revealed no visible perforation, but Pascal experienced vertigo and mild tinnitus for approximately 2 hours post-incident. The employee was monitored in the medical office and released with instructions for follow-up audiological assessment within 48 hours. This near-miss highlighted unsafe compressed air handling practices and the inadequacy of current training regarding maximum safe pressure exposure limits.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Jing Wang, Materials Engineer (EMP-00054), conducted a routine safety inspection of the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009) as part of quarterly hazard assessments. During the walkthrough, Jing identified that Emergency Exit Door #2, located at the north end of the dock, was partially obstructed by a stack of five wooden pallets containing finished composite parts awaiting shipment. The pallets were positioned approximately 18 inches from the exit door, reducing the effective door opening width to approximately 24 inches—below the required 28-inch CNESST minimum clearance standard. Additionally, the exit signage above the door was obscured by warehouse shelving that had been repositioned during recent facility reorganization. Jing photographed the condition, documented the findings, and immediately notified Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi. The hazard was reported as a preventive declaration to ensure corrective action before any potential emergency evacuation scenario. No personnel were at immediate risk, but the non-compliance posed significant regulatory and safety concerns.

On November 20, 2024, at 4:45 PM during the evening shift, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), Injection Molding Operator for Line A, was performing routine maintenance on the hydraulic system of the injection molding equipment located in UNIT-003 (Medical Components Clean Room). While adjusting a hydraulic hose connector, the fitting suddenly fractured due to metal fatigue from repeated thermal cycles. High-pressure hydraulic fluid—approximately 8 liters of ISO 32 mineral oil—sprayed forcefully across the work area, damaging nearby electrical control panels, soaking critical machine instrumentation, and coating the clean room's precision work surfaces and mold storage areas. The hydraulic fluid contaminated approximately 40 medical-grade molds stored on adjacent shelving, rendering them unusable and requiring immediate replacement. Emergency procedures were activated, the area was isolated, and cleanup began immediately. Estimated material damage exceeded $47,000, including replacement molds ($28,000), electrical panel repairs ($12,000), instrumentation recalibration ($5,000), and clean room decontamination ($2,000). The incident was documented by Sanaa Rachidi, Fire Safety Coordinator, due to the severity of equipment damage and environmental containment concerns.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, was operating the overhead crane in the Warehouse and Shipping facility to move a pallet of polycarbonate resin destined for the composite materials processing area. At approximately 2:18 PM, while the 2-ton load was suspended 12 feet above the warehouse floor, the cable connection on the crane's lifting mechanism began to fray and ultimately failed. The load dropped suddenly, missing Owusu by approximately 3 feet and striking a storage rack containing finished goods packaging materials. The impact scattered boxes across a 20-foot radius and damaged approximately $8,400 worth of inventory. Owusu immediately activated the facility's emergency alert system. Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a nearby Production Operator, and Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133), the Facilities Manager, responded within seconds. No personnel were struck, but the incident triggered a full facility evacuation per safety protocols. Investigation revealed that the cable had not been inspected in accordance with the quarterly maintenance schedule, and wear indicators had not been properly documented.

On November 16, 2024, at approximately 6:45 PM during the evening shift, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a Machine Operator, was removing finished composite parts from a cooling chamber when his left hand made contact with a partially solidified resin piece still at approximately 85°C. The brief contact resulted in a second-degree thermal burn affecting approximately 8 square centimeters of skin on the dorsal surface of his left hand between the thumb and index finger. Kouassi immediately immersed his hand in cool water from a nearby wash station and reported the incident to his supervisor, Michael Chen (EMP-00004). Chen provided first aid by applying sterile gauze and topical burn ointment from the facility's first aid station located in Unit 015. The incident was documented per CNESST requirements, and Kouassi was instructed to monitor the injury over the next 24 hours. No hospitalization was required. The employee was able to continue modified duty work for the remainder of his shift, assisting with quality control documentation using voice commands while his hand healed.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician, was performing preventive maintenance on a hydraulic system in the Central Maintenance Workshop when he noticed an unusual vibration pattern in a pressure relief valve. Upon visual inspection, Gravel identified that the valve's internal spring mechanism showed signs of corrosion and was producing a faint but escalating whistling sound, indicating internal pressure buildup. The pressure gauge reading was fluctuating erratically between 45 and 65 PSI, when normal operating range should be stable at 55 PSI. Gravel immediately isolated the system by closing the main isolation valve and placed caution tape and warning signs around the equipment. He documented the anomaly in the maintenance log and contacted Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006), the Maintenance Manager, who was on call. Rodriguez arrived at the facility within 45 minutes and confirmed that continued operation would have likely resulted in a catastrophic hydraulic system failure or explosion risk within the next 12-24 hours, potentially affecting multiple injection molding machines and causing serious injury. The equipment was safely depressurized, and replacement parts were ordered.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos observed potential hazardous conditions in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT area). While conducting a routine inspection of the resin mixing operations, Santos noticed that three large containers of epoxy resin were stored without secondary containment trays beneath them, creating a significant spill risk. Additionally, she identified that the ventilation system's intake valves were partially obstructed by accumulated dust and debris, which could lead to inadequate air circulation and increased vapor concentrations. The chemical storage area lacked clear labeling on several containers, and there was no evidence of recent inspections or maintenance logs. Santos immediately documented these findings and flagged them as preventive safety concerns before any incident occurred. She photographed the conditions and notified the Facilities Maintenance team. This preventive declaration was submitted proactively to address multiple chemical handling hazards and prevent potential exposures to employees in the facility.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Aaliyah Jackson sustained a minor burn injury while performing finishing work on automotive composite parts at the Packaging and Labeling Station. Jackson was transferring hot-cured composite components from an industrial oven staging area when she accidentally made brief contact with a still-warm polymer component that had cooled insufficiently. The component, approximately 85°C, caused a first-degree burn to the dorsal surface of her left hand covering an area of approximately 3 square centimeters. Coworker Ana Silva immediately responded and guided Jackson to the first aid station. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen administered first aid, which included immediate application of cool water for 10 minutes, followed by application of sterile burn dressing and topical antibiotic ointment. Jackson's burn was photographed and documented. She was advised to monitor for signs of infection and given written care instructions. Ice packs and pain relief were provided. Jackson resumed light duty work after 30 minutes. No hospitalization was required. The incident was logged as a first aid case requiring treatment but not resulting in lost time.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 6:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant equipment failure occurred at Injection Molding Line A in the Main Production Building. Injection Molding Operator François Gagnon was monitoring production of automotive bracket components when the hydraulic pump assembly on the 250-ton injection molding machine (Unit #14) experienced catastrophic failure. The pump began making unusual grinding noises, then seized completely, causing immediate loss of hydraulic pressure to all machine functions. The machine shut down with a full hopper of molten plastic resin at 280°C still inside the injection chamber. Emergency stop procedures were activated by Gagnon and confirmed by Quality Control Lead Petra Mueller who was nearby conducting line inspections. Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand was immediately called to assess the damage. The pump had internal seal failure causing hydraulic fluid to leak into the machine's cavity. Preliminary inspection revealed the pump's internal bearing had seized due to lack of lubrication, likely resulting from missed maintenance intervals. The pump assembly required complete replacement. The machine remained offline for investigation and repair, disrupting production of critical automotive components scheduled for customer delivery the following day.

On January 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a catastrophic failure occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (UNIT-017). An industrial oven door hinge assembly failed suddenly while Composite Materials Operator Rania Abdallah was removing a batch of cured composite parts. The 150-pound reinforced glass door swung open unexpectedly and struck a nearby storage rack containing finished goods inventory worth approximately $78,000. The impact caused the rack to partially collapse, scattering composite parts across a 12-foot radius. Additionally, hydraulic fluid from the oven's temperature control system began leaking onto the floor. Production Engineer Sébastien Carrier and Material Handler Elif Yilmaz witnessed the incident and immediately initiated emergency shutdown protocols. Facility maintenance confirmed the hinge welds had corroded due to thermal cycling and inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling. No personnel injuries occurred, but equipment damage exceeded $45,000 including oven repairs, replacement parts, and inventory losses.

On January 22, 2025, at approximately 11:15 PM during night shift operations, Production Operator Kwame Mensah was performing routine maintenance on a 500-ton injection molding machine (Machine #28) in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). While cleaning the mold cavity with compressed air after completing a production run, Mensah failed to engage the machine's lockout/tagout (LOTO) safety system as required by company protocol. A co-worker, Mold Repair Technician Armand Lévesque, inadvertently activated the machine's startup sequence from the control panel while conducting equipment diagnostics nearby. The mold assembly suddenly closed with extreme force, trapping Mensah's left gloved hand in the mold cavity. The incident was immediately halted by the machine's safety interlock system, which detected the hand presence through the motion sensor. However, Mensah sustained significant bruising to his hand and fingers, with swelling and temporary loss of dexterity. Mensah was transported to the emergency clinic by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid, who responded to the scene within 3 minutes. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur conducted an immediate investigation and discovered that LOTO procedures had not been performed due to time pressure and production scheduling conflicts. No permanent injury resulted, but the incident classified as a near-miss with high potential for amputation or fatality.

On January 28, 2025, at approximately 10:30 AM during day shift operations, Material Handler Salma Haddad was coordinating the transfer of finished composite materials from the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) to the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009) using an overhead crane system. Approximately 2,400 pounds of precision-molded automotive components were secured in a standard pallet frame suspended 18 feet above the dock floor. As Crane Operator Gaston Picard was executing the transfer sequence, a visual inspection routine detected minor corrosion on the left support cable assembly. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois was conducting routine facility inspections in the warehouse zone and observed the corrosion during her air quality sampling work. She immediately flagged the crane operation and halted the material transfer through the facility's communication system. The load was carefully lowered and secured. Upon detailed engineering inspection, metal fatigue testing revealed the cable had lost approximately 12% of its load-bearing capacity due to inadequate dehumidification in the warehouse storage zone. The corrosive salt air environment near the facility's loading dock, combined with insufficient protective coating maintenance, had accelerated deterioration. The incident was classified as a preventive declaration because the hazard was identified and neutralized before load failure occurred. Had the transfer continued, potential consequences included load drop, property destruction, and severe personnel injuries. The facility's preventive maintenance program successfully identified the risk through routine environmental monitoring.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a hydraulic press malfunction occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing). Bernard Allard, the Hydraulic Press Operator, was performing routine setup for a fiber-reinforced composite layup when the press's pressure relief valve failed catastrophically. The valve, which had not been serviced in 18 months despite a 12-month maintenance interval, suddenly released pressurized hydraulic fluid at 2,800 PSI. The fluid spray struck the control panel and ignition source wiring, creating a small electrical arc. Although no fire materialized due to quick response, the incident exposed critical gaps in preventive maintenance scheduling. The press was immediately shut down and isolated. A secondary risk emerged when Mario Bélisle, the Tool and Die Maker, arrived to assess the damage and discovered the equipment was still under residual pressure. Raj Patel, Process Engineer, properly locked out and tagged the equipment before inspection could proceed. The incident resulted in $43,000 in equipment damage and 6 hours of production downtime.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). Normand Vaillancourt, Shipping Coordinator, was preparing pallets for shipment when he noticed a forklift (operated by a temporary contractor not employed by TechnoPlast) approaching an unstable stack of resin containers that had been improperly stowed the previous day. The stack consisted of 12 high-density polyethylene (HDPE) containers weighing approximately 45 kg each, arranged in a pyramid formation with inadequate cross-bracing. Normand immediately halted the forklift operator and prevented what would have been a catastrophic load failure. The containers were positioned directly above the loading dock edge, and failure would have resulted in containers falling approximately 8 feet onto the dock below, creating a serious injury risk for dock personnel below. Upon investigation, Leila Farah, Production Operator, admitted she had organized the stack hastily without following proper warehouse stacking procedures documented in the facility's materials handling protocol. No injuries occurred, but the incident exposed critical gaps in contractor oversight and materials management procedures. The containers were immediately restacked correctly using proper pallet configurations.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a thermal burn injury occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Kwame Mensah, Production Operator on the night shift, was assisting with preparation of a polyester resin batch for the morning shift's composite production run. While transferring heated resin from a jacketed kettle (maintained at 85°C) to a secondary mixing vessel, the transfer hose unexpectedly disconnected from its quick-coupling, spraying approximately 2 liters of hot resin onto Mensah's left forearm and hand. The employee was wearing only a light cotton shirt rather than the required chemical-resistant apron and flame-resistant sleeves specified for hot resin handling. The resin rapidly cooled and hardened on the skin, resulting in partial-thickness burns covering approximately 8% of the forearm and hand. Mensah immediately plunged his arm into cold water and activated the emergency eyewash/safety shower. Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, responded and arranged immediate transport to the nearest hospital emergency department. The employee received treatment for second-degree thermal burns and was prescribed pain management and wound care protocols. Investigation revealed the quick-coupling had not been visually inspected for wear or proper seating as part of the daily equipment checklist. The coupling showed visible corrosion and stress fractures suggesting age-related degradation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine mold changeover at Injection Molding Line D when he noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge reading was fluctuating erratically between 150 and 280 PSI. Before engaging the mold closing mechanism, Ahmed decided to inspect the hydraulic hose connections. He discovered a small hairline crack developing on a high-pressure coupling that was beginning to weep fluid. Ahmed immediately notified his supervisor and shut down the machine using proper lockout procedures. The potential hazard was that continued operation could have resulted in a catastrophic hydraulic line rupture, which would have sprayed high-pressure hydraulic fluid directly at operator height—a known hazard that can cause severe injection injuries. Deepa Gupta, the Process Quality Engineer, arrived within minutes and confirmed the equipment should remain offline. Maintenance was called, and the equipment was safely secured. No injury occurred because the operator followed proper inspection protocols and halted operations before failure.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during day shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator in the Assembly and Finishing Department, was manually grinding burrs from molded consumer packaging components using a handheld die grinder with a 3-inch rotating disc. Despite wearing standard work gloves, Amal's left index finger made contact with the spinning disc when reaching across a workpiece to improve grip angle. The disc caught the edge of the glove and pulled the fingertip into contact, causing a laceration approximately 1.5 cm long on the lateral side of the finger. The operator immediately withdrew their hand and applied pressure with a cloth. Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), the Material Handler working nearby, heard the exclamation and brought the first aid kit. Petra Mueller (EMP-00166), the Quality Control Lead, provided immediate first aid treatment including wound cleaning, antiseptic application, and sterile bandaging. The wound did not require stitches but was classified as a reportable first-aid injury. The employee continued work with modified duty for the remainder of the shift.

On March 19, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift operations, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was monitoring the discharge of hot molded parts from a 350-ton injection molding machine. The coolant/mold release spray system malfunctioned, causing incomplete coverage on a fresh batch of components. Without proper cooling, the plastic parts retained significantly higher temperatures than normal—approximately 160°C instead of the standard 85°C. When Conrad reached with bare hands to manually adjust a guide rail, his right forearm made incidental contact with an exposed hot component for approximately 2 seconds. He immediately withdrew and experienced acute thermal pain. Conrad ran his arm under cool running water at the nearest wash station for approximately 3 minutes, then reported to the first aid station. Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), the Environmental Compliance Specialist, provided immediate first aid treatment including continued cool water irrigation, application of sterile non-adherent dressing, and pain assessment. The burn was classified as a first-degree burn with partial second-degree involvement covering approximately 40 square centimeters. The employee was advised to seek follow-up medical evaluation and placed on modified duty.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, Production Operator Aisha Kamara was working at Injection Molding Line B when she noticed unusual vibration from the automated robotic arm during the molding cycle. She immediately stopped the machine and called over Tool Room Technician Raynald Vézina to investigate. Upon inspection, Raynald discovered that the robotic arm's servo motor coupling had begun to loosen, which could have led to catastrophic misalignment and potential entanglement with the moving mold plates. The issue was caught before any parts were ejected or the arm made contact with personnel. Raynald immediately secured the coupling and performed a full calibration check. The near-miss was documented within 30 minutes of discovery. Had the operator not been attentive to the subtle vibration changes, continued operation would have resulted in serious injury from the high-speed robotic mechanism. The incident highlights the effectiveness of operator awareness training and the importance of equipment monitoring.

On April 22, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Material Handler Hassan Diallo was transferring bags of polypropylene resin in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when he noticed a small electrical spark emanating from a worn junction box on the wall near the material heating station. The spark ignited a small quantity of residual polypropylene dust that had accumulated on a nearby shelf, creating a localized fire approximately 30 centimeters in diameter. Hassan immediately activated the nearest ABC dry powder fire extinguisher and suppressed the flames within 60 seconds. He then evacuated the area and triggered the facility alarm at 22:16. The evening shift supervisor Emmanuel Kouassi coordinated evacuation while the HSE director Marie-Claude Beaumont arrived on scene at 22:22 to assess damage. The fire was completely extinguished with no spread to adjacent materials. The electrical junction box was severely damaged and required replacement. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate housekeeping in the storage room combined with deteriorating electrical infrastructure. No injuries occurred, but the incident demonstrated the facility's vulnerability to ignition sources in high-dust environments.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, material handler Elif Yilmaz was organizing finished goods pallets in Section B of the Finished Goods Warehouse when a stack of molded automotive components began to shift. The pallet rack, loaded with approximately 300 kg of polypropylene parts across three shelves, had been stacked to maximum capacity. As Elif repositioned a lower pallet, vibrations caused the upper shelves to tilt. A cascading failure appeared imminent as several cartons began sliding toward the edge. Elif quickly stepped back and alerted nearby supervisor Robert Fournier, who immediately cleared the area. The topmost stack of materials teetered for approximately 45 seconds before stabilizing. No materials fell, and no injuries occurred. However, the incident revealed that the pallet rack had not been inspected for structural integrity in over 18 months, and load weight specifications had been exceeded by an estimated 15%. The warehouse supervisor conducted an immediate visual inspection of all storage racks and documented the near-miss in the safety log.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, machine operator Hawa Traore was adjusting cooling parameters on Injection Molding Line B when she noticed an unusual odor emanating from the resin hopper area. The machine was processing polypropylene resin with colorant additives. Hawa immediately shut down the machine and activated the local ventilation system. She contacted her supervisor Julie Bergeron and reported the incident. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the hopper overflow sensor had malfunctioned, causing resin material to accumulate at the junction between the hopper and the feed screw assembly. The excess material had begun to thermally degrade, releasing styrene-based fumes. No employees reported respiratory symptoms. However, the incident demonstrated a potential gap in preventive maintenance procedures, as the sensor should have been replaced during the previous scheduled maintenance cycle three weeks earlier. The equipment was isolated and tagged out. A maintenance technician inspected the overflow system, replaced the faulty sensor, and cleared the degraded material. Environmental monitoring equipment confirmed air quality had returned to normal baseline readings within 30 minutes of remediation.

On March 22, 2024, during a routine pre-shift safety audit, Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi conducted an inspection of the Hazardous Waste Management Area located in the exterior zone of the Chemical Storage Building. Upon review, Sanaa discovered that plastic solvent containers (acetone and isopropanol waste) were being stored in an aluminum bin without proper secondary containment barriers. According to the company's hazardous waste management procedures, all flammable chemical waste must be stored in dedicated, fire-rated containers with spill containment systems rated for 110% of the largest single container volume. The aluminum bin in use provided no spill containment and was positioned approximately 2 meters from an electrical junction box. Additionally, Sanaa noted that the area lacked proper "Flammable Materials" signage visible from the exterior access points. No spill had occurred, and no environmental or safety incidents had resulted. However, the situation represented a violation of both internal safety protocols and CNESST regulations regarding flammable waste storage. Sanaa immediately documented the finding in the safety audit log, placed warning tape around the affected area, and notified the Materials Management supervisor. The non-compliant container was removed from service and the waste was transferred to appropriate storage within 24 hours. This discovery prompted a facility-wide audit of all chemical storage and waste areas.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) was performing routine mold cleaning on Injection Molding Line B when he inadvertently contacted a heated mold surface. The mold, part of an automotive dashboard component production run, had been cooling for only 8 minutes after the injection cycle completed. Despite standard cooling time protocols indicating 15 minutes minimum before manual contact, François reached directly onto the mold surface to remove a minor flash without waiting for the thermal indicator light. He sustained second-degree burns across the palm and inner fingers of his right hand, covering approximately 15% of the affected hand area. The burn required immediate first aid with cool water application and medical attention at a nearby clinic. Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175) witnessed the incident and immediately notified the HSE office. François was temporarily reassigned to lighter duties while his hand healed over the subsequent two weeks.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) was retrieving finished goods from a high storage rack in the Warehouse and Shipping facility when the uppermost pallet, containing approximately 200 kg of packaged automotive trim components, became unstable due to improper stacking and load distribution by the previous shift. As Marc reached upward with a handheld scanner to verify inventory, the pallet shifted and fell, striking him across the left shoulder and upper arm. The impact resulted in a fractured left clavicle and severe contusions requiring emergency room treatment and a three-week medical leave. The incident occurred because the previous shift had stacked lighter pallets beneath heavier ones, violating weight distribution protocols, and had not used racking safety pins as required. Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) was conducting an evening inventory audit nearby and immediately summoned emergency responders. The fallen materials damaged approximately 80 units of finished goods valued at approximately $12,000.

On May 8, 2024, at 4:30 AM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was inspecting the Resin Drying and Preparation Room following a production quality alert. While checking a resin dryer unit that had shut down unexpectedly, he discovered that the heating element had overheated, causing internal electrical arcing that damaged the control circuit board and left visible scorch marks inside the unit cabinet. The equipment malfunction was determined to be caused by a failed thermostat that had not been replaced during the scheduled preventive maintenance in February, despite appearing on the maintenance schedule. The dryer's backup thermal cutoff also failed to activate, indicating potential age-related degradation of the safety system. While Alain was not injured, the damaged dryer remained non-functional, disrupting material preparation for two production lines and causing a production delay of 18 hours. The electrical damage to the control board and associated wiring required replacement components valued at approximately $28,000, plus labor costs. Tool Room Supervisor Richard Beaulieu (EMP-00043) was contacted for emergency equipment repair assessment. This property damage incident resulted from deferred maintenance and inadequate system redundancy.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM, Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050), a Production Operator on the day shift, sustained a minor laceration to her left hand while operating injection molding machine Line D in the Main Production Building. While removing a completed part from the mold cavity, her hand contacted the edge of a partially cooled plastic component. The part, still at approximately 65°C, caused a first-degree burn and minor abrasion to her palm. Fatou immediately reported the incident to her supervisor James Thompson (EMP-00029), who provided first aid treatment including cool water irrigation and application of antibiotic ointment. The injury was treated on-site in the facility's first aid station without requiring external medical attention. The employee returned to modified duties within 30 minutes, avoiding direct contact with hot materials. No lost work time occurred. The incident was witnessed by Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), a CNC Operator nearby.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, an unplanned material spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a Machine Operator on the evening shift, was transferring reclaimed polycarbonate pellets from a bulk storage bin to a processing hopper when the 500-pound bin's support bracket failed due to metal fatigue. The bin tipped forward, spilling approximately 400 pounds of material across an approximate 15-foot area of the warehouse floor. The spillage resulted in material loss valued at approximately $2,400, based on current polycarbonate resin pricing. Additionally, the bin damage and bent support structure required replacement, accounting for approximately $1,200 in equipment costs. The incident occurred at 10:15 PM with minimal ambient light, reducing visibility. Material scattered across the floor created a slip hazard that required immediate containment and cleanup lasting approximately 4 hours. No employees were injured during the incident. Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, assisted with cleanup operations.

On March 29, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Maintenance Workshop. Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician on the night shift, was performing routine maintenance on a resin dryer unit (Model HDT-2000) when the temperature control system malfunctioned. The dryer's digital thermostat failed, displaying erratic readings oscillating between 45°C and 180°C. At the time of failure, the dryer was processing a batch of fiber-reinforced polyamide pellets. The uncontrolled temperature spike caused the heating element to overheat beyond the safe operating range of 130°C. Internal inspection later revealed that the heating coils had warped, the thermal cutoff switch failed to trigger, and resin material had partially decomposed, releasing volatile organic compounds. The equipment required complete replacement of the heating assembly, thermal controls, and internal components, estimated at $18,500. The batch of material in processing (approximately $3,200 worth) was rendered unusable due to thermal degradation. Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), an Automation Technician, assisted in documenting the failure and shutdown procedures. The incident was discovered when Gravel noticed the strong chemical odor and abnormal dryer housing temperature.

On March 14, 2024, at 10:45 AM during day shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was retrieving polypropylene resin bags from the overhead storage shelf in the Regrind and Recycling Department. While pulling down a stack of four 25-kg bags, one bag's corner caught on the metal bracket of an adjacent shelf. As Bianchi attempted to free it, the bag shifted suddenly and fell approximately 1.2 meters, passing within 15 centimeters of her head before striking the concrete floor and bursting open. The resin pellets scattered across the work area. Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183) was nearby and immediately moved to assist. The incident was immediately reported because the falling object could have caused serious head injury if the trajectory had been different. No contact was made with the employee. The root cause was identified as inadequate securing of stacked materials and lack of designated clearance zones beneath overhead storage.
