On April 2, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074) was working at Line C when she noticed mold release agent spray had accumulated on the injection molding machine's control panel and floor around her workstation. The chemical residue, a silicone-based mold release agent (hydrophobic), had created a slippery surface. While moving between the molding machine and the quality inspection station, Gonzalez's shoe slipped on the contaminated floor. She fell backward onto her left hip and wrist, sustaining an abrasion and minor contusion. Production Supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) was notified immediately and moved her to the first aid station. The facility's on-site medical personnel applied antiseptic wash, antibiotic ointment, and sterile bandaging to the abrasion. An ice pack was applied to reduce swelling of the wrist. No fracture was suspected, but mild swelling persisted. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate ventilation had concentrated mold release agent vapors, causing excessive overspray deposition on nearby surfaces, combined with infrequent floor cleaning in that zone.

On May 8, 2024, at 2:15 AM during night shift, Machine Setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. While inspecting the cooling water circulation system, Yusuf observed a hairline crack in a rubber hose connected to the machine's temperature control manifold. The crack was weeping coolant, a mixture of water and industrial coolant concentrate. Yusuf immediately isolated the circuit by closing the supply valve and notified Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) via radio. Before Champagne arrived, the hose suddenly failed under residual pressure, spraying approximately 8 liters of coolant across the machine's electrical control box and partially onto the floor adjacent to the machine. The coolant splashed onto approximately 1 square meter of floor surface, creating a slick area. However, the spray did not contact Yusuf due to his positioning behind the machine. Champagne responded within 5 minutes, immediately shut off all power to the machine using the main disconnect, and deployed absorbent mats to contain the liquid. No employee contact with the coolant occurred, and no injury resulted. The incident was reported because the sudden pressurized coolant discharge posed potential electrical hazard and slip/fall risk to nearby personnel.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was working at Injection Molding Line B when he noticed the hopper material level indicator was malfunctioning. While investigating the issue, he observed that resin pellets were beginning to overflow from the top of the hopper onto the production floor. Hassan immediately stopped the machine and activated the emergency shutdown procedure. However, as he was clearing the overflow material manually using a dustpan, he nearly slipped on the scattered pellets near the machine base. A coworker, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), witnessed the near-miss and helped secure the area. The overflow was contained within 10 minutes, and no injuries occurred. The incident was reported to Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier immediately. Root cause analysis revealed that the hopper level sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months, and preventive maintenance records were incomplete.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026) was performing dimensional verification on medical device components in the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006). While handling a batch of finished parts from Line C, she sustained a laceration on her left index finger from a sharp edge on an injection-molded component. The edge was an unreported burr that had not been properly deburred during post-processing. Leblanc immediately applied direct pressure and reported the injury to Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069). First aid was administered: the wound was cleaned with soap and water, disinfected with antiseptic, and covered with sterile gauze and a bandage. The laceration was approximately 0.5 cm deep but did not require stitches. Leblanc was provided with tetanus information and advised to monitor the wound. She was able to return to work with the hand properly bandaged. The incident was documented and the defective part batch was flagged for rework in the molding department.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, Crane Operator Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041) was moving a skid of raw composite material (prepreg carbon fiber sheets) from the warehouse receiving area to the production building using an overhead crane. The material weigh approximately 1,200 pounds and was secured on a standard industrial pallet with ratchet straps. As Lavoie was lowering the load over the main aisle near the Finished Goods Warehouse section, one of the ratchet straps failed due to corrosion and metal fatigue. The load shifted, and approximately 80 pounds of material fell approximately 12 feet to the concrete floor, scattering across the warehouse aisle and damaging several finished product boxes stacked below. Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) was in the adjacent area and heard the crash. No personnel were directly under the falling material, but the area was immediately cordoned off. The damaged material was sorted; approximately $18,500 in composite materials and finished goods were damaged beyond recovery. The incident was investigated by Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133) and Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136). Root cause: the ratchet straps had not been inspected or replaced in over three years, and no load restraint verification procedure existed.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was operating injection molding machine Line D in the main production area when he noticed unusual vibrations and a grinding noise emanating from the machine's hydraulic pump assembly. The pump had been showing intermittent pressure fluctuations over the previous week, but maintenance had deferred service due to production scheduling. At 2:47 PM, the hydraulic pump suddenly failed catastrophically, rupturing a pressurized hose and spraying hot hydraulic fluid across the operator station. The fluid contacted Said's right arm and shoulder, causing thermal burns. Machine setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) immediately activated the emergency stop and called for first aid response. The machine was shut down and locked out. First aid personnel treated Said's second-degree burns covering approximately 8% of his upper right arm and shoulder. He was transported to the on-site medical clinic for further evaluation and bandaging. The incident was triggered by prolonged equipment degradation without preventive maintenance scheduling.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, material handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was working in the Material Drying and Preparation Room moving large bags of polypropylene resin from the storage area to the drying hoppers. While carrying a 50-pound bag of resin, she stepped on a section of the polished concrete floor that had been inadvertently wet by condensation from a malfunctioning dehumidifier. Her foot slipped, and she fell backward, striking the edge of a steel work table with her lower back and right ribs. She experienced acute pain and difficulty breathing. Regrind operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), who was nearby, immediately assisted her to a seated position and called for first aid response. The company's first aid responder, along with the industrial hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084), arrived within five minutes. Santos assessed the injury, applied ice packs, and monitored breathing. After a 20-minute observation period, Saleh reported decreased pain and was able to stand with assistance. She was transported to the occupational health clinic for X-ray evaluation to rule out rib fractures. The fall was classified as a minor slip-and-fall incident with potential musculoskeletal injury.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, quality inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026) was conducting a pre-production quality inspection at the Finished Goods Warehouse when she was reviewing stacked pallets of molded components. A stack of four pallets containing automotive door handle components (totaling approximately 800 pounds) that had been stored on unstable racking shifted unexpectedly and fell. One pallet struck Leblanc on her left shoulder and upper arm, causing her to fall to the ground. The impact resulted in a painful shoulder contusion and a laceration on her left forearm from a broken pallet edge. Production supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037), who was conducting rounds nearby, immediately responded and called for medical assistance. First aid responder Nina Santos (EMP-00084) arrived within three minutes, applied direct pressure to the laceration to control bleeding, and administered first aid bandaging. The wound was cleaned with sterile saline and dressed with antibiotic ointment and sterile gauze. Leblanc experienced significant shoulder pain and swelling and was transported to the urgent care clinic for further evaluation and potential X-rays. The incident was caused by improper stacking and inadequate pallet weight distribution on storage racks.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, assembly operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room area. While preparing to load polycarbonate resin into the hopper of the injection molding machine, Lopez noticed that the hopper cover was not fully secured. As she attempted to reseat the cover, the machine's feed auger unexpectedly activated, causing plastic pellets to overflow from the hopper opening. The overflow scattered approximately 15 kg of material across the work station and nearby floor area. Lopez immediately stepped back and called for assistance. The incident was contained within 8 minutes with no material entering production lines or clean room air circulation systems. Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran responded and confirmed that the overflow was limited to raw material staging area with no contamination to finished product. Machine was shut down for inspection and the area was cleaned according to protocol.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during evening shift operations, material handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was unloading a wooden pallet containing fiber-reinforced plastic components in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). While manually stacking bundles of composite materials from a damaged pallet, a wooden splinter approximately 8 cm long became embedded in the palm of her left hand near the base of her thumb. Mansour immediately reported the injury to her supervisor, Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), who escorted her to the on-site first aid station. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed the wound, removed the splinter with sterile tweezers, cleaned and disinfected the puncture site with antiseptic solution, and applied antibiotic ointment and a sterile dressing. The wound was documented as a first aid treatment with no need for external medical referral. Mansour was able to return to modified duties after 30 minutes of first aid treatment. The damaged pallet was segregated and marked for disposal.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during night shift maintenance activities, maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine cleaning and solvent recirculation system maintenance in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing). While transferring acetone solvent from a 200-liter storage container to a smaller 20-liter work container, the transfer hose connection failed due to a cracked fitting, causing approximately 8 liters of acetone to spill directly onto the concrete floor. The spill created a continuous 2-meter x 3-meter chemical pool with visible vapors. Gravel immediately activated the area emergency shut-down procedures and notified the night supervisor through radio. The spill was not contained by secondary containment as the storage area lacked compliant spill containment infrastructure. Acetone vapors began accumulating in the work area, creating airborne concentration risks. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was contacted emergently and arrived on-site within 25 minutes. She assessed vapor concentrations using portable monitoring equipment, confirmed acetone levels at 450 ppm (PEL = 250 ppm), and implemented immediate ventilation protocols by opening all available windows and activating auxiliary exhaust fans. The area was evacuated and cordoned off. Absorbent material was deployed to contain the remaining liquid, and the spill was cleaned and disposed of according to provincial hazardous waste protocols. No personnel exposure injuries were reported.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine mold maintenance in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper feed system, Sofia reached into the heated drying chamber without proper lockout procedures being followed. The equipment cycled unexpectedly, and her right hand came into contact with the interior mold surface, which was maintained at 180°C for processing thermoplastic composites. She sustained severe thermal burns across her palm and fingers, with blistering extending to the wrist. Sofia immediately withdrew her hand and alerted nearby workers. First aid was administered immediately, but due to the depth and extent of the burns (approximately 15% of hand surface area), she was transported by ambulance to the regional burn center at Hôpital de l'Enfant-Jésus. She required hospitalization for 5 days, with skin grafting procedures performed. Sofia was unable to return to work for 8 weeks, resulting in lost time.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, was retrieving pallets of raw composite materials from the upper storage racks in the Warehouse and Shipping area (UNIT-009). While maneuvering the forklift to access a pallet positioned near the dock edge, Tariq's shoe caught on a spilled accumulation of plastic pellets and moisture on the warehouse floor. He lost his balance while stepping down from the forklift cabin and fell approximately 1.2 meters to the concrete floor. He landed on his left knee and ankle, sustaining a fracture of the left tibial plateau and severe ligament damage to the ankle. David O'Connor (EMP-00010), the Warehouse Supervisor, witnessed the fall and immediately called emergency services. Tariq was immobilized on-site and transported by ambulance to Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal. X-rays and MRI imaging confirmed the fracture, requiring surgical intervention. Tariq underwent arthroscopic repair surgery and was hospitalized for 3 days. He was unable to work for 12 weeks during recovery and rehabilitation, resulting in lost-time injury classification.

On May 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician working on the night shift, was performing routine cleaning and inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While wiping down storage shelves containing various resin catalysts and cleaning solvents, Alain accidentally knocked over a one-liter container of methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) solvent. The container cracked open, and approximately 750 ml of MEK spilled across the shelf and onto Alain's left arm and shirt. He immediately experienced skin irritation and chemical fumes inhalation. Alain quickly moved to the emergency eyewash and shower station, rinsed his arm for approximately 3 minutes, and then proceeded to the employee first aid station. The Industrial Hygienist, Nina Santos (EMP-00084), was called and assessed the exposure. Alain had localized chemical dermatitis on his forearm with mild erythema and chemical burns affecting approximately 5% of his forearm surface. He experienced mild respiratory irritation from vapor inhalation but did not require hospitalization. First aid treatment included wound cleansing, application of barrier cream, and administration of antihistamines. Alain was treated and released to return to duty the same day after decontamination and observation for 2 hours.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Injection Molding Operator Mathieu Gendron was performing routine maintenance on Molding Machine Line B in the Main Production Building when the hydraulic cooling water system experienced a catastrophic leak. While inspecting a suspected drip from the upper manifold connections, pressurized coolant sprayed directly onto the machine's electrical control panel, causing an immediate short circuit and partial system failure. The operator attempted to manually shut down the machine but the controls were unresponsive. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert responded to the alarm and used the emergency stop button to halt operations. The cooling system leak resulted in approximately 200 liters of contaminated water spreading across the production floor, creating a slip hazard and forcing immediate evacuation of the east wing. Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim was called to assess electrical damage. The machine was taken offline for 18 hours pending repairs and component replacement. Investigation revealed that the hydraulic hose connectors had not been inspected per the quarterly maintenance schedule due to a missed work order entry.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Assembly Operator Ana Silva was performing manual finishing work on composite material panels at Workstation 7 in the Assembly and Finishing Department. While handling a finished fiberglass-reinforced plastic part, her right hand contacted multiple sharp edges created by the molding process and trim operations that had not been fully deburred. The sharp edges penetrated the latex glove and lacerated her palm and three fingers, resulting in active bleeding and significant pain. Coworker Diego Morales immediately applied direct pressure with clean gauze and activated the First Aid station. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury was summoned and assessed the injury, which required professional medical evaluation. The lacerations were cleaned, bandaged, and treated with antibiotic ointment at the on-site first aid station. Ana received 5 stitches on her palm and 2 on her middle finger at the local urgent care clinic. She was cleared to return to modified duty after 3 days. Root cause investigation revealed that the part deburring process had been skipped on 47 parts due to a conveyor system jam that backed up production, causing operators to prioritize speed over safety protocols.

On March 18, 2024 at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Tool Maker René Caron was working in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop when he cut his left index finger on a sharp burr edge while manually deburring a newly manufactured injection mold cavity. The cut was approximately 8mm long and 4mm deep, causing immediate bleeding. René applied pressure with clean cloth and reported the injury to the night shift supervisor. Training Coordinator Amélie Roy arrived at 6:45 AM and assessed the wound. The bleeding was controlled using direct pressure and sterile gauze. The wound was cleaned with antiseptic solution, inspected for any embedded metal particles (none found), and covered with an adhesive bandage and antibiotic ointment. René received tetanus prophylaxis clearance verification. The injury did not require sutures or external medical attention as it was determined to be minor in nature, though close monitoring was recommended for signs of infection. René continued light duty work with modified hand positioning for the remainder of his shift. The incident was recorded in the First Aid Log as a minor laceration successfully managed through on-site first aid protocols.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) was working at Station C in the Composite Materials Processing Area when he experienced a significant chemical exposure incident. While manually mixing a batch of epoxy resin with glass fiber reinforcement, the lid of the mixing vessel was not properly secured. As Fernandez reached over the container to add colorant, the vessel tipped, spilling approximately 2 liters of uncured resin containing volatile organic compounds directly onto his right arm and upper torso. The resin, heated to approximately 60°C, caused immediate thermal and chemical burns. Fernandez immediately removed his contaminated work shirt and flushed the affected area with the emergency eyewash station for 8 minutes. Co-worker Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) witnessed the incident and alerted supervision. Due to the extent of the burns and chemical absorption concerns, Fernandez was transported via ambulance to Laval Medical Center where he was admitted for treatment of second-degree chemical burns requiring hospitalization for 5 days. The incident was caused by inadequate vessel securing procedures and lack of secondary containment. Investigation revealed the mixing area lacked proper ventilation controls and workers had not received updated chemical handling training in 18 months.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 AM during day shift operations, Shipping and Receiving Clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019) sustained a lower extremity injury while working in the Warehouse and Shipping area. Fortin was descending from the loading dock using the standard steel stairway to access ground level. As she stepped onto the third stair from the bottom, her foot caught on a compressed air hose that had been positioned across the stairway steps by maintenance personnel conducting equipment checks. The hose created a trip hazard that Fortin did not notice due to shadows and the hose color blending with the stair surface. Fortin fell forward, landing on the concrete platform below and sustaining a fractured right tibia (shin bone) and a severe ankle sprain. Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183) was nearby and immediately called for medical assistance. Fortin received emergency care on-site and was transported to the hospital where X-rays confirmed the fracture. She was prescribed a walking cast and crutches. She returned to full duty after 6 weeks, resulting in 42 work days lost. Root cause analysis identified inadequate coordination between maintenance and warehouse operations, lack of housekeeping standards for equipment placement, and absence of high-visibility markings on hoses and cables.

On May 8, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) sustained a minor eye injury while performing routine mold cleaning at Injection Molding Line B. Zaidi was using compressed air at 90 PSI to clear plastic residue from a cooling cavity when a small fragment of hardened resin became dislodged and struck his right eye. Despite wearing standard safety glasses, the trajectory and force of the particle caused corneal abrasion and mild conjunctivitis. Zaidi immediately reported to the on-site first aid station where trained first aid provider Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) provided initial treatment consisting of sterile eye irrigation, topical antibiotic ointment, and protective eye patch. Jackson documented the incident and advised Zaidi to follow up with an ophthalmologist. Zaidi was able to return to work the following morning after obtaining medical clearance. The incident was minor but highlighted inadequate compressed air handling training and use of inappropriate cleaning methods. Investigation revealed operators were not trained on proper compressed air PSI limits or required use of safety barriers when using compressed air for cleaning operations.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-016 adjacent area). While preparing a batch of colorant for the injection molding lines, Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was transferring a 20-liter container of mold release agent from storage to the mixing station. Due to improper handling and a wet floor from earlier cleaning, the container slipped from her grasp and fell approximately 1.5 meters, striking the concrete floor and rupturing. Approximately 15 liters of the solvent-based mold release agent spread across the floor, creating a slippery hazard and releasing volatile organic vapors. The spill reached within 2 meters of the electrical panel serving the adjacent production line. Leila immediately notified her supervisor, Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who initiated the spill response protocol. The area was evacuated within 5 minutes. Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), Chemical Safety Officer, arrived on scene at 14:52 and coordinated containment using absorbent material and proper disposal procedures. No personnel were exposed to hazardous levels of vapor, and the spill was fully contained within 45 minutes. Environmental impact was limited to the contained area with proper cleanup and ventilation restoration.

On March 22, 2024, during the night shift (approximately 02:15), a laceration injury occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021), Mold Technician, was operating a CNC milling machine to machine precision components for a complex automotive mold. While performing a tool change operation without fully securing the machine's protective enclosure, Stéphane's right hand contacted the rotating spindle head, causing a deep laceration across his palm and four fingers. The cut was approximately 8 centimeters in length with significant depth. Witnessing the incident, maintenance technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) immediately stopped the machine using the emergency stop button and applied direct pressure using a clean cloth. Stéphane was transported to the on-site first aid station where Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), Occupational Health Nurse, assessed the wound as requiring emergency medical attention. He was referred to Centre Hospitalier de Laval with a diagnosis of deep laceration requiring sutures and possible tendon evaluation. The root cause was identified as insufficient guarding on the CNC enclosure and lack of adherence to lockout procedures during tool changes. Stéphane was released after 6 hours of medical treatment with restricted duty for 10 days.

On March 28, 2024, at 16:42 during the evening shift, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Main Production Building affecting Lines A, B, and C. A minor electrical fault in the heating element of an injection molding machine (Machine #7, a 250-ton unit) caused arcing and smoke generation within the machine's barrel assembly. The onboard fire detection system triggered immediately, activating the building's fire suppression alarm. Production Operator Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074) was operating Machine #7 and noticed the smoke warning indicator on the control panel just prior to automatic alarm activation. The facility evacuation protocol was initiated at 16:43, with all 87 personnel on the evening shift evacuating safely to the designated assembly points within 4 minutes. David O'Connor (EMP-00010), Warehouse Supervisor and trained fire response coordinator, conducted headcount verification and confirmed all personnel accounted for. The Laval Fire Department arrived at 16:58 and confirmed the electrical fire was contained within the machine housing with no external fire spread. The machine's thermal cutoff and automatic shutdown systems functioned correctly, preventing fuel escalation. The Occupational Health Nurse confirmed no injuries or smoke inhalation symptoms among evacuees. The building was cleared for re-entry at 17:35 after mechanical ventilation cleared residual smoke.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), a Machine Setter working on Injection Molding Line B, experienced a crush injury to his right hand while attempting to clear a plastic jam from the mold cavity. Tremblay had not properly engaged the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures before reaching into the machine's closing mechanism. A coworker, Céline Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on the same line, noticed Tremblay had not emerged from maintenance and found him in pain with his hand caught between the mold halves. The machine had auto-cycled due to residual pressure in the hydraulic system. Emergency response was initiated immediately; first aid was administered on-site by HSE personnel, and Tremblay was transported to Hôpital de Laval for emergency surgery. He sustained a compound fracture to the 3rd and 4th metacarpals, crushing injuries to multiple fingers, and required 12 days hospitalization with subsequent physiotherapy. The incident was attributed to inadequate LOTO compliance, insufficient hydraulic pressure relief verification, and lack of machine interlocks to prevent accidental cycling during maintenance.

On February 8, 2024, at 9:30 PM during evening shift operations, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Warehouse and Shipping facility's packaging and labeling station (UNIT-019). The primary conveyor belt system (a 25-year-old Rexnord belt conveyor) experienced catastrophic chain rupture due to advanced metal fatigue and inadequate lubrication maintenance. The failure occurred while Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), Packaging Operator, was feeding finished composite parts into the labeling station. The conveyor suddenly seized, causing approximately 400 finished automotive components valued at $52,000 to be damaged in the backup and subsequent manual sorting process. The rupture also created sharp metal shards that struck the guide rail and bent the conveyor frame, requiring complete replacement of the drive motor assembly ($38,000) and the entire conveyor belt section ($67,500). An estimated 18 hours of downtime ensued, halting all shipping operations. Root cause analysis revealed the equipment had not received scheduled bearing lubrication since November 2023 (3-month overdue), preventive maintenance logs were incomplete, and no condition monitoring (vibration analysis or thermal imaging) had been performed. The failure compromised the facility's ability to meet customer deadlines for two major automotive contracts.

On March 22, 2024, at 11:15 AM during day shift operations, Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142), Receiving Coordinator, sustained a significant laceration and eye injury while unloading raw materials in the Warehouse and Shipping facility. While using a utility knife to open a cardboard box containing glass-fiber reinforced polypropylene pellets, the blade slipped and struck her left eye area, causing a 3-centimeter laceration along the orbital ridge and corneal abrasion. Simultaneously, glass fiber fragments from the damaged packaging dispersed into the air, with several fibers becoming embedded in the laceration wound and visible conjunctiva. A nearby coworker, Miriam Cohen (EMP-00132), Supply Chain Analyst, immediately provided first aid with sterile gauze and directed Belkacem to the medical clinic. She was transported to Hôpital Cité-de-la-Santé for ophthalmologic evaluation and wound closure requiring 6 stitches. The eye injury resulted in temporary vision impairment for 8 days and required follow-up appointments to rule out retained glass fiber fragments. Root cause investigation identified: utility knife had a dull blade with insufficient safety guard, employee had not received recent training on safe box-opening techniques, and no eye protection was being worn despite the presence of glass fiber materials in the work area.

On November 12, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was monitoring Injection Molding Line B (UNIT-002) when he noticed unusual vibration and a grinding noise from the cooling water circulation pump. The pump, installed two years ago, had been operating continuously without scheduled maintenance for the past 18 months due to production demands overriding preventive maintenance scheduling. Hassan reported the noise to the Line Supervisor, but production was not stopped because a high-priority automotive client order was running behind schedule. Approximately 15 minutes later, the pump bearing seized completely, causing the pump shaft to lock. This sudden mechanical failure sent a pressure surge through the cooling water system, rupturing a corroded section of copper tubing connected to the injection molding head. Cooling water sprayed across the hot molding dies and Hassan's work station. Hassan sustained thermal discomfort from water spray but no serious burns due to quick response. The spilled cooling water mixed with residual plastic material created a slippery hazard. Line B was shut down for 6 hours requiring bearing and tubing replacement. Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) was called to assess the damage.

On November 10, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Assembly Lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) was assembling medical-grade composite components at her workstation in the Assembly area when she reached across a work table to retrieve a small plastic fitting from a lower shelf. While extending her arm at an awkward angle, she felt a sharp pain in her right wrist. She had been performing the same repetitive assembly motions for 6 hours without a break, and the ergonomic station had not been adjusted to her height despite her previous complaints to HR. Tatiana continued working through the pain for another 2 hours before noticing significant swelling in her wrist and reduced grip strength. She reported the injury to HR Generalist Noor Ahmed (EMP-00076) at 11:00 AM. Tatiana was examined by the company medical team and diagnosed with acute tendinitis and suspected early carpal tunnel syndrome. She was placed on modified duty restrictions for one week and given anti-inflammatory treatment. The incident revealed that Tatiana's workstation had never received a formal ergonomic assessment despite her tenure of 4 years in the role and her earlier verbal complaints documented in an HR email from March 2024.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) was working at a manual assembly station in the Finished Goods Warehouse when she reached across a pallet of finished composite parts to retrieve a completed product. Her left hand made contact with a sharp, unfinished edge on a polycarbonate component that had not been properly deburred during post-processing. The sharp edge caused a 2-inch laceration on the palm of her hand, resulting in moderate bleeding. A coworker, Shipping and Receiving Clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019), immediately provided first aid by applying pressure with gauze and notifying the HSE team. Elena received treatment in the facility's first aid station, including wound cleaning, topical antibiotic application, and bandaging. The wound required 5 stitches but did not necessitate external hospitalization. Root cause analysis determined that quality control inspection procedures had not caught the improperly deburred part before it reached the warehouse staging area.

On April 2, 2025, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053) was performing routine cleaning of an injection molding machine on Line A when he inadvertently bumped the machine's emergency stop button while repositioning his work platform. The machine's heated barrel, which operates at 240°C, had not completely cooled. As Benoit attempted to restart the machine to verify it was functioning, residual heat and internal pressure caused a small amount of molten plastic material to be expelled through an access port. The material contacted his right forearm, causing a first and second-degree thermal burn across approximately 4 inches of skin. Process Improvement Engineer Yuki Yamamoto (EMP-00112), working nearby, immediately applied cold water to the affected area and notified HSE personnel. The burn was treated with topical cooling gel, wrapped in sterile gauze, and tetanus status was updated. Benoit did not require hospitalization but was restricted from hands-on production duties for 5 days pending wound healing evaluation. The incident was attributed to inadequate knowledge of proper machine shutdown and cooldown procedures.

On April 18, 2025, at approximately 1:15 AM during the night shift, Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) discovered smoke and a burning smell emanating from the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Upon investigation with night shift Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160), he identified an electrical fault in the heating system of a 55-gallon drum containing thermoplastic elastomer (TPE) resin mixed with colorant that had self-ignited, creating a small localized fire on the floor beneath the drum. The fire had begun to spread to adjacent flammable materials including boxes of polypropylene resin stored nearby. Normand immediately activated the facility's fire alarm (pull station 07 in Chemical Storage Building), evacuated all personnel to the assembly point, and retrieved a Class C dry powder fire extinguisher from the wall-mounted cabinet. He made two controlled applications of the extinguisher, successfully suppressing the flames before they spread beyond a 3-foot diameter. Emergency responders from Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. No employees were injured. The incident was declared as a fire alarm event and environmental hazard due to potential chemical release and smoke containment concerns.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during the day shift, machine setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was operating Injection Molding Line A when he noticed the mold wasn't ejecting parts properly. While attempting to clear a suspected jam near the mold closing mechanism without properly engaging the lockout/tagout procedure, the mold suddenly cycled. Karim's left hand was caught between the mold halves, suffering a crush injury to his palm and two fingers. Co-worker Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) was notified and called emergency services. Karim was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé with significant swelling, lacerations, and suspected fractures. He remained hospitalized for 48 hours and required surgery for tendon repair, resulting in 6 weeks of lost time from work.

On April 3, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift, quality auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) was conducting a routine inspection in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility when she discovered a small chemical splash incident. While transferring a batch of mold release agent (silicone-based, solvent-containing product) from a bulk container to a smaller mixing vessel, a fellow worker accidentally bumped the transfer line, causing approximately 50 mL of the chemical to splash onto Indira's left forearm and neck area. Indira immediately rinsed the affected area with water from the eyewash station for approximately 3 minutes. The chemical caused mild skin irritation with localized redness and slight burning sensation but no blister formation. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) was notified and reviewed the incident. Indira was sent to the on-site first aid station where the injury was cleaned, documented, and treated with anti-irritant cream and a protective dressing. She continued working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift with no lost time. The incident revealed inadequate secondary containment around the transfer station and lack of proper spill prevention barriers.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 on the day shift, assembly operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station in the Warehouse and Shipping prep area. She was manually loading finished composite parts into cardboard boxes for shipment to a medical device client. While lifting a box containing approximately 18 kg of molded components, she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. The box had awkward dimensions (60cm × 40cm × 25cm) making it difficult to maintain proper lifting posture. Elena set the box down and reported immediate lower back discomfort. She was unable to continue working and was sent to the on-site medical clinic where an initial assessment indicated possible lumbar strain. The incident was witnessed by packaging supervisor Patricia Martin (EMP-00035), who helped Elena to a chair and contacted HSE. Medical imaging later revealed a mild disc bulge at L4-L5. Elena missed 3 days of work and required physiotherapy. The root cause was identified as inadequate training on proper lifting techniques for awkwardly-sized loads and lack of mechanical lifting assistance at the packaging station.

On February 8, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, electrical maintenance lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was conducting routine inspections in the Central Maintenance Workshop when he discovered that one of three primary hydraulic pump motors driving the automated material handling system had failed. The motor, a 15 kW unit installed in 2019, showed signs of bearing seizure and emitted a grinding noise. Upon closer inspection, Claude found that the preventive maintenance schedule had not been followed for this unit for the past 18 months due to staffing shortages and prioritization of other equipment. The motor's lubrication system had degraded, causing internal friction and eventual bearing failure. The equipment was immediately de-energized and tagged out. Maintenance technician Viktor Novak (EMP-00116) assisted in the assessment. The failure caused a 4-hour production delay the following morning until a replacement motor could be sourced and installed. The material handling system operated at reduced capacity at 67% efficiency using the two remaining pumps. This incident highlighted gaps in the preventive maintenance program and the absence of automated monitoring systems.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:30 during the day shift, injection molding operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) was working at Line A in the Main Production Building. He was removing cured plastic parts from a mold cavity when he noticed the machine's automated ejection system had partially malfunctioned, leaving one component stuck in the mold. Following standard procedure, François initiated the manual part removal sequence and pressed the emergency stop button to halt the machine cycle. However, due to a known but unaddressed software glitch in the controller (documented in maintenance logs since January 2024), the hydraulic pressure in the mold clamp did not fully release. When François opened the mold gate to attempt removal, he felt a sudden pressure release that nearly caused the mold to close on his hand. He quickly withdrew his hand, experiencing only a minor pinch on his left thumb but narrowly avoiding a serious crush injury. Coworker Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181) was nearby and witnessed the near-miss event. The machine was immediately de-energized and locked out. Investigation revealed the software glitch had been flagged but deprioritized in the maintenance backlog for 7 weeks.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 9:45 AM, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a burn injury while removing molded parts from the machine. Sofia was extracting medical-grade polycarbonate components from the injection molding machine when hot plastic material (~280°C) dripped onto her right forearm. She had been working without adequate insulation gloves, relying instead on standard cotton work gloves that provided insufficient thermal protection. The incident occurred because the automatic part ejector malfunctioned, requiring manual removal. Sofia immediately immersed her arm in cool water and reported to first aid. A coworker, Petra Mueller (EMP-00166), witnessed the incident and assisted in getting Sofia to the first aid station. The burn covered approximately 4 cm² of her forearm with superficial redness and mild blistering. First aid treatment included cooling, sterile dressing application, and pain management. Sofia returned to light duties after 2 hours but continued monitoring the wound throughout the shift.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:20 PM during the evening shift, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, experienced a hand laceration while assembling components in the post-processing area. Ahmed was manually assembling medical device parts that had sharp flash edges from the molding process. Despite wearing standard nitrile gloves, a sharp edge on a polycarbonate component cut through the glove and his left index finger, creating a 1.5 cm laceration on the side of the finger. Ahmed did not immediately report the injury, continuing work for approximately 15 minutes before Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), the Assembly Line Lead, noticed blood on the work surface and required him to seek first aid. The cut was cleaned, bandaged with sterile gauze, and monitored. No stitches were required, but the wound remained tender. The root cause was identified as inadequate hand protection and lack of awareness about the sharp edge hazard on freshly molded parts. Ahmed returned to modified duties for the remainder of the shift.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 2:15 AM during the night shift, a propane-powered forklift operated by Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) struck and damaged three storage racks in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Raymond was moving a pallet of pre-dried polypropylene resin when the forklift's hydraulic steering system partially failed, causing loss of directional control. The vehicle veered left, colliding with three metal storage racks containing approximately 2,400 kg of thermoplastic elastomer (TPE) raw material. Two racks were bent and one was overturned, scattering material across the floor. The estimated inventory loss was approximately 850 kg of material ($12,400 value). No personnel were in the immediate impact zone, preventing injury. Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), the Evening Shift Machine Operator assigned to monitor material preparation, was present and immediately evacuated the area and called for assistance. Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), the Environmental Compliance Specialist on emergency call, coordinated cleanup and damage assessment. The incident was contained within 45 minutes with no environmental release.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic failure occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). An employee, Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), was operating the automated material handling system to transfer pre-dried plastic pellets from a large hopper to injection molding machines when the conveyor belt drive motor suddenly seized. The mechanical shock caused the entire conveyor frame to shift laterally, striking an adjacent high-pressure air distribution manifold. The impact ruptured three compressed air lines, sending a shower of sharp metal fragments and plastic pellets across the workspace. The conveyor frame sustained approximately $87,000 in structural damage, the manifold required complete replacement ($12,500), and two adjacent workstations were damaged by flying debris. The incident was immediately reported by Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead, who responded to the emergency shutdown call. Emergency services were notified as a precaution, though no injuries occurred. Investigation revealed that routine preventive maintenance on the motor drive system had been deferred by six weeks due to production scheduling pressure.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a Machine Operator on Injection Molding Line D, sustained a serious thermal burn while performing routine mold changeout procedures. The employee was removing a cured plastic part from a high-temperature injection molding machine (operating at 280°C) when the protective insulation on the mold release mechanism failed. Hot plastic material (approximately 260°C) made direct contact with his right forearm and hand. The employee immediately contacted his supervisor, Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), who activated the emergency eyewash station and applied first aid while summoning emergency response. The employee was transported by ambulance to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur in Montreal, where he was diagnosed with second and third-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his right arm. He remained hospitalized for four days for wound care and pain management. Investigation revealed that the insulation material had degraded due to inadequate heat resistance specifications and had not been inspected during the previous maintenance cycle. An incident investigation was formally documented by Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123), the Incident Investigation Specialist.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 3:20 AM during the night shift, a critical fire incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a Production Operator, was monitoring the material recycling process when she noticed unusual smoke emanating from the plastic scrap accumulation bin. The bin, which collects post-production plastic waste for grinding and reuse, had developed an internal thermal hotspot due to inadequate ventilation and the accumulation of incompatible thermoplastic materials that generated excessive friction heat during the grinding process. The temperature reached critical levels, causing spontaneous ignition of accumulated plastic dust and volatile organic compounds released during material breakdown. A small flame appeared at the bin opening at 3:22 AM. Naomi immediately activated the facility fire alarm, evacuated the area, and used a dry powder fire extinguisher to contain the initial flames before the automatic suppression system activated. The fire department arrived at 3:41 AM and confirmed full containment. The incident resulted in approximately $34,000 in damage to the recycling equipment, destruction of $15,000 worth of feedstock material, and facility closure for 18 hours for safety inspection and air quality monitoring. André Bellavance (EMP-00157), the Confined Space Entry Supervisor, coordinated emergency procedures and formally declared the incident after fire department clearance.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:22 hours, Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030), a Machine Setter on the day shift, was performing routine setup adjustments on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building (South Zone, UNIT-004). While calibrating the hopper feed system, the electronic control module for the automatic material feeder malfunctioned, causing the hopper to continuously dispense plastic pellets without stopping. The overflow material spilled across the production floor at a rate of approximately 50 kg per minute. Karim immediately attempted to manually shut down the system using the emergency stop button, but the button was unresponsive due to a known wiring issue that had been reported 6 weeks prior but not addressed. The material spill created a 2-meter diameter pile of plastic pellets, creating a significant slip hazard. Coworker Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171) slipped on the accumulated pellets while attempting to help contain the spill, causing him to fall and sustain a minor ankle strain. The incident was contained after 12 minutes when Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), an Automation Technician, manually disconnected the hopper power supply at the main electrical panel. Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), Chemical Safety Officer, was notified and declared the incident.

On March 22, 2024, at 09:18 hours, Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160), a Production Operator on the evening shift assigned to Post-Processing and Heat Treatment (UNIT-017), sustained a thermal burn to her right forearm while transferring finished plastic components from the cooling station. The components, molded from high-temperature composite material, were being removed from the post-processing oven that maintains an operating temperature of 185°C. Although the facility requires heat-resistant gloves (nitrile-lined cotton) for this task, Zainab was wearing only standard cotton work gloves that had become damp from perspiration during the shift. The dampness reduced the insulating properties of the gloves significantly. As she lifted a batch of components using tongs, one component shifted and made direct contact with her right forearm just above the wrist, causing a second-degree thermal burn approximately 8 cm in length. Zainab immediately notified her supervisor, Deepa Gupta (EMP-00080), Process Quality Engineer, who provided first aid using the facility's first aid kit and cold water irrigation. Emergency medical services were called and Zainab was transported to the hospital for treatment. The burn required 14 stitches and resulted in a 5-day lost-time injury. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), Safety Trainer, investigated the incident the following day.

On March 28, 2024, at 22:47 hours, a fire incident was declared in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) during the night shift. Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate, was conducting inventory checks of solvent containers when he noticed an unusual odor and faint smoke near the northeast storage rack. Investigation revealed that a 55-gallon drum of flammable resin solvent (acetone-based, flash point -9°C) had developed a pinhole leak from corrosion of the drum wall. The solvent had been pooling beneath the rack for an estimated 4-6 hours, accumulating approximately 8 liters on the concrete floor. Dust accumulation from composite fiber manufacturing operations in adjacent areas, combined with the solvent vapors, had created a highly flammable atmosphere in the enclosed space. At 22:49 hours, an unknown ignition source (likely from static electricity during the movement of nearby metal equipment) ignited the vapor-solvent mixture, resulting in a flash fire. The fire spread rapidly across the solvent pool and up the storage rack, reaching the overhead pipe rack before facility sprinklers activated at 22:51 hours. The automatic fire suppression system successfully contained the fire within 3 minutes, but not before two secondary drums on the rack were compromised by heat, releasing additional solvent vapors. Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), Electrical Maintenance Lead, immediately activated the facility emergency evacuation alarm and assisted in evacuating all night shift personnel (approximately 18 workers). The local fire department arrived at 23:08 hours and confirmed the fire was completely extinguished by 23:14 hours. Damage assessment revealed approximately $48,000 in property damage including the original leaking drum, two secondary drums, storage rack damage, and thermal damage to overhead piping. The facility was evacuated for 6 hours during fire department investigation and ventilation procedures. No injuries occurred, but the incident prompted immediate facility-wide closure and comprehensive safety review. Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) declared the incident as part of the emergency response team.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, suffered a thermal burn while performing routine mold cleaning. The incident occurred in the Main Production Building when Youssef attempted to clear a partially solidified resin blockage from the mold cavity using a metal tool without allowing sufficient cooling time. The mold was maintained at 85°C for optimal production parameters. As he inserted the tool into the cavity, contact with the hot plastic material caused immediate skin contact on his right palm and inner wrist. The burn area covered approximately 8 square centimeters with visible blistering and redness. A first-aid responder applied cool water for 15 minutes and dressed the wound with sterile gauze. The employee remained at work and continued duties with modified responsibilities for the remainder of the shift. Medical assessment indicated a Grade 2 thermal burn requiring topical treatment and monitoring for infection.

On November 21, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a Material Handler, was performing routine inventory organization in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop mezzanine level when she noticed a deteriorated electrical cable creating a potential hazard. The cable, approximately 20 feet in length, was supplying power to a pneumatic compressor and showed visible insulation damage and multiple areas of exposed copper wiring along its length. The damage appeared to have developed gradually from abrasion against sharp metal shelving edges. Before any work was performed with this equipment, Marwa immediately ceased operations and reported the condition to her supervisor. The area was secured with caution tape, and electrical power to the circuit was isolated using the main disconnect switch. No personnel contacted the damaged cable. The equipment was tagged out of service pending electrical inspection and repair. This hazard was identified during a routine floor inspection and prevented potential electrocution or arc flash incidents.

On November 8, 2024, at 3:30 AM during the night shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a significant laceration and contusion to his left forearm when attempting to retrieve a dropped mold component from beneath the machine base. While performing routine shut-down procedures, a high-pressure hydraulic fitting connection broke free from the injection molding press, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid and causing the connected mold guide plate to shift unexpectedly. Bruno reached beneath the machine to recover the fallen component without properly isolating the hydraulic system or verifying system pressure was relieved. His forearm made contact with the pressurized system release point, resulting in a deep laceration approximately 4 inches in length on the inner forearm with minor bleeding. Immediate first-aid response included wound irrigation, pressure dressing application, and antibiotic ointment. The employee was transported to the local clinic where 6 stitches were applied. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury with 3 days absence from work. Root cause investigation identified inadequate LOTO procedure compliance and insufficient maintenance records on the hydraulic fitting.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire alarm was accidentally triggered in the Main Production Building. Employee Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a machine operator on the evening shift who was present for cross-training, was performing routine maintenance on the ventilation system near Injection Molding Line C when she inadvertently bumped a manual fire alarm pull station mounted on a support column. The alarm activated the facility-wide fire suppression system, causing all four zone sprinkler systems to discharge. The unexpected activation resulted in approximately 8,000 gallons of water flooding the clean room area and adjacent equipment zones. Production operations were immediately halted, and all 47 personnel present evacuated safely within 3 minutes following established protocols. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette coordinated the response, confirmed no injuries, and initiated damage assessment. The incident caused significant water damage to sensitive injection molding equipment, quality control instruments, and finished medical device components valued at approximately $240,000. The fire alarm pull station lacked proper protective guarding, and its placement in a high-traffic work area contributed to the accidental activation.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Employee Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an injection molding technician, was transferring a 20-liter container of mold release agent (silicone-based, flammable liquid classified as Category 3 irritant) from storage shelving to a mixing station when the container's cap was not properly sealed. While moving the container across the room, approximately 12 liters of mold release agent spilled onto the concrete floor, spreading across an area of approximately 40 square meters. The spill created a significant fire hazard, generated strong chemical vapors, and posed skin contact and inhalation risks. Immediate action included evacuation of the facility, deployment of dry chemical absorbent materials, and containment measures. The incident was declared by Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), who coordinated with emergency responders. Environmental cleanup required specialized hazardous waste disposal contractors and took 6 hours to complete. Root causes included improper container cap sealing during the previous shift's storage procedure and lack of secondary containment systems in the mixing area. The spill resulted in approximately $18,000 in cleanup costs and temporary closure of the chemical handling facility.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 4:20 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident was reported in the Shipping and Receiving Dock area. Employee Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a forklift operator, was transporting a pallet stack of finished medical device housings (approximately 2,800 kg total load) toward the shipping staging area when he observed the load beginning to shift on the pallet. The stack was improperly secured with inadequate strapping, and movement during acceleration had caused the load to lean approximately 15 degrees from vertical. Aziz immediately reduced speed, stopped the forklift in an open area away from personnel, and carefully lowered the load to the ground. Shipping Clerk Julien Racine (EMP-00177) witnessed the incident and assisted in securing the load properly. The near-miss was reported by Aziz to Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), who documented the incident. Investigation revealed that the packaging supervisor Patricia Martin (EMP-00035) had not followed standard load securing procedures during pallet preparation, resulting in insufficient restraint strapping. Had the forklift accelerated further or the load shifted during transport through occupied work areas, the falling stack could have caused serious injuries or fatalities to personnel. No injuries occurred due to Aziz's quick recognition and response. This incident highlighted critical gaps in load securing procedures and the importance of operator situational awareness.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103) was performing routine maintenance on Line A in the Injection Molding Line A - Automotive unit. While cleaning the hopper area with compressed air to remove residual polypropylene resin, an air hose became dislodged from its coupling. The pressurized hose whipped across the work area, narrowly missing Demers' face by approximately 6 inches. The hose struck a nearby quality control station, causing minor damage to a measurement device. Demers immediately stepped back and alerted his supervisor. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed that the air hose coupling lacked a proper retaining clip and that the hose routing created a trip hazard across the main production pathway. This near-miss was classified as critical due to the proximity to facial/head impact, which could have resulted in serious injury. The incident was immediately reported to Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson, who documented the event and initiated a facility walkthrough to identify similar hazards.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was transferring finished composite parts from a cooling rack to cardboard shipping boxes in the Assembly and Finishing Department. As she reached for parts from an upper shelf approximately 5 feet high, the metal cooling rack shifted unexpectedly, causing several assembled parts to slide toward her. De Luca quickly moved backward to avoid being struck, and the parts fell safely to the floor without hitting her. However, several parts sustained minor cosmetic damage. The incident was witnessed by Injection Molding Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), who was working nearby. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the cooling rack had not been properly secured to the floor per standard procedures, and the locking casters were missing from two wheels. The rack had been moved during shift changeover without proper securing. While no injury occurred, the potential for serious impact injuries to the head, chest, or extremities was significant. The incident was reported immediately to Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid, who conducted an incident assessment and noted that this represented a critical near-miss situation.

On December 10, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Injection Molding Technician Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181) was performing mold changeover operations on Injection Molding Line B. While attempting to loosen a thermal coupling on a high-temperature mold assembly, Bisson did not properly lock out and tag out (LOTO) the machine as required by company procedure. The machine unexpectedly cycled due to a timer malfunction, causing the coupling to rotate rapidly. Bisson's right hand was caught between the rotating coupling and a fixed bracket, resulting in a crush injury to his hand with visible contusions and significant swelling. His ring finger and middle finger sustained lacerations requiring 12 stitches. Bisson immediately withdrew his hand and alerted coworkers. He was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital emergency department where he received wound treatment and was placed on pain management. X-rays confirmed no fractures but revealed significant soft tissue damage. Due to the severity of injuries and the need for wound care follow-up, Bisson was placed on modified duty for 2 weeks and lost 5 working days. The incident was reported by Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi, who arrived on scene within minutes. Root cause analysis identified that Bisson had bypassed LOTO procedures due to perceived time pressure to meet production quotas. Additionally, the machine's auto-cycle timer had experienced a known intermittent fault that maintenance had failed to repair despite previous reports.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), an Assembly Operator, sustained a minor laceration to her left index finger while performing quality control assembly work at the composite materials processing station in UNIT-015. While manually assembling fiber-reinforced plastic components, Isabella reached to reposition a partially cured composite panel. A sharp edge protruding from the panel's trimmed surface caught her gloved finger, creating a small but bleeding laceration. The wound was approximately 1.5 cm long and required immediate first aid. Her supervisor, Diego Morales (EMP-00056), who was working nearby, immediately applied direct pressure and escorted Isabella to the on-site first aid station where Karine Cloutier, Safety Trainer, administered wound cleaning, applied antibiotic ointment, and dressed the laceration with sterile gauze and medical tape. No sutures were required. The incident was treated with first aid only and Isabella returned to modified duties after 30 minutes of observation. Root cause analysis indicated that the composite panel's edge had not been properly deburred during the finishing process, creating an unexpected sharp hazard.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) and identified a significant ventilation deficiency. While performing air quality checks using calibrated monitoring equipment, Zahra observed that the overhead ventilation system was operating at only 65% of its designed airflow capacity. The inspection revealed that multiple air intake filters had not been replaced according to the facility's preventive maintenance schedule, resulting in severe clogging. This reduction in ventilation posed a direct risk to chemical mixing operators, as the facility regularly processes volatile resin compounds that require continuous evacuation. The chemical mixing area is designed for safe exposure to vapors only when ventilation operates at full capacity. Zahra immediately documented the hazard, shut down non-essential mixing operations, and escalated the finding to the Maintenance department and HSE leadership. The situation was declared as a preventive declaration to trigger corrective action before any actual employee exposure incident occurred. No employees exhibited symptoms of chemical inhalation exposure at the time of detection.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 1:15 AM during the night shift, James Thompson (EMP-00029), an Injection Molding Operator assigned to Line D, sustained a significant burn injury to his right forearm and hand. James was performing routine maintenance cleaning of an injection molding machine (a 250-ton press) that was supposed to have been powered down and cooled following the evening shift. According to witness statement from Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), also an operator on Line D, James did not follow proper lockout/tagout procedures before beginning his cleaning work. The machine's heating barrel was still at approximately 180°C (356°F) despite being visually "turned off." When James reached into the mold cavity area to remove accumulated plastic residue, his forearm made direct contact with the heated barrel surface. He sustained partial-thickness thermal burns covering approximately 8 cm² of his right forearm and 12 cm² of his right hand. James immediately withdrew from the equipment and ran cold water over the burned area. The night shift supervisor called emergency medical services. James was transported to the regional burn center for advanced wound care and received treatment for second-degree burns requiring hospitalization for three days. Investigation determined that the LOTO procedures were not properly documented or verified before he began work, and that James had not received recent refresher training on LOTO requirements for his equipment assignments.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Fernand Comeau, a Regrind Operator, was transferring a 25-liter container of acetone-based mold release agent from storage to the mixing station when the container's lid dislodged due to improper sealing. Approximately 18 liters of solvent spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous pool that immediately began to evaporate, releasing significant fumes throughout the work area. The spill occurred near the ventilation intake, and several production staff reported eye irritation and respiratory discomfort within minutes. Emergency response was initiated by Simon Bélanger, Chemical Safety Officer, who implemented immediate containment procedures using absorbent material and activated the secondary ventilation system. No employees required medical attention, but the area was evacuated for 45 minutes while the spill was cleaned and ventilation was restored. The incident revealed that the chemical storage container's seal had degraded over time, and staff had not been following proper lid inspection protocols before transfer.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 AM during the day shift, Aaliyah Jackson, an Assembly Operator working in the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006), sustained a minor laceration to her left index finger while inspecting a composite part with sharp edge burrs. The part, a fiber-reinforced plastic automotive component fresh from the molding line, had not been properly deburred before quality inspection. Jackson was running her finger along the edge to check for surface uniformity when a 3mm burr penetrated the skin, causing a small but bleeding wound. The injury was immediately treated by Léa Parent, a Quality Control Technician and first aid responder, who applied direct pressure, cleaned the wound with antiseptic, and applied a sterile bandage with antibiotic ointment. Jackson continued working after first aid treatment. The incident was attributed to inconsistent finishing procedures on Line A and lack of edge inspection protocols before parts reach quality control. No hospitalization was required, and the wound was fully healed within 5 days.

On November 22, 2024, at 11:30 PM during the night shift, Kwame Mensah, a Production Operator on the night shift, sustained a significant burn injury to his right forearm while performing maintenance on an injection molding machine on Line A. Mensah was attempting to clear a plastic blockage from the hopper assembly when his sleeve caught on the heated barrel component operating at 240°C (464°F). The contact lasted approximately 2-3 seconds before he pulled away, resulting in a partial-thickness thermal burn approximately 8cm x 6cm on his forearm. Despite immediate cooling with cold water and application of sterile dressings, the severity of the burn necessitated transportation to the emergency department by Sanaa Rachidi, Fire Safety Coordinator. Mensah received medical treatment for the burn and was instructed to stay home for 10 days for wound care and healing. Investigation revealed that the machine's thermal guard had been removed three weeks prior during a maintenance cycle and never reinstalled. Additionally, Mensah was not wearing the required high-temperature-resistant sleeve that should have been part of his PPE for this task. Lost time totaled 240 hours over the healing period.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:30 during day shift, Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin from storage to the Chemical Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While positioning the drum on the elevated mixing platform using a drum dolly, the drum's bung plug became partially dislodged due to improper threading during the previous shift's storage. As Mariam tilted the drum to secure it in the mixing station's clamp, approximately 12 gallons of uncatalyzed polyester resin spilled onto the floor, work surfaces, and partially onto Mariam's left arm and torso. The spill created a slippery hazard covering approximately 200 square feet. Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) was nearby and immediately assisted with containment using absorbent pads. The spill was contained within 8 minutes. Mariam experienced minor skin irritation from resin contact. Root cause investigation revealed: (1) drum bung was cross-threaded during previous shift due to lack of inspection protocol, (2) spill kit location was 40 feet away, requiring excessive response time, and (3) secondary containment tray was not in use, allowing spill to spread across floor.

On April 2, 2024 at 22:15 during evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053) was performing routine hot-mold cleaning on Injection Molding Line C (UNIT-003, Medical Components production). While wiping the interior cavity of a 300-ton injection mold with a solvent-saturated cloth, residual pressure in the mold system was not fully relieved despite following standard lockout procedures. The mold closed unexpectedly during the cleaning cycle, trapping Benoit's right hand between the upper and lower cavity plates. Benoit sustained a crushing injury to his right palm and index/middle fingers. Immediate response: Production Supervisor Anika Johansson (EMP-00144) activated the emergency mold opening mechanism, releasing Benoit's hand within 45 seconds. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided immediate first aid including ice application and bandaging. Benoit was transported to nearby Hôpital Sacré-Cœur with suspected fractures and soft tissue damage. Medical evaluation confirmed two metacarpal fractures and crush syndrome requiring 72-hour observation. Root cause: nitrogen accumulator pressure gauge was not functioning (last calibrated 18 months prior), creating false indication of pressure relief. Operator followed procedures but received false confirmation of safe lockout state.

On May 8, 2024 at 06:45 during night shift, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was preparing to load composite mold blanks into the CNC milling machine in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). While positioning a 40-pound aluminum mold blank on the workbench, the blank began to slide off due to insufficient edge clearance. Dimitri instinctively reached to catch the falling blank, extending his right arm directly into the path of the CNC spindle head which was programmed to begin an automatic cycle in 8 seconds. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), who was performing preventive maintenance on adjacent equipment, immediately noticed Dimitri's positioning and activated the emergency stop button, halting the spindle 3 seconds before it would have contacted Dimitri's arm. No physical contact occurred. Immediate response: Claude helped Dimitri step back to safe distance and documented the near-miss incident. Dimitri showed no signs of injury. Root cause analysis identified: (1) inadequate workbench setup with sloped surface allowing parts to roll, (2) CNC machine spindle safety interlock was non-functional (disabled during maintenance 2 weeks prior but not re-enabled), (3) operator was focused on part positioning rather than spindle status awareness, and (4) supervisor did not verify re-enablement of safety interlock after maintenance completion.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line A in the Main Production Building when a catastrophic failure occurred. While attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper using a wooden rod, the LOTO procedure was not properly followed—the machine had been tagged but not fully de-energized. When Pascal reached into the hopper area, the injection screw suddenly activated due to residual pressure, catching his right hand and pulling it into the compression chamber. His hand sustained severe crush injuries to multiple fingers and the palm, with lacerations and partial tissue loss.
