Coworkers immediately activated the emergency stop, and first responder Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) administered initial first aid while emergency services were called. Pascal was transported via ambulance to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé and admitted for emergency surgery. He required 47 days away from work for wound care, grafting procedures, and physical rehabilitation.

On April 2, 2024, at 8:15 AM during the day shift, Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), a Material Handler working in the Finished Goods Warehouse, noticed an accumulation of moisture and visible mold growth on several pallets of finished composite parts stored in Section B. The parts are destined for medical device manufacturers under ISO 13485 compliance. While inspecting the pallets, Marwa observed that the environmental monitoring system was malfunctioning and warehouse humidity levels had risen to 78% (beyond the specified 45-55% range for medical device components). She immediately halted further material movement in that section and documented the contamination risk. Upon investigation by Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104), it was confirmed that approximately 240 units of finished medical device housings had been compromised by mold contamination. The warehouse's HVAC dehumidification system had failed three days prior but was not reported due to shift handover communication breakdown. This discovery prevented shipment of non-compliant product and potential regulatory action from customers.

On May 8, 2024, at 4:20 PM during the evening shift, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, was moving pallets of raw plastic resin from the Warehouse receiving dock toward the Material Drying and Preparation Room. While navigating a turn in the narrow corridor between the Warehouse and Production Building (approximately 3.5 meters wide), Tariq misjudged the clearance distance on the left side of the forklift. The lift's load backrest made contact with an unsecured metal utility cart positioned against the wall, causing the cart to shift. The impact dislodged a stack of three storage racks mounted on the cart, which fell from approximately 1.8 meters height. The falling racks passed within 30 centimeters of Tariq's position, landing on the floor directly behind the forklift. Marwa Saleh (EMP-00194), who was standing nearby preparing materials for drying, immediately retreated to safety. No one was struck, but had Tariq not completed his turn motion, the racks would have struck the side of the forklift cabin. Tariq immediately reported the incident to shift supervisor Roland Dostie (EMP-00199), recognizing the serious near-miss potential.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a minor thermal burn to his right forearm while performing routine mold cavity inspection. While checking the temperature consistency of mold surfaces on the automotive component injection line, Conrad inadvertently made contact with an exposed hot mold surface that was cooling following a production cycle. The surface temperature was approximately 85°C. Conrad immediately reported the incident to his supervisor, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), who was working nearby. The burn area, approximately 3cm x 2cm, presented with mild erythema and minor blistering. First aid was administered on-site by the trained first aid responders in the production area. The injury was treated with cool water irrigation, antibiotic ointment application, and a sterile dressing. Conrad remained on modified duty for the remainder of the shift, focusing on documentation tasks rather than direct equipment operation. The incident was triggered by inadequate awareness of mold surface temperatures and insufficient thermal barriers in the work area.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, sustained a significant crush injury to his left hand while managing material loads in the warehouse and packaging area. Kwesi was attempting to reposition a skid of raw polycarbonate pellets using a manual pallet jack when the load suddenly shifted. The pallet jack handle disengaged from the load, causing approximately 600 kg of compressed material to fall forward. Kwesi's left hand and forearm were caught between the falling skid and a stationary support column. The incident resulted in a compound fracture of the 4th and 5th metacarpals, severe tissue contusion, and minor lacerations. Emergency services were called at 10:47 PM. Kwesi was transported to Laval Hospital emergency department where he underwent surgical intervention to stabilize the fractures. He was hospitalized for 3 days for pain management and post-operative monitoring. Initial investigation revealed the pallet jack's safety latch was not fully engaged, and the material stacking height exceeded recommended limits by approximately 30 cm. This was a lost-time incident resulting in 14 days off work during initial recovery phase.

On January 8, 2025, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator, sustained a laceration and partial finger injury when his gloved right hand contacted an improperly guarded press platen during routine mold positioning. Bernard was adjusting a composite material mold in preparation for the morning production run when the hydraulic press control malfunctioned, causing unexpected partial actuation. The press platen descended approximately 3 cm onto Bernard's hand, which was still within the danger zone. Despite wearing heavy-duty work gloves, the pressure caused the glove material to compress into the pinch point, resulting in laceration of the right index and middle fingers. Bernard immediately activated the emergency stop button with his left hand. Plant maintenance supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) and the night shift supervisor responded within 2 minutes. Bernard received immediate first aid on-site: wound irrigation, antiseptic application, and careful monitoring for deeper tissue damage. Medical evaluation determined the injuries required 4 stitches to the index finger and 3 stitches to the middle finger, with no fractures or permanent damage anticipated. Bernard remained off work for 5 days during initial healing and suture management, requiring twice-daily medical dressing changes.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) was removing finished parts from Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-001) when he made contact with a mold release agent residue on a freshly ejected component. While handling the still-warm plastic part with bare hands to expedite removal for quality inspection, he did not notice the oily coating from the mold release agent. Within minutes, Bruno developed localized skin irritation and burning sensation on his right palm and fingers. He reported immediate itching and mild erythema (redness). Bruno washed his hands thoroughly with soap and water at the nearest station and reported the incident to safety representative Serge Lafleur. The employee experienced temporary discomfort lasting approximately 2 hours but did not require medical attention beyond first aid. However, the incident highlighted gaps in PPE compliance and material handling procedures during part removal operations.

On March 22, 2024, at 1:30 PM during the day shift, maintenance technician Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) was performing routine cooling system maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #12 located in the Automotive Production Area (UNIT-001). While disconnecting a high-pressure cooling water line to replace a corroded coupling, an unexpected system pressure surge caused a rapid cooling fluid leak. The 15-liter hydraulic-water mixture sprayed onto the machine's electrical control panel and adjacent servo motor connectors, immediately causing visible electrical arcing and sparking. The control panel caught fire briefly before automatic fire suppression activated. The machine's automation system was damaged, with a burned-out PLC (Programmable Logic Controller) module, fried servo driver cards, and compromised electrical harnesses. Estimated equipment damage exceeded $87,000. The incident caused a complete production shutdown of the machine for 12 days while replacement parts were ordered and installed. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux declared the incident. No personnel were physically injured, but the facility sustained significant operational and financial impact.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 hours during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Building 5). Employee Claude Poirier (EMP-00071), a forklift operator, was transporting a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin when the drum's securing straps failed as he was navigating a tight corner near the mixing station. The drum fell from the forklift and ruptured on impact, releasing approximately 40 gallons of hazardous resin material onto the concrete floor. The spill created a slippery surface and released volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes into the immediate area. Production operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was working 15 feet away and immediately experienced eye irritation and respiratory irritation from the fume exposure. The area was evacuated within 3 minutes. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) responded and initiated spill containment procedures. Cleanup required 6 hours, involving hazardous materials cleanup contractors. Environmental sampling revealed VOC concentrations exceeded WHMIS threshold limits in a 20-foot radius. No personal injuries requiring hospitalization occurred, but three additional employees reported mild respiratory symptoms.

On April 3, 2024, at 22:15 hours during the evening shift, a critical equipment failure occurred on Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building. Injection molding operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) was conducting routine maintenance on a 300-ton injection molding machine (Serial #IM-B-47) when he discovered that the emergency stop (E-stop) button mechanism had malfunctioned. When he attempted to test the E-stop as part of pre-shift validation, the button failed to trigger the machine shutdown sequence. The machine continued operating, and a partially ejected plastic component remained in the mold cavity. Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) arrived within 2 minutes to assess the situation. Investigation revealed that the E-stop button's solenoid valve was defective due to corrosion from inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling. The specific failure: the valve internal contacts had oxidized, preventing electrical current flow to the shutdown relay. This represented a critical safety system failure that exposed all 12 workers on Line B to uncontrolled machine operation risk. The machine was immediately locked out and tagged per LOTO procedures. Maintenance could not restore the unit until replacement parts arrived 18 hours later, resulting in 8 hours of unplanned downtime (evening shift + 2 hours night shift).

On April 8, 2024, at 08:30 hours during the day shift, a preventive safety declaration was submitted by Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123) following a routine workplace assessment of the Packaging and Labeling Station. During a scheduled safety walkthrough, Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026) identified a recurring occupational health concern affecting packaging line workers. Seven of nine full-time packaging operators reported experiencing progressive wrist and hand pain consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome symptoms over the preceding 3-month period. The work requires repetitive gripping, twisting, and fine motor movements during label application and box sealing operations, with production targets requiring workers to process approximately 800 units per 8-hour shift. Ergonomic assessment revealed insufficient wrist support during the repetitive labeling task, inadequate work surface height (27 inches vs. recommended 30-32 inches for standing assembly), and lack of micro-break scheduling. Worker interviews indicated no formal rest periods were built into the shift schedule. This represents a significant ergonomic hazard with early indicators of cumulative trauma disorder development. No acute injury event occurred, but the prevalence of early-stage symptoms warranted proactive intervention before cases progressed to medical leave status.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, during day shift operations at Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components), a resin supply hose ruptured while Finishing Operator Amal Farsi was transferring composite material from a 55-gallon drum to the hopper system. Approximately 12 liters of uncured epoxy resin spilled onto the production floor, creating a hazardous chemical pool near the clean room entrance. The operator immediately notified supervision, and the area was evacuated. The spill occurred because the hose had not been replaced during the scheduled maintenance interval—it was 18 months past its recommended lifespan of 12 months. Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang witnessed the incident and assisted with containment procedures. The facility's spill kit was deployed, and the material was neutralized with absorbent powder. No personal injury occurred, but the incident contaminated approximately 8 square meters of flooring and required 4 hours of cleanup and decontamination before operations could resume. The medical-grade cleanroom area required complete recertification before resuming production.

On February 28, 2024 at 02:15, during night shift operations in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A), Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert sustained a significant lower back strain while manually repositioning a stack of plastic resin pellet bags. Marc was attempting to organize storage racks to make space for incoming shipment of automotive-grade polycarbonate. He lifted a approximately 25-kg bag from waist height to an upper shelf (approximately 1.8 meters high) without proper lifting technique or assistance from mechanical equipment. The bags had not been stacked with optimal accessibility—they were positioned at awkward angles requiring twisting motions during the lift. Marc immediately felt sharp pain in his lumbar region and reported the incident to the night shift supervisor. He was unable to continue working and was transported to the local hospital for evaluation. Medical imaging revealed muscular strain with minor disc involvement. Marc was placed on modified duty status and prescribed a 3-week leave of absence, resulting in lost-time classification. The incident was classified as a serious ergonomic injury requiring CNESST notification.

On April 9, 2024 at 10:30, during day shift operations at the Shipping and Receiving Dock, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov sustained a partial hand laceration while unloading a pallet of finished composite components from an inbound truck. The components were stacked on wooden pallets with inadequate securing straps. As Dimitri reached between stacked parts to adjust the pallet position for forklift entry, the stack shifted and a sharp-edged fiber-reinforced plastic component (approximately 3 kg) fell, striking his right hand and creating a 4-cm laceration across the dorsal surface of his hand near the wrist. The component's glass fiber composite edge was particularly sharp due to incomplete finishing. Dimitri immediately withdrew his hand, and blood flow was significant. Plant Manager Jean-François Lefebvre responded and applied first aid with direct pressure and sterile dressing. The injury was evaluated at the facility's first aid station and determined to require external sutures (12 stitches). Dimitri was transported to urgent care for professional wound closure and received tetanus prophylaxis. The incident resulted in 6 hours of lost work time. The laceration required careful monitoring for potential composite fiber contamination and infection risk.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:30 PM during evening shift, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician on Line D (UNIT-004), was performing end-of-shift equipment inspection and maintenance. While checking the temperature gauges on the injection molding machine, he noticed residual hot plastic material (approximately 200°C) on the mold surface from the final production run. Against standard protocol, he decided to manually wipe the surface with a shop cloth to expedite cleanup rather than allowing the mandatory 30-minute cooling period. At 10:35 PM, his right hand contacted the hot mold surface, resulting in immediate thermal burns to his palm and three fingers. The pain caused him to reflexively pull away, further aggravating the injury. His coworker, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), immediately notified Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), Ergonomics Specialist, who responded within 2 minutes. First aid was administered: cold water immersion for 15 minutes followed by sterile dressing. Christian was transported to the clinic; assessment confirmed second-degree burns covering approximately 8% of his right hand. No requirement for hospitalization, but two weeks of restricted duty assigned during healing phase.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a serious burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. Youssef was cleaning residual plastic from a mold cavity on the 250-ton injection molding machine when he inadvertently made contact with the heated mold surface, which was maintained at 285°C. Despite wearing standard heat-resistant gloves, the intense surface temperature caused second-degree burns across his right palm and three fingers. The mold had not been properly cooled or isolated before maintenance began—a critical oversight in the LOTO procedure. Youssef immediately reported pain and sought first aid from Hana Al-Rashid, the Occupational Health Nurse, who provided initial wound care and determined hospitalization was necessary. He was transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur and admitted for burn treatment and infection prevention. The incident revealed gaps in the pre-maintenance cooling protocol and supervision during high-risk tasks. Witnesses present included Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion and Process Engineer Raj Patel, who assisted in the immediate response.

On February 28, 2024, at 10:45 AM during the day shift, Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was repositioning large reels of regrind material in the Regrind and Recycling Department when several reels became destabilized on the overhead storage rack due to inadequate securing straps. Two 100-pound reels fell approximately 8 feet, striking Elif's left leg and hip area. Elif sustained a fractured fibula and severe contusions but remained conscious and alert. Immediate response was provided by nearby Assembly Operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040), who called emergency services and Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), the EHS Coordinator, who initiated incident response protocols. Elif was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital where imaging confirmed the fibula fracture. Investigation revealed that reel storage racks had never undergone formal load capacity assessment, and securing straps were deteriorated from age and chemical exposure. Warehouse shelving had no secondary containment or fall protection barriers. This represented a significant gap in preventive maintenance and asset management oversight within Materials Management.

On April 5, 2024, at 4:30 PM during the evening shift, Quality Technician Natalya Kozlov (EMP-00192) was processing medical-grade composite samples in the Clean Room area when she experienced an acute skin reaction. While handling freshly cured fiber-reinforced plastic components, Natalya came into direct contact with uncured epoxy resin residue on a component surface. The resin, containing glass fibers, caused immediate irritation and a localized allergic reaction on her forearms and hands. She experienced itching, redness, and mild swelling. Natalya immediately reported to the Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) who applied topical anti-inflammatory cream, antihistamine, and documented the exposure. The nurse recommended monitoring over the next 2-4 hours and prescribed preventive measures for future shifts. The component had inadvertently been moved to the inspection station with residual uncured material—typically a quality control responsibility. This incident highlighted inadequate material preparation procedures and insufficient barrier protection in the medical device clean room. No hospitalization was required, and Natalya returned to limited duties the following day after symptoms resolved. Evening Shift Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) was notified of the incident.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM, production operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was working at Injection Molding Line D in the South Zone when she reached into the mold cavity to remove a partially formed part. The mold cycle unexpectedly activated due to a faulty proximity sensor, catching her left hand between the upper and lower mold halves. The machine safety guard had been removed two days earlier for maintenance and was never reinstalled. Her hand suffered severe crush injuries including fractures to three metacarpals and lacerations. Witness David O'Connor from the warehouse responded immediately and activated the emergency stop. Paramedics arrived within 12 minutes and transported her to Laval Hospital. The incident was reported by Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier who was conducting a routine floor inspection when she found the machine unguarded and still operating.

On March 18, 2024 at 10:45 PM during the night shift, maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine mold repairs in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. While using a ladder to access an overhead mold fixture stored on a high shelf, the ladder suddenly shifted. The ladder's base had been placed on an uneven concrete surface with debris underneath. Gravel fell approximately 6 feet, landing on his right shoulder and upper back. He experienced immediate sharp pain and inability to move his arm. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury was notified and arrived within 15 minutes. Paramedics transported him to the hospital where X-rays revealed a fractured scapula and several rib fractures. The incident was formally declared by El-Khoury who discovered the contributing factor of inadequate ladder placement procedures.

On March 22, 2024 at 1:30 PM, packaging operators Amara Diop (EMP-00110) and Amina Ba (EMP-00164) were organizing finished goods inventory in the Packaging and Labeling Station. A stack of polypropylene resin bags stored on a metal pallet rack began to shift due to uneven weight distribution. Several bags tilted forward and nearly struck Amina as she walked past the rack. She quickly moved away and was not hit, but the bags came within 12 inches of her head. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor witnessed the near-miss and immediately stabilized the stack by repositioning the bags. He then conducted a visual inspection and found that three pallets in the storage area had similar precarious stacking arrangements with heavy materials exceeding safe load limits. O'Connor reported the incident to EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury, who documented the near-miss and initiated corrective actions. No injuries occurred, but the potential for serious head/crush injuries was significant.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator on Injection Molding Line A, sustained a thermal burn to her right forearm while removing a finished automotive dashboard component from the mold. The component had just been ejected and was still at approximately 85°C. Elena was not wearing the required heat-resistant sleeve gloves, which were available but had been left on a nearby workstation. She reached to position the hot part on the cooling conveyor when her forearm made contact with the plastic surface. The burn covered an area approximately 4 inches by 2 inches with partial thickness involvement. Coworker Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) immediately assisted by applying cold water from the safety station and notifying the HSE office. Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), Ergonomics Specialist, responded within 5 minutes and coordinated transport to the on-site first aid station where the burn was treated with sterile dressing. The incident was attributed to non-compliance with PPE requirements and inadequate break time between molding cycles, contributing to worker fatigue and inattention.

On November 18, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area, experienced skin contact with uncured epoxy resin while transferring material between mixing vats. Oscar was wearing nitrile gloves, but a small tear in the left glove went unnoticed. Approximately 50 mL of epoxy resin made contact with the back of his left hand, causing localized irritation and mild erythema (redness). Oscar immediately rinsed the affected area with water for 3 minutes and applied soap. He then proceeded to the on-site first aid station where the reaction was assessed as minor chemical contact dermatitis. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, evaluated the incident and provided basic first aid treatment including monitoring, anti-inflammatory cream application, and observation for 30 minutes. No medical referral was necessary. The incident was classified as first aid treatable due to the limited exposure time and immediate response. Root cause: inadequate inspection of PPE before use and lack of secondary containment for the transfer operation.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift, Soraya Alami (EMP-00196) and Layla Hussein (EMP-00098), both Assembly Operators, were working on Injection Molding Line D (Consumer Packaging) when a critical machine malfunction occurred. During a standard cycle transition, the mold clamp mechanism failed to fully open, trapping a partially ejected component and creating a pinch point hazard. Soraya reached in to manually clear the component when the backup clamp system engaged unexpectedly, crushing her right hand between the mold halves. The incident resulted in fractures of the 3rd and 4th metacarpal bones, deep lacerations to the palm, and significant soft tissue damage. Layla immediately activated the emergency stop button and called HSE. Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), Chemical Safety Officer, arrived within 3 minutes and coordinated first aid response. An ambulance was dispatched at 6:35 PM and Soraya was transported to Centre Hospitalier Régional de Lanaudière with suspected compartment syndrome. Imaging confirmed comminuted fractures requiring surgical intervention. Investigation revealed that the preventive maintenance schedule on the Line D clamp system had been deferred by 2 weeks due to production demands, and the backup safety system had not been tested per protocol in over 60 days.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire originated in the Chemical Storage Building's solvent mixing area (Hazardous Waste Management Area). An employee was transferring acetone from a large storage container to smaller working bottles when a static discharge ignited vapors near an open container. The initial flame spread rapidly to nearby isopropanol containers on the adjacent shelf. The employee immediately activated the nearest pull-station alarm and evacuated the area. The facility's automated fire suppression system activated within 45 seconds, containing the fire to the immediate vicinity. However, thick smoke spread through the ventilation system into adjacent production areas. Emergency services arrived within 8 minutes. Two employees sustained minor smoke inhalation injuries and were treated on-site. The incident resulted in approximately 4 hours of facility evacuation and production shutdown. Root causes included inadequate grounding of the transfer equipment and lack of static-dissipative flooring in the mixing area.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, an Injection Molding Operator on Line C (Sofia Gonzalez, EMP-00074) sustained a significant laceration to her left hand while attempting to clear a material jam from the injection nozzle. The machine was supposed to be in locked-out status, but a communication failure between the shift supervisor and maintenance technician resulted in the machine remaining energized. When Sofia reached into the nozzle area with a cleaning rod, the machine cycled unexpectedly, causing the heated nozzle to contact her hand and subsequently pulling her hand into the barrel opening. The injury resulted in deep lacerations on three fingers and partial avulsion of the palm. Emergency response was initiated immediately; an ambulance arrived within 12 minutes and transported Sofia to the regional trauma center. She required emergency surgery for wound closure and repair of tendons. Investigation revealed that the LOTO procedure had been bypassed due to time pressure to meet production quotas. The incident consumed 6 hours of production downtime and resulted in significant worker's compensation costs.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop. A forklift operator (Hassan Diallo, EMP-00020) was moving a 55-gallon drum of hydraulic oil when the drum shifted during an uneven load transfer, causing it to tip and rupture on contact with the concrete floor. Approximately 40 gallons of hydraulic oil spilled across the workshop floor, flowing toward electrical equipment and the spare parts storage area. The employee immediately notified the HSE department and initiated spill containment using available absorbent materials. However, the spill had already spread approximately 200 square feet before containment began. A portion of the spill drained into a floor drain, subsequently contaminating the facility's secondary containment basin. The workshop remained closed for 8 hours for cleanup and decontamination. Environmental sampling revealed no off-site contamination, but remediation costs exceeded initial estimates. Root causes included inadequate drum securing procedures, improper forklift load configuration, and lack of secondary containment under the spill area.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire initiated in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Section C) when overheated recycled plastic material in a grinding hopper came into contact with an electrical heating element that had malfunctioned. The hopper temperature sensor had failed three days earlier but was not replaced due to maintenance backlog. Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) noticed smoke emerging from the hopper and immediately activated the emergency stop, evacuating the area. The fire spread to approximately 12 linear feet of conveyor belt material before being contained by the automatic dry powder suppression system. No employees were directly exposed to flames, but two workers—Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) and Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186)—were in adjacent areas and experienced smoke inhalation. The facility was evacuated for 90 minutes while emergency services confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. Damage to equipment was estimated at $48,000. Training Coordinator Amélie Roy discovered during investigation that the preventive maintenance log for the regrind area had not been updated in six weeks.

On April 2, 2024, at 8:15 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) sustained a laceration to her right palm while removing a finished part from injection molding machine #18 in the Production Operations area. The mold closing cycle was not fully complete when Yara reached into the machine to retrieve what she believed was a finished component. The mold descended unexpectedly, catching her hand between the stationary platen and moving mold half. She withdrew her hand immediately, incurring a 2.5-inch laceration across the palm and minor crush abrasion to the metacarpal area. Yara reported the injury to Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) at 8:22 AM. First aid was administered on-site, and the employee was transported to a local urgent care clinic where the wound required 7 stitches and a tetanus booster. The injury was classified as a recordable injury under CNESST regulations. Investigation revealed that the machine's interlock sensor on the operator side had been bypassed six weeks prior during a mold changeover when a technician encountered a sticky sensor—the bypass was never formally documented or corrected.

On May 8, 2024, at 4:30 PM during the evening shift, Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) fell from a ladder in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Maintenance Workshop, Storage Mezzanine) while attempting to retrieve a pressure gauge calibration kit from an upper shelf. The 6-foot aluminum ladder was positioned on a concrete floor at an improper angle, and Indira was reaching laterally approximately 18 inches beyond the ladder's side rails when the ladder shifted. She fell approximately 4 feet to the floor, landing on her left side. She immediately reported sharp pain in her left ankle and was unable to bear weight. Evening shift supervisor was notified at 4:35 PM. First aid administered by facility medical responder Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013) who immobilized the ankle and summoned emergency medical services. Indira was transported to the hospital where imaging revealed a spiral fracture of the left fibula requiring surgical intervention and a 3-inch incision with internal fixation plates. She was hospitalized for 2 days and provided written work restriction documentation: no standing, walking, or climbing for 8 weeks. Investigation determined the ladder was defective (base feet had worn rubber, reducing grip) and had not been inspected per ANSI standards in 18 months. Additionally, no fall protection assessment had been conducted for the 8-foot mezzanine height.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) was working at Station 3 in the Finished Goods Warehouse when he reached to retrieve a finished composite part from the top shelf of a storage rack. As he pulled the 8-kg part toward him, the securing strap failed and the part fell approximately 1.5 meters, striking his left shoulder and upper arm. The impact caused immediate sharp pain and swelling. Coworker Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) witnessed the incident and immediately notified supervision. The injured employee was taken to the on-site first aid station where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed him and determined he required hospital evaluation for a possible rotator cuff injury. He was transported to the local hospital where imaging confirmed a partial rotator cuff tear and Grade 2 shoulder dislocation. The incident resulted in 45 days of work restrictions and eventual surgical intervention.

On October 22, 2024, at 9:45 PM during the evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (Building 5). Machine Operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) was transferring a 200-liter container of polyester resin from the storage area to the mixing station using a modified hand truck designed for drum transport. As she navigated through the doorway between storage and mixing areas, the container's cap became partially unscrewed due to vibration during transport. Approximately 15 liters of polyester resin spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard extending 4 meters in length. The operator immediately activated the emergency alarm and evacuated the area. Maintenance Technician Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189) responded and contained the spill using absorbent material and granules. Director of HSE Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001) was notified and documented the incident. Environmental contamination was minimal as the floor drain had an activated carbon filter. The spill created a health hazard due to resin fumes and was classified as a reportable incident under Quebec environmental regulations. Cleanup and decontamination required 4 hours.

On December 1, 2024, at 6:20 AM during the night shift, a serious entanglement incident occurred at the Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building. Injection Molding Operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was performing routine maintenance on a 350-ton injection molding machine after the previous production cycle had completed. Although the machine was locked out at the electrical panel, a delayed hydraulic pressure release in the mold clamping mechanism had not been properly vented according to updated LOTO procedures. When Rémi attempted to manually open the mold cavity to inspect internal cooling lines, the residual hydraulic pressure caused the mold to suddenly close with tremendous force. His right hand became entrapped between the mold halves, crushing three fingers (index, middle, and ring) at the metacarpal joints. His coworker, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120), heard his anguished cry and immediately activated the emergency stop button, which prevented further injury. Emergency services were called at 6:22 AM. The employee was transported to the regional trauma center where emergency amputation of the right index and middle fingers was performed. The incident was classified as a serious injury with permanent partial disability. Investigation revealed the hydraulic pressure venting procedure in the LOTO checklist had not been updated following a recent equipment modification.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on the mold ejector pins when his left hand became caught between the mold halves as they unexpectedly closed. The machine's safety interlock had been bypassed by a maintenance technician earlier that morning who failed to properly re-engage it after repairs. Paul sustained a crush injury to his left hand with fractures to the second and third metacarpals and severe bruising across the palm and fingers. He was immediately transported to Laval Hospital by ambulance at 2:47 PM, where X-rays confirmed the fractures. The incident occurred in the Main Production Building, Injection Molding Line A. Witness Thanh Pham (EMP-00062), the Maintenance Planner, was in the area and immediately activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. Paul was hospitalized overnight for pain management and monitoring, resulting in 5 days of lost work time. The root cause investigation revealed that the safety bypass procedure was not properly documented and no verification protocol existed to ensure the interlock was re-engaged before production resumed.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), a Material Handler working in the Finished Goods Warehouse, observed a significant deterioration of the overhead crane rail system in Section B. While moving finished product pallets, she noticed visible rust, pitting corrosion, and what appeared to be hairline fractures in two welds connecting the rail support brackets to the main beam. The crane had been in operation for approximately 12 years with minimal maintenance beyond annual CNESST inspections. Concerned about the structural integrity and potential for catastrophic load drop, Bianca immediately stopped operations and reported the hazard to her supervisor, Robert Fournier (via supervisor) and documented the findings with photographs. The warehouse was evacuated of personnel in the affected zone, and a "DO NOT USE" sign was affixed to the crane pendant controls. A third-party structural engineer was contracted to conduct a comprehensive evaluation. The inspection confirmed the rail system was in critical condition with a calculated remaining fatigue life of less than 30 days under normal loading. This was a preventive declaration with no injury occurring, but the incident demonstrates early hazard identification preventing potential catastrophic failure.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 8:45 PM during the evening shift, Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), a Packaging Operator working on Line D in the Main Production Building (Consumer Packaging section), was operating the automated case sealing equipment when a small amount of chemical-based packaging adhesive splashed onto her face as a pressure seal connection momentarily separated during a conveyor jam-up. The adhesive contacted her left eye and right cheek. Lucia immediately reported the exposure to her line supervisor Diego Morales (EMP-00056), who directed her to the eyewash station located 30 meters away. She flushed her eye for approximately 3 minutes with copious amounts of water from the eyewash station. The right cheek area developed minor erythema (redness) but no blistering. Her left eye showed mild conjunctival irritation with slight tearing. Following first aid, Lucia was evaluated by the on-site occupational health nurse, Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), who confirmed the irritation was superficial and would resolve within 24-48 hours with continued hydration and rest. No medical referral was necessary. This incident was managed entirely through first aid protocols and did not require hospitalization or lost work time beyond the remainder of the shift.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a critical failure occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Mohamed Ibrahim, Regrind Operator, was preparing a batch of fiber-reinforced plastic compound when the ventilation system abruptly failed. Within minutes, solvent vapors accumulated to hazardous levels in the confined space. Mohamed began experiencing dizziness and respiratory distress. A nearby Quality Inspector, Jasmine Patel, noticed Mohamed's distress and immediately alerted Serge Lafleur, the Workplace Safety Representative. Emergency response protocols were activated, and Mohamed was evacuated to fresh air within 8 minutes. An emergency technician assessed him and recommended hospital evaluation as a precaution. The root cause investigation revealed a catastrophic bearing failure in the primary ventilation motor, which had not been included in the predictive maintenance schedule. The system had been operating beyond its service interval due to scheduling oversight. No formal inspection records existed for the past 18 months.

On March 22, 2025, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019). Investigation revealed that a discarded plastic waste container in the immediate vicinity of a heat-sealing machine had caught fire due to residual heat exposure from the equipment. The container was left approximately 18 inches from the sealing station's operational zone. Raoul Blanchard, Machine Operator on day shift, had improperly disposed of reject packaging materials into a cardboard box placed beside the sealing machine rather than following proper waste segregation protocols. During evening shift setup, incoming shift personnel noticed smoke and activated the alarm at 10:47 PM. Georges Plante, Facilities Technician, responded immediately and extinguished the small fire using a Class B dry chemical extinguisher within 2 minutes. The fire was contained to the waste container with minimal damage to surrounding materials. However, the incident revealed multiple contributing factors: inadequate waste disposal procedures, lack of clear signage for proper waste segregation, and insufficient distance between heat sources and combustible materials. No personal injuries occurred, but the incident prompted immediate facility evacuation and fire department response.

On April 8, 2025, at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift, severe equipment damage occurred at the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025). Vincent Létourneau, Instrumentation Technician, was performing calibration maintenance on a CNC milling machine spindle bearing when a compressed air line coupling ruptured under pressure. The sudden release of compressed air (at 120 PSI) propelled the bearing assembly and associated metal components across the mezzanine work area. One heavy steel fixture weighing approximately 12 pounds struck a precision CMM (Coordinate Measuring Machine) display panel and control module, causing severe impact damage. The bearing assembly itself fell 8 feet to the floor below, striking the concrete and scattering metal shavings throughout the storage area. Total equipment damage was estimated at $34,000 (CMM control module replacement and recalibration). The coupling failure analysis revealed metal fatigue and corrosion that had been progressing for approximately 6 months. Inspection records showed the compressed air line system had not been inspected or flushed in over 2 years, leading to moisture accumulation and internal corrosion. The night shift supervisor, Claude Rioux, discovered the damage during rounds and documented the incident.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Injection Molding Technician Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045) was operating Line B in the Production Operations area when the hydraulic pump on Injection Molding Machine #7 (a 250-ton unit) began exhibiting unusual vibration and noise. The machine had been in continuous operation for 18 hours without scheduled maintenance. At 11:20 AM, while Ouellet was clearing a minor mold blockage, the hydraulic pressure gauge spiked unexpectedly. The pump seal failed catastrophically, spraying hot hydraulic oil across a 6-foot radius. Ouellet sustained thermal burns to his right forearm and shoulder. Automation Technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) was nearby and immediately activated the emergency stop, shut down the machine, and called for emergency medical response. The facility's emergency response team arrived within 4 minutes. Ouellet was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital with second-degree burns covering approximately 12% of his upper body. The machine remained offline for 8 days during investigation and pump replacement. Root cause analysis revealed the hydraulic fluid had degraded due to extended operating periods without filter replacement, and the pump had exceeded its 5,000-hour service interval by 340 hours.

On November 20, 2024, at 2:15 PM, Composite Materials Operator Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086) reported to Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi that she observed elevated dust levels in the fiber reinforcement preparation area of UNIT-011 (Hazardous Waste Management Area) despite normally adequate ventilation. Abdallah had been working the evening shift crossover and noticed increased respiratory irritation after 3 hours of exposure. She voluntarily reported the concern before experiencing significant symptoms, recognizing the potential for composite fiber dust inhalation hazard. Upon inspection, Rachidi identified that the ventilation system's HEPA filter had reached 85% saturation—approaching the recommended 90% replacement threshold but still technically operational. Air quality monitoring equipment measured fiber particle concentration at 4.2 mg/m³, which remained below Quebec's occupational exposure limit of 5 mg/m³ but demonstrated declining performance. The facility's medical team evaluated Abdallah and confirmed no acute respiratory issues. Rachidi immediately scheduled filter replacement for the following morning and conducted a facility walk-through to verify ventilation performance in all chemical handling areas. This preventive declaration identified deteriorating conditions before they resulted in regulatory non-compliance or employee illness.

On November 18, 2024, at 4:50 PM during evening shift operations, Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was transferring acetone-based mold release agent from a 55-gallon storage drum to smaller 5-liter working containers in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). At approximately 4:55 PM, a forklift operator maneuvering nearby containers inadvertently struck the transfer station, dislodging the partially-filled 5-liter container. The container fell to the concrete floor and ruptured, releasing approximately 3.2 liters of acetone solvent. The spill spread rapidly across a 42-square-foot area. Petrov immediately notified her supervisor and activated the facility's spill response protocol. The acetone generated significant vapor, creating visibility issues and mild inhalation irritation for Petrov and nearby dock staff. Materials Engineer Jing Wang (EMP-00054) coordinated emergency response with Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and neutralized according to WHMIS protocols. Ventilation fans were increased to maximum capacity. The spill remediation took 2.5 hours. Environmental monitoring detected no off-site vapor migration. Approximately 15 liters of contaminated absorbent material was properly disposed of per Quebec hazardous waste regulations. No injuries resulted, but the incident exposed gaps in forklift traffic control near chemical transfer operations.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was adjusting the mold closing mechanism on Injection Molding Machine #12 in the Main Production Building's East Wing when the hydraulic system unexpectedly activated. Bouazizi had completed the mold temperature calibration and was manually repositioning the mold alignment pins without properly engaging the machine's lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure. A colleague, Production Operator Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), was working nearby on Line B when he heard Bouazizi cry out. The mold doors closed rapidly, crushing Bouazizi's left hand between the mold plates. The injury resulted in a compound fracture of the metacarpals and lacerations requiring surgical intervention and 8 weeks of lost time. Emergency response was immediate, with Yves Thibault (Quality Supervisor) applying first aid while emergency services were contacted. The incident investigation revealed that the LOTO checklist had been bypassed due to time pressure from production quotas, and the machine's emergency stop button was obscured by production debris.

On April 3, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was organizing raw material pallets in the Warehouse and Shipping area (Section C) when she noticed a faint hissing sound coming from a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin that had been recently received from the supplier. She observed a small crystalline residue around the drum's upper edge and detected a chemical odor characteristic of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Mansour immediately notified Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme verbally, who informed her that the drum had been sitting in direct sunlight for approximately 3 hours after delivery while waiting for inventory verification. Mansour did not open or disturb the drum but instead flagged it for quarantine. Upon inspection by Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) and Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), it was determined that the drum's internal pressure had increased due to temperature exposure, creating a potential rupture or explosion hazard. The resin was classified as a hazardous material requiring proper temperature-controlled storage between 65-75°F. Although no injury occurred, the incident represented a serious near-miss with potential for significant harm to personnel and facility.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the evening shift, Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was transferring finished composite material sheets from the curing oven to the cooling rack in the Composite Materials Processing Area when she accidentally tripped over a coiled air hose that extended across the walkway behind the equipment. She fell forward onto the cooling rack, which struck the adjacent hydraulic press control panel. The impact damaged three critical circuit boards in the control system and severed the main power relay, rendering the hydraulic press inoperable. The estimated cost of parts and labor for repair was approximately $28,000. Additionally, the fall resulted in minor bruising to Iqbal's ribs and shoulder, though she declined medical treatment. The incident caused a 14-hour production delay as the hydraulic press could not be used for die-forming operations. Investigation revealed that the air hose had been temporarily routed across the walkway for maintenance work three days prior and was never relocated to its proper overhead pathway.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Employee Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030), a Machine Setter, was assisting with resin transfer operations when a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin was being moved by forklift operator Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167). The drum's securing straps failed due to corrosion, causing the drum to shift and strike a storage rack containing multiple containers of solvent and mold release agents. Approximately 12 gallons of mixed chemical solution spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous pool that began to emit strong toxic vapors. The spill was immediately adjacent to the room's ventilation intake. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified and initiated containment procedures. The area was evacuated, emergency ventilation was activated, and the spill was contained using absorbent material and neutralizing agents. No direct contact injuries occurred, but three employees experienced mild respiratory irritation from vapor exposure.

On March 18, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift, Injection Molding Machine Line A (UNIT-001) experienced a catastrophic coolant circulation system failure. Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) noticed irregular temperature readings on the machine display and unusual noise emanating from the cooling pump assembly. He immediately notified Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105), who arrived within minutes to assess the situation. Upon inspection, Mailhot discovered that the circulating pump's bearing assembly had completely failed, causing the internal rotor to seize. The pump housing had developed a hairline fracture, allowing pressurized coolant to leak onto electrical components and the machine's control panel. The leak pooled on the production floor in a 15-foot radius, creating a slip hazard and damaging approximately $8,000 worth of tooling mounted on adjacent equipment. The machine was immediately shut down and isolated using LOTO procedures by Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161). The coolant line was depressurized and sealed. Production was halted for 6 hours while the pump assembly was replaced and the equipment returned to service.

On March 20, 2024, at 8:50 PM during evening shift operations, Assembly Operator Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186) sustained a significant laceration injury while manually removing parts from a CNC milling machine in the Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-014). Rossi was performing part removal duties on a composite material component when her right hand became caught on a rotating burr head that had not fully disengaged when the cycle ended. Quality Control Lead Petra Mueller (EMP-00166) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button. Rossi's palm and three fingers sustained deep lacerations requiring immediate first aid intervention and emergency transport to the hospital. She received 14 stitches across multiple wounds and was diagnosed with a minor nerve irritation in her right index finger. The machine was secured using lockout/tagout procedures by Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) for investigation. Root cause analysis determined that the machine's mechanical spindle brake was operating below specification, allowing the cutting head to continue rotating for 3-4 seconds after the programmed stop command. The incident resulted in 12 hours of unplanned downtime and temporary loss of production capacity.

On October 14, 2024, at 14:45, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, suffered a severe hand laceration while performing routine mold cleaning operations. Benoit was removing cooled plastic flash from a recently ejected mold when his left hand made contact with a sharp edge on the mold cavity that had not been properly deburred during the previous maintenance cycle. The cut was approximately 4 cm long and 2 cm deep, requiring immediate first aid and emergency transport to Centre Hospitalier de Saint-Eustache for sutures and tetanus prophylaxis. The employee was unable to return to work for 23 days, resulting in lost time. Witness Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165) from Line C observed the incident and immediately alerted Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), Safety Trainer, who initiated the incident response protocol. Investigation revealed that the mold had been returned from maintenance without proper edge finishing, and that Benoit had not been wearing the prescribed cut-resistant gloves for this specific task despite their availability in the workplace.

On November 8, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167), a Forklift Operator, nearly caused a serious incident in the Warehouse and Shipping area while moving a stack of finished goods pallets. While navigating through the narrow aisles of the warehouse, Hugues was operating the forklift at approximately 8 km/h when he approached a blind corner where raw materials are being prepared for loading. Due to the high stack of pallets he was carrying (approximately 1.8 meters tall), his visibility was severely compromised. As he turned the corner, he nearly collided with Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170), a Material Handler, who was manually preparing a shipment at dock position 3. Chiara heard the forklift approaching and quickly moved out of the pathway. No collision occurred, and no injuries resulted, but the incident demonstrated a clear hazard that could have resulted in a serious struck-by incident. Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), Workplace Safety Representative, was notified immediately and arrived at the scene to assess the near-miss situation and interviewed both employees.

On November 22, 2024, at 10:30 during the day shift, Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a Production Operator in the Material Drying and Preparation Room, sustained a moderate chemical burn to her right forearm and hand. While transferring plastic resin pellets from a bulk storage bin into a material dryer, Leila accidentally spilled approximately 250 milliliters of mold release agent (a silicone-based liquid) onto her arm. The substance, which was being used to pre-treat the storage bins, caused immediate skin irritation and redness. Although Leila immediately rinsed the affected area at the nearest emergency eyewash and shower station for approximately 3 minutes, the chemical had already begun to cause a superficial burn pattern. She was transported to the occupational health clinic for evaluation and treatment, where she received topical cream application and was cleared to return to modified duty the following day with restrictions on exposure to further chemical contact for 5 days. Mei Zhang (EMP-00068), Quality Control Inspector, witnessed the incident and alerted Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, who initiated the incident response and prepared the incident report.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, during day shift operations at Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171) was performing routine maintenance on the hopper system when he noticed a partial blockage of resin material. While attempting to clear the obstruction by hand, the automatic feed mechanism unexpectedly activated despite the equipment being tagged for maintenance. The sudden material flow caused approximately 8 kg of polypropylene pellets to discharge rapidly into the hopper area, creating a significant spillage across the production floor. The material scattered in a 4-meter radius, creating slip hazards and obscuring floor markings. Jalbert immediately notified his supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031), who assessed the situation. No personal injury occurred, but the incident highlighted inadequate lockout procedures and potential gaps in preventive maintenance scheduling. The area was immediately cordoned off, and cleanup operations were completed within 2 hours. This preventive declaration is being filed to address the systemic risk of unexpected equipment activation during maintenance operations.

On April 2, 2024 at 09:20, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a material handler working the day shift at the Packaging and Labeling Station in the Warehouse and Shipping Prep Area, was transferring finished components from a production cart to shipping boxes when his right hand contacted a sharp burr on the edge of a polycarbonate part. The jagged edge, approximately 3 mm in length, caused a laceration across his palm resulting in moderate bleeding. Diallo immediately reported the injury to his supervisor and proceeded to the first aid station where Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), the EHS Coordinator, assessed the wound. The laceration required cleaning, antiseptic treatment, and sterile bandaging but did not require sutures or external medical attention. The incident was documented as a recordable first aid case. The defective part was segregated for quality investigation, and it was determined that the post-processing deburring step had been bypassed due to equipment downtime. Diallo received updated safety briefing on identifying and reporting defective parts before handling.

On May 18, 2024 at 22:15, during evening shift operations at the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop in the Maintenance Workshop Tool Room, Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), a mechanical maintenance technician, and Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), a machine setter, were performing scheduled maintenance on a hydraulic press used for mold repairs. While Rossi was inspecting a hydraulic line connection for leaks, a pressurized line coupling suddenly failed under approximately 200 bar pressure. Hydraulic fluid at 65°C sprayed onto Rossi's left forearm and hand, causing a second-degree thermal burn affecting approximately 15% of the exposed skin surface. Rossi immediately immersed his arm in cold water from the emergency eyewash station while Jimenez activated the facility alarm and summoned emergency responders. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), the Emergency Response Team Leader, coordinated first aid response including application of sterile dressings. An ambulance was called and Rossi was transported to Laval Medical Center where he received advanced burn treatment. The incident required hospitalization for 48 hours and resulted in 5 days of lost work time. Root cause analysis identified inadequate pressure relief valve maintenance and missing secondary containment protocols.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #18 in UNIT-002 (Injection Molding Line B - Automotive). While clearing a material jam from the hopper feed system, Patrick's left hand became caught between the rotating auger screw and the hopper wall when a co-worker inadvertently activated the machine without proper lockout procedures in place. The machine cycled unexpectedly, crushing Patrick's hand between the auger and the housing. Patrick sustained a complex fracture of the left metacarpal bones and significant soft tissue damage. Emergency response was activated immediately, and Patrick was transported to Laval Hospital with a lost-time injury. The incident was witnessed by Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), Machine Setter on the evening shift who had come in early for shift overlap. Investigation revealed that the LOTO procedures were not being consistently followed during routine troubleshooting, and the machine's safety interlock had been bypassed during a previous maintenance session and not restored.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the night shift, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead, was organizing raw material inventory in the Warehouse and Shipping facility (UNIT-009). While manually lifting a 45-kg pallet of polycarbonate resin pellets from a lower shelf to an upper storage rack, Michel experienced acute lower back pain and collapsed to the floor. He was unable to move and complained of severe pain in his lumbar region and left hip. Emergency medical personnel were called, and Michel was transported to the emergency department where imaging revealed a herniated disc at the L4-L5 level with compression of the nerve root, resulting in hospitalization and subsequent surgical intervention. The incident was witnessed by Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), Inventory Control Specialist, who was assisting with the inventory audit. Contributing factors included improper lifting technique, inadequate mechanical assistance equipment for heavy loads, and lack of recent ergonomics training. The load exceeded the safe manual lifting limit of 25 kg recommended by CNESST guidelines.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-024, note: incident occurred in Chemical Storage area, reported to cafeteria unit due to proximity of emergency response coordination). Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189), Mold Release Agent, was transferring approximately 50 liters of epoxy resin hardener (diethyltoluamide, a hazardous chemical) from a 200-liter storage drum to smaller mixing containers using a gravity-fed transfer system. Due to a defective connector on the transfer hose, the hardener began leaking onto the floor at a rate of approximately 2 liters per minute. Armand initially attempted to contain the spill using absorbent pads but failed to notify supervisors or activate emergency response protocols. After 8 minutes, approximately 16 liters of chemical had accumulated on the floor and began seeping toward the storm drain system. The spill was finally discovered by Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), Composite Materials Operator, who immediately activated the emergency spill response procedure and notified Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer. The facility's hazmat team responded, contained the spill using granular absorbent and dikes, and properly disposed of contaminated materials in accordance with WHMIS and environmental regulations. No personal injury resulted, but environmental contamination risk was significant.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Kwesi Owusu was transferring a pallet of pre-molded plastic components from the receiving area in Materials Management and Warehousing (UNIT-025) to an injection molding machine staging area. While maneuvering the electric forklift around a blind corner near the mezzanine storage section, Kwesi failed to notice that Assembly Operator Ana Silva was walking through the narrow aisle conducting a routine inventory count. The forklift's left tire caught the edge of a wooden pallet that had been left partially in the walkway, causing the forklift to lurch suddenly. Kwesi swerved to avoid the obstacle, and the load shifted precariously but remained secured to the forks. Ana, who was directly in the projected path, quickly moved backward and pressed herself against the storage shelving, avoiding direct contact with the forklift. The incident lasted approximately 3 seconds. Kwesi immediately stopped the forklift and assisted Ana in confirming she had not been struck. Both employees reported the near-miss to Zahra Nasri, the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, who documented the event and verified that no injuries had occurred.

On March 20, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Process Quality Engineer Deepa Gupta conducted a routine inspection of the chemical storage and mixing area in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). During her inspection, Deepa observed that several 55-gallon drums of polyurethane resin were stored directly adjacent to a heat source—an industrial oven used for post-processing composite materials. The oven's exterior surface temperature was measured at 165°C (330°F), and the resin drums were positioned approximately 30 cm from the oven wall. Per TechnoPlast's Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for polyurethane resin, storage temperature must not exceed 25°C, and the material should be kept at least 3 meters away from any heat source exceeding 60°C. Deepa immediately notified Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov of the hazardous condition. Natasha and maintenance staff relocated the drums to the designated cool storage area within the Chemical Inventory Room, where temperature is maintained at 18-22°C. A review of the facility layout and chemical storage procedures revealed that the oven area had been reconfigured during recent equipment maintenance, and the new storage location had not been communicated to personnel. No spill, fire, or chemical degradation occurred.

On March 25, 2024, at approximately 4:15 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Technician Patrick Ouellet was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #18 (a 250-ton Engel machine processing medical-grade polycarbonate components). Patrick was wearing standard factory PPE including nitrile gloves, safety glasses, and flame-resistant coveralls. While using a soft-bristle brush to clear residual plastic material from the machine's hopper, Patrick's work glove became partially caught on a rotating shaft component that was part of the material conveyor system. The shaft was rotating at approximately 45 RPM due to residual mechanical motion from a prior cycle. The rotating shaft wound the glove material around itself, pulling Patrick's left hand into the pinch point between the rotating shaft and an adjacent fixed guard plate. Patrick immediately cried out, and nearby Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel rushed to activate the emergency stop button on the machine. The rotation ceased within 1.5 seconds. Upon extraction of his hand, Patrick was found to have sustained a partial laceration and crushing injury to his left ring finger between the first and second knuckle, with significant bleeding. Jasmine applied immediate first aid using pressure bandaging while Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette called for emergency medical services. Patrick was transported to Laval Hospital by ambulance at 4:28 PM where he received 8 stitches and was diagnosed with a non-displaced fracture of the proximal phalanx. He was released the same evening with follow-up care instructions.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Soraya Alami (EMP-00196), an Assembly Operator, was working at a manual assembly station in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) when she noticed her right hand becoming numb and tingling while performing repetitive packaging motions. She immediately reported the symptoms to her supervisor, Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who was monitoring the production line. Upon inspection, it was noted that her workstation lacked proper ergonomic support and the assembly task required continuous gripping motions without adequate breaks. Soraya had been performing the same assembly task for 6 consecutive hours without a scheduled break. The symptoms were consistent with early-stage carpal tunnel syndrome. Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, was notified and documented the incident as a near-miss warning sign. The employee was immediately relieved from the repetitive task and provided with rest and ice therapy at the on-site first aid station. No medical intervention was required beyond occupational health evaluation, but the incident highlighted a systemic issue with workstation ergonomics that could result in serious musculoskeletal injury if left unaddressed.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120), a CNC Machinist, was working in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013) when he experienced a minor laceration to his left index finger while removing a finished mold from a precision milling machine. The incident occurred when Dimitri attempted to manually clear away metal shavings from the mold surface without first disengaging the machine's spindle. Although the machine was running at reduced speed (approximately 200 RPM), his finger made contact with a rotating cutting tool edge, creating a shallow 2-centimeter laceration on the lateral side of the finger. The bleeding was controlled within 2 minutes by direct pressure. Guillaume Deschamps (EMP-00033), Operations Manager, was immediately present and assessed the wound. First aid was administered by Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), the Safety Officer, who cleaned the wound with antiseptic solution, applied antibiotic ointment, and dressed it with sterile gauze and medical tape. The injury required only basic first aid treatment with no stitches necessary. Dimitri was able to continue working after the incident with modified duties to keep the wound dry. The root cause was identified as a procedural violation; the operator had not followed standard lockout procedures before attempting manual mold clearing.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), a Regrind Operator, suffered a lost-time injury while working in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Mohamed was manually transferring dried composite material pellets from a large storage hopper to a grinding hopper using a metal scoop when he lost his footing on the polished concrete floor that had been inadvertently contaminated with a thin film of lubricating oil. He fell approximately 4 feet to the floor, landing on his left side and striking a stack of storage bins. Medical assessment revealed a fractured left radius and multiple abrasions. Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator who was present for a material handoff, immediately called emergency services. The injury required hospitalization and orthopedic surgery to stabilize the fracture with a plate and screws. Mohamed was unable to return to work for 16 weeks (112 days), making this a significant lost-time injury. Investigation revealed that the night shift supervisor had not completed the required end-of-shift floor inspection and cleaning protocol, and the maintenance team had not addressed a known oil leak in the adjacent hydraulic press system. The slippery floor condition, combined with inadequate housekeeping and insufficient slip-resistant flooring in high-risk areas, created a hazardous walking surface during the night shift when supervision was minimal.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Bianca De Luca, Material Handler, was transferring a 25-liter container of mold release agent (silicone-based) from storage to the mixing station when the container's valve connection failed due to corrosion. Approximately 18 liters of the viscous liquid spilled onto the concrete floor, spreading across an area of approximately 4 square meters. The spill occurred near the floor drain system, creating a slippery hazard and releasing volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors into the workspace. Bianca immediately notified her supervisor Luc Girard, who activated the spill response protocol. The area was evacuated within 5 minutes. Emergency response involved deploying absorbent materials and establishing a containment perimeter. No personal injury occurred, but three employees experienced mild respiratory irritation from vapor exposure. The incident was contained within 45 minutes, and all contaminated materials were properly disposed of according to provincial hazardous waste regulations. Root cause investigation revealed the container valve had not been inspected for corrosion as part of the monthly equipment maintenance schedule.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, an equipment failure occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment Department (UNIT-017). Production Engineer Sébastien Carrier was monitoring the industrial resin dryer unit (Model Wittmann Battenfeld WHP 800) when it suddenly began emitting an unusual grinding noise from the heating element motor. Within 90 seconds, the motor seized completely, causing the rotating drum to stop abruptly while still containing approximately 200 kilograms of polycarbonate resin at elevated temperature (220°C). The sudden stoppage created uneven cooling and thermally-induced stress on the drum's internal heating coils. The motor's bearing failure was caused by inadequate lubrication—maintenance records showed the bearing had not been re-greased in 18 months despite a manufacturer-recommended 12-month interval. When production crew attempted to manually rotate the drum to clear the material, they discovered the internal heating coil had cracked due to thermal stress, resulting in contamination of the polycarbonate batch. Estimated equipment damage: $34,000. Estimated material loss: $12,500. The dryer required shutdown for 72 hours pending coil replacement and motor rebuild. This incident disrupted the medical device component production schedule, delaying shipments to a key customer.

On March 18, 2024, at 4:20 PM during the evening shift, a lost-time injury occurred in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005). Tomas Jimenez, Machine Setter, was performing repetitive part removal operations from injection molding equipment when he experienced acute onset of severe pain in his right wrist and forearm. He had been removing small automotive dashboard trim components from injection mold cavities for approximately 4 hours without break, performing an estimated 800-900 part removal cycles. The repetitive gripping, twisting, and forceful extraction motions caused acute inflammation of the wrist tendons (suspected acute tenosynovitis). Tomas initially attempted to continue working with his left hand but experienced progressive pain and swelling in his right wrist within 45 minutes. At 5:05 PM, he reported the injury to his supervisor Anika Johansson and requested medical evaluation. He was immediately removed from the production line and transported to the occupational health clinic. Clinical evaluation confirmed acute wrist strain with significant inflammation. Tomas was prescribed 5 days of complete work restriction, returning to light-duty tasks only after medical clearance. This incident was classified as lost-time injury due to work restriction exceeding 24 hours.
