Root cause analysis identified inadequate work rotation procedures and no scheduled micro-breaks during repetitive tasks, combined with poorly designed extraction tooling that required excessive force.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a thermal burn to her right forearm while removing a finished part from a mold. The mold temperature was approximately 180°C. Claudine was wearing standard nitrile gloves, which proved inadequate for the high-temperature operation. As she extracted the part, her glove slipped, and her forearm made direct contact with the hot mold surface for approximately 2-3 seconds before she pulled away. She immediately ran her arm under cool water at a nearby station and reported the injury to her supervisor, Sébastien Carrier. The burn resulted in a second-degree thermal injury approximately 8 cm in length across the forearm. Claudine was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé for assessment and treatment. The incident was witnessed by fellow operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040) and production coordinator Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175). Root cause investigation revealed that the heat-resistant gloves that should have been supplied had not been restocked after the previous shift, and Claudine was unaware of the correct PPE requirement for this specific task.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a Production Operator, nearly sustained a serious chemical exposure incident in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While transferring a 25 kg batch of polypropylene resin from a bulk container into a heated dryer unit, the transfer hose coupling suddenly separated due to vibration-induced loosening. Approximately 2-3 liters of damp resin material (containing residual moisture and fine particulates) spilled onto the floor and workbench before Leila could shut off the material hopper. The release created a significant dust cloud containing polymer fines and moisture. Leila immediately stepped back and covered her face, avoiding direct inhalation. She did not activate the spill kit or emergency ventilation procedures. Fellow operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) witnessed the event and alerted supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010), who arrived within 2 minutes. David implemented proper cleanup procedures and verified that no material entered the drainage system. Investigation revealed that the coupling had not been checked or re-torqued as part of the preventive maintenance schedule. The hose coupling specifications called for inspection and retightening every 500 operating hours, but this had not been performed for over 800 hours. A near-miss report was filed noting that had Leila been positioned differently or delayed her response, she could have suffered respiratory exposure requiring hospitalization.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 8:20 AM during the day shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, sustained a minor eye irritation incident while preparing a batch of colorant masterbatch in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. While measuring acetone solvent into a graduated cylinder, Elena inadvertently splashed approximately 5-10 mL of acetone directly into her right eye. Elena was not wearing chemical splash goggles at the time, only standard safety glasses, which provide insufficient protection against liquid chemical splash. She immediately rinsed her eye at the eyewash station for the required 15 minutes. Initial assessment by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) revealed minor conjunctival irritation and mild erythema but no corneal damage. Elena's vision was not affected, and she was cleared to return to light duty work after 2 hours of observation. The incident was categorized as first aid level treatment. Root cause analysis identified that: (1) acetone was being measured in an open graduated cylinder without secondary containment, (2) splash goggles were not being consistently used despite being available in the work area, and (3) no procedural reminder signage was present at the chemical dispensing station. Witness Christine Desrosiers (EMP-00055), Purchasing Coordinator, was nearby and confirmed Elena's immediate response was appropriate.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area. While removing a partially cured plastic part from the mold cavity, his left hand came into contact with the hot mold surface heated to 85°C. He sustained a first-degree burn across the palm and three fingers. Gosselin immediately immersed his hand in cool water from a nearby station and reported the incident to his supervisor Eric Surprenant. The burn area measured approximately 15 cm² with visible redness but no blistering. First aid was administered on-site including topical burn gel and sterile bandaging. The employee continued work for the remainder of his shift with modified duties. The incident occurred because Gosselin did not wait the required 10-minute cool-down period specified in the standard operating procedures, opting instead to speed up production to meet a medical device deadline. The mold contact warning label had partially faded, contributing to complacency.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Monique Dion (EMP-00119), a Warehouse Associate, was retrieving raw plastic resin materials from the upper shelf storage area in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. As she reached for a 25 kg bag of polycarbonate resin positioned at approximately 2.1 meters height, the bag became dislodged from its placement. The bag began to fall toward Dion but she quickly stepped backward, causing the bag to miss her by approximately 30 centimeters and fall harmlessly to a padded work surface below. Dion's coworker, David O'Connor (EMP-00010), the Warehouse Supervisor, witnessed the near-miss from across the storage area. No injuries were sustained. The incident was immediately reported to Johanne Paquette, the Emergency Response Team Leader. Investigation revealed that the resin bag had been improperly stacked: it was placed horizontally on a shelf designed for vertical placement, and the weight distribution created instability. Additionally, the chemical storage area lacked secondary containment barriers that would have prevented the bag from reaching the work floor even if dropped from height. No signage indicated the maximum shelf loading capacity.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on the Evening Shift (working the night shift coverage), was cleaning accumulated plastic dust from around the base of Injection Molding Line D using a compressed air hose with a pressure nozzle. He was directing pressurized air into tight spaces between the machine's support frame and the floor. While clearing debris near the hydraulic connection point, the compressed air nozzle slipped from his control and the jet of air struck his face, specifically his left eye and cheekbone area. Rahman immediately removed the nozzle, felt pain and slight discomfort in his eye, but could see normally. He reported the incident to the night shift supervisor Guillaume Deschamps who documented the near-miss and provided ice packs for potential swelling. No visible injury occurred, and Rahman's vision remained unaffected. Medical evaluation performed by the on-site occupational health nurse confirmed no corneal abrasion or damage. The incident occurred because Rahman was not wearing the required face shield during compressed air operations, and the compressed air pressure had not been verified against the 6 bar maximum limit specified in the WHMIS safety procedures. No proper tool holder existed for securing the nozzle when not actively in use.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021), a mold technician, was performing maintenance on a 300-ton injection molding machine in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). While attempting to clear a material jam from the machine's nozzle without properly engaging the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure, the machine unexpectedly cycled. Stéphane's right hand became caught between the mold halves as they closed, resulting in a crushing injury to three fingers. A coworker, Roberto Santos (EMP-00012), heard Stéphane's cry for help and immediately activated the emergency stop button. Stéphane was transported to Hôpital de Laval where X-rays revealed fractures to the second, third, and fourth metacarpal bones. He underwent surgery for fracture reduction and remained hospitalized for two days. Initial investigation revealed that the LOTO checklist had been bypassed due to time pressure to restart production. The employee was placed on modified duty for 6 weeks during recovery.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Ana Silva (EMP-00040), an assembly operator, was manually handling finished injection-molded consumer packaging components on Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-004). While transferring a batch of approximately 200 units from a production bin to a staging cart, Ana cut her left index finger on a sharp edge burr present on several parts. The parts had not been properly deburred during the quality control process. The cut required 8 stitches at the on-site first aid station and resulted in a minor laceration to the finger pad. A colleague, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), witnessed the incident and immediately alerted the supervisor. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the deburring station had been running behind schedule due to equipment maintenance, and quality control staff had reduced inspection rigor to expedite the line. Ana received first aid treatment and was able to continue working with a protective bandage, requiring no lost work time.

On April 18, 2024, at 11:50 PM during the night shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a material handler, was moving resin containers in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) using a manually operated pallet jack. While navigating around a work area with poor lighting near the storage racks, Elif did not notice an air hose and power cable bundled across the floor. She tripped over the bundled cables and stumbled forward, nearly colliding with an elevated storage rack that held approximately 300 kg of curing composite materials. Another worker, Noor Ahmed (EMP-00076) from HR who was conducting a night shift walkthrough, observed the near-miss and immediately reported it to Normand Ouellette (EMP-00147), the regrind supervisor on duty. The materials on the rack did not fall, and no injury occurred. However, the investigation revealed that the cables had not been properly secured or managed per facility guidelines, creating a significant trip hazard. Had Elif fallen differently or struck the rack support column, a serious injury from falling objects could have resulted.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B when he attempted to clear a resin blockage from the hopper using a wooden rod. Despite the machine being in cycle, the rod became caught between the rotating screw and the barrel wall. The force pulled Gosselin's right hand into the mechanism, causing severe crushing injuries to his fingers and hand. Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101), the Production Supervisor, immediately activated the emergency stop and called for emergency response. Gosselin was taken to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé where he underwent emergency surgery for multiple fractures and tissue damage. He required hospitalization for three days and is expected to be off work for approximately 12 weeks during recovery. The incident was witnessed by assembly line operator Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), who alerted Boisvert immediately. Investigation revealed the machine had not been properly locked out before maintenance began.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), Warehouse Supervisor for the evening shift, was conducting inventory in the Hazardous Waste Management Area when he noticed an improperly sealed 20-liter container of acetone-based cleaning solvent on a middle shelf of storage rack UNIT-011-C. As he reached to reposition the container, the seal failed and approximately 15 liters of solvent spilled onto his left arm and shoulder, causing chemical burns. Additionally, three other containers above became destabilized and fell, with one striking his left hip. Beaudoin immediately moved to the emergency eyewash station and flushed the affected area for 15 minutes before seeking medical attention. He was examined at the facility's medical clinic where chemical burns were treated with topical medication and the hip contusion was assessed. Due to pain and limited mobility, Beaudoin was placed on modified duty with medical restrictions against lifting objects exceeding 10 pounds for 10 business days. Witness Miriam Cohen (EMP-00132), Supply Chain Analyst, called for emergency medical response. The incident was reported by occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052).

On December 8, 2024, at approximately 1:20 AM during the night shift, Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170), Material Handler, was moving stacked pallets of regrind plastic material in the Regrind and Recycling Department using a propane-powered forklift. While navigating a narrow aisle between storage racks, the operator of an electric forklift, Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), who was also working the night shift from his position as Machine Setter, was traveling in the opposite direction with his load raised to approximately 1.5 meters height. The two operators did not have clear sightlines due to the size of their loads and the narrow workspace configuration. The vehicles collided, causing Jimenez's load of compounded resin material to shift and fall partially onto Bianchi's left leg. The impact fractured Bianchi's left tibia and fibula. She fell to the ground and was unable to move without assistance. An emergency call was placed to Laval Fire Department EMS, and Bianchi was transported to Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM) where she underwent surgery to stabilize the fractures with internal fixation. She was hospitalized for four days and has been placed on leave-without-pay status pending recovery, expected to be 14-16 weeks before return-to-work clearance. Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006), Maintenance Manager, responded to the incident and secured the area. The incident was formally reported by Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, acting in his EHS capacity.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, assembly operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) was working at Station 5 in the Assembly and Finishing Department when she experienced acute pain in her right wrist and hand. Over the preceding 8 weeks, Carmen had been performing repetitive gripping and twisting motions while removing molded components from fixtures and inserting fasteners. She reported gradual onset of numbness in her thumb and index finger, particularly during morning shifts. On this date, the symptoms intensified to the point where she could no longer maintain her grip on components. Carmen continued working for approximately 2 hours before notifying her line lead, Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), of her symptoms. Medical evaluation at the occupational health clinic confirmed classic signs of carpal tunnel syndrome with nerve compression. The employee was placed on modified duty and referred for specialist consultation. Root cause analysis identified inadequate ergonomic assessment of the assembly station, lack of job rotation among team members, and absence of regular stretching breaks during shifts.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, injection molding operator Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171) was monitoring Injection Molding Line D when he observed excessive vibration and unusual noise from the hopper assembly. The hopper, which feeds granular polycarbonate resin into the injection molding machine, had been operating continuously for 18 hours without routine maintenance inspection. Bertrand attempted to visually inspect the hopper interior without stopping the machine or implementing lockout/tagout procedures. As he leaned toward the hopper opening, approximately 60 pounds of resin suddenly overflowed from the hopper opening, striking him on the left shoulder, arm, and upper chest. The material, heated to approximately 80°C, caused first-degree burns across the affected areas. Machine setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) immediately shut down the line and summoned medical assistance. Bertrand was treated at the facility's first aid station and later hospitalized for assessment of thermal injuries. Investigation revealed the hopper outlet valve had become partially clogged, causing material accumulation and pressure buildup.

On January 22, 2024, at approximately 06:30 during the night shift, warehouse supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) was directing operations in the Finished Goods Warehouse when he observed chemical odors emanating from Section B. Upon investigation, warehouse associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) reported that a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin hardener had been inadvertently placed on a racking unit above a stack of finished composite components without secondary containment. The drum had developed a small hairline crack, likely from stress during transport, causing approximately 8-10 liters of the corrosive hardener to leak onto the shelves below. The chemical had saturated several cardboard boxes containing finished medical-grade components and dripped onto the floor. The night shift had inadequate ventilation in that zone, and the odor had been present for an estimated 1-2 hours before discovery. Emergency response was initiated: affected inventory was isolated, chemical spill cleanup materials were deployed, and the area was ventilated. No personnel were directly exposed to the chemical, but the incident resulted in total loss of approximately $47,000 in finished goods inventory.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Production Operator Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198) was working at Injection Molding Line C when she experienced a minor laceration to her left index finger while manually removing a molded component from a cooling fixture. The part had cooled insufficiently, and as she attempted to extract it, a sharp edge on the composite mold caught her finger, creating a 2 cm laceration with minimal bleeding. A coworker, Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran (EMP-00046), immediately applied pressure with clean gauze and escorted Laila to the first aid station in the Administrative Building. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury treated the wound with antiseptic solution and applied a sterile adhesive bandage. The injury did not require stitches or further medical intervention. Root cause analysis determined that the cooling cycle timer on the Line C equipment had drifted, reducing the standard 3-minute cooling time to approximately 1.5 minutes. Laila was able to return to work the same day with modified duties. The incident highlighted the need for equipment maintenance oversight and adherence to cooling protocols.

On March 22, 2024 at 22:15 during evening shift operations, Composite Materials Operator Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174) was transferring fiber-reinforced resin batches in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area when she noticed an unusual vibration and grinding noise from one of the industrial ovens (Oven Unit 3). She immediately stopped transferring materials and relocated to a safe distance, alerting her supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015). Upon inspection, Julie discovered that the oven's circulation fan was making metal-to-metal contact due to a loose mounting bracket that had shifted approximately 1 inch from its original position. The internal fan blade was making intermittent contact with the oven housing. No personnel were in close proximity when the grinding occurred, and the oven was immediately shut down by Maintenance Technician Luc Girard who responded to the area. A cursory examination revealed that continued operation would have resulted in complete fan failure, likely causing overheating of composite materials and potential fire risk. Lina's quick recognition of the hazard and immediate action prevented what could have become a serious incident. The mounting bracket was secured with additional fasteners, and vibration testing was performed before restart. This near-miss demonstrates the value of operator awareness and rapid hazard communication.

On April 8, 2024 at 08:30 during day shift operations, Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was retrieving raw resin from the top shelf of a storage rack in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility when a 25-pound container of ABS (Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene) resin shifted and fell from approximately 6 feet above, striking her right shoulder and upper arm. The impact caused immediate acute pain and limited mobility. Mariam collapsed to the floor, and nearby colleague Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093) immediately called for medical assistance. Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne responded first and initiated basic first aid while awaiting emergency medical personnel. Paramedics arrived within 12 minutes and transported Mariam to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur in Montreal. Medical evaluation confirmed a displaced fracture of the right proximal humerus (shoulder bone) requiring surgical intervention and hospitalization for 4 days. Post-operative imaging and assessments indicated probable 6-8 week recovery period with restricted work activities. Investigation revealed that the storage rack's safety restraint straps had not been properly fastened on the top shelf, and the resin containers were stacked without intermediate shelf dividers. The facility had received new inventory the previous evening, and the receiving personnel had not followed the established shelf-loading protocol. This serious injury highlights critical deficiencies in inventory management procedures and equipment maintenance.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45 during day shift, Injection Molding Operator Céline Morin (EMP-00153) was performing routine material loading on Line A in the Production Engineering area when she noticed mold release agent residue accumulating on the machine's feed hopper. While attempting to clean the hopper with a cloth, she made skin contact with the concentrated mold release agent that had pooled in a corner of the equipment. She immediately felt burning and itching on her right palm and forearm. A coworker, Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), witnessed the incident and directed her to the emergency eyewash station. Céline washed the affected area for 5 minutes and reported the incident to Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057). Medical evaluation determined mild contact dermatitis with slight erythema. The incident was classified as a near-miss because proper PPE (nitrile gloves) were readily available but not being worn during the maintenance task. Root cause: Inadequate work practice regarding PPE compliance during cleaning operations and lack of secondary containment for chemical residue.

On March 22, 2024 at 11:20 during day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) when Receiving Clerk Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin to the mixing station. The drum slipped during transfer due to wet flooring from routine cleaning, causing it to tip and spill approximately 15 gallons of resin across the concrete floor. The spill spread across an area of approximately 12 square meters. Resin contacted the base of an electrical panel located 3 meters from the spill origin, causing visible staining and minor equipment contamination. Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was nearby and immediately notified Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136). Natasha initiated containment procedures using absorbent materials and segregated the affected area. A professional hazmat cleanup contractor was called to remove contaminated materials and decontaminate the electrical panel. Total cleanup and remediation time: 4 hours. Equipment repair costs and hazmat disposal exceeded $18,000. No personnel injuries occurred, but the spill created a slip hazard and temporary electrical equipment shutdown.

On March 28, 2024 at 23:15 during night shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) when Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) detected visible smoke emanating from a resin dryer unit in the West Wing. The dryer had been operating continuously for 18 hours processing fiber-reinforced plastic components. Temperature sensors indicated the internal chamber had reached 285°C, exceeding the safe operating range of 260°C maximum. Overheating caused thermal degradation of residual resin material inside the dryer chamber, producing acrid smoke. The facility's fire detection system automatically triggered alarms at 23:16, initiating full evacuation protocols. Emergency responders (local fire department) arrived at 23:28. Night shift maintenance technician Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) was present and assisted with orderly evacuation. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) conducted headcount verification at the assembly point. Fire department investigation determined no active fire but confirmed thermal runaway condition. The dryer was powered down and allowed to cool for 6 hours before being placed in quarantine for inspection. Root cause: Temperature controller malfunction caused the thermostat to fail at the maximum setpoint, unable to regulate cooling cycles. The malfunction went undetected due to skipped preventive maintenance checks.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), a Machine Setter on Day Shift, was adjusting the temperature controls on Injection Molding Machine 7 in Line A when hot plastic resin spilled from a partially disconnected hose coupling. The material, at approximately 210°C, contacted his right forearm and hand, causing thermal burns across an area of approximately 8 cm². Ibrahim immediately placed his arm under cold running water at the nearby safety station and notified his supervisor. Luc Girard (EMP-00039), a Maintenance Technician, arrived within 2 minutes and assessed the situation. Medical personnel arrived at 15:10 and transported Ibrahim to the on-site first aid station where second-degree burns were confirmed. The incident occurred because the hose coupling had not been properly secured after routine maintenance performed the previous evening, and Ibrahim was not wearing protective heat-resistant gloves as required by procedure. No other employees were in immediate proximity. The equipment was shut down and locked out pending investigation.

On March 18, 2024 at 22:15, during evening shift operations, an electric forklift being operated by Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), a Machine Setter on Evening Shift, struck and damaged a loaded wooden pallet rack in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). Tomas was maneuvering through the narrow aisle between rows of pallets containing finished composite medical device components when the forklift's right rear tire caught on a misaligned pallet floor edge, causing the vehicle to veer sideways. The forklift's left outer stabilizer arm collided with a supporting vertical post of a 4-tier pallet rack holding approximately 800 kg of boxed finished goods. The impact bent the vertical post by approximately 15 cm and dislodged 6 boxes from the second tier. The boxes fell but were caught by the lower tier, preventing full collapse. No personnel were in the immediate vicinity, but the potential for serious injury was high. The incident was discovered during a routine walkthrough by Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142), the Receiving Coordinator, who immediately cordoned off the area and notified management. Estimated damage to the pallet rack structure: $3,200. Estimated damage to packaging and product containment: $1,100. The root cause was inadequate aisle width combined with worn forklift tires with reduced traction and an unsecured pallet that had shifted position.

On March 22, 2024 at 02:30, during night shift operations, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician on Night Shift, was performing routine cleaning and inspection of a chemical mixing tank in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when he experienced acute respiratory distress and dizziness. The tank, used for blending polyurethane resin compounds, had been partially emptied but residual vapors remained. Although Alain consulted the chemical inventory log before beginning work, he did not follow the mandatory confined space entry protocol and did not activate the mechanical ventilation system for the area. He entered the workspace without a respirator, relying only on ambient air circulation from a ceiling fan. After approximately 8 minutes of exposure, Alain noticed chemical odor intensifying and reported feeling light-headed. He immediately exited the tank area and moved to fresh air. André Bellavance (EMP-00157), the Confined Space Entry Supervisor, was contacted at 02:45 and found Alain sitting outside with flushed skin and shortness of breath. André called emergency medical services at 02:48. Paramedics arrived at 03:05 and transported Alain to the hospital for observation. Blood oxygen levels were 88% on arrival (normal: 95-100%). Hospital assessment confirmed acute inhalation of organic solvent vapors, specifically isopropanol and acetone residue. Alain was discharged after 6 hours of oxygen therapy and observation. The root cause was failure to follow established confined space procedures despite available safeguards and inadequate understanding of hazard severity.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, injection molding technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) was operating Line D in the Main Production Building when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on a 250-ton injection molding machine failed catastrophically. The valve, which had not been serviced in 18 months despite a recommended 12-month maintenance schedule, ruptured and sprayed hot hydraulic fluid across the operator station. Gosselin sustained thermal burns on his left arm and shoulder. Machine setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), working nearby on Line C, witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. The machine was shut down and isolated. Gosselin was transported to Hôpital de Laval for treatment of second-degree burns covering approximately 8% of his body. The incident was caused by degraded seals in the pressure relief valve, which failed under normal operating pressure (2,800 PSI). Post-incident inspection revealed the hydraulic system had not received preventive maintenance as scheduled, and maintenance records showed no documentation of valve inspections since August 2022.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant fire broke out in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011) located exterior to the Chemical Storage Building. Material handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was staging empty solvent containers for disposal when she noticed smoke emanating from a collection bin containing used mold release agent-soaked rags and acetone-contaminated materials. The bin, which should have been sealed and stored in a fireproof cabinet per WHMIS protocols, was instead left open in a staging area near an electric heater used to maintain ambient temperature. An ignition source (likely from the heater's exposed heating element) ignited the volatile solvent vapors. Within minutes, flames engulfed the bin and spread to three adjacent containers of isopropanol and acetone. Mansour evacuated the area and activated the facility alarm at 10:17 PM. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) initiated emergency procedures and coordinated with Laval Fire Department. Firefighters arrived at 10:28 PM and contained the fire by 11:05 PM. The facility sustained significant damage to the storage area ($185,000 in equipment and materials destroyed), and the entire facility was evacuated for 4 hours while fire suppression systems were inspected. No injuries occurred due to proper evacuation procedures.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:10 AM during the night shift, injection molding operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) was cleaning Line A after completion of a polycarbonate production run. Per established LOTO procedures, the machine had been locked out and tagged by the previous shift supervisor. However, due to miscommunication between night shift supervisor and day shift team regarding equipment status, a maintenance work order was inadvertently created for the same machine without verification that LOTO had been properly communicated. At 6:15 AM, another operator, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), began attempting to restart the machine following what he believed were completed maintenance activities. Although Gagnon had placed warning signs on the control panel, Charbonneau bypassed the lockout device using an unauthorized bypass pin (found in the equipment cabinet). When Charbonneau pressed the start button, the carousel rotated suddenly, striking Gagnon's left hand, which was still positioned inside the part ejection area. Gagnon sustained a crush injury resulting in a fractured metacarpal bone and severe tissue damage requiring emergency orthopedic surgery at Hôpital Maisonneuve-Rosemont. The incident resulted in 42 days of lost work time and permanent reduction in hand mobility. Investigation revealed the LOTO procedures had not been followed by both operators, the bypass pin should not have been accessible, and no communication protocol existed between shifts regarding equipment status.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, injection molding operator Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159) was working at Injection Molding Line B in the Production Operations area when he attempted to clear a material jam from the hopper without properly following lockout/tagout procedures. While reaching into the hopper to dislodge compacted polypropylene resin, the machine unexpectedly cycled and activated. The rotating auger engaged, catching Duchesne's left forearm and pulling it approximately 8 inches into the hopper mechanism before a nearby operator, Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), immediately hit the emergency stop button. Duchesne sustained a second-degree thermal burn across his forearm from friction and contact with heated plastic material, measuring approximately 15 cm in length. He was transported to Laval General Hospital where he received treatment for thermal burns and soft tissue damage. The incident was witnessed by three production workers. Root cause analysis determined that the LOTO procedure was bypassed due to time pressure from production deadlines, and the machine's safety interlocks had not been tested in over 8 months.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, regrind technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on the plastic regrind processing equipment in the Composite Materials Processing Area when he noticed a partially detached electrical conduit near the motor housing. The conduit showed visible fraying of its protective sheathing and appeared to be at risk of contact with rotating equipment components. Ramirez immediately ceased operations and reported the hazard to his shift supervisor. Upon inspection, maintenance manager Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006) confirmed that the conduit was loose and that continued operation with the equipment in this state could have resulted in electrical shock or equipment malfunction. The conduit was temporarily secured with zip ties and tagged, and the equipment was taken offline pending proper repair. No employee contact with the hazard occurred. The incident was categorized as a near-miss because the hazard was identified and corrected before any personnel could be exposed to electrical danger or equipment failure. Root cause: inadequate preventive maintenance inspection protocols had allowed progressive deterioration of electrical systems to go undetected for an estimated 3-4 weeks.

On April 5, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, warehouse associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) was retrieving large spools of carbon fiber reinforcement material from the upper storage mezzanine in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop to prepare for early morning composite processing. While climbing the metal access ladder with a manifest clipboard in hand, Croteau's foot slipped on a rung approximately 4 feet above the ground level due to a light coating of hydraulic oil that had spilled from a nearby maintenance station earlier in the evening. Croteau lost his grip on the ladder rung and began to fall but managed to grab a horizontal support beam, stopping his descent after dropping approximately 2 feet. He hung from the beam for several seconds before carefully swinging himself to a nearby workbench surface and dropping the remaining distance of approximately 2 feet to the ground. Confined space entry supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) was alerted immediately and assisted Croteau. Upon initial assessment, Croteau reported experiencing minor abdominal discomfort but no significant injury. He was monitored for 30 minutes and reported feeling stable. This incident was classified as a near-miss because while Croteau prevented a serious fall-to-ground impact through his own physical intervention, the conditions that created the hazard—slippery ladder rungs combined with compromised visibility during night shift—remained present and could have caused serious injury to another worker.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a significant spill occurred in the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006). Mei Zhang, Quality Control Inspector (EMP-00068), was conducting routine testing of molded parts using a 5-liter container of acetone-based cleaning solvent. While transferring the solution between containers, the primary container slipped from her hands due to inadequate grip on the wet exterior surface and fell onto the concrete floor, fracturing and spilling approximately 3 liters of acetone across the lab workspace and into an adjacent hallway. The spill created a visible wet hazard covering approximately 200 square feet. Immediate response included evacuation of the lab area, ventilation system activation, and containment using absorbent materials. No personnel were injured in the incident, but approximately $2,400 in damaged equipment (analytical balance, sample holders) and $800 in contaminated materials resulted from the spill exposure. The incident was discovered within minutes by Richard Beaulieu (Tool Room Supervisor, EMP-00043) who was passing through the adjacent hallway and immediately alerted safety personnel. Anh Nguyen (Safety Officer, EMP-00007) initiated the incident response protocol and coordinated cleanup operations.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a serious burn injury occurred at Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging production area (UNIT-004). Bruno Landry, Injection Molding Operator on Line D (EMP-00083), was performing routine mold temperature verification when he inadvertently made contact with an exposed hot mold surface temperature measuring approximately 285°C (545°F). The mold had been in active production for 6 hours without breaks, and the thermal warning labels had deteriorated and become illegible due to repeated heat exposure and acetone vapor contact over the past month. Bruno's right forearm made direct contact with the mold surface for approximately 2-3 seconds before he withdrew. He sustained a severe thermal burn covering approximately 15 cm x 8 cm of the forearm with partial-thickness burn characteristics. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) was immediately notified and initiated first aid protocols, applying cool water irrigation for 20 minutes. Emergency medical services were called at 10:52 PM, and Bruno was transported to the Regional Burn Center via ambulance. He was hospitalized for 5 days and required specialized burn care and wound management. The incident was declared by Zahra Nasri (Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, EMP-00168) following hospital notification protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at 3:30 AM during the night shift, the primary cooling water circulation system serving Injection Molding Lines C and D experienced catastrophic equipment failure in the main production building. The system's centrifugal pump bearing seized due to accumulated mineral deposits and inadequate maintenance intervals, causing the pump to lock up and creating a water pressure surge in the circulation piping. This pressure spike ruptured a corroded 2-inch supply line at a connection point near UNIT-004, releasing approximately 200 gallons of cooling water and 15 gallons of hydraulic coolant additive onto the production floor. The leak cascaded through the facility's electrical conduit trays, creating a hazardous electrical situation. Night shift supervisor Raymond Tessier (Crane Operator, EMP-00143) immediately shut down Lines C and D and initiated emergency protocols. The facility's automatic water detection system activated, shutting off the main water supply. Cleanup required 18 hours and involved removal of 40 cubic meters of water-saturated materials, decontamination of electrical equipment, and temporary production shutdown. Estimated equipment damage totaled $156,000 (pump replacement, line repair, electrical panel restoration) plus $48,000 in lost production capacity for a 36-hour manufacturing halt. The incident was declared by Natasha Ivanov (Chemical Inventory Specialist, EMP-00136) who coordinated environmental compliance notification due to coolant discharge.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a Production Operator, was working on Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging section when the hydraulic cooling system experienced a catastrophic failure. A high-pressure hydraulic hose coupling fractured without warning, spraying pressurized cooling fluid at approximately 95°C across the operator's left arm and torso. The fluid penetrated her protective apron and caused second-degree thermal burns across approximately 15% of her left forearm and shoulder area. Naomi immediately reported the incident to her supervisor, Sébastien Carrier (EMP-00065), who activated first aid protocols and called emergency services. The line was immediately shut down via emergency stop. A maintenance inspection revealed the coupling had corroded internally due to inadequate coolant filtration and had never been replaced since the machine's installation in 2019. The incident exposed systemic failures in preventive maintenance scheduling for high-temperature hydraulic systems. Naomi was transported to the hospital and treated for thermal burns, requiring hospitalization for three days.

On November 9, 2024, at approximately 10:47 PM during the evening shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a significant pinch point injury while performing routine material handling. While transferring a large resin storage container from a pallet to the molding station using a two-person lift with Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), the container shifted unexpectedly and trapped Paul's right hand between the container edge and the metal support frame of the injection machine. Paul's middle and ring fingers were caught, resulting in crush injuries with significant swelling, bruising, and suspected fractures. Jacques immediately freed Paul's hand and alerted supervisor Guillaume Deschamps (EMP-00051). First aid was administered on-site, and Paul was transported to the hospital where X-rays confirmed two fractured fingers. Root cause analysis revealed that the storage container lacked proper handles and that no mechanical assist device (such as a pneumatic or hydraulic lift) was available in the production area, forcing operators to perform manual lifts of 35-40 pound containers.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 8:32 AM during the day shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, experienced a minor chemical splash incident in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. While transferring epoxy resin from a bulk storage drum to smaller dispensing containers, a colleague, Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042), accidentally bumped the transfer hose, causing a small amount (approximately 50 mL) of epoxy resin to splash onto Rania's right hand and forearm. Despite wearing chemical-resistant gloves, a small amount made contact with exposed skin near the wrist area where the glove had slipped down. Rania immediately moved to the emergency eyewash station and began rinsing her skin with water and mild soap as per facility protocol. Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), the Environmental Compliance Specialist, was nearby and assisted with first aid procedures. The affected area showed mild irritation and redness but no severe burns. Rania was evaluated by the on-site first aid attendant and treated with topical antihistamine. The incident was documented as a first aid case requiring only local wound care and observation. Root cause: Inadequate spacing around the transfer station and insufficient bumpers to prevent hose displacement.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, was operating Injection Molding Machine #12 in the main production area when the machine's hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned. The valve, which had not been serviced since January 2023, failed to release excess pressure during a standard molding cycle. This caused the mold clamping mechanism to remain in a partially open state while internal pressure continued to build. When Pascal attempted to manually open the mold to retrieve a part that appeared stuck, the sudden release of built-up hydraulic pressure forced the mold halves together with extreme force, striking his right hand and causing a crush injury to his index and middle fingers. Daniel Kim (EMP-00025), the Electrical Maintenance Technician, was working nearby and immediately shut down the machine and called for emergency response. Pascal was transported to Laval General Hospital with suspected fractures and soft tissue damage. The incident was attributed to deferred maintenance on critical safety components.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift, Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), a Machine Setter, was working in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop preparing a custom injection mold for the next production run. She was manually grinding sharp edges on a fabricated mold component using a hand-held rotary grinder without wearing cut-resistant gloves, as required by company procedure. At approximately 10:20 PM, the rotating grinding wheel caught the edge of her left hand, causing a laceration across her palm and fingers. Luc Girard (EMP-00039), a Maintenance Technician on the evening shift, heard her cry out and immediately stopped the machine and applied first aid using a first aid kit. The wound required 8 stitches at the urgent care clinic. Post-incident investigation revealed that the required PPE had been removed to improve "dexterity" on what Svetlana believed was a low-risk task. The incident was classified as a violation of established PPE procedures.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift, Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), the Warehouse Lead, was manually unloading finished composite material parts from a pallet in the Finished Goods Warehouse. The parts were stacked in a high pyramid configuration (approximately 1.8 meters tall) that had been arranged the previous day. As Normand reached for a part near the top of the stack without proper stabilization, the pyramid became unstable. Several large composite panels weighing approximately 15 kg each fell from the stack, striking Normand on his left shoulder, back, and left leg. Georges Plante (EMP-00179), a Facilities Technician also present in the warehouse, immediately provided first aid and called for emergency response. Normand was transported to hospital with contusions, a suspected sprain of the left shoulder, and bruising along his back. Root cause analysis indicated that the previous shift had not followed proper pallet stacking procedures outlined in the Material Management SOP, and the stack exceeded recommended height limits for unstable composite parts.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a forklift operated by Yvon Croteau was moving a pallet of polycarbonate resin from the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) to the Main Production Building when the load shifted unexpectedly on the uneven floor surface near the loading dock transition. The pallet, weighing approximately 2,800 lbs, tipped sideways and struck a wall-mounted chemical storage cabinet and a wooden support beam used for material staging. The impact caused significant structural damage to the cabinet mounting hardware, denting the cabinet doors, and cracking the wooden beam at the connection point. Several resin bags fell from the pallet, with one tearing open and spilling approximately 50 lbs of virgin polypropylene pellets across the dock area. Yvon immediately stopped operations and alerted the warehouse supervisor Roland Dostie, who called in maintenance. The incident was witnessed by Carmen Lopez, an assembly operator passing through the area. No personnel injuries occurred, but the material handling infrastructure sustained damage requiring repair estimates totaling $8,500. The root cause was inadequate floor maintenance and lack of proper load securing procedures during transfer operations.

On April 8, 2024 at 6:15 PM during the evening shift, Elena Popescu, a Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent (containing mineral oil and silicone additives) from the bulk storage tank into smaller 5-liter containers for production line distribution at the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Due to a combination of factors—inadequate ventilation in the mixing area, a cracked transfer hose connection that was not visible during inspection, and improper grounding of the metal containers—approximately 12 liters of the mold release agent leaked onto the concrete floor before the rupture was detected. The spill created a slippery hazard across an estimated 150 square feet and released volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors, triggering the facility's fume detection alarm after approximately 8 minutes. Elena immediately shut down the transfer operation and notified Brigitte Mathieu, the Incident Investigation Specialist, who activated the chemical spill response protocol. The area was cordoned off and absorbent materials were deployed. Testing indicated VOC concentrations reached 340 ppm near the spill source (threshold limit: 300 ppm TWA). Cleanup and remediation required 3 hours of work by two maintenance technicians wearing Level C PPE. No personnel health effects were reported, but the incident resulted in lost production time and required disposal of contaminated absorbent materials at a cost of $2,100. Root cause analysis identified inadequate hose inspection procedures and insufficient ventilation system maintenance.

On May 22, 2024 at 11:20 AM during the day shift, Christian Gosselin, an Injection Molding Technician, was operating a 250-ton Engel injection molding machine (Machine #14) in the Main Production Building when he noticed unusual vibration and a grinding noise emanating from the hydraulic pump assembly. Christian attempted to make a minor pressure adjustment via the control panel, but the hydraulic pressure spiked suddenly to 285 bar (45 bar above operating specification), triggering an emergency shutdown. Upon inspection by the maintenance team led by Roland Dostie and Viktor Novak (Electrical Technician), they discovered that the main hydraulic pump's internal gears had suffered catastrophic wear, resulting in metal shavings circulating through the hydraulic fluid and damaging multiple seals and valve components. The pump had been in continuous operation for 18,200 hours since the last major overhaul (scheduled interval was 15,000 hours). The equipment failure caused a complete production halt for that machine, affecting output on a critical automotive component contract. Preliminary assessment indicated damage to the pump motor, pressure relief valve, and several hoses, with total replacement parts cost estimated at $67,000 plus $12,000 in labor for rebuilding and testing. The machine remained out of service for 8 days. Priya Sharma, the Industrial Engineer, documented the incident and notified Alain Mercier for safety assessment. No injuries occurred, but the incident represented a significant operational and financial loss due to deferred maintenance and insufficient condition monitoring.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a serious burn injury in the Main Production Building. Sofia was performing routine mold temperature checks on a 300-ton injection molding machine when she inadvertently touched a hot mold surface that had reached 185°C. The mold's thermal insulation wrap had partially degraded, exposing the heated metal. Sofia immediately withdrew her hand but sustained second-degree thermal burns across her palm and three fingers. She was unable to continue work and was transported to the on-site first aid station where initial treatment was administered. The incident was witnessed by Yuki Yamamoto (EMP-00112), the Process Improvement Engineer, who was conducting equipment efficiency observations nearby. The injury required immediate cooling, sterile dressing, and pain management, with Sofia requiring three weeks of medical leave and modified duty work upon return. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate preventive maintenance of thermal insulation systems and insufficient worker awareness of hot surface hazards despite training.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), a Material Handler in the Warehouse and Shipping facility, sustained a significant back injury while manually lifting resin bags. In the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008), Bianca was preparing shipments when she attempted to lift a 25 kg bag of polypropylene resin from a pallet positioned at knee height using improper technique. She bent at the waist with straight legs rather than using proper squat lifting form, and as she lifted, she felt acute lower back pain radiating to her left leg. Bianca immediately reported the injury to her supervisor Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133), the Facilities Manager, who assessed the situation and provided immediate first aid support. The pain was severe enough to prevent continued work. Luc Girard (EMP-00039), a Maintenance Technician present for equipment checks, witnessed the incident and assisted with moving Bianca to the break room for rest and ice application. The employee required emergency medical evaluation, was diagnosed with acute lumbar strain with possible disc involvement, and was placed on modified duty for six weeks. The incident occurred during a period of understaffing and increased production demand.

On March 10, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173), a Tool Room Technician, sustained a minor laceration to his left hand while handling glass fiber composite materials in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025). While retrieving a bundle of pre-cut glass fiber sheets from the storage mezzanine, Raynald accidentally brushed his palm against an exposed edge of the composite material. The sharp edges of the glass fiber, which had not been properly deburred or wrapped, caused a superficial cut approximately 2 cm long on his palm. Raynald immediately washed the wound with soap and water and reported to the first aid station where Indira Singh (EMP-00104), a Quality Auditor who was conducting equipment verification nearby, assisted him. The wound was cleaned, inspected for embedded glass fibers, treated with antiseptic ointment, and covered with a sterile bandage. No embedded fibers were discovered. The injury required only basic first aid treatment with no need for medical leave or time away from regular duties. Raynald was able to return to work immediately after treatment with instructions to keep the wound dry and monitor for signs of infection.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a hydraulic hose failure occurred on Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building North Zone. Operator Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109) was performing routine mold changeover when the primary hydraulic line connecting the injection unit ruptured without warning. Pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the work station, damaging electrical control panels, soaking insulation materials on adjacent equipment, and contaminating approximately 200 pounds of raw polypropylene resin inventory staged nearby. The fluid also leaked onto the concrete floor, creating a slippery surface hazard. Quick-thinking supervisor Paul Demers (EMP-00103) immediately shut down the line using the emergency stop button and activated the spill containment protocol. The maintenance team arrived within 15 minutes and confined the spill using absorbent pads and designated waste containers. Total equipment downtime: 6 hours. Root cause analysis revealed the hose had reached end-of-service life (7 years in operation) and lacked scheduled replacement in the predictive maintenance program. The incident resulted in approximately $47,000 in equipment damage, lost productivity costs, and environmental remediation.

On April 3, 2024 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) suffered a lost-time injury while retrieving raw material from high-level storage racks in the Materials Management and Warehousing area. While attempting to access a box of glass-filled nylon on the third tier (approximately 10 feet high), the load suddenly shifted and fell, striking Hébert on the left shoulder and upper arm. The impact caused him to lose balance and fall approximately 4 feet from a mobile ladder onto concrete flooring below, resulting in a fractured left humerus and left shoulder dislocation. Emergency services arrived at 11:32 PM and transported Hébert to Hôpital de la Cité in Laval. He underwent emergency reduction and orthopedic surgery that evening. The incident was witnessed by night shift supervisor Omar Said (EMP-00122), who immediately initiated emergency protocols and documented the scene. Investigation revealed the load had been improperly secured on the rack during the day shift, with inadequate strapping for a 45-pound box positioned precariously at the shelf edge. The box had partially shifted during ambient vibration from nearby forklift traffic. Hébert was hospitalized for 3 days and subsequently placed on medical leave for 12 weeks during recovery.

On February 22, 2024 at 9:20 AM during the day shift, Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran (EMP-00046) sustained a first-aid level laceration while inspecting finished parts on Line C at the Injection Molding Line D facility. While handling polycarbonate components for dimensional verification, Tran's right index finger came into contact with a sharp edge burr on the part's ejection gate interface—an area typically removed during the standard deburring process but overlooked during a production run of medical-grade housings. The burr created a 1.5-inch laceration on the lateral aspect of the finger, resulting in minor bleeding but no structural damage. Tran immediately notified supervisor Daniel Turgeon (EMP-00137), who provided first aid using the workplace medical station: wound cleansing, antibiotic ointment application, and sterile bandaging. No sutures were required. The injury was documented in the workplace health log and Tran was able to continue work with modified duty, wearing protective gloves for the remainder of the shift. The incident prompted an immediate halt of the affected production batch (143 units) for comprehensive deburring inspection. Root cause analysis identified that the deburring machine on that line had experienced a calibration drift, causing incomplete removal of excess plastic material.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45 during the day shift, a fire alarm was accidentally triggered in the Composite Materials Processing Area (Main Production Building - West Wing). An assembly operator, Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176), was performing routine maintenance on an industrial oven used for post-processing composite materials. While cleaning the oven's exterior ventilation louvers with compressed air, she inadvertently directed a burst of air toward the ceiling-mounted heat sensor array. The sudden temperature fluctuation from the compressed air stream was misinterpreted by the automated fire detection system as a rapid heat increase, causing the alarm to activate at 14:47. The facility's fire suppression system did not engage, but the alarm triggered an immediate evacuation of the west wing affecting approximately 35 employees. Production on three active composite curing lines was halted. Emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed no actual fire hazard. The alarm was reset at 15:12. The incident highlighted inadequate positioning of heat sensors near potential sources of false triggers and insufficient training on equipment maintenance procedures in proximity to safety systems.

On April 2, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop located in the Maintenance Workshop Tool Room. The incident began when Richard Beaulieu (EMP-00043), Tool Room Supervisor, and two maintenance technicians were conducting routine CNC milling machine inspections following a predictive maintenance alert. While cleaning accumulated plastic dust from machine coolant lines using a high-pressure water spray attachment, pressurized coolant mist was inadvertently sprayed across electrical junction boxes mounted above the workstation. The moisture contacted exposed copper contacts on a terminal strip, causing a brief electrical arc and triggering the thermal sensor in an adjacent smoke detector at 22:17. The fire alarm activated, initiating facility-wide evacuation protocols and alerting emergency services. Firefighters arrived at 22:28 and confirmed the arc was isolated with no fire risk, though the electrical box required inspection and drying. Production resumed at 23:45 after electrical systems were verified. The incident revealed inadequate protection of electrical infrastructure from liquid spray during routine maintenance in the tool room environment where moisture is frequently present.

On March 28, 2024 at 09:30 during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area within the dedicated hazardous materials building. Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of unsaturated polyester resin from storage rack section C-4 to the mixing station using a drum dolly. The storage rack, installed in 2018 and last inspected 18 months prior, had two corroded anchor bolts connecting it to the concrete floor. As Diallo maneuvered the dolly toward the exit, vibrations from the uneven floor surface caused the rack to shift. The top shelf, containing three drums of epoxy resin and one drum of styrene monomer, destabilized and tipped forward. All four drums fell, with one styrene monomer drum (approximately 45 liters) rupturing on impact at 09:32. Approximately 35-40 liters of styrene spilled across the floor, with 8-10 liters flowing toward the floor drain. The volatile liquid created a strong chemical vapor cloud affecting the immediate work area. Diallo immediately activated the emergency response protocol, evacuating the area and activating the overhead alarm system. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) and the facility safety team arrived within 4 minutes. The spill was contained using commercial absorbent materials within 18 minutes, and the contaminated area was sealed. Air quality monitoring showed styrene vapor levels peaked at 145 ppm (OSHA PEL: 100 ppm) in the immediate vicinity before natural ventilation reduced it to 62 ppm by 10:15. No employees required medical attention, though four workers experienced eye and respiratory irritation during evacuation. Environmental assessment determined approximately 12 liters entered the municipal drain system before containment. External remediation and regulatory reporting were initiated. Root cause analysis identified structural fatigue of anchor bolts, inadequate rack maintenance scheduling, and insufficient verification of floor levelness in the chemical storage area.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, production operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) was working at Injection Molding Line B when she attempted to remove a finished part from the mold. The part had sharp flash edges from the injection process. While extracting the component, her right hand came into contact with the sharp edge, causing a laceration to her palm and fingers. The operator was wearing standard nitrile gloves which provided minimal protection against the sharp molded edges. She immediately reported the injury to her supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot. First aid was administered at the on-site medical station, including wound cleaning, antiseptic application, and bandaging. The injury required 5 stitches and did not result in lost work time. Investigation revealed that the mold's edge finishing process had been skipped due to production schedule pressure, leaving dangerous sharp edges on multiple parts in the batch.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift, mold maintenance technician Réjan Simard (EMP-00077) was working in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop on a complex cavity maintenance task. He was operating a CNC milling machine to precision-finish a cavity insert when his left hand came into contact with the rotating cutting tool. The high-speed spindle caught his left index finger, causing a deep laceration and partial amputation of the fingertip. Simard immediately shut down the machine and applied pressure to the wound with a cloth. Machine setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), who was setting up an adjacent machine, heard his cry and quickly called the on-site nurse and emergency response. The severed fingertip was recovered and placed in ice. Emergency medical personnel arrived and transported Simard to the regional trauma center within 18 minutes. Despite surgical intervention, the fingertip could not be successfully reattached. Investigation revealed the machine's guard had been partially removed earlier in the week to accommodate a specific part dimension and had not been reinstalled. Additionally, Simard was not wearing required cut-resistant gloves, having removed them because he felt they reduced his tactile sensitivity for precision work.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Raoul Blanchard, a Machine Operator on the day shift, sustained a significant back injury while manually removing finished composite parts from Injection Molding Line A. The employee was performing his routine task of extracting cured plastic components from the molding press when he attempted to lift a 22-kg batch of parts without using the mechanical assist hoist available at the workstation. According to witnesses, Blanchard had worked through his scheduled break and appeared fatigued. As he lifted the heavy parts with an awkward twisting motion, he immediately reported sharp lower back pain and fell to the ground. He was unable to stand unassisted and was transported to the hospital by ambulance. Emergency imaging revealed a herniated disc at L4-L5 requiring surgical intervention. The employee was unable to return to work for 12 weeks, resulting in a lost-time injury. Investigation revealed that the mechanical assist hoist had been out of service for maintenance for three days, and no temporary lifting device had been provided as a substitute.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Lidia Fernandes, Quality Inspector, experienced a chemical eye splash while conducting quality control testing in the composite materials laboratory located in the Administrative Building. While mixing a batch of resin hardener for material samples, the container cap became loose due to improper seating, causing approximately 50 mL of liquid epoxy resin to splash into her face and eyes. Although Fernandes was wearing safety glasses, the chemical contacted her eyes around the lens edges. She immediately flushed her eyes at the emergency eyewash station for 15 minutes per protocol. A coworker called emergency services as a precaution. She was transported to the local hospital where she was evaluated for chemical conjunctivitis and corneal irritation. The employee received treatment including topical anesthetic drops and antibacterial ointment, and was released after 4 hours of observation. She returned to work the following day but reported continued eye irritation and sensitivity to light for three days. Root cause analysis identified that the chemical container was not properly sealed during storage, and the eyewash station had not been inspected in 8 months.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during the night shift, Alain Gravel, Maintenance Technician, sustained a serious laceration and partial finger amputation while performing emergency maintenance on a malfunctioning plastic granule hopper in the Composite Materials Processing Area. The hopper discharge mechanism had become jammed, preventing material flow. Gravel was attempting to manually clear the blockage by reaching into the discharge chute with a clearing rod when the hopper's automatic vibration motor unexpectedly restarted without warning. The restart was triggered by a timer override on the control panel that had not been communicated to maintenance personnel. Gravel's left index and middle fingers were caught between the vibrating hopper wall and discharge mechanism, resulting in deep lacerations and partial amputation of the index finger at the second joint. The employee immediately removed his hand and applied pressure using his work glove. A coworker called emergency services. Gravel was transported to the regional hospital where he underwent emergency surgery to reattach the partially severed finger. He was hospitalized for 48 hours and placed on medical leave for 8 weeks, constituting a lost-time injury with permanent disability implications.

On March 15, 2025 at 2:45 PM, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), an Injection Molding Technician on the day shift, was operating Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone when he noticed the hopper feed system was jamming. Following established procedures, he initiated a lockout of the machine and began troubleshooting. While investigating the blockage in the resin feed line, Patrick discovered a foreign object (a plastic tie-wrap) lodged in the intake valve. He attempted to dislodge it manually without fully verifying that the lockout was complete. Suddenly, the feed auger motor engaged unexpectedly, causing the rotating screw inside the hopper to activate. Patrick's left hand came into contact with the spinning auger, but he reflexively withdrew his hand within 1-2 seconds. The incident was immediately stopped when co-worker Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) hit the emergency stop button. Patrick sustained minor lacerations and abrasions to his left palm and fingers but no fractures or deep tissue damage. First aid was administered on-site, and the incident was reported to the HSE office within 15 minutes. Investigation revealed that the lockout procedure had not been fully engaged because the motor contactor had not been physically locked out with a hasp.

On March 28, 2025 at 9:30 PM during the evening shift, Yuki Yamamoto (EMP-00112), a Process Improvement Engineer, was conducting a routine quality assessment in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017). While measuring the temperature of parts exiting the heat treatment oven using a non-contact infrared thermometer, Yuki reached across a hot resin mixing station to access a data logging device mounted on the wall. His forearm made brief contact (approximately 1-2 seconds) with a heated composite material curing tray that was maintained at 145°C (293°F). The contact area measured approximately 4 inches by 2 inches on his right forearm. Although the contact was brief, the high temperature caused the surface layer of skin to turn red with slight blistering beginning to form. Yuki immediately ran cool water over the affected area for approximately 10 minutes and reported the incident to his supervisor, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092). First aid was applied with cool compresses and topical salve, and the wound was covered with sterile gauze. Yuki did not require hospitalization, but the incident was classified as a near-miss because only superficial thermal burns occurred rather than deep tissue damage that could have resulted from longer contact or higher temperature exposure. The root cause was identified as inadequate workspace organization and lack of clear demarcation of high-temperature equipment zones.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, injection molding operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103) was removing finished parts from Molding Machine #18 in the Main Production Building when he contacted hot plastic material still cooling in the mold cavity. The machine had cycled faster than normal due to a recent parameter adjustment, and the cooling time was insufficient. Demers did not wait the full cycle time before opening the mold guard. He sustained second-degree thermal burns to his right palm and inner fingers. The employee immediately reported the burn to supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101), who applied cold water and contacted first aid. Demers was transported to the on-site medical station and subsequently to Hôpital Cité-de-la-Santé for treatment. The incident occurred because the machine's temperature sensor had drifted, causing accelerated cycles without corresponding cooling adjustments. No machine guarding failure was identified; this was operator error combined with inadequate monitoring of cycle parameters.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire hazard was discovered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-005 area). Warehouse staff member Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) noticed a significant accumulation of plastic powder dust on horizontal surfaces, overhead pipes, and ventilation equipment in the resin compound preparation area. The dust layer ranged from 2-5mm in depth across approximately 150 square meters. The facility had experienced a recent expansion of medical device production capacity, which doubled the volume of resin processing, but the ventilation system had not been correspondingly upgraded, and cleaning schedules had not been adjusted. A combustible dust atmosphere existed with multiple ignition sources nearby (hot equipment surfaces, electrical connections). Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) was immediately notified and the area was evacuated as a precautionary measure. The ventilation system was shut down to prevent dust resuspension, and the area was manually cleaned under controlled conditions over the following 18 hours. No fire or explosion occurred, but the potential was extremely high. CNESST regulations classify this as a serious fire hazard violation.

On February 22, 2024, at approximately 5:50 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Tool room technician Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173) was performing routine maintenance on an overhead crane system above the material storage area. He had initiated a Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedure and believed he had properly isolated all power sources to the crane's electric hoist motor. However, a secondary backup power line connected through a different circuit breaker panel—not clearly documented in the equipment manual—remained energized. When Vézina attempted to manually lower a test load using hand cranks, the main motor suddenly engaged and began raising the load at full speed. Vézina immediately stepped back and shouted a warning to the night shift supervisor Diego Morales (EMP-00056), who activated the emergency stop button. The crane halted within 2 seconds. The test load (approximately 200 kg) had risen 1.2 meters before stopping. No one was directly under the load at the moment of unintended activation, and no impact injuries occurred. However, if the load had dropped or collided with personnel below, a critical injury or fatality would have resulted. The incident revealed deficiencies in LOTO procedure documentation and inadequate labeling of the secondary power circuit. This was classified as a serious near-miss with potential for catastrophic outcomes.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024) was operating Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building when the hydraulic cooling system developed a sudden leak. As Yasmin attempted to manually adjust a coolant valve on the starboard side of the 250-ton molding machine, pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed directly onto her right forearm and hand, causing immediate thermal and chemical burns. The high-pressure fluid, estimated at 180°C, penetrated through her standard latex glove. Yasmin immediately removed her glove and immersed her arm in ice water from a nearby station sink. Assembly Lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) responded immediately, calling emergency services. The facility's emergency eyewash and shower station was activated as a precaution. Paramedics arrived within 8 minutes and transported Yasmin to Hôpital Pierre-Boucher in Longueuil for treatment of second-degree thermal and chemical burns covering approximately 15% of her right upper extremity. The incident was witnessed by Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) who was restocking resin bins nearby. Root cause investigation revealed the hydraulic hose had experienced micro-fracturing due to improper maintenance scheduling and failure to replace hoses on the recommended 5-year interval. The machine had not received scheduled preventive maintenance for 18 months.
