On April 2, 2024, at 10:45 AM during day shift, Assembly Operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) was performing manual finishing work on medical device components in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005). Diego was removing excess flashing from precision-molded components using a hand-held finishing tool when he experienced a sudden sharp pain in his right wrist. Over the following three days, despite self-medication with over-the-counter pain relievers, the pain intensified and swelling developed. On April 5, 2024, Diego reported the injury to his supervisor and visited the occupational health clinic, where X-rays revealed a hairline fracture of the scaphoid bone in his right wrist. Medical examination and MRI imaging confirmed severe inflammation consistent with repetitive strain combined with acute trauma. Diego was placed on modified duty restriction and prescribed a custom wrist brace. The employee was unable to perform assembly work for 6 weeks, resulting in a lost-time injury. Root cause analysis revealed that Diego performs approximately 1,200 repetitive gripping and flexion motions daily, with inadequate ergonomic workstation design. His workbench height was 3 inches too high, forcing constant wrist extension. Additionally, assembly tool design required excessive grip force. No formal break schedule was enforced, and ergonomic assessments had not been conducted in 14 months. Quality Documentation Specialist Gabrielle Levesque (EMP-00095) witnessed the initial injury reporting process.

On May 18, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was operating an electric forklift in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) to retrieve pallets of waste plastic material for processing. As Elif maneuvered the forklift near Storage Rack Section C-7, the left front wheel struck a recessed floor drain that had been left uncovered by maintenance personnel following a water system cleaning. The sudden drop of approximately 4 inches caused the forklift's main hydraulic cylinder to strike the overhead conveyor system structure. The collision severed the main hydraulic hose, causing a complete hydraulic fluid leak of approximately 45 gallons onto the concrete floor. The forklift became immobilized with its load of approximately 2,400 pounds of regrind material suspended 6 feet in the air. Elif immediately dismounted the vehicle and activated the emergency alert system. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) was called to the scene. The hydraulic spill created a significant slip hazard across the 2,000-square-foot section. Emergency response procedures were activated; the area was cordoned off with hazard tape, and environmental cleanup contractors were called to address the hazardous fluid spill. The forklift remained inoperable for 18 hours pending complete hydraulic system replacement. Estimated repair costs exceeded $47,000 including parts, labor, environmental remediation, and operational downtime. Root cause was inadequate floor inspection protocols and incomplete communication between maintenance and operations regarding hazard locations.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45, Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) reported to Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur concerning a near-miss incident that occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) during the day shift. While operating the material hopper feeder system for the composite resin preparation line, Yilmaz noticed excessive vibration and unusual grinding noises emanating from the motor assembly. Rather than continuing operations, the employee immediately powered down the equipment and notified maintenance. Upon inspection, the coupling between the motor and the drying drum was found to be severely worn with visible metal shavings in the lubricant reservoir. The bearing races showed signs of imminent failure. Had the equipment continued operating, catastrophic failure could have resulted in sudden equipment shutdown, potential material spill, or injury from flying debris. This preventive identification prevented a significant safety incident and equipment damage estimated at $35,000. The incident was documented as a positive safety intervention demonstrating the effectiveness of worker awareness training.

On November 18, 2024, at 22:15, Production Operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) was operating Injection Molding Line D during the night shift when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the molding press (a critical safety component) suddenly failed. The valve, designed to protect the system from over-pressure conditions, had been in service for 8 years without replacement. A hairline fracture in the valve body, invisible during routine inspections, propagated under cyclic pressure stress. When pressure exceeded the set point of 2,200 PSI, the fractured valve could not properly vent excess pressure. Hydraulic fluid began leaking at an alarming rate, creating a slippery hazard on the production floor and reducing system pressure unpredictably. The mold clamp cylinders began to operate erratically, moving with unexpected force. Mensah managed to initiate emergency stop procedures before serious injury occurred. The incident revealed a critical maintenance gap: relief valves had never been subjected to preventive replacement protocols despite manufacturers recommending replacement every 5-7 years.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, during the day shift, a chemical storage container malfunction occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was transferring acetone solvent from a 55-gallon drum into smaller working containers using a manual pump system. Due to improper coupling connection and inadequate secondary containment verification, approximately 12 liters of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor before the leak was detected. The spill occurred near the open mixing area where three additional employees were present. Acetone vapors immediately became noticeable, triggering concern about ventilation adequacy. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury responded within 5 minutes, implemented emergency containment protocols, evacuated non-essential personnel, and activated the spill cleanup procedure. No personal contact with the chemical occurred, but the incident exposed the need for improved transfer procedures and secondary containment systems. The spill was fully contained and cleaned within 45 minutes. Investigation revealed the pump coupling was worn and the secondary containment basin had accumulated debris that compromised its capacity.

On March 18, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Injection Molding Line C (Medical Components) experienced a critical equipment failure. Production Operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was monitoring the automated injection sequence when the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned, causing sudden pressure loss in the mold clamping system. The mold opened unexpectedly mid-cycle, ejecting a partially solidified polycarbonate component with force. The component struck the protective cage of the machine, ricocheted, and struck the adjacent work station monitor, shattering the screen. The operator was not directly struck but experienced sudden alarm and stress from the unexpected ejection. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) responded and immediately shut down the line through emergency stop procedures. Investigation revealed the relief valve had not been serviced in 18 months despite a required 12-month maintenance schedule. Pressure gauges had not been calibrated in over 2 years. The failure caused $6,200 in equipment damage including the monitor, and resulted in 6 hours of production downtime on a critical medical device line.

On March 22, 2024 at 08:30 during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103) working on Line A (Automotive) sustained a significant burn injury. While performing mold cleaning operations between production cycles, the operator attempted to manually wipe the hot mold surface (approximately 120°C) without sufficient cooling time. The production schedule was behind, and supervisory pressure encouraged rapid cycle times. The operator was wearing standard nitrile gloves rather than heat-resistant gloves. Contact with the mold surface for approximately 3 seconds caused second-degree thermal burns across the palm and three fingers of the right hand. The operator immediately reported the injury to Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104), who initiated first aid and contacted EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury. The employee received on-site first aid but required transport to the hospital emergency department for assessment and burn treatment. Medical evaluation confirmed partial-thickness burns requiring 8 weeks of healing and 5 days of lost work time. The incident exposed insufficient cooling protocols, inadequate PPE specifications, and production pressure overriding safety procedures.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D when he noticed excessive vibration in the hydraulic pump assembly. While inspecting the equipment with the machine in standby mode (not locked out), he observed a small hydraulic fluid leak near a connection fitting. As he reached toward the fitting with a wrench to tighten it, the pump suddenly reactivated due to a timer-controlled cycle that he was unaware of. The sudden movement of the rotating coupling came within approximately 2 inches of his hand, which would have caused severe laceration or amputation had contact occurred. Pascal immediately withdrew his hand and activated the emergency stop button. Production Supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) arrived within seconds and properly shut down and locked out the equipment per LOTO procedures. No contact was made and no injury occurred, but the near-miss demonstrated a critical gap in pre-maintenance communication and equipment energy isolation protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Gabrielle Levesque (EMP-00095), a Quality Documentation Specialist, was organizing batch records in the warehouse storage area when she accidentally cut her left index finger on the sharp edge of a cardboard box containing medical device components. The cut was approximately 1 inch long and caused minor bleeding. She immediately reported to the on-site first aid station where Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) cleaned and bandaged the wound. The cut required topical antibiotic ointment and a sterile adhesive bandage but did not require stitches or medical attention beyond first aid. Gabrielle was able to continue her duties after a 15-minute treatment and observation period. The incident was documented in the first aid log and the employee was advised to monitor the wound for signs of infection.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 9:30 PM during the evening shift, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, was transporting a pallet of raw plastic resin materials from the receiving dock to the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). While maneuvering the forklift through a narrow aisle, the left front wheel struck an air hose that was coiled on the floor near a maintenance work area. The sudden obstacle caused the forklift to jolt, and the pallet load (approximately 1,500 lbs of resin) shifted forward. Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on evening shift who was working nearby, was struck on his right leg by the corner of the pallet as it shifted. Abdul sustained a laceration approximately 2 inches long on his right shin, causing significant bleeding. He was immediately transported to the facility's first aid station where Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), the Safety Officer, provided emergency first aid including wound cleaning, pressure dressing, and wound closure with adhesive strips. However, the depth and location of the laceration necessitated external medical evaluation. Abdul was transported to a local urgent care facility where the wound required 6 stitches and an X-ray to rule out bone involvement. He was kept under observation for 2 hours and released with instructions for wound care and follow-up. The incident resulted in lost work time of approximately 8 hours for the initial shift and partial duty restrictions for 3 days.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging section. While removing accumulated plastic residue from around the mold closing mechanism, Patrick inadvertently left the machine in a semi-powered state after attempting to manually disengage the safety interlock. When his colleague Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) arrived to assist with resetting the machine parameters, she pressed the startup sequence without verifying the machine was properly locked out. The mold suddenly closed with tremendous force, catching Patrick's left hand and fingers between the upper and lower mold halves. Patrick sustained a crush injury with fractures to three fingers and severe soft tissue damage requiring emergency transport to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé. He was hospitalized for 3 days and required surgical intervention. The incident was witnessed by supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) who immediately initiated emergency stop procedures and called emergency services.

On October 3, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, was transferring raw plastic pellets from large storage bins to the hopper feed system in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Unit-007). While manually scooping and transferring approximately 50-pound bags of polycarbonate pellets, Kwesi's hand became pinched between the metal edge of a hopper and a loaded material cart he was positioning. He sustained a laceration to his left palm and minor crush abrasion but continued working. By late afternoon, swelling increased and Kwesi reported the incident to his supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) at 3:00 PM. Upon examination, it was determined the wound required cleaning and three stitches at the on-site occupational health clinic. Kwesi received first aid treatment from occupational health staff and returned to light-duty work the same day. He was given tetanus prophylaxis and instructed to keep the wound clean. The incident did not result in lost work time but was documented as a first-aid case. No other employees were directly involved, though Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), the Receiving Clerk, witnessed the incident and confirmed Kwesi's account.

On September 22, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was working in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (Unit-011) organizing and categorizing waste resins and solvents for disposal. While transferring a large container of uncured epoxy resin near the flammable solvent storage section, the container tipped and spilled approximately 15 liters of volatile resin material onto the concrete floor. The spill created a slick surface, and as Rania attempted to step back from the spill, her foot slipped on the wet resin. She fell backward hard onto the concrete floor, striking her lower back and right hip directly. Rania immediately reported severe pain and was unable to stand unassisted. Emergency responders were called at 11:35 PM. Paramedics assessed her on-site and determined she had sustained a possible fracture of the right hip and significant lower back strain. She was transported by ambulance to Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal at 12:10 AM on September 23. Imaging confirmed a non-displaced fracture of the right femoral neck. Rania required hospitalization for 5 days and was placed on medical leave for 8 weeks. The incident was reported by Night Shift Supervisor (acting) and verified by Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) who arrived on-site at 6:00 AM.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) was working at Injection Molding Line A when she noticed unusual vibration and a slight burning odor emanating from the cooling water system of a 200-ton molding machine. Before touching any equipment, she immediately notified her supervisor Guillaume Deschamps and stepped back from the machine. Upon inspection, a small hairline crack was discovered in the cooling water circulation line near the pump assembly, with a minor leak of coolant (approximately 50 mL) pooling on the production floor. The coolant had not yet contacted any electrical components or created a slip hazard. The machine was immediately locked out and tagged by Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) who arrived within 10 minutes. The situation was contained before any environmental release or employee exposure occurred. Quick identification by the operator prevented a potential escalation into a full system failure that could have resulted in equipment damage or chemical exposure.

On December 3, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) was manually loading finished plastic components from a molding machine into a cardboard box for packaging at Injection Molding Line D. While bending to pick up a heavy box of components (approximately 18 kg) from the floor level using improper lifting technique, she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. She attempted to continue working but experienced increasing discomfort and reduced mobility. After 20 minutes, Carmen notified Packaging Supervisor Patricia Martin (EMP-00035) and reported the injury. Carmen was unable to continue working and was escorted to the on-site first aid station. The incident was determined to be a back strain injury from repetitive bending and lifting without proper ergonomic technique. Carmen was referred for medical evaluation and was placed on modified duty. Workers' compensation documentation was initiated, and she was unable to return to regular assembly duties for 8 weeks, resulting in a lost-time injury classification.

On December 10, 2024, at approximately 4:30 AM during the night shift, a significant fire incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Overnight operator observations indicated that fine plastic powder residue had accumulated excessively on overhead surfaces, ventilation ducts, and horizontal ledges around the material drying ovens due to deferred cleaning over a 3-week period during increased production demands. When a heating element in one of the industrial ovens developed an electrical fault and began operating at an elevated temperature (approximately 280°C instead of the normal 240°C setpoint), it ignited the accumulated dust layer. The resulting dust fire spread rapidly through suspended particles in the air, causing flames to extend across approximately 15 square meters of the ceiling area and into the ventilation system. Night shift supervisor was on-site and immediately activated the fire alarm and evacuation protocols. All 18 night shift employees evacuated safely to the assembly point. The facility's fire suppression system activated automatically, extinguishing the majority of the flames within 3 minutes. Local emergency services arrived and confirmed full suppression. The incident resulted in significant equipment damage to the drying room ($180,000 in losses), temporary facility closure for 48 hours, and extensive investigation. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate dust control procedures and deferred maintenance created the perfect conditions for fire propagation.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was operating Injection Molding Line D in the Production Operations area when he noticed excessive resin fumes emanating from the hopper area. Rather than immediately stopping the machine and notifying supervision, Rémi continued operating for approximately 8 minutes while leaning closer to the equipment to inspect the resin feed mechanism. A coworker, Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), observed the situation and alerted him to the visible vapor buildup. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the material drying system had malfunctioned, causing moisture-contaminated resin to overheat and release noxious fumes. The equipment was immediately shut down following proper LOTO procedures. Rémi experienced mild respiratory irritation and throat discomfort but declined medical attention. The incident was contained within 15 minutes of discovery. Investigation revealed that the preventive maintenance schedule for the drying system had been delayed by two weeks due to production demands.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) was operating an electric forklift in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B) to retrieve pallets of completed composite parts for shipment. The warehouse floor had been recently cleaned by maintenance staff, but wet residue from cleaning solution remained in several areas. As Roberto navigated around a stack of pallets near the loading dock, the forklift's front left wheel contacted a wet patch of floor. The vehicle briefly skidded laterally approximately 2 feet before Roberto corrected course by reducing speed and adjusting steering. A nearby material handler, Amina Mansour (EMP-00044), was positioning product boxes 15 feet away and witnessed the near-loss of control incident. No collision occurred, and no damage to equipment or product resulted. The forklift was brought to a complete stop without further incident. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the warehouse's slip-resistant floor coating had deteriorated in several high-traffic areas, and the cleaning protocol had not been updated to account for seasonal humidity changes in Quebec.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 4:30 AM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), the Maintenance Technician on night shift, was performing routine inspection work in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop when he was performing electrical checks on a CNC milling machine's control panel. The machine was supposed to be in LOTO status, but due to a communication error between the day shift supervisor and night shift coordinator, the main circuit breaker was not physically locked out—only the machine's software was disabled. As Alain reached toward the electrical connection area to measure voltage, a day shift technician accidentally powered up the equipment remotely via the central control system, unaware of the maintenance activity. The CNC spindle began rotating at low speed. Alain's gloved hand came within 2 inches of the rotating cutting tool before he pulled back reflexively. No physical contact occurred, but the near-miss created extreme shock to the technician. The situation was immediately halted by the day shift technician upon hearing Alain's verbal warning. Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was present in an adjacent area and witnessed the incident sequence.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, material handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was transferring containers of mold release agent from storage shelves in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) to a production cart. While reaching for a container on the third shelf, his bare forearm made direct contact with a partially opened mold release agent canister that had been left on the shelf edge by a previous worker. The contact caused immediate skin irritation and localized redness across approximately 15 square centimeters of his forearm. Habib immediately rinsed the affected area with water from the emergency eyewash station and reported the incident to his supervisor. First aid was administered on-site consisting of gentle cleaning and application of a soothing lotion. No medical treatment beyond first aid was required. The incident was witnessed by production operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) who was in the adjacent area. Root cause analysis identified inadequate labeling of the container and lack of secondary containment protocols for chemical storage.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, forklift operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) was moving a loaded pallet of polycarbonate (PC) resin bags through the Materials Management and Warehousing area (UNIT-012, part of UNIT-011 adjacent operations) toward the storage rack system. Due to a combination of inadequate lighting in the narrow aisle and a wet floor from recent cleaning operations in the adjacent Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011), Santos did not notice a spill of hydraulic fluid approximately 8 meters ahead. As the forklift traversed the slick surface, the front wheels lost traction. Santos attempted to correct the steering but the pallet shifted laterally, causing approximately 12 bags of PC resin (total weight approximately 480 kg) to slide off and strike a structural support column. Eight bags sustained moderate damage with visible cracking and material leakage. Three bags were completely compromised. The incident resulted in approximately $18,500 in damaged raw materials. No personnel were injured as the area was cleared during the incident. The shift supervisor was notified immediately and documented the damage.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, injection molding operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was performing routine maintenance on Line D injection molding machine in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017). While attempting to clear a polymer jam from the hopper chute using a metal rod, Charbonneau failed to fully engage the machine lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure—specifically, he did not wait for the heating elements to fully cool to safe temperature and did not verify the lockout device was functioning. Another night shift worker, believing the machine was cleared for reset, initiated a partial startup sequence remotely. This caused the heating barrel to rapidly pressurize. The resulting pressure release expelled molten polymer material (approximately 160°C) in a narrow stream that contacted Charbonneau's left shoulder and upper arm, causing second-degree thermal burns across approximately 40 square centimeters. Charbonneau was immediately transported to the on-site medical facility and subsequently hospitalized at a local hospital for burn treatment and pain management. He was admitted for overnight observation and required 18 days of lost work time. The incident was witnessed by night shift supervisor Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045) and reported by EHS coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003).

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on the mold cooling system. While checking the mold temperature sensors, François reached into the equipment to adjust a thermocouple. The injection cycle unexpectedly activated while his right hand was positioned near the mold closing mechanism. His hand was caught between the mold halves as they closed, resulting in a crush injury to his index and middle fingers. The employee immediately pulled his hand back and called for assistance. Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156), an Assembly Operator nearby, heard the cry and immediately notified Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer. First aid was administered on-site, and François was transported to Laval Hospital where X-rays confirmed fractures to two metacarpal bones and severe contusions. The incident was caused by inadequate lockout procedures—the machine was not properly locked out during maintenance, and the automatic cycle timer was not disabled.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a hydraulic line rupture occurred on the overhead gantry crane in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Unit 007). Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler, was positioning a 500-kg pallet of polycarbonate resin when the primary hydraulic hose connecting the lift cylinder to the manifold failed catastrophically. Pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across an approximate 4-meter radius, covering approximately 200 liters of ISO 32 hydraulic oil across the warehouse floor and onto adjacent stored materials. The pallet was safely lowered by manual operation before structural failure occurred. Monique Dion (EMP-00119), the Warehouse Associate on duty, immediately activated the emergency spill containment protocol, deployed absorbent material, and secured the area with warning tape. The crane system was isolated and tagged out. Investigation revealed the hose had developed micro-fractures due to fatigue over the past 18 months without scheduled replacement. No personnel were injured, but the spill contaminated approximately 50 kg of raw materials and required professional hazmat cleanup, resulting in approximately $34,000 in material loss and remediation costs.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 5:30 AM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician, was performing an emergency repair on the resin dryer in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility when he noticed the equipment temperature gauge reading 185°C, significantly above the normal operating range of 120-130°C. The dryer had been running continuously for 16 hours without operator monitoring due to an oversight in the previous shift's handover procedures. Alain immediately shut down the equipment and ventilated the area. He detected an unusual plastic-burning odor and observed slight discoloration on the heating element housing. Investigation revealed that the temperature control thermostat had malfunctioned, failing to regulate the heating cycle properly. While the situation did not result in a fire or injury, conditions were present where ignition could have occurred if resin residue had accumulated on the exterior housing. Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, was called to the scene and documented the potential fire hazard. The near-miss was classified as CRITICAL because the facility stores significant quantities of combustible polypropylene and polyethylene pellets in adjacent storage racks.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator, was operating Injection Molding Line B when he attempted to clear a material jam from the hopper without properly engaging the lockout/tagout procedure. A coworker, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), was nearby performing routine maintenance checks. As Bernard reached into the hopper to dislodge compacted polypropylene pellets, the machine unexpectedly cycled due to a faulty pressure relief valve that had been scheduled for maintenance but not yet replaced. Bernard's right hand was caught between the hopper wall and the descending auger, resulting in crushing injuries to three fingers. Emmanuel immediately triggered the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. Bernard was transported to Laval Hospital with fractures to the index, middle, and ring fingers requiring surgical intervention. The incident was caused by failure to follow LOTO procedures, inadequate equipment maintenance scheduling, and a known defect in the pressure relief system.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, a chemical storage incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-025 adjacent facility). A container of isopropanol solvent (approximately 200 liters) that was improperly stored near a heat source began leaking due to a corroded valve seal. The vapors accumulated near a malfunctioning ventilation unit that had not been serviced in six months. An electrical arcing event from an outdated panel nearby ignited the accumulated solvent vapors, causing a localized fire that spread to nearby acetone containers. The fire was contained within the storage cabinet by the facility's dry chemical suppression system, but flames reached approximately 4 feet in height before being extinguished. Luc Girard (EMP-00039), a Maintenance Technician, discovered the fire during a routine rounds check and immediately activated the suppression system and alarm. No personnel were directly exposed to flames, but the incident revealed critical gaps in chemical storage protocols, ventilation maintenance, and electrical safety in hazardous areas.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), a Packaging Operator, was working at the Shipping and Receiving Dock to prepare finished composite materials for customer shipment. While walking across the dock floor to retrieve packaging materials, she stepped on a small quantity of acetone that had been inadvertently spilled during equipment cleaning the previous evening. The slippery surface caused her to lose her footing and fall forward, striking her right knee against a metal dock plate edge. She experienced immediate pain and mild swelling but remained conscious and alert. A nearby witness, Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), a Hydraulic Systems Technician performing early morning equipment checks, immediately assisted her and summoned first aid support. Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead who also serves as a certified first aider, arrived within 3 minutes and administered ice therapy and immobilization. Lucia was able to walk with assistance and was transported to an occupational health clinic for evaluation, which confirmed a minor contusion with no fracture. The incident was attributed to inadequate floor cleanup procedures, lack of slip-resistant flooring in wet areas, and insufficient signage warning of hazardous floor conditions.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, machine setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) was performing maintenance cleaning on injection molding machine #7 in the Production Operations area. After completing the cleaning cycle, Tremblay inadvertently failed to re-engage the machine's lockout/tagout (LOTO) safety interlock before stepping away. Production supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) arrived to restart the machine for the afternoon production run and, believing the machine was properly secured, pressed the startup button. The machine suddenly activated, and the rotating barrel cam caught Tremblay's left hand as he reached back toward the control panel, causing a severe laceration and crushing injury to his palm and fingers. Tremblay was immediately transported to Laval General Hospital where he underwent emergency surgery for nerve and tendon repair. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury requiring 18 weeks of recovery and modified duty assignment. Investigation revealed that the LOTO procedure checklist had not been properly completed and documented, and machine startup protocols lacked sufficient verification steps.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM, quality control inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) was conducting routine material testing in the Quality Control Laboratory when she noticed an unusual odor and mild respiratory irritation while handling a batch of carbon fiber-reinforced composite material. The material was being processed with a new supplier batch that had arrived the previous day. Zhang immediately moved to the laboratory's ventilation hood and recognized symptoms consistent with exposure to composite fiber dust. She self-reported the incident to Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) before symptoms progressed. Al-Rashid conducted a health assessment and determined that Zhang had inhaled a significant quantity of uncaptured composite fiber dust during initial material inspection. The new composite batch contained a higher percentage of chopped glass fiber than previous shipments, and the material had not been properly wetted before unpacking, allowing fibers to become airborne. This incident was classified as a preventive declaration to address the material handling procedures for new composite shipments and to review air quality monitoring in the laboratory.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 6:20 PM during the evening shift, material handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was transferring large rolls of regrind material from storage racks to the conveyor system in the Regrind and Recycling Department. While manually positioning a 45-kilogram roll, Bianchi experienced a sudden sharp pain in her lower back as the material shifted unexpectedly. The roll partially slipped from her grip, and she compensated by twisting her torso and hyperextending her lumbar spine to prevent the material from falling to the ground. Bianchi felt immediate onset of severe back pain and muscle spasms and was assisted by nearby coworker Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073). Training coordinator Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) was called to assess the injury. Bianchi was provided initial first aid and ice therapy, and the incident was recorded as a non-lost-time injury. The root cause investigation identified that the regrind rolls lacked proper handles, that lifting assistance equipment (mechanical hoist) had been broken for three weeks and remained unrepaired, and that no recent ergonomic refresher training had been conducted for materials handling personnel.

On December 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was removing cooled parts from a mold when his right hand became caught between the closing mold halves. The mold had been programmed for automatic closure, but the machine's safety interlock had not been properly engaged due to maintenance work performed earlier that morning. Jalbert's colleagues heard him cry out and immediately activated the emergency stop. However, his hand had already sustained a crushing injury to two fingers and the palm. First aid responders applied pressure and ice. Jalbert was transported to the hospital where X-rays revealed a fracture to his ring finger and significant soft tissue damage requiring surgical intervention. The incident was witnessed by Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072), a Production Operator working adjacent to Line D, who called for emergency assistance. The root cause was traced to incomplete safety system verification after maintenance.

On December 16, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant fire occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), an Inventory Control Specialist, was conducting a routine inventory check when she discovered that a 20-liter container of acetone cleaning solvent had been left open on a workbench near an active hot plate used for warming mold release agents. The hot plate, left unattended by a maintenance technician, had elevated the temperature in the confined area. Vapors from the acetone ignited, creating a rapid fire that spread to adjacent storage shelves containing colorant masterbatches and additional solvents. Proulx immediately activated the fire alarm and evacuated the building. The facility's automated fire suppression system engaged, but not before approximately 15 storage containers were damaged or destroyed, along with shelving infrastructure valued at approximately $47,000. No personnel injuries occurred, but the chemical storage area was rendered inoperable for three days. The incident revealed multiple failures: inadequate chemical storage protocols, improper hot plate usage without supervision, and lack of spill containment measures.

On December 18, 2024, at approximately 4:30 AM during the night shift, an overhead crane load drop incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), a Material Handler, had loaded approximately 2,800 kg of packaged automotive components onto a pallet for shipment. The crane operator, Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), an Automation Technician operating the bridge crane system, began lifting the load toward the staging area. Approximately 3 meters into the lift, the left hook assembly on the crane failed due to metal fatigue in a weld joint that had not been identified during routine maintenance inspections. The load fell approximately 2.5 meters onto the concrete floor, destroying 340 individual parts valued at $31,200 and crushing the wooden pallet completely. The load fell in an area where no personnel were standing at the time of failure, preventing injuries. However, the incident damaged the loading dock flooring and created a significant hazard. Investigation revealed that the overhead crane had not undergone its required annual certified inspection by a professional engineer in the past 18 months despite company policy mandating annual inspections.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of polyurethane resin in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While transferring a 55-gallon drum of solvent from storage to the mixing tank, the drum's spigot valve became loose due to vibration from nearby equipment. Approximately 12 gallons of volatile organic compound (VOC) solvent spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous pool. The spill released significant fumes into the work area. Elena immediately evacuated the room and activated the spill response procedure. The facility's emergency response team contained the spill using absorbent materials and ventilation fans. Air quality monitoring showed VOC concentrations reached 450 ppm in the mixing room—exceeding the 200 ppm exposure limit. Two other workers in adjacent areas reported mild headaches and respiratory irritation. The spill was fully contained within 90 minutes, and the area was decontaminated. This incident revealed inadequate drum storage procedures and insufficient secondary containment systems.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:20 AM during the day shift, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator working on Line D, was removing finished parts from a high-temperature mold cavity. Despite wearing heat-resistant gloves, Bertrand misjudged the mold temperature and made direct contact with a plastic component that had cooled to approximately 240°C. The contact lasted approximately 3 seconds before he withdrew his hand. Bertrand sustained second-degree thermal burns across his right palm and two fingers. He immediately immersed his hand in cool water and reported to the facility's first aid station. The company nurse provided emergency burn care and recommended hospital evaluation. Bertrand was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where he received treatment for partial-thickness burns affecting 8% of his hand surface. He was hospitalized for 12 hours for monitoring and pain management, then released with discharge instructions. The injury resulted in 14 days of lost work time while the burns healed. Michael Chen (EMP-00004), the Production Supervisor, witnessed the incident and immediately initiated emergency protocols.

On May 22, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), the Warehouse Lead working in the Materials Management area, was organizing stacks of finished goods on the third-level mezzanine of the Warehouse and Shipping facility (UNIT-019). While reaching for a carton of medical device housings, Normand accidentally bumped a forklift pallet jack that had been left unattended on the mezzanine edge with its load still partially positioned over the railing. The impact dislodged an approximately 85-pound carton of composite materials components from the top tier of the pallet. The carton fell 18 feet to the concrete floor below, striking and severely damaging the hood and windshield of a company forklift parked directly beneath. The equipment sustained approximately $34,000 in damage including structural frame damage, electrical system destruction, and total loss of hydraulic systems. Additionally, the falling carton caused secondary damage to three pallets of finished goods valued at approximately $8,600. No employees were directly struck by the falling materials, as the night shift had minimal staffing in that area. However, the incident revealed dangerous storage practices, inadequate equipment positioning procedures, and insufficient load securing methods. Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) was called to the site to assess equipment safety.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, packaging operator Amara Diop (EMP-00110) was working at Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging area when she inadvertently made skin contact with a pool of uncleaned mold release agent that had accumulated on the machine's horizontal surface. The agent had been applied during the previous evening shift but was not properly wiped down during shift changeover. Amara developed immediate itching and mild redness on her right forearm and the back of her hand within minutes of contact. She reported the incident to her supervisor immediately and proceeded to wash the affected area thoroughly with soap and water for 15 minutes at the nearest safety station. Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180) was nearby and witnessed the incident. The affected area showed minor dermatitis but no blistering or severe reaction. First aid was administered on-site with antihistamine cream, and Amara remained on duty. No lost time occurred, and the employee fully recovered within 24 hours.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:20 PM during evening shift operations in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B), forklift operator Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167) was executing a routine pallet retrieval from the upper storage rack when he noticed the rear left tire of his propane-powered forklift had partially deflated, causing the vehicle to list approximately 3 inches to the left. Realizing the unsafe condition, Hugues immediately ceased operations and carefully lowered his current load to ground level. He then positioned the forklift in a designated safe zone and reported the mechanical failure to maintenance technician Fernand Gigière (EMP-00169). Fernand inspected the tire and confirmed a slow leak from the sidewall, likely caused by contact with a pallet edge or sharp debris. No employee was endangered during the near-miss event as Hugues identified the hazard before attempting to raise or transport loads to height. The forklift was isolated with hazard tape and tagged out of service. Maintenance replaced the tire on April 3rd. Machine operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) was also present in the warehouse and observed Hugues's corrective action.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 1:15 AM during night shift operations in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing), mold technician Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021) was performing routine mold maintenance on a high-pressure composite forming press when his right hand became caught between the descending mold plate and the fixed support frame as the press cycled unexpectedly. Stéphane had failed to activate the emergency stop button located 18 inches away despite company lockout/tagout procedures requiring the press to be de-energized during maintenance. The press compression resulted in a crush injury to his index and middle fingers, causing a comminuted fracture of the index finger (requiring partial amputation of the distal phalanx) and a simple fracture of the middle finger. Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) heard Stéphane's cry for help and immediately pressed the emergency stop button, stopping the press cycle. Daniel provided initial first aid while calling emergency services. Stéphane was transported via ambulance to Saint-Jérôme Hospital at 1:35 AM and underwent emergency surgery. The employee was hospitalized for 4 days and required 6 weeks of medical leave for wound healing and rehabilitation, constituting a lost-time injury. Root cause investigation revealed that Stéphane had bypassed LOTO procedures due to time pressure to complete maintenance before shift end.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:30, Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois conducted a routine inspection of the Hazardous Waste Management Area exterior zone and discovered a potentially hazardous condition. During her assessment of the chemical waste storage containers, she noticed that three large 55-gallon drums of spent resin solvent were stored without proper secondary containment and were positioned within 2 meters of a storm drain system. The drums lacked visible hazard labeling per WHMIS requirements, and inspection records showed no documentation of containment integrity checks for the past 60 days. Additionally, the storage area showed evidence of minor seepage and staining on the ground beneath the drums. Dubois immediately photographed the condition, documented GPS coordinates, and notified the Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron and HSE team. She initiated a preventive declaration to address the chemical storage protocol violations before environmental contamination could occur or worker exposure risk could escalate. This declaration triggered a comprehensive review of all hazardous waste storage procedures across the facility.

On November 25, 2024 at 10:45 during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator James Thompson (Line D) was performing routine mold changeover on the injection molding machine. Following standard LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures, Thompson isolated electrical and pneumatic systems and applied his personal lockout device. However, due to a communication breakdown, Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert was not informed of the maintenance work and attempted to clear a material jam in the adjacent hopper by manually cycling the machine's feed system using the local pendant control. The hydraulic pressure that Thompson believed was isolated suddenly activated, causing the mold to shift position and trap Thompson's left hand between the mold cavity and the cavity cooler lines. Thompson sustained a crushing injury to his left hand with partial lacerations to his index and middle fingers. Emergency procedures were initiated; paramedics arrived within 8 minutes. Thompson was transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur with crush injuries requiring emergency surgical evaluation. Hand imaging confirmed fractures in both affected fingers with tissue damage. Thompson underwent surgical repair and was admitted for 2 days for post-operative monitoring and pain management.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), a Production Operator at Injection Molding Line B - Automotive, was performing routine material loading when she reached toward the injection port of a 250-ton molding machine. Despite wearing standard cotton gloves, her left hand made contact with exposed heating elements at approximately 180°C. The machine's thermal guard had been partially removed two days earlier during maintenance by Réjean Simard and was never reinstalled. Yara immediately withdrew her hand and reported severe burning pain. First-degree and partial second-degree burns covered the dorsal surface of her left hand and wrist. She was immediately escorted to the on-site medical station where occupational health nurse Hana Al-Rashid provided initial treatment, including cold water irrigation and sterile dressing application. The employee was transported to Laval Hospital Emergency Department for further evaluation and pain management. The incident was witnessed by fellow operator Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) who was working at the adjacent injection station. Investigation revealed the thermal guard removal had not been documented in the maintenance log, and no work order closure checklist was completed.

On March 21, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, environmental monitoring equipment in the Hazardous Waste Management Area detected an unexpected pressure buildup in a secondary containment collection tank. Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was performing routine waste material processing when he noticed an unusual odor near the secondary containment area. Upon visual inspection, he discovered a hairline crack (approximately 8 centimeters long) had developed in the welded seam of a polypropylene collection tank, allowing approximately 120 liters of mixed solvent waste containing acetone, methylethylketone, and trace heavy metals to seep into the underlying concrete containment basin. The crack appeared to be stress-induced from thermal cycling combined with corrosion from acidic waste contact. The material was not contained within the proper secondary containment system, and approximately 30 liters penetrated through a drainage gap in the concrete to reach the subsurface soil layer. Oscar immediately isolated the area, notified his supervisor via radio, and Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was contacted at 1:45 AM. Emergency containment procedures were initiated with absorbent materials deployed at 2:10 AM. Soil remediation assessment identified contamination of the upper 60 centimeters of soil requiring excavation and disposal. No immediate environmental monitoring of groundwater was conducted, and the incident was not reported to CNESST or municipal environmental authorities for 18 hours.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, an employee in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building was transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum to smaller containers using a manual pump system. While disconnecting the pump from the drum, the seal failed catastrophically, releasing approximately 12 liters of acetone onto the floor and into the employee's work area. The spill occurred because the pump seal had not been inspected during the previous maintenance cycle and had degraded from repeated exposure to the solvent. The acetone rapidly evaporated, creating a significant vapor hazard in the confined area. The employee immediately notified their supervisor, and the HSE team was called. The area was evacuated, ventilation fans were activated, and the spill was contained using absorbent materials. The incident resulted in no direct injury but posed serious inhalation risks and fire hazard given the proximity of electrical equipment.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:20 PM during the evening shift, a maintenance technician was performing routine cleaning of the composite materials mixing station in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. While disposing of residual resin and hardener materials into the hazardous waste container, the technician accidentally mixed incompatible chemical residues—polyester resin and epoxy hardener—that had accumulated in the bottom of the waste bin from previous shifts. The exothermic chemical reaction generated significant heat, causing the container to swell and release acidic vapors. The technician immediately evacuated the area and alerted supervisors. The Fire Safety Coordinator was called, ventilation was maximized, and the container was moved to the exterior holding area. The spill itself was contained, but approximately 8 liters of reactive chemical mixture was rendered unusable and required special disposal. The incident revealed inadequate labeling and segregation procedures for different chemical waste streams.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, an injection molding operator on Line A was performing routine material hopper cleaning when his left hand became caught between the hopper base and a support bracket while reaching to clear accumulated resin buildup. The employee had failed to follow lockout/tagout procedures and had not de-energized the material feeder system before beginning maintenance. When the automated feeder cycled unexpectedly, it compressed the support bracket against the fixed base, trapping the employee's hand. The employee immediately called for help, and the shift supervisor responded within 2 minutes. Emergency shutdown was activated, and the Fire Safety Coordinator called for emergency medical services. The employee was extricated after 8 minutes of careful manipulation and was transported to the hospital with a fractured left hand, crushed fingers, and significant soft tissue damage. The incident resulted in 26 lost workdays and required surgical intervention to preserve hand function.

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, an overflow incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was transferring a batch of colorant masterbatch from a 50-gallon drum into the automated mixing hopper when the hopper's level sensor malfunctioned. The continuous feed system did not shut off as designed, and approximately 35 liters of liquid colorant overflowed from the hopper onto the concrete floor, creating a slippery hazard. The spill spread across approximately 8 square meters of the mixing room floor. Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) arrived to assist with cleanup and discovered that the overflow had also splashed onto electrical connections near the base of the mixing equipment. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) was immediately notified and responded to assess air quality. The spill was contained using absorbent material, and the area was ventilated for 90 minutes before operations resumed. No employees were injured, but the incident revealed a critical gap in preventive maintenance of hopper sensors.

On December 3, 2024 at 10:47 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Assembly Operator Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134) was transferring isopropanol cleaning solvent from a 20-liter container to smaller 2-liter dispensing bottles when she inadvertently knocked over the source container on the edge of the work bench. Approximately 8 liters of isopropanol splashed onto the floor, storage shelves, and nearby hydraulic equipment. The volatile solvent immediately began evaporating, creating visible fumes. El Amrani activated the emergency alarm and evacuated the room. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) arrived within 3 minutes and found that the spill had reached within 2 meters of the electrical panel serving the mixing equipment. Using the emergency spill kit, Lafleur deployed absorbent materials and organic vapor cartridge respirators were distributed to nearby personnel. The area was declared hazardous and isolated for 4 hours until fumes dissipated below safe levels. Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) analyzed air samples and confirmed volatile organic compound concentrations had returned to baseline. Investigation revealed the work surface lacked proper containment trays and that the chemical container was not secured to the work surface.

On November 28, 2024 at 6:33 AM during the night shift, equipment damage occurred in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014). Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was conducting routine maintenance on an overhead crane control system when he inadvertently left a 2-kilogram steel wrench resting on a shelf directly above an open control panel. While performing tests on the panel's electrical connections, Desbiens reached up to remove a cable conduit, and his movement dislodged the wrench. The tool fell approximately 1.8 meters into the control panel, striking a programmable logic controller (PLC) and relay module array. The impact caused a short circuit that damaged three solid-state relays and scorched the main circuit board. The overhead crane became inoperable, halting material movement in the adjacent Production Building South Zone. The wrench also damaged the panel's metal enclosure with a deep dent. Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) arrived and isolated power to the damaged equipment to prevent further electrical damage or fire risk. Tool Room Supervisor Richard Beaulieu (EMP-00043) inspected the tools present and found that the tool storage area lacked proper securing mechanisms. Replacement of the PLC and relay components required emergency procurement with a lead time of 5 days, causing significant production delays totaling approximately $47,000 in lost throughput.

On March 14, 2024, at 14:45, Celine Morin (EMP-00153) was operating Injection Molding Line A in the Main Production Building when she noticed unusual vibration from the automated robotic arm. Rather than immediately stopping the machine, she attempted to adjust the arm's position manually while it was still powered. Her left hand became caught between the robot's gripper and a mold cavity as the arm unexpectedly cycled. A nearby operator, Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176), heard Celine's cry and immediately activated the emergency stop button. The incident was contained within seconds, and Celine experienced minor crushing but no fractures. The incident was reported immediately by Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator who was conducting a routine inspection nearby. The robotic arm was found to have a faulty proximity sensor that failed to detect the hand position. This represents a near-miss as the quick response prevented serious injury.

On April 2, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring polyurethane resin from a 55-gallon drum to the mixing tank in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). According to eyewitness Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026), Elena was using an improvised siphon system rather than the approved transfer pump because the pump was reported broken that morning. While transferring approximately 20 gallons, the hose connection loosened and approximately 8 gallons of unreacted polyurethane resin splashed across Elena's legs, feet, and work boots. The chemical began to set and harden on contact with skin and fabric. Elena was immediately assisted to the emergency shower station and decontaminated for 15 minutes. She was transported to the Regional Hospital with second-degree chemical burns covering approximately 12% of her lower extremities and ankles. The incident was declared by Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123), the Incident Investigation Specialist, who arrived at the scene within 10 minutes. Elena required hospitalization for 3 days and resulted in 14 days of lost work time due to wound care and mobility restrictions.

On May 8, 2024, at 06:30 during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter, was preparing Injection Molding Line D (Consumer Packaging) for startup after weekend maintenance. He was performing the standard mold installation procedure when he noticed the mold locking mechanism appeared stiff. Instead of waiting for the maintenance supervisor, Louis applied excessive force using a rubber mallet to seat the mold. The mechanism suddenly released and the 150-pound mold shifted, striking his left shoulder and upper arm. Louis fell backward but remained conscious. Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), the CNC Operator who was conducting a nearby equipment check, immediately called emergency response. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), the Emergency Response Team Leader, arrived within 3 minutes and assessed the injury. Louis suffered a deep contusion and partial rotator cuff strain but no fractures. He was treated at the on-site first aid station and released with recommendations for medical follow-up. The incident was classified as a near-miss because while significant pain was experienced, no hospitalization or lost time occurred. However, medical evaluation one week later revealed the rotator cuff strain required 6 weeks of light duty work.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, experienced a burn injury while removing a finished component from the injection mold. The mold temperature was 280°C. Ahmed was wearing standard work gloves but made contact with the hot plastic runner system while extracting a medical device housing. The plastic material adhered to his right hand and fingers, causing a partial-thickness thermal burn covering approximately 8% of his hand surface. The burn was immediately cooled with cold water from the emergency eyewash station, and first aid was administered by Hana Al-Rashid, the Occupational Health Nurse. The employee experienced significant pain but remained conscious. No hospitalization was required, but the injury required professional medical evaluation and dressing at a local clinic. The incident was witnessed by Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), who immediately alerted supervision. Root cause analysis indicated insufficient insulation on the runner extraction point and inadequate burn-resistant glove specification for high-temperature handling tasks.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the evening shift, Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), a Packaging Operator at the Packaging and Labeling Station, sustained a laceration to her left index finger while manually cutting shrink wrap packaging film with a utility knife. The knife blade slipped during a cutting motion, deflecting off the plastic film edge and contacting her finger. The wound measured approximately 1.2 cm in length with minor bleeding. Lucia immediately notified her supervisor and reported to the first aid station where Hana Al-Rashid cleaned, assessed, and dressed the wound with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. The laceration did not require stitches but needed professional wound care confirmation. No lost time resulted from this incident. The root causes identified were inadequate knife blade control training, lack of proper cutting surface/guide, and employee fatigue during a high-volume packaging run. Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) witnessed the incident and confirmed the events to safety personnel.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:50 PM during the night shift, Daniel Kim (EMP-00025), an Electrical Maintenance Technician, discovered a potentially catastrophic hazard while performing routine maintenance in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While inspecting the ventilation exhaust ducting, Daniel noticed that the main ductwork connection to the fume extraction hood had partially separated from its mounting bracket, leaving a 6 cm gap. The hood handles volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from composite resin mixing operations. Had the duct failed completely during the next shift, chemical vapors would have accumulated in the facility rather than being safely vented, creating a severe inhalation hazard for all personnel. Daniel immediately secured the connection with temporary strapping and notified Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist. The facility conducted an immediate ventilation system audit. No actual chemical exposure occurred due to early detection. The root cause was inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling and insufficient visual inspection protocols. This near-miss revealed a critical gap in facility inspection procedures.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:30 during day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. While adjusting the mold clamping mechanism without properly engaging the LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure, another operator accidentally activated the machine's cycle. Mathieu's left hand was caught between the mold platens as they closed, resulting in crush injuries to his index and middle fingers. The machine was immediately stopped by a nearby supervisor, André Paradis, who activated the emergency stop button. First responders arrived within 8 minutes. Mathieu was conscious and alert, experiencing severe pain but no arterial bleeding. The injured fingers showed signs of crushing but were salvageable. Mathieu was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé for emergency treatment. The incident was witnessed by Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), an Assembly Operator who was working adjacent to Line B. Root cause investigation revealed the LOTO checklist was not followed and the machine interlock system had been previously bypassed during a maintenance cycle.

On April 2, 2024 at 09:15 during day shift, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, was transferring pallets of polycarbonate (PC) resin from the receiving dock in the Warehouse and Shipping building to the storage racks. While moving a pallet jack loaded with six bags of PC resin (approximately 300 kg total), Hassan's left boot caught on an edge of the concrete floor near the dock threshold. He stumbled but quickly regained his footing without falling. However, during the stumble, his left hand contacted the rough edge of a metal storage rack, resulting in a laceration approximately 3 cm long on the back of his left hand between the thumb and index finger. The laceration was bleeding moderately. Hassan immediately reported the incident to his supervisor Wei Liu (EMP-00088), the Production Scheduler, who was present in the warehouse. Wei assessed the wound, cleaned it with soap and water, applied direct pressure with gauze, and bandaged it with an antibiotic ointment and adhesive bandage. The wound did not require stitches. Hassan was given the remainder of the morning off to rest and ice the injury. By afternoon, Hassan returned to light-duty work. The incident was reported as a first-aid case. Root cause: uneven floor surface combined with worn work boots and inattention to walking hazards.

On May 8, 2024 at 23:45 during night shift, Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), a Production Operator, was working in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building preparing a batch of custom-colored polypropylene masterbatch. The facility ventilation system in the chemical storage area had been operating below specifications due to a clogged intake filter that should have been replaced 40 hours earlier per maintenance schedule. While transferring acetone-based cleaning solvent from a 55-gallon drum into smaller containers for equipment cleaning, Yara began experiencing dizziness, mild headache, and slight nausea. She initially attributed symptoms to fatigue from the night shift but after 20 minutes of continued symptoms, she alerted her supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037), the Night Shift Production Supervisor. André immediately noticed a strong chemical odor in the work area and activated the emergency ventilation override, opening all roof vents manually. He escorted Yara to fresh air outside the building and assessed her condition. Yara's symptoms subsided within 10 minutes in fresh air. André documented the incident and contacted Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, who conducted a real-time air quality measurement showing acetone vapor concentration at 450 ppm (OSHA PEL is 750 ppm, but ACGIH TLV is 250 ppm). Yara was evaluated by occupational health and released with instructions to monitor for delayed symptoms. Incident classified as occupational illness from chemical exposure.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic failure occurred on Injection Molding Machine #12 (500-ton press) in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi was conducting routine part extraction when the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned, causing uncontrolled mold closure. The mold plates came together at full force while Kouassi's left hand was still positioned inside the cavity to remove a partially cured composite part. The sudden closure resulted in a severe crush injury to his hand, fracturing multiple metacarpal bones and causing tissue damage. Emergency response was activated immediately; first aid was administered on-site, and the employee was transported via ambulance to Laval Hospital where he underwent emergency surgery. The machine was immediately locked out and tagged. Root cause analysis revealed that the relief valve had not been properly maintained according to the preventive maintenance schedule—the last service was 8 months overdue. Maintenance records showed the valve was scheduled for quarterly inspection but this was missed due to staffing shortages during the February production surge.

On March 18, 2024, during the evening shift at approximately 8:15 PM, a significant chemical spill incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov was conducting a routine stock rotation of solvent containers when she noticed that a 55-gallon drum of acetone (used as a cleaning solvent in the manufacturing process) had developed a hairline crack in its sidewall. The drum had been stored on a middle shelf of the racking system and appeared to have minor impact damage. As Ivanov moved the container to remove it from inventory, the crack expanded and approximately 8 gallons of acetone leaked onto the warehouse floor before she could apply emergency containment procedures. The solvent spread across approximately 120 square feet of concrete flooring, creating a serious slip/fall hazard and releasing volatile organic compound vapors throughout the warehouse. The area was immediately evacuated, emergency response was activated, and the incident was contained using absorbent materials and emergency cleanup procedures. Air quality monitoring detected acetone vapor concentrations at 650 ppm in the affected zone (OSHA PEL is 750 ppm). The incident resulted in a 6-hour operational shutdown while cleanup and ventilation restoration was completed. Investigation revealed the drum damage likely occurred during a forklift movement 3 days prior; no inspection was conducted to verify container integrity after that event.

On March 21, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, a ventilation system malfunction was discovered in the chemical mixing and compounding area adjacent to the Raw Materials Warehouse. Night Shift Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel was performing routine equipment inspections when he observed that the primary exhaust fan serving the solvent mixing station had ceased operation. Visual inspection revealed that a belt-drive pulley system had become misaligned, causing the drive belt to slip and eventually disengage completely. The backup ventilation system was not engaged because the facility's HVAC management system failed to trigger the automatic switchover—a software glitch prevented the pressure sensor from communicating the fault condition. As a result, volatile organic compounds (primarily isopropanol and acetone vapors) began accumulating in the confined mixing area. When Bernard Allard, a Hydraulic Press Operator, arrived for his shift at midnight and entered the area to retrieve supplies for the 500-ton press, he experienced immediate dizziness, headache, and mild respiratory irritation. Air quality monitoring conducted 20 minutes after his complaint detected isopropanol concentrations at 920 ppm (OSHA PEL is 400 ppm). The area was immediately evacuated and ventilation was manually restored by Gravel within 45 minutes. Allard was assessed by on-site first aid and released without requiring hospitalization, though he reported ongoing mild symptoms for approximately 2 hours after fresh air exposure. Root cause analysis identified both mechanical failure (pulley misalignment) and a critical control system failure that allowed the hazardous condition to develop undetected.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Layla Hussein (EMP-00098), an Assembly Operator, was working on Line D in the Main Production Building when she noticed excessive plastic material accumulating in the hopper of Injection Molding Machine #7. The hopper had not been emptied since the previous shift change, and material was beginning to overflow onto the surrounding work surface and floor. Layla immediately stopped work and informed her team lead before the overflow could cause a complete blockage or equipment malfunction. The spilled material created a minor slip hazard on the adjacent walkway. Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer, was notified and arrived within 10 minutes to assess the situation. No employees were injured, but the incident highlighted a gap in the preventive maintenance schedule for hopper monitoring and material level checks. The area was cleaned and secured, and the machine was safely cleared by the maintenance team. This near-miss event was declared as a preventive declaration to address systematic issues with material handling procedures.

On December 8, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, a refrigeration system failure occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. The cooling water system that maintains optimal temperature for resin storage developed a significant leak from a corroded coupling joint in the main distribution line. The leak resulted in approximately 450 liters of cooling water being discharged across the chemical storage floor over approximately 2 hours before the night shift operator, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), discovered the issue during a routine inspection round. The water pooled around several storage containers of epoxy resin and polyurethane compounds. Although no chemical spillage occurred, the standing water created a slip hazard and risked potential water infiltration into electrical junction boxes nearby. Claude Rioux, Electrical Maintenance Lead, was called in at 1:30 AM to assess electrical safety. The water was pumped out and the area dried by 4:00 AM. The damaged coupling was replaced, but the incident revealed that the cooling system had not been serviced or inspected in over 18 months despite the preventive maintenance schedule calling for quarterly inspections. Approximately 8 hours of production was lost on the night shift due to safety shutdown procedures.

On January 22, 2025, at 9:30 AM during the day shift, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, was transferring pallets of raw polycarbonate resin from the receiving dock to the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). Hassan was using a manual pallet jack to move a pallet weighing approximately 850 kg up a slight incline toward the warehouse entrance. As he was pushing the pallet jack, the front wheels caught on a gap where two concrete sections meet on the warehouse floor. The sudden stop caused Hassan to stumble forward and fall onto the pallet, landing on his left shoulder and upper back. He experienced immediate sharp pain and difficulty moving his left arm. Co-worker Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), a Facilities Maintenance Technician working nearby, assisted Hassan to sit down and called for first aid assistance. Hassan was transported to the on-site first aid station and subsequently to the hospital for evaluation, where X-rays confirmed a fractured left clavicle and a partially dislocated shoulder joint. Hassan was placed on medical leave for 6 weeks, resulting in lost work time. Investigation revealed the concrete gap had been present for over 6 months and had been noted in previous facility inspections but not repaired. The pallet jack was found to be functioning normally with adequate tire tread.
