On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Packaging Operator Amara Diop (EMP-00110) was working in the Assembly and Finishing Department when she noticed a potential ergonomic hazard at her workstation. While performing repetitive hand-assembly operations on consumer packaging components, Amara experienced mild discomfort in her wrists and forearms after approximately 4 hours of continuous assembly work without breaks. She self-reported this concern to her supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) before any injury occurred. Upon investigation, it was determined that the workstation height and positioning were not optimally adjusted for her frame, and no anti-fatigue mat was present at the station. Additionally, assembly workers had not received formal ergonomic training in the past 18 months. This preventive declaration was made to identify and correct the ergonomic risk before it resulted in a musculoskeletal disorder diagnosis. Amara was moved to a temporarily adjusted workstation while a comprehensive ergonomic assessment was scheduled.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 1:15 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was transferring a 25-liter container of epoxy resin from the storage rack to a mixing station when the container's lid was improperly sealed. The container tilted during the transfer, and approximately 12 liters of epoxy resin spilled onto the floor over an area of approximately 15 square meters. The spill immediately contacted the concrete flooring and began spreading toward a floor drain. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) immediately implemented the emergency spill response protocol: she evacuated nearby workers, activated the ventilation system to maximum capacity, and placed absorbent spill kits around the perimeter to contain further spread. Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) responded as part of the emergency team and assisted in containing the spill using sand and absorbent materials. The facility's HSE team was notified within 5 minutes. No workers were directly exposed to the chemical, though several reported headaches from the increased fume levels. The spill was fully contained and cleaned within 90 minutes. Root cause: improper lid sealing and lack of secondary containment during transport.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 11:00 PM during the evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse. Shipping and Receiving Clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019) was organizing inventory when she discovered that a palletized stack of polyol resin containers (4 containers stacked 2 high, each containing 20 liters) had partially collapsed. Two containers from the top tier had shifted and fallen, with one container's seal compromised during the fall. Approximately 16 liters of polyol resin spilled onto the warehouse floor, creating a slippery hazard across an approximate 8 square meter area. The resin began pooling near electrical conduits and a material storage area. Mélanie immediately reported the incident to the evening shift supervisor, who activated the warehouse spill containment protocol. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), though off-shift, was called in for emergency response coordination. Maintenance Manager Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006) assessed the structural integrity of the pallet storage system and determined that the stacking configuration had exceeded weight limits and the pallet itself had weakened. Emergency response team deployed absorbent material and placed temporary warning barriers. The chemical was safely cleaned and disposed of within 2 hours. Environmental compliance protocols were followed for wastewater containment. Root cause: improper pallet stacking configuration, pallet weight limit not marked, and lack of secondary containment for hazardous material storage.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a severe burn injury while servicing an active injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. François was attempting to clear a material blockage in the hopper feed system without properly shutting down and locking out the machine. A colleague, Ana Silva (EMP-00040), was working adjacent to Line A when she heard François cry out. The molten plastic material at approximately 280°C contacted François's left forearm and hand, causing second and third-degree burns across 12% of his exposed skin. Ana immediately activated the emergency stop, called for medical assistance, and applied cold water to the affected area. François was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital emergency department via ambulance at 15:10. He required hospitalization for 5 days with specialized burn treatment and will be unable to return to full duties for 8-10 weeks, resulting in lost time from work. The incident investigation revealed that the LOTO procedure was not followed, and the employee had not completed recent refresher training on lockout/tagout protocols.

On February 8, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift, Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), Assembly Line Lead, sustained an eye injury in the Assembly and Finishing Department (East Wing). Chantal was monitoring assembly of medical device housings on the automated line when a defective part ejector mechanism on Station 4 suddenly failed. The ejector, under pneumatic pressure, launched a small plastic connector clip at high velocity across the work area. The clip struck Chantal's right eye, penetrating between her safety glasses and facial anatomy. She immediately reported eye pain and blurred vision. Colleague Patricia Martin (EMP-00035) was nearby and helped Chantal to the emergency eyewash station on-site, where she flushed her eye for 5 minutes. Medical personnel were called and Chantal was transported to Laval General Hospital's ophthalmology department. Clinical examination revealed a corneal abrasion and minor subconjunctival hemorrhage. Chantal received topical treatment and was prescribed antibacterial eye drops. She returned to modified duty the next day but required 3 weeks of restrictions (no overhead work, minimal close-focus tasks) before full return to Assembly Line Lead duties.

On January 22, 2024, at 03:30 during night shift, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment zone. The primary industrial oven (Model IR-3500, used for curing composite materials at 160-180°C) experienced a catastrophic failure of its temperature control thermostat. The thermostat stuck in the 'on' position, causing the oven chamber to overheat to approximately 240°C—well beyond safe operating parameters. Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147), Regrind Supervisor, was monitoring overnight production when instrumentation alerts signaled the temperature exceedance at 03:27. Normand immediately activated the emergency shutoff procedure and called Thanh Pham (EMP-00062), Maintenance Planner, who arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the thermostat malfunction. The oven interior contained 12 kg of partially cured composite material valued at $18,500. At 240°C, the material began to thermally degrade, discoloring and becoming brittle. An estimated 80% of the batch was rendered unusable. The oven itself sustained no structural damage, but the thermostat unit required complete replacement. Equipment was out of service for 6 hours, resulting in delayed fulfillment of a customer order for medical device enclosures. Root cause analysis identified that the thermostat had not been calibrated or tested since installation 18 months prior.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was conducting routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine when a hydraulic line rupture occurred. The machine's pressure relief system failed to activate properly, causing hot hydraulic fluid under extreme pressure to spray across his right forearm and hand. Gendron immediately reported the incident to his supervisor and sought first aid. The facility's emergency response team was activated. He was transported to the on-site medical facility where burns to approximately 8% of his right arm were treated with advanced wound care. The incident was caused by inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling on the hydraulic system and a blocked pressure relief valve. Gendron required hospitalization for 3 days due to the severity of the thermal burns and infection risk. The machine was immediately shut down and tagged out pending full hydraulic system inspection and replacement.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 AM during day shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator, was handling finished plastic components at the Packaging and Labeling Station when she sustained a sharp laceration to her left index finger from an exposed edge on a molded part. The part, manufactured on Line D for consumer packaging, had a burr or sharp protrusion that was not adequately deburred during the finishing process. Farsi immediately reported the injury to her supervisor, Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026), Quality Inspector, who provided first aid including wound cleansing, antibiotic ointment application, and a sterile bandage. The wound was approximately 1 cm long and did not require stitches. Farsi completed the remainder of her shift with modified duties, avoiding water immersion. The incident was documented and reported to Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011), Environmental Compliance Specialist, who investigated root cause. Quality control sampling procedures were reviewed and enhanced to catch parts with sharp edges before they reach finishing operations.

On April 10, 2024, at 11:45 PM during night shift operations, Denis Savard (EMP-00099), Purchasing Manager, was conducting an inventory assessment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when he slipped on a wet floor surface near the resin mixing station. The slip occurred due to a spill from the previous shift that had not been properly cleaned or marked with warning signage. Savard fell backward onto the concrete floor, sustaining minor lacerations to his left elbow and hip. He was immediately assisted by night shift supervisor Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, who was present conducting routine equipment audits. Thompson provided first aid treatment including wound cleaning, antiseptic application, and non-adhesive bandages. Savard did not require hospitalization and returned to light duty the next day. The incident was investigated by Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, revealing inadequate spill response procedures and insufficient hazard communication in the chemical storage area.

On March 14, 2024, at 9:15 AM during day shift operations, Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), a Composite Materials Operator, was preparing raw glass fiber reinforcements in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While removing a bundle of glass fiber from a storage rack, she noticed the resin dryer unit (a critical piece of equipment for moisture content reduction) was displaying an unusual heating pattern on its digital display. The dryer temperature was fluctuating between 65°C and 95°C rather than maintaining the standard 80°C ± 2°C setpoint. Recognizing this as a potential equipment malfunction that could compromise material quality and pose a fire risk, Lina immediately halted the drying cycle, removed the material batch currently inside, and notified her supervisor Samantha Brown. The equipment was isolated and tagged for maintenance inspection. No injuries occurred, but the incident prompted a preventive review of all temperature-controlled equipment to establish baseline maintenance protocols. This declaration reflects TechnoPlast's commitment to proactive hazard identification before equipment failures result in injuries or fires.

On March 18, 2024, at 4:45 PM during evening shift operations, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), a Machine Operator, was transferring finished composite material parts to the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005) using a manual four-wheel dolly. As he navigated through the narrow corridor connecting the production area to UNIT-005, the dolly's front wheel struck a recently spilled puddle of uncleaned hydraulic lubricant on the floor near the Maintenance technician's storage area. The sudden loss of traction caused the dolly to veer sharply toward a wall-mounted electrical distribution panel. Emmanuel quickly corrected course by shifting his body weight and pushing hard on the dolly handle, preventing a collision with the panel. The dolly came to rest safely, and no parts were damaged. Indira Singh (EMP-00104), a Quality Auditor who was nearby, witnessed the incident. Upon investigation, the hydraulic spill was determined to have occurred during routine machine maintenance but was not immediately cleaned or marked with warning signage. This near-miss scenario highlighted a critical gap in hazmat cleanup procedures and floor hazard management during shift transitions.

On March 22, 2024, at 11:20 PM during night shift operations, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, was organizing finished goods inventory in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) when she sustained a splinter injury to her right index finger. While removing a plastic-wrapped product batch from a wooden storage pallet, a protruding wooden splinter from the pallet's edge penetrated the glove she was wearing and embedded in her finger. Elif immediately reported the injury to the night shift supervisor, who contacted the Occupational Health Nurse, Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), via the on-call paging system. Hana arrived at the warehouse within 8 minutes. Upon examination, the splinter was approximately 8mm long and had penetrated the finger to a depth of 3-4mm, causing bleeding and localized swelling. Hana performed first aid treatment including: thorough cleaning with antiseptic solution, careful splinter extraction using sterile tweezers, application of antibiotic ointment, and bandaging with sterile gauze. The wound did not require sutures or external medical referral. Elif was released to light duty for the remainder of the shift, with instructions to monitor for infection and follow-up assessment after 24 hours. The incident was documented on the workplace first aid log.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:30 PM during the day shift, Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), the Ergonomics Specialist, conducted a routine workstation assessment in the Injection Molding Line B - Automotive section. While observing operators performing repetitive part removal tasks, he identified that three assembly operators, including Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), were exhibiting improper body mechanics and strain patterns consistent with early-stage repetitive strain injury development. The operators were removing cooled plastic components from mold cavities using pinching motions without adequate breaks or rotational tasks. Mercier observed that workstations lacked adjustable height platforms and anti-fatigue matting, contributing to prolonged static postures. He documented excessive wrist extension, shoulder elevation, and lack of neutral spine positioning across all three stations. No injury had yet occurred, but the ergonomic hazards were clearly present. Mercier immediately reported these findings to production supervision and initiated a preventive intervention process to mitigate RSI risk before any lost-time injuries developed.

On April 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring polyester resin from a large storage drum to a smaller mixing vessel in the Raw Materials Warehouse - Section A. While opening the storage drum's bung, pressurized chemical vapor escaped unexpectedly, spraying concentrated epoxy hardener directly onto her left forearm and hand. The chemical contact caused immediate thermal sensation and visible reddening of the skin. Elena was wearing minimal PPE—no chemical-resistant gloves and only a standard shop apron. A nearby material handler, Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), heard her cry out and immediately assisted. The spill was contained using absorbent material, and Elena was taken to the facility's first aid station where her arm was rinsed with copious amounts of water for 15 minutes. Second-degree chemical burns approximately 4 inches by 2 inches developed on her forearm, with blistering and partial thickness involvement. She was transported to the local hospital for evaluation and treatment, requiring 8 stitches and a 5-day medical leave. The incident was caused by inadequate pressure release procedures and failure to use required chemical-resistant PPE.

On May 8, 2024, at 11:45 PM during the night shift, René Caron (EMP-00097), the Tool Maker, was performing preventive maintenance on a hydraulic injection press in the Central Maintenance Workshop. He had begun work to replace worn seals in the mold closing system. While checking the mold position using manual hand movements (without applying proper lockout/tagout), a co-worker in another section accidentally activated a remote control for the hydraulic pump, unaware that maintenance was being performed. The mold suddenly began closing, pinching René's right hand between the lower and upper mold plates at approximately 6 inches of travel before the worker noticed and stopped the pump. René sustained a severely crushed right hand with fractures to the 3rd, 4th, and 5th metacarpals, crush injuries to soft tissues, and contusions across the palm and fingers. He was transported by ambulance to the trauma center and hospitalized for 6 days, undergoing emergency orthopedic surgery. The primary root cause was failure to execute lockout/tagout procedures before initiating maintenance work—the equipment remained energized and controllable by other personnel.

On June 3, 2024, at 4:15 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was retrieving composite material spools from a high storage shelf in the Hazardous Waste Management Area - Exterior Zone. While reaching upward to grab a spool of fiberglass-reinforced plastic strips, her hand came into contact with the sharp fiberglass edge of an improperly stored spool that was protruding from the shelf. The contact caused multiple microscopic glass fiber splinters to embed in her palm and fingers. Simultaneously, several spools shifted on the shelf due to unstable stacking, and one spool nearly fell but was caught by the shelf edge, coming to rest 2 inches above Marwa's head. Had the spool fallen, it would have caused a serious head injury. Marwa immediately withdrew her hand and reported minor skin irritation consistent with glass fiber splinters. The spools were immediately restabilized. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, was nearby and helped document the near-miss. First aid treatment consisted of gentle skin washing and splinter removal. No lost time occurred, but the incident highlighted serious storage and handling deficiencies.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire originated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) when Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of colorant masterbatch. While transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum to a smaller mixing vessel, static electricity discharged near an open container of isopropanol solvent. The spark ignited the solvent vapors, creating a flash fire that spread across the work surface. Elena immediately activated the emergency stop and attempted to contain the fire with a Type B fire extinguisher, but the fire grew rapidly due to the presence of multiple flammable materials stored nearby, including rolls of polypropylene shrink wrap and additional solvent containers. The facility's fire suppression system activated automatically, and emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes. The fire was fully extinguished within 12 minutes. The incident resulted in significant damage to equipment and materials in the storage area, but no employee injuries occurred. Karine Cloutier from HSE arrived on scene to coordinate emergency response and document the incident.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 9:15 AM during the day shift, Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030), a Machine Setter on Injection Molding Line A, sustained a laceration to his left hand while removing flash (excess plastic) from a molded component. The part had just been ejected from the injection mold and retained significant heat. Karim was not wearing cut-resistant gloves as required by departmental procedures—he had removed them briefly to improve tactile sensitivity while inspecting part quality. As he picked up a sharp trim tool to remove flash material, the tool slipped on the still-warm plastic surface and cut across his palm, requiring six stitches at the facility medical clinic. The injury was treated on-site by the occupational health nurse, Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), who provided immediate first aid including wound cleaning, hemostasis application, and proper dressing. The wound was classified as a minor laceration not requiring hospitalization or lost work time. Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190), operating the adjacent Line B machine, witnessed the incident and immediately alerted supervision. The incident occurred because Karim prioritized production speed over safety protocol adherence, combined with inadequate awareness of post-mold thermal hazards.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 4:20 PM during the evening shift, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, suffered a significant back injury while manually lifting a 45-pound bin of composite scrap material from the production floor to a collection cart positioned 28 inches above ground level. The bin was awkwardly shaped, reducing grip stability, and Benoit had not been provided with mechanical assistance tools (such as a vacuum lifter or pneumatic hoist) despite repeated requests. He bent at the waist rather than using proper lifting technique, compounding the biomechanical stress. As he lifted the bin to chest height, he felt acute pain in his lower lumbar region and immediately dropped the bin, unable to continue. Benoit reported the injury to his supervisor and was transported to a local medical facility by ambulance. Clinical examination revealed a lumbar strain with muscle spasm affecting the L4-L5 vertebral region. The physician recommended 5 days of medical leave and prescribed physical therapy. This injury resulted in lost work time exceeding 24 hours, making it a recordable lost-time incident. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), the Emergency Response Team Leader, coordinated the emergency transport and subsequent incident documentation. Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), a colleague on the evening shift, witnessed the incident and provided immediate support.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) was operating the automated material handling system in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) to transfer dried polypropylene resin into the hopper of Injection Molding Line B. The system's cooling water circulation pump began exhibiting unusual vibration and audible grinding sounds around 2:30 PM. Despite these warning signs, operations continued. At 2:45 PM, the cooling water pump seal failed catastrophically, causing a pressurized leak of approximately 50 liters of heated coolant (operating temperature 65°C) across the material preparation area. The leak spread across the floor, and Mansour slipped on the wet surface, falling backward and striking her left shoulder against the edge of a resin storage bin. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) witnessed the incident and immediately shut down the system and called for first aid. Mansour experienced acute pain and limited mobility in her shoulder. The incident resulted in 4 hours of cleanup and equipment shutdown before operations could resume. The cooling water system had not received preventive maintenance in 18 months, well beyond the manufacturer's recommended 12-month service interval.

On April 2, 2025, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171) was working at Line D in the Injection Molding Line B facility (UNIT-002). While removing molded components from the injection machine, Jalbert attempted to clear a minor jam in the part ejection system without following proper lockout/tagout procedures. A colleague, Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030), was performing routine mold temperature adjustments nearby. When Jalbert reached into the machine cavity to dislodge a stuck part, the molding cycle unexpectedly initiated—apparently triggered by residual pressure in the hydraulic system from the previous cycle. The moving mold clamp compressed rapidly, pinching Jalbert's right hand and ring finger between the two mold halves. The fingertip of his ring finger was partially crushed, causing laceration and tissue damage. Jalbert screamed, and Bouazizi immediately triggered the emergency stop button, halting the machine within 2 seconds. First aid responders applied direct pressure and called emergency services. Jalbert was transported to the hospital for surgical evaluation; the finger was ultimately preserved but required 45 stitches and significant post-operative care. Investigation revealed that the machine's pressure relief valve had been set above specification, and the daily pre-shift safety checklist had been skipped. Jalbert had been working overtime for 6 consecutive days and appeared fatigued.

On May 8, 2025, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) conducted a routine walkthrough inspection of the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) and discovered a potential safety concern. While inspecting the compressed air distribution system, Rioux noticed that the pressure relief valve on the main air compressor tank had been manually adjusted and was no longer set to the manufacturer's specified pressure limit of 120 PSI. A pressure gauge reading indicated the system was pressurized to approximately 165 PSI—37% above safe operating limits. The relief valve appeared to have been tampered with, possibly by a maintenance technician attempting to achieve faster air tool cycling times for efficiency purposes. Rioux immediately depressurized the system following protocol and labeled the compressor with a maintenance-required tag. Investigation determined that no incident had yet occurred, but the hazardous condition posed an imminent risk of tank rupture or sudden decompression causing pressurized air misuse injuries. Rioux documented his finding and reported it to the HSE office. This preventive discovery demonstrates the facility's commitment to proactive hazard identification before injuries occur. The pressure relief valve was recalibrated and locked to prevent future tampering. All maintenance staff received refresher training on compressed air safety protocols.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, a hydraulic line rupture occurred on Injection Molding Line B during routine production of automotive dashboard components. Operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) was monitoring the machine when pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the work station, damaging critical control panel electronics and soaking approximately 800 lbs of polycarbonate resin inventory stored nearby. The hydraulic hose, originally installed in 2019, had developed micro-fractures due to vibration and age but was not included in the preventive maintenance rotation. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) responded immediately and isolated the line. The incident resulted in an estimated $47,000 in equipment damage, loss of 12 hours of production, and contamination of finished goods in process. The control panel required complete replacement and the affected resin batch was deemed unsuitable for medical-grade applications. Investigation revealed the hydraulic system maintenance schedule had not been updated since facility expansion in 2021.

On March 22, 2024 at 02:15 during the night shift, a major chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of acetone-based mold release agent when the drum's bottom valve was accidentally left in the partially open position by the previous shift operator. Approximately 35 gallons spilled across the concrete floor before Marwa discovered the leak. The spill migrated toward the floor drain system and threatened to contaminate the stormwater system. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) was called in immediately and activated the spill response protocol. Absorbent materials were deployed and the drain system was isolated using emergency plugs. Environmental cleanup required specialized hazmat contractors and cost $62,000. The incident revealed that valve inspection procedures were missing from the chemical handling standard operating procedures, and shift handover documentation was inadequate. Approximately 8 hours of production delay occurred as the area was isolated during remediation.

On March 10, 2024 at 09:30, a near-miss incident occurred at the Shipping and Receiving Dock during routine material handling. Packaging Operator Amina Ba (EMP-00164) was walking along the dock when she nearly stepped into a gap created by improperly stacked pallets of finished goods. The stack had been arranged by Material Handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) approximately 30 minutes earlier without proper spacing or securing. Amina caught herself on a nearby railing, preventing a fall approximately 24 inches to a lower loading area. Shipping Clerk Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019) witnessed the near-miss and immediately reported it to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007). Inspection revealed that the pallet arrangement violated stack height protocols (stacked 8 pallets high instead of maximum 6) and was not secured with safety straps. The dock had accumulated cardboard debris and packaging materials in the walking path, creating multiple trip hazards. Investigation determined that the material handler training curriculum did not include current dock layout procedures, and the dock area lacked clear lane markings and hazard signage.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195) was working at Line A in the Main Production Building when he experienced a burn injury. While adjusting the mold temperature settings on a 250-ton injection molding machine, Conrad's left forearm made contact with an exposed hot mold surface that had reached approximately 180°C. The operator was wearing standard work gloves but they were insufficient to prevent heat transfer. Conrad immediately withdrew his arm and reported the incident to his supervisor. Emergency first aid was administered by the on-site safety officer within 5 minutes. The burn affected approximately 12% of the forearm surface area, resulting in second-degree thermal burns. Conrad was transported to the local medical facility for treatment and observation. The incident was witnessed by Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) who was working nearby. Root cause analysis revealed that the machine's thermal insulation blanket had partially deteriorated, exposing hot surfaces that should have been covered. Additionally, the operator's task required close proximity to the mold without adequate protective barriers.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the night shift, Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was performing routine maintenance in the Hazardous Waste Management Area when he experienced acute inhalation exposure to solvent vapors. While transferring residual resin solvents from storage containers into a waste collection tank, the local exhaust ventilation system malfunctioned, causing vapors to concentrate in the work area. Louis began experiencing dizziness, headache, and difficulty breathing within 10 minutes of starting the transfer operation. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) noticed Louis exhibiting signs of distress and immediately evacuated him from the area and called for emergency medical assistance. First responders arrived at 11:02 PM and provided oxygen therapy. Louis was transported to the hospital for observation and pulmonary function testing. The incident occurred because the ventilation system had not been inspected in over 6 months, and a blocked filter was restricting airflow. No other employees were in the immediate vicinity, preventing secondary exposures.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, a critical equipment failure occurred at the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility in the Main Production Building. The primary resin dryer, a large industrial oven used for drying and curing composite materials, experienced uncontrolled temperature escalation. The internal thermostat and automatic shutoff mechanism failed simultaneously, causing internal temperatures to exceed 220°C, well above the safe operating limit of 150°C for the materials being processed. The malfunction was detected when Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), who was monitoring production logistics, noticed smoke emanating from the unit at approximately 8:32 AM. He immediately activated the emergency shutdown and evacuated the immediate area. The facility's automated fire suppression system engaged, containing the situation and preventing a potential fire. Post-incident inspection revealed that the temperature control module had suffered catastrophic failure due to corrosion of internal circuitry, likely accelerated by inadequate preventive maintenance. The heating elements were damaged beyond repair, and the internal ceramic lining sustained significant thermal stress damage. Replacement cost estimates exceeded $85,000. The dryer was out of service for 18 days, causing production delays for composite materials contracts.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was working at Injection Molding Line B when she noticed unusual resistance while removing finished automotive trim parts from the mold cavity. Upon closer inspection, she identified that the mold cooling system had developed a hairline crack, allowing coolant to seep into the product. The crack appeared to have originated from thermal stress cycles over the past week. Fatou immediately reported the issue to her supervisor and ceased production. The mold was quarantined pending inspection. Quality Control Technician Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013) was called to verify that no contaminated parts had entered the distribution pipeline. A preliminary assessment revealed approximately 340 parts produced over the past 8 hours were at risk of mold contamination. The incident was escalated to Mold Technician Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021) for detailed failure analysis. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) was notified to document the preventive declaration and assess whether the mold's maintenance schedule requires adjustment. No employee injuries occurred; however, the incident highlighted the need for enhanced mold condition monitoring protocols.

On April 2, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Forklift Operator Claude Poirier (EMP-00071) was transporting a pallet of raw plastic resin to the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. As he maneuvered the propane-powered forklift through the warehouse corridor, the vehicle's left front tire struck a metal debris edge on the concrete floor, causing the forklift to suddenly tilt. The load of resin pallets, weighing approximately 2,400 pounds, shifted laterally and toppled to the ground, spilling resin granules across an 8-foot area. The forklift itself came to rest at a 15-degree angle but remained upright. Poirier was not injured but was shaken by the incident. Materials Management Technician Denis Savard (EMP-00099) responded and immediately cordoned off the spill area using hazard tape. The spilled resin was carefully collected and segregated for recycling evaluation. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie (EMP-00199) inspected both the forklift tire condition and the warehouse floor surface, discovering significant wear on the tire's tread (estimated 40% remaining) and an unrepaired pothole that had created the debris edge that caused the tip. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) documented the incident and assessed environmental impact—minimal, as the spilled resin remained contained within secondary containment protocols. Director Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001) required a full investigation into equipment maintenance and floor safety standards.

On April 8, 2024, at 03:30 during the night shift, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was operating a precision CNC milling machine in the maintenance workshop to fabricate a replacement core pin for an injection mold. The machine's spindle began emitting an irregular grinding noise and vibrating erratically. Sokolov attempted to continue the machining operation, assuming the noise would subside. Approximately 90 seconds later, the spindle bearing catastrophically failed, causing the cutting tool to break free and strike the machine's control panel, shattering the protective polycarbonate guard and damaging three electronic control modules. Sokolov was wearing safety glasses and was not struck by the tool fragment. Instrumentation Technician Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075) was called immediately and discovered that the spindle bearing's lubrication system had failed—the oil reservoir was empty despite being filled only 72 hours prior. Investigation revealed a hairline crack in the oil circulation hose that had been gradually leaking for several days. The bearing had been operating dry for an estimated 6-8 hours of cumulative machine time, causing progressive degradation. Hydraulic Systems Technician Andrei Popov (EMP-00094) examined the failed hose and confirmed it was original equipment installed 7 years ago, well beyond its recommended 5-year service life. The CNC machine was taken offline for full spindle replacement and control module repair. Director Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001) initiated a comprehensive review of maintenance intervals for all milling equipment. Estimated machine downtime: 4 business days.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was operating a forklift in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) to relocate pallets of completed medical device housings. While navigating between storage racks, the forklift's right front tire struck a water puddle from a recent cooling system maintenance check. The sudden hydroplaning caused the forklift to veer left, and the load of approximately 1,200 kg shifted laterally. The forklift tipped over at approximately 35 degrees, with the mast striking the floor. De Luca jumped clear of the vehicle but sustained a laceration to her left forearm from sharp metal contact with the mast assembly during her exit. She was conscious and alert, and her injury was contained to a 4 cm laceration requiring 6 stitches and tetanus prophylaxis. Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) witnessed the incident and immediately called for first aid response. The forklift operator certification and equipment inspection records were reviewed and found to be current.

On April 2, 2024 at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was performing routine cleaning of injection molding equipment in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005). While using compressed air to clear plastic debris from a mold cavity, she inadvertently directed the air stream toward her left hand, which was supporting the mold frame. The compressed air penetrated the webbing between her thumb and index finger, creating a small puncture wound approximately 2 mm in diameter. The injury was not immediately painful but displayed minor swelling and bruising within minutes. Supervisor Petra Mueller (EMP-00166) observed the incident and directed Petrov to the on-site first aid station where the wound was cleaned, disinfected with antiseptic solution, and dressed with a sterile bandage. No sutures were required. Ice was applied for 15 minutes to reduce swelling. Tetanus status was verified as current. The injury was classified as a minor puncture wound and Petrov returned to modified duty for the remainder of her shift, avoiding heavy gripping tasks.

On April 18, 2024 at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) was performing preventive maintenance on a cooling water circulation pump located in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014). While loosening a union fitting on a 50 mm discharge line to replace a worn seal, residual pressure in the system unexpectedly discharged approximately 15 liters of coolant solution containing a mixture of water and propylene glycol-based coolant. The sudden release sprayed Rossi's face, upper torso, and left arm with the coolant solution. Although propylene glycol-based coolants are considered low-toxicity, the solution caused immediate eye irritation and mild skin irritation upon exposed areas. Rossi rinsed his face and affected skin areas with water for 10 minutes at the safety shower station. He reported mild conjunctivitis and first-degree skin irritation to his left shoulder and forearm. Quality Technician Natalya Kozlov (EMP-00192), who was performing night shift quality checks nearby, assisted Rossi to the first aid station. Medical evaluation confirmed no systemic toxicity exposure. The incident investigation revealed that system pressure had not been fully relieved through the correct bleeder valve before opening the union.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Diego Morales was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station when he experienced a chemical splash incident. While transferring finished medical device components from the post-processing area to the packaging station, a container of isopropyl alcohol used for final cleaning tipped over on the conveyor system. The spill rolled toward Morales as he was organizing labeled components. Some of the liquid splashed upward, contacting his right forearm and the outer edge of his safety glasses. Morales immediately reported the incident to his supervisor, Julie Bergeron, who directed him to the eyewash station. Although he was wearing safety glasses, a small amount of the chemical irritated the corner of his right eye. Morales rinsed for the recommended 15 minutes at the eyewash station and reported minor discomfort. No medical attention beyond first aid was required. The incident was contained quickly by maintenance staff who absorbent materials to clean the spill within 20 minutes.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu was performing routine maintenance on the chemical compounding equipment in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. While cleaning the exterior of a resin dryer that had cooled for approximately 2 hours, Popescu noticed steam still being emitted from a valve near the heating element. She attempted to tighten the valve using a wrench without first confirming the internal temperature had fully decreased. The residual heat caused a small burst of hot steam and resin vapor to escape, making contact with the back of her left hand and wrist despite her wearing nitrile gloves. She immediately removed the gloves and ran her hand under cool water at the nearby sink for 10 minutes. Her supervisor, Julie Bergeron, was notified and assessed the injury—two small first-degree burns approximately 2 cm in diameter on the dorsal surface of the hand. Popescu was treated with topical burn ointment, bandaged with sterile gauze, and instructed to monitor for infection. No lost time occurred. The incident was recorded and reviewed during the safety briefing the following morning.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, Injection Molding Operator Rémi Charbonneau was conducting a routine part removal cycle from Molding Line D when the mold closing mechanism experienced a sudden hydraulic pressure surge. Despite the machine showing a green ready light, the mold plates began closing unexpectedly while Charbonneau's left hand was still positioned in the lower die cavity removing a finished component. His fingers were caught between the upper and lower mold halves as they compressed. Colleague Kwame Mensah, also working on the night shift, immediately hit the emergency stop button, halting the mold closure within 2 seconds. However, Charbonneau sustained crushing injuries to his left index and middle fingers. Emergency response was initiated at 6:18 AM. Paramedics arrived within 12 minutes and transported Charbonneau to Laval General Hospital. X-rays revealed fractures to both fingers and soft tissue damage. He was admitted for observation and surgical consultation. Medical evaluation determined that amputation of the index finger at the second joint was necessary due to irreparable tissue damage. Charbonneau underwent surgery on April 19 and spent 3 days hospitalized.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, injection molding operator Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117) was working at Injection Molding Line C when she experienced a minor burn injury. While removing a finished part from the mold cavity, the mold temperature control system malfunctioned, causing the mold plate to reach 185°C instead of the normal operating temperature of 145°C. Desjardins made contact with the hot mold surface for approximately 2 seconds before retracting her hand. She sustained a first-degree burn approximately 3cm x 2cm on the dorsal surface of her right hand. The employee immediately notified her supervisor, applied cold water to the affected area for 10 minutes, and reported to the facility first aid station. The burn was cleaned, dressed with antibiotic ointment, and covered with a sterile bandage. No hospitalization was required. Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) witnessed the incident and assisted in documenting the event. The root cause was identified as a faulty temperature sensor that had not been calibrated in over 18 months, allowing the mold to overheat beyond safe operating parameters.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was operating an overhead crane in the Finished Goods Warehouse to move a pallet of medical device housings weighing approximately 2,400 kg. The pallet was positioned on the warehouse floor near the loading dock. As Mwangi raised the load approximately 4 meters, the left lifting hook assembly suddenly separated from the crane's load hook due to metal fatigue and corrosion in the hook eye. The pallet tilted and dropped, with approximately 60% of the load falling to the floor. The remaining load suspended from the right hook swung unpredictably. Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) was present in the area and immediately activated the emergency stop. No personnel were struck by falling materials, though several boxes were damaged. Investigation revealed the left hook had not been inspected in 24 months and showed significant corrosion pitting and stress cracks consistent with 18+ months of heavy use without maintenance. The equipment failure created an immediate hazard and resulted in approximately $34,000 in product damage and rework costs.

On April 3, 2024 at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Shipping Clerk Julien Racine (EMP-00177) was operating a propane-powered forklift in the Packaging and Labeling Station to move a pallet of consumer packaging containers into the shipping area. As Racine was maneuvering the forklift between narrow aisles near a stacked inventory area, the rear wheels struck a metal support pillar anchor point due to inadequate aisle width. The forklift tipped approximately 25 degrees to the right. Though Racine remained in the operator seat, the forward-facing load consisting of 8 large cartons of packaged cosmetic containers shifted and fell forward, with approximately 5 cartons landing on the ground. The remaining cartons caused damage to the forklift's overhead guard. The incident was witnessed by Packaging Operator Nour Jaber (EMP-00188) who immediately called for assistance. Investigation revealed that the storage rack layout had been reconfigured 3 weeks prior during inventory reorganization, reducing the main aisle width from 3.2 meters to 2.8 meters without updating forklift traffic patterns or conducting a hazard assessment. The equipment sustained damage to the right side forks and hydraulic cylinder, requiring repair estimated at $22,000. Approximately $8,500 in product damage occurred.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 14:45, Production Operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was working on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone when she experienced acute exposure to resin fumes. The line had been running automotive component parts with polyurethane resin when a vent duct connection loosened, releasing concentrated fumes directly into the work area. Leila reported immediate symptoms including dizziness, eye irritation, and respiratory distress. She was assisted by her shift supervisor Valérie Pelletier (EMP-00031) who initiated emergency response protocols. Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) from Facilities Maintenance was called to address the mechanical failure. Leila was moved to fresh air and provided oxygen from the first aid station. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) conducted air quality measurements confirming fume concentrations exceeded safe WHMIS limits. Leila was transported to a local medical facility where she was treated for chemical inhalation exposure and released after 4 hours of observation. The incident was traced to inadequate preventive maintenance on ventilation connections and missing inspection tags. This was a High-gravity, Medium-probability risk that materialized due to deferred equipment maintenance.

On March 18, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, a significant material handling incident occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Maintenance Workshop Storage Mezzanine). Receiving Clerk Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085) was retrieving mold components from the upper storage rack when he dislodged a stack of metal injection mold frames. The approximately 250-pound stack fell from the 2.5-meter mezzanine platform, impacting the concrete floor below and damaging adjacent equipment, including a precision temperature controller valued at $18,000 and a hydraulic pressure gauge assembly worth $3,200. Additionally, the falling molds struck a fork truck parked beneath the mezzanine, damaging its hydraulic hose connections and front bumper (estimated repair: $4,500). Jacques was startled but uninjured, positioned approximately 3 meters from the impact site. Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) witnessed the incident from the adjacent storage area. Tool Room Technician Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173) conducted a damage assessment. Investigation revealed that the storage rack lacked proper load containment barriers and was overloaded beyond its rated capacity of 300 pounds per shelf, with items stored 90 pounds over limit. Total property damage: $25,700. No personnel were hospitalized, but the incident exposed critical hazards in material storage practices.

On March 22, 2024 at approximately 03:30 during the night shift, a fire hazard alert was triggered in the Assembly and Finishing Department (Main Production Building East Wing). Night shift Assembly Operator Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186) observed visible dust accumulation on horizontal surfaces and equipment ledges, particularly near the post-processing ovens where composite curing occurs. The facility operates with strict fire protocols, and per ISO 45001 procedures, visible dust accumulation exceeding 1/32 inch (approximately 0.8 mm) is classified as a fire risk. Valentina immediately reported the hazard to Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), who conducted a full inspection. Sanaa identified dust buildup in three critical areas: along the oven exhaust ductwork, on top of material staging cabinets, and in the corner near electrical distribution panels. Air quality monitoring by Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) the following morning confirmed combustible dust concentrations in the 5-15 mg/m³ range (heightened risk zone). The root cause was identified as a malfunction in the automated dust collection system that had been offline for 72 hours due to a faulty sensor. No actual fire occurred, but the risk was substantial given the proximity to ignition sources (ovens operating at 180°C). This incident represents both a HIGH-gravity, LOW-probability risk (Dust Accumulation Fire Hazard) that materialized due to inadequate equipment maintenance and monitoring procedures.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, Material Handler Mariam Osman was transferring resin bags from a pallet to storage shelving in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) when the bottom shelf of a four-tier industrial storage rack suddenly collapsed. The rack had been in service for 12 years with no documented maintenance or load capacity verification. Approximately 180 kg of polypropylene resin bags cascaded downward, striking the adjacent equipment and scattering material across a 4-meter radius. While Mariam was not directly struck, the incident created a significant hazard zone. Witness Production Operator Maya Kumar immediately alerted Supervisory staff. The collapsed shelf caused approximately $8,500 in property damage including damaged resin inventory, bent shelf components, and minor damage to a nearby dehumidification unit. The facility's HSE team cordoned off the area and initiated an inspection of all other storage racks in the facility. Root cause analysis identified lack of routine rack maintenance, no documented load calculations, and absence of regular safety inspections as contributing factors.

On March 18, 2024 at 09:20, Production Operator Leila Farah was operating Injection Molding Machine #7 (a 250-ton Engel system) on the day shift when she detected unusual vibrations and grinding noise from the mold closing mechanism. Despite the abnormal sounds, she attempted to continue production to meet daily quotas. At 09:47, while the mold was in the closing cycle with no parts inside, the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned, causing uncontrolled closing force. Leila's left hand was positioned near the mold entrance to inspect part flow, and her fingers (index, middle, and ring finger) were caught between the mold plates as they closed. The automatic safety interlock failed to activate due to a disconnected proximity sensor. Emergency response was initiated immediately by her supervisor, Lucie Fillion. The mold was manually forced open using emergency manual override procedures within 3 minutes. Leila sustained severe crush injuries to her left hand requiring immediate transport to Laval Hospital emergency department. Preliminary assessment indicated possible fractures to multiple finger bones and crush tissue damage. The incident triggered an immediate facility-wide halt of all 32 injection molding machines pending safety verification.

On March 21, 2024 at 18:15 during the evening shift, a malfunction in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) triggered an inadvertent discharge of the dry chemical fire suppression system. Shipping and Receiving Clerk Mélanie Fortin was transferring colorant masterbatch containers from a storage shelf when her elbow accidentally struck the manual pull-handle of the sprinkler activation system mounted on a support column. The system was not equipped with a protective shroud or tamper-resistant design. Within seconds, approximately 60 kg of monoammonium phosphate powder was discharged throughout the room, coating all surfaces including equipment, storage containers, and work surfaces with a fine white residue. The alarm activated automatically, triggering facility evacuation procedures. Evening Shift Supervisor Lucie Fillion coordinated the evacuation. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger and maintenance staff arrived to assess the discharge. While no actual fire occurred and no personnel were exposed to fire suppression residue for extended periods, the discharge required several hours of cleanup to restore the room to operational status. The incident caused approximately $6,200 in losses including damaged chemical inventory ($3,400), contaminated equipment requiring decontamination ($1,800), and cleanup labor costs ($1,000). The suppression system powder residue damaged several resin bags and required disposal of approximately 45 kg of stored materials.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, an assembly operator (EMP-00078) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station when she noticed that a robotic arm on an adjacent injection molding line was moving erratically. The arm's normal cyclical motion appeared to have increased in speed and amplitude. She immediately called over her supervisor and a nearby quality assurance specialist (EMP-00046) to observe. Upon investigation, it was discovered that a loose sensor cable had caused the arm's proximity detection system to malfunction, creating a pinch point hazard approximately 18 inches from the operator's workstation. The arm was immediately powered down using the emergency stop button at 2:47 PM. No contact occurred between personnel and the equipment. Witness EMP-00046 documented the incident and a maintenance engineer was called to repair the sensor connection. The area was cordoned off with yellow caution tape for 45 minutes until the equipment was repaired and tested. This near-miss highlighted a critical gap in preventive maintenance protocols for sensor systems.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. An employee (EMP-00085) was transferring polyester resin from a 55-gallon drum into smaller containers for the next day's production run. A static electricity discharge occurred as the resin was being poured, igniting vapors above the liquid surface. The resulting flash fire burned approximately 2 square feet of the work surface and ignited nearby packaging materials stacked 4 feet away. The alarm was activated at 10:17 PM. The plant manager (EMP-00002) arrived within 2 minutes. The employee used the nearby Type B dry chemical fire extinguisher to suppress the flames, successfully containing the fire to the immediate work area by 10:19 PM. No personnel injuries occurred. The fire suppression system was activated as a precaution, affecting 40% of the chemical storage building. Local fire department arrived at 10:28 PM and confirmed the incident was controlled. Approximately 25 gallons of resin and various packaging materials were destroyed. The incident was caused by inadequate grounding of the transfer equipment and insufficient spacing between resin containers and combustible materials.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room located on the maintenance workshop mezzanine. A receiving clerk (EMP-00085) was moving a pallet of hydraulic fluid containers (5-liter cans) using a manual pallet jack when the load shifted. One container fell approximately 8 feet to the concrete floor below and ruptured, releasing approximately 3 gallons of ISO 32 hydraulic fluid. The fluid spread across approximately 20 square feet of the floor surface and began dripping through the mezzanine grating onto the main workshop floor where maintenance equipment was being serviced. The spill was discovered at 8:32 AM when a maintenance supervisor (EMP-00105) noticed fluid dripping and activated the spill response protocol. The area was immediately cordoned off with caution tape. Absorbent material was deployed and the spilled fluid was contained within 15 minutes. All personnel were evacuated from the lower floor as a precaution. The spill was classified as minor under Quebec environmental regulations, but the fluid cleanup took approximately 2 hours and created a slip hazard. Root cause analysis identified inadequate load securing on the pallet jack and insufficient staff training on material handling procedures.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Stéphane Moreau, a Mold Technician, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of mold release agent from a storage shelf when the drum's bung plug became loose due to improper sealing during the previous shift. As he tilted the drum onto a cart, approximately 12 gallons of the oily mold release agent spilled onto the concrete floor. The chemical spread rapidly across the 400 square-foot work area, creating a slip hazard. Immediate response included evacuation of the room, notification of the HSE coordinator, and deployment of absorbent materials (clay-based spill kit). The spill was contained within 20 minutes and properly disposed of according to WHMIS protocol. No personal injury occurred, but the incident highlighted gaps in chemical container management and shift handover procedures. The area was cleaned and decontaminated within 2 hours.

On November 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the evening shift setup, Paul Demers, Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a laceration to his right index finger while removing hardened plastic overflow from the mold cavity of Injection Molding Line D. He was cleaning excess material from the previous production run when his hand slipped, causing his finger to contact the sharp edge of accumulated polycarbonate. The cut was approximately 1.5 inches long and 0.25 inches deep, requiring 8 stitches at the urgent care clinic. Paul was unable to return to work for the remainder of his shift and took the following day off, resulting in 24 hours of lost production time. The incident occurred because proper LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures were not followed—the machine was not fully de-energized and locked out before cleaning operations commenced. A fellow operator, Yara Mustafa, witnessed the incident and immediately summoned first aid assistance. The machine was shut down for a full safety inspection before resumption of operations.

On November 10, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, a near-miss incident was narrowly averted in the Maintenance Workshop (adjacent to UNIT-004). Luc Girard, a Maintenance Technician, was performing routine hydraulic hose replacement on an injection molding machine when he failed to fully depressurize the hydraulic system before disconnecting a high-pressure line. As he loosened the fitting, a sudden spray of hydraulic fluid (approximate volume: 2 liters) discharged from the pressurized line, missing his face and torso by approximately 6 inches. Had the angle of discharge been slightly different, the incident would have resulted in serious burns and potential hydraulic fluid injection injury. Luc immediately stepped back and secured the area. A witness, Giovanni Bianchi (CNC Operator on break), observed the incident and alerted the Maintenance Lead. The system was properly depressurized following proper procedures, and the repair was safely completed. Investigation revealed that the pressure relief checklist was bypassed due to time pressure from an earlier production delay. No injury occurred, but the severity of potential consequences warranted formal documentation.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the clean room area when her left hand became caught in the mold clamping mechanism. Sofia was attempting to manually eject a finished component that had not fully released from the mold when a coworker inadvertently activated the machine cycle. The hydraulic clamp compressed her hand between the moving mold halves, resulting in a crush injury to her left palm and fingers. Emergency stop was activated by assembly lead Chantal Côté (EMP-00017) who witnessed the incident. Sofia was transported by ambulance to the nearest hospital with suspected fractures and soft tissue damage. The machine was immediately locked out and tagged. Investigation revealed that the manual component ejection procedure lacked adequate safeguards and inter-lock verification protocols were not being consistently followed by operators.

On March 21, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, material handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) was transferring finished product containers from the production area to the warehouse staging zone. While navigating through the warehouse aisle in the Warehouse and Shipping building, Salma slipped on a wet floor caused by leaked coolant from a nearby forklift maintenance area. She fell backward, striking her left elbow and shoulder against a steel storage rack. Warehouse associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) immediately assisted her, and first aid was administered by the on-site safety officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069). Salma reported pain and restricted range of motion in her shoulder. Upon examination at the facility medical office, a moderate contusion and possible rotator cuff strain were diagnosed. She was referred to external medical care for further evaluation. The spill was immediately cleaned, but investigation revealed that warning signage for the wet area had been removed during maintenance.

On March 25, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, maintenance technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) was performing routine inspection of chemical storage tanks in the Hazardous Waste Management Area. While checking resin level indicators, Fernand splashed a small amount of uncured polyester resin onto his right forearm, causing immediate skin irritation and a mild chemical burn (first-degree, approximately 5cm x 3cm area). He immediately rinsed the affected area with water for 15 minutes per WHMIS procedures. Chemical safety officer Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was notified and provided first aid treatment with topical antibiotic ointment and a protective bandage. No lost time or emergency hospitalization was required. The incident was caused by an improperly secured resin container cap that partially dislodged during routine handling. Fernand was able to resume light duties after treatment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Zara Khan (EMP-00106) was working at Injection Molding Line C when she noticed an unusual odor emanating from the resin mixing station adjacent to her workstation. She immediately informed her supervisor and the area began to feel uncomfortably warm. Upon investigation, facility personnel discovered that the ventilation system serving the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room had partially failed, causing solvent vapors from the resin batch being prepared to accumulate in the production area. The temperature in the clean room had risen to 28°C (82°F), exceeding normal operating parameters. Ms. Khan reported experiencing mild headache and slight dizziness but was not seriously affected due to the quick detection. The facility was partially evacuated as a precautionary measure, and the ventilation system was immediately shut down for inspection. This incident was identified as a preventive declaration to document the near-miss condition and implement corrective measures before a more serious exposure event could occur. No medical treatment was required, but the incident highlighted gaps in preventive maintenance protocols for critical ventilation systems.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, packaging supervisor Anika Johansson (EMP-00144) sustained a laceration to her left hand while operating the automated part trimming station in the Warehouse and Shipping area. Ms. Johansson was manually removing a jammed finished component from the trimmer's feed hopper when her gloved hand contacted the reciprocating blade mechanism. The sharp edge of the plastic component she was retrieving caused a 4-cm laceration across her palm and fingers. Blood loss was minimal but the wound required immediate attention. First aid was administered on-site by the facility first aider, who cleaned and bandaged the wound, applied topical antibiotic, and covered it with sterile gauze. Ms. Johansson was then transported to the on-site occupational health clinic where the wound was evaluated, found to require no sutures, and properly documented. The employee was cleared to return to light duty work the following day. The incident was classified as First Aid because it required professional medical evaluation and wound care beyond basic treatment, though it did not result in lost time or hospitalization.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, a fire alarm was activated at the Warehouse and Shipping facility. The alarm was triggered by an automatic fire detection sensor in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018), which detected smoke and elevated temperature levels. Investigation revealed that a batch of recycled plastic pellets stored in an open bin near the heating station had spontaneously initiated thermal degradation, producing smoke and heat. The facility's automated fire suppression system immediately activated, discharging CO2 into the affected area and halting the thermal event within seconds. All personnel on the night shift (approximately 18 workers) were evacuated following standard procedures. The fire department was called as a precautionary measure and arrived within 8 minutes, confirmed the incident was contained, and cleared the facility for re-entry. No injuries occurred. The bin of degraded material was safely removed and isolated. Root cause analysis determined that the pellet batch had absorbed moisture during storage due to inadequate environmental controls, and the elevated ambient temperature in the recycling area combined with poor ventilation created conditions conducive to thermal degradation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Injection Molding Machine 7 on Line A in the Main Production Building experienced a critical hydraulic system failure. Machine Operator Céline Morin was performing routine material loading when the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned, causing the injection platen to drop unexpectedly during a cycle. The 250-ton platen descended approximately 8 inches before the mechanical safety stops engaged. Although the machine's emergency stop was triggered, the platen had already struck a partially finished component on the mold surface. The malfunction caused significant damage to the mold cavity, with estimated repair costs exceeding $45,000. The component in progress was destroyed. Investigation revealed the relief valve had not been serviced in 18 months despite manufacturer recommendations for 12-month intervals. Maintenance records indicated the inspection was overlooked during a staffing shortage in the previous quarter. No employee was struck directly, but the incident highlighted critical gaps in preventive maintenance scheduling.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during day shift, Assembly Operator Fatima-Zahra El Amrani sustained a significant burn injury while working in the Assembly and Finishing Department. She was manually removing a molded polycarbonate component from a post-curing oven set to 85°C. Despite wearing standard cotton work gloves, she misjudged the component's position and her right forearm made direct contact with the oven's heating element for approximately 2-3 seconds. The contact resulted in a partial-thickness thermal burn covering approximately 12% of her forearm surface area. A fellow operator, Valentina Rossi, immediately assisted by running cold water over the affected area for 15 minutes. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette was notified and provided first aid before EMS transported the employee to Cité-de-la-Santé Hospital in Laval. The employee was hospitalized for 3 days for burn management and has required ongoing wound care. Root cause analysis indicated the oven's temperature warning label had faded, and operators had not received formal training on proper component removal techniques for high-temperature materials.

On April 8, 2024, at 8:30 PM during evening shift, Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron experienced a minor laceration injury while operating the plastic regrind and pelletizing equipment in the Materials Management area. While troubleshooting a material blockage in the extruder hopper, he inadvertently placed his left hand near the rotating feed screw auger. His sleeve caught momentarily on the rotating screw, causing a superficial 2-inch laceration on the back of his hand between the thumb and index finger. The injury began bleeding moderately, and Bergeron immediately removed his hand and triggered the emergency stop button. He reported the incident to Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov, who provided first aid using the on-site first aid kit. Wound cleaning was performed with antiseptic solution, and the laceration was dressed with sterile gauze and medical tape. The employee did not require hospital transport or stitches, meeting first aid criteria. The injury was treated and the employee was able to continue work with modified duty for 2 hours before returning to full duty the next shift. Root cause: The machine's safety guard was missing a cover panel that had been removed 3 weeks prior for maintenance but never reinstalled.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was removing cooled parts from the mold cavity of an injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. After completing his 6th hour of continuous part removal without a break, François began experiencing sharp pain in his wrists and forearms. He reported the pain to his Assembly Lead, Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128), who immediately notified the HSE team. Upon evaluation by Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084), François was found to have acute inflammation consistent with repetitive strain injury from the repetitive grasping and twisting motions required to extract parts from molds. The employee was removed from the line and sent for medical evaluation. X-rays revealed no fractures, but MRI imaging showed tendon inflammation. François was placed on modified duty for 8 weeks and required physiotherapy. The incident occurred due to inadequate job rotation practices and lack of enforced microbreak protocols during high-volume production runs.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of custom resin formulation in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. While transferring acetone solvent from a 5-gallon container to a smaller mixing vessel, the container slipped from her hand due to inadequate grip caused by wet gloves from a previous cleaning operation. The container tipped but did not spill, catching the edge of a nearby workbench. Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073), the Shipping Coordinator working nearby, immediately noticed the near-miss and alerted Elena. No chemical was released, no one was injured, and no equipment was damaged. However, a spill would have created a significant fire hazard given the proximity to electrical equipment and the flammable nature of acetone. The incident was reported by Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) who arrived on scene within 3 minutes to assess conditions. Investigation revealed that the employee was not following the required dry-hands protocol before handling solvent containers.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Layla Hussein (EMP-00098), an Assembly Operator in the Finished Goods Warehouse, was retrieving packaged automotive components from a high storage rack (approximately 8 feet high) to prepare them for shipment. While reaching for a box on the third shelf, a pallet stack above shifted due to improper weight distribution and uneven loading from earlier that day. A bundle of approximately 40 pounds of plastic packaging materials fell directly onto Layla's left shoulder and arm. The impact caused immediate severe pain, and Layla fell to the concrete floor, striking her head against the rack support column. She lost consciousness for approximately 2 minutes. Shipping Coordinator Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073) was the first responder and immediately called emergency services. Paramedics arrived within 8 minutes and transported Layla to the regional hospital. Medical imaging revealed a fractured left clavicle, left shoulder dislocation, and moderate concussion. She required surgery to repair the shoulder dislocation and was hospitalized for 3 days. The incident resulted in 12 weeks of lost work time. Root cause analysis identified inadequate rack load capacity labeling, lack of load verification procedures, and insufficient training on proper stacking techniques.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was transferring a 25-liter container of mold release agent from the storage rack to a prep cart in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While lifting the container onto the cart, the cap was not fully secured. As she tilted the container slightly, approximately 200 mL of the solvent-based release agent splashed directly into her right eye and onto her face. The employee immediately reported pain and vision impairment. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) was notified and rushed to the scene. First aid was administered immediately: the eye was flushed with water from the eyewash station for 15 minutes per WHMIS protocol. The employee was taken to the on-site clinic where the Occupational Health Nurse (EMP-00052) assessed the injury. No corneal damage was detected, but mild chemical conjunctivitis developed. The employee was sent home with prescribed eye drops and advised to follow up with an ophthalmologist the next day. She returned to work after 2 days with full visual recovery. The incident was caused by improper container sealing procedures and inadequate awareness of safe chemical handling during material transfers.

On November 21, 2024, at 10:47 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) was performing routine maintenance and cleaning on Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-004) when a critical error occurred. The machine was in standby mode, but not fully locked out via LOTO procedures—only emergency stop was activated. While Gosselin was reaching into the mold cavity to remove a stubborn piece of hardened plastic, another technician on the line briefly activated the hydraulic system to relieve pressure.
