The mold suddenly closed, trapping Gosselin's right hand between the upper and lower mold plates. He immediately shouted for help. Gosselin sustained a crushing injury to his right hand with fractures to three fingers (index, middle, and ring) and severe contusions to the palm. Assembly Lead Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128) was present and immediately called emergency services and notified Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007). The employee was transported to Laval Hospital where emergency surgery was performed to realign and pin the fractured bones. The investigation revealed that LOTO lockout tags were not properly installed—the machine had been left in a partially de-energized state rather than fully locked out with individual padlocks from each technician. Medical leave: 6 weeks with return-to-work restrictions for 4 additional weeks.

On November 28, 2024, at 6:22 AM during the night shift, Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) discovered a critical failure in the cooling water system serving the post-processing ovens in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017). The primary cooling water pump had ceased operation, and a significant leak was detected in the copper piping beneath the equipment. When Marchand attempted to isolate the system by closing the manual ball valve, the corroded valve stem broke, causing water pressure to build and spray forcefully from the fractured connection. Approximately 40 liters of 65°C cooling water was suddenly released, spraying onto the floor and equipment. Although no personnel were directly in the spray zone at that moment, the pooling water created a slip hazard and the heat from the water damaged three nearby electrical junction boxes, causing them to spark and trigger the emergency circuit breaker. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie (EMP-00199) was called to the scene and safety was maintained by activating emergency shutdown procedures. The cooling system was completely unavailable for 18 hours, forcing production suspension on all post-processing jobs and causing approximately $85,000 in lost production revenue. Root cause analysis revealed that the cooling system had not received preventive maintenance in 14 months—the design maintenance interval was 6 months. Corrosion of internal piping and valve components had progressed undetected.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM, quality inspector Jasmine Patel was conducting routine visual inspections at the Quality Control Laboratory when she accidentally cut her left index finger on a sharp edge of a polycarbonate test specimen. The specimen had been freshly removed from a tensile testing machine and had developed a jagged burr during the fracture testing process. While handling the part without cut-resistant gloves (as they were not considered necessary for visual inspection tasks), Patel sustained a 2cm laceration requiring immediate first aid treatment. The wound was cleaned, bandaged, and monitored by the facility's first aid station. No sutures were required. The specimen was immediately flagged for proper edge conditioning before quality release. Witness Sakura Kobayashi, Quality Systems Coordinator, observed the incident and assisted with initial first aid application.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, the automated resin dryer serving Injection Molding Line A unexpectedly shut down due to a thermostat malfunction. Temperature sensors indicated a critical overheating condition (380°C, exceeding safe operating limits of 180°C), triggering automatic shutoff protocols. Upon investigation by instrumentation technician Vincent Létourneau, a corroded temperature probe was discovered, causing erroneous readings and thermostat failure. The defective probe had not been replaced during the scheduled quarterly maintenance cycle in March, creating a cascade failure. Approximately 180 kg of polypropylene resin was partially degraded in the dryer chamber. The equipment remained inoperable for 6 hours pending replacement of the temperature probe and thermal calibration. Maintenance technician Alain Gravel assisted with parts replacement. No personnel were injured; however, the incident disrupted production of automotive components scheduled for overnight processing.

On May 3, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift operations, forklift operator Hugues Fontaine was removing a load of polypropylene resin pallets from high storage racks (approximately 4.5 meters high) in the Raw Materials Warehouse. While positioning the forklift beneath the upper rack, the left hydraulic cylinder of the mast assembly failed catastrophically, causing the load to tilt and collapse. Approximately 12 plastic pallets (total weight ~2,400 kg) fell onto the forklift cabin. Fontaine sustained crush injuries to his right shoulder and arm, and was immediately transported to CHU Sainte-Justine hospital. He was diagnosed with a fractured right clavicle, displaced humeral fracture, and soft tissue damage requiring surgical intervention. Fontaine was hospitalized for 8 days and required 6 weeks of restricted duty during recovery. Material handler Salma Haddad, working nearby, immediately called emergency services. Root cause investigation revealed the hydraulic cylinder had not been inspected or serviced in over 18 months despite manufacturer recommendations for annual maintenance. No backup safety mechanisms or load restraints were in place.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:20, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a burn injury while performing routine material loading. Rémi was adding pre-dried plastic resin pellets to the hopper of an injection molding machine when hot plastic residue from a previous cycle splashed onto his right forearm and wrist. The splash occurred because the hopper temperature sensor had malfunctioned, causing the equipment to retain residual material at 280°C instead of the standard cooling cycle. Rémi immediately removed his arm from the splash zone and reported the incident to his supervisor, André Paradis. First aid was administered on-site by the shift supervisor, who applied cool water to the burn area for 15 minutes and applied a sterile dressing. The burn covered approximately 8 square centimeters of the forearm with partial-thickness injury (2nd degree). Rémi was transported to the on-site first aid station where pain management and advanced wound care were provided. No hospitalization was required. The equipment was immediately shut down and tagged out for maintenance inspection. James Thompson (EMP-00029) witnessed the incident and assisted in moving Rémi to the first aid station.

On April 3, 2024 at 22:45 during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (Unit-015) involving Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator. While transferring a batch of uncured epoxy resin from a 50-liter drum using the automated pumping system, the connection coupling between the supply line and the application nozzle began to vibrate excessively. Rania noticed the vibration and the beginnings of a resin leak but did not immediately shut down the equipment. Approximately 500 milliliters of solvent-based epoxy resin began spraying into the immediate work area, creating an inhalation hazard. The mist began to spread toward the adjacent workstation where Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) was conducting quality checks. Rania quickly activated the emergency stop button, immediately halting the system. She then warned Youssef to move away from the vapor cloud and opened all nearby ventilation ports. The local exhaust ventilation system cleared the fumes within 4 minutes. No personnel were directly exposed to hazardous vapors, and no equipment damage resulted. However, the incident revealed that the coupling had developed micro-fractures from metal fatigue due to vibration from the pump motor that had been operating with an out-of-balance impeller for several weeks.

On May 22, 2024 at 09:15 during the day shift, Jing Wang (EMP-00054), a Materials Engineer, conducted a preventive audit of the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Unit-025) located on the Maintenance Workshop mezzanine and identified significant safety concerns requiring immediate attention. During a routine inspection of stored hydraulic equipment and spare injection molding machine components, Jing observed three critical issues: (1) boxes of heavy metal mold plates stacked eight feet high on the mezzanine shelving system without proper securing straps or load-limiting devices, creating a falling object hazard; (2) a partially blocked emergency exit door on the mezzanine level obscured by stored equipment boxes; and (3) missing guardrails on one section of the mezzanine platform where the barrier had been removed for equipment maintenance three weeks prior and never reinstalled. The mezzanine platform is located approximately 15 feet above the warehouse floor. Additionally, Jing documented that the facility's recent inventory expansion had increased storage density beyond the original rated capacity of the mezzanine structure. These deficiencies represent potential violations of workplace safety standards and could result in serious injuries from falling objects or falls from heights. No incidents had occurred as of the audit date, but the conditions posed imminent risk.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Soraya Alami (EMP-00196) was removing finished parts from an injection molding machine in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit when she made contact with a hot mold surface that had not cooled sufficiently. The machine's temperature indicator had malfunctioned, displaying 45°C when the actual surface temperature was 82°C. Ms. Alami sustained a thermal burn approximately 5 cm in diameter on the dorsal surface of her right hand. She immediately immersed the affected area in cold water and reported the incident to her supervisor, Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101), who provided first-aid treatment consisting of sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. The burn was classified as a minor thermal injury requiring no hospitalization. Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was notified and documented the incident. The employee returned to work the following day with a protective dressing and modified duties.

On February 28, 2025, at 10:30 AM during day shift operations, Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) identified a critical failure in the hydraulic pump system of the main injection press (Press Unit 7) located in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room mezzanine. The pump's pressure relief valve had become stuck in the open position due to internal corrosion and mineral deposit accumulation, causing a complete loss of hydraulic pressure. This resulted in the mold remaining in the open position, rendering the press inoperable and halting production of critical automotive components scheduled for shipment within 24 hours. The supervisor immediately isolated the equipment using lockout/tagout procedures and contacted Hydraulic Systems Technician Andrei Popov (EMP-00094) for emergency diagnostics. Upon inspection, Andrei discovered that the hydraulic fluid had not been changed in 18 months despite a 12-month service interval specified by the manufacturer. The contaminated fluid had corroded internal components. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) was informed of the 8-hour repair timeline. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) documented the incident as an equipment failure with medium business impact.

On April 10, 2025, at 1:15 AM during the night shift, Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was performing routine mold changeover on injection press unit 4 in the Raw Materials Warehouse when he inadvertently slipped on a small quantity of hydraulic fluid that had leaked from the press base. The leak, approximately 2 liters, had not been contained with absorbent material or barriers. Louis fell backward onto concrete flooring, striking his lower left leg against the metal base of a storage rack. He sustained a laceration approximately 8 cm long on his left calf with moderate bleeding. Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), who was working nearby, immediately provided basic first aid using the facility's first aid kit, applying direct pressure with sterile gauze and elevating the leg. Louis was conscious and alert. After 15 minutes of wound care, the bleeding was controlled and the wound was bandaged with sterile dressing and antibiotic ointment. Louis was observed for signs of deeper tissue damage but none were evident. Production line operations continued with temporary staffing adjustments. Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) was notified and filed the incident report. Louis returned to work on April 11 with light-duty assignments and modified footwear to prevent wound pressure.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-007 area). An electrical overload in the chemical mixing equipment's control panel caused arcing and smoke generation near the resin storage tanks. The facility's automatic fire detection system activated the alarm at 2:16 PM. Production Operator Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198) was working in the adjacent Raw Materials Warehouse when she noticed the alarm and immediately evacuated. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) responded to investigate and discovered the source of the smoke. Emergency procedures were activated, all personnel were evacuated safely within 8 minutes, and the local fire department arrived at 2:28 PM. Electrical power to the affected equipment was immediately cut off by the main panel. No injuries occurred, but the control panel required replacement and the area remained secured for 4 hours pending inspection. The incident highlighted deficiencies in equipment maintenance scheduling.

On November 12, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. Supply Chain Analyst Miriam Cohen (EMP-00132) was transporting a 5-gallon container of epoxy resin from the storage area to the production line using a hand truck. As she navigated a doorway, the container's cap was not properly secured (the threads had become partially cross-threaded during storage), and approximately 3.5 gallons of epoxy resin spilled onto the concrete floor, spreading across approximately 40 square meters. The spilled material created a slippery hazard and released volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) responded within 2 minutes and immediately isolated the area using caution tape, activated the emergency ventilation system, and notified EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury. Response crews deployed absorbent pads and swept the material into containment drums within 25 minutes. The area required 6 hours of ventilation and cleaning before safe reoccupancy. No direct personal injury occurred, but the spill created respiratory irritation concerns for nearby personnel.

On November 10, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during the evening shift, a hand laceration injury occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was working on cleaning and maintenance of a CNC milling machine used for precision mold manufacturing. While deburring a freshly machined aluminum mold insert with a hand file, Abdul's hand slipped and made contact with an unguarded sharp edge on the workpiece, resulting in a deep laceration to the palm of his left hand measuring approximately 3 cm long and 0.5 cm deep. The injury caused immediate bleeding, and nearby Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) immediately applied direct pressure with clean gauze and called for first aid assistance. First aid was administered on-site within 3 minutes, but due to the depth and length of the laceration, Abdul was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval for sutures and professional wound assessment at 6:45 PM. He received 8 stitches and was cleared to return to modified duty the following day. The root cause was identified as inadequate workpiece securing during the deburring process and lack of edge guarding on sharp metal burrs.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #18 in the Main Production Building. The machine was supposed to be in lockout/tagout (LOTO) status following standard shutdown procedures. However, a communication breakdown between the evening shift supervisor and day shift team resulted in incomplete energy isolation. While Fatou was clearing solidified resin from the hopper area with a hand tool, an automatic cycle initiated unexpectedly. The machine's ram descended rapidly, and Fatou's right hand was briefly trapped between the mold closing plates. She immediately withdrew her hand and reported sharp pain in her fingers. A coworker, Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072), who was working nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately notified Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion. First aid assessment revealed superficial lacerations and significant bruising to the index and middle fingers, but no fractures or deep tissue damage. The incident was contained within seconds due to Fatou's quick reflexes and the relatively low closing pressure at that moment. Machine #18 was immediately secured and locked down. No hospitalization was required, but the employee experienced considerable shock and anxiety from the near-miss event.

On April 3, 2024, at 4:15 PM during the evening shift transition, Receiving Coordinator Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142) was unloading raw material pallets of virgin polycarbonate resin from a delivery truck at the Warehouse and Shipping dock. She was operating an electric forklift to move three stacked pallets (approximately 2,200 lbs total) from the truck bed to the designated storage area in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. The dock floor had been wet from earlier cleaning operations, and a small puddle of hydraulic fluid from a previous maintenance issue had not been cleaned up. As Nadia maneuvered the forklift around a tight corner near the dock edge, the rear wheel of the forklift lost traction on the slippery surface. The forklift tilted approximately 15 degrees to the right, causing one pallet to shift and fall off the load. The falling pallet struck Nadia's left leg below the knee, causing immediate severe pain. She was unable to bear weight and remained on the forklift until responders arrived. Emergency response personnel from the facility called 911, and Nadia was transported to Laval Hospital emergency department. Medical evaluation confirmed a comminuted fracture of the left tibia and fibula requiring surgical intervention. She was hospitalized for 3 days and required 8 weeks of restricted duty recovery. The incident resulted in production delays as material handling operations were disrupted for investigation and corrective actions.

On May 22, 2024, at 11:50 PM during the night shift, Electrical Technician Viktor Novak (EMP-00116) was performing routine maintenance on the cooling water system for the injection molding machine cluster in the Central Maintenance Workshop. He was inspecting pressure relief valves on the high-temperature cooling circuit when a corroded section of copper tubing ruptured suddenly. Superheated water at approximately 85°C (185°F) and 40 psi pressure sprayed across Viktor's left arm and torso. He immediately moved away from the spray and called for assistance. Assembly Lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), who was working on medical component assemblies in the adjacent area, heard the call and radioed for emergency response. She assisted Viktor in removing his contaminated work shirt and applied cool water from the emergency eyewash station to the affected areas. Paramedics arrived within 8 minutes. Medical assessment revealed second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 12% of his body surface area (TBSA) on the left arm, shoulder, and upper chest. Viktor was transported to the specialized burn unit at Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur where he remained admitted for 5 days. The incident resulted in 6 weeks of lost work time and permanent scarring despite specialized wound care. The rupture was traced to inadequate monitoring of water system corrosion and failure to replace aging tubing according to maintenance protocols.

On March 15, 2024 at 10:45 AM, Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160), a Production Operator on the day shift, was operating Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Production Operations area when she experienced a minor burn to her left forearm. While removing a completed composite part from the mold, the part's surface temperature was higher than expected at approximately 65°C. Her sleeve briefly contacted the hot component despite wearing standard production PPE. She immediately immersed the affected area in cold water at the first aid station. A first aid assessment by the safety team revealed a first-degree thermal burn approximately 3cm x 2cm on the inner forearm. The incident was caused by a calibration drift in the mold's cooling system that had not been detected during the morning equipment check. Zainab received topical burn cream and a sterile dressing. She continued her shift with reassurance that the burn was minor and did not require medical evaluation beyond first aid treatment. The incident was documented and the machine was flagged for maintenance inspection.

On February 28, 2024 at 2:15 PM, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, was transferring resin pellets from a bulk storage hopper to a material feeder cart in the Materials Management and Warehousing area using a hand truck. As he positioned a 50-pound bag of polypropylene resin, the bag shifted unexpectedly when another handler approached with a powered pallet jack. Kwesi reached to stabilize the bag and his left hand became caught between the bag and the metal framework of the cart. He sustained a crush injury to his left hand, resulting in fractures to the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones and severe soft tissue damage. Immediate first aid was applied and emergency medical services were called. Kwesi was transported to Hôpital de Sacré-Cœur in Montreal where X-rays confirmed the fractures. He required surgical intervention with pin placement and was hospitalized for 3 days. Medical assessment indicates a recovery period of 6-8 weeks with lost work time expected for at least 4 weeks. The incident was caused by inadequate spacing between material handling operations and insufficient communication protocols between handlers.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Omar Said (EMP-00122), a Production Operator, was operating Injection Molding Line A in UNIT-017 (Post-Processing and Heat Treatment). While removing finished parts from the mold cavity, Omar's right hand made contact with a hot mold surface that had not cooled sufficiently. The mold temperature was approximately 165°C. Omar sustained second-degree thermal burns across his palm and three fingers. He immediately notified his supervisor Celine Morin (EMP-00153) who applied first aid and activated emergency medical response. Omar was transported to Laval General Hospital where he was treated for thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his hand surface area. He was hospitalized overnight for monitoring and pain management. Root cause analysis revealed that the automatic cooling cycle timer had been manually overridden by a maintenance technician the previous evening and was not reset to normal operation. The override was performed to expedite a mold change but documentation was incomplete.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), a Material Handler, was transferring raw plastic pellets from a bulk storage hopper to production hoppers in UNIT-010 (Chemical Storage and Mixing Room). While positioning a 50-liter hopper beneath the flow gate of the large bulk storage container, the storage hopper's pressure relief valve malfunctioned, causing a sudden release of pressurized pellets. Approximately 15 kilograms of hot pellets (approximately 85°C) expelled forcefully, striking Amani's left arm, shoulder, and neck area. The material adhered to his skin, causing first and second-degree thermal burns. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) and coworker Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) immediately assisted Amani, removing contaminated clothing and applying cool water treatment before emergency medical services arrived. Amani was transported to hospital and admitted for burn treatment and observation. He remained hospitalized for 3 days. Investigation revealed the relief valve had not been inspected in 18 months, well beyond the 6-month maintenance interval specified in equipment documentation.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead for Night Shift, was conducting inventory verification in UNIT-008 (Finished Goods Warehouse, Section B). While reaching to retrieve a quality control document that had fallen between a high storage rack (approximately 2.5 meters tall) and the adjacent wall, Michel lost his footing on the polished concrete floor that was still wet from the evening cleaning cycle. He fell sideways, striking his left hip and lower back against the concrete edge of a raised pallet platform. Michel remained conscious but unable to stand due to sharp pain in his hip region. Coworker Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), who was working nearby, called for assistance. First aid responder Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) arrived and provided initial care, immobilizing Michel's lower body before emergency medical services transported him to hospital. Medical imaging revealed a fracture of the left femoral neck (hip fracture) requiring surgical intervention. Michel underwent hip repair surgery on March 29, 2024, and was hospitalized for 5 days post-surgery. Incident investigation identified that warehouse cleaning was scheduled too close to peak inventory work times, creating hazardous wet floor conditions during active operations.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Injection Molding Operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) was working on Line D in the Main Production Building when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the injection molding machine malfunctioned. While Bruno was performing routine mold temperature adjustment near the machine's hot end, the faulty valve caused an unexpected pressure release. Pressurized hot plastic material and hydraulic fluid sprayed across Bruno's right arm and shoulder, causing thermal burns. The equipment malfunction occurred due to inadequate maintenance records showing the valve had not been inspected in 14 months, exceeding the 12-month service interval. Bruno was immediately escorted to the first aid station by Production Supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) where the burns were assessed and treated with cooling water and sterile dressings. The incident was reported by Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) after Bruno received treatment. Estimated burn area was approximately 8% of body surface, classified as second-degree burns requiring medical follow-up.

On May 8, 2024, at 10:30 PM during evening shift, Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was transferring a pallet of raw polypropylene resin bags in the Warehouse and Shipping area when his forklift struck a support column while maneuvering in a congested storage zone. The impact caused the forklift's left front tire to puncture on a protruding bolt, and the vehicle lurched sideways. Three pallets of finished automotive components (worth approximately $47,000) stacked 8 feet high became unstable and collapsed onto the adjacent storage rack, damaging approximately 60% of the inventory on that rack. Additional finished goods estimated at $31,500 were damaged from secondary impacts. The incident occurred due to inadequate aisle markings, poor visibility caused by stacked boxes blocking sightlines, and the forklift operator exceeding safe speed for the cluttered workspace. Witness Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066) observed the incident and immediately notified Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101). No personnel were injured, but property damage was significant. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was notified and investigated the incident.

On April 2, 2024, at 9:15 AM during day shift, Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) was inspecting finished composite parts in the Quality Control Laboratory when she sustained a laceration to her left index finger from a sharp edge on a carbon fiber-reinforced plastic component. While handling a molded part for dimensional verification, Mei's finger contacted an undeburned edge left on the part after the injection molding process. The sharp edge penetrated the superficial layers of skin, creating a 2 cm laceration with mild bleeding. The root cause was inadequate deburring procedures in the post-molding quality process; the part should have been de-flashed before reaching QC inspection. Mei immediately applied direct pressure to the wound and proceeded to the first aid station where Training Coordinator Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) provided initial treatment consisting of thorough wound cleaning, antibiotic ointment application, and sterile bandaging. The laceration did not require sutures but was monitored for infection over the following week. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) documented the incident and investigated the source part.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), a Material Handler, was transferring pallets of polypropylene resin from the receiving dock to the chemical storage building. While moving a pallet containing 15 bags of PE (HDPE) resin using a manual pallet jack, the material handler did not secure the load properly. As Bianca was navigating a tight corner near the Shipping and Receiving Dock, the stack of bags shifted and approximately 8 bags (totaling ~200 lbs) fell from the pallet onto the loading dock concrete surface. The bags tore open, releasing granular plastic material across a 15-foot area of the dock floor. The spilled material created a slippery surface, and several smaller plastic pellets scattered into the dock drainage system. Bianca immediately notified her supervisor and the spill was contained using push brooms and collection bins. The incident took approximately 2 hours to fully clean up. Environmental impact was minimal as the material is inert, but the event highlighted inadequate load securing procedures and potential drainage contamination risks.

On April 2, 2024, at 11:50 PM during the night shift, Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, discovered a significant leak in the acetone storage tank located in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. While conducting routine inventory rounds, Natasha noticed acetone pooling beneath the 200-liter storage tank and a strong chemical odor throughout the enclosed storage building. The leak originated from a corroded valve connection on the tank's lower section. Approximately 30-40 liters of acetone had already evaporated or leaked onto the floor before discovery. Natasha immediately evacuated the area, activated the emergency ventilation system, and notified the EHS Coordinator. The chemical storage room's inadequate ventilation system could not fully clear the acetone vapors within the 15-minute timeframe before the night shift supervisor arrived. Air quality monitoring indicated acetone vapor concentrations reached 1,200 ppm (permissible exposure limit is 750 ppm during an 8-hour TWA). The incident required emergency tank isolation, hazmat cleanup, and activation of external air filtration units. No employees were directly exposed for extended periods, but potential for serious respiratory injury existed.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B (Automotive) in the North Zone when she noticed an unusual vibration in the hydraulic system. While inspecting the source of the vibration near the machine's moving carriage, Fatou's sleeve became caught on a rotating shaft coupling. She immediately called out, and nearby Production Operator Naomi Okafor rushed to assist. Naomi quickly activated the emergency stop button, halting the machinery within seconds. Fatou's sleeve tore, but she sustained no physical injury. The incident was caused by inadequate machine guarding on the coupling and insufficient awareness of pinch points in the work area. Fatou reported the near-miss to her supervisor, and the area was immediately cordoned off pending investigation. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi was notified and documented the event.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Tool and Die Maker Mario Béisle was performing routine inspection and maintenance on custom injection molds stored in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (Tool Room). He was examining a large automotive component mold (approximately 2 meters in length) when he noticed what appeared to be a hairline crack in the mold's parting line. While leaning over the mold to inspect the suspected defect more closely with a handheld magnifying glass, Mario felt a sudden pain in his lower back as he over-extended during the inspection. He straightened up carefully and noticed discomfort in his lumbar region but was able to continue working. Mario mentioned the incident to Crane Operator Gaston Picard, who suggested he report it to HSE. Mario reported the back strain incident to Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi at shift end, noting it as a work-related musculoskeletal strain from awkward positioning during equipment inspection. Medical evaluation revealed minor acute strain with no serious injury, but the incident was classified as a near-miss given the potential for more serious injury had the strain been severe. The mold was flagged for additional engineering review.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, was moving a pallet of raw polycarbonate resin using a manual pallet jack in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While navigating between drying equipment, Hassan's left foot became caught between the pallet jack's forks and a stationary drying oven frame. Another worker, Monique Dion (EMP-00119), was nearby and immediately called for assistance. The pallet jack's weight, combined with the immobilized foot, resulted in a crushing injury to Hassan's ankle and lower leg. Emergency response was initiated, and Hassan was transported to Laval Hospital where X-rays confirmed a fractured fibula and tibia. Hassan required emergency surgery and was hospitalized for 4 days, resulting in a lost-time injury of 28 days. The incident occurred because Hassan was not trained on proper pallet jack positioning in confined spaces, and the drying room's narrow aisles created pinch points that were not adequately marked.

On January 8, 2024, at approximately 6:15 PM during evening shift, Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176), an Assembly Operator on the medical components line, sustained a minor eye injury while performing part removal from an injection-molded thermoplastic component. A small plastic burr or flash from the finished part became airborne and struck her right eye as she was trimming excess material. Aaliyah immediately reported the incident to her supervisor, Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070). First aid was administered on-site: the eye was flushed with sterile saline solution for approximately 3 minutes, and Aaliyah's eye was examined for foreign material. No embedded particles were found, and the irritation resolved within 20 minutes. Aaliyah did not require medical attention beyond first aid and returned to modified duties (non-assembly work) for the remainder of the shift as a precaution. The incident was documented and reported to the HSE office. Root cause analysis determined that Aaliyah was wearing safety glasses with inadequate lateral coverage for this specific assembly operation, and the part design included a known sharp burr issue that had not been fully addressed during the mold design review.

On February 2, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during night shift, Roland Dostie (EMP-00199), a Maintenance Planner, was conducting a routine inspection of the electrical panel in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014) when he noticed a concerning issue: the backup power supply unit showed signs of deterioration including visible corrosion on battery terminals and a slight overheating of the voltage regulator. The battery casing appeared slightly swollen. Roland immediately documented the observations in the maintenance log and photographed the equipment. He did not attempt any direct intervention with the equipment. Roland reported his findings to André Bellavance (EMP-00157), the Confined Space Entry Supervisor, who coordinates with HSE staff on hazard detection. This preventive declaration was made to alert management to a potential arc flash and electrical fire hazard before it could develop into a critical incident. The backup power unit had been in service for 7 years without replacement, exceeding the manufacturer's recommended 5-year service life. No immediate incident occurred, but the hazard recognition and reporting prevented a potentially catastrophic equipment failure.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B's hydraulic system in the Main Production Building. While conducting pressure tests on the hydraulic pump assembly, the pressure relief valve malfunctioned and failed to regulate system pressure properly. The hydraulic line connecting the pump to the manifold ruptured suddenly, spraying hot hydraulic fluid (approximately 65°C) across Marco's left arm and upper torso. The incident was witnessed by Production Operator Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), who immediately activated the emergency stop on the molding line and called for first aid assistance. Marco was treated on-site for thermal burns to approximately 12% of his body surface area and was transported to Laval General Hospital for advanced burn management. The hydraulic pump assembly showed signs of internal corrosion and seal degradation, indicating lack of preventive maintenance on this aging component.

On March 22, 2025, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was accessing inventory in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) using a 12-foot extension ladder to retrieve composite material stock from upper shelving. While positioned on the 8th rung of the ladder, Rashid noticed the ladder's feet had shifted slightly on the concrete floor due to an uneven surface caused by water pooling from earlier cleaning operations. As he reached for a 25 kg container of fiber-reinforced polymer resin, the ladder tilted approximately 15 degrees from vertical. Rashid immediately descended and repositioned the ladder on a dry, level surface before attempting again. Witnesses including Materials Engineer Jing Wang (EMP-00054) and Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) observed the near-miss event. No contact with the ladder or materials occurred, and Rashid completed the task safely after repositioning. The incident revealed significant housekeeping deficiencies in the warehouse, with water accumulation and uneven flooring creating slip hazards.

On March 28, 2025, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Production Operator Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174) was manually removing cured composite parts from an autoclave station in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Despite wearing nitrile gloves, Lina made repetitive grasping and twisting motions to extract approximately 40 fiber-reinforced plastic components from the heating chamber over a 3-hour period. By mid-morning at 8:00 AM, Lina reported pain and tingling in her right wrist and fingers, consistent with acute carpal tunnel syndrome exacerbation. She also noted reduced grip strength and mild swelling. Lina's coworker Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) assisted in the final removals and documented the incident. First aid assessment determined conservative treatment was required, but the symptoms persisted beyond 24 hours, necessitating an occupational medicine referral. Medical evaluation confirmed acute inflammation of the median nerve. The repetitive extraction work, combined with inadequate ergonomic tool design and lack of job rotation, contributed to this overuse injury.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, was operating the plastic regrind equipment in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While attempting to clear a material jam in the regrind hopper without proper lockout/tagout procedures, his right hand became caught between the rotating auger shaft and the hopper housing. The equipment was running at approximately 120 RPM. Oscar's coworker, Jing Wang (EMP-00054), heard his screams and immediately shut down the equipment using the emergency stop button. Oscar sustained a severe laceration to his right palm and two fractured metacarpal bones, requiring immediate medical attention and hospitalization for surgical intervention. The incident resulted in a loss of 12 work days during recovery. Emergency response was coordinated by Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, who initiated first aid and arranged emergency transport.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, an unintended discharge of the Chemical Storage Building's fire suppression system (UNIT-010) occurred. The incident was triggered when Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, was moving chemical storage containers and inadvertently struck a sprinkler head with a 25-kilogram container of epoxy resin. The collision damaged the sprinkler head mechanism, causing the entire wet-pipe suppression system serving the north section of the chemical storage area to activate. Approximately 4,500 gallons of water flooded the facility over 8 minutes before the system was manually shut down. The discharge contaminated multiple pallets of finished goods stored in the adjacent section, rendered several chemical inventory items unusable due to water damage and potential cross-contamination, and temporarily disabled the facility's chemical storage capacity. Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073), Shipping Coordinator, and Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), Material Handler, assisted with emergency response and mitigation. No injuries occurred, but the incident resulted in facility shutdown for 6 hours for cleanup and system inspection. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) coordinated the incident documentation.

On May 28, 2024, at approximately 1:15 AM during the night shift, a fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), a CNC Operator assigned to chemical preparation duties during the skeleton night crew, was transferring isopropyl alcohol from a 55-gallon drum into smaller 5-liter containers for distribution to production areas. While transferring the solvent, a static electricity discharge ignited the flammable vapor above the alcohol surface. The initial flame spread to nearby solvent-soaked rags stored improperly in an open bin, causing a rapidly expanding fire. The fire consumed approximately 150 liters of various flammable solvents and damaged chemical storage shelving before Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), the night shift Emergency Response Team Leader, activated the fire suppression system and manually deployed a Class B dry chemical fire extinguisher. The facility's automatic fire alarm system triggered, evacuation procedures were executed, and local fire department responded within 12 minutes. No personnel were injured, but the incident resulted in facility evacuation for 4 hours, temporary shutdown of production operations, and significant property damage estimated at $87,000. The incident was declared by Johanne Paquette.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak occurred in the Injection Molding area of the Main Production Building. Equipment operator Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) noticed pressurized water spraying from a corroded coupling on the cooling circuit of Injection Molding Machine #7. The coupling had developed a hairline fracture over several weeks due to inadequate maintenance inspection protocols. Within 15 minutes, approximately 200 gallons of coolant-mixed water had accumulated on the production floor, creating a slippery hazard and damaging approximately $8,400 worth of raw plastic pellets stored in bins adjacent to the equipment. The leaked fluid also compromised the electrical integrity of floor-mounted sensors, rendering three quality control monitors inoperable. Maintenance technician Svetlana Petrov responded immediately, isolating the machine and shutting down the cooling system. The spill was contained using absorbent materials, and the affected production area was cordoned off for 6 hours during cleanup and equipment inspection.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040) sustained a laceration to her right index finger while assembling medical device housings in the Assembly and Finishing Department. Silva was manually inserting a precision plastic component into a metal fixture when the component shifted unexpectedly, causing a sharp burr edge on the component to contact her finger. The laceration was approximately 1.5 inches long and penetrated 3-4 millimeters into the subcutaneous tissue but did not damage underlying tendons or nerves. Silva immediately reported the injury to her supervisor. First aid was administered by Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), who cleaned the wound with sterile saline, applied antibiotic ointment, and covered it with a sterile bandage and gauze wrap. Silva received a tetanus booster and was advised to monitor for signs of infection. The wound required 5 sutures at the on-site occupational health clinic. Silva returned to modified duty (non-assembly work) for 3 days while the wound healed, with full duty resumption on day 4. No lost work time was recorded.

On April 8, 2024, at 9:30 PM during the evening shift, a forklift operated by Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) experienced hydraulic brake failure in the Shipping and Receiving Dock area while transporting a pallet of finished medical device components. Diallo was moving the loaded pallet from the staging area toward the loading dock when he attempted to slow the vehicle approaching a 90-degree corner turn. The hydraulic pressure loss, caused by a ruptured brake line resulting from metal fatigue, caused the forklift to continue at approximately 8-10 mph despite brake pedal pressure. Unable to stop the vehicle, Diallo steered to avoid pedestrian Julien Racine (EMP-00177) but struck a stacked pallet of raw materials, toppling it and breaking open 6 bundles of polycarbonate sheet stock worth approximately $14,600. The impact also damaged the forklift's right front tire and broke the seat mounting bracket. Diallo was uninjured but shaken. Witness Racine immediately notified Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) of the incident. The forklift was immediately removed from service, and the spilled materials were inventoried and segregated for potential salvage.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a hydraulic press malfunction occurred in Injection Molding Line B (Automotive). Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator with 8 years experience, was positioning a finished automotive dashboard component when the press's pressure relief valve failed. The faulty valve allowed system pressure to exceed safe limits, causing a violent rupture of the hydraulic line connected to the mold clamping mechanism. High-pressure hydraulic fluid sprayed across the work area, striking the mold assembly and nearby equipment. The pressurized fluid also contacted Bernard's left arm, causing a superficial laceration approximately 4 inches long on his forearm. The equipment sustained significant damage to the hydraulic manifold, pressure gauges, and connecting hoses. The incident was immediately reported by Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175) who witnessed the event. Emergency response procedures were activated, and Bernard received first aid treatment for the minor laceration. The press was immediately shut down for investigation and repair. Root cause analysis identified that the relief valve had not been properly maintained according to preventive maintenance schedules, with the last service inspection occurring 18 months prior instead of the recommended 12-month interval.

On April 8, 2024 at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, an acute musculoskeletal injury occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). Amara Diop (EMP-00110), a Packaging Operator, was manually lifting and moving large boxes of finished composite material components from a lower storage shelf to a pallet on a work cart. The boxes weighed approximately 45 pounds each. While lifting the fourth box without proper lifting technique and without assistance, Amara felt a sharp pain in her lower back and was unable to straighten up. She immediately stopped work and informed her supervisor, Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), Packaging Supervisor, who provided first aid assessment and called for medical evaluation. A company nurse conducted an initial evaluation and determined that Amara likely sustained a lumbar strain injury. Amara was transported to a local urgent care facility where X-rays and examination confirmed acute lower back strain with muscle spasm. She was prescribed rest, ice therapy, and anti-inflammatory medication, and was directed to cease work activities. The medical provider documented the injury as work-related and recommended a minimum of 5 days of restricted duty with no lifting beyond 10 pounds. This incident represents a lost-time injury as Amara was unable to return to her regular duties for the remainder of the shift and subsequent shifts pending medical clearance. The injury occurred in an area where manual material handling is routine but where no mechanical lifting aids were available for this particular task.

On May 22, 2024 at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, an entanglement incident occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (Main Production Building - West Wing). Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was performing routine maintenance on the composite fiber reinforcement system when he became distracted by equipment noise and inadvertently reached toward a rotating feed screw mechanism without first performing a complete lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure. His work glove made contact with the rotating auger, and the glove became wound around the rotating shaft. The wrapping of the glove pulled Conrad's left hand into the mechanism, causing crush and abrasion injuries to his hand and wrist. His screams alerted night shift supervisor Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175) who immediately accessed the emergency stop button and halted the equipment. Emergency medical services were called immediately. Conrad was transported via ambulance to the regional trauma center where he received emergency treatment for crush injuries to the left hand with partial loss of sensation in two fingers and significant lacerations. Medical evaluation determined he sustained a serious hand injury requiring surgical intervention and extended recovery. Conrad was admitted for observation and underwent surgical repair of tendons and nerve tissue. Medical documentation clearly indicated lost-work-time compensation was warranted, with the employee unable to return to work for an estimated minimum of 12 weeks pending surgical recovery and rehabilitation. The immediate cause was failure to follow established LOTO procedures, compounded by the employee working on rotating equipment without proper guards in place.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) was working at Line B in the Main Production Building when he attempted to remove a molded part from the hot mold cavity without waiting for the cooling cycle to complete. The mold temperature was approximately 180°C. As Zaidi reached into the cavity with his bare hand to extract the part, his right palm and fingers made direct contact with the hot mold surface. He immediately withdrew his hand and reported severe burning pain. Coworkers witnessed the incident and immediately directed him to the first aid station where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided initial treatment with cold water irrigation and sterile dressings. The employee sustained partial-thickness thermal burns on his palm and three fingers covering approximately 8% of his hand surface. He was transported to the local hospital emergency department for further assessment and pain management. The incident was caused by inadequate understanding of cooling time requirements and lack of enforcement of mandatory cooling procedures before part removal.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a cooling water system failure occurred in the Main Production Building affecting three injection molding lines. Maintenance technician Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was conducting a routine equipment check when he discovered a significant pressure drop in the main cooling loop. Upon investigation, he identified a fractured coupling connection on the primary heat exchange unit that had been gradually deteriorating over several days due to vibration and thermal cycling. The coupling failed completely, causing approximately 200 liters of pressurized coolant water mixed with ethylene glycol to spray across the equipment area and floor before the emergency shut-down valve could be activated. The spill damaged electrical control panels for two molding machines, contaminated the production floor with hazardous coolant fluid, and created a slip hazard. The rapid response prevented further equipment damage, but resulted in approximately 8 hours of production downtime affecting 15 active molds in process. Environmental cleanup was required due to the glycol content in the spilled fluid.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a material handling incident occurred in the Warehouse and Shipping area. Forklift Operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) was transferring pallets of raw plastic resin (polyethylene pellets) from the receiving dock to the bulk storage area when a poorly secured load of approximately 1,200 kg shifted during a sharp directional turn. The pallets tipped, causing resin bags to spill across the warehouse floor and into adjacent stacking racks. Approximately 45 bags (roughly 2,000 kg of resin) cascaded from the storage racks above, creating a secondary collapse hazard. The incident damaged 8 storage racks, crushed 3 pallets, and contaminated approximately 200 kg of resin that had to be discarded due to floor contamination. Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093) discovered the incident during her 7:00 AM shift start and reported it immediately. No personnel were in the immediate impact zone, preventing injuries. The incident caused inventory tracking errors and required 6 hours of cleanup and equipment repair before normal warehouse operations could resume.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159) was operating Line B in the Automotive production zone when the hydraulic pressure system began showing erratic readings. The operator noticed unusual resistance in the mold clamping mechanism and attempted to manually override the system to complete the current cycle. Approximately 30 seconds later, a hydraulic line fractured near the base of the injection unit, spraying hot hydraulic fluid (approximately 85°C) across the machine operator's station. The operator sustained second-degree burns on his right forearm and hand. Production Supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) was working nearby and immediately assisted by activating the emergency stop and directing the operator to the first aid station. Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) responded and isolated the hydraulic system. The incident was declared by Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:30 AM, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was working in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) in the Warehouse and Shipping area, loading recycled plastic granules into storage hoppers. While reaching across a 1.2-meter-high storage rack to position a collection bag, the top shelf unit shifted approximately 15 centimeters due to inadequate weight distribution below. A large bin of polypropylene regrind material (approximately 35 kg) fell from the shifted shelf, striking Bianchi's left shoulder and upper arm. The impact caused the worker to fall backward onto the concrete floor, resulting in a fractured left clavicle and significant soft tissue trauma. Bianchi was unable to bear weight and required immediate medical attention. Forklift Operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) witnessed the incident and immediately called emergency services. The worker was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval and admitted for orthopedic surgery. The incident was formally declared by Brigitte Mathieu, who attended the facility and initiated investigation procedures.

On March 28, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine equipment diagnostics in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014) in the Maintenance Workshop. While testing voltage levels on a secondary distribution panel serving Injection Molding Line D, Gravel noticed loose electrical connections on a 480V three-phase breaker. He identified that one terminal clamp had partially detached, creating a potential arc flash hazard. Immediately upon discovering the condition, Gravel locked out and tagged out the panel using proper LOTO procedures, preventing any accidental energization. Gravel then notified Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) of the hazard. Laplante arrived within 10 minutes and verified the unsafe condition, confirming that any attempt to energize the panel would have resulted in a catastrophic arc flash. The defect was documented as a near-miss incident with significant potential for serious injury or death. The electrical issue was secured and scheduled for correction by a certified electrician during the following day shift. Gaétan Laplante declared the incident to ensure proper documentation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) was operating Line D in the Main Production Building when he noticed the hopper level indicator displaying an unusual reading. While investigating the Material Drying and Preparation Room, Bruno observed that resin pellets were beginning to overflow from the top of the material dryer hopper due to a stuck auger mechanism. Bruno immediately stopped the machine and notified his supervisor. The overflow created a 2-meter diameter pile of polycarbonate pellets on the floor around the equipment base, blocking part of the material handling pathway. Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) witnessed the spill and assisted in cordoning off the area with caution tape. The maintenance team arrived within 15 minutes to investigate. Upon examination, they discovered that a moisture sensor had malfunctioned, causing the automated feed cutoff to fail. The spill was contained and cleaned up within 45 minutes with no injuries reported. This near-miss was classified as NEAR_MISS because the overflow was detected and stopped before causing any personnel injury or significant equipment damage, though the potential for tripping hazards and material damage existed.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 23:15 during the evening shift, Machine Setter Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124) was performing routine setup adjustments on Injection Molding Line C in the Main Production Building when he heard an unusual grinding noise emanating from the hydraulic system. Approximately 8 minutes later, the hydraulic pump suddenly failed catastrophically, causing a complete loss of pressure in the molding machine's clamping unit. The machine abruptly released its clamp, and the partially-formed composite part ejected from the mold cavity with force, striking the machine's safety shroud but not impacting personnel. The hydraulic fluid began leaking from a ruptured seal at an estimated rate of 0.5 liters per minute, pooling on the machine deck. Tomas immediately activated the emergency stop and notified the maintenance team. Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) was performing end-of-shift inspections nearby and witnessed the failure. Maintenance technician Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189) arrived within 12 minutes and confirmed that the hydraulic pump had experienced complete bearing failure and seal rupture. The machine was taken offline for repairs that required 36 hours of downtime, including pump replacement and system flushing. The failure resulted in approximately $78,000 in lost production and $22,000 in replacement parts and labor.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 06:30 during the night shift, Composite Materials Operator Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086) was operating a fiber-reinforced plastic curing oven in the Composite Materials Processing Area when she noticed that the heating element temperature controller was displaying erratic readings, alternating between normal range (180°C) and dangerously high temperatures (260°C+). She immediately contacted the night shift supervisor and attempted to reduce the temperature using the manual override control, but the oven continued to experience temperature fluctuations. Within 15 minutes, the resin dryer began emitting smoke and a burning odor from the heating chamber. The safety thermostat failed to engage, and the heating element continued operating at extreme temperatures. Night maintenance technician on call was notified, and the oven was manually powered down at the main electrical panel by Armand Lévesque, who responded to the site. The heating element had partially overheated, causing localized degradation of the internal insulation materials and minor scorching of the oven interior. The equipment required complete replacement of the heating element assembly, thermostat control module, and internal insulation, totaling $35,000 in parts and labor. The oven was out of service for 48 hours, resulting in production delays for composite part orders and approximately $42,000 in delayed shipment penalties.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Naomi Okafor was working at Injection Molding Line D when she noticed the hopper material level was unusually high. As she approached to inspect the automated feed system, the hopper suddenly overflowed, releasing approximately 50 kg of molten polypropylene resin pellets and powder onto the floor around her workstation. The material scattered across a 2-meter radius, creating a slip hazard. Okafor immediately stepped back and did not slip or sustain injuries. She activated the emergency stop button and notified her supervisor Guillaume Deschamps. The overflow was caused by a malfunctioning level sensor that failed to signal the material handler to stop feeding. The incident was contained within 10 minutes with no personnel injuries, but production was halted for 45 minutes while the area was cleaned and the sensor was inspected. This near-miss highlighted a critical gap in preventive maintenance of the hopper monitoring system.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, maintenance technician Luc Girard was performing routine lubrication on a CNC milling machine in the Maintenance Workshop. While applying hydraulic oil to a rotating spindle coupling, his right hand glove caught on the spinning shaft. His hand was drawn toward the rotating component, resulting in a laceration to his index and middle finger. The machine was not properly locked out during routine maintenance, violating LOTO procedures. Girard immediately withdrew his hand and activated the emergency stop. Blood loss was moderate; he applied direct pressure and was transported to the on-site first aid station where his wounds were cleaned and bandaged. The laceration on his index finger required 6 stitches. Production on that CNC machine was suspended for the remainder of the shift. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate enforcement of lockout/tagout protocols for routine maintenance tasks and insufficient machine guarding on the spindle coupling.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, regrind operator Fernand Comeau was preparing the Material Drying and Preparation Room for the morning production run. He observed that the resin drying hopper temperature display showed 185°C, which exceeded the normal operating range of 80-120°C for polypropylene materials. The hopper's heating element appeared to have a stuck thermostat, creating an overheating hazard that could degrade the plastic material and create fire risk. Comeau immediately notified his supervisor and the night shift maintenance staff. The hopper was shut down, and the material inside was carefully unloaded and discarded. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen declared this a preventive incident requiring proactive intervention. Investigation revealed that the last preventive maintenance check was conducted 6 months ago, well beyond the recommended 3-month interval. The incident was prevented from escalating through prompt detection, but it highlighted the need for more rigorous preventive maintenance scheduling and temperature monitoring protocols.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Nathalie Dubois, Environmental Compliance Specialist, was notified by warehouse staff that Bianca De Luca and Amani Mwangi had been mixing a batch of polyurethane resin when a 55-gallon drum of liquid mold release agent was being transferred to a smaller container. The transfer hose became disconnected from the dispenser nozzle, causing approximately 12 gallons of the chemical to spill onto the concrete floor. The spill spread across an area of roughly 200 square feet before containment berms were deployed. The chemical mixture contains volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and poses skin sensitization and inhalation hazards. Both material handlers evacuated the immediate area within 90 seconds of recognizing the spill. Emergency response procedures were activated, including ventilation system activation and spill containment kit deployment. No personal injuries were reported, but the incident required 4 hours of cleanup and disposal operations. The root cause was determined to be inadequate hose crimping and lack of secondary containment during transfer operations.

On February 22, 2024, at approximately 6:15 PM during the evening shift, a serious machinery incident occurred at Injection Molding Line B in the Automotive Department (UNIT-002). Benoit Arsenault, Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was called to assist at Line B when he heard a sudden loud noise. Bernard Allard, Hydraulic Press Operator, had been performing routine mold changeover procedures when a sudden machine startup during cleaning operations occurred. The safety lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures had apparently been bypassed or improperly executed by a technician earlier that day. As Bernard was reaching into the mold cavity to clear residual plastic material, the hydraulic press initiated automatically, compressing the mold plates. His right hand became caught between the mold halves, sustaining crush injuries to four fingers and requiring immediate emergency medical services intervention. Bernard was transported to the hospital with severe crush trauma and multiple fractures. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury requiring hospitalization and multiple surgical interventions. Investigation revealed that the LOTO device was not properly engaged and the machine's emergency stop button was obstructed by tooling equipment.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, a material handling injury occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Normand Ouellette, Warehouse Lead, was conducting a routine inventory check when he observed that Raymond Tessier, Crane Operator, was preparing to move a stack of cured composite material bundles using the overhead crane system. A load of approximately 800 pounds of composite resin-impregnated fiberglass sheets was being hoisted from a lower storage rack to an upper shelf. Due to inadequate tie-down strapping and improper weight distribution, the load shifted during hoisting. Approximately four sheets from the middle of the stack slipped and fell approximately 12 feet, striking Tessier on the left shoulder and upper arm. He sustained a fractured clavicle and a contusion to the upper arm requiring emergency room treatment. The incident was immediately reported by Ouellette. Investigation determined that the strapping harness had not been properly inspected for wear before the lift, and the load had not been secured according to established procedures. Weather conditions in the facility were cool, which may have contributed to brittle composite material behavior.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072), a Production Operator, was performing routine material handling in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While transferring dried plastic pellets from a storage rack to a hopper for the injection molding line, she noticed an unusual vibration and grinding sound coming from the drying equipment. She immediately stopped operations and documented the anomaly in the shift log. Upon inspection, she discovered that the heating element thermostatic control was malfunctioning, causing temperature fluctuations that could compromise material quality and potentially create a fire hazard if continued unchecked. The equipment was immediately powered down and a lockout/tagout procedure was initiated. No injury occurred, but the potential for significant equipment damage and safety risks was averted through prompt detection and reporting. Aisha notified her supervisor Sébastien Carrier and EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury of the condition immediately.

On April 3, 2025, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198), a Production Operator at Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-004), suffered a significant repetitive strain injury to her right wrist and forearm. After performing part removal and quality inspection operations continuously for 6 hours without adequate breaks, she experienced acute pain and swelling in her wrist. The repetitive grasping and twisting motions required to remove molded components from the hot molds had caused strain accumulation. Laila reported her symptoms to the shift supervisor at 11:15 PM. Initial first aid was provided by on-site medical personnel, including ice application and compression wrapping. She was referred to an external medical clinic for evaluation and was subsequently prescribed anti-inflammatory medication and required to wear a wrist brace. Medical records indicated early signs of carpal tunnel syndrome. The employee required 3 days of modified duties before returning to full production work. This incident was classified as a lost-time injury requiring CNESST notification.

On March 28, 2025, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) experienced a significant property damage incident. A temporary pressure relief valve on a 500-liter storage tank containing polyester resin catalyst failed due to corrosion and improper maintenance. The sudden release caused approximately 120 liters of liquid chemical to spill across the concrete floor, spreading into adjacent areas including the drainage system. The spill damaged multiple items: three 55-gallon metal drums (valued at $1,200), approximately $4,500 of stored composite material precursor components, $2,800 of packaging materials stored in the adjacent section, and required emergency cleanup services ($6,200). Additionally, temporary closure of the chemical storage area disrupted production scheduling for 14 hours, resulting in lost production capacity valued at approximately $8,400. Environmental containment protocols were activated immediately by the night shift supervisor, and external hazmat contractors were called. The incident was reported to CNESST and Quebec's environmental protection authority. No employee injuries occurred, but the financial impact totaled approximately $23,100 in direct and indirect costs.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak was discovered in the Main Production Building's Injection Molding Line A - Automotive zone. Operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) noticed water pooling around the base of an injection molding machine and immediately notified his supervisor. Upon investigation, facility coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) identified a ruptured coupling on the primary cooling line feeding the 500-ton molding machine, causing approximately 200 gallons of treated cooling water to discharge onto the production floor over a 30-minute period before the system was shut down. The water spread across approximately 800 square feet of the production area, creating both an environmental hazard and a slip-and-fall risk. The facility's secondary containment system failed to capture the full volume due to a blocked drain valve. Environmental samples were collected and the spill was contained using absorbent materials. The incident resulted in production downtime of 4 hours and triggered a review of the cooling system maintenance schedule. No employees were injured, but the environmental impact required notification to CNESST and implementation of immediate corrective actions.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, an electrical fault occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop affecting the primary hydraulic press used for mold manufacturing and repair. Electrical technician Viktor Novak (EMP-00116) was performing routine testing on the press's control panel when he noticed sparking from a corroded terminal connection. He immediately de-energized the equipment and discovered that the main control relay had failed due to water ingress from a leaking coolant line above the electrical cabinet. The relay failure caused the press safety interlock to become inoperative, creating a critical hazard where the machine could operate without all required safety guards being engaged. CNC machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was working nearby and witnessed the electrical failure. The equipment was immediately tagged out and locked per LOTO procedures. During a subsequent inspection, multiple issues were identified: inadequate electrical cabinet enclosure protection, lack of surge protection devices, and deteriorated cable insulation. The incident prevented 6 hours of scheduled mold manufacturing work and required emergency replacement of the control relay and cabinet sealing. No injuries occurred, but the safety interlock failure represented a critical risk for crush injuries if the machine had been operated.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, a forklift operated by facilities coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) collided with a storage rack in the Warehouse and Shipping area while navigating a narrow aisle. The collision occurred when Mr. Champagne attempted to reposition a pallet of raw plastic resin without adequate visibility due to the large size of the load. The impact caused the upper shelf of a metal storage rack to collapse, spilling approximately 15 boxes of molded automotive components (valued at approximately $18,000) onto the floor and creating a hazardous obstruction. Assembly operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040) was working in an adjacent aisle and witnessed the incident. Fortunately, no personnel were in the impact zone and no injuries occurred. However, approximately 40% of the crashed components were damaged beyond acceptable quality standards. The incident also caused damage to the storage rack (estimated $6,500 repair cost) and required 8 hours of cleanup and reorganization work. Investigation revealed that the warehouse layout had been modified two weeks prior without updating the forklift traffic flow map, and no traffic control signage had been installed in the reorganized area.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM, an acetone spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room during routine inventory procedures. Employee Natasha Ivanov was transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum to smaller containers when a valve coupling failed, releasing approximately 12 liters of acetone onto the concrete floor. The spill created a volatile vapor hazard in the enclosed space. Emergency response was initiated immediately: the area was evacuated, ventilation fans were activated at maximum capacity, and the spill was contained using absorbent materials. The incident exposed a gap in preventive maintenance for drum handling equipment and chemical storage protocols. No employee was directly exposed to significant quantities, but the incident highlighted risks related to solvent vapor accumulation in the chemical storage area. The spill was fully contained within 45 minutes and properly disposed of according to CNESST regulations. Follow-up air quality monitoring confirmed vapor levels returned to safe thresholds within 2 hours of remediation.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM, during the night shift in the Composite Materials Processing Area, employee Louis Desbiens (Machine Setter - Night Shift) sustained a serious thermal burn while attempting to clear a resin dryer that had overheated. The dryer had malfunctioned, causing the internal temperature to rise above safe operating parameters. Without proper lockout/tagout procedures being followed, Desbiens opened the dryer access panel to investigate. A burst of superheated air and partially cured composite material exited the opening, contacting his right forearm and upper torso.
