The employee sustained second-degree burns covering approximately 15% of his exposed skin. First aid was immediately administered by night shift supervisor Emmanuel Kouassi. Emergency medical services transported Desbiens to the regional burn center for treatment. Investigation revealed that the equipment had no operational temperature monitoring alarm, and the LOTO procedure required for maintenance had been bypassed due to shift pressure to maintain production schedules. Desbiens required hospitalization for three days and is on medical leave.

On May 2, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM during day shift operations in the Regrind and Recycling Department, a material handling incident resulted in significant equipment damage. Employee Monique Dion was operating the industrial shredder to process recycled composite scrap when a large aluminum mold fragment—approximately 30 cm x 20 cm x 5 cm, inadvertently mixed with the composite waste—entered the shredder hopper. The metal fragment became lodged in the shredder's rotor assembly, causing immediate mechanical jamming. The impact of the metal striking the rotor generated internal sparks that ignited residual plastic dust accumulation inside the machine housing, resulting in a small fire within the shredder chamber. The fire was contained within the equipment but caused significant damage to the rotor assembly, heating elements, and internal chamber lining. The equipment was immediately shut down by emergency stop and the contained fire self-extinguished within minutes as oxygen was depleted. No injuries occurred. Estimated equipment damage is approximately $47,000 including replacement rotor and chamber repairs. The incident highlighted inadequate incoming material inspection procedures and insufficient housekeeping to manage plastic dust accumulation.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, Production Operator Maya Kumar (EMP-00138) was operating Injection Molding Line A when she noticed unusual vibrations and a grinding noise emanating from the machine's hydraulic pump assembly. Despite attempting to continue production, the pump began leaking pressurized hydraulic fluid at 11:30 AM the following day. Upon inspection by Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the pump's internal seals were found to be completely deteriorated due to lack of preventive maintenance over an 18-month period. The pump failed catastrophically, spraying hot hydraulic fluid across the machine bed and causing temporary shutdown of the line. The failure resulted in approximately 16 hours of downtime, affecting production of automotive dashboard components for a major OEM customer. Emergency repairs cost $28,000 and included replacement of the entire pump assembly, seals, and hoses. The root cause was identified as inadequate maintenance scheduling and failure to replace seals according to manufacturer specifications.

On April 2, 2024 at 10:15 AM, Assembly Operator Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134) was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) cutting glass fiber-reinforced plastic parts using a hand-held utility knife. While trimming excess resin from a medical device housing component, the knife slipped and she cut the palm of her left hand, creating a laceration approximately 2 cm long with minor bleeding. Quality Technician Natalya Kozlov (EMP-00192), who was working nearby performing dimensional checks, witnessed the incident and immediately called for first aid assistance. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) responded with the first aid kit and cleaned the wound with sterile gauze and saline solution. After assessment, it was determined that the laceration did not require stitches but did require proper bandaging with antibiotic ointment and a sterile adhesive bandage. El Amrani completed an incident report and received documented first aid treatment. She resumed work 30 minutes later with the wound properly dressed. No lost work time occurred beyond the immediate treatment period.

On April 8, 2024 at 1:20 AM during the night shift, Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was retrieving plastic pellets from a storage bin in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Maintenance Workshop mezzanine level) when he reached to grab a container from an upper shelf approximately 1.8 meters high. While pulling the container toward himself, he lost his grip and the 15-kilogram container of polycarbonate pellets fell directly onto his right foot, striking the top of his boot. Mwangi immediately experienced sharp pain and was unable to put weight on the affected foot. His colleague, who was also in the storage area retrieving maintenance supplies, immediately notified the night shift supervisor. The employee was transported to the on-site first aid station where the Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) conducted an assessment. X-rays at the local hospital revealed a fractured metatarsal bone in the right foot. Mwangi was placed on light duty for 6 weeks with crutches and was unable to perform material handling work during recovery. The incident was classified as a lost-time injury with 28 days away from work.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) was removing finished medical device housings from Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Assembly and Finishing Department. While extracting a batch of components, Morales experienced sudden onset of severe pain in his right wrist and forearm. He reported feeling a sharp twisting sensation as he gripped a partially molded part that had cooled unevenly, causing it to crack unexpectedly under manual extraction pressure. The part's sharp edges lacerated his palm and caused a hyperextension injury to his wrist. Morales immediately notified his supervisor and was taken to the on-site first aid station where the laceration was treated and bandaged. Due to swelling and limited range of motion, he was referred to urgent care for X-rays, which revealed a non-displaced fracture of the radial styloid process. He was placed on modified duty for 8 weeks and required 3 weeks of lost time during the initial acute phase. Witness Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021), the Mold Technician, observed the incident and confirmed the part quality issue. This incident revealed inadequate post-extraction cooling procedures and insufficient part removal training.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing scheduled maintenance on the resin mixing equipment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building. While inspecting valve connections on a pressurized resin tank, a hairline fracture in a coupling suddenly failed, releasing a pressurized stream of uncured epoxy resin directly onto Gravel's right arm and shoulder. The resin, heated to 65°C as part of the mixing process, caused immediate first and second-degree thermal burns across approximately 15% of his arm surface. Gravel removed his contaminated work shirt and immediately moved to the safety shower station, where he flushed the affected area for 12 minutes. He was assisted by Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), who was nearby restocking chemical supplies and called emergency services. Gravel was transported to the local burn center by ambulance, where he received treatment for thermal and chemical burns requiring hospitalization for 5 days and specialized burn care. He returned to modified duty after 6 weeks. Root cause analysis identified that the coupling was original equipment from 1998 installation and had never been scheduled for replacement. Preventive maintenance records showed no inspection history for this specific coupling.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) was conducting routine inventory in the Raw Materials Warehouse when he discovered that several cartons of thermoplastic resin (supplier lot #TR-2024-0312) showed external signs of moisture penetration and potential contamination. The cartons were stored in the section nearest the exterior wall, and recent heavy rainfall had saturated the warehouse foundation in that area. Upon closer inspection, Hébert noted visible mold growth and a musty odor emanating from multiple boxes. He immediately isolated the affected materials and notified his supervisor and the HSE department. Testing by the Quality Control team confirmed the resin had absorbed moisture above acceptable limits (8.2% vs. 0.5% specification) and showed bacterial contamination that could compromise medical device component sterility certification. The affected materials, valued at approximately $47,000, had to be quarantined and eventually scrapped. This incident required documentation with ISO 13485 regulatory implications. Warehouse environmental conditions were found to lack adequate moisture monitoring, and the building's exterior drainage system had failed during heavy rain. Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) from the Workplace Hazard Assessment team confirmed the warehouse section had been flagged in the previous year's facility audit but the recommendation for foundation waterproofing had not been prioritized.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-011) after an overheated resin dryer malfunctioned. Gilles Marchand, Facilities Maintenance Technician, was performing routine maintenance on the dryer when he noticed unusual heat emanation and a burning smell coming from the equipment's heating element. The dryer's thermostat had failed, causing internal temperatures to exceed safe operating limits. Marchand immediately shut down the equipment and activated the nearest fire alarm pull station. The alarm system functioned correctly, initiating facility-wide evacuation procedures. The HSE team, led by Anh Nguyen (Safety Officer), coordinated the evacuation and ensured all 47 employees in the building cleared safely within 4 minutes. The local fire department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed no actual fire had started, but the dryer's internal components had begun to char. The incident was classified as a precautionary fire alarm activation due to equipment malfunction. No injuries occurred, and operations resumed 2 hours later after the fire department cleared the area.

On March 22, 2024 at 9:47 AM during the day shift, Hassan Diallo, Material Handler, was moving palletized raw polypropylene resin from the warehouse (UNIT-007) to the injection molding production area via manual four-wheel hand truck. While navigating through the main corridor connecting the warehouse to the production building, Hassan's foot caught on a coiled pneumatic air hose that was improperly secured near the doorway threshold. Hassan stumbled but recovered his balance without falling. He immediately reported the trip hazard to his supervisor, François-Xavier Mailhot, who arrived within minutes to assess the situation. The air hose was found to be part of a portable air cleaning station installed three days prior by maintenance staff during equipment upgrades. No formal routing or securing procedures had been documented for this temporary hose installation. Hassan was not injured and continued his work without incident. Upon inspection, the facility identified seven additional unsecured hoses and cables creating similar hazards throughout the production and warehouse areas. Nina Santos, Industrial Hygienist, classified this as a near-miss incident with high probability of recurrence if not addressed.

On March 28, 2024 at 10:32 PM during the evening shift, Rémi Charbonneau, Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a thermal burn injury while performing mold cleaning operations. Rémi was clearing excess plastic material from the cooling manifold of an injection molding machine when a pressurized cooling water line ruptured unexpectedly. Scalding water at approximately 82°C (180°F) sprayed across Rémi's left forearm and hand, causing second-degree burns across an area measuring approximately 8 cm × 12 cm. Colleagues immediately assisted Rémi to the first aid station where Bruno Landry, another operator on Line D and trained first aider, irrigated the burn with cool water for 20 minutes per protocol. Simon Bélanger, Chemical Safety Officer, was notified and arrived at 10:47 PM to assess the injury and document the incident. Rémi was transported to the local hospital's emergency department at 11:05 PM where he received specialized burn treatment and dressing. Medical evaluation determined the injury required hospitalization for 48 hours and would result in approximately 3 weeks of lost work time. Investigation revealed the cooling system had not been inspected for pressure line integrity in 18 months, exceeding the recommended 12-month maintenance interval.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, machine operator Mathieu Gendron was setting up Injection Molding Line B for a new automotive component run. While repositioning a mold carriage to verify alignment, Mathieu noticed the safety interlock on the machine guard appeared to be stuck in the partially open position. Rather than operating the machine in this condition, he immediately stopped work and contacted maintenance. Upon inspection by Carlos Rodriguez, the maintenance manager, a worn solenoid was identified as the root cause of the interlock malfunction. The issue was caught before the machine was energized, preventing potential entanglement or crushing injuries. The machine was locked out and tagged, and the solenoid was replaced within 4 hours. No injuries occurred, but the potential for serious harm was significant given the 50-ton clamping force of the machine.

On March 22, 2024, Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-019 area) during the evening shift. While reviewing inventory logs and conducting environmental observations, Samira identified that several containers of epoxy resin hardener were stored on a lower shelf directly adjacent to a heating element used for temperature control of the storage room. The heating element was operating at approximately 45°C to maintain optimal material viscosity. According to WHMIS documentation, the hardener material has a flash point of 93°C, but the proximity to a heat source and lack of thermal barriers created an unacceptable risk of accidental heating and potential chemical reaction. No spill or fire had occurred, but the hazardous configuration was identified before an incident could develop. The containers were immediately relocated to an upper shelf away from the heating element with improved spacing.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 10:47 PM during night shift operations, a fire alarm was triggered in the Warehouse and Shipping facility (Section A - Raw Materials Warehouse, UNIT-007). The alarm was activated by an automated thermal detection system located near Rack Row 12, where pallets of polycarbonate raw material (in plastic pellet form) and acetone-based cleaning solvents were stored in proximity to one another. Investigation revealed that a forklift battery charging station located 15 meters away had experienced a thermal runaway event, with sparks visible in the vicinity of the solvent storage area. The facility's automated sprinkler system activated immediately, dousing the affected area before any fire could spread. Facility occupants conducted an orderly evacuation following established procedures, with all 18 night shift warehouse personnel accounted for within 6 minutes. Fire services arrived on scene at 11:03 PM and confirmed the thermal event was contained with no injuries or significant property damage.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a minor thermal burn while performing routine mold maintenance in the Medical Components production area. Sofia was inspecting a polycarbonate mold that had recently completed a production cycle when she accidentally made contact with the mold surface, which was still at approximately 85°C despite the cooling cycle. The mold release agent she was applying with a cloth brush came into contact with her left forearm, and she immediately felt a stinging sensation. Sofia removed herself from the heat source and notified her supervisor within seconds. First aid was administered on-site by Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), the Quality Inspector, who applied cool water to the affected area for 10 minutes and applied a sterile dressing. The burn was superficial (first-degree) affecting approximately 2 square inches of skin. Sofia remained at her workstation and continued her shift with modified duties, avoiding direct contact with hot equipment. No hospitalization was required, and the incident was resolved with standard first aid protocols.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter on the night shift, sustained a significant laceration and partial finger injury while troubleshooting a jammed material hopper on Injection Molding Line D. Louis was attempting to manually clear a polyethylene resin blockage in the hopper feed mechanism when the equipment unexpectedly restarted due to a maintenance communication failure. His right hand became caught between the rotating auger and the hopper wall, resulting in a deep laceration across his palm and significant partial amputation of his index fingertip (first knuckle level). Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), the Production Operator on night shift, immediately called emergency services and applied direct pressure with a clean towel to control bleeding. Louis was transported to CHU Sainte-Justine trauma center in Montreal by ambulance, arriving at 12:15 AM. The injury required surgical intervention including partial finger reconstruction and 18 stitches. Louis was hospitalized for 24 hours for observation and pain management. He was released with a two-week work restriction and occupational therapy referral.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM during day shift, Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler in the Maintenance Workshop Storage Mezzanine, experienced a minor allergic reaction to cleaning products while organizing storage supplies. Mariam was rearranging acetone and isopropanol containers in preparation for a deep cleaning scheduled for later that week when she noticed mild itching and redness developing on her exposed forearms and neck area. She had been handling containers without wearing long sleeves, despite standard PPE requirements posted at the storage area entrance. Her symptoms progressed to slight throat tightness and increased skin irritation within 15 minutes. Mariam immediately moved to fresh air at the loading dock and ringed her supervisor. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer, responded within 5 minutes and administered first aid including removal of contaminated clothing, thorough water rinse of affected skin areas, and application of a topical hydrocortisone cream from the first aid station. Mariam's symptoms resolved within 45 minutes of treatment. She was held for observation for an additional 1.5 hours to ensure no progression of symptoms. Medical evaluation confirmed a mild chemical contact dermatitis reaction, not requiring professional medical intervention. She completed her shift with reassignment to non-chemical handling duties.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a Machine Operator on the evening shift who was covering for an absent colleague, was operating Injection Molding Line D in the Production Operations area. While attempting to clear a polymer jam from the hopper using a wooden rod, Hawa's right hand slipped and contacted the rotating auger screw mechanism. The rotating screw caught her sleeve and pulled her arm partially into the mechanism before automatic shutdown sensors activated. Her right forearm and hand sustained significant lacerations and crush injuries. Immediate first aid was provided by nearby supervisor Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128), and Hawa was transported to the hospital via ambulance. Emergency medical evaluation revealed multiple fractures to the metacarpals, significant soft tissue damage, and compartment syndrome requiring surgical intervention. The employee was hospitalized for 5 days and required extensive rehabilitation. Investigation revealed that lockout/tagout procedures were bypassed due to time pressure, and the employee had received inadequate training on emergency hopper clearing procedures.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), a Material Handler, was moving bags of polypropylene resin from the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) to the Material Drying and Preparation Room using a hydraulic pallet jack. While navigating a sharp turn near the chemical storage area, Amani misjudged the clearance and the loaded pallet jack struck a shelving unit containing cleaning solvents. The impact caused approximately 8 bags of acetone-based cleaning solvent to fall from the shelf, striking Amani on the left shoulder and back. One bag ruptured upon impact, releasing volatile fumes and caustic liquid that contacted Amani's skin and clothing. The employee immediately reported pain and respiratory irritation. First aid station personnel (Ana Silva, EMP-00040, responding) flushed the affected areas with water and provided respiratory support. Amani was transported to the emergency department where chemical burns were documented on the left shoulder and upper back, classified as first and second-degree burns. The employee was treated and released but required 8 days off work for wound care and pain management. Investigation revealed inadequate spacing between material pathways and chemical storage, poor visibility at the turn, and lack of operator training on load stability.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, a chemical storage incident occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025). Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) was organizing cleaning solvents on the mezzanine storage shelves when she noticed a leaking container of isopropanol. The 5-liter container had a defective cap that had partially unscrewed, causing approximately 2 liters of solvent to spill across the mezzanine floor and drip down to the maintenance workshop below. The spill created a slippery hazard and released significant solvent vapors in the enclosed mezzanine space. Salma immediately evacuated the area and contacted Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) who initiated the spill response protocol. The facility's emergency response team contained the spill using absorbent materials and increased ventilation. The affected area was cordoned off for 3 hours while vapors dissipated. No personnel were directly exposed to the liquid, but two employees (Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay and Forklift Operator Tariq Aziz) reported mild eye irritation from vapor exposure and were treated with saline rinses by the first aid station.

On March 22, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM during the afternoon/evening shift transition, Injection Molding Operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) sustained a burn injury while performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line A (UNIT-005). While cleaning a mold cavity with a soft brush, François accidentally made contact with an active heating element on the mold that was inadvertently left at operational temperature (approximately 95°C). The operator was wearing standard work gloves but the brief contact (approximately 2 seconds) resulted in a thermal burn on the dorsal surface of his right hand, affecting approximately 3% body surface area. The burn was classified as a first-degree burn with some areas of superficial second-degree involvement. Operations Manager Guillaume Deschamps (EMP-00051) immediately provided first aid using ice-water immersion for 15 minutes followed by application of a sterile burn dressing. François was transported to the on-site first aid station where Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) documented the incident and provided additional wound care. The employee was cleared to continue work with a bandaged hand after being advised to monitor for infection and report any worsening symptoms.

On March 28, 2024 at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) sustained a laceration and contusion to his left forearm while positioning a large mold assembly above an injection molding station in UNIT-005. While guiding the suspended load with hand signals to Injection Molding Technician Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181) who was operating the overhead crane controls, a cable shift caused the load to swing unexpectedly. The mold assembly bracket caught Raymond's left forearm between the mold and the equipment frame, resulting in a 4-inch laceration with moderate bleeding and significant bruising. The operator immediately applied pressure using a cloth to control bleeding while Pascal slowly lowered the load to release the trapped arm. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157), who was present for routine night shift inspections, responded immediately. He provided first aid including wound cleaning, hemostasis using pressure bandages, and topical antiseptic application. Raymond was transported to the facility's first aid station where the wound was assessed as requiring sutures (7 stitches) but no hospitalization was necessary. The injury was documented and the employee was advised to keep the wound clean and return for suture removal after 10 days.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift, Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090), a Machine Setter on Line D, was adjusting mold release agent spray nozzles on a 200-ton injection molding machine when his right forearm made contact with the mold release agent being dispensed. The chemical splashed onto approximately 15% of his forearm skin surface, causing immediate skin irritation and redness. Ibrahim noticed a burning sensation and immediately notified his supervisor, Michael Chen. First aid was applied with soap and water rinse at the safety station for 10 minutes. Ibrahim complained of persistent redness and mild swelling. The incident occurred because the machine's safety interlocks were temporarily disabled during maintenance, and no secondary containment was in place for the chemical dispenser. A coworker, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), witnessed the incident and helped escort Ibrahim to the first aid station. The area was cleaned and documented, and the machine was taken offline for inspection.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift transition, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), the Regrind Operator, was operating the granulation system that processes rejected molded parts and material scrap for recycling. The system uses heated screws and conveyors to break down plastic waste into reusable pellets. At approximately 6:28 AM, Mohamed noticed a mechanical noise coming from the hopper motor and attempted to investigate while the system was still running. He did not follow proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures and did not inform anyone of his maintenance attempt. His work glove became caught in the rotating conveyor screw, pulling his left hand partially into the mechanism. His coworker, Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072), heard him shout and immediately activated the emergency stop button, preventing further injury. Mohamed sustained significant lacerations and abrasions to his left hand and forearm, with partial avulsion of the palm skin. Emergency response was called and Mohamed was transported for surgical evaluation and wound care. The root causes included: inadequate LOTO compliance, insufficient training on mechanical hazard recognition, and failure to communicate maintenance needs through proper channels.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, suffered a lost-time injury while performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. While cleaning the hopper area after a material changeover, the machine unexpectedly activated due to a faulty proximity sensor that failed to register the safety interlock. Zaidi's left hand was caught between the hydraulic injection platen and the fixed mold frame, resulting in a crushing injury with significant laceration and contusion. Emergency response was initiated immediately; first aid was administered on-site by Sophie Lapointe (Quality Control Technician) who was working nearby, and Zaidi was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital by ambulance. The injury required 8 hours of emergency surgery and resulted in 45 days of lost work time. Initial investigation revealed that the proximity sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months, well beyond the manufacturer's recommended 6-month interval. The machine had also been operated without proper lockout/tagout procedures during maintenance activities.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, an environmental incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of polyester resin for composite manufacturing. While transferring approximately 500 liters of liquid polyurethane catalyst from a bulk storage drum to a smaller working container using a manual transfer pump, a high-pressure hose connection failed due to corrosion and improper fitting torque. The resulting spill released approximately 80 liters of the catalyst directly onto the concrete floor, where it began to spread toward the floor drain system. Popescu immediately activated the emergency response procedures and notified Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, who initiated containment procedures. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and emergency dikes before it reached the drain. The facility environmental specialist conducted a thorough assessment and determined that approximately 15 liters had already entered the facility's segregated stormwater system, which flows to a retention pond on the property. The incident required notification to the Quebec Ministry of Environment, as the release exceeded the reportable quantity threshold for this hazardous material. Environmental sampling of the retention pond was initiated and showed elevated chemical concentrations requiring remediation measures.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a significant burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. Jalbert was removing a finished part from a mold on one of TechnoPlast's 250-ton injection molding machines in UNIT-002 when the thermal safety interlock malfunctioned. The mold temperature was approximately 180°C instead of the expected 120°C due to a faulty temperature controller that had not been replaced during the previous week's scheduled maintenance window. As Jalbert reached into the mold cavity to extract the part, his right forearm contacted the hot cavity surface, resulting in a second-degree burn covering approximately 8% of the affected area. The employee immediately reported the injury to his supervisor, Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), who provided first aid and arranged transportation to the local medical facility. The machine was immediately shut down and locked out. Investigation revealed that the maintenance department had identified the faulty controller but had not prioritized its replacement due to production scheduling pressures.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in UNIT-010 (Chemical Storage and Mixing Room). Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), a Hydraulic Systems Technician, was attempting to transfer a 20-liter container of epoxy resin from a high shelf when the container's cap was not fully secured. The container fell approximately 1.2 meters to the concrete floor, rupturing and releasing approximately 18 liters of epoxy resin mixed with hardener catalyst. The spill spread across approximately 12 square meters of floor space and began releasing strong chemical vapors. Popov immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency alarm. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) notified Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) of the incident. The chemical storage area's ventilation system was insufficient to manage the vapor concentration, and three employees in adjacent areas reported mild respiratory irritation. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and properly disposed of according to hazardous waste procedures. No environmental release to exterior areas occurred. Root cause: improper container storage procedures and inadequate container securing mechanisms.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter on the night shift, sustained a serious back injury resulting in lost-time injury status. Desbiens was manually repositioning a 45-kilogram mold assembly in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013) when he attempted to lift it using improper body mechanics. The mold assembly, which should have been moved using the overhead crane system, was being shifted by hand to make room for incoming equipment due to time pressure to meet a production deadline. Desbiens felt immediate sharp pain in his lower back and lower left side as he twisted while lifting. He was unable to continue working and reported the injury to the maintenance workshop supervisor, Richard Beaulieu (EMP-00043). Beaulieu immediately contacted HSE Director Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001). Desbiens was transported to the hospital for evaluation and diagnostic imaging, which revealed a herniated disc at L4-L5 with nerve involvement. Medical assessment resulted in a work restriction preventing him from working for 14 days, qualifying this as a lost-time injury under CNESST regulations. Root cause analysis indicated that the night shift crew had only one operator and the crane was in use on another project, combined with inadequate training on material handling limits and available equipment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a hydraulic leak was discovered in the injection molding equipment at Line B in the Main Production Building. Injection Molding Operator Youssef Zaidi was performing routine maintenance when he noticed a fine mist of hydraulic oil spraying from a deteriorated hose connection near the heating element. The leak created a slippery condition on the production floor around a 4-meter radius. Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant was notified immediately, and the affected equipment was shut down. The hydraulic oil pooled near electrical equipment, creating both a slip hazard and a potential fire risk given the proximity to heated molds operating at 200°C. Emergency response procedures were initiated. The spill was contained using absorbent material, and the area was cordoned off. Environmental monitoring confirmed no vapor release above acceptable limits, but the incident exposed deficiencies in preventive maintenance scheduling for hydraulic systems across all production lines.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Material Handler Kwesi Owusu suffered a lost-time injury while moving resin pallets in the Raw Materials Warehouse. Owusu was attempting to reposition a pallet of polypropylene resin (approximately 800 kg) using a manual pallet jack when the load shifted unexpectedly. The pallet corner struck his left foot, and he lost balance, falling backward onto the concrete floor. He struck the back of his head and neck on impact. Emergency response was initiated immediately. First aid assessment revealed acute back pain, left foot contusion, and head impact trauma. Owusu was transported by ambulance to a local hospital where imaging revealed a lumbar strain (L4-L5 disc involvement) and a mild concussion. He was admitted for 24-hour observation and prescribed bed rest. The incident was witnessed by Inventory Control Specialist Nicole Proulx, who called emergency services. Root cause analysis indicated inadequate pallet jack maintenance (worn wheels, compromised load stability) and the employee's unfamiliarity with the updated load weight specifications introduced three months prior.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 7:55 PM during the evening shift, Packaging Operator Amina Ba sustained a first-aid level injury while operating the automated packaging line in the Finished Goods Warehouse. Ba was clearing a paper jam from the shrink-wrap sealing station when her left hand made contact with a moving conveyor belt drive mechanism. The belt caught her work glove, pulling her hand toward the pinch point. Her coworker, Shipping and Receiving Clerk Mélanie Fortin, immediately activated the emergency stop button, halting the conveyor within 1.2 seconds. Ba suffered a laceration to the heel of her left palm and moderate abrasion across her knuckles. First aid was administered on-site by Training Coordinator Amélie Roy, who was conducting a scheduled safety audit. The wound was cleaned, treated with antiseptic, and covered with a sterile dressing. No sutures were required, and no lost time occurred. The incident was documented in the first-aid log. Investigation revealed that the conveyor's safety guard had a gap in coverage at the jam-clearing access point, and the hazard communication signage was partially obscured by packaging materials.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was operating Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Main Production Building when she noticed coolant leaking from the machine's cooling water system onto the production floor. She immediately stopped the machine and notified her supervisor, Chantal Côté (EMP-00017). Upon inspection, a hairline crack was discovered in the cooling water supply line near the manifold connection. The coolant created a slick surface on the floor around the machine station. Before the maintenance team arrived, Kamara placed warning cones around the affected area and applied absorbent material to the floor to prevent a slip hazard. The leak was contained to approximately 2 gallons of industrial coolant. Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) responded immediately and verified that the crack had not yet damaged the machine's electrical components. The cooling water system was isolated and the machine was taken offline for repairs. This near-miss incident demonstrated effective hazard recognition and proactive response, preventing potential injuries to other operators working nearby.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Forklift Operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was moving a pallet of raw polycarbonate resin containers from the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) to the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when the forklift's hydraulic lift mechanism suddenly failed. The pallet, weighing approximately 800 pounds, descended rapidly and struck the concrete floor with significant force. One of the resin containers cracked open, spilling approximately 10 liters of uncured resin onto the floor. Aziz was not injured as he was positioned safely on the forklift seat. However, the spilled resin created a slipping hazard and began to harden on contact with the floor. Receiving Clerk Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085) witnessed the incident from nearby and immediately evacuated the immediate area. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) responded to assess chemical exposure risk and activated the facility's emergency ventilation protocols. The hydraulic system was completely inoperable, requiring the forklift to be removed from service. Emergency cleanup was completed, and the forklift was tagged out of service pending full hydraulic system replacement and certification.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Tool and Die Maker Mario Béslisle (EMP-00149) was performing maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-021) when the machine's spindle drive belt suddenly snapped. The broken belt whipped out of its housing and struck Béslisle on the left shoulder, causing him to stumble backward. He did not fall but reported immediate shoulder pain. The sudden failure also caused the spindle to decelerate rapidly, creating a loss of cutting precision on the part being worked on at the time. Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) was in an adjacent work station and immediately responded. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the spindle belt was severely worn and cracked—a condition that had been developing for weeks but went unnoticed. The belt had reached the end of its service life but had not been replaced during the company's normal maintenance schedule. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) assisted in isolating the machine and tagging it out of service. The incident required the machine to be offline for belt replacement and spindle re-calibration, causing significant production delays on a medical device order.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) was working at Injection Molding Line A in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). While performing routine material loading operations, Khalil reached toward a heated mold surface to reposition a partially molded component. Despite wearing standard production gloves, she made direct contact with the mold surface which was operating at 185°C. The operator sustained a thermal burn to the palmar surface of her right hand, affecting approximately 4% of total body surface area. Immediate first aid was administered by nearby Quality Control Technician Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013), who applied cool water to the affected area for 15 minutes. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) evaluated the injury and determined it was a second-degree burn requiring medical attention. The employee was transported to the on-site medical clinic for wound cleaning, topical antibiotic application, and non-adherent dressing. The incident was caused by inadequate thermal awareness and insufficient barrier protection. Production on Line A was halted for 30 minutes during incident response and investigation.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 1:15 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was performing routine maintenance on a hydraulic pressure line in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). Hassan was attempting to loosen a corroded coupling fitting on Line B's injection unit when the line suddenly ruptured under pressure, spraying high-temperature hydraulic fluid (approximately 60°C) across his left arm and torso. Hassan immediately fell backward, striking his left side against a metal workbench edge. The operator sustained a combination injury: chemical burns from the hydraulic fluid exposure across his left forearm and shoulder, and a fractured left rib from the impact. Colleague François Gagnon (EMP-00008) witnessed the incident and immediately assisted Hassan to the emergency wash station. Process Engineer Raj Patel (EMP-00018) arrived within minutes and called for emergency medical services. Hassan was transported to the local hospital where he was diagnosed with second-degree chemical burns affecting approximately 6% of body surface and a non-displaced fracture of the left 5th rib. Hassan was unable to return to work and remained hospitalized for 3 days. Investigation revealed the coupling had not been replaced in 7 years despite manufacturing recommendations for replacement every 5 years. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) documented the incident for CNESST reporting.

On January 8, 2025, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, Crane Operator Gaston Picard (EMP-00193) was transferring large composite material spools from the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009) to storage in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) using an overhead gantry crane. At approximately 11:32 PM, while lifting a 1,200 kg composite spool approximately 6 meters above the warehouse floor, the crane's main lifting cable suddenly snapped, causing the spool to fall freely. The spool impacted a metal storage rack below, causing significant damage to the rack and crushing several boxes of finished goods valued at approximately $18,000. Forklift Operator Claude Poirier (EMP-00071) and Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) were working in an adjacent area of the warehouse and heard the cable failure and impact. Emergency procedures were immediately activated. Fortunately, no employees were directly beneath the falling load, though the impact zone was only 3 meters from where Bianchi had been standing 2 minutes prior. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was called to investigate the incident immediately. Upon examination of the failed cable, it was discovered that the cable had not been inspected or certified in 18 months, exceeding the required 12-month inspection interval. The cable showed visible signs of corrosion and wire breakage consistent with age-related degradation. The crane was immediately taken out of service pending full equipment certification.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), an Assembly Operator, was working at Station 7 in the Main Production Building's assembly line. While removing cured plastic components from a completed assembly fixture, Luis's right hand came into contact with sharp burrs and gate remnants on a freshly molded automotive interior trim part. The component had not been properly deburring-processed due to a maintenance delay on the automated edge finishing system. Luis sustained a deep laceration across his palm and sustained minor bleeding. His colleague Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) immediately applied pressure with gauze from the first aid station and alerted the shift supervisor. The wound required cleaning, antibiotic ointment, and a sterile bandage. Luis was able to return to modified duty within 30 minutes after treatment and was monitored for infection risk throughout the remainder of his shift.

On March 20, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift operations in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010), Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147), the Regrind Supervisor, was conducting a routine inspection of the material drying system when he noticed unusual vibration and temperature elevation on the resin dryer unit (Model IRC-500). The resin dryer, which processes recycled composite material, was operating at 168°C with internal sensor readings indicating potential overheating. Normand immediately ceased the drying operation by switching the unit to standby mode and documented his observations. He then notified Roland Dostie (EMP-00199), the Maintenance Planner on call, who conducted a preliminary diagnostic assessment. The investigation identified a failing thermostat that was causing temperature overshooting. While no personnel were injured and no material damage occurred, the incident was classified as a preventive declaration because the equipment failure created a potential fire hazard and risk of thermal burn exposure. The unit was locked out pending replacement of the thermostat controller.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the early morning transition from night to day shift in the Maintenance Workshop (Building 4), Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), a Mechanical Maintenance Technician, was conducting a hydraulic system inspection on injection molding machine #18. While he was working on pressurized hydraulic lines, a pinhole leak developed in a 90-degree elbow fitting under high pressure. Pressurized hydraulic fluid at approximately 2,000 PSI was injected directly into Marco's left forearm, creating a small but deep penetration wound approximately 3 millimeters in diameter. The immediate pain was severe, and Marco reacted by withdrawing his arm. He immediately notified Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), the Hydraulic Systems Technician also working in the workshop. Andrei de-pressurized the system using the emergency lockout procedure, and both technicians proceeded to the on-site first aid station. Marco received immediate medical assessment, wound cleaning, and tetanus prophylaxis. Due to the nature of hydraulic fluid injection injuries—which carry high infection risk—Marco was transported to the local emergency department for advanced wound management including exploratory surgery to confirm no deep tissue damage occurred. He was treated and released the same day but remained on modified duty for 48 hours pending infection monitoring.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Celine Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was removing finished automotive components from a 250-ton injection molding machine. Due to inadequate ergonomic setup and repetitive gripping motions required to extract parts from tight mold cavities, she experienced acute pain in both wrists and forearms. After completing her shift, the pain intensified significantly. The next morning, she reported severe carpal tunnel symptoms and could not grip objects. Medical evaluation confirmed acute carpal tunnel syndrome exacerbation. The incident resulted from the combination of high-frequency repetitive motions (approximately 800 part cycles per shift), improper workstation height causing wrist deviation, and lack of adequate recovery time between cycles. A witness, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), noted that Celine had been complaining of wrist discomfort for several weeks prior. The facility's EHS Coordinator, Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), was notified and documented the injury.

On February 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant fire incident occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042), a Composite Materials Technician, was processing fiber-reinforced plastic components in a heated cure oven maintained at 160°C. Due to accumulated plastic dust and resin particles on horizontal surfaces near the oven, combined with inadequate housekeeping and insufficient ventilation exhaust capacity, a dust accumulation fire hazard had developed undetected over several weeks. When Olga transferred hot cured components to a nearby work surface, residual heat ignited the accumulated composite dust. Flames rapidly spread across the work area. The facility's Fire Safety Coordinator, Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), activated the emergency response system immediately upon notification. Automatic sprinkler systems partially controlled the fire within 8 minutes; however, the fire caused significant damage to equipment, materials, and required evacuation of the entire west wing. Three nearby employees—including Olga—were evacuated and assessed for smoke inhalation (none required hospitalization). The fire was extinguished by responding fire department. Post-incident investigation revealed systematic failures in dust collection maintenance and inadequate cleaning protocols.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 8:20 AM during the day shift, Denis Savard (EMP-00099), the Purchasing Manager, was in the Cafeteria and Break Room preparing his morning coffee. While pouring hot water from an industrial-sized kettle into his cup, his hand slipped due to a wet countertop surface (residual water from another employee's beverage preparation). The kettle tipped, and approximately 200 ml of near-boiling water (approximately 85°C) spilled directly onto his right forearm and hand. The employee immediately immersed his arm in cold water from the nearby sink for approximately 15 minutes. Other break room occupants, including Noor Ahmed (EMP-00076), the HR Generalist, provided initial first aid by assisting with cooling and locating first aid supplies. The burn area (approximately 8 cm × 5 cm) showed characteristic first-degree burn symptoms: mild erythema, slight swelling, and localized pain. No blistering or deeper tissue damage was apparent. The employee's burn was dressed with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment from the facility's first aid kit. Pain medication (over-the-counter ibuprofen) was provided. The employee remained on light duty for one day with no time away from work required. This incident exemplifies typical cafeteria hazard scenarios in industrial facilities.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a fire alarm was triggered in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) located in the Main Production Building's West Wing. An employee, Giovanni Bianchi (CNC Operator), was performing routine maintenance on a glass fiber reinforcement curing oven when he accidentally knocked over a container of mold release agent near a heat source. The flammable liquid pooled near the oven's exterior and ignited, creating visible flames approximately 2 feet high. The fire alarm system automatically activated, triggering facility-wide evacuation procedures. Facility maintenance technician Gilles Marchand responded immediately with a nearby Class B fire extinguisher and successfully suppressed the flames within 90 seconds. No injuries occurred, and the fire was fully extinguished before emergency services arrived. The incident resulted in production halt for 4 hours while the area was inspected and cleared for safe restart. Contributing factors included improper storage of flammable materials near heat sources and lack of secondary containment.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM during day shift, an environmental incident was discovered in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Material Handler Hassan Diallo noticed a slow leak from a hydraulic oil line connected to the drying system's pneumatic controls. Approximately 15 liters of mineral-based hydraulic oil had accumulated on the concrete floor, creating a slip hazard and beginning to seep toward the facility's storm drain system located near the exterior wall. The spill was not contained by secondary barriers as required by facility protocols. Environmental compliance representative Natasha Ivanov was immediately notified and coordinated containment efforts. The area was isolated with warning signs, and absorbent material was deployed to contain the remaining liquid. The contaminated concrete was cleaned and disposed of according to Quebec Environmental Protection Act requirements. Investigation revealed the hydraulic line coupling had corroded due to inadequate maintenance and was due for replacement per the preventive maintenance schedule, but the work order had been pending for 6 weeks. The spill was reported to CNESST and provincial environmental authorities as a precautionary measure.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 9:15 PM during evening shift operations, a near-miss incident was reported in Injection Molding Line B - Automotive (UNIT-002). Machine Setter Tomas Jimenez was performing routine cleaning of the injection molding machine's mold cavity after production shutdown when he noticed the safety interlock light on the machine's control panel was illuminated (green), indicating the machine was supposedly in a safe state. However, upon closer inspection during his pre-cleaning safety check, he discovered that the hydraulic pressure gauge showed residual pressure still present in the system at 150 PSI, despite the machine being shut down 15 minutes earlier. According to facility LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures, the system must reach zero pressure before manual cleaning can commence. Jimenez immediately stopped and notified his supervisor, Luc-André Beaudoin. The system was properly de-pressurized using the manual pressure relief valve before cleaning proceeded. Investigation revealed that the automatic pressure relief valve had a stuck poppet, preventing complete depressurization. If Jimenez had proceeded without verification, contact with the pressurized system could have caused injection of hydraulic fluid into his hand, a serious injury risk. The situation was reported as a near-miss by Safety Representative Serge Lafleur.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a fire originated in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) when a malfunctioning industrial oven's temperature control failed, causing the internal chamber temperature to exceed safe operating limits. The oven, used for pre-drying polycarbonate (PC) resin before injection molding, reached approximately 380°C instead of the normal 120°C operating temperature. Nearby stored bags of colorant masterbatch and glass fiber reinforcement materials ignited from radiant heat exposure. Materials Supervisor Valérie Pelletier was in the adjacent material staging area when she detected smoke and immediately activated the emergency alarm at 2:16 PM. The facility's automatic fire suppression system activated within 90 seconds, containing the fire to the oven and immediate vicinity. The fire was fully extinguished by 2:28 PM. Local fire department arrived at 2:35 PM for verification and safety assessment. No personnel were injured. Damage was limited to the oven unit (estimated $85,000) and approximately 200 kg of ruined raw materials. The incident was traced to a failed temperature sensor that had been showing intermittent readings for three days but was not escalated for immediate maintenance.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift, Production Operator Yara Mustafa was performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Machine Line B when her left hand came into contact with dried mold release agent residue on the machine's exterior cooling jacket. The contact caused immediate skin irritation with redness, itching, and mild burning sensation affecting approximately 15% of her left palm and fingers. Yara notified her line supervisor Éric Surprenant at 10:52 PM. First aid was administered immediately by on-site first aid attendant, consisting of thorough washing with soap and water for 5 minutes followed by application of a mild hydrocortisone cream and a protective bandage. The irritation subsided within 30 minutes. The employee was monitored for 2 hours to ensure no systemic reaction developed. No hospitalization or lost time was required. The incident was documented in the facility's first aid log and reported to the HSE department. Root cause: inadequate PPE (gloves had small tears from previous use) and insufficient warning labels on the equipment indicating mold release agent presence on cooling surfaces.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during night shift, Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was performing scheduled maintenance on a 300-ton injection molding machine when a pinch point injury occurred. Louis was adjusting the mold clamping mechanism's hydraulic pressure relief valve when his right hand became caught between the valve assembly and the machine frame as the hydraulic system unexpectedly cycled. The incident occurred because the machine had not been fully locked out and tagged out (LOTO) as required by company procedures—only the main power was disabled, but residual hydraulic pressure remained active in the system. Louis sustained a crush injury to his right ring and middle fingers, resulting in lacerations, contusions, and suspected fractures. Coworker Ahmed Hassan heard Louis's cry for help and immediately notified the shift supervisor. First aid was administered at 12:35 AM, and Louis was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital at 12:42 AM, arriving with moderate to severe hand trauma. Emergency room evaluation confirmed fractures of the distal phalanges in both fingers and deep lacerations requiring sutures. Louis required hospitalization for 3 days and is expected to miss 8 weeks of work. Investigation revealed the LOTO coordinator had not conducted the morning pre-shift equipment verification, and the previous shift operator failed to document the incomplete lockout status.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-005). Olga Ivanova, a Composite Materials Technician, was transferring a 20-liter container of epoxy resin from a storage shelf to a mixing station when the container slipped from her hands due to inadequate grip from worn gloves. The container struck the concrete floor and ruptured, releasing approximately 15 liters of mixed epoxy resin across an area of roughly 50 square meters. The spill immediately created a slippery hazard and released volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the air. Emergency response was initiated by Johanne Paquette, the Emergency Response Team Leader, who activated the facility's spill response protocol. Ventilation systems were manually increased, and the area was evacuated within 5 minutes. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and neutralizing agents stored in the spill kit. No personnel were directly exposed to significant quantities of the chemical, though three employees in adjacent areas reported mild respiratory irritation that resolved within 30 minutes of increased ventilation. The incident was contained and cleaned within 2 hours. Environmental monitoring confirmed air quality returned to normal levels within 90 minutes post-cleanup.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Leila Farah, a Production Operator on Injection Molding Line B (Automotive Components), suffered a significant laceration to her left index and middle fingers while performing routine maintenance on the plastic injection molding equipment. Leila was attempting to clear a material jam in the feed hopper when the machine's cooling cycle reactivated unexpectedly due to a malfunction in the safety interlock system. The rotating auger screw contacted her gloved hand, causing deep lacerations to both fingers requiring immediate first aid and emergency transport to the hospital. Her supervisor, Julie Bergeron, initiated emergency response protocols at 10:17 PM, calling for immediate medical assistance. Leila was transported to Laval Regional Hospital by ambulance, where she received 15 stitches and was kept overnight for observation due to concerns about potential nerve damage. The incident resulted in lost time of 8 working days as Leila required medical leave for wound care and physiotherapy. The production line was immediately shut down, and a LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedure was initiated to prevent further unsafe machine operations. Investigation revealed that the safety interlock had not been serviced in over 18 months, exceeding the required maintenance interval by six months.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 5:30 AM during the night shift, Anh Nguyen, the Safety Officer, conducted a routine facility inspection of the Warehouse and Shipping area (UNIT-009) and identified a significant workplace hazard requiring immediate preventive action. During the inspection, Anh discovered that emergency exit routes from the main warehouse were partially obstructed by palletized finished goods that had been stacked too close to the emergency exit doors. Specifically, three large pallets of packaged automotive components were positioned approximately 1.2 meters from the designated emergency exit, reducing the required 1.8-meter clearance to only 0.6 meters. This violation of facility safety protocols and local fire codes created a critical fire safety hazard that could prevent rapid evacuation in an emergency. Additionally, Anh observed that the emergency exit signage was partially obscured by dust and had not been cleaned in several weeks. While no incident had occurred, the preventive identification of this hazard prevented a potentially catastrophic situation during an actual emergency. Anh immediately notified Julien Racine, the Shipping Clerk, to relocate the materials and initiated a facility-wide audit of all emergency exit routes. The blocked areas were cleared within 45 minutes. This preventive declaration ensures that the facility maintains compliance with CNESST and fire safety regulations.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak was discovered in the Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components clean room area. Operator Paul Demers (EMP-00103) noticed water pooling near the base of the injection molding machine and immediately reported it to the facility. The cooling system had developed a hairline fracture in one of the copper feed lines connecting to the mold cooling circuit, likely due to thermal stress from repeated heating and cooling cycles. Water was leaking at an estimated rate of 2-3 liters per minute onto the production floor. The leak contaminated approximately 15 square meters of the clean room floor, posing a slipping hazard and potentially compromising the sterile environment required for medical-grade component production. Maintenance technician Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085) was called to assess the damage. The area was cordoned off with warning signs, and production on that line was halted for 8 hours while the damaged section of copper tubing was replaced and the cooling system was flushed and pressure-tested to ensure no further leaks.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) sustained a hand laceration while inspecting finished medical device components at her workstation in the Quality Control area. Singh was manually examining a batch of polycarbonate connectors with extremely sharp machined edges when her right index finger contacted a burr that had not been properly de-burred during the finishing process. The cut, approximately 1.5 cm in length, penetrated the dermis layer and caused controlled bleeding. First aid responder Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) from Training and HR immediately applied direct pressure with sterile gauze, cleaned the wound with antiseptic solution, and applied antibiotic ointment followed by a sterile adhesive bandage. The injury was assessed as requiring no stitches, and Singh was able to continue working after 20 minutes of treatment with the wound protected by a reinforced bandage and protective finger cap. The incident was documented and reported to the JHSC. The component batch was flagged for additional de-burring quality checks before release to shipping.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047) narrowly avoided a serious injury when reaching for a box of polypropylene resin pellets stored on the third shelf of a metal storage rack in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. As Hébert stretched upward and reached past the second shelf, the improperly balanced load above shifted unexpectedly, causing three boxes (approximately 8 kg each) to begin sliding from the top shelf. Hébert noticed the movement from his peripheral vision and immediately stepped backward, allowing the boxes to fall harmlessly to the floor beside him. The boxes landed exactly where Hébert had been standing seconds before. Post-incident investigation revealed that the boxes had been stacked in violation of facility procedures—heavier boxes were placed on top of lighter ones, creating an unstable pyramid configuration. Additionally, no load retention bars or anti-slip mats were installed on the shelves. Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was called immediately and documented the incident as a near-miss with high severity potential. The area was secured, the material was re-stacked correctly, and a full audit of all warehouse racking was initiated.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Raoul Blanchard (EMP-00141), a machine operator, was performing routine mold extraction from injection molding machine #18 in the Assembly and Finishing Department when his right hand became caught between the mold and the machine frame as the hydraulic clamp cycled unexpectedly. The incident occurred because the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure was bypassed to expedite production due to a delayed customer shipment. Raoul's hand was compressed for approximately 8 seconds before the machine cycled back. He sustained a crush injury to his right palm and fingers, resulting in severe bruising, two fractured metacarpals, and nerve compression requiring immediate hospitalization. Emergency responders were called and he was transported to Laval Hospital where he underwent surgical assessment and spent 3 days hospitalized. He required 6 weeks off work for recovery and physical therapy. The incident was witnessed by Catherine Leblanc (Quality Inspector), who immediately activated the emergency stop button.

On April 3, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, the Material Drying and Preparation Room experienced a critical equipment malfunction. Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), a machine operator, was monitoring the material drying carousel when she noticed unusual sounds and vibrations emanating from the dryer motor assembly. The main drive motor bearing had failed due to inadequate lubrication, causing metal-on-metal contact and generating excessive heat. The motor began smoking, and within minutes, the heating element started to overheat uncontrollably, causing the internal temperature to spike to 185°C (the safe operating limit is 120°C). The control system's temperature sensor had been malfunctioning for 3 weeks but had not been replaced due to supply chain delays. Hawa immediately activated the emergency shutoff and evacuated the area, alerting her supervisor Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142). The Receiving Coordinator called maintenance, and Réjan Simard (EMP-00077), the Mold Maintenance Technician, arrived within 10 minutes to secure the equipment. No personnel were injured, but the dryer sustained $28,000 in damage and required 2 weeks of downtime for repairs, impacting production schedules.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a chemical mixing operator, was transferring a batch of polyurethane resin from a supply drum to the mixing tank in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The transfer hose connection was worn and had a small hairline fracture that was not visible during routine inspection. As pressure was applied to pump the resin, the hose suddenly failed at the coupling, spraying approximately 3 liters of resin directly into Elena's face and upper torso. The resin, which contains isocyanates and other irritant chemicals, caused immediate eye irritation, facial burns, and respiratory distress. Elena's safety glasses were present but had slipped down on her forehead during the transfer operation due to poor fit. She immediately flushed her face with the emergency eyewash station for 15 minutes while Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120), a CNC Machinist working nearby, called emergency services and the HSE director. Elena was transported to the regional hospital where she was treated for chemical burns to her face and neck (second-degree equivalent severity) and chemical conjunctivitis. She spent 2 days in the hospital and required 10 days of medical leave for recovery.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a laceration to his left hand while performing routine mold maintenance. Zaidi was removing hardened plastic residue from a mold cavity using a metal scraper when the tool slipped, causing a sharp edge of the mold to cut his palm and fingers. The mold cavity had not been fully cooled and cleaned according to protocol before maintenance work began. A colleague, Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), witnessed the incident and immediately alerted supervision. The injury resulted in significant bleeding and required wound closure with 6 stitches at the on-site first aid station. The employee was able to continue work after treatment but with restricted hand duties for 48 hours. The root cause investigation identified inadequate cooling time verification and lack of enforcement of pre-maintenance safety checklists on Line B.

On November 16, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift, Amina Mansour (EMP-00044), a Material Handler in the Raw Materials Warehouse, experienced a minor allergic reaction after handling latex gloves used for material sorting. Mansour developed localized skin redness, mild swelling on her hands, and slight itching approximately 15 minutes into her shift. She reported the symptoms to her supervisor Wei Liu (EMP-00088), who immediately provided first aid treatment including topical corticosteroid cream and access to clean water for hand washing. The employee rested in the break room (UNIT-024) for 30 minutes and symptoms resolved completely. Investigation revealed that the facility's inventory of nitrile alternative gloves was depleted, and only latex gloves were available in the warehouse section that day. Mansour had a known latex sensitivity documented in her employee health file but had not previously reported issues as alternative gloves were typically available. This incident highlights a procedural gap in PPE inventory management and communication with employees who have documented sensitivities.

On November 18, 2024, at 6:20 AM during night shift operations, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). A drying oven malfunction resulted in a sudden loss of temperature regulation and control panel responsiveness, causing approximately $87,000 in damage to the equipment and resulting in complete shutdown of the drying system for 18 hours. The oven, a Mocon DVS-3000 model purchased in 2015, experienced failure in its thermal control board and heating element array without warning indicators. The equipment was scheduled for preventive maintenance in December (2 weeks after the incident), suggesting maintenance was not performed at recommended intervals due to production scheduling pressures. Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), the CNC Operator assigned to monitor the drying operations during night shift, discovered the malfunction when alarm displays ceased functioning and he noticed the temperature readings were frozen at 78°C. No personnel were injured, but the incident disrupted production of composite materials for automotive customers, resulting in delayed shipments. Réjan Simard (EMP-00077), Mold Maintenance Technician, responded and safely isolated the equipment to prevent further damage. Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), Chemical Safety Officer, declared the incident and documented the failure analysis.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45 hours, Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was performing a mold changeover on Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building when she failed to properly engage the lockout/tagout (LOTO) mechanism before accessing the hydraulic pressure relief valve. As she reached toward the valve to inspect a suspected leak, residual pressure in the system was suddenly released, causing a pressurized stream of hot hydraulic fluid to contact her right forearm and hand. The fluid temperature exceeded 65°C. Petrov immediately withdrew her arm and alerted nearby colleague Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), who called for medical assistance. First aid was administered on-site with cold water irrigation. She was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval with second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of her forearm. The incident was attributed to incomplete LOTO procedures and failure to depressurize equipment before maintenance access. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur responded and documented the incident.

On December 3, 2024, Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility (UNIT-018) during the day shift at 10:30 hours. During his walkthrough, he discovered that multiple 5-gallon containers of polyurethane resin solvent were stored directly on floor-level shelving without secondary containment, and several containers showed visible corrosion on their lids indicating potential sealing degradation. Additionally, the facility's solvent vapor monitoring equipment (calibrated last in March 2024) was overdue for recalibration and the maintenance log was incomplete. Bélanger also noted that the emergency eyewash station near the mixing area had not been flushed in over 6 months according to inspection records. The chemical inventory management system showed discrepancies between recorded quantities and physical counts. These findings indicated a significant risk for chemical spill incidents, inhalation exposure to solvent vapors, and inadequate emergency response capability. No immediate incident occurred, but the hazard conditions warranted formal documentation and corrective action planning. This preventive declaration was documented in the TechnoPlast safety management system and escalated to management.

On December 8, 2024, at 23:15 hours during the night shift, Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was organizing finished goods inventory in Section B of the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) when she stepped on a small pool of water that had accumulated on the concrete floor near the perimeter wall. The water was from an undiagnosed roof leak that had persisted for several days. As her left foot slipped on the wet surface, Yilmaz lost her balance and fell backward, attempting to catch herself on nearby storage racks. Her right shoulder struck the edge of a metal shelving unit with significant force, and approximately 12 boxes of molded automotive components (approximately 25 kg total) dislodged from the third shelf and fell onto her right hip and thigh. Night Shift Supervisor Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) witnessed the incident and immediately called for medical assistance. Yilmaz was unable to stand and reported severe pain in her right hip and shoulder. Emergency responders transported her to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé where imaging confirmed a severe hip contusion with possible soft tissue damage requiring overnight observation. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was called in for incident investigation at 06:00 on December 9.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station when she noticed a potential hazard while organizing finished goods on wooden pallets. As she was manually sorting composite material components into shipping boxes, Jackson observed that one of the wooden pallets had begun to splinter along its top edge where previous product had been stacked.
