She immediately recognized the risk of splinters penetrating gloves and causing hand injuries, and she correctly ceased work and reported the hazard to her supervisor, Michael Chen (EMP-00004), who was present in the warehouse area. Chen verified the hazard and immediately removed the pallet from service, placing it in the maintenance area for repair. Jackson's proactive identification of this hazard and the correct reporting protocol prevented a potential splinter injury. No workers were injured during this incident. The near-miss was formally documented by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) following company near-miss reporting procedures.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (South Zone). Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was conducting routine cleaning of the industrial oven exhaust vents using approved compressed air procedures. At 11:47 PM, the fire alarm system activated, triggering the facility evacuation protocol and alerting emergency responders. Upon investigation by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen and Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid, it was determined that compressed air pressure from Gravel's cleaning work had dislodged accumulated resin particulates and composite fiber dust from the exhaust ductwork. This dust dispersal caused a minor static electricity discharge within the duct that activated the thermal smoke detection sensor. The alarm proved to be a false alarm with no actual fire, but the incident revealed a maintenance procedure gap. No injuries occurred. The building was evacuated safely, accounting for all 20 night shift personnel. Emergency responders cleared the facility within 15 minutes. Incident was logged as a fire alarm activation requiring investigation of root causes.

On December 18, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm was activated in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) was testing a repaired injection molding machine control panel after replacing faulty electrical components. During the testing phase at low power settings, an electrical short circuit occurred within the control panel's power distribution module due to improper wire insulation replacement during the repair. The short circuit generated a small electrical arc and localized heat that triggered the thermal sensor on the fire suppression system. The fire alarm activated automatically at 6:31 PM, initiating full facility evacuation protocol. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) and Production Supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) coordinated the evacuation, accounting for all personnel. Emergency response personnel arrived and confirmed no actual fire existed, determining that the alarm was triggered by residual heat and smoke from the electrical fault. The machine control panel sustained damage estimated at $12,000 and required replacement. No workers were injured, but the incident revealed inadequate quality control procedures in the electrical repair process.

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter on the day shift, was performing routine setup operations at Injection Molding Line A when he inadvertently touched a heated barrel section of the machine. The barrel temperature was approximately 280°C. Robert immediately withdrew his hand and reported the incident to his supervisor. He sustained a first-degree thermal burn on the palm and fingers of his right hand, covering approximately 8% of the affected area. The burn was immediately treated with cold water irrigation for 10 minutes at the first aid station, followed by application of sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. Robert remained at work but was monitored for the remainder of the shift. The incident occurred because the machine's thermal guard had been partially dislodged during a mold changeover earlier that morning, leaving an approximately 6-inch section of the barrel unprotected. Standard operating procedures require guards to be checked after every mold change, but the check was not documented on this occasion. A witness, Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), confirmed observing the guard issue but did not report it immediately.

On November 18, 2024 at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Mario Bélisl (EMP-00149), a Tool and Die Maker, was conducting routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop when he discovered that the emergency stop (E-stop) button was not functioning properly. While testing the button sequence, Mario noticed the machine continued running for approximately 8 seconds after pressing the E-stop button, rather than the immediate stop that should occur. He immediately shut down the machine using the main power disconnect and did not attempt to clear any debris or perform any work inside the machine. The machine contained active cutting tools rotating at 2,400 RPM at the time of discovery. Yves Thibault (EMP-00079), the Quality Supervisor who was performing a facility walkthrough, observed Mario's corrective action and immediately reported the incident to Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, who escalated it to the HSE department. Upon investigation, it was determined that the E-stop circuit had experienced a relay malfunction, preventing immediate power cutoff. This represents a serious potential hazard, as any worker attempt to clear a jam or adjust tooling would have been exposed to running cutting tools.

On November 21, 2024 at approximately 4:30 AM during the night shift, Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), a Mold Maintenance Technician, was transferring a 180-kilogram composite mold from a storage rack to a workbench using a manual hand truck in the Maintenance Workshop. The mold was positioned on the top shelf of the rack, approximately 1.6 meters high. As Réjean was carefully maneuvering the hand truck, the mold shifted slightly on the rack due to the rack's uneven loading pattern. The mold began to tip forward off the rack. Réjean immediately stepped backward and raised his arms defensively. The mold fell approximately 1.4 meters, landing on the concrete floor less than 30 centimeters from where Réjean stood. The mold struck the floor with significant force, creating a loud impact that echoed through the workshop. Although the mold did not contact Réjean, he experienced acute stress and elevated heart rate from the near-miss event. Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), a Facilities Maintenance Technician working nearby on HVAC maintenance, heard the impact and immediately came to assist. Upon inspection, the mold sustained significant surface damage and cracks, requiring extensive repair work. Investigation revealed the storage rack had poor weight distribution guidelines posted, and the mold had been stacked in violation of the facility's material storage procedures.

On March 15, 2024, at 10:30 AM during day shift, Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019), Shipping and Receiving Clerk at the Shipping and Receiving Dock, was conducting a pre-shift inspection of the loading area as part of TechnoPlast's preventive safety program. During routine observation of pallet storage in the warehouse section, she identified that three large pallets of finished medical device housings (approximately 800 lbs each) were stacked 6 feet high on shelving units without proper cross-bracing or load-rated signage. The shelving units, installed approximately 8 years ago, showed visible rust and slight bowing on the support beams. Fortin noted that the pallets were positioned within 3 feet of the main loading dock walkway where employees regularly pass during receiving operations. She immediately photographed the situation and reported the hazard to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen, who confirmed the risk of potential collapse. The hazard was escalated and the area was cordoned off pending corrective action. No injury occurred due to timely detection.

On March 22, 2024, at 2:15 PM during evening shift, Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was performing routine setup of an injection molding machine (a 150-ton Engel model) for production of automotive dashboard components. As part of the LOTO (lockout/tagout) procedure being supervised by Lockout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), Rahman was preparing to clean internal mold surfaces with compressed air after the machine had been de-energized and locked. However, a residual pressure pocket in the hydraulic accumulator suddenly released, causing the mold to shift approximately 2 inches. Rahman's right hand, positioned near the mold opening for cleaning access, was momentarily trapped in the gap but he quickly withdrew it before any crushing could occur. Laplante immediately assessed the situation and confirmed no injury had been sustained. The incident was attributed to incomplete accumulator pressure bleed-down following the LOTO sequence. This near-miss occurred during a critical safety procedure—if the mold had closed fully, severe crushing injuries would have resulted.

On March 28, 2024, at 11:45 PM during night shift, Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) was processing scrap composite material in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) as part of TechnoPlast's material recycling program. The regrind system malfunctioned when a metering valve in the colorant injection line failed to close properly. This resulted in an uncontrolled release of approximately 8 liters of concentrated liquid colorant (a solvent-based dye containing 40% acetone and 15% isopropanol) directly onto the floor and adjacent storage shelving. The spill spread across approximately 12 square meters of the work area. The colorant vapors rapidly accumulated in the confined space, reaching concentrations estimated at 800 ppm acetone (well above the OSHA PEL of 250 ppm). Comeau immediately evacuated the room and activated the facility alarm at 11:47 PM. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen responded and initiated containment procedures: deployed absorbent materials, activated emergency ventilation, and cordoned off the spill area. The affected solvent waste was containerized and segregated for hazardous waste disposal. Air monitoring was conducted 30 minutes post-containment, confirming vapor levels had reduced to safe levels.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Amina Mansour (EMP-00044), a Material Handler in the Warehouse and Shipping area, was manually transferring raw plastic pellets from a bulk storage hopper to smaller containers near the loading dock. While positioning a container beneath the hopper discharge chute, she noticed the hopper's gate valve was beginning to stick. Without notifying her supervisor or waiting for maintenance assistance, she attempted to dislodge the valve by striking it with a rubber mallet. This caused an unexpected surge of approximately 80 pounds of hot polyethylene pellets (approximately 160°C) to discharge suddenly from the chute. The pellets scattered across the floor and several struck Amina's left arm and shoulder area. She immediately stepped back and called for assistance. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) arrived within minutes and assessed that while her protective apron absorbed most of the impact, she had sustained minor surface contact burns on her left forearm. The incident was reported to Hana Al-Rashid, Occupational Health Nurse, who provided immediate first aid treatment including cooling the affected area with cold water and applying sterile gauze. No hospitalization was required, but the employee experienced localized redness and minor blistering consistent with a first-degree burn.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift operations, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician assigned to Line A in the Main Production Building North Zone, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #7. The machine had been in operation for a 12-hour production run and was scheduled for mold changeover. Pascal initiated the Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedure and secured the energy isolation points; however, due to inadequate communication between shifts, the incoming night shift supervisor (Lucie Fillion, EMP-00151) was not immediately aware that the machine was locked out. While Pascal was accessing the interior of the mold cavity to remove residual plastic material, Lucie attempted to restart the machine from the remote control panel to check if the LOTO was functioning properly. The machine's hydraulic press cycled partially, causing the upper mold to descend approximately 3 inches before hydraulic pressure sensors detected the anomaly and triggered an automatic shutoff. Pascal's left hand was between the molds at the time. The safety interlock system prevented full compression, and the mold halted before causing severe injury. Pascal immediately felt pressure on his hand and called out; Lucie ceased operations. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) arrived and verified proper LOTO procedures were in place. Upon inspection, Pascal sustained bruising and minor laceration to his left hand but no fractures. First aid was administered by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid. Investigation revealed that the evening-to-night shift handoff procedures did not include a formal LOTO status briefing, creating confusion about which machines were secured.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during day shift operations, Tran Le (EMP-00036), a Quality Control Lab Technician, was conducting routine material composition testing in the Quality Control Laboratory located in the Administrative Building. The lab was processing samples from a recent batch of medical-grade composite materials intended for ISO 13485-certified medical device housings. While transferring a sample container from the analytical balance to a staging rack, Tran inadvertently struck the container against the edge of an open filing cabinet drawer that another technician, Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180), had left partially open at approximately chest height. The collision dislodged the sample container, which fell onto the laboratory floor, scattering approximately 50 grams of fine glass fiber-reinforced resin powder across an approximate 6-foot radius. The powder created a small cloud that briefly dispersed through the immediate work area. Tran immediately stepped back, and Lidia quickly closed the drawer and retrieved a laboratory vacuum equipped with HEPA filtration to contain the spill. The lab ventilation system, operating at normal levels, assisted in dispersing any airborne particles within 3-4 minutes. No personnel reported respiratory symptoms or visible skin irritation. The sample was documented as contaminated and destroyed per waste management protocols. Investigation determined that the filing cabinet had no closure mechanism and was positioned in a high-traffic area of the lab workspace. The incident was reported to Deepa Gupta (EMP-00080), Process Quality Engineer, who documented it as a near-miss because the quantity of exposure was minimal and no injury occurred, although under different circumstances (larger quantity, longer exposure duration, or closer proximity to personnel with respiratory sensitivities) the outcome could have been more serious.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162) was working at Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building's North Zone. She was performing routine assembly operations on automotive components when her right hand became caught between a rotating shaft coupling and the frame guard during a machine cycle. The coupling had partially separated from its protective housing due to a loose fastener that had vibrated free over several shifts. Isabella's hand was compressed, resulting in a laceration to her palm and two fractured metacarpal bones. She immediately called for assistance, and Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) responded within seconds. Emergency services were contacted, and Isabella was transported to Laval General Hospital where she underwent imaging and received treatment. The injury resulted in a lost-time incident requiring her to take 6 weeks of medical leave for bone healing and rehabilitation. Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) secured the area and documented the equipment failure.

On March 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) was conducting routine inventory in the Warehouse and Shipping area when a storage rack containing raw plastic resin pellets began to shift. A forklift operated by Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) had been positioning pallets of finished goods nearby, and the vibration from the equipment destabilized the older rack system which had uneven weight distribution. Approximately 15 cardboard boxes (each weighing 25 kg) fell from the second shelf of the rack, striking a stack of finished composite material parts valued at approximately $34,000. The fallen boxes crushed several high-value automotive components that were scheduled for shipment to a major automotive supplier. The damaged goods required a complete write-off and created a 48-hour delay in order fulfillment. Raymond immediately ceased operations, and both employees surveyed the damage. Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) was notified and documented the property damage incident. No employees were physically injured, though Monique reported being shaken by the near-miss.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was working at Injection Molding Line B in the Production Operations area when he noticed the material hopper beginning to overflow with resin pellets. The hopper level sensor had malfunctioned, causing the automated feed system to continue dispensing material beyond capacity. Omar immediately stopped the feed system and alerted his supervisor. Upon inspection, approximately 150 kg of material had accumulated around the hopper base, creating a slip hazard on the production floor. The material was contained and cleaned up within 30 minutes. No injuries occurred, but the situation presented a significant risk of slipping, potential machine damage, and workflow interruption. The hopper sensor malfunction was traced to a loose electrical connection that had degraded over time due to vibration and thermal cycling.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room and identified a potential hazard that warranted preventive action. While reviewing inventory and storage procedures, he discovered that the secondary containment system beneath the epoxy resin storage tanks showed early signs of micro-cracks in the concrete floor, which had been exposed to minor chemical drips over the past several months. Although no spill had occurred and the containment remained functional, Simon recognized that continued degradation could compromise containment integrity during a major spill event. He also noted that three staff members had recently been rotated to the mixing room without completing the updated WHMIS chemical handling training that now included new epoxy formulations recently introduced to production. This preventive declaration was made to address these potential vulnerabilities before they could result in an actual incident.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, a fire incident occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area located outside the Chemical Storage Building. Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was transferring expired mold release agent containers into a designated waste bin when she inadvertently placed a partially full solvent container near a heat lamp that had been installed to prevent condensation buildup in the outdoor storage area. The solvent vapors from the open container ignited when they contacted the heat lamp element, creating a small but intense fire approximately 1 meter in diameter. The night shift supervisor immediately activated the alarm system and deployed a Class B dry chemical fire extinguisher to suppress the flames within 2 minutes. No personnel were injured, but the incident resulted in damage to three waste containers and heat discoloration of the adjacent storage shed wall. The fire was fully extinguished and the area was secured by emergency responders who arrived 8 minutes after the alarm. Root cause analysis revealed that the heat lamp had no protective cage or thermostat control, and there was inadequate separation between flammable waste storage and ignition sources.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was moving resin pellets from the Raw Materials Warehouse to the Composite Materials Processing Area using a manual pallet jack. As she was navigating through the narrow aisle between storage racks in UNIT-007, the pallet jack's wheel caught on a small piece of plastic debris on the floor. The jack tipped slightly, causing several bags of polypropylene resin to shift. Marwa quickly stabilized the load and prevented it from falling, but her right hand was momentarily caught between the pallet and a steel rack support. She experienced a brief pinching sensation but no visible injury. She immediately reported the incident to her supervisor, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), who was nearby. Emmanuel assessed her hand and found no cuts or bruising. Marwa was given ice and encouraged to monitor for swelling. The debris was immediately cleaned up, and the incident was logged as a near-miss with potential for serious pinch-point injury.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Production Operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) was monitoring Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging area (UNIT-004). While performing routine quality checks between cycles, she noticed the resin hopper's level indicator was not functioning properly. She attempted to manually check the resin level by leaning over the hopper edge to peer inside. As she did so, a residual vibration from the previous injection cycle caused a small amount of granulated plastic material to cascade down from the hopper lip, striking her left shoulder and upper arm. The material was room temperature but created a startling moment. Naomi immediately stepped back and assessed herself for injury. Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180), who was conducting evening quality rounds, witnessed the incident and called for immediate assistance. Naomi reported no pain or visible injury, but experienced minor emotional distress from the unexpected event. The incident was treated as a near-miss because the falling material posed a potential eye injury risk if Naomi's head position had been slightly different.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) was performing routine preventive maintenance on the ventilation system in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). While inspecting ductwork connections, he inadvertently made contact with a sharp metal burr on a poorly finished duct seam. The burr created a laceration approximately 1 inch long on his left index finger, causing bleeding. Daniel immediately recognized the injury, excused himself from the work area, and proceeded to the first-aid station in the Administrative Building. Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead, was notified and accompanied Daniel to ensure proper treatment. At the first-aid station, the wound was cleaned with soap and water, the bleeding was controlled with pressure, and the laceration was covered with an adhesive bandage and antibiotic ointment. Daniel was instructed to monitor the wound for signs of infection and to report back if any complications developed. The incident was classified as a first-aid injury because it required cleaning and dressing but no sutures or professional medical evaluation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter, was operating Injection Molding Line D in the South Zone when he noticed excessive heat emanating from the mold. While attempting to open the mold housing to inspect cooling water lines, he inadvertently touched the exposed mold surface with his left forearm, sustaining a thermal burn approximately 8 cm in diameter. The mold temperature was reading 185°C due to a partially clogged cooling water line. Fournier immediately removed his arm and ran cold water over the affected area for approximately 3 minutes. His supervisor, Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015), arrived within seconds and applied a sterile burn dressing from the first aid station. The employee reported mild to moderate pain and blistering. First aid treatment was administered on-site including topical antibiotic ointment and a non-adherent bandage. The employee remained on duty for the remainder of the shift with modified duties, avoiding further contact with hot surfaces. The cooling water line was inspected and cleared of debris the following morning.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 9:15 PM during evening shift, Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042), a Composite Materials Technician, was transferring a 50-liter drum of colorant masterbatch from the storage rack to the mixing station in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The employee was manually rolling the drum across the floor when the drum's internal pressure caused the lid to suddenly release. Approximately 15 liters of liquid colorant spilled onto the floor, splashing onto Ivanova's left leg and shoe. The employee immediately moved away from the spill and notified her supervisor, Patricia Martin (EMP-00035), who activated the emergency response protocol. While removing contaminated clothing in the safety shower area, Ivanova developed significant skin irritation and respiratory distress from colorant vapors. She was transported to the on-site medical clinic where she was treated for chemical burn injuries to her lower leg (second-degree equivalent, approximately 5% body surface area) and mild inhalation exposure. The employee was hospitalized for 2 days for wound management and observation, resulting in 3 consecutive lost shifts. Investigation revealed the drum had been overfilled during the previous day's refill procedure, and the ventilation system in the mixing room was operating at 60% capacity due to a clogged filter.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift, David O'Connor (EMP-00010), the Warehouse Supervisor, was observing packaging operations at the Packaging and Labeling Station when he noticed Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), an Inventory Control Specialist, attempting to reposition a forklift that had become wedged between two rows of stacked plastic component pallets in the warehouse prep area. The forklift's right tire had caught on an uneven floor transition, and Nicole was attempting to rock the vehicle free by repeatedly engaging forward and reverse gears without dismounting. O'Connor immediately approached and observed that Proulx was leaning out of the forklift seat without proper harness engagement, and her right arm was extended dangerously close to the gap between the forklift and the adjacent pallet stack. O'Connor shouted a warning and signaled Proulx to stop. Proulx immediately halted the maneuver. Upon inspection, O'Connor noted that the forklift seat belt had been deliberately routed behind the seat rather than across the operator, and the floor transition that caused the catch point had several raised edges creating a trip hazard. The warehouse maintenance log showed no recent repairs to that floor section. The near-miss was documented with photographs of the hazardous positioning and floor condition. No injuries occurred, but the potential for a crush injury from the forklift or pallet stack collapse was significant.

On January 15, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator, was working at Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) in the Warehouse and Shipping prep area. While applying labels to completed automotive trim parts, Amal accidentally spilled hot water from a nearby heating kettle onto their left forearm while reaching across the workstation. The water, maintained at approximately 85°C for label adhesive purposes, contacted bare skin for approximately 3 seconds before Amal removed their arm from the heat source. An immediate first-aid response was initiated by nearby coworker Patricia Martin (EMP-00035), Packaging Supervisor, who applied cold running water to the affected area for 10 minutes. The burn resulted in a first-degree thermal injury with minor redness and slight swelling but no blistering. The incident was documented and first aid was administered on-site. Amal returned to work after a 30-minute rest period. No lost time occurred. The kettle was noted to have inadequate insulation and was marked for maintenance review.

On February 3, 2025, at approximately 10:20 PM during the evening shift, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter, was preparing Injection Molding Line B for a production changeover at the Main Production Building North Zone (UNIT-002). As part of the setup procedure, Robert was manually guiding a new mold into the clamping unit when he noticed that the safety interlock system had not fully activated before the press started to close. The mold was approximately 15 centimeters from full closure when Robert detected the malfunction. He immediately activated the emergency stop button, halting the press with the mold partially inserted. The press did not make contact with Robert's hands, which were still positioned near the mold cavity opening. Investigation revealed that a proximity sensor had become misaligned due to vibration from the previous production run, causing the safety system to bypass proper lockout sequence. Had the emergency stop not been activated within 2 seconds, Robert's fingers would have been at direct risk of crushing injury. No physical contact occurred. The near-miss was immediately reported to Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) and documented by Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007).

On February 10, 2025, at approximately 1:15 AM during the night shift, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), a Regrind Operator, was operating the plastic recycling equipment in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) at Warehouse and Shipping Section C. While feeding scrap composite material into the hopper of the grinder, Mohamed reached into the feed area to dislodge a piece of fiber-reinforced plastic that had become jammed. As he withdrew his right hand, the composite material suddenly shifted and a sharp fiber bundle brushed against his hand, nearly catching his sleeve. Had his hand been positioned 2 centimeters lower, the rotating blade would have made direct contact with his fingers. Mohamed immediately stepped back and activated the emergency stop. Upon investigation, the hopper guard was found to be missing its bottom section, which should have prevented hand access to the blade area. The guard assembly had been removed during maintenance three days earlier and not reinstalled. The near-miss was reported by Mohamed to Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot and documented by Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107). No injury occurred, but the risk of severe laceration or amputation was significant.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Production Operator Zainab Khalil was performing routine material loading on Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area. While transferring polypropylene resin from a hopper cart to the machine's feed hopper, she noticed the hydraulic lift on the cart was partially stuck. As she manually adjusted the cart position to align it better with the injection molding machine's intake chute, the cart's locking mechanism suddenly released. The heavy cart lurched forward approximately 18 inches, and Zainab's left hand was caught between the cart frame and the machine's fixed support column. She immediately called out, and Assembly Operator Luis Fernandez, who was working nearby, quickly helped reposition the cart to relieve the pressure. Upon initial inspection, Zainab had redness and mild swelling on her left palm but no fractures or lacerations. She was able to move all fingers with full range of motion. The incident was immediately reported to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen. First aid was administered in the on-site medical station with ice application and anti-inflammatory cream. Zainab resumed normal duties after 30 minutes of observation.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift operations in the Shipping and Receiving Dock, Forklift Operator Tariq Aziz was moving pallets of finished goods to staging area B. As he maneuvered a fully loaded pallet (approximately 1,200 pounds of injection-molded medical components) near the loading dock edge, he observed that several air hoses and electrical cables from the dock's pneumatic systems were coiled loosely across the floor in the direct traffic path. Tariq carefully navigated around the hazard and successfully moved the pallet to its destination without incident. However, he immediately recognized that the cable arrangement presented a significant trip hazard for other dock workers and equipment operators. He reported the condition to Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin, who inspected the area and verified the hazard. Together, they secured the cables using cable management clips and routed them along the dock perimeter using wall-mounted conduits. No worker was injured, and no near-miss events occurred, but the proactive identification and correction of this hazard prevented a potential incident. The situation was documented as a near-miss and reported to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen as an example of effective hazard recognition by front-line workers.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift operations, Production Supervisor André Paradis was conducting equipment rounds in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment zone when he discovered a significant hydraulic oil leak from one of the three industrial ovens used for polymer curing cycles. The leak, estimated at approximately 3-4 gallons per hour, was pooling on the concrete floor beneath the oven's cooling water circulation system, creating both a slipping hazard and potential environmental contamination risk. The hydraulic fluid, a synthetic ISO VG 46 oil used in the oven's thermal regulation system, was beginning to migrate toward a floor drain connected to the facility's wastewater system. André immediately shut down the affected oven, cordoned off the leaking area with warning tape, and placed absorbent pads and a collection pan under the leak point to prevent further environmental release. He notified Safety Officer Anh Nguyen and Maintenance Engineer Sylvain Jodoin. The spill area was documented and photographed. A preliminary investigation indicated that a connection fitting on the cooling system had corroded and failed due to improper installation angle during the last maintenance cycle (8 months prior). Maintenance personnel determined the oven would require 48 hours of repairs. During this time, production was rerouted to the two functional ovens, causing a 12-hour production delay for one customer order. Environmental assessment confirmed that approximately 2.5 gallons had been released to the floor, and none had entered the wastewater system due to rapid containment efforts.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030), a Machine Setter, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #7 in Line B - Automotive (UNIT-002). The machine's hydraulic pressure relief valve had been showing intermittent pressure fluctuations throughout the morning. While Karim was adjusting the valve settings with the machine in standby mode, the valve suddenly released pressurized hydraulic fluid with extreme force, spraying scalding hot oil across his right arm and shoulder. The incident occurred at 14:47 hours. A nearby operator, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), immediately assisted Karim and alerted the Occupational Health Nurse. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided first aid treatment for thermal burns covering approximately 12% of Karim's right upper body. The machine was immediately shut down and isolated. Root cause investigation revealed that the pressure relief valve had experienced internal seal degradation due to lack of scheduled preventive maintenance, combined with contaminated hydraulic fluid that had not been replaced per manufacturer specifications in over 18 months.

On February 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), an experienced Crane Operator, was positioning a 2,500-pound pallet of raw polycarbonate resin above the storage racks in the Warehouse and Shipping area (UNIT-009). The pallet was being transferred from the receiving dock to designated storage in Section B. As Raymond lowered the load using the overhead crane, a critical component of the crane's hoist mechanism—the load limit switch—failed to engage as the pallet approached its maximum height. The pallet continued descending despite reaching its intended elevation, striking the corner edge of an adjacent storage structure. The impact caused the pallet to shift, and approximately 400 pounds of resin bags spilled onto the concrete floor below. The spilled material scattered across a 200-square-foot area. David O'Connor (EMP-00010), the Warehouse Supervisor, was present and immediately secured the area. The crane mechanism was locked down and taken out of service pending inspection. No personnel were in the fall zone, preventing serious injury. However, the equipment damage included a bent crane hoist cable and damage to the load limit switch assembly. The incident was attributed to inadequate preventive maintenance on the crane's safety systems and delayed replacement of a worn load limit switch that had been flagged in a previous inspection report three months prior.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a fire incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) within the Warehouse and Shipping building. The fire originated near the plastic regrind processing area where waste plastic scraps are collected, sorted, and prepared for reprocessing. A combination of factors created a perfect storm: plastic dust had accumulated on horizontal surfaces and equipment over a three-week period due to inadequate housekeeping during extended overtime operations, the ambient temperature in the area had risen to 28°C (82°F) due to failing HVAC maintenance, and a spark was generated when a metal containment bin was inadvertently moved across the concrete floor by a forklift operator, creating friction. The dust ignited, and the fire rapidly spread through accumulated material. Although no personnel were directly in the immediate area, the fire consumed approximately 4,000 pounds of accumulated plastic scrap material, damaged two regrind processing machines (estimated loss $180,000), destroyed one containment bin system, and caused significant smoke damage to adjacent areas. The night shift supervisor on duty, operating under skeleton crew conditions, did not have adequate communication tools to rapidly coordinate evacuation and emergency response. The fire was extinguished by the on-site sprinkler system and contained by the facility's fire suppression systems within 22 minutes. Emergency services responded at 6:47 AM. The incident revealed multiple system failures: inadequate dust control procedures, deferred HVAC maintenance, insufficient staffing for safety oversight during high-production periods, and gaps in fire hazard awareness training.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was organizing storage racks in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) when she noticed significant deterioration of the upper shelf support brackets. The mezzanine-level storage contained approximately 150 kg of assorted mechanical components and spare parts distributed across three shelves. Upon closer inspection, Marwa identified visible rust, corrosion, and stress fractures in the welds connecting the shelf brackets to the vertical support posts. The brackets showed clear signs of metal fatigue from years of supporting heavy loads. Recognizing the critical safety risk, Marwa immediately ceased all work in that area, cordoned off the section with warning tape, and notified her supervisor. The storage rack remained stable at the time of inspection, but the structural compromise presented a clear and imminent hazard of potential load collapse. Marwa's proactive identification prevented what could have resulted in serious injury from falling materials. The incident was documented as a near-miss and reported through the facility's preventive safety system.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Céline Morin (EMP-00153) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building North Zone (UNIT-002). While cleaning the injection nozzle area with a soft cloth, Céline failed to engage the equipment lockout-tagout (LOTO) procedure as required by company protocol. A coworker, Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122), inadvertently initiated a test cycle on the machine, unaware that Céline was working in the danger zone. The molding ram activated suddenly, catching Céline's right hand between the mold cavity and the moving platen. The compression resulted in a fracture of the third metacarpal bone and crushing injuries to adjacent soft tissue. Omar immediately hit the emergency stop button, and first responders arrived within 4 minutes. Céline was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where X-rays confirmed a complete fracture requiring surgical intervention. The incident was fully reported to CNESST within 24 hours, classified as a serious injury requiring hospitalization and medical treatment beyond first aid.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine material loading when he noticed the hopper feed system was moving erratically. He immediately recognized this as abnormal behavior and stopped the machine before proceeding further. Upon inspection, a section of the flexible feed tube had partially separated from its coupling, which could have caused material blockage or equipment damage if operation had continued. The operator correctly identified the risk and did not attempt repairs himself. He reported the issue to his supervisor, Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), who documented the near-miss and contacted maintenance. The incident was prevented due to the operator's attentiveness and adherence to safety protocols. No equipment damage or injuries occurred. The maintenance team found that vibration from the adjacent Line C had loosened the coupling fasteners over time due to lack of periodic inspection.

On November 16, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, an electrical surge caused by a utility grid fluctuation damaged critical equipment in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), the Regrind Operator, was actively monitoring the grinding and compounding operations when multiple electrical protection devices activated simultaneously. The surge damaged the power supply unit of the primary regrind extruder and corrupted the programmable logic controller (PLC) settings, requiring complete replacement of both components. Additionally, approximately 15 kg of partially processed regrind material in the extruder's barrel hardened and required manual removal and disposal, representing lost material value of approximately $340. Three secondary electrical outlets in the chemical storage area also sustained damage. The facility's uninterruptible power supply (UPS) backup system, which was overdue for maintenance, failed to engage, allowing the full surge to propagate through equipment. Investigation revealed the facility's surge protection surge arrestors had not been inspected since 2022.

On November 18, 2024 at 10:32, a fire alarm was activated in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit when an industrial oven's temperature sensor malfunctioned, causing the internal thermostat to fail. The oven temperature climbed uncontrolled to approximately 310°C (normal operating range: 220-240°C), triggering the thermal detection system in the oven's ventilation hood. The heat and smoke triggered both the local smoke detector and the central fire alarm system throughout the facility. Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), the Production Operator responsible for monitoring post-processing, was the first to notice the alarm audible alert and initiated immediate facility evacuation procedures. The on-site HSE coordinator, Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), coordinated with the Laval Fire Department who arrived within 8 minutes. No flames or fire were detected; however, the oven's control panel sustained electrical damage from the thermal event, and the heating elements required replacement. The local fire department confirmed the thermal detection system functioned properly and contained the hazard. Production in the unit was halted for 6 hours pending equipment inspection and clearance. Root cause analysis revealed the temperature sensor had exceeded its calibration cycle and was last serviced 18 months prior.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room. While attempting to clear a material jam near the injection port, Naomi noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge reading was abnormally high at 3,200 PSI, well above the normal operating range of 2,000-2,400 PSI. Before she could activate the emergency pressure relief valve, a small hydraulic line coupling began leaking pressurized fluid. Naomi immediately stepped back and activated the machine's emergency stop button. The pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across the work area but did not make contact with her skin due to her positioning. Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) from the evening shift, who was present for cross-training, witnessed the event and immediately assisted in isolating the equipment. No injuries occurred, but the near-miss highlighted a critical gap in pressure monitoring procedures. The incident was immediately reported to Production Supervisor Michael Chen, who secured the equipment and initiated a pressure system inspection.

On April 8, 2024, at 9:47 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) at the warehouse and shipping prep area. The alarm was activated by automated smoke detection sensors in the overhead ventilation system. Upon investigation, Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) and shift supervisor discovered that a defective heat shrink tunnel used for sealing plastic packaging around finished medical device components had overheated and begun smoking. The equipment's thermostat had malfunctioned, causing internal temperatures to exceed 450°F, well beyond the design limit of 320°F. The shrink film on several pallets of finished goods had begun to char, producing acrid smoke that was detected by the sensors. Sanaa immediately activated the facility-wide evacuation alarm and coordinated with the local fire department. The Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes, inspected the equipment, and confirmed there was no active fire—only smoke from overheated equipment. The building was cleared of all 58 occupants present (mix of evening and night shift workers). All personnel were accounted for and evacuated to the assembly point in the north parking lot within 12 minutes. No injuries occurred. The heat shrink tunnel was immediately powered down and quarantined with yellow safety tape.

On May 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was performing maintenance in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) on the maintenance workshop storage mezzanine. René was replacing worn bearings on a CNC milling machine spindle assembly that had been removed from service two days prior. While using an adjustable wrench to remove a stubborn fastener, the wrench slipped off the bolt head and struck his left hand against the sharp edge of the spindle housing, causing a deep laceration across the palm and base of his middle finger. Blood loss was immediate and significant. Maintenance Technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169), who was working in the adjacent area, heard René's exclamation and immediately came to assist. Fernand applied direct pressure with clean shop towels and called EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) at 6:35 AM, who initiated first aid protocols and contacted the emergency medical services. René was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital in Montreal by ambulance at 6:52 AM with the laceration still bleeding despite tourniquet application. At the hospital, a physician determined that the laceration required 23 stitches and that partial nerve damage had occurred in the ring finger, resulting in temporary loss of sensation. René was admitted for overnight observation and released the following day with restrictions on hand use for six weeks. This incident resulted in a lost-time injury, with René unable to return to work-related duties due to medical restrictions on grip strength and fine motor control.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:35 during day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a significant burn injury while troubleshooting a stuck injection nozzle in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment zone (UNIT-017). Zaidi was attempting to manually clear a blockage of solidified polycarbonate resin from the heating element when the nozzle temperature alarm malfunctioned, indicating safe operating conditions at 85°C when the actual surface temperature was 310°C. Upon contact with the nozzle, Zaidi's right palm and forearm sustained second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 40 square centimeters. Although Zaidi was wearing standard work gloves rated only for light heat exposure, the intensity of the contact caused penetration. Luc Girard (EMP-00039), Maintenance Technician, immediately applied cold running water for 20 minutes and activated emergency response protocols. Zaidi was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval for treatment. The incident was witnessed by Jade Wong (EMP-00140), Process Technician, who was monitoring adjacent Line C. Root cause analysis identified that the temperature sensor calibration had drifted 12% below actual readings due to lack of preventive maintenance on sensing equipment. The operator had not received annual retraining on proper nozzle clearing procedures.

On October 8, 2024 at 09:20 during day shift, Tran Le (EMP-00036), Quality Control Lab Technician, experienced a minor eye injury in the Quality Control and Assurance laboratory (UNIT-020) while performing tensile strength testing on glass-fiber reinforced nylon samples. While using an automated test machine to measure composite material strength, a hairline crack in a nylon specimen propagated suddenly under load, causing the sample to fragment. A small splinter approximately 3mm in length traveled at high velocity and struck Le directly in the right eye, causing immediate discomfort and mild corneal abrasion. Although Le was wearing standard safety glasses (Z87+ rated for general industrial use), the fragment penetrated between the lens frame and orbital area. Le immediately flushed the eye with saline solution from the first aid kit and reported to Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), Occupational Health Nurse, at 09:35. Al-Rashid examined the eye using a slit lamp, confirmed superficial corneal abrasion, and applied lubricating eye drops and a protective eye patch. Le was advised to seek ophthalmology evaluation as a precaution. The incident was classified as a first aid case requiring only workplace medical attention without hospitalization. Root causes included: inadequate sample preparation procedures that failed to detect pre-existing microfractures, lack of containment shielding around the test apparatus, and safety glasses with incomplete orbital protection.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109) was performing routine mold cleaning on Injection Molding Line B when he noticed the machine's hydraulic pressure gauge reading unusually high at 280 bar (normal operating range: 210-240 bar). Before he could alert his supervisor, a small hairline fracture in a hydraulic hose connection began spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid. Gendron immediately stepped back and activated the emergency stop button. The spray lasted approximately 3 seconds before the system depressurized. A small amount of hydraulic fluid contacted his left forearm, but his long-sleeve work shirt and quick reflexes prevented significant skin exposure. Coworker Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) witnessed the incident and immediately notified supervisor Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191). The area was cordoned off within 2 minutes. Post-incident inspection revealed the hose had a manufacturing defect dating back 18 months. The situation was identified as a near-miss because the employee's positioning and rapid reaction prevented a serious hydraulic fluid injection injury.

On March 22, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during the evening shift, a routine resin mixing operation in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility resulted in an environmental incident. Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was preparing a batch of polyethylene colorant resin when he inadvertently mixed acetone solvent with an incompatible epoxy-based mold release agent. The exothermic reaction caused the container to rupture, releasing approximately 18 liters of volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors and liquid contents. The spill extended across approximately 12 square meters of the mixing room floor and partially migrated toward the facility's floor drain system. Omar immediately evacuated the area and triggered the facility alarm. Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) arrived within 3 minutes and initiated emergency containment protocols. The facility's secondary containment trays captured approximately 60% of the liquid before any entered the municipal drainage system. Air quality monitoring detected VOC concentrations reaching 185 ppm in the immediate area (OSHA PEL: 200 ppm). The spill was successfully contained within 45 minutes. Water and soil testing conducted the next day revealed no environmental contamination beyond the contained area, but the incident required notification to CNESST and a municipal environmental assessment.

On March 28, 2025, at approximately 11:20 PM during night shift operations, Julien Racine (EMP-00177), Shipping Clerk in the Finished Goods Warehouse, was organizing stacked pallets of injection-molded medical components when an improperly secured uppermost pallet (approximately 800 kg gross weight including product) shifted due to minor vibration from a forklift operation in an adjacent section. The pallet tilted and fell approximately 1.8 meters, striking a structural steel support column with significant force. The impact caused the pallet frame to fracture and approximately 320 units of high-value medical-grade polycarbonate housings to scatter across the warehouse floor. Approximately 12 units sustained irreparable damage (cracked or shattered), 180 units had cosmetic damage requiring rework, and 128 units remained undamaged. The fallen pallet also struck and damaged a nearby shelving unit, creating a 2.3-meter section of twisted metal framework. Estimated total property damage: $47,800 (product loss $38,200 plus equipment damage $9,600). Material Handler Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) witnessed the incident and immediately reported it. No personnel were injured due to the work area being clear of active operations at that moment. The incident was caused by improper pallet stacking height (exceeding warehouse guidelines of 1.4 meters to prevent center-of-gravity issues) combined with inadequate load securing straps.

On April 22, 2024 at 08:15 during the day shift, the overhead crane system in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop experienced a mechanical failure while Armand Lévesque, a Mold Repair Technician, was preparing to lift a 250-pound composite mold assembly for delivery to Injection Molding Line C. As the hoist began to raise the load, the load cell sensor malfunctioned and reported incorrect weight readings to the control system. The cable tension monitoring system failed to detect an overload condition, and the primary lifting cable began to slip on the drum. Approximately 15 feet into the lift, the cable detached from the drum under load, causing the mold assembly to swing violently and strike the workbench where François-Xavier Mailhot, the Maintenance Supervisor, was standing 8 feet away. The mold narrowly missed striking Mailhot, but debris and metal fragments were ejected, striking his left arm and shoulder. The crane came to an emergency stop due to the load release mechanism activating. Mailhot sustained lacerations and contusions requiring 5 stitches. The mold assembly struck the concrete floor with a loud impact but remained largely intact. The overhead crane was immediately taken out of service. Investigation revealed the load cell had not been recalibrated since the last annual inspection 18 months prior, exceeding the manufacturer's recommended 12-month calibration interval.

On May 8, 2024 at 22:30 during the evening shift, Fernand Comeau, a Regrind Operator, was operating the material recycling equipment in the Regrind and Recycling Department when he experienced severe inhalation exposure to plastic fumes and solvent vapors. The ventilation system in the recycling area had partially failed due to a clogged intake filter that accumulated plastic dust over approximately three weeks without proper maintenance inspection. As Fernand fed shredded composite reject material into the compounding hopper, volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from the heated material and residual solvent vapors accumulated in the enclosed workspace. He noticed a strong chemical smell around 22:20 but continued working, assuming normal operations. By 22:35, Fernand began experiencing dizziness, difficulty breathing, and a burning sensation in his throat and eyes. He called for Normand Bergeron, the Regrind Supervisor, who immediately evacuated him from the area and moved him to fresh air. Anh Nguyen, the Safety Officer, was called to the scene. Fernand was transported to the hospital at 23:15 where he was treated for acute chemical inhalation with respiratory irritation. Blood oxygen levels were initially low at 92%. He was monitored overnight and discharged the following morning with instructions for follow-up care. The ventilation system was immediately shut down and a qualified HVAC technician was called for emergency repairs.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a significant dust accumulation fire hazard was discovered in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Materials handler Salma Haddad was performing routine cleaning when she noticed a thick layer of composite fiber dust (approximately 2-3 inches) accumulated on overhead pipes, equipment ledges, and behind the material dryers. The dust had built up over several weeks due to inadequate housekeeping protocols and insufficient local exhaust ventilation. Production operator Laila Hamdan, who works in the same area, confirmed the dust had been accumulating for at least three weeks. When Haddad attempted to vacuum the dust manually using a standard household vacuum, facility technician Georges Plante intervened and immediately shut down the operation, recognizing the fire hazard. The composite fiber dust is highly flammable and can create explosive atmospheres. Plante evacuated the area and notified the HSE department. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid responded and documented the hazard. No ignition source was present, and no injuries occurred, but the potential for a catastrophic fire was significant given the proximity of hot equipment surfaces and potential electrical ignition sources.

On November 17, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift, machine operator Emmanuel Kouassi sustained a moderate laceration to his right palm while performing routine mold release agent cleaning at an injection molding machine station in the Main Production Building. Kouassi was applying a solvent-based mold release cleaner to remove residual plastic from a mold using a standard cloth when the cloth caught on a sharp burr protruding from the mold edge. The burr, approximately 0.5 inches in length, had developed due to normal wear and inadequate mold maintenance. The laceration measured approximately 2 inches long and penetrated approximately 1/8 inch into the dermis layer, causing moderate bleeding. Kouassi immediately applied direct pressure with gauze and reported to the break room where he self-administered first aid using the facility's first aid kit. Machine setter Svetlana Petrov, working at an adjacent station, witnessed the incident and helped bandage the wound. After 20 minutes of direct pressure, bleeding slowed to an ooze. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson was notified and arrived within 10 minutes. Thompson assessed the wound and determined that while significant, it did not require stitches or hospitalization. The wound was cleaned with antiseptic, covered with antibiotic ointment, and bandaged with a sterile dressing. Kouassi was cleared to continue working with appropriate bandaging and PPE.

On November 19, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift operations, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Warehouse lead Michel Laflamme was transferring approximately 50 liters of isopropanol solvent from a 200-liter bulk container to multiple 5-liter portable containers for distribution to production areas when the transfer hose connection failed at the coupling point. The failure was caused by corrosion of the aluminum coupling, which had not been inspected or replaced during the facility's last maintenance cycle (9 months prior). Approximately 15-20 liters of isopropanol spilled onto the concrete floor before Laflamme was able to close the bulk container valve, requiring approximately 2 minutes. The spill spread across approximately 200 square feet of floor space and began evaporating rapidly, creating a strong solvent vapor plume. Laflamme immediately vacated the area and activated the chemical spill alarm at 1:32 AM. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance responded within 3 minutes and initiated spill containment procedures. Secondary containment barriers were deployed, and the area was evacuated to prevent inhalation exposure. Respiratory equipment was made available to responders. The spill was successfully contained and absorbed using absorbent materials over a 45-minute period. Air quality monitoring indicated vapor concentrations peaked at 380 ppm isopropanol (OSHA TWA limit is 400 ppm), requiring temporary evacuation of adjacent areas until ventilation could restore safe conditions.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in the Injection Molding Line D facility. Machine operator Bertrand Jalbert was performing routine setup adjustments on Molding Machine #7 when the hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned. The sudden pressurization caused the machine's hopper assembly to rupture violently, ejecting approximately 450 kilograms of molten polycarbonate resin across a 3-meter radius. The material spilled onto the machine platform, adjacent work surfaces, and the concrete floor, solidifying into hardened chunks within minutes. The hopper's metal cover plate was ejected and struck the edge of the material handling conveyor system, causing a 12-centimeter dent and minor mechanical misalignment. Material Handler Mariam Osman, who was nearby staging raw materials, witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop. No personnel were injured due to their positioning, but approximately €8,400 worth of finished parts in the adjacent curing station were contaminated with airborne resin particles and rendered unusable. The facility's maintenance team spent 6 hours clearing debris and assessing equipment damage before Line D could resume operations.

On March 18, 2024 at 10:45 AM during the day shift, Quality Control Technician Léa Parent experienced a chemical splash incident in the Materials Management and Warehousing section while transferring acetone-based solvent from a 20-liter container to smaller laboratory bottles. The container's lid was improperly secured from the previous shift, and as Léa tilted it to pour, approximately 150 milliliters of acetone solvent splashed upward, striking her left eye and the upper left cheek area. She immediately rinsed her eye at the nearest eyewash station for 3 minutes following company protocol. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid responded within 2 minutes and conducted a secondary rinse for an additional 5 minutes, observing mild conjunctival redness and temporary vision blurriness. The employee was transported to the on-site first aid clinic where she received topical antibiotic ointment and was advised to monitor for delayed irritation. She remained on modified duty (computer-based work only) for 24 hours as a precautionary measure. No hospitalization was required, but the incident was classified as a recordable first-aid injury under CNESST guidelines.

On March 22, 2024 at 11:30 PM during the night shift, Instrumentation Technician Vincent Létourneau discovered a significant environmental incident in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop during routine equipment inspection. An automated coolant recirculation line serving the CNC milling machines had fractured at a compression fitting, allowing approximately 85 liters of oil-based machining coolant to accumulate on the workshop floor over an estimated 3-hour period. The coolant had seeped beneath secondary containment barriers and migrated toward the facility's storm drain system via floor cracks. Vincent immediately shut off the circulation pump, isolated the damaged line with LOTO procedures, and notified the HSE department at 11:47 PM. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois arrived within 20 minutes and activated emergency containment protocols. Absorbent booms were positioned to block the drain entry, and approximately 120 kilograms of oil-absorbent granules were applied to the affected areas. The facility's environmental contractor was called for professional remediation. Preliminary soil testing was ordered for the drain system. The incident triggered notification to CNESST and local environmental authorities per Quebec regulations, with estimated cleanup costs exceeding €18,000.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a minor chemical burn to her left forearm while transferring mold release agent from a storage container to the application spray system. The incident occurred in the Main Production Building when the container's cap was not fully tightened during transfer. As Claudine positioned the container over the spray system nozzle, approximately 50 mL of the mold release agent splashed onto her skin. She immediately rinsed the affected area with water from the emergency eyewash station located 10 meters away and reported the incident to her supervisor, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165). First aid was administered on-site: the burn area was cleaned and treated with antibiotic ointment, and a sterile gauze bandage was applied. The employee remained on duty with no lost work time. The incident was witnessed by two other operators working nearby on Line C. Root cause analysis identified inadequate handling procedures and insufficient training on proper container closure protocols.

On March 22, 2024 at 02:30 during the night shift, a critical equipment failure occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012). The CNC milling machine used for precision mold manufacturing experienced a catastrophic spindle bearing failure while Richard Beaulieu (EMP-00043), the Tool Room Supervisor, was preparing a complex medical device mold cavity. The spindle bearing, which had been in operation for 18 months without scheduled maintenance, suddenly seized under load. The sudden stoppage caused a cutting tool to jam against the workpiece, resulting in tool breakage and damage to the spindle assembly's internal components. The damaged spindle required immediate removal from the machine. Vibration sensors that should have triggered automatic shutdown failed to activate due to disconnected wiring, likely dating from a previous repair. The incident rendered the primary CNC mill inoperable, disrupting the scheduled production of critical medical device components. Secondary damage included a precision cutting tool worth $3,200 and partial damage to the mold workpiece (approximately $7,500 in scrap material). Maintenance technician Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075) was on-site and immediately secured the machine and initiated failure documentation.

On March 29, 2024 at 11:15 during the evening shift, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D in the Consumer Packaging section, sustained a significant thermal burn to his right hand and forearm when he attempted to clear a material jam in the injection molding machine's hopper assembly without proper lockout/tagout procedures. The machine, a 250-ton Engel injection molder, had been experiencing intermittent material feed issues that morning. At 11:15, Bruno manually reached into the heated hopper (operating temperature 280°C) to dislodge what he believed was a blocked resin pellet, not realizing the hopper heater element remained active. His right hand came into direct contact with the heating element, causing thermal burns covering approximately 15% of his right hand and extending up his forearm. Bruno immediately withdrew his hand and alerted his supervisor Omar Said (EMP-00122). Emergency response was activated: the area was secured, first aid was administered with ice water irrigation, and emergency medical services were called at 11:22. Bruno was transported to Hôpital-Sacré-Cœur at 11:35 and admitted for treatment of second-degree thermal burns requiring hospitalization and skin grafting. The incident was witnessed by two assembly line operators working at adjacent stations. Root causes included failure to follow LOTO procedures, lack of hazard awareness regarding hopper temperature, and absence of automatic thermal cutoff safeguards.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a significant laceration to his left hand while attempting to clear a material jam in the injection molding machine. The employee did not properly follow lockout/tagout procedures before reaching into the mold cavity. When a coworker, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), restarted the machine without realizing Stéphane was still working on it, the mold closed unexpectedly, crushing his hand between the mold plates. The employee sustained deep lacerations requiring 18 stitches and underwent X-rays to rule out fractures. Emergency response was coordinated by Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), who arrived within 5 minutes. The incident resulted in 6 days of lost work time during recovery. Root causes identified include inadequate LOTO procedure enforcement, insufficient communication between operators, and operator fatigue at end of shift.

On April 8, 2024 at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, a near-miss incident was identified in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B) when Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), a Material Handler, narrowly avoided being struck by falling plastic component containers from a storage rack. The employee was walking through an aisle between two 16-foot-high storage racks when he heard a cracking sound. He immediately moved to the side just as approximately 15 boxes of finished automotive dashboard components (total weight ~280 kg) cascaded from the upper shelf level of the adjacent rack. The boxes landed where the employee had been standing seconds earlier. Investigation revealed that the upper shelf's safety restraint cable had corroded and partially failed due to moisture accumulation in the warehouse environment. David O'Connor (EMP-00010), the Warehouse Supervisor, was notified immediately and secured the area. Nina Santos (EMP-00084), the Industrial Hygienist, conducted a detailed investigation. No injuries occurred, but the potential severity was extremely high given the fall distance and container mass.

On May 3, 2024 at 9:30 AM during the day shift, André Bellavance (EMP-00157), the Confined Space Entry Supervisor, conducted a routine safety inspection and identified a potential hazard in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). During equipment maintenance planning discussions with Roland Dostie (EMP-00199), the Maintenance Planner, André noticed that the recently installed large resin mixing tank had an inadequate warning label regarding the "Fire from Flammable Solvents" risk. The tank was positioned near a heat-generating solvent mixing station, and fire extinguishers rated for flammable liquid fires were not properly positioned or clearly marked in the immediate vicinity. Additionally, André identified that three of the five emergency exits from the chemical storage building had cardboard boxes stored in front of them, partially blocking egress pathways. These issues were classified as preventive declarations to address hazards before an incident could occur. The supervisor immediately escalated findings to Nina Santos (EMP-00084) for formal investigation and documentation. No incident had occurred, but the preventive measures were deemed critical for regulatory compliance and worker safety.

On February 14, 2025, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, production operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) was removing finished parts from an injection molding machine at Line C in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). While reaching into the mold cavity to extract a polycarbonate automotive dashboard component, her left hand made contact with a residual hot mold surface that had not cooled sufficiently between cycles. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C, higher than the standard operating range of 60-75°C due to a thermostat calibration drift that had not been detected during the morning equipment check. Naomi sustained a second-degree thermal burn across the palm and three fingers. She immediately ran her hand under cold water at the nearby safety station and alerted her supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004). First aid was administered on-site, and after assessment, Naomi was sent to the local clinic for wound care and dressing. She returned to work the same day with modified duties and protective bandaging. The incident was reported by Training Coordinator Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) who arrived at the scene 15 minutes after the event.

On February 20, 2025, at approximately 8:15 PM during the evening shift, material handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was retrieving raw plastic resin pallets from high-storage racks in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). He was using a reach truck to access pallets stored at approximately 4.5 meters height. While maneuvering the truck to position himself beneath a pallet of polypropylene resin, the overhead pallet load shifted unexpectedly. The securing straps, which had degraded due to exposure to solvent vapors in the warehouse environment, failed suddenly. A 380-kilogram pallet of resin fell from the rack, striking Kwesi on his right shoulder and upper back. He was thrown to the ground by the impact and lost consciousness briefly. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) was nearby and immediately called emergency services. Kwesi was transported to the hospital with a fractured right clavicle, severe contusion to the right shoulder, and possible spinal trauma. He remained hospitalized for 3 days and required 12 weeks of restricted duty upon return. The incident was formally reported by Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), who arrived at the scene within minutes of the emergency call.

On February 25, 2025, at approximately 2:30 AM during the night shift, chemical mixing operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was preparing a batch of colorant masterbatch in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). She was transferring acetone-based cleaning solvent from a 25-liter drum into smaller containers for use in the mold release process. While pouring, the container she was filling tipped over due to inadequate stabilization on the uneven floor surface, spilling approximately 8 liters of acetone across the work surface and her left hand and forearm. The solvent caused immediate chemical burns to her skin as well as inhalation exposure to vapors. Elena immediately moved to the safety shower station and rinsed the affected area thoroughly for 15 minutes. She also experienced dizziness and nausea from vapor exposure. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was performing preventive maintenance nearby and responded quickly. Emergency medical services were called, and Elena was transported to the hospital for evaluation of both chemical burns (first and second-degree across 12% of her left forearm and hand) and inhalation exposure. She was admitted overnight for observation and released the next morning. Due to the severity of the burns and medical restrictions on water immersion for her work duties, Elena was unable to return to work for 6 weeks, requiring modified duties in administrative roles upon gradual return. The incident was formally documented by Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168).

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a significant acetone spill occurred in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Stéphane Moreau, Mold Technician, was transferring acetone from a 20-liter drum to smaller containers for cleaning mold components when the transfer pump malfunctioned.
