The pump continued dispensing acetone after the valve was closed, causing approximately 8 liters to overflow onto the concrete floor and into an open drain. The spill created a hazardous vapor condition in the confined tool room space, with acetone fumes spreading rapidly. Gaétan Laplante, the LOTO Coordinator, discovered the situation when entering the area and immediately activated the emergency ventilation system and evacuated personnel. The spill was contained using absorbent materials, and the area was cordoned off for 4 hours until vapors dissipated. No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident exposed inadequate maintenance procedures for the transfer equipment and insufficient emergency response protocols for chemical spills in confined spaces.

On December 3, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a hydraulic oil leak was discovered in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). Mariam Osman, Material Handler, noticed an accumulation of oily liquid on the concrete floor near the material compactor equipment and immediately reported it to Carlos Rodriguez, Maintenance Manager. Investigation revealed that a hydraulic hose connector on the compactor had partially disconnected, allowing approximately 15 liters of hydraulic oil to seep onto the floor and into adjacent floor drains over an estimated 2-3 hour period. The spill area created slippery conditions and posed a contamination risk to the facility's waste stream. Nina Santos, Industrial Hygienist, was called to assess environmental exposure and oversee cleanup using oil absorbent materials and temporary secondary containment. The hydraulic fluid was properly disposed of according to regulations. The incident revealed inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling and lack of regular hose integrity inspections.

On January 8, 2025, at 6:20 AM during the night shift, an environmental incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) when a storage rack containing polycarbonate resin bags partially collapsed. Omar Said, Production Operator (assigned to night inventory duties), was walking past the rack when three bags of resin fell to the floor, rupturing upon impact and releasing fine polycarbonate powder into the air. The powder created visible dust clouds within the warehouse, contaminating approximately 30 square meters of floor space and adjacent finished goods. Safety Representative Serge Lafleur, who was conducting a night shift safety check, witnessed the incident and immediately evacuated the area and activated HEPA filtration equipment. Medical screening was performed on Omar to check for inhalation exposure. Investigation determined that the rack had been overloaded beyond rated capacity (estimated 40% over maximum load), and several support bolts were corroded and missing. The incident exposed inadequate inventory management procedures, lack of load-bearing inspections, and insufficient rack maintenance.

On November 18, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, a fire alarm was activated in the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) located in the Warehouse and Shipping Prep Area. Production operator Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198) had been restocking finished composite parts into cardboard boxes when she noticed smoke emanating from an overheated heat shrink packaging machine. The machine's thermostat had malfunctioned, causing internal temperature to exceed safe operating limits. Hamdan immediately pressed the emergency stop button and evacuated the area, triggering the automatic fire alarm system. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) arrived on scene within 2 minutes and assessed the situation. The machine had not yet produced visible flames, but the plastic film media inside had begun to smolder and emit acrid smoke. Paquette activated the CO2 fire suppression system dedicated to this equipment zone and shut down the machine's power supply. The local fire department (Laval Fire Services) arrived 8 minutes after alarm activation and confirmed the hazard was contained with no structural fire damage. The equipment was locked out and quarantined pending maintenance investigation. Quality Auditor Indira Singh (EMP-00104) provided witness testimony that the machine had shown erratic temperature readings for approximately 3 hours prior to the alarm. Root cause analysis determined the temperature sensor had failed, resulting in the control system inability to properly regulate heating element output.

On November 20, 2024, at 06:15 during the night shift, regrind technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) was operating the material drying equipment in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) when he sustained a severe laceration to his right hand. Ramirez was manually clearing a material jam from the screw feeder mechanism when the equipment unexpectedly cycled due to a faulty interlock switch that was supposed to prevent operation during maintenance access. The rotating screw pulled his gloved hand into the mechanism, causing a laceration approximately 8 centimeters long across the dorsal surface of his right hand between the thumb and index finger. Co-worker Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), also present during night shift operations, witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button, stopping the equipment within 2 seconds. Mensah applied direct pressure with clean gauze pads and elevated Ramirez's hand while calling for emergency medical services. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), who was conducting a facility walk-through, arrived within 3 minutes and provided additional first aid support. Ramirez was transported by ambulance to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur where the laceration required 14 sutures. Investigation revealed that the interlock switch had been disabled approximately 4 months prior during a maintenance procedure and was never re-enabled, representing a significant lockout/tagout protocol failure.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant property damage incident occurred at the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), the Crane Operator, was moving a large pallet of raw composite materials using the overhead crane system when a mechanical failure in the crane's hoist mechanism occurred. The load, weighing approximately 2,400 pounds of pre-impregnated fiber-reinforced plastic materials destined for the Composite Materials Processing Area, suddenly dropped approximately 8 feet onto the warehouse floor. The pallet struck several storage racks containing approximately 15,000 pounds of secondary materials, causing a cascade failure of the racking system. Multiple pallets of raw plastics, resins, and hardeners were scattered across an approximately 400-square-foot area of the warehouse floor. The materials spilled across the concrete floor, creating a significant cleanup hazard. Estimated property damage included destroyed materials valued at $34,000, damaged racking systems valued at $12,000, and required remediation of spilled hazardous materials. Evening Shift Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) immediately secured the area and notified EHS. The incident was declared by Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, after inspection of the crane system revealed inadequate maintenance records and failure to perform required load testing.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator working in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015), nearly experienced a critical incident while preparing the resin mixing station. She was about to manually transfer a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin from storage when she noticed that the drum's handling ring was cracked and beginning to separate from the container wall. Had she proceeded with lifting the drum without inspection, the ring would likely have failed completely, causing the heavy drum to fall and potentially striking her legs or feet. Instead, Rania immediately stopped and alerted her team lead, Viktor Novak (EMP-00116), an Electrical Technician who was performing maintenance nearby. Viktor confirmed the defect and secured the damaged drum in a safe location. The incident was reported as a near-miss by Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) who arrived to investigate within 30 minutes. The root cause analysis revealed that the drum had been delivered with a manufacturing defect that was not caught during receiving inspection. No actual injury occurred, but the potential for serious injury was significant given that improper handling of heavy chemical containers is classified as a critical risk in the facility's hazard register.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Céline Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a significant burn injury while performing routine maintenance on an active injection molding machine. The employee was attempting to clear a resin blockage from the barrel of the 200-ton molding machine without properly shutting down and cooling the equipment. While reaching into the barrel area, her right forearm made direct contact with molten plastic material at approximately 280°C. The employee immediately withdrew her arm and ran to the first aid station, where she applied cold water to the affected area. A coworker witnessed the incident and immediately notified the shift supervisor. The burn covered approximately 8% of her forearm, characterized as a second-degree thermal burn. Emergency medical services were called, and the employee was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval where she received specialized burn treatment. She required 7 stitches and was placed on medical leave for 6 weeks. The immediate cause was failure to follow LOTO procedures and inadequate cooling time verification before manual intervention.

On October 28, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), a Regrind Operator in the Materials Management section, sustained a pinch point injury while operating the plastic regrind machine. The employee was feeding recycled plastic scrap into the hopper when a co-worker inadvertently activated the grinding mechanism without proper communication. Mohamed's left hand was caught between the rotating auger and the hopper wall, resulting in compression injuries to his index and middle fingers. The operator who activated the machine immediately stopped the equipment and alerted supervisors. First aid was administered on-site for swelling and minor lacerations. The employee was transported to a local urgent care facility where X-rays confirmed no fractures but significant soft tissue damage and bruising requiring 2 weeks off work with light duty restrictions for an additional 2 weeks. Root causes included lack of proper lockout procedures before feeding material and inadequate communication between operators sharing the workstation.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, a chemical storage incident occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) when a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin compound began leaking from a corroded base seam. The drum had been stored in the temperature-controlled storage section for approximately 18 months and was scheduled for use in the morning shift. During routine inventory checks, Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), a Material Handler, discovered approximately 12 liters of resin had pooled on the concrete floor, creating a hazardous chemical spill. The resin compound contains styrene and reactive polyester compounds classified as hazardous under WHMIS regulations. Mwangi immediately stopped other material movement, alerted supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), and cleared the area within a 5-meter radius. Nathalie Dubois, Environmental Compliance Specialist, was called to assess and coordinate spill response. The chemical was contained using absorbent materials and professional disposal contractor was contacted. Approximately 8 liters were recovered and disposed of as hazardous waste at a cost of $1,240. The incident resulted in a 4-hour production delay in the composite area. Root cause: inadequate drum inspection protocols and storage duration limits were not enforced.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:30, Assembly Operator Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) was working at Station 4 in the Assembly and Finishing Department when she sustained a laceration to her right index finger. While removing a finished polycarbonate medical component from the assembly fixture, her finger caught on a sharp edge that had not been deburred during the post-processing phase. The component had a burr approximately 2mm in height along its internal edge. Jackson immediately withdrew her hand, resulting in a 3cm laceration requiring 4 stitches at the on-site first aid station. The wound was cleaned, bandaged, and documented. Quality Supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079) was present as a witness and assisted with first aid response. The incident was attributed to inadequate quality control during the heat treatment phase where edge finishing should have been completed. Jackson returned to light duty work the following day with a protective finger wrap.

On March 22, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) and Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) were transferring regrind material from a collection bin to the regrinding hopper using a pneumatic lift cart. As they tilted the cart to empty the approximately 250kg bin of recycled polypropylene pellets, the cart's hydraulic cylinder unexpectedly failed, causing the bin to drop suddenly onto Haddad's left foot. Haddad sustained a fractured metatarsal (third and fourth bones) and was immediately transported to Laval Hospital Emergency by company vehicle, accompanied by Bergeron. Radiographs confirmed fractures requiring immobilization and four weeks of non-weight-bearing recovery. The hydraulic system showed signs of inadequate maintenance with visible oil seepage and corroded fittings. This was a lost-time injury requiring modified duty assignment upon return. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) investigated and documented the incident as reportable to CNESST.

On April 3, 2024, at 08:45 during the day shift, Production Operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) was removing molded components from Injection Molding Line C when she experienced acute respiratory distress and chest tightness. She had been operating the medical device line for three hours without proper ventilation adjustment. The line had been processing polycarbonate with a newly supplied masterbatch colorant batch that contained elevated levels of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Within minutes, Okafor developed wheezing and shortness of breath consistent with acute chemical exposure. She was immediately moved to fresh air and assessed by the on-site occupational health nurse. Oxygen supplementation was provided, and she was transported to Laval Hospital for pulmonary evaluation where she was diagnosed with acute chemical bronchitis. She was hospitalized for 18 hours for monitoring and treatment. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) from the chemical inventory team noted that the new masterbatch supplier had not been properly qualified, and material data sheets had not been reviewed before use. This was classified as a serious injury requiring CNESST reporting and investigation.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) suffered a laceration to his right index finger while performing manual part removal operations at Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area. Morales was extracting cooled plastic medical device housings from the molding fixture when his finger made contact with a sharp burr edge that had not been properly deburred during the previous finishing operation. The burr, approximately 2mm in length, was located on an internal edge of the component that required manual handling during extraction. Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) witnessed the incident and immediately applied pressure to the wound. First aid was administered on-site, and the employee received 3 stitches at the facility's occupational health clinic. The incident was traced to inadequate quality control procedures and the absence of protective finger guards during part extraction. Root cause analysis revealed that the mold had developed minor wear, and the post-processing deburring step had been shortened due to production schedule pressure.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a critical equipment failure occurred at the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). The main conveyor belt system, Model TransLine 3000, experienced a hydraulic hose rupture that caused immediate loss of pressure and belt stoppage. Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was processing finished goods for shipment when she heard an unusual grinding noise followed by a sudden loud hiss. She immediately halted operations and notified her supervisor. Inspection revealed that the high-pressure hose coupling on the hydraulic pump had failed due to metal fatigue and corrosion. The rupture sprayed hydraulic fluid across an approximately 3-meter area of the dock floor, creating a significant slip hazard. No employees were directly sprayed, but the incident caused a 4-hour production halt while the system was repaired by the maintenance team. The conveyor belt was completely non-operational during this period, preventing the shipment of 12 pallets of finished medical device components. Root cause investigation indicated that the hydraulic system had not been serviced in 18 months despite manufacturer recommendations for 12-month intervals, and the corrosion protection coating had deteriorated due to warehouse humidity exposure.

On November 12, 2024, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, an environmental incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. A containment spill was discovered when night shift supervisor Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) conducted routine facility rounds. Approximately 45 liters of uncatalyzed epoxy resin had leaked from a storage drum (Container ID: RES-2847) that had been improperly sealed after the previous day's mixing operations. The resin had pooled on the concrete floor, overflowing into secondary containment berm and partially escaping into a floor drain that connects to the facility's treatment system. The source of the leak was traced to a damaged bung seal that had been cracked during rough handling by Injection Molding Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) during stock rotation activities the previous afternoon. The employee had dropped the 200-liter drum approximately 15 centimeters during repositioning, but did not report the impact. Warehouse staff did not perform a visual integrity check before returning the drum to storage. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and the contaminated material was collected for hazardous waste disposal. Environmental testing of the floor drain effluent revealed elevated volatile organic compound (VOC) levels consistent with epoxy resin. The incident required notification to CNESST and coordination with an environmental remediation contractor for drain line flushing.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine maintenance on a temperature control valve when he noticed a hairline fracture developing in the hydraulic coupling connecting the cooling water system to the injection molding machine. The coupling was pressurized at approximately 150 PSI. Stéphane immediately stepped back and used the emergency shutdown procedure to depressurize the system within 30 seconds. He then notified his supervisor and the maintenance team via radio. The hairline fracture did not rupture, but had it continued under pressure, pressurized cooling water would have sprayed the operator's upper body and face, potentially causing severe scalding burns and eye damage. The incident was caught during the critical moment before catastrophic failure. Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) arrived as a responder and confirmed proper shutdown procedures were followed. The coupling was replaced within 2 hours with a newer model featuring enhanced pressure relief valving.

On April 2, 2024 at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), a Material Handler in the Raw Materials Warehouse, was retrieving a pallet of polycarbonate (PC) resin from a storage rack system (approximately 12 feet high) when she noticed several stainless steel binding straps securing the upper pallets had corroded and fractured, causing multiple pallets to shift. Bianca immediately retreated from beneath the racks and alerted her supervisor via radio. Within seconds, one pallet weighing approximately 500 kg shifted 6 inches downward but did not fall completely due to guide rails. Had Bianca remained under the rack or had the guide rails failed, the falling pallet would have struck her directly, causing severe crushing injuries to her legs and potentially her torso. Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027), an Assembly Operator who was nearby, witnessed the pallet shift and helped Bianca move the material handling equipment away from the unstable racks. The warehouse was immediately cordoned off and remedial action was initiated.

On May 8, 2024 at approximately 3:20 AM during the night shift, an equipment malfunction in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room resulted in a significant fire incident. Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), the Machine Setter on night shift, was performing routine solvent transfer from a 55-gallon acetone drum when a static electricity discharge ignited vapors accumulated in the transfer zone near the mixing equipment. The acetone vapors immediately ignited, creating a localized flash fire approximately 4 feet in diameter near the storage area. Emergency systems activated automatically: the foam suppression system discharged and contained the fire within 45 seconds before it could spread to adjacent chemical storage areas containing isopropanol and flammable adhesives. The night shift supervisor immediately initiated the facility-wide evacuation alarm and contacted emergency services. No personnel were injured as Louis had evacuated the immediate area instinctively when he detected the odor spike. However, the fire damaged approximately $95,000 in stored materials and caused significant smoke damage to ventilation ductwork throughout the chemical building. The incident was contained by engineering controls but represents a critical near-miss for catastrophic facility fire.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician, sustained a minor chemical burn to his left forearm while working at Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building. Pascal was transferring a batch of freshly molded automotive components to the cooling station when he accidentally brushed his bare forearm against a warm mold release agent applicator that had residual product on its exterior surface. The contact lasted approximately 2-3 seconds before Pascal withdrew his arm. He immediately reported the incident to his supervisor Valérie Pelletier. The affected area showed mild erythema (redness) and mild inflammation consistent with a first-degree contact burn. Pascal washed the area thoroughly with cool water and soap, and applied a topical antibiotic ointment from the first aid station. He continued working for the remainder of the shift with the area covered by a sterile gauze pad and antibiotic dressing. No hospitalization was required. The incident occurred due to the mold release agent applicator not having proper insulation covering on its heat-retaining surfaces, and Pascal was not wearing the recommended nitrile gloves at that particular moment of the work cycle.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, James Thompson (EMP-00029), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, suffered a laceration to his right palm while performing mold maintenance in the Maintenance Workshop. James was manually cleaning a complex mold cavity using a stainless steel brush and compressed air when the brush suddenly caught on an internal edge of the mold, causing him to lose grip. His right hand slipped and contacted a sharp, unguarded edge within the mold cavity, resulting in a 4-centimeter laceration requiring eight stitches at the local medical clinic. The incident was immediately reported by witness Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169), a Maintenance Technician present in the workshop. Upon examination, the mold was found to have multiple unfinished sharp edges that were never properly deburred during the initial mold design phase. James was transported to the clinic for wound closure and received a tetanus booster. He returned to light-duty work the following day and was cleared for full-duty work three days later. The root cause was identified as inadequate mold design review procedures that failed to catch sharp edges and lack of proper guards or edge protection on the mold cavity.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 11:55 PM during the night shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area when Tran Le (EMP-00036), a Quality Control Lab Technician, nearly suffered an inhalation injury from solvent vapors. Tran was transferring spent acetone solution from production waste containers into a larger disposal drum when they noticed the drum's vent cap was improperly sealed, causing concentrated solvent vapors to emit from the opening. Tran immediately felt dizziness and mild headache within seconds of exposure and instinctively stepped back from the area, raising an alarm that alerted night-shift supervisor Noor Ahmed (EMP-00076), who was nearby conducting rounds. Noor immediately ventilated the area using portable exhaust fans and moved Tran to fresh air outside the chemical storage building. After approximately 10 minutes of fresh air exposure, Tran's symptoms resolved completely. Noor checked Tran's vital signs and confirmed normal respiratory function. A formal air quality test was conducted the following morning, confirming acetone vapor concentrations had exceeded the OSHA PEL of 750 ppm in the immediate vicinity of the drum. The incident was classified as a near-miss because Tran's exposure was brief and symptoms were mild and fully reversible. The root cause was identified as an employee in the prior shift failing to properly secure the vent cap when adding waste to the drum, combined with inadequate ventilation system performance in that area of the warehouse.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak was discovered on Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building. Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) noticed water spraying from a corroded coupling on the hydraulic cooling circuit of a 250-ton injection molding machine. The leak had developed over several weeks due to inadequate maintenance intervals and corrosion from mineral deposits in the cooling water. Within minutes, approximately 80 liters of heated coolant had leaked onto the floor around the machine base. The spill created a slippery hazard and activated the facility's automatic floor drain system. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was immediately notified and responded within 5 minutes. The affected area was cordoned off using warning tape, and the machine was shut down to prevent further leakage. Maintenance technician Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) was called to assess the coupling damage. Initial inspection revealed the coupling had experienced stress corrosion cracking, which could have led to complete system failure and potential loss of machine temperature control, risking molten plastic overflow. The incident resulted in 4 hours of production downtime and required replacement of the coupling assembly.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) sustained a laceration injury while performing maintenance on the mold assembly of Injection Molding Line A in the Main Production Building. Despite following LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures and ensuring the machine was de-energized, Gosselin was extracting a stuck plastic part from the mold cavity when his right hand contacted a sharp, unfinished edge on the mold insert that had developed a burr during the previous molding cycle. The jagged edge cut through his work glove and lacerated his palm and three fingers, requiring immediate first aid treatment. Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180), who was conducting post-shift inspections nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately called for medical assistance. Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) arrived within 3 minutes and rendered first aid, applying pressure and sterile gauze to control bleeding. The employee was transported to Laval General Hospital, where he received 12 stitches across his palm and fingers. The incident resulted in the employee being released with restrictions on hand use for 7 days and required documentation of the mold defect that contributed to the injury.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, Injection Molding Operator James Thompson (EMP-00029) on Line D experienced acute symptoms of respiratory distress while working near the material hopper mixing station. Thompson had been manually adding a batch of glass-filled nylon resin (fiber-reinforced polymer) to the hopper when a sudden gust from the facility's ventilation system redirected composite fiber dust toward his work station. He inhaled a significant quantity of fine glass fiber particles while preparing the material. Within minutes, Thompson began coughing severely and reported difficulty breathing. His supervisor, Patricia Martin (EMP-00035), Packaging Supervisor, was alerted by Thompson's distress and immediately moved him to a nearby fresh air location and activated the facility emergency response protocol. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) arrived at 11:25 PM and assessed Thompson's condition. Thompson was experiencing throat irritation, coughing, and mild wheezing. First aid was administered including removal from the contaminated area and provision of cool water for throat irrigation. Thompson was transported to Laval General Hospital as a precautionary measure for respiratory evaluation. Hospital assessment revealed acute bronchial irritation from fiber exposure but no permanent lung damage. Thompson was released with recommendations for respiratory recovery and remained on medical leave for 3 days. Investigation revealed the facility's local exhaust ventilation at the mixing station had not been maintained, and intake air filters had not been replaced in 9 months.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a forklift operated by Julien Racine (EMP-00177) was transporting a pallet of finished composite materials from the Main Production Building to the Warehouse and Shipping area. As the forklift was navigating through the narrow corridor between production line D and the storage racks, the load shifted unexpectedly due to improper securing with deteriorated plastic banding. The pallet tipped, causing approximately 150 kg of resin-impregnated composite sheets to fall onto the concrete floor and partially strike a nearby quality control work station. Several sheets were damaged beyond recovery, and the work station's computer monitor was cracked. The incident was immediately reported by Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093), the Inventory Control Specialist who witnessed the event from 3 meters away. No personnel were physically injured, but the property damage included an estimated $8,400 in destroyed materials and $2,200 in equipment replacement costs.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm was activated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Building 5) due to a suspected chemical reaction in the resin mixing room. Samantha Brown (EMP-00146), the Composite Materials Lead, was preparing a batch of epoxy resin when she noticed an unusual rapid temperature rise in the mixing vessel. The vessel, which had not been properly cleaned from the previous shift, contained residual polyester resin that began reacting exothermically with the freshly added epoxy catalyst. The rapid heat generation triggered the thermal detection fire alarm at 10:15 PM. Amélie Roy (EMP-00028), the Training Coordinator, was conducting a compliance review nearby and immediately activated the facility's emergency evacuation protocol. The on-site safety team arrived within 3 minutes and controlled the reaction by shutting off power to the mixer and deploying the dry chemical suppression system. The alarm remained active for 18 minutes until all-clear was confirmed. No fire occurred, but the incident highlighted a critical gap in shift handover procedures for chemical storage areas.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn injury to his right hand and forearm while retrieving a finished plastic component from the mold. The injection molding machine's temperature control unit had malfunctioned during the previous shift without being reported, causing the mold to reach 185°C instead of the standard 155°C operating temperature. As Hassan opened the mold to remove the component, steam and hot plastic material splashed onto his hand and arm. He immediately immersed his arm in the ice water station located 2 meters away. Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), working on Line B adjacent to Hassan, witnessed the incident and immediately summoned on-site medical personnel. Hassan was transported to the facility's first aid station where second-degree burns covering approximately 80 square centimeters on the palm, fingers, and forearm were documented. The employee was treated with topical antibiotic ointment and sterile dressing, then transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval for specialized burn treatment and was hospitalized overnight for observation. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury with Hassan out of work for 14 days during recovery.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a thermal burn injury to his right hand and forearm. Arsenault was performing routine mold extraction from a 150-ton injection molding machine when the hydraulic ejector system malfunctioned, causing the mold to remain partially engaged. When he manually attempted to disengage the mold using a metal extraction tool, his gloved hand made direct contact with the mold surface, which was maintained at 180°C for the polycarbonate medical component being produced. He immediately withdrew his hand and reported the injury to his supervisor, Maxime Boisvert. First aid was administered on-site with cold water application, followed by transport to the facility medical clinic where the burn was assessed as a second-degree thermal injury affecting approximately 8% of his right hand. The incident was caused by inadequate preventive maintenance on the hydraulic ejector system and the absence of automated mold extraction protocols. Tatiana Volkov, Assembly Lead on the adjacent medical components station, witnessed the incident and assisted in initial response.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, a significant fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), Chemical Mixing Operator, was transferring acetone-based cleaning solvent from a 55-gallon drum into a smaller 5-gallon work container. Due to static electricity accumulation and inadequate grounding procedures, a spark ignited the solvent vapors above the open container, initiating a flash fire. The flames rapidly spread to nearby storage shelves containing additional flammable materials including methylene chloride and ethyl acetate, creating a multi-chemical fire. The facility's fire suppression system activated automatically, but the standard water-based sprinklers proved ineffective for flammable liquid fires, causing the fire to spread across approximately 40 square meters of the storage room. Emergency personnel were notified at 10:18 PM, and the facility was evacuated per emergency procedures. The fire department arrived at 10:31 PM and extinguished the blaze using Class B dry chemical foam suppressant. Damage was extensive, including destruction of $180,000 in raw materials, minor damage to storage infrastructure, and temporary closure of the chemical preparation area for 72 hours. Root causes included: absence of proper grounding/bonding during solvent transfer, lack of Class B fire extinguishers in the chemical storage area, inadequate ventilation to remove accumulated solvent vapors, and failure to follow documented transfer procedures requiring static dissipation bonding.

On February 28, 2024, at 1:30 AM during night shift operations, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), Production Operator on night shift, was performing routine material loading on Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room area. While carrying a 25-kilogram spool of polycarbonate resin pellets from the material staging area to the hopper feed mechanism, his foot caught on a coiled compressed air hose that had been left partially across the walkway following maintenance activities earlier that day. The hose was not properly secured or routed through the designated cable management channels. Mensah tripped forward but regained his balance before falling, catching himself against the injection molding machine frame. His hands made contact with the machine's exterior casing but did not penetrate any safety guards or enter active work zones. No injury resulted from the incident. The load of resin pellets was dropped but contained within its spool structure without material loss. However, the near-miss highlighted a critical hazard: if Mensah had lost his balance completely, he would have fallen directly into the partially open mold housing of the adjacent injection molding machine, which was in active cycle. Potential consequences would have included entanglement in the mold mechanism or crushing injury. The root cause was attributed to inadequate housekeeping procedures following maintenance, absence of immediate post-maintenance area inspections, and insufficient visual hazard identification protocols. Yuki Yamamoto (EMP-00112), Process Improvement Engineer, was notified during shift handover and documented the near-miss incident.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine maintenance on molding machine #18 in the Main Production Building. While adjusting the temperature controller after a barrel temperature anomaly, his left hand came into contact with the heated mold surface that was actively maintaining 280°C for polycarbonate processing. The employee did not realize the mold cooling cycle had not yet initiated. Bertrand sustained a second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters across his palm and inner fingers. He immediately ran cold water over the injury for 15 minutes and reported to the first aid station. Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), the Fire Safety Coordinator, was alerted and documented the incident. The burn was treated with sterile dressing and topical antibiotic ointment. Bertrand was sent to a local clinic for evaluation and possible further treatment. The machine was immediately shut down for a full safety inspection to verify temperature display accuracy and cooling cycle sequencing.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:20 AM during the day shift, Amina Mansour (EMP-00044), a Material Handler, was moving a palletized load of raw polycarbonate pellets through the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) using an electric pallet jack. As she was transporting the load toward storage racking, she encountered a small hydraulic leak from a nearby forklift that had been parked but not fully drained after the previous evening shift. The leaked hydraulic fluid created a slippery residue on the concrete floor approximately 2 meters in length. Amina's pallet jack wheels lost traction, causing the load to shift suddenly. She attempted to stabilize the load but her right hand brushed against the sharp edge of a plastic resin drum that was stacked nearby, resulting in a laceration approximately 3cm long on her palm. Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142), the Receiving Coordinator, witnessed the incident and immediately assisted Amina to the first aid station. The wound was cleaned, disinfected with antiseptic solution, and covered with a sterile bandage and antibiotic ointment. No stitches were required. Amina was able to return to work after 45 minutes of treatment and observation.

On March 22, 2024, at 1:15 AM during the night shift, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a Production Operator, was conducting a visual inspection of the resin mixing equipment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility as part of pre-production startup procedures. He noticed a strong chemical odor emanating from the solvent vapors being released from an aging batch of epoxy resin that had been stored improperly with a loose container cap. The ventilation system in that section of the facility was operating at only 60% capacity due to a partially blocked intake filter that maintenance had not yet scheduled for replacement. Kwame experienced dizziness, mild headache, and throat irritation after approximately 10 minutes of exposure. He immediately left the area and reported the symptoms to the night shift supervisor. Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, was contacted and arrived at the facility by 2:00 AM. Kwame was assessed and provided oxygen therapy as a precautionary measure. He was observed for 2 hours and symptoms resolved completely. No hospitalization was required. The affected chemical storage area was sealed off, and the ventilation system was brought to full capacity immediately.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) was working at Injection Molding Line D when his left hand became caught between the mold closing plate and the stationary frame. Morales was attempting to manually remove a partially formed plastic component that had adhered to the mold surface, contrary to established lockout/tagout procedures. He did not wait for the production supervisor to properly isolate and lock out the equipment before attempting the manual extraction. The mold cycled unexpectedly, crushing his hand between the surfaces. Coworker Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074) immediately activated the emergency stop button and called for assistance. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) arrived within minutes and found Morales with severe laceration and crushing injuries to his left hand, including a fractured metacarpal. Emergency medical services were contacted and Morales was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé where he underwent surgical repair. He required 6 weeks of medical leave and was unable to return to production work for 8 weeks total, resulting in a lost-time injury.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building when Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was transferring a 200-liter container of polyurethane resin from storage to the mixing station. The container's securing strap broke during transport, and the container tipped over onto the concrete floor, rupturing a seam and releasing approximately 150 liters of the chemical. The resin began flowing toward the floor drain system, which would have directed it into the groundwater management system serving the facility. Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) discovered the spill and immediately activated the spill containment protocol. The chemical spread across approximately 120 square meters of the storage area. While no personnel were in the direct spill zone, the resin's volatile organic compounds (VOCs) created an atmospheric hazard. Beaudoin deployed absorbent materials and containment booms, but approximately 40 liters entered the facility's retention basin before the floor drain could be manually blocked. Environmental response contractor was called and subsequent testing revealed elevated levels of organic compounds in the retention system.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, CNC Operator Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032) was operating a CNC milling machine in the Maintenance Workshop when metal shavings accumulated near the cutting tool. While the machine was running at normal operating speed, Bianchi attempted to brush away the accumulating shavings using a small brush without reducing machine speed or activating the emergency stop. His hand came into contact with the rotating cutting tool, resulting in a laceration approximately 3 centimeters long across the palm of his right hand. The cut penetrated into subcutaneous tissue but did not damage tendons or major blood vessels. Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) immediately stopped the machine and applied direct pressure with gauze to control bleeding. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) arrived within 5 minutes, cleaned the wound, applied antibiotic ointment and a sterile dressing, and assessed the injury as manageable with first aid treatment. Bianchi received tetanus prophylaxis and was released to continue work with restricted duty (no machine operation) for 3 days while the wound healed. The incident required only first aid intervention with no sutures or hospitalization needed.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on Molding Machine 7 in the Main Production Building when he sustained a minor laceration to his left index finger. While removing cooled plastic components from the machine's ejection area, Gosselin's finger made contact with a sharp edge on a partially formed part that had not been properly deburred during the previous shift. The sharp burr, approximately 3mm in length, caused a shallow 2cm laceration requiring first aid treatment. Gosselin immediately reported the injury to his supervisor and proceeded to the on-site first aid station where Nina Santos, the Industrial Hygienist, cleaned and bandaged the wound. The incident was witnessed by Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), another Injection Molding Technician working at the adjacent station. Upon investigation, it was determined that the deburring process had been rushed due to production schedule pressures, and quality control had not caught the defective part before it reached the molding stage.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Armand Lévesque (EMP-00189), a Mold Repair Technician, was conducting routine inspection of overhead crane cable systems in the Maintenance Workshop when he discovered a potentially hazardous condition. While visually examining the cables for fraying or wear, Lévesque noticed that the left cable assembly showed minor stress corrosion cracking in a non-critical section of the cable, approximately 2 meters from the primary load-bearing connector. The damage was superficial and did not affect load capacity, but represented a deviation from established inspection standards that could develop into a critical condition if left unattended. Lévesque immediately halted all crane operations for that unit and posted lockout/tagout warning signs per company procedure. He notified Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), the Mold Maintenance Technician on duty, who verified the finding. The incident was reported by Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), the EHS Coordinator, who arrived on-site within 15 minutes to conduct documentation. A detailed inspection revealed the corrosion was caused by improper storage of a chemical solvent near the cable during the previous week. No equipment damage or personal injury occurred. The crane was removed from service for cable replacement within 24 hours.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), a Regrind Operator, sustained a significant laceration and partial amputation injury while operating the material recycling grinder in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Comeau was feeding scrap plastic material into the automated hopper when the feed mechanism suddenly jammed with a large piece of composite material that had not been properly pre-sized per standard operating procedures. Attempting to clear the jam manually without proper lockout/tagout procedures, Comeau inserted his right hand into the hopper to dislodge the material. The mechanism suddenly restarted, catching his hand between the feed auger and the hopper wall. His right ring and middle fingers were partially amputated at the proximal interphalangeal joint, and he sustained a deep laceration across the dorsal hand surface. Comeau immediately withdrew his hand and applied pressure with his left hand while calling for emergency assistance. Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), the Instrumentation Technician on night shift duty, responded within 2 minutes and applied emergency first aid including pressure dressing and ice. Emergency medical services arrived at 6:28 AM and transported Comeau to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur in Montréal. He underwent emergency surgical repair and was hospitalized for 4 days. Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), the Workplace Safety Representative, initiated a full incident investigation revealing multiple procedure violations including bypassed LOTO procedures and inadequate training on manual jam clearance protocols.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, material handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was moving a pallet of raw resin powder using a forklift in the warehouse area. While navigating between stacked pallets near the receiving dock, forklift operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) inadvertently struck a wooden pallet with the lift tines, causing it to shift. A sealed 25-kilogram bag of mold release agent fell from the top of the stack, striking Marwa's left shoulder and upper arm. The employee experienced immediate sharp pain and localized swelling. Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026), who was conducting inventory in the area, witnessed the incident and immediately assisted the employee to the first aid station. First aid assessment revealed no fractures, but significant bruising and mild soft tissue strain. The employee was advised to apply ice and was cleared to return to modified duty. Root cause analysis identified inadequate pallet stacking procedures and failure to use safety strapping for unstable loads.

On November 20, 2024, during the evening shift at approximately 8:30 PM, the maintenance team at TechnoPlast identified a potential hazard in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area that requires immediate attention and notification to regulatory authorities. During a routine inspection of the hazardous waste management system, technicians discovered that the ventilation hood above the chemical mixing station has experienced a 40% reduction in airflow due to accumulated resin residue in the intake filter. This degradation was detected by direct measurement using an anemometer during the HSE manager's weekly facility walk-through. The condition creates potential exposure risk to harmful solvent vapors including toluene and acetone used in the resin mixing process. Although no employee has reported symptoms or complaints, the airflow reduction represents a control failure that violates Quebec's RSST regulations and TechnoPlast's own ISO 45001 requirements. The affected area has been immediately restricted from use pending corrective action. This preventive declaration is being submitted to ensure documentation of the hazard discovery, risk assessment, and corrective actions taken before the system is returned to service.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, conducted a routine inspection of the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). During visual assessment of the resin dryer equipment, she identified that the temperature monitoring display on the primary dryer unit was showing erratic readings, fluctuating between 75°C and 145°C within seconds. The equipment had been in continuous operation since 6:00 AM without maintenance intervention. Upon closer inspection, Samira discovered a loose connection on the temperature sensor probe and visible dust accumulation around the dryer's cooling vents, restricting proper airflow. She immediately notified the maintenance team and initiated a controlled shutdown of the affected dryer. No employee exposure to hazardous conditions occurred, and the equipment was successfully isolated. This preventive declaration was filed to address the potential for equipment malfunction that could lead to material overheating, degradation, or thermal runaway conditions that could compromise product quality and create fire hazards in the facility.

On April 3, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift operations, Luc-André Beaudoin, Warehouse Supervisor, was conducting inventory verification in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) when he observed Martin Lavoie, Crane Operator, preparing to move a stacked load of plastic resin pallets stored on the upper shelving system approximately 8 feet above ground level. During the lifting procedure, one pallet shifted slightly in the sling configuration, causing a subtle misalignment that was barely visible from Martin's position in the crane cabin. Luc-André quickly signaled an immediate stop to the operation by activating the emergency hand signal protocol. Upon investigation, the team discovered that the securing straps on the middle pallet had not been properly tensioned, and the load was at imminent risk of partial collapse during the 12-foot horizontal movement. The load was carefully lowered and re-secured. No employee was struck, and no materials fell. This near-miss incident was documented to highlight the critical importance of load inspection procedures and communication protocols during overhead material handling operations.

On April 18, 2024, at 1:30 AM during night shift operations, Bruno Landry, Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was removing finished plastic components from the hot mold cavity during routine production cycle. The mold temperature was approximately 95°C, above the normal operational range due to a malfunctioning thermostat that had not been detected during the shift start-up inspection. While reaching into the mold area to extract a part, Bruno's right forearm made contact with the interior mold surface. He sustained a thermal burn covering approximately 12 square centimeters on his forearm with blistering and redness characteristic of a second-degree burn. Bruno immediately notified his supervisor Mathieu Gendron, who activated first aid response protocols. Bruno received on-site first aid treatment including cool water irrigation and sterile dressing application. He was transported to Laval General Hospital for medical evaluation and treatment at 2:15 AM. Medical assessment confirmed a thermal burn requiring topical antibiotic treatment and follow-up wound care, resulting in a recordable injury and 3 days of lost work time. The incident was investigated and attributed to inadequate PPE protection and malfunctioning temperature monitoring equipment.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM, Production Operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) was working at Injection Molding Line B when she reached into the mold cavity to manually extract a part that had not been properly ejected by the automated system. The molding machine's safety interlock had been bypassed by Machine Setter Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124) during maintenance the previous shift and was never re-enabled. As Naomi's hand entered the mold area, the machine cycled unexpectedly, causing the mold to close on her right hand and forearm. Her fingers became trapped between the upper and lower mold halves, resulting in crushing injuries to three fingers and severe contusions on the dorsal surface of her hand. She screamed for help, and nearby Assembly Operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) immediately activated the emergency stop button. Naomi was transported to the hospital with a fractured index finger, dislocated middle finger, and severe soft tissue damage requiring surgical intervention and a 6-week leave of absence.

On May 22, 2024 at 11:47 PM during the night shift, a fire incident occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). Regrind Operator Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034) was transferring acetone-contaminated plastic scraps into a designated waste container when he accidentally knocked over a 20-liter canister of cleaning solvent (acetone/isopropanol mixture). The liquid spilled across the floor and came into contact with an improperly stored pile of polypropylene regrind material that had accumulated near a faulty electrical outlet. Static electricity discharge from the regrind pile ignited the solvent vapors, creating a small but intense localized fire approximately 2 meters in diameter. Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), also present during night shift, immediately activated the fire alarm and grabbed a Class B fire extinguisher, successfully suppressing the flames within 90 seconds. However, the fire damaged approximately 15 cubic meters of regrind material (valued at $18,500), melted portions of the waste container system, and caused significant smoke damage to adjacent storage areas. The local fire department responded and confirmed no structural damage to the building, but the facility remained partially operational for 3 days during remediation and inspection.

On July 8, 2024 at 9:33 AM, Tool and Die Maker Mario Bélisle (EMP-00149) was performing routine maintenance on CNC Milling Machine #7 in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility when the machine's spindle motor began exhibiting unusual vibration and a grinding noise. Mario had been checking coolant levels and inspecting the cutting tool when he noticed the vibration was increasing in intensity and severity. He attempted to power down the machine using the main control panel, but the emergency stop button failed to respond. The spindle continued rotating at 8,000 RPM, generating excessive vibration that caused the machine's precision alignment to shift. Within 45 seconds, a cutting tool holder became dislodged from the spindle and was ejected across the workspace, striking a nearby workbench but fortunately not injuring Mario, who had stepped back. The tool holder impact caused a secondary failure: hydraulic fluid began leaking from a damaged hose, pooling on the floor. The spindle motor subsequently overheated and automatically shut down after the internal thermal cutoff engaged. Inspection revealed a failed spindle bearing with advanced wear, a malfunctioning emergency stop relay circuit, and deteriorated hydraulic hoses that should have been replaced 6 months prior according to the maintenance schedule. The machine was taken offline for 5 days of repairs requiring replacement of the spindle assembly, repair of the hydraulic system, and restoration of emergency control systems, resulting in estimated repair costs of $42,000 and significant production delays.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, an automated material handling robotic arm on Injection Molding Line B malfunctioned while transferring finished automotive components to a conveyor system. The robotic arm's gripper failed to release a large plastic housing (approximately 8 kg), causing the component to be flung forcefully into an adjacent workstation control panel. The impact shattered the polycarbonate panel cover and damaged internal circuitry, resulting in an estimated $28,000 in equipment damage. Production Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was working approximately 1.5 meters away and witnessed the incident. The malfunction occurred due to inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling on the robotic arm's pneumatic actuation system. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux responded immediately and isolated the equipment. No personnel were injured, but the incident highlighted critical gaps in the maintenance program for automated equipment.

On April 8, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop when an overheated electric motor from a CNC milling machine sparked and ignited accumulated composite fiber dust in the overhead area near the equipment. The alarm functioned correctly, triggering emergency evacuation and sprinkler system activation. However, investigation revealed that dust accumulation had been ongoing for approximately three weeks due to inadequate ventilation filter maintenance. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) responded to the incident and found that the workshop ventilation system had not been serviced according to schedule. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) confirmed that filter replacement had been deferred due to supply chain delays. The fire alarm response was effective, but the underlying hazard—dust accumulation combined with aging electrical equipment—posed significant risk. No injuries occurred, but the incident exposed critical gaps in maintenance scheduling and inventory management.

On May 22, 2024 at 5:30 AM during the night shift, a forklift operated by Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) struck and damaged multiple finished goods storage racks in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). The incident occurred when the forklift experienced sudden brake failure while navigating between stacked pallets of medical-grade composite components. The operator attempted emergency stopping procedures but the vehicle continued forward, colliding with three metal storage racks and destroying approximately 47 units of finished inventory valued at $34,500. The brake failure resulted from worn brake pads that had exceeded safe operating limits but had not been identified during the previous week's equipment inspection. Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) was working nearby and immediately notified Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) who secured the equipment and initiated incident response. No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident resulted in significant production delays due to loss of completed medical device components for a major customer.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a catastrophic failure occurred on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone of the Main Production Building. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert discovered that the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the 350-ton molding machine had ruptured without warning, causing a sudden loss of system pressure. The molding cycle abruptly halted mid-operation, and the mold clamping unit failed to maintain position. Machine Setter Tomas Jimenez, who was adjusting material feed settings approximately 8 feet from the machine, heard a loud hissing sound followed by a sharp metallic ping as the failed valve cartridge ejected from its housing and struck the steel frame near his position. The incident resulted in approximately 200 liters of ISO 46 hydraulic fluid spraying across the production floor, creating a significant slip hazard and coating nearby equipment. Production Operator Omar Said, working at an adjacent station, immediately activated the emergency stop and notified supervision. Gilles Marchand from Facilities Maintenance arrived within 5 minutes to contain the spill and isolate the machine from the plant's hydraulic system.

On April 22, 2024, at 10:45 AM during day shift operations in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A), Material Handler Chiara Bianchi was retrieving polyethylene terephthalate (PET) resin from the upper shelving system when the ventilation system unexpectedly failed. The HVAC unit had been operating continuously for 18 months without maintenance, and the main supply fan motor seized due to bearing degradation and accumulated dust accumulation in the filter cartridges. Within 20 minutes of the fan shutdown, volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes from recently received shipments of composite resin precursors began accumulating in the warehouse space. Bianchi reported feeling lightheaded and experiencing mild throat irritation at 11:05 AM, notifying her supervisor Yves Thibault who immediately evacuated the warehouse and opened all emergency exits. The facility's air quality monitoring system triggered an alarm at 11:12 AM, indicating VOC concentrations had reached 85% of the OSHA permissible exposure limit. Warehouse personnel remained outside the building for 35 minutes while Gilles Marchand assessed the ventilation system and manually opened the roof vents to restore air circulation. An emergency HVAC technician was called and restored partial ventilation at 11:50 AM.

On May 8, 2024, at 3:55 PM during evening shift operations at the Packaging and Labeling Station (Warehouse Prep Area), Quality Control Inspector Mei Zhang sustained a minor laceration to her left index finger while inspecting molded medical device housings for dimensional accuracy. While removing a finished part from a protective foam insert, the edge of a partially cured plastic flashing—a thin, sharp burr left from the injection molding process—caught her fingertip, creating a 1.2 cm laceration that penetrated approximately 2 mm into the dermis layer. The cut bled moderately and Zhang immediately reported the injury to Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant at 3:57 PM. Surprenant escorted her to the first aid station located in the HSE Office on the second floor of the Administrative Building. Occupational Health and Safety Specialist Zahra Nasri cleaned the wound with antiseptic solution, applied direct pressure to control bleeding, and dressed the laceration with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment at 4:12 PM. The wound was documented as non-serious but required monitoring, and Zhang was advised to keep the area clean and dry for 48 hours. She returned to her workstation at 4:30 PM with instructions to report any signs of infection.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134) was working on Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room area. While removing cured polycarbonate housing components from the injection mold, she contacted the hot mold surface which was maintained at 85°C. Her left forearm made direct contact with the mold cavity edge, causing a significant thermal burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters. The operator had been wearing standard nitrile gloves, which provided insufficient insulation from the sustained heat. She immediately notified her supervisor and was directed to the first aid station where the burn was cooled with water for 15 minutes and covered with sterile gauze. The employee required medical attention at a local clinic for burn assessment and dressing. Production on Line C was halted for 2 hours to investigate the incident and inspect mold temperature controls. The burn was classified as a second-degree thermal injury requiring ongoing wound care and resulted in 3 days of lost work.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM during the day shift, material handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was transferring bags of polypropylene resin from the warehouse to the resin dryer staging area in Materials Management. While carrying a 25-kilogram bag from a pallet stack, he stepped on a small spill of mold release agent that had leaked from a nearby storage container. His foot slipped on the slick floor surface, causing him to lose his balance. He fell forward, catching himself with his right hand on a metal shelving unit. Upon impact, a shallow laceration approximately 2 centimeters long opened on his right palm from the sharp edge of the shelf. Kwesi immediately went to the first aid station where HSE coordinator Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) cleaned and bandaged the wound with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. The laceration did not require stitches. The incident was investigated and the spill was immediately cleaned and the area marked with caution tape. Kwesi was able to return to work after first aid treatment with a bandage and precautions to keep the wound clean and dry.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, crane operator Gaston Picard (EMP-00193) was operating the overhead crane in the main production building to reposition a large composite material mold (approximately 800 kilograms) from the storage area to Production Engineering workstation. While lowering the mold, a cable connection on the lifting apparatus showed signs of stress and one wire began to fray. The mold was safely lowered to its destination without dropping, but upon visual inspection, material handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194), who was guiding the load from below, noticed the damaged cable. He immediately stopped operations and notified shift supervisor. The frayed cable created a minor cut on Amani's left index finger as he was securing the load positioning straps—approximately 1 centimeter laceration with minimal bleeding. Amani received first aid treatment from the night shift medical responder, including wound cleaning, antibiotic application, and a sterile bandage. The incident was documented and the crane was taken offline for full cable inspection and replacement. No lost work time resulted.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi, an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a laceration to his left palm while removing cooled parts from the mold. The molded automotive dashboard component had sharp flash edges that were not properly deburred before part removal. As Zaidi reached into the mold cavity to extract the part, his hand slipped and made contact with the sharp edge, creating a 2-inch laceration requiring 5 stitches. The incident occurred in the Main Production Building - North Zone. Immediate first aid was provided by Bianca De Luca, a Material Handler present at the station, who applied direct pressure and activated the emergency response protocol. Serge Lafleur, the Workplace Safety Representative, arrived within 3 minutes and assessed the wound. The injury was classified as a first-aid case requiring professional medical attention but not hospitalization. The root cause was identified as inadequate quality control inspection procedures and missing machine guarding on the sharp edge point of the mold.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 23:15 during the evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Warehouse and Shipping - Loading Area (UNIT-009). Roberto Santos, a Forklift Operator, was transporting four 55-gallon drums of mold release agent (silicone-based) from the Materials Management warehouse to the production area. One drum was improperly secured in the forklift basket, causing it to tip and rupture when Santos navigated a slight incline near the loading dock. Approximately 40 gallons of the chemical agent spilled onto the concrete surface, creating a slippery hazard covering an area of approximately 200 square feet. The spill was discovered by Rashid Habib, a Material Handler, who immediately notified the shift supervisor. Johanne Paquette, the Emergency Response Team Leader, was called in and supervised the containment and cleanup operation. The spill was contained using absorbent granules and collected into hazardous waste containers. No personnel came into direct contact with the chemical, but the loading dock area was rendered inaccessible for 3.5 hours during cleanup. The root cause was inadequate drum securing procedures and lack of secondary containment on the forklift.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 08:30 during the day shift, Amina Mansour, a Material Handler, sustained a finger laceration while operating the packaging and labeling equipment at the Warehouse and Shipping - Prep Area. Mansour was manually feeding plastic automotive trim parts into the automated labeling machine when her right index finger was caught between the conveyor feed mechanism and a stationary guide plate. The machine was operating at normal speed, and the pinch point was not adequately shielded. The laceration required 4 stitches and was treated as a first-aid incident. Marc Hébert, a Warehouse Associate working nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately shut down the machine using the emergency stop button. Zahra Nasri, the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, responded and provided initial assessment. The employee was transported to an urgent care facility for wound treatment and received a tetanus booster. The root cause was identified as missing machine guarding on the pinch point and lack of operator awareness training regarding the specific hazard.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012), Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) was performing routine maintenance on a 200-ton injection molding machine's hydraulic system. While attempting to replace a worn pressure relief valve, the hydraulic pump unexpectedly activated despite the machine being in lockout status. The pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed directly onto Marchand's left arm and torso, causing second-degree thermal burns across approximately 15% of his body. The incident was immediately reported by safety trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), who was conducting a nearby equipment inspection. Emergency medical services responded within 8 minutes. Investigation revealed that the lockout/tagout procedure had been improperly documented, with the energy isolation checklist incomplete. The hydraulic accumulator retained residual pressure that was not dissipated per protocol. Marchand was transported to Laval Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries requiring hospitalization for wound treatment and fluid management. The machine remained out of service for 48 hours during investigation and system verification.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:30 AM during routine facilities inspection in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010), workplace hazard assessment specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) conducted a preventive walk-through assessment as part of TechnoPlast's quarterly hazard review cycle. During this inspection, Nasri identified a significant ventilation deficiency: the exhaust fan serving the resin mixing station had been running at approximately 60% capacity for an unknown duration. Air velocity measurements indicated insufficient airflow to adequately capture fumes from the epoxy resin and polyester compound mixing operations. Nasri's preliminary testing with thermal smoke tracers revealed stagnant zones near employee workstations where composite dust and solvent vapors were accumulating. Three production operators (Fatou Ndiaye EMP-00050, Hawa Traore EMP-00178, and Youssef Zaidi EMP-00060) who work in this area reported experiencing occasional headaches and throat irritation during extended shifts. Nasri immediately notified facility management and documented all findings with photographs and air velocity readings. This preventive declaration was made in accordance with company safety protocols to address the hazard before an injury occurred. The ventilation system was subsequently inspected by external HVAC specialists who confirmed bearing degradation in the exhaust fan motor.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 8:45 PM during evening shift operations in Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components (UNIT-003), a critical equipment failure occurred when the thermal control system on a 300-ton Engel injection molding machine malfunctioned. The barrel temperature sensor failed intermittently, causing the heating element to overheat to approximately 380°C instead of the required 285°C. Production operator Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) noticed the molten resin beginning to degrade and emit dark smoke approximately 90 seconds into the heating cycle. The operator immediately initiated emergency shutdown procedures and activated the facility alarm system. However, before the machine could fully cool, a pressure relief valve ruptured due to excessive system pressure created by the superheated material. The rupture ejected a portion of degraded resin composite material that struck the adjacent robotic loading arm, causing approximately $34,000 in damage to the arm's servo motor assembly and control electronics. The damaged arm controls a critical handling operation for medical device housings. Fire suppression systems activated appropriately when the overheated material triggered thermal sensors. No personnel were injured due to proper emergency response protocols. The machine was immediately removed from service and referred for complete thermal management system replacement. The incident was formally reported by fire safety coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) who responded to the alarm.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45, an acetone spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) during routine resin preparation operations. Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a production operator, was transferring cleaning solvent from a 55-gallon drum into smaller 5-gallon containers using a manual pump system. Due to inadequate ventilation in the room and a partially loose pump valve, approximately 8 gallons of acetone spilled onto the concrete floor. The spill created a slippery hazard and generated significant fumes throughout the enclosed space. Leila immediately notified her supervisor, Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), the Safety Representative, who initiated emergency procedures. The area was evacuated within 5 minutes. Response included deployment of absorbent material, activation of emergency ventilation fans, and documentation by Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist. No injuries occurred, but three nearby employees experienced mild irritation from fume exposure. The incident was contained within 45 minutes with proper cleanup and disposal procedures followed. Root cause was identified as inadequate pump maintenance and insufficient pre-transfer inspection protocols.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, an isopropanol spill incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Ibrahim Ibrahim (EMP-00090), a machine setter on day shift covering evening duties, was performing maintenance on the material drying oven when he discovered a cracked hose connection on the solvent recirculation line.
