Upon inspection, approximately 12 gallons of isopropanol had accumulated in the collection pan beneath the equipment over an unknown period. While attempting to transfer the contaminated solvent to a disposal container, the transfer line connection failed completely, spilling the remaining isopropanol across approximately 150 square feet of the work area. The spill generated considerable vapor and created a fire hazard due to the material's flammability. Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), the Ergonomics Specialist, was notified and immediately activated emergency procedures. The area was evacuated and secured. Emergency responders contained the spill using specialized absorbent materials. The incident highlighted inadequate equipment inspection schedules and lack of proper spill response training for maintenance personnel. Investigation revealed the hose had been cracked for at least 3 shifts, suggesting deficient preventive maintenance protocols.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 11:20 on the day shift, an equipment failure incident occurred on Injection Molding Line B (UNIT-002) in the Main Production Building. Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), the line B injection molding operator, was running a production cycle for automotive dashboard components when the primary hydraulic pump pressure relief valve failed without warning. The valve malfunction caused a catastrophic pressure surge that ruptured a secondary hydraulic line, spraying hot hydraulic fluid (approximately 180°F) across a 4-foot radius. Mathieu sustained minor splash burns to his left forearm and neck. The hydraulic fluid also contaminated approximately 400 units of in-process material, rendering them non-conformant and requiring scrappage. Production on Line B was halted for 6 hours pending emergency repairs. Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), the injection molding technician, responded immediately, applying first aid and shutting down the equipment using emergency stop procedures. The incident was declared by Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) after initial assessment. Investigation revealed the pressure relief valve had not been serviced in 18 months, well beyond the manufacturer's recommended 6-month maintenance interval. The failure represents a critical breakdown in preventive maintenance protocols and equipment condition monitoring.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM, production operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was working at Injection Molding Line A during the day shift when she experienced a burn injury. While removing parts from a mold that had just completed its cooling cycle, the mold temperature was higher than expected due to a malfunctioning thermostat on the injection unit. As she reached to extract a polycarbonate component, her left forearm made direct contact with the mold cavity, resulting in a thermal burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters of her skin. The burn was immediately treated with cold water at the workstation for 10 minutes, followed by application of a sterile dressing. First aid was administered by the on-site HSE team, and the employee was monitored for 2 hours to ensure no systemic effects. She remained at work with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. The incident was caused by inadequate maintenance of the injection machine's temperature control system, which had been operating 15 degrees Celsius above the normal setpoint without operator awareness due to a faulty digital display.

On March 21, 2024 at approximately 9:45 PM during the evening shift, tool maker René Caron (EMP-00097) was performing routine maintenance on the solvent cleaning system in the Post-Processing area when he inadvertently made contact with acetone vapors that had accumulated in an inadequately ventilated section of the workspace. René was using isopropanol to clean precision mold components when he experienced sudden eye irritation and mild respiratory irritation. He immediately moved to the fresh air intake area and thoroughly flushed his eyes with the eyewash station for approximately 3 minutes. The symptoms subsided within 15 minutes, and first aid assessment by the on-site HSE coordinator determined the exposure was minor with no lasting effects. The incident was logged and investigated; it was determined that the ventilation system's damper in the south zone had been partially closed during earlier HVAC maintenance and had not been restored to full operational status, creating a chemical vapor accumulation zone.

On March 10, 2024 at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Mold Technician Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021) was performing a routine inspection of the Hazardous Waste Management Area when he observed a potential leak developing from a 55-gallon drum of contaminated coolant that had been staged for disposal. The drum was positioned on a deteriorating wooden pallet near the secondary containment area. Upon closer examination, Stéphane noticed a hairline crack forming along the seam where the drum's side wall met the base, with approximately 2-3 milliliters of fluid having seeped onto the concrete floor over the preceding hours. The potential leak had not yet reached the soil or surface water, as the secondary containment system was functioning. Stéphane immediately isolated the area using hazard tape, notified the HSE team, and transferred the damaged drum to a new pallet within the containment system using proper spill response protocols. No environmental release occurred. Root cause analysis determined that the wooden pallet had deteriorated due to moisture exposure and weight stress, and had subsided unevenly, placing unbalanced stress on the drum.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, during the day shift at UNIT-016 (Material Drying and Preparation Room), Jade Wong (EMP-00140) was monitoring the resin dryer unit when she noticed unusual vibration and a burning smell emanating from the equipment. The dryer's thermostat had malfunctioned, causing the internal temperature to spike to 285°C, well above the safe operating limit of 220°C for polypropylene resin. The heating element continued cycling without temperature feedback, leading to resin degradation and smoke emission. Jade immediately shut down the unit and activated the emergency ventilation system. The incident was discovered by process technician Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), who was nearby preparing batch materials. No personnel were injured, but approximately 150 kg of polypropylene resin was ruined, and the dryer required replacement of the thermostat and heating element. The facility's fire suppression system remained on standby but was not activated. Facility manager Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) was notified immediately and coordinated shutdown procedures.

On March 18, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), a crane operator at UNIT-012 (Central Maintenance Workshop), was relocating a 400-lb steel mold assembly from the storage rack to a maintenance workbench. While positioning the mold over the work surface, a lifting chain's clevis pin partially disengaged due to inadequate locking wire, causing the mold to slip laterally within the sling. The 400-lb assembly struck a stack of precision gauges and calibration equipment valued at approximately $18,000, destroying three electronic height gauges and two digital calipers. The mold itself sustained a 2-inch crack along one edge, rendering it temporarily unusable pending repair assessment. Maintenance technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) was working at the adjacent bench and heard the impact but was not struck. Aya immediately stopped operations and activated the emergency lockout on the crane. Facility Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) arrived within 5 minutes and initiated incident response procedures. The dropped mold caused $24,000 in total property damage (gauges plus mold repair). No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident halted mold maintenance operations for 8 hours.

On March 20, 2024 at 06:30 during the night shift, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an injection molding operator on Line C at UNIT-003 (Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components), was performing routine maintenance on the mold clamping mechanism when she noticed a small hydraulic fluid leak from a pressure relief valve. Rather than immediately stopping operations and calling maintenance, Yasmin continued production for approximately 15 minutes, monitoring the leak rate. The hydraulic pressure fluctuated between normal and approximately 20% above specification due to pressure relief valve malfunction. At 06:47, the accumulating pressure caused a sudden violent release from a maintenance port on the injection cylinder, creating a pressurized hydraulic spray that narrowly missed Yasmin's left shoulder by approximately 8 inches. The spray struck the adjacent mold tool instead, causing minor surface damage. Yasmin immediately shut down Line C and activated the lockout/tagout procedure. Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150) witnessed the pressure release event from the cleanroom observation window. No personnel injuries occurred, but the near-miss incident exposed a critical failure in pressure containment systems and operator awareness protocols. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) was called to assess the equipment hazard and documented the near-miss event.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, production operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the clean room area when she began experiencing repetitive strain pain in her right wrist and forearm. Over the course of a 6-hour shift, Mustafa had been continuously removing molded medical components from the injection press and placing them into sorting trays. The repetitive gripping and twisting motions required for part removal from the hot molds caused cumulative stress on her flexor tendons. By the end of her shift, she reported significant pain and swelling to her supervisor, Pierre Bouchard (EMP-00023). Bouchard documented the complaint and immediately contacted EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) to file a preventive declaration. The employee was provided with an ice pack and wrist support, and was reassigned to lighter duties the following day. This incident was flagged as a near-miss requiring intervention to prevent future RSI claims among the assembly team, as similar complaints had been noted in previous months among three other operators on the same line.

On March 18, 2024, at 22:30 during the night shift, Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) discovered that the emergency exit door leading from the Warehouse and Shipping section to the exterior loading dock was obstructed by a stack of 12 pallets containing finished goods awaiting shipment. The pallets had been temporarily stacked against the exit during an inventory reorganization earlier that evening by Forklift Operator Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167) and were not removed afterward. When Laflamme tested the exit door handle, it would only open partially before striking the pallet stack. Laflamme immediately contacted Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) to document this safety violation. The pallets were relocated within 15 minutes, and the emergency exit was verified to be fully functional. This incident represents a critical fire code violation and emergency egress issue. Bellavance filed a preventive declaration noting that warehouse staff had not received refresher training on emergency exit protocols in 18 months, and that the night shift operates with minimal supervision, creating conditions for such blockages to occur undetected.

On March 20, 2024, at 10:15 on the day shift, Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026) was examining cured composite material samples at the Composite Materials Processing Area when she experienced a sharp pain in her left eye. A small glass fiber fragment, approximately 2mm in length, had become airborne during the edge trimming operation performed by nearby technician Amal Farsi (EMP-00200) and embedded itself in Leblanc's conjunctiva. Leblanc immediately flushed her eye with the emergency eyewash station for 15 minutes and reported to the on-site first aid station. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) responded and performed initial assessment, confirming the fiber had caused minor abrasion with slight bleeding. The fragment was carefully removed using sterile tweezers, the eye was flushed again, and antibiotic drops were applied. Leblanc was advised to monitor for infection and given a written incident report. She remained at work but with modified duties avoiding the trimming area. This incident occurred because Leblanc was not wearing her safety glasses at the time, having removed them briefly to examine sample color. Santos documented the incident as first aid treatment requiring employer notification.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. Paul was cleaning residual polymer buildup from the mold cavity using a cloth soaked in acetone when he made contact with the mold surface that had not fully cooled following the previous production cycle. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C. Paul immediately felt burning sensation on his left hand and wrist. He immersed his hand in cool water at the nearest sink and reported the incident to his supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151). The burn affected approximately 8% of his left hand, classified as a first-degree to shallow second-degree thermal burn. Paul was sent to the on-site clinic where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed the injury, applied burn dressing, and arranged for him to visit the local hospital for evaluation. Paul was able to return to work the following day with modified duties.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the evening shift, Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), a Machine Setter, experienced a serious back injury while manually lifting a 45-kg spool of polypropylene resin from the warehouse floor to a drying hopper at shoulder height in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Svetlana was working alone as the shift had just begun and was attempting to lift the spool without mechanical assistance. She bent at the waist with legs straight, lifted the heavy spool, and felt a sharp pain in her lower back. She immediately set the spool down and reported severe pain to Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151). Fillion called for Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) who arrived within 10 minutes. Initial assessment indicated acute lower back strain with possible lumbar disc involvement. Svetlana was unable to continue work and was transported to the emergency department by ambulance. She was diagnosed with a lumbar strain and a small disc herniation at L4-L5. She was placed on medical leave for 3 weeks and required physical therapy.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 2:30 PM, Monique Dion (EMP-00119), a Warehouse Associate, identified a significant safety hazard during routine inventory in the Finished Goods Warehouse, Section B. While organizing stacks of medical device component boxes, Monique noticed that storage pallet racking near the emergency exit had been loaded beyond rated capacity limits, with boxes stacked 1.2 meters high, creating an obstruction that partially blocked the emergency exit door swing. Additionally, she observed that several fluorescent light fixtures above the stored materials had been inactivated, reducing visibility in that section. Monique immediately documented the condition with photographs, notified her supervisor, and filed a preventive safety declaration with the HSE department. Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) was notified and conducted an immediate walk-through inspection. Zahra confirmed both hazards: the overloaded racking created a crush hazard and the blocked emergency exit violated fire code and CNESST regulations. No employee was injured, but the conditions presented immediate risk. The situation was corrected within 2 hours—materials were redistributed to proper storage locations and lighting was restored.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 14:45, a fire broke out in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) in the Main Production Building's West Wing. Fernand Comeau, Regrind Operator, was processing recycled composite material through the grinding station when plastic dust that had accumulated on overhead surfaces and electrical conduits ignited from contact with a malfunctioning heating element on the adjacent resin mixer. The element had exceeded its safe operating temperature due to a failed thermostat that had not been replaced during the previous maintenance cycle. The dust fire spread rapidly along the underside of the roof infrastructure, creating heavy black smoke. Fernand immediately activated the nearest fire alarm and evacuated the area. The automatic sprinkler system engaged after approximately 90 seconds. Emergency responders from Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes. The fire was extinguished within 22 minutes with no injuries, but the West Wing processing equipment sustained approximately $185,000 in damage, and production was halted for 4 days. Investigation revealed that dust accumulation on high surfaces had not been included in standard cleaning procedures for over 18 months.

On April 8, 2024 at 22:15, a fire alarm was triggered in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011), located in the exterior zone of the Chemical Storage Building. Monique Dion, Warehouse Associate on the evening shift, was conducting a routine inventory count of solvent waste containers when she noticed chemical fumes emanating from a damaged container of acetone-based mold release solvent. The container's cap had corroded and was not sealing properly, and the contents had begun to evaporate at an elevated rate due to the ambient temperature (24°C) in the unshaded exterior storage zone. The vapors triggered the area's vapor detection system, which automatically activated the fire alarm at 22:14. Monique immediately notified her supervisor and evacuated the area. Plant management initiated the facility-wide evacuation protocol. Emergency response team assessed the area and confirmed no fire was present—the alarm was triggered by the vapor concentration threshold (explosive range detection). The solvent container was moved to secondary containment and resealed within 45 minutes. No injuries occurred. The false alarm resulted in 2 hours of production interruption while the facility was cleared and re-entered. Root cause analysis identified that the container had been stored in direct sunlight for 3 weeks due to inventory tracking errors.

On May 2, 2024 at 09:30, an employee suffered a laceration requiring first aid treatment in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Richard Beaulieu, Tool Room Supervisor, was assisting with the manual cleanup of aluminum shavings and metal debris that had accumulated around a precision milling machine during the night shift. While using an industrial-grade shop brush to sweep shavings into a collection bin, a sharp aluminum chip embedded in the bristles cut across the palm of his right hand as the brush caught on the edge of a worktable. The laceration was approximately 4 centimeters long and approximately 3 millimeters deep, creating a clean but moderately bleeding wound. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid, present in the facility for a routine safety inspection, immediately provided first aid treatment: thorough cleaning with sterile saline, application of antibiotic ointment, and closure using sterile adhesive strips. After assessment, the wound did not require sutures or external medical attention. Richard completed incident documentation and was cleared to return to modified duties (no heavy gripping) for the following 5 days. The incident was attributed to inadequate personal protective equipment—standard cloth work gloves provided insufficient protection against sharp metal chips. Production continued without interruption.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room area (UNIT-003). While performing routine material loading, she noticed that the mold cooling water system was releasing an unusual amount of condensation around the connection points near the injection unit. She observed small water droplets accumulating on the floor near the machine base. Before proceeding, Kamara immediately notified her supervisor, Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who arrived within minutes. Upon inspection, they identified a hairline crack developing in one of the secondary cooling water circuit connections. No water had yet pooled on the production floor, and the machine's primary cooling system remained functional. Kamara's quick recognition of the anomaly and immediate reporting prevented potential equipment damage, electrical hazard, or slip-and-fall incident. The situation was classified as a near-miss with corrective action taken before any injury or significant damage occurred.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195) was operating Line A when a malfunction occurred in the automatic part ejection system. A molded component did not fully eject from the mold cavity. Following standard procedure, Therrien initiated an emergency stop and contacted Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) for assistance. Rossi arrived at 10:22 PM and initiated a Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) procedure. However, during the process, a hydraulic pressure valve that had not been fully isolated suddenly released residual pressure, causing a small amount of hydraulic fluid to spray onto Rossi's left forearm. Although Rossi was wearing standard work clothing, the hydraulic fluid caused minor skin irritation and was absorbed through a small cut on his arm. Rossi immediately washed the affected area and reported to the first aid station. He was treated for chemical exposure and skin irritation. Due to the hydraulic fluid exposure and the need for medical evaluation, Rossi was unable to continue work and took the remainder of the shift off plus the following day, resulting in a lost-time injury.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Forklift Operator Claude Poirier (EMP-00071) was moving palletized resin materials in the Materials Management and Warehousing area. While transporting a load of polypropylene (PP) resin bags from the receiving dock to storage racks in the west section of the warehouse, Poirier attempted to navigate between two rows of storage racks. The warehouse was dimly lit during night shift operations, and visibility was reduced. As Poirier maneuvered the forklift, the right-side load struck one of the storage racks supporting approximately 1,200 kilograms of composite material components in bins. The impact caused several bins to shift and fall from the upper shelf, striking Poirier on the left shoulder and back. Although Poirier was wearing standard PPE including a hard hat and safety vest, the falling materials caused significant bruising and a fractured left scapula (shoulder blade). Crane Operator Gaston Picard (EMP-00193) witnessed the incident and immediately called for emergency response. Poirier was transported to the hospital by ambulance, admitted with a confirmed fracture, and required surgical consultation. He remained hospitalized for 3 days and was unable to return to work for 6 weeks due to recovery time and physical therapy requirements.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a laceration to her left index finger while removing cooled parts from the mold cavity. She was performing routine part extraction when her finger made contact with a sharp edge on a newly molded automotive dashboard component. The edge, which should have been deburred during the finishing process, caught her finger as she was lifting the part from the mold. Claudine immediately reported the injury to her supervisor Sonia Dasilva, who provided first aid including wound cleaning and a sterile bandage. The wound was approximately 1.5 cm long but superficial, not requiring stitches. Claudine continued working for the remainder of her shift with the injury properly dressed. The incident was documented and first aid treatment was administered on-site by HSE personnel. No lost time resulted from this incident. The root cause was identified as inadequate deburring procedures on parts with complex geometry.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, narrowly avoided a serious hand injury when he noticed the machine was beginning its automatic cycle while he was reaching into the mold cavity to position a component. The machine had been in manual mode for maintenance setup, but due to a communication breakdown between the previous shift operator and Ahmed, the emergency stop had not been properly engaged and the LOTO procedures had not been followed. Ahmed was preparing to insert a part when the audible warning system sounded. He quickly withdrew his hand approximately 2 seconds before the mold would have closed, potentially causing crushing injuries to his fingers. No contact occurred and no injury resulted. The incident was immediately reported to Gaétan Laplante, the LOTO Coordinator, who investigated and found that the machine had been left in an unsafe state by the day shift. An emergency meeting was called with the production team to review the incident. Investigation revealed that the night shift handover documentation was incomplete and LOTO compliance procedures were not being consistently followed across all shifts.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, a minor fire alarm activation occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (exterior zone). Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), the Warehouse Lead on night shift, noticed an acrid odor near the hazardous waste storage containers and observed slight discoloration on one of the chemical storage drums. Upon closer inspection with proper PPE, he identified that a drum containing polyester resin solvent had developed a small leak. Residual vapors combined with spontaneous oxidation of absorbed rags in the adjacent disposal bin created localized heat accumulation that triggered the facility's thermal fire detection system in that zone. The alarm system immediately activated the suppression system, releasing dry chemical powder. No actual fire occurred, but the alarm triggered facility-wide evacuation protocols as required by emergency procedures. Emergency responders arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the area was safe after the suppression system discharge. The leak was contained by Natasha Ivanov from the Chemical Inventory team using spill containment procedures. Investigation revealed that the drum had developed micro-cracks due to improper storage positioning against a rough concrete wall.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Injection Molding Operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was operating Line D in the Assembly and Finishing Department when a catastrophic equipment failure occurred. While processing a batch of automotive connectors, the 150-ton injection molding machine's hydraulic pressure relief valve malfunctioned, causing excessive pressure buildup. The pressurized mold clamp assembly suddenly released, projecting the mold base and attached tooling approximately 8 feet across the production floor. The mold struck the adjacent material staging rack, rupturing three 55-gallon drums of virgin polycarbonate pellets and scattering approximately 200 pounds of plastic material across a 400-square-foot area. The impact also damaged the machine's electronic control panel and severed a high-pressure hydraulic line, creating a secondary spill of approximately 25 gallons of ISO 46 hydraulic fluid. Material Handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was working nearby and immediately evacuated the area and notified Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007). No personnel were struck, but the incident rendered Line D inoperable for 6 days pending equipment repair and full area decontamination.

On February 8, 2024, at approximately 9:20 PM during the evening shift, Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) was processing recycled polycarbonate material in the Regrind and Recycling Department when a drum of uncoded chemical additive was mistakenly loaded into the batch feeder. The material had been temporarily stored near the regrind operation following equipment maintenance and was missing its original WHMIS label. When mixed with hot recycled plastic at 280°C, the unknown additive underwent an exothermic reaction, generating an estimated 15 gallons of acidic vapors and an unknown organic compound mist. The reaction caused the compounding equipment vent line to release a concentrated plume of acrid fumes directly above the work station. Fernand immediately experienced burning sensations in his eyes, nose, and throat, and began coughing uncontrollably. Production Operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), positioned 20 feet downwind on the packaging line, also reported eye irritation and respiratory discomfort. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) was alerted and initiated emergency ventilation procedures. Both employees were escorted to the on-site first aid station, where they received eye rinses and respiratory observation for approximately 45 minutes. The chemical composition of the additive was eventually identified from remaining documentation as an acidified phenolic resin accelerator, normally prohibited in this production stream due to compatibility issues.

On January 22, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, Assembly Operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) was assembling medical-device composite components at workstation 3 in the Assembly and Finishing Department when he experienced a sharp cut to his left index finger. While manually positioning a pre-cured fiberglass-reinforced composite part into an assembly jig, a microscopic delamination on the part's edge caught his fingertip, creating a laceration approximately 0.75 inches long and 0.125 inches deep. The cut bled moderately but did not require stitches. Luis immediately rinsed the wound under running water in the nearest safety station sink for 2 minutes, applied direct pressure with sterile gauze for 8 minutes, then proceeded to the on-site first aid station where Office Manager Louise Bernier (EMP-00089) cleaned and bandaged the wound with antibiotic ointment and a sterile adhesive bandage. The incident was documented in the first aid log at 6:28 AM. Luis continued working for the remainder of his shift with a protective nitrile glove over the bandage. Upon investigation, the defective composite part was traced to a mold contamination issue during production on the previous shift where a water droplet had created a micro-void during the cure cycle. The part should have been rejected during post-cure quality inspection but was missed due to inadequate visual inspection protocol.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, material handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was performing routine inventory checks in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B) when she noticed that several pallets of packaged consumer goods were stacked unevenly on the upper shelves of a storage rack system. The pallets, containing approximately 800 kg of finished plastic containers, were positioned precariously near the edge. De Luca immediately halted her activities and notified her supervisor Patricia Martin. Upon visual inspection, Martin confirmed that the stacking procedure had not followed the established load distribution guidelines, creating an immediate hazard of material collapse. De Luca documented the condition with photographs and reported it to the HSE department as a preventive measure before any worker was struck. No immediate intervention was required beyond documentation, but the discovery prompted a comprehensive review of warehouse storage procedures and staff refresher training on load stability requirements.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:20 PM during the evening shift, injection molding operator Bruno Landry (EMP-00083) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D when his right hand came into contact with a mold that had not cooled sufficiently after the last production cycle. The mold temperature exceeded safe handling limits (approximately 95°C), resulting in second-degree thermal burns across the palm and three fingers. Landry immediately immersed his hand in cool water and reported the injury to his supervisor. First aid was administered on-site, and Landry was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital in Montreal for treatment. Medical evaluation confirmed partial-thickness burns requiring wound care, topical antibiotic application, and pain management. Landry was placed on restricted duty for 10 days. Investigation revealed that the mold cooling cycle had been interrupted due to a faulty temperature sensor that failed to trigger the cooling sequence. The sensor malfunction was not detected during the pre-shift equipment checklist.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, CNC machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was performing mold maintenance in the Maintenance Workshop when he noticed an electrical spark originating from a faulty connection on a CNC milling machine control panel. Sokolov immediately ceased work on the machine and moved away from the equipment. He then notified hydraulic systems technician Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), who was also working the night shift, to cordon off the area. Popov placed caution tape and a warning sign around the machine and contacted the electrical and instrumentation shop supervisor through the facility radio. The faulty connection involved a 240-volt power supply line that had become partially loose due to vibration from the machine's operation. No personnel made direct contact with the electrical hazard, and no injury occurred. The situation was stabilized within 15 minutes of detection. Investigation determined that the monthly electrical equipment inspection had been completed 3 weeks prior but failed to identify the loose connection due to incomplete visual assessment protocol. The machine remained out of service for 4 hours pending corrective maintenance.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, assembly operator Aaliyah Jackson was working at Station 3 in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) during the day shift. She was manually removing completed composite parts from packaging and stacking them on pallets for shipping. While lifting a 12 kg bundle of medical-grade connectors, she felt a sharp pain in her lower back. The bundle slipped from her hands and fell approximately 0.5 meters to the floor, causing minor damage to three units in the bundle. Jackson immediately reported the incident to supervisor Michael Chen. She experienced acute lower back strain with muscle spasms. First aid was administered on-site by the HSE team, including ice application, rest, and over-the-counter pain relief. She was able to continue working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. The root cause was identified as improper lifting technique combined with the heavy weight of bundles and lack of mechanical lifting aids at the packing station.

On March 18, 2024 at 23:15, during the night shift, maintenance technician Fernand Giguère was performing routine hydraulic fluid top-up on Injection Molding Machine Line D in the Main Production Building. While unscrewing the hydraulic reservoir cap with a wrench, the cap suddenly released under residual system pressure. Approximately 2.5 liters of hydraulic fluid sprayed across the work area, coating the floor, nearby equipment, and Giguère's work boots and lower leg. The fluid pooled on the concrete floor creating a significant slip hazard. Giguère immediately notified the night shift supervisor Rémi Charbonneau. No personnel injuries occurred, but the hydraulic fluid spillage caused visible damage to the epoxy floor coating in a 3 square meter area and contaminated approximately 45 kg of regrind plastic material stored in open bins nearby. Cleanup required 90 minutes. Root cause was a faulty pressure relief valve that failed to maintain proper pressure bleed-off during system shutdown. The damaged floor coating will require refinishing.

On March 22, 2024 at 09:30, regrind technician Oscar Ramirez was operating the plastic regrind mill in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) during the day shift. While monitoring material flow through the grinder, he noticed reduced output and manually reached toward the feed hopper to check for blockages without first powering down the equipment or engaging the lockout device. His right hand contacted the rotating auger screw, causing laceration to his index and middle fingers. Ramirez immediately withdrew his hand and applied pressure with his left hand. Emergency response team leader Johanne Paquette arrived within 2 minutes and provided immediate first aid, cleaning the wounds and applying sterile dressings with antibiotic ointment. The lacerations were superficial, approximately 2-3 cm long on the dorsal surface, not requiring stitches. Ramirez received tetanus prophylaxis and was released to continue work with hand wrapping and modified duties. The incident was witnessed by materials handler Nicole Proulx. Root cause analysis identified failure to follow lockout/tagout procedure and inadequate guards on the auger feed section.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:15 PM, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, experienced a burn injury while removing finished parts from a mold cavity. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C. While performing the repetitive task of extracting molded automotive dashboard components, Yasmin's gloved hand made direct contact with the hot mold surface when she reached into the cavity to dislodge a part that appeared to be sticking. The contact lasted approximately 3 seconds before she withdrew her hand. She immediately reported soreness and redness to her forearm. Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), her line partner, witnessed the incident and alerted the line supervisor. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), the Occupational Health Nurse, was called to the production floor within 5 minutes. Initial assessment revealed a first-degree thermal burn across approximately 8 square centimeters of the forearm. The employee was treated with cool water irrigation and topical burn ointment. She was able to continue working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift, with pain management support. The incident was caused by inadequate thermal protection in the current PPE and lack of ergonomic tool provision for part extraction.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator, sustained a crushing injury to his left hand while operating a custom composite compression mold press. The incident occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) while Bernard was monitoring the press cycle for a medical device housing component. During the mold closing sequence, which was automated but required periodic manual repositioning of prepreg material, Bernard's hand remained partially within the mold cavity. The press descended with 150 tons of force, crushing his hand between the upper and lower mold platens. The emergency stop button was not within immediate reach due to poor workstation ergonomics. Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), working nearby, heard Bernard's cry and immediately activated the facility emergency stop, halting the press within 2 seconds. Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), the Composite Materials Operator, called emergency services. Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, arrived and secured the equipment. Bernard was transported to the hospital with suspected hand fractures, lacerations, and crushing injuries. He required surgery and spent two nights in hospital for observation and pain management.

On March 28, 2024 at 5:20 AM during the night shift, Claude Rioux (EMP-00185), the Electrical Maintenance Lead, discovered a critical ventilation system failure in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) while conducting routine equipment inspections. The main exhaust fan motor had seized during overnight operations, likely due to bearing failure from inadequate lubrication. The fan had not been operating for an estimated 3-4 hours, during which chemical fume levels had accumulated significantly. Air quality sensors in the room registered volatile organic compound (VOC) concentrations at 320 ppm, exceeding the facility's 150 ppm alert threshold by 113%. The failure occurred without any alarm activation because the system's sensor-to-alarm integration had not been maintained. Claude immediately identified the hazard and manually shut down all chemical processing in the room. He initiated the facility's ventilation emergency protocol and notified Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) of potential exposure risk. Air monitoring was conducted for the next 90 minutes until the backup ventilation system was brought fully online and VOC levels declined to 85 ppm. No employees reported symptoms, as the room had been unoccupied during the critical period. However, if processing had continued with workers present, significant health risks could have resulted.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a fire originated in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) due to spontaneous combustion of improperly stored epoxy resin-saturated cloth waste. Employee Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was conducting material inventory when she noticed smoke emanating from a storage cabinet in the west corner of the facility. The cabinet, which had been storing composite waste materials for approximately 8 days without proper ventilation or chemical segregation, had reached critical temperature due to exothermic curing reactions. Ndiaye immediately activated the nearest fire alarm and evacuated the area. The facility's automatic sprinkler system engaged within 90 seconds, preventing the fire from spreading to adjacent injection molding equipment. However, the cabinet contents were completely destroyed, causing approximately $32,000 in material loss. The fire department arrived within 12 minutes and confirmed the incident was contained. No personnel were injured, but the incident exposed critical gaps in chemical waste storage procedures and ventilation protocols in the composite processing area.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, Assembly Operator Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134) sustained a laceration injury while processing finished parts on Injection Molding Line D. El Amrani was removing components from the molding press and inspecting them for quality when her right index finger came into contact with a sharp edge burr on a plastic part. The burr, approximately 2mm in length, was located on the interior corner of a consumer packaging component that had not been deburred during post-processing. The laceration was approximately 1.5 inches long on the interior surface of her right index finger, with moderate bleeding. El Amrani immediately reported the injury to her supervisor Eric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who provided first aid with antiseptic wash and sterile bandaging. The injury was evaluated by the on-site health services coordinator and determined to require sutures. El Amrani was transported to a local urgent care facility where she received 6 sutures. She returned to modified duty (non-handling inspection work) the following day and full duty within 5 days. Root cause analysis determined that the deburring stage had been skipped on this production batch due to equipment maintenance scheduling conflicts.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during evening shift operations, Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) suffered a crush injury to her left hand while working in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025). Iqbal was retrieving hydraulic pump components from the mezzanine storage area when the wooden pallet beneath a stack of metal fabrication supplies suddenly shifted. The approximately 150-pound stack of steel plates and injection mold components collapsed, pinning her left hand and wrist between the pallet edge and the concrete floor. Iqbal immediately called for assistance, and Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) and Maintenance Manager Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006) responded within 45 seconds. They carefully lifted the materials to free her hand. Iqbal experienced severe pain, swelling, and visible bruising. She was transported via ambulance to Laval General Hospital where X-rays revealed a non-displaced fracture of the fourth and fifth metacarpal bones and significant soft tissue damage to her left hand. She was placed on modified duty effective immediately and remained off work for 12 days before returning to light-duty assignments. The incident was classified as a lost-time injury with 12 calendar days of lost work time.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a significant burn injury while performing routine mold maintenance. Sofia was manually cleaning a mold cavity on an injection molding machine that had been shut down but not properly cooled. The mold surface temperature was approximately 140°C. While wiping the internal mold surface with a cloth to remove residual resin, she accidentally made direct contact with a heated mold insert, resulting in a second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 8 cm² on her right palm and inner wrist. The incident occurred because the mold cooling time was inadequate—standard procedure required 30 minutes cooling time, but Sofia began work after only 12 minutes due to production pressure. She immediately withdrew her hand and ran to the emergency eye wash/safety shower station. Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), working nearby on the same line, witnessed the incident and alerted the supervisor. First aid was administered by the site nurse, and Sofia was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé for assessment and treatment. She was unable to return to work for 14 days, resulting in lost-time injury status. Root cause analysis identified inadequate cooling time enforcement and lack of temperature warning labels on equipment.

On February 28, 2024, at 4:15 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was performing routine inventory verification in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) when she observed an unusual odor and visible moisture condensation on the interior walls of the drying chamber used for polypropylene resin preparation. The dryer had been operating continuously for 18 hours. Upon closer inspection, she noticed the temperature display was malfunctioning, showing inconsistent readings. Mariam immediately ceased operations and informed Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), the Warehouse Supervisor for the evening shift. Upon investigation, the dryer's internal thermostat had failed, causing the chamber temperature to exceed 95°C—significantly above the optimal 60-70°C range for resin storage. This elevated temperature had begun degrading the resin quality and creating excessive moisture absorption. Material worth approximately $18,000 was at risk of becoming unsuitable for production use. The drying chamber ventilation system was also operating at reduced capacity. This preventive declaration was made to prevent potential production delays, material waste, and subsequent quality issues in finished products. No personnel were exposed to hazardous conditions, but the equipment failure created operational risk.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was transferring raw polypropylene resin from a bulk storage silo into a pre-measured container using an automated dispensing system in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. After completing the transfer, she manually repositioned the collection container to clear space for the next batch. While lifting the approximately 45-kilogram container of resin, her grip slipped momentarily. She attempted to catch it, but the asymmetric load shifted during the lift, forcing her to extend her spine and rotate her torso excessively. She immediately felt sharp pain in her lower back region and was unable to maintain upright posture. Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), the Chemical Mixing Operator working nearby, heard Sana cry out and came to assist. Sana was able to walk slowly to the first aid station with support, where she reported significant pain in the L4-L5 region of her lumbar spine. She was evaluated by the occupational health nurse and advised to seek medical imaging. A subsequent MRI revealed a minor disc bulge and muscle strain. She was prescribed rest and physical therapy and returned to modified duties after 3 days. This incident was classified as a non-lost-time recordable injury but with significant ergonomic implications. Root cause analysis identified inadequate engineering for manual handling and insufficient worker awareness of proper lifting mechanics.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift, Omar Said (EMP-00122), a Production Operator, was conducting routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Production Operations area. While removing a stuck mold cavity insert using a pry bar, the hydraulic pressure relief valve suddenly activated unexpectedly. A burst of pressurized hydraulic fluid at approximately 180°C sprayed across Omar's right forearm and hand, causing immediate severe thermal and chemical burns. The incident occurred because the machine had not been properly locked out and tagged out before maintenance began, and the relief valve had accumulated internal debris reducing its pressure threshold. Omar immediately immersed his arm in cool water and alerted nearby colleagues. First responders from the on-site medical station provided immediate burn treatment and transportation to Laval Hospital's emergency department. Omar sustained second-degree burns covering approximately 15% of his forearm and required overnight hospitalization for fluid management and burn care. The incident was witnessed by Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), a Material Handler, who was working nearby.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:30 AM during day shift, Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), Fire Safety Coordinator, conducted a routine inspection of the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011) adjacent to the Chemical Storage Building. During her quarterly compliance review, Sanaa discovered that the emergency exit door (marked as primary evacuation route for this zone) had been partially blocked by storage pallets containing empty solvent containers awaiting disposal. The blockage reduced the effective door opening to approximately 24 inches, below the CNESST-required minimum of 32 inches. Additionally, Sanaa found that the emergency lighting fixture above the exit had burned out, making the exit pathway difficult to locate in low-light conditions. The pallets had been stored there by the materials team over the past two weeks during a temporary reorganization, but no one had notified the HSE department. This represents a potential violation of the Regulation respecting occupational health and safety. Sanaa immediately documented the conditions photographically, secured the area with warning tape, and notified the Materials Management supervisor to relocate the pallets.

On March 28, 2024, at 11:15 PM during night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), Machine Setter on Night Shift, was working in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013) preparing tooling for the next production run. While cleaning excess epoxy resin from a composite mold using acetone-based solvent, Louis began experiencing dizziness, mild headache, and throat irritation. He had been working in the tool room for approximately 45 minutes with the exhaust ventilation system running at reduced capacity (the night shift maintenance team had not yet completed repairs from the previous day's filter replacement). Louis notified his supervisor Richard Beaulieu (EMP-00043) about his symptoms. Richard immediately moved Louis to the outdoor fresh-air area and provided bottled water. After 20 minutes of fresh air exposure, Louis's symptoms subsided significantly. Richard contacted the on-site first aid station, and Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026), a Quality Inspector who is certified in first aid, evaluated Louis and confirmed the symptoms were consistent with mild solvent vapor inhalation. No hospitalization was required. The incident was documented as a first-aid case with occupational health follow-up recommended.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) was working at the Assembly and Finishing Department removing finished composite components from a semi-automated trimming station. She was manually extracting a large polycarbonate housing unit when her left hand came into contact with a partially retracted pneumatic clamp that suddenly activated without warning. The clamp mechanism, which should have been fully disengaged during parts removal, compressed her hand between the component and the metal frame, causing significant crushing injuries to her fingers. A coworker immediately called for first aid response. Ms. Jackson was treated on-site for severe contusions and swelling, then transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where X-rays revealed fractures to her 4th and 5th metacarpals. The immediate cause was a malfunctioning solenoid valve that failed to maintain the deactivation state during the manual extraction phase. Investigation revealed the pneumatic system had not been serviced in 18 months despite manufacturer recommendations for quarterly maintenance.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, inventory control specialist Nicole Proulx (EMP-00093) was supervising material handling operations in the Warehouse and Shipping receiving area. Material handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was positioning an electric forklift to stack pallets of raw polypropylene resin when the forklift operator misjudged the load weight distribution on one pallet. As the load was lifted approximately 8 feet high on the storage rack, the left fork began to bend under pressure. The pallet suddenly shifted and the entire load of approximately 2,400 pounds of bagged resin cascaded off the rack, with packages striking the concrete floor and several impacting a nearby empty cardboard recycling bin, which was punctured and damaged. Fortunately, no personnel were directly struck, but Ms. Proulx quickly moved to a safe distance and called maintenance. The collision resulted in significant damage to the recycling bin (dented, one side compromised) and approximately $4,800 in damaged resin product requiring disposal. Post-incident inspection revealed the forklift's load capacity indicator light was not functioning properly, and the operator had not visually verified safe stacking height before the lift.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 5:30 AM during the night shift, composite materials operator Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174) was processing a batch of glass fiber-reinforced nylon components in the Composite Materials Processing Area. She was manually repositioning partially cured parts on a conveyor line when she felt a sharp, sudden pain in her right palm. Upon inspection, she discovered a deep laceration approximately 2 inches long with active bleeding from contact with a burr edge on a freshly molded component. The part had sharp flash (excess plastic) extending from the mold line that had not been properly de-flashed during post-processing. First aid personnel applied pressure dressing and cleaned the wound, which required 8 stitches at the on-site clinic. The incident was witnessed by night shift supervisor who noted that the de-flashing station had been offline for maintenance, and parts were being manually processed without the standard tool protection. Ms. Sokolova's injury was classified as a lost-time incident due to inability to perform duties requiring hand grip for the next 5 days.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a thermal burn while performing routine material changeover. Zaidi was loading fresh ABS resin pellets into the hopper of a 250-ton injection molding machine when he inadvertently made contact with the heated barrel of the machine, which was operating at 230°C. The operator's gloved left hand brushed against the exposed heating element on the machine's side while reaching to adjust the feed rate. The contact resulted in a second-degree burn covering approximately 8 cm² of his palm and inner wrist. Zaidi immediately removed his hand and notified his line supervisor, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045). First aid was administered at the facility's medical station, and the burn was treated with cooling water and sterile dressing. The employee was transferred to a local hospital for further evaluation and was released with outpatient care instructions. The incident was witnessed by Céline Morin (EMP-00153), who was operating the adjacent Line A machine. Root cause investigation revealed that the machine's heat shroud had been partially removed during a previous maintenance session and was never reinstalled, leaving the heating element exposed in violation of machine guarding protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Mohamed Ibrahim (EMP-00034), a Regrind Operator working in the Regrind and Recycling Department, experienced a chemical splash incident while transferring acetone-based cleaning solvent from a 55-gallon drum to a 5-gallon working container. Ibrahim was positioned at the chemical transfer station in UNIT-018 when a forklift operated by an evening shift associate created vibrations by driving past approximately 3 meters away. The vibration caused the 55-gallon drum (which was improperly secured on a wheeled cart) to shift suddenly, striking a metal support beam. The impact jarred the drum and caused approximately 500 mL of acetone solvent to splash out, with approximately 200 mL making direct contact with Ibrahim's face and upper torso before he could react. The employee immediately experienced burning sensations in both eyes and on his exposed neck and upper chest. He flushed his face with water from the emergency eyewash station for 15 minutes as per protocol. Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), the EHS Coordinator, was notified and responded to the scene. Ibrahim was transported to the hospital emergency department for evaluation of chemical eye exposure. Hospital examination revealed mild chemical conjunctivitis in both eyes with no permanent damage. The employee received prescribed eye drops and was cleared to return to work the following day with restrictions on close chemical work for 48 hours. Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100), an Automation Technician who witnessed the incident from across the warehouse, reported that the drum had been sitting unsecured on the cart for over an hour before the incident.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during the day shift, Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183), Warehouse Lead for Day Shift, sustained a laceration and minor crush injury to his right hand while manually organizing fiber-reinforced composite material spools on high storage racks in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). Ouellette was attempting to reposition a heavy glass-fiber-reinforced polypropylene (GFRP) spool weighing approximately 18 kg on the third tier of a pallet rack when his grip slipped. As he attempted to catch the falling spool, his right hand became trapped between the falling spool and the metal edge of the storage rack below. The spool fell approximately 45 cm before impact. Ouellette immediately withdrew his hand and assessed the injury. He noted a 3 cm laceration on the dorsal surface of his right hand (between thumb and forefinger) and significant bruising across the back of the hand. First aid was administered immediately at the warehouse station by Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), who applied pressure to the laceration with sterile gauze and applied ice. The wound was cleaned with antiseptic and covered with a sterile dressing. After assessment, it was determined the laceration required 4 stitches and Ouellette was transported to a local urgent care facility for closure. He returned to work the same day on restricted duty (no heavy lifting with right hand for one week). Amélie Roy (EMP-00028), Training Coordinator, was on site conducting a safety audit and witnessed the incident. Investigation revealed the spool had been placed on the rack hastily during shift change without proper securing, and the storage system lacked secondary restraints for heavy cylindrical items.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, machine operator Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053) was working at Injection Molding Line A when he noticed excessive plastic buildup around the hopper of the 200-ton molding machine. Following standard procedure, he attempted to clear the blockage using a metal rod while the machine was running in idle mode. However, the hopper suddenly activated unexpectedly due to a faulty proximity sensor, and the rotating auger mechanism engaged, catching Benoit's right hand and pulling it into the hopper opening. His hand became trapped for approximately 8 seconds before a nearby operator, Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058), activated the emergency stop button. Benoit suffered severe lacerations to his palm and fingers, partial loss of two fingertips, and crush injuries requiring emergency hospitalization and surgical intervention. He remained hospitalized for 4 days and was unable to return to work for 6 weeks, resulting in 240 hours of lost time. The incident was reported to CNESST and investigated by the JHSC.

On April 8, 2024, at 9:45 AM during the day shift, material handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was organizing finished composite components in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B) when she accidentally made contact with freshly cured resin-coated surfaces. A small area of exposed skin on her left forearm came into contact with dried epoxy resin containing uncured hardening agent residue. Within 15 minutes, she developed localized itching and mild erythema (redness). Elif immediately reported the contact to her supervisor, Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), who guided her to the first aid station. The site was washed thoroughly with soap and water for 5 minutes, followed by application of antihistamine cream. Elif experienced mild discomfort and slight swelling that resolved within 3 hours without requiring medical attention beyond first aid treatment. She remained at work and continued her duties. The incident was documented in the first aid log and reported to Nina Santos, the Industrial Hygienist, for investigation.

On May 3, 2024, at 10:20 AM during the day shift, quality engineer Daniel Turgeon (EMP-00137) was performing maintenance and cleaning tasks in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop when he stepped on a wet concrete floor near the washout station. His foot slipped on the slick surface, and he fell, catching his right arm under his body to break the fall. He sustained a fractured right wrist (radius fracture) and was taken by ambulance to Hopital de la Cite de la Sante for X-ray confirmation and treatment. The fracture was confirmed and treated with casting and physical therapy referral. Daniel missed 3 weeks of work (120 hours), though he returned to modified light duty after 2 weeks. The incident was witnessed by injection molding setter Robert Fournier (EMP-00067) who called for emergency response. Environmental conditions (wet floor from active cleaning operations) and lack of slip prevention measures were identified as contributing factors.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a fire alarm was activated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT area). An employee, Marwa Saleh (Material Handler), was transferring resin pellets from a bulk storage hopper when the hopper's heating element malfunctioned, causing overheating of the resin dryer. The elevated temperature ignited accumulated plastic dust near the ventilation intake. A wisp of smoke was detected, triggering the facility's fire suppression system and alarm. The alarm sounded throughout the building, and all personnel evacuated to the designated assembly point within 4 minutes. The Laval Fire Department arrived on scene and confirmed a small fire in the dryer's heating element area. They extinguished the fire using dry powder extinguishers and ventilated the space. No injuries occurred. The incident was contained within 15 minutes of alarm activation. Post-incident investigation revealed the heating element thermostat had drifted out of calibration, and dust accumulation around the dryer had not been cleaned in 6 weeks.

On April 2, 2024, at 9:15 AM during the day shift, Celine Morin (Injection Molding Operator - Line A) sustained a laceration injury while performing routine mold maintenance on Injection Molding Line A. She was removing a metal ejector pin assembly from a cooled mold cavity when her right hand slipped, and her index and middle fingers contacted the sharp edge of an internal mold cavity corner. The operator sustained a 2-inch laceration on the dorsal surface of her right hand between the thumb and index finger, with moderate bleeding. Coworker Sana Iqbal (Production Operator) applied pressure with clean gauze and assisted Celine to the first aid station. The Plant Health Services Coordinator, Jamal Thompson, assessed the wound and determined it required professional medical attention. Celine was transported to Laval General Hospital's emergency department via ambulance, where the laceration required 8 stitches and a tetanus booster. She was released the same day with instructions for wound care and light duty restrictions for 5 days. Root cause analysis revealed the mold had not been properly secured in its cooling jig, and no guards were in place on the sharp internal cavity edges.

On May 8, 2024, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Tariq Aziz (Forklift Operator) sustained a significant back injury that resulted in lost-time incident classification. Tariq was transferring pallets of finished automotive components from the production area to the Finished Goods Warehouse. While lifting a particularly heavy pallet (estimated at 850 lbs, above the safe manual handling limit), his lower back experienced acute strain. He felt a sharp pain in his lumbar region and immediately reported the injury to his supervisor. Initial assessment suggested a muscle strain with possible disc involvement. Tariq was transported to Laval General Hospital where imaging confirmed a herniated L4-L5 disc with nerve root compression. He was prescribed bed rest, physical therapy, and anti-inflammatory medication. Tariq was unable to return to work for 18 days and required modified duty for an additional 14 days upon return. Post-incident investigation revealed the pallet weight exceeded documented limits due to a labeling error, and no recent refresher training on proper lifting techniques had been conducted in 8 months.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, production operator Laila Hamdan was removing finished medical device housings from Injection Molding Line D when her right hand made contact with the hot mold release agent residue on a component. The mold had just ejected parts at approximately 80°C. Laila was not wearing the prescribed nitrile gloves due to them being torn earlier in her shift, and she had not reported this to her supervisor. She immediately reported a burning sensation and pain on her palm and fingers. First aid was applied by the line supervisor within 5 minutes. The injury resulted in minor burns with redness and slight blistering on the right palm and two fingers. Laila was treated at the facility first aid station and advised to monitor for infection. The incident was documented at 15:10 by Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette. Contributing factors included inadequate PPE compliance verification, absence of temperature warning labels on the production line, and insufficient refresher training on mold release agent hazards.

On April 2, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Tool and Die Maker Mario Bélisle was performing routine maintenance on the CNC milling machine in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. While changing a routing bit on the machine, Mario's left glove became caught in the rotating spindle despite the machine being in what he believed was a stopped position. The machine had not been properly locked out using the LOTO procedure—the emergency stop was pressed but the machine was not electrically disconnected or mechanically locked. Mario's left middle finger sustained a laceration approximately 2 cm in length on the dorsal surface, requiring 6 stitches. The injury did not result in amputation but caused significant bleeding and required immediate transport to the hospital. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos was notified at 22:35 and completed the incident investigation. Root causes included inadequate LOTO compliance, insufficient verification that equipment was de-energized before maintenance, and lack of supervision during after-hours maintenance activities.

On May 18, 2024 at 03:30 during night shift operations, Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme discovered smoke and visible flames emerging from the Hazardous Waste Management Area adjacent to the chemical storage building. The fire originated in an improperly sealed container of flammable solvent waste that had been accumulating composite material dust over several weeks. The combination of reactive solvent vapors, concentrated dust particles, and inadequate container ventilation created conditions for spontaneous ignition. Warehouse personnel immediately evacuated the area and activated the facility fire alarm at 03:32. The emergency response team and local fire department arrived by 03:47. Firefighters contained the fire within 45 minutes using CO2 extinguishers and foam, preventing spread to adjacent chemical storage. The waste management area suffered approximately 30% damage to storage infrastructure. No personnel were injured, but the incident revealed critical gaps in waste segregation, dust control, and container maintenance procedures. The fire suppression system did not activate because the fire originated in an exterior zone.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, assembly operator Zara Khan was working in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017) removing partially cured composite parts from a batch processing tray. While handling a fiber-reinforced plastic component, she felt a sharp stinging sensation on her left forearm. Upon inspection, she discovered a small laceration approximately 2 cm in length caused by a protruding fiber edge on the workpiece. The cut was superficial but bleeding. Her supervisor, Éric Surprenant, was notified immediately. First aid was administered on-site by the facility's trained first aid responder, including wound cleaning, antibiotic ointment application, and a sterile adhesive bandage. The employee continued working after treatment with no lost time. The incident was attributed to inadequate edge finishing on the composite part and lack of proper handling gloves designed for composite materials work.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, maintenance technician Fernand Giguère was performing preventive maintenance on a large industrial injection molding machine in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). The machine had been scheduled for shutdown and lockout procedures were initiated. However, due to a communication breakdown between Fernand and the evening shift production coordinator, a residual pressure pocket remained in the hydraulic system. As Fernand loosened a connection to inspect the cooling lines, pressurized hydraulic fluid suddenly released, striking his right hand and forearm. The fluid, heated to 65°C, caused thermal burns across approximately 8% of his hand surface area and 12% of his forearm. Fernand immediately immersed the affected area in cool water and sought medical attention at the on-site medical station. First aid treatment included pain management and wound dressing. He was transported to the regional hospital emergency department where the injuries were classified as moderate partial-thickness burns requiring specialized treatment. Lost time injury resulted in 5 days of absence from work.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, tool and die maker Mario Bélisle was transporting a large injection mold cavity (approximately 45 kg) from the Tool Room (UNIT-014) to the main production floor. He was carrying the mold manually on a cart without proper securing straps when the cart encountered a slight depression in the facility floor near the entrance to the Chemical Storage Building (UNIT-010). The mold shifted suddenly and Mario instinctively reached out with both hands to stabilize it, placing his right hand directly between the mold and the cart framework. His hand became pinched, causing immediate sharp pain and visible swelling of his middle and ring fingers. Mario called for assistance from nearby warehouse associate Yvon Croteau, who helped free his hand and accompanied him to the first aid station. X-rays at the medical clinic revealed no fractures, but significant soft tissue contusions and mild ligament strain were diagnosed. Ice was applied, compression wrapping was completed, and anti-inflammatory medication was administered. Mario was placed on modified duty for 3 days with restricted gripping activities. The incident was classified as a near-miss that resulted in minor injury but could have caused serious fracture or amputation if the pressure had been greater or sustained longer.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, a near-miss incident occurred at Injection Molding Line A involving operator Robert Fournier. While performing routine maintenance on the mold assembly, Fournier reached toward a cooling line to adjust a connector without first verifying that the machine's emergency stop had been activated. As he positioned his right hand near the mold cavity, another operator on the adjacent station accidentally bumped the start button on Line A. The mold began to close automatically, and Fournier immediately withdrew his hand, narrowly avoiding a serious crush injury to his fingers. The mold completed its cycle without contact. Colleague Wei Liu, the production scheduler who was observing line efficiency, witnessed the incident and immediately reported it to the shift supervisor. No injury occurred, but the incident revealed a critical gap in lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure compliance. The emergency stop station was functional but had not been engaged as required by protocol before maintenance work began. The incident was logged as a near-miss due to the close proximity to serious hand injury.

On March 22, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, a first-aid incident occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger was conducting a routine inventory of waste containers when he noticed a small polyethylene glycol spill on the floor near the mixing station. While cleaning up the spill with absorbent material, Bélanger's right hand made direct contact with a small amount of undiluted epoxy resin that had remained on a container surface. The chemical caused immediate mild skin irritation and a localized burning sensation on the dorsal surface of his hand. Bélanger immediately reported to the first-aid station where he washed the affected area with copious amounts of water for 15 minutes. After rinsing, the irritation subsided significantly. The incident was treated as a first-aid case requiring only water irrigation and observation. No medical attention beyond first-aid treatment was necessary, and no lost work time occurred. The root cause was inadequate surface cleaning of chemical containers and the absence of a secondary containment verification procedure before handling.

On March 28, 2024, at 11:18 PM during the night shift, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Packaging and Labeling Station. Machine Setter Louis Desbiens was operating the automated labeling equipment when a static electricity discharge ignited cleaning solvent vapors that had accumulated near a heat-shrink packaging tunnel. The spontaneous ignition triggered the facility's fire detection system, which immediately activated the alarm and triggered automatic suppression systems. The small flame was extinguished within seconds by the overhead sprinkler system before spreading. The night shift security team evacuated the facility as per protocol, and the local fire department responded within 12 minutes for confirmation and facility sweep. No injuries occurred, and damage was limited to the affected labeling equipment requiring approximately $3,200 in repairs. The incident investigation revealed that cleaning solvents had been stored too close to the heat tunnel, and static grounding procedures for equipment handling were not being followed. The WHMIS chemical data sheet for the solvent indicated flash point of 22°C, well below ambient facility temperature near the tunnel.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during day shift operations, assembly operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) was removing finished composite parts from the cooling station at Injection Molding Line D when his right hand became caught between a part ejector pin and a freshly molded component. The part temperature was approximately 85°C. Morales attempted to manually extract the part before the cooling cycle completed, a practice that violated established lockout procedures. His hand sustained second-degree thermal burns across the palm and fingers. Coworker Fatima-Zahra El Amrani (EMP-00134) witnessed the incident and immediately called for assistance. Production supervisor responded within 2 minutes and activated first aid protocols. Morales was transported to the on-site medical facility and later transferred to Sacré-Cœur Hospital for specialized burn treatment. Investigation revealed that the automatic ejection system had a sensor malfunction, causing delayed part ejection, which created the pinch point hazard.
