On March 18, 2024, at 10:47 PM during evening shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility when a 200-liter container of epoxy resin hardener (containing 40% diethylamine and 30% 2-methoxyethanol) was knocked over by warehouse associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) while repositioning storage racks. The container had not been properly secured to the storage shelf, violating storage protocols. Approximately 160 liters of the hazardous liquid spilled across the concrete floor, spreading toward the facility's secondary drain system. The spill generated significant vapor release, creating inhalation hazard. Evening shift supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) initiated emergency response: activated ventilation systems, evacuated the area, and deployed absorbent materials. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) was called on-site for hazmat assessment. The spill required 4 hours to contain and cleanup, with the contaminated absorbent materials and rinse water requiring hazardous waste disposal per WHMIS protocols. No personal injury occurred, but the incident resulted in facility closure of the chemical wing for 8 hours and $12,000 in waste disposal costs.

On March 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift operations, maintenance coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) conducted a preventive safety audit of the Regrind and Recycling Department and identified multiple hazards requiring immediate declaration: (1) compressed air system pressure relief valve showing signs of corrosion with erratic pressure gauge readings, (2) missing safety guards on the regrind mill entrance despite documented requirement from 2022 safety assessment, and (3) inadequate ventilation in the material grinding area with visible composite fiber dust accumulation on horizontal surfaces and equipment. Laplante documented that three previous maintenance work orders for these items remained incomplete for 6-8 months. The situation created potential exposure to high-velocity air discharge, rotating machinery entanglement, and respiratory hazards from composite fiber inhalation. No worker was injured, but the conditions represented critical preventive safety concerns. Laplante immediately declared the equipment area as restricted access pending corrective action and notified the JHSC chairman. This preventive declaration triggers mandatory corrective action protocols under ISO 45001 requirements and CNESST compliance obligations.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, machine setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was preparing Injection Molding Line A for a production run of automotive dashboard components. While loading polypropylene resin into the hopper using the automated material handling system, a mechanical jam occurred in the feed mechanism. Karim attempted to clear the blockage by reaching into the partially obstructed hopper opening without properly locking out the equipment. The automated system unexpectedly cycled, causing the hopper auger to engage and catch Karim's left hand. His hand was pulled partially into the rotating mechanism, resulting in a laceration to his palm and crush injury to two fingers. The incident was immediately halted by nearby operator Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), who activated the emergency stop button. Karim was transported via ambulance to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval. Medical assessment revealed deep lacerations requiring 22 stitches and significant tissue bruising. The employee remained hospitalized for 6 hours for observation and infection prevention protocols.

On February 8, 2024, at 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (Unit 015). Material handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was transferring a 200-liter drum of epoxy resin bonding agent from storage to the mixing station using a motorized pallet jack. The drum's securing straps had become loose during transport, and when Amani navigated a 90-degree turn near the chemical mixing room entrance, the drum shifted and fell onto the concrete floor. Approximately 140 liters of epoxy resin spilled across an area of roughly 15 square meters, creating a significant hazardous chemical release. The spill also damaged $34,700 worth of finished composite panel inventory stacked in the adjacent storage zone, with material exposure causing partial curing and product degradation. Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), working nearby, immediately notified Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007). The area was cordoned off, and the spill was contained using absorbent materials and neutralizing agents over approximately 4 hours. No personnel were chemically exposed, and the incident was reported to CNESST as required. The facility's environmental compliance protocols triggered a full facility inspection of chemical storage and handling procedures.

On January 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during night shift operations, maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine servicing of the hydraulic system for Injection Molding Line D in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. While attempting to reach a hydraulic pump connection located approximately 1.8 meters above the ground, Alain was standing on the third rung of a 6-foot aluminum ladder positioned on the concrete production floor. The ladder's rubber feet had become degraded and slippery from exposure to residual plastic pellets and hydraulic oil residue on the floor. As Alain leaned to his left to disconnect a hydraulic coupling, the ladder's base shifted unexpectedly. Alain lost his grip and fell from the ladder, landing on his right side on the concrete floor. He sustained a fracture to his right tibia, a contusion to his right hip, and a sprain to his left shoulder. Emergency medical services responded within 8 minutes. Alain was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur and admitted for overnight observation and orthopedic assessment. Medical imaging confirmed a closed fracture requiring a full-leg immobilization cast and crutches. The incident was classified as a lost-time injury, with Alain unable to return to work for 16 days during initial immobilization and recovery. Supervisor Georges Plante (EMP-00179) was present as responder and initiated incident documentation immediately.

On March 15, 2024, at 10:45 AM, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine material loading when he inadvertently made contact with hot plastic material exiting the nozzle of the injection molding machine. While reaching to adjust the hopper feed mechanism, his left forearm brushed against the discharge area where molten resin at approximately 280°C was flowing. He sustained a thermal burn covering approximately 8% of his forearm and hand. The employee immediately alerted his supervisor and proceeded to the on-site first aid station where initial cold water treatment was applied. The incident occurred because the machine's thermal shield had become misaligned during the previous shift's maintenance work, and the standard operating procedure for checking barrier integrity before shift start was not followed. Witness Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195) from Line A observed the incident and immediately assisted in directing the employee to medical care. The employee received treatment for second-degree burns and was released after 6 hours of observation.

On March 19, 2024, at 11:30 PM during the night shift, an environmental incident was detected in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-020 reporting, UNIT-005 location). Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician, discovered that one of the secondary containment trays beneath the epoxy resin storage tanks was overflowing. Upon investigation, he found that a threaded fitting connection on Tank C-7 had corroded and was leaking approximately 45 liters of two-part epoxy resin directly into the containment tray over an 8-hour period. The tray capacity was only 50 liters, and the overflow had seeped into the floor drain system, which connects to the facility's wastewater treatment area. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, was called immediately and initiated the environmental incident protocol. Testing of the drain system revealed the epoxy contamination had reached the treatment tank, requiring an emergency water treatment intervention and temporary shutdown of the wastewater system. The cause was identified as inadequate corrosion prevention maintenance on storage tank fittings combined with failed weekly tank inspections due to staffing shortage. No personnel injuries occurred, but environmental remediation costs were substantial.

On November 14, 2024, at 10:45 AM during the day shift, Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (currently assigned to evening shift but covering for absent colleague) was preparing Injection Molding Line C for a medical-grade polycarbonate production run in the Main Production Building. While performing her standard pre-shift machine inspection and adjusting the hopper temperature control, Petrov noticed unusual vibration in the injection unit's hydraulic pump and audible grinding noise coming from the motor assembly. She immediately ceased all operations and reported the equipment anomaly to Production Supervisor Michael Chen. Initial visual inspection revealed hydraulic fluid leakage from a deteriorating seal on the pump housing and visible wear on the motor bearings. The equipment had not been formally flagged for maintenance despite these developing issues. Petrov's prompt identification of the problem prevented potential catastrophic equipment failure that could have damaged the injection molding machine, delayed production schedules, and potentially exposed workers to equipment entanglement hazards or sudden pressure release events. The incident demonstrates the critical importance of worker vigilance in identifying equipment degradation before failure occurs. Production Supervisor Chen immediately isolated the machine using LOTO procedures and notified Maintenance Technician Luc Girard to schedule repairs.

On November 18, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the evening shift, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye was operating the automated material drying and preparation system in the Material Drying and Preparation Room when the primary heating element in Resin Dryer Unit #3 began displaying erratic temperature readings on the control panel. Initial readings jumped from the programmed setpoint of 85°C to 127°C in approximately 90 seconds, triggering the equipment's safety alarm system. The operator immediately contacted Evening Shift Supervisor Lucie Fillion, who identified that the temperature sensor calibration had drifted significantly from its required specifications due to lack of scheduled maintenance. The heating element thermostat malfunction created a critical overheat condition that could have thermally degraded the polycarbonate resin material currently being processed, contaminating an entire batch valued at approximately $28,000, and potentially causing equipment fire. Additionally, the malfunctioning heating element posed a burn hazard to personnel if the external housing had been touched. Supervisor Fillion immediately shut down the dryer system using emergency stop procedures and isolated it from the circuit breaker. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard was called to diagnose the sensor failure and verify safe conditions before restart. The incident resulted in a 4-hour production delay and loss of one batch of processed material.

On November 21, 2024, at 11:20 PM during the night shift, Quality Systems Coordinator Sakura Kobayashi discovered a significant chemical spill in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) involving approximately 45 liters of solvent-based resin release agent that had leaked from a damaged container of industrial-grade mold release compound. The spill originated from a 55-liter steel drum stored on the third shelf of a materials rack that had rusted through at its lower seam, likely due to extended exposure to moisture and inadequate storage conditions. The release agent (containing volatile organic compounds and hydrocarbon solvents) pooled across approximately 18 square meters of concrete flooring, creating a significant environmental and health hazard. The spill emitted strong chemical vapors throughout the warehouse area, and the volatile fumes migrated into adjacent administrative areas despite closed doors. Kobayashi immediately activated the facility's chemical spill emergency protocol: she evacuated warehouse personnel, activated local ventilation systems, and notified Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri. Nasri coordinated with maintenance staff and initiated containment procedures including placement of absorbent booms around the perimeter to prevent liquid migration toward floor drains. The night shift supervisor secured the area and initiated air quality monitoring. Remediation required overnight containment, professional hazmat cleanup services, and complete warehouse ventilation cycles. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois filed incident reports with CNESST and documented the environmental exposure.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was working at Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building when she experienced a minor laceration to her left index finger. While removing a finished composite part from the mold cavity, her gloved hand made contact with a sharp edge on the ejector pin assembly. The part had not fully cooled, and the operator was attempting to accelerate the removal process due to production pressure. She sustained a shallow cut approximately 1.5 cm long through the glove into the skin. First aid was administered immediately by the safety officer on duty, including wound cleaning, antibiotic ointment, and a sterile bandage. The injury did not require stitches or off-site medical attention. The operator returned to modified duties within 30 minutes, avoiding tasks requiring fine motor control of the injured hand. Witness Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), also working on Line D, observed the incident and assisted in alerting the safety officer. The incident was documented in the facility's first aid log.

On February 22, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) suffered a significant fall while attempting to access equipment on the upper storage mezzanine in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room. Gravel was retrieving a replacement hydraulic pump (approximately 25 kg) without using the facility's mobile access stairs. Instead, he climbed a 6-foot aluminum ladder that was not rated for overhead work and had a bent rung from a previous incident. As he reached for the pump at the top of his reach, his grip slipped, and he fell approximately 5.5 feet to the concrete floor below. He sustained a fractured right wrist, significant contusions to his right hip and shoulder, and a laceration to his forehead requiring 6 stitches. Emergency responders arrived within 12 minutes, and Gravel was transported to Laval Hospital where he spent 4 days receiving treatment including orthopedic assessment. He subsequently required 18 days away from work for medical care and recovery. The incident occurred during a period when the night shift supervisor was conducting rounds in another building. Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) responded as the first on-scene responder.

On March 8, 2024, at 1:30 PM during the day shift, Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) conducted a routine inspection of the Composite Materials Processing Area and identified a significant accumulation of fiberglass dust on horizontal surfaces, including the tops of equipment enclosures, ventilation ductwork, and storage shelving. Upon further investigation, Anh determined that the secondary dust collection system for the fiberglass trimming operation had been operating at reduced efficiency for approximately 10 days due to a partially clogged filter that maintenance staff had not yet replaced. The dust layer exceeded 3mm depth in several locations, creating both a respiratory hazard for workers in the area and a potential fire hazard per CNESST regulations. Compressed air lines were present in the area, creating additional fire risk if dust were to be disturbed. No active fire or health emergency had occurred, but the conditions represented an imminent danger if left unaddressed. This discovery was made during preventive inspection activities rather than as a result of an incident. Anh immediately documented the findings with photographic evidence and initiated a lockout of the affected trimming equipment to prevent further dust generation.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant ventilation system failure occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018). The facility's main exhaust fan motor bearing seized due to inadequate lubrication maintenance, causing complete shutdown of air handling in this chemical-intensive area. Workers Chiara Bianchi and Amani Mwangi were present, processing reclaimed plastic materials and exposing them to resin fumes in a confined space. Within 15 minutes, both employees began experiencing headaches, dizziness, and respiratory irritation. The accumulation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from the regrind process created unsafe air quality levels. Facility supervisor David O'Connor was alerted and immediately evacuated the area, activating emergency ventilation protocols and calling for medical evaluation. Both workers were assessed by first aid responders and referred to occupational health for monitoring. The incident was declared by Zahra Nasri, Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, after reviewing environmental monitoring data showing VOC concentrations exceeding safe exposure limits for 18 minutes before the secondary ventilation system engaged.

On November 16, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, an injection molding operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) sustained a serious laceration and partial crush injury while performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Line D. The operator was clearing a resin blockage in the hopper area when a colleague, James Thompson, accidentally activated the equipment during manual material purge, not realizing anyone was working inside the accessible cavity. Omar's right hand became caught between the hopper's auger screw and the housing, resulting in a deep laceration across his palm and three fingers, with crush injuries to his ring finger. The equipment ran for approximately 4 seconds before emergency stop procedures were initiated by nearby Production Operator Maya Kumar who heard screaming. Omar was immediately attended to by responders and transported to the hospital where he received 27 stitches and underwent surgical evaluation for potential nerve damage. The incident was declared by Alain Mercier, Ergonomics Specialist, in his capacity as HSE committee member on duty. Root cause analysis identified inadequate lockout/tagout procedures and lack of communication between operators during maintenance activities.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) discovered a critical resin dryer overheating condition in the materials preparation area. While conducting routine temperature monitoring on the composite materials processing line, he found that the dryer's heating element thermostat had failed, causing internal temperatures to exceed 180°C (well above the safe operating limit of 120°C). The equipment's thermal cut-off safety mechanism also malfunctioned, creating a compounding failure. Gravel immediately powered down the unit and initiated an inspection revealing severe oxidation damage to the heating coil and a burned-out temperature sensor. The dryer's control board showed signs of electrical stress from the overheating event. Jacques Lachance, Receiving Clerk, was present in the adjacent material staging area and alerted facility personnel to the burning plastic smell and visible heat distortion around the dryer casing. Claude Rioux, Electrical Maintenance Lead, was called to assess the electrical systems. The incident was declared by Zahra Nasri after reviewing maintenance logs and identifying a pattern of delayed calibration checks on temperature monitoring equipment across multiple production zones.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine material hopper refilling in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While transferring polypropylene resin from a 50 kg bag into the overhead hopper using the manual lifting system, she noticed the hopper's safety interlock was not functioning properly. The interlock, designed to prevent material overflow, had become stuck in the open position due to accumulated resin dust and debris. Desjardins immediately ceased operations and notified her supervisor. The hopper contained approximately 85% of its 200 kg capacity, creating an overflow risk. She isolated the equipment by switching off the conveyor system and placed a wet floor caution sign in the area. Nina Santos (EMP-00084), the Industrial Hygienist, was called to assess the situation. Upon inspection, Santos confirmed the interlock malfunction and determined that had the operator not noticed the issue, a material spill of 30-40 kg would have occurred, creating a slip hazard and potential contamination of adjacent workstations. The equipment was immediately locked out and tagged as out of service pending maintenance. No material was spilled, and no employees were injured. This near-miss was reported within two hours and documented in the safety log.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082), a Material Handler, was retrieving polycarbonate resin bags from the upper shelf of a storage rack in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). The facility uses 6-tier industrial shelving units holding 200 kg bags of raw materials. While reaching for a bag positioned on the fifth tier (approximately 5.5 meters high), Yilmaz used an aluminum ladder that was stored in the work area. The ladder, which had been borrowed from the maintenance workshop earlier that day, had a defective side rail joint that was not immediately visible. As Yilmaz climbed to reach the targeted bag, her weight shifted and the ladder's side rail partially failed, causing her to lose balance. She fell 1.2 meters to the concrete floor below, landing on her left shoulder and arm. Immediate pain and loss of function in her left arm was observed. Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator working nearby, witnessed the fall and immediately called for first aid. Yilmaz was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé in Laval where X-rays confirmed a fractured left clavicle (collarbone) requiring immobilization. She was admitted for 6 hours for pain management and initial treatment, then discharged with a 4-week recovery period and work restrictions. Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), Safety Trainer, initiated the incident investigation within 2 hours.

On January 18, 2025, at approximately 3:20 AM during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter working on the night shift (11 PM - 7:30 AM), was performing mold changeover procedures on Injection Line B in the Main Production Building. During the changeover operation, which involves disconnecting heated hydraulic hoses from the old mold and connecting them to a new mold, Desbiens was required to temporarily work with exposed hot surfaces and pressurized hydraulic systems. The new mold was preheated to 95°C as part of standard setup protocol. While positioning a hydraulic hose connection, Desbiens' right hand made direct contact with an unshielded portion of the mold's heated manifold block, sustaining a second-degree thermal burn across his palm and first three fingers. The contact lasted approximately 2-3 seconds before reflexive withdrawal. Immediate pain and visible blistering developed within minutes. Desbiens immediately reported the injury to his supervisor and proceeded to the on-site first aid station at 3:25 AM. The burn area measured approximately 25 cm² and required professional medical evaluation. He was transported to the emergency department at Hôpital Cité de la Santé, treated for second-degree thermal burns with topical antibiotic and blister care, and prescribed pain medication. Due to hand function impairment, Desbiens was placed on modified duty beginning the following shift, unable to perform machine setup work, assembly operations, or quality inspection tasks. Medical clearance for full duty was estimated at 3-4 weeks pending wound healing and functional assessment. Nina Santos (EMP-00084), Industrial Hygienist, documented the incident and initiated investigation the same morning.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM, Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D in the South Zone, was performing routine mold changeover when his right hand became caught in the closing mechanism of a 250-ton injection molding machine. The machine was in semi-automatic mode, and a safety interlock had been bypassed during maintenance earlier that morning by the maintenance team. Rémi did not realize the interlock was disabled and reached into the mold cavity to clear a plastic residue while the machine cycled. The mold closed suddenly, crushing the dorsal aspect of his hand between the mold plates. His coworker, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159) from Line B, heard the cry and immediately initiated emergency stop procedures. The machine was halted within 3 seconds, but significant soft tissue damage and a compound fracture of the third and fourth metacarpals had occurred. Rémi was transported by ambulance to Hôpital de Laval and required surgical intervention. He was hospitalized for 4 days and placed on full work restrictions for 6 weeks. The incident was triggered by inadequate communication between maintenance and production regarding equipment lockout status, combined with the absence of redundant safety systems.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:30 AM during day shift operations, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator working at Line C in the Medical Components Clean Room Area, sustained a thermal burn to her left forearm while removing a finished component from an active injection mold. The mold surface temperature was approximately 65°C. Sofia had been operating Line C for 3 years and routinely handled warm parts, but on this occasion she was not wearing her required heat-resistant sleeve. The sleeve had been borrowed by another operator the previous day and not returned to her workstation. Upon contact with the mold, she experienced an immediate sharp pain and partial-thickness burn measuring approximately 4cm x 6cm. She immediately reported to the on-site first aid station where Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist with first aid certification, provided initial treatment: cooling with water for 15 minutes, applying sterile gauze, and administering over-the-counter pain relief. After initial assessment, Sofia was released to light duty work for 3 days. The incident was attributable to inadequate PPE management procedures and lack of accountability for safety equipment at individual workstations.

On May 2, 2024, at 11:15 PM during night shift operations, a significant quantity of high-viscosity epoxy resin spilled in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area when a 55-gallon drum being transferred by forklift tilted and ruptured against the corner of an adjacent storage rack. Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), the Crane Operator, was assisting Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler, with repositioning three drums of raw resin when the load shifted. The drum contained approximately 48 gallons of partially cured epoxy valued at $12,400. The resin spread across approximately 120 square feet of the concrete floor, seeping into drainage areas and creating environmental and operational hazards. The facility's spill containment barrier was insufficient, allowing liquid to reach the collection sump. Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), Receiving Clerk working the night shift, discovered the spill during routine rounds and immediately initiated emergency procedures: alerting all personnel, activating containment protocols, and calling for cleanup. Response time was 6 minutes from discovery to full containment. Environmental remediation cost was estimated at $18,600, including specialized cleaning, waste disposal, and regulatory reporting. Root cause analysis determined that the forklift operator did not secure the drum load with proper strapping, and the storage rack was not rated for the weight and positioning of the drums.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during day shift operations, Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, was performing routine maintenance on injection molding machine #7 (250-ton capacity) in the production area. While attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper, Gosselin failed to properly engage the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures before reaching into the machine cavity. A coworker, unaware of the maintenance work, activated the machine remotely from the control panel. The injection cycle engaged suddenly, causing hot plastic material at 290°C to spray onto Gosselin's right forearm and hand. Gosselin sustained second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 12% of his right upper extremity. Emergency response team leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) immediately activated emergency protocols, applied first aid cooling measures, and arranged transport to Laval Hospital emergency department. The employee was hospitalized for 3 days for wound management and pain control. Investigation revealed the LOTO tagout station was missing a critical warning placard, and the employee had not completed LOTO recertification training in 18 months.

On February 8, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift, a fire suppression system malfunction occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), Machine Operator on evening shift, was conducting a routine chemical inventory check when he accidentally bumped the emergency pull-station handle while reaching for stock documentation on a high shelf. The dry chemical suppression system discharged automatically, releasing approximately 80 kilograms of monoammonium polyphosphate powder throughout the 1,200 square-foot storage facility. The discharge lasted 18 seconds and completely obscured visibility. Rahman immediately evacuated the space and triggered the facility alarm via the adjacent fire alarm box. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) coordinated evacuation of the chemical building wing affecting 12 employees. Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, arrived within 8 minutes and assessed the chemical discharge. No injuries occurred, but the accidental discharge contaminated 47 containers of raw plastic resin and required a 4-hour hazmat cleanup operation. Facility maintenance identified the pull-station was mounted only 1.2 meters from a commonly-accessed storage shelf with insufficient clearance and protective guarding.

On April 2, 2024, at 06:30 during night shift preparation, Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087), Facilities Maintenance Technician, conducted a routine preventive hazard assessment in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) as part of TechnoPlast's transition to ISO 45001 safety management system. During this inspection, Marchand identified a significant trip hazard created by multiple compressed air hoses and electrical power cables running across the main aisle between rows of plastic resin storage racks. The hoses lacked proper overhead routing or floor-mounted conduit protection and created a 15-centimeter vertical step hazard. Additionally, Marchand observed that the warehouse lighting had degraded to approximately 150 lux in several sections, below the recommended 300 lux minimum for material handling areas. He noted three near-miss incidents from the past month where forklift operators had swerved to avoid the hose configuration. No injury occurred during this assessment, but Marchand recognized this as a serious preventive priority given the high traffic volume (average 45 forklift movements per shift) and the presence of newly hired material handlers with limited spatial awareness. Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer, was immediately notified and documented this finding for corrective action.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler, was transferring a 50-lb bag of polycarbonate resin from a storage rack in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) to a hopper cart. While reaching up to grab a bag from the third shelf (approximately 6 feet high), the top bag on the stack became unstable due to improper stacking. The bag shifted and fell, striking Osman on the left shoulder and upper arm. The impact caused her to lose balance and fall to the floor, resulting in a fractured left clavicle and significant contusion to the shoulder. She was unable to bear weight on the arm and was immediately assisted by coworker Rashid Habib (EMP-00154). Emergency response was initiated, and Osman was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé where X-rays confirmed the fracture. She required immediate orthopedic intervention and was placed on medical leave for 6 weeks. The incident was witnessed by Jade Wong (EMP-00140), a Process Technician, who was preparing material in the adjacent drying station. Root cause analysis indicated that bags were stacked above the manufacturer's recommended height limit and there were no dividers or restraint systems in place to prevent shifting.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), a Crane Operator, was conducting routine maintenance on the overhead bridge crane in the Warehouse and Shipping area (UNIT-019). While performing lubrication checks on the trolley mechanism, Lavoie noticed that the emergency stop button on the pendant control was becoming unresponsive. He tested the button by pressing it multiple times to verify functionality. During this testing sequence, the button suddenly became stuck in the depressed position, causing the crane to begin an uncontrolled descent with the load hook carrying approximately 300 lbs of finished composite component pallets. Lavoie immediately attempted to restart the crane and reset the control, but was uncertain if the descent was halting safely. He quickly radioed a warning to the area, and Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), a Material Handler, who was staging inventory nearby, recognized the warning and moved away from the drop zone. The load descended and stopped approximately 2 feet above the floor, preventing any equipment or personnel contact. Lavoie secured the crane and documented the malfunction. Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, responded and isolated the crane from electrical service, tagging it out of service pending repair. The near-miss was reported to Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer, who identified the root cause as wear on the emergency stop button contact mechanism and inadequate maintenance intervals for electrical controls.

On April 3, 2024, at 6:20 PM during the evening shift, a chemical storage fire was narrowly averted in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-005). Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter working the night shift transition, was conducting end-of-shift inventory checks and noticed an unusual odor and visible fumes near the mold release agent storage cabinet. Upon closer inspection, he observed that a 5-gallon container of acetone-based solvent had tipped over inside the cabinet, and approximately 2 liters of solvent had spilled onto the concrete floor. The spill had created a thin film that extended approximately 8 feet across the floor toward an active electrical receptacle used by nearby equipment. More critically, the cabinet was stored directly adjacent to the facility's natural gas supply line entry point for the resin mixing equipment. Desbiens immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency alarm at 6:22 PM. Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115), Emergency Response Team Leader, coordinated the response. The facility was partially evacuated as a precaution, and the chemical spill response team (including Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer) isolated the area, ventilated the room using emergency exhaust fans, contained the spill with absorbent material, and removed the damaged container. Laval Fire Department was called and arrived at 6:35 PM to conduct a hazard assessment, confirming that the spill proximity to both electrical systems and gas lines created a significant ignition risk. Fire Department personnel concluded that had the spill contacted the active electrical outlet or had there been an ignition source, a serious fire involving flammable vapors would have resulted, potentially spreading through the chemical storage area. Root cause investigation determined that the cabinet was overcrowded, the container was not properly secured, and the cabinet location adjacent to utility lines violated company safety standards.

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room area. While removing finished polycarbonate surgical instrument housings from the injection mold, her left hand made contact with a hot mold surface that had not cooled to safe handling temperature. The mold temperature was approximately 85°C, causing first-degree burns across her palm and first two fingers. The incident occurred because the cooling cycle had been interrupted due to a hydraulic pressure fluctuation, but the mold was still being cycled. Elena immediately applied cold water from the nearby safety station and reported the injury to her supervisor. Tatiana Volkov, the Assembly Lead for Medical Components, provided first aid treatment and documented the incident. No hospitalization was required, and Elena returned to modified duty after bandaging.

On November 19, 2024 at 8:30 AM, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) was conducting a visual inspection of the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) as part of routine morning safety checks. While walking through the west wing production space, she observed that air hoses and electrical cables from the recent weekend maintenance work were coiled and laid across the main floor walkway near the fiber-reinforced plastic curing station. The hoses and cables created a significant trip hazard that was not present during the previous shift. Fatou documented the hazard with photographs and immediately reported it to Serge Lafleur, the Workplace Safety Representative. Serge initiated a preventive declaration to document the hazard condition and prevent potential injuries before production activities resumed. The cables were repositioned and properly secured to the wall with cable trays within 30 minutes. No employee was injured, but the hazard posed risk to the approximately 8 workers scheduled for the 9:00 AM shift in that area.

On November 21, 2024 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) was operating the overhead crane in the warehouse area to transfer pallets of raw polypropylene resin from the receiving dock to storage racks. At approximately 11:15 PM, while raising a 1,500 kg pallet approximately 3 meters above the warehouse floor, the crane's lifting cable suddenly failed, causing the pallet to fall to the concrete floor with significant force. The pallet split open, scattering approximately 50 kg of polypropylene pellets across a 4-meter radius. Fortunately, no employees were positioned directly below the falling load due to proper exclusion zone practices, preventing serious injury. However, Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), who was on break 8 meters away, heard the crash and came to assess the situation. The incident was immediately reported to the night shift supervisor and Claude Rioux, the Electrical Maintenance Lead, who initiated equipment failure documentation. The crane was immediately taken out of service pending inspection and repairs.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:47 PM, a fire alarm was accidentally triggered in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) during routine inventory management. Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator, was assisting with material organization when he knocked over a cleaning supply container near the fire suppression system control panel. The cleaning solution leaked and made contact with the fire alarm sensor, causing the automatic sprinkler system to discharge. Within seconds, water was spraying throughout the warehouse section containing approximately 8 tons of plastic resin pellets, composite material feedstock, and packaging materials. The accidental discharge lasted approximately 3 minutes before being manually shut down by facility maintenance staff. The incident resulted in significant water damage to approximately 2.3 tons of raw materials valued at approximately $45,000. Response team members Robert Fournier (EMP-00067) and Gaston Picard (EMP-00193) quickly isolated the affected area and relocated undamaged inventory. Emergency procedures were activated, and all personnel safely evacuated the warehouse. No injuries occurred, but the water damage necessitated material disposal and emergency procurement from suppliers.

On April 2, 2024, at 9:15 AM during the day shift, Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), Assembly Operator, sustained a thermal burn injury while working at an assembly station in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005). Ricci was removing finished composite components from a cooling conveyor when she inadvertently made contact with a hot plastic component that had not reached the target cooling temperature. The component, processed through an injection molding cycle, retained residual heat of approximately 185°C (365°F). The contact resulted in a second-degree burn approximately 8 cm × 6 cm on her right forearm between the wrist and elbow. She immediately withdrew her arm and reported the injury to her supervisor, Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015). First aid was administered by the on-site health officer with topical cooling, sterile dressing application, and pain management. The employee was sent to the local medical center for professional assessment and burn care. Investigation revealed that the conveyor cooling cycle had been reduced from standard 45 seconds to 30 seconds due to production schedule pressure, causing components to exit the cooling station at elevated temperatures. The root cause was inadequate communication between production planning and assembly operations regarding cycle time modifications.

On May 8, 2024, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), Injection Molding Technician, sustained a serious finger laceration and partial amputation while performing maintenance on Injection Molding Line C in the Production Operations area (UNIT-005). Ouellet was attempting to clear a material jam in the injection unit's hopper gate mechanism when his left hand became caught between the motorized gate blade and the hopper frame as the machine cycled unexpectedly. The gate, which was supposed to be mechanically locked during maintenance per LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) procedures, was not properly secured due to a missing lock pin. A temporary substitute pin had been installed earlier during the shift by an untrained material handler, who failed to verify the pin's security before leaving the station. The hydraulic gate descended and severed Ouellet's index and middle fingers at the knuckle joint. Immediate response was initiated by Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) and evening shift operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), who stopped the equipment and activated emergency medical services. Ouellet was transported to the regional trauma center where one finger was successfully reattached and one was treated as a partial amputation. Investigation confirmed that the LOTO lock pin replacement procedure had not been followed, and substitute pins of incorrect diameter were being used. This resulted in a 47-day lost-time injury requiring ongoing medical treatment and rehabilitation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, a cooling water system leak occurred in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Maintenance Workshop - Storage Mezzanine). Maintenance technician Dimitri Sokolov was performing routine inspection of hydraulic equipment when he noticed water dripping from a corroded coupling on the main cooling line that feeds the injection molding machines. The coupling had developed micro-fractures due to age and thermal cycling. Within 20 minutes, the leak escalated to approximately 200 liters of coolant mixed with water spreading across the mezzanine floor and dripping to the workshop level below. The spill created a slippery hazard and contaminated several spare parts and equipment boxes stored below. Emergency response was initiated immediately. Johanne Paquette (Emergency Response Team Leader) coordinated containment efforts while the maintenance team shut down the affected cooling circuit. Total estimated property damage included replacement of the coupling ($2,400), disposal of contaminated parts ($1,800), cleanup materials ($600), and lost production time during system flush and restart ($4,200). No employees were injured, but the incident highlighted deficiencies in preventive maintenance scheduling for aging cooling infrastructure.

On April 2, 2024, at 16:20 during the evening shift, Production Operator Omar Said sustained a minor laceration requiring first aid while operating the regrind and recycling equipment in Warehouse Section C. Omar was feeding sorted plastic scrap into the grinding hopper when a piece of composite material became wedged in the feed mechanism. Following standard procedure, he attempted to clear the jam using the manual rake tool while the equipment was still powered (a violation of lockout/tagout protocol). His left hand slipped, and his palm made contact with the rotating grinding blade, resulting in a 3-centimeter laceration across the thenar eminence. The cut was shallow with minimal bleeding. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid provided immediate first aid care: wound irrigation with sterile saline, assessment for tendon/nerve involvement (negative), application of butterfly sutures and sterile dressing, and tetanus status verification. The incident was documented and reported. No lost work time occurred as Omar returned to duty after treatment with modified hand duties for 48 hours. The near-miss revealed gaps in enforcement of LOTO procedures on secondary equipment that operators perceive as low-risk.

On May 8, 2024, at 02:15 during night shift operations, CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov sustained a significant hand laceration in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop while performing mold finish work on a custom automotive component mold. Dimitri was manually deburring a precision edge on a steel mold cavity using a carbide burring tool when the tool caught on a micro-burr and slipped, creating a deep laceration across his right index and middle finger webbing. The cut severed a small superficial artery, resulting in significant blood loss within 90 seconds. Night Supervisor André Paradis applied direct pressure with clean gauze while calling emergency services. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid arrived within 8 minutes and escalated care, applying tourniquent above the wrist and transporting Dimitri to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur de Montréal emergency department via ambulance. The injury required 12 stitches, micro-vascular examination (all structures intact), and exploration for foreign material. Dimitri was released after 6 hours but required 14 days of lost time while the wound healed sufficiently for return to precision work (sutures removed on day 10, graduated return to light duties beginning day 11). Root cause analysis identified inadequate tool ergonomics, fatigue during overnight shift, and absence of mechanical deburring guards on the precision work station.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, suffered a severe thermal burn while performing routine mold maintenance. He was clearing plastic residue from the injection nozzle of the molding machine when the equipment unexpectedly cycled, forcing hot plastic material (operating temperature 220°C) directly onto his left forearm and hand. Despite wearing standard cotton work gloves, the intense heat penetrated the material, causing second-degree burns across approximately 8% of his forearm. The incident occurred during the day shift in UNIT-004 (Injection Molding Line D area). Coworker Céline Morin (EMP-00153) immediately assisted by applying cold water for 15 minutes while emergency response was activated. Mathieu was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur for treatment requiring hospitalization for 5 days, with an estimated 6-week recovery period before returning to full duties. The root cause investigation revealed that the emergency stop button proximity to the work area allowed accidental activation during maintenance, and the lockout/tagout procedure was not properly followed before beginning the maintenance task.

On February 8, 2024 at 22:15, Amara Diop (EMP-00110), a Packaging Operator working the evening shift, sustained a hand laceration and contusion while operating packaging equipment in UNIT-019 (Packaging and Labeling Station). While feeding pre-molded plastic components into the automated labeling system, a mechanical jam occurred when two parts became wedged in the feed mechanism. Following standard procedure, Amara attempted to clear the jam without fully engaging the equipment lockout switch. As she reached into the mechanism to manually separate the parts, the automated feed system unexpectedly resumed operation, causing the metal guide rail to strike her right hand between the thumb and index finger. The impact resulted in a deep 3-inch laceration requiring 7 stitches and moderate contusion with temporary loss of grip strength. Emergency response lead Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) provided first aid within 2 minutes. Root cause analysis revealed the emergency stop mechanism was obscured by packaging boxes stored in the work area, making it difficult for operators to access quickly during jam situations.

On January 22, 2024 at 03:30, during routine night shift maintenance operations in UNIT-015 (Composite Materials Processing Area), a significant chemical spill was discovered by Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194). A storage container of polyester resin (approximately 25 liters) had developed a stress fracture at its base seam, resulting in gradual leakage over an estimated 8-hour period. The spill had accumulated on the floor directly beneath storage shelving, spreading across approximately 12 square meters. The night shift's limited visibility and minimal staffing (only 2 workers) delayed detection. Environmental Health & Safety Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) was immediately notified and declared the incident. The resin pooled near the facility's secondary drainage system, creating concern for soil and groundwater contamination. Approximately 22 liters were recovered and contained within secondary spill trays. The remaining 3 liters had seeped into the concrete flooring, requiring professional remediation. Root cause: the storage container was visibly cracked during the previous day shift inspection but was not flagged for replacement due to understaffing and communication breakdown between day and evening shift supervisors.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, noticed unusual vibration and a slight burning smell emanating from the hydraulic system of the injection molding machine. The machine had been operating continuously for 8 hours without interruption. Claudine immediately alerted her supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) and stopped the machine. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the hydraulic fluid level was critically low due to a slow leak in the pressure hose connection point. The hose clamp securing the connection had partially loosened, allowing pressurized fluid to spray onto the hot manifold block, creating the burning smell. No personnel were directly exposed to the spray, but the situation posed immediate risks of hydraulic fluid burns and potential equipment fire. Samira El-Khoury from HSE was called to document the incident as a preventive declaration before any personnel could be harmed. The machine was taken offline for 6 hours for hose replacement and system pressure testing. This incident was classified as a preventive declaration because the hazard was identified and reported before anyone sustained injury.

On March 18, 2024, at 22:30 during the evening shift, a forklift operated by Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate, was transporting a pallet stack of raw plastic resin bags from the receiving dock toward the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007). The pallet, stacked approximately 7 feet high with 48 bags of polypropylene resin (totaling 2,400 kg), was traveling along the main warehouse aisle. As Marc approached a 90-degree turn, he accelerated slightly to maintain momentum. The load shifted due to inadequate load securing - only 2 out of 4 corner straps were properly fastened, with the upper two straps loose. Three bags from the top of the stack fell onto the concrete floor, bursting open and spilling approximately 45 kg of resin pellets across a 4-meter area. No personnel were within the fall zone, but the spilled material created a slipping hazard and required 3 hours of cleanup by warehouse staff. Material loss was valued at approximately $1,200. The incident was reported to Nadia Belkacem (EMP-00142), the Receiving Coordinator, who documented it as property damage.

On March 22, 2024, at 06:15 during the night shift, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was working in the chemical mixing and resin preparation area. She was manually stirring a 200-liter batch of epoxy resin composite in preparation for the morning production shift. While stirring with a wooden paddle, Rania suddenly felt sharp pain in her left wrist and forearm. Upon immediate examination, a large splinter approximately 8 cm long and 3 mm diameter had penetrated through the glove into the soft tissue of her inner forearm, causing a laceration approximately 4 cm long with moderate bleeding. The wooden stirring paddle had deteriorated over multiple uses without proper maintenance or inspection. Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) applied first aid and called emergency medical services. Rania was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé where she received 6 stitches and tetanus prophylaxis. She was deemed unable to work for 5 days due to pain and risk of infection. The incident resulted in lost time of 40 hours from her regular shift schedule. Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer, documented this as a lost-time incident requiring regulatory reporting to CNESST.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator, was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) removing finished parts from a cooling rack. While handling a polycarbonate medical device housing that had cooled to approximately 60°C, Amal made contact with a sharp edge on the part, causing a 3cm laceration on the palm of the left hand. The cut penetrated superficially but did not reach tendons or major blood vessels. Amal immediately reported the injury to the assembly lead, Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070), who was working nearby. First aid was administered on-site by Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer, who cleaned the wound, applied antibiotic ointment, and dressed it with sterile gauze and medical tape. The employee remained at work and completed the shift with restricted duties. The incident was caused by inadequate part edge finishing and the employee not wearing cut-resistant gloves despite handling materials with known sharp edges. No lost work time occurred, but PPE compliance was identified as deficient.

On November 22, 2024, at 8:45 PM during the evening shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, suffered a second-degree thermal burn to the dorsal surface of his right hand and forearm while transferring hot plastic material from a molding machine to a curing station. The material temperature was approximately 95°C. Youssef had completed his glove change but failed to verify that the replacement glove seals were intact before beginning work. A small tear in the cuff allowed molten plastic residue to contact bare skin, causing burns over an area approximately 4cm x 6cm. The employee immediately removed the glove and ran cold water over the affected area for approximately 3 minutes. Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, who was performing evening maintenance nearby, responded and provided first aid including continued cooling and covering with a clean cloth. Youssef was transported to the local urgent care facility for wound assessment and received treatment including pain management and dressing application. He was released with instructions for home care and returned to full duty after 5 days. Root causes included inadequate pre-shift PPE inspection procedures and insufficient training on identifying glove defects.

On November 28, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, a hydraulic system failure occurred on Injection Molding Machine #7 located in the Production Operations area, causing the machine to cease functioning. François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105), the Maintenance Supervisor, and his night shift maintenance team discovered during routine inspection that the hydraulic pressure gauge had failed, masking a critical pressure drop. Investigation revealed that the main hydraulic pump seal had degraded and ruptured, spraying approximately 40 liters of hydraulic oil onto the machine bed and surrounding floor area. The contaminated oil dripped onto electrical components and created a significant slip hazard. The machine remained inoperable for approximately 18 hours while the hydraulic system was drained, the pump seal replaced, the system flushed, all components cleaned, and the system repressurized and tested. Production of automotive dashboard components scheduled for the next day was delayed, impacting two customer orders. The incident resulted in approximately $28,000 in lost production revenue, $12,000 in replacement parts and disposal costs, and 24 technician hours for repairs. Root cause analysis identified that the hydraulic system had not been serviced according to the manufacturer's recommended 2,000-hour maintenance interval; records showed the last service was 2,800 hours prior.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a dust accumulation fire hazard incident occurred in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit (UNIT-017). Operator James Thompson (EMP-00029) was performing routine maintenance on an industrial oven used for curing composite materials. During cleaning operations, he discovered significant plastic dust and resin particle buildup on horizontal surfaces near the oven's heating elements. The dust layer, approximately 3-5 mm thick, had accumulated over several weeks due to inadequate ventilation maintenance. While Thompson was removing the dust with compressed air, a static discharge from his work glove ignited the accumulated particles, causing a small flash fire within the oven chamber. The fire triggered the facility's fire alarm system at 2:47 PM. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) immediately activated the emergency protocol, evacuating the south zone and deploying the ABC fire extinguisher. The fire was contained within 90 seconds and extinguished completely. No personnel injuries occurred. Root cause analysis determined that the oven's internal collection system had partially failed, and the preventive maintenance schedule for dust removal had been extended beyond safe intervals due to production pressure.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift operations, an inhalation injury incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-005). CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120) was preparing material for the morning production run by mixing a batch of epoxy resin with hardener in the chemical mixing station. Due to a mechanical malfunction in the ventilation extraction hood that had gone undetected, the hood was operating at only 35% capacity instead of the required 95% airflow. As Sokolov mixed the two-component epoxy system, volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors accumulated in the breathing zone rather than being extracted. After approximately 8 minutes of mixing operations, Sokolov began experiencing dizziness, headache, and mild respiratory irritation. He immediately ceased operations and exited the chemical area, moving to fresh air. Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039), conducting routine equipment rounds, found Sokolov sitting outside the chemical area and immediately notified Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052). Al-Rashid assessed Sokolov and determined he had acute inhalation exposure requiring observation. Sokolov was sent to the occupational health clinic for monitoring over 4 hours. Blood oxygen and respiratory function returned to normal within 6 hours. Root cause: the ventilation hood's motor had developed a bearing issue that gradually reduced airflow, but this condition had not been caught during the preventive maintenance cycle due to inadequate monitoring protocols. The hood's airflow indicator had been disabled for six weeks pending repair.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:30 during the day shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Nathalie Dubois, Environmental Compliance Specialist, was conducting a routine inventory check when she discovered that a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin had developed a slow leak at the base, likely caused by corrosion of the drum's steel bottom. Approximately 8-10 gallons of epoxy resin had accumulated on the concrete floor around the drum, creating a slippery hazard. The resin was beginning to emit strong fumes in the confined space. Nathalie immediately notified facility management and evacuated the area. She activated the spill response protocol, placed absorbent materials around the spill perimeter, and ensured adequate ventilation by opening emergency exhaust vents. Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher responded and assisted in containing the spill with additional absorbent material. The incident was contained within 45 minutes, and the affected area was cleaned and decontaminated. No employees came into direct contact with the spill, but three workers in adjacent areas reported respiratory irritation from resin fumes that dissipated after ventilation improvements.

On April 22, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Tomas Jimenez, Machine Setter on Line B, suffered a lost-time injury while performing maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #14 in the Main Production Building. Tomas was troubleshooting a temperature control malfunction on the machine's heating system when he did not follow proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedures. While examining the heating element compartment with the machine in a partially powered state, another operator activated a remote control panel to run a diagnostic cycle. The machine's hydraulic-assisted clamp suddenly closed, catching Tomas's left hand between the mold and the fixed frame. He sustained a crush injury to his hand with multiple contusions and a fracture to his fourth metacarpal bone. Tomas immediately called for help, and first aid responders Marcel Duchesne and facility staff quickly released him from the equipment. He was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur by ambulance and admitted for overnight observation and orthopedic treatment. Due to the severity of the hand fracture and pain management requirements, Tomas was placed on medical leave for 21 days, constituting a lost-time injury. Root cause analysis revealed failure to isolate energy sources and inadequate communication between maintenance and operations personnel.

On May 8, 2024 at 09:45 during the day shift, an injury incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). Salma Haddad, Material Handler, was retrieving stacked plastic component bins from an upper shelf approximately 6 feet high using a wheeled ladder when she lost her footing while reaching for a bin at an awkward angle. She fell backward approximately 4-5 feet to the concrete warehouse floor, landing on her lower back and right hip. Salma remained on the ground, experiencing acute pain in her lumbar region. Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert, who was nearby organizing pallets, immediately called for first aid assistance. First responders provided initial care and determined that while there was no suspected fracture, Salma had suffered a significant soft tissue injury and acute lower back strain. She was transported to a local clinic for evaluation via company vehicle and was examined by an occupational health physician. The physician determined that Salma would require 7 days of restricted duty with no heavy lifting, materials handling, or climbing. She returned to modified duty work on day 8, making this a recordable injury with restricted work activity. The incident was attributed to inadequate ladder stability, awkward reaching posture, and inadequate fall protection measures in the warehouse.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during day shift operations, François Gagnon (EMP-00008), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a minor thermal burn to his right hand while removing a finished component from the mold. The part had been ejected at approximately 85°C, and despite wearing standard heat-resistant gloves, hot plastic residue contacted his index and middle finger when he attempted to trim a small flash from the part edge. The employee immediately submerged his hand in cool water at the nearby wash station and reported the injury to his supervisor, Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030). First aid was administered on-site by the facilities manager, Gérard Gosselin (EMP-00133), consisting of cool water irrigation for 10 minutes followed by sterile dressing application. The burn was classified as a superficial first-degree thermal injury affecting approximately 2% of the hand surface. The employee continued work with modified duty for the remainder of the shift. Root cause investigation revealed that the part removal tool had been slightly misaligned due to routine mold wear, causing parts to be ejected at slightly higher temperatures than standard operating parameters.

On April 2, 2024, at 2:15 PM during evening shift operations, a near-miss incident was observed in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) when Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073), Shipping Coordinator, was relocating a pallet of color-concentrate containers stacked approximately 1.8 meters high using an electric forklift. As he maneuvered the pallet near the loading dock entrance, a sudden loss of hydraulic pressure caused the forklift's load clamps to momentarily disengage by approximately 2 centimeters. The pallet shifted visibly but remained on the forks due to the slight upward angle of the platform. Vaillancourt immediately lowered the load to the ground and reported the equipment malfunction to maintenance. Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184), a nearby Production Operator conducting inventory checks, witnessed the incident and served as a secondary observer. No employee was struck, and no containers were damaged. The forklift was immediately taken out of service. Investigation revealed that the hydraulic fluid level was approximately 0.5 liters below minimum specification, likely due to a slow micro-leak in a connection fitting that had not been caught during the previous maintenance cycle scheduled for March 28.

On May 18, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift operations in the Central Maintenance Workshop, Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169), Maintenance Technician, sustained a significant laceration and partial crush injury to his left hand while attempting to clear a blockage in the hydraulic oil filter assembly of a large 300-ton injection molding machine (Machine #18). Giguère was using a rubber mallet to dislodge a stubborn filter cartridge when the pressure relief valve suddenly released residual system pressure. The cartridge ejected forcefully, striking his left hand between the index and middle fingers. The impact caused the cartridge edge to lacerate the web of his hand and crush the soft tissue, resulting in significant bleeding. A co-worker, Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097), who was assisting with the maintenance task, immediately applied direct pressure with clean rags and assisted Giguère to the first aid station. The Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator, Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), responded within 3 minutes and provided advanced first aid, bandaging the wound and elevating the hand. After 15 minutes of observation, it became clear that the injury required professional medical evaluation, and Giguère was transported to the nearby Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé in Laval by company vehicle, accompanied by Caron. Emergency department examination revealed a 4-centimeter laceration requiring 8 stitches, deep tissue bruising, and mild crush syndrome affecting soft tissue viability. The employee was hospitalized for overnight observation and discharged the following morning with a return-to-work restriction of modified duty for 10 days. Root cause analysis identified that the hydraulic system pressure had not been properly relieved before maintenance began; standard LOTO procedures were not fully followed, as the relief valve was depressed manually rather than using the designated pressure bleeding tool.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) was adjusting the mold temperature controller on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building when he inadvertently touched the exposed heating element of the mold. The element was operating at approximately 200°C. Bouazizi sustained a first-degree burn to his right palm approximately 4 cm in diameter. He immediately ran cold water over the affected area for 10 minutes and reported the incident to line supervisor Guillaume Deschamps (EMP-00051). First aid was administered on-site: the wound was cleaned, dried, and covered with a sterile non-adhesive dressing and antibiotic ointment. Ibuprofen was provided for pain management. The employee was able to continue work with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. No hospitalization was required. The root cause was identified as inadequate labeling of hot surfaces and the lack of thermal protective gloves readily available at the workstation. Line D injection molding operator James Thompson (EMP-00029) witnessed the incident and confirmed the sequence of events.

On April 2, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, a lost-time injury occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). Crane operator Gaston Picard (EMP-00193) was positioning an overhead crane to move a pallet of finished composite parts when the spreader bar attachment suddenly failed, causing approximately 600 kg of packaged parts to fall from a height of approximately 3.5 meters onto the concrete floor below. The falling materials struck warehouse worker Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) on the left leg and lower back as he was walking beneath the load to guide it. Rossi suffered a fracture of the left tibia and multiple contusions to the lumbar region. Emergency services were called at 10:32 AM; paramedics arrived at 10:48 AM and transported Rossi to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur in Cartierville. He required hospitalization for 4 days and subsequent surgical intervention. Investigation revealed that the spreader bar had not been inspected for mechanical integrity in 18 months, far exceeding the recommended 6-month inspection interval. Maintenance planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) discovered worn attachment points and metal fatigue during post-incident inspection. The incident was witnessed by quality documentation specialist Gabrielle Levesque (EMP-00095), who was performing inventory in an adjacent section.

On May 28, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, an injury incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. Maintenance technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) was cleaning the exterior of a 200-liter acetone storage tank using a pressure washer when the tank's pressure relief valve, which had been stuck in the partially open position due to crystallized solvent residue, suddenly released pressurized acetone vapor directly onto his face and upper torso. The acetone splashed into both eyes and caused irritation to exposed skin on his neck and forearms. Rossi immediately moved to the eyewash station and flushed both eyes for 15 minutes with water. The affected skin areas were also rinsed with water for 10 minutes. Due to continued eye discomfort and concern about potential corneal involvement, Rossi was transported to the emergency department at Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur by company vehicle at 11:45 PM, arriving at 12:10 AM. Medical evaluation confirmed chemical conjunctivitis in both eyes and mild dermal irritation but no corneal abrasion. He was treated with topical antibiotics and pain management and released after 4 hours. Rossi was unable to return to work for 3 days due to eye sensitivity and pain. The incident was immediately reported to EHS director Marie-Claude Beaumont (EMP-00001). Investigation revealed that the pressure relief valve had not been serviced in over 2 years and chemical storage procedures lacked explicit guidance on safe equipment maintenance during operational conditions.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, during day shift operations in the Injection Molding Line A - Automotive (UNIT-001), machine operator Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was performing routine mold changeover procedures. While removing a hot mold from the injection press without waiting for the mandatory 15-minute cooling period, she accidentally contacted the mold surface with her left forearm. The mold temperature was approximately 180°C. Mariam immediately withdrew her arm and reported the near-miss to her supervisor. She experienced minor redness on her forearm but no blister formation. First aid was administered immediately with cool water irrigation for 3 minutes. The incident was caught before any serious thermal injury occurred due to the brief contact duration. Root cause analysis revealed that the cooling timer alarm had been disabled by maintenance personnel during troubleshooting and was never re-enabled, creating an unsafe condition where operators could not verify proper cooling time.

On November 16, 2024 at 22:15 during evening shift operations in the Assembly and Finishing Department (UNIT-005), assembly lead Tatiana Volkov (EMP-00070) was supervising the manual assembly of medical device housings. Quality Control Technician Léa Parent (EMP-00121) was performing precision finishing work on polycarbonate components using a small CNC milling machine for edge refinement. While clearing plastic shavings from the cutting area without proper lockout/tagout procedures, the machine unexpectedly restarted due to a proximity sensor malfunction. Léa's left index finger contacted the rotating end mill, resulting in a deep laceration across the dorsal surface of the finger and partial damage to the fingernail bed. The machine was immediately emergency stopped by Tatiana. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid provided initial wound care, and Léa was transported to the emergency department for suturing (7 stitches required). The finger remained functional but with temporary sensory loss. Investigation revealed the proximity sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months, far exceeding the manufacturer's 6-month interval.

On November 19, 2024 at 02:30 during night shift operations in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009), material handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was operating a propane-powered forklift to move pallets of finished automotive components from the warehouse to the loading dock for shipment. The night shift typically operates with minimal supervision, with only two material handlers present. While maneuvering in the congested dock area, the forklift's right rear tire caught a loose air hose connected to pneumatic tools near the dock perimeter. The hose wrapped around the tire, and the forklift briefly became unstable. Although Amani quickly stopped and safely dismounted, the incident exposed a serious hazard: the air hose created a trip hazard and potential entanglement point in the high-traffic material handling area. No injury occurred, and the forklift remained upright, but a potential for severe injury or tip-over existed. The root cause was inadequate cable and hose management, with pneumatic equipment lines routed across the active material handling pathway without proper conduit or elevation.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), Quality Inspector, was performing a routine inspection of finished composite parts in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). While examining a batch of cured resin components, she inadvertently splashed a small quantity of uncured epoxy resin onto her left forearm and hand while transferring materials between inspection stations. The resin caused immediate skin irritation and minor contact dermatitis. A colleague immediately directed her to the emergency eyewash/safety shower station where she rinsed the affected area thoroughly with water for 5 minutes. The area was then cleaned with mild soap and water. Hana Al-Rashid, Occupational Health Nurse (EMP-00052), provided basic first aid treatment including application of a topical antibiotic ointment and a sterile gauze bandage. The employee experienced minor redness and localized swelling that resolved within 24 hours with no systemic symptoms. No lost work time occurred. The incident was attributed to inadequate PPE usage - the employee was not wearing the required nitrile gloves and forearm protection when handling uncured materials.

On October 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), Injection Molding Operator on Line A, suffered a laceration to his right hand while removing finished parts from an injection molding machine. The machine was operating at full production speed (cycle time approximately 45 seconds per part).
