After the mold ejected a component, Demers reached into the mold cavity to manually remove a part that had not fully ejected, despite safety protocols requiring waiting for the automatic removal system. His hand became caught between the mold halves as they began closing for the next cycle. The mold pressure, set at 850 PSI, caused a deep laceration approximately 2 inches long across his palm and fingers. He immediately withdrew his hand and activated the emergency stop button. Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143), Crane Operator working nearby, heard his cry and immediately came to assist, applying direct pressure to the wound with clean towels while calling for emergency response. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) arrived within 2 minutes and provided emergency first aid, then arranged immediate transport to the local trauma center where the wound required 12 stitches and exploratory surgery to rule out tendon damage. The injury resulted in 8 days of lost time while the employee recovered.

On December 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during the evening shift, René Caron (EMP-00097), Tool Maker, suffered a significant ladder fall while performing routine maintenance on mold assembly equipment stored on a mezzanine level (approximately 12 feet high) in the Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-011). Caron was ascending a 16-foot aluminum extension ladder to access a mold that required dimensional inspection. The ladder had been positioned on an uneven concrete floor where a small oil spill from earlier maintenance work had created a slippery surface. As Caron reached the eighth rung, his left foot slipped on a contaminated rung, causing him to lose grip with both hands. He fell approximately 6 feet before striking a tool cart on the lower level, then falling an additional 3 feet to the concrete floor. The impact resulted in a fractured left tibia, a compound fracture of the right fibula, and multiple contusions to the torso and left shoulder. François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105), Maintenance Supervisor, heard the crash and immediately called emergency services (911). Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), Safety Officer, arrived at the scene within 5 minutes and provided preliminary assessment while awaiting paramedics. Emergency services transported Caron to the hospital where he underwent emergency surgery for the compound fracture. He was hospitalized for 6 days and released with severe mobility restrictions. Total lost-time injury resulted in 42 days away from work during recovery and rehabilitation.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a fire originated in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT area). Mohamed Ibrahim, Regrind Operator, was transferring acetone-based solvent from a 55-gallon drum into smaller containers for distribution to production lines. While pouring the solvent, he accidentally knocked over a container of partially used cleaning rags soaked in the same solvent near an electrical outlet. The rags ignited when they contacted a faulty space heater that was being used to warm the storage area during cooler weather. The fire spread rapidly across approximately 8 square meters of floor space before Ibrahim used a nearby Class B fire extinguisher to suppress it. The flames were contained within 4 minutes, but not before causing significant damage to the drum storage rack, chemical inventory labeling, and the heating equipment. Two other workers nearby, Olga Ivanova and a temporary contractor, evacuated the area safely. Emergency services arrived within 12 minutes and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. No personal injuries were sustained, but smoke damage affected adjacent areas.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a ventilation system failure was discovered in the Injection Molding Line D - Consumer Packaging production area. Stéphane Couture, Injection Molding Operator on Line C, noticed a significant reduction in air flow and reported the issue to his supervisor. Investigation revealed that the main ventilation duct serving the consumer packaging line had partially collapsed due to inadequate structural support at a junction point, restricting airflow to approximately 30% of normal capacity. The failure occurred gradually over several hours, and production operators had been exposed to elevated concentrations of polymer fumes and styrene vapors without realizing the ventilation was compromised. The area had been operating with substandard air quality for approximately 3.5 hours before detection. Environmental monitoring was immediately conducted, revealing fume concentrations at 85% of the OSHA PEL for styrene. The production line was immediately shut down. Two workers reported mild headaches and throat irritation, consistent with chemical fume exposure. The duct required emergency repair involving temporary support structures and rerouting of ventilation paths. Full system restoration took 18 hours.

On November 22, 2024, at 6:20 AM during the night shift, a material drying equipment malfunction occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Kwame Mensah, Production Operator on night shift, was preparing resin batches for the morning production run when he noticed the resin dryer temperature display showed 185°C, significantly higher than the 160°C programmed setpoint. The heating element control thermostat had failed, causing the dryer to overheat continuously. Upon investigation, it was discovered that condensation and dust accumulation had corroded the thermostat's electrical contacts over the previous 4 weeks due to inadequate ventilation in the equipment storage area. The overheated resin material (approximately 120 kg) began to chemically degrade, releasing acrid fumes of aromatic hydrocarbons and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) into the preparation room. The fumes spread into adjacent areas before being detected. Environmental air sampling detected VOC concentrations 2.3 times the facility's internal exposure limit. Mensah and one maintenance technician (Fernand Giguère) were briefly exposed to elevated VOC levels, experiencing eye irritation and respiratory tract irritation. The contaminated resin batch had to be discarded (material loss: €3,200), and the room underwent emergency ventilation and decontamination. Production start-up was delayed by 4 hours.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 on the day shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, sustained a burn injury while removing a part from a 350-ton injection molding machine. The mold temperature was set to 85°C for the automotive component run. While extracting a finished part using manual tongs, Youssef inadvertently contacted the mold surface with his left forearm, resulting in a thermal burn approximately 8 cm in diameter covering the outer forearm. The employee immediately reported the injury to Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140), who was monitoring the line. First aid was applied onsite by the HSE coordinator with ice water immersion for 15 minutes, followed by sterile dressing application. The employee was then transported to Laval Medical Center for evaluation and received treatment for a partial-thickness thermal burn. The root cause investigation revealed that the employee had not been wearing the required heat-resistant sleeve PPE due to discomfort during a warm afternoon, and the machine's mold temperature warning label had faded, reducing visibility of hazard warnings.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108), a Material Handler in the Regrind and Recycling Department, sustained a laceration to her right hand while processing plastic scrap material. While operating the grinding hopper for regrind preparation, Bianca reached into the material chute to clear a jam caused by bundled polypropylene waste. The rotating screw conveyor suddenly activated (due to a failed lockout procedure by the previous shift operator who had not properly engaged the LOTO mechanism), catching her right hand between the screw and the hopper wall. She sustained a 4 cm laceration on her right palm and minor contusions on fingers 2-4. The employee immediately withdrew her hand and notified her supervisor Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078), who was working nearby. First aid was administered onsite: the wound was thoroughly cleaned, irrigated with sterile saline, and dressed with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. The injury was classified as minor and did not require hospital transport, though tetanus prophylaxis was recommended. The employee completed a full shift with modified duties.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 09:30 during the day shift, Paul Demers (EMP-00103), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, experienced a chemical splash incident while cleaning the hopper of his molding machine with acetone solvent. Paul was performing routine maintenance when a pressurized cleaning container unexpectedly sprayed solvent, resulting in splashing of acetone into his right eye and on his right cheek. The employee immediately flushed his eye at the eyewash station for approximately 3 minutes, then reported to the on-site first aid station. HSE Specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) provided additional eye irrigation using sterile saline solution and applied a clean eye pad. The employee experienced mild eye irritation and redness but no significant pain or vision impairment after irrigation. Celine Morin (EMP-00153), working on an adjacent station, witnessed the incident and assisted in directing Paul to the eyewash station. The employee remained on modified duty for the remainder of the shift and was advised to monitor for delayed symptoms. Investigation revealed the spray bottle's trigger mechanism was faulty, creating pressure buildup.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (EMP-00165), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was performing routine part removal when he noticed the cooling water system on his machine was leaking. Before investigating, he attempted to manually clear a jam in the part ejection mechanism while the machine was still powered but in idle mode. The machine unexpectedly cycled, causing the mold to close rapidly. Stéphane's left hand was caught between the mold plates for approximately 2 seconds before emergency stop was activated by a nearby colleague, Yasmin Ali (EMP-00024). Stéphane experienced significant pain and swelling to his hand but no fractures or lacerations were confirmed. He was able to walk to the first aid station with assistance. The incident was witnessed by Yasmin Ali and quality control technician Sophie Lapointe (EMP-00013). Root cause analysis identified inadequate lockout/tagout (LOTO) compliance and insufficient awareness of the cooling water leak maintenance protocol.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170), a Material Handler, was organizing resin pallets in the Raw Materials Warehouse (UNIT-007) when she accidentally brushed her exposed forearm against a bundle of glass fiber reinforcement material. The sharp fibers penetrated approximately 2 cm into her skin along her inner forearm, causing immediate irritation and minor bleeding. She reported the injury to her supervisor and proceeded to the first aid station where the wound was cleaned with soap and water and covered with an adhesive bandage. Minor inflammation and itching developed over the following 24 hours. The incident was treated on-site by the first aid team and documented. Root cause identified: inadequate PPE compliance—Chiara was wearing short-sleeved shirt rather than required long sleeves when handling glass fiber materials, despite WHMIS training and facility guidelines clearly stating protective clothing requirements.

On March 20, 2024, at approximately 11:10 PM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician, was performing routine belt replacement on a recirculating cooling pump in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While the pump motor had been de-energized per standard procedure, the belt tension release mechanism malfunctioned, suddenly ejecting the old belt with significant force. The belt struck Alain on the shoulder and upper back, causing temporary loss of balance. He fell against a metal equipment frame, causing a 3-inch laceration on his left arm that required 6 stitches at the local hospital. Alain was transported by company vehicle and returned to limited duty the following day. The equipment malfunction was later traced to a corroded tension spring that had weakened over 18 months of operation without replacement. Emergency response was initiated by fellow night shift worker, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), who provided immediate first aid and called emergency services. This represents equipment failure due to inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) was working at Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging unit when she experienced a severe burn injury. While removing a finished part from the mold cavity, a pressure relief valve on the heated mold suddenly released compressed steam due to a failed pressure regulator. The superheated steam and liquid coolant mixture sprayed across her right arm and shoulder, causing second and third-degree burns covering approximately 15% of her upper body. Carmen immediately alerted nearby Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101), who activated emergency protocols and called for immediate first aid. The employee was transported via ambulance to the regional burn center and hospitalized for 5 days requiring skin grafting procedures. Investigation revealed the pressure relief valve had not been serviced in 18 months, exceeding maintenance intervals. The mold cooling system lacked proper pressure monitoring gauges, and employees had not received recent training on pressure system hazards.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the evening shift, Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was preparing a batch of mold release agent in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when a 25-liter container of acetone-based solvent tipped over during transfer from storage shelving. The container was improperly secured and became unstable as Elena reached across adjacent containers. Approximately 18 liters of acetone spilled across the concrete floor, creating a vapor cloud throughout the 8,000 sq ft chemical storage facility. The spill immediately triggered the facility's vapor detection alarm system. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) was on-site conducting a routine audit and immediately initiated containment procedures. The spill was contained within 2 hours using absorbent material and neutralizing agents. All personnel in the chemical storage area and adjacent packaging zone were evacuated. Environmental monitoring detected acetone vapor concentrations at 850 ppm in the immediate area, exceeding the 400 ppm facility threshold. No direct employee exposure resulted, but three employees experienced mild eye irritation during evacuation.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM during the day shift, Lockout/Tagout Coordinator Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161) conducted a routine inspection of the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop as part of TechnoPlast's preventive safety program. While inspecting a CNC milling machine that had recently been serviced, Gaétan discovered that the machine's emergency stop button was unresponsive and the safety interlock on the access gate had been bypassed with a shim inserted in the mechanical latch. The bypass device prevented the gate from properly disengaging the electrical control circuit during maintenance. Further investigation revealed that during a recent repair, maintenance technician Roland Dostie (EMP-00199) had improvised this bypass to expedite equipment restoration without following proper LOTO procedures. Gaétan immediately documented the violation, secured the machine with proper LOTO devices, and reported the findings to Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123). This preventive declaration identified a critical gap in LOTO compliance and potential for a catastrophic machine startup injury. The incident demonstrates that despite existing training, field pressures are leading to unsafe shortcuts in lockout procedures.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was removing finished automotive dashboard components from Molding Machine #12 in UNIT-001. The machine cycle had completed, but the safety interlock gate had malfunctioned and did not fully retract. Sofia, wearing standard nitrile gloves, attempted to manually remove a partially cooled component (approximately 85°C) while the mold was still in a partially closed position. Her left hand became caught between the mold halves as residual hydraulic pressure caused unexpected partial closure. She sustained a crush injury to her hand with partial thickness burns on her palm and fingers. Her screams alerted Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101), who immediately activated the emergency stop and summoned Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052). Sofia was transported to the local hospital with suspected fractures to metacarpal bones and significant soft tissue damage. She required 18 days of hospitalization and subsequent physical therapy, resulting in 42 lost workdays.

On April 2, 2024, at 8:30 PM during the evening shift, Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), a Packaging Operator, sustained a repetitive strain injury while performing her routine duty of manually removing and stacking finished medical device housings at UNIT-017 (Post-Processing and Heat Treatment). Over the course of a 7-hour shift, Lucia repeatedly reached forward and lifted components weighing approximately 2.5 kg each, performing approximately 2,400 lift cycles. She reported sharp pain in her right wrist and forearm around 7:45 PM and immediately notified her supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139). She was seen by Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) at 9:15 PM, who diagnosed acute tendinitis with significant inflammation. X-rays confirmed no fractures but showed soft tissue swelling. Lucia was placed on work restrictions (no repetitive grasping) and prescribed anti-inflammatory medication. She missed 12 working days before returning to modified duty with graduated return-to-work plan.

On May 8, 2024, at 11:15 AM during day shift operations, an environmental incident was discovered in UNIT-011 (Hazardous Waste Management Area). Maintenance Manager Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006) identified a slow drip from the lower seal of a 500-liter storage tank containing spent solvent (trichloroethylene-based mold release agent cleanup solution). The tank, installed in 2008, had developed micro-fractures in its steel exterior lining. Approximately 45 liters of contaminated solution had leaked into the secondary containment basin, but 8-10 liters had escaped through a drain valve that was left partially open during the previous day's inventory check. The leaked material infiltrated approximately 2 cubic meters of soil in the designated hazardous waste storage zone. Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123) was immediately notified and launched environmental response protocols. The area was cordoned off, spill containment materials deployed, and the Quebec Ministry of Environment was notified per CNESST regulations. Soil remediation contractor was engaged for contaminated soil excavation and proper disposal.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area (UNIT-003). While removing finished medical-grade polycarbonate components from the molding press, she made contact with residual mold release agent on a component surface. The agent, a petroleum-based compound, came into direct contact with her right forearm and wrist area despite wearing standard nitrile gloves. Farah immediately experienced skin irritation, erythema, and a burning sensation. She reported the exposure to her supervisor Robert Fournier (EMP-00067) at 2:50 PM. First aid was administered on-site: the affected area was thoroughly washed with soap and water for 15 minutes, followed by application of a topical skin protectant. The irritation subsided within 2 hours. Farah remained on duty. No further medical intervention was required. The incident was documented and reported by Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) at 3:30 PM.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, maintenance technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine preventive maintenance on the hydraulic system of Injection Molding Line A in the main production building. While inspecting the pressure relief valve assembly, a hairline fracture in the valve body—undetected by the previous inspection cycle—suddenly ruptured under operating pressure. Pressurized hydraulic fluid (approximately 2,100 PSI) was suddenly released, spraying across the machine framework and work area. The high-pressure discharge damaged adjacent electrical conduit, safety interlocks, and soaked insulation material. The incident triggered automatic emergency shutdown procedures. CNC Machinist Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120), working nearby, witnessed the failure and immediately notified Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105). The crew identified approximately $47,000 in equipment damage including hydraulic components, electrical wiring, PLC modules, and production line downtime (estimated 36 hours of lost production). The valve manufacturer investigation revealed material fatigue from inadequate heat treatment during manufacturing. The incident was formally documented by Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168).

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift transition period, Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) was performing inventory restocking in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). While retrieving bulk polypropylene resin bags from a high storage rack (approximately 2.1 meters height), he used an improperly secured wooden crate as a makeshift step stool. As he reached for the fifth bag, the crate shifted and collapsed, destabilizing the storage rack above. Approximately 18 bags of PP resin (each weighing 25 kg) fell from the top rack shelf. Croteau attempted to dodge but was struck on the left shoulder and upper back by three falling bags before he could move clear. He fell to the ground and remained there for approximately 30 seconds before recovering enough to sit up. Crane Operator Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), arriving for the morning shift, discovered Croteau and immediately called for assistance. First aid was administered: ice application to the left shoulder, pain assessment, and monitoring. After 90 minutes of observation, Croteau reported residual soreness but no significant functional limitation or neurological symptoms. He was sent home with instructions for follow-up medical evaluation. The incident was formally reported by Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) and documented as a near-miss that resulted in minor musculoskeletal trauma.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak was discovered in the Main Production Building's south zone, specifically in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit. Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel and Machine Setter Louis Desbiens were performing routine temperature monitoring on industrial ovens used for post-curing composite materials when they noticed water pooling beneath equipment and a visible spray emanating from a corroded section of copper piping. The leak had been developing gradually over several weeks due to inadequate preventative maintenance protocols and corrosion from hard water minerals. Within 30 minutes, approximately 200 gallons of cooling water had accumulated on the production floor, creating slip hazards and electrical safety risks near nearby machinery. The area was immediately cordoned off by Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne. Water was diverted using emergency containment barriers, and the leaking section was temporarily sealed pending replacement. The incident resulted in 4 hours of production downtime but no personal injuries. Environmental containment procedures were activated to prevent water contamination of the facility's storm drain system.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Injection Molding Operator Mathieu Gendron suffered a serious crush injury while performing a mold changeover on Injection Molding Line B. Gendron was manually positioning a 400-pound composite mold into the injection press when the hydraulic locking mechanism unexpectedly released due to a faulty pressure sensor that had not been replaced despite being flagged in the previous week's maintenance log. The mold descended rapidly, trapping Gendron's left hand and forearm between the mold and the machine's fixed support frame. His colleague François Gagnon immediately activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. Gendron sustained a compound fracture to his radius and ulna, severe tissue bruising, and laceration requiring 47 stitches. He was transported by ambulance to Hôpital de Laval and hospitalized for 3 days, followed by 6 weeks of medical leave. Root cause analysis determined that the pressure sensor maintenance had been deferred due to parts shortage, and no secondary safety verification system existed. This resulted in a lost-time injury with WSIB claim filed.

On February 22, 2024, at approximately 6:50 AM during the night shift, Material Handler Bianca De Luca was transferring bulk resin containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building when she noticed a pressure relief valve on a 500-gallon polyester resin storage tank beginning to vent a fine mist. De Luca immediately halted her activities and moved to a safe distance, then notified Night Shift Supervisor (not listed in provided roster) who contacted Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel. The relief valve had begun leaking due to crystallized resin buildup on the valve seat, a known issue that occurs when the heating system cycle completes without proper cooldown procedures. Gravel isolated the tank using the secondary containment valve and verified that exposure levels remained below action levels using a portable organic vapor detector. Had the valve completely failed, ambient concentration of styrene and other volatile organic compounds would have exceeded OSHA PEL limits within 15 minutes in the 8,000 square foot chemical storage area. The incident was classified as a near-miss because De Luca's early detection prevented actual worker exposure. Environmental sampling confirmed no release occurred beyond the immediate tank area. The valve was replaced within 2 hours and proper cooldown procedures were reinforced with all shift staff.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift, an electrical fire occurred in the motor control center serving the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie (EMP-00199) was conducting routine equipment inspection when he noticed scorching and smoke emanating from a contactor relay that controls the industrial oven heating elements. The overheating was caused by a corroded electrical connection that had increased resistance, generating heat exceeding 450°C. Roland immediately de-energized the circuit using the main disconnect switch and activated the emergency fire suppression system. Facilities Technician Georges Plante (EMP-00179) evacuated personnel and called the Laval Fire Department. The fire was contained to the motor control center cabinet, but resulted in approximately $127,000 in damage including the contactor assembly, associated wiring, and control circuit board replacement. The cabinet exterior showed significant thermal stress and internal components were damaged beyond repair. No personnel were injured, but the oven remained out of service for 11 days, causing production delays on medical device component contracts.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during night shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Lead operator Samantha Brown (EMP-00146) was conducting routine maintenance on the resin mixing system when she discovered a hairline fracture in the 500-liter polypropylene storage tank containing uncatalyzed epoxy resin. The fracture had developed due to stress concentration at a welded joint combined with thermal cycling. Approximately 180 liters of epoxy resin leaked onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous slick and vapor emissions. Samantha immediately activated the emergency spillage protocol, shutting down the resin feed system and alerting Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) and Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011). The night shift supervisor initiated evacuation of the immediate area due to fume concentration. The spill was contained using absorbent granules and collected in hazardous waste containers. The area was ventilated for 2 hours before re-entry. Disposal of contaminated materials cost $8,600, and remediation cleaning cost $3,200. The incident resulted in 6 hours of production downtime for the composite line.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45 during day shift, assembly operator Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162) was performing part removal from Injection Molding Line B in the Automotive section. While manually extracting cooled plastic components from the mold cavity, Isabella experienced sharp pain in her right wrist and hand. She had been performing repetitive gripping and twisting motions for approximately 4 hours without a break. Upon inspection, slight swelling and redness were noted at the wrist joint. The employee reported the discomfort to her supervisor, Patricia Martin (EMP-00035), who provided ice and recommended acetaminophen. Isabella continued work after a 15-minute rest but experienced ongoing mild pain. She was assessed by the on-site first aid attendant at 15:30 and diagnosed with early-stage repetitive strain from the monotonous part removal task. The incident was documented as a first-aid treatment case with no lost work time. Root cause analysis identified inadequate job rotation and insufficient ergonomic breaks in the assembly process.

On March 18, 2024 at 22:15 during evening shift, forklift operator Claude Poirier (EMP-00071) was transporting a pallet of raw polypropylene resin bags from the warehouse to the Material Drying and Preparation Room. As he navigated through the main production building's narrow corridor, the forklift's left front wheel caught an improperly secured electrical cable running across the floor. The cable momentarily caught under the tire but released without incident. Claude immediately stopped the forklift and inspected both the cable and the equipment. Witnessing the event, production operator Yara Mustafa (EMP-00184) rushed to assist. Upon inspection, the electrical cable showed no visible damage, and the forklift sustained no damage. The cable was part of the new LED lighting installation project that had been ongoing. Claude reported the near-miss to his supervisor, Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who immediately contacted the HSE department. Zahra Nasri conducted a rapid investigation and confirmed no injuries, no equipment damage, and no operational disruption occurred. The cable was immediately rerouted through proper conduit to prevent recurrence.

On March 22, 2024 at 09:30 during day shift, maintenance technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) discovered a significant leak in the chemical storage area while conducting his routine morning inspection of the Regrind and Recycling Department. A 55-gallon drum containing mold release agent (silicone-based, CAS# 63148-62-9) had developed a hairline crack along its base seam, resulting in approximately 12-15 liters of the substance pooling on the concrete floor. The drum was positioned near a floor drain that connects to the facility's industrial waste system. Luc immediately isolated the area by placing orange safety cones around the spill, turned off the floor drain valve to prevent environmental release, and notified Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) of the Environmental Compliance team at 09:35. Nathalie arrived at 09:50 with the spill response kit and hazmat absorbent materials. The team used approximately 40 kg of specialized absorbent granules to contain and absorb the spilled liquid over a 45-minute period. Air quality monitoring confirmed no airborne vapor concentrations exceeding 50% of the OSHA PEL. The contaminated absorbent material was properly containerized and labeled for hazardous waste disposal. The failed drum was placed in a secondary containment vessel and scheduled for replacement. Environmental sampling of the drain area and surrounding soil showed no contaminant migration.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a dust accumulation fire occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Dimitri Sokolov, a CNC Machinist, was operating grinding equipment to prepare fiber-reinforced composite molds when sparks from the grinding process ignited accumulated composite dust near the ventilation intake. The dust had accumulated over several weeks due to inadequate cleaning protocols. The fire spread rapidly through the dust layer, reaching approximately 1.5 meters in height before being contained by the automatic dry powder suppression system. The area was evacuated immediately, and the facility fire suppression team responded within 3 minutes. No personnel were injured, but equipment damage included scorching of the mold preparation workbench and partial damage to the ventilation duct system. The incident resulted in a 6-hour production halt while the area was cleared and inspected.

On January 19, 2024, at 8:30 AM during the day shift, a cooling water system leak resulted in equipment damage at Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-004). Tomas Jimenez, a Machine Setter on evening shift covering a day shift assignment, was conducting routine pre-shift inspection of the 250-ton injection molding machine when he noticed coolant dripping from a corroded section of the high-pressure cooling water manifold. The corrosion, caused by inadequate water treatment and deferred maintenance over 18 months, had weakened the manifold wall. Within minutes of his discovery, the manifold ruptured under operating pressure, releasing approximately 150 liters of cooling fluid across the production floor. The fluid spread across electrical connections and motor assemblies, creating a slip hazard and damaging the machine's control panel. Production was halted immediately for 8 hours while maintenance technicians drained the system, replaced the manifold, and verified electrical safety. The incident resulted in approximately $32,000 in equipment damage and a $18,000 production loss.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Amina Mansour (EMP-00044), a Material Handler, was unloading raw plastic resin bags from a pallet in the Warehouse and Shipping receiving area. She was using a powered pallet jack to move a stack of 12 bags (approximately 600 lbs total) when the stack became unstable. One bag shifted and fell from the pallet, striking Amina on her left shoulder and upper arm. The impact caused immediate pain and swelling. A witness, Rashid Habib (EMP-00154), another material handler nearby, immediately alerted the supervisor. First aid was administered on-site, and Amina was transported to the local hospital where X-rays revealed a fractured left clavicle requiring surgical intervention. The incident was caused by improper stacking technique and insufficient training on load securing procedures. The pallet had not been wrapped or strapped, and the bags were stacked beyond the safe height recommendation of 5 feet.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter on Line D, was preparing a 250-ton injection molding machine for a production run in the Main Production Building. As he was adjusting the mold clamping mechanism, he noticed an unusual grinding noise coming from the hydraulic pressure relief valve. He immediately stepped back and shut down the machine using the emergency stop button. The relieving pressure hose showed signs of microscopic leaks and crystalline residue buildup. Upon closer inspection, technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135) discovered that the relief valve had a partially clogged internal passageway due to resin contamination, causing pressure fluctuations. Robert recognized this was a potential safety hazard that could lead to sudden pressure release or equipment failure, potentially causing a "Pressure Release Burn" incident. He documented the observation and reported it immediately to Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), the Maintenance Technician on night shift. The machine was locked out and tagged for repair. No injury occurred, and the situation was prevented from escalating.

On March 10, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift transition, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), Maintenance Technician on night shift, was conducting routine preventive maintenance on the resin dryer unit in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. This equipment is critical for removing moisture from raw plastic pellets before injection molding. While testing the internal thermostat calibration, Alain discovered that the heating element temperature controller had drifted significantly, causing the dryer to overheat to 185°C instead of the safe operating temperature of 160°C. The internal chamber walls showed visible discoloration and minor degradation of the internal insulation material. Upon opening the access panel, he observed that the temperature sensor probe connection had corroded due to moisture ingress, causing the control system to receive inaccurate temperature readings. The dryer had been operating in this overheated state for an estimated 6-8 hours before the night shift maintenance team detected it. Alain immediately powered down the dryer, isolated it from the system, and initiated a full inspection. No personnel were injured, but had the overheating continued, it could have caused thermal damage to the equipment, material degradation, or potentially ignited residual resin particles inside the chamber.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:15 PM, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, noticed unusual vibrations and a burning smell emanating from the hopper loading system in the Production Operations area. She immediately stopped the line and reported the issue to her supervisor Lucie Fillion. Upon inspection, it was discovered that the ventilation duct connecting the regrind hopper to the main ventilation system had partially dislodged, causing plastic fumes to accumulate in the enclosed space above the hopper. The regrind material temperature had also risen significantly due to inadequate air circulation. Sofia experienced minor respiratory irritation and dizziness. Gaétan Laplante, the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, was called to assess the situation. The equipment was immediately de-energized and locked out. Maintenance personnel confirmed the vent connection had loosened due to vibration from a nearby injection molding machine that had been recently repositioned without proper vibration isolation. This was a preventive declaration identifying the hazard before a more serious incident could occur.

On May 8, 2024 at 6:30 AM during the end of the night shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse Section C) following the activation of an automatic smoke detector mounted above the regrind processing area. Upon investigation, plant security discovered a smoldering condition in an accumulated plastic dust accumulation zone beneath the elevated regrind collection chute. The dust layer, approximately 15 centimeters thick, had accumulated over a three-week period due to a malfunction in the dust collection bag filter assembly that had gone unnoticed. The source of ignition was determined to be static electricity discharge between the collection equipment and the metal dust container during a high-speed regrind cycle. The accumulated dust temperature had reached approximately 95°C, approaching the auto-ignition temperature of certain plastic compounds (approximately 350-400°C depending on composition). Emergency response team evacuated the immediate area, ventilated the space, and cooled the material. Fire suppression systems were not activated, as the condition was detected and contained before a flame ignition occurred. The incident resulted in no injuries but posed a significant fire hazard to the facility. Investigation revealed that the dust collection maintenance schedule had been suspended due to staffing shortages, and static dissipation grounding cables on the equipment had not been inspected in over six months.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during the day shift, Céline Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was removing finished automotive dashboard components from a mold cavity when she did not notice the hydraulic pressure release valve had begun leaking. As she reached toward the mold surface to extract a part, pressurized steam and hot resin vapor erupted from the valve, striking her right forearm and hand. The temperature of the released material exceeded 180°C. Céline immediately withdrew her arm and alerted her supervisor. First aid was administered on-site, but severe thermal burns covering approximately 15% of her forearm required immediate transport to the Laval Regional Hospital emergency department. She was hospitalized for 4 days for wound care and infection prevention. The root cause investigation revealed that the monthly preventive maintenance on the pressure relief system had been skipped due to production scheduling pressures, and the valve seal had degraded without inspection.

On April 3, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine part removal from a completed molding cycle. While extracting automotive door handle components, he felt a sharp pain in his left ring finger. The automated material handling robotic arm, which had not fully retracted after its cycle, suddenly reactivated due to a faulty proximity sensor. The arm's gripper mechanism caught Bertrand's finger between the gripping pads and the component being removed. The finger was partially crushed, resulting in a compound fracture of the middle phalanx and laceration requiring 12 stitches. Bertrand was transported by ambulance to the hospital where he underwent surgical realignment and received a tetanus vaccination. He was unable to return to work for 23 days due to wound healing and occupational therapy requirements. The malfunction was traced to a sensor calibration drift that had not been detected by the quarterly maintenance check.

On May 22, 2024, at 09:30 during a routine morning safety inspection, Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107), the Workplace Safety Representative, conducted a walkthrough of the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT facility). During his inspection of the resin compound storage area, Serge discovered that the ventilation system exhaust duct had become partially blocked by accumulated plastic particulate and dust buildup over the past 6 weeks. Air velocity measurements showed airflow reduced to 35% of design specification. He immediately noticed elevated concentrations of styrene vapor in the air (measured at 42 ppm using a portable detector, exceeding the 20 ppm exposure action level). The blockage was preventing adequate capture of fumes from the mixing equipment where three workers had been assigned that morning. Upon further investigation, it was discovered that the ventilation maintenance schedule had been inadvertently removed from the facility calendar following a software system update two months prior. No incidents or employee illnesses had been formally reported yet, but several operators had mentioned headaches and throat irritation during the previous week. Serge immediately shut down the mixing operations and notified management of the hazard.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), a Hydraulic Press Operator, was performing routine maintenance on the hydraulic system of Press Unit 7 in the Central Maintenance Workshop. While adjusting a high-pressure hydraulic line, the connection point failed suddenly, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid directly into Bernard's left forearm and hand. The fluid penetrated his work glove, causing a severe injection injury. Bernard immediately reported intense pain and swelling. First aid was administered on-site, but given the nature of hydraulic injection injuries and the risk of compartment syndrome, Bernard was transported by ambulance to the nearest hospital emergency department. Medical evaluation revealed fluid tracking through tissue planes requiring emergency surgical intervention to prevent tissue necrosis. Bernard was admitted for observation and underwent two surgical procedures over 48 hours. He was discharged with significant restrictions and required 6 weeks of medical leave. The incident was caused by inadequate lockout/tagout procedures—the hydraulic system was not fully depressurized before maintenance commenced.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, Leila Farah (EMP-00130), a Production Operator working on Injection Molding Line D, experienced a burn injury while monitoring the material hopper temperature. As she reached across the machine to adjust a sensor near the resin dryer outlet, her right forearm contacted the heated dryer surface, which was operating at 280°C (536°F). Her short-sleeved work shirt provided minimal protection. Leila immediately withdrew her arm and reported the incident to her supervisor. The burn covered approximately 8 square centimeters on her forearm with partial-thickness blistering. She received immediate first aid with cold water application, sterile dressing application, and over-the-counter pain medication. Leila continued working with protective wrapping for the remainder of the shift but reported increased discomfort over the following hours. She returned to modified duty for 3 days with restrictions on hot work areas and received wound care at the occupational health clinic. The root cause was identified as inadequate machine guarding on the resin dryer and insufficient reach distance design at the sensor adjustment point.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during the evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (Building 5). Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169), a Maintenance Technician, was performing routine inspection of the epoxy resin storage tanks when he discovered that Tank C-4 (containing approximately 450 liters of two-part epoxy resin) had developed a small stress fracture along a weld seam near the base. The tank was actively leaking at an estimated rate of 3-4 liters per minute. Epoxy resin was pooling on the concrete floor and beginning to flow toward the floor drain system. Fernand immediately notified his supervisor Valerie Pelletier (EMP-00031) and triggered the emergency response procedure. The area was evacuated and secured with barriers within 10 minutes. Approximately 120 liters of epoxy resin had spilled before the leak was contained. The spill was absorbed using TechnoPlast's approved absorbent material (expanded clay granules), and contaminated material was placed in designated hazardous waste containers. The concrete floor was decontaminated with solvent wipes and high-pressure washing. Environmental monitoring confirmed no discharge to the storm drain system. The tank was removed for disposal as hazardous waste. Root cause analysis identified that the tank had not undergone scheduled pressure testing for three years.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Machine Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was performing routine setup and calibration on Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building. While adjusting the hopper feed mechanism, Hassan noticed what appeared to be a partial blockage in the material inlet. He began to manually clear the area with a small rod, but failed to follow proper lockout/tagout procedures and did not shut down the machine first. As he probed deeper into the hopper area, the automatic feed system suddenly activated, causing a significant amount of regrind plastic material to overflow from the top of the hopper onto Hassan's work station and upper body. The spill covered approximately 15 square feet of flooring with approximately 40 pounds of loose plastic pellets. Hassan immediately stepped back, unharmed but shaken. A witness, Assembly Lead Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128), was working at an adjacent station and observed the incident. The overflow was contained within the production area with no spillage beyond the immediate workstation. Hassan reported the incident to his supervisor within 5 minutes. The flooring was cleaned up within 30 minutes, and the hopper system was inspected and found to be functioning normally after the blockage was manually cleared with power disabled.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 4:45 PM during the evening shift, Assembly Operator Soraya Alami (EMP-00196) was performing manual edge finishing on automotive composite parts at a workstation in the Main Production Building. While handling a freshly molded composite panel, Alami inadvertently contacted the sharp edge of the part with the palm of her left hand. The part had several unfinished edges with micro-burrs typical of injection-molded composite components. Alami sustained a 2-inch laceration on her palm that required immediate first aid attention. She reported the injury to her supervisor immediately and proceeded to the on-site medical station where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided wound cleaning, antiseptic treatment, and a sterile bandage. The laceration was deemed a minor wound not requiring stitches but warranting first aid documentation. Alami was able to return to work after 15 minutes of medical attention. The part was set aside for proper edge smoothing in the regrind department. No lost work time resulted from the injury, which was classified as a recordable first aid case under CNESST requirements.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, a cooling water system leak was discovered in the Main Production Building's injection molding area (Line B). Equipment operator Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195) noticed water pooling near the base of an injection molding machine and immediately notified his supervisor, Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151). The cooling system supply line had developed a hairline fracture near a connection joint, likely due to thermal stress and inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling. Approximately 120 gallons of coolant-water mixture had leaked onto the production floor before the main valve was shut off. The spill created a slip hazard and contaminated approximately 500 square feet of floor space. Emergency response involved isolating the affected area with caution tape, deploying absorbent materials, and notifying the HSE department. Maintenance technician Fernand Giguère (EMP-00169) was called in to assess the system. The incident resulted in 6 hours of production downtime on Line B while repairs were completed. No injuries occurred, but the environmental spill required proper disposal and documentation per Quebec environmental regulations.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 09:15 during the day shift in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Maintenance Workshop mezzanine level), a minor but significant incident occurred when Finishing Operator Amal Farsi (EMP-00200) sustained a laceration to the left palm while removing a precision mold insert from a storage rack. The mold insert, weighing approximately 8 kilograms, was improperly stored on a shelf edge without proper stabilization. When Farsi reached for the insert, it shifted and the sharp edge of the metal mold contacted the operator's hand, causing a 3-centimeter laceration that required immediate first aid. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was summoned to the scene. The wound was thoroughly cleaned with sterile saline solution, bleeding was controlled with direct pressure, and the laceration was closed with adhesive strips after assessment by the facility's first aid attendant. No sutures were required, but the employee was provided with a tetanus status update and instructed on wound care and activity restrictions for 48 hours. The incident was classified as a first aid case requiring documentation but not hospitalization. Root cause investigation revealed inadequate storage procedures and insufficient employee training on proper mold handling and storage techniques.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 22:30 during the evening shift in the Material Drying and Preparation Room, Production Operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) sustained a first-degree burn to the right forearm while transferring dried plastic resin from a hopper to a molding machine feed system. The resin material, heated to approximately 65°C during the drying cycle, made contact with her forearm when she accidentally leaned against the hopper outlet during material transfer. The operator was not wearing the required extended-cuff heat-resistant gloves and had removed her arm sleeve protection to adjust her watch. The burn area, measuring approximately 12 centimeters in length, was immediately flushed with cool running water for 10 minutes and covered with a sterile, non-adhesive dressing. Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) responded to the incident scene within 2 minutes and provided first aid support, documenting vital signs and monitoring for signs of shock. The employee experienced mild pain and localized redness but no blistering. She was instructed to monitor the burn site and report any changes to the first aid station. The incident required documentation in the HSE incident log and triggered a review of PPE compliance in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. No lost time occurred, and the employee returned to modified duties after 30 minutes of observation.

On March 15, 2025, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124), a Machine Setter on the evening shift, was conducting a setup verification on injection molding machine #7 in the Main Production Building. While performing a trial run without proper lockout/tagout procedures in place, an automated robotic arm (Aya Tanaka's maintenance responsibility) unexpectedly cycled and nearly struck Tomas's right hand as he was adjusting mold alignment. Tomas quickly withdrew his hand and the robotic arm completed its cycle harmlessly. No physical contact occurred. Witnesses Patricia Martin and Giovanni Bianchi observed the near-miss from adjacent workstations. Immediate investigation revealed that the machine's emergency stop button was not functioning properly and the LOTO checklist had not been completed. The near-miss was reported to the HSE office within 30 minutes. This incident highlighted critical gaps in pre-operation safety verification procedures.

On March 22, 2025, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092), a Regrind Technician, was transferring recycled plastic material from a collection hopper to the regrind processing unit in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). The hopper, which was scheduled for maintenance earlier but bypassed due to production schedule pressure, suddenly overflowed as Ramirez attempted to empty it. Approximately 450 kilograms of moistened plastic granules spilled across the production floor, spreading across an area roughly 12 meters by 8 meters. The material mixed with residual coolant and cleaning solutions on the floor, creating a slippery hazard. The spillage also damaged three rolls of finished composite material worth approximately €8,200 (CAD $12,400) that were staged nearby for quality testing. Ramirez activated the emergency alarm and the spill was contained within 90 minutes using wet vacuum systems. The Root cause analysis identified a faulty level sensor in the hopper that had been flagged for replacement two weeks prior but was deprioritized.

On April 3, 2025, at approximately 5:30 AM during the night shift, Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician working the night shift, was performing routine inspection and cleaning of the CNC milling machines in the Maintenance Workshop. While repositioning cooling water hoses on CNC machine #5 to improve drainage and reduce floor wetness near the work area, a corroded coupling joint at the base of the hose assembly suddenly failed. A high-pressure stream of industrial cutting coolant (approximately 45 liters) sprayed across the workshop floor and damaged multiple precision measuring instruments including a calibrated dial indicator, two digital calipers, and a depth gauge—items essential for quality control verification. The spillage also saturated approximately 15 meters of electrical wiring conduit and created a slip hazard requiring the night shift crew to evacuate the workshop for 4 hours while cleanup was performed. Estimated equipment damage: CAD $18,700. The root cause was deferred maintenance on a cooling system that had been documented as requiring attention for 8 weeks but had not been scheduled due to lack of workshop downtime windows.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during day shift operations, a fire alarm was triggered in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment facility (South Zone). Celine Morin, Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was transferring finished parts from the industrial oven when she noticed smoke emanating from the oven's ventilation system. The smoke appeared to be from an accumulation of plastic resin fumes that had not been properly vented. Celine immediately activated the manual fire alarm and evacuated the area. The alarm system automatically triggered the facility's emergency response protocol, including the activation of the suppression system in the post-processing zone and immediate notification to the Laval fire department. Upon inspection by maintenance staff, no active fire was detected, but the ventilation system was found to have a partially blocked filter that had accumulated composite material residue. The incident resulted in a 3-hour facility evacuation and production halt while the fire department cleared the area and maintenance replaced the ventilation filter. No injuries were reported, but the event highlighted a critical gap in preventive maintenance scheduling for the ventilation systems.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during evening shift operations, a fire alarm was activated in Injection Molding Line B (Automotive) in the North Zone production area. Louis Desbiens, Machine Setter on night shift, was conducting a setup changeover for a new automotive trim component when a malfunction in one of the 200-ton injection molding machines caused an electrical short circuit in the machine's heating element control panel. The short generated visible sparks and a burning smell from the electrical enclosure. Automatic fire suppression systems discharged CO2 into the affected equipment area, triggering the facility-wide fire alarm. Normand Vaillancourt, Shipping Coordinator, and Hugues Fontaine, Forklift Operator, were in adjacent areas and immediately evacuated following standard procedures. Emergency response personnel from the Laval Fire Department arrived within 8 minutes. Investigation revealed that the machine's thermal overload protection had not been properly calibrated during the previous maintenance cycle, allowing the heating element to exceed safe operating temperatures. The incident resulted in damage to the machine's control panel (approximately $18,000 in repairs) and 4 hours of production downtime. The affected machine remained offline for 2 days while replacement parts were sourced and installed.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 09:30 during day shift operations, a significant equipment failure occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse and Shipping - Section C). Amara Diop, Packaging Operator, was operating the regrind processing machine to process recycled composite scrap material when the machine's rotating grinding drum suddenly seized due to bearing failure. The sudden stop caused a violent jolt, throwing loose plastic chips and fragments throughout the equipment bay. Several pieces of composite material were ejected from the hopper opening, scattering across approximately 12 square meters of the warehouse floor and damaging three spools of packing tape, two cardboard boxes of finished components, and one partially assembled shipping crate. The material spill also damaged the floor surface with deep scratch marks and minor structural damage to a floor-mounted cable tray. Total estimated property damage was approximately $8,400, including equipment repair costs ($6,200), replacement inventory ($1,800), and infrastructure damage ($400). Fatou Ndiaye, Production Operator, was working nearby and witnessed the incident. The machine was immediately shut down and taken out of service pending bearing replacement and thorough inspection. Production of recycled material halted for 2 days until the machine was repaired and validated for safe operation.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:22, Marcel Duchesne (EMP-00159), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was performing routine maintenance on the mold closing mechanism of a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building South Zone. Despite having completed lockout/tagout procedures, the machine's hydraulic accumulator had not fully depressurized due to a faulty isolation valve that was not properly maintained. When Marcel attempted to manually adjust the mold guide pins, the machine unexpectedly cycled, causing the mold to close on his left hand. His hand was caught between the upper and lower mold platens for approximately 8 seconds before a coworker activated the emergency stop button. Marcel sustained crush injuries to his left hand including two fractured metacarpals, severe contusions, and partial loss of sensation in his ring finger. Emergency services transported him to Hôpital de Verdun where he underwent surgical intervention. The incident was immediately reported and the machine was secured pending investigation.

On March 18, 2024 at 22:45 during the evening shift, a solvent storage container failure occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (UNIT-005). Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), a Maintenance Technician on the night shift, was performing routine equipment checks when he discovered that a 55-gallon drum of acetone (used for cleaning molds and equipment) had developed a hairline crack along its bottom weld seam. Approximately 8-10 gallons of acetone had leaked into the containment tray system over an unknown period. The spilled solvent had partially evaporated, creating a visible chemical haze in the immediate work area. Alain immediately evacuated the chemical storage section, activated the ventilation override switches, and notified Serge Lafleur from the Safety office. The spill was contained using absorbent material and properly disposed of according to hazardous waste protocols. The incident resulted in no personnel injuries but caused approximately $18,000 in material loss (solvent, contaminated containment materials, and disposal costs). The drum was replaced and storage area ventilation was audited.

On March 21, 2024 at 09:15 during the day shift, Deepa Gupta (EMP-00080), a Process Quality Engineer, was conducting quality testing on molded polycarbonate components in the Quality Control Laboratory (Administrative Building, Ground Floor). While examining a finished part for dimensional accuracy using a coordinate measuring machine (CMM), Deepa leaned over to reposition the component and inadvertently brushed her left forearm against the sharp edge of an unmounted mold cavity that was stored upright near the testing station. The contact created a 2-inch laceration on her inner forearm, causing immediate bleeding. Deepa applied pressure with a cloth and immediately proceeded to the first aid station where Michael Chen (EMP-00004), Production Supervisor, was present for his shift transition. Michael activated the first aid protocol, cleaned the wound with sterile saline, assessed that the laceration required professional medical attention for potential stitching (approximately 4-5 millimeters deep), and documented the incident. Deepa was transported to a nearby clinic where she received 6 stitches. She returned to light-duty work the following day. The incident was categorized as a minor occupational injury requiring first aid intervention.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM, an environmental incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum into smaller containers for use in the cleaning solvent station. While decanting the solvent, the transfer pump malfunctioned and pressurized, causing approximately 12 liters of acetone to spray across the storage room floor and partially onto adjacent shelving containing polypropylene resin bags. The spill created a slippery hazard and released significant solvent vapors throughout the confined space. Mold Maintenance Technician Réjean Simard (EMP-00077) was present nearby and immediately identified the hazard. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) was notified and activated emergency response procedures. The facility's secondary containment system partially contained the spill, but approximately 8 liters reached the floor drain system before it could be isolated. The chemical storage area was evacuated, and ventilation systems were activated. Local environmental authorities were notified per Quebec regulations. No personnel were chemically exposed, but the incident resulted in approximately 4 hours of facility remediation and environmental documentation.

On March 18, 2024 at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Equipment Failure Incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was monitoring the resin drying hopper system when the main motor bearing assembly experienced catastrophic failure, causing the rotating auger shaft to seize suddenly. The grinding and metal-on-metal friction generated extreme heat, melting the polymer seals and warping the internal chamber walls. Approximately 120 kilograms of Nylon PA resin in the hopper was ruined as the material solidified around the damaged auger mechanism. The equipment's thermal cutoff failed to activate, allowing temperatures to exceed 280°C before power was manually disconnected by Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015). Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) was called to assess the damage. Investigation revealed the bearing assembly had not been lubricated in six months due to a gap in the preventive maintenance schedule. The equipment was completely offline for 18 hours, causing production delays affecting three scheduled injection molding runs. Estimated material loss: $8,400 CAD. Equipment repair estimate: $16,200 CAD.

On March 22, 2024 at 6:30 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident was identified in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop (UNIT-014). Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim (EMP-00025) was performing routine panel inspection on an industrial control box when he discovered that a critical LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) device was missing from the main electrical disconnect. The technician had been preparing to work on energized circuits within the control panel. A second technician, who was entering the shop, noticed the missing safety device and immediately alerted Kim. Investigation revealed that another maintenance worker had removed the LOTO device three days prior without proper documentation or authorization, creating a potential electrocution hazard rated at 480 volts, 3-phase. The facility's LOTO log showed no entry for the disconnect, indicating a breakdown in the safety management system. No actual electrical contact or injury occurred because the near-miss was caught during the pre-work inspection phase. The incident revealed gaps in LOTO compliance procedures and accountability for safety device management. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) was notified to investigate the unauthorized removal.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, a fire alarm was triggered in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing) after an unexpected exothermic reaction in the resin compounding equipment. Technician Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181) was preparing a batch of fiber-reinforced polycarbonate when he noticed smoke emanating from the chemical mixing vessel. He immediately activated the emergency shutdown and pulled the fire alarm. The facility's automated suppression system activated, flooding the area with dry powder extinguishant. Production Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037), who was conducting rounds on the night shift, responded within 2 minutes and confirmed the area was secure. Investigation revealed that incompatible resin additives had been accidentally mixed due to mislabeled containers received from the warehouse. The additives combined to generate excessive heat (estimated 180°C), exceeding the equipment's safe operating temperature of 120°C. No injuries occurred, but approximately 400 kg of material was destroyed and production was halted for 8 hours while the equipment was inspected and cleaned.

On March 22, 2024 at 09:15, Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye (EMP-00050) suffered a laceration to her left index finger while removing finished automotive components from Injection Molding Line B. Ndiaye was performing her routine task of extracting dashboard trim parts from the cooling tray when her gloved hand contacted a sharp edge where the plastic had partially fractured during the cooling cycle. The sharp edge created a 3 cm laceration through the outer glove and punctured the skin, causing moderate bleeding. Her workstation colleague immediately applied direct pressure and alerted the line supervisor. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) responded and administered first aid: wound cleaning with sterile saline, topical antibiotic application, and a sterile bandage with secondary gauze wrap. The wound did not require stitches but was treated as a preventive measure. Fatou completed an incident report and received tetanus documentation. She returned to work the same day after one hour, with modified duties avoiding direct contact with unfinished plastic edges. The incident was classified as a minor injury requiring first aid treatment.

On April 3, 2024 at 22:30, Forklift Operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) sustained a crush injury to his right foot when a pallet of resin feedstock tipped during unloading in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Santos was maneuvering a loaded pallet (approximately 800 kg) off the truck using a propane-powered forklift when the pallet's corner caught on the truck bed edge. The sudden contact caused the load to shift laterally, and the pallet began to tip toward Santos. He attempted to jump clear but was unable to move fast enough due to the tight workspace. The corner of the pallet struck his right foot, crushing it against the concrete floor below. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) heard Santos cry out and immediately called emergency services. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) provided immediate care: immobilization, ice application, and pain management while awaiting the ambulance. Santos was transported to Sacré-Cœur Hospital where X-rays confirmed a compound fracture of the fifth metatarsal with soft tissue damage. He underwent surgical repair and was admitted for 48-hour observation. This resulted in a lost-time injury requiring 12 weeks of medical leave and modified duty restrictions upon return.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186) was removing finished medical device components from Injection Molding Line C in the clean room area when she experienced sharp pain in her right wrist and forearm. She had been performing the same repetitive gripping and twisting motions for approximately 6 hours without breaks, removing parts from the mold cavity every 45 seconds. Over the previous three weeks, she reported experiencing intermittent discomfort, but continued working through the pain. Witness Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176), another assembly operator at the adjacent station, noticed Valentina favoring her right arm and recommended she report it to the occupational health nurse. Valentina reported to the HSE office at 3:15 PM where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed her condition. Clinical examination revealed inflammation and tenderness consistent with repetitive strain injury affecting the extensor carpi radialis and flexor carpi muscles. Hana recommended immediate work restriction and ice application. The employee was advised to seek external medical evaluation. This incident highlights the need for enhanced job rotation protocols and mandatory microbreaks in the high-repetition assembly operations.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:32 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop (UNIT-012) without any actual fire. Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) was conducting routine hydraulic system maintenance on injection molding Line B equipment when he inadvertently sprayed cleaning solvent (acetone-based) directly onto a smoke detector while cleaning overhead equipment. The aerosol mist from the solvent triggered the photoelectric smoke detector, activating the facility-wide fire alarm system. The alarm sounded throughout the entire 150,000 square foot facility at 10:32 PM, initiating full evacuation procedures. Approximately 65 evening shift workers evacuated the building in an orderly fashion following established protocols. Emergency responders arrived at 10:47 PM and confirmed no fire hazard after visual inspection. The false alarm lasted 22 minutes total. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) responded to the maintenance workshop and identified the root cause: the solvent spray contacted the smoke detector mounted directly above the maintenance area without any protective barrier. This incident exposed a gap in maintenance procedures regarding chemical compatibility with fire detection systems.

On May 22, 2024, at 12:18 AM during the night shift, a serious ladder fall incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was accessing inventory stored on high shelving (approximately 14 feet elevation) to retrieve finished medical device components for early morning shipment. Elif was using a 16-foot aluminum extension ladder leaning against the shelving unit. The warehouse floor, recently cleaned by evening shift staff, remained slightly damp in areas not fully dried. As Elif ascended the ladder (approximately 10 feet up), her left foot slipped on a damp rung, causing her to lose balance and fall approximately 9 feet to the concrete warehouse floor. She struck her head, right shoulder, and right hip during the fall. Packaging Operator Amina Ba (EMP-00164), working nearby for late-night inventory verification, immediately called for emergency assistance at 12:19 AM. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) and Production Scheduler Wei Liu (EMP-00088) responded as first responders. Emergency medical services arrived at 12:31 AM. Elif was transported to the hospital with suspected right shoulder fracture, possible concussion, and bruising to the right hip. She was hospitalized for 2 days. The incident investigation revealed inadequate ladder maintenance protocols, insufficient floor drying procedures, and lack of fall protection equipment.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, during the day shift, a chemical storage technician was transferring isopropanol solvent from a 55-gallon drum to smaller 5-gallon containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The employee was using a manual hand pump with an old rubber gasket that had degraded over time. As pressure built during the transfer, the gasket failed catastrophically, releasing approximately 8 gallons of isopropanol onto the floor and saturating the employee's lower legs and work boots. The spill created a slick hazardous surface covering an area of roughly 20 square feet. The employee immediately notified their supervisor, and the spill was contained using absorbent material and proper cleanup procedures. The employee experienced minor skin irritation from solvent contact but did not require medical attention. The incident was discovered during routine inspection when the employee reported the smell of solvent throughout the storage area.

On March 22, 2024 at 09:15 during the day shift, a maintenance planner was conducting routine inspection of an injection molding machine (Model XYZ-500) in the Composite Materials Processing Area when a hydraulic hose under high pressure suddenly ruptured due to metal fatigue in the connector fitting. The pressurized hydraulic fluid (approximately 12 gallons) sprayed across the machine's control cabinet, electrical panel, and nearby workstations. The hot hydraulic fluid damaged the PLC controller, soaked multiple electrical connections, and contaminated quality control monitoring equipment. The machine immediately shut down due to electrical damage. Initial assessment estimated equipment damage at $34,000 including controller replacement ($8,500), electrical rewiring ($6,200), and sensor replacement ($4,800). The incident caused a 16-hour production halt affecting three customer orders. Two employees were in the vicinity but were not physically injured as they were positioned away from the direct spray pattern. The equipment was immediately de-energized and cordoned off pending repairs.

On April 3, 2024 at 22:30 during the evening shift, a machine setter was preparing an injection molding line for a product changeover on Line B in the Main Production Building. The setter needed to perform a routine cleaning of the heating element cavity and attempted to reach into the mold area while the machine was in idle mode. Although the machine showed a green status light indicating standby, a compressed air line valve controlling the mold clamp mechanism was stuck in a partially open position due to mineral deposits.
