As the employee's hand entered the mold cavity to insert a cleaning tool, the compressed air suddenly released, activating the clamp mechanism. The employee's hand was caught momentarily between the mold halves but was able to withdraw within 1-2 seconds when they heard the mechanical engagement sound. No physical injury occurred—the employee reported only minor skin redness on their knuckles from contact with the mold edge. The incident was immediately reported to the maintenance team. Investigation revealed the compressed air valve had not been properly maintained and mineral buildup had caused erratic operation. The machine was locked out and tagged pending maintenance.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Fatou Ndiaye, a Production Operator, was transferring a 25-liter container of epoxy resin from storage to a mixing station when the container's cap was not properly secured. As she lifted the container onto the mixing platform, approximately 8 liters of epoxy resin spilled onto the concrete floor, spreading across an area of roughly 4 square meters. The spill occurred near the ventilation intake, creating vapor exposure concerns. Fatou immediately notified her supervisor, Sébastien Carrier, who initiated the facility's chemical spill response protocol. The area was evacuated within 5 minutes, and containment berms were deployed. Mariam Osman, the Material Handler, assisted in the cleanup operation by deploying absorbent materials and using the emergency eyewash station to rinse her contaminated glove. The spill was fully contained within 45 minutes. Environmental samples were taken to confirm no hazardous vapor levels exceeded WHMIS thresholds. Root cause analysis identified that the container cap was cross-threaded during the previous shift, and staff had not visually inspected container integrity before transfer.

On March 22, 2024 at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Bertrand Jalbert, an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, sustained a burn injury to his right hand and forearm. While performing routine maintenance on the injection nozzle of Molding Line D, Bertrand inadvertently activated the machine's pressure release valve without properly confirming the equipment was in lockout/tagout status. A sudden pressure release of heated molten plastic at 280°C discharged directly onto his right hand and lower forearm, causing second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his body surface area. Immediately following the injury, Bertrand ran cold water over the affected area for approximately 3 minutes before calling for assistance. Celine Morin, another operator on the same line, witnessed the incident and immediately alerted supervision. Omar Said, a production operator, escorted Bertrand to the on-site first aid station where Marie-Claude Beaumont, the Director of Health, Safety and Environment, was notified. First aid was administered including cooling with sterile gauze pads and application of non-adherent dressings. Bertrand was transported to Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé for emergency treatment due to burn severity. Investigation revealed the LOTO procedure was incomplete because the operator had only tagged the electrical panel but failed to verify isolation of the compressed air supply system.

On March 28, 2024 at approximately 7:50 AM during the day shift, Léa Parent, a Quality Control Technician, sustained a minor thermal burn to her left hand while handling a quality control sample in the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006). Léa had removed a test specimen from a high-temperature aging oven set at 85°C without allowing the standard 15-minute cooling period specified in the facility's quality procedures. She picked up the specimen with bare hands to transfer it to the testing apparatus, immediately feeling heat through her palm. The specimen was approximately 60°C when contacted. She experienced mild pain and redness on her left palm and first two fingers, consistent with a first-degree thermal burn. Léa immediately immersed her hand in cool water at the laboratory sink for approximately 5 minutes. Her supervisor, Deepa Gupta, was notified and assessed the injury. Deepa applied a sterile burn ointment and a light gauze bandage from the laboratory first aid kit. The burn did not require further medical attention and was classified as a minor occupational injury. Léa returned to work within 30 minutes. The incident root cause was identified as time pressure to complete testing for a customer deadline, which led to bypassing the established cooling protocol. No systemic equipment failure was involved.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Aisha Kamara was working at Injection Molding Line C in the medical components clean room when she noticed unusual vibration and a burning smell coming from the resin dryer unit. The dryer, which had been operating continuously for 18 hours without scheduled maintenance, was displaying irregular temperature readings on the control panel. Despite initial concerns, Aisha attempted to adjust the settings to compensate for the fluctuations. At 2:47 PM, the dryer's internal heating element began overheating, causing the resin material inside to char and emit acrid fumes throughout the clean room area. The situation triggered the facility's chemical alarm system. Aisha immediately evacuated the area and notified her supervisor. No direct injury occurred, but the incident revealed critical gaps in preventive maintenance scheduling and equipment monitoring protocols. The medical device production line was shut down for 6 hours for equipment inspection and cleaning, affecting production targets for a major customer order.

On February 28, 2024, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Mold Maintenance Technician Réjan Simard was performing routine maintenance on the injection molding line when he discovered a hydraulic fluid leak from a pressurized hose connection near the mold ejection system. While attempting to tighten the fitting using a wrench, the corroded hose fitting suddenly gave way, releasing a high-pressure spray of hydraulic oil directly onto Réjan's right forearm and hand. The pressurized fluid, at approximately 2000 PSI, caused immediate thermal and pressure-related burns across an area of approximately 3 inches by 4 inches on his forearm. Additionally, the sudden pressure release created a forceful impact that caused a small laceration. Réjan immediately flushed the affected area with cold water for 15 minutes and reported to the first aid station. He was treated for second-degree burn injuries by the onsite medical response team and transported to the local hospital for advanced burn treatment. He required hospitalization for 2 days and was on medical leave for 3 weeks. The incident investigation revealed that the hydraulic system had not undergone a comprehensive pressure testing and component inspection in 18 months, well beyond manufacturer recommendations.

On March 9, 2024, at 1:45 AM during the night shift, Production Operator Kwame Mensah was working in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse Section C) processing reclaimed plastic material. While transferring reground polypropylene pellets from a collection hopper to a storage bin using a hand scoop, Kwame's left index finger became caught between the metal scoop handle and the edge of the collection hopper during a hand slip. The pinching force resulted in a laceration and bruising of the finger but no fracture or permanent damage. Kwame immediately withdrew his hand, applied pressure to stop minor bleeding, and reported the incident to his supervisor within 2 minutes. The first aid responder, Karine Cloutier (Safety Trainer on-call), cleaned the wound with antiseptic solution, applied antibiotic ointment, and bandaged the injury with sterile medical-grade dressing. The wound was classified as a minor laceration requiring basic first aid only, with no sutures or medical facility referral necessary. Kwame resumed work 30 minutes later with modified duty restrictions on hand-intensive tasks for 48 hours. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate ergonomic design of material transfer equipment and insufficient awareness of pinch point hazards during night shift operations.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, production operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) was working on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone, removing finished automotive components from a mold. She was performing rapid part extraction when her right hand made contact with a pinch point between the mold halves as they began to close prematurely due to a faulty proximity sensor. The mold closure caught her fingers between the stationary base and moving platen, causing immediate crushing injuries to her index and middle fingers. A coworker activated the emergency stop, and she was transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur by ambulance. X-rays revealed fractures to both fingers and soft tissue damage requiring 8 weeks of recovery. The incident occurred because maintenance had deferred sensor recalibration for 3 weeks beyond the recommended interval, and the operator was not aware of the known sensor sensitivity issue.

On March 18, 2024 at 23:15 during the night shift, a critical cooling water system failure occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing). Maintenance technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) was conducting routine inspections when he discovered a 2-inch diameter rubber hose connection on the primary coolant supply line had ruptured. Approximately 800 gallons of industrial coolant containing mineral oil and water-soluble additives sprayed across the production floor, equipment, and storage shelves over a 45-minute period before the leak was discovered by the shift supervisor. The spill reached approximately 3,000 square feet of floor space and saturated fiberglass material inventory valued at $125,000. Emergency response involved containment with absorbent materials and cleanup by a certified hazmat contractor. The hose had exceeded its 5-year replacement interval by 18 months, and pressure relief valves had not been maintained per protocol, allowing pressure to build unchecked.

On March 20, 2024 at 10:30, a chemical handling error occurred in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop during routine equipment cleaning. Maintenance lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) had instructed tool maker René Caron (EMP-00097) to clean circuit board assemblies using two different solvents sequentially. Caron first used a mineral spirits rinse, then without proper ventilation verification or chemical compatibility review, applied an ammonia-based electronics cleaner to the same parts. The resulting chemical reaction generated chloramine gas, causing immediate respiratory irritation. Caron experienced acute coughing, chest tightness, and eye irritation. He was moved to fresh air and received first aid. CNESST environmental monitoring detected chloramine concentrations of 8 ppm in the immediate work area (exposure limit is 1 ppm ceiling). The incident was caused by inadequate hazard communication regarding chemical incompatibilities, lack of pre-work chemical compatibility review, and insufficient ventilation controls in the work area.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a hydraulic malfunction occurred on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone of the Main Production Building. Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) was performing routine material loading when the automated robotic arm suddenly jerked unexpectedly during its injection cycle. The arm's servo control system failed, causing erratic movements that struck the mold housing with significant force. The impact dislodged the mold assembly, which fell partially onto the conveyor system below. Omar instinctively stepped back, avoiding direct contact with the falling equipment. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) was nearby and immediately activated the emergency stop button. Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was called to inspect the equipment. Upon investigation, a hydraulic pressure regulator valve was found to be malfunctioning, causing pressure fluctuations that destabilized the robotic arm's positioning system. The incident resulted in equipment damage and a 4-hour production halt while repairs were completed. No employee injuries occurred, though the near-miss highlighted critical maintenance gaps.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 5:45 PM during the evening shift, Production Operator Céline Morin (EMP-00153) sustained a thermal burn injury while operating Injection Molding Line A. Céline was extracting finished plastic components from the mold cavity when a pressurized resin line began leaking hot melted polypropylene at approximately 210°C. The heated material sprayed onto her right forearm and hand, causing immediate second-degree burns across the wrist and dorsal hand surface. Evening Shift Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) was nearby and immediately assisted in removing Céline's contaminated glove, rinsed the affected area with cool water, and applied a sterile burn dressing. First aid was administered within 3 minutes of the incident. Céline was transported to the local medical clinic where she received professional burn care and pain management. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury requiring Céline to take 5 days off work for recovery and wound care. Investigation revealed that the resin line coupling had corroded internally, weakening its structural integrity and causing the pressurized rupture. Preventive maintenance had been deferred by 3 weeks due to production pressure.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, a significant property damage incident occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse and Shipping - Section C). Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was operating an electric forklift to transport pallets of recycled plastic resin when the mast hydraulic cylinder failed catastrophically. The forklift's load-bearing arms collapsed suddenly, dropping a pallet containing approximately 1,200 kg of high-value polycarbonate (PC) resin pellets. The pallet impacted the concrete floor with sufficient force to rupture multiple bags, scattering approximately 400 kg of material across an 8-meter area. The scattered resin mixed with condensation on the floor, creating a contaminated batch unsuitable for processing. Additionally, the impact damaged three adjacent storage bins and cracked a 2-meter section of epoxy floor coating. Property damage was estimated at $47,000 including: material loss ($18,000), equipment repair ($16,000), floor restoration ($8,000), and cleanup labor ($5,000). No employee injuries occurred as Hassan was not directly under the falling load. Night Shift Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) documented the incident. Investigation revealed that scheduled forklift maintenance had been incomplete; the hydraulic cylinder inspection was skipped during the last service cycle.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, production operator Laila Hamdan (EMP-00198) was performing routine cleaning and maintenance on injection molding machine #7 in the Main Production Building (UNIT-Main Production). Despite following standard procedures, the machine unexpectedly restarted while she was reaching into the hopper area to clear a partial blockage. The sudden activation caused her left forearm to be caught between the auger screw and the hopper wall. She sustained a crush injury with significant soft tissue damage, swelling, and multiple contusions extending from wrist to elbow. Coworker Mei Zhang (EMP-00068) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button, halting the machine within 3 seconds. Mei called for medical assistance while Laila was carefully extracted by maintenance technician Andrei Popov (EMP-00094). First responders arrived within 12 minutes and transported Laila to the hospital where X-rays confirmed no fractures but extensive soft tissue trauma requiring hospitalization for 48 hours and 10 days of lost work time.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, assembly operator Diego Morales (EMP-00056) was working at station 4 in the Medical Device Assembly Line when he experienced acute eye irritation and redness while handling composite material components treated with mold release agent. The chemical vapors from the release agent (containing silicone-based compounds) came into contact with his eyes despite wearing standard safety glasses. Diego immediately went to the eyewash station in the Main Production Building (adjacent to UNIT-008) where he flushed his eyes for 15 minutes per protocol. The irritation subsided within 30 minutes of flushing. Coworker Zara Khan (EMP-00106) assisted Diego to the first aid station where first aid responder Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) evaluated him and documented the incident. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) was notified and reviewed the incident. Diego's vision returned to normal within 2 hours with no lasting effects. The incident was treated as first aid with no medical referral required.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, material handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was retrieving rolls of raw plastic material from the overhead storage mezzanine in the Warehouse and Shipping facility (UNIT-008) using the motorized lift system. While positioning a 45-pound roll at the edge of the mezzanine for descent, the material handler briefly lost grip on the roll due to moisture on her glove. The roll tumbled from approximately 12 feet and struck the concrete floor below with significant impact force. The roll did not land on any personnel as the area below had been cleared per safety protocol. However, the impact fractured the outer shell of the roll, creating sharp plastic fragments scattered across approximately 8 square feet of floor space. Crane operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) was spotting from below and immediately called out a warning, ensuring no one entered the area. Mariam descended safely and reported the incident to the night shift supervisor. The area was cordoned off and cleaned up within 20 minutes. Mariam received first aid assessment for minor abrasion to her right palm where she had gripped the roll during its slip. No other injuries occurred. The incident was treated as first aid with wound cleaning and bandaging.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) when a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin adhesive was being transferred from storage to the mixing room. Production Operator Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074) was assisting Tool Maker René Caron (EMP-00097) with the transfer using a manual drum dolly. As they navigated through a narrow corridor near the chemical mixing station, the dolly struck an uneven floor tile, causing the drum to tip and spill approximately 20 gallons of epoxy resin onto the concrete floor. The spilled chemical spread across an area of approximately 400 square feet, creating a slippery hazard and releasing volatile organic compound (VOC) vapors into the immediate work area. The existing ventilation system in that section was operating at reduced capacity due to a maintenance issue that had not been addressed. Multiple workers in the vicinity were exposed to the fumes before the area was evacuated. Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) was immediately notified and initiated emergency response protocols. The spill was contained using absorbent materials and properly disposed of according to WHMIS guidelines. Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) documented the incident and identified inadequate floor maintenance and insufficient ventilation as contributing factors.

On February 28, 2024, during the night shift at approximately 11:45 PM, Production Operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) was monitoring Line D in the Injection Molding section when he observed unusual vibration and a grinding sound emanating from the injection press hydraulic system. The primary pressure gauge indicated a sudden drop from the normal operating range of 1,800-2,000 PSI to approximately 900 PSI. Kwame immediately halted the machine and notified his supervisor via the production floor communication system. Upon visual inspection by Injection Molding Technician Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), a small hydraulic fluid leak was identified at a coupling connection on the secondary circuit. Before any work was initiated, Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) conducted a lockout-tagout (LOTO) procedure to ensure the machine remained de-energized. The technician discovered that the coupling had not been properly tightened during the previous maintenance cycle performed one week prior. The leak was contained using absorbent pads, and the escaped hydraulic fluid was properly contained in secondary containment. The coupling was tightened, and system pressure was restored. No personnel were exposed to hydraulic fluid spray, and no injuries occurred. The potential for a pressurized fluid injection hazard was averted through early detection and adherence to LOTO protocols.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM during the day shift, Shipping Coordinator Normand Vaillancourt (EMP-00073) was organizing finished goods inventory in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) when he attempted to retrieve a storage container from a high shelf in the equipment storage mezzanine. The container, weighing approximately 35 pounds and containing polypropylene regrind pellets, was not properly secured to the shelf. As Normand pulled the container, it became unstable and fell from approximately 8 feet above the concrete floor, striking and damaging three shipping pallets containing automotive component parts valued at approximately $47,000. The falling container narrowly missed striking Normand, who managed to step backward quickly when he noticed the container shifting. Assembly Line Lead Chantal Côté (EMP-00017) was working nearby and witnessed the near-miss incident. The container itself sustained significant damage to its structural integrity and will require replacement. Approximately 18 pounds of regrind material spilled onto the warehouse floor and surrounding packaged products. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) was notified to assess the scope of material loss and contamination. The incident revealed that the mezzanine storage system lacks proper securing mechanisms for containers, and no secondary containment guardrails are present.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, a cooling water system leak was discovered in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). Rodrigue Tremblay, Machine Setter, was performing routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine when he noticed water spraying from a corroded coupling joint on the cooling line. The leak rapidly escalated, creating a 2-meter-wide puddle on the workshop floor containing approximately 150 liters of coolant-contaminated water. The spill created a slippery hazard and threatened to damage precision tooling stored nearby. Rodrigue immediately shut down the affected equipment and notified Safety Officer Anh Nguyen. The leak was isolated within 20 minutes using manual shut-off valves. Facility maintenance staff performed cleanup using absorbent materials and a wet-vac system. Environmental samples were collected to assess coolant concentration in the spill. Root cause analysis revealed that the coupling had not been inspected during the last predictive maintenance cycle due to scheduling gaps. The cooling system operates at high pressure and supplies multiple pieces of equipment, making this a recurring vulnerability.

On August 22, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Security video and witness accounts indicate that Marwa Saleh, Material Handler, was transferring acetone (a highly flammable solvent) from a 55-gallon drum to smaller dispensing containers using a manual pump. An electrical fault in the pump motor sparked approximately 10 centimeters from the open container. The acetone vapors ignited, creating a localized flash fire that burned Marwa's right forearm (approximately 8% body surface area, second-degree burns). The fire extinguished itself when acetone vapors dissipated after approximately 45 seconds. Emergency response was initiated immediately: Marwa received first aid for burns from Safety Officer Anh Nguyen, the room was evacuated and secured, and the Quebec Fire Department was called (arriving 8 minutes later). Investigation revealed that the pump had not been certified for use in classified hazardous locations and lacked proper bonding/grounding. The solvent transfer process lacked ventilation controls and used non-approved equipment. Marwa was transported to the Laval Regional Hospital burn unit for treatment and was released after two days of observation.

On February 8, 2024, at 09:30 during the day shift, Aaliyah Jackson, Assembly Operator, suffered an acute eye injury while working at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019). A pressurized spray container of silicone release agent malfunctioned, suddenly discharging its contents in an unexpected direction. The spray splashed directly into Aaliyah's left eye, causing immediate pain and redness. Although Aaliyah was wearing standard safety glasses (not splash-rated), the spray found its way around the frame, contacting the cornea and conjunctiva. Nearby coworker Diego Morales immediately initiated first aid by guiding Aaliyah to the eyewash station located 8 meters away. Aaliyah flushed her eye for approximately 15 minutes while Diego notified Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos. Basic first aid assessment showed mild conjunctival irritation and temporary vision blurring. Nina applied sterile saline irrigation pads and monitored Aaliyah for 30 minutes. Given the nature of the substance (silicone-based with no declared hazardous constituents beyond eye irritant), Aaliyah declined transport to emergency care. However, she was referred to occupational health for follow-up assessment 24 hours later, which confirmed mild chemical conjunctivitis resolving without corneal damage. The incident was classified as recordable under CNESST guidelines.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM, production operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was working at Injection Molding Line A when she noticed a small laceration on her left index finger from a sharp edge on a freshly ejected automotive component. The injury occurred while removing parts from the mold without wearing cut-resistant gloves, contrary to standard procedure. The laceration was approximately 1.5 cm long and bleeding moderately. Sana immediately reported the incident to her supervisor, Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), who was present at the workstation. First aid was administered on-site: the wound was cleaned with antiseptic solution, dressed with a sterile bandage, and wrapped with medical tape. No sutures were required. The employee continued working for the remainder of the shift with the injury properly bandaged. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified and documented the incident. A safety toolbox talk was conducted the following morning regarding proper PPE usage during part removal operations.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, maintenance planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) was performing routine maintenance on a propane-powered forklift in the Finished Goods Warehouse. While inspecting the fuel connections, a small propane leak developed from a deteriorated connection valve. Thanh noticed the characteristic odor of propane and immediately evacuated the immediate area, shouting warnings to nearby warehouse staff. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) and Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) both evacuated to a safe distance approximately 50 meters away. The warehouse was ventilated for 20 minutes before operations resumed. Thanh sustained mild symptoms of dizziness and nausea from brief exposure to propane vapors in the confined maintenance area. He was assisted to fresh air by Lucie and rested for approximately 2 hours before being transported to the occupational health clinic for evaluation. Clinical assessment confirmed mild inhalation exposure with no lasting effects. The forklift was immediately tagged out and removed from service for full fuel system replacement.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area. Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) was preparing composite resin for a medical device production run when he inadvertently knocked over a 55-liter drum of epoxy resin catalyst (containing dimethylaniline) while repositioning containers. Approximately 40 liters spilled across the floor, spreading toward the electrical junction box and creating a hazardous chemical vapor. The pungent odor immediately alerted nearby IT Systems Administrator Jean-Pierre Nadeau (EMP-00111), who was performing night network maintenance. Rodrigue immediately activated the spill alarm and evacuated the area. Composite Materials Lead Samantha Brown (EMP-00146), who was monitoring production from the adjacent area, responded with the spill containment kit. The chemical was contained using absorbent material and neutralization procedures as outlined in the facility's chemical handling procedures. The affected area was thoroughly ventilated for 45 minutes before safe cleanup was completed. No personnel sustained direct skin or eye contact, though three employees experienced mild respiratory irritation from vapor exposure. All affected employees were assessed at the occupational health clinic.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Ana Silva (Assembly Operator, EMP-00040) was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) assembling medical device housings for quality control verification. While manually inserting precision-molded components into protective packaging, Ana sustained a minor laceration on her left index finger from a sharp edge on an improperly trimmed plastic component. The component had a micro-burr approximately 2mm in length that was not caught during the QC inspection phase. Ana immediately reported the injury to her supervisor, Anika Johansson, who provided first aid using the facility's first aid kit. The wound was cleaned with antiseptic solution, the bleeding was controlled with pressure and a sterile bandage, and antibiotic ointment was applied. No sutures were required. Ana completed an incident report and continued working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. A witness, Jasmine Patel (Quality Inspector, EMP-00150), observed the incident and confirmed that the component's edge quality was substandard.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). Nadia Belkacem (Receiving Coordinator, EMP-00142) was transferring rejected batch material—approximately 45 liters of uncured polyol resin formulation—from a 200-liter collection drum to a 55-liter secondary container for disposal processing. The secondary container's lid was not properly secured, and as Nadia tilted the transfer pump apparatus, the container tipped over, spilling an estimated 38 liters of polyol resin across the concrete floor. The spill spread approximately 6 meters in length and 3 meters in width. The polyol resin is classified as a hazardous material (flash point 185°C, skin irritant) and requires immediate containment. Nadia immediately notified her supervisor and activated the spill response protocol. The Chemical Safety Officer, Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), was called to the site. Emergency absorbent materials (diatomaceous earth-based spill kit) were deployed, and the spill was contained within 25 minutes. Tran Le (Quality Control Lab Technician, EMP-00036) served as witness and documented the incident. The affected area was cordoned off with warning tape, and hazardous waste disposal contractor was contacted for cleanup of contaminated absorbent materials.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during the night shift, Ahmed Hassan (Injection Molding Operator - Line B, EMP-00014) sustained a serious crush injury while performing scheduled maintenance on an injection molding machine. Ahmed was attempting to clear a material jam in the hopper of a 200-ton Arburg injection molding machine (Machine 15-B) in the production area. Despite initiating the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure, a critical step was missed: the hopper chute hydraulic ram was not fully de-pressurized before Ahmed began manual material extraction. As Ahmed reached into the hopper with his right hand, pressure in the hydraulic system released unexpectedly, and the hopper ram descended rapidly, crushing Ahmed's right hand between the hopper floor and the descending ram. Ahmed immediately withdrew his hand and called for assistance. His supervisor, Raj Patel (Process Engineer, EMP-00018), responded within two minutes. Ahmed's right hand sustained significant crush injuries: contusions on all fingers, a fracture of the fourth metacarpal bone, and severe soft tissue damage to the palm and dorsal surface. Emergency medical services (EMS) was called at 12:35 AM, and Ahmed was transported to the nearest trauma center at 12:52 AM. Hospital imaging confirmed the metacarpal fracture requiring surgical intervention. The incident was witnessed by Julien Racine (Shipping Clerk, EMP-00177), who was present for equipment relocation work. LOTO tags and documentation were reviewed post-incident, revealing the incomplete de-pressurization procedure on the specific hopper ram system.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Machine Operator Emmanuel Kouassi (EMP-00058) was working on Injection Molding Line A during the evening shift setup when he noticed unusual vibration and grinding sounds coming from the hydraulic pump assembly. The pump, which had been in continuous operation for 18 months without scheduled maintenance, began leaking hydraulic fluid onto the production floor. Emmanuel immediately shut down the machine and notified his supervisor. Upon inspection by the maintenance team, it was discovered that the pump's internal seals had deteriorated completely, and metal shavings were present in the hydraulic fluid reservoir—indicating bearing wear. The equipment failure resulted in a complete production shutdown affecting the automotive component molding schedule. The machine remained non-operational for 6 hours while emergency repairs were coordinated. Root cause analysis revealed that the predictive maintenance program had flagged this pump for service three weeks prior, but the work order was not prioritized due to staffing constraints in the Maintenance department.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:45 AM during day shift operations, Quality Control Lab Technician Tran Le (EMP-00036) was conducting routine chemical testing in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when he noticed a small crack forming in the valve assembly of a 200-liter resin storage tank. The tank was pressurized to 15 PSI and contained a mixture of epoxy resin and hardener. Tran immediately recognized the hazard and evacuated the immediate area, then notified Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069). The crack was located near a weld joint that showed stress corrosion cracking—a condition that could have resulted in a complete catastrophic failure and chemical spill of approximately 180 liters into the production floor. Simon responded within 5 minutes, verified the hazard by visual inspection, and implemented emergency containment procedures. The tank was isolated using manual shut-off valves, and the contents were carefully transferred to a secondary storage vessel over the course of 90 minutes. No chemical spill occurred, and no personnel were exposed to hazardous materials. The incident was classified as a near-miss because the hazard was identified and controlled before any release occurred.

On November 21, 2024, at 6:30 PM during evening shift operations, Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148) discovered that the Regrind and Recycling Department had experienced an uncontrolled discharge of plastic waste material into the storm drain system located adjacent to the warehouse facility. Approximately 450 kilograms of shredded polycarbonate and polystyrene waste, along with processing water containing trace amounts of mold release agent residue, had accumulated in the collection bin and overflowed through a defective drain valve that had been leaking for an estimated 8-10 hours. The material entered the storm water runoff channel, which flows directly into the Laval municipal storm drainage system and ultimately into the Saint-Laurent River watershed. Salma immediately reported the incident to Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), who coordinated with the HSE department. Environmental monitoring was initiated, and the company contacted the CNESST environmental compliance office and Laval municipal authorities as required by Quebec environmental regulations. The facility was required to file an environmental incident report within 24 hours. Root cause investigation revealed that the drain valve had been scheduled for replacement 6 weeks prior but was postponed due to budget reallocation. No personnel were injured, but the incident represents a reportable environmental release under provincial environmental protection legislation.

On March 14, 2024, at 14:45, Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180) was conducting a visual inspection of finished composite parts in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008) when she noticed a wooden pallet stack leaning precariously against the wall. As she attempted to photograph the unstable configuration for documentation, the top pallet shifted and began to tip toward her. Fernandes quickly stepped backward and the pallet missed her by approximately 18 inches, landing on the concrete floor with a loud crash. The near-miss was immediately reported to Zahra Nasri, the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist. Investigation revealed that the pallets had been stacked improperly during the evening shift without regard to weight distribution or stability protocols. No employees were injured, but the incident highlighted a critical gap in warehouse organization procedures. The warehouse supervisor acknowledged that recent staffing changes on the evening shift had resulted in inconsistent adherence to material stacking guidelines established in the facility's safety manual.

On April 8, 2024, at 22:30 during the evening shift, Machine Setter Tomas Jimenez (EMP-00124) was performing routine maintenance on injection molding equipment in the Main Production Building when he discovered that a hydraulic hose connector had partially loosened from vibration during extended operation. As Jimenez began to hand-tighten the connector while the system remained pressurized at 2,000 PSI, a fine mist of hydraulic fluid sprayed onto his face and exposed skin on his arms. Jimenez immediately shut down the system and moved to the emergency eyewash station where he rinsed his eyes and face for the full 15-minute protocol. Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand (EMP-00087) responded and provided first aid assessment. The exposed skin showed minor redness and irritation but no significant injury resulted. However, the incident was classified as a near-miss because Jimenez could have sustained serious chemical burns or eye damage if the pressurized spray had contacted his eyes directly or if the duration of exposure had been longer. Root cause analysis identified that pre-shift equipment inspections had been eliminated due to time pressures, and operators were not consistently checking hydraulic connections.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, was removing a molded part from a 300-ton injection molding machine when his right hand became caught between the mold halves as they unexpectedly closed. The machine's safety interlock had been bypassed by maintenance personnel earlier that morning for troubleshooting purposes and was never re-enabled. Conrad sustained a crush injury to his right palm and fingers, resulting in fractures to the 3rd and 4th metacarpals and severe soft tissue damage. He was immediately transported to Laval Hospital by ambulance and admitted for surgery. The incident occurred during day shift in the Injection Molding Line A - Automotive unit. Witnesses included Jade Wong (Process Technician) and Ibrahim Yusuf (Machine Setter), who immediately activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. Investigation revealed the safety bypass protocol lacked proper documentation and re-activation verification procedures.

On April 2, 2024 at 22:15, during evening shift operations in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop mezzanine, Gaston Picard (EMP-00193), a Crane Operator, was repositioning overhead storage racks to make space for new hydraulic cylinder inventory. A poorly secured aluminum beam that was resting on the top shelf of a storage rack shifted and fell approximately 8 feet, striking a nearby workbench and damaging three precision CMM calibration fixtures valued at approximately $47,000. The beam also destroyed two complete hydraulic hose assemblies ($3,200) and crushed an inventory management computer terminal ($2,100). No personnel were struck by the falling beam as Gaston had stepped away moments before the collapse to retrieve lifting equipment. The incident was caused by deteriorated shelf support welds and inadequate load calculations for the storage configuration. Gilles Marchand (Facilities Maintenance Technician) discovered the damage during his evening walkthrough and immediately reported it to Samira El-Khoury (EHS Coordinator).

On May 8, 2024 at 09:30, Ana Silva (EMP-00040), an Assembly Operator working in the Assembly and Finishing Department, sustained a laceration to her left index finger while hand-finishing a batch of automotive interior trim components. The plastic part had a sharp, unfinished edge that had not been properly deburred during the molding process quality control stage. Ana was inspecting and assembling components when her finger caught on the edge, creating a 2-centimeter laceration requiring 4 stitches at the on-site first aid station. The incident was witnessed by Omar Said (EMP-00122), a Production Operator, who immediately accompanied Ana to the first aid clinic. Investigation revealed that the deburring quality check had been skipped on this particular batch due to equipment maintenance that morning. Ana received proper wound cleaning, suturing by the company nurse, tetanus verification, and was provided with protective gloves and a wound care kit. She returned to light duty work after 2 hours of first aid treatment. Samira El-Khoury documented the incident and provided follow-up care instructions.

On March 14, 2025 at 2:15 PM, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter on the day shift, was performing maintenance on Injection Molding Line D when a sudden machine startup occurred. While cleaning internal components with the machine in what he believed was a locked-out state, a coworker inadvertently restarted the equipment from a remote control station without verifying LOTO procedures. Fournier's right hand became caught in the molding press closure mechanism, resulting in severe crush injuries to his index and middle fingers. The machine was immediately stopped by nearby Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) who witnessed the incident. Emergency services transported Fournier to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé with compound fractures requiring surgical intervention. He was hospitalized for 6 days and lost 15 working days due to recovery and subsequent complications. The incident revealed critical gaps in LOTO enforcement and communication protocols between maintenance and operating personnel.

On April 8, 2025 at 11:45 PM during the night shift, a fire alarm activation occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B) without any actual fire emergency. The incident began when Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was conducting routine inventory on the mezzanine level near stored finished goods pallets. While repositioning boxes of packaged composite materials, she inadvertently bumped an overhead sprinkler head, damaging its protective cap. Water began trickling onto stacked electrical equipment below, causing a short circuit in the warehouse management system's power distribution box. The short circuit triggered a false alarm signal to the facility's fire detection system. The alarm automatically activated the emergency notification system, initiating building evacuation procedures. Fire department responded within 8 minutes, finding no fire but confirming the sprinkler malfunction. The incident resulted in 2 hours of operational downtime, disrupted night shift activities, and identified inadequate clearance around fire safety infrastructure. No injuries occurred, but the incident revealed maintenance gaps in protective equipment and insufficient training on equipment positioning near critical systems.

On May 22, 2025 at 1:30 AM during the night shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Area that escalated to fire risk conditions. Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on evening shift working overtime, was transferring isopropanol solvent from a storage container to a mixing tank when a faulty valve seal failed, causing approximately 15 liters of isopropanol to spray across the floor and onto nearby storage shelves. The flammable solvent pooled near a heat exchanger operating at elevated temperature, creating ignition risk. A lit cigarette discarded by an unidentified person near the entrance ignited solvent vapors approximately 3 minutes after the spill occurred. A small fire (approximately 2 meters in diameter) erupted near the storage area. Night shift supervisor Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182), who was working as Material Handler, immediately activated the emergency alarm and deployed a Class B fire extinguisher, successfully suppressing the flames within 90 seconds. Fire department arrived and confirmed fire containment. The facility was evacuated for 45 minutes while atmospheric monitoring confirmed solvent vapor levels had returned to safe ranges. No injuries occurred, but the incident damaged approximately $18,000 worth of stored materials and equipment. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate maintenance of valve seals, insufficient ventilation in chemical storage areas, and lack of enforcement of no-smoking policies near flammable materials storage.

On March 14, 2025 at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Material Handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was transferring raw composite resin material from a 55-gallon drum into the hopper of Injection Molding Line A when the hopper lid suddenly became dislodged. As he was tightening the securing clamp, the material began to overflow onto the production floor in a thick stream. Owusu immediately stepped back and activated the emergency stop button, preventing the complete discharge. The spilled material (approximately 20 gallons of uncured epoxy resin) created a significant slipping hazard and released volatile organic compound fumes into the workspace. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) witnessed the incident and immediately evacuated nearby workers. The HSE team responded within 3 minutes, ventilated the area using portable fans, and cordoned off the affected zone. No injuries occurred, but the near-miss potential was high—had Owusu not reacted quickly, the overflow could have caused chemical burns and a floor-based slip hazard affecting multiple workers during shift changeover. The incident was traced to improper hopper lid maintenance performed during the previous night shift.

On March 17, 2025 at 9:47 PM during the evening shift, an electrical fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) due to a detected temperature anomaly in the resin mixing equipment. Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) responded immediately with the facility's emergency response team. Upon investigation, a failed heating element in one of the industrial mixing tanks had begun to overheat, causing the thermostatic overload sensor to activate the alarm system. The temperature had reached 185°C, exceeding the safe operating range of 165°C by approximately 12%. While the alarm functioned correctly and prevented equipment damage, the root cause was a lack of preventive maintenance scheduling for heating elements. The facility was evacuated for 18 minutes as a precautionary measure. The equipment was safely cooled down, and no fire or explosive conditions developed. However, this incident revealed a critical gap in predictive maintenance procedures for chemical processing equipment. Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) assisted with the evacuation coordination and confirmed all personnel accounted for.

On March 19, 2025 at 10:33 AM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Carmen Lopez (EMP-00078) sustained a minor cut to her left index finger while handling a sharp composite edge on a freshly molded medical device component. She was performing quality inspection and part removal from the fixture when her finger caught the unfinished composite edge, creating a laceration approximately 1.2 cm in length and 0.3 cm deep. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) immediately directed her to the first aid station where HSE Training Coordinator Amélie Roy (EMP-00028) provided treatment. The wound was cleaned with sterile saline solution, a thin layer of antibiotic ointment was applied, and the cut was covered with a sterile adhesive bandage. No sutures were required. The operator was advised to keep the wound clean and to monitor for signs of infection. She returned to modified duties (visual inspection only, no part handling) for the remainder of the shift and resumed full duties the following day. The incident was documented as a first-aid treatment case. The root cause was identified as inadequate edge finishing on components from the upstream molding process, combined with the operator not wearing cut-resistant gloves during part inspection.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during the day shift, a chemical storage technician discovered that approximately 50 liters of acetone had leaked from a damaged storage container in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. The container, labeled for mold release agent storage, had been knocked over by a forklift during routine material repositioning. The acetone vapor concentration in the room reached hazardous levels (650 ppm), exceeding WHMIS exposure limits. The spill occurred on a concrete floor with inadequate secondary containment, allowing the solvent to spread toward the room's drainage system. A production operator who entered the room to collect materials complained of headache and eye irritation within 5 minutes. Emergency response was activated immediately: the area was evacuated, ventilation systems were maximized, and the spill was contained using absorbent materials. The affected employee was monitored and released after symptoms subsided. Post-incident investigation revealed the container had corroded due to improper storage conditions and the forklift operator had not followed proper traffic control procedures in the chemical storage area.

On March 22, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, an injection molding technician (Christian Gosselin) was adjusting the mold temperature controls on Injection Molding Line B when his right hand contacted the ejector pin mechanism as it cycled unexpectedly. The mold had not completed its full cooling cycle, and the automatic ejection sequence initiated due to a faulty proximity sensor that failed to detect the technician's presence in the danger zone. The ejector pins struck his hand, causing a crushing injury to three fingers (middle, ring, and pinky). The technician immediately withdrew his hand, and the mold cycling completed. A witness production operator activated the emergency stop and called for medical assistance. The technician was transported to Laval Hospital where X-rays confirmed displaced fractures of the 4th and 5th metacarpals and crush syndrome affecting all three fingers. He was hospitalized for 18 hours and required orthopedic surgery. Investigation revealed the proximity sensor had not been replaced in over 18 months despite a maintenance schedule recommending replacement every 12 months.

On March 28, 2024, at 09:30 during the day shift, a material handler (Bianca De Luca) was organizing inventory in the Shipping and Receiving Dock when she stepped on a wooden pallet edge while reaching for boxes on a high shelf. The pallet had been stacked improperly with one corner extending into the main walkway. Her foot rolled off the pallet edge, causing her to twist her left ankle. She fell to the ground and reported immediate sharp pain. A coworker helped her to the first aid station where the workplace nurse evaluated her. The nurse assessed the injury as a moderate ankle sprain with possible ligament involvement. Ice was applied, the ankle was wrapped with compression bandaging, and the employee was advised to seek medical evaluation. The employee attended a local clinic where X-rays confirmed a Grade 2 ankle sprain. She was advised to rest the ankle for 2-3 weeks with follow-up care. Root cause analysis identified that the pallet had been positioned incorrectly by warehouse staff during an inventory reorganization, and there was inadequate floor marking to indicate hazardous pallet placement.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, machine setter Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Main Production Building. While attempting to clear a blockage in the hopper system without following proper lockout/tagout procedures, the machine suddenly cycled unexpectedly. Ibrahim's right hand was caught between the rotating screw assembly and the hopper wall, resulting in severe laceration and partial amputation of his index and middle fingers. Coworkers immediately activated the emergency stop and called for first aid. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette responded within 2 minutes and administered immediate first aid before paramedics transported Ibrahim to Hôpital de la Cité in Laval. The incident occurred due to incomplete LOTO compliance and lack of lockout verification by the maintenance supervisor. Ibrahim underwent emergency surgery and was hospitalized for 4 days.

On March 22, 2024, at 11:15 PM during the night shift, warehouse associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) was refilling cleaning solvent containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-011). While transferring acetone from a 55-gallon drum using a manual pump, the pump seal failed catastrophically, releasing approximately 12 gallons of acetone across the hazardous waste management area floor. The spill spread across the concrete surface creating a volatile vapor cloud. Yvon attempted to contain the spill using standard absorbent pads, but the chemical rapidly saturated the materials and continued spreading toward a storm drain on the exterior zone. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois was called to the scene and immediately activated the spill containment protocol. She deployed emergency dikes and absorbent booms to prevent environmental discharge while evacuating non-essential personnel. The incident required 6 hours of remediation, including soil sampling and documentation for CNESST reporting. Root cause was lack of preventive maintenance on chemical transfer equipment and absence of secondary containment in the mixing area.

On April 2, 2024, at 8:30 AM during the day shift, materials engineer Jing Wang (EMP-00054) was inspecting finished composite materials in the Packaging and Labeling Station when a deteriorated metal storage rack holding approximately 800 pounds of packaged polycarbonate components suddenly collapsed without warning. The rack's corroded support welds failed, causing the entire load to crash to the floor with significant force. The falling materials damaged numerous finished goods and destroyed palletized components worth approximately $47,000. Fortunately, no personnel were directly struck as the area had been temporarily evacuated for cleaning. Jing immediately notified Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) and Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115). An inspection revealed that the rack had not been inspected or maintained in over 5 years, with visible rust and corrosion throughout. The facility's material storage system had no documented inspection schedule, no load-rating verification, and no preventive maintenance program. The incident revealed critical gaps in asset management and facility maintenance oversight.

On March 14, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a hydraulic line rupture occurred on Injection Molding Line B in the North Zone. Operator Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) was conducting routine material feed adjustments when pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed across a 6-foot section of the molding equipment, saturating electrical junction boxes and control panels. The fluid contacted a live 480V circuit breaker, creating an electrical arc that damaged nearby wiring harnesses and control modules valued at approximately $47,000. The incident was immediately isolated by line supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015), who activated emergency stop protocols and initiated equipment lockout procedures. Production supervisor Julie Bergeron witnessed the arc flash event and called for immediate support. The hydraulic leak was traced to a corroded fitting that had not been replaced during the previous maintenance cycle, despite visible corrosion noted in February inspection reports. No personnel were injured, but the equipment remained offline for 18 hours pending electrical system inspection and hydraulic system replacement.

On April 2, 2024 at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Material Handler Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polycarbonate solvent (dichloromethane) from storage to the drying station using a drum dolly when the drum's bung plug became loose during transport. Approximately 12 gallons of the volatile organic compound spilled across the concrete floor, creating a chemical hazard zone approximately 20 feet in diameter. The fumes from the spill activated the facility's VOC detection system at 9:30 PM but were not immediately addressed due to miscommunication between evening shift supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) and the on-call maintenance team. Material Handler Rashid Habib (EMP-00154) discovered the spill during a routine supply check and immediately evacuated the area, activating the emergency response protocol. Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) was called in and documented the spill at 10:45 PM. The area was sealed off, and professional hazmat contractor spent 4 hours containing and absorbing the chemical. Root cause analysis revealed the drum's bung had not been properly secured during the previous transfer, and no verification checklist was being followed for chemical drum handling.

On April 18, 2024 at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift operations, Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) sustained a severe laceration to his left forearm while manually removing partially cooled plastic components from Injection Molding Line B. The operator was clearing a production jam when his left arm contacted an exposed pinch point where the mold clamp mechanism was operating. The clamp partially closed on his forearm, creating a deep 4-inch laceration requiring 15 stitches and resulting in immediate hospitalization at Sacré-Cœur Hospital. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) was notified and arrived on scene within 8 minutes, providing first aid and coordinating with emergency medical services. Night shift supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) secured the equipment and interviewed witnesses. Root cause investigation revealed: (1) the machine's safety interlocks had been bypassed to increase production speed during a high-demand order, (2) operator Omar Said had not received updated training on the machine's hazard zones, and (3) production scheduling pressure led to unsafe work practices. The employee sustained lost time exceeding 14 days and underwent follow-up surgical evaluation to assess nerve and tendon damage.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, was transferring bundles of carbon fiber reinforcement materials from the storage shelf in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) when a wooden pallet underneath the materials suddenly split due to dry rot. The weight shift caused the bundle to tilt toward Owusu. He quickly stepped backward and raised his arm protectively. The bundle passed within 6 inches of his left shoulder, missing him by a minimal margin, and crashed onto the floor directly behind where he had been standing just 1.2 seconds prior. No contact was made with Owusu's body. Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), an Assembly Operator working nearby, observed the near-miss and immediately reported the incident to supervisor Yves Thibault. Investigation revealed the pallet had been in service for over 5 years without documented inspection. The incident classification is NEAR_MISS with severity score of 6 due to high potential for serious crushing injuries had the timing been slightly different.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 5:30 AM during night shift operations, Daniel Kim (EMP-00025), an Electrical Maintenance Technician, was performing routine maintenance on the ventilation control system in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010) when he discovered a corroded electrical connector on a motor control module. While inspecting the connector more closely with a multimeter, Kim noticed slight arcing between the terminals, indicating potential arc flash hazard. He immediately stopped work, disconnected the equipment at the main panel, and locked out the circuit using LOTO procedures. No physical contact with electrical current occurred, and no injuries resulted. Kim notified André Bellavance (EMP-00157), the Confined Space Entry Supervisor, of the potential hazard. This near-miss situation resulted from deferred maintenance on electrical connections in the chemically corrosive environment. The incident demonstrates successful application of safety protocols that prevented serious injury, classified as NEAR_MISS with severity score of 5. Had Kim contacted the corroded connector before noticing the arcing, severe electrical burns or arc flash injuries could have resulted.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45 on the day shift, Omar Said (EMP-00122), a Production Operator on Injection Molding Line B, was performing routine material feeding when the servo motor controlling the mold clamping mechanism began exhibiting erratic behavior. The motor had been showing signs of wear for approximately two weeks, with occasional stuttering observed during cycle operations. At 14:47, the clamping mechanism suddenly released mid-cycle while a mold containing hot plastic material was positioned for cooling. The pressurized mold sprayed hot plastic residue across Omar's right arm and shoulder, causing second-degree thermal burns. The incident was immediately reported to François-Xavier Mailhot (Maintenance Supervisor) who activated first aid protocols. Omar was treated on-site by the company nurse for approximately 45 minutes with ice water immersion and sterile dressing application before being transported to Laval General Hospital for further evaluation. The servo motor subsequently failed complete diagnostic testing, revealing internal bearing degradation and inadequate lubrication as root causes. The machine remained offline for investigation.

On November 18, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162), an Assembly Operator in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment unit, sustained a laceration to her left index and middle fingers while assembling composite material components. Isabella was performing manual deburring of injection-molded edges using a handheld rotary tool when her left hand slipped into the spinning burring wheel. She immediately withdrew her hand, but not before the high-speed abrasive wheel created a deep cut approximately 3cm in length across the proximal phalanx area of both fingers. Blood loss was moderate (estimated 150-200mL). Colleague Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042) witnessed the incident and immediately alerted the shift supervisor. First aid responder Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), the Safety Officer, arrived within 4 minutes and applied direct pressure with sterile gauze, elevated the hand, and initiated wound management protocols. After 12 minutes of pressure application, bleeding was controlled. Isabella received on-site wound irrigation, topical antibiotic application, and sterile bandaging. She was released with instructions for self-care monitoring, provided with emergency contact information for after-hours complications, and scheduled for a follow-up visit with occupational health the next morning.

On November 22, 2024, at 03:30 during the night shift, Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate in the Finished Goods Warehouse, experienced a chemical exposure incident while organizing stored resin barrels. Marc was performing inventory rotation when he noticed a small pinhole leak in a polyester resin barrel (approximately 55-gallon size) stored in Section B. As he attempted to reposition the barrel to prevent further spillage, the pinhole rupture suddenly enlarged, releasing an estimated 2-3 liters of liquid resin across the warehouse floor and partially onto Marc's work boots and lower pant legs. The resin began to polymerize rapidly due to elevated ambient temperature (23°C) and the presence of catalytic residue on the floor from previous handling. Marc experienced immediate skin irritation, mild burning sensation, and strong chemical odor exposure. He immediately removed his contaminated boots and notified his supervisor by radio. Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003), EHS Coordinator on-call, arrived at 03:42 and initiated emergency response protocols. Marc was directed to the eyewash/shower station where he rinsed his feet and lower legs with water for 15 minutes under guidance. Examination revealed chemical irritation of the skin (mild erythema) but no deep burns. A respiratory assessment confirmed no inhalation damage. Marc was cleared to return to duties after receiving new PPE and reassignment to non-chemical handling tasks for the remainder of the shift.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Production Operator Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172) was performing routine material loading at Injection Molding Machine #7 in the Main Production Building when she reached to guide a batch of pre-heated polycarbonate pellets into the hopper. A malfunction in the machine's temperature control system caused the barrel to exceed safe operating limits, reaching 290°C instead of the standard 260°C setpoint. As Okafor guided the material, a sudden surge of molten plastic ejected from the barrel opening, spraying her right hand and forearm. She immediately withdrew her hand and immersed it in the emergency eyewash station. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert responded within seconds, activating first aid protocols and contacting emergency services. The employee sustained second-degree thermal burns across the dorsum of her right hand and the lateral forearm, requiring hospitalization for wound management and pain control. Maintenance staff later identified a failed temperature sensor as the root cause of the overheat condition.

On March 18, 2024, at 10:45 AM, Electrical Maintenance Lead Claude Rioux (EMP-00185) was conducting a routine equipment inspection in the Central Maintenance Workshop when he observed significant dust accumulation on the upper surfaces of electrical panels and motor housings in the area. During his visual assessment, he noticed that dust had collected to approximately 1/4 inch thickness on multiple high-voltage equipment enclosures, creating a potential fire hazard per NFPA 652 guidelines for combustible dust management. The dust appeared to be a mixture of plastic resin particles from the adjacent material handling systems and synthetic fiber particles. Rioux immediately ceased work in the area and documented the hazard condition with photographs. He contacted the HSE department and initiated a work order to prevent any electrical ignition sources until the area could be properly cleaned. No injuries or incidents occurred; this was identified as a proactive hazard recognition during routine maintenance activities. The facility's recent expansion of medical device production had increased material throughput, contributing to elevated dust levels that exceeded the established housekeeping standards.

On March 20, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during evening shift operations, Quality Control Lead Petra Mueller (EMP-00166) was inspecting finished composite components in the Raw Materials Warehouse when she discovered that Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez (EMP-00092) had suffered a minor laceration to his left palm while operating the plastic grinder earlier that afternoon. Ramirez explained that while clearing a minor jam in the grinding chamber (with the machine powered off), he had attempted to use his bare hand rather than the provided retrieval tool, and when he placed his hand in the chamber to remove lodged material, the piece suddenly came loose, causing his palm to contact the grinding wheel surface momentarily. The laceration was superficial, approximately 2 cm in length, with minimal bleeding. Mueller immediately directed Ramirez to the first aid station where Supply Chain Analyst Miriam Cohen (EMP-00132), who holds current First Aid certification, cleaned the wound with sterile gauze, applied antibiotic ointment, and dressed it with sterile adhesive bandages. No sutures were required, and the injury was classified as a minor first aid case. Ramirez was able to return to modified duty without lost time, though he was restricted from operating grinding equipment for 48 hours pending reassessment.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), an Injection Molding Operator on Line D, suffered a serious burn injury while attempting to remove a stuck part from Injection Molding Machine #18 in the Production Operations area. The machine's mold temperature was set to 280°C for processing polycarbonate components for a medical device customer. Bruno did not wait for the mold to cool sufficiently and contacted the hot mold surface with his right palm while using a metal tool to dislodge a part that had partially fused to the cavity. He sustained second-degree thermal burns across approximately 15% of his palm and inner fingers. The incident occurred during day shift operations with limited supervision, as the area's assistant supervisor was attending a meeting. Bruno immediately immersed his hand in cold water and reported to the on-site medical clinic. He was treated for thermal burns and prescribed topical antibiotics and pain medication. Due to the severity of the burn and risk of infection, he was unable to return to work for eight business days, resulting in significant lost time from his regular production duties.

On November 8, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, the automated cooling water circulation system for the injection molding machines experienced a critical pump failure in the Composite Materials Processing Area (Unit 015). The primary circulation pump, which had been in continuous operation for 18 months without scheduled maintenance, suddenly seized with an audible grinding noise. This caused immediate loss of coolant flow to five active molding machines, resulting in rapid temperature buildup in the equipment. Within minutes, two machines began showing overheating alarms and automatic shutdown was triggered by the safety interlocks. Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), the Hydraulic Systems Technician, and Alain Gravel (EMP-00131), the Night Shift Maintenance Technician, responded to the alarms. They discovered the pump had internal bearing failure and metal debris contamination in the coolant lines. The equipment was safely de-energized. Investigation revealed no preventive maintenance work orders had been completed on this pump since installation in May 2023, violating the company's ISO 45001 maintenance schedule. Production was halted for 3.5 hours while the pump was replaced, resulting in approximately 420 units of lost production capacity and scheduling delays for the customer.

On November 10, 2024, at approximately 8:20 AM during day shift operations, Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler in the Materials Management and Warehousing area, sustained a laceration to her left index finger while organizing resin hoppers in Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (Unit 025). While manually stacking polypropylene resin bags against a metal storage rack, a sharp burr or edge on the rack's corner caught and tore through the outer layer of her work glove, creating a 2-centimeter laceration on the inside of her index finger. The cut was clean but moderately deep, with minor bleeding. Mariam immediately reported to the on-site first aid station where Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069), Chemical Safety Officer, provided wound irrigation, applied antiseptic solution, and dressed the wound with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. No stitches were required. The injury was documented as first aid treatment only. Mariam returned to her duties within 30 minutes with the wound properly bandaged and wearing a reinforced glove on the injured hand. She experienced minor discomfort throughout the remainder of her shift but completed all assigned material handling tasks. No lost work time occurred. The incident highlighted an equipment maintenance issue with the storage rack's sharp edges that had not been previously identified.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Machine Operator Hawa Traore was performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Line A during the evening shift changeover. While wiping down the mold cavity with a lint-free cloth, she noticed residual plastic material buildup around the ejector pins. She proceeded to use compressed air from the facility's air line to blow out the debris without first verifying that the machine had been properly locked out. The compression nozzle slipped from her grip and the high-pressure stream (approximately 90 psi) struck her left forearm, causing a small laceration and temporary numbness. A witness, Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert, immediately shut down the equipment and applied first aid. The employee reported the incident to Safety Officer Anh Nguyen within 15 minutes. Investigation revealed that the LOTO procedure had not been fully completed before cleaning commenced, and the employee had not received recent refresher training on compressed air safety protocols.

On November 21, 2024 at 09:15, Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot and Electrical Maintenance Technician Daniel Kim were performing preventive maintenance on the hydraulic press system in the equipment storage area. While servicing the pump assembly, a hydraulic hose under high pressure (2,800 psi) suddenly ruptured without warning, spraying hot hydraulic fluid (approximately 140°F) across Daniel Kim's left arm and shoulder. The fluid penetrated his work shirt, causing a second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 15 square centimeters on his upper arm and shoulder blade. Immediate first aid was administered by Facilities Maintenance Technician Gilles Marchand, who was present in the workshop. The employee was transported to the emergency department at Hôpital de la Cité de la Santé by ambulance. Treatment included wound cleaning, topical antibiotic application, and pain management. The employee required 8 days of leave for recovery and wound care. Root cause analysis revealed that the hydraulic hose had not been replaced despite exceeding its 5-year service life specification by 18 months. The maintenance schedule had drifted due to staffing shortages.

On November 28, 2024 at 22:30, Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau was transferring recycled plastic material from a collection bin to the resin hopper in the Raw Materials Warehouse during the night shift. As he lifted a 25-kilogram bin onto the elevated loading platform, he felt a sudden sharp pain in his lower back. He attempted to continue working but experienced increasing discomfort and stiffness. By the end of his shift at 07:30 on November 29, he reported the incident to Night Shift Supervisor André Paradis. Initial assessment by the HSE team suggested possible muscle strain with no acute neurological symptoms. However, medical evaluation at a local clinic revealed a minor disc bulge at L4-L5 with nerve irritation. The operator was placed on modified duty (light administrative tasks only) for two weeks. Investigation revealed that the employee had not been trained on proper lifting mechanics for loads over 20 kilograms, and no mechanical lifting assistance equipment was available in the warehouse. The bin dimensions and weight distribution made it difficult to maintain proper spinal alignment during the lift.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Employee Hawa Traore (EMP-00178) was transferring a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin from the storage area when the drum's valve assembly failed, releasing approximately 20 liters of liquid resin onto the production floor. The spill occurred near the active fiber-reinforcement station where three other production operators were working. Due to inadequate ventilation in the west wing section and the volatile nature of the epoxy solvent, strong chemical fumes rapidly dispersed throughout the immediate work area. Two employees reported difficulty breathing and eye irritation within minutes. The incident was contained using absorbent material and the area was evacuated. Investigation revealed that the drum had been stored improperly in a location exposed to temperature fluctuations, causing seal degradation. The ventilation system in UNIT-015 had been operating at reduced capacity due to a filter that had not been replaced according to schedule.
