On March 18, 2024, during a routine production floor inspection at 10:30 AM, Safety Coordinator Gaétan Laplante identified a serious near-miss hazard in the Injection Molding Line C - Medical Components facility (UNIT-003). A compressed air hose running along the clean room production line had developed a hairline fracture approximately 2 meters from the injection mold station. The hose, which supplied air pressure to the mold-clamping mechanism, was deteriorated from age and had begun to show signs of micro-fractures. A production operator, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), had been working in close proximity to this hose for the entire morning shift without incident, but the potential for sudden hose failure creating a high-pressure air jet injury was significant. The hose showed no visible external damage that would have alerted workers to the hazard. A full investigation determined that the hose had not been replaced since the equipment installation 8 years prior, exceeding the manufacturer's recommended 5-year replacement interval. This was a preventive declaration made to avoid a serious injury incident.

On March 20, 2024, at 1:15 PM during the day shift at the Quality Control Laboratory (UNIT-006), a production operator, Maya Kumar (EMP-00138), sustained a thermal burn injury while conducting heat-resistance testing on medical device components. The test procedure required placing plastic samples into a 220°C oven and removing them after 5 minutes using provided tongs. Maya removed the sample and was transferring it to a cooling station when the component slipped from the tongs and fell onto the top of her left hand, causing immediate thermal burn across the dorsal surface. The burn was approximately 5cm x 3cm with partial-thickness injury (second-degree). First aid was immediately administered by Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026), who applied cool water for 15 minutes and sterile burn dressing. Maya was taken to a nearby urgent care facility for professional medical evaluation and treatment. The incident occurred because the testing tongs, while present in the lab, were not ergonomically designed for the size and shape of the specific components being tested, making secure grip difficult. Additionally, no heat-resistant gloves were required by the current procedure despite the high-temperature nature of the work.

On November 14, 2024 at approximately 2:15 PM, a fire alarm was triggered in the Injection Molding Line D facility (Main Production Building - South Zone) during the day shift. An operator, Emmanuel Kouassi, was conducting routine maintenance on injection molding machine #18 when he noticed smoke emanating from the hydraulic fluid reservoir area. The machine had experienced a slow leak over several days, and hydraulic fluid had accumulated on the electrical panel below. When the panel temperature rose during normal operation, the fluid ignited, creating a small fire. Emmanuel immediately activated the nearest fire alarm pull station and evacuated all personnel from the area following standard emergency protocols. The facility's automated suppression system activated within 45 seconds, extinguishing the fire before it spread to adjacent equipment or material storage areas. The evening shift supervisor, Guillaume Deschamps, arrived within minutes to coordinate the evacuation and liaison with emergency responders. Fire services arrived on scene at 2:28 PM and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. No injuries were sustained. The incident revealed a gap in preventive maintenance procedures for hydraulic equipment monitoring.

On December 3, 2024 at 10:45 PM, during the evening shift, a critical equipment failure occurred on the CNC milling machine in the Central Maintenance Workshop. Réjean Simard, the mold maintenance technician, was operating the machine to fabricate precision cavity components for a medical device mold when the spindle bearing housing suddenly fractured. The machine had been in service for 8,700 operating hours since the last major overhaul in 2019. Inspection revealed that the bearing assembly had developed internal micro-fractures due to inadequate lubrication and thermal cycling stress. The spindle locked up violently, causing sudden deceleration that transmitted shock loads through the drive train, resulting in damage to the gear assembly, belt drive system, and the spindle motor coupling. The machine immediately shut down via safety interlock. Ferrous metal fragments were contained within the machine enclosure, preventing secondary hazards. Repair assessment indicates approximately $87,000 in parts and labor needed to restore full functionality. Production of mold components for critical automotive orders was delayed by 6 days, impacting customer delivery schedules.

On December 18, 2024 at 6:20 AM, during the night shift, Mohamed Ibrahim, a regrind operator, suffered a serious back injury while performing material handling tasks in the Materials Management and Warehousing area. Mohamed was transferring plastic regrind material from a large collection bin into a pneumatic transfer hopper when he bent forward awkwardly to reach material at the bottom of the bin. He felt immediate sharp pain in his lower lumbar region and could not straighten up. Initial assessment indicated acute lower back strain with possible disc involvement. Mohamed was unable to continue working and was transported via ambulance to Laval General Hospital at 6:45 AM for emergency evaluation and imaging. Diagnostic imaging confirmed a herniated lumbar disc at the L5-S1 level with nerve involvement. Mohamed was hospitalized overnight for pain management and prescribed 6-8 weeks of restricted duty. Medical documentation classifies this as a lost-time injury requiring modified duty for 4 weeks followed by gradual return-to-work. The incident was attributed to awkward lifting posture, lack of mechanical assist equipment, and inadequate ergonomic training for material handling tasks.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, a fire alarm was triggered in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). An employee, Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), was transferring acetone from a large storage container into smaller mixing vessels when a static discharge ignited vapors near the transfer station. The resulting small flash fire activated the overhead sprinkler system and fire alarm. The facility was evacuated within 4 minutes following standard emergency procedures. Local fire department arrived within 8 minutes and confirmed the fire was extinguished by the sprinkler system. No personnel were injured, but approximately 20 liters of acetone was lost and the transfer equipment sustained minor damage. The incident revealed that the grounding cable on the transfer pump had corroded and was not functioning properly, creating a static hazard that was not detected during routine inspections. Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois (EMP-00011) responded and documented the event.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift, a material handling incident occurred at the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) located on the maintenance workshop storage mezzanine. Claude Poirier (EMP-00071), forklift operator, was retrieving hydraulic pump components from an upper shelf unit when the shelf bracket began to fail. As Poirier repositioned the forklift to access a different section, the entire shelf assembly (approximately 400 pounds of equipment and components) collapsed and fell 8 feet onto the forklift's overhead guard and cab roof. The impact dented the cab roof, cracked the protective guard, and scattered spare parts across the mezzanine floor. While the overhead guard prevented direct injury to Poirier, he sustained a minor neck strain from the impact jolt and reported discomfort. The incident was witnessed by Noor Ahmed (EMP-00076) from HR who was conducting a facility tour. Investigation revealed that the shelf unit had been overloaded beyond its rated capacity (marked 300 lbs maximum per shelf, but approximately 450 lbs stored), and the mounting bolts had corroded over 12 years of operation without replacement. EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) documented the property damage and equipment failure.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 8:30 AM during day shift, a minor workplace injury occurred at Injection Molding Line A - Automotive (UNIT-001). Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran (EMP-00046) was performing routine part inspection when he reached into a cooling hopper to retrieve a finished component. A burr or sharp edge on the interior of the plastic part created a laceration on the palm of his right hand, approximately 1.5 inches long and 0.25 inches deep. The cut began bleeding immediately. Tran notified his supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015), who applied first aid using materials from the production area first aid kit. After initial assessment, Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) was called to the production floor. Al-Rashid cleaned the wound with antiseptic, applied antibiotic ointment, and dressed it with sterile gauze and surgical tape. The nurse assessed that the wound did not require stitches but would need monitoring for infection. Tran was advised to keep the wound clean and dry, and to return to the nurse the following day for a check-up. The incident was documented as a first aid case. Root cause analysis identified that the injection mold had developed micro-burrs due to wear in the ejector pin area, which had not been detected during the previous quality control cycle. The part met dimensional specifications but had developed sharp edges not visible during standard visual inspection.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Assembly Operator Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186) was working at the assembly line in UNIT-005 (Assembly and Finishing Department) when she reached across a moving conveyor belt to retrieve a finished component. Her right sleeve caught on an unguarded pulley mechanism, pulling her hand into the belt-pulley interface. The machinery was not equipped with adequate guards and emergency stop procedures were not clearly posted at the workstation. Coworker Giovanni Bianchi witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button, preventing further entanglement. Valentina sustained a deep laceration on her right forearm requiring 12 stitches and a partial fracture of the radius bone. She was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur by ambulance at 15:10. The incident resulted in 21 days of lost work time during recovery and rehabilitation. Marie-Claude Beaumont (HSE Director) arrived on scene at 15:25 to secure the workstation and document evidence.

On April 3, 2024 at 11:20, a hopper overflow incident occurred in UNIT-016 (Material Drying and Preparation Room) at the polypropylene resin drying station. Production Operator Leila Farah (EMP-00130) was monitoring the automated material feed system when a Level sensor malfunction went undetected, allowing resin pellets to accumulate beyond the hopper capacity. Approximately 180 kilograms of dry polypropylene pellets spilled onto the floor, creating an airborne dust cloud containing ultrafine plastic particles. The material dispersed across 120 square meters of the preparation room and into the adjacent Material Drying area. Ventilation systems were unable to contain the dust generation, exposing 6 nearby employees to respiratory irritation. Industrial Engineer Priya Sharma (EMP-00038) was notified at 11:35 and immediately initiated emergency ventilation protocols and ordered all personnel to evacuate the affected zones. The spilled material required 4 hours of manual cleanup using vacuums equipped with HEPA filters. This incident is classified as a chemical/material spill with environmental contamination potential due to the airborne particulate nature and exposure to multiple workers.

On May 8, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Receiving Clerk Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085) was manually unloading cardboard boxes of nylon resin pellets from a delivery truck in the Warehouse and Shipping area (UNIT-019 Packaging and Labeling Station). He was reaching for a box positioned on the third tier of an unstable stack when the entire stack shifted and collapsed. Approximately 450 kilograms of boxes fell, with several striking Jacques on his left shoulder, upper back, and head. He was knocked to the ground and lost consciousness for approximately 2 minutes. Packaging Supervisor Patricia Martin (EMP-00035) discovered him at 22:18 and immediately called emergency services. Paramedics arrived at 22:35 and transported Jacques to Hôpital Général de Montréal with suspected spinal cord injury, multiple rib fractures, and a concussion. He remained hospitalized for 8 days and required 35 days of medical leave before returning to light duty work. Radiographs confirmed three rib fractures and significant soft tissue damage. Safety Trainer Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) attended the scene at 23:10 to initiate incident investigation and secure evidence.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, machine operator François Gagnon (EMP-00008) was performing routine setup on Injection Molding Line A when he noticed the hydraulic pressure gauge reading abnormally low. He informed his supervisor and was preparing to shut down the machine for inspection when he observed a small hydraulic fluid leak from a connection point near the injection unit. Before the machine could be fully secured, the pressure relief valve malfunctioned and a sudden burst of pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed toward Gagnon's arm. He quickly moved away, avoiding direct contact with the fluid jet. Céline Morin (EMP-00153), another operator on the same line, witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button. The area was cordoned off and Workplace Safety Representative Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) was called to assess the situation. The machine was locked out and tagged out within 15 minutes. No one was struck by the pressurized fluid, but the incident demonstrated a critical gap in equipment maintenance protocols. The hydraulic system had not been serviced according to the manufacturer's recommended schedule.

On December 3, 2024, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, the ventilation system in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Unit-018) experienced a catastrophic failure. Material Handler Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126) was processing ground plastic scrap when he noticed an unusual burning odor and increasing temperatures in the work area. The ceiling-mounted exhaust fan had suddenly stopped operating. Within minutes, airborne resin fumes from the grinding process began accumulating in the enclosed space, causing visible haze and activating the facility's air quality alarm. Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) also working in the area reported difficulty breathing and eye irritation. The area was immediately evacuated and all grinding operations halted. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) responded and confirmed elevated volatile organic compound (VOC) levels at 2.8 ppm, exceeding the facility's 2.0 ppm action level. The ventilation system investigation revealed a complete motor failure in the primary exhaust unit. A backup unit was not available, leaving the department with zero active ventilation until repair. The motor had reached the end of its serviceable life but no preventive replacement schedule existed.

On December 8, 2024, at 7:45 AM during the day shift, Forklift Operator Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167) was moving pallets of polypropylene resin from the receiving area to the production storage section. While navigating between stacked inventory in the warehouse, Fontaine attempted to turn the forklift too sharply while carrying a full pallet approximately 6 feet high. The load shifted due to improper positioning on the forks, and the combined weight destabilized the vehicle. The forklift tipped sideways, throwing Fontaine from the operator seat. He struck his right hip against the corner of a steel storage rack as he fell, then landed on the concrete floor. Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), who was working nearby, immediately called for medical assistance. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) arrived within 3 minutes and assessed a severe contusion to the right hip and suspected fracture. Fontaine was transported to a local hospital via ambulance where X-rays confirmed a fractured right hip requiring surgical intervention. Investigation revealed that Fontaine had not received forklift certification training in over 3 years, the forklift's load capacity had been exceeded by approximately 15%, and there were no load securing straps on the pallet. The operator had been pressured to work faster due to production delays.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053) was operating Injection Molding Line A in the Production Operations area when he noticed a small amount of mold release agent residue on his left hand. He continued working without immediately cleaning his hands, as he was focused on meeting production targets. By 3:00 PM, he developed mild erythema and localized itching on the affected area. Benoit reported the irritation to his line supervisor, who directed him to the first aid station. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed the skin contact exposure and determined it was a minor allergic reaction to the mold release agent. She cleaned the affected area thoroughly, applied a soothing topical cream, and provided antihistamine. The incident was resolved within 2 hours with no systemic effects. The root cause was inadequate hand hygiene during a busy production run and lack of barrier protection awareness.

On May 8, 2024, at 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060) was performing routine cleaning of Injection Molding Line B in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area. While wiping down the exterior surfaces with a cloth, he accidentally bumped the emergency stop button with his elbow, which immediately halted the machine's cooling cycle. Youssef continued cleaning unaware the machine had stopped its normal cooling sequence. As he reached toward the mold cavity to clear an accumulated plastic strand, the residual heat from the mold surface (approximately 95°C) came into contact with his right forearm, causing an immediate sharp pain. However, he instinctively pulled his arm away within 1 second. Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), the Injection Molding Technician on duty nearby, heard Youssef's exclamation and immediately provided first aid with cool running water for 5 minutes. Upon inspection, the contact area showed mild erythema without blistering. Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152), the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator who was conducting an evening safety round, assessed the incident and confirmed no serious burn injury had occurred. The near-miss was classified as such because injury was prevented by rapid reflexive withdrawal and quick first aid response.

On July 22, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was retrieving bulk resin containers from the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011) for transport to the main compounding facility. While navigating the narrow storage corridor between two stacks of containers, she misjudged the clearance and caught her left shoulder against a protruding metal corner bracket on a container stack. The sudden impact caused her to lose her footing and fall backward approximately 1.2 meters, landing hard on her left hip and lower back on the concrete floor. Mario Bélisle (EMP-00149), the Tool and Die Maker working in an adjacent area, heard the fall and immediately called for emergency response. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) and Andrei Popov (EMP-00094) arrived within 3 minutes. Bianca reported severe pain in her left hip and lower back. Emergency medical services were called and arrived within 12 minutes. X-ray examination at the hospital revealed a fractured left femoral neck and a compression fracture of the L4 vertebra. Bianca was hospitalized for 4 days and required surgical intervention. She was unable to return to work for 8 weeks. Root cause investigation identified inadequate aisle spacing, poor lighting in the storage area, and absence of impact guards on container stacks.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a solvent storage container in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) developed a small leak near its base valve connection. Mohamed Ibrahim, Regrind Operator, noticed a strong chemical odor and observed approximately 2 liters of acetone-based resin solvent pooling on the concrete floor near the chemical storage shelving. The container had been improperly seated on its shelf following routine restocking by warehouse staff earlier that morning. As Ibrahim attempted to move the container to contain the spill, he inadvertently kicked over a portable propane heater used for maintaining ambient temperature in the area during winter months. The heater's pilot light was still active, and the escaping solvent vapors ignited, creating a flash fire approximately 1.5 meters in diameter. Ibrahim suffered minor first-degree burns on his right forearm and hand. Emergency response was immediate: facility alarm was activated, evening shift supervisor Tomas Jimenez arrived within 2 minutes with the nearest fire extinguisher, extinguished the flames using a Class B dry powder extinguisher, and the facility evacuation protocol was initiated. No additional injuries occurred, but the incident resulted in approximately 3 hours of production downtime and facility closure for the remainder of the day shift to allow for ventilation and inspection.

On March 18, 2024, during the evening shift (6:45 PM), Aya Tanaka, Automation Technician, was performing routine maintenance on a collaborative robotic arm on Injection Molding Line C (UNIT-003, Medical Components clean room). While resetting the teach pendant after troubleshooting an encoder error, Tanaka's loose lab coat sleeve became momentarily caught between the robotic arm's end-effector and a mounting bracket as the arm moved through its home position sequence. The robot's motion was immediately halted by the collaborative safety system (force-limiting technology designed to detect unexpected resistance), preventing any injury. However, the incident demonstrated a gap in the facility's near-miss reporting procedures: Tanaka did not immediately report the event, discovering it only when reviewing video footage from the facility's safety camera during a routine quarterly review on March 22, 2024. The catch lasted approximately 1.2 seconds, and the sleeve suffered minor tearing but no skin contact occurred. Investigation revealed that the robotic arm's documentation required "hands-free operation during teach pendant use," but this procedure was not consistently enforced during evening shift maintenance activities. No production impact occurred, and no medical treatment was required.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 11:20 PM during the night shift, Conrad Therrien, Injection Molding Operator for Line A (UNIT-001, Automotive Components), experienced a catastrophic mold failure on a 200-ton injection molding machine. During a production run of automotive door handle components, excessive back pressure developed due to a partially clogged hydraulic filter that had not been replaced according to the preventive maintenance schedule (last replaced 340 operating hours prior, exceeding the 300-hour recommended interval). The elevated pressure caused a hairline fracture in the upper mold cavity insert to propagate during the injection cycle. At the moment of mold separation, the upper cavity insert catastrophically fractured and dislodged, striking the machine's protective enclosure and damaging approximately 40% of the acrylic safety window. The mold's titanium base plate struck the product collection conveyor system, causing approximately $127,000 in combined damage: $94,000 for the mold cavity replacement, $21,000 for the machine enclosure window and frame, and $12,000 for conveyor system repairs. No employees were injured due to the functioning guard system, but the incident resulted in complete Line A shutdown for 8 calendar days. Root cause investigation revealed that the night shift maintenance technician had failed to complete the scheduled 300-hour hydraulic filter replacement, and the computerized maintenance alert system had malfunctioned, failing to send the scheduled notification.

On March 15, 2025, at 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) reported a potential hazard in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area (UNIT-017). While monitoring an industrial oven used for curing composite materials, Iqbal noticed that the cooling water system feeding into the heat exchanger was producing an unusual hissing sound and showing visible moisture accumulation on the exterior tubing. Upon closer inspection, she identified a hairline crack developing in a compression fitting on the main coolant return line. The crack had not yet progressed to active leakage, but Iqbal immediately recognized the risk of a full system failure that could result in loss of temperature control and potential equipment damage or worker exposure to hot surfaces. She stopped operations in that zone and notified her supervisor and the HSE department. This preventive declaration allowed the maintenance team to schedule a controlled replacement of the fitting before any catastrophic failure occurred. The incident demonstrates the value of worker vigilance in identifying emerging equipment issues before they become serious safety events.

On March 22, 2025, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Crane Operator Gaston Picard (EMP-00193) was performing a routine material transfer in the Warehouse and Shipping area when he nearly experienced a serious incident. While moving a pallet of pre-molded composite parts using an overhead crane, Picard noticed that one of the lifting hooks showed signs of metal fatigue with a visible stress fracture along the weld joint. The hook had not failed, but given the load it was carrying (approximately 1,200 kg), failure would have resulted in the entire pallet falling 15 feet onto the warehouse floor where Material Handler Elif Yilmaz (EMP-00082) was walking below. Picard immediately stopped the lift, lowered the load safely to the ground, and reported the defective hook to Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham. The potentially catastrophic incident was prevented by the operator's attentiveness to equipment condition. Investigation revealed that the hook had been in service for 12 years with no formal inspection protocol in place. This near-miss prompted immediate action to implement comprehensive equipment inspection procedures.

On March 28, 2025, at 1:30 AM during the night shift, Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was preparing a batch of colorant masterbatch in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-011 adjacent area) when a critical incident occurred. While transferring approximately 50 liters of industrial acetone solvent from a bulk storage container to a mixing vessel, the transfer hose connection at the storage container suddenly failed due to a corroded coupling. The pressurized solvent sprayed uncontrollably across the work surface, with approximately 15 liters released before Popescu could shut off the supply valve. The acetone spilled across the concrete floor in the hazardous waste management area, creating an immediate vapor hazard and environmental contamination. Popescu evacuated the area and pulled the emergency alarm. Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne (EMP-00049) responded and initiated spill containment protocols. The incident resulted in the release of a volatile organic compound (acetone) to the environment and required external hazmat cleanup services. Root cause analysis identified that the 12-year-old coupling had never been inspected or replaced despite being exposed to corrosive chemical vapor, a serious oversight in preventive maintenance protocols.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, Material Handler Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170) was operating Injection Molding Equipment in the Main Production Building when her left hand became caught between the mold closing mechanism and the fixed mold plate. The employee was performing routine material placement and did not notice that the automatic cycle had initiated due to a malfunctioning proximity sensor. Her fingers sustained significant crushing injuries to the index and middle fingers. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette immediately responded to the scene and called emergency services. The employee was transported to Centre Hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal (CHUM) with suspected fractures and severe contusions. Initial assessment indicated the proximity sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months, exceeding the required 12-month maintenance interval. Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion was present on the floor and witnessed the incident. The machine was immediately secured and locked out following the incident.

On November 18, 2024, at 09:30 during the day shift, Production Operator Zainab Khalil (EMP-00160) sustained a minor laceration to her right hand while working in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. The employee was cleaning a stainless steel mold cavity using a brass brush when she slipped on a wet work surface and her hand contacted a sharp edge on the mold assembly. The laceration was approximately 2 centimeters long and 3 millimeters deep, requiring immediate first aid response. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) provided on-site first aid, cleaning the wound with sterile saline solution and applying a sterile gauze dressing with pressure to control bleeding. After 10 minutes, bleeding ceased and the wound was dressed with antibiotic ointment and a waterproof adhesive bandage. The employee declined further medical attention and returned to modified duty, avoiding water-based tasks for the remainder of the shift. The incident was documented and the work area was cleaned and dried to prevent recurrence.

On November 22, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, the Regrind and Recycling Department identified a potential ventilation system concern that posed an occupational health risk. During routine environmental monitoring, materials engineer Jing Wang (EMP-00054) detected elevated concentrations of polypropylene and polyethylene vapor in the regrind area using a calibrated multi-gas detector. The readings indicated approximately 45% of the occupational exposure limit for volatile organic compounds, well above the 10% threshold that triggers preventive action under company policy. The main exhaust fan in the area was operating normally, but secondary circulation ducts showed visible dust accumulation around damper seals, indicating potential air bypass. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette was notified and immediately issued a preventive work suspension for non-essential regrinding operations. Two material handlers (Rashid Habib and Salma Haddad) who were scheduled to work in the area were reassigned to alternative tasks. The maintenance team conducted visual inspection and found that the ventilation system filters had not been replaced for 14 months, exceeding the recommended 12-month interval. This preventive action prevented potential long-term exposure to resin fumes and respiratory irritation.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Material Handler Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) was transferring a batch of polypropylene resin from storage bins in the Materials Management and Warehousing area when he inadvertently made contact with a heated transfer conveyor belt. The conveyor, which operates at approximately 85°C to facilitate plastic material flow, came into contact with the back of his right hand as he was positioning a hopper underneath. Diallo immediately withdrew his hand and reported the incident to his supervisor. A first aid assessment revealed a superficial thermal burn approximately 2 inches in diameter on the dorsal surface of his hand. The burn was cleaned with cool water for 10 minutes, dried, and dressed with a topical antibiotic and sterile gauze. Pain management with over-the-counter analgesics was provided. The employee remained on duty with modified tasks avoiding further heat exposure for the remainder of the shift. No medical leave was required.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Omar Said (EMP-00122) sustained a work-related injury while operating Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area. Said was performing routine quality checks and material loading when his left hand became caught between the mold platen and the injection unit during an unexpected partial machine cycle. The machine had not been properly locked out despite maintenance personnel (Luc Girard, EMP-00039) completing calibration work moments earlier. Said's hand was compressed for approximately 8 seconds before coworkers noticed the alarm activation and initiated an emergency stop. The trapped hand resulted in significant swelling, contusion, and a suspected fracture of the 4th and 5th metacarpal bones. Said was immediately transported via ambulance to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur for radiographic evaluation and treatment. X-rays confirmed two metacarpal fractures requiring immobilization and follow-up orthopedic care. Said was placed on medical leave for 4 weeks pending healing and rehabilitation.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Tool Room Technician Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173) was retrieving composite material dies from upper shelving in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room when he lost his footing on a rolling ladder. The ladder, which was not equipped with rubber feet and had been positioned on a slick epoxy floor recently treated with a cleaning solvent (isopropanol), slipped backward unexpectedly. Vézina fell approximately 7 feet to the concrete floor below, striking his left side and head. Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) witnessed the incident and immediately called emergency services. Vézina was found conscious but disoriented with significant pain in his left ribs and shoulder. Paramedics transported him to Hôpital Général de Montréal where CT imaging revealed three fractured ribs (left ribs 5, 6, 7), a left shoulder contusion, and a mild concussion. Vézina was hospitalized for 2 days for pain management and monitoring. He was subsequently placed on work restrictions for 6 weeks with graduated return-to-work accommodations beginning week 3.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant water leak occurred in the cooling system of Injection Molding Line C located in the clean room medical components production area. Machine Operator Raoul Blanchard noticed pressurized coolant spraying from a corroded coupling on the primary heat exchanger while he was performing routine maintenance checks. The coupling had deteriorated due to inadequate maintenance records and lack of preventive inspection schedules. Approximately 400 liters of cooling fluid was lost before the main circulation pump was manually shut down by Luc Girard, the maintenance technician responding to the emergency. The spilled hydraulic coolant contaminated the production floor, creating a slipping hazard and requiring immediate cleanup with absorbent materials. Environmental compliance specialist Nathalie Dubois was notified to assess potential environmental impact and ensure proper waste disposal protocols were followed. The incident resulted in approximately 8 hours of production downtime and required replacement of the corroded coupling assembly at significant cost.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A). Materials Management operator Soraya Alami was retrieving a pallet of polycarbonate resin from the upper storage rack system when she noticed that three pallets stacked directly above her work position showed visible signs of improper securing. The wooden pallets were not properly banded together, and cardboard corner braces were beginning to separate from the lower pallet due to moisture absorption from the facility's humidity control system. The pallets, totaling approximately 900 kilograms, were positioned precariously and could have collapsed onto Alami's position had she not noticed the instability before pulling materials from below. She immediately alerted Facilities Technician Georges Plante, who secured the upper pallets using industrial strapping and repositioned them to a lower, safer location. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger documented the near-miss and investigated storage practices. No injury occurred, but the potential for serious crush injuries was significant had the materials shifted during the retrieval operation.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during the night shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop. Automation Engineer Sylvain Jodoin was performing diagnostic testing on a programmable logic controller (PLC) that controls the automated material feeding system on Line B. While testing input signals, Jodoin inadvertently touched an energized 240-volt terminal on the main distribution panel while both hands were wet from condensation buildup in the equipment enclosure. He received a mild electrical shock lasting approximately 1-2 seconds before instinctively pulling his hand away. Jodoin immediately reported the incident to Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance, who was supervising night shift maintenance operations. The shock caused minor tingling and temporary numbness in his fingers but no permanent injury. Investigation revealed that the PLC testing procedure lacked proper lockout/tagout (LOTO) protocols, the distribution panel had no warning labels, and the equipment enclosure's humidity control system was malfunctioning, creating condensation hazards. The incident demonstrated a critical gap in electrical safety procedures that could have resulted in serious electrocution.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Soraya Alami (EMP-00196), an Assembly Operator, was working at Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area. While manually removing finished composite parts from the cooling station, Soraya's right hand came into contact with uncovered fiberglass reinforcement material. The sharp fibers caused multiple small lacerations and puncture wounds across her palm and between her fingers. The material had been exposed due to a missing protective cover on the parts staging area—a cover that should have been in place but was removed during morning maintenance and not reinstalled. Soraya immediately reported the injury to her supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004), who provided first aid using the on-site first aid kit, cleaning and bandaging the wounds. The incident was minor but painful, with no lost work time. A witness, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), observed the incident and confirmed the missing protective cover. The area was immediately secured and the cover reinstalled to prevent further exposures.

On April 3, 2024, at 10:30 PM during the evening shift, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020), a Material Handler, was operating a warehouse forklift in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) to relocate pallets of virgin polystyrene resin. While maneuvering between two narrow storage racks, the forklift struck an overhead support beam, causing a pallet of resin to shift and fall from the rack above. The pallet struck Hassan's left shoulder and upper arm, causing a severe crush injury with immediate pain and visible swelling. Hassan was unable to move his left arm and was experiencing significant pain and possible shock. Evening supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) immediately called emergency services and provided comfort while awaiting medical response. Hassan was transported by ambulance to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur and admitted with a diagnosis of left shoulder fracture, rotator cuff tear, and crush syndrome requiring surgical intervention. The injury resulted in 14 days of hospitalization and required 3 months off work for recovery and physical therapy. Witnesses Miriam Cohen (EMP-00132) and Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), who were nearby organizing materials, confirmed the sequence of events and stated that warehouse aisles were congested with overflow inventory that day.

On May 22, 2024, at 6:15 AM during the night shift, Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081), Warehouse Lead - Night Shift, was performing inventory verification in the Raw Materials Warehouse when he discovered a small chemical spill in the resin storage section. A 25-liter container of polystyrene processing additive had developed a pinhole leak in its aluminum vessel, releasing approximately 3-4 liters of liquid chemical. The additive, a reactive polymer solvent, produced strong vapors that caused mild eye irritation and a burning sensation in Michel's throat. Despite the discomfort, Michel immediately implemented spill containment by placing absorbent mats around the leak, isolating the area with caution tape, and activating the warehouse ventilation system. He notified Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102), the Fire Safety Coordinator, who arrived within 10 minutes to verify proper containment procedures. First aid for eye and respiratory irritation was administered using the eyewash station and fresh air exposure. The incident was contained successfully with no spread to other materials or personnel. Investigation revealed the container had been stored against a sharp metal rack edge that had punctured the vessel over time due to vibration from forklift operations. Michel experienced mild symptoms that resolved within 2 hours with no requirement for medical treatment beyond first aid.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, was removing finished parts from a 250-ton injection molding machine when her left hand made contact with a mold cavity that had not cooled sufficiently. The operator had been working continuously for 6 hours without relief and was fatigued. The machine's cooling cycle had been shortened by 12 seconds due to a recent production schedule change that was not fully communicated to floor staff. Desjardins sustained second-degree thermal burns across her palm and three fingers. She immediately immersed her hand in cold water and reported to the Occupational Health Nurse. The incident was witnessed by Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), the Mold Maintenance Technician on duty. Investigation revealed that the cooling system setpoint had been adjusted without proper LOTO procedures and the updated cycle time was not posted at the machine station. Desjardins received emergency first aid and was transported to the local hospital for burn treatment, resulting in 3 days of lost work.

On February 28, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Roberto Santos (EMP-00012), a Forklift Operator, was moving a pallet of dried polypropylene resin from the Material Drying and Preparation Room to the Injection Molding Line A staging area. As he navigated through the warehouse aisle, a coil of strapping material that had been loosely placed on a high shelf (approximately 8 feet above ground level) became dislodged and fell directly in Santos's path. The forklift operator immediately swerved left to avoid the falling object, narrowly missing collision with both the strapping coil and a stationary electrical panel. Santos stopped the forklift and assessed the situation. The strapping coil landed approximately 2 feet behind the forklift's rear wheel. Jing Wang (EMP-00054), a Materials Engineer who was conducting inventory checks nearby, witnessed the incident and confirmed that Santos responded appropriately. The loosened strapping had been from a delivery received the previous evening that was improperly stored on the shelf without securing mechanisms. No injuries occurred, but the incident had high potential for serious head/neck injury had the object struck the operator.

On March 22, 2024, at 11:47 PM during the night shift, a critical failure occurred in Resin Dryer Unit RD-03 located in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. The heating element thermostat malfunctioned, causing the internal temperature to rise uncontrollably from the normal 85°C to an estimated 220°C within 45 minutes. The temperature exceeded the machine's upper safety threshold, triggering the high-temperature emergency shutdown sensor at 11:52 PM. However, residual thermal energy caused the internal chamber to remain at dangerous temperatures for several minutes before cooling commenced. The dryer contained approximately 180 kg of Nylon PA6 resin that was partially degraded by the excessive heat. Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), the Composite Materials Operator on night shift, noticed the acrid smell of burning polymer and unusual smoke emanating from the dryer vents and immediately evacuated the area and activated the emergency alarm. Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), the Workplace Hazard Assessment Specialist, was called to the facility and confirmed the equipment failure. The thermal stress caused warping of the dryer's internal aluminum heating chamber and failure of the silicone heating pad gasket. An estimated 280 kg of resin inventory was lost due to contamination and thermal degradation. Equipment repair costs are estimated at $85,000, and production was delayed by 18 hours as a backup dryer was brought online.

On March 14, 2025, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Materials Engineer Jing Wang was transferring a 200-liter drum of polyester resin from storage to the mixing station when the drum's spigot valve was inadvertently left partially open from a previous transfer. As the drum was being positioned on the transfer cart by Material Handler Elif Yilmaz, approximately 80 liters of resin spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous pool that spread across the room toward the electrical panel area. The resin's fumes began to accumulate in the room, and both employees immediately evacuated the area. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen responded within minutes and initiated containment protocols, deploying absorbent materials and establishing a perimeter. The spill required 4 hours to fully contain and clean. Investigation revealed that valve inspection procedures had not been performed that morning due to a missed pre-shift checklist, and the employee was unfamiliar with the specific valve design used on this particular drum type.

On March 25, 2025, at approximately 11:30 PM during the night shift, a potential fire incident was narrowly prevented in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Injection Molding Operator James Thompson was running a production batch of fiber-reinforced plastic components when he noticed an electrical spark emanating from the heating element control panel on Molding Machine #8. A small accumulated pile of composite dust and cured resin fragments (approximately 2 kg) had accumulated near the base of the control panel from earlier processing. The spark briefly ignited this material, creating a small flame approximately 30 centimeters high. Thompson immediately activated the nearby dry powder fire extinguisher, suppressing the flame within seconds. The night shift supervisor Pierre Bouchard responded and ensured the machine was safely shut down. Fire Safety Officer Anh Nguyen was called to investigate the following morning. The root cause was determined to be inadequate housekeeping, a loose electrical connector in the control panel creating arcing conditions, and the accumulation of flammable composite debris in proximity to energized electrical equipment. No injuries occurred, but the incident represented a critical near-miss.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), an Injection Molding Setter at Injection Molding Line B, was adjusting mold temperature settings when he noticed excessive resin fumes coming from the adjacent mixing station. He proceeded to investigate the chemical storage area and discovered that the ventilation system's exhaust fan had failed due to a burnt-out motor. The chemical fumes had accumulated in the enclosed space for an estimated 90 minutes. Robert experienced immediate respiratory distress, dizziness, and eye irritation. He alerted his supervisor and was taken to the on-site first aid station. Medical evaluation revealed chemical exposure to styrene vapors with moderate respiratory inflammation. Robert was transported to a local hospital for further observation and remained hospitalized for 48 hours with a diagnosis of acute chemical inhalation injury. He was unable to work for 7 days following the incident. The ventilation system had not been subject to a preventive maintenance inspection in 18 months despite manufacturer recommendations for annual checks.

On March 22, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), a Machine Operator on the evening shift, was removing cooled plastic parts from Injection Molding Line B when he inadvertently placed his left hand near a pinch point as another operator lowered a mold assembly. The mold closing mechanism, which had been semi-engaged, completed its cycle and caught Rahman's left hand between the mold cavity and the mold base, resulting in compression injuries to the palm and three fingers. Initial assessment revealed significant soft tissue damage, possible fracture to the fourth metacarpal bone, and partial laceration. Rahman was transported via ambulance to the hospital where X-rays confirmed a metacarpal fracture requiring surgical intervention and casting. He received 6 stitches for the laceration. Rahman was placed on modified duty for 4 weeks and unable to return to full production work for 10 days. Investigation revealed that the mold safety interlock had been bypassed by maintenance personnel 8 days prior and was never re-engaged. No work order existed documenting this bypass.

On April 2, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Shipping and Receiving Dock (Unit-009) when automatic sprinkler heads were activated by an electrical fire originating in the dock's automated conveyor system control panel. The fire was caused by a short circuit in the power distribution board, which had accumulated dust and moisture over several months due to inadequate ventilation. The control panel fire was limited to the electrical enclosure, with flames contained to approximately 12 inches in size before the sprinkler system suppressed the fire completely. However, the water discharge from the sprinklers resulted in significant damage to approximately 85 boxes of finished medical device components worth approximately $34,000. The fire department responded within 8 minutes and confirmed the fire was extinguished. No personnel were injured as the dock was minimally staffed at that hour. The electrical panel had not been inspected or cleaned since the facility opened 5 years ago. The incident revealed that routine preventive maintenance for electrical enclosures had not been implemented in the maintenance schedule.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a chemical spill occurred in the Hazardous Waste Management Area (UNIT-011). Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), a Composite Materials Operator, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin from a storage shelf to a mixing cart when the drum's lug wrench connection failed due to corrosion. Approximately 40 gallons of the resin spilled across the concrete floor, creating a significant hazard. The spill extended toward the exterior drainage system and posed an environmental risk. Lina immediately notified nearby personnel and activated the emergency response protocol. The facility's HSE team, led by Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), arrived within 10 minutes. Personnel cordoned off the area with hazard tape, deployed absorbent materials (sand and specialized absorbent pads), and began containment procedures. Environmental monitoring detected no off-site migration, but the incident required notification to Quebec's environmental authority (MDDEFP) and documentation of remediation efforts. Cleanup took approximately 6 hours. Root cause analysis revealed inadequate drum inspection protocols and corrosion of connection hardware due to humidity exposure.

On February 8, 2024, at 10:15 AM during the day shift, Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room (UNIT-025) experienced a critical equipment failure affecting the overhead crane system. Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), a Warehouse Associate, was using the crane to relocate mold components from the storage mezzanine when the cable tension sensor malfunctioned, causing an erroneous weight reading. The control system indicated the load was at capacity when it was actually at 65% capacity, preventing further operation. Investigation by Christian Gosselin (EMP-00135), an Injection Molding Technician, revealed that the sensor's calibration had drifted significantly beyond acceptable tolerances due to lack of preventive maintenance. The sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months, well beyond the manufacturer's recommended 6-month interval. The failed sensor created an unsafe condition where the load limiter could not function properly, posing a critical safety risk. The crane was immediately taken out of service, and alternative manual handling procedures were implemented. A replacement sensor was ordered and installed within 48 hours. The incident disrupted warehouse operations for 2 days and required manual material handling of heavy molds, increasing ergonomic risks for personnel.

On January 22, 2024, at 6:50 PM during the evening shift, an incident occurred at the Shipping and Receiving Dock (UNIT-009). Mélanie Fortin (EMP-00019), a Shipping and Receiving Clerk, was manually loading palletized finished goods onto a transport truck when she stepped on a coiled air hose that had been left on the floor near the loading area. The hose was not secured or clearly marked, creating a trip hazard. Mélanie's foot caught the hose and she fell forward onto the concrete dock surface, striking her left shoulder and chest. She immediately experienced sharp pain in her left shoulder and difficulty breathing. Witnesses Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) and Amina Mansour (EMP-00044) immediately called for medical assistance. The facility's Occupational Health Nurse, Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), arrived within 5 minutes and initiated first aid protocols. Mélanie was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé for X-ray evaluation, which revealed a fractured left clavicle and three rib fractures. She was hospitalized overnight for observation due to rib fractures and potential internal injury risk. The incident resulted in 12 weeks of lost time as Mélanie required significant recovery for bone healing and was unable to perform shipping duties during this period. Root cause analysis identified inadequate housekeeping procedures and lack of hose management protocols in the loading area.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, a hydraulic-powered injection molding machine (Model 350-T) in Injection Molding Line A ceased functioning during the afternoon shift. Technician Christian Gosselin was operating the machine when he noticed reduced clamping pressure and erratic mold opening cycles. Upon investigation by maintenance supervisor Priya Sharma, a critical seal failure was discovered in the primary hydraulic pump assembly, causing a slow leak of hydraulic fluid into the mold cavity. The equipment had been operational since 6:00 AM without scheduled maintenance due to production demands exceeding planned downtime windows. Assembly Operator Zara Khan, stationed 15 feet away, noticed the malfunction and alerted Gosselin immediately. The machine was shut down within 5 minutes, preventing potential contamination of molded parts destined for medical device customers. However, approximately 2 liters of hydraulic fluid leaked into the production area, creating a slippery condition on the concrete floor. Facilities Coordinator Éric Champagne was called to the scene for cleanup. The machine remained offline for 8 hours while the pump seal was replaced. Root cause analysis determined the seal had exceeded its service life due to extended operating intervals without replacement.

On April 2, 2024 at 11:15 PM during the night shift, Material Handler Amani Mwangi sustained a significant thermal burn while unloading freshly molded automotive trim components from Injection Molding Line A. The parts, extracted from molds maintained at 280°C, had been placed on a conveyor belt moving toward the cooling station. Mwangi was instructed to transfer parts to a staging tray using bare hands despite company policy requiring heat-resistant gloves for this task. A glove dispenser in the work area was found to be empty during investigation. As Mwangi reached for a component that appeared to have cooled sufficiently (surface temperature was actually 185°C), he made direct contact with the plastic part for approximately 2 seconds before reflexively withdrawing his hand. The contact resulted in second-degree burns across the palm and inner fingers of his right hand, with blistering visible within minutes. Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron witnessed the incident and immediately provided cold water irrigation for 10 minutes before activating first aid protocols. Mwangi was transported to the onsite medical station where the wound was cleaned, bandaged, and documented. He received a tetanus update and was instructed to seek external medical evaluation. The employee was sent home and remained off work for 5 days due to pain and reduced hand functionality. Root cause: inadequate PPE availability, lack of temperature-warning labels on hot components, and insufficient operator training on thermal hazard recognition.

On April 18, 2024 at 9:30 AM, Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert experienced a minor laceration and chemical exposure incident while organizing raw material containers in the Warehouse and Shipping facility. Hébert was consolidating inventory of polyurethane resin barrels when he attempted to lift a damaged 50-liter drum without first inspecting its integrity. The corroded bottom seam of the barrel, weakened by exposure to moisture and time, ruptured upon lifting, spilling approximately 3 liters of clear polyurethane resin solution onto the concrete floor and Hébert's work boots and lower leg. The liquid splashed onto his right hand, causing immediate skin irritation. Hébert did not sustain a serious injury but complained of mild burning sensation and visible redness on the affected area. He immediately removed his contaminated gloves and work boots, rinsed the affected skin with cool water from the facility washstation for 5 minutes, and reported to the onsite first aid station. Packaging Supervisor Patricia Martin was notified and assessed the situation. The employee's skin was flushed thoroughly with water, dried, and covered with a light bandage. No external medical attention was required. The spilled resin was contained using absorbent pads and disposed of according to WHMIS guidelines. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger inspected the incident scene and identified that the drum had not been included in the facility's routine container integrity inspection program. The incident required only first aid treatment with no lost work time or hospitalization.

On March 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Stéphane Couture (Injection Molding Operator - Line C) suffered severe burns while attempting to clear a resin blockage in the heated barrel assembly of Line C in the Medical Components clean room area (UNIT-003). The operator noticed reduced material flow and attempted to manually dislodge the solidified composite material using a metal rod without first powering down the equipment or following proper lockout/tagout procedures. When he applied pressure, the pressurized resin suddenly released, spraying approximately 180°C molten plastic composite material directly onto his right forearm, hand, and neck. The exposure duration lasted approximately 3-4 seconds before he reflexively pulled away. Coworkers immediately assisted by removing contaminated clothing and flushing the affected areas with cool water from the emergency eye wash station. Emergency services were called at 2:18 PM and the employee was transported to the regional burn center with deep second-degree and partial third-degree burns covering approximately 15% of his body. The employee required hospitalization for 14 days and subsequent rehabilitation, resulting in 42 days of lost work time. Investigation revealed that the operator had not received recent retraining on pressure release hazards and the equipment lacked proper pressure relief signage.

On April 8, 2024, at 6:47 PM during the evening shift, a fire alarm was triggered in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) due to improper storage and spontaneous ignition of waste composite materials. Emmanuel Kouassi, a Machine Operator on the evening shift, was conducting end-of-shift material disposal procedures when he placed a container of freshly ground fiber-reinforced plastic composite scrap—still warm from the grinding process (approximately 65°C)—directly adjacent to a cardboard waste box containing acetone-soaked cleaning rags. The combination of residual heat, inadequate ventilation in that storage zone, and the flammable solvent vapors created an auto-ignition condition. At 6:47 PM, the cardboard box spontaneously ignited, setting off the thermal fire detection system. The fire alarm activated facility-wide evacuation procedures. The evening shift supervisor immediately deployed the nearest portable fire extinguisher (Class B) and contained the flame to the storage area. Emergency responders arrived at 6:56 PM and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. No personnel injuries occurred, and material damage was limited to the cardboard waste box and approximately 8 kg of composite scrap. The incident resulted in a 2-hour facility shutdown for investigation and air quality monitoring. Root cause analysis identified three violations: commingling of hot waste with solvent-contaminated materials, lack of proper segregated storage, and inadequate ventilation monitoring in the recycling section.

On May 22, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Conrad Therrien (Injection Molding Operator - Line A) sustained a significant back injury while attempting to manually transfer a 45 kg mold base from a workbench to a cart during preventive maintenance operations. Therrien was working alone in the production area when he reached across a waist-height workbench with insufficient leverage and attempted to lift the casting using primarily his lower back and hip muscles rather than his legs. The mold shifted unexpectedly during the lift, causing him to hyperextend and rotate his lumbar spine while maintaining the lift. He immediately felt sharp pain in his lower left side and was unable to set the mold down safely. A coworker, Mathieu Gendron, heard his cry of pain and assisted in lowering the mold to the bench. Therrien could not stand upright and was experiencing significant back spasms. Emergency medical response was initiated at 10:35 AM. A paramedic assessment determined acute lumbar strain with potential disc involvement. Therrien was transported to the emergency department where imaging confirmed a Grade 2 lumbar strain with inflammatory response. He was prescribed a 2-week medical leave with progressive return-to-work restrictions. Subsequent investigation revealed the mold base lacked proper lifting lugs, the employee had not received ergonomic training on proper lifting mechanics in over 18 months, and no mechanical assist equipment (hoist) was available in the production area for heavy component transfers.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Amina Ba (EMP-00164), a Packaging Operator, was working at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019) preparing finished composite parts for shipment. While transferring a stack of labeled components from the assembly line to a shipping pallet, Amina's right hand made contact with a sharp burr left on an injection-molded edge. The burr, which had not been properly deburred during the finishing process, created a laceration approximately 2 cm long on her palm. The wound bled moderately and Amina immediately reported the injury to her supervisor, Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101). First aid was administered at the station by the on-site medical kit, including cleaning, antiseptic application, and sterile bandaging. The laceration did not require stitches or hospitalization. Lucia Martinez (EMP-00066), another Packaging Operator working nearby, witnessed the incident. The injury was classified as a first-aid case and documented in the incident log. Root cause analysis identified that quality control inspection had failed to catch the sharp edge defect, and the part should have been rejected before reaching the packaging station.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the evening shift, a cooling water system leak developed in the injection molding production area. The leak originated from a corroded coupling on the cooling circuit serving Line A, where Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195) operates the injection molding equipment. Over approximately 45 minutes, an estimated 1,200 liters of coolant-contaminated water leaked onto the concrete floor of the production area, creating a slippery hazard and spreading approximately 30 meters across the facility. The coolant mixture (water + industrial cooling additives) is classified as low-toxicity but creates a slip hazard and environmental concern. The spill was discovered when Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101), the Day Shift Production Supervisor who was completing handoff documentation, noticed the spreading liquid. The evening shift supervisor immediately activated the spill containment protocol, deployed absorbent materials, and notified Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) from HSE. No injuries occurred, but the spill damaged approximately 200 meters of electrical cabling conduit infrastructure beneath and adjacent to the affected area, estimated at $8,500 in replacement costs. The production line was shut down for 6 hours for cleanup and system inspection.

On March 21, 2024, at approximately 11:50 PM during the night shift, Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021), a Mold Technician, was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Machine C in the production area. He was replacing worn hydraulic seals in the mold-closing mechanism and had begun the process of securing components. Due to inadequate communication with the night shift supervisor regarding lockout/tagout procedures, the machine was not properly isolated with a lockout device. At 11:58 PM, an automated cycle initiated unexpectedly—triggered by a residual signal in the control system—and the mold began to close with approximately 2,000 PSI of clamping force. Stéphane's left hand was positioned inside the mold cavity during installation work. His hand was crushed between the moving mold plates, resulting in a crush injury affecting the metacarpal bones and soft tissue of the left hand. He immediately called for emergency assistance. Soraya Alami (EMP-00196), an Assembly Operator who was working in an adjacent area, heard the alert and called emergency services. Stéphane was transported by ambulance to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur de Montréal at 12:07 AM on March 22, where he was treated for crush injuries with temporary immobilization pending surgical evaluation. He remained hospitalized for 2 days and sustained permanent partial loss of function in fingers 3 and 4 of his left hand. Gaétan Laplante (EMP-00161), the Lockout/Tagout Coordinator, conducted immediate investigation revealing the LOTO procedure had not been followed and the machine's automated restart capability had not been disabled during maintenance.

On November 14, 2024, at 14:45 during the day shift, a chemical inventory specialist was conducting routine stock rotation in the Materials Management and Warehousing area (UNIT-024). While moving a 20-liter container of mold release agent (silicone-based), the employee accidentally dropped it on the concrete floor. The container's seal was compromised, and approximately 15 liters of the oily liquid spilled across a 4-meter radius. The chemical began pooling near electrical outlets and created a slipping hazard. Initial response involved immediate area evacuation and notification of the HSE coordinator. The maintenance team deployed absorbent materials and established containment barriers within 30 minutes. No employees were directly exposed to the chemical, but the spill resulted in a 3-hour production delay due to facility lockdown and ventilation cycling. Environmental assessment confirmed no release to external drainage systems.

On November 18, 2024, at 08:20 during the day shift, an Injection Molding Operator on Line D was performing routine part removal and quality inspection when she experienced acute onset of sharp pain in her right wrist and forearm. The employee had been performing repetitive hand and wrist motions for 6 hours without breaks—removing parts from molds, inspecting for defects, and stacking finished components. Medical examination at 09:45 revealed acute tenosynovitis with mild swelling. The employee was placed on modified duty with restricted use of the right upper extremity. Investigation revealed that the production schedule had been compressed due to expedited customer orders, eliminating the standard mid-shift 15-minute rest period. The ergonomic workstation assessment showed the part removal station lacked proper wrist support and the work surface height was 3 inches above recommended specifications.

On November 20, 2024, at 23:15 during the night shift, the Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator conducted a routine inspection of the Central Maintenance Workshop and identified a significant hazard requiring immediate preventive intervention. During an examination of the compressed air systems servicing the injection molding lines, the coordinator discovered that three of four pressure relief valves on the main air distribution manifold were showing signs of corrosion and mineral buildup. System pressure gauges indicated inconsistent readings, suggesting potential valve malfunction. The coordinator identified that these conditions could lead to uncontrolled pressure release events, potentially causing burns or injuries to maintenance personnel working in close proximity. No immediate incident had occurred, but the risk assessment classified this as a critical probability event given the high-use nature of the compressed air system and the proximity of maintenance work stations. Immediate action was taken to isolate the affected system sections and schedule emergency maintenance.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Maya Kumar (EMP-00138) was working at Injection Molding Line B assembling automotive dashboard components. While removing a finished part from the mold, the plastic component had a sharp edge burr that caught her left index finger, creating a deep laceration between the knuckle and fingernail. The cut was approximately 1.5 cm long and bled moderately. Maya immediately reported the injury to her supervisor Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), who provided first aid with antiseptic wash and sterile bandaging. The wound did not require stitches but was cleaned thoroughly and covered with antibiotic ointment and a protective bandage. Maya continued working with modified duties for the remainder of the shift. The incident was caused by inadequate deburring of parts and lack of cut-resistant gloves at the workstation. Quality Assurance Specialist Linh Tran (EMP-00046) witnessed the incident and assisted with first aid supplies.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Maintenance Manager Carlos Rodriguez (EMP-00006) was troubleshooting an electrical fault in the control panel of Injection Molding Line C (medical components). While testing voltage with a multimeter, the panel door suddenly swung open due to a faulty latch, and an arc flash occurred across the open contacts of the 480-volt power distribution terminal. Carlos sustained second-degree electrical burns to his right forearm and hand, causing blistering and severe pain. He was immediately transported by ambulance to the hospital emergency department where the burns were treated with wound care and pain management. The incident resulted in a lost-time injury and required 14 days of recovery. Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) witnessed the arc flash and immediately called emergency services. Root causes included lack of proper arc flash protective equipment, inadequate lockout/tagout procedures, and insufficient signage on the electrical panel hazards. The electrical system remained operational despite the incident.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, Receiving Clerk Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085) was unloading a delivery of raw materials at the Shipping and Receiving Dock. While handling a pallet containing five 25-liter drums of solvent-based mold release agent (containing petroleum distillates and silicone compounds), one drum tipped over during forklift movement directed by Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047). The drum struck the concrete floor, and the valve connection fractured, releasing approximately 18 liters of the chemical directly onto the dock surface and flowing toward a floor drain. The pungent odor was immediately noticeable, and vapors began accumulating in the warehouse area. Within minutes, three nearby workers (Christine Desrosiers, EMP-00055; Layla Hussein, EMP-00098; and Valentina Rossi, EMP-00186) began reporting headaches and mild dizziness. Jacques immediately activated the facility's emergency response protocol, establishing a containment barrier with absorbent pads and notifying the HSE department. The spill was neutralized within 90 minutes using designated absorbent material and properly disposed of according to provincial hazardous waste regulations. No environmental release occurred outside the facility. The incident was caused by improper securing of drum pallets, inadequate forklift operator training on load stability, and insufficient ventilation in the receiving area.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D when he discovered a hydraulic leak in the machine's pressure manifold. While attempting to tighten a connection point, the corroded fitting suddenly gave way, releasing a pressurized spray of hydraulic fluid directly onto his left forearm and hand. The fluid temperature was approximately 65°C, causing immediate thermal injury combined with chemical irritation. Desbiens immediately ran cold water over the affected area and reported to the HSE office. Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140) witnessed the incident and called for first aid response. The machine was immediately shut down and locked out. Emergency response team applied first aid and transported Desbiens to the clinic for treatment of second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 8% of his forearm, requiring hospitalization for 3 days and subsequent wound care. Post-incident investigation revealed that the hydraulic system had not been inspected as part of the predictive maintenance program due to scheduling oversight.

On April 8, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the evening shift, Forklift Operator Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118) was transferring pallets of polypropylene resin from Raw Materials Warehouse Section A to the compounding area. While navigating a turn near the chemical storage rack, Aziz applied excessive brake pressure, causing the forklift's rear end to swing outward. The swing knocked over a 200-liter drum of isopropanol solvent that was temporarily staged outside the designated Hazardous Waste Management Area pending disposal. The drum ruptured on impact, releasing approximately 180 liters of isopropanol across approximately 150 square meters of the warehouse floor. The chemical pooled near an electrical outlet and created immediate slip hazards. Warehouse Lead Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183) was called to the scene. The facility's spill response team was activated, emergency ventilation was increased, and the affected area was cordoned off. No personnel were directly contaminated, but three employees experienced respiratory irritation from vapors. The spill was contained and neutralized using absorbent materials, requiring 4 hours of cleanup. Root cause analysis identified that the drum had not been properly secured in a designated storage rack and the forklift operator had insufficient training on load stabilization procedures.

On May 2, 2024, at approximately 3:30 AM during the night shift, Crane Operator Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) was transferring spools of glass-fiber reinforcement material from the receiving dock to the Regrind and Recycling Department. During a routine material transfer operation, excessive vibration from an unbalanced spool caused the crane's spreader bar to malfunction, dropping the entire 850-kg spool of glass fiber approximately 1.5 meters onto the concrete floor of the warehouse. The impact ruptured the spool's outer wrapping, dispersing glass fiber fragments across an area of approximately 40 square meters. Additionally, the dropped load damaged several stacked boxes of finished medical-grade packaging components stored below. Mechanical Maintenance Technician Marco Rossi (EMP-00016) was the only witness in the facility at that hour. Neither employee was directly struck, but both experienced eye irritation and mild respiratory irritation from airborne glass fiber particles. The cleanup operation took 6 hours and required specialized containment procedures due to the medical-grade packaging contamination. Environmental sampling detected glass fiber particles in dust samples from the work area. Investigation revealed that the crane's load-sensing equipment had not been calibrated for three months, and the spreader bar maintenance schedule had been deferred due to resource constraints. This incident occurred in an area with only basic ventilation systems and inadequate personal protective equipment storage.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant water leak developed in the chiller system servicing the injection molding equipment in the Main Production Building's central area.
