Equipment operator Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074) noticed coolant dripping from an overhead supply line above Injection Molding Line C and immediately notified her supervisor. The leak was caused by a corroded fitting that had weakened over several months of operation without proper inspection. Within 30 minutes, approximately 200 liters of coolant had pooled on the production floor, creating a slippery surface and damaging electrical conduit routing beneath the equipment. The spill also partially saturated three boxes of finished polycarbonate components waiting for shipment, rendering them non-compliant. Maintenance supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) responded and isolated the system. The affected area required 8 hours of cleanup, and the damaged inventory resulted in approximately $12,000 in losses. No personnel were injured, but the incident disrupted production for the remainder of the shift.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Material Handler Bianca De Luca (EMP-00108) was moving resin storage bins in the Warehouse and Shipping area when she nearly suffered a serious struck-by incident. While using a manual four-wheel dolly to transport a 45-kg polypropylene resin bin from the storage rack, a second bin located on the top shelf of an adjacent rack (approximately 2 meters high) began to shift due to improper weight distribution and inadequate restraint strapping. The top bin started to tip forward, and De Luca noticed the movement at the last second. She immediately stepped backward, and the bin fell to the floor approximately 30 centimeters from where she had been standing. The bin impacted the concrete floor with significant force but did not rupture. The resin material remained contained, but the collision left a small indentation in the floor. De Luca's heart rate elevated significantly, and she reported feeling shaken. Maintenance Supervisor François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105) and Fire Safety Coordinator Sanaa Rachidi (EMP-00102) responded to assess the incident. Investigation revealed that the storage rack shelf had been loaded incorrectly with heavier bins stacked on upper shelves without proper weight distribution documentation. No personal injury occurred, but the near-miss highlighted a critical gap in storage procedures and rack capacity management protocols.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Sofia Gonzalez (EMP-00074), an Injection Molding Operator on Line C, sustained a thermal burn injury while removing parts from a mold. Sofia was performing routine part ejection when the mold temperature sensor malfunctioned, causing the mold surface to reach 185°C instead of the standard 120°C operating temperature. As she reached to remove a molded component using her bare hand (PPE protocol violation), her right palm and inner wrist came into direct contact with the hot mold surface. She experienced immediate second-degree burns covering approximately 15 square centimeters. Sofia immediately immersed her hand in the emergency eyewash station and reported the incident to her supervisor, Bertrand Jalbert (EMP-00171). First aid was administered on-site, and Sofia was transported to Hôpital de la Cité for emergency burn treatment and bandaging. The incident was declared by Samira El-Khoury, EHS Coordinator, within 30 minutes of occurrence.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift operations in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, sustained a minor chemical splash exposure to her left arm while transferring acetone from a 20-liter container to smaller working bottles. As Elena was pouring acetone through a funnel into a one-liter container, a coworker unexpectedly opened the adjacent storage cabinet door, creating an air pressure disturbance that caused the funnel to shift. Approximately 100 milliliters of acetone splashed onto her left forearm and wrist area, creating immediate skin irritation and slight redness. Elena immediately rinsed the affected area with copious amounts of water from the safety shower station for 10 minutes, as per WHMIS protocol. She reported the incident to Serge Lafleur, Workplace Safety Representative, who assessed the exposure. First aid treatment included application of a cooling compress and antihistamine cream. No medical attention was required, but incident documentation was completed.

On March 20, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during night shift operations, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a Forklift Operator, narrowly avoided a collision with a pedestrian in the Raw Materials Warehouse. Tariq was operating a propane-powered forklift while transporting a pallet of polypropylene resin (PP) pellets from storage section A to the loading dock staging area. Due to inadequate lighting in the warehouse section near the far wall and the forklift's limited rear visibility, Tariq did not see Raynald Vézina (EMP-00173), a Tool Room Technician, who was conducting routine equipment inventory in the aisle. Raynald was reviewing inventory clipboard data while walking and did not hear the approaching forklift due to its relatively quiet electric motor. At approximately 2 meters distance, Tariq noticed a slight movement and immediately applied full brakes, bringing the forklift to a complete stop within 1.5 meters of Raynald. Raynald looked up and stepped quickly to the side, avoiding any physical contact. Both employees were visibly shaken. Serge Lafleur was notified and completed a near-miss investigation within 2 hours. No injuries were sustained.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations in the Assembly and Finishing Department, Ibrahim Yusuf (EMP-00090) was removing finished automotive trim parts from an injection molding machine (Line A, 250-ton press). While performing routine part extraction, his left hand made contact with a hot resin runner gate still at 165°C. The part had just been ejected from the mold, and standard cooling time had not fully elapsed. Ibrahim immediately withdrew his hand and reported a sharp burning pain on his palm and fingers. He immersed the affected area in cool water at a nearby sink for approximately 10 minutes. A first-aid station assessment revealed first-degree burns across the palm and second-degree blistering on two fingers. The incident was witnessed by Claudine Desjardins (EMP-00117), the adjacent line operator, who assisted in immediate first aid. No hospitalization was required; treatment consisted of topical burn cream and sterile gauze dressing at the on-site first-aid station.

On April 8, 2024, at 4:15 AM during night shift operations, Hassan Diallo (EMP-00020) and Hugues Fontaine (EMP-00167) were transferring 50-pound resin pellet bags from a pallet in the Material Drying and Preparation Room to drying hoppers using a manual two-person lift technique. While positioning a bag approximately 48 inches high onto a hopper platform, Hassan experienced acute lower back pain and felt a sudden 'popping' sensation in his lumbar region. He immediately set down the bag and reported severe pain radiating down his left leg. Hassan was unable to continue work and sat on a nearby bench. Hugues called for supervisor support. Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168) responded and assessed Hassan's condition. After 20 minutes, Hassan was unable to stand without significant pain. An ambulance was called, and Hassan was transported to Laval General Hospital where imaging revealed a herniated L4-L5 disc with nerve compression. He was hospitalized for 2 days and subsequently placed on medical leave for 6 weeks. This incident resulted in lost work time exceeding 480 hours.

On May 22, 2024, at 10:30 AM during day shift in the Electrical and Instrumentation Shop, Vincent Lé tourneau (EMP-00075) was performing routine preventive maintenance on a 400-amp electrical panel serving the injection molding Line C circuit. While checking voltage readings with a handheld multimeter, Vincent noticed a loose terminal connection on a 208V three-phase supply line. He attempted to tighten the connection using an insulated wrench while the panel remained energized (per standard protocol requiring power to remain on during live circuit diagnostics). As he applied torque, the wrench slipped and made momentary contact with both the terminal and an adjacent ground bus bar, creating a low-resistance arc. A bright flash occurred, and Vincent experienced a mild electrical shock through his right arm. He immediately stepped back, and the incident triggered the facility's electrical safety interlock, which de-energized the panel within 200 milliseconds. Vincent reported tingling in his fingers and mild chest discomfort. Luc Girard (EMP-00039) witnessed the event from across the shop. Serge Lafleur (EMP-00107) arrived within minutes and provided immediate first aid assessment. Vincent was evaluated at the on-site first-aid station and treated for minor electrical contact burns on his wrist (approximately 1 cm diameter). No hospitalization was required, but he was sent home for observation and instructed to seek medical evaluation if any cardiac symptoms developed.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45, machine setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) was performing routine setup on Injection Molding Line A when he noticed excessive heat emanating from the barrel assembly. The equipment had been operating continuously for 12 hours without a scheduled temperature sensor calibration check. Tremblay contacted production engineer Sébastien Carrier (EMP-00065) to investigate. Upon inspection, Carrier discovered that the cooling water system had developed a slow leak in the thermal regulation subsystem, causing the barrel temperature to rise to 285°C instead of the normal 220°C setpoint. The mold surface temperature exceeded safe handling limits. Carrier immediately shut down the line and notified the HSE team. No injuries occurred, but the incident demonstrated a gap in preventive maintenance protocols and equipment monitoring. This preventive declaration was submitted by Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) to document the near-miss and initiate corrective action before an employee sustained a serious burn injury.

On April 22, 2024, at 09:15 during day shift operations, a chemical spill occurred in the Assembly and Finishing Department. Assembly operator Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) was transferring a 20-liter container of mold release agent (silicone-based, flammable liquid) from the supply storage to the application station. The container's cap was not fully secured following the previous shift's use. As Jackson moved the container, approximately 8 liters of the clear, viscous liquid spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a slip hazard and potential fire risk. Jackson immediately notified her supervisor who initiated the spill response protocol. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) arrived within 10 minutes with absorbent materials and contained the spill using diatomaceous earth and specialized absorbent pads. The spilled material was transferred to a hazardous waste drum and properly labeled. No personnel were injured, but the incident exposed deficiencies in container handling procedures and cap verification protocols before transport.

On May 8, 2024, at 22:30 during evening shift operations, an environmental incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Machine setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), working the night shift, was transferring dried nylon (PA) resin from a heated hopper to a sealed storage container. A seal failure on the hopper outlet caused approximately 15 kilograms of fine nylon powder to be released into the air, dispersing throughout the Material Handling Zone and adjacent areas. The powder settled on work surfaces, equipment, and the floor, creating a dust accumulation hazard. Additionally, the airborne particles migrated into the adjacent production area, triggering air quality concerns. Maintenance technician Aya Tanaka (EMP-00100) discovered the issue during equipment walkthrough and immediately shut down the hopper. Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147) and Desbiens began manual cleanup using wet-wiping methods (dry sweeping was avoided per protocol to prevent re-aerosolization). Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger (EMP-00069) was notified and documented the incident as a dust release with potential environmental impact due to material loss and facility contamination.

On November 14, 2024 at 14:45, Assembly Operator Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) was working at Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room area when she contacted hot plastic material extruding from a mold cavity. She was removing a finished component from the mold press when the operator at the adjacent station began the cooling cycle prematurely. The plastic material, maintained at approximately 280°C for medical-grade polycarbonate processing, contacted the back of her right hand and wrist. She immediately immersed her hand in cold water from the nearby safety station and reported the incident to Packaging Supervisor Anika Johansson. First aid assessment revealed minor erythema and mild blistering on the dorsal surface of the right hand. The injury was treated with antibiotic ointment and sterile gauze dressing. No medical leave was required. Quality Technician Natalya Kozlov witnessed the incident and assisted with first aid response.

On December 3, 2024 at 10:30, Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was loading raw materials into storage racks in the Raw Materials Warehouse (Section A) when a stack of plastic resin bags collapsed. She was restocking 50-lb bags of polycarbonate resin on a 12-foot metal shelving unit when she inadvertently struck the load with her pallet jack, destabilizing the upper tier. Approximately 15 bags from the third shelf (8 feet high) fell and struck her left shoulder, back, and left leg. She was knocked to the ground and unable to bear weight on her left leg. Receiving Coordinator Nadia Belkacem called emergency services at 10:35. EMS arrived at 10:48 and transported Saleh to Laval Hospital with suspected femur fracture and multiple contusions. X-rays confirmed a non-displaced fracture of the left femoral shaft. She underwent orthopedic reduction and was admitted for 2 days. Total lost time: 6 weeks. Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) witnessed the incident and assisted until emergency arrival.

On November 28, 2024 at 22:15 during the evening shift, Maintenance Planner Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) was performing routine maintenance on a 250-ton injection molding machine (Unit IIM-47) in the Main Production Building. He was inspecting hydraulic fluid lines for leaks when a hairline fracture in a high-pressure coupling suddenly ruptured under 2,000 PSI pressure. Pressurized hydraulic fluid sprayed directly into his left forearm, creating a penetrating injection wound approximately 2 cm in depth. The fluid entered through the skin, causing severe localized tissue damage. Pham immediately reported to the facility medical station where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed the injury at 22:28. Despite initial appearance as a small puncture wound, imaging revealed fluid distribution through the fascial planes of the forearm. He was transported to Laval Hospital at 22:45 where surgical intervention was required to flush contaminated tissue and prevent necrotizing infection. He underwent emergency fasciotomy and was hospitalized for 3 days. Lost time: 4 weeks with 2 weeks restricted duty. Production Scheduler Wei Liu (EMP-00088) was present and activated emergency procedures.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Benoit Arsenault (EMP-00053), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A in the Main Production Building, was performing routine maintenance on the hopper feed system when his work glove became caught in the rotating auger mechanism. The machine was not properly locked out despite standing procedures requiring LOTO compliance before any maintenance work. As the auger continued rotating, the glove was drawn in, pulling Benoit's left hand into the pinch point. His hand suffered severe lacerations and a partial amputation of his index finger at the middle knuckle. Production Supervisor Michael Chen (EMP-00004) immediately initiated emergency stop procedures and called for emergency medical services. Benoit was transported to Laval Hospital where he underwent surgical intervention to preserve remaining tissue and control bleeding. The incident occurred because the maintenance technician who normally performs this task was absent, and Benoit attempted the repair without following proper lockout procedures. Co-worker Ahmed Hassan (EMP-00014) witnessed the incident and assisted in emergency response.

On November 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Chiara Bianchi (EMP-00170), a Material Handler working in the Finished Goods Warehouse, sustained a laceration to her right palm while unloading packaged medical device components from a wooden pallet. As she was moving boxes of sterile components from pallet stack Section B-7, a wooden splinter approximately 3 inches long protruded from the pallet's edge at an unexpected angle, penetrating her work gloves and embedding itself in her palm. She immediately felt sharp pain and withdrew her hand, discovering blood seeping from the wound. Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor (EMP-00010) applied first aid using the facility's first aid kit, cleaned the wound with antiseptic, applied antibiotic ointment, and covered it with a sterile bandage. The splinter was successfully removed without requiring sutures. Colleague Mariam Osman (EMP-00064) observed the incident and confirmed the pallet's damaged condition. The medical components Chiara was handling were quarantined pending contamination verification per ISO 13485 protocols. The incident resulted in 45 minutes of lost productivity and required documentation for quality assurance purposes.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 9:30 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Maintenance Technician Luc Girard (EMP-00039) was conducting routine inspection of the storage area when he discovered that a 55-gallon drum of polyester resin had developed a pinhole leak at its base seam, likely due to corrosion from a manufacturing defect. The drum had been stored in position for approximately 18 months without rotation or inspection. Approximately 12 gallons of resin had accumulated in the secondary containment basin before overflowing onto the concrete floor, creating a 6-foot diameter chemical spill. The spill spread toward the floor drain before Girard initiated containment procedures using absorbent pads and a portable chemical spill kit. Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) was notified and directed shutdown of the HVAC system to prevent vapor distribution throughout the facility. Hazardous waste removal contractor was called; containment and cleanup required 6 hours. The incident resulted in approximately $18,000 in remediation costs, waste disposal fees, and temporary production delays in the composite materials line. No personnel were injured, but the spill created significant environmental liability exposure.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), a CNC Operator, was operating a CNC milling machine in the Composite Materials Processing Area when the machine's spindle cooling system experienced a catastrophic failure. The cooling water system, which maintains optimal temperatures during high-precision mold manufacturing, ruptured at a critical joint, causing pressurized coolant fluid to spray across the work station. The 85-degree Celsius coolant contacted Giovanni's left forearm and hand, causing immediate thermal burns. The machine continued running for approximately 12 seconds before automatic emergency shutdown activated. Colleagues at adjacent stations heard Giovanni's distress call and immediately assisted him to the first aid station. Robert Fournier (EMP-00067), a nearby Injection Molding Setter, applied cold water irrigation per company protocol while Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057), the Safety Trainer, coordinated emergency response and documented the incident. Giovanni was treated for second-degree burns covering approximately 8% of his body and was transported to the local medical facility for advanced burn care.

On March 20, 2024 at 09:15, Pascal Bisson (EMP-00181), an Injection Molding Technician working the day shift, sustained a laceration to his right palm while cleaning the hopper of an injection molding machine. While performing routine maintenance, Pascal inadvertently placed his hand on the hopper lip edge, which had been abraded during regular use and created a sharp burr approximately 3mm in height. As he repositioned his grip, the burr caught the fleshy area of his palm, creating a 4cm laceration with moderate bleeding. Conrad Therrien (EMP-00195), an Injection Molding Operator stationed at Line A, observed the incident immediately and assisted Pascal to the first aid station. Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101), the Production Supervisor for Day Shift, called in Karine Cloutier (EMP-00057) from the HSE department to provide advanced first aid treatment. The wound was cleaned, irrigated with saline solution, and dressed with sterile gauze and antibiotic ointment. Pascal received tetanus prophylaxis and was returned to light duty work pending wound evaluation by occupational health services the following day.

On March 25, 2024 at 16:30, during the evening shift transition period, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Regrind and Recycling Department when a 200-liter container of acetone cleaning solvent fell from a temporary storage shelf during an inventory relocation. The container fractured on impact with the concrete floor, releasing approximately 160 liters of acetone across an area of approximately 80 square meters. The solvent pooled near electrical equipment and floor drains, creating multiple hazards including fire risk (acetone is highly flammable), environmental contamination (potential entry into the facility's stormwater drainage system), and vapor inhalation risk to personnel in the vicinity. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), the Chemical Inventory Specialist, detected the spill through vapor odor alerts and immediately initiated emergency response protocols. She activated the facility alarm system and directed Anika Johansson (EMP-00144), the Packaging Supervisor, to evacuate the area and isolate the chemical storage section. Wei Liu (EMP-00088), the Production Scheduler who was nearby reviewing inventory records, assisted in securing the area and preventing further movement of adjacent chemical containers. Emergency response teams deployed absorbent materials and initiated cleanup operations that required 6 hours to complete. Environmental monitoring confirmed that no acetone entered the stormwater system due to rapid containment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 AM during the day shift, Patrick Ouellet (EMP-00045), an Injection Molding Technician, was operating Injection Molding Line C in the Medical Components clean room. While removing a finished part from the mold cavity, Patrick's right hand came into contact with a mold release agent (silicone-based) that had accumulated on the mold surface. The exposure caused immediate skin irritation and redness across his palm and fingers. Patrick noticed the reaction within minutes and reported it to his supervisor, Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101). Maxime immediately escorted Patrick to the first aid station where Hana Al-Rashid, the Occupational Health Nurse, assessed the contact dermatitis. The affected area was rinsed thoroughly with water and a mild topical treatment was applied. Patrick experienced mild burning and itching that subsided within 30 minutes. No medical leave was required, and Patrick returned to work after receiving first aid treatment and changing his gloves.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 1:15 PM during the day shift, Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), a Material Handler, was transferring resin pellets from a storage bin to the hopper system of Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging area. While operating the pneumatic conveying system, the hopper outlet became partially clogged with compacted material. Kwesi attempted to clear the blockage by manually striking the hopper with a rubber mallet. During this operation, the accumulated pressure was suddenly released, and a mass of approximately 15 kg of polypropylene resin pellets explosively discharged from the hopper, striking Kwesi on his left shoulder and upper arm. The force of the discharge caused Kwesi to lose his balance and fall approximately 0.5 meters onto the production floor. Kwesi sustained a left shoulder contusion with swelling and localized bruising. Production Supervisor Maxime Boisvert (EMP-00101) immediately stopped the equipment and called for first aid assistance. Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) arrived within 5 minutes and assessed the injury. Ice was applied to reduce swelling, and after initial treatment, Kwesi was unable to continue his duties due to pain and limited arm mobility. He was referred to urgent care for further evaluation and remained off work for the following two days.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 8:30 PM during the evening shift, Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), a Regrind Operator, was performing routine maintenance on a CNC milling machine in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop. Fernand was adjusting a cutting tool holder when his left hand became caught between the rotating spindle head and the fixed machine frame as the automatic spindle start cycle unexpectedly engaged. Although the machine's emergency stop button was immediately pressed by a nearby coworker, Fernand sustained a laceration across the dorsal surface of his left hand between the thumb and index finger, approximately 4 cm in length with moderate bleeding. François-Xavier Mailhot (EMP-00105), the Maintenance Supervisor, responded immediately and applied direct pressure to control bleeding while calling for emergency medical services. Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123), an Incident Investigation Specialist, arrived and provided advanced first aid. An ambulance arrived within 12 minutes, and Fernand was transported to the hospital emergency department. Medical evaluation revealed the laceration required 8 stitches and deeper soft tissue assessment to rule out tendon involvement. Fernand was admitted for observation and underwent surgical exploration to confirm no structural damage. He was discharged after 6 hours of hospitalization but required one week of medical leave for wound healing and infection prevention.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Bruno Landry (EMP-00083), Injection Molding Operator on Line D, was performing routine mold changeout procedures in the Main Production Building. While disconnecting the cooling water hose from a mold that had been in operation for 6 hours, residual high-temperature coolant (approximately 85°C) suddenly discharged from a pressurized coupling that had not been fully vented. The hot liquid contacted Bruno's left forearm and hand, causing second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 15% of the affected area. Bruno immediately alerted nearby colleagues and proceeded to the first aid station where initial cooling treatment was administered. The incident was discovered when Marco Rossi (EMP-00016), Mechanical Maintenance Technician, arrived to assist with the mold changeout and found Bruno receiving first aid. Emergency medical services were called and Bruno was transported to the facility's hospital partner for treatment of burn wounds. Root cause investigation revealed that the pressure release valve on the cooling system had not been functioning properly for several weeks, and the standard operating procedures for mold cooling system depressurization had not been followed due to time pressures from increased production demand.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during evening shift operations, Hawa Traore (EMP-00178), Machine Operator on evening shift, was working in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013) performing precision grinding operations on a custom mold cavity. While positioning a glass-fiber reinforced composite component for final dimensioning, the component suddenly slipped from her gloved grip and fell onto the stainless steel work surface, splintering into multiple sharp fragments. As Hawa reached to clear the debris, a sharp glass-fiber splinter penetrated her right palm, becoming embedded approximately 8mm deep. She immediately notified her supervisor, Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who assisted in controlling minor bleeding and escorted her to first aid. The splinter was removed by the on-site nurse. Follow-up examination revealed minor skin irritation and localized inflammation but no deep tissue damage. However, the potential for serious infection prompted referral to occupational health for monitoring. Root cause analysis identified that gloves being used (standard nitrile) provided inadequate protection against sharp glass-fiber fragments, and the work surface layout created awkward positioning angles that increased dropped-part risk.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the resin drying system in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016) experienced a catastrophic failure. The heating element control thermostat malfunctioned, allowing the drying chamber temperature to escalate beyond safe operating limits, reaching approximately 280°C instead of the designed maximum of 120°C. Over a 45-minute period before detection, the excessive heat damaged the chamber's internal insulation, warped the aluminum chassis, and partially melted several polymer control components. The internal heating element suffered permanent damage with visible cracks and discoloration. Material in the drying chamber—approximately 450 kg of polycarbonate resin batches—was rendered unusable due to thermal degradation and discoloration. Equipment shutdown was performed immediately when the overheating condition was detected by automated monitoring systems. Damage assessment indicated the dryer would require complete internal rebuild and replacement of the heating element assembly, estimated at 72 hours downtime. The incident was discovered and reported by Dimitri Sokolov (EMP-00120), CNC Machinist, who routinely monitors material preparation logs at shift change. Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, was notified for waste material management and regulatory reporting.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during day shift operations, Assembly Operator Ana Silva (EMP-00040) was working at Injection Molding Line B when she contacted hot plastic material that had overflowed from the hopper during a material feed cycle. The operator was reaching across the machine to clear a minor jam when the hopper mechanism malfunctioned, causing approximately 8 kg of molten polycarbonate resin (temperature ~280°C) to spill onto her right forearm and hand. Ana immediately immersed her arm in the emergency eye wash station and was transported by Warehouse Associate Marc Hébert (EMP-00047), who witnessed the incident, to Laval General Hospital. She suffered second-degree thermal burns covering approximately 12% of her right arm requiring hospitalization for 3 days. The incident was caused by inadequate guarding around the hopper discharge area and lack of proper PPE (heat-resistant sleeves were available but not consistently enforced). Root cause analysis revealed the hopper overflow sensor had not been calibrated in 18 months.

On May 22, 2024, at 10:45 PM during evening shift operations, Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line A when she discovered that the compressed air line feeding the pneumatic mold opener had developed a significant leak. While investigating the leak point near the mold assembly, Svetlana noticed the pressure gauge was reading 160 PSI above the normal operating threshold. She was about to use compressed air from a secondary line to dry components when Quality Inspector Jasmine Patel (EMP-00150), performing end-of-shift quality checks, observed the unusual pressure reading and immediately alerted Svetlana to the hazard. Jasmine directed Svetlana to isolate the line and contact maintenance before proceeding. The relief valve appeared to be stuck in the closed position, which could have caused the secondary line to rupture or release compressed air violently if used improperly. No injury occurred because the near-miss was caught before equipment failure. The incident highlighted inadequate pre-shift pressure system verification and missing pressure relief system inspection labels.

On June 8, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift operations, Packaging Operator Nour Jaber (EMP-00188) was preparing medical device components for shipment in the Packaging and Labeling Station when he attempted to retrieve finished product boxes from a cantilever storage rack that extended 2.3 meters above the floor level. Nour was standing on a standard two-step ladder (approved for maximum 1.8 meter reach) and over-reached to grab a box positioned on the upper shelf, causing him to lose balance momentarily. Maintenance worker on rounds, Quality Supervisor Yves Thibault (EMP-00079), noticed Nour's precarious position and immediately called out a warning. Nour regained his footing and carefully descended the ladder without falling. The box remained on the shelf. No injury occurred, but the incident revealed that storage rack heights exceeded the safe reach recommendations for available ladder equipment and proper material handling procedures were not followed. Post-incident investigation showed that workers had been regularly over-reaching to avoid using the motorized lift equipment due to perceived inconvenience.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Céline Morin (EMP-00153), an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a minor thermal burn to her left forearm while removing molded parts from the injection mold. The mold temperature was 285°C, within normal operating parameters. While using the standard extraction tool to remove a batch of automotive connector housings, the tool slipped from her grip due to residual coolant on her hand. She instinctively caught the falling part with her bare forearm, resulting in a first-degree burn approximately 3cm x 5cm in area. The incident occurred in the Main Production Building, North Zone (Injection Molding Line B area). A nearby colleague, Youssef Zaidi (EMP-00060), witnessed the incident and immediately alerted the shift supervisor. First aid was administered on-site by the facility's trained first aid responder, including cool water application and sterile dressing. The employee continued working after treatment with modified duties to avoid further exposure. Root cause analysis identified inadequate grip surface on the extraction tool and insufficient PPE (lacking cut-resistant gloves rated for thermal protection).

On April 2, 2024, at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139), Warehouse Supervisor, suffered a significant crushing injury to his right foot resulting in a lost-time incident requiring hospitalization and surgical intervention. Beaudoin was operating a Hyster forklift to relocate a pallet of finished composite motor housings (approximately 1,200 kg) in the Warehouse and Shipping facility when the load shifted unexpectedly due to improper weight distribution on the pallet. The pallet tipped, and one corner of the wooden pallet frame contacted the concrete floor, causing the load to rotate. As Beaudoin attempted to dismount from the forklift to assess the situation, his right foot became trapped between the descending pallet load and the concrete floor. The crushing force resulted in three metatarsal fractures and severe soft tissue damage. Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler working nearby, immediately called emergency services. Beaudoin was transported to Hôpital Sacré-Cœur and hospitalized for 4 days. Medical prognosis indicates 8-10 weeks of lost work time. Investigation revealed that load securing procedures were not followed, and the forklift operator lacked current certification for the load weight class.

On March 28, 2024, at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Thanh Pham (EMP-00062), Maintenance Planner, conducted a routine inspection of the chemical mixing operations in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility and identified a potential hazard related to respiratory safety. While inspecting the ventilation system above the epoxy resin mixing station, Pham observed that three of the six exhaust ductwork connections had become partially loose, reducing airflow by approximately 40% based on anemometer measurements. The resin mixing operation, scheduled to commence at 8:00 AM, would expose two production operators and one maintenance technician to elevated concentrations of styrene and other volatile organic compounds (VOCs). No workers had yet been exposed to unsafe conditions, but continued operation would have likely resulted in acute respiratory irritation or chronic exposure issues. Zahra Nasri (EMP-00168), HSE Specialist, was immediately notified and the resin mixing operation was preemptively shut down pending corrective action. This is classified as a preventive declaration as no injury occurred but a serious hazard was proactively identified and reported before exposure could result in harm. Root cause: vibration from adjacent equipment and lack of preventive maintenance scheduling for ductwork connections.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a solvent storage cabinet malfunction in the Regrind and Recycling Department led to a fire incident. Employee Yvon Croteau was transferring acetone-based solvent from a large container to smaller bottles for redistribution when he noticed the cabinet's temperature control unit had failed, causing excessive heat buildup. The cabinet, which contained approximately 40 liters of flammable solvent, reached an unsafe temperature. A small spark from nearby grinding equipment ignited vapors escaping from the cabinet. Flames erupted from the cabinet opening, and Yvon immediately activated the nearest emergency alarm and evacuated the area. The facility's automatic sprinkler system activated within 30 seconds, and the on-site fire suppression team responded with a Class B foam extinguisher, fully extinguishing the fire within 2 minutes. No personnel were injured, but the cabinet and approximately 15 liters of solvent were lost. The incident was caused by a failed thermostat in the cabinet that had not been inspected during the previous month's maintenance cycle.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 9:30 AM during the day shift, a first-aid injury occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Production Operator Fatou Ndiaye was loading pre-dried polycarbonate pellets into the input hopper of the material dryer when her right hand inadvertently contacted the edge of a freshly molded composite part that was cooling on an adjacent work surface. The part had sharp, unburred edges from the injection molding process and had not yet undergone post-processing edge smoothing. The sharp edge lacerated the webbing between Fatou's right thumb and index finger, creating a 2-inch cut that bled profusely. Assembly Lead Sonia Dasilva immediately applied direct pressure with clean gauze and elevated the hand above heart level. First Aid Coordinator Ahmed Hassan was summoned from the adjacent production line and applied a sterile bandage with antibiotic ointment after the bleeding subsided. The wound required 6 stitches but did not require hospital referral as it did not involve deep structure damage or loss of sensation. Fatou received tetanus prophylaxis and was cleared to return to modified duty the following day.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176), an Assembly Operator, was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) performing hand layup operations on a fiberglass-reinforced polymer component. While reaching across a work table to retrieve a pre-cut composite sheet, Jackson's right hand came into contact with an unguarded rotating shaft of a curing oven that had been accidentally left running during maintenance. The rotating shaft caught her sleeve and pulled her hand into the mechanism, causing a crush injury to her right hand with fractures to the metacarpal bones and lacerations to her palm. Coworker Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086) immediately called for emergency response and applied direct pressure to the wound. The injury required surgical intervention and resulted in 8 weeks of lost time. Root cause analysis revealed that the equipment had not been properly locked out/tagged out during the maintenance window, and no physical guards were installed on the rotating shaft despite it being identified as a pinch point hazard during the 2023 facility audit.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:20 PM during the evening shift, Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136), Chemical Inventory Specialist, was transferring a 200-liter drum of epoxy resin primer from storage to the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). While connecting the transfer hose to the receiving tank using a manual pump system, a fitting connection failed due to corrosion of the brass coupler. Approximately 45 liters of epoxy resin spilled onto the concrete floor, creating a hazardous slick surface and releasing volatile organic compound (VOC) fumes into the production area. The spill extended approximately 8 meters across the room and partially seeped into the floor drain system. Emergency response was initiated at 10:25 PM by witness Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), who activated the facility's chemical spill protocol, evacuated personnel from the area, and notified the HSE department. Hazmat team response contained the spill using absorbent materials and decontamination occurred over 90 minutes. No injuries resulted, but approximately 15 employees were temporarily evacuated and the mixing room was closed for 6 hours pending air quality verification. Root cause was insufficient preventive maintenance on storage connections and lack of secondary containment in the transfer area.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:15 AM during the night shift, Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), Machine Setter on night shift, was performing setup activities on a 300-ton injection molding machine in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). While adjusting the mold alignment using a pneumatic torque wrench, the tool suffered a catastrophic seal failure causing the wrench head to separate and strike the adjacent control panel with significant force. The impact penetrated the panel's access cover and damaged multiple pneumatic solenoid valves and electrical relay circuits. The equipment became inoperable, and a secondary explosion of compressed air from the ruptured hose caused minor laceration to Desbiens' left forearm requiring 3 stitches. Monique Dion (EMP-00119), Warehouse Associate who was retrieving materials in the adjacent area, witnessed the incident and activated emergency response at 6:18 AM. Equipment was isolated and a full system inspection was conducted. The damaged pneumatic and electrical components required complete replacement, costing approximately $32,000 in parts and labor. The machine remained out of service for 7 days during repair and component sourcing. Root cause investigation determined the torque wrench had exceeded its service life (4 years) without replacement and had not been included in the preventive maintenance rotation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Tariq Aziz (EMP-00118), a forklift operator, was transporting a pallet of raw polycarbonate resin from the receiving dock to the Chemical Storage and Mixing area. As he navigated through the narrow corridor between the Warehouse and Shipping section and the Main Production Building, he noticed that one of the upper storage racks appeared to be unstable, with several cardboard boxes of plastic additives positioned precariously near the edge. The rack had not been properly secured after recent inventory adjustments. Tariq immediately stopped his forklift and alerted nearby personnel. Before any materials could fall, he documented the hazardous condition and reported it to Facilities Coordinator Eric Champagne. The potential for struck-by injuries was high given the weight and height of the materials. No injuries occurred, and the situation was contained through immediate work stoppage and notification.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096), a production operator on the night shift, sustained a minor laceration to his left index finger while removing finished parts from Injection Molding Line D. The parts had sharp edges from the molding process that had not been adequately deburred during quality control. As Kwame was extracting a batch of automotive dashboard components, his hand made contact with the unfinished edge, causing a 2-centimeter cut requiring five stitches at the facility first aid station. Emergency Response Team Leader Johanne Paquette (EMP-00115) administered immediate first aid including wound cleaning, bleeding control, and proper bandaging. The employee was able to return to work after treatment with a protective bandage and continued for the remainder of the shift. The incident was documented and the affected parts batch was flagged for additional inspection.

On March 28, 2024, at 8:30 AM during day shift operations, Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) conducted a routine inspection of the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility and identified a potential hazard that had not yet resulted in an incident. She discovered that several containers of epoxy resin hardener had been stored in an area where the ambient temperature had exceeded the manufacturer's recommended storage limit of 25°C due to a malfunctioning HVAC unit. The storage area temperature had reached 34°C. Additionally, she noted that the ventilation system was operating at reduced capacity, creating potential for inadequate air circulation during mixing operations. The containers were immediately relocated to a compliant storage area, and facilities were notified of the HVAC malfunction. This proactive identification prevented potential chemical decomposition and worker exposure to hazardous vapors.

On March 15, 2024, at 2:45 PM during day shift operations, Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a Production Operator on Injection Molding Line B, sustained a thermal burn to her right forearm while removing a finished part from the mold cavity. The mold temperature was approximately 280°C. Naomi was removing parts from the automotive dashboard component production run when her protective sleeve rode up during the extraction process, exposing approximately 4 inches of skin on her inner forearm directly to the hot mold surface. She maintained contact for approximately 2-3 seconds before withdrawing her arm. The burn resulted in a second-degree injury covering roughly 3% of her body surface area. Naomi immediately reported to the on-site health clinic where Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed the injury, applied appropriate wound care, and recommended follow-up treatment. The incident occurred in UNIT-002 (Injection Molding Line B - Automotive). No production line stoppage was required, and the employee remained at work with modified duties for the remainder of the shift.

On April 8, 2024, at 10:15 PM during evening shift, Réjean Simard (EMP-00077), a Mold Maintenance Technician, suffered a crush injury to his left hand while repositioning a 1,600-pound injection mold inside the Tool Room of UNIT-013 (Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop). Réjean was assisting with lowering the mold onto a work bench using an overhead gantry crane when the mold support bracket misaligned with the receiving cradle. The mold tilted approximately 15 degrees, causing the edge of the mold cavity to pinch his left hand between the mold and the cradle structure. Réjean's ring finger and middle finger sustained crush injuries with suspected fractures. He was immediately attended to by Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151), who called emergency services. Réjean was transported to Laval General Hospital and admitted for X-rays, surgical assessment, and orthopedic treatment. The incident resulted in 8 days of lost work time. The mold operation was secured and documented; the overhead crane was immediately taken out of service for inspection. Root cause: inadequate work space clearance and missing mechanical alignment guides.

On May 22, 2024, at 3:20 AM during night shift operations, an environmental incident was discovered in UNIT-018 (Regrind and Recycling Department) located in Warehouse and Shipping - Section C. Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) noticed an uncontrolled solvent spill on the warehouse floor approximately 15 square meters in area. Investigation revealed that a 200-liter drum of acetone (cleaning solvent) positioned on a damaged lower shelf had developed a crack due to corrosion, with the drum having partially leaked over an estimated 6-hour period. Approximately 80 liters of acetone had escaped onto the concrete floor and concrete barrier, with approximately 5-8 liters having entered the storm drain system before containment. The spill created airborne vapors, and multiple warning signs of volatile organic compound (VOC) exposure were evident. Night Shift Supervisor André Paradis (EMP-00037) immediately implemented emergency response: he evacuated non-essential personnel from Section C, activated the spill containment kit, placed absorbent material, and established isolation barriers. Confined Space Entry Supervisor André Bellavance (EMP-00157) was called to coordinate air monitoring and ensure worker safety during cleanup. The incident was reported to CNESST within 2 hours. Environmental impact: low concentration acetone (2-3 ppm) detected in surface water runoff; storm drain isolation was implemented to prevent further environmental migration. Cleanup and disposal required 14 hours.

On March 22, 2025, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) was conducting a routine inventory check in the Equipment Storage and Spare Parts Room on the maintenance workshop storage mezzanine. While reaching for a box of CNC tooling components stored on a high shelf (approximately 7 feet above ground level), he noticed that the shelf bracket supporting the upper storage section appeared to be bent and misaligned. Upon closer inspection, he discovered that several anchor bolts connecting the shelving unit to the wall were severely corroded and partially loosened, with visible rust and degradation. Luc-André immediately stopped work and did not attempt to remove any items from the affected shelf. He photographed the condition and reported the finding to the EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) via the facility's mobile alert system. The area was cordoned off with warning tape and a DANGER sign was posted. Samira conducted a comprehensive shelf inspection which identified that the bracket failure was imminent and could have resulted in the entire shelf assembly collapsing, potentially causing severe injury to any worker beneath it. The hazard was eliminated before the end of shift by securing the shelves and removing unsafe inventory.

On March 28, 2025, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was performing routine material transfers in the Post-Processing and Heat Treatment area when she accidentally spilled approximately 500 milliliters of cleaning solvent (acetone mixture) while transferring it from a large storage container to smaller spray bottles. The solvent splashed onto her face, eyes, and upper torso despite wearing basic safety glasses. Marwa immediately flushed her eyes with the emergency eyewash station located 15 feet from the spill site, rinsing for approximately 90 seconds. However, she experienced significant eye irritation, redness, and temporary blurred vision. She reported the incident to the Warehouse Lead Michel Laflamme (EMP-00081) who was present on the night shift. Michel immediately radioed for the Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052), who was called in from the on-call roster given the time of day. Hana assessed Marwa's condition and determined that she required evaluation at the emergency department due to persistent eye inflammation and vision problems. Marwa was transported to the hospital where she was treated for chemical conjunctivitis and minor corneal irritation. She was released after 4 hours of care but required 2 days of restricted duty. The spill was contained, cleaned up by the night shift team, and reported to the HSE office. Root cause analysis identified that Marwa was not wearing face shield protection and the solvent transfer procedure lacked secondary containment measures.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, a significant material spill occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), the Regrind Operator, was transferring reground polypropylene material from a collection bin into the main hopper when the collection bin's support bracket failed. The 200-pound bin fell approximately 3 feet, striking a nearby workbench and rupturing open. Approximately 80 pounds of mixed reground PP material and processing residue spilled across the work area, and more critically, the impact caused a 5-gallon container of acetone-based mold release agent to overturn, spilling its contents onto the floor and partially onto the material pile. The chemical spread across approximately 400 square feet of the work surface and flooring. Fumes from the acetone rapidly filled the immediate area. Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), a Machine Setter on the night shift, was working nearby and noticed the spill immediately. He activated the emergency ventilation system and moved Fernand to fresh air. The cleanup required 4 hours of work by the maintenance team using absorbent materials and specialized cleaning procedures. No personal injuries occurred, but equipment damage included the ruined collection bin ($800), damaged workbench ($1,200), and lost materials valued at approximately $2,100. The facility's production schedule was delayed as the area remained closed during cleanup and air quality verification.

On November 20, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the main production ventilation system for Injection Molding Line D suffered a critical failure. Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163), Machine Setter on night shift, noticed diminished airflow at his workstation and reported unusual plastic fume accumulation in the work area. He immediately alerted the maintenance team. Investigation revealed that the primary supply fan motor had seized due to bearing failure, leaving the 8,000 CFM ventilation system inoperative. The system had been operating continuously without scheduled maintenance since April 2024—8 months beyond the recommended 6-month service interval. The failure rendered the line unable to maintain safe air quality standards for the temperature-sensitive casting and cooling processes. Production was halted for the entire night shift affecting 15 workers. James Thompson (EMP-00029), the operator for Line D, was reassigned to other duties. Replacement of the motor ($3,400), emergency bearing maintenance ($1,100), and labor costs ($2,200) totaled $6,700 in unplanned expenses. The system remained offline for 18 hours until repairs were completed by an external HVAC contractor. This created a production backlog affecting delivery timelines for automotive component orders.

On March 15, 2024 at 14:45, Assembly Operator Isabella Ricci (EMP-00162) sustained a burn injury while working on Injection Molding Line A in the Main Production Building. Ricci was removing a finished automotive trim component from a mold that had just completed its cycle. Despite wearing standard heat-resistant gloves, she made contact with an exposed mold surface at approximately 165°C while extracting the part. The gloves provided insufficient insulation for the duration of contact. She experienced a second-degree burn across her left palm and two fingers. Immediate first aid was administered by Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140) who was working nearby. Ice was applied for 15 minutes, and the wound was cleaned and bandaged with antibiotic ointment and sterile gauze. Ricci was transported to the on-site first aid station where Safety Officer Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007) documented the injury and provided additional treatment including pain management. The employee remained on light duty for three days while the burn healed. Root cause analysis indicated that the automatic part ejector had partially malfunctioned, requiring manual extraction while the mold was still hot.

On March 22, 2024 at 23:15 during the night shift, Production Operator Kwame Mensah (EMP-00096) nearly suffered a serious fall in the Finished Goods Warehouse while conducting inventory. Mensah was reaching for a box on a mid-level shelf approximately 1.8 meters high when his foot caught on an air hose that had been routed across the floor without proper securing. The hose was connected to pneumatic equipment in the adjacent area. As Mensah stumbled, he instinctively grabbed the shelf edge, preventing a fall to the concrete floor below. A nearby forklift operator Roberto Santos (EMP-00012) immediately approached to assist. The incident was witnessed by Material Handler Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), who reported it to the HSE department. Investigation revealed that the air hose had been temporarily routed through a high-traffic area two weeks prior during equipment reconfiguration, but permanent installation had not been completed. The trip hazard created a significant risk of serious injury given the height of the shelving and hard floor surface. No actual injury occurred, but the potential for hospitalization was high.

On March 28, 2024, Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) completed a routine air quality assessment in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area and identified a developing dust accumulation fire hazard. During inspection of the composite material mixing operation, Santos observed plastic dust accumulation on horizontal surfaces of equipment and along wall ledges, particularly near the regrind station operated by Regrind Supervisor Normand Bergeron (EMP-00147). The dust layer measured 2-3 millimeters thick in several locations. Although no ignition sources were present and no incident had occurred, the accumulation represents a significant fire risk per NFPA guidelines, particularly given the proximity of spark-generating equipment and the presence of stored solvents. Santos documented photographic evidence and measured dust particle concentration at 8.5 mg/m³. The facility's preventive maintenance logs showed that vacuum cleaning operations had been sporadic over the past 6 weeks due to staffing constraints. This preventive declaration was issued to address the hazard before an actual fire incident could occur, triggering facility-wide dust control improvements.

On March 15, 2024, at 14:45 during day shift, assembly operator Luis Fernandez (EMP-00027) was working at Station 4 in Injection Molding Line B when he reached into the mold cavity to remove a stuck component. The molding cycle had not fully completed, and the mold suddenly closed, catching his left hand between the core and cavity. His ring and middle fingers sustained crush injuries with significant tissue damage. Coworker Robert Fournier (EMP-00067) immediately activated the emergency stop button and called for assistance. Medical responder Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) arrived within 2 minutes and provided initial first aid before paramedics transported Luis to Sacré-Cœur Hospital in Montreal. Investigation revealed the interlock safety system had a mechanical failure that prevented proper detection of foreign objects in the mold cavity. The employee remained hospitalized for 6 days with surgical intervention required. This resulted in 21 lost workdays during recovery and rehabilitation.

On February 3, 2024, at 22:15 during evening shift, a chemical spill incident occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room. Material Handler Amani Mwangi (EMP-00194) was transferring a 50-liter container of isopropanol solvent from storage to the mixing prep area when the container's closure cap was not properly secured. The container tipped over during transfer, spilling approximately 35 liters of isopropanol across the floor and into a drainage channel. The spill spread approximately 8 meters, reaching near electrical equipment and creating a significant fire hazard. Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) immediately evacuated the area, activated the fire alarm as a precaution, and contacted Emergency Response. Respiratory Protection Program Coordinator Jamal Thompson (EMP-00152) coordinated containment efforts using absorbent materials and proper disposal procedures. The spill was contained within 45 minutes. No employees were injured, but approximately $18,000 in raw materials and equipment were damaged due to chemical contact and cleaning requirements. The facility was ventilated for 2 hours before normal operations resumed.

On January 28, 2024, at 06:20 during night shift, Quality Engineer Daniel Turgeon (EMP-00137) was performing routine inspection of finished medical device components in the Quality Control Laboratory. While handling a batch of polycarbonate housing units, he inadvertently made contact with uncured epoxy adhesive residue on one component, causing a mild allergic reaction manifesting as localized skin erythema and mild swelling on his right palm and fingers. The reaction developed within 15 minutes of exposure. Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) examined him and provided antihistamine treatment and supportive care. Investigation determined that components were processed through a new batch of adhesive from an alternate supplier that contained a different chemical formulation with potential sensitizing agents. Daniel experienced discomfort for approximately 6 hours before symptoms resolved, and he was able to continue work after decontamination. The incident was classified as non-recordable minor injury but prompted immediate review of adhesive supplier specifications and material safety data sheets.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Sana Iqbal (EMP-00190) was operating injection molding machine #7 in the Production Operations area when she noticed unusual vibration and noise from the machine. While attempting to inspect the mold cavity, the machine suddenly restarted without warning due to a failed proximity sensor on the safety interlock system. Her left hand was caught between the mold platens as they closed, resulting in crush injuries to her palm and fingers. Co-worker Jade Wong (EMP-00140) witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop button. Sana was transported by ambulance to Laval Hospital with fractures to the 3rd and 4th metacarpals and severe soft tissue damage. The incident occurred because maintenance personnel had recently serviced the sensor but failed to properly test the safety interlock before returning the machine to service. She required surgery and was unable to work for 6 weeks.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the materials mixing room (UNIT-018, Regrind and Recycling Department). Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) was transferring approximately 85 liters of polyurethane resin from a 200-liter drum to the automated mixer when the transfer hose suddenly ruptured due to material degradation and prolonged pressure exposure. Approximately 60 liters of resin spilled across the floor, creating a hazardous pool approximately 4 meters in diameter. The volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from the spill triggered the facility's air quality alarm. Evening Shift Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) immediately evacuated the department and notified the HSE team. The spill was contained using absorbent pads and the contaminated materials were properly disposed of according to WHMIS protocols. The incident required 8 hours of cleanup and temporarily shut down mixing operations. Root cause analysis determined the hose had exceeded its service life and should have been replaced during recent preventive maintenance.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 12:30 AM during the night shift, Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was retrieving a finished goods pallet from the high-bay storage area (UNIT-008, Finished Goods Warehouse) using an electric forklift when the pallet load suddenly shifted and collapsed. Approximately 200 kg of packaged composite parts tumbled down from the 4-meter height, striking Marwa on the right shoulder and upper back. She fell to the ground and was unable to move her right arm. Night shift responder Giovanni Bianchi (EMP-00032), the only other operator present, immediately contacted emergency services and stayed with Marwa until paramedics arrived. She was transported to Laval Hospital with a fractured right scapula, rotator cuff tear, and multiple contusions. The investigation revealed that pallets had been stacked incorrectly by day shift workers 3 days earlier, with uneven weight distribution that gradually destabilized during storage. Marwa required 14 weeks of recovery and physical therapy before returning to modified duties.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Assembly Operator Ana Silva was working at Injection Molding Line B when she noticed molten plastic material leaking from a connection point on the material hopper. Rather than immediately stopping operations and notifying maintenance, she attempted to tighten the connection using a wrench while the system was still pressurized and heated to 280°C. As she applied pressure to the fitting, a sudden pressure release occurred, spraying hot plastic material across her right forearm and hand. Silva immediately removed her PPE glove and ran to the break room sink to cool the burn. The burn area showed second-degree characteristics with blistering approximately 3 inches in diameter. Production Planner Pierre Bouchard witnessed the incident and immediately called for first aid response. Safety Officer Anh Nguyen arrived within 2 minutes and provided initial first aid treatment, applying cool water for 10 minutes and sterile gauze. Silva was transported to the on-site medical clinic where the burn was properly dressed and documented. The root cause was identified as inadequate training on pressure release procedures and failure to follow lockout/tagout protocols before attempting equipment adjustments.

On November 18, 2024, at 10:30 AM during routine inspection of the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop, Tool and Die Maker Mario Béisle discovered a significant potential safety issue that had not yet resulted in an incident. While inspecting work-holding fixtures on an older CNC milling machine, he noticed that the machine's interlocked safety guard had corroded mounting bolts that were approximately 40% stripped of their threads. The guard, designed to prevent contact with rotating cutting tools, was loose and could potentially fail to engage properly if a door were opened during operation. The machine had been in service for 8 years and this preventive inspection would have been missed during the regular quarterly maintenance cycle due to scheduling conflicts. Béisle immediately deactivated the machine, posted a temporary lockout tag, and documented the condition with photographs. He reported the finding to Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger, who initiated a work order for immediate replacement of the mounting hardware and guard re-certification. No workers were exposed to the hazard due to Béisle's proactive discovery during routine inspection. The corroded hardware represented a potential crush injury or amputation risk if the guard had failed during operation.

On November 21, 2024, at 5:45 PM during the evening shift, Material Handler Salma Haddad was organizing resin storage containers in the Hazardous Waste Management Area when she noticed an open solvent drum that had not been properly sealed. The 55-gallon acetone container, which should have been sealed with a locking lid, was sitting open with its bung removed. She estimated the container had been unsecured for at least 2-3 hours based on production schedules. The chemical storage area ventilation system was operational, but the open container represented a significant volatilization hazard and fire risk. Haddad did not attempt to handle the drum but immediately stepped back, closed the access door to the waste management area, and reported the condition to Environmental Compliance Specialist Nathalie Dubois. Dubois arrived within 5 minutes, confirmed the hazard, and properly sealed the container using safety procedures. Air quality measurements taken after sealing showed solvent vapor concentrations had reached 450 ppm in a localized area near the container (the OSHA PEL is 750 ppm, but company safety standards maintain a 300 ppm action level). No workers reported respiratory symptoms. Investigation revealed that a temporary worker had removed the lid during a material transfer but forgotten to reseal it before departing.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during the evening shift, an accumulation of plastic dust and finely ground regrind material was discovered in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015). Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187), a Regrind Operator, was conducting routine dust collection maintenance when he noticed significant buildup on overhead ledges, ceiling corners, and around the industrial compressor unit that had been running continuously due to a maintenance scheduling oversight. The facility's dust collection system had been operating at reduced efficiency due to a clogged filter that was not replaced during the last scheduled maintenance interval. Approximately 8 pounds of accumulated plastic dust was found within 3 feet of the natural gas pilot light assembly and the compressor's hot exhaust manifold (surface temperature approximately 180°C). A small spark from the compressor's motor starter momentarily ignited a small portion of the dust cloud, creating a visible flame approximately 12 inches high that self-extinguished within seconds. No structural damage or secondary ignition occurred. Fernand immediately activated the facility's emergency dust collection protocol and notified Industrial Hygienist Nina Santos (EMP-00084) of the hazard.

On March 28, 2024, at approximately 6:20 AM during the night shift, Mariam Osman (EMP-00064), a Material Handler in the Materials Management and Warehousing area, was unloading a shipment of polypropylene resin pellets from a delivery truck. While reaching up to grab a heavy bag of resin (approximately 25 kg) from a high shelf, her grip slipped and the bag fell, striking her on the right shoulder and upper arm. The impact caused acute shoulder strain and a shallow laceration approximately 3 cm in length on her right upper arm from a sharp corner of the shelf. Mariam immediately reported the incident to her supervisor, Chantal Côté (EMP-00017), who assessed the injury and provided first aid treatment including wound cleaning, topical antibiotic application, and sterile gauze dressing. The laceration did not require sutures but was monitored for proper healing. Mariam was advised to monitor the shoulder for increased pain or reduced mobility over the following 48 hours. The incident was documented as a first aid case requiring medical evaluation but no hospitalization. Root cause analysis indicated inadequate material storage height planning and insufficient ergonomic assessment of the warehouse layout.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a catastrophic failure occurred on Injection Molding Line B in the Main Production Building's North Zone. Machine Setter Tomas Jimenez was performing routine material feed adjustments when the hydraulic pressure relief valve on the injection unit suddenly malfunctioned, failing to regulate pressure as designed. The system pressure spiked to 450 PSI, far exceeding the safe operating limit of 280 PSI. The increased pressure caused the mold clamp assembly to release unexpectedly, ejecting a partially-formed automotive component at high velocity. The component struck Jimenez on the left shoulder and upper arm, causing a laceration approximately 8 cm long. Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant, working nearby on line configuration, witnessed the incident and immediately activated the emergency stop. Jimenez received first aid treatment from the on-site medical responder and was transported to Laval Hospital for suture placement. The equipment was immediately taken out of service pending investigation. Root cause analysis revealed the pressure valve had not been serviced according to the maintenance schedule for 18 months.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 AM during day shift operations, a near-miss incident was identified in the Finished Goods Warehouse (Section B). Forklift Operator Roberto Santos was maneuvering a loaded pallet of finished composite parts through the warehouse aisle when he noticed the overhead ceiling-mounted chain hoist had a noticeably bent chain link, approximately 2 meters above his position. The chain was supporting a suspended mold component weighing approximately 120 kg. Santos immediately halted his forklift movement and alerted Quality Auditor Indira Singh, who was conducting inventory nearby. Together they notified Warehouse Supervisor David O'Connor, who cleared the area beneath the hoist as a precautionary measure. The potential failure was averted when maintenance personnel arrived within 20 minutes and secured the load. Inspection revealed that metal fatigue had compromised the chain's integrity, likely from years of repeated loading cycles without proper inspection. The chain was manufactured in 2015 and had never been formally replaced or undergo non-destructive testing. No injuries occurred, but the incident demonstrated a critical gap in asset maintenance procedures. The warehouse had no documentation of hoist certification or inspection records.

On April 3, 2024 at 11:42 PM during night shift operations, a fire incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing area (8,000 sq ft facility). Regrind Technician Oscar Ramirez was transferring acetone-based cleaning solvent from a bulk storage container to smaller working vessels when a static discharge event occurred. The regrind technician had not utilized the bonding cable properly during transfer, resulting in charge accumulation. When he reached toward a metal funnel positioned in the receiving container, a spark ignited the acetone vapors in the immediate area. A localized flash fire approximately 1 meter in diameter ignited, spreading quickly along a spill trail that had accumulated on the concrete floor from a previous day's transfer. The fire traveled approximately 2 meters toward stored polyester resin containers before Ramirez activated the nearby Class B dry powder fire extinguisher, suppending the flames within 45 seconds. Night shift supervisor was on break in the administrative building, unaware of the incident for approximately 3 minutes. When discovered, emergency responders confirmed the fire was fully extinguished but mandated evacuation of the chemical storage building as a precaution. No injuries resulted, but approximately 15 liters of solvent was consumed by the fire, and structural damage to the concrete floor included scorch marks over 3 square meters. Investigation revealed that the facility's static grounding procedure training was outdated (last updated in 2019) and the bonding cable had deteriorated with a partially damaged connector that was not visually obvious during routine use.

On March 14, 2024 at 14:45, Rania Abdallah (EMP-00086), a Composite Materials Operator, was working in the Composite Materials Processing Area (UNIT-015) during the day shift. While handling fiberglass-reinforced composite sheets during a material preparation task, she developed acute skin irritation on her forearms and neck. The fiberglass fibers had become airborne during the cutting and trimming operation, and despite wearing a standard work shirt, small glass fibers penetrated the fabric and embedded in her skin. Initial symptoms included localized redness, itching, and a burning sensation. Her colleague Olga Ivanova (EMP-00042) witnessed the exposure and immediately notified supervision. Rania was directed to the first aid station where she washed the affected areas with cool water and soap under guidance from Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052). The itching and irritation subsided within 30 minutes. No medical leave was required, and the employee returned to work after receiving first aid treatment and skin care instructions. The incident was documented as a first aid case with no lost time.

On April 2, 2024 at 09:15, Andrei Popov (EMP-00094), a Hydraulic Systems Technician, was performing preventive maintenance on the hydraulic system of a 300-ton injection molding machine in UNIT-001 (Injection Molding Line A - Automotive) during the day shift. While disconnecting a high-pressure hydraulic hose after the machine had been shut down but before proper pressure release procedures were completed, residual pressure in the system caused a sudden discharge of hydraulic fluid. The pressurized spray struck Popov's left forearm and hand, causing a thermal burn injury (hydraulic fluid temperature was approximately 65°C). The burn covered approximately 40 square centimeters of his forearm. Popov immediately ran cold water over the affected area and was escorted to the on-site medical clinic by his supervisor Claude Poirier (EMP-00071). Occupational Health Nurse Hana Al-Rashid (EMP-00052) assessed the burn as a second-degree thermal injury requiring medical treatment. Popov received professional wound care, topical antibiotic treatment, and a sterile dressing. He was referred to an external healthcare facility for further evaluation and was placed on restricted duty for one week due to pain and limited range of motion. This incident resulted in a lost-time injury.

On May 18, 2024 at 23:47, a fire alarm was triggered in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) during the night shift.
