Material Handler Marwa Saleh (EMP-00182) was processing waste composite materials in a grinder when a spontaneous ignition occurred in an improperly stored pile of regrind material that had been exposed to elevated ambient temperatures throughout the evening shift. The pile, which contained residual mold release agent (a petroleum-based product), reached a critical temperature and initiated smoldering combustion. Smoke detectors activated the building fire alarm system at 23:47. Night shift supervisor Valerie Pelletier (EMP-00031) was immediately notified and initiated evacuation procedures. The facility's automated fire suppression system engaged, discharging CO2 into the storage area and extinguishing the incipient fire within seconds. No personnel were injured, and the fire was contained entirely within the material storage bin. Local fire department responded as a precaution and confirmed the fire was fully extinguished. The incident was classified as a fire alarm event with no property damage or personnel exposure beyond the alarm activation itself. Investigation revealed inadequate temperature monitoring and poor material storage practices.

On March 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Lina Sokolova (EMP-00174), a Composite Materials Operator working in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016), noticed unusual vibrations and a burning odor emanating from the resin dryer unit. The dryer, which had been in continuous operation for 16 hours, was exhibiting signs of thermal stress. Upon inspection, Lina observed that the temperature gauge was reading 285°C, significantly above the normal operating range of 220-240°C. The heating element appeared to have a partial malfunction causing uneven heat distribution. Rather than continue operating the equipment, Lina immediately shut down the dryer and notified her supervisor, Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175). The quick action prevented potential equipment failure, resin degradation, and possible fire hazard. Lina documented the incident and reported it to the HSE department. A maintenance inspection later revealed that the thermostat calibration had drifted, and the heating element controller was failing intermittently.

On March 19, 2024, at approximately 9:45 PM during the evening shift, a significant property damage incident occurred in the Finished Goods Warehouse (UNIT-008). Claude Poirier (EMP-00071), a Forklift Operator, was retrieving stacked pallets of finished polycarbonate medical components from the upper storage area. While maneuvering the forklift to retrieve a pallet at approximately 12 feet height, the forklift's hydraulic lift system experienced a sudden pressure failure. The mast collapsed unexpectedly, causing the raised pallet load (approximately 2,400 pounds of finished goods) to fall directly onto a secondary stack of inventory below. The impact damaged approximately 850 units of precision-molded components valued at approximately $127,000, destroyed three wooden pallets, and caused a domino effect damaging another 340 units in an adjacent stack. The forklift itself sustained damage to the mast assembly (estimated $18,500 in repairs). No personnel were struck, as Amara Diop (EMP-00110), a Packaging Operator working nearby, had moved away moments before the collapse upon hearing unusual hydraulic sounds. The incident was immediately reported to Production Coordinator Éric Surprenant (EMP-00175) and HSE staff.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during the day shift, a significant hopper overflow occurred at Injection Molding Line D in the Consumer Packaging area. Machine Setter Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048) was adjusting the material feed rate when the resin hopper's level sensor malfunctioned, causing continuous material flow into an already-full hopper. Within minutes, approximately 80 kg of plastic pellets overflowed onto the production floor, creating a slipping hazard and partially blocking the emergency exit corridor on the south side of the facility. Production Operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was working adjacent to the line and immediately notified Production Supervisor Julie Bergeron (EMP-00015) of the overflow. The material spread across approximately 15 square meters of floor space. While the immediate area was cordoned off and the overflow was manually cleaned within 30 minutes using a industrial vacuum system, the incident revealed inadequate hopper monitoring protocols and a failed sensor that had not been replaced despite maintenance alerts issued 4 weeks prior. No personnel were injured, but the near-blockage of the emergency exit presented a serious secondary hazard. Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu documented the event and initiated a formal investigation into the sensor failure and preventive maintenance gaps.

On February 28, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during the evening shift, a critical near-miss occurred in the Composite Materials Processing Area when Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), a Chemical Mixing Operator, nearly suffered an eye splash from concentrated epoxy resin. While transferring a 5-liter container of epoxy from a storage drum to a smaller mixing vessel, the container's lid was not fully seated. As Elena tilted the container to pour, a sudden pressure release caused a small spray of epoxy resin that missed her face by approximately 15 centimeters, striking the stainless steel workbench instead. The incident was witnessed by Process Technician Jade Wong (EMP-00140), who immediately alerted Elena to the hazard. Post-incident investigation revealed that Elena was wearing safety glasses but not the required full-face shield specified in the Standard Operating Procedure for this task. The container's seal had degraded from improper storage conditions—it had been left uncapped in the storage area for 36 hours rather than being properly sealed in the sealed materials cabinet. Elena reported feeling momentary panic as she saw the spray approach her face. Chemical Safety Officer Simon Bélanger responded within 5 minutes and secured the chemical storage area. The near-miss was documented as a critical finding because direct eye contact with concentrated epoxy would have caused serious chemical burns and potential vision impairment requiring emergency medical intervention.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 23:30 during the night shift, a near-miss incident occurred in the Central Maintenance Workshop when Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) narrowly avoided a crush injury while performing routine mold maintenance. Louis was removing a large injection mold (approximately 45 kg) from a workbench using an overhead chain hoist mounted to the workshop's beam system. He had properly connected the lifting lugs to the chain, but as he activated the hoist to raise the mold, one of the lugs began to slip due to inadequate alignment between the lug holes and the lifting hook. The mold tilted at a 35-degree angle and started to descend unexpectedly. Louis had positioned himself directly beneath the mold to guide it, and as it began falling, he reflexively jumped backward, causing the mold to miss his left foot by approximately 30 centimeters before it crashed onto the concrete floor with significant impact. The impact created a loud noise that alerted Maintenance Workshop supervisor (and witness), who arrived within 60 seconds. The mold sustained visible cracks and damage estimated at $8,200, rendering it non-functional for immediate production use. Post-incident investigation by Incident Investigation Specialist Brigitte Mathieu revealed three contributing factors: (1) the lifting lugs had micro-damage from previous near-miss events that compromised their holding capacity, (2) Louis had not performed the required pre-lift safety check documented in the LOTO procedures, and (3) there was no spotter or secondary positioning protocol requiring personnel to stand clear of the load's direct path. The investigation classified this as a critical near-miss because a crush injury to Louis's foot would have resulted in fractures, potential amputation, and hospitalization.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, production operator Stéphane Couture was working at Injection Molding Line C when he reached into the mold cavity to manually remove a stuck polycarbonate component. The machine's hydraulic pressure release valve malfunctioned, causing a sudden pressurized burst of hot plastic and pressurized air directly onto his right hand and forearm. Couture immediately withdrew his hand and ran to the eyewash station in the production area, shouting for assistance. Co-worker Pascal Bisson, an injection molding technician, responded immediately and helped apply cool water to the affected area. The burns affected approximately 30% of Couture's right hand with second-degree thermal injuries. Emergency medical services were called at 2:22 PM, and Couture was transported to Hôpital du Sacré-Cœur in Montreal for specialized burn treatment and observation. The incident was witnessed by Bisson and nearby material handler Kwesi Owusu. Investigation revealed the pressure release valve had not been inspected during the previous maintenance cycle due to a scheduling oversight.

On November 15, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, chemical safety officer Simon Bélanger discovered a significant chemical spill in the Hazardous Waste Management Area while conducting a routine end-of-shift inspection. Approximately 45 liters of acetone (used as a cleaning solvent) had leaked from a damaged 200-liter storage container positioned on the mezzanine level of the Chemical Storage Building. The container's outlet valve had corroded and failed, with the breach occurring approximately 3-4 hours before discovery based on the spill pattern and evaporation analysis. The acetone had pooled on the concrete floor and partially seeped into the secondary containment tray, with approximately 5 liters spilling beyond the berm onto the exterior concrete pad near the building foundation. The immediate area was sealed off with barrier tape and warning signs. Bélanger initiated the spill response protocol at 10:48 PM, notifying facility management and the HSE team. Absorbent material was deployed to contain the remaining pooled acetone by 11:15 PM, with all contaminated materials properly containerized for hazardous waste disposal. Environmental monitoring confirmed no groundwater infiltration risk due to the facility's impermeable surface treatment. The incident was attributed to inadequate inspection protocols for valve integrity.

On November 16, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, assembly line lead Chantal Côté was training new employee on quality control procedures in the Quality Control Laboratory when she experienced a minor cut to her left index finger while handling a sharp edge on a molded plastic test component. The component, a precision medical device bracket with unfinished injection molding gates, had a burr edge that was missed during the standard deburring process. Côté immediately applied pressure to the wound and notified her supervisor at 6:32 AM. First aid responder Alain Mercier, the ergonomics specialist who maintains first aid certification, arrived within 3 minutes. Mercier assessed the wound as a superficial laceration approximately 8 mm in length with minimal bleeding. The wound was cleaned with antiseptic wash, dressed with antibiotic ointment, and covered with a sterile adhesive bandage. Vital signs were normal, and Côté remained on duty with modified task assignment. The incident did not result in lost work time or hospitalization. Root cause analysis identified that the component had slipped through quality inspection due to inadequate lighting at the visual inspection station during the night shift.

On March 15, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Assembly Operator Aaliyah Jackson (EMP-00176) was working at Station 4 in the Main Production Building, removing cooled plastic parts from injection molds. She was extracting a medical device housing component when her right hand made contact with a sharp edge flash on the molded part. The burr, approximately 2mm in length, created a laceration on her palm and index finger. The cut was approximately 1.5 inches long and required immediate first aid. Her supervisor, Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026), was working nearby and witnessed the incident. She immediately provided first aid, cleaned the wound with antiseptic, and applied a sterile dressing. The injury was classified as a minor laceration requiring documentation but no stitches. Jackson continued work with modified duties for the remainder of the shift, focusing on inspection rather than part removal. The incident highlighted inadequate edge finishing processes on medical-grade components destined for sterile assembly environments.

On March 22, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Machine Operator Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114) was performing routine maintenance on injection molding machine #7 in the Main Production Building. While adjusting the hydraulic cooling water system hose connections, a pressurized coolant line suddenly ruptured, spraying approximately 2 liters of hot (65°C) water and coolant mixture across his upper torso and left arm. Rahman immediately stepped back and alerted his team. Coworker Elena Vasquez (EMP-00156) helped him move to the emergency eyewash station where he rinsed the affected area for 5 minutes. The burns were superficial (first-degree) affecting approximately 8% of his upper body surface. Emergency medical services were called as a precaution, and Rahman was transported to the local hospital for evaluation. He was treated and released after 4 hours with instructions for burn care. The root cause was identified as degraded hose material from improper storage in direct sunlight near the Chemical Storage Building exterior zone, causing brittleness and failure under normal operating pressure.

On April 3, 2024 at 6:30 AM during the night shift, Warehouse Associate Monique Dion (EMP-00119) was retrieving raw material from the upper storage mezzanine in the Maintenance Workshop. While climbing down a fixed metal ladder with an armload of plastic resin containers (total weight approximately 8 kg), her foot missed the third step from the bottom. She fell approximately 1.8 meters, landing on her left hip and lower back on the concrete floor. The impact resulted in a fracture of the left femoral neck and contusions to her lumbar spine. Coworker Jacques Lachance (EMP-00085), present in the storage area, immediately called for emergency medical assistance. Paramedics arrived within 12 minutes and transported Dion to the regional trauma center where she underwent surgical intervention for the femur fracture. She was hospitalized for 5 days. Investigation revealed the ladder had no anti-slip treads and inadequate lighting in the mezzanine area. Additionally, Dion was carrying materials in a manner that obscured her vision of the ladder steps.

On November 14, 2024, at 2:15 PM during the day shift, Mathieu Gendron (EMP-00109), an Injection Molding Operator on Line B, was removing finished parts from a 250-ton injection molding machine in the Main Production Building. As he reached into the mold cavity to extract a batch of automotive dashboard components, the machine's safety interlock failed and the mold began closing unexpectedly. Mathieu's right hand became trapped between the upper and lower mold halves. The closing force was approximately 180 tons. A coworker immediately activated the emergency stop button, halting the machine within 2 seconds. However, Mathieu sustained a crushing injury to his right hand with fractures to the 3rd, 4th, and 5th metacarpals and severe soft tissue damage. Emergency services were called and he was transported to Hôpital de la Cité-de-la-Santé. The incident was witnessed by Vincent Létourneau (EMP-00075), an Instrumentation Technician who was performing routine maintenance nearby. Initial investigation revealed that the safety interlock solenoid had not been tested in accordance with the maintenance schedule.

On November 16, 2024, at 11:45 PM during the night shift, Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler, was conducting routine inventory and restocking of raw plastic pellets in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse and Shipping - Section C). While moving stacked bags of polycarbonate resin (25 kg each) using a manual hand truck, she noticed unusual moisture condensation on the exterior of several bags. Upon closer inspection, she observed a small leak in one of the storage racks where approximately 80 kg of recycled plastic granules had become exposed to water ingress from a roof leak discovered during the evening shift. The wet material had begun to absorb moisture, and the chemical composition of the resin (containing approximately 8% fiberglass content) had degraded to an unstable state. The affected material was immediately quarantined and segregated from the production-grade inventory. Environmental assessment indicated that approximately 15 liters of water contaminated with fiberglass particles and resin binders had infiltrated the warehouse section. The material was documented as hazardous waste requiring proper disposal per Quebec environmental regulations. No employees were exposed to airborne fibers, but the incident triggered a comprehensive facility inspection.

On November 18, 2024, at 9:30 AM during the day shift, Amal Farsi (EMP-00200), a Finishing Operator, was manually deburring injection-molded medical device housings at a workstation in the Composite Materials Processing Area (Main Production Building - West Wing). While using a fine abrasive brush to remove micro-burrs from internal cavities of a polycarbonate component, a small fiberglass fragment became dislodged from the brush bristles and struck Amal's left eye. The fragment caused immediate pain, redness, and sensation of a foreign body. Following company first-aid protocols, Amal immediately reported to the on-site first-aid station where Brigitte Mathieu (EMP-00123), the Incident Investigation Specialist who is also a certified first-aid attendant, was present. Brigitte flushed the eye with sterile saline solution for 3 minutes and examined the eye under magnification. A small linear scratch approximately 2 mm was identified on the conjunctiva. The eye was treated with antibiotic ointment and covered with a protective pad. Amal was referred to an ophthalmologist for verification that no corneal penetration occurred. The incident was documented as a first-aid treatment with no lost time or further medical intervention required beyond the eye wash station treatment.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 14:45, machine operator James Thompson (EMP-00029) was working on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building when he noticed a small coolant leak from the hydraulic system. While reaching to inspect the connection point, a pressurized spray of hydraulic fluid struck his left forearm, causing immediate skin irritation and a small laceration approximately 2 inches long. The employee immediately notified his supervisor Eric Surprenant (EMP-00175), who instructed him to wash the affected area thoroughly with soap and water at the safety station. Thompson experienced mild burning sensation and redness but no systemic symptoms. First aid was administered on-site: the wound was cleaned, disinfected, and covered with an antibiotic ointment and sterile bandage. The employee was able to continue working after treatment. The incident was documented and the hydraulic line was scheduled for maintenance repair within 48 hours. No hospitalization was required. Quality Inspector Lidia Fernandes (EMP-00180) witnessed the initial incident and assisted with first aid response.

On March 22, 2024, at 22:15 during the evening shift, Maintenance Technician Alain Gravel (EMP-00131) was performing routine lockout/tagout procedures on a resin dryer unit in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room. While verifying that the equipment was de-energized before beginning maintenance work, Gravel noticed that a secondary electrical disconnect switch had not been properly locked in the OFF position by the previous shift. The switch was accessible and could have been accidentally toggled back to ON, which would have energized the heating elements and potentially caused an arc flash or electrocution hazard. Gravel immediately secured the switch with a lockout hasp and notified his supervisor Thanh Pham (EMP-00062) of the finding. The situation was corrected within 10 minutes and maintenance work proceeded safely. No personnel were injured or exposed to electrical hazards. The incident was identified as a near-miss during the equipment inspection process. Crane operator Gaston Picard (EMP-00193) was present in the adjacent area and aware of the situation.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during day shift operations, a chemical spill occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing building (UNIT-011). Roberto Santos, a forklift operator, was transporting a pallet of epoxy resin containers when one of the securing straps failed. A 55-gallon drum of two-part epoxy compound fell from the pallet, striking the concrete floor and rupturing. Approximately 40 gallons of resin spread across the warehouse floor, creating a slippery hazard and releasing strong chemical fumes throughout the storage area. The spill occurred near the hazardous waste management zone where inadequate ventilation systems failed to evacuate the fumes efficiently. Two nearby employees, Gabrielle Levesque and Valentina Rossi, who were conducting inventory, were exposed to the chemical vapors for approximately 10 minutes before the area was evacuated. Emergency response procedures were initiated, the spill was contained using absorbent material, and the affected area was cordoned off. No personal injury occurred, but environmental contamination required professional cleanup services.

On March 18, 2024, at approximately 10:15 PM during evening shift operations, François Gagnon, an Injection Molding Operator on Line A, sustained a thermal burn while removing a part from a 180-ton injection molding machine. The machine had completed its cooling cycle, and Gagnon attempted to extract the molded plastic component without waiting the full 30-second cool-down period specified in the standard operating procedure. His left hand made contact with plastic material at approximately 85°C (185°F), resulting in a second-degree burn covering approximately 12 square centimeters on his palm and three fingers. The burn caused immediate pain and visible blistering. Benoit Arsenault, the operator on the adjacent Line A station, witnessed the incident and immediately alerted the shift supervisor. First aid was administered on-site by the occupational health nurse, Hana Al-Rashid, who was called to the production floor. The employee was transported to a local medical clinic for treatment and observation. Investigation revealed the employee had modified the machine's cool-down timer to accelerate production, directly violating safety protocols.

On March 22, 2024, at approximately 1:30 AM during night shift operations, Louis Desbiens, a Machine Setter on night shift, sustained a minor laceration to his right index finger while performing preventive maintenance on CNC milling machine UM-047 in the Maintenance Workshop. Desbiens was adjusting the spindle head assembly and inadvertently placed his hand near a sharp edge on the milling spindle during reassembly. The exposed metal edge, which should have been covered by a safety guard that was currently removed for maintenance, cut approximately 2 centimeters of his finger, resulting in moderate bleeding. Carlos Rodriguez, the Maintenance Manager, was present in the workshop and immediately provided first aid using the facility's first aid kit, applying direct pressure with sterile gauze and covering the wound with an antibiotic ointment and sterile bandage. The bleeding stopped within 5 minutes. Hana Al-Rashid, the occupational health nurse, was called and assessed the injury at 1:45 AM, determining no stitches were required but recommending monitoring for infection and tetanus status verification. The employee returned to light-duty work after the assessment with instructions to keep the wound clean and dry. Root cause analysis identified that the spindle guard had been removed but not properly documented in the lockout/tagout log.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, a significant water leak was discovered in the Injection Molding Line D facility (South Zone). Machine Setter Karim Bouazizi (EMP-00030) noticed coolant pooling beneath Injection Molding Machine #12 (a 250-ton unit) while performing routine setup checks. Upon investigation, he identified a fractured connection point on the primary cooling water line that supplies temperature regulation to the molding cavity. The leak had been ongoing for approximately 30 minutes before discovery, resulting in an estimated 200 liters of contaminated coolant water spreading across the production floor and seeping into the concrete foundation. The coolant mixture contains mineral oils and corrosion inhibitors classified as hazardous under WHMIS 2015. Immediate response included shutting down the affected machine, placing absorbent material around the leak, and notifying Facilities Manager Gérard Boucher (EMP-00133). The contaminated water required professional cleanup and disposal per Quebec environmental regulations. Production on Line D was halted for 4 hours while repairs were completed and the area was decontaminated. No personnel were directly exposed to the coolant, but the incident posed risks to equipment integrity and environmental compliance.

On November 18, 2024, during the evening shift (4:30 PM), Chemical Mixing Operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was operating the automated material mixing station in the Composite Materials Processing Area (West Wing) when a critical malfunction occurred. The heating element control system experienced an electronic failure, causing the temperature sensor to register incorrectly and activate an emergency shutdown sequence. However, the automated discharge valve failed to close properly, resulting in approximately 80 kilograms of partially heated epoxy resin and fiber reinforcement mixture beginning to extrude onto the concrete floor. The backup mechanical valve, designed to prevent such failures, was found to be corroded and non-functional due to inadequate maintenance intervals. The equipment continued expelling material for approximately 2 minutes before Operator Popescu manually engaged the emergency stop and physically closed the isolation valve. Warehouse Supervisor Luc-André Beaudoin (EMP-00139) responded immediately and contained the spill. The incident revealed that the automated backup system had not been inspected in over 18 months, violating the ISO 45001 implementation requirements. Approximately 85 kilograms of material was wasted, and the area required professional hazardous waste cleanup due to epoxy resin classification.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 11:45 PM during the night shift, Regrind Operator Fernand Comeau (EMP-00187) was operating the material recycling shredder in the Regrind and Recycling Department (Warehouse Section C) when a near-miss incident occurred. A bundle of recycled plastic feedstock approximately 15 kg in weight became slightly jammed in the hopper entrance due to improper stacking by day shift personnel. Operator Comeau placed his right hand into the hopper opening to manually dislodge the material, positioning his fingers dangerously close to the shredder intake opening located approximately 20 cm below the hopper lip. As he began to work the jammed material free, the automated feed roller activated (triggered by a faulty proximity sensor that should have been disabled during manual intervention). The rollers began turning, and Comeau's fingers came within 8 cm of the rotating intake blades before he jerked his hand back reflexively, preventing direct contact. Maintenance Planner Roland Dostie (EMP-00199) was present as a witness conducting a nighttime rounds inspection and immediately halted the equipment by engaging the main emergency stop. No laceration or contact injury occurred, but the incident demonstrated a critical failure in the lockout/tagout (LOTO) procedure—the equipment had not been properly isolated before manual intervention. Investigation revealed the proximity sensor had been malfunctioning for approximately 3 days without repair documentation.

On March 14, 2024 at 2:45 PM, Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), a Machine Setter on the day shift, was performing routine mold changeover on Injection Molding Line B when a hydraulic pressure release valve malfunctioned. While attempting to manually adjust the mold closing pressure, pressurized hot fluid sprayed across his right hand and forearm, causing second-degree thermal burns. The incident occurred because the pressure relief system had not been inspected during the monthly maintenance cycle due to scheduling conflicts. Rodrigue immediately reported the incident and was taken to the on-site first aid station where the burns were treated with sterile dressings and antibiotic ointment. Johanne Paquette, Emergency Response Team Leader, responded within 3 minutes and coordinated the response. The employee was initially treated on-site but due to burn severity (approximately 8% of body surface area), he was transported to the local hospital for additional treatment and observation. He required hospitalization for 2 days and returned to modified duty after 5 days, with full return to regular duties after 21 days.

On February 28, 2024 at 9:30 AM, Monique Dion (EMP-00119), a Warehouse Associate, was retrieving a pallet of ABS resin from the upper storage area in the Finished Goods Warehouse when she experienced acute chest pain and shortness of breath. While reaching for a box on a high shelf (approximately 8 feet), she felt a sudden sharp pain in her sternum and experienced dizziness. She immediately called for assistance, and nearby supervisor Normand Ouellette (EMP-00183) helped her down safely. Anh Nguyen, Safety Officer, arrived and assessed the situation. Initial symptoms suggested possible cardiac involvement, though further evaluation revealed the incident was actually an acute anxiety and musculoskeletal episode triggered by overexertion and poor ergonomic positioning. Emergency medical services were called as a precautionary measure, and Monique was transported to the hospital for cardiac evaluation, which was determined to be negative. However, she was hospitalized overnight for observation and released with a diagnosis of acute musculoskeletal strain and anxiety. She remained on modified duty for 7 days, unable to perform lifting tasks.

On April 2, 2024 at 10:15 PM during the evening shift, Elena Popescu (EMP-00022), Chemical Mixing Operator, was preparing a batch of colorant masterbatch in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility when she noticed the ventilation system had reduced airflow and an unusual chemical odor was present. She immediately shut down the mixing process and informed her supervisor. Upon investigation by Anh Nguyen (Safety Officer) and Yves Thibault (Quality Supervisor), it was discovered that the main ventilation intake filter had become 85% clogged with dust and particulate matter, reducing effective air exchange rate from the design specification of 12 air changes per hour to approximately 2 changes per hour. The chemical fumes (from heated resin and colorant components) were accumulating in the work area. Elena experienced minor nasal irritation and slight dizziness but did not require medical attention. The area was immediately evacuated and ventilation fans were shut down. The filter was replaced and ventilation system was purged for 30 minutes before operations resumed. No exposure documentation was necessary as the duration of exposure was minimal (approximately 8 minutes before the operator detected the hazard) and symptoms resolved within 1 hour after fresh air exposure.

On March 15, 2024 at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, a significant chemical spill occurred in the Material Drying and Preparation Room (UNIT-016). Salma Haddad (EMP-00148), a Material Handler, was transferring a 55-gallon drum of polycarbonate resin release agent from storage to a preparation station when the drum's top fitting became loose. The drum tipped over during the transfer, spilling approximately 40 gallons of the solvent-based release agent across the floor and into a floor drain. The chemical, which contains volatile organic compounds (VOCs), began to evaporate rapidly, creating visible fumes throughout the room. Kwesi Owusu (EMP-00126), another Material Handler working in the adjacent area, immediately noticed the strong chemical odor and activated the area emergency ventilation system. The spill triggered the facility's chemical response protocol. Eric Champagne (EMP-00049), Facilities Coordinator, was notified and coordinated containment efforts using absorbent mats and proper chemical cleanup procedures. The incident required evacuation of the immediate area for 90 minutes until ventilation cleared the fumes. No personal injury occurred, but the spill contaminated approximately 15 square meters of floor space and required professional hazardous waste removal.

On April 2, 2024 at 7:15 AM during the night shift, Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191), a Machine Setter on day shift assignment (covering for night shift), sustained a serious burn injury at Injection Molding Line A (UNIT-001). While setting up a new automotive component mold on an industrial injection molding machine, Tremblay reached into the mold area to clear a minor plastic flash. The machine's heating element was at operating temperature (approximately 280°C), and his right forearm made direct contact with the hot barrel for an estimated 2-3 seconds before he retracted his arm. Tremblay immediately reported severe pain and visible blistering on his forearm. Martin Lavoie (EMP-00041), a Crane Operator working nearby, witnessed the incident and immediately assisted Tremblay to the first aid station. The employee received initial first aid treatment including cool water irrigation and sterile dressing application, but the extent of the burn (estimated second-degree across 8% of forearm surface area) required transport to the Laval hospital emergency department at 7:35 AM. The employee was hospitalized for 3 days and required specialized burn care. This incident resulted in a lost-time injury with 45 days away from work during the healing and recovery period.

On May 18, 2024 at 1:20 PM during the day shift, Valentina Rossi (EMP-00186), an Assembly Operator working at Injection Molding Line D (UNIT-004), sustained a laceration to her left index finger that required first aid treatment. While assembling consumer packaging components at a manual workstation, Rossi was trimming excess plastic flash from molded parts using a handheld deburring tool. Her hand slipped on a wet surface (residual coolant from the molding process), causing the deburring tool blade to contact her finger across the first two knuckles. The laceration was approximately 2 centimeters long and 0.3 centimeters deep, with minor bleeding. A nearby coworker, Abdul Rahman (EMP-00114), an evening shift Machine Operator who happened to be in the area during shift transition, immediately provided basic first aid by applying direct pressure with sterile gauze. Alain Mercier (EMP-00063), Ergonomics Specialist, was called to the workstation and assessed the injury. The wound was cleaned, disinfected with antiseptic solution, and closed with sterile adhesive strips and a protective bandage. The employee continued working for the remainder of the shift with the wound dressed and protected. The incident required no hospitalization, no lost work time, and was managed entirely within the facility's first aid protocols.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:45 PM during the day shift, Production Operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was working at Injection Molding Line A in the North Zone when she experienced a sudden burn injury. While removing a finished part from the mold cavity, the mold temperature controller malfunctioned, causing the mold surface to reach approximately 180°C instead of the normal 95°C. Kamara's right forearm made contact with the exposed mold surface for approximately 2 seconds before she pulled away. She sustained a second-degree thermal burn covering approximately 8 cm² on her inner forearm. Machine Setter Rodrigue Tremblay (EMP-00191) was nearby and immediately assisted by applying cool water from the first aid station and alerting the HSE department. Alain Mercier from Ergonomics arrived within 5 minutes and coordinated transfer to the on-site medical clinic where the burn was treated, dressed, and documented. The employee was able to return to modified duties after 3 days. Root cause investigation revealed the temperature sensor had drifted out of calibration and the preventive maintenance schedule had lapsed by 2 weeks due to staffing issues.

On April 3, 2024, at approximately 10:20 AM during the day shift, Warehouse Associate Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197) sustained a laceration while processing recycled plastic materials in the Regrind and Recycling Department. Croteau was operating the material grinder to process polypropylene scraps when a piece of hardened plastic became caught in the grinding mechanism. Following standard procedure, he attempted to dislodge the blockage using a metal probe while the machine was powered down. However, the material suddenly released and his left hand contacted the spinning rotor blade, resulting in a 3 cm laceration on his index and middle fingers. The cut required 6 stitches and was treated at the local urgent care facility. Croteau returned to work the next day with bandaging. Chemical Inventory Specialist Natasha Ivanov (EMP-00136) was called to the scene and documented the incident. Upon investigation, it was discovered that the emergency stop button had been covered by stored materials, making it inaccessible, and the energy isolation procedure had not been properly followed before attempting to clear the blockage.

On May 22, 2024, at approximately 11:15 PM during the night shift, Machine Setter Louis Desbiens (EMP-00163) was performing routine setup and adjustment on Injection Molding Line D in the South Zone when he developed acute carpal tunnel symptoms. Desbiens had been repetitively adjusting mold components, tightening fasteners, and making micro-adjustments to gate positions for approximately 4 hours without breaks. He reported severe pain and tingling in his right wrist and hand, with numbness extending into his fingers. The symptoms were consistent with acute nerve compression from repetitive wrist flexion and extension motions. Desbiens reported the symptoms to Shift Supervisor Patricia Martin (EMP-00035), who immediately removed him from the repetitive task. Ergonomics Specialist Alain Mercier (EMP-00063) was called and performed an on-site ergonomic assessment, discovering that the workbench height was 8 cm too low for Desbiens' frame, forcing him to work with his wrists in constant hyperflexion. The incident was documented, and Desbiens was assigned to alternative duties the next day. Medical evaluation confirmed acute carpal tunnel inflammation without nerve damage, and conservative treatment was recommended.

On March 15, 2024, at approximately 2:15 PM during the day shift, Naomi Okafor (EMP-00172), a production operator, was performing a visual inspection of freshly molded automotive dashboard components at the Packaging and Labeling Station (UNIT-019). While handling a batch of polycarbonate parts fresh from the injection molding process, she sustained a laceration on her left index finger from a sharp edge on one of the molded components. The part had an unfinished edge burr that was not detected during quality control screening. Naomi immediately applied pressure with a clean cloth and reported the injury to her supervisor, Yves Thibault (EMP-00079). First aid was administered by the on-site occupational health representative, including wound cleaning, antiseptic application, and a sterile adhesive bandage. The laceration was approximately 0.5 cm deep but did not require sutures. The injury was documented and monitored for signs of infection over the following week.

On April 2, 2024, at approximately 10:45 PM during the evening shift, Svetlana Petrov (EMP-00048), a machine setter, sustained a thermal burn on her right hand while attempting to clear a material jam in an injection molding machine (250-ton Engel model). The machine's barrel temperature was 285°C when Svetlana attempted to manually extract stuck polypropylene resin using a metal tool without allowing the system to cool. Despite wearing standard cotton work gloves, the radiant heat and brief contact with the heated nozzle resulted in a partial-thickness burn covering approximately 8 square centimeters on the dorsal surface of her hand. Yves Thibault's shift replacement, Bernard Allard (EMP-00145), heard Svetlana's exclamation and immediately assisted her to the first aid station. The wound was flushed with cool water for 10 minutes, covered with sterile gauze, and wrapped with a pressure bandage. Occupational health staff determined the injury required emergency room evaluation for burn assessment and possible topical antibiotic therapy. The employee was transported to the local hospital and treated for minor thermal burns, returning to work three days later with modified duty restrictions.

On April 18, 2024, at approximately 6:30 AM during the night shift, the main ventilation system serving the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018) experienced a catastrophic failure when the primary exhaust fan motor bearing seized, causing the motor to stop abruptly. The failure occurred due to inadequate lubrication maintenance—the bearing grease had not been replenished in 18 months despite the equipment manual specifying quarterly lubrication intervals. Within 15 minutes of failure, solvent vapor concentrations in the recycling area exceeded the OSHA Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) of 200 ppm for acetone vapors, reaching 340 ppm as measured by the facility's continuous air quality monitor. Raymond Tessier (EMP-00143) and Yvon Croteau (EMP-00197), the two night shift workers in the department, did not immediately notice the odor increase due to olfactory adaptation. Anh Nguyen (EMP-00007), the Safety Officer conducting routine night shift monitoring, detected the alarm on the air quality system at 6:47 AM and immediately initiated facility-wide emergency ventilation protocols. The affected workers were evacuated to fresh air and held in the administrative building for medical observation. The HVAC system was manually shut down, and backup ventilation was activated. Local environmental health authorities were notified. No workers reported acute symptoms beyond mild dizziness, which resolved within 30 minutes of fresh air exposure.

On April 22, 2024, at approximately 10:15 AM during the day shift, injection molding operator Rémi Charbonneau (EMP-00127) was performing routine maintenance on Injection Molding Line D in the Main Production Building. While attempting to clear a resin blockage in the hopper feed system, his right hand became caught between the rotating auger screw and the fixed hopper wall. Despite having completed LOTO (Lockout/Tagout) training, Charbonneau had not fully de-energized the equipment before beginning maintenance—he had only paused the current cycle. When the system auto-cycled unexpectedly during his intervention, his hand was compressed, resulting in lacerations to his palm and fingers, a fractured metacarpal bone in his right hand, and partial avulsion of skin on his index finger. Quality Inspector Catherine Leblanc (EMP-00026) heard his cry for help and immediately activated emergency stop and called first aid. The employee was transported to the regional trauma center where he underwent emergency surgery and was hospitalized for 3 days. He was subsequently placed on light duty for 6 weeks during recovery.

On May 8, 2024, at approximately 6:30 PM during the evening shift, chemical mixing operator Elena Popescu (EMP-00022) was transferring a large batch of epoxy resin catalyst from a 200-liter storage drum to smaller mixing containers in the Chemical Storage and Mixing facility. While disconnecting the transfer hose from the supply drum, the quick-disconnect coupling failed and a pressurized spray of catalyst solution discharged directly into her face and eyes. The chemical exposure caused immediate burning sensation and temporary vision impairment. Popescu rinsed her eyes at the emergency eyewash station for 15 minutes, but the irritation persisted. She reported the incident to her supervisor and was transported to the occupational health clinic where she was examined, treated with topical medication, and prescribed 48 hours of restricted work duty. Over the following weeks, she experienced residual eye irritation and sensitivity to light, resulting in 8 additional days of lost work time spread over a 4-week period as her condition improved. Root cause analysis identified that the coupling was 8 years old with visible wear, regular pressure testing had not been performed, and protective face shields were not consistently worn during chemical handling operations.

On April 3, 2024, at 10:30 AM during the day shift, Production Operator Aisha Kamara (EMP-00072) was performing routine part removal and sorting tasks on Injection Molding Line B at the Automotive assembly station (UNIT-002). After completing her 4th consecutive hour of repetitive gripping and twisting motions to remove cooled plastic components from the mold, Aisha began experiencing acute sharp pain in her right wrist and forearm. She reported the symptoms to her line supervisor, Sonia Dasilva (EMP-00128), who immediately provided ice and offered first aid. The pain was consistent with acute repetitive strain syndrome affecting the extensor carpi radialis muscle group. Aisha completed her shift with modified duties focusing on lighter assembly tasks. She was sent to the on-site occupational health clinic where the injury was assessed and documented. Ibuprofen and a wrist compression wrap were provided, along with recommendations for rest and ergonomic modification of her workstation. The injury did not result in lost time but was recorded as a first aid case requiring medical evaluation and follow-up care over the next two weeks.

On February 28, 2024, at 3:15 PM during the evening shift, Mold Technician Stéphane Moreau (EMP-00021) was performing routine mold maintenance and inspection in the Mold Manufacturing and Repair Shop (UNIT-013). While examining a composite injection mold for hairline fractures using visual inspection under standard fluorescent lighting, Stéphane noticed that the existing lighting in the work area has become increasingly inadequate over the past 3 months due to two failed fluorescent ballasts that had not been replaced. The poor lighting conditions have caused significant eye strain during detailed precision work, and Stéphane has been experiencing mild headaches and fatigue during his shifts. He documented this observation and reported it to Production Supervisor Lucie Fillion (EMP-00151) and EHS Coordinator Samira El-Khoury (EMP-00003) as a preventive hazard declaration before any injury occurred. The report noted that inadequate lighting in the tool room poses risks not only for vision fatigue and headaches but also increases the likelihood of missed defects in mold quality and potential eye strain-related errors. This preventive declaration was registered in the JHSC incident log and initiated a workplace hazard assessment to address the lighting deficiency.

On November 14, 2024, at approximately 14:45 during day shift operations, a catastrophic equipment failure occurred in Injection Molding Line D. Machine operator Leila Farah was monitoring the injection cycle when a high-pressure hydraulic line coupling on the mold clamping mechanism suddenly failed, spraying pressurized hydraulic fluid across the work station. The fluid struck the adjacent control console and electrical junction box, causing an electrical short circuit and triggering a small fire in the cabinet. The operator quickly shut down the machine using the emergency stop button and activated the facility fire suppression system. Maintenance technician Fernand Giguère responded immediately with a portable fire extinguisher, extinguishing the small blaze within 90 seconds. The hydraulic fluid damaged approximately $47,000 worth of electrical components and control systems. The coupling failure was attributed to metal fatigue from inadequate preventive maintenance scheduling—the coupling had exceeded its manufacturer-recommended service interval by eight months. No personnel injuries occurred, but the incident resulted in 18 hours of production downtime.

On November 18, 2024, at approximately 22:15 during evening shift operations, a significant chemical spill incident occurred in the Chemical Storage and Mixing Room (UNIT-010). Machine setter Tomas Jimenez was transferring a 55-gallon drum of epoxy resin from a storage rack when the drum suddenly slipped from the handling straps and fell approximately 4 feet onto the concrete floor. The impact ruptured the drum, releasing approximately 35 gallons of epoxy resin mixed with hardener across the floor. The spill spread rapidly across 120 square feet of the chemical storage area, seeping toward floor drains and creating a slip hazard. Supervisor Lucie Fillion immediately evacuated personnel from the area, activated the ventilation system to maximum capacity, and notified the HSE team. Fumes from the hardener (containing methyl ethyl ketone) created poor air quality affecting a radius of approximately 30 feet. Alain Mercier from HSE response deployed absorbent materials and contained the spill within 25 minutes. The contaminated materials were placed in hazardous waste containers. The room required 4 hours of ventilation before re-entry was permitted. The incident resulted in a 2-hour production delay for composite materials processing in the adjacent area.

On November 21, 2024, at approximately 06:30 during night shift operations in the Regrind and Recycling Department (UNIT-018), material handler Salma Haddad sustained a significant back and shoulder injury while performing manual material handling tasks. Haddad was transferring rejected plastic parts from a quality control reject bin into a grinding hopper when she reached awkwardly to grasp a large batch of parts from the bottom of an overflowing bin. The bin was positioned at knee height without proper ergonomic accommodation, forcing Haddad to bend at the waist with a twisted spine. As she lifted approximately 18 kg of parts, she felt a sudden sharp pain in her lower left back and shoulder. She immediately stopped work and reported the injury to night shift supervisor on duty. The incident was assessed as a potential herniated disc with acute muscle strain. Haddad was transported to the occupational health clinic where imaging confirmed a Grade 2 lumbar strain with ligamentous injury. She was placed on modified duty for 6 weeks and prescribed physiotherapy. The incident was investigated by Brigitte Mathieu from the incident investigation team, revealing that the material handling station had not been evaluated for ergonomic compliance in over 18 months.
